column2: WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 22 -- A procession of touchdowns that began soon after the start and ended with No. 7 in the last fifteen seconds carried Holy Cross to a 48-0 triumph over Fordham at Fitton Field today.

TODAY'S casual shopper, walking around any rug department in a "just looking" mood, may well be struck toy the bright variety of fresh designs, interesting textures and inspiring colors -- a bigger variety probably than she has ever seen before. "Randomtex," a simpler texture at the same store. At Altman's you will find "Curl-weave," the uncut pile carpet of tightly twisted yarn which we reported when the manufacturer introduced it last January.

IT may be something of an exaggeration to say that the history of Russian literature is the history of Russian fiction, but the novel plainly overshadows all else and has an importance in the ebb and flow of intellectual movements in Russia unequaled in the development of fiction in any other European country.

THE Ansco twin-lens reflex camera for 2 1/4 by 2 1/4 inch pictures, equipped With coated 83mm f/3.5 Ansco anastigmat taking lens and f/3.2 viewing lens, is now available. Price of the new camera, with eveready case, tax included, is $275.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Indiana University's football Hoosiers convincingly defeated the Purdue Boilermakers today, 16 to 14, in as nerve-twisting a game as any in the 1891-born series.

IN 1942 Preston Schoyer's first novel, "The Foreigners," was praised by the critics for its understanding treatment of the Chinese character and the beauty of its prose style. In the intervening years Schoyer has served as an intelligence officer in East China, where (as the dust jacket informs us) he created an "underground railway for escaping Allied personnel."

TEN years ago the National Music League was obviously on its last legs. The organization had been founded in 1924 to help young artists, and aided such performers as Rise Stevens, Dalies Frantz and John Gurney.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Will you allow an Englishman who has known America for nearly sixty years and has lived here on and off a third of that period, to say a word or two about American reaction to the royal wedding of this last week?

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Seven fires of obvious incendiary, origin that started within forty-five minutes in a radius of three blocks after 4 A.M. today imperiled twenty-five families, rendered eight of them homeless and caused damage between $25,000 and $30,000.

HOWARD GRIFFIN, who was the winner of the 1947 annual contest sponsored by the League to Support Poetry, has unfortunately been non-selective to his choices for his first volume. His abundance of poetic forms shows a margin of craftsmanship not always used to his own advantage.

MORE THAN anything else the Eureka, Calif., Fire Company, a volunteer outfit, was proud of the trophies it had won for its fire-fighting skill during the past half century. But now, alas, it doesn't have the trophies any more -- and it's very embarrassing. A fire broke out in the firehouse and destroyed them.

ATLANTA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Georgia Tech's Yellow Jackets ran over an undermanned Furman eleven today on a wet field, 51 -- 0, with Tech's third and fourth stringers playing most of the time. The attendance was 20,000.
CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Today's Report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

THERE are many good reasons for Americans to give thanks this year. Food is plentiful, we are eating well, and few, if any, of the signs of deprivation are evident among us as they are in so many other countries of the world.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Georgia Bulldogs rolled over little Chattanooga 27 to 0 in a mud battle today with substitutes carrying most of the load in the last half.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The dull fires of partisan strife are smoldering again on Capitol Hill, rekindled this week by President Truman's demand for consumer rationing and price controls and the kindred restraints by which he would cushion the shock of foreign aid on the domestic economy.
TO THE EDITOR : Your diverting article, "Utah Skyride," concerning the delight with which Salt Lake City greeted its first escalator is seemingly one reflection of a major post-war social phe-
The flourish of trumpets ceased as I entered the chapel. * * * The ceremony was very imposing. * * * I felt so happy. * * * the crowd was immense * * * they cheered us again and again.

A sampling of farm opinion indicates that many farmers expect farm food prices to rise even further in 1948, level off in 1949, and then fall sharply in 1950, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., announced yesterday.

BALLET THEATRE will present the first novelty of its season at the City Center when it opens its second week there on Wednesday evening. It is George Balanchine's "Theme and Variations," set to Tchaikovsky's "Suite No. 3 for Orchestra," with scenery and costumes by Woodman Thompson.
THESE two additions to the long, long bookrack of young men's war-novels are both competently written, earnestly planned -- and like so many of their brothers-in-uniform, overshoot their target.

A renewed proposal to restrict the competition by foreign athletes in the United States' national championships is one of the twenty-nine amendments to the constitution, by-laws and general rules to be considered by the Amateur Athletic Union at its fifty-ninth convention at Omaha, Neb., Dec. 5-7.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- If the nation's attention is to be concentrated upon expansion of government power and controls, the real causes of inflation will continue unchecked, Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, today told the National Editorial Association at its annual meeting.

Although he considers subsidized housing undesirable from both a social and an economic point of view, William J. Demorest, president of William J. White Sons, believes that under present conditions it is probably necessary to build a certain amount of such housing.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Despite investigations, programs and optimistic promises for several years, the freight car supply today is worse than it was at the end of the war -- about 41,000 cars worse. The car-building program failed and the only thing good to be said about the situation is that the worst appears to be over.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22 -- While there is some opposition to rationing and price and wage controls, there is evidence that a great many people are reserving a decision on the President's proposals.

BOSTON, Mass. PERHAPS it is my presence in a city so pleasantly tenacious of its past that has determined my choice of a subject for this week's column. Be that as it may, I have been carrying about with me for weeks a paper-bound book issued in September by the G. and C. Merriam Company of Springfield, which was published in commemoration of its first hundred years as the publisher of Webster's dictionaries.

Mrs. Florence W. Bowers, former publicity director of E.P. Dutton Co., Inc., who recently has been collecting material, for the publishing firm's centennial celebration, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. She was 59 years old.

Party leaders in the United States concerned with problems abroad, should not forget the hunger and suffering among our own citizens caused by inflated food prices, and should take this matter out of party politics, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum said in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- Housewives of this metropolis, who have not forgotten the evils of the black markets and the years when they stood in lines and exchanged coupons for food, were apparently overwhelmingly opposed to the President's proposal for re-enactment of wartime powers to fix prices and regulate distribution.

Farmer-members of the Farm Panel of America are sharply divided in their views of the future trend of farm food prices, it was revealed yesterday in a survey completed by the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., according to Paul S. Willis, president.

The Philadelphia Warriors, displaying an uncanny ability to tighten up when it counted most, defeated the Knickerbockers, 83-78, at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night. A sell-out crowd of 5,342 turned out for the Basketball Association of America game.

Robert Schuman, Minister of Finance in the Ramadier Cabinet, heads a new French government, "to defend the Republic." The Assembly accepted him as Premier by a vote of 412 to 184, with only the Communists and their sympathizers dissenting. Supporters of General de Gaulle swelled his healthy total.

Never in time of peace and seldom in time of war has the modern world been in such danger as it is today. The situation is comparable with that in the fall of 1940, when Hitler made his bid to conquer Britain by air; with that during the winter after Pearl Harbor; with that following the Normandy landings.

The tempo of activity in all sections of department stores last week stepped up according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The survey reported coat departments busy, children's departments -- especially in snow suits -- very good, vacation shops and sporting goods departments commanding attention, stationery getting Christmas business and toy departments active.

Federal legislation authorizing Government reimbursement for wartime utilization of the Port of New York's shipping facilities would be "in order" and might be sought, Commodore Frederick G. Reinicke, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, said yesterday.
''Domine, dirlge nos -- O Lord! direct us." -- Motto of City of London, 1633.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- The plans of the Indian Government to rebuild the famous shrine of Somnath in Junagadh State, which was destroyed by a Moslem conqueror more than 900 years ago, have captured the imagination of Hindu India and, conversely, have aroused some resentment in Moslem Pakistan.

AS the dull browns of late fall and winter engulf the slumbering garden, the vividness of the birds serves to appease our yearning for lost blossom color. The pleasure provided by their striking appearances and interesting antics would be reason enough to attract them to garden feeding stations, even if there were not also practical gains from having them as allies.

THE collection of French tapestries dating all the way from 1375 to 1947 and lent by the Government of France for the exhibition which opened at the Metropolitan Museum yesterday, is so magnificent that it is difficult to discuss the event with restraint.

Many industrial materials have changed back to a tight seller's market, as a result of fears of future price and allocation controls, industrial purchasing executives disclosed here yesterday. Offers of orders for as many as 500 steel desks, 1,000 chairs, and large tonnages of metal parts and products have suddenly become unattractive to vendors and "no bids at all" have been made on some very important inquiries, they revealed.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- Penn State gained its first unbeaten and untied season in thirty-five years with consummate ease today by rolling over the Pitt Panthers, 29 -- 0, and thus laying a jinx which had frustrated the Nittany Lions in other years.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Boston University's Terriers, superior in everything but touchdowns for three periods, capitalized on a final-period break to submerge Colgate University, 20 to 14, before 10,000 at Penway Park today.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Bob Higgins, the coaching veteran, who achieved his first unbeaten and untied season in 27 seasons today when Penn State walloped Pitt, said "It's wonderful" to tutor a winner.

WITH its second issue, out tomorrow, Photography Quarterly begins to assume the role for which it was planned, a closer approximation of Editor Bruce Downes' conception of photography as "not merely an amusing diversion, but an inexhaustible process capable of meeting man's maturest demands and expressing his highest aspirations."

Closing hour at the bar in the Hotel Markwell, 220 West Forty-ninth Street, came too early yesterday for Frankie Carbo and five assorted prize fight managers and "salesmen," so they set up a ruckus that brought them into Week-End Court on disorderly conduct charges.

When, in years to come, old grads gather to recall and relive the glorious deeds of Columbia's 1947 gridiron campaign, yesterday finale against Syracuse will not be omitted. It was, after all, the vehicle that carried the Lions to a 28-8 victory, terminating an eminently successful season which boasted seven triumphs in nine games.

THE "Children of the Albatross" are Djuna, Sabrina, Lillian, Donald, Michael, Jay, Paul, Lawrence. Though not children in years, they have no last names. Last names appear to suggest worldly status, formality, externality, the domination by the father.

THIS book, a translation of the relevant chapters from the official Russian textbook on pedagogy by B.P. Yesipov and N. K. Goncherov, affords an important insight into the Russian mind and aspirations as they are shaping up as the result of World War II.

PHOTOGRAPHY as an effective morale builder for service men confined to hospitals, was extolled last week by Capt. Edward Steichen, director of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, at a reception in his honor by the Volunteer Service Photographers, Inc.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Replying to a rising tide of legal objections to the proposed partition of Palestine, Hershel V. Johnson, the United States representative, today criticized Great Britain for having confronted the United Nations General Assembly with an almost insuperable task.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- In New England a widespread feeling exists that as a result of President Truman's message to Congress politics has been interjected into the vital problems of domestic price control and foreign aid.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- A categorical denunciation of the Military Governments of the Western powers was delivered yesterday at the Allied Control Council meeting by Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, Soviet commander. The speech, delivered on the eve of the London conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, obviously was prepared well in advance.

A total of $2,067,300 in sales of real estate have been made thus far this year by Realty Associates, Inc., and its affiliates, according to a report released by Harry D. Burchell, vice president. The transactions, he said, included a wide variety of both improved and unimproved properties, most of which are located in the metropolitan area.

FOR his fifth novel Guy McCrone has written a warm, ample, comfortable book about a Lowland Scots family, several members of which came up to Glasgow in the plush Eighteen Seventies and did very well for themselves.

THE theatre's business men have hit on a plan for warming up first-night audiences by putting the chill on the press list. This has provoked a bloodless vendetta between producers and drama reporters in which the former are lurking behind their embarrassed press agents and the latter are pouting behind smoking typewriters.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 22 (AP) -- North Carolina State's football team stormed through a cold haze today to upset Virginia, 7 to 2, and virtually dump the Cavaliers out of all Bowl consideration.

CUBA will release next Saturday a four-stamp series to mark the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of Marta Abreu, philanthropist and humanitarian. The decree authorizing these commemoratives was enacted in 1945, the centenary year.

TURNING to the immediate backgrounds of contemporary painting, Paul Rosenberg has selected for his current show a baker's dozen of pictures by as many French nineteenth century artists, including Corot, Courbet (a striking portrait with a minimum of modeling), Daumier (the famous "Le Liseur"), Delacroix ("Lion and Serpent"), Ingres, Manet ("La Sultane" with its shimmering translucent drapery), Monet, Morisot, Pissarro, Renoir (a head and a landscape) and Lautrec (one of the outstanding profile heads).

Writer Catches Tartar Leonid Leonov, a writer well-known in the Soviet Union, recently restated the attitude of the Russians toward western Europe. Russia is not so much angry with the West, he explains, as deeply hurt.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- Anyone who may be hoping that Germany will be abruptly and officially split if the Foreign Ministers-fail to agree in London is doomed to disappointment, top United States officials here say.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The railroad strike spreading northward from Marseille today brought to Paris travellers the first indications of renewal of the travel inconvenience with which they had been made glumly familiar by the war and by last June's rail workers' walkout.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The post-war world of the United Nations is still waiting for a Thackeray or a Tolstoi, or even a Hemingway. But its melancholy history perhaps can be outlined in terms borrowed from Dickens. From the great expectations of San Francisco it has descended to bleak house; now like Mr. Micawber, it is waiting for something to turn up to save it from bankruptcy.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Princess Elizabeth, and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, will attend their first Sunday service as man and wife in the ancient Romsey Abbey tomorrow, it was officially announced today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Maryland's crushing line and sleight-of-hand backfield brightened its Sun or Gator Bowl chances and ground Vanderbilt's Orange Bowl dreams to bits today, winning 20 to 6, in a savage, penalty-studded football game before a crowd of 20,000.

STUDENTS -- Enrollment in the nation's 1,778 colleges and universities this year totals nearly 2,300,000, an all-time high and 1,000,000 more than the prewar peak, the United States Office of Education announced recently.

Speaking at a recent meeting of the Long Island Real Estate Board, Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation urged realtors to keep abreast of the current trends in the real estate market and the mortgage scene.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Republicans in Congress, sharply reminded by the press and some of their own membership that they are in power at the Capitol and must cast off the psychology of mere opposition to the Executive, seem to have accepted that counsel. This is implicit in yesterday's decision by their Senate Policy Committee to draw up a program of their own to curb inflation and level off the present scale of prices.

To the Drama Editor: ON Sunday last, the D'Oyly Carte Company announced its program for the first seven weeks of its engagement of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas, commencing in December. As a Savoyard, I was extremely disappointed in noticing again the absence of three operas, "The Sorcerer," "Ruddigore," and "Princess Ida."

THE earthbound can take off on a dramatic and-frightening-flight as Douglas Ingells unfolds the story of how the Air Force conquered brass, inertia and the elements before taming the enemy. By opening the throttle on information once classified as secret, civilian and military technicians, the men who turned frail biplanes into terrifying drones, finally receive their tribute.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Nov. 22 -- An underdog Haverford College upset Swarthmore College, 13 to 0, before 7,000 fans today in the thirty-eighth gridiron meeting of the traditional rivals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- The European Recovery Program was born in an airplane flying across the North Atlantic last April, The Washington Post reported tonight.

With the opening this fall of the Ecole Ldbre des Hautes Etudes as an independent institution, an opportunity has been provided scholars, teachers and the general public interested in French culture to obtain free courses on the university level.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- With electric power requirements in excess of the wartime peak and approaching the limits of dependable capacity, the Federal Power Commission urged today that electric companies investigate immediately whether interconnections with other companies or systems should be established.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today the dismissal of petitions filed by fourteen unions which have not complied with the requirements of the Taft-Hartley law for non-Communist affidavits and financial reports.

"A POLITICIAN writes books about politics," said my publisher a few months ago, "a mathematician writes books about mathematics, and a dietitian writes books about dietetics -- but a bridge expert doesn't write books about gin rummy." Thereupon I sat down and wrote a book about gin rummy.
The American Export Line, veteran operators in the New YorkMediterranean service, announced yesterday immediate plans for two fast 20,000-ton passenger liners costing $40,000,000.

JUST twenty years ago this week in this review: Emil Ludwig's "Genius and Character,' studies of Frederick the Great, Balzac, Schiller, Byron, LaSalle, etc., took the spotlight, with the anonymous reviewer making a neat distinction between biography and portraiture.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 -- In distinct contrast to the situation in eastern European countries Germany faces a forty-year period of population decline, according to a United States Military Government report made available today. The report, which was prepared by the Civil Administration Division, said the turning point of the population development was "immediately imminent."

Although it uses the thrifty cuts of meat, this meat loaf is in the prize-winning class for savory and nutritious eating. Glazed and garnished for a dressed-up Sunday touch, as suggested, it vies with any roast.

A COLLECTION of house plants has a habit of growing until suddenly there are more than can be tended -- or even watered -- comfortably. Whenever this stage is reached the assortment also is likely to be nondescript and crowded.

Wagner College crushed Hartwick College of Oneonta, N.Y., 27 -- 6 before a homecoming day crowd of 3,500 at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday. Resorting almost exclusively to a passing game, Wagner punched across three scores and blacked a kick for a safety in the second half for 21 points, after being held to a 6-6 tie for the first two periods.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Northwestern, saving its best performance of the season until the last game, today closed out its Big Nine football season by vacating the cellar position with a stunning 28-to-13 triumph over highly favored Illinois.

MONTREAL, Nov. 22 -- The New York Rangers, with an all-out offensive, defeated the Canadiens, 5--3, at the Forum tonight and pulled themselves up one point behind fourth-place Montreal in the National Hockey League standing. It was a doubly costly setback for the Canadiens, who lost Goalie Bill Durnan through an injury early in the second period.

Giving a most spectacular exhibition of passing, Jack Boyle pitched three touchdown passes in the last quarter to give Manual Training a 19-19 tie with Lafayette in the first game of the doubleheader at Ebbets Field before 10,000 fans yesterday.

PARIS, Sunday, Nov. 23 -- Robert Schuman, 61-year-old Minister of Finance in the fallen Ramadier Government and a member of the Catholic Popular Republican Movement, became Premier of France by vote of the National Assembly yesterday.

NO doubt you've known a family like the Olivers: always fighting and arguing and "calling names" among themselves, but let anyone else try it and together they'll blaze out their united wrath on the offender. The Olivers were Ohioans; Grandpa Pitman Oliver, a pioneer on the land, continued to hold the family together by hard work, an iron will and sometimes just plain cussedness.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Except for two items, rationing and wage and price control, President Truman's proposals to Congress this week, had been more or less foretold.

A strong second-half rally, enabled DeWitt Clinton to score a 21-13 victory over previously indefeated James Monroe and thereby lay claim to the mythical Bronx-Manhattan P.S.A.L. football crown yesterday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 22 -- Undefeated Notre Dame, exploding for five opening period touchdowns, rolled up its eighth straight victory and its largest score of the season with a 59-6 rout of bewildered Tulane before an Irish home finale crowd of 57,000 today.
Seton Hall's harriers ran true to form in capturing team honors in the City College invitation crosscountry run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.
IN 1910, at a moment of earlier pre-war tension in Europe, Charles Peguy made his Joan of Arc say:

THE American Booksellers Association's Give-a-Book Certificate Plan, now well under way, came into being because, according to the ABA, too many people who wanted to give books to friends didn't. They didn't because they didn't know what their friends had read or what they wanted to read; and so they decided on American Beauties or assorted candies, which make no money for booksellers.

PARENTS may think of sundry awkward moments when small fry first sprint to answer the telephone; yet Col. H. Edmund Bullis has been telling us that it is a good idea to let the children answer doorbell and telephone "even before they can do it well."

To the Music Editor: Having read the recent interesting articles on American music by Marks Levine, manager, and Isadore Freed, composer, I am prompted to express certain ideas which have come to me -- as a performing artist, the third side of the triangle.

HIGHLANDS, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Mrs. Lavinia Mount Minton, celebrating her 103d birthday today with an open house, cake and coffee party, welcomed more than 100 relatives and friends, including five new great-great grandchildren standing in formal hostess style just inside the parlor of her daughtor's home here.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Nine days ahead of schedule, through the enthusiastic response of officers and men to the individual training program, 1600 troops from the famfed Eighty second Airborne Division already have entered upon the second phase of "Exercise Snowdrop" that is to culminate next February in establishing an airhead and a mass descent of paratroopers, combat infantry, artillery and communications details upon a theoretical enemy shore of Lake Ontario.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Both St. Louis major league baseball clubs were rumored up for sale tonight as the St. Louis Browns continued their week-long personnel shake-up by trading Second Baseman John Berardino to the Washington Senators for Gerry Priddy and "a lot" of cash.
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 22 -- Individual views and editorial opinions expressed in this region reveal:

HOLLYWOOD. IDEOLOGICAL matters continued to agitate the Hollywood mind last week, as the RKO management announced a company policy of Hiring no ''known Communists" and the Screen Actors Guild resolved at a membership meeting that only signers of non-Communist affidavits would be eligible to hold office in the guild.

A staff has been assembled to handle the entertainment on the Holland-America liners Nieuw Amsterdam and Veendam on their forthcoming West Indies cruises, Frederick R. Wierdsma, general manager of the company in this country and Canada, announced yesterday.
Myra Hess, British pianist now playing in this country for the second season since the war, gave a recital yesterday afternoon which drew an audience of 2700 to Carnegie Hall.

IT was with sincere disappointment that Harriet Eager discovered that Malcolm Davis, her interesting and masculine young man, could be concerned with anything so "suspect" as foreign affairs. She hoped he would bring himself to do something more interesting and lucrative.

RECENT criticisms of the program of American history in the schools and colleges of America have focused the attention of the general public upon this area of our educational system. Thinking people have become convinced of the need for more effective teaching of American history, particularly in our elementary and high schools.

THIS is not the book for lovers of back-stairs diplomacy or political gossip. But readers who wish a clearer picture of the fortunes of Britain in the momentous year 1941 and of how those fortunes affected the United States and were in turn affected by America, will find it here.

A 10 to 15 per cent shortage of fuel oil this winter was predicted yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer's Emergency Fuel Committee, which urged the public to take every precaution to conserve heat in order to avert a "serious situation."

LATE November, or even early December in a season as open as this fall has been, is an excellent time to prepare heavy clay soil for future planting. Work next spring is then in no way delayed, and frost action has a chance to accomplish its familiar benefits.

THIS first novel is a happy combination of history, romance and character. Since the last ingredient is so rare in fiction nowadays, Miss Lockwood deserves special commendation. Although the setting and time she has chosen are not particularly fresh -- Wisconsin in the Eighties, when the mining and lumber industries were growing with alarming voracity and rapidity -- the main characters are developed sufficiently to hold any reader's attention.

BOSTON -- Nursing School To meet the need for nurses, Boston University's School of Nursing has inaugurated a new four-and-one-half-year program which will enable students to obtain practical first-hand experience. It is designed to give students a broad background of general knowledge which would be of special value because of its relation to various aspects of nursing.

CANDOR compels me to say of "Breaking New Ground" that it is somewhat less than a half-told tale. One gets the impression that the subject was not approached objectively. The title might well have been "Gifford Pinchot and Forestry in the United States."

IT is not usually dangerous to make a bid in a three-card minor suit, even though such bids often get bridge players in trouble. The trouble arises from the fact that the player who makes a bid in a-three-card suit becomes panicky when his partner raises it, and tries to rescue himself by bidding another suit.

FRANKUN DELANO ROOSEVELT wrote his first letter to his mother in 1887 when he was 5 years old. "Dear Sallie." he scratched with his pen, "I am very sorry you have a cold and you are in bed I played with Mary today for a little while I hope by tomorrow you will be able to be up I am glad to say my cold is better your loving Franklin D. Roosevelt."

THANKSGIVING DAY, at the turn of the century, was, for New Yorkers, a holiday even richer in aspect than it is today. In those times the city was addicted to fulldress parades, in addition to dressed turkey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. and Representative John C. Brophy, Republican, of Wisconsin, threatened Congressional action today to force the distribution of from $1,500,000,000 to $2,000,000,000 which the Veterans Administration is reported to have on hand in overpayments of insurance premiums by veterans.

LAKES SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- The General Assembly has shown in two months' work that the small and middle powers can prevent the United Nations from breaking up into two rigidly antagonistic blocs, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australia's Minister of External Affairs, declared today.

BIKINI REVISITED -- Preliminary results of a scientific resurvey last summer at Bikini Atoll were reported last week before the meeting of the National Academy of Sciences at Washington by Comdr. Roger Revelle of the geophysics branch, Office of Naval Research.

SEVERAL years ago Howard Breslin stood in a clearing on the ridge of a long, verdant mountain in Vermont and read a metal marker that bad been set in rock by the wand of history. The marker designated the clearing as the spot where the clamorous Whig Convention of 1840 was held.

TORONTO, Ont. WITH "Antony and Cleopatra," which opens at the Martin Beck Wednesday evening, Katharine Cornell is making her second obeisance to William Shakespeare, and for somebody, who frankly admits she used to be bored by the bard, her Shakespearean record has been very good indeed.

Time lost on the ground is one of the major problems of air travel. A survey of this problem is now being made by the Air Transport Association and the Port of New York Authority. All passengers on the nineteen domestic and overseas airlines serving New York will have an opportunity to answer simple questionnaires after they have taken off or are about to land.

The City Department of Housings and Buildings has begun a campaign to make owners of buildings within the five boroughs remove, as far as conditions permit, pending violations of the building code on their properties, it became known yesterday.

Caught in the web of a deficit that has been mounting for more than a decade, and with slight prospect for solution of the problem the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company soon may approach the Port of New York Authority in the hope that the agency will purchase its property for about $55,000,000.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 -- Playing before a record-smashing crowd of 102,050 frenzied fans, southern California's powerful Trojans defeated the University of California at Los Angeles, 6 to 0, today to win the Pacific Coast Conference football championship and roll on to play mighty Michigan in the Rose Bowl New Year's Day.

Beverly Somach, 12-year-old violinist of this city, made her debut in a recital given last night at Times Hall. In an exacting schedule, which included Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole," Tartini's "Devil's Trill" Sonata, two movements from a Bach Partita, and other difficult offerings, Miss So mach disclosed marked talent.

Ira A. Hirscnmann, a member of the Board of Higher Education, denounced his colleagues yesterday for "creating confusion" in the city colleges by a "weasel-worded" resolution condemning the organization called American Youth for Democracy.
ROME, Nov. 22 -- A considerable step toward normal in southern Italy was taken today when the general strike in Bari Province was called off and the men returned to work.

One hundred and sixty-five million Chinese were theoretically qualified to vote in the three-day national elections ending today. A million or so were actually expected to cast ballots. The candidates chosen will form a National Assembly, and this body, meeting at the end of December, will elect a President and Vice President.

SELDOM does a publisher's blurb dispense unvarnished truth. The jacket of "Rebel at Large" supplies an illuminating exception, in its characterization of the author, "ready now as ever to break a lance with what he considers the forces of evil -- in effect, everyone who doesn't agree with him."

The annual Polka Ball under the auspices of the Kosciuszko Foundation will take place on Dec. 26 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. It will be the fifteenth fete in a series of dances which in pre-war years was entitled the "Night in Poland" ball.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Delegate Joseph R. Farrington of Hawaii asked the Justice Department today to give the American Legion all information available on Communuist activity in Hawaii.

BERLIN, Nov. 22 (U.P.) -- Three alleged German "stool pigeons" and a Soviet Army officer were arrested in the United States sector of Berlin yesterday as they attempted to kidnap a German political refugee, the United States Provost Marshal's office announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- Following is the text of the statement made today by Herschel V. Johnson, United States delegate, in the Ad Hoc Committee on the Palestine Question of the United Nations General Assembly:

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 22 -- Lafayette met with unexpected opposition from its traditional foe, Lehigh, in their annual football clash today, but the Leopards, showing a punch just when it was needed, carved out a victory.

Financial markets finally were relieved last week of the uncertainly which had been overhanging them since the special session of Congress was announced. The address of President Truman contained no "surprises" and detracted nothing from the confusion which has existed for some time.

The American Ethical Union announced yesterday that it has asked the United States Supreme Court for permission to join in a brief submitted to test the constitutional validity of a system under which sectarian religious instruction is conducted in public school buildings during regular school hours.

PORTLAND Ore., Nov. 22 -- In a logging camp notched into the pine-covered foothills of Klamath Falls a brawny high-climber said he was not sure whether President Truman's plan to restore rationing and price controls would work, but that Congress "should try any scheme to make the cost of living come down."

TO THE EDITOR: This is not a letter about our dearest pets, dogs and cats, about whom there has been much in your recent letter columns, but still about "animals" who are tortured -- not for the sake of human future and present health, not for experiments, but just because their agony is used for window dressing.

To the Drama Editor: I HAVE observed with increasing concern the many articles both in the Drama Mailbag and in your editorial section relative to the alarming percentage of unemployed actors. Figures quoted elsewhere represent 92 per cent of Equity's membership as presently "at liberty."

Religious leaders of most faiths are becoming increasingly disturbed over the lack of adequate country-wide church and synagogue membership statistics, it was learned yesterday, despite the fact that the Federal Bureau of the Census has gathered figures on church membership every ten years beginning in 1906.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Figures now available indicate Japan's recovery is likely to be surprisingly quick after the peace treaty takes the occupation troops and the occupation economic controls off Japan's neck.

THE Glades is the only river of grass in the world. More to the point, it is the vital core of South Florida, for reasons of no interest, probably, to readers in forty-seven other states. The personalities of the Glades, however, are worth documenting.

VISITORS come in from the road bringing a curious mixture of reports on the state of the theatre beyond Broadway. One says it's bad, the other says it's good and you pays your money and takes your pick. Recently, however, a survey in Chicago brought out the fact that more people in the Windy City habitually are going to the theatre than before the war and that out-of-town attendance has boomed to a new high.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 22 -- Soviet Union officials have been in direct contact recently with Stern group terrorists, a responsible informant here asserted tonight.

FROM boyhood Francis Parkman seemed destined to be as much a man of action as a man of books. Brought up on the farm of his maternal grandfather at Medford, Mass., hard by the four-thousand-acre forest of Middlesex Fells, a miniature version of the primeval American wilderness, he early formed hardy outdoor tastes.

The oil industry is much concerned over what may be done in Washington with respect to re-imposition of controls over the distribution and sale of its products. While it is recognized generally that some controls may be necessary to ship additional quantities of oil to aid Europe, the industry would much prefer that these be through voluntary cooperation than through some government agency.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- St. Mary's Galloping Gaels had only one galloper at Braves Field today -- Squirmin' Herman Wedemeyer -- and since the terrain was muddy and the St. Mary's line was inadequate, Boston College overpowered the Moraga Marauders by a score of 25 -- 7.

Now in its twenty-first year of philanthropic service, the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor" on the night of Dec. 16 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The most daring long-range experiment by the United States to unshackle trade and head the world economy toward some semblance of balance was unveiled this week with publication of the results of the trade treaty conferences among twenty-three nations at Geneva.

HAVANA, Nov. 22 -- Sergio I. Clark, chairman of the Cuban delegation, was unanimously elected president of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment at a five-minute plenary session this afternoon.

PRAGUE, Nov. 22 -- Czechoslovakia's trade agreement with the Soviet Union is practically completed. A Foreign Trade Ministry spokesman said today that Minister Hubert Ripka would affirm it when he went to Moscow, probably next Thursday.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Japanese politicians of moderate outlook today are attempting quietly to ascertain if United States opinion now supports a new union of Conservative parties which, it is asserted, might serve as a stabilizing force in Asia for several years to come.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 22 -- Three hundred to 400 "leaders" of the insurgent forces in the recent civil war are at present being "tried," President Higinio Morinigo told this correspondent today in an interview. The men jailed include "ten to fifteen" Communits, he added.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Consumers' Price Index rose 2.2 per cent from mid-August to mid-September. The index reached a record high of 163.8 per cent of the 1935-39 base period.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. John Fayson Adams Burning Dream today took the $10,000 added San Francisco County Handicap at Bay Meadows and the winning jockey, Johnny Longden, equaled a 9-year-old California record by booting home six victors.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- An action to test the legality of the prospective ban by the American Federation of Musicians on music transcriptions and recordings has been started in New Jersey Chancery Court, but Vice Chancellor Wilfred H. Jayne today declined to issue a preliminary restraint while a decision is pending. The suit seeks a permanent injuction against the union's proposed blockade.

FOOTBALL Yale downed Harvard in their sixty-fourth meeting yesterday, while Princeton and Columbia took other big Eastern contests. Southern California, defeating U.C.L.A., became assured of playing Michigan in the Rose Bowl.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 22 -- Dr. Esteban Jaramillo,. noted lawyer and financier, died today of a heart attack a few hours before the time set for the wedding of his son. He was born in the State of Antioquia seventy-three years ago.

New housing in New York City, far from overtaking the urgent need, is actually lagging so far this year about 20 per cent behind last year's activity, it was shown yesterday on the basis of building permits issued by the State Labor Department.

BERLIN. MISERY loves not only company but an occasional sardonic chuckle, at its own expanse. The hard times in Germany have produced self-examination as well as self-pity, as these anecdotes, culled from the autumn crop of Berlin humorous periodicals, bear witness.

WHEN Hitler came to power few expected the septuagenarian, Gerhart Hauptmann, accustomed to the life of a Silesian grand seigneur, to follow the example of the other Nobel Prize winner. Thomas Mann, who preferred the discomfort of exile to a gilded cage under the swastika.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Nov. 22 -- The annual meeting of the Cocker Spaniel Field Trial Club of New Jersey, held today at Hamilton Farms, helped to emphasize the value of the American cocker spaniel as a hunter. Veterans of the game were loud in praise of the work here.

LUGNE-POE was what the Germans call a theatre-mensch, a man to whom life in the theatre is more real than the world outside. He was, moreover, the sort of man, familiar to every generation of artists, who is so poor that he does not need to worry about the cost of dreams, and who -- if fate favors him -- sometimes sees his dreams come true.

ONE of the phenomena of modern culture is an increasing interest in the musical expression of the past. This interest has resulted in extensive research into folk tunes, historical music and the popular songs of bygone days.

CHINA is today a blank space in the disorderly pattern of American world policy. Washington either does not know what to "do" about China or if it does know it is not sure how to go about it. Only recently a China specialist in the State Department caustically put it up to a visitor: "Here's your chance," he said, "to make American policy for China.

Late autumn burnishes the stars and hangs them back in place closer at hand. Or so it seems to one who walks a park path or a country road at this time of year, when the sun has set and the quick dusk has fallen. For there is an intimacy to the evening now, with the trees lifting bare branches against the sky and the stars coming down to the nearest hilltop.

WHEN Jimmy Savo arrived at La Rocca di Poggio, which is in Umbria, to become lord of the castle, the villagers couldn't have been aware that he had also been lord of the old Palace and the Keith-Albee chain, and likewise the Orpheum, Pantages and Poli circuits.

Under the direction of the United States Office of Education, vast changes are being planned for the 6,500,000 boys and girls attending the nation's high schools. A nine-man commission has been created to recommend revisions in the school curriculum and bring the courses closer to the needs of the day.

OTTAWA, Nov. 22 -- None of the restrictive or compulsory measures taken by the Canadian government during the war -- and these were numerous and severe -- aroused so much criticism and resentment among the general public as those taken this week for the alleged purpose of protecting Canada's dollar exchange situation.

Here and Abroad Last Thursday afternoon two men stood bareheaded in the chill wind at the National Airport on the banks of the Potomac. They clasped hands on the loading ramp beside a DC-4. One said, "Good luck and Godspeed." The other responded, "I'll do my best."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 22 -- In Illinois across the Mississippi River from the northern section of St. Louis, engineers and workmen have started construction of an eight-mile canal with a giant lock that will eliminate the last major obstacle to navigation in 1,100 river miles from Minneapolis-St. Paul to the Gulf of Mexico.

OTTAWA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Protests by the basketfuls and price increases as high as $500 on motor cars confronted the Canadian Government today in the aftermath of its decision to ease a shortage of United States dollars by cutting imports.
CASTEL, GANDOLFO, Italy, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The text of the Pope's broadcast follows:

Glenn Dobbs came back to Brooklyn yesterday and while the former Dodger ace gave no extraordinary performance, he had the satisfaction of seeing his team, the Los Angeles Dons, come from behind to beat the Dodgers, 16 -- 12, at Ebbets Field before a crowd announced as 11,866.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 23 -- The world's largest land airplane, the six-engined Consolidated Vultee XC-99 military transport, flew for one hour and two minutes today in its initial flight from Lindbergh Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The House Select Committee on Foreign Aid pointed out today how European nations could pay at least in part for American help by giving the United States access to strategic materials in three specific areas.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov arrived in London this afternoon to present the Soviet Union's case to what British Foreign Secretary Bevin describes as "the most vital" and what many believe will be the last meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 23 -- Champion Knightscroft Symphony, a gray Irish setter who looked as though she enjoyed every minute in the ring tonight, was chosen for best in show in the Newark Kennel Club's twenty - ninth all - breed event, revived after six years.

The Canadian free dollar took over the major role in the foreign exchange market last week in consequence of the regulations set down by the Canadian Government, on Monday, Nov. 17, to protect the dollar position of the Dominion.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 23 -- After long, difficult negotiations, details of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company's issue of new stock at last has been published.
Two "fire buffs," whose helpful deeds in the last few years have won the acclaim of upper East Side firemen, were accused yesterday of setting fire to two tenement houses "for excitement."

Rabbi Irving Miller, chairman of the Administrative Council of the Zionist Organization of America, denounced Great Britain yesterday for failure to cooperate with the United Nations in implementing the partition plan for Palestine. He accused Britain of "direct sabotage."

MANILA, Nov. 23 -- The extent and significance of the political revolt against President Manuel Roxas' still dominant majority Liberal party evidenced in the general elections is becoming easier to estimate with accuracy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A new nation-wide move to locate cancer cases at the best-chance stage, before there are any symptoms whatever, already has resulted in the establishment of 181 cancer-detection centers in thirty states and Washington, D.C.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Prices of lard, fats and oils were on the upgrade last week with December, January and July lard selling at a new seasonal peak as the result of general buying induced by the strong undertone shown in the general fat and oil situation and reports that soap manufacturers were inquiring for lard.

An agreement allowing for television coverage of twenty-five events at Madison Square Garden this season over WCBS-TV has been concluded under which the Maxwell House division of General Foods will undertake sponsorship. During the term of the contract, extending from Dec. 7 into April, 1948, hockey, intercollegiate and professional basketball and the Ringling Bros., Barnum Bailey's circus, will be among the events on the air.

Representatives of the steamship industry and maritime labor groups are preparing material for hearings scheduled for January in San Francisco on wages and working conditions on Government-subsidized merchant ships.

Gas-engined model airplanes roared in circles in a wire enclosure, lathes whirred and drills bit into plastic blocks as the 1947 Hobby, Crafts and Science Show opened yesterday afternoon in the exposition hall at Madison Square Garden.

The Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street, gave a total of $9,015,000 to 119 agencies and special projects in the social field from 1907 to 1946, Ralph G. Hurlin, acting general director, reported yesterday.

LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 23 -- The hope was expressed by Pope Piux XII today that "relief for the multitudes of uprooted, displaced persons of Europe may be brought nearer through understanding cooperation by men and governments of good will."

New York Ninety Years Ago On a wall in a New York home there hangs a panoramic view of the mid-Manhattan of 1855 which is a sure source of fascination to those who delight in comparing what was with what is.

Blackwell Smith has resigned as secretary and treasurer of the Kudner Agency, Inc., advertising, to take over his post with the Liberia Company, sponsored by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., it was announced over the week-end.
An attendance of more than 4,500 children and adults marked yesterday's sessions of the four-day Boys and Girls Book Fair at The American Museum of Natural History.

That fine and useful civic agency, the Citizens Union, will celebrate its fiftieth anniversary with a banquet this evening. We are confident we speak the sentiments of many citizens when we express gratitude for the steady, conscientious fight this organization has made through the years in the interest of good government in state and city.

OSLO, Norway, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, chairman of the Social Democratic party in Germany, met with angry demonstrations from an audience today when he attacked the Soviet occupation policy and said "Communists in all countries are the Quislings of Soviet Russia."

HAVANA, Nov. 23 -- The draft rules of procedure for the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment were amended by a subcommittee today to permit Sergio I. Clark of Cuba, conference president, to delegate his powers to a vice president whenever Senor Clark was absent or not presiding.
Total expenditures for all units of government in the United States will probably be in the neighborhood of $56,000,000,000 for 1947, the Tax Institute estimated yesterday.

Issuance in France of a dollar loan of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, to which French residents could subscribe anonymously in gold, thus permitting access to the gold now being hoarded in France, has been proposed by Andre Istel, former financial adviser to the French Government and French delegate at the United Nations Monetary Conference of Bretton Woods.

America's policy in the months ahead must be based upon right, humanity and justice, Francis B. Sayre declared last night. Mr. Sayre, president of the United Nations Trusteeship Council and alternate United States Representative at the Second Session of the General Assembly, spoke at a Sunday night meeting at Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, in the series titled "Christ the Answer Today."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Army disclosed today a decision to build up its only home-based airborne division to the full 16,000-man strength of a standard infantry division.

Michigan has completed its football schedule with a perfect record for the first time since 1932 and Penn State for the first time since 1912. These two stand among the nation's best With the season at an end for all but a few teams.
The first major test of a non-complying union's ability to withstand management challenge under the Taft-Hartley Law is developing at seven plants of Remington-Rand, Inc., in this state and Michigan.

The reconstructed First Methodist Church of Corona, Queens, which had fallen into semi-decay until the Rev. Damiano Rossi undertook the task of rebuilding it three years ago, received a new lease on life yesterday when it was rededicated by Methodist Bishop Herbert Welch, retired.
OMAHA, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Archbishop Ryan was formerly rector of the Catholic University of America in Washington, and was an author on religious philosophy.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took over first place in the National Hockey League tonight with a 9-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 16,681.

Danitza Ilitsch, the Metropolitan soprano, was heard in her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. As so commonly happens when a vocalist who belongs on the stage of the lyric theatre tempts fate on the concert stage, Miss Ilitsch was completely out of her element in essaying to make headway as a song interpreter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Senator Wallace H. White Jr. of Maine recently submitted his resignation as Republican majority leader in the Senate but the Republican conference refused to accept it, it became known tonight.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 23 -- Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican nomination for the Presidency, made a direct appeal to President Truman today to avoid "economic appeasement" of Russia, and virtually demanded further consideration of his program for an embargo on shipments of heavy machinery and machine tools to Russia until she is willing to co-operate in the rebuilding of Europe.

It is not often that a turnstile count at a football game rates as much attention as the outcome of the contest. This, however, was the situation yesterday at the Stadium, where 70,060 fans taxed the arena's capacity to witness a thrill-packed struggle in which the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Browns fought to a 28-28 story-book standstill.

An investigation into depreciation practices here and abroad by the Association of American Ship Owners indicates that the "straight-line" principle of depreciation has little relation to the rate of consumption of capital assets by the shipping industry, the association reported yesterday.

The campaign to raise $200,000 for a new clubhouse for the Brownsville Boys' Club in Brooklyn came to a successful close last night at a $100-a-plate dinner at the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn. Fifteen hundred persons attended.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, will have a signed editorial in the coming issue of The Republican News, official party organ, placing the party in virtual blanket opposition to President Truman's program to fight inflation.

General amnesty for conscientious objectors and other Selective Service violators, including Jehovah's Witnesses, was urged yesterday upon President Truman by a committee of 545 clergymen, educators and other persons.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The Foreign Ministers of the four great Allied powers will meet this week in London in about as bad an atmosphere as could have been imagined by a Jeremiah two and one-half years ago when Germany collapsed.
Harry D. Myers has been appointed executive vice president, director and general manager of the eight plants of The Standard Products Company, Detroit.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- With all reports indicating that the Government will ship as much wheat abroad as possible, combined with a sharp drop in temperatures over the winter wheat belt and the development of a scarcity of cash corn and oats at primary markets, prices of grains were kept on the upgrade last week on the Board of Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- An increase of $1,271,000,000 in loans and discounts made by the 5,019 national banks between June 30 and Oct. 6 was reported tonight by Preston A. Delano, Controller of the Currency.

The Election Day rescue at sea of thirty-one Portuguese fishermen by the transport Charles A. Stafford was one of twenty-three heroic achievements in the last seven months by men from an Army Transportation Corps ship.

Anticipating final Government approval of its acceptance as a member of the Atlantic, Gulf-Far East Conference, the Salen-Skaugen Line announced yesterday establishment of a regular fast freight service from New York and other East Coast ports to Orient ports, including Hong Kong, Shanghai and Manila.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The shock to the City of the dramatic resignation of Hugh Dalton as Chancellor of the Exchequer some ten days ago subsided quickly and the stock markets have staged a considerable recovery in the last few days.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Thanks partly to improved prospects of aid under the Marshall plan, the outlook for Great Britain is brighter than at any time since the war, two prominent members of the Government said today.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York sold the thirteen-story apartment house for forty-six families on a plot 104 by 85 feet at 410 Riverside Drive, north corner of 113th Street, to an investing client of Levy Nevins, attorneys, for cash over a mortgage of $250,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is much to be regretted that such an authority as Professor Peyre, in his letter to THE TIMES of Nov. 18, should unwillingly, I am sure, supply ammunition to the propagandists bent on undermining General de Gaulle's prestige in the eyes of the American public.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- Nobody has figured how much the recent Communist-instigated strikes cost Italian economy. It is certain that they called for the expenditure of large sums by the Italian Communist party.

Handicapped persons and needy families in Brooklyn know that when their problems become too overpowering for them to solve there is one sympathetic and willing friend to whom they can always turn -- the Brooklyn Bureau of Social Service, at 285 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn 17.

The executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations debated yesterday in closed meeting a proposal to change the name of the organization to that of The Union of Liberal Synagogues. After considerable discussion, it was decided to refer the question to the next executive board meeting and ultimately to the biennial council that will meet in Boston next autumn.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week were featured by a sharp advance in spots and in the nearer future deliveries, while the more distant months were relatively easy. At the close of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange on Saturday, active futures contracts from December through July showed for the week net gains of 53 to 154 points, while the more distant contracts showed net declines of 19 to 31 points.

More parents seeking help in child guidance, more youngsters badly in need of help, long waiting lists at every agency with no other place to turn are factors in a "critical situation" discussed yesterday by the Jewish Board of Guardians, 228 East Nineteenth Street.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The annual convention of the House of Delegates of the New York State Teachers Association opened today with individual delegates urging increased retirement benefits and repeal of the system of promotional pay increments for teachers.

A campaign to raise $100,000 for the establishment of a war memorial concert hall in the present auditorium of the Abraham Lincoln High School, Ocean Parkway and West Avenue, Brooklyn, was started yesterday at a meeting in the Half Moon Hotel, Coney Island.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Corn futures led the advance in the grain markets last week. Relatively small country offerings for this season of the year, unfavorable weather for completion of harvest and reports that a shortage of corn for feeding was developing in parts of Iowa and that truckers were bidding higher prices than were country elevators served to increase bullish enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Senator Owen Brewster, chairman of the Senate War Investigating Committee, asked to be informed today why the $117,000,000 profits of two wholly owned subsidiaries of American companies, chartered and operating abroad, should go untaxed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Villanova Wildcats came from behind to score two touchdowns in the final period and defeat the University of San Francisco Dons by 21 -- 19 today in a thrill-filled game before a crowd of 20,000.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Scoring in every period, the Buffalo Bills kept alive their hopes for the Eastern Division title in the All-America Football Conference today by defeating the Baltimore Colts, 33 -- 14, in a rough contest before 19,593 persons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- It was "Sammy Baugh Day" at Griffith Stadium today and the old pass master of the Washington Redskins gratefully responded by throwing six touchdown passes for a stunning 45-21 upset victory over the Chicago Cardinals.

Richard Strauss' "Rosenkavalier" and Verdi's "Aida" will receive their first performances of the season during the Metropolitan Opera's fourth week, it was announced yesterday. The role of the Marschallin in the former will be sung by Erna Schlueter, the new soprano from Germany.

Careful analysis of the actual amount of consumer credit outstanding, and its true components, should be made before Congress moves toward reinstatement of Regulation W, it was urged here last week by J. Anton Hagios, executive manager of the Broad Street and Merchants Association of Newark, N.J., and an authority on consumer credit.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- While being out-shot by the top-heavy margin of 19 -- 9, the Boston Bruins gained a 2-2 National Hockey League tie with the Montreal Canadiens tonight before 13,900 fans at the Garden. Kenny Reardon, Canadiens star defenseman, won the dubious honor of scoring for both sides.

The case of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers has now passed from the hands of the Senate War Investigating sub-committee to those of the Department of Justice. The subcommittee's record, which includes Gen. H.H. Arnold's testimony on Saturday, is shocking. General Meyers, a pilot in the first World War, rose in this war from major to deputy chief of the Army Air Forces procurement command.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- Raw material shortages and production troubles notwithstanding, steel in-got output last week continued at the post-war peak of 97.5 per cent of rated capacity. Several areas, including this one, have been able to maintain output above 100 per cent for weeks on end.

Large lots of stationery and safety razors for the light consumer goods field as well as major offerings of automotive maintenance tools, construction power tools and supplies highway equipment and wire and cable are among the listings in government surplus sales, announced over the week-end by Alwyn A. Throckmorton, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

PARIS, Monday, Nov. 24 -- Premier Robert Schuman announced at 1 o'clock this morning the composition of his Cabinet. Its first task will be to deal with the creeping strike movement that is slowly paralyzing all activities in France.

Once again within the lifetime of this generation the United States finds itself cast in a role of leadership such as destiny has seldom thrust on any nation. Once again, as during and after the first World War, this country, which provided the decisive power for victory, is looked upon by free men everywhere as their main hope for the realization of the aims for which they fought and so many of them died.

Mr. Truman must have wondered last week what a President has to do to win general approbation for his policies. For weeks before he summoned Congress back to Washington he had been subjected to a running fire of criticism for his lack of leadership in tackling the twin problems of European aid, on the one hand, and domestic price inflation on the other.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation swept up forty-seven prisoners in a sudden smash late last night at what it called far-flung white slavery operations centering at Ironton, Ohio.

Despite the Thanksgiving holiday many shows of paintings and sculpture have been scheduled in another crowded week of art events. Among today's openings is a "One World Exhibition" at the Argent Galleries sponsored by the National Association of Women Artists for the benefit of Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE).

The more careful and concentrated one's reading is the less he learns, it was asserted yesterday by Norman Lewis, supervisor of reading-improvement courses for City College's adult education program. He said the fast reader developed a much keener perception and understanding of the material.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, announced tonight farm-production goals for 1948 calling for a continuation of high wartime levels of output.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent editorial, "Warmongeing," you seem to have joined with the press, radio and public speaker generally in the almost universal d nunciation of the policy pursued the Kremlin, and in imputing entire blame on Russia for the impasse which has developed between Russia and the United States.

LAKE SUCCESS N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The United Nations Ad Hoc Committee on the Palestine Question is within sight of its goal -- a vote on the two plans before it for the government of the Holy Land after the British Government ends its mandate.

This is the tea-and-toast season, when it's pleasant to close the blinds on a late Sunday afternoon (or any other day when there's the time to do so) and sip a cup of the steaming brew. Embellishments for the hot, crisp toast that is part of the tea tray are Greenwich Inn preserves, old standbys at Abraham Straus in Brooklyn and presented this autumn in a new and highly useful manner.

Failure to score in four tries from the two-yard line cost the Giants their first National Football League victory of the season yesterday. They wound up in a 24-to-24 deadlock as Green Bay came back after this reprieve to tie the count with six minutes and five seconds to play.

Spring ready-to-wear lines in the wholesale market last week were being favorably accepted, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Raincoat reorders, the report stated, were heavy.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 23 -- The Government of the Dominion of India is considering "parallel measures" to Pakistan's recently announced export levy on jute at the Moslem Dominion's borders "to protect the interests of the Indian Dominion," the Indian Finance Ministry announced tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has assigned the long-projected remake of Edna Ferber's 1930 novel, "Cimarron," to Arthur Freed, producer, for filming early next year and has named Kathryn Grayson to play the leading role.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 23 -- The Rumanian Government tonight declared that its courts properly had condemned "treasonable actions" by former National Peasant party leaders "who were in the service of certain foreign interests" and had condemned at the same time attempts at foreign intervention into Rumania's internal affairs.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Boley Dancewicz tossed two touchdown passes and scored himself to give the Boston Yanks their first victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in National Football League-history by a 21 -- 14 margin today before 15,368 fans at Fenway Park.

ALBANY, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The Civil Service Employes Association, charging that state workers are receiving "shabby" treatment, made public today a letter sent to members of the Legislature asking for minimum salary adjustments of 25 per cent.
Eight Eastern colleges placed men on the sector's all-star football team for 1947 in contrast to recent years when Army's dominant outfit garnered virtually all the glory.

A sweeping reorganization of the Department of Correction to place it on a "peace officer" basis with a clear-cut chain of command and definite fixing of responsibility at various levels was disclosed yesterday in a report submitted to Mayor O'Dwyer by Correction Commissioner Albert Williams.

TWO years ago a novelette by John Steinbeck was published in The Woman's Home Companion. It was a good novelette, infinitely superior to the wretched novels which Mr. Steinbeck was, writing at about the same time and which have done so much to damage his literary reputation. It was called "The Pearl of the World" and it seems to have been written after "Cannery Row" and before "The Wayward Bus."

With three arrests made over the weekend, detectives of the Automobile and Forgery Squad said yesterday that they had broken up a well-organized ring responsible for the theft and re-sale of fourteen automobiles this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The announced intention of the Senate War Investigating subcommittee to enter a grand-scale inquiry into wartime procurement by the armed services raised today the possibility of fresh Senatorial disputes over the whole question of inquisitorial activities.

BOSTON, Mass., Nov. 23 -- Eighty brand names identifying products made in the Boston area for half a century or more will be honored with "certificates of public service" at a dinner in the Statler Hotel Tuesday night. The dinner, sponsored by the Boston Chamber of Commerce and the Advertising Club of Boston in cooperation with the Brand Names Foundation, will be attended by business, industrial and advertising leaders.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- The coal miners in Lorraine voted today to return to work. This vote constituted the first important check to the wave of strikes that threatens to affect the railroads, shipping and steel industries, already partly strike-bound.

The one-story showroom and Service building containing about 24,000 square feet of space and occupied by the Tech-Art Plastics Manufacturing Company on Northern Boulevard between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by Herbert Properties to the Island Pontiac Corporation, Andrew Neville, president The C. Grant Keck Organization was the broker and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

In many quarters it is being alleged that high taxes are the cause of high prices. To ease the pressure on prices, therefore it is proposed to lower taxes. An analysis of the relationship between prices and taxes indicates that this line of reasoning involves a serious oversimplification of the problem under present conditions.

BOSTON, Nov. 23 -- The Atlantic Fishermen's Union, AFL, is dividing among its 1,300 members a $40,000 welfare fund won after a six-months tie-up of the Boston trawler fleet in 1946, a union official said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Kenton R. Cravens of St. Louis, president of the American Bankers Association, said today that he would urge Congress to turn down President Truman's request for restoration of consumer credit controls as a means of fighting inflation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (U.P.) -- William Green, president, of the American Federation of Labor, today extended his trades-union campaign against Soviet Russia to Latin America and charged that the Mexican labor leader, Vicente Lombardo Toledano, was trying to entice Latin-American workers into the Communist camp.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The board of directors of the United States Chamber of Commerce advised Congress today to set up a separate corporation to control and administer our program of aid to Europe. Such an administrating body has been proposed by the Herter Committee of the House.

Educational opportunity is the best method of perpetuating democracy, former Governor Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday at the fourth annual conference of the Council of Organizations for Yeshiva University in the Hotel Astor. The university, located at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street, is campaigning for $7,500,000 for its expansion program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) --The Chicago Bears smashed 422 yards during seven scoring thrusts -- averaging 11.1 yards per play -- to overwhelm the Pittsburgh Steelers, 49 -- 7, in a National Football League game before a crowd of 34,142 today.

PRAGUE, Nov. 23 -- Czechoslovakia's economic planners appear to have decided against a subsidy system to lower prices. Studies of efforts to lower prices by subsidy showed they had proved largely ineffective and Czechoslovak economists believe the money could have been used to better effect by having subsidized the earnings of the low income groups to enable them to pay prices maintained by price and wage controls.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- The United Nations is renewing its lease on the New York City Building at Flushing Meadow, Queens, it was learned today, in preparation for a "probable" special session of the General Assembly early next year.

Juvenile delinquency is treated through vocational training and compliance with authority but not as a psychiatric problem at the New York State Training School for Girls in Hudson, Dr.J. Louise Despert, Professor of Psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College, declares in the fall issue of The Nervous Child, to be published today.

The National Legion of Decency yesterday announced the lifting of the total ban it imposed last August on "Black Narcissus," the British-made drama written, produced and directed by Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger, the producing team known as The Archers, which was presented by J. Arthur Rank and released here by Universal - International.

A special blessing from Pope Pius on the clergy and parishioners of St. Luke's Roman Catholic Church, 623 East 138th Street, the Bronx, was read yesterday by Cardinal Spellman at the close of a solemn pontifical mass of thanks-giving marking the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the parish.
A group of elderly Bronx residents ranging in age from 65 to 89 presented yesterday an original three-act play, "The Stranger," in the Bronx House, 1637 Washington Avenue.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 23 -- Widespread reorganization of educational systems throughout the world to prevent wars was envisaged as one of the principal objectives of the second general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization that is entering the home stretch here this week.
Mayor O'Dwyer will break ground tomorrow for two school additions, one in Brooklyn and the other in Queens, the Board of Education announced yesterday.
Statements condemning and approving the work of the House Committee on Un-American Activities were issued yesterday by a group of local clergymen and a group of writers.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 23 (AP) -- The National Ski Association, closing its four-day fortieth convention today, re-elected Roger Langley of Barre, Mass., president, and named Alfred D. Lindley, Minneapolis, to represent the association at the forthcoming Olympic games at St. Moritz, Switzerland.

With the Ballet Theatre season in full swing at the City Center and Harald Kreutzberg in his third recital of the season at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night, dance activities of the week-end were well concentrated in the middle Fifties. Novelties were rare in both places, but at least one was on each of the two schedules.

The United States Olympic Committee will not permit the International Ice Hockey Federation to "dictate to us" in the selection of this country's entry in the winter Olympics, Avery Brundage, chairman of the committee, said yesterday through The Associated Press.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- Pope Pius XII today urged the people of the United States to help alleviate hunger and general suffering in Europe and in the Orient. He warned of an increase in suffering with the coming of winter.

ROME, Nov. 23 -- Italy passed a second comparatively quiet day after two weeks of strikes, disorders and confusion, although new strikes have begun or are about to start and the wave of lawlessness has not subsided completely.

ROMSEY, England, Nov. 23 -- Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, came out from the walled Broadlands estate today to meet the neighbors attending late Sunday morning service at Romsey's twelfth-century abbey Church of Sts. Mary and Elfleda.

Analysis, of a Federal Trade Commission study of industry wartime profits shows that manufacturers of cotton textiles in 1945 ranked ninth among industries showing an increase of net earnings over 1941, according to The Cotton-Textile Institute in a bulletin released over the week-end.

Mayor O'Dwyer's 1948 legislative program, including the proposal to pave the way for a limited fare rise on the municipal transit lines without a referendum, has been completed, it was announced last night. The Mayor will discuss it in detail tomorrow at a conference with State Senator Elmer F. Quinn of Manhattan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut of Brooklyn, leaders of the Democratic minority in the State Legislature.
VIENNA, Nov. 23 -- Swiss sources have revealed how the Soviet Union has exploited its seizure of heavy industry in eastern Austria to dominate industry in western Austria as well.

He was born Willie Sims, but his name now is Willie Six. Willie had a pretty nice time the day of the big football game last Saturday down at Sewanee in Tennessee. It didn't start out so good. It was cold and rainy and the old man had twinges of rheumatism. Worst of all, at 61, he was quitting his beloved job after thirty-nine years.
