Slowly gaining impetus is a worthy project -- the City Center's Theatre Company. Over the weekend it became known that the program under consideration for the six-week period (Jan. 5 - Feb. 14) would comprise "Volpone," "Angel Street" and "Arms and the Man."

The presence or lack of poetry is a touchstone of the freedom or servility of a particular political system, Sir Alexander Cadogan, British delegate to the United Nations, asserted last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel sponsored by the Academy of American Poets.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: This letter is to explain, why the Outdoor Cleanliness Association appeals to the public for funds.

Several hundred youngsters gathered in the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, for a pre-Thanksgiving service yesterday morning. Later they took part in the dedication of four plane trees outside the synagogue.

The Rev. Thomas F. Maher of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared yesterday at solemn mass that the Thanksgiving Food Appeal for Europe and the Far East constituted a "challenge to every Christian" to relieve the "burning necessity of his neighbor."
NANKING, Nov. 23 -- China's first experiment with democracy in the three-day elections for delegates to the National Assembly ended tonight

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams, sparked by Tom Harmon and Jim Benton, breezed to a 28-17 victory over the Detroit Lions today to push the Lions deeper into the National Football League's Western Division cellar.

The Samuel H. Kress Foundation, 745 Fifth Avenue, has made a "conditional" contribution of $1,000,000 to the projected $15,575,000 New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center, Rush H. Kress, vice president of the foundation and officials of the Medical Center fund campaign announced yesterday.

The freedom of Northern Ireland can be achieved only "by the use or the threat of force" against Britain, Patrick Maxwell, member of the Northern Ireland Parliament, said yesterday. He charged that the present British Government, was more "anti-Irish" than previous ones.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Great Britain has reached another turning point in her history. An old and very great era has ended; a new one is beginning. As before, her enemies and friends are writing her off as a great power and even at home the faint-hearted and the weary are saying:
The twenty-sixth annual service for patriotic societies of New York was held yesterday afternoon in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Industrialist Henry J. Kaiser called on Congress yesterday for immediate action to increase production and suggested tax concessions as an incentive. Speaking over Station WJZ Mr. Kaiser asserted that "the way to lick shortages and ever-rising prices is to increase manufacturing facilities and production.

CRUGERS, N.Y., Nov. 23 -- A new veterans' hospital with 16,500,000 cubic feet of space and many miles of corridors is rising in quick time from a rocky plateau here beside the Hudson River, somewhat as Washington's sprawing Pentagon Building mushroomed to meet the war emergency.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Sixteen hundred members of the Chicago Typographical Union No. 16, of the International Typographical Union, AFL, voted a pay-rise ultimatum on six Chicago newspapers today and decided to take a strike vote tomorrow at 6 P.M. if the rise was not granted.

Large savings in production costs, now being reported for the first time since the end of the war, were an outstanding feature of recent technical sessions of Meehanite foundries during their annual meeting in Cleveland, Ohio, C.E. Herington, director of the engineering services, Meehanite Metal Corporation, consultants, revealed here yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- With the favorite, Joseph Dushock's Mahmoudess practically left at the post, H.L. Straus' hard-running March Chick today was the winner of the Comar Manor Purse, featuring the final Monday program of the Bowie session.

DALLAS, Texas, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Cotton Bowl Athletic Association officials today were stymied in efforts to agree upon an opponent for their New Year's Day classic because of the possibility that the Southwest Conference race may still end in a tie.

The arrest of eight business men on charges of having received goods stolen in two burglaries at the terminal of the Whisenant Transfer Company, 417 East Thirty-seventh Street, was announced yesterday by Edward Scheidt, chief of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The Canadian Broadcasting Corportation plans to introduce next month a full evening's schedule of programs which are "stimulating, substantial, different and at times more demanding on the attention of the listener," according to word received yesterday from Toronto.

Tribute to the late Miss Martha Berry, founder of the Berry Schools for poor mountain children in Georgia forty-six years ago, and its present-day sponsors was paid last night at a Thanksgiving dinner in the Roosevelt Hotel. Five hundred guests heard Dr. Sarah Gibson Blanding, president of Vassar College, cite the need for greater equalization of educational opportunity.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 24 -- Mayor Donal J. Connolly of Trenton, was charged today in an indictment returned by a, Mercer County grand jury "with conspiring while a state employe to issue illegal beauty shop and beauty school licenses for which money was accepted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Ignoring legal niceties, the Air Force threw Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, off its payroll today, stripped him of his medals and made preparations for his trial by a court-martial.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Truman reported to Congress today that less than $25,000,000 remained uncommitted out of the $332,000,000 appropriated last July for the assistance of Austria, China, Greece, Italy and Trieste. This appropriation was voted before, and is in addition to the $400,000,000 emergency grant President Truman asked for Greece and Turkey last March.

Present-day education in the professional fields is no longer adequate to meet the problems of a rapidly changing world, Prof. Elliott Dunlap Smith, provost at the Carnegie Institute of Technology, declared yesterday.

BAD HOECHST, Germany, Nov. 24 -- Over strong British protests, the United States Military Government has placed a "temporary" ban on all new contracts for the purchase in the United States zone of German goods by countries offering payment in sterling, it was learned here today at the headquarters of the Joint Export-Import Agency.

Travel and resort fashions in woven and knitted woolens were shown yesterday by the International Wool Secretariat at a luncheon at the Junior League Clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Among the featured colors were those inspired by the bark and grain of cedar -- one a warm brown of polished cedar tones, another a beige, the shade of the wood grain.

The Cundard White Star liner Mauretania docked at Pier 90, North River, yesterday with 1,158 passengers, among them Jascha Heifetz, concert violinist, and his wife, and Bruno Walter, conductor of the New York Philharmonic.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Traffic congestion is moving from New York into Westchester County "like a conflagration" and soon will be out of hand unless a control organization is created here, Leslie Williams, New York planning and traffic engineer, told the County Board of Supervisors today.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Francis T. Spaulding, State Commisioner of Education, today advocated "a substantial increase" in state aid to schools and said he would "do everything in my power" to increase the number of automatic pay rises for teachers.

In contrast with previous years, budget millinery will receive the greatest emphasis by the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission in 1948, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Finkelstein, executive director of the commission.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Lou Boudreau today signed "what virtually amounts to a two-year contract to manage the Indians," the Cleveland president, Bill Veeck, announced tonight, putting a stopper on persistent reports the star shortstop would be traded.

The Consumer Service Section of the Citizens Food Committee ha prepared ideas to "save wheat; save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: A Peace Plate omelet like any of those suggested below is a simple solution to the problem of observing "meatless" Tuesday -- and a nutritionally sound one, too.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Members of Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union, a unit of the International Typographical Union, AFL, walked out on strike tonight against the city's six daily newspapers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Prof. Leo Szilard of the University of Chicago, who was the first to discover the chain reaction that made the atomic bomb possible, has addressed an open letter to Premier Josef Stalin of Russia, urging him to initiate a new type of chain reaction that might "remove the block which has caused the deadlock" between Russia and the United States.

Catherine Klimiades, an 18month-old child born in Greece, approached reunion with her mother yesterday when she left La Guardia Field for Minneapolis in the care of a Northwest Airline hostess. The baby's mother, who is an American citizen, had returned to the United States earlier to prepare for her daughter's legal entry.

That the blind can do more than make brooms was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the annual Christmas sale of articles made by the blind. The exhibition, conducted by the New York State Commission for the Blind will be at 1 East Forty-fourth Street through Dec. 16.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Estimates of the future need for professional nurses, released today by the Woman's Bureau of the Department of Labor, indicate that 500,000 to 550,000 professional nurses, or some 200,000 more than were available in 1946, will be required by 1960 if current standards of nursing are maintained.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Johnny Berardino, second baseman traded by the St. Louis Browns to the Washington Senators Saturday, said today he has signed a seven-year acting contract with Richard K. Polimer Productions and is "through with baseball."

Two Navy men were killed yesterday when a two-engined Navy plane crashed in a lot at Francis Lewis Boulevard and 130th Avenue, Laurelton, Queens. The plane was on a routine flight from Norfolk, Va., to Floyd Bennett Field.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Democrats in the Senate have developed a new way of demonstrating their respect for Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg's aid on foreign policy issues. They all gather politely in the upper chamber, as they did this morning, to hear him launch the debate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, told an unprecedented session of the Senate Appropriations Committee late today that the same type of wide powers as were in effect during the war on commodities in short supply would be asked by the Administration from the present session of Congress.

Governor Dewey in looking over the state's budget prospects for the coming year apparently finds small reason for comfort. Dispatches from Albany in recent days suggest that the budget for 1948-49 is likely to pass the $700,000,000 mark. Obviously no tax cuts are in prospect.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A new technique for repairing hernias, employing a screen-like tantalum mesh, was reported today at the opening session of the Southern. Medical Association's fortyfirst meeting, by Dr. Amos R. Koontz, a surgeon at Johns Hopkins Hospital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Southern California, Conference champion and Rose Bowl nominee, placed four men on the Associated Press 1947 All-Pacific Coast football team. The 23d annual consensus of coaches and experts was announced today.

Marc Blitzstein's musical show, "The Cradle Will Rock," was given an electrifying performance last night, under Leonard Bernstein's direction, at the City Center of Arts and Drama. We understand that on this occasion, which signalized Mr. Bernstein's last performances of his orchestral series this season, the work was presented for the first time as completely, with orchestra, chorus and cast, as the composer conceived it.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 24 -- "Police state" methods of the Federal Government were scored here today by Lowell B. Mason, so-called minority member of the Federal Trade Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Senate speech of Senator Vandenberg on emergency aid for Europs: Mr. President: I present to the Senate the bill for interim aid to France, Italy and Austria in their battle against winter hunger and winter cold and against the lurking tyranny which feeds upon such disaster.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Following is the text of an Arab proposal regarding Jewish refugees that resulted in a tie vote tonight in the Palestine Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. The vote was 16-16, with twentythree abstentions and two absentees.

Less than four months after the election of William T. Rossell as president of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company, he announced yesterday that he would resign at the end of this year "to return to the Transit Research Corporation."

Philip F. LaFollette and Commodore Jennings B. Dow, U.S.N., retired, have been elected to the board of directors of the Hazeltine Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Mr. La Follette was three times Governor of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Three American Federation of Labor affiliates whose members are employed in forty-eight states by the Western Union Telegraph Company, announced today that they were circulating a strike vote ballot, among 50,000 telegraph employes.

MANILA, Nov. 24 -- President Manuel Roxas opened the second plenary session of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East with a bold plea for an Asiatic share in "dollar altruism" and outspoken criticism of exclusive world concern for European problems.

The Ives-Quinn anti-bias law is "not directed against any group or individual, but works for the selfinterests of all concerned," John B. Sullivan, director of public relations, education and research of the State Commission Against Discrimination, told the Brooklyn College Interfaith Council yesterday at its annual Thanksgiving convocation.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Hams, toys and pots and pans will be tucked away in the baggage of United Nations officials who are leaving here this week, homebound for Christmas.

TRIESTE, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- Army headquarters announced tonight that six American soldiers were seized today by Yugoslav troops along the northern border of Trieste free territory. The men were identified as a staff sergeant and five other members of the Eighty-eighth Cavalry Reconnaissance Group.

WAUPUN, Wis., Tuesday, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Sixty-nine prisoners held four unarmed guards as hostages in the barricaded laundry of the State Prison early today, eight hours after they started a sit-down strike.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Pianist Oscar Levant earns $200,000 a year, and his wife, June, wants $36,600 of it she declared today in a suit for separate maintenance. They have three children. Among the major items listed in her plea for $3,050 a month were rent, $450; food $400; clothing, $500; transportation, $200; medical expenses, $200; household help, $500; schooling, $200; gifts, $200; incidentals, $300.

Twenty-five thousand children, with parents and teachers, attended the first Boys' and Girls' Book Fair, which closed yesterday after four days at the Museum of Natural History. The fair, for which the museum, the Children's Book Council and THE NEW YORK TIMES were sponsors, displayed 5,000 volumes ranging in type from picture books to popular science discussions.

Substantial sums were lost to the city and state in unpaid Federal reimbursements for relief because of the city Welfare Department's laxity in classifying relief recipients, according to testimony produced yesterday before the state relief inquiry in the State Office Building.
Mrs. Freya Compain, known in France during the war to thousands of GI's, for whom she made "a home away from home," arrived here yesterday from Le Havre aboard the French Line vessel Oregon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Leo T. Crowley, president and chairman of the board of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that since it began its investigation of the facts surrounding the company's annual meeting "an attempt has been made to tap my telephone wire and four or five detectives have been hired to follow me."

Sacramento, Calif. The First Boston Corporation and associates were high bidders yesterday for a new issue of $1,938,000 of unified school district bonds of Sacramento City, Calif., due on each June 15 from 1963 to 1972.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The chairman of the State Food Commission, noting that the amount of duck in storage was more than double that of a year ago, urged housewives today "to consider seriously the use of Long Island, ducklings" in daily menus.

Notre Dame's resounding 59-6 rout of Tulane sent the Fighting Irish back into the No. 1 spot in the weekly Associated Press poll of football writers in a close finish with the powerful Michigan Wolverines.

Partitioning of Palestine was defended last night by Dr. Carl Hermann Voss, extension secretary of the Church peace Union, and opposed by Kermit Roosevelt Jr., former adviser to the State Department on mid-eastern affairs, in a debate at a dinner forum in the New School for Social Research, 68 West Twelfth Street.

Fifty leading executives of the motion picture industry, with special legal advisers, including James F. Byrnes and Paul V. McNutt, met yesterday in closed session at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to formulate a policy in regard to the employment of Communists.

LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 24 -- Mrs. Rosemary McDonald of Twin Lakes, Minn., a mother of five children, told delegates to the National Catholic Rural Life Conference here today that she would rather be a housewife on a farm than an angel.

GRAVESEND, England, Nov. 24 -- Winston Churchill, in a telegram tonight to the conservative candidate in the parliamentary by-election here Wednesday, "disputed what he said were widespread Laborite insinuations that postwar shortages in Britain were due to his failure to come an arrangement with President Roosevelt to continue lend-lease after the war ended."

"Thursdays Till 9," a musical comedy produced by the New York Department Store Joint Board, CIO, gave the first of four performances last evening at the Central Needle Trades High School on West Twenty-fourth Street. A Broadway contingent was there, ready to pounce on another "Pins and Needles."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Due, perhaps, to the widespread belief that the Marshall Plan is going to be accepted by Congress, little public attention has yet been paid to one of its most significant aspects. That is its value as a safeguard against imminent war, which can be appreciated only by considering some of the logical consequences of adverse Congressional action.

Football uniforms have been laid away in the moth balls at a majority of colleges and coaches now are worrying about 1948, but a great deal of unfinished business remains for the current season. Although only a comparative handful of games are scheduled, this will be one of the biggest weeks of the year, with important clashes listed for Thanksgiving Day and Saturday that will draw vast crowds.
Publication today of "The American College Dictionary," by Random House, Inc., 457 Madison Avenue, was hailed yesterday as a significant advance in the field of lexicography.

OLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- n L. Miller has been assigned Warner Brothers to adapt FosFitzsimmon's novel, "Bright f," to the screen and to proe the film next year, the studio ounced today. The novel deals i a Southern tobacco dynasty, the author is a member of the lty of the University of South olina.

In view of progressively good business, Clifford C. Fischer has decided to extend the engagement of the French variety show headed by Edith Piaf. The entertainment will remain at the Playhouse through Dec. 6, although originally scheduled to shut down after next Saturday night's performance.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Grain prices continued to advance today on the Board of Trade, with all deliveries of wheat, corn, oats, and soy beans, except July wheat and oats, selling at new seasonal peak prices. December wheat and oats sold at a record top, as did cash oats in the spot market.

BERNE, Nov. 24 -- American mass-produced products, often regarded in Europe as sacrificing quality for quantity, have established themselves in Switzerland as quality leaders, a high Swiss trade official said today.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 24 -- A clear definition of freedom of information is a basic issue of the second general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, Milton S. Eisenhower, chairman of the United Stated National Commission for the UNESCO, said today.

Offerings of $14,500,000 of railroad equipment trust certificates and $1,350,000 of convertible preferred stock of a financing company were made yesterday by underwriting managers as follows: Southern Pacific Company -- $14,500,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing serially over ten years at prices to yield from 1.35 per cent to 2.90 per cent, by Salomon Brothers Hutzler.

Distributing industries comprise the largest undeveloped market for the billion dollar materials handling equipment industry, Samuel W. Gibb, general sales manager, Philadelphia division, The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Although the situation in education is still serious, the nation's schools have shown a "substantial" improvement over conditions that existed a year ago, a survey issued today by the National Education Association indicates.

A completely new system of budgetary planning is now being used by Ford Motor Company, and first steps of putting new policies into action were taken here yesterday in a Ford Motor Company regional meeting of more than 70 executives at the opening of a twoday conference at the Commodore Hotel.

Reporting on operations of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, C.N. Hilton, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the business volume and earnings in the first nine months of this year exceeded that of any corresponding period by the individual hotel properties that now comprise the present corporation, formed on May 31, 1946.

Appointment of Joseph M. Brennan as general manager of the drop forge division and George F. Bluth as director of manufacturing facilities and methods of Willys-Overland Motors was announced in Toledo, Ohio, yesterday by William E. Paris, vice president in charge of operations.

The decline in refunding of bonds, which has been under way since 1945, when the peak of such refinancing occurred, has become more pronounced since money rates have hardened and since prices of listed bonds began to decline.

While Senator Vandenberg was introducing legislation yesterday to give effect to the first of the three requests made of Congress by the President a week ago, machinery was beginning to move which is expected to grind out the answer to his second request -- power to deal with the domestic inflation situation.

There are sound reasons for concentrating in Europe the bulk of such aid as the United States is now able to furnish to nations which are threatened by Russo-Communist expansion. For one thing, the complex industrial economy of Europe is far more vulnerable to an assault of this kind than is the predominantly agrarian economy of Asia.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Jack Milne, a dark horse from North Carolina, sloshed through the gluey, sticky snow that covered the four-mile Michigan State cross country course here today to win the ninth annual N.C.A.A. meet in 20:41.1.

The finding of four package's of heroin among the effects of a narcotic smuggler, who died of a heart attack aboard a plane Sunday night, touched off an intensive search yesterday for the leaders of an international ring.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Maj. Gen. Paul R. Hawley, who reorganized the medical service, of the Veterans Administration under Gen. Omar N. Bradley, announced today his own resignation dated Jan. 1, within a few days after announcement that General Bradley would retire as Veterans Administrator.

Store Sales Up 5% in Week Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 5 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Four ways in which consumer can -- and should -- help to ease the shortage of gasoline and other oil were listed yesterday in a rapor by the American Petroleum Institute. The report noted that the petroleum industry has built reserves up to a new high, that it has refining facilities adequate for the expected record demand of 5,803,000 barrels daily, and that it is spending hundreds of millions of dollars on new facilities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A United States proposal that European participants in the Marshall plan enlist the aid of Canada and Latin America as prospective sources of credit and supplies has been rejected by British representatives on the Committee of European Economic Cooperation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The editorial entitled "Australia Turns Right," in your issue of Nov. 14, is an oversimplification of an extremely difficult political situation. It is quite true that the defeat of the Labor party in the recent elections in Victoria follows a similar reversal in state elections in Western Australia a few months ago.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 24 -- Heavy drains on state financial resources were proposed today in the 1948-49 budget outlined for the State Teachers Pension and Annuity Fund and for maintenance of state wards.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- The Toledo Edison Company, a subsidiary of the Cities Service Company, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to borrow up to $6,200,000 from certain banks.

Random notes. Having made a light cast on troubled waters, Ed Zern, the devil-may-care author of "To Hell with Fishing" and "To Hell with Hunting," has dared the libel laws with another opus, this one giving the fine points on "How to Tell Fish from Fishermen."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- What with the laughing jackasses, hungry Australian polo ponies; cockatoos, polo players, customs, men and agricultural authorities, things were pretty noisy down at the docks today.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 -- William K. Jackson of 169 Chestnut Hill Road, suburban Chestnut Hill, vice president, general counsel and a director of the United Fruit Company and former president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, died here today of a heart attack.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Floor debate on the $597,000,000 stopgap relief program for France, Italy and Austria opened today with a dramatic warning from Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg that fast action was required to block Communist "wrecking crews" already working to kill Western Europe's hope for recovery.

Tuesday, Nov. 25, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Ad Hoc Committee on Palestine Question-Rejected, 29 to 12 with 14 abstentions, Arab proposal for unitary state in Palestine. Voted, 16 to 16 with 23 abstentions, on another Arab proposal for action concerning Jewish refugees, thereby sending question to full Assembly.

Gamble Lists Video Needs All financing of television should come from money that advertisers pay for using the medium, Frederic R. Gamble, head of the AAAA, told a luncheon meeting of the American Television Society yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.
Forty special trains will be operated by the Pennsylvania Railroad direct to Municipal Stadium, Philadelphia, Saturday for the convenience of fans attending the Army-Navy football game.

John H. Ferguson of Washington, D.C., has been appointed executive director of the Committee for the Marshall Plan to Aid European Recovery, Robert P. Patterson chairman of the executive committee, announced yesterday.

Declaring that it will be "at least two years" before the bulk of the steel industry's $1,000,000,000 expansion program will show results, C.M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, predicted yesterday that domestic steel production next year will not be substantially greater than the 1947 output and stated that "nobody will solve the steel shortage this year or next."

Housewives expecting to pay considerably more for this year's Thanksgiving feast than they did last season may find after the final outlay has been made that their expenditures do not total as much as they had feared. From a comparative market list issued yesterday by the City Department of Markets a menu may be drawn up for six persons that comes to $11.20.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A group of New York and New Jersey fuel oil retailers said today that they were receiving only about half their 1946 supplies.

At his Carnegie Hall recital last night Benno Rabinof, violinist, was accompanied in New York for the first time by his wife, who as Sylvia Smith has given two Town Hall recitals of her own, as well as earning a reputation as a composer.

Declaring that New York no longer can afford the luxury of an "uneconomic, cowardly, cruel and politcially dishonest" tradition, Mayor O'Dwyer told the members of the Citizens Union last night at a dinner in the Roosevelt Hotel that the five-cent transit fare must be increased if the city is to remain sound fiscally.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Great Britain is poor. To make that simple and obvious statement of fact is to say something startling from the historical viewpoint and of profound significance to the world. It provides the best possible evidence that an era has ended.

WINTER PARK, Fla., Nov. 24 -- Rollins College officials tonight issued the following statement: "At a meeting of the executive committee of the board of trustees of Rollins College, together with all the other trustees of Rollins College available in the neighborhood, and with the chief administrative officers of the college, held on Saturday, Nov. 22, the following resolution was unanimously passed:

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 24 -- Harold E. Stassen, climaxing the first phase of his delegate drive with a speech tonight at the Milwaukee Auditorium, delivered a direct attack on "powerful Presidentpickers" who did not want a candidate for the nomination to be frank and forthright.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Reports persisted today that the Cardinals and the National League club's minor league properties have been sold to a syndicate including Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan, and Owner Sam Breadon called a news conference for 10 A.M. (CST) tomorrow, presumably to make an announcement on the matter.
Trading was active yesterday in futures on the New York Cotton Exchange and active months rose 34 to 62 points net.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 24 -- Preparations are being made to put back in commission thirteen tankers tied up in the United States Maritime Commission fleet near Mobile. The ships will be used at once to help relieve the world-wide gasoline shortage, according to Lieut.

PARIS, Nov. 24 -- The new Cabinet, formed early today by Premier Robert Schuman held its first meeting this afternoon. Afterward, its members indicated that it would increase wages, while protecting public order and "the liberty to work."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Most Republicans and a number of Democrats in Congress have so deeply resented the President's request for advance blanket powers to impose piecemeal rationing when he sees fit that several measures which depend on bi-partisan support in a presidential election year may suffer damage.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Bowing to his wife's wishes, John (Ox) DaGrosa tonight resigned as Holy Cross' head football coach, four days before his team's traditional final game with Boston College, its ancient Jesuit rival.

F. Abbot Goodhue, president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, has been made a chevalier of the French Legion of Honor "in recognition of Mr. Goodhue's services to the French Republic," Ludvic Chancel, French consul general here, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- James B. Carey, secretary of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, was reported today to have won a tactical victory by preventing Soviet delegates at the Paris meeting of the executive bureau of the World Federation of Trade Unions from attacking the Marshall plan after he had forced its consideration on the agenda.

Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Commissioner of Health, declared yesterday that in the war on cancer his department planned to keep the public informed of the menace, aid physicians to establish early diagnosis of cancer and help coordinate community control of the disease.

Muffled but continuing explosions of sewer gas rumbled underground along Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, between Jay and Lawrence Streets, shortly after 5 P.M. yesterday, knocking off manhole covers, jarring pedestrians and sending the neighborhood back to the candlelight era when electric service failed.

Come what may at Philadelphia on Saturday, when Army and Navy clash, Admiral Jonas Ingram yesterday recommended that Capt. Tom Hamilton be retired from the Navy and be named permanent football coach at Annapolis. The Naval Academy's former mentor and director of athletics, who currently is commissioner of the AllAmerica Conference, disclosed his views at the weekly luncheonmeeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- About 500 diplomats, correspondents, secretaries, clerks and guards have moved into London for the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers, which opens here tomorrow.
Vivian O'Rourke, 30 years old, of Chicago, did not reflect on the adventure possibilities of membership in the Women's Army Corps when she enlisted five years ago.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The three Federal mentors of the country's banks issued tonight a drastic warning to bankers to use "extreme caution" in their lending policies. Joining in the statement were the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Senior Western diplomats who have been in Moscow expect the Soviet delegation to make concessions during the Big Four meeting opening tomorrow to avoid a partition of Germany. They add that Moscow desires to prevent the exclusion of Soviet influence from the three Western zones of Germany.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 24 -- An affidavit read today at the trial of the I.G. Farben officials in the Palace of Justice here charged that executives of the company had initiated and carried through experiments with various typhus vaccines on prisoners in the Buchenwald concentration camp.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The ten screen personalities cited by the House issued a joint statement expressing the opinion that "the Thomas-Rankin committee succeeded today in having the Congress cite the Bill of Rights for contempt."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- With newsprint an outstanding exception, the Department of Commerce said today most grades of paper will reach a balance in supply and demand by the spring of 1948.
NANKING, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Chinese Communists are rapidly winning back the ground they lost in the Government's successful fall campaign shantung Province, reliable sources indicated today.
New York University's football squad went through a light drill in the mud of Ohio Field yesterday in preparation for the traditional game with Fordham at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

HAVANA, Nov. 24 -- The heads of delegations at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment decided today on the election of Max Suetens of Belgium as first vice president, C.H. Bhabha of India as second vice president and five other vice presidents.

Capt. Hazel Vincent of the Women's Army Corps died of coronary thrombosis yesterday in her quarters on Governors Island. The funeral service is to be held tomorrow, the date set for her Thanksgiving-eve wedding to Maj. Reginald Theodore Weber, a Governors Island supply officer.

TOKYO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Former Gen. Iwane Matsui, who has denied knowing much about Japanese atrocities at Nanking in December, 1937, acknowledged today that he asked a United States correspondent to quell "rumors" of the atrocities "by putting forth the facts."

Armstrong Cork The Armstrong Cork Company announced the declaration of a year-end dividend of $1 a share payable to common stockholders on Dec. 22. This brings total disbursements for the current year to $2.60 compared with $1.80 paid in 1946.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 -- A committee is registering young Jews who are willing to serve the proposed Jewish state and defend it if necessary, Mrs. Golda Meyerson, chief political officer of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said today.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 24 (AP) -- "We'll attempt to justify the Western Conference's faith in us," Fritz Crisler said today following Michigan's unanimous selection as Big Nine standard-bearer in the New Year's Day Rose Bowl game against Southern California.
ROME, Nov. 24 -- Another step toward normality in southern Italy was taken today when the last remaining strikes in the Provinces of Bari and Lecce were called off.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, chairman of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report, asserted today that the Administration was asking "complete power over everything and everybody" in requesting authority to Impose full wartime allocation controls to combat inflation.

Professional football, which got a tremendous lift last Sunday, expects to continue to fare handsomely at the gate in coming games. On Thanksgiving Day the improving Dodgers will have the field to themselves, opposing the San Francisco Forty-Niners in Brooklyn.

GENEVA, Nov. 24 -- A complete breakdown of the effort to draft a multilateral civil aviation accord was conceded by delegates from all the leading air powers during today's session of the International Civil Aviation Organization commission charged with preparing such an agreement.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- An Arab proposal to create a single Palestinian state was rejected tonight by the Committee on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly. The vote was 29 against, 12 for, 14 abstentions and two countries absent.

THE longest and most hysterical books on foreign relations, the United Nations and the peculiar behavior of Soviet Russia are rarely the most useful and illuminating. Hamilton Fish Armstrong's "The Calculated Risk"* is a very short book, but in its cool, lucid, logical fashion it is extremely illuminating and provocative.

Immediate American assistance to keep China from falling under Communist domination was demanded last night by Governor Dewey. He said it was an integral part of the "Two Ocean" foreign policy he believed the United States should have.

Columbia University honored Governor Dewey, a graduate of its Law School, for his "splendid public service," by awarding him an honorary Doctor of Laws degree yesterday at a ceremony in Low Memorial Library.

TEHERAN, Iran, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Premier Ahmad Ghavin rejected tonight as "unreasonable" Soviet charges that the action of the Iranian Parliament in ruling void the 1946 oil agreement with Russia had constituted "hostile activity" by Iran.

Manufacturers of electrical appliances will not accept reimposition of Government control over installment purchases of their products without protest, an industry representative said yesterday. He stated that the industry definitely does not regard restoration of such controls in the appliance field as inevitable.

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 (U.P.) -- The Canada Commonwealth Federation leader, M.J. Coldwell, said today that the reimposition of food priceceilings was "the beginning of a reversal" of the Government's decontrol policy. The move, said Mr. Coldwell, was "absolutely necessary."

Sustained buying interest in cotton textiles is reflected in purchases of print cloths bought as far ahead as the fourth quarter of 1948, according to Worth Street commission men yesterday. What is more impressive, however, they said, is the faot that a 30-centper-yard price, was offered for '80 squares to be delivered ten months hence.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 17,000 head, total 29,000; market generally moderately active. 15 to 25 cents lower; closed low and fully 50 cents lower with estimated 3,000 unsold; early top $25.25;

ATHENS, Nov. 24 -- A tentative agreement has been reached between the Greek Government and the United States Aid Mission and the United States and British Military Governments in Germany to trade $15,000,000 worth of Greek tobacco and dried fruits for $35,000,000 worth of German manufactured goods.

The easier tone which developed late last week on the stock market persisted yesterday, with losses widened and a wider range of issues under pressure. Prices weakened further on slim offerings, however, as business on the Stock Exchange fell to 790,000 shares, smallest in a week, against 980,000 shares on last Friday.

A consent decree terminating an anti-trust suit brought by the Department of Justice on May 16, 1945, against the Electric Storage Battery Company and its subsidiary, the Willard Storage Battery Company, both located in Cleveland, Ohio, was entered here yesterday in Federal Court before Judge John C. Knox.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Michigan's mighty Wolverines have landed four players, including three backs, on the 1947 Associated Press All-Big Nine football team selected annually by the conference coaches.

Estanislao Caterenechuk, a 22year-old seaman, has a love for flying matched only by his dislike of paying plane fares. The two characteristics overwhelmned him yesterday and a trip from Havana as an aerial stowaway ended in a journey from La Guardia Field to Ellis Island.

A resolution declaring that employment of physicians in Government service should be based solely on professional merit and capacity for useful service, without regard to political or social views, was defeated last night, 215 votes to 205, at a meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New York in the Academy of Medicine, 2 East 103rd Street.

As the Big Four Foreign Ministers meet in London for what is expected to be a quick showdown on the peace settlements for Germany and Austria, a preliminary showdown is already under way in France. There, under the command of Moscow, the French sector of the Communist International has undertaken to stage a test of its strength.

Treasury Call One of the largest of the recent calls by the United States Treasury on its war loan accounts was issued yesterday on both classes of banks. The call on the A banks is for 60 per cent of deposits as of Nov. 21 and payable on Dec. 1.

In accord with the growing emphasis on imports in American foreign trade, a panel of customs administration experts yesterday at the Hotel Astor told a meeting of the National Council of American Importers how delays in clearance of goods could be minimized.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Millions of dollars worth of machinery that British industrialists want desperately remains in storage while a resumption of British-Soviet trade talks is awaited, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The House approved overwhelmingly today citations for contempt of Congress against ten Hollywood personalities who refused last month to tell the Committee on Un-American Activities whether they were members of the Communist party.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Ralph S. Damon, president of American Airlines, Inc., recommended before the President's Air Policy Commission today that the Government spend a minimum of $750,000,000 annually on procurement of war planes.

LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers will reopen discussions of the German and Austrian peace treaties tomorrow in an atmosphere of utter gloom. Nothing had happened up to a late hour tonight to give the slightest reason to hope for success.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 24 -- Arab and Jewish spokesmen, contradicting each other on all other essentials, agreed here today in predicting widespread blooded and war if the different solutions they urged for the Palestine question were disregarded by the United Nations.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 -- With four areas of Delhi, the old city adjacent to the capital, under a twenty-four-hour curfew, the military today dispersed the threatening mob at rifle point as an aftermath of the outbreak of rioting yesterday in which three Moslems were reported slain.

VIENNA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Austrian President Karl Renner declared today that "Austria is neither desirous nor willing to serve as a focal point in world relations" and called on the Council of Foreign Ministers in London to find a general solution for Austria "which will free her from imposed international entanglements."

OTTAWA, Nov. 24 -- The Canadian Government reimposed price ceilings today on most canned fruits and vegetables and gave notice that it would probably reimpose "mark-up" control -- that is, price control on fresh fruits and vegetables.

In the Philippines, as in the United States, the protests of defeated candidates in an election may be discounted, but there seem to have been enough provable incidents in the Senatorial and provincial elections to lend more than the usual credence to the charges now being made by the Nacionalistas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, today sustained the conviction of three members of Jehovah's Witnesses who refused to work at civilian public service camps as conscientious objectors during the war on the grounds that they were actually ordained ministers.

The text of the address delivered by Governor Dewey at the dinner of the alumni of Columbia University Law School at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night follows: This is a wholly non-political occasion. But in the state of the world today, there is no subject which is not deeply fraught with heavy political implications.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Mayor of New Orleans, De Lesseps S. Morrison, and the eleven railroads operating in the city, today jointly asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to acquire and construct certain lines of railroad, and for the city to sell bonds, incidental to the construction of a union passenger terminal in New Orleans.

LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Leading entries for the water polo event in the 1948 Olympic Games will be "seeded" -- similar to tennis tournaments -- to insure that the strongest nations meet in the finals.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Apart from selected issues, business in the stock markets here today was slack.

Defending a Good Name Renewal of a proposal -- rejected ten years ago -- to improve the Bowery by changing its name has brought to this corner an expression of opinion from one who describes himself as an old inhabitant of this city.

Grateful for the blessings of peace and mindful of the needs of the less fortunate here and overseas, countless numbers of New Yorkers are preparing to celebrate an old fashioned Thanksgiving on Thursday.

Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink signed an order yesterday in Brooklyn calling upon the Board of Education to show cause why it should not be prohibited from making public school buildings available to the Communist party and the American Youth for Democracy.

The Long and Short of It A recent report froir the corner of Wall Street and Nassau, described as the birthplace of our nation, has invited from nostalgic downtowner the remirider that, while the marble pile now standing on that historic spot was slowly rising stone on stone as a government project, another building was in more rapid process under private auspices and the pressure of capitalistic enterprise.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers tonight defeated the Boston Celtics 91 -- 75, as the local team, suffered its fourth consecutive home defeat in the Basketball Association of America. A crowd of 2,976 saw the quintets establish a new Boston Garden scoring record of 166 points for two teams.

Municipal Court Justice Charles Marks, in a test case for which the Automobile Club of New York was sponsor, ruled in a decision filed yesterday in Seventh District Court that automobile owners who keep their cars in public garages were not protected against storage fee increases under the State Commercial Rent Control Law.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska., Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The gale-tossed Army freighter Clarksdale Victory, with a crew of fifty-one aboard, broke in half on the rocky shores of Hippa Island today and two Coast Guard rescue parties which went ashore tonight reported that there was no sign of life in the wreckage.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- Russian political terror tactics, carried out and supported by favored German lieutenants in the communistic Socialist Unity party (SED), were described here today in the headquarters of the Liberal Democratic party.

The first retrospective exhibition of Jo Davidson's sculpture of the last thirty years opens today in the Gallery of the American Academy of Arts and Letters, Broadway and 155th Street, under the joint sponsorship of the National Institute of Arts and Letters and the American Academy and will continue through February.

Considerations of personal expediency should not deter politcal leaders from giving the people clear, "provocative" statements of their own views, Harold E. Stassen declared yesterday. The former Minnnesota Governor, who is campaigning for the Republican nomination for the Presidency, addressed 1,650 persons at the Book and Author Luncheon of The New York Herald Tribune at the Astor Hotel.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The charges of Leo T. Crowley, president of Standard Gas and Electric Company, that private detectives had been hired to trail him and that efforts had been made to "tap" his telephone wires will be referred to the Department of Justice, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS. N.Y., Nov. 25 -- A recommendation that Jaffa, predominately Arab port city, become an enclave in the proposed Jewish state in Palestine was the most important alteration the United Nations General Assembly's committees made in the boundaries drawn by the Special Committee on Palestine.

MOSCOW, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The Moscow press greeted the opening session of the Big Four Foreign Ministers today with a charge that the United States had tried to sabotage the conference in advance in the interest of "American imperialism."

By reorientation of employes and placing the right man in each job, industrial management can boost productivity 40 per cent and meet industrial requirements of the European Recovery Program (Marshall plan) without endangering the American standard of living, according to the annual national survey report to the Society of the Advancement of Management, released yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Grain markets made a strong start and a tame finish on the Board of Trade today. All deliveries of wheat, corn and soy beans sold at new seasonal peak prices early, but December wheat broke 8 cents a bushel from the top later.

BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- Automobile manufacturers competing with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company today opened another round here in their fight against what they say are discriminatory freight rates accorded assembly plants of G. M. and Ford as compared with the higher rates that they must pay on new automobiles from their plants at Detroit, Kenosha, Wis.;

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Chairman Marriner S. Eccles presented a Federal Reserve Board anti-inflation program to Congress today, a program which he said would go to the roots of the problem rather than dealing merely with its effects.

MANILA, Nov. 25 -- Russian recalcitrance dominated the first business session of the eleven-nation United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in Bagnio today. However, the Soviet delegates were blocked on every issue that came to a vote, including the ticklish Korean question, which they had tried to rule out of the discussion.

A plan to remedy traffic congestion in the city through the creation of a Board of Traffic Control as the supreme authority over traffic problems and of two auxiliary agencies was proposed yesterday by the executive group of the Traffic Action Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Following is the text of the resolution adopted here today by the United Nations General Assembly's Committee on Palestine, approving the partition plan for the Holy Land:

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Lawrence B. Carey State Commission of Banking and Insurance of New Jersey, announced today that holders of first mortgage participation certificates against the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company, which was placed in liquidation in 1939, will be paid a final liquidating dividend of 20 1/2 per cent on the face value of the certificates.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The Government took its case against Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, before a Federal grand jury today, asking his indictment on the first of a long series of criminal charges that could put the retired procurement officer behind prison bars for about the rest of his life.

Reconversion of the modern coastal liner Cristobal of the Panma Line, operated by the Panama Railroad, will be done in the yard of the Bethlehem Steel Company at Quincy, Mass., the operators announced yesterday

SINGING Sam Breadon formally disposed of his St. Louis Cardinals yesterday and he didn't sell them for a song. Not Samivel. Hes' getting a reported three million for them, more than Dan Topping and Del Webb paid for the Yankee baseball empire. That's typical, of course. Breadon is the luckiest guy in the world and always has been able to get the longest possible mileage out of a dollar bill.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 25 -- The next few months will be a crucial test whether the Jews are capable of functioning as a nation, David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared tonight in opening a drive to raise an emergency defense fund of $2,000,000.
Before completing preparations for the traditional Battle of the Bronx" with Fordham on Saturday, Coach E.E. (Hook) Mylin of New York University personally observed the Rams in action.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- Merit increase or "promotional increment" provisions of the new state teachers salary law were overwhelmingly repudiated here tonight by the 800 members of the House of Delegates of the State Teachers Association in final session of the 102d annual convention.

ALBANY, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A stat civil service worker's suit fo higher pay under the Dewey ad ministration's program to elimi nate salary inequalities was uphel today in a Supreme Court test cas that may result in an estimate $2,000,000 of added compensation for more than 4,000 employes.

Citations for medical, missionary and educational service to the people of China were presented yesterday by Wellington Koo, Chinese Ambassador to the United States, to leaders in these fields who served as directors of the American Bureau for Medical Aid to China.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Details of a bilateral monetary agreement between Britain and Sweden were disclosed here tonight. The pact, which was signed yesterday, provides for easing dollar claims in settlement of trade balances between the two nations.

Wednesday, Nov. 28, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Ad Hoc Committee on Palestine Question -- Approved, 25 to 13 with 17 abstentions, plan for partition of Palestine into Arab and Jewish states, after completing plan by series of amendments.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25 -- A four-year economic and social plan to solve Brazil's key problems has been submitted to President Eurico Gaspar Dutra. If accepted, it will denote a new political era for the nation, based on a coalition Cabinet composed of democratic parties.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was again active and highly irregular yesterday. Closing prices were 19 points higher to 17 points lower, with the strength most pronounced in the near months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal ordered the two transport services of the armed forces today to cease carrying passengers or cargo in competition with established civil air lines. His order, sought since the end of the war by the commercial air carriers, affected both the Air Transport Command, operated by the Air Force, and the Naval Air Transport Service, operated by the Navy.
At a special meeting yesterday, stockholders of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., approved a proposal to increase the authorized common stock of the company from 1,500,000 to 2,500,000 shares.

ATHENS, Nov. 25 -- Dwight P. Griswold, director of the United States program of aid to Greece, said today that the State Department had been obliged to reject his request for $15,000,000 in additional funds to care for refugees because all such funds had been allocated.

The Appalachian Electric Power Company authorized the First Boston Corporation and the Union Securities Corporation yesterday to form a syndicate to negotiate with it, probably on Dec. 2, for purchase of a proposed issue of $7,500,000 of new preferred stock.

A major share of the responsibility for shipping damage must go to the shippers and their personnel, according to early results of a study being conducted by the Shipping Container Institute, it was announced yesterday by T. J. Gross, managing director.

Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican, of Wisconsin, wno returned here yesterday after a study of education and labor in Europe, urged the reconstruction of Germany and an early end of the denazification program.

The motion picture industry, in an action unprecedented in American industrial fields, voted unanimously yesterday to refuse employment to Communists and to "discharge or suspend without compensation" the ten Hollywood figures who have been cited for contempt of Congress.

* * * Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,180, compared with 1,800 last week and 1,136 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 394 arrivals yesterday against 975 last Tuesday.
Five months after its enactment, the Taft-Hartley Law still is as controversial an issue as it was before it went on the statute books, it was indicated yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov 25 -- Legal experts of the United Nations have been working for almost three months planning the administration of Jerusalem, a job handed to the Trusteeship Council under the partition plan for Palestine, it was learned today.

Gross sales of the Beech Aircraft Corporation for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, increased to $26,211,411 from the $19,116,456 unconsolidated volume for the previous fiscal year, and were more than ten times the total in the first full pre-war year of 1940, Walter H. Beech, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.
John F. Dreier, formerly assistant sales manager, has been appointed sales manager of the Hart Manufacturing Company, Hartford, Conn.
Philadelphia announced yesterday that a $4,950,000 offering of refunding bonds scheduled for Dec. 4 had been withdrawn from, the market.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The Union Electric Power Company's Continued on Page 35, Column 1 Continued From Page 33 proposal to sell 250,000 additional shares of its $20 par value common stock, from time to time, to its parent, the Union Electric Company of Missouri, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Famine is certain in France by February unless something is done to increase the country's bread supply, Dr. Hughes Gounelle, medical adviser to American Aid to France, declared yesterday.

The bacteria that cause tuberculosis have, a tendency to become resistant to streptomycin when the drug is used over a long period, it was reported last night by Dr. John G. Kidd of the department of pathology of the New York Hospital-Cornell University Medical Center.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 25 -- The leaders of Hungary and Rumania proclaimed, today that the ancient enmities between their countries were dead and announced that they had concluded successful negotiations looking toward a pact of collaboration and mutual assistance.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Flying Weather, owned by D. K. Kerr Jr. of Washington, D.C., stuck by his running guns long enough to win the featured Piscataway Purse before 6,811 racegoers at the Bowie track today.

The Mystery of the Forbidden Tarpaulin still enveloped the Brooklyn football Dodgers yesterday as they were preparing to take over whatever local gridiron lime-light there is tomorrow when they tangle with the San Francisco Forty-Niners at Ebbets Field.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began an investigation last night of charges that records in Welfare Center 23, at 157 East Sixty-seventh Street, had been fabricated in thirty cases, with the prospect that grand jury action will follow if the charges are substantiated.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- A general strike on France's railways, to take effect immediately, was ordered tonight by the executive committee of the Railway Federation. If the order were carried out it would mean a close approach to a general strike, since paralysis of the railways soon would close nearly all industries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Mayor James M. Curley of Boston, serving a prison term for mail fraud, is expected to be freed by a commutation of sentence which President Truman probably will sign tomorrow.

GANANOQUE, Ont., Nov. 25 (AP) -- The 180 employe-owners of Parmenter Bulloch paid themselves a dividend of $2.50 a share today, the third since they took over the company a year and seven months ago. Today's payment amounts to about $7,000.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- "This is not a pleasant day for me" said Sam Breadon as he sold his beloved Cardinals today, "but every year I am less sufficient, and at my age it's time to quit." He is 71 years old.

ISLIP, L.I., Nov. 25 -- Hopeful that MacArthur Field, the big modern airport owned by this town and used by the Army and Navy during the war, may be chosen as an alternate United States terminus for five foreign commercial airlines, the town board of Islip authorized today the expenditure of $44,000 for improvement of the field.
Like the prodigal son, the forward pass finally has come home to roost.

Thanksgiving services in the churches and synagogues of this city tomorrow will have as their purpose not only to give thanks as Americans for blessings received but to share material blessings such as food and clothing with post-war sufferers overseas.

One of those unsung heroes of Norway's powerful resistance movement against the Nazis during the war, Reidar Ulland, 34-year-old member of the famous Kongsberg skiing family, yesterday arrived aboard the Norwegian American liner Stavangerfjord.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The Big Four met today in an atmosphere approaching sweetness and light, despite the boom of Russian propaganda and Secretary of State Marshall's blunt words in his Chicago speech.
The Board of Estimate, adding $6,391,520 to the total already proposed by the City Planning Commission, adopted yesterday a 1948 capital budget of $250,932,816.

European laundry operators are prepared to place substantial orders for American commercial laundry machinery if they can obtain the necessary dollar exchange, according to a delegation of laundry owners from Sweden, Norway, The Netherlands and France.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- A "definite change" for the better in Bratain's production picture occurred in the last two weeks, W. Glenville Hall, Financial Secretary to the Treasury, told the House of Commons today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Carroli Reece, Republican National Chairman, conceding there had been criticism that the Republican National Committee did not always bespeak the views of the Republican majority in Congress, said today there was no plan to establish closer liaison.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd declared yesterday that the only way to meet the problems of the atomic bomb was to change human nature. This, he said in a talk at the Coronet Theatre, could be done by accepting the humanitarian principles of moral rearmament.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Beardsley Ruml, author of the "pay-as-you-go" tax system, proposed tonight another pay-as-you-go plan for financing the Marshall plan through savings bond sales.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 25 (AP) -- William and Mary, top team in the Southern Conference, were named today to inaugurate the Dixie Bowl football game on Jan. 1. The committee indicated the Indians' opponent would be announced within two or three days, with a Southeastern Conference team likely to be chosen.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- At this turning point in history, British politics, unlike British economics, has puzzled the world in general and the United States in particular. Whatever his party affiliations, a Briton is continually surprised and annoyed at an inability of foreigners to understand what he considers to be the simplest and most obvious facts of his political life.

TRENTON, Nov. 25 -- Mayor Donal J. Connolly of Trenton, asserting his innocence of grand jury charges of illegally arranging issuance of beauty shop and school permits while a state employe, today began preparation of a defense.
Reports on the Catskill deer hunting have improved over the past few days, with both Sullivan and Greene Counties producing some large bucks.

A testimonial dinner to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, world Zionist leader, made a swift transition last night into something of a political rally to make him the first President of the proposed new Jewish state in Palestine.

GENEVA, Nov. 25 -- Four proposals for dealing with problems of human rights and discrimination against minorities were presented today by Jonathan Daniels, United States delegate to the United Nations subcommission, beginning consideration of these problems in Geneva.

A $1,000,000 emergency relief project in twelve countries, coupled with an educational program for wider understanding of the Marshall plan, was announced yesterday by Irving Abramson, chairman of the community services committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Postmaster General Bob Hannegan is leaving to become boss of the St. Louis Cardinals, and so official Washington is losing the man who probably is its No. 1 sports fan.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 25 -- Officials of I. G. Farbenindustrie on trial here spent a harassing day today as the assistant prosecutor, E. E. Minskoff of New York, completed the submission of evidence of their criminal complicity in the illegal and often fatal medical experiments conducted on human beings at various concentration camps by the SS and camp physicians.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan resigned today, and President Truman nominated a former letter carrier, the present first assistant postmaster general, Jesse M. Donaldson, to succeed him.

Calling entry into Palestine only part of the solution to the problem of the 220,000 displaced Jews of Europe, Samuel A. Telsey, president of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS), asked officials of fiftyfour leading labor unions in New York yesterday to urge governments here and abroad to accept more of these homeless people.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Chicago newspapers appeared in a new type dress today as striking printers, members of Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union, placed picket lines in front of all five plants in which the city's six daily papers are published.

What happens to prices and the cost of living depends primarily on the law of supply and demand. But in a money economy we cannot ignore the part played by the monetary factor -- that is to say, the supply of purchasing power expressed in terms of currency and credit.

Plans to increase the New York Telephone Company's facilities in the midtown area of Manhattan, along the West Side, were outlined yesterday by Carl Whitmore, president of that organization, to business officials and representatives of service organizations who visited the central office building at 435 West Fiftieth Street.

Alabama Great Southern The Alabama Great Southern Railroad Company voted a dividend of $3 a share on the preferred and $3 on the ordinary stock, both payable Dec. 24. This brings payments for 1947 on each issue to $6.50 a share, against $5 distributed last year.

There can be no mistaking Mayor O'Dwyer's sincerity of purpose now to fight to the finish for a higher transit fare. To hear him state the city's needs, as many civic leaders did at the anniversary meeting of the Citizens Union, is to be convinced of the strength of his determination.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The scene at Lancaster House at the opening of the fifth session of the Foreign Minister today was almost exactly like the inauguration of the first conference two years ago. Outwardly this meeting is just a continuation of the peacemaking procedure that began then.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 25 -- A major legal contest appeared to be in prospect tonight over the decision taken by the major motion picture companies in New York to discharge the ten Hollywood men cited for contempt of Congress.

The resignation of Maj. Gen. Paul R. Hawley as Medical Director of the Veterans Administration only four days after that of Gen. Omar N. Bradley as Veterans Administrator takes from our largest federal agency its two topranking leaders. They leave large shoes for their successors to fill.

The Committee Against Discrimination in Military Service and Training, which was started Saturday by a group headed by Grant Reynolds, New York State Commissioner of Correction, and A. Philip Randolph, president of the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, AFL, announced yesterday a campaign "to insure inclusion of equality amendments in pending legislation for universal training."

Nehring Brothers, in conjunction with Henry Brady, sold for the estate of Eva Drabick the five-story apartment house at 608-10 West 191st Street, at the southeast corner of Wadsworth Avenue. The building occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and contains 110 rooms.

NANKING, Nov. 25 -- Despite his withdrawal as a candidate for membership in the National Assembly, Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek has been elected delegate for the district of Fenghwa in Chekiang Province, Kuomintang party headquarters announced today.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Eddie Dyer, manager of the Cardinals and for almost twenty-five years an employe of the organization, said he was "sorry to see Sam Breadon leave.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 25 -- Paring a few feet from the broad sidewalks of New York City to make room for additional vehicular travel lanes to alleviate traffic and parking congestion was urged today at the annual meeting of the New York Highway Users Conference here.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

Who says tragedy doesn't pay off on Broadway? An old-timer ke "Medea" is still sturdy enough o garner $29,957 last week. Of course, the acting in that company is in no small measure accountble for that stylish figure. Now covering into view is "Antony and Cleopatra," another tragedy of qual renown.
A six-course Thanksgiving dinner will cost from two to three dollars in most of the restaurants here, a check of eating places showed yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers opened its fateful conference on Germany and Austria today by agreeing on all the items for the agenda. The extent of the accord and the friendliness of the atmosphere were a pleasant surprise to all, even though nothing vital was decided and no agreement could be reached on the order of discussing the items.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Comdr. Edward N. Little of Decatur, Ill., has been acquitted by a Navy court-martial of all charges of mistreating American prisoners at a Japanese prison camp, it was announced tonight.

Distrust of banks by two East Harlem families, which caused one to permit the other to hold her $10,100 life savings in a cookie jar, resutled yesterday in the arraignment of a man and his wife in Felony Court on a grand larceny charge.

Ground-breaking ceremonies for two public school projects that will have a total construction cost of $1,356,500 were held yesterday in Brooklyn, and Queens. The "double-header" event brought to seventeen the number of new structures under way in the Board of Education's post-war building program.

Sydenham Hospital, where for four years a Negro-white staff has served an inter-racial clientele, announced yesterday plans for a new program costing $7,500,000 that will bring under one roof for the first time medical men, social workers, psychiatrists, researchers and students.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The Administration was challenged today by Representative Leslie C. Arends, Republican, of Illinois, to submit the Marshall plan for foreign aid to a national referendum. He suggested that the voters of the country be asked to register "yes" or "no" on the following question:

Railroads, airlines and bus companies completed last night arrangements for handling a heavy rush of Thanksgiving holiday traffic to and from the city. With thousands of persons headed homeward for the traditional family dinner tomorrow, the rush was expected to start this afternoon and reach a peak tonight.

Six children, who were being driven home from school in lunch recess, were injured slightly yesterday when the automobile in which they were riding collided with a fire truck at 103d and Madison Avenue.

E. Robert Schmitz, who gave a piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has a style of playing with its own virtues -- crispness of tone, clarity of outlines and an interpretive approach that eliminates sentimentality. When this musical style is placed at the disposal of a work like Bach's C minor Partita, the result is a cleancut, satisfactory performance.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- Seymour Nebenzal, Arthur Ripley and Rudolph Monter, who will produce "Look Homeward, Angel" for United Artists release, have concluded verbal agreements with Joan Blondell and Vincent Price to appear in the film, the producers disclosed today.

Yella Pessl, the harpsichordist, will inaugurate a new concert series over WQXR and its frequency modulation affiliate, WQXQ, beginning Dec. 4. She will be heard from 3:45 to 4 P. M. Thursdays and also from 10:05 to 10:30 P.M. Sundays.

The labels on relatively new specialty foods exclaim: "Modern living at its best!" Modern, yes, but "at its most convenient" rather than "at its best." For convenience is Hotcans' reason for being. They are tinned products that heat without electricity, gas, coal or other conventional fuel.

The apathy that has characterized the market's reception to new preferred stock issues resulted yesterday in an announcement by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., that it has postponed for at least three months the previously scheduled Feb. 2 call date for the $5 cumulative preferred stock for refunding of the shares. The stock, which is callable at 104 1/2, closed yesterday at 105 1/8, a yield of 4.76 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- President Truman's appointment today of Jesse M. Donaldson as Postmaster-General is a concentrated example of his endeavor to head the Federal departments -- and thus man the Cabinet -- with citizens of experience in the public service as contrasted with a generally political background.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- John Taber, Republican, of New York, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, today accused the State Department of violating the law by permitting shipment of food and other supplies to Russia and Soviet-dominated countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- Gen. J.D. Balmer, of the United States Army Agricultural Advisory Staff in Austria, today told the Senate Appropriations Committee that to revert to a split into four zones would mean "a victory for Communist aims and a complete fadeout of the small light of hope."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- It-was lunch hour and the cadets were marching to mess. Their rhythmic steps were guided by "Beat Navy" chants, inspired, no doubt, by painted bed sheets hanging from the gray-walled barracks that called for Army to "Sink the Navy" and similar catchy exhortations.

SOMETIMES it seems that novels about the deep South differ only in minor details and degrees of literary merit. Most of them are written by angry Southerners, men and women who love their native country so much that they become quite furious when they consider its shortcomings. Most of them include a majority of the foil owing ingredients:

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 25 -- Seventeen representatives of a wide variety of public activities formally organized today as Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's committee to investigate alleged abuses in New Jersey civil liberties and map a course of corrective action.

The stock prices remained yesterday largely within Monday's range, although there was some attempt at recovery, prices leaned to the lower side. The combined averages showed, however, a slight sdge. Expanded interest in a few issues raised business on the Stock Exchange to 860,000 shares, compared with 790,000 shares on Monday.

Eleven individual and four team records were set by Columbia during the football season which ended Saturday, the Athletic Office announced yesterday. The Lions enjoyed one of their most successful seasons, having won seven of nine games and ending Army's defeatless streak at thirtytwo.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Doubts about the outcome of the Four-Power Conference had a restraining influence on the stock markets here today.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 25 -- The new Postmaster General, Jesse M. Donaldson, has the postal service in his blood.

Any doubt about Joe Louis' feelings on his condition for the fifteen-round bout in which he will defend his title against Jersey Joe Walcott Dec. 5 in Madison Square. Garden was removed yesterday on a visit to the title-holder's training quarters at Pompton Lakes, N.J.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

The 10 per cent price reduction on Agfa cameras will "help," but prices in Germany are still "too high" for active competition, it was stated yesterday at the offices of Burleigh Brooks, leading camera importer.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 25 -- The Palestine Committee of the United Nations General Assembly approved today a plan to partition Palestine and set up two independent states, one Arab and the other Jewish, after the termination of the British mandate over the Holy Land.
