LOS ANGELES, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The All-America Football Conference accepted today a bid from the Los Angeles City Council for a post-season "Charity Bowl" game between its champion and that of the rival National Football League.

British, industry is not displaying excessive complacency in its attitude toward the Labor Government but is biding its time and trying to educate the middle class English voter to the issues which will come up in the 1950 election, according to H.E.G. West, managing director of Newton Chambers Co., Ltd., engineering, foundry and chemical company of Thorncliffe, England.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The seven signatories to the letter "Against Palestine Partition," published in your issue of Nov. 21, base their argument on what they conceive to be the best American interests. It was this consideration alone, they maintain, which prompted them to urge our Government to reverse its policy on Palestine and to withdraw its support from the partition plan, now under consideration by the United Nations.

Branch headquarters of the National Draft Eisenhower League, Inc., have been established in up-state New York and in Maine, Winston H. Thornburg, chairman of its board of directors, announced yesterday at league headquarters in the Hotel Astor.
Business sites and industrial parcels comprised the bulk of trading in Queens as reported by brokers yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Judge George W. Smyth of Westchester County (N.Y.) Children's Court said today that to make their contribution to the prevention of juvenile delinquency, juvenile courts should be separate from other branches of the judicial system and should be presided over by full time specialist judges.

Party frocks for little girls and their older sisters, as well as skating costumes, rainwear and robes, were presented as gift suggestions by Mary Lewis yesterday at the Rite Carlton Hotel Fifteen red-haired youngsters, from 2 years old up, modeled the presentation, which opened with a group of party frocks with lacy frills and ruffles.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The advisability of seeking an injunction to restrain the strike of compositors on six Chicago daily newspapers is being considered by Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board. Mr. Denham said today that he was studying the dispute between Local 16 of the International Typographical Union (AFL) and the Chicago publishers.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Agreement of Herold (Muddy) Ruel, deposed Brown's manager, to becoma a 1948 coach, for Cleveland signaled a new experiment by President Bill Veeck of the Indians today to "find out just how much value there is in a high-class coaching staff."

Belgium now has between 40,000 and 50,000 oil furnaces and heaters on order from American exporters and has "gone a long way" toward meeting increasing internal demand for American refrigerators, household appliances, oil heating apparatus and mechanical farm equipment, George E. Quisenberry, vice president, McGraw International Corporation, disclosed yesterday.

HAVANA, Nov. 25 -- Dr. Diego Luis Molinari, chairman of the Argentine delegation, pushed the fight to gain voting rights for non-members of the United Nations into the special closed meeting of heads of delegations at the Conference on Trade and Employment this afternoon.

Higher prices, lower taxes, Marshall plan aid and a third round of wage increases lie ahead in 1948, according to parallel conclusions drawn separately from over 130 members of the American Marketing Association and forecasts presented by Leo Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America at the regular monthly meeting of the A.M.A. New York chapter at Hotel Commodore yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The far-flung chain of 16 minor league clubs sold as part of the Cardinal organization is one of the most extensive "farm systems" in baseball. Player - stocked franchises owned by the National League club include:
SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 25 -- Repeated Communist charges that south Korean jails are packed with political prisoners was answered by the authorities here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (U.P.) -- The Government arranged today to bring union and company officials together in New York Dec. 4 in another effort to stave off a nation-wide telegraph strike, but spokesmen for 50,000 workers said they would continue to make plans for a walkout that "could come within two weeks."

TOKYO, Nov. 25 -- After five days of bickering, marked by fistfights in committee room and on the floor of Parliament, the Socialist-dominated Government tonight forced through the lower house the bill for state control of coal mines.
The Soviet freighter Tchernigov, with a cargo including machinery and trucks, sailed yesterday from Claremont Terminal, Jersey City, for Odessa.

Ad Council Adds Advisers H. E. Babcock, chairman of the board of trustees, Cornell University; Elmo Roper, marketing consultant and public opinion analyst; Allan L. Swim, CIO publicity director and editor of the CIO News, and Reese H. Taylor, president of the Union Oil Company, have accepted membership on the Advertising Council's public advisory committee.

LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 25 -- Legislation "to discourage ever-increasing large landholdings and to provide opportunity for genuine family farm operations," was advocated here today in a resolution adopted at the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 25 -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Prime Minister of India, directly accused "high officials of the Pakistan Government" today of complicity in the tribal invasion of Kashmir and Jammu that still is engaging a division of Indian Army troops.

Resort fashions, keeping in step with the more sophisticated city ones, are going feminine. The collection shown by Lord Taylor yesterday in the Bird Cage tea room was eloquent of the change. The little boy look was banished; tha lovely girl look took its place.

The news from London is that the conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers has been able to agree at its very first session on the main items of the agenda which it will discuss. It has thus accomplished in a few hours what the Ministers' deputies had been unable to accomplish in three weeks.

Governor Dewey presented yesterday cash prizes and medals to five New York members of the National Guard who did the most for recruiting during a recent contest. The awards were made in the Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The wheat loss caused by consignment selling of bread has not ended, the Secretary of Agriculture, Clinton P. Anderson, said today.

Thirteen Columbia College students from this city who have been elected to Phi Beta Kappa, scholastic honorary society, were initiated yesterday by Dr. Nicholas McD. McKnight, associate dean of Columbia College, and Prof. Arthur Pollister of the zoology department, president and secretarytreasurer, respectively, of the Columbia Chapter.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals and their far-flung minor league holdings were sold today to Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan and Fred M. Saigh Jr., St. Louis attorney.

In a major change in packaging methods, a new process known as "service packaging" has been adopted by Behr-Manning Corporation, Troy, N. Y., to substitute decimal system quantities for former "quire" quantities of standard units of sheet abrasive products, according to distributors yesterday.

MONTREAL, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Maurice Richard of the Canadiens and Syl Apps of the Toronto Maple Leafs are tied for the National Hockey League's individual scoring leadership today at twenty points apiece.

Forced by choppy waters in the Hudson River to land on a Spuyten Duyvil beach, Peter Burtt, 28 years old, a former Canadian Army bagpiper, ended yesterday a 6,000-mile canoe trip from Victoria, B.C., to New York, just ten miles short of his West Thirty-seventh Street goal.

GRAVESEND, Nov. 25 -- As the Gravesend by-election campaign reached its eve of the poll tonight Herbert Morrison, Deputy Prime Minister in Britain's Labor Government, castigated the Conservatives and called on the voters to "let the world know that Britain still stands firm for social progress, economic order and true freedom."

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Over Communist opposition, the National Assembly today approved, 394 to 184, an accord that would enable the Bank of France to obtain a loan from the United States Federal Reserve on a guarantee of French gold.

ROME, Nov. 25 -- The riots, and bloodshed that had kept Italy in a turmoil since early this month spread yesterday to Calabria, in the "toe" of the Italian "boot," just when the populace was beginning to hope, after three relatively quiet days, that the worst of the disturbances were over.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted today to slash $108,000,000 from the Administration's program for giving stop gap relief to France, Italy and Austria.

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- A plan to unite the sugar workers of the United States, Cuba, Hawaii, Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic under Communist leadership is being drafted in Havana at the World Sugar Workers Congress.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The new account that opened in the stock markets here today saw an intensification of the Orange Free State gold mines boomlet.

The Department of the Interior will oppose bills pending in Congress that would take 56,000 acres for lumbering purposes out of the great forests of virgin Douglas fir and Sitka pine in Olympic National Park, Washington, the Emergency Conservation Committee, 767 Lexington Avenue, announced yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A group of Yale Law School professors, asserting that the nation's liberty is in danger "from within," has urged in a letter to President Truman that the House Committee on Un-American Activities be abolished and the practice of submitting Government employes to "loyalty checks" be revised.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, announced tonight that its executive board was ready to charter seagoing members of the American Communications Association, CIO.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, former New York City Controller, was elected yesterday chairman of the board of the Thompson-Starrett Company, a construction company, following the official announcement that stockholders had voted overwhelmingly to oust the old management as demanded by the opposition group which he led.

Prof. Branch Rickey, it seems, is swinging into the bell lap of his monumental task of naming the Dodgers' manager for 1948, a task which many believe will conclude with Leo Durocher right back where he was in the driver's seat prior to being unseated for one season by Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler last April.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A second investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into the "split personality" aspects of the Standard Gas and Electric Company's board of directors loomed today.

Condemnation of lifetime guarantees was listed yesterday by the merchandise committee of the Association of Better Business Bureaus, Inc., among recommended revisions and additions to its guide to retail advertising and selling. The group, ending three days of conferences at the Hotel Lexington, also suggested an agreement with the tire industry on standard usage of the terms "ply" and "100-level," and continued support of the FTC ruling on terminology describing rayon products.

The United States, in its approach to housing, planning and rebuilding was described here last night as "a cowed and servile country in the grip of dictatorship" by Hermann H. Field of this city, a member of the American Institute of Architects, at a meeting of the building industry division, Progressive Citizens of America, in the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,500 head, total 13,500. Market fairly active 25 to 40 cents higher on all weights of hogs and sows; top. $25.35 sparingly; bulk of good and choice, 190 to 230

If the partition plan for Palestine goes through, "there is great danger of a popular uprising throughout the Arab world," Mme. Sarah Powell Jamali, wife of Dr. Mohammad Fadhel Jamail, Iraqi Foreign Minister and co-chairman of its delegation to the United Nations, declared yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Truman signed today a commutation of sentence which immediately freed Mayor James M. Curley of Boston from the Federal correctional institution at Danbury, Conn., five months to the day of his imprisonment for mail fraud.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Grains turned upward in the late trading on the Board of Trade today, wheat advancing as much as 6 cents and corn 5 cents after an early break, shorts covering freely on the way up, finding offerings light.
Market Holiday In observance of Thanksgiving Day, all financial and commodity exchanges in the United States will be closed today. Canadian markets will be open, as will the London Stock Exchange.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 26 -- Over the sole opposition of the Soviet Union the United Nations Subcommission on Minorities and Discrimination voted today to include "political and other opinions" among human rights deserving United Nations protection.
Leon Henderson, former Administrator of the Office of Price Administration, charged the Republican party yesterday with a drive to wreck President Truman's plan to fight the high cost of living.
TOKYO, Nov. 26 -- Japan's educational progress under Gen. Douglas MacArthur faced a virtually unanimous attack today in the meeting of the Allied Council for Japan.

Santa Claus evidently has conferred with scientific experts and other technicians as well as with small boys and girls this year to bring the most varied pack of toys he has toted since before the war. Better construction and improved materials, plus the widest assortment of lower-priced playthings in recent years, add up to happy news for parents as well as their children.

Veterans of World War II who seek "disabled veteran's preference" on city civil service lists hereafter must have disabilities rated by the Veterans Administration at not less than 10 per cent, Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan ruled yesterday.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Jamestown Post-Journal notified its readers today that unless an agreement were reached within three days its twenty-eight compositors "may possibly terminate their employment."

HAVANA, Nov. 26 -- Ramon Beteta Quintana of Mexico served notice on the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today that economically undeveloped and debtor nations were not satisfied with some provisions of the charter drafted at Geneva last summer for the proposed International Trade Organization.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- A confidential survey of the bi-zonal organizations, the joint United States and British Military Government agencies and the physical facilities in the Frankfort on the Main area, has just been completed for the guidance of Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, authorative sources said today.

"'Ben Hur' Wallace," by Irving McKee, has been scheduled for publication Saturday by the University of California Press. It is a biography of Lew Wallace, who besides being the author of "Ben Hur" was at various times a major-general in the Union Army and in the Mexican Army under Juarez, Governor of New Mexico and Minister to Turkey when it was ruled by Abdul-Hamid.

As the Big Four Foreign Ministers get down to business in a "last-chance" attempt to write a joint peace, it is clear that nothing could do more to strengthen the hand of the American delegation in London, and hearten the nations standing with us, than quick Congressional approval of the proposed measures for European stabilization and recovery.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The prospects of development of the natural resources of Africa offer Britain an opportunity to alter the whole dollar-sterling relationship, Sir Miles Thomas, chairman of the British Development Coordinating Commission, said today.

ANSONIA, Conn., Nov. 26 -- Violence flared here today at the plant of the Hershey Metal Products Company when a crowd, estimated at 500, including striking employes and sympathizers, sought to keep a token force within the factory from checking out for the day.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States Office of Education announced today as "a statistical achievement" the most complete early college count ever made in this country. It shows a grand total enrollment this year of 2,338,226.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, lifted yesterday the longstanding ban against instrumental music for network radio programs that are sponsored cooperatively by local interests in the various cities included in the chains.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Rod E. Geiger, associate producer of the Italian film, "Open City," announced today that he has taken a lease on Cine Citta, Italy's largest motion picture studio, for the production in January of a screen adaptation, in English, of Pietro di Donato's 1939 novel, "Christ In Concrete."

WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- The story of "mission double dare" in which a C-47 Transport plane made a hazardous landing on ice only twenty inches thick to rescue a stricken soldier was told today by the Air Transport Command.

Editors of country weekly newspapers are overwhelmingly in favor of the Marshall Plan for European relief in general, but believe there should be "strings" on any assistance furnished by the United States, according to a survey made by The American Press, trade journal for country newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Warnings against excessive grain exports for foreign aid were given to the Senate Appropriations Committee today by several dealers and millers, who feared that the emergency relief plan would leave the United States without a prudent carry-over of grain.

In an effort to prevent serious injury to key men before Saturday's traditional game with Fordham Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin had his New York University squad go through a light passing and kicking drill yesterday at Ohio Field.

With the deer season scheduled to open on Dec. 1, the Pennsylvania Game Commission is urging some of the anticipated 400,000 deer hunters to give some attention to the outlying woodland patches remote from the large forested areas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The European recovery program may cause definite hardship in this country and in the absence of effective controls send prices to new highs, the Truman Administration conceded for the first time today through an authorized spokesman at policy level.

OTTAWA, Nov. 26 (By The Canadian Press) -- Canada's growing position as a supplier in a trade-hungry post-war world was reflected today in figures showing the Dominion's export trade with other nations jumped sharply to $250,000,000 in October of this year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Stalemated negotiations between the Washington Publishers Association and the printers of four daily newspapers in this city may lead to a strike of compositors following the visit here next week of Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union (AFL).

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, demanded today the resignation of Carroll Reece as Republican National Chairman on the ground that he had "failed miserably to win the confidence of the voting public."

Independent appliance stores are experiencing difficulty in selling all but a few top brand refrigerators despite continued shortages, a spokesman for several independent appliance dealers reported yesterday. He said that customers who are definitely interested in purchasing refrigerators are passing up merchandise available for immediate delivery to wait for top brands.
BOWIE,. Md., Nov. 26 (AP) -- H.L. Straus' Pilaster, who found his form late this season, turned in his third straight victory in today's Charles Purse, top offering on the Bowie program.

Verdi's opera "Otello" will be presented in full, in two weekly installments, under the direction of Arturo Toscanini on Dec. 6 and 13, during the time held by the NBC Symphony, which, of course, will participate. Curtain time has been set for 6:15 P.M., a quarter hour earlier than usual, in order not to cut the performances, each of which will present two acts of the four-act opera.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Penn State is not going to the Cotton Bowl for a "joy ride" but to win an important football game, Coach Bob Higgins said today. As If to prove his words, Higgins flashed train reservations for a trip to scout the Mustangs in their final regular season game against Texas Christian on Saturday.

Playing that remained on the highest plane of excellence, throughout a noble and exacting program, was heard from Leonard Rose, the eminent 'cellist, last night at Town Hall. His performances, whether considered from the technical, tonal or interpretive angle, were of a distinguished order not easily surpassed, being equally remarkable for their communicativeness and musicianship.

Pre-holiday influences dominated trading in shares yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Tax selling reappeared and depressed some issues but, in the main, switching operations accounted largely for the changes of the day. Quotations were affected only mildly for the most part.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The British Government is determined that the textile industry shall reach its export targets in 1948 even if present skimpy rations of wool and cotton cloth for home consumption have to be slashed, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today.
Three persons were killed and fourteen others injured last night when a private car and a bus collided head-on at Hillside Avenue and 262d Street, Floral Park, L.I.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- Rumors that the Communists might be about to make an effort to seize power by force, perhaps simultaneously with a similar attempt in France, were widespread in Italy today while the Government hastily took extensive measures to face such a possibility.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- President Truman said today, as he received the gold medal of the Pan American Society of the United States, that preservation of friendly inter-American relations would make easier the solution of Eastern Hemisphere problems.

LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 26 -- A mile-long parade of 4,000 school children, the largest youth gathering in the history of this Frenchspeaking community, marked the close here today of the annual convention of the National Catholic Rural life Conference.

Plans for new groups of dwellings in Brooklyn and Queens were included in the construction projects filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The plans follow: Manhattan Baruch PI, 26-30: new storage building: Myer

Carelessness in the home, one of the leading factors in our disgraceful toll of accidental death and injury, is now in the spotlight in New York. In the annual campaign of the Greater New York Safety Council nearly a million check lists distributed to the schools through the Police Department have been taken home by school children, to be filled out on the ground where the accidents occur.

The Queen Mary sailed for Southampton yesterday with 111 United Nations diplomats and advisers, who were lukewarm about the work of the ten-week General Assembly. There was, however, one determinedly optimistic note in the comments from the British, the Russians and the smaller delegations -- the vitriolic debate in the Assembly had provided a safetyvalve for bitter feelings.

When Governor William Bradford of Plymouth Plantation ordained a feast of thanksgiving in the fall of 1621 he was not doing anything new, nor could he realize he was setting a precedent. There had been feasts of thanksgiving in all lands since time out of mind.

Hailing the action of the United States in binding natural rubber imports under the Geneva trade pacts on the duty-free list for the next three years, Alvaro A. da Silveira, Brazilian Senator and delegate to the United Nations, said yesterday that about 25 per cent of the crude rubber yield of Brazil may be available in 1948 for the United States market despite the rising.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- General Bennett Meyers' involved transactions in government bonds were described in detail today as Chairman Charles W. Tobey of the Senate Banking Committee promised an investigation to "stop this joyriding in government securities."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- As a result of the Senate investigation of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, President Truman has asked James V. Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, to submit to him a list of all officers of the second World War who are receiving tax-free disability retirement pay.

First tabulations of a national survey of steel mills reveal that steel distributors have a definite national problem of obtaining adequate supplies despite a remarkable, unanimity among mill spokesmen concerning the importance of uninterrupted distributor service to industrial users.

Long Island University's basketball team rolled to its third straight victory by crushing Paterson State Teachers College, 76 -- 39, last night on the Brooklyn College of Pharmacy court. The Blackbirds, who enjoyed a 17-9 margin at the end of the first quarter, tossed in fifteen straight points in the second period to be ahead, 32 -- 9, at the intermission.

Favorable weather for selling women's winter coats has made it possible for retailers to exceed coat figures of November, 1946, by sizable margins, according to resident buyers yesterday. Larger unit volume and higher prices, they said, have enabled coat and suit departments to equal in the first three weeks of the month dollar receipts of the entire month a year ago.

The Grace Line's Santa Teresa left port yesterday morning with two forty-ton, 1,000-kilowatt diesel electric generators as part of her deck cargo, company officials announced last night. The generators are the first of five being rushed to Venezuela to relieve a critical power shortage, they said.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I suggest that every one of the millions of closets in America yield up one or even two pairs of shoes for the unshod feet of hapless war victims. Not discards, and certainly not the new style things, but wearable shoes fashioned of good leather with full toes and leather heels.

Mickey and Sparky, the cat and the dog that saved twenty-eight persons in a Brooklyn apartment house from death by asphyxiation, received official recognition for their feat yesterday from the American Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The United States Government, which owns more than 60 per cent of the world's gold and is worrying about the prospect of getting more, is suffering an additional headache from a Canadian scheme to dig gold faster.

It was cold and raw on Fordham's exposed practice field yesterday but, in their fierce concentration on the offensive and defensive didoes with which they hope to confound New York University in the twenty-fifth Battle of the Bronx at the Polo Grounds Saturday, the Rams were oblivious of the wintry blasts.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Rutgers, which lost only its opener to Columbia by 40 -- 28, will oppose a scrappy Brown eleven tomorrow morning.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- The Treasury today announced revision of its Social Security regulations to broaden coverage in the light of recent Supreme Court decisions.

If a two-thirds majority is lacking when it votes tomorrow, experts on procedure said yesterday that the United Nations General Assembly would send the Palestine question back to the special committee that produced the partition plan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- United States trade with Russia was slated today for Congressional inquiry next week amid mounting criticism that compared shipments of metal and machinery to the Soviets with sales of scrap iron and oil to Japan prior to World War II. Chairman Charles Wolverton called a meeting of the House Commerce Committee for Monday to consider a resolution to require the Administration to report on all machinery shipments to Russia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, told Congress today that the Administration would limit application of the proposed allocation, priority and inventory control powers over basic industrial commodities to steel for the present and to "a very few materials" in the future.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Four survivors and the bodies of four other crew members were found today on the beached bow section of the shattered Army transport Clarksdale Victory, and the second mate said he thought the forty-three other crewmen went to the bottom in the stern half of the broken ship.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 26 -- Navy enthusiasm and defiance to Army reached the fever mark tonight as the entire brigade assembled on Farragut Field on the eve of the football team's departure for Philadelphia.

The First Army asked the assistance yesterday of citizens in preventing "live" ammunition from reaching scrap piles at steel mills, where inspectors have found unexploded shells up to 155 millimeters awaiting the scrap furnace.

VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- The Russian representatives refused at today's meeting of the Allied Council for Austria to state their attitude toward this country's proposed currency conversion law, but said they would define it at a special meeting to be called after a conference tomorrow with the Austrian Finance Minister, Dr. Georg Zimmern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Louis Bromfield, co-chairman of the American League for a Free Palestine, asserted today that the league received the "brush-off" when it urged State Department action on a five-point program to prevent bloodshed and strife in the Middle East.

Raw Furs Opening Higher Opening prices for the new raw fur season on several major skins will range 40 per cent or more over last year, it was reported here yesterday. This is particularly true of muskrats and mink. Quotations last year, however, were affected by the decline in prices and reduced demand which marked the fall season in fur merchandise.

Three Rumanians, formerly leading figures in their country's foreign relations but now refugees from a Communist-dominated nation, took the Soviet Union to task yesterday for exterminating democratic ideals and endangering world peace.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 26 (AP) -- United States soldiers will be taught in official Army classes next week that the aim of the Communist party in the United States is "to ssize control of the existing Government by penetration and infiltration, or force if necessary, to set up a dictatorship."

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 26 -- After hearing long arguments, the military tribunal in the trial of the I.G. Farbenindustrie executives here today admitted to evidence a mass of documents placing on individual defendants the ultimate responsibility for the manufacture of "Cyclone B" gas.

Two of the three local professional football coaches may be said to be worried about coming events in their business. Ray Flaherty, who bosses the "almost" Eastern champion Yankees, must be classed as the chief worrier because a Sunday triumph over the runner-up Buffalo Bills will clinch the flag for him, while a reverse will make him worry more than ever.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Senate rejected by a 56-to-30 vote today an attempt to cut authorizations for the stop-gap relief program for France, Italy and Austria from $597,000,000 to $400,000,000.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov 26 (AP) -- Powerful Penn State will match its undefeated, untied record against Southern Methodist University in the Cotton Bowl here New Year's Day. Acceptance by the Nittany Lions was announced by Chairman Dan D. Rogers of the Cotton Bowl Athletic Association.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 26 -- Coach Earl Blaik today called for "full speed," usually a familiar Navy signal, in Army's last major practice for the football clash with the midshipmen in Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium Saturday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- RKO-Radio Pictures announced late today that Adrian Scott, "producer, and Edward Dmytryk, director, who were cited Monday for contempt of Congress, have been discharged by the studio. The letters of dismissal, signed by M. Peter Rathyon, RKO president, and giving breach of the so-called moral clauses in the contracts of Scott and Dmytryk as the reason for the action, said:

LONDON, Nov. 26 (U.P.) -- The elimination of ice hockey from the winter Olympic games was suggested today by a high-ranking official of the International Ice Hockey Federation because of the current dispute concerning selection of the United States team.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, notwithstanding its long and glorious history, its roster of the greatest names that musicdrama of the last sixty-odd years has known, attained a new distinction last night when it presented the first "Tristan und Isolde" of the season.

BLOOMINGDALE, N.J., Nov. 26 -- James A. White, newspaper publisher here and prominent figure in the public life of Passaic County, died of a heart attack this afternoon at the home of his daughter in Ardmore, Pa. His age was 56.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The deep gloom that settled over Embassy Row and certain other capital areas today when it was learned that a House committee had reduced the estimates of the cost of stop-gap aid to Europe, and the outcries that may be expected, are periodic manifestations which no amount of experience seems able to eradicate.

Since time out of mind it has been impossible to distinguish the leading political administrator of the party in power from the Postmaster General of the United States. They were the same person. It was true even when these states were colonies and Benjamin Franklin held the job.

A vital provision of the city's rent control law that requires a landlord to obtain a certificate of eviction from the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission was declared invalid yesterday in a Supreme Court ruling in Brooklyn.
Six hundred men and women mourned over their war dead on Pier 3 at the Army Base in Brooklyn yesterday forenoon.

Paul O'Dwyer, vice president of the National Lawyers Guild, asked last night for "a change in the law or whatever is necessary to make our State Committee Against Discrimination effective in breaking down job discrimination."

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The Government's effort to put an end to the widespread strikes in France by granting a cost-of-living bonus fell flat tonight. The proposal was quickly rejected as "unacceptable" by a meeting of the secretaries of the eighteen national unions now idle, who said they would call on their members to continue and intensify the strikes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- An austere program in aid of Europe's hungry, backed with great Government powers over basic food in all its aspects to be held as a weapon behind the door, was laid out for Congress by the Administration today.
PARIS, Nov. 26 -- A bustle silhouette, daring in proportions, is a feature of Jacques Fath's opening.

Offensive brilliance, which paid off in victories on the field, keynotes the 1947 United Press AllAmerica Football Team, announced yesterday and selected by sports writers and sports broadcasters in the annual nation-wide poll.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Increases of $237,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $347,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and a decrease of $225,000,000 in borrowings.

Signs of a possible break in the League of New York Theatres plan to curtail the first-night press list became evident yesterday when James F. Reilly, executive director of the organization of theatre owners, operators and producers, confirmed a report that no action would be taken on the matter until the board of governors meets on Dec. 4.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Following is the text of today's statement by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov to the Council of Foreign Ministers as distributed in English by the Soviet Monitor, an affiliate of the Soviet News Agency Tass: We have decided to examine six questions, having placed them on our agenda.

The Staten Island Edison Corporation petitioned the Public Service Commission yesterday for authority to sell its property, franchises and other assets to the newly formed Staten Island Electric Corporation, organized to carry on the business.

Hope that the European recovery program advanced by Secretary of State George C. Marshall would meet the "danger of general starvation and famine" in Europe before it was "too late" was expressed by Pastor Martin Niemoeller, president of the German Evangelical Church of Hesse and Nassau, in a letter to the Emergency Committee for German Protestantism, Inc., 325 Central Park West, it was learned yesterday.

Commissioner John J. Allan, chief of staff of the International Salvation Army, London, said in an interview yesterday morning at the Salvation Army headquarters, 120 West Fourteenth Street, that he had found differences among Communists in western Europe in their attitudes toward religion.

General Assembly Met at 11 A.M. at Flushing Meadow, Queens, and debated partition report of Ad Hoc Committee on Palestine Questions. Heard representatives of Sweden, Philippines, Yemen, Canada, Greece, Brazil, United Kingdom, United States, Iran and Egypt.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- A call for a national non-partisan conference on German peace was issued today by the Soviet-dominated Socialist Unity party. On the basis of immediate reaction the meeting, set for Dec. 6 and 7, will be attended by delegates from the Soviet zone only.

The owner of an apartment house at 222 East Sixty-first Street, who was arrested yesterday morning on a charge of violating one of the Sharkey rent laws, will be the first person to be prosecuted by the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission for asking a "bonus" for an apartment.

Fighting off a spirited bid by the New Yorkers in the last three minutes, the Boston Celtics topped the Knickerbockers, 65 to 63, in a Basketball Association of America tussle at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory last night.

Money raised for research into the cause and possible cure for rheumatic fever by the Masonic Foundation for Medical Research and Human Welfare will be allocated to medical facilities, according to the recommendations of an advisory board of eleven doctors appointed yesterday, it was announced by Gay H. Brown, Grand Master of Masons of New York State.

The punting average of Leslie (Footsie) Palmer of North Carolina State wobbled a bit last week-end, but he still has a chance in his remaining game against Maryland Saturday to set a new collegiate record, The Associated Press reports.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- Nineteen Soviet citizens were ordered expelled from France today on charges of intervening in French internal affairs in connection with the recent social disorders, according to a statement by the Ministry of the Interior.
The United Nations General Assembly postponed a vote on the partition of Palestine yesterday after Zionist supporters found that they still lacked an assured twothirds majority.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -- Pennsylvania's undefeated but once-tied football team will play Cornell before a capacity crowd of 78,205 tomorrow in the fifty-fourth game of a series that started in 1893. Kick-off time has been moved up to 1:30 P.M.
Trading in cotton future on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday, with final prices 6 to 31 points net higher.

BOSTON, Nov. 26 -- James M. Curley, noticeably thinner and whiter than when he began serving his penitentiary sentence five months ago, returned to his Jamaicaway home at 8:30 tonight to be greeted by about fifty friends and relatives who had gathered inside the house.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Executive Committee of Britain's Trades Union Congress side-stepped a decision today on the delicate problem of whether it would support the American Federation of Labor in its demand for a cleavage between the union movements of democratic nations and trade unions from Communist-dominated countries.

WASHINGTON, NOV. 26 -- President Truman was reported today to have urged Senator Scott W. Lucas of Illinois, who has been weighing the idea of running for Governor back home, to stay on in Congress where he is Democratic Senate whip.

Ads to Back Fair Trade The American Fair Trade Council, Inc., is preparing ten advertisements for issuance early next year as part of a public relations program to counter what it regards as an organized campaign to weaken the Federal Fair Trade Law, Frank Masterson, assistant to John W. Anderson, council president, stated yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your comment of Nov. 18 on "the dark curtain descending on Prague" seems to me to be overrated. That the Communist power in Czechoslovakia is "entrenched in the internal administration" is an illusion. It is untrue that the Army is in the Communist hands.

ON Thanksgiving Day, 1898, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, then 16 and a student at Groton School, got up at 6:30 in the morning. He went for a long drive with some friends, stopping the buckboard at a mill for a two-gallon jug of sweet cider. Then they went back to the school and had "a glorious Thanksgiving dinner, turkey, ham, cranberry sauce, vegetables, pies (three kinds), icecream, pudding, fruit, etc."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 26 (AP) -- You can't bank on a change of climate to help you lick your asthma or some other allergic condition, Dr. Carroll M. Pounders of Oklahoma City said today at the closing session of the Southern Medical Association's convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Air Force table of preparedness, based on the State Department's estimate of the international situation, calls for at least 630 of the heaviest bombers distributed at strategic bases over the world, with 504 immediately ready to take to the air and the remainder in the base reserves.
The New York City Housing Authority awarded at competitive sale yesterday temporary loan notes amounting to $11,889,000 for financing Astoria Houses, Stephen Poster Houses and Melrose Houses.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 26 -- Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, defended at a news conference today the progress in the dismantling and removal of plants from Germany.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The last-place Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Boston Bruins, 5 to 3, before 16,504 fans tonight, forcing the Bruins to remain in second place in the National Hockey League with the Toronto Maple Leafs.
Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Polish Peasant party leader who fled from Poland last month, arrived in New York yesterday morning by plane from London.

If we are to assume, as we must, that increased production is one of the most effective of our anti-inflation weapons, then it is difficult to dissent from the thesis that business should be permitted to depreciate its plant and equipment on more liberal terms than at present.

Stockholders of many American companies will have more reason to celebrate this Thanksgiving Day and will face the Christmas shopping season with more confidence following announcements of dividend distributions totaling millions of dollars voted by directors in increasing volume yesterday.

THE end of the football season is always one of the more attractive parts of the gridiron year since it invariably brings together traditional rivals for the flourish of the grand wind-up. We had Yale-Harvard before a packed house last Saturday; we have PennCornell today before a ditto gathering and on this coming Saturday we have Army-Navy -- and has anyone a spare ticket?

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- A joint note urging the restoration of economic unity in Germany and the gradual restoration of a German autonomy and political responsibility under Allied supervision was delivered to the Council of Foreign Ministers here today by the Benelux nations -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

Despite the disappointments of a troubled peace, millions of Americans here and abroad will observe Thanksgiving Day today in a spirit of humble gratitude for their countless blessings and of profound compassion for the less fortunate.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased 1,736,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend total supplies were 84,777,000 barrels, compared with 83,041,000 a week earlier and 87,620,000 on Nov. 23, 1946.

The ship Alawai of the Waterman Steamship Lines will be renamed the Friendship for a special trip to Genoa, Italy, leaving this port about Dec. 15 with a cargo of food donated by Americans through the Friendship Train, it was announced yesterday.

In honor of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," Katharine Cornell and her husband have staged a beautiful and respectful production, which was put on at the Martin Beck last evening. The tragedy is a difficult one with a broken story line, and few actresses have been happy in it.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh stopped in London briefly today en route to Scotland for the remainder of their wedding trip. They will stay at Birkhall House, Deeside, near Aberdeen. They cut short by several days their scheduled stay at Earl Mountbatten's residence in Romsey, Hampshire.

Stamp dealers from Canada to Bermuda, including several in the metropolitan area, have lost stamps valued at $30,000 in a swindle allegedly conducted by a former Brooklyn couple, United States Attorney John F.X. McGohey said yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Disraeli's famous witticism that England was divided into two nations, the rich and the poor, could not be said today. Therein lies one striking proof that Great Britain socially, as well as imperially, economically and politically, is at the end of an era.

We Love Parades New York's Thanksgiving Day Parade comes of age today. That is to say, this is the twenty-first year that Macy's looses that prancing procession of jolly storybook characters and, with beckoning from Santa Claus himself, thereby opens the Christmas shopping season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Department of Agriculture officials said today that the slaughter program against foot-and-mouth, disease started nine months ago in Mexico was too hard on the Mexican economy and would end immediately.

Two Municipal Court Justices, in essentially similar rulings, refused yesterday to order the eviction of high-income tenants from Knickerbocker Village, the East Side housing project whose 1,600 apartments are rented at about $12.50 a room a month.

Justice L. Barron Hill presumably has met only normal dogs, with both pairs of feet planted on the ground. Yesterday, in a special term of the Queens Supreme Court, he decided to reserve decision in a case in which a dog had allegedly damaged the ceiling of his master's apartment.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Although I have encountered many deficiencies in the Taft-Hartley law in my professional experiences, there is one serious omission which has overtones and implications of a public nature warranting immediate consideration.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If one were casting around for a long-range program for better understanding among nations of this world, consideration might be thoughfully given to the new nursery school recently inaugurated at the United Nations.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, dismissed Samuel Moskowitz from his $47-a-week job as provisional social investigator in the Welfare Department yesterday in an atmosphere of official reticence on the nature of the charge against the employe.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 26 -- The Public Utilities Commission of New Jersey announced today that it had granted the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company rate increases on intra-state service estimated at 15 per cent for residential and 25 per cent for business subscribers.

Representatives of ten nations supported the partition of Palestine and those of eight opposed it in the course of an all-day debate yesterday in the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- About 53,000 wholesale and retail organizations of North Carolina "operate for profit without paying corporation taxes," Harry Caldwell of Greensboro, N.C., said today.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Operational plans for Britain's $4,000,000,000 venture into the nationalization of railroads and inland transportation were disclosed today by Sir Cyril Hurcomb, chairman of the British Transport Commission. The commission will take over the railroads and auxiliary properties Jan. 1.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers witnessed a great explosion today, with Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov making all the expected accusations against the three other powers, as anti-democratic and imperialistic and even as fomenting war.

Aboard the Queen Mary at the pier here yesterday in his fourbunk cabin deep astern sat a littleknown, young, Soviet attache. He began a new public relations policy for his country that United Nations' correspondents hope will be as permanent as it was unprecedented.

Further evidence of the hardening of interest rates became apparent yesterday with the announcement by the National City Bank of New York that, effective on Monday, it would raise its bankers' acceptance yield rates 1/8 to 1/4 per cent for short and long term bills above the levels now prevailing in the market.

One of the most-traveled Negro college elevens in the country, Wilberforce State will meet Bergen College of New Jersey at the Polo Grounds today in the first intercollegiate interracial game ever played in the city. A crowd of 20,000 is expected to be on hand at the 2 P.M. starting time.

MANILA, Nov. 26 -- Political problems entered today's session of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in Baguio despite the United Nations order to adhere to economics and eschew politics.

GRAVESEND, England, Thursday, Nov. 27 -- The political position of Britain's Labor Government has been strengthened by a victory in the Gravesend election yesterday. Sir Richard, Acland, Labor candidate, won by 24,692 votes to 23,017 for his Conservative opponent Frank Taylor.

A week ago in Cleveland the senior federal judge of the northern Ohio district ruled that the housing and rent act of 1947 was unconstitutional on the grounds that it was beyond the power of Congress to enforce local rent controls as a war emergency action when peace had returned "in fact," if not technically.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 27 -- Because of a grave deterioration in dollar credits, Australia is facing more drastic cuts in imports from North America, Prime Minister Joseph B. Chifley told the Federal Labor Parliamentary party yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The belief that American democracy is flexible and strong enough to overcome defects in the practice of democratic human relations was expressed here tonight by Langston Hughes of New York, poet and playwright.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Warner Brothers has signed a new contract with Errol Flynn by which the actor will star in one film annually for the studio through 1961 and will have the right to make one picture annually away from the studio, beginning in 1950.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Nov. 27 -- The Baldwin and Lawrence High School football teams battled to a scoreless tie today in the fifth annual Class A play-off of the South Shore Athletic League on Firemen's Memorial Field.
JUNEAU, Alaska, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A twin-engine air transport carried thirteen persons to death in a pre-dawn crash today as it approached the Yakutat Village airport for a scheduled landing.

Robert Taylor and his wife Edna, who came to New York from Manchester, England, early in 1907, were found yesterday accidentally dead of illuminating gas in their three-room cold-water flat at 236 East Twenty-first Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- As 1,500 members of Local 16 of the International Typographical Union, AFL, rounded out the fourth day of their strike against the city's six daily newspapers, the publishers and editors, finding their girl typewriter operators becoming more efficient as substitutes for the printers, were preparing tonight large issues of tomorrow's papers for their nearly 3,000,000 readers.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Deputies appointed by the Council of Foreign Ministers to try to break the stalemate on the Austrian peace treaty agreed today to discuss the French compromise proposal.

Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota chose Thanksgiving Day to call the Administration's emergency European relief program "a combination of blitzkrieg and the old mousetrap play" and to tell the world that "no one will suffer if Congress takes two or three weeks to examine the facts thoroughly."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- American historical documents aboard the Freedom Train are a "beacon of hope to the world," Speaker Martin of the House declared today at a special ceremony held at Union Station.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Stopping the Boston Bruins for the third straight time this season, the Detroit Red Wings tightened their National Hockey League lead tonight. They beat the short-handed Bruins, 4 to 1, before 12,856 fans.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 27 --The Palestine Government's intention to sell Government land on the Haifa waterfront, which has aroused a storm of protest from the Jewish community here, was confirmed today in the official Palestine Gazette.

ATHENS, Nov. 27 -- The United Nations special Balkans committee, following a series of closed meetings, adopted today a resolution asking Secretary General Trygve Lie to seek the consent of the Albanian, Bulgarian, Greek and Yugoslav Governments for the committee to maintain observation groups "near and on both sides of" the Greek frontier.

Picture books, imaginative tales and an exhibit of original illustrations, all representing outstanding books published during the year, are on display in the children's room of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Brooklyn Prep enjoyed its first unbeaten scholastic football season in the history of the school by defeating St. John's Prep, 28 to 0, for its, ninth triumph before 12,000 onlookers at Boys High Field yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- The Bavarian Ministry of Education has proposed a school reform plan that would re-establish the "old aristocratic structure of the Prussian system in 1911," United States Military Government officials said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- After a fruitless search all season, George Washington finally found that elusive football victory today at Griffith Stadium, routing Kings Point, 40 -- 0.

Inflationary trends are being given a sharp upward spiral spurt by greatly increased competition between buyers for available supplies of scrap, metals of all types, standard machine parts, tools and light machinery, purchasing spokesmen disclosed this week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- There is a growing movement in the country for an embargo on the shipment of raw materials, machinery and machine tools to the Soviet Union.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Friday, Nov. 28 -- The twelfth and final indictment to be registered with United States Military Government tribunals here was filed late today against thirteen former German Army generals and one admiral.
Accounts Heatron, Inc., Wilmington, Del., to Henry A. Stephens, Inc., New York City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- The Government urged householders today to insulate their homes, put rugs under the doors at night and keep their furnace exit dampers closed if they wanted to help beat the fuel shortage and, incidentally, save up to 50 or 60 per cent on their heating bills.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 -- Rehabilitation of Germany's educational system and direction of its communications media must be accomplished if the defeated country is to come into the family of democratic nations, John H. Haefner, a member of the National Council of Social Studies committee which returned recently from Germany, asserted today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (U.P.) -- The American Products Council today accused the State Department of "crystal gazing" in its recentlyannounced mass trade agreement with twenty-two nations and urged Congress to kill the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act and "recapture its authority over the United States tariff structure."

HAVANA, Nov. 27 -- William L. Clayton, United States chairman, urged the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today to adopt the Geneva draft charter of rules for world trade without "overloading it with a multiplicity of exceptions and escape clauses."

General reorganization of the Welfare Department will proceed today as the result of criticisms of its policy and procedures expressed in a recent report of Mayor O'Dwyer's executive committee on administration, Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 27 -- The Communists have begun their expected attack on the Ministry of Justice and the Czech National Socialist Minister of Justice Prokop Drtina.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The best features in the stock markets here today were a recovery in gilt-edge stocks and continued speculative activity in gold-mining shares.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Navy football team -- hungering for the victory over Army that would make this heretofore dismal season a glittering success -- dropped anchor here today and promptly sat down to what the middles hope and believe will be the first of two feasts.

Sales of Federated Department Stores, Inc., in the quarter ended on Nov. 1, rose $10,478,410 to $72,609,789 from the $62,131,379 volume transacted in the corresponding three months of 1946, Fred Lazarus Jr., president, announced in the statement of operations released today.

Municipal bond men are keeping their fingers crossed in regard to the immediate market outlook for tax-exempt obligations of local governments. For the first time in weeks, dealers are seeing evidences of stabilization in the market for tax-exempt bonds, which, like that for high-grade taxable securities, has been undergoing downward readjustment since the summer.

Negotiations are going on between the city and a number of steamship lines for occupancy of the proposed new shipping terminal at West Thirty-ninth Street, it was reported yesterday at offices of the Department of Marine and Aviation.

The world's hungry shared Thanksgiving yesterday with all America, in fact and in spirit. Prayers for their delivery from want rose from festive boards throughout the land, and from altars and pews in houses of worship. In New York and at other docksides, ships were loaded with staple foods, a Thanksgiving-Christmas gift from America's millions to unfed millions abroad.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Roaring back in the second half to overcome a 12-0 deficit while wearing down their rivals with weight advantage and superior line play, the White Plains Tigers turned back the fast Alliance (Ohio) High School eleven, 25 to 12, in the intersectional schoolboy football game at White Plains High Stadium today.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- William and Mary Indians, Southern Conference champions, humbled the University of Richmond Spiders before 15,000 fans today, 35-0.
The American Press Institute of the Columbia School of Journalism will open a seminar for twenty-five editorial writers on Monday, Floyd Taylor, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

Centering its attack around the passing of Mike Carter and the running of Walter Sellers, Wilberforce College of Xenia, Ohio, defeated Bergen Junior College of Teaneck, N. J., 40 -- 12, before 16,000 persons at the Polo Grounds yesterday. It was the first interracial college football game ever played here.

Giving solemn thanks for their own blessings, thousands of worshipers attending special church services here were reminded yesterday of the misery that blankets much of the world, of the failure of true world brotherhood and the threats to the spiritual fabric of America.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Gilbert Dodds today won the Elks thirty - seventh annual six - mile cross-country run for the fourth consecutive time. He was hard-pushed all the way by Mike Stavole of Miami University.

The very brilliant Dmitri Mitropoulos, for his second Thursday night concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall, chose again an odd program; a program, on the whole, of pretty bad music, of which the real climax and the single musical satisfaction was the masterly performance by Mischa Elman of the Tchaikovsky concerto.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission said yesterday that companies which pipe natural gas from state to state should change their marketing policy to cope with the problem of seasonal demands.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska Nov. 27 (AP) -- A Coast Guard rescue party completed today the removal of the four known survivors of the wrecked Army transport Clarksdale Victory from desolate Hippa Island, as the probable death toll was placed at forty-nine.

LONDON, Nov. 27 --The Labor victory in the parliamentary byelection at Gravesend yesterday is regarded by Government supporters as evidence that socialism in Britain has now turned the corner of a difficult period and is on the up grade again.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The vaunted "invincibility" of the Soviet Army is a carefully nurtured myth made possible by the secrecy behind the "iron curtain," in the view of an Estonian exile who fought as an officer both with and against Russia's forces.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Colonies of United States citizens scattered all across impoverished Europe observed Thanksgiving Day with gratitude for their small oases of plenty.

An American policy of "toughness and more toughness" toward Russia will preserve peace but any lapse into appeasement may endanger it, according to Victor Kravchenko, a former Soviet official who declined to return to Russia to be purged.

Throughout the city thousands of veterans in Army, Navy and Marine hospitals participated yesterday in traditional Thanksgiving festivities. Church services were held in most Hospitals, and the joyous custom of downing turkey with all the trimmings became the order of the day at all of them.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The old clash about the Polish-German frontier came up today at the third day's meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers. Everyone repeated the stand he had taken in Moscow last spring, and Secretary of State Marshall was especially firm in making it clear that the United States still did not consider Poland's western frontier as settled.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- The Government's precautionary measures against the possibility of a Communist attempt to seize power by violence remained in force today but the tense atmosphere that prevailed yesterday had to a large extant disappeared.
Two hundred and fifty men and women observing their first Thanksgiving in America heard Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman assert yesterday that this country must admit more refugees.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- President Truman stood with, head bowed today as a minister of the gospel prayed for the success of the Foreign Ministers' Conference in London and of the United Nations "where the future of the world is in the balance."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 27 -- The country's teachers of English were cautioned tonight by Dr. Thomas Clark Pollock, dean of the Washington, Square College of Arts and Sciences of New York University, not to "lose our balance in a foolish rushing to extremes."
American, democracy is threatened by political corruption, race prejudice and selfishness at home, Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, director of Cooper Union, declared yesterday.

Waterfowl shooting and deer hunting seem to be the big incentives right now, with the Catskill and Adirondack deer situation improving considerably and the Connecticut and New Jersey duck shooting attracting many New York hunters.

LONDON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's statement read to the Council of foreign Ministers here today and made available by the United States delegation: At the Moscow session, the United States proposed the creation of a special boundary commission which, under the direction of the deputies, would consider and make recommendations to the Council concerning the PolishGerman frontier.

GREENVILLE, S. C., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Davidson's Wildcats struck in the second period for two touchdowns, one on a freak Furman fumble, to defeat-the Hurricanes, 20-6, today in the final game of the 1947 season for both teams.

ARMY vs. Navy -- It was just a year ago that the cadet invincibles stampeded proudly into the Municipal Stadium in Philadelphia for their joust with a midshipman contingent which had lost seven in a row. Those omniscient gentlemen who figure out betting odds with coldblooded exactitude were inclined to rate Army as some thirty points better than Navy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Export-Import Bank has granted a credit of $50,000,000 to the Belgian Government, it was announced here today. The bank made public an exchange of letters between its president, William McC. Martin, and Maurice Frere, governor of the National Bank of Belgium.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Secretary of State Marshall and Foreign Secretary Bevin were among dozens of prominent guests today at the annual Thanksgiving Day luncheon of the American Society in London. United States Ambassador Lewis W. Douglas presided at the gathering.

A spurt in the last quarter of a mile enabled Carl Krowicki of the Polish-American A. C. of Elizabeth, N. J., to capture the thirty-seventh annual City Hall to Coney Island Thanksgiving Day handicap walk sponsored by the Walkers Club of America yesterday. Forty-nine started the ten-and-a-half-mile contest through Brooklyn streets and all finisfied. However, four were disqualified for illegal walking.

San Francisco's brilliant backfield combination of Frankie Albert, Len Eshmont, John Strzykalski and Norman Standlee functioned with clocklike precision in the first half yesterday as the Forty-Niners defeated the Brooklyn Dodders, 21-7 in an All-America Conference game at Ebbets Field.

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- The commission created by the 1946 Legislature and headed by Owen D. Young to study the need for and feasibility of a state university is preparing to write a final report which is expected to stop short of recommending establishment of such an institution.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Virginia Military Institute roared back in the second half today to defeat Virginia Tech, 28 to 14, before a Thanksgiving Day crowd of 29,000, which broke all records for attendance at a sports event in the Old Dominion.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, through George A. Sloan, chairman of the board, took a stand yesterday deploring the behavior of a few persons on opening nights whose actions, he said, reflected on "the character of the Metropolitan Opera and its normal audience."

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Striking in the closing seconds of the first period after a pass interception set the stage for a 58 yard touchdown march, South Carolina's Gamecocks handed favored Wake Forest a 6-0 defeat today.

Lake trout, we were told recently by a particularly fervent enthusiast for this fresh-water fish, tastes even better than salt-water salmon. That statement may seem biased to those who argue that all ocean species are superior to all fresh-water varieties

Operations of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company for the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30, resulted in a consolidated net income of $11,004,262 after all deductions, according to the report issued yesterday by Laurence A. Crosby, president.

MONTREAL, Nov. 27 -- A "day of infamy" that will rank with the Japanese betrayal of the United States and the attack on Pearl Harbor threatens the peace-loving Arabic peoples of the world today, M.S. Massoud, president of the Canadian Arab Friendship League, said here last night.

The average American probably feels pretty helpless when it comes to doing anything personally about the widespread hunger and misery that exist in Europe. He doesn't have any known relatives in the distressed areas. He doesn't even know anyone in those areas.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 27 -- The second General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization this evening unanimously voted to hold its third meeting" in Beirut, Lebanon, in November and December of next year.

BERLIN, Nov. 27 -- The Christian Democratic leadership which has been walking the political tightrope in the Soviet zone for more than a year is completely out of favor with the Soviet military administration.

Tickets foxy the All-America Football Conference championship play-off between the Cleveland Browns and the Eastern Division champion, yet to be established, will be placed on sale at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday and in Buffalo on Monday, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Jonas H. Ingram. The title game is scheduled for Dec. 14.

A police captain, a sergeant and a detective, attached to the Sheepshead Bay precinct, Brooklyn, put their heads together yesterday, made several telephone calls, and presented a starving family of four persons with the finest Thanksgiving they had ever had.

DETROIT, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The riproaring Chicago Bears, running a red-hot winning streak to eight games in a row, used long runs and long passes to set up all five of their touchdowns today as they whipped the Detroit Lions, 34 to 14, in a National Football League game.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 27 -- An unscheduled "turkey" delayed Thanksgiving Day dinners yesterday for hundreds of South Shore customers of the Long Island Lighting Company when the gas supply to cook their holiday birds became exhausted because of "an unprecedented demand."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 27 -- A Bucharest Military Tribunal overruled today arguments that a requirement for the Government's censorship of political manifestos produced by Opposition parties was unconstitutional. But the military court postponed for nearly two months the trial of the Independent Social Democratic party on charges of reproducing for general distribution "subversive" literature, which had been submitted to the Allied Control Commission for Rumania.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Pledges and contributions totaling $7O,000 were made tonight at the end of the opening day of the three-day national convention of Junior Hadassah for the Meier Shfeyah Building Fund, devoted to the children's village of Junior Hadassah in Palestine.

MANILA, Nov. 27 -- Piqued at cooling their heels for three days while delegates to the conference of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East argued the acceptability of Siam's new regime, the two-man Siamese delegation walked out of the Baguio conference today and flew to Manila.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 27 -- More than 300,000 persons, with youngsters strongly outnumbered, lined up in Newark and East Orange today to watch the annual L. Bamberger Co. Thanksgiving Day parade which escorted Santa Claus to the city's largest department store, where he will reign until Dec, 24.

To the editor of the new york times : A survey of sidewalk newsstands along Broadway, especially in the Times Square area, shows that the operators of a number of them are going "all-out" in displaying specimens of the new crop of "cheesecake" publications which have made their appearance lately.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Department of Commerce's proposed ban on the use of metal cans for packaging" beer, coffee, pet foods and motor oil would save negligible amounts of steel and tin, and would hurt many small businesses, R. S. Solinsky, president of the Can Manufacturers Institute, said today. The proposal has been attributed directly to Secretary Harriman, and an order putting the ban into effect is said to be in preparation.

The death of George Rector, son of the famous restaurateur and a culinary expert in his own right, no doubt reminded many of us of the sparkling era in which he and his father figured importantly. It was an era when fine food and colorful places in which to eat it were beginning to be plentiful in the midtown district.

Reduced demand for low-end dresses has brought about a shutdown of numerous concerns making this class of goods, it was learned yesterday, and unemployment in the industry is much greater than Usual at this point of the season.

To the editor of the new york times: The vote on Palestine in the U.N raises a vital issue. In the poll of 25 to 13 in the Ad Hoc Committee there were 10 Arab votes, including six members of the Arab League and three non-Arab states, Cuba, Siam, Turkey. In court of law or equity no judge can sit in a case in which he has an interest.

Rose Dirman, soprano, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The interesting and unusual program, she had prepared included arias from Handel's "Orlando" and Mozart's "Idomeneo," German lieder by Mendelssohn, Wetzler and Marx, the complete "Melodies populaires grecques" of Ravel, songs by Poulenc, Nadia Boulanger, Scriabin and Medtner, and a final group of English items, featuring the first performance of John Duke's "The Bird."
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The United States liner America, due to sail at 2 P.M. (9 A.M. EST) today, postponed her departure and altered her route because of the French transport strike.

Macy's annual Thanksgiving parade cavorted down Central Park West and Broadway yesterday. Crowds numbering 2,000,000 lined the sidewalks, peered from open windows, crowded rooftops and marquees and roared their delight.

DUNKIRK, N.Y., Nov. 27 -- Dunkirk, this time assisted by Fredonia, today for the second time in a year opened wide its heart and, in a "hands-across-the-sea" gesture, contributed $100,000 in clothing, food and cash for the rehabilitation of Anzio, Italy, where so many American youths fell in Word War II.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 27 -- The Hempstead High Tigers finished their 1947 season undefeated in seven games today by defeating Brooklyn Tech, 27 -- 7, before a crowd of 6,500. The defeat was the first for Tech in eight contests.

With both sides now puzzled over the outcome, the United Nations General Assembly will meet at Flushing Meadow at 11 A.M. today in a new effort to reach a decision on the long-debated proposal for the partition of Palestine.

The United States has entertained many distinguished guests in recent years, but it is doubtful whether any other visitor has had so profound an influence on American opinon in so short a time as that exerted by a statesman who has just sailed on the Queen Mary, London bound.

If turkey is the reigning monarch of Thanksgiving, cranberries head the honors list of his kingdom for a day. Without their dash and sauce, he would be a colorless, tasteless and tangless old bird. They mellow the dark meat, tone the white. They have a fine cutting edge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Henry T. Myers, President Truman's personal pilot, said today tests showing that recent fires aboard two Douglas DC-6 planes may have been caused by gasoline sucked into the cabin heating system from an overflowing tank in the wing pointed to No. 3 alternate tank as "suspect."

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 27 -- Rutgers wrote finis to a great gridiron campaign today as Harvey Harman's Queensmen from the banks of the Raritan conquered Brown, 27 -- 20. It was the eighth straight victory of the season for Rutgers which started with a heart-breaking 40-28 setback by Columbia.

The Lolos and Lololand That interesting story in the papers about the two daring American Army men who penetrated into the land of the practically unknown and reputedly ferocious Lolos in western China, on a search for American aviators said to have been held captive ever since they had crashed there during the war, reminded one newspaper peruser that somewhere, at some time or other, he had read a book about Lololand.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Handsome satins and dark brocades are handled by Jacques Heim with generosity and simplicity for Christmas party frocks. Voluminous ankle-length skirts are set onto tight basque bodices. The most fetching of these is piped in black velvet along this seaming in nineteenth, century fashion.

Advancing its plan for a large bus terminal on the West Side, the Port of New York Authority has acquired for cash the eight-story loft building at 345 West Fortieth Street, near Eighth Avenue. The property is assessed at $150,000 and measures 45 by 100 feet.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- When drawing conclusions about Great Britain at the end of a great era, it is well to remember that there have been other crises in the past as bad as this one.

Declaring that the decision on Wednesday of Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink in Brooklyn against the eviction provision of the city's rent control laws had thrown the housing situation into turmoil, Assemblyman Philip J. Schupler, Brooklyn Democrat, called yesterday for an immediate session of the Legislature to enact reinforcing legislation against evictions.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Pennsylvania undergraduates tore down their own goal posts in next to nothing flat today as the Red and Blue completed its first football season since 1924 without a defeat.

JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The West Chester State Teachers College of West Chester, Pa., defeated Carson-Newman College of Jefferson City, Tenn., 20 to 6, here today in the third annual Burley Bowl football game.

As yesterday's repasts were being prepared in millions of kitchens across the land, three religious leaders and Charles Luckman, who headed the President's Citizens Food Committee, went on the air to remind a, fortunate nation of the hunger of millions abroad.

The Glidden Company announced yesterday that it has started a $1,000,000 modernization program in four major paint and varnish plants located in Cleveland, San Francisco, Reading and Minneapolis. According; to A. D. Duncan, vice president, the work will be completed in a year.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The first-half passing of Ken Holland and the second-half running of Aubrey Fowler gave the University of Arkansas Razorbacks a 27-13 triumph over the University of Tulsa today, its first victory in the school's traditional football series since 1941.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 28 -- The Cabinet of Premier Robert Schuman received a vote of confidence at 4:30 o'clock this morning after the Premier had promised energetic action in the strike situation before the day was out.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- The same war production techniques used to produce bombers here must be marshaled by Britain to get quick results in her drive for mechanization of the cotton textile industry, according to the report of the Evershed committee of the cotton machinery industry which was issued today as a White Paper.
