Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, self-exiled leader of the Peasant party in Poland, described the country from which he fled last month as "a pure totalitarian state" in an interview here yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 27 -- Italy is the first former European belligerent to abolish artificial exchange rates and to allow the force of supply and demand to establish the value of its currency in terms of foreign money.

Twenty-six men, a port supervisor, and a guard gave up their Thanksgiving Day yesterday and worked at re-packaging gifts to the Friendship Train because, as one of them put it: "We can't be happy over here until they're a little happier over there."

YONKERS, N. Y., Nov. 27Meeting stubborn resistance from its city rival, Saunders Trade, in the annual Thanksgiving Day game at Roosevelt Field, the' Roosevelt High School team nevertheless scored a 15-to-12 triumph j to annex the Yonkers schoolboy' football crown.

The tables were bright with flowers and candles, white linens and gay china. Pumpkins stood on the window sills. It was a big day yesterday at the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, 121 West 105th Street. Former Governor and Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman and their son John were both hosts and guests of honor at the twentyeighth annual Thanksgiving dinner given at the home in memory of Mr. Lehman's mother, Mrs. Mayer Lehman.

By the slender margin of a single point, Joe DiMaggio, star centerfielder of the Yankees has been named the American League's most valuable player for 1947, it was announced yesterday by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

"The Chemistry of Penicillin," a report on all the research done in this field during the war, will be published by the Princeton University Press next year. The report was compiled under the direction of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Congress formally observed a rather anxious Thanksgiving today, but the contending forces on the Administration's $597,000,000 European emergency aid bill took no holiday as the time of decision approached on that issue.

Man and boy, we have never known of a smash hit announcing its transfer in favor of an attraction that hasn't even been fully cast, let alone tried out. Those things simply aren't done in the theatre and any manager voicing such thoughts would be considered off base, euphemistically speaking.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- New England, home of the original Thanksgiving, observed its traditional day of prayer and feasting with turkey and the fruits of the harvest on every table today, and in thousands of homes an extra "silent guest" shared the bounty.

Dorothy Kirsten gave one of the most distinguished performances of her career last night when she sang the title role of "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan opera House. The American soprano, who has become one of the most gifted artists in the company, sang and played Cio-Cio-San so movingly that Puccini's opera took on fresh dimensions of expressivity.

Throughout the war years considerable emphasis was given to the concentration of war orders in large manufacturing corporations. Fears were expressed that this meant a further concentration of business in the hands of these industrial giants. The Department of Commerce has made available a study which indicates that these fears have not materialized.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- From two high Republican sources this week came expressions of active interest in the future of China, accompanied by a statement and an implication that the administration is neglecting a vital area of national security in its concentration on Western Europe.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I recommend your editorial of Nov. 14, "Fairy-Tale Welfare," as "must" reading for all persons in the area of social welfare services. In connection with the Welfare Department investigations, you pointed out that our real concern must be with the deserving persons in distress whose welfare is placed in jeopardy by lack of efficient and sufficient services.
OTTAWA, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Dana Doten, special assistant to United States Ambassador Ray Atherton, said today that there had been hints from his superiors that his resignation would be welcomed.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here ar its recommendations for today; Of course, you'll plan to use up every bit of the Thanksgiving dinner. But on the day after Thanksgiving, it's a good idea to serve something quite different -- makes ths left-overs taste extra-good later.

Preliminary approval of the site plan for a 1,000-family garden apartment center on a tract of 103 acres at Central Avenue and Christfield Street, in Yonkers, has been given by the Federal Housing Administration, according to Arthur Cutler of New York, sponsor of the project.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Tennessee Agricultural and Industrial College today claimed the national Negro football championship by virtue of its 20-to-13 defeat of Kentucky State College of Frankfort, Ky. Tennessee A. and I. was undefeated in ten games this year.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- High Ground Stable's Hefty, who made his racing debut on Aug. 30, proved the top 2-year-old of Maryland's Fall racing season when he won the $10,000 added Endurance Handicap, the East's final juvenile test. Performing before a Thanksgiving Day crowd of 17,181 the colt stuck to his running guns to take a length victory from Belair Stud's Vashti.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 27 (U.P) -- Texas blasted through touchdowns in every period and then sat out a last-ditch counteroffensive today to down Texas A. and M., 32 to 13, before 41,000 spectators and earned a Sugar Bowl invitation which immediately was accepted.

LONDON, Nov. 27 -- Although the Government opposes the abolition of capital punishment at present, the House of Commons will decide the issue by a vote in which Labor members will be free of party discipline, J. Chuter Ede, Home Secretary, told the House today.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, who retired last year after twenty-five years as Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New Tork, was honored yesterday during the Thanksgiving Service at the Cathedral of 'St. John the Divine by the unveiling in his honor of a statue of the cathedral's patron saint.

It was Christmas for two children yesterday. One was 7-yearold Joey Rizzuto 3d of Queens, suffering from acute leukemia, who, doctors say, will die before Christmas. The other was 5-year-old Peggy Bennett of Hilltop, Titusville, N.J., who will be blind in a few weeks.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- St. Louis University, outplayed in every department, were saved from a tie by a wide placement kick on an attempted conversion as they gained a 14-13 victory over Duquesne before 9,272 fans.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Quarterback Otto Graham and the Cleveland Browns, avenging their only defeat of the 1947 All-America Football Conference campaign, packed too many explosives for Los Angeles today and whipped the Dons, 27 -- 17, before 45,009 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

Opposition to the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway is growing in interior sections of the country as a, result of campaigns conducted by anti-seaway, groups, according to Carroll B. Huntress, chairman of the National St. Lawrence Projlect Conference, a national organization fighting the project.
The New York University School of Law issued yesterday its war service brochure recording participation and achievements of the school's students, alumni and faculty in the second World War.

There was no Thanksgiving Day respite for New York University's football team as Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin had his Violet squad run through a light practice session at Ohio Field, in preparation for its traditional game with Fordham tomorrow at the Polo Grounds.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- The expulsion of nineteen Soviet citizens from France for interference in internal politics drew a protest from the Soviet Embassy in Paris today. The embassy demanded explanations and insisted that the persons expelled should be turned over to the Soviet authorities in France.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 27 -- The commission on the projected multilateral agreement of the International Civil Aviation Organization ended its sessions at an early hour this morning alter adopting a report acknowledging failure to achieve its main objective.

Washington, nov. 27 -- On the island of Nevis in the British West Indies, birthplace of Alexander Hamilton, the long-neglected acres of an old and once-famous estate are being cleared and its seventeenth-century plantation house and other buildings remodeled for use as a stateless children's sanctuary, the first in recorded history.

Josefina Megret, Cuban pianist, was heard in her first New York recital last night in Town Hall. Her playing was clean and alert, but blemished by a brash, bony tone, which only became agreeable in softer work, where it was usually submitted to niceties of gradations.

The new "coastal fleet" of the American South African Line -- one former freight and supply vessel and two former LCT's -- has safely negotiated a 3,500-mile crossing of the Atlantic, arriving yesterday at Monrovia, Liberia. This was announced by James A. Farrell Jr., president of the line.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, tonight appealed to educators to provide leadership in a nationwide program of self-education by the people of this country in "the basic facts and the essential meaning of atomic energy," lest democracy perish.

College and university administrators who attempt to prevent forcibly the nation's fraternities from exercising racial and religious restrictions in choosing members are violating the tenets of democracy, David A. Embury, chairman of the National Inter-Fraternity Conference, said yesterday at the conference's thirty-ninth annual convention at the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The text of Robert A. Taft's speech in the Senate today on the interim aid program for Europe follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Three companies filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Monsanto Chemical Company of St. Louis registered 250,000 shares of no par value cumulative preference stock, Series B, $4 dividend, which are to be offered to the public at a price to be fixed by amendment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Senator Robert A. Taft announced to the Senate today his support of the full $597,000,000 authorization for winter relief for France, Italy and Austria. On Wednesday Mr. Taft, chairman of the Republican Policy Committee and candidate for his party's Presidential nomination, voted to slash the amount by $197,000,000 to $400,000,000.

The October volume of mortgage loans executed by the savings and loan associations in this state exceeded all previous records, Zebulon V. Woodward, executive vice president of the New York State Savings and Loan League, announced yesterday.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

New Capital Market Stand-by financing will be prominent in the market for new capital issues next week. Among preferential or exchange offerings scheduled to become effective are 272,694 shares of $20 par value convertible preference stock of the Northern Indiana Public Service Company and 75,000 shares of $100 par value cumulative preferred stock of the Appalachian Electric Power Company, both by syndicates headed by the First Boston Corporation.

After complaints yesterday from the Cianci family of Brooklyn that they had been dropped from relief because they twice refused to give presents to a Welfare Department investigator, John M. Murtagh, Investigation Commissioner impounded records in the case and issued subpoenas for all individuals concerned in it.

Antony Tudor's "Dark Elegies," set to Gustav Mahler's "Kindertotenlieder," had its first presentation of the season in last night's program of the Ballet Theatre at the City Center. It has perhaps been more compellingly performed on some other occasions, but it remains a poignant work, simply and beautifully composed and eminently musical.
There was a heavy volume of business yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, as prices moved upward to new high levels for the season. Net gains for the day were from 50 to 74 points.

Instead of keeping her playing on the consistently high plane of excellence that has come to be expected of her, Erica Morini sometimes lapsed from the best of which she is capable, at her violin recital last night in Carnegie Hall. Even so exceedingly accomplished an artist, like all other public performers can not hope to be in top form invariably.

English chinaware Importers probably will not reduce prices to retailers after Jan. 1 when lower duties under the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act become effective, E.N. Khouri, vice president of Worcester Royal Porcelain Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- James E. Webb, Director of the Budget, announced today that the ceiling for Federal civilian job-holders would be reduced by the equivalent of 106,148 full-time jobs for the three-month period beginning Jan. 1, 1948.

With shoe output tending to outstrip footwear sales by 10 per cent or more, marked attention is now being given retail pairage sales. Estimates in trade quarters yesterday were that shoe production is running at a rate in excess of 460,000,000 pairs, while retail sales are at the 420,000,000-pair level.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 28 -- The major motion picture producers today pursued their announced policy of discharging production personnel who refused to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee whether they were Communists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Opposition to acquisition of further stock in the New York Central by the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad by George Estin of Boston, a director of the Alleghany Corporation and a member of its executive committee and vice chairman of its finance committee, is revealed in correspondence with the Interstate Commerce Commission.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 28 -- Some method satisfactory to all citizens by which the growing domination of the public schools by sectarian religions can be arrested and eliminated should be devised immediately, Mrs. Eugene Meyer, wife of the Washington publisher, said here tonight.

The first serious test of the season for the highly-rated City College basketball team looms tonight as the Beavers clash with a tall, experienced American U. quintet at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

HAVANA, Nov. 28 -- The Dutch administration of Indonesia was charged today at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment with a "discriminatory, monopolistic blockade to strangle the Republic of Indonesia economically" and with responsibility for the natives' low living standards.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- After a four-hour Cabinet meeting tonight, the Government announced that it would submit to Parliament tomorrow a series of measures to deal with the nation-wide strikes. Premier Robert Schuman will address the nation by radio tomorrow night to explain the new measures and the need for them.

One pedestrian was injured and scores of others scampered from danger yesterday when a heavy electric sign crashed the windows of a second-floor Times Square restaurant. A rigging boom snapped while the sign was being lowered from the roof of 1485 Broadway, between Forty-second and Forty-third Streets.

Publication by the Chamber of Commerce of the Borough of Queens of an illustrated folder giving facts and figures about the borough serves to remind us that, for all the overcrowding of our city and the metropolitan area generally, Queens still has ample room to expand its industry, trade, residence and recreation.

Despite the fact that he was dethroned by Stymie as the world's leading money-winning thorough-bred, the Calumet Farm's golden gelding Armed has been voted "horse of the year" in the first of two major polls among turf experts.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The results of two more by-elections, announced today, confirmed the verdict at Gravesend on Wednesday that there has been no swing away from Labor in Britain.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- A message from President Truman commending the activities of Junior Hadassah was heard tonight by nearly 1,000 delegates and guests at a dinner of the annual convention of the Young Women's Zionist Organization.

Tomorrow is the feast of St. Andrew, the patron of Scotland. (He is patron of Russia and of spinsters, too, by the way.) It seems a good time, therefore, to talk about John Duncanson's bakery in Astoria, at 37-03 Thirty-first Avenue.

Random notes. Unseasonal it may be, but some of the late fishing news threatens to crowd the shooting news to one side, for a 37-pound rainbow trout is up in the same bracket as a 400-pound white tail deer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -- Considering the time spent, the results obtained in secondary schools and colleges from the teaching of English composition are poorer than for any other subject, J. Paul Leonard, president of San Francisco State College, told the annual meeting of the National Council of Teachers of English today.

"Orchestras of the Nation," offering a series of concerts by major symphonic groups in the United States and Canada, will return to the NBC network at 3 P.M. Saturdays, beginning Dec. 13. The first program will be provided by the Vancouver Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jacques Singer.

One fireman lost his life, two others were injured critically and two more were believed still to be trapped early today in the ruins of a burning warehouse at 334 East Ninety-eighth Street. Damage to the building was estimated at $500,000.

Selection of the University of Kansas and Georgia Tech to play in Miami's Orange Bowl yesterday rounded out the New Year's Day college football picture as far as the "Big Four" post-season games are concerned, The Associated Press reported.

Prices of the nine-billion-dollar war surplus stocks remaining in War Assets Administration inventories will be adjusted progressively downward until all stocks are sold, Jess Larson, newly appointed acting administrator, revealed here yesterday in his first public statement since appointment.

In time and space, Robert H Davenport Jr. moves in a remarkably compact orbit. This became apparent yesterday as Davenport awaited the action of the grand jury on a charge that he deserted his bride of a few days to commit bigamy one month later around the corner from her home.

Thomas A. O'Hara, a member of the board of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, testified before the Securities and Exchange Commission here yesterday that Leo T. Crowley, who will retire today as chairman and president of Standard Gas, "could have stayed in" but elected to take a contract termination settlement.

Zion-St. Mark's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 339 East Eightyfourth Street, will celebrate its one-hundredth anniversary with a special service tomorrow at 4 P.M. The chief feature will be the reading of a letter of felicitation from President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, indicated today that President Truman's anti-inflation program contemplated a rollback of prices which were out of line. He cited meat, lumber and steel as examples.

Lavern Roach, Plainview, Tex., middleweight, showed promise of developing into a contender for Rocky Graziano's title last night at the St. Nicholas Arena, when he outpointed Herb Kronowitz, Coney Island slugger, in the feature bout of ten rounds.

The toll of the nation's observance of the long Thanksgiving holiday week-end mounted yesterday to 123. Of these, 107 persons were killed in automobile accidents, and most of the others died in hunting accidents and drownings.

The people "can't afford" to lose the "fight" to upset Wednesday's Supreme Court decision invalidating part of the city's eviction control law, Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council and sponsor of the law, declared yesterday.
ANTWERP, Belgium, Nov. 28 -- The fourth international Socialist conference since the war will open here tomorrow with about one hundred delegates and observers from some twenty countries present.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 28 -- Demands by the extreme Rightists that a general election be held here in disregard of the United Nations' decision were characterized today by Maj. Gen. William F. Dean, Military Governor, as "playing into Communist hands."

Through the good offices of Goethe, who wrote the first part of "Faust" nearly a century and a half ago, there is now an opportunity to see the illustrious Albert Bassermann playing the devil in German, and enjoying it, too. As the chief actor in The Players From Abroad company, he appeared in the diminutive theatre at the Barbizon-Plaza last evening.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The Committee on Industry and Materials of the Economic Commission for Europe has established two permanent organizations to deal with steel and manpower respectively, it was announced here today.

Asks Ad Cost Ceiling Paul B. West, president of the Association of National Advertisers, declared yesterday that national advertisers feel that there must be a ceiling on unit costs of advertising and that in some instances it is being rapidly approached if not already surpassed.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -- Negotiations between three of the major oil companies in California and the Oil Workers International Union, CIO, continued here and in San Francisco today in an effort to avert a strike which would disrupt about one-third of the state's refinery production.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28 -- The Government bluntly repudiated today Rolando Lagomarsino, former Secretary of Industry and Commerce, who is in the United States on a special economic mission in connection with which he had farewell audiences with President Juan D. Peron, Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, and Foreign Minister Juan A. Bramuglia.
Fordham and N.Y.U. will clash today in the twenty-fifth game of their metropolitan football rivalry at the Polo Grounds. A crowd of 25,000 is expected.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 28 -- Czechoslovakia's students, who were the first openly to challenge National Socialist totalitarian rule during the occupation, with resulting executions and the closing of the universities, have now become the most outspoken opponents of communism.

St. Petersburg, Fla., Port Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 12 on $15,000,000 of revenue bonds dated Sept. 1, 1947, due on Sept. 1, 1987, and callable on March 1, 1953. Interest must not exceed 3 1/2 per cent.

Younger members of society at home from colleges and schools for the Thanksgiving recess were feted at another round of parties yesterday, the majority of the entertainments being given in compliment to debutantes of the season.

GENEVA, Nov. 28 -- The United Nations Subcommission on Minorities and Discrimination declined today to endorse a Russian proposal to make advocacy of racial or religious discrimination a punishable crime.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- During the week ended Nov. 26, member bank reserve balances increased $53,000,000, the Federal Rserve Board announced today.

The Manufacturers Trust Company has been appointed warrant and subscription agent for the Phillips Petroleum Company's offer to common stockholders of one new share for each five held at $49 a share, expiring Dec. 3.

NANKING, Nov. 28 -- Twenty-five thousand troops commanded by Gen. Fu Tso-yi, who entered Manchuria from North China two months ago, are being pulled back to help defend the Peiping-Tientsin-Pacting triangle against the Communists.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- William Glenvil Hall, Financial Secretary of the Treasury, today told T.C. Skeffington-Lodge, a well-read Labor member of Parliament that he, too, deplored what Mr. Skeffington-Lodge called the "Niagara of piffle and tush" appearing in British magazines but that Britain was bound by Article 9 of the loan agreement with the United States not to discriminate against American products.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Sir Oswald Mosley, pre-war Fascist leader who passed the war years in jail on security grounds, made his first post-war bid for political power today -- but not as a "Fascist."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- With generally higher prices in most of the major commodity groups, average primary market prices rose 0.4 per cent during the week ended Nov. 22, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

On-Stage, that group of players which has been holding forth in Greenwic Village since summer, attempted last night to render T.S. Eliot's verse drama, "The Family Reunion," at the Cherry Lane Theatre. "The Family Reunion" has been produced only on infrequent occasions by college drama clubs and the like, and On-Stage claims credit for giving it its local premiere.

PRAGUE, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Bulgaria and Yugoslavia have agreed to prohibit the United Nations Balkan commission from entering their territories, the semi-official Yugoslav news agency, Tanjug, said today.

TOKYO, Nov. 28 -- Japan's parliamentary troubles over the government's bill for limited state control of coal mines are not over. About one-fifth of the Democratic members of the lower house today were expelled from their party or quit because of their stand on the mine control measure.

Prices of shares on the New York Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday. Final quotations were at or near the low marks for the session and off fractions to 2 points or more. The decline was the widest for the month and it was made in the face of sharply rising prices on most major commodity exchanges.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -- Whittling down the funds propesed under the Marshall plan for aid to Western European countries would be turning a recovery program into "mere relief," the Commonwealth Club was told tonight by Dean Acheson, former Under-Secretary of State.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Committee for the Marshall Plan, of which Henry L. Stimson is national chairman, would be called on to give its position on President Truman's program of economic controls under a proposal today by Representative Clarence Brown, Republican, of Ohio.

The United Nations General Assembly again postponed a vote on the Palestine question yesterday, this time after it appeared that the supporters of partition were assured of the required two-thirds majority. The proposal for a twenty-four-hour recess was approved, 25 to 15, and the Assembly will meet again at Flushing Meadow at 4 P.M. today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- As delegates arrived here to begin discussion tomorrow of the plan of the American Jewish Conference to create a permanent body to act as spokesman on domestic and foreign problems for all Jewry in the United States, a number of recognized agencies which function in the field of defense of Jewish rights made known their objections to the plan.
The index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- After a week of rising prices Orange Free State gold-mining shares underwent a big shake-out in the stock markets here today as speculators at the Cape took their profits before the week-end. With London joining in the selling, prices -- even after a partial rally around midday -- finished with many losses.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 28 -- The decision of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to cease further attempts to deliver relief supplies to Communist areas will result in the closing of the Communist relief liaison offices in Shanghai and Tientsin not later than Dec. 10.

Mayor O'Dwyer inspected yesterday in City Hall Plaza twentynine new motor buses that will be put into operation tomorrow on the Jamaica Avenue line in Queens to replace obsolescent trolley cars. The buses are the first of the 130 new vehicles recently purchased by the Board of Transportation for use in Brooklyn and Queens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A jaunty National, Guardsman drew from President Truman today the announcement that the Chief Executive would ask Congress in January, to enact a measure for universal military training.
Foundry managements are opposed to government allocation of gray iron castings and would rather see free market conditions determine final distribution, leading executives revealed here yesterday.
ROME, Nov. 28 -- Communists and members of other leftist groups seized the Prefecture and other Government offices in Milan early today.

WILTON, Conn., Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- A horse-drawn wagon, carrying twenty teen-age boys and girls on a hayride, was smashed to pieces tonight by an automobile driven by Cass Gilbert Jr., nationally known architect, who worked on the United States Supreme Court Building and other famous buildings.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 28 (U.P.) -- Thousands of Jews flocked to the Wailing Wall today to pray "on this most crucial day in Jewish history" for a favorable United Nations vote on partition of Palestine.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- A French deal, whereby the Soviet Union would receive from Austria most of the $100,000,000 due in redemption obligations, one-third of the Austrian oil production and most of the Danubian shipping as the price for an Austrian peace treaty and the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Austria, was presented to the Foreign Ministers deputies for Austria today.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 -- Wan and thin, but gaily doffing his hat to a crowd cheering from the side-walks, James M. Curley returned to Boston City Hall today to take up the mayoral duties he laid aside last June to serve a Federal jail term for mail fraud.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Felix R. Gerard, 60 years old, of 428 Sheridan Avenue, former president of the Lehigh Valley Railroad, committed suicide today, according to Louis Lombardi, chief of the Union County Prosecutor's detective staff.

Apparently indicating the beginning of a seasonal tapering-off process, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, while still expanding, gained only $18,000,000 last week, the smallest weekly advance since Aug. 20.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I think the privilege of indulging in criticism of the Un-American Activities Committee for its conduct of the inquiry into the growth of communism in the motion picture industry carries with it a corresponding obligation to base such criticism upon the facts and the record in the case.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The announcement by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, of the commencement of an open propaganda, drive against communisin in the "United States zone is of considerable significance in view of the approaching Foreign Ministers' Conference in London later this month.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- More than appears on the surface, the Foreign Ministers Conference revolves around the political storm in France, now epicenter of the "cold war." So far the Big Four discussions are like soundings in a deep sea, taken to feel out the possible shifts in the bedrock positions revealed in Moscow last spring.

WASHINGTON Nov. 28 -- The resumption of sugar marketing quotas next year was made possible today with the issuance by President Truman of a proclamation revoking a wartime order under which quotas were suspended as of April 13, 1942.

Vandals invaded one of the oldest cemeteries in the country Thursday night or early yesterday morning and overturned fifty-four head stones. Thirty-four of overturned stones were broken, according to the police.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Army and Navy meet here tomorrow on the football field in their forty-eighth game and inevitably memory turns back the clock to last year's thrilling race against time.

Everything in the American theatre "is leveled down to the success formula," Gian-Cario Menotti, playwright-composer of "The Medium" and "The Telephone," declared yesterday at the opening session of the National Theatre Conference in the Piccadilly Hotel.

The reactivation of the American Repertory Theatre, a subject of discussion these recent weeks, may be realized sooner than anticipated. Louis J. Singer, the banker-turned-producer and co-sponsor of this season's "Our Lan'," has signed contracts whereby he and ART will present Eva Le Gallienne in "Hedda Gabler."
Realty activity in Manhattan reported yesterday was confined largely to sales of dwellings and small apartment buildings in scattered areas.

The last fourteen top Nazi military men in "United States hands who led the German armies on their bloody march through Europe have now been indicted at Nuremberg. They bring to 134 the total of individual defendants accused in the war trials there of crimes against humanity.

A special meeting of the Queens College faculty was called yesterday for next Thursday to consider the future status of American Youth for Democracy and the possibility that return of the organization to the campus may jeopardize civic support for the institution.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A snow plow to be attached to the bumper of an automobile was patented this week (No. 2,431,410) by Hiram Maxim of Hartford, Conn., as one of 367 inventions for which patents were issued by the United States Patent Office.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Two horsemen today were ruled off Maryland tracks for life for cruelty to the race horse Saguaro.
Nathan Katz, 42-year-old notorious Brownsville hoodlum with reported ambitions to get ahead in his precarious field, faces a gloomy future.
Dr. Abraham Stone, veteran adviser on marital problems, outlined yesterday a set of standards for marriage counselors, whose work, he said, is emerging as a "serious social science and art."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 -- Plans for a ten-year, $100,000 project were announced today by Dr. Abraham A. Neuman, president of the Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate Learning, calling for publication of a new, 30-volume English translation, of the nonbiblical scriptural writings known as the Apocrypha and Pseudepigrapha.

One hundred thousand sets of "Metropolitan Miniatures," poster stamps in color, of paintings and objects of art in the collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, will be mailed within the next few days to persons all over the United States, the museum announced yesterday.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Favorite players who have been doing well at the local meeting went down with a mighty thud today. After Brookmeade Stable's Master Bid had been played into odds-on favoritism, the 4-year-old was forced to lower his colors to E.A. Nicodemus' Laran.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 28 -- The Round Hill Community Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Caroline Lee Marshall, daughter of Hugh Dow Marshall of this place and the late Mrs. Adelaide Porter Marshall, to Charles Wallace Adair Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Adair of Xenia, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Unon of National Labor Relations Board Employes has appealed to the five-member board against the refusal of Robert N. Denham, the NLRB's general counsel, to bargain collectively with it on the posting of vacancies so employes might bid for them Before outsiders are hired.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov fought hard today at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers to block a future separate government for the Western zones of Germany. In so doing he brought this hitherto somnolent conference to hectic life, although the three Western Foreign Ministers Ignored his basic proposal.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Communist-organized strikes that are gradually throttling France's economy have already gravely damaged French revival chances under the European Recovery Program in the opinion of French official sources now in London.
The European recovery program, according to a high government official quoted anonymously in this paper, may result in "definite hardships" for Americans.

An air of tension unparalleled since the day Andrei A. Gromyko walked out of the Security Council during the debate over Iran eighteen months ago pervaded the General Assembly building at Flushing Meadow, Queens, yesterday as the United Nations tried in vain to dispose of the Palestine problem.

Some urbane and gracefully expressed remarks were made to the National Council of Teachers of English, meeting in San Francisco, by Dean Pollock of New York University. What he said is particularly needed by teachers, perhaps, but it has its uses for all of us.

Any major extension of the Department of Commerce's proposed ban on the use of metal containers for coffee, beer, pet foods and oil was viewed yesterday by packaging industry spokesmen as likely to create shortages of alternative materials already in heavy demand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The United States Zones today petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board to reconsider an order of Oct. 20 stripping it of authority to act as passenger agent in Europe for Pan American Airways.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- An Italian-Yugoslav agreement covering trade exchanges for more than $250,000,000 was signed today by Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, and Dr. Mladen Ivekovitch, Yugoslav Minister to Rome.
The National Broadcasting Company has eased its ban of many years standing on mention of the word "diaper" over the facilities of the network, it became known yesterday.

Robert W. Dowling, head of the City Investing Company, has been elected president of the Citizens Budget Commission, Inc. He succeeds William Church Osborn, who has been named honorary president and will continue as a member of the executive committee.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 28 -- Rumanian Government control of the press is tightening. The Liberal, the only remaining opposition newspaper as the organ of the National Liberal party, has not appeared for two days and it is understood that publication has finally been suspended.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Grain, soy bean and lard futures soared on the Board of Trade today to new seasonal high prices on all deliveries except July and September oats. Wheat and corn were up around 25 cents a bushel and oats, 11 cents from the low marks on Nov. 17, when President Truman asked Congress for a return of rationing and price control.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28 -- Dr. J. Calvin MeCracken, 74, returned today aboard the American President liner General M.C. Meigs after forty years as head of St. John's University Medical School in Shanghai. He said the retirement age was 65 and he did "not know what I'll do now."

A plea for the immediate enactment of the Interim Aid Bill and the provision of the full amount of $597,000,000 proposed by the House Foreign Affairs Committee, was forwarded yesterday to leaders of the Senate and House by Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, who is chairman of the executive committee of the Committee for the Marshall Plan to Aid European Recovery.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 28 -- Dr. John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, warned tonight of the challenge of communism and called upon educators to make a more determined and successful effort to create in American youth a zeal for American democracy in the interest of national strength and security.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 22, totaled 902,672 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania sailed at 5 P. M. yesterday from West Fiftieth Street with 932 passengers, among them Dmitri Mariuilsky, one of forty-two United Nations officials on their way home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Several more wartime purchasing officers of the armed forces will be called upon, to explain their relations with contractors who made large profits, members of a House committee indicated today after a long hunt for alleged war frauds.

Reports made at the annual dinner-meeting last night of the Atlantic Class of sloops, held in the New York Yacht Club, included one of a new fleet of the craft on Long Island Sound. It will be centered at Oyster Bay, with such skippers enrolled as Charles F. (Bubbles) Havemeyer, P. James Roosevelt, A. Lee Loomis Jr. and Ward C. Campbell.
Small-scaled bedroom furniture designed to fit into the restricted areas of modern apartments in Sweden have been imported by a New York concern to serve here as juvenile furniture.

ATHENS, Nov. 28 -- A crisis is brewing in Athens, which some have dubbed "the gold crisis" because it centers on the rise in the price of gold sovereigns here, the general rise in prices that appears to have followed and what to do about it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Administrative responsibility for continuance of the conservation programs inaugurated by the Citizens Food Committee was vested today in James A. Stillwell, Special Assistant to the Under-Secretary of State.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- James and William Cagney, and Jack L. Warner, of Warner Brothers Studios, have concluded a deal whereby the actor and his producer brother will make their next two films for Warner distribution.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Nov. 28 -- The Inter-Allied Reparation Agency, which just adjourned its thirteenth session here, made two technical decisions of considerable importance in the field of German external assets held by Allied and neutral countries, an official statement said today.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc, Inspector General of the French armed forces in North Africa and a hero of the Fighting French military effort during the war, was killed this afternoon in the crash of a military plane.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The 1948 production of the four major types of tobacco will drop about 25 per cent below this year if farmers carry out production control programs announced by Secretary of Agriculture Anderson.

Extensions of the Long Island State Parkway System took another step forward yesterday when bids were opened by the State Department of Public Works for paying five miles of the Northern State Parkway Extension from Union Avenue, Westbury, easterly to Plamview Road in Nassau County.

On the eve of his team's important game against the Buffalo Bills at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow, Coach Ray Flaherty of the Yankees heard some heartening news -- his star end, Bruce Alford, will be able to play.

The 16-year-old Sylvia Zaremba, pianist, played last night in Town Hall, and this with extraordinary virtuosity and musical understanding. She opened her program with the great C major organ toccata of Bach-Busoni and closed it -- exclusively of encores -- with a whirlwind performance of Balakireff's "Islamey," which few pianists could have surpassed for fire and bravura.

Exhibiting a devastating running attack complemented by an efficient passing combination, Fordham's freshman football squad overpowered an undermanned New York University yearling group, 33--0, at Fordham Field yesterday.

Steel, though under export controls and one of the limiting factors in American shipbuilding because of short supply in this country, is being exported to shipbuilding countries in sufficient quantity to constitute a form of subsidy to those nations, in the opinion of J. Grenville Mellen, United States Maritime Commissioner.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Boston College, which is celebrating its golden jubilee of football -- there were no teams in the 1903-1907 period -- will tangle with Holy Cross in the forty-fourth renewal of this traditional rivalry tomorrow before a sell-out crowd of 42,500 at Braves Field.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- Following is the official Soviet text of the proposal put before the Council of Foreign Ministers yesterday by Foreign Minister Molotov and, distributed in English today by Tass, Soviet news agency:

The manuscript of a novel about Andrew and Rachel Jackson by A. L. Crabb has been turned over to Bobbs-Merrill. Entitled "Home to the Hermitage," the story deals with the early years of the Jacksons up to the time they go to the White House.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Because of existing admission practices, many worthwhile and highly qualified students are denied entrance to American colleges and universities, educators attending the sixty-first annual convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools charged here today.

Abbott Laboratories A regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents and an extra of 35 cents, both payable Dec. 30, were declared by the Abbott Laboratories. This makes a total of $3.25 for the year, compared with $2.87 1/2 in 1946.

The manuscript of a novel about Andrew and Rachel Jackson by A. L. Crabb has been turned over to Bobbs-Merrill. Entitled "Home to the Hermitage," the story deals with the early years of the Jacksons up to the time they go to the White House.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 28 -- Because of existing admission practices, many worthwhile and highly qualified students are denied entrance to American colleges and universities, educators attending the sixty-first annual convention of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools charged here today.
To THE EDITOR:

John W. Snyder, as Secretary of the Treasury, has rejected the proposals of the Federal Reserve Board to increase requirements for bank reserves. That development, according to banking observers, is the most significant event in the current Congressional efforts to curb the inflationary trend.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Senator Scott W. Lucas, Democrat, of Illinois, took himself out of the Illinois Democratic Governorship race today in an action interpreted as leaving him available for possible nomination as his party's Vice Presidential candidate.

RECENT sculpture by Maria, who was once a concert pianist and is now the wife of the Ambassador from Brazil, is being shown at the Julien Levy Gallery. It is pleasing to report that her former idiom, supposedly inspired by jungle vegetation and which, led to some of the most involved and intricate forms that ever taxed the capacity of the casting industry, has given way to more clearly plastic manifestation.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- The Rice Owls unleashed a furious second-half attack in their final game of the season today to overwhelm the Baylor Bears, 34 to 6, and clinch third place in the 1947 Southwest Conference race.

The body of a second fireman was found yesterday morning in the wreckage of a warehouse at 334 East Ninety-eighth Street, twelve hours after a five-alarm fire had swept through the structure. Earlier another dead fireman had been removed from the debris.

After a two-hour conference with Mayor O'Dwyer at Police Headquarters, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander announced yesterday two further moves in the department's efforts to ease traffic congestion in the city.

RECENT action of the new sovereign state of India in lifting all curbs on the export of pepper was big news in the spice trade. Since India has been the world's leading pepper producer for thirty years, it was felt that a pepper shortage, and consequent rocketing prices, may have been averted.
Jewish groups here received with mixed emotions the adoption yesterday by the United Nations General Assembly of the participation plan for Palestine.

SINCE it is a human tendency to delay a decision as long as possible, it is only natural that bridge players should do so. A bridge player likewise tries to avoid a risky play until the last possible moment. Sometimes this is wise; sometimes it is not.

Bitter Arab delegates walked out of the General Assembly hall at Flushing Meadow last night after the vote for the partition of Palestine and solemnly announced that in their eyes the United Nations had died.

Mayor vs. Nickel New York City this year is operating under the first billion-dollar budget in its history, and next year the budget may be at least $75,000,000 higher. The Democratic city administration is already levying taxes to the limit of its powers, which are regulated by the state.

FOR THIS WEEK: Fill any irregular areas in the lawn with topsoil so that it will settle and be level next spring. . . . Start to prune grapes whenever weather and time permit. . . . For those who live near the shore seaweed is an excellent winter mulch for delphiniums and roses.

PRIZES for camera reportage during 1947 are offered in a competition jointly sponsored by the Encyclopaedia Britannica and the University of Missouri School of Journalism. These organizations have been running separate news photography contests for the past four years.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The annual convention of Junior Hadassah, the young women's Zionist organization of America, at its concluding session today, received from Dr. Chaim Weizmaiin, former president of the World Zionist Organization, a call for young men and women, "who are nurtured in western methods and standards" to "further the building of the (Jewish) state."

In recent lieder programs, Elisabeth Schumann, soprano, has been narrowing the number of her composers. Four years ago she sang only Schubert and Wolf; the year after only Schubert and Strauss. Yesterday afternoon at Town Hall her program was all-Schubert.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 29 (U.P.) -- A Catholic priest, 41 years old, today carried a tiny, 108-year-old Negro woman to safety through blinding clouds of smoke which billowed into her home from a burning warehouse next door.

THIS symposium, if that is what it is, was "originally planned as a new kind of textbook for journalism students." The students will be interested and the book will do them good. But the appeal is far wider. Every working newspaper man, of no matter how long experience, will be interested.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 -- Communal violence, at least on a noteworthy scale, does not now exist in India. Law and order have had the upper hand for some time through Government efforts. But whether communal feeling, as apart from communal action, has abated is another matter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A recommendation, that Congress appropriate $2,000,000 immediately to aid Navajo Indians in New Mexico and Arizona this winter is before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Indian Affairs.

(Author of "A Streetcar Named Desire," opening Wednesday.) SOME time this month I will observe the third anniversary of the Chicago opening of "The Glass Menagerie," an event which terminated one part of my life and began another about as different in all external circumstances as could be well imagined

THE Automobile Club of New receives about 400,000 inquiries a year from motorists who want to know not only about how to go places by car but also about frying pans, romance in Mexico and the effect of climate on growing hair.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 29 -- Georgia Tech's Orange Bowl-bound eleven, expected to present a strong passing attack, failed miserably at it at times but connected on a 13-yard scoring heave for a 7-0 victory over Georgia today.
DYERSBURG, Tenn., Nov. 29 (UP) -- A lanky 15-year-old girl told police today that she killed her grandmother and 14-year-old brother "because I was afraid they would beat me."

THE successful first flight in California last week of the huge Consolidated Vultee XC-99, world's biggest landplane and a transport version of the" Air Force's long-range- B-36 bomber, probably has little or no significance for commercial aviation.

It is the mission of the United Nations to achieve world peace and the General Assembly made memorable contribution in that direction, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, president of the Assembly told the delegates of the fiftyseven member nations yesterday in his speech closing the second regular session in Flushing Meadows.
A marked increase in transatlantic travel on American-fla vessels in the current year is indicated in totals for the firs eleven months made public yester day by the United States Lines.

HOLLYWOOD. THE decision taken by film producers in New York last week to fire or suspend from salary the ten men cited by Congress for contempt in connection with the recent Communist inquiry by the House Un-American Activities Committee in Washington has divided Hollywood into two factions again, after a period of comparative solidarity of opinion against the smearing effects of the inquiry itself.

The Squadron A regulars rattled nine goals off the backboard in the last two chukkers to wallop Essex Troop, 12 to 5, in the main match of the indoor polo double-header at Squadron A Armory last night.

Price policies for 1948, now being shaped by industrial supply and machinery manufacturers, are aimed at expanding major long term markets rather than at temporary profit advantages. The lines include machine tool, factory equipment and process equipment.

The wholesale markets last week were quiet because of the Thanks-giving holiday, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.

THE late afternoon crowd swirled around the corner of the Boulevard de la Madeleine. Everyone was pushing and jostling. The dark, thick-set little man with the large suitcase ran into the little old woman.

Showing amazing vitality, American college fraternities have recovered from the slump they suffered during the war and are now stronger than ever before. Reports from colleges and universities throughout the country indicate that the Greek-letter groups have entered upon an era of unprecedented expansion and campus prestige.
The attention of the entire Arab and Jewish worlds focused on Blushing Meadow yesterday to hear the verdict of the United Nations General Assembly on the future of Palestine.

Emergency control of fluid milk entering the city area will be continued through December, Dr. Charles J. Blanford, administrator of the New York Metropolitan Milk Marketing Area, ruled yesterday. Dr. Blanford, however, reduced from 92 to 84 per cent the amount of fluid milk to be shipped here.

IN the field of domestic humor, "The Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" very handily has gone to the head of the class (6 P.M. Sundays -- CBS). On the air for only a comparatively few Seasons, the program steadily has grown in charm and humor, yet has steadfastly avoided any of the Vaudeville pretentions which, to name just one program, have crept into "Fibber McGee and Molly."

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Grains tumbled today on the Board of Trade, losing about all of yesterday's gains at times. The selling movement stemmed from warnings issued by commission houses, emphasizing the possibility of a temporary setback in view of recent sharp gains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Representative Ralph A. Gamble, Republican, of New York, formally protested today to the Export-Import Bank and Secretary of State George C. Marshall that shipment of pig Iron to Italy is delaying completion of 350,000 American homes.

FORT MYERS, Fla. -- The 1947-48 winter season of Fort Myers started officially last Sunday with the opening to the public of the Thomas Alva Edison home. The property, on elegant McGregor Boulevard, a few blocks from the heart of town, was presented to Fort Myers by the late Mrs. Edison.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Hundreds of telegrams and cables from all parts of the world were pouring into Winston Churchill's London home today congratulating him on the seventy-third birthday which the wartime Prime Minister will celebrate tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Nearly 30 per cent of the affidavit forms submitted to the National Labor Relations Board have been returned to the unions because they were incorrectly executed. Robert N. Denham, general counsel, said a frequent error among local unions was failure to furnish to their members the same financial data required to be filed with the Secretary of Labor.

Verdi's "La Traviata" received its first performance of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The popular work moved along smoothly under the leadership of Giuseppe Antonicelli, who conducted with spirit and adapted tempi that were always well chosen.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The discovery or sound waves which produce such intense heat that they are lethal to mice and small insects was announced today by the Army.

As one phase of an industry program to spur restoration of shipping in the coastal and inter-coastal trades, the National Federation of American Shipping has appealed to Congress to consider reducing Panama Canal tolls.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Twelve hundred persons, mostly children, heard the first of six scheduled concerts by the United Nations Symphony of sixty-six professional instrumentalists this afternoon in the main auditorium of the Westchester County Center here.

Baseball's current off-season, which did not remain any too quiet, while football was still occupying the stage, is about to swing its full winter tempo as the annual December conclaves move on the scene.

IN observance of the hundredth anniversary of the death of Mendelssohn, Columbia has made available a new recording of his oratorio, Elijah. The forces that have collaborated to pay this tribute are largely the same as those that made the recently released recording of "The Messiah," and the result is again a performance which conveys the letter and the spirit of a formidable musical document.

BINGHAM, UTAH. THIN, sunbrowned young Harold Chesler, owner-manager of the Princess Theatre here, rarely dusts the chandeliers in his picture-palace, but the arms on the 436 seats in his mining-town movie house are in need of frequent repair.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- The utter confusion of the strike situation in France arises, first, from completely new tactics adopted by Communist instigators of the movement and, secondly, from the fact that throughout the labor organization the strikers are meeting with a growing opposition against the use of the trade unions as political instruments.

Recent investigations by Drs. Frederick D. Sisler and Claude E. ZoBell at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography of the University of California, reported by them in the current issue of Science (official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science), have revealed that micro-organisms of marine origin, may be capable of decomposing the type of hydrocarbons known to produce cancer in animals.

Retail trade here showed a decline last week that was chiefly due to comparison with the heavy buying last year which followed the end of the trucking and delivery strike. Department store sales were estimated at about 10 per cent lower than in the same week of 1946.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Five players who placed on this year's All-Southeastern Conference squad, two on the first team, were among nineteen named today to perform for the South in the annual Blue-Gray football contest here Dec. 27.

ALBERT SCHWEITZER was born on Jan. 14, 1875, at Kayersberg in Upper Alsace. At the age of 21 he decided what he wanted to do with his life, how and when he should do it, then went ahead and did it. Today, aged 72, he is still doing it.

TOKYO, Nov. 29 -- Japan's new Income tax law, which becomes effective Monday underlines that unless the tax structure here is materially changed it will bar foreign business and foreign intercourse following the peace treaty.

A SERIES of pictures featuring one subject has been, found a useful project by many amateurs who want to combine other hobbies with their photographic activities. An interest in genealogy led Mrs. Katharine Mawhinney, amateur photographer of New Rochelle, to photograph authentic early American doorways.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Congress set aside the troublesome problems of European aid and domestic inflation today and attended the Army-Navy game practically en masse, while pressures for accelerated action on the legislative problems awaited members' return to work Monday.

THERE is an abstract quality, as tenuous as a shade, about this unconventional first novel by the short story writer, Henrietta Weigel, that will discourage best - seller readers even before they get acquainted with the shadowy (though hardly ethereal) heroine.

LONDON. CAROL REED'S position as Britain's currently most-talked-of motion picture director has placed the newspaper and magazine writers on something of a spot. No matter how deeply they probe for an esoteric explanation of his artistic prominence they invariably come up with a success formula so traditional it could just as well apply to a successful brewer.
LONDON, Nov. 29 -- On Dec. 8 Britain will begin her quest for the estimated "missing million" workers reputedly available to man her essential industries.

The Ernie Pyle, an "emergency class" passenger vessel operated by the United States Lines, docked here yesterday morning with 633 passengers. Among them were 522 displaced persons and several German war brides or fiancees of ex-service men.

The steel industry is unanimous in opposing unequivocally either part or total allocations of its products by the Government, prominent steel executives declared in interviews last week after the request of W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, that a Federal agency be accorded limited priority and allocation powers over the distribution of the vital commodity.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The Soviet delegation continued its minute exploration of the French proposals for the disposal of German assets in Austria, but refused to agree in principle today on any of the points in the proposal before the Foreign Ministers deputies for Austria.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 29 -- Indian tribesmen in southeastern Utah, Arizona and New Mexico are faced with semi-starvation this winter. According to Monson missionaries in the inaccessible region, as many as 6,000 Navajo, Piute, Ute and Hopi natives will spend the winter in distressed conditions.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall plans to ask the Council of Foreign Ministers next week to achieve the economic unification of Germany by the removal of all zonal barriers and the subsequent formation of a provisional central German government, it was learned today.

IN the first place, let's hope that nobody is going to pop up today with that old crack which is usually made by Hollywood's champions whenever anyone praises a foreign film-you Know: "We only see their best ones but, brother, you should see their junk!"

GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- The latest but no means the last attempt to catch up with monetary realities in Europe has been devaluation of the Italian lira to the rate of 589 to the dollar. The importance of this move is more apparent than real because Italian currency has long been practically free to find its own level.

WASHINGTON, Nev. 29 -- The mood of Congress appeased to be undergoing a change this week, The anger which was registered within the Senate and House Republican, majorities," on Nov. 17, when President Tranrum recommended unpleasant steps for stopgap European relief, the longrange European Recovery Program, and a halting of price rises at home seemed to have been dulled by examination of the realities.

THE acute theatre shortage today will soon give rise to a boom in theatre construction. Are these new theatres going to be built along the outdated lines of those now housing our Broadway plays -- theatres which were designed originally to suit the needs and fancies of the horse-carriage trade?

THE biggest news along Publisher's Row at the moment concerns the basic model contract just arrived at between the Authors Guild and Random House -- a contract which, if less comprehensive than the one between the Dramatists Guild and Broadway producers, could nevertheless be a significant step in publisher-author relations if other publishers model their contracts on the one just negotiated.

Polyna Stoska, new American soprano, made her debut yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera house in the role of Eva in Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," having been forced to postpone her scheduled opening on Nov. 21. Although the part is not a large one, in quantity of singing, she endowed it with vitality and credibility, and enriched the production with some lovely singing.

A new laboratory for the Air Reduction Company near Summit, N.J., has been completed by the Wigton-Abbott Corporation, engineers and contractors, of Plainfieid. In the same area, these contractors recently converted a former school into a research center for the Celanese Corporation.

NANKING, Nov. 29 -- The Foreign Ministry was noncommittal today on the Soviet reply to China's note on the Japanese peace treaty. It said it would withhold official comment until the United States and Britain replied to Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh's "compromise" proposal on voting procedure.

GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- The United Nations Subcommittee on Discriminations and Minorities voted today over Russian objection to include the right to emigrate and change nationality among the fundamental rights of man.

ROME, Nov. 29 -- Pope Pius XII issued today an encyclical letter in which he urged the Catholic hierarchy to promote more rigid observance of liturgical laws. At the same time he warned against the infiltration of errors which he identified as false mysticism, exaggerated archeologism in liturgy, quietism and naturalism.

LYON, France, Nov. 29 -- Conditions approaching those of a general strike gripped the great industrial city of Lyon today. At least half of the 226,000 workers of the city and vicinity were idle by reason of the walk-out.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- Canvassers founding up signatures for the Independent Progressive party, as the third-party movement in California is known, have obtained some 75,000 signatures. To qualify as a political party in California they need a total of 275,970 signatures by Feb. 26.

SEVERAL weeks ago I mentioned my resolve to write something about the attempt which has been made to prove that Cuttyhunk, off the Massachusetts coast, known in Shakespeare's day as Elizabeth's Island, was the scene of "The Tempest."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Navy disposed today it was putting through its leapfrog paces an entirely new kind of amphibious vehicle, designed to operate at sea, in sand, mud, swamps and quagmires -- in short, just about everywhere except In the air.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 29 -- Warning that universal military training would give the nation a false sense of security, Dr. Edward L. Bortz, president of the American. Medical Association, asserted here today that the basis of a modern defense program was greater training in science.

Modernization of outmoded building codes, elimination of "feather-bedding" and other restrictive labor practices, and easing, of licensing systems for contractors and workers are badly needed to cut construction costs and solve the housing problem, according to the National Association of Manufacturers.

SOME time during the black Nazi night, in Cell 84 on the third floor of the Vienna city jail, a series of scientific demonstrations took place which could have rendered the atomic age obsolete before it was born. That astounding series of demonstrations is the subject of an unusual new book which is either a short novel or a long parable or both.

MR. GEISMAR has arranged five rather heterogeneous American writers in a group portrait, somewhat as a painter might arrange a stuffed Baltimore oriole, a prize-winning gopher, an Archbishop's miter, a horseshoe and a very large diamond

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen today reiterated his expressions of optimism that Russo-American problems could be worked out without war but voiced what he called grave "concern as to the outcome of the policies" Russian leadership had been following recently.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- When the American President Lines' freighter Arcadia Victory left yesterday for the Orient it carried as its first officer a former Middle Western Mayor, bank president and lumber merchant who went to sea at 60 as an ordinary seaman.
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Florida spotted Kansas State a one-point half-time lead and then smeared the Wildcats, 25 -- 7, with three second-half touchdowns today.
To the Music Editor:

THE sartorial splendor affected by Charlie McCarthy, it develops, is the handiwork of Brooks Brothers in New York City. Edgar Bergen stopped in on his recent visit to this city and had the dummy outfitted with three new suits including a mustard yellow dinner jacket.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The united Nations decision for the partition of Palestine was received here without surprise tonight. British officials felt that the postponement of the vote Friday had made partition a certainty, since the delay had permitted the United States to gain time to bring certain Latin American republics into line with its own views.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Junior Thomas broke clear for touchdown romps of 38 and 59 yards in the final period to pull Oklahoma ahead of Oklahoma A M College, 21 -- 13, today in the forty-second renewal of the cross-state football rivalry.

MR. WILLIAM JAY SMITH'S "Poems" is the first volume of his work to be published, and it makes one eager to see what this young and extremely promising poet will produce in the next few years. For this collection gives only tantalizing saggestions of the scope of Mr. Smith's talent.

MADISON, WIS. BY the end of its centennial year Wisconsin will have its story well and widely told. Under the leadership of Professor Robert E. Gard of the University of Wisconsin, the Wisconsin Idea Theatre is cooperating with the state's centennial committee In dramatizing Wisconsin's story for and by its own people.

Gratitude to the United Nations for giving to the Jewish people the opportunity for statehood was expressed by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein in West Side Institutional Synagogue, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday.
DENVER, Nov. 29 -- Quigg Newton, Denver's young Mayor who took office last May with the largest plurality in history, has had a peck of trouble lately, but he has taken it with grace.

In a joint statement issued last night after a meeting at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the Arab delegations to the United Nations assailed the partition vote in the General Assembly as unjust to the Arab states and one that was rendered "under great pressure and duress."

PARIS, Sunday, Nov. 30 -- Premier Robert Schuman refused early today to meet the leaders of the Confederation of Labor to discuss a strike settlement different from that offered by the French Government.

Aid in Congress In Washington last week the atmosphere of the second session of the Eightieth Congress seemed undramatic. In the spectators' galleries on both sides of Capitol Hill there were many empty seats. On the House floor there was little action.

ASA LEVENTHAL is a frightened and lonely man. As his story begins, he holds a modest position in a publishing house, but he is troubled always with thoughts of the past from whence he has come and with fears that he may be thrown back into it.

AGAIN and again, in his Journals and in the three books he has written on the art of the novelist, Francois Mauriac has said such things as this: "Even when I am in a state of grace, the creatures of my imagination are born of my muddied self; they are formed of what remains in me despite myself."

Five days of the Big Four Conference of Foreign. Ministers have produced the expected results, or lack of results-in the words of an Associated Press dispatch, "no sign of agreement on a single major point." There is a note of urgency in the announced meeting of Secretary Marshall and Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov on Monday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 29 -- More than 2,000 jet engines have been produced here for the United States Air Force and for naval aviation. They continue to be produced at a monthly rate which is said to be larger than that of any country in the world.
DUAL purpose rooms have become so commonplace that the living-dining room, the bed-sitting room, and the study-guest room seem almost as conventional today as once upon a time the parlor was.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 29 (AP) -- A remarkable exhibition of passing by Dick Gray and excellent receiving by substitute backs Bob Laidlaw and Don Campbell broke a jinx today as Oregon State racked up a resounding 27-to-6 victory over Nebraska before 20,000 fans.

Marking a gradual but nevertheless perceptible shift in emphasis, the trend toward greater imports is gaining headway in United States foreign trade. The gap between exports and imports is still large, but the possibility of narrowing it appears to be more soundly based than for many years past.

Do remember how you felt of a long life, Harriet Maras a child? Nearing the end tineau looked back to the bewilderment, fears and tempers of her first eight years and wrote, "I must have been an intolerable child, but I need not have been so."

THE general belief that steamship cruises to the West Indies this winter have all been sold out in advance is not true, according to an official of the Cunard White Star Line. An example is the Mauretania's schedule of five fourteen-day cruises to southern waters.
TO THE EDITOR:

EVER since Harnett Kane's excellent account of the Huey Long period, "Louisiana Hayride," he has been turning out books at a journalistic pace, dipping both hands into the barrelfuls of rich material that lie about him in his native State and in the adjoining commonwealth of Mississippi.

WHILE the news from Britain continues to highlight her economic difficulties, a significant cultural movement, financed in part by the Government, is going forward there. This movement may have much to do with the British people's willingness to accept further austerity with the traditional stiff upper lip.

The role of marketing research in cutting production and distribution costs was pictured yesterday by Dr. Vergil Reed, associate director of research for the J. Walter Thompson Company, as secondary to the more urgent problems of guiding business to (1) increase quality and (2) make other than indispensable necessities available to lower income groups.

ANYONE who has seen the hilarious theatrical interlude in "High Button Shoes" known as the "Mack Sennett Ballet" can understand why musicians in the pit of the Century Theatre call it "The Ballet of the Bleeding Lips."

FAR AND NEAR" is Pearl Buck'a third book of short stories, but unlike her former collections, it includes a number of stories devoted to the American scene. The first three stories are set in Japan, the next two in China, and the rest in the American West.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- Appealing for literature to be taught "as literature in English, not as English literature," Prof. Albert Guarard, of Stanford University protested today against the present "woefully haphazard" choice of translated works.

Mayor O'Dwyer urged yesterday support of the 1947 appeal of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for $15,000,000. He warned that failure to reach this goal "could well spell disaster" for the 116 federation affiliated hospitals, health and social welfare institutions and would cause the city to suffer because they make "an enormous contribution to the solution of our social welfare problems."

EVERYBODY has experienced those evenings in which personages discuss world affairs over their highballs, each contributing urbanely his own brand of confusion. Suddenly from across the room comes an indignant voice, badly phrased but talking such good sense that it cuts refreshingly through the stale tobacco smoke.
The strategic importance of Austria to the future of Europe will provide a somber background to the political discussions of that country's fate in London.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Nov 29 -- Eddie C. Oelsner of the home club and John Smith, representing the Seventh Regiment, led the way into the semi-final round of the invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.
ANTWERP, Belgium, Nov. 29 -- The gulf between the Socialists of eastern and western Europe became more than ever apparent at an opening here today of the International Socialist Conference.
LONDON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- King Michael of Rumania delayed his departure for Bucharest for the second time today because of bad flying weather.
DINOSAURS laid eggs about as large as footballs.
