THE late afternoons of Dec. 6 and 13 should be memorable ones for Arturo Toscanini, and still more memorable for the nation-wide audience that will hear him on those dates. For he will then give in two halves from Radio City, Verdi's "Otello," in the premiere of which, in 1886, Toscanini participated as one of the 'cellists in the orchestra.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- All season long Navy has borne the reputation of being what the trade calls "a hard-luck team." It would bob up with a fumble, an interception or some other gridiron misfeasance at the most inopportune time. Apparently they still don't grow four-leaf clovers in the vicinity of Annapolis. Their horses must be unshod, because the middies have no horseshoes, and their rabbits are born without the usual rabbit-foot impedimenta.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 29 -- The Congressional Investigation of leftism in Hollywood, culminating this week in discharges of alleged Communists among production personnel, has thrown the motion-picture industry into a panic, the effects of which will be felt for years.

MR. MANTLE'S invaluable annual -- reflecting, as always, the high-lights as well as the paste-diamond lures of Broadway -- offers but thin fare to the play-reader this year. Obliged to select ten "bests," Mr. Mantle is forced to include considerable shoddy between his covers.

As far as New York was concerned, Cloe Elmo was a sleeper. In the course of his annual press interview last month, Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan, merely said that the mezzo-soprano from Italy was one of fourteen singers to join the company.

HONOLULU, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A 5,000-mile journey from chilly Michigan to summery Hawaii failed to faze Michigan State today, and the Spartans won 58 to 19 from a futile University of Hawaii football team.

Various problems confronting real estate men will be discussed at the convention of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, which opens on Wednesday evening in Atlantic City. With the exception of United States Senator Albert W. Hawkes and Representative Frank L. Sundstrom, speakers at the various sessions will be men who are engaged in one phase or another of the real estate business.

New York's rival professions football teams will have their fins schedule conflict of the season to day. The Yankees of the All America Conference oppose the Buffalo Bills at the Stadium in a contest that may decide Easter divisional honors, while the Giant of the National League meet the colorful Chicago Cardinals at the Polo Grounds.

According to reports reaching New York, Dr. Theodor Romzha, Catholic Bishop of Carpatho-Ukraine, was killed in an automobile accident Nov. 2. Carpatho-Ukraine, formerly a part of Czechoslovakia, is now a part of the Soviet Union.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Foreign. Ministry announced today that Chile might ask the United Nations Security Council or General Assembly to act on the Soviet refusal to permit the Russian-born daughter-in-law of Chilean Ambassador David Cruz Ocampo to leave the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- When Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, told Senate investigators recently about his Government war bond speculations, he did not supply information of special interest to a grand jury. In this indulgence, no evidence that a law was violated has yet appeared.

The action of the United Nations General Assembly in approving separate Jewish and Arab states in Palestine was the occasion last night for a joyful demonstration by thousands who attended a mass meeting in the St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- "I want you to meet our great big fullback," said Army Coach Ear Blaik, placing his hand affectionately on the shoulder of a compact big-muscled youth.

DESPITE resolutions to make and mail their Christmas cards long before the holiday rush, many amateurs are always sure to leave the matter to the last minute. That last minute is just about now, particularly if the mailing list is extensive.

THIS book consists of a prologue, three separate stories -- two of them novella size -- and an epilogue. A character named John Everyman, an air raid warden in the London of 1944, figures largely in the prologue as a man of good-will; after a somewhat contrived discussion (in which various standard political points of view are typically represented) this John Everyman is laid low in an air raid.

For the second successive time, occupancy of commercial space throughout the country has declined slightly, according to the semi-annual rental market survey of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The reported world tanker shortage and a concomitant fuel crisis in the eastern United States appear to be greatly exaggerated, according to studies released by oil authorities last week and an independent survey of fuel-carrying facilities.

History was written yesterday at Lake Success, when the General Assembly of the United Nations approved, without major change, the plan recommended by its special committee for the partition of Palestine. Under this plan two independent states, one Arab and the other Jewish, linked together in an economic union, will be established after the termination of the British mandate.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- To go along with all the other elements that make the Army-Navy game football's most colorful spectacle, there was an altogether new wrinkle today. President Truman, most distinguished of the 101,500 onlookers at the big service academy show in Municipal Stadium, flipped the coin for the choice of goals prior to the start of the contest.

WHEN a ground cover is wanted under trees, on banks hard to keep in grass, or in any place where a carpeting plant is appropriate, most gardeners use pachysandra, vinca or English ivy. They are good looking and dependable, but if something a little out of the ordinary is preferred, a wide variety of attractive ground covers can be found.

THE movie makers last week made decisions that also made news. There was Hollywood's statement of policy in regard to the employment of Communists and changes made and offered in two films banned by the National Legion of Decency.

The United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday proposal to partition Palestine into two states, one Arab and the other Jewish, that are to become fully independent by Oct. 1. The vote was 33 to 13 with ten abstentions and one delegation, the Siamese, absent.

BALLET THEATRE will present its final novelty of the season on Tuesday evening when it opens its third week it the City Center. This is Jerome Robbins' "Summer Day," created o music of Prokofieff for an American-Soviet Musical Society Benefit last May.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The armed services are preparing to turn over to President Truman at his request the records of 28,000 wartime Army officers who have been retired for disability on taxfree pay normally amounting to three-fourths of their active service remuneration.

IT is the contention of the veteran detective novelist Dorothy L. Sayers that a woman is "just as much an ordinary human being as a man, with the same individual preferences, and with just as much right to the tastes and preferences of an individual."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors was named today to confer with the Atomic Energy Commission on making available to the American people information on the development of atomic energy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- A call for immediate creation of a coordinating agency to represent Jews in the United States on all domestic and foreign problems was made tonight by speakers at a mass meeting held under the auspices of the American Jewish Conference in the Chicago Civic Opera House.

Robert F. Loree, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council, in appealing yesterday for industry support for the United Hospital Fund, emphasized the important, position of the voluntary hospital in the community and in medicine.

UPKEEP -- Before World War II, the Department of Agriculture estimated that it cost a farmer about $2 a year to support a rat on a farm. The department now estimates that, what with the high price of corn and other factors, a rat's annual upkeep has mounted to $4.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The American Education Fellowship unanimously adopted at its national conference here today a policy claiming the support of educators for "two great constructive purposes," the determination of basic policy by the will of the majority, and establishment of a world authority empowered to override national sovereignties in issues affecting peace and security.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A service unique in the history of the Washington Cathedral will be held here tomorrow under the sponsorship of the four colleges belonging to the Protestant Episcopal Church. Student representatives, officials, and alumni of the institutions wm march in the procession, wearing their academic regalia.

The Battle of the Bronx was fought to a stalemate yesterday at the Polo Grounds, where Fordham and N.Y.U., natural and traditional rivals, struggled to a 13 -- 13 deadlock. On comparative records and according to form, N.Y.U. figured to win, but the Violets were lucky to tie.

ignoring a flood of favorable announcements of earnings and dividends, the stock market last week drifted lower in dull trading. Traders were more concerned with the outcome of Congressional action on European aid and inflation controls than they were with the immediate good corporate news.

INDUSTRIAL production is now probably running above the post-war peak. The former high was made last March at 190 on the Federal Reserve Board index. Last week the Board reported that the October level of its index was 189 and it has undoubtedly moved up over the intervening period.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 29 -- Government delegates from six nations of the Middle East have taken the first step toward introducing in their countries the standards laid down by the International Labor Organization.

TRAVELERS who have trouble getting passage, hotel space, visas and passports, can look enviously upon United Nations personnel and the ease with which they flit across oceans and continents. Behind the simplified comings and goings of U.N. delegates and officials is a "travel agency" the private tourist cannot call upon.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Without benefit of Doc Blanchard and Junior Davis, Army again scored 21 points on Navy, as a year ago, and won the battle of the service academies today for the fourth successive time.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Unbeaten all-England put on a dazzling display today defeating the first southeast team, 6 -- 0, in the Women's National Field Hockey tournament at the Philadelphia Cricket Club. The invaders registered their seventeenth victory and 200th goal of their tour.

Only 6 per cent of "the top-ranking senior high school students in the New York and New Jersey area intend to enter the teaching profession, according to a survey recently completed by the Metropolitan School Study Council, a research affiliate of Teachers College, Columbia University.

Mrs. Louis Cianci of 2516 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, was questioned yesterday by Deputy Commissioner James H. Sheils at the Department of Investigation, 50 Pine Street. Mrs. Cianci had said she and her husband and two small children were dropped from relief after refusing demands for gifts by a Welfare Department investigator.

DR. OPPENHEIMER -- Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced-Study, Princeton, N.J., who directed the Los Alamos Laboratory, where the atomic bomb was developed, delivered the second annual Arthur Dehon Little Memorial Lecture last week at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in which he outlined some of the problems physicists are working' on today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Some, at least, of the Republican opposition to President Truman's anti-inflation program has been based on the assertion that the President already has a substantial budget of economic control powers in his hands but that he has failed to exercise them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg said today he favored administration of the Marshall plan, for European recovery by an independent agency, linked only to the State Department at the policy-making level.

TOKYO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Premier Tetsu Katayama, a Social Democrat, won a tacit vote of confidence by a narrow 50-vote margin in the House of Representatives today during the first test of strength with his increasingly influential Conservative opponents.

READERS of "Men Out of Asia" -- which won honorable mention in the $10,000 Whittlesey House Fellowship Contest for scientific books written for the layman -- will find a lively and entertaining -- if even seriously misleading -- tract on the peopling of the American continents in pre-Columbian times and on the origin of their cultures.

IT is an unfailing puzzle to the working members of the press, and to the genuine alumni, why so many otherwise solid lawyers, dental appliance mechanics, casket designers, motion picture executives and scooter salesmen should feel a compulsion to aver, upon meeting a reporter, "You know, I used to be a newspaper man myself, once."

"ESCAPE" is a word as easy to misuse as to use, yet it is almost inevitable in any consideration of the novels of Jeffrey Farnol. His first novel, "The Broad Highway," Kindled in this reviewer the mad desire to buy a blackthorn stick and some time to walk from London to the Scottish border because, forsooth, nowhere but in England were the inns so conveniently spaced and the ale so nut-brown.

More than one hundred football stars representing twenty-five leading universities and colleges throughout the country ran through an off-schedule appearance last night as special guests at the Winter Ball given in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

PUBLIC opinion must learn to be impressed by the composer's integrity." The words are those of Ernst Krenek, who came from Los Angeles to hear the Philharmonic - Symphony under Dimitri Mitropoulos play the first performance of his Fourth Symphony last Thursday, spoken as he took time off to chat about musical life in America.

IN an age of determined specialization in football even the fans have their specialists. Perhaps the most individual of these is Louis Henry Baker, M.D., football's self-appointed historian and fact-finder. Coaches and sports writers do not hesitate to turn to him for information, for Dr. Baker has built a boy's enthusiasm for a game into a reputation as one of the gridiron's greatest authorities.

Rare first editions, autographs and manuscripts, incunabula, Americana and other fine literary property belonging to Miss Edith Eyre of New York and other owners will be auctioned tomorrow evening and Tuesday afternoon at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The tumult and shouting that greeted Mayor James Michael Curley's return to Boston City Hall the morning after Thanksgiving was vocal evidence that he still was a hero in the eyes of those who four times had elected him to that office, once to the Governorship and thrice to the United States House of Representatives.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Following is a summary of the major decisions taken by the United Nations General Assembly during its second regular session, which convened on Sept. 16:

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 29 -- The development of world-minded American citizens must take priority over all other needs and must be the common concern of social studies teachers, Dr. W. Linwood Chase of Boston University, retiring president of the National Council for Social Studies, declared today.

The Binding Element GOD is the binding element in the world. The consciousness which is individual in us is universal in Him; the love which is partial in us is all-embracing in Him. Apart from Him there could be no world, because there could be no adjustment of individuality.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 29 -- Emmet Lavery's new comedy, "The Gentleman From Athens," was presented for the first time on any stage last night at the Playhouse before a blue ribbon audience which included officials of the du Pont Company and other Delaware corporations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Stirred by the plight of the Navajo Indians in New Mexico and Arizona, the American Friends Service Committee is mobilizing its resources to provide them with shoes, clothing and other assistance until plans for a long-range "rehabilitation" project are worked out.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- -- The first-round scramble for football cup honors began among English soccer teams today with Notts County and its expensive star, Tommy Lawton, surprised by the opening strength of Horsham. However, the amateurs finally went down, 9 -- 1, before the professionals.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Prevaricator, the favorite, led from wire to wire at Bay Meadows today to win the $10,000 added Alameda Handicap by three-quarters of a length from Happy Issue. Time for the mile and one-sixteenth was 1:42 4-5, four-fifths of a second slower than the track record.

EVERGLADES, Fla. -- This tiny fishing and truck-farming community on the southwest coast of Florida will find itself holding the nation's spotlight next Saturday when it will be the dedication site for the nation's twenty-eighth national park.
TO THE EDITOR:

Storewide activity was heightened last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Coat departments continued active, blouse departments excellent, hat bars very busy and housewares very good, the report stated.

MOST of us don't know anything about Chile, and a living novel about the country could help a lot. It could show us Chileans from the inside out, the way we want to see them. From the looks of things, an American will have trouble doing this job.

A one more indication of the general upheaval that is under way in the field of the ballet, S. Hurok has relinquished his tenure of the pre-opera and post-opera seasons at the Metropolitan Opera, House, where for the past twelve years he has reigned as chief ballet impresario.
JERUSALEM, Sunday, Nov. 30 -- The decision of the General Assembly of the United Nations in favor of partition of Palestine was announced here by radio early this morning.

DESPITE an unusually mad autumn which finds roses blooming in the garden much later than is normal, the alert gardener will make ready for cold weather by taking steps for protection of his roses. The very fact that we are experiencing a delayed winter will tend to shorten the time in which this chore can be properly done.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The magazine Party Life reported today that the Communist parties in Italy and China were the largest outside the Soviet Union. The membership was placed at more than 2,000,000 for each of those countries.

STARKVILLE, Miss., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Charley' Conerly reached the climax of his brilliant football season today with a superb performance which gave the University of Mississippi a 33-to-14 victory over Mississippi State -- and the Rebels' first undisputed Southeastern Conference championship.
The writer of the following letter is an American diplomat who prefers to remain anonymous.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Alabama's Sugar Bowl bound Crimson Tide, in a delayed action assault, swept over the scrappy "University of Miami Hurricanes, 21 to 6, in the Orange Bowl stadium tonight in the regular season finale for both teams.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned reactionary yesterday, and with heavy trading ended the day 10 to 57 points net lower.

SHANGHAI, Nov. 29 -- Chinese reaction here to United States Congressional proposals to include $60,000,000 for China in the European assistance appropriations has been similar to the response that greeted the recent estimates of Secretary of State Marshall on a China aid program.

AT the present time American industry is producing 10 per cent more goods and services than the Brookings Institution recently estimated it would be able to produce by 1950 and about 2.5 per cent more than the careful estimates of capacity in 1950 made by the Twentieth Century Fund.

In the course of its consideration of new tax legislation affecting cooperative business organizations, the Ways and Means Committee of the House of Representatives is, of course, vitally interested in the amount of business done by such associations as an indication of the volume of business which partly or wholly escapes the income tax. Current Government statistics on this subject are not available.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 29 -- A corner to the Elihu Root Room of Langdell Hall, Harvard Law School, was dedicated today to the memory of Lieut. Col. Guidi Pantaleoni, an alumnus, who was killed in action in Sicily.

Foreign venders of American-made light machine tools are marketing them at price levels in some cases more than 300 per cent above the prices of the same tools here, machine tool distributors here revealed yesterday. They cited the case of a standard 529.50 power-driven jigsaw quoted in Havana, Cuba, at $105 without the electric motor.

The schools, press, radio, theatre and motion pictures, all are important factors in influencing public opinion, senior high school students decided yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

BARNEGAT, N.J., Nov. 29 -- A day's duck shooting on Barnegat with one of the old-baymen is a memorable event, even though you don't get a shot; but the old-timer would consider it a personal affront if a few ducks didn't pass within range.

OMAHA, Nov. 29 -- Many farmers, now in the high-finance class, are withholding grain from market until after Jan. 1 because of income taxes. It is necessary to add, however, that the trend does not appear to be seriously hampering the Government's buying program for foreign relief.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- Chicago's ix daily newspapers appeared this week in a new typographical dress produced by girl typists instead of composing room employes.

THE night of May 3, 1939, was charged with dramatic import for the city of Chungking, the wartime capital of China. For on that night began the Japanese air raids during which Chungking transformed itself into a center of resistance and courage.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 29 -- Southern Methodist stormed back with only twenty seconds to play today to tie Texas Christian, 19-19, in one of the thrillers of South-west Conference history.

THIS novel, dealing with early settlers, frontier people, their encounters with the Indians, their conquest of the wilderness and other Americana, is by a Viennese author who previously has written in German. It also attempts to imbue the traditional covered-wagon theme with a deep significance, to make it a story of angels, saints, the Devil and man's fall into disobedience -- an undertaking to tax a much more experienced writer than John Kafka.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The finest assortment of backs in years and an oversupply of outstanding centers dot The Associated Press' all-star Big Six Conference football teams for 1947.

Theatre, parties at current Broadway productions continue as a popular means of raising funds to further philanthropic enterprises. Greenwich House will be the beneficiary of the performance of Katharine Cornell's production of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra" on the night of Dec. 11 at the Martin Beck Theatre.
After an irregularly lower opening, prices of shares steadied in the brief session yesterday in the Stock Exchange and final quotations were irregular, with changes either way mostly small.

JOHN CHRISTIE, who established the Glyndebourne Opera Festival on his Sussex estate in 1934 and helped to found the International Festival at Edinburgh last summer, has just completed his first visit to this country. He spent fifteen days here making contacts, looking for orchestras and individual artists for next year's festival at Edinburgh and examining sites where Americans could establish an opera festival similar to the one at Glyndebourne.

The thirty-sixth annual meeting and convention of the American Association of Port Authorities will open at West Palm Beach, Fla., on Wednesday and continue through Saturday, with five important panel discussions scheduled.

Sunday, Nov. 30, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 4:27 P.M. and, continuing discussion of Palestine problem, heard representative of Lebanon present Arab League's plan for federated state of Palestine instead of proposed partition.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 29 (UP) -- The first major upset of the Fair Grounds' 1947 season was scored today when Ekard, M.E. Reizen's 3-year-old colt, the longest shot in the field of four, led all the way to win the featured Waveland Purse.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Public hearings will begin on Tuesday to consider proposed revisions in regulations governing so-called "white collar" employe exemptions under the Fair Labor Standards Act.

Fifteen debutantes of the season were formally presented to society last night at dinners given by their parents in the Oval Robin of the Ritz-Carlton in conjunction with the annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball, held in the main ballroom suite of the hotel.
Following is the text of the address of Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, President of the United Nations General Assembly, at the closing meeting at Flushing Meadow yesterday.
The humanity in the heart of a young Marine who went into battle and was killed inspired a unique gift this year to THE NEW YORK TIMES Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 29 -- A King Ranch cast-off who a couple of months ago had run with a $15,000 claiming tag on him took the twenty-fifth edition of the $20,000 added Bryan and O'Hara Memorial Handicap at Bowie today as the major Eastern racing season ended.

IT is easy to find Christmas gifts for gardeners. They include everything from seeds to trees, from hand trowels to fully equipped home greenhouses, from necessities like garden gloves and watering cans to ornaments like statues and sundials.

RONNE ANTARCTIC RESEARCH EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Nov. 22 (Delayed) -- My flight force and I returned to this Palmer Island base tonight, having successfully completed the Filchner Ice Shelf mapping flights from the advance base on the Weddell Sea coast at Cape Keeler.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 29 -- With every available plane alerted at air bases throughout Europe, only three were reported able to get off the ground today in a search for a United States Air Force C-47 missing since last night with twenty-one persons aboard, Air Force headquarters at Wiesbaden reported.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 29 (AP) -- The University of Maryland's bowl fever was quieted a little today as it met its match in North Carolina State, which battled the Terrapins to a scoreless tie before 14,500 in Byrd Stadium.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- The meetings of the Council of Foreign Ministers have been running so true to pattern that experienced observers, including newspaper men, have reached the point where they are willing to tell anyone in advance just what is going to happen.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : The reference to "Talleyrand and America," in the Topics of the Times column in one of your recent issues brought to mind several striking points of resemblance, with, reservations, of course, between those early pages of American history and some current difficulties.

In addition to expanding operations in the rental housing field, the life insurance companies of the United States doubled their investment in income-producing real estate outside of the housing field during the first nine months of 1947, the Institute of Life Insurance reported yesterday.

THE woman entered Brian Kimberley's compartment when the Bombay Mail halted briefly in the night to permit the passage of the Lahore Express. She avoided conversation, but out of the hot Indian darkness she sang for him the haunting melody of "Mouchandolin."

Veterans are signing leases and preparing to move their families Into the sixteen modern apartments in the former boarded-up building at 170 East 107th Street, the first tenement house in the city to be rehabililtated under the veterans' emergency housing program of the state, Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, announced yesterday.

"THE ECHOING GREEN" is an acute, sustained study -- a portrait in emotions -- of the joys, despairs and hopes of a very young girl growing up. Here is the sure probing of the mind and personality of the awakening adolescent -- the recapturing, in its fierce intensity, of the humiliations and ecstasies of youth.

SEVEN years ago during a trip to the Gulf of California (the same which provided materials for his "Sea of Cortez"), John Steinbeck heard a Mexican folk tale about a pearl as big as a gull's egg and the woe it worked in the lives of those who found it.

HENRY MILLER, one-time Paris expatriate, vieux-terrible of long standing, and author of "Tropic of Cancer," returned to the country of his birth, the United States, as World War II began to make its appearance on the face of Europe.

THE fact that sugar is unrationed for the first winter since 1942 should inspire the cook to try her hand again at home-made candies. Probably few fields of culinary endeavor give results more spontaneously applauded by family and friends.

THE road to normalcy is one that has been traveled successfully by an overwhelming majority of returning veterans. Though the percentage is small, there are still many thousands who are having both psychological and emotional adjustment problems.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- After the tempestuous session of the General Assembly, the hopes of many supporters of the United Nations centered on the Little Assembly, which is to carry over between now and the meeting of the next Assembly in Europe on Sept. 21, 1948.
On a fifty-five-acre tract overlooking the site of the World's Fair of 1939, the country's largest veterans' cooperative apartment community soon will begin to take form, it became known last night.

The National Inter-Fraternity Conference, representing more than one million persons in the United States and Canada, voted unanimously yesterday to set up a special committee to consider the problem, of forming enough fraternities to accommodate the needs of college students of all races, creed and colors.

An upsurge of community service activities and aid to veterans during the last fiscal year highlighted the annual report of the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, which, was made public last night. The chapter will observe on Tuesday its forty-second anniversary as the Brooklyn sub-division of the American Red Cross, making it the first formal Red Cross organization established in this city.

HAVANA, Nov. 29 -- C.H. Bhabha, delegation chief for India, warned the United Nations Trade and Employment Conference today that the "considerable misgivings" of undeveloped countries toward the draft charter of the proposed International Trade Organization were "genuine and cannot be disregarded."

SEVERAL days before retiring as Postmaster General last week Robert E. Hannegan announced he had approved for issuance in 1948 two stamps -- one honoring Frances Scott Key (1779-1843), author of "The Star-Spangled Banner," and another commemorating the centenary of discovery of gold near Coloma in California.

VANDERBILT -- Brazilian Studies A special summer school dealing with Brazilian studies is scheduled for Vanderbilt University next season. The school will be of six weeks' duration and will be open to undergraduate and graduate students.

TORONTO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into second place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating Montreal's Canadiens, 3 -- 1, before 14,574 fans. The decision evened the score between Canada's only two big league clubs this season, with two victories each.

An increasing number of business organizations are adopting "bottom-up management" or "up-the-line communications" on an, informal as well as formal basis as part of the steady growth of management decentralization, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association, revealed in an interview last week.

A long the shows current this week several have a distinctly international tone and are almost exclusively devoted to exploring the avenues of abstract, plastic experimentation opened by Cezanne and the cubists.

With the return of the element of competition in consumer goods merchandising, the Incidence of fraud has again become a factor for credit men to watch, it was pointed out last week. Dishonest debtors had all but disappeared during the war and immediate post-war periods, credit men said, chiefly because they had found that black market operations offered more lucrative fields.

TORONTO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs moved into second place in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating Montreal's Canadiens, 3 -- 1, before 14,574 fans. The decision evened the score between Canada's only two big league clubs this season, with two victories each.

New methods for making gasoline and Diesel oils from natural gas are among major chemical developments aimed at improving the fuel supply which will be revealed at the twenty-first exposition of Chemical Industries opening tomorrow and continuing to Dec. 6 at Grand Central Palace, Charles F. Roth, manager of the International Exposition Company, disclosed here yesterday.

THE occasion was an impromptu school lecture in Connecticut years ago during Miss Stein's last visit to America. She was to speak extempore on "How Writing Is Written," and I had planted a veritable battery of stenographers in the audience, for she had given us permission to print her speech.
OTTAWA, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Eastern Canada's inland shipping season is nearly over, but lake and river ports can look back on a boom year of near-record proportions.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Nov. 29 -- One year ago Monday afternoon, Miss Paula Weldon, 18-year-old Bennington College sophomore from Stamford, Conn., told her friends she was going on a "long walk." She has never returned.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 -- The Government Has for eight months blocked the entry into Argentina of four boxes of United Nations literature and color posters consigned to the Argentine United Nations Association, it was learned today.

Peacetime England is faced with a critical "battle of the family," with domestic life in that country "threatened as never before" by a breakdown, in marriage and sexual behavior, Dr. David Mace, director of the British Marriage Guidance Council, said here yesterday.

Alaska's canneries have completed the most valuable salmon pack in the territory's history -- by a dollars and cents yardstick-and some of the experts attribute part of the rich take to the Japanese invasion of the Aleutians in 1942.

The general trend of business in November is up, according to 46 per cent of the purchasing agents who reported to the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The report revealed a marked change of trend, compared with "June, low point of the year when only 6 per cent reported increases," with the figure for November said to be "the highest number so far this year."

More than one-fourth of the nation's cities anticipate "extensive" construction of new industrial and commercial buildings during the coming year to keep pace with business needs, according to figures compiled by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

THIS is the last day of the month and along with tomorrow's bills comes the usual slump in the theatre. Or at least that's the way it's always been, and ticket brokers and box-office treasurers regard the period between Thanksgiving and Christmas as the time when they catch up on their courtesy and heal their ulcers.

Labor Victory In the House of Commons the Labor party has 399 seats to the Conservatives' 189 -- a majority large enough to guarantee passage of any Government measure. Nevertheless a by-election victory in a single parliamentary district last week got almost as much attention as a national poll.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Arthur D. Hill, a counsel for Sacco and Vanzetti, a prominent Boston lawyer and one-time District Attorney, died today in Port Chester, N.Y., at the age of 78.

JO DAVIDSON'S first retrospective exhibition opened this week at the Academy Gallery under sponsorship of the National Institute of Arts and Letters and the American Academy of Arts and Letters. The show, devoted generally to conventionally realistic portraiture of public personalities, covers thirty years of his work and lists more than 175 pieces in plaster, polychrome terra cotta, bronze, pewter, marble and stone.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 29 -- Jewish leaders, struggling with, the enormous task of preparing to build a new state from scratch, accuse the British not only of indifference to their problems but complete unwillingness to cooperate.

NEDRA TYRE must have listened to many a life story since she became a social worker down South in 1939. She must have listened patiently and understandingly and have remembered what she heard. Because she has reported in "Red Wine First" twenty-five monologues -- by persons on relief or old-age pensions or somehow connected with those who are -- that are, on the whole, remarkably convincing, in language, content and psychology.

Last week there were examples of contrasting tactics on two fronts of the world struggle: on the labor front and the diplomatic front in the two key areas of Europe-France and Italy.

This is the season of year when American Power Boat Association moguls unlimber their adding machines, get out their slide rules and after a great hub-bub they come up with some tentative and approximate totals of the season's regattas.

OTTAWA, Nov. 29 -- Since the conscription crisis of 1944 the Liberal Government of Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King has not had to face so much criticism from its own supporters or throughout the country as Has arisen to consequence of the dollar conservation policy announced last week simultaneously with the Geneva trade treaties.

Nef, chairman of the University's Committee on Social Thought. As in the case of so many products of the St. Johns-Chicago school, the value of some parts much exceeds the value of the whole.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 29 -- Miss Barbara Pease of Larchmont and the Boulder Brook Club became the first qualifier for the 1948 National Horse Show Good Hands riding championship when she won in a field of sixteen as the seventeenth annual Boulder Brook indoor fixture opened today.

PARIS, Nov. 29 -- Lewis M. Neikrug of New York, European director of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society (HIAS) and four other officials of the organization have been arrested and jailed on charges of illegal trafficking in United States, Swiss and French, currencies, the Paris police announced today.

THE first post-war shipment of British Ensign cameras has been, received at Dowling's, Inc., 570 Fifth Avenue. Four models are announced, the Commando, the Autorange, the Selfix and the Ful-Vue. All take 120 rollfflm.

WHILE the Broadway managers are yielding to the fates with melancholy resignation, Maurice Schwartz keeps his Yiddish Art Theatre intact in Second Avenue. Since 1918 the Yiddish Art Theatre has continued to stand for something worth respecting.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday it had applied to the State Public Service Commission for permission to increase the maximum charge for gas from $1.15 a thousand cubic feet to $2 with declining rates after the first thousand.

FORCING plants from the garden for flowering indoors in late winter or earliest spring is a possibility for the indoor gardener. It is not, however, so certain a process that ail results can be forecast as a probability. Having a small greenhouse would make these much more than the dreams they sometimes turn out to be in the house.

THE nine former troopships operated by Moore-McCormack lines on an emergency basis to fill the gap in transatlantic shipping are giving thousands of Americans a new kind of sea trip to Europe. The vessels, which are expected to continue on this run at least through next June, provide low-cost transportation and a new kind of shipboard camaraderie, which seems to be liked by 1947 travelers, judging from the demand for next summer's crossings.

ARCTIC lands, as well as most other fearsome and misunderstood places, one begins to suspect, are less cruel than cruel and ignorant man himself may be as he walks over the earth," the Helmericks write in the early pages of "We Live in the Arctic."

More than 700 investment bankers from all parts of the nation are expected to register beginning today for the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association of America to be held this week in the Hollywood Beach Hotel, Hollywood, Fla. Special trains that left this city yesterday carried about 350 investment men from this area and New England.

What intimidation besets the millions when their favorite fiction model arrives between boards?

With, every sign pointing to the fact that all of the programs will be staged before capacity crowds, the fourteenth season of intercollegiate basketball at Madison Square Garden gets under way this week. The scarcity of tickets for contests at the Eighth Avenue arena is cited but fans have become accustomed to this situation in recent years.

QUIETLY, but determinedly, seventeen nations have been struggling for more than a year over the creation of a new basis for world trade. Their efforts have now culminated in the all-important draft charter for an International Trade Organization which was to be presented to a conference of more than sixty nations at Havana, starting Nov. 21.

ROME, Nov. 29 -- The United States Army Department today ordered Maj. Gen. Lawrence Jaynes, commanding the Mediterranean Theatre of Operations, and his entire staff to postpone their departure from Italy. With them will remain about 2,500 officers and men who are leading specialists of the United States Army in Italy.

WASHINGTON. OMAR NELSON BRADLEY has bossed two monumental jobs, one in war, the other in peace. The President has just given him another, in some ways the most difficult one of all -- General Bradley is to command the Army.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Another chapter in the unpredictable football series between Holy Cross and Boston College ended today with the Crusaders registering a 20-to-6 triumph before a sellout crowd of 42,000 at Braves Field.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 29 (U.P.) --The North Carolina Tarheels climaxed a successful season today by trouncing the Virginia Cavaliers, 40 to 7, with a powerful and versatile, offensive. The victory marked the seventh straight triumph for the Tarheels after losing to Texas and Wake Forest earlier in the season.

Depth of capable, experienced players, one of the stronger points of the City College Basketball Squad, paid off with a victory for the Beavers in their first official game of the season at the Sixtyninth Regiment Armory last night. Battling tooth and nail with American University before 4,926 spectators, City suddenly turned the tight contest into a decisive 66-57 triumph with Coach Nat Holman's insertion of a fresh five-man unit six minutes before the end.

The American Society of Mechanical Engineers Medal for 1947 will be presented to Paul W. Kiefer of this city at an "honors night dinner" to Be held next Wednesday during the annual meeting of the society in Atlantic City, it was announced yesterday at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29 -- Tennessee's Volunteers roared from behind today to mark up their third major upset in as many games by defeating their traditional foe, Vanderbilt, 12 to 7, in a game featuring snappy passes and savage line play.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Commissioner Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson of the Big Nine is investigating reported laxities of athletic policy at several Conference schools and will read the law to athletic directors on the subject at the league's winter meeting here, Dec. 11-13.
The longest vacation Joe Louis has enjoyed from boxing, save for the years he served in the Army conies to an end Friday night in Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Florida's 170-day racing season opens Monday at Gulfstream Park, 14 miles north of Miami, with horsemen threatening "drastic action" unless there is an increase in the minimum purses from $2,000 to $2,500.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A ten-point "middle ground" program for Germany, between the extremes of coercion and of standing aside in the hope that she will turn to democracy, was urged by Rabbi James G. Heller of Cincinnati. His report to Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall was issued by the Army Department today.

Family music-making is rarely fit for public consumption, but the Times Hall debut of Rolf Persinger, violist, assisted by the piano and violin playing of his father, Louis Persinger, was a delightful event. Not that the performing was flawless, but there wag an air of solid musicianship strong enough to cover most deficiencies.

Between major assaults the Weather Man cranks his sky-churn and whips up a froth of light dry snow. Then he calls for a moderate breeze, turns the churn upside down and the snow drops casually and unhurriedly on meadows and woodlands. The countryman claims one can tell when the little snows are coming.

Lewis G. Sherman, formerly of C.M. DeLand, has formed the Sherman Woolen Corporation, at 450 Seventh Avenue, to distribute fabrics of, leading woolen mills catering to the women's and children's wear, sportswear and men's and boys' clothing trade.

There is a good deal of oversimplification involved in saying that this country or that country has succeeded in achieving a substantial measure of recovery because it elected to pursue such and such a course; it is an even greater oversimplification, perhaps, to assert that country "B" would have fared better had it chosen to follow the same pattern as country "A."

A force of fifty patrolmen and eight motorcycle police will begin at 8 o'clock this morning to issue warnings to motorists in the newly restricted downtown parking area. Four hundred signs have been posted on stanchions and an additional 700 have been pasted on walls and on electric-light poles calling attention to the restricted area.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 30 -- Maurice Sugar, left-wing chief counsel of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, for the last decade, was fired today by the international executive board under the personal domination of Walter P. Reuther.

The day has come when love for the church must take the form of the passion Jesus had for it, the Rev. Dr. Frederick R. Knubel, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, said yesterday in a sermon celebrating the centenary of the Zion-St. Mark's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 339 East Eighty-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Delegates from sixty-two major organizations and communities in the United States unanimously voted this evening to accept the recommendations of the American Jewish Conference and establish a permanent agency to act as spokesman for all Jews in America on domestic and foreign problems.

MANILA, Nov. 30 -- Col. Robert McCormick, Chicago Tribune publisher, who is touring the Orient, lambasted the United States delegation to the conference of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in a press interview here today.

Customs and immigration 'authorities have rejected as impractical the examination of passengers and .their baggage at sea during liner voyages, according to officials of the departments here. A proposal to send Immigration and customs examiners back and forth on the Atlantic has been studied for months in an effort to expedite clearance of passengers despite a shortage of personnel.

Man becomes nothing more than a "cog in a machine" when he forgets God, the Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan, Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday at the morning service of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Limited country offerings of cash corn, lack of hedging sales of consequence and what is said to be a fairly liberal holding of futures by processing interests against future requirements of the actual grain helped the upturn in corn futures last week on the Board of Trade.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Seven Syrians were Killed in a student-Communist clash over the partition of Palestine today after an enraged mob stoned the United States and French legations and hauled down the American flag.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Current shortages of fuel oil, certain to be followed by a gasoline drought next spring, stem from a "terrific demand" on the domestic market that exceeds anything ever known in the peacetime history of the country, a high Government official said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A complete price-wage freeze was proposed today by Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, as the best method of meeting the rising cost of living.

Blanche Thebom, Metropolitan mezzo-soprano, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Since her debut in the same auditorium four years ago, Miss Thebom had not been heard in this city outside of the opera house, where she has made an enviable name for herself.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- As if French and Italian crises did not provide a sufficiently disagreeable contrapuntal theme to the slow movement of the Foreign Ministers Council session here, United States diplomats here have been worried by nervous reports of a gathering crisis in Austria

The Canadian free dollar dominated trading in the foreign exchange market last week, as it slipped to 88.50 cents, lowest since December, 1943. Pound sterling presented a firm undertone, fractional gains featuring the spot and "forward" positions. Swiss free francs also showed a modest gain. Minor size variations also occurred in the Belgian, Argentine and Peruvian documents.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A world bill of rights, calling for such things as "a decent living," social security and freedom of information for everyone, was proposed on behalf of the United States today by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt.

With colder weather and the pending holidays to spur consumer buying, retail volume last week went into high gear, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
ROME, Nov. 30 -- Three Communist Partisan brigades marched past Luigi Longo, member of the Communist directorate in charge of armed 'organizations, for three and a half hours in Genoa this morning.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Violence and strikes today marked the first vengeful actions by Arabs.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The outstanding feature of the first week's sessions of the Foreign Ministers is Mr. Molotov's consistent appeal to German nationalist sentiment. The longest speeches at this conference are made, as usual, by the Soviet delegate, and the theme of these speeches is a demand for the formation of a central government for all of Germany as a preliminary step to a peace treaty.

Many lines of hardware, supplies and light equipment originally valued at $1,600,000; a number of lots of new and scrap metals which cost $2,274,000, and industrial equipment and machine tools costing $688,000 are among offerings announced over the week-end by the regional office of the War Assets Administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The United States' production rate by New Year's may be around $235,000,000,000 annually in terms of dollar totals -- a record never closely approached before and a 15 per cent gain over last year.
Cleveland and New York, principals in the first championship play-off of the infant All-America Football Conference last year, will play the same roles here at the Stadium on Dec. 14.

The Morgan Library's exhibition, "The Bible," from its famous collection of ancient and modern scripture manuscripts, opens today. With a display of modern French and American painting at the Knoedler Gallery, donated by artists and dealers for auction on Dec. 9 to benefit the United Hospital Fund, it highlights another crowded week of local art events.

Eighty-four records, including five that break world standards, made during the past year will be put before the Amateur Athletic Union when that body meets for its fifty-ninth annual convention at Omaha, Neb., this week, it was announced yesterday.

Tidings From the Harbor Lately a budget of news has come to this pilot house from the Harbor. There's the matter of radar versus our nineteenth -century navigation laws; the case of the nautical junkmen; and, of course, the threatened Battle of Newark Bay, which promised high drama but turned out to be pure farce with legal trimmings.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- State Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, announced today that he would introduce a bill in the Legislature in January which would authorize the Port of New York Authority to construct and maintain or lease parking garages in New York City, including a 2,000-car structure proposed in connection with plans for a new Madison Square Garden at Columbus Circle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Overwhelming passage by the Senate of the bill to authorize $597,000,000 for immediate emergency assistance to France, Italy and Austria is expected this week, possibly by tomorrow night.

Monday, Dec. 1, 1947. MEETINGS TODAY Trusteeship Council Meets in full session at 11 A.M. and again at 3 P.M. (Open). Economic and Social Council Subcommission on Economic Development meets at 11 A.M. and again at 3 P.M. (Open).
SEATTLE, Nov. 30 -- An Alaska Airlines DC-4 with twenty-eight persons on board hurtled off a runway at the Seattle-Tacoma Airport this afternoon and crashed into a car, bringing death to six persons.

OTTAWA, Nov. 30 -- Canada's effort to increase gold production and improve her dollar situation will need much more than the inducement of $7 per fine ounce for extra production to be effective, a delegation of mining operators told Reconstruction Minister C.D. Howe during a two-day meeting which has Just been completed here.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 30 -- The story of the execution in Germany by the Gestapo of American-born Mildred Fish Harnack and her German husband, an economist and underground leader, has just been published in The Wisconsin Alumnus, official publication of the University of Wisconsin, from which Mrs. Harnack was graduated in 1925.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a dispatch published on Nov. 23 your Tokyo correspondent, Lindesay Parrott, reports that "Japanese politicians of moderate outlook today are attempting quietly to ascertain if United States opinion now supports the new union of conservative parties, which, it is asserted, might serve as a stabilizing force in Asia for several years to come."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Joe Muha scored one touchdown and set up another with a booming quick kick as the Philadelphia Eagles beat the Pittsburgh Steelers, 21 -- 0, today and took undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Division of the National Football League.
Three landlord applications for eviction certificates are being denied for every two that are granted by the City Rent Commission, it was disclosed yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Despite the loss of Center Milt Schmidt and defense man, Murray Henderson, early in the third period, the Boston Bruins battled the Toronto Maple Leafs to a scoreless tie in their National Hockey League game before 13,900 fans tonight in the Boston Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- The bull movement in grains, soy beans and lard continued last week on the Board of Trade, all deliveries advancing to new seasonal peaks except for July and September oats. December wheat at the top sold at $3.20 1/4 a bushel, or within 4 3/4 cents of the record established on May 11, 1917.

WHEN the brigade of midshipmen marched into Philadelphia's sprawling Municipal Stadium on Saturday the Annapolis contingent was precision personified. There was not a flaw in the orderly array. On a given signal the white caps were doffed. Suddenly there was a horrified gasp of consternation from the Navy Well-wishers in the huge gathering of 101,500.
An old school building in Queens, remodeled into a modern apartment house, will be opened today for occupancy by veterans of World War II and their families.
The end of a college football season that has undoubtedly broken all records for revenue once again finds Notre Dame sharing in the top honors.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 -- The 6,103-ton United States Lines freighter, American Leader left here this afternoon for New York, carrying 208 carloads of grain and milled flour brought here by a section of the Friendship Train.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Green Bay Packers, paced by the bull-like rushes of Fullback Ted Fritsch, bounced back for four touchdowns in the second half today to smother the Los Angeles Rams under a 30-10 score in a National Football League game.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The breach between the Soviet Union and France is widening, and it may well be questioned whether it will be possible soon for the two countries to maintain normal diplomatic relations.

Abba Hushi, chairman of the Histadrut (Jewish Labor Federation) delegation from Palestine, proposed yesterday that the United Nations and this country make available arms and equipment for the Jewish forces in Palestine in lieu of an international police force to preserve peace and order.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Pointing to "the essential godlessness of many of our secular schools and colleges and in many of the other areas of our national life," the Very Rev. Robert McC. Hatch, dean of the Cathedral Church of St. John, in Wilmington, Del., praised the record today of the four colleges belonging to the Protestant Episcopal Church.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 30 -- There was little change in demand for steel products last week. Most steel consumers were clamoring for more material. Most of this pressure was aggravated by the fact that quotas had been cut for the last two months of this year.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- A grave conflict over the future of the Ruhr has arisen in the United States delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Reconversion work has been started on three of the four vessels that American Export Lanes will put into operation next summer, resuming its pre-war "Four Aces" service between New York and Mediterranean ports, it was made known yesterday.

Opposition to a proposal for organic union of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church was voiced yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton, pastor of the Flatbush-Tompkins Congregational Church, Dorchester Road and East Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn.

BILLINGS, Mont., Nov. 30 -- There were 3,500 American products listed for tariff reduction in a State Department announcement Nov. 17, but Western wool growers, members of Congress and Chamber of Commerce officials had eyes for only one -- wool.

Advocating a political education program for American youth to bring persons of integrity, intelligence and responsibility into politics, Dr. Homer P. Rainey, president of Stephens College, Columbia, Mo., charged yesterday that this country's political leadership was at a low ebb and in the hands of "submerged intellects."

Until Celeste Holm threw off the shackles of obscurity to create the role of Ado Annie in "Oklahoma!" on March 31, 1943, she was just another actress wondering when her great chance would ever come. Seizing the long-sought opportunity, her characterization was as piquant as it was refreshing.
A new twist to a Biblical quotation was discovered last week-end by the Auster family of 437 Crown Street in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. They met a stranger and she "took" them in.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- An offer to make any wage agreement with the International Typographical Union, AFL, retroactive to Oct. 21 has been withdrawn by the Chicago newspapers as a result of the week-old strike by the union.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- Governor Dewey's fiscal advisers revealed today that the appropriation in the 1948-49 state budget to reimburse localities for social welfare costs would approximate $169,700,000, an increase of $54,200,000 over this $115,000,000 item in the current budget.

ZURICH, Nov. 30 -- Shareholders of the Compania Hispanoamericana de Electricidad (CHADE) voted overwhelmingly at a general meeting held in Luxembourg on Nov. 17, when 62 per cent of the share capital was represented, to resuscitate the Societe d'Electricite (SODEC) and transfer all assets of CHADE from Madrid to SODEC in Luxembourg.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The New York Rangers won their fourth straight National Hockey League game tonight and thereby extended their margin over the last-place Black Hawks by defeating them, 6 to 2, before 16,792 fans.

OTTAWA, Nov. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Relaxing of export restrictions on Eastern Canadian timber to allow the free sale of 290,000,000 feet of softwood on the world market in 1948 was announced tonight by Canadian Reconstruction Minister C.D. Howe.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 -- Star of David flags and banners fluttered from windows and staffs throughout Jerusalem today as thousands of jubilant Jews jammed the streets singing and dancing in celebration of what they called the realization of a dream that was 2,000 years old. This was "Liberation Day" and even British soldiers joined in the rejoicing.

William Edlin, editor in chief of The Day, Jewish daily newspaper with editorial offices at 183 East Broadway, died yesterday afternoon of a heart attack in his home at 200 West 108th Street. His age was 69. He had been ill several weeks ago and on Saturday worked long hours preparing an editorial on the partition of Palestine after the vote of the United Nations General Assembly approving it.

PRAGUE, Nov. 30 -- President Eduard Benes' policy of the middle way seems for the moment to have triumphed in Czechoslovakia. The lack of significant events in the past few days is generally regarded as an important development.

Edward E. Rhatigan, ousted as Commissioner of Welfare last Oct. 24 by Mayor O'Dwyer, is scheduled to appear tomorrow as a witness at the hearing of the State Board of Social Welfare inquiry into relief administration in the city, it was learned yesterday.

[From Late Editions of Yesterday's Times.] History was written at Lake Success when the General Assembly of the United Nations approved, without major change, the plan recommended by its special committee for the partition of Palestine. Under this plan two independent states, one Arab and the other Jewish, linked together in an economic union, will be established after the termination of the British mandate.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in November was the smallest since September and the dullest for a corresponding month since 1942.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The first week of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers has ended in frustration but at least it is now very clear that the Russians do not want a break with the Western powers.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Threat of a strike that might cancel Tuesday's program hung over Gulfstream Park today amid plans for tomorrow's winter season opening.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- R.D. Gillmor's Towie annexed the conformation hunter championship as the seventeenth annual fall horse show at the Boulder Brook Club came to an end tonight.
Albert Weinert, sculptor, died Saturday night in his studio-home at 1125 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, after a brief illness. His age was 84.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: One partial solution to the problem described by Jules Backman in his letter to THE TIMES was reviewed at the Constituent Meeting of the Council of Profit Sharing Industries in Cleveland on Oct. 17, 1947, when representatives of management and labor met with technicians to evolve certain basic principles of profit-sharing.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- With sharpshooter Boley Dancewicz overshadowing the famed Sammy Baugh, the Boston Yanks completed their National Football League home season by topping the Washington Redskins, 27 -- 24, today before a chilled crowd of 24,800 at Fenway Park.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 16 -- Part of India's interest in Kashmir, the northwestern Princely State and famous natural wonderland where Indian Army troops have been fighting invading tribesmen, lies in the understanding here that the state has a common frontier with the Soviet Union for a few miles.

Difficulty on the part of silk weavers to obtain yarn-throwing facilities has proved to be a formidable obstacle in silk cloth production, according to weavers last week. This factor coupled with the relatively high price of Japanese raw silk has been instrumental in reducing the output of the fabric to its lowest point since the end of the war.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared, ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: A one-dish specialty for busy Monday teams a homespun trio -- sausage links, sweet potatoes and apples -- all three timely conservation choices, and all brought together in a sausage casserole that bakes while you work or wait.

The National Association of Wool Manufacturers yesterday termed the recent cut in United States tariff rates "the most flagrant misuse of delegated Congressional authority ever witnessed in this country."

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A tentative agreement between two shipping companies and the West Coast Masters, Mates and Pilots (AFL) today averted a threatened midnight strike which would have affected some seventy tankers.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The unsettlement in the market for Government stocks is almost completely dominating the financial markets at present, although there are other factors in plenty to keep the markets on tenterhooks.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- "Featured For June," an unproduced play by Eileen Tighe and Graeme Lorimer, which Warner Brothers recently acquired from Paramount, has been scheduled as Bette Davis' next vehicle, after "Winter Meeting," Warners has announced.
Patrons of 1,100 Manhattan taverns may have to mix their own drinks soon as a result of a strike vote taken yesterday by 1,500 unionized bartenders.

The Atlantic air lanes are becoming an ever more populous highway for international travel. Air passenger traffic across this ocean increased more than 19 per cent in the first six months of this year, according to figures recently made public by the Air Transport Association, with a total of 80,108 passengers entering or leaving New York in the first half of this year.

Detroit Red Wings played a briskchecking, hard-hitting 1-all tie with the Montreal Canadians tonight and maintained their halfgame lead over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National League hockey race.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 30 -- Edward E. Rhatigan, who resigned last month as New York City Commissioner of Welfare, is under consideration for the post of Deputy Chief of the United States Military Government's Public Welfare Branch, it was learned here today.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The few British newspapers that have commented on the Palestine decision do so without great enthusiasm. They foresee danger and difficulty in its execution.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts and Chicago Rockets, battling for the cellar "championship" of the All-America football conference, put on a thriller today with the Colts emerging 14-7 winner.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- After a parliamentary battle lasting thirtythree hours, with the Communists resisting at every point, the National Assembly passed tonight that part of Premier Robert Schuman's strike measure authorizing the mobilization for police use of 80,000 military reservists.

The United Nations General Assembly was not intended to be an instrument of world government. Yet the record of its third meeting (actually the second part of its second session) indicates that it is growing in importance. In his concluding address Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, the presiding officer, was obliged to admit that "recrimination marred, at times, the debate."

The National Administrative Council of the Zionist Organization of America, comprising all Zionist groups in this country, will hold an extraordinary conference at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Saturday night and Sunday, Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (U.P.) -- Senator Taft of Ohio said today that he liked the idea of combining income tax cuts and general tax revisions in a "single package" for enactment early next year.

REBECCA WEST'S first book in seven years, "The Meaning of Treason,"* is a subtle and intricate study of the psychology of England's most notorious traitors. Miss West has brought to it the alert, trained observation of a good court reporter and the sensitive imagination of a creative writer. The result is not simple or easy reading, but it is interesting.

Despite a dull market which has had but two 1,000,000-share days since the increased commission rates went into effect on the New York Stock Exchange on Nov. 3, Wall Street is very optimistic about the investing public's acceptance of the higher scales.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30 -- The Metropolitan Church Federation, of St. Louis will ask nearly 300 member Protestant churches in St. Louis and St. Louis County tomorrow to end racial segregation in religious services, institutions and activities.

Thanksgiving is hardly over when housewives are asked to turn their attention to poultry again, this time to the more mature and less tender chickens known as fowl in this section of the country and stewing hens in other areas. According to strict market terms, fowl must be more than a year old and weigh at least three pounds.

TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- Painstaking statisticians of Tokyo's city government are attempting to discover how the Japanese woman lives now that she has been emancipated, at least in theory, by directives of the Allied occupation forces.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Nov. 30 -- After surviving four crises, each of which threatened to wreck the International Socialist Conference, a 1,200-word resolutioa recommending unity was adopted here today Toy Socialists of eighteen countries.

Joyous paeans of victory echoed through the Giant dressing room for the first time this season yesterday. Steve Owen's hard-luck team, beaten seven times and tied twice in National Football League competition, engineered one of the big upsets of the campaign by toppling the high-ranking Chicago Cardinals, 35 to 31, in a wild-andwooly fracas at the Polo Grounds.

The latest draft of the bill to increase transit fares that Mayor O'Dwyer plans to submit to the 1948 Legislature would give the Board of Transportation exclusive power to alter the rate on the cityowned lines. It would make mandatory, however, a referendum on any increase that would reduce or eliminate the debt service deficit on city bonds issued for transit purposes.

Representatives of Actors Equity and the Stage Managers Association addressed the final session of the annual meeting of the National Theatre Conference yesterday at the Hotel Piccadilly and offered their cooperation in helping professionalize university and community theatres.

Grace Castagnetta, pianist, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. Her program consisted of Bach's "Italian Concerto"; Brahms' "Variations on an Original Theme," Op. 21; Mozart's Sonata in D major (K. 311), twelve preludes by Chopin, Ravel's "Gaspard de la Nuit" and a group of improvisations on themes suggested by the audience.

Conflicting trends were shown in the new investment market in November. Flotations of new issues of stock were the largest since July, while bond offerings fell to the smallest total since August, 1946. Both classes of securities were off from November, 1946.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 30 -- The decision by the General Assembly to partition Palestine is generally recognized as a turning point in the history of the United Nations. If the Assembly's resolution brings about a workable solution, the prestige of the United Nations will be greatly increased.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The phenomenal and now unseasonal fall in the Bank of England's note circulation continues and is causing much speculation and comment in financial quarters. Instead of the usual pre-Christmas expansion, there was a further decline last week of nearly u8,000,000, which makes a total drop, since the holiday peak of last August, of u81,000,000, against a fall of only u25,000,000 in the same period last year.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov 30 -- One hundred and forty-four players began play here this afternoon for the open individual contract bridge championship of the United States, the first event in a national tournament that will extend through next Sunday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The undefeated All-England field hockey team completed its eighteen -game tour of the United States today with an 8-0 victory over the All-America team at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

His dampened spirits yearning for his North Carolina home, Edward Robinson, 20 years old, of 227 West 145th Street, decided early yesterday to drive southward in an empty bus parked outside the New York City Omnibus Corporation's garage at 146th Street and Lenox Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- President Truman will face in the next month a decision whether to recommend that the Congress pile on the other necessary domestic and foreign commitments a vast fiveyear program of expenditures to assure the United States of military security in the air.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Baseball opened its winter meetings today, three days before the national association convention starts, with a series of preliminary sessions designed to clarify the Pacific Coast League's gloomy big league ambitions.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 -- In a violent Arab retort to the United Nations decision on Palestine seven Jews were killed by Arab ambushes in Palestine today. Five were slain in an attack on one bus and one in an assault on another bus.

BLOOMPIELD, N.J., Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Paterson Panthers captured the Eastern Division crown of the American Football League today by defeating the Bloomfield Cardinals, 14 -- 13, with Steve Nemeth tossing passes for both the victors' tallies and booting both extra points.

The Stanley's management, which is capable of a change of pace, having switched from serious Russian to a comic French film recently, is continuing to change pace by reverting to Russian fare. The switch this time, however, is double-barreled for "The Winner," which arrived at that house on Saturday, not only is Russian but projects as much Soviet ideology as a Hollywood musical.

The colorful mass of the Exposition of the Blessed Sacrament was celebrated yesterday morning at St. Patrick's Cathedral to mark the opening of the annual Forty Hours Devotion services. Cardinal Spellman presided at the mass.

Kenneth Spencer, American basso, has come up in the musical world. He began at Cafe Society Uptown. Then came a Town Hall debut in 1941, a couple of motion pictures, further study, the part of Joe in last year's revival of "Show Boat," an appearance with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, and last night his first Carnegie Hall recital.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 30 -- The treatment of foreign holders of shares of the Royal Dutch Company continues to form a topic of discussion. It has resulted in sharp questions by a member of the upper chamber to Finance Minister Pieter Lieftinck regarding the influence of the measures in New York and the influence on Amsterdam's position as a financial center.

TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- Negotiations for a British-American loan to finance Japan's foreign trade are still proceeding slowly. Banking interests and General Headquarters are trying to persuade the Far Eastern commission to clarify the terms of the agreement under which it would permit Gen. Douglas MacArthur to pledge the Bank of Japan's gold as security for a self-liquidating loan.

BERLIN, Nov. 30 -- The rebirth of the Jewish nation was solemnly celebrated in the displaced persons camps of Berlin today. It was considered a good omen among these oldest victims of Nazi persecution that the occasion almost coincides with Hanukkah, or the Feast of Lights, which commemorates the last time, two thousand years ago, that the Jews were an independent nation.

Export Ad Increase Expected The opening up of new foreign markets for United States products and the end effects of the Marshall plan are viewed by representative export advertising men as factors likely to increase the amount of this advertising in 1948, both in American and foreign media.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The experience of ten years has removed administrative considerations as a barrier to bringing into the Federal Social Security System 19,000,000 farm, domestic arid other workers not now covered, a research group in the Treasury Department reported today.

If the cold war had not effectively replaced the shooting war, Armand Salacrou's "Nights of Wrath" might have a more exact meaning in the theatre. Translated from "Les Nuits de la Colere" by Maria Ley-Piscator and John McGrew, it relives some of the physical and spiritual tortures of the French underground resistance in 1944, and draws a scornful line between those who risked their lives and those who tried to preserve a safe private neutrality.

Cotton prices in the domestic market advanced sharply in active trading last week. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 67 to 124 points for the week. All active months made new high marks for the season.

Week-end novelties in the repertory of the Ballet Theatre at the City Center consisted of the first performance this season of "Pas de Quatre" on Saturday evening, the first of "Apollo" last night, and a guest appearance by Harold Lang in the role he originated in "Fancy Free," also last night.

With a resoluteness displayed by few French Governments in the last few decades, the new Cabinet of Premier Sehuman has taken up the RussoCommunist challenge flung down to the French Republic, as to the whole Western world, and is mobilizing both the political and military forces of the country to crush what amounts to an attempted insurrection by a small minority acting in the service of an alien Power.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Princeton University, confronted with a choice between the two members of what Charlie Caldwell called "one of the greatest defensive combinations in modern Princeton gridiron history," split its highest football honor -- the Poe Cup -- between Quarterback Richard T. West of Washington, D. C., and Center Francis J. Perantoni of Raritan, at its annual football dinner tonight.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 1 -- The Premiers and Foreign Ministers of seven Arab states will meet here about Dec. 12 to take steps for combating the United Nations decision for a partition of Palestine, the Secretary General of the Arab League announced tonight.
