A United Press dispatch said a League meeting had been called for Saturday.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Nov. 10 I read the dispatch of your special correspondent in Istanbul, on conditions in Turkey today. Encouraged by your policy to supply your readers with reliable information, I am writing you to correct and clarify certain of your correspondent's points.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 -- Leopold J. Wolf, one of the nation's earliest developers of the now virtually extinct interurban trolley system, died today at the age of 91.

NANKING, Dec. 1 -- A China-Burma border dispute involving 75,000 square miles of North Burma territory will be taken up with the Rangoon Government after Burma attains independence from Britain in January.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Conversion of the Panama Canal into a sea-level waterway at a cost of $2,482,000,000 was recommended to Congress today as a means of meeting the threat of atomic bomb attack.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Nervous, but able to laugh afterward, Mrs. Mildred Lamarre told her story today to a Federal grand jury inquiring into the case of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers. She was in the grand jury room for more than an hour and, the district attorney's office said, might return tomorrow.

MONTREAL, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Two Los Angeles sportsmen, Stanley Murphy and William Vaughan, conferred with President Clarence Campbell of the National Hockey League here today and discussed the possibility of the West Coast city obtaining a franchise in the N.H.L.

As usual, the tittle Orchestra Society gave a program of various orchestral pieces either unknown or infrequently performed at its concert last night in Town Hall. It is to be added, however, that not all of the music provided unfailing entertainment, and the society must take care to maintain the level of its first programs and its earlier performances of the season if its succeeding concerts are not to become anti-climactic.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- Western European, nations standing to benefit from the Marshall plan should stabilize their overvalued currencies at true worth if possible even before the plan or any part of it goes into effect, Edward Hopkinson Jr. asserted here today in a speech keynoting the thirty-sixth annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association.

Following losses in six out of the last seven sessions, the stocfc market recovered hesitantly yesterday with steel shares leading the advance. After the opening, the trading pace slackened appreciably and the turnover for the day was the smallest in a week, at 800,000 shares, compared with 930,000 on last Friday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Grain markets fluctuated in an uncertain manner today, with scattered liquidatton developing in the December deliveries. Corn had a range of around 5 cents, breaking early only to rally later, with May selling at a new seasonal high.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 -- American women and children may be advised to leave Palestine, it was learned tonight. There is no emergency at the moment, but a crystallization of anti-American feeling throughout the Middle East indicates the advisability of such a move.
The steady decline in United States exports in recent months is causing concern in some sections of the shipping industry, operators here said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Dec. 1 -- Premier Stalin, in response to a personal appeal from Czechoslovakia's Communist Premier, Klement Gottwald, has sent a telegraph message that the Soviet Union will double its promised deliveries of wheat and rye to this country, according to an official announcement issued tonight.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 1 -- The United Nations Human Rights Commission met this morning and immediately adjourned because neither the chairman, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, nor the delegates from Britain, the Ukraine, the Philippines, White Russia and several other members had arrived because of bad flying weather.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Administration declined today, primarily on the ground that "public interest" would be damaged, willingly to disclose to Congress the details of past and prospective shipments of certain goods to the Soviet Union by private American business interests.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards told the Federal District Court here today that its commission rates are designed only to protect the public against profiteering.

STEVE OWEN wore a gray suit and a grin which spread from ear to ear. Judging from the way the other coaches shook his hand and pounded his back yesterday, a passerby would think that the well-upholstered Giant mentor had just won a championship instead of his first victory of the year. It's indicative, perhaps, of the tremendous esteem and affection they have for him.

The golden touch that has made the Stork Club internationally famous extended to the club's efforts to keep its kitchen help from joining an American Federation of Labor union, according to testimony presented by an ex-dishwasher at a State Labor Relations Board hearing yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Governor Dewey, already hard-pressed to keep the new state budget below $800,000,000, announced today that he was impelled by the impact of rising living costs upon state employes to propose a temporary salary increase for them.

Difficulties that have hindered the Broadway revival of Marc Blitzstein's "The Cradle Will Rock" may be resolved within several days. The New Theatre, which has been preparing a production of the play with music for a series of performances at the Hudson Guild Theatre starting Dec. 20, and Mr. Blitzstein are reported to be working out an agreement, that might prove of advantage to both.

Plans for a four-story garage at 216-224 West Fifty-eighth Street at an estimated cost of $300,000 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. The Normandie Development Corporation of 4 East Forty-sixth Street is the owner.

Surgical operations upon children should be postponed until age three or older whenever possible and frightening hospital experiences should be kept to a minimum, Dr. David M. Levy, assistant Professor of Psychiatry, Columbia University, counsels.
Congress should provide funds to "magnify" the State Department's Voice of America broadcasts to foreign lands, James F. O'Neil, commander of the American Legion, declared yesterday.

Traffic was speeded around the City Hall area, with a fifty per cent decrease in parking, the police reported yesterday as new restrictions in lower Manhattan went into effect at 8 A. M. At 6 P. M. 1,540 warnings had been issued to trucks and cars packed in the restricted area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A five-year downward trend in education has been reversed, according to a progress report issued today by the Citizens Federal Committee on Education through the United States Office of Education.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Counsel for the Standard Gas and Electric Company asKed the Securities and Exchange Commission today to Investigate formation of a protective committee for the $7 and $6 prior preference stocks, of the company and to prohibit further solicitation of authorizations by the group.

Santa Clauses have caused a little concern to the Volunteers of America. In Newark, N.J., Col. Richard Niederbuhl, commanding officer of that chapter, is having trouble recruiting the men who lend an attentive ear to children. With Col. William R. Apetz, head of the Volunteers' New York division, it is a matter of whiskers.
ROME, Dec, 1 -- A few signs are beginning to be seen here and there, but especially in southern Italy, that the workers themselves are getting tired ot Communist - instigated agitations.

New Treasury Call The United States Treasury has issued a further call on the "B" banks for 10 per cent of its "War Loan" accounts as of the close of business Nov. 28, payable on Dec. 8. The banks generally will be expected to provide $115,999,000, while those in this area will account for $36,328,000.

Store Sales Here Off 2% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a decline of 2 per cent last week under the comparative week of last year, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The National Wildlife Federation proposed today that the $13,000,000 Pittman-Robertson Federal Wildlife Restoration Fund be spent in a five-year waterfowl refuge program -- before Congress can use it some other way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Commissioner John W. Studebaker of the United States Office of Education today put before the first meeting of the new nine-member commission on life-adjustment education for youth some ideas on a thorough overhaul of high school and junior college education.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- A solid majority of this city's population expect the Ministers' meeting at London to reach some points of agreement and 14 per cent hopefully expect the Western powers and Russia to reach a complete agreement on the German peace treaty, according to a Military Government survey made available today.

Tuesday, Dec. 2, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Security Council Committee on Experts -- Discussed functions of Council in relation to the strategic trust territory of former Japanese mandated islands and possible assistance to be offered by the Trusteeship Council.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1 -- The Palestine police flrere ordered tonight to stand by, ready for any emergency in the next four days of active Arab protest against a partition of Palestine. The Arabs will begin tomorrow a three-day general strike and a day of mass demonstrations.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Dec. 1 -- The German Social Democrats, represented by Dr. Kurt Schumacher, were today elected to full membership in the international Socialist Conference here. It was generally felt among delegates of the eighteen nations participating that the step would strengthen the Socialist cause throughout Europe.

The first landlord to be jailed in this city for violating the so-called "coercion" section of the Sharkey rent law by demanding a $500 "bonus" for an apartment was sentenced yesterday to a five-day workhouse term by Magistrate Vincent J. Kowalski in War Emergency Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate voted today, 83 to 6, to authorize the full $597,000,000 recommended by the Administration for emergency winter relief to France, Italy and Austria.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Florida's prospective glittering winter racing season opened on a gloomy note today, when a strike of horsemen demanding an increase in minimum purses forced Gulfstream Park to announce that there would be no racing tomorrow and the track would remain closed until an agreement is reached.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, President of the United Nations General Assembly, expressed today the hope that the partitioning of Palestine would ultimately become one of the greatest factors for stability in international relations.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The announcement that Britain had sold u48,000,000 worth of gold during November and in addition bought $60,000,000 from the International Monetary Fund checked a rally in gilt-edged stocks in the stock markets here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Truman informed Congress today that foreign relief needs made it "essential that the Maritime Commission's authority to oparate, sell and charter governmentowned vessels be continued until June 30, 1949."

It is a pity, when a mature pianist has the mechanical ability to play the most difficult music at any tempo and dynamic, to be unable to say more for her. But that is all one can say for Poldi Mildner, Viennese pianist, who played before a scattered audience at Carnegie Hall last night.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Dec. 1 -- This community in Oyster Bay Township, one of the richest in the United States, has started a movement to have American towns, cities and villages adopt devastated communities in Europe. The committee announced today it hoped to see the project become nationwide.

Stockholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., authorized yesterday by a vote of 10,116,716 shares, or 74 per cent, inclusion of a conversion feature in $57,382,600 of new debentures, subject to approval by the Public Service Commission.
Evidence against Samuel Moskowitz, dismissed relief investigator, will be presented to the Kings County Grand Jury tomorrow morning, District Attorney Miles McDonald of Brooklyn said late yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 1 (AP) -- An official announcement said today that Burma did not intend to surrender any portion of her territory and would defend it "without any hesitation" against any encroachment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Government allocation of petroleum, products would be preferable to present conditions -- independents are being driven out of the business -- at Borne, N. Y., fuel dealer said today.

The first strike in connection with union efforts to sign individual contracts with 1,100 Manhattan tan taverns was called yesterday afternoon. Four pickets were stationed outside Moriarty's Grill, 875 Third Avenue, but the proprietors, Michael and Daniel Moriarty, continued to draw beer and mix drinks for all comers.

An exhibit that portrays the desire of men and women around the world to change their natural features and adorn themselves "from the neck up" -- as the exhibit is entitled -- opens to the public today at the American Museum of Natural History.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- Richard T. Leonard, former vice president of the United Auto Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, was hired today as a welder at the rate of $1.42 an hour in contrast to the $7,000 a year he had been making in the union.

Outstanding artists of Italy have turned to the decorative arts to help stimulate their country's handicraft program. The results comprise an exhibit opening today at the House of Italian Handicrafts, 217 East Forty-ninth Street.

The growing shortage of oil products was making itself apparent here yesterday. There was an increase in the number of complaints to the Health Department of lack of heat caused by inability to buy oil, and many gasoline stations curtailed their hours of sale.

Promotion of Gordon P. Lovell to be assistant to the general sales manager of the International Business Machines Corporation, was announced yesterday. Successor to Mr. Lovell as Gistrict sales manager will be McLain B. Smith, electric accounting machine manager in Philadelphia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council decided today to examine a report by the Union of South Africa on its mandate of South-west Africa as if the Council were the Mandates Commission of the defunct League of Nations.
Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed a rise of 4 per cent in November over the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The War Assets Administration said today it was considering eleven offers to buy the ghost village of Passamaquoddy, Me., site of an abandoned tidal-power project.

Bob Mulvihill, defensive star and playmaker of Fordham's basketball team last season, has been declared eligible for another year of intercollegiate athletics, Jack Coffey, graduate athletic manager, announced yesterday.

DALLAS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Champion Southern Methodist and runner-up Texas, as should be, placed the most men on the All-Southwest Conference football team. Each landed three, and four of those selections were unanimous.
The Senate's decisive action yesterday in voting 83 to 6 in favor of the President's $597 million emergency aid program to France, Italy and Austria is news of the most heartening kind.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- Deliveries of CARE food packages in time for the holiday enabled about 10,000 European orphans to eat their first Thanksgiving dinners this year as, the "silent guests" of the American people, Gov. Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts said today.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Joey Angelo, 137 1/2, of Providence, R. I., combined a stinging left jab with a lusty right cross to gain a divided decision over Dennis Pat Brady, 131 1/2, of Hartford, Conn., in their ten-round feature boxing bout tonight at the Boston Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- A great proving ground for atomic weapons and beneficial products of nuclear fission is being created on the bloody Marine battleground of Eniwetok atoll, the United States Atomic Energy Commission disclosed today.

The fourteenth consecutive season of college basketball at Madison Square Garden will get under way tonight with N.Y.U. facing Tulane and Pratt engaging Brooklyn Poly. There are tickets available to the public, Ned Irish, executive vice president of the Garden, announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Under the compulsion of Britain's straitened circumstances, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, submitted to Parliament today an economy program, entailing curtailments and postponements of longcherished and long-delayed capital improvements such as roads, factories, railroads and housing.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 -- Ninety one young women were formally presented to society tonight at the first Monday German of the Bachelors Cotillon, a dance which for generations has been considered the most important social event of the winter in Baltimore.

Any substantial Increase in imports of Canadian spruce next year will encourage generally lower softwood lumber prices in the metropolitan area, all trade elements agreed here yesterday. Although such an increase is possible under new Canadian softwood export rules which no longer require Eastern Canadian mills to set aside a good portion of export shipments for the United Kingdom, wholesalers and yard representatives pointed out that several obstacles stand in the way.

Failure of styles in millinery to show a newness commensurate with those of the apparel trades is holding up placement of early orders for spring, Bea Rosenberg, millinery merchandise manager of R. H. Macy & Co., declared yesterday. Buyers are in sympathy with the aims of hat manufacturers to get a quick start for the early 1948 Easter season, she said, but they will not make commitments on what has been, shown thus far.
A remarkable selection of more than 140 scriptural manuscripts from its famous Bible collection has been assembled in the Pierpont Morgan Library for the annual holiday exhibition, "The Bible."

City and state officials voiced the need yesterday for an expanded day-care program in this city as the United Neighborhood Houses began a three-day "open house" tour of ten of its ninety-four centers in Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx.

Random notes. Later reports from Currituck and Pamlico Sounds on the North Carolina coast Indicate a larger number of geese than last season, but rather spotty duck prospects in several areas. Because of the present goose limit, however, it is Hot anticipated that many Yankee hunters will make the trip just for the goose shooting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The United States must produce in volume in peacetime a constantly improving stream of war planes to assure its security, three witnesses declared today before the Air Policy Commission. Each said that planning alone was not enough.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 1 -- The prosecutors formally rested their case today in the trial here of twenty-three top executives of the I. G. Farbenindustrie chemical cartel, in which the taking of evidence began on Aug. 27.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors, already protesting against the state's "discrimination" in the distribution of educational and gasoline tax monies, received voluminous data today concerning another form of "discrimination" practiced from Albany -- the slashing of allowances to Westchester villages.

The popular suspicion that Joe Louis will have an easy time disposing of Jersey Joe Walcott when he defends his heavy weight title for the twenty-fourth time Friday night in Madison Square Garden is not shared by the world heavy-weight champion, at least to the extent of making him careless in training.
On Dec. 22, Cincinnati, Ohio, will receive bids for $4,839,000 in various bonds, at interest rates not exceeding 2 per cent, dated Feb. 1, 1948 and maturing from Sept. 1, 1949 to 1973.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, today denied that the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association had ever made a wage offer to Local 16, which is now on strike.

The recently formed Liberia Company has made substantial progress toward development of a national Liberian bank, an airways system, a cocoa program, utilities construction and a broad program to expand health and educational facilities in that African republic, it was announced yesterday.

MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 1 -- Although all French Prefects today received orders from the Minister of the Interior to forbid the use of municipal funds for strikers' relief, the Marseille City Council today voted 15,000,000 francs for "general" relief, admittedly mainly for the strikers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board has obtained from a Federal court for the first time a show-cause order against a union seeking to exact a fee for work not done, a violation of the Taft-Hartley Act, it was disclosed at the board's offices today.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Liquidation of E. C. Brown Co., manufacturers of spray pumps, as the result of a dispute between the company and the International Association of Machinists (independent) was indicated today by a management spokesman.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- Secretary General Trygve Lie and other United Nations officials began immediate preparations today to speed the establishment of the Palestine Commission staff that will help administer affairs in the Holy Land during the interim period before formal partition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- Mary Renault's "Return to Night," which won the $175,000 prize in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's novel contest in 1946, will be adapted to the screen as a vehicle for Greer Garson, the studio announced today. Warren Chatham-Strode, British playwright, will write the cinematic adaptation, which will go before the cameras after Miss Garson completes "Julia Misbehaves," the screen version of "The Nutmeg Tree."

Concocting a welsh rabbit that is smooth and sizzling hot, yet ready for the table in a matter of minutes, always seems a skill that's possible only for experienced chefs. Now housewives can do just as well, for it appears that the secret behind the success of many of those gentlemen is a prepared mix in powdered form that simply is dissolved in water and brought to a boil.
The New York Museum of Science and Industry opened yesterday a holiday exhibit for children. Its show was composed of an assortment of mechanical toys and a cross-eyed chicken.

A hint that the National Football League is taking cognizance of the existence of the All-America Conference was heard at the final 1947 meeting of the New York Football Writers yesterday at Toots Shor's. In a colloquy between Alexis Thompson, owner of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Loop, and Red Dawson, coach of the All-America Buffalo Bills, it developed that the pair favored a common draft of players.
STORKS, Conn., Dec. 1 (AP) -- The University of Connecticut opened its 1947-48 basketball season tonight by defeating American University of Washington, D.C., 48 to 37.

The Elmwood Apartments development in Bayside, Queens, has received a Federal Housing Administration commitment of $668,000 in financing arranged with the Bowery Savings Bank through Henry J. White Son, brokers. The Elmwood Apartments Corporation of 163-18 Jamaica Avenue, Jamaica, is the builder.
Tuesday, Dec. 2, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Asked Congress to extend authority of Maritime Commission to charter, operate or sell Government owned vessels.

BBB Checks Video Ad Claims To eliminate any possibility of misleading or confusing the reader, the National Better Business Bureau reported yesterday it has recommended that when the size of the picture tube is specified in a television advertisement, the actual picture size also be stated.

MANILA, Dec. 1 -- Between the Russian and Indian delegations and Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, the absorbing subject of colonialism succeeded again today in retaining the spotlight at the continuing sessions of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East in Baguio.
A rollback of garage fees, to the levels of Sept. 3O or earlier, will be sought by the city administration through state legislation, it was learned yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Col. William Quarterman of Windor, Ga., United States military attache, set up machine guns today to protect his office in the event of a serious attack.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Dec. 1 -- Sixty pairs began play tonight for the national masters' contract bridge mixed pair championship in the American Contract Bridge League's Tournament here. Alvin Roth and Mrs. Anne Bernstein of Miami, Fla., who won the title last year, were not among those competing.

Rubber goods production at higher than pre-war levels has been the result of the growing trend to motorized transportation throughout Western Europe, C. A. Carlton, technical director of the rubber and new products division, J. M. Huber Corporation, New York, declared yesterday.

The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Variety meats are much in the news today, and, of course, they always are nutritionally important. Appropriately, liver loaf is on Tuesday's Peace Plate, served with creamy panned potatoes and crisp orange-apple cole slaw.

HAVANA, Dec. 1 -- Political strife within the ranks of President Grau San Martin's Autentico party resulted in the death of two persons and the wounding of several in yesterday's primary elections held by all political parties.

Experience, an 18-pound pull in weight and a brute strength that has always been his greatest characteristic, carried Arturo Godoy, veteran Chilean heavy weight, to victory last night over Phil Muscato, promising young Buffalo boxer, in ten exciting rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena.

In his annual message to the Legislature last January Governor Dewey remarked that the state was "in the strongest financial position in its history." He was determined at that time to resist efforts to raid post-war savings for pet projects, lest our house of government come "crashing down on the people's heads."

The first privately owned and operated laboratory for experiments in fuels for jet and rocketpowered aircraft will be opened at Beacon, N.Y., next month by the Texas Petroleum Company, it was announced here yesterday.
Bath Iron Works The Bath Iron Works Corporation announced yesterday that at a meeting of the board, directors considered it inadvisable to take any action on a dividend at this time.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 1 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will spend $5,000,000 next year to finance the projects approved by the second general assembly. Total expenditures, including administrative expenses, will be $7,707,637.

The lessons learned in rehabilitating the health of soldiers during the war have been applied to the care of crippled children, Dr. A. R. Shands Jr., medical director of the Alfred I. du Pont Institute in Wilmington, Del., reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 1 -- With only a handful of delegates still here after Saturday's closing of the General Assembly's second session, United Nations technical workers, program, and maintenance staffs moved in today to rush work on the Assembly hall in Flushing Meadow and "seal off" the building until further use.

A uniform system of port markings, plus specific size, weight and durability standards, are expected to be major items in a code of minimum requirements for export packaging soon to be promulgated by steamship companies, it was learned yesterday.

The struggle between the French Government and the French sector of the Communist International has assumed proportions which make France the first real battlefield in the "cold war" between Russia and the West. The outcome of this struggle will go far in determining the future course of events both at the London peace conference and in Europe.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The British Olympic Organizing Committee raised the window of the box office to home fans today, offering tickets for the games next July 29 to Aug. 14 at prices ranging upward from two shillings (40 cents) for standing room.

HAVANA, Dec. 1 -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today adopted a resolution that conference decisions shall be made without voting whenever possible but that only United Nations members have voting rights in cases where ballots prove necessary.

Earth taken from the Holy Land in 1917 when the Balfour Declaration was enacted was mingled with the soil at the base of the Statue of Liberty yesterday. At the same time a spadeful of earth from the base of the statue was taken to be sent to Palestine to be mingled with the Palestinian soil on the day the new capital of the Jewish state there is dedicated.
JACKSONVILLE, Pla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Georgia and Maryland will meet in the Gator Bowl's third football game here on New Year's Day.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, announced yesterday that, for the first time, the public would be asked to give financial aid to New York's four municipal colleges. The request will be for gifts and bequests from private citizens to provide for the students special services not available under the city budget.

Three hundred and seventy-five men, most of them veterans, lined up in the cold on West Fifty-ninth Street last night to wait until 9 A.M. to apply for $41.54-a-week laboring jobs in various city departments.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Informed Republicans, both in and out of Congress, believe that Carroll Reece will carry on as Republican National Chairman through the national convention next June, despite criticism in party ranks of the way he has conducted the office.

Exports from the United States to the so-called "Marshall plan" countries -- those included in the European Recovery Plan -- and their dependencies, during the third quarter of this year were more than 300 per cent above the 1036-38 rate, with less than half this increase attributable to higher prices, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The internationalization of the Ruhr would put the Western powers on an equal bargaining basis with the Soviet Union when a unified Germany is established, according to advocates of this policy in the United States delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers.

Unless one read the program it would be difficult to tell which team was atop the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America and which was in the cellar of the Western Division as the New York Knickerbockers engaged the Washington Capitols at Madison Square Garden last night.

Johnny Lujack, whose aerial artistry has sparked Notre Dame throughout its current unbeaten campaign, yesterday was named the winner of the Heisman Trophy. The South Bend senior, who is expected to join the professional ranks next season, will receive the award on the night of Dec. 10 at the Downtown Athletic Club.

One of the cheerful harbingers of the season is the appearance of the Christmas seal, the 1947 version of which depicts a woodsman driving: an ox-cart load of Christimas trees across the snow out of the Far North. Each year more and more of these attractive stickers are sold and each year they are used to adorn ever-increasing numbers of greeting card envelopes and gifts.

HONOLULU, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. John E. Hull was disclosed today as commander of a joint task force of the armed services which is creating an experimental base on Eniwetok in the Marshall Islands and will support atomic energy tests directed by the Atomic Energy Commission.

Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, urged Congress yesterday to make available the funds necessary for the "sound and vital construction program" recommended by the President's merchant marine committee, calling for the building of forty-six passenger ships.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 1 -- The drama, as known around here, ranged extensively tonight on the small arena stage of Dallas Theatre '47 when Margo Jones added Vivian Connell's "Throng O'Scarlet" to her growing repertory.

Held back only by shortages of materials, record business volume for 1948 was forecast by seventeen out of twenty-one exhibitors interviewed yesterday at the opening of the twenty-first Exposition of the Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers, led by Russia's V. M. Molotov, put on record today that Germany was in for a long period of four-power control. Considering the snail's pace at which the conference here is proceeding, this is easy to believe.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The prospects for an Austrian peace treaty, fairly good a week ago, vanished today into the fog of words that hangs over every international conference.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 -- Declaring that "if we don't want high prices, we and our Government will nave to spend less," Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio set forth tonight an eight-point program to combat inflation.

CHICAGO, Dee. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 16,000 head, total 23,500; market active, fully SO cents higher than Erlday on all butchers and sows: top $26.35 sparingly;
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday losses suffered early in the day and closed at or near the best levels of the day, with net gains of 17 to 49 points.

At a bearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday on the application of the New York Telephone Company for authority to issue $60,000,000 of thirty-year refunding mortgage bonds, Series E. John B. King, the company's counsel, told Ernest A. Bamman, hearing examiner, that in the nine month-period beginning on Oct. 1, 1947, the company required for construction $108,000,000, about $50,000,0000 of which will be needed before Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Testimony that the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey transported an average total of 10,137 "pass" passengers daily in 1946 was heard today at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Appointment of commissioners in ten states to direct operation of Independent Basketball Association of America tournaments was announced today by Lowell M. Davis, national commissioner.

To the editor of the new york times : Having just returned from France, after a visit of several months, I can easily imagine the eager joy with which the Communist press in Paris has welcomed the obstructions that Senators Taft, Ball, Millikin and Wherry and Congressman Taber and their friends are throwing in the path of emergency aid to Europe.

Plans for construction of an osteopathic hospital -- the first in the city's history -- at a cost of $1,500,000 were made public yesterday by Dr. Omar C. Latimer, president of the Osteopathic Society of New York.

Although several large banks here have followed the action of the National City Bank of New York in raising the rates on bankers' acceptances 1/8 to 1/4 per cent for short and long term, bills, some of the larger discount houses are "going along" only in part, it was learned yesterday.

Pulse, Inc., which undertakes to probe for the comparative popularity standings of radio programs among listeners in the metropolitan area, has announced in its latest findings that Jack Benny's show leads the way in evening entertainment. Completing the top ten in that category, in descending order, are listed Fred Alien, Edgar Bergen, Lux Radio Theatre, Fibber McGee and Molly, Bob Hope, Red Skelton, Walter Winchell, Bing Crosby and "Mr. District Attorney."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The State Department gave today a report of the tearing down of the American flag by a mob of 2,000 in a raid on the legation in Damascus. All Americans in that area have been ordered to stay at home by Robert B. Memminger, United States Charged Affaires, the department said.

To the editor of the new york times : The nonrealization of the decisive implications of "just a little government control" has never been more strikingly exhibited than in the present attitude of our public and legislators toward President Truman's proposal to impose peacetime government control over the availability of consumer credit.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 1 -- Efforts on the part of the Yankees to break through the anti-trading bloc that has been ringing the world champions ever since the close of the 1947 season stood out today as the baseball clans from far and wide filtered down the Grapefruit State for the annual minor league convention that gets under way this week.

JOHN MANNINGHAM, a law student of the Middle Temple, wrote in his diary on March 13, 1602, a story he had heard about two of the most prominent persons of the London theatre. "Upon a time when Burbidge played Rich 3. there was a citizen grewe soe farr in liking with him that before shee went from the play shee appointed him to come that night unto her by the name of Rir he 3.

The Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, No. 126, of Brooklyn, has gone on record as opposing the reappointment of Leo Durocher as manager of the Brooklyn Dodgers for the 1948 season, it was announced last night by John B. Fitzpatrick, Grand Knight of the Council.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- An administrator was appointed unanimously today by the international executive board of the United, Automobile Workers, CIO, to preside over the affairs of Local 248, which was embroiled for eleven months in a strike with the Allis-Chalmers Company in Milwaukee.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- The American Jewish Conference called on the British Government today to maintain order in Palestine until the Jewish national state began to function and assumed responsibility for peace.

TRENTTON, N. J., Dec. 1 -- Whether New Jersey shall move forward next year with the $10,000,000 "stepping stone" program of penal reform drafted by the Department of Institutions appeared tonight to depend upon a budgetary study undertaken over the Thanksgiving holiday by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.
Directors of the National Malleable and Steel Castings Company took no action yesterday on the declaration of a dividend.
Maj. Gen. Raymond W. Bliss, Surgeon General of the Army, urged last night that fewer patients be admitted to hospitals, if they can be treated in a dispensary or out-patient clinic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Deed covenants that seek to restrict the sale of real estate they cover to members of specified races or religious groups should be ruled unenforcible, according to a brief filed today in the United States Supreme Court on behalf of four national Jewish organizations.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Ancient Sportsman's Park, which would be a major stumbling block in any transfer of the Browns to another city, could be sold to the Cardinals "at the right price," one of the new Cardinal owners said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Truman's suggested program for domestic economic controls to prevent inflation met a frankly hostile reception from the House Banking Committee today. It was examining Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Haniman on details of the proposal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Two leaders of the rubber industry recommended to Congress today that the Government retain control of its synthetic plants temporarily, then get out of the business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Truman dedicated the children's wing of the new Georgetown University Hospital today as a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt and then visited three sick persons -- a child, a news photographer and the superintendent of the House press gallery.
Directors of the National Malleable and Steel Castings Company took no action yesterday on the declaration of a dividend.
Maj. Gen. Raymond W. Bliss, Surgeon General of the Army, urged last night that fewer patients be admitted to hospitals, if they can be treated in a dispensary or out-patient clinic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Two leaders of the rubber industry recommended to Congress today that the Government retain control of its synthetic plants temporarily, then get out of the business.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- President Truman dedicated the children's wing of the new Georgetown University Hospital today as a memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt and then visited three sick persons -- a child, a news photographer and the superintendent of the House press gallery.
NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Suggestions for well-designed gifts for the budget-conscious holiday shopper may be seen in an exhibittion, "Under Ten Dollars," which opened today at the Newark Museum.

LISBON, Portugal, Wednesday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The worst storm in Portuguese history smashed the Portuguese north coast fishing fleet Monday and yesterday, claiming at least 165 lives and sinking most of the ships.

The stock market furthered yesterday its advance although gains were limited as dull trading continued. There were some top gains of more than a point but the price average only rose 0.19 point on the day. Leading groups held within a nominal price range with the oil issues most prominent.
BATAVIA, Java., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The United States Navy transport Renville arrived here today to serve as the scene of peace negotiations between Dutch and Indonesian representatives.

For the first time in ten years the city accepted applications for laboring jobs yesterday and more than 4,000 men stormed West Fifty -ninth Street from dawn to dusk to put in their bids for the openings.

AMONG this season's handsome picture books few are more alluring than "Time and Chance,"* by Cyrus LeRoy Baldridge. Profusely illustrated with the wonderful drawings which Mr. Baldridge has been producing all over the world for the last thirty years, it is an eyecatching and fascinating book -- that is, so far as its illustrations go.

The first of the scheduled wage discussions between the Committee for the Companies and Agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts and three Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions opened yesterday, with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association asking for increases in base pay and overtime wages.
Manhattan tavern owners took the offensive in the "battle of the bars" yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Wheat futures broke over 7 cents and com was down around 5 cents at the low price on the Board of Trade today as the result of general selling by commission houses, which uncovered stop loss orders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- House Republicans, in a long party conference, indicated almost universal support today for the authorization without undue delay of an emergency winter relief program for France, Italy and Austria. What they would seek to do to the program recommended by the Foreign Affairs Committee, however, was left open to widespread speculation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- United States military observers pointed today to the possibility that a war in Palestine might bring Soviet Army units into the country, ostensibly to protect the projected new Jewish state against the Arabs.

PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- The National Assembly was still in a weary battle at 7 A.M. today as the Communists continued their delaying attacks against Premier Robert Schuman's emergency strike bill.

Full disclosures of profit-building methods and policies of the National Dealers Council, an elected group heading up 6,500 automobile dealers throughout the country, were revealed yesterday by Walker A. Williams, general sales manager of Ford Motor Company, at a luncheon of the Sales Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Board of Estimate at its meeting at 10:30 tomorrow morning In City Hall will have before it unfavorable reports by the Corporation Counsel and the City Planning Commission regarding the "dream city" shopping and business center in Flushing proposed by Webb Knapp, real estate operators. When first announced, the firm estimated the cost at $50,000,000.

Marking the first major break in the pattern of prime commercial loan rates to be announced in recent years, Bankers Trust Company began advising its commercial borrowers yesterday that effective on Dec. 15, its rates will be increased from 1 1/2 per cent to 1 3/4 per cent.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Under pressure from voluntary hospitals, Governor Dewey's State Food Commission is considering sponsoring legislation that would lift temporarily the existing statutory ban against substituting oleomargarine for butter in any institution supported in whole or in part by public funds.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The split between the United States' policy of wide representation at a German peace conference and Soviet proposals for a restricted parley widened today in the Council of Foreign Ministers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- The fifth anniversary of the birth of the Atomic Age -- the first successful operation of a nuclear chain reactor in a squash court under the west stands of the University of Chicago's Stagg Field -- was observed today with declarations that man's use or misuse of the forces unleased was a problem the scientist must pass on to the citizen.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 2 -- As trading Tines of the major leagues remained badly snarled, the spotlight in the minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues' conclave reverted to the Pacific Coast League today as Clarence Rowland, enterprising president of that circuit, for the first time gained some support in his efforts to win eventual major league recognition.
MOSCOW, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Pravda published today a charge that the United States, Britain and France went to the London Conference of Foreign Ministers armed with preliminary agreements.

NANKING, Dec. 2 -- A policy of "economic martial law" for major commercial cities was approved today by the Executive Yuan [Cabinet] as the Government continued mobilizing its resources to combat Communist military threats in the Yangtze valley and in north China.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The existence of at least three political concentration camps in the Soviet zone where treatment is as bad as that inflicted formerly by the Nazis, is directly charged by The Sozialdemokrat, the Berlin organ of the Social Democratic Party.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 2 -- "The growing paralysis" of Protestantism will never be "cured" until churches adjust themselves to the needs of the community rather than the individual, the Rev. Dr. Mark A. Dawber, executive secretary of the Home Missions Council of North America, declared today at the opening of a four-day National Conference on the Community and Religious Education.

With solemn preoccupation, a group of 4 to 8-year-olds sat yesterday creating their art at easels, working away with paintbrushes and making mysterious pictures out of bits of brightly colored papers. It was the opening day of the Children's Holiday Fair, the annual event at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, arranged under the museum's educational program.

WASHINGTON. Wednesday, Dec. 3 -- Pope Pius XII has appointed Bishop Francis P. Keougn to be Archbishop of Baltimore and the Right Rev. Msgr. Patrick A. O'Boyle to be Archbishop of Washington, the National Catholic Welfare Conference announced today.

Partition of Palestine may result in a temporary boycott of American goods in some areas of the Middle East, Leslie Larson of the Hitchcock Publishing Company said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Where Freedom Stops Our friend who boasts that the freedom of the city is his, and who regards the attachment of commuters to time tables as a state of slavery more to be pitied than envied, was interested, he said, in two things he had read in the papers.

Belittling charges of inefficiency on the part of the management of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, made by Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., Col. Sosthenes Behn, chairman and president of the world-wide communications company, broke yesterday a precedent of more than twenty years.

Democratic leaders indicated yesterday they had no intention of restoring the Communist party membership in the City Council to its full quota of two by seating Simon W. Gerson, the Communist party designee to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Peter V. Cacchione of Brooklyn.
R.E. Warn, formerly managing director of the Western Electric Company (Australia) Pty. Ltd., has been named chief of engineerng of the Westrex Corporation.

A new issue of $500,000 of Pittsburgh 1 3/4 per cent bonds maturing in December, 1948 to 1967, will be offered today by the Union Securities Corporation and Kean, Taylor Co. at prices to yield 0.80 per cent to a dollar price of 98.

Although they finished in fourth place, the Columbia Lions landed three men on the Ivy League allstar football team selected for The Associated Press yesterday by league coaches, a mark equaled only by Pennsylvania's unbeaten but once-tied champions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Committee which unhappily is seeing double on the subject of the American ice hockey entry in the 1948 Olympics tomorrow will review its ramified feud with the American Hockey Association and perhaps discuss the possibility of keeping the United States entirely out of the winter games.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 2 -- Leaders of Local 248, United Automobile Workers of America, CIO, at the Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company locked themselves in their headquarters today in defiance of an administrator named by the executive board of the international union to take over the local's affairs.

A proposal that the United Nations undertake an investigation into slave labor will be considered at the Feb. 2 meeting of the Economic and Social Council, it was announced yesterday by Matthew Woll, chairman of the international relations committee of the American Federation of Labor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- (AP) The New York City Bar Association proposed today that Congress look into the idea of setting up a self-finan pension plan for everybody who works for a living.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations decided today to lead labor's fight for a third round of wage increases since the end of the war. This policy was adopted at a meeting of the group's vice presidents presided over by Philip Murray, president.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 AP -- Two commuters testified today that if the Central Railroad of New Jersey discontinued its suburban service to New York City they would, in effect, be confronted by a personal economic upheaval.

Jerome Robbins' little pas de deux called "Summer Day" was added to the repertoire of the Ballet Theatre at the City Center last night, with Mr. Robbing himself and the pianist, Ray Lev, both guest artists for this occasion only, and Ruth Ann Koesun of the regular company constituting the cast.

Claudia Pinza sang Mimi in "Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and there was a better opportunity to measure the young soprano's talent than at her debut as Micaela" in "Carmen" a fortnight ago. For one thing, the role was longer, richer and more exigent in its acting demands; for another thing, it was not a debut and less margin needed to be allowed for nervousness.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 2 -- The holymen of al-Azhar University, fountainhead of Moslem learning, called today on the Moslem world to proclaim a holy war as Suleiman did against the Crusaders 800 years ago. They acted in protest against the proposed partition of Palestine.

Joe Louis is going to England for an exhibition tour in February if he is still the world heavyweight champion. The titlehnlder, following a brisk four-round sparring drill at his Pompton Lakes, N.J., training camp yesterday in preparation for the defense of his crown Friday night in Madison Square Garden against Jersey Joe Walcott, announced he had completed arrangements for his first civilian visit to England.

Buyers' Total Down in Month Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,091, against 1,180 last week and 838 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The National Labor Relations Board invoked the Taft-Hartley law yesterday to curb alleged secondary picketing by a Congress of Industrial Organizations union.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 2 -- Arab threats of violence in protest against the Palestine partition plan materialized today in stoning and stabbing attacks against Jews and in the burning and looting of their shops. In reprisal, Jews burned an Arab-owned movie theatre and an Arab-owned garage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Truman called attention today to widespread destitution among the nation's 61,000 Navajo Indians, and soon thereafter a move to provide $2,000,000 for immediate relief developed in Congress.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Viscount Addison, Government leader of the House of Lords, informed that body this afternoon that he had received a message from King George informing him that Captain Lord Colwyn, a member of the House of Lords, had been placed under arrest to be tried by courtmartial.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Presidents of the fifty-four minor baseball leagues rested today after forty-eight hours of lobby pounding to hear George Trautman, president of their National Association, lift a storm warning against further expansion.

Communist party membership is not a sufficient ground for dismissal from the city payroll, Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday, following testimony that there was strong Communist influence in New York's $142,000,000 relief set-up.

Steps were taken yesterday by American management to promote world-wide industrial output essential to international prosperity, Harold B. Maynard, president, Methods Engineering Council, Pittsburgh, declared yesterday.

MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 2 -- The general strike call issued by Marseille's Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor for today had not succeeded by nightfall. No important labor group not already on strike heeded the call.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Fringe parking on the outskirts of municipalities and elimination of curbstone "motor hogs" in midtown areas were recommended today as fundamental remedies for traffic and parking: congestion in New York City and other communities throughout the country.

Citing the Port of New York Authority's own report of its financial position, the Automobile Clubof New Tork called yesterday for an immediate reduction in the 50 cent tolls levied on such facilities as the George Washington Bridge and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels.

In this era of point-conscious, streamlined basketball, it was rather startling that N.Y.U. defeated Tulane, 41-37, as the collegiate court season bowed in last night at Madison Square Garden. The surprise was not in the outcome, but in the low-point production by both sides.

New efforts must be made to encourage teen-aged boys and girls to stay in school instead of searching for jobs, Mrs. Gertrude Folks Zimand, general secretary of the National Child Labor Committee, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Lieut. Gen. Leonard T. Gerow will be the new commander of the Second Army, it was announced today.

All was sweetness and light, broad smiles and merry quips, at the weekly luncheon of the football Giants at the Polo Grounds yesterday. This was, incidentally, the farewell gathering of the season, since the Giants play their final home game against the Washington Redskins next Sunday.

A more intensive campaign, in the New York area in behalf of those stricken with infantile paralysis was advocated yesterday at a meeting of the Greater New York Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paraysis. The meeting marked the tenth anniversary of the March of Dimes.

More Bate Increases. The Chase National Bank has joined the list of leading banks here which have raised rates on bankers' acceptances, it was disclosed yesterday. The new schedule compares exactly with that announced last week by the National City Bank of New York and became effective yesterday.

RENO, Nov., Dec. 2 (AP) -- University of Nevada football players tonight were reconsidering their decision not to play North Texas State Teachers College in the Phoenix (Ariz.) Salad Bowl on New Tear's Day.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- Plants for producing fissionable uranium and plutonium are going through a largescale improvement and expansion program that in the "next several years" may double the expenditures made up to now on atomic energy, David Lilienthal, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 --President Truman was writing a conservation speech today for the dedication on Saturday of the New Everglades National Park, a vast subtropical area on the southwest coast of Florida.

Mayor O'Dwyer is scheduled to make public his 1948 legislative program of measures to increase the city's revenues and borrowing power in a broadcast Friday evening from 6:15 to 6:45 o'clock, the Mayor's office announced last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- Australia, China, France, Mexico, Britain and the United States were named to a United Nations working committee to write a draft constitution for the Jerusalem international zone, which will be created under the Assembly resolution calling for partition of Palestine.

Though the President's Air Policy Commission, headed by Thomas K. Finletter, has not yet completed its hearings, the Commission -- and the nation -- must be impressed by the cumulative impact of the statements made by witnesses of the highest character, representing not only the military departments but other governmental and non-governmental agencies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Oscar R. Ewing, Federal Security administrator, told the annual conference of State and Territorial Health Officers today that his office was hampered by lack of cabinet rank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The country's big grain exchanges defended speculative trading in basic food commodities today as essential to orderly marketing and contended that it caused absolutely no increases in prices in the long run, being responsible only for day-today fluctuations.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The United States Military Government's propagenda campaign against communism, which, is entering its second month, has had little apparent effect on editors of German newspapers or on the German public, a survey or newspapers in the United States zone showed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The most important of the anti-inflation controls on credit proposed by the Federal Reserve Board, a requirement that the commercial banks set aside big new "special reserves" of untouched money, came under powerful attack today before Congress.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 2 (AP) -- A beautiful blonde Danish, princess who worked briefly as a sales girl in a New York department store will wed King Michael of Rumania, an informant close to the Danish royal family said today.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- A referendum petition bearing 80,180 names, asking for an amendment to the state law to permit physicians to give birth control advice to married women for the protection of life and health was filed today with the Secretary of State, Frederic W. Cook.

The reconversion of the United Fruit Company's Jamaica, delayed for nearly five months by the recent strike of shipyard workers, is now in its final stages and the vessel will be delivered to her owners on Friday, Arthur Hiltebrant, general manager of the Bethlehem Steel Company's New York District shipyards, announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Steve Brooks, bidding for national riding honors, brought Rockwood Lou home first in today's feature at Fair Grounds. The W.H. Bishop entry, 2-5 favorite, finished a head in front of Little Stick.

Of Hollywood lineage, Irene M. Selznick (she's the daughter of Metro's prexy, Louis B. Mayer) refused to be detoured from the stage after the failure of her first offering, "Heartsong," the Arthur Laurents play which capsized on the road.

Manufacturers, speaking as sellers rather than buyers of goods, are Sharply divided regarding justification for cash discounts, according to the latest survey of business practices conducted by the National Industrial Conference Board, released yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- The New Jersey State Horticultural Society urged today a $75,000,000 state bond issue to finance construction of new buildings for the Department of Institutions and Agencies, the State Board of Education and the State University at Rutgers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- An industry witness suggested to the Wage and Hour Administrator today that any change in the definitions of executive, administrative and professional employes should recognize a salary in excess of $200 a month as presumption of an exempt status.

Many producers of bedroom and dining room furniture will exhibit few, if any, new numbers at the January furniture markets, manufacturers' representatives disclosed yesterday. They stated that factories have decided to concentrate on numbers now on the market to reduce the steadily increasing backlog.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, told the legislative conference of the State Federation of Labor today that the Dewey, state administration favors an increase in unemployment insurance benefits and is opposed to any "repressive" labor legislation.

Prof. John A. Wheeler or Princeton University, one of the world's leaders in nuclear physics who played a maojr role in the development of the atomic bomb, outlined last night the possibility of a new type of fission of uranium, or heavier elements, in which the energy liberated would be 50 per cent greater than that released in the explosion of the atomic bomb.
All the homely pleasures of a Christmas at home are expressed in decorations suggested this year by Ann Hagan, New York floral designer, 141 East Fortieth Street.
Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would swear in John P. McGrath, a Brooklyn lawyer, as the city's new Corporation Counsel on Monday at City Hall at 1 P.M.
Notre Dame and Michigan, as befits the victorious records of these Midwestern football giants dominate the 1947 Associated Press All-America squad announced yesterday.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 2 -- Comdr. Fitzhugh Green, Naval Reserve officer, Arctic explorer and author, who recently was placed on probation for five years for violation of the Federal Narcotics Act, died at 3 P.M. today in the Danbury Hospital.

MIAMI, Pla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Gulfstream race course headed into its second consecutive idle day tomorrow as all efforts to break a deadlock between striking horsemen demanding richer purses and the track management failed.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Otto Preminger was named today by Twentieth Century-Fox to take over production and direction of the Ernst Lubitsch film, "This Is the Moment," which was halted by Lubitsch's death last Sunday.

Production records which are being established in the textile industry will have solved the problems of shortages and high prices. before definite action can be obtained on a voluntary plan for anti-inflation controls, it was pointed out by trade spokesmen yesterday.

Sometimes short news dispatches in a corner of one's newspaper serve as flashes of light enabling the mind to visualize for a moment, in clear and concentrated form, the incredible'51 changes wrought through the centuries by the march of progress.

The early reports on the long Island duck shooting as well as the Pennsylvania deer hunting Were excellent and although the duck hunters faced some bluebird weather they found black ducks and broadbill quite plentiful.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers faced the prospect of a $10,000 court suit today as a Federal grand jury pressed its investigation of his financial dealings with a war contract firm.
Joseph T. Sharkey, vice-chairman of the City Council, said yesterday he was "seriously considering" a bill to give the City Rent Commission control over storage fees in public garages.

A plea that the "American Bible Society's 1948 plans be greatly expanded" and that more Bibles be sent to Japan was received by cable from Gen. Douglas MacArthur and read yesterday at the annual budget session of the society at the Bible House, 450 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Assistant Secretary of the Interior William E. Warne said today a return to compulsory rationing of gasoline and fuel oil should not be necessary "unless something unprecedented occurs."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- The Children's Emergency Fund is carrying out emergency feeding programs in schools, orphanages and institutions in seven European countries, Maurice Pate, director of the executive board, reported today.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Further consideration of the large gold sales in November, uncertainties of the Big Pour conference, and the Palestine and French situations had a depressing effect on the stock markets here today.

Cyrus Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, chided representatives of his own agency and state mediation boards yesterday for their occasional conflicts over jurisdiction in labor-management disputes.
Familiar and new lines were combined in a collection of resort and early spring fashions presented yesterday at the Ritz-Cariton Hotel by Joseph Halpert.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- The second session of the American Contract Bridge League's mixed pair championship opened here tonight with four master teams holding top positions in the two sections of play.
YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Called attention in a statement to destitution of 61,000 Navajo Indians and suggested relief appropriations and other aid measures.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Ezzard Charles, light-heavyweight title contender, was awarded a technical knockout over Fitzy Fitzpatrick of Los Angeles in the fourth of a scheduled twelverounder before a sellout crowd of 13,384 at the Arena tonight.

Thirty thousand cards bearing Christmas greetings from the children of Europe to the children of this country have been received at the headquarters of World Festivals for Friendship, 2 West Fortyfifth Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The emphasis in your editorial of Nov. 22, "Medical Care," on the broad experience and "sound common sense" behind Bernard M. Baruch's advocacy of compulsory health insurance is most gratifying. It is common sense, not necessarily common knowledge, that "socialized medicine" is a system in many respects distinct and different from "compulsory health insurance," a point well stressed in your editorial.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- W Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, issued today new orders which will bring under export control, after Jan. 1, 95 per cent of all iron and steel exports.

New York's Yankees and the Cleveland Browns, who will meet for the All-America Football Conference championship at the Yankee Stadium on Dec. 14, are setting the pace in the circuit in the race for individual and team, statistical honors, according to official figures announced yesterday.

Leading figures of the hockey world will be present tonight in the special ceremonies that will be staged at Madison Square Garden prior to the game between the New York Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs as a tribute to Lester Patrick.

Notre Dame clung to its ranking as No. 1 college football team in The Associated Press poll yesterday and the Fighting Irish will be defending that lofty position as well as their perfect record when they collide with Southern California Saturday.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 2 -- Soviet delegates pressed on two fronts today for immediate investigation of the Negro problem in the United States and conditions in colonial territories.

An elaborate program, topped off by a reception at City Hall by Mayor O'Dwyer, is being prepared this week-end by metropolitan skiing enthusiasts for the United States Olympic ski team that is to start arriving in this city by Friday and be at top strength the following morning.

The American Tariff League has requested President Truman to withhold proclamation of the rates of duty negotiated at Geneva until the name of the foreign country party to each United States tariff concession negotiated is made public and a reasonable time accorded in which to study the information before the date of the proclamation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Army and the Navy strongly challenged today the supremacy of the Air Force as the premier weapon of modern warfare in testimony before the President's Air Policy Commission. Their presentations were designed to offset recent testimony by air proponents who pictured warfare of the future as smashing transocean attacks by vast fleets of giant planes fanning out from an enemy power or the United States.

Having broken a Communist occupation of its council chamber by the forcible ejection of the Communist Deputies, the French National Assembly has moved to adopt measures dealing with the incipient insurrection of the French sector of the Communist International.

A new center offering a design and planning service as well as a selection of furniture and accessories by contemporary designers opened yesterday at 33 East Seventy -fifth Street. "New Design, Inc." is the project of three young women, Dorothy Q. Noyes, Harriet S. Rosenberg and Edith Perlman, an of whom have had training in various aspects of design and architecture.

The Christmas spirit sparkled yesterday morning in the penthouse of Edwin Goodman, president of Bergdorf Goodman, where a tempting array of gifts was on exhibit. The objects, brought together by Tom Lied, ranged from little fur pieces to pieces of antique jewelry.

Since so often young pianists make a flash debut and then develop no further, it is a pleasure to report that Abbey Simon, who played last night at Carnegie Hall, is still growing. It was his sixth local recital since his debut as a Naumburg Award Winner in 1940.

The United States Lines freighter American Leader, scheduled to be the first American-flag vessel to leave here with "Friendship Cargo" for France, is due here this morning. The vessel previously was scheduled to dock here yesterday morning, but was held over in Philadelphia to take on a quantity of bulk grain.

A public offering of 150,000 shares of common stock of Mack Trucks, Inc., and an offering to stockholders of 211,861 shares of capital stock of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation will be made today by underwriting groups.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 -- The British commercial mission that is here to seek an over-all settlement of pending financial problems with Argentina this morning met Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, who will represent President Juan D. Peron in negotiations beginning tomorrow at 10 A.M. Sir Clive Latham Baillieu is head of the British group.

LONDON, Dec. 2 -- An exhaustive survey of Greek natural resources and economy by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation mission to Athens states that an expenditure of $558,000,000 in Greece over the next fifteen years would completely revamp her national economy and could make the nation self-sustaining, it became known today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 2 (Canadian Press) -- Jimmy McFadden, Detroit's prize rookie, made the most headway in an otherwise lean week for National Hockey League marksmen, and today the Irishborn center finds himself in a firstplace tie with Montreal's Maurice Richard, each with 21 points.

The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: What can you do with veal shoulder or neck? Today's Peace Plate tells the satisfying story, presenting a well-seasoned, tender veal stew with vegetables.

YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Trusteeship Council Named Australia, Britain, China, France, Mexico and United States to working group on Jerusalem statute and discussed suggested changes in rules of procedure. Subcommittee on drafting petitions drafted resolution embodying views of Council relating to petitions from Tanganyika.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- BritishSoviet trade talks, broken off last summer, will reopen as soon as Harold Wilson, President of Britain's Board of Trade, can reach Moscow, he disclosed today.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Dec. 2 -- Josiah E. Cass, last surviving member of Wisconsin's famous Iron Brigade of the Civil War, died at a hospital here last night at the age of 100. He never joined the Grand Army of the Republic.

Much less aggressive mill dem for cotton futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday caused prices to drop from the new high levels established in the early trading, and final prices were 35 points lower to 15 points higher than the day before.

Large orders for scarce chemicals, containers and machinery were placed yesterday by leading industrial buyers attending the 21st Exposition of the Chemical Industries at Grand Central Palace, exhibitors revealed. John D. Halford of Carpenter Container Corporation, Brooklyn, disclosed that more than 50 per cent of the orders taken by his company, most of which exceeded expectations, came from new accounts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- There are several easy explanations why Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont got only a shred of support among Republicans in Congress for his call on National Chairman B. Carroll Reece to resign. One is that Mr. Reece is working hard and effectively at his job, was at the helm in the victory of 1946 and is satisfactory to the organization.

Several hundred members of society, including many patrons of music, danced to the music of seventy-five members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton at a winter ball given to augment the Philharmonic's pension fund.

A jubilant and excited crowd overflowed the Manhattan Center last night to celebrate the United Nations vote for a Jewish state in Palestine. The meeting was under the auspices of the Zionist Organization of America.

A child learns discipline only in an atmosphere where adults practice it among themselves, Miss Judith Cauman, director of the Hamilton School, told seventy members of Ivriah yesterday at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel. Miss Cauman was the first lecturer in a series of eight bi-weekly discussions on "Children Need Roots to Grow," sponsored by the organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 2 -- The United Nations has begun an organization-wide tightening of its budget strings and has sent dismissal notices to the first of more than 800 employes who will be dropped by January, it was learned today.

HAVANA, Dec. 2 -- Charging an attempt by United States capitalism to impose its economic system on a World that wants, socialism, Dr. Diego Luis Molinari told the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today that the Argentine delegation, of which he is the head, refused to accept as a "fait accompli" the charter for the proposed International Trade Organization drafted last summer at Geneva.

Twenty miniature rooms, representing historical periods of several nations, went on exhibition yesterday in the galleries of Portraits, Inc., 460 Park Avenue, for the benefit of the Wellesley College Seventy-fifth Anniversary Fund.

Heads ANA Radio Council Thomas H. Brown Jr. has been appointed executive head of the Association of National Advertisers' radio council, according to joint announcement yesterday by A.N. Halverstadt, council chairman, and Paul B. West, ANA president.

As a "minimum program," the Federal Reserve Board should abandon all stated or implied commitments to hold yields on United States Government securities at specific levels, J. Stewart Baker, chairman of the board of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Profits, far more than increased wages, are responsible for the cost of living being at the highest level the United States has ever known, Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach told the House Banking Committee today.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- John B. Garrison, former Harvard ice star who has been appointed by the American Hockey Association to coach the United States Olympic hockey team, today announced the names of 20 men who will make up the squad from which the sextet will be selected.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Dec. 2 -- A panel of four, three of them natives of Greece, agreed today in the "What's On Your Mind?" forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES, broadcast over WQXR from, the Hackensack Woman's Club, that although American policy in Greece had not yet restored peace and democracy, it was on the right track.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 AP -- Murray Taylor, counsel for the Standard Power and Light Corporation, announced tonight that he will be in Wilmington, Del., tomorrow morning to vote his company's holdings of common stock in its subsidiary, the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

ROME, Dec. 2 -- News from Washington that the United States Army would be willing to give the Italian Government military "assistance and advice" if requested, exploded like a bomb in Leftist circles here today. Most Left Wing leaders refused to believe there was any truth in it.

Negotiations for the construction of two new passenger liners for the Mediterranean service are under way between officials of the American Export Line and the Maritime Commission, a spokesman for the ship line said last night.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 2 -- Rumanian Communist leaders today stepped up their campaign against church elements, especially the Roman Catholics, that did not support the present regime 100 per cent.

It is interesting and encouraging to note that the Investment Bankers Association has placed the European aid program high on the agenda of its annual convention. Edward Hopkinson Jr., president of the association, gave the subject major attention in his keynote address, declaring that "the tensions and uncertainties of our foreign relations" make it a logical and important point on which to concentrate discussion at this time.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 2 -- A new type of chemical process by which life-saving drugs and other modern miracles of the chemist's laboratory may be produced with greater ease and speed, was reported today before the American Society of Mechanical Engineers by Dr. M.C. Shaw, assistant professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The achievements of the Advertising Council in stimulating the American public to act on matters of national importance are the basis of a half-hour recorded dramatization, which more than 1,000 stations throughout the country are to broadcast on or after Dec. 10.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Notwithstanding Britain's foggy weather and the general austerity, Oscac Hammerstein 2d is finding nothing but cheer and good news on his week's stay in England.
