WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A Treasury order permitting Great Britain to draw upon the $400,000,000 remaining under the Anglo -American financial agreement was in preparation today after a secret discussion by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder with the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

The challenge to American industry to maintain high prosperity through high production to be able to aid Europe and demonstrate to opposing collectivist systems the worth of private enterprise will be studied at the fifty-second annual Congress of American Industry opening today.

Business is in a secondary postwar boom that promises to last for months, a business and a financial economist agreed yesterday at a session before the National Association of Manufacturers devoted to the economic outlook.

Dr. and Mrs. Carl F.Cori, joint winners of one-half of the 1947 Nobel Prize in Medicine, who next Wednesday will receive from King Gustav of Sweden, the traditional Nobel scroll and a check for approximately $25,000, left La Guardia Field for Stockholm, yesterday aboard a Scandinavia Airlines System plane.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Bishop Paul N. Garber of the Geneva, Switzerland, area, reported today to the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church at its opening session here that the real threat to religious freedom in Europe is from political regimes such as that of Franco Spain "where protestantism is not granted religious freedom."

Public demand has increased that the medical profession's previous "inattention" to anesthesiology be directed toward making surgery "safe" for the 9,000,000 Americans, or one in fifteen, who undergo it each year, specialists asserted yesterday.

PIERRE, S.D., Dec. 3 -- The Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee formulated a guide for an accelerated six-year program in the basin today, but it was considerably broader than had been expected by the five Federal agencies dealing with flood control, navigation, hydro-electric power and irrigation.

THE most stimulating discussion of what man can still do to avoid blowing himself and his world to smithereens that has come this way in a long time is Cord Meyer Jr.'s "Peace or Anarchy."* Mr. Meyer is a young ex-marine who saw a good deal of combat in the Pacific and was severely wounded in action. He was one of Harold Stassen's assistants at the San Francisco Conference.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- Fears that a strike of fuel truck drivers in Yonkers may spread to threaten the oil and coal supplies of thousands of Westchester homes, apartments and office buildings were voiced today by a spokesman for the Westchester Allied Trades Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, wife of the General of the Army, and Mrs. Carl Spaatz, wife of the Commanding General of the Air Forces, have added their names to that of Mrs. De Witt C. Ramsey, wife of Admiral Ramsey, United States Navy, on the lengthening list of sponsors of Stateless Children's Sanctuary, Inc.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- French diplomacy, which, has been enacting at increasingly positive role during the six meetings of the Council of Foreign Ministers, now is commencing strongly to advocate the formation of a Western German state with its capital at Frankfort on the Main should the present session fail -- as most observers reluctantly predict.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The United States contingent of some 500 athletes competing in twenty sports will leave July 14 aboard the S.S. America for the 1948 Olympic Games at London, July 29Aug. 14.

A clothespin "angel" wearing a paper napkin dress and tin foil wings smiled from the top of a small white tree yesterday at the women and children, who were learning how to make Christmas gifts and ornaments from household scraps.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A court attack on the provision of the Taft-Hartley Act covering the filing of non-Communist affidavits was started today by the National Maritime Union, CIO.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 3 -- Pillage, arson and assault continued in Palestine today as the Arabs rejected a peace plea from the British.
PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 4 -- The struggle between the Government and Communist-led strikers suddenly grew much more violent yesterday in many parts of France.

The cloud of gloom hanging over the London Conference assumed a darker hue yesterday when, after only eight days of discussion, Mr. Molotov proposed that all further consideration of the German peace treaty be postponed for another two months. On French objection he backed down on this proposal.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The State Department's official "Voice of America" radio broadcast overseas in twenty-three languages tonight a report of "a wave of panic buying" in Moscow and other Soviet Russian cities.
Thursday, Dec. 4, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Trusteeship Council Completed general debate on report of visiting mission, to Western Samoa.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The British Government, it was learned today, has told the United States that it intends to terminate its League of Nations mandate over Palestine in May of 1948.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Arthur Creech Jones, Colonial Secretary, sale today that the present British troops and perhaps an even augmented personnel would be responsible for law and order in Palestine until the mandate was surrendered.

Imported Scotch whiskies and brandies will be from 31 to 39 cents a bottle lower in price after Jan. 1, when new tariff rates going into effect make it possible for importers to pass along these entire savings to beverage consumers; trade spokesmen revealed "here yesterday.

Fines totaling $1,440,000 were imposed yesterday by Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan upon a war-born textile company and two officers who extended priority ratings to obtain at least 3,350,000 yards of cotton and rayon goods. The illegally obtained textiles were sold later to at least sixty manufacturers for $1,015,423 above ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Jesse Jones, former Secretary of Commerce and head of the Federal Reconstruction Finance Corporation for thirteen years, volunteered today to testify before a Congressional subcommittee investigating wartime expenditures of the RFC.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -- Rod "E. Geiger, associate producer of the Italian film, "Open City," announced today that he has registered a priority with the Producers Association on Herman MeZville's novel, "Moby Dick," which is in the public domain.

The singing of sea chanteys and trading of salty tales were unofficial orders of business last night at the New York Athletic Club, where alumni of the maritime schoolship St. Mary's between the years of 1883 and 1908 held their annual reunion.

Thursday, Dec. 4, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Tbe president Left at 8'A. M. by plane for Key West, Fla. Tbe Senate Not in session. Banking and Currency Committee heard Robert R. Nathan, economist, testify price roll-back might have deterrent effect on new wage demands by organized labor.

The reduced demand for shipping space on American-flag vessels operating on foreign trade routes is reflected in the sharp decrease in the number of Government-owned ships under bareboat charter to private companies, according to statistics issued yesterday by the Maritime Commission.
LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Dec. 3 (AP) -- King Michael of Rumania said today that there was "absolutely nothing" to Copenhagen reports of his engagement to Princess Anne of Bourbon-Parma.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Not Forgetting China" you have given some excellent reasons why aid to Europe should have priority. I like the way you argue the case.

Justin Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, asserted yesterday that among broadcasters "there is greater understanding and more complete good-will toward the adoption of standards than there ever has been before." He spoke at a joint meeting of the Radio Executives Club and the Advertising Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Revised methods of pricing which might result in lower consumer prices, far greater volume, more promotions in the corset department and greater savings to the manufacturers were suggested last night by Prank A. Cohen of Bifley Foundations, Inc., president of the Associated Corset and Brassiere Manufacturers, Inc., at the annual meeting of the group at the Hotel Astor.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Charges of gambling against five Hoboken men, among them James Chirichella, secretary to Mayor Fred M. DeSapio of that city, were dropped today by the Hudson County Prosecutor's office after the Hudson County Grand Jury refused to hand up indictments in the case.

CARSON Cmr, Nev., Dec. (AP) -- A temporary injunction was issued today, blocking a three-way merger designed to create a new giant in the petroleum industry as W. G. Skelly, Tulsa, Okla., oil man, won the first skirmish in a court battle with the J. Paul Getty interests of Los Angeles.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -- The United States must not wait until an emergency period, when costs would be excessively high, to establish plants for the production of synthetic liquid fuels needed to supplement the natural crude oil reserves in this country, W.C. Schroeder said here today.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- The foremost political leader among India's 6,000,000 Sikhs, Master Tara Singh, today predicted a war between India and Pakistan "in six months or not more than a year."

A program to reduce the inflationary pressure on prices and thus make unnecessary a third round of general wage increase was presented yesterday to American industry by Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 3 -- President Truman came to Florida today for sleep and relaxation and made good on both counts after his arrival at the naval submarine base here.

Jack Bigel, president of the New York District of the United Public Workers, CIO, denied yesterday that his union exercised Communist domination of relief and added that the only line it followed was the policy line of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The New York Central System, through its assistant general passenger agent, J. Russell Grant, yesterday announced good tidings to metropolitan skiers in the form of a comprehensive schedule of "snow trains" to operate this winter. For the devotees who thrill to winter sports at Bear Mountain Park, the Catskills, Berkshjres and Green Mountains, the news that special coach trains again will leave to those popular areas.

HAVANA, Dec. 10 -- Walter Stucki of Switzerland was elected one of the seven vice presidents of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today. rhia completed the election of officers that had remained unfinished because Mr. Stucki had said he could not serve in view of the conference decision that withheld voting rights from Switzerland and other non-members of the United Nations.

Vivian Rivkin, pianist, who gave a recital last night at Town Hall, has often played to better purpose in this city. Her performances in the past have always been filled with vitality, but at this latest appearance there was little else to commend them, except in the set of Shostakovich "Preludes" presented as" a final offering, which proved the redeeming feature of the evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers (CIO) asked today for a revision of wage-and-hour regulations to require overtime pay rates for all salaried employes who earn less than $500 a month.

Directors of the Empire, Steel Corporation of' Mansfield, Ohio, yesterday authorized sale of the company's assets, subject to approval of stockholders, to the Studebaker Corporation for $7,430,000 according to an announcement by J. M. Hill, chairman of the steel company, whose principal products, are not-rolled terne and electrical sheets.

Declared eligible to play only two days ago, Bob Mulvihill made the difference in the Fordham basketball squad that launched its season with a 51-49 victory over Iona College of New Rochelle last night at the Rose Hill gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Price controls will be required on meat by next spring, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson assured the House Banking Committee today. He qualified his prediction only by the proviso "unless there is an unexpected falling off in demand."

TOKYO, Dec. 3 -- Coal mine labor today heard Gen. Douglas MacArthur's threat that it must produce more coal or lose its special rations. No longer will special incentive goods be delivered to miners who work only two or three hours daily.

The time-honored referee protest cropped up yesterday In connection with the world heavyweight title bout between Champion Joe Louis and the Camden, N.J., challenger, Jersey Joe Walcott, to be waged tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The State Federation of Labor, acting through its executive council, voted today to seek increases in workmen's compensation and unemployment insurance benefits at the next session of the Legislature.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov astonished the three other delegates at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers this afternoon by suddenly and inexplicably suggesting that their four Governments should submit separate proposals for the preparation of a German peace treaty within two months.

One did not have to agree with every interpretation given by Alexander Brailowsky, the pianist at his recital last night in Carnegie Hall to perceive his constantly increasing power of projecting a musical concept over the footlights. Mr. Brailowsky's musician-ship and resources of a virtuoso are now taken for granted.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Chicago's vastly improved Black Hawks provided the National Hockey League's Boston public with its fastest action of the season by coming from behind to gain a 4-4 tie with the Bruins tonight before 13,900 at the Garden. Bud Poile established the deadlock while the Bruins were playing short-handed with but two minutes remaining.

Streptomycin can challenge penicillin as the No. 1 antibiotic because the former has proved beneficial in treatment of tuberculosis and other devastating human diseases that previously had not been touched by any direct drug action, Dr. H. Corwin Hinshaw of the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn., told 1,000 chemical engineers last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 3 -- Attachments totaling $260,000 have been filed on the real estate of Cass Gilbert Jr. of Maple Avenue, this place, prominent New York architect, in connection with damage suits being filed as a result of a traffic accident last Friday in Wilton, Conn., in which he drove into the rear of a hayride, injuring twenty-eight persons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Prospects of Congressional approval of President Truman's request far power to curb speculation on commodity markets were cast into extreme doubt today as the country's principal grain exchanges completed a two-day counteroffensive before a Senate-House committee.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board asked the Supreme Court today to sustain a board order directing that reinstatement and back pay be given a foreman who was discharged for activity in a foremen's union before the Taft-Hartley Act took effect.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Relief from traffic congestion equal to the vehicular capacity of five midManhattan crosstown streets when the Union Bus Terminal, scheduled to open in early 1949 in New York City, is in operation was predicted by Nathan Cherniack, expert of the Port of New York Authority, tonight at the annual meeting of the National Highway Research Board here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 3 -- Close finishes marked the play in the national contract bridge tournament here today as men's teams-of-four and women's teams-of-four competed in the first of two session for the championships in their classes.

The nation's gasoline stocks were increased an additional 1,542,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 86,319,000 barrels, compared with 84,777,000 a week earlier and 88,619,000 on Nov. 30, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 26:

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 3 (UP) -- President George Trautman told minor league club owners in his report at the opening of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues convention today that organized baseball was doing an outstanding job in combating a gambling evil which for a time threatened to cause loss of public confidence in some areas.

The one vital stumbling block to Leo Durocher's return as the 1948 manager of the Dodgers -- the lack of full approval by Commissioner Albert B. (Happy) Chandler -- has been removed, Branch Rickey president of the Dodgers, made clear last night.
Some Manhattan taverns closed yesterday as an outgrowth of the dispute between owners and bartenders, but enough, stayed open to keep the borough from taking on any resemblance to the Sahara.

The need for doctors in physical medicine for the Veterans Administration "continues to be acute," and there probably will be shortages in this field for the next four or five years, Dr. A. Ray Dawson, assistant medical director of the VA's Physical Medicine Rehabilitation Service, declared here yesterday.
Bids will be opened on Dec. 10 on $1,940,000 of Richmond, Va., public improvement bonds, not exceeding 3 per cent, dated Jan. 1, 1948, and maturing Jan. 1, 1949 to 1968.

Soviet Russia is now attempting to conquer France and Italy by internal fifth, columns and China by the Chinese Communist armies, so that it can eventually mobilize both Europe and Asia against us, William C. Bullitt charged last night.

Export credit on orders from Latin-American countries, with some exceptions, continues to tighten, reports indicated yesterday at the meeting of the Foreign Credit Interchange Bureau at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 3 (AP) -- American, British, Greek and other foreign establishments were damaged today by students demonstrating for the third successive day against the United Nations' decision to partition Palestine.

Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin, president of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, Inc., declared yesterday that the "world has the responsibility to provide arms and equipment" needed by Jews to defend their newlycreated Jewish state against "Arab provocateurs."

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 3 -- Replying to the Government's request for proof of its contention that newsprint used for newspaper advertising is no more dutiable than that used for news, the Prensa insisted today that Argentine law supported that contention and that it had always obeyed the law.

The stock market moved yesterday into lower ground as offerings increased, especially in those issues recently favored for speculative reasons. It was the first set-back of the week, with the price average lowered 0.67 point on the day and the industrials showing" heavier losses. Dealings on the Stock Exchange rose to 920,000 shares, largest in a week, compared with Tuesday's turnover of 850,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Strong indications arose today that much of organized labor and some of its backers had determined upon a policy of pointedly suggesting in effect to Congress that early action toward driving back prices might soften the declared insistence for third-round wage increases.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The House Rules Committee agreed unanimously today to allow a 590,000,000 authorization for emergency winter relief to France, Italy, Austria and China to go to the floor for consideration, starting at 11 A.M. tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- A behind-the-scenes row between State Department officials and the Army appeared to be shaping up tonight over a high Army officr's prediction that Russia would use civil war in Palestine as an excuse to seize a bridgehead on the Mediterranean.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- A comprehensive "declaration of Protestant strategy" relating to the role of Christian education in the community is being prepared here by 250 religious educators, ministers and lay church-workers attending a national conference on the Community and Religious Education, it was learned today.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 3 -- The convention of Investment Bankers of America here was told

Within the last few years great advances have been made in surgical techniques. One of the most spectacular of these advances has been in the utilization of the corneal tissue from the eyes of the dead for transplantation to the eyes of the living in certain types of eye disorders.

The Eye-Bank for Sight Restoration, Inc., reporting on its second year, announced yesterday that hospital affiliations in the United States had grown to 150, that contributions through membership support had increased 50 per cent and that affiliate eye-banks had been established in Boston and New Orleans.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The stock markets here today were "heavy," the latest Palestine developments causing a further shrinkage of business.
St. John's and City College will face basketball opponents from the Rocky Mountain area in a twin bill at Madison Square Garden tonight.

An anti-Communist group opposed to the present leadership of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, obtained yesterday a Supreme Court order requiring the union to show cause why it should not be prevented from holding its biennial election for New York local officers tomorrow.

Reacting to criticism from the clergy and other sources both within and outside the trade, the Motion Picture Association of America announced yesterday new and stronger regulations to prevent the glorification of crime and criminals on the screen and to guard against the presentation of other subject material that might be regarded as offensive to good taste.

The knack of giving an appealing new twist to simple silhouettes was characteristic of the hat collection presented yesterday by Irene of New York at her salon at 16 East Fifty-second Street. This was the first of this designer's work to be shown to the press.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 3 -- An emphatic declaration by the military tribunal that the population of Germany generaly and the defendants in particular realized fully the extent and extremities of Nazi cruelties in concentration camps highlighted today's reading of the first half of the judgment in the trial of former "officials of the Reich Ministry of Justice.

Plans of reorganization for the St. Lawrence Corporation, Ltd., and the St. Lawrence Paper Mills Company, Ltd., Canadian concerns, have been drafted by directors of the companies and a special committee of stockholders, it was announced yesterday.

Msgr. John J. Corrigan, director of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin at Mount Loretto, S. I., outlined yesterday during a habeas corpus action before Supreme Court Justice J. Edward Lumbard some of his reasons for objecting to the release of two children now in the care of the mission so that they might join their parents in Soviet Armenia.

Sherman Billingsley, whose munificence as owner of the Stork Club has made him a legendary figure in the city's night life, was depicted yesterday as a man prepared to spend $20,000,000 to "buy" the union that was seeking to organize his kitchen employes.

Loading operations aboard the United States Lanes freighter American Leader, which will be the first American-flag vessel to carry "Friendship Food" to France, started yesterday at 1 P. M., as about 150 longshoremen opened her five hatches and began moving 5,000,000 pounds of assorted foodstuffs into the ship.

Post Cereals Men Named Three men have been added to the advertising staff of the Post Cereals division of General Foods Corporation, according to announcement yesterday by Clarence ELdridge, general manager of the division.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Commission on Life Adjustment Education for Youth, in its first press conference today, envisaged a drastically changed, closer-toreal-life high-school curriculum.

MIAMI, Pla., Dec. 3 -- Branch Rickey Jr. today set the record straight on the status of Dixie Walker of the Dodgers. Brooklyn's popular outfielder was invited some time ago to accept the management of the St. Paul farm but declined.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A move by state and territorial health officers to secure the transfer of health functions of the Children's Bureau to the Public Health Service by administrative action will be made tomorrow, it was authoritatively learned today.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State Marshall's Republican adviser, will leave for Paris tomorrow for a brief visit, where he will try to assess the status of the French domestic crisis and its effect on United States plans.
GENEVA, Dec. 10 -- The United Nations Subcommission on Minorities and Discrimination rejected today Russian proposals to investigate the Negro problem in the United States.

The higher Interest rate on prime commercial loans just established by the Bankers Trust Company will undoubtedly be adopted in the near future by other leading banks here, it was reported yesterday. Marking the first upward revision in such rates in about a dozen years, the Bankers Trust Company on Tuesday announced that effective Dec. 15 its rate would be increased from 1% per cent to 1% per cent.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Grain markets made a weak start and a strong finish on the Board of Trade today. Corn led the upturn and finished 2 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday and oats were up 11/2 to 2 1/4 cents. Wheat was under pressure early, but rallied later and gained 3/4 to 1 3/4 cents.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- In drafting the European Recovery Program for the regular session of Congress in January, differences of opinion over basic details have naturally arisen. Many of these appear as generalities in the various group reports made to the President and to Congress.

Congress will examine each of President Truman's anti-inflationary proposals carefully. Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House, told the National Association of Manufacturers yesterday.

A $28,000,000 issue of 3 1/8 per cent thirty-year first mortgage bonds of the Appalachian Electric Power Company will be offered publicly today by Kuhn, Loeb Co. and the Union Securities Corporation. The bonds, priced at 100 1/2 and accrued interest, to yield 3.10 per cent to maturity, were awarded to the underwriters at competitive sale on a bid of 100.10.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Charles Luckman, who has resigned as chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, stressed in a final interview today the "tremendous urgency of the long-range food problem." He will return to Boston and to the presidency of Lever Brothers tomorrow.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 3 -- If America is to contribute effectively to the recovery of Europe some measure of price control and other anti-inflation measures will have to be taken here, Dr. John M. Cassels, economist of the United States Department of Commerce, told the Investment Bankers Association in convention here today.

It was back to work for the Football Yankees yesterday. Gfranted a two-day respite from practice as a reward for clinching the All-America Conference's Eastern Division title last Sunday, the Bronx Bombers were full of fire on resuming their daily chores at the Stadium.

Benjamin Fielding,Welfare Commissioner, declared yesterday that he would confer with "all New York City members of the State Legislature before it convenes in January to acquaint them regarding continuation of the child daycare program."

Tenants who voluntarily agree to pay rent increases should receive the same "protection" under the Federal rent control law as those who refuse to do so, the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee declared yesterday.
Santa Claus will remember 4,500 children this Christmas with gifts provided by employes of the New York Telephone Company.

Top bad the Toronto Maple Leafs had to spoil Lester Patrick's party last night. The former manager of the Nevr York Bangers was honored with the presentation of a scroll to hockey's Hall of Fame before the Leafs and the Rangers went into action at Madison Square Garden.

WARSAW, Dec. 3 -- Six members of the coordination committee of the all-Polish Underground forces and Mrs. Maria Marynowska of the British Embassy staff here went on trial today on charges of treason and espionage. Once again the Polish Government's complaints involved Arthur Bliss Lane and Victor Cavendish-Bentinck, former United States and British Ambassadors respectively.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Paris correspondent reported recently that the railway strike order demands a minimum pay of 10,800 francs a month, which, in parentheses, you calculate to be equal to $91.26. This habit of translating francs into dollars at the official rate of exchange gives a completely false notion of what is going on in France.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 3 -- The Standard Power and Light Corporation sent a representative here today to vote its stock holdings in its subsidiary, the Standard Gas and Electric Company, in an effort to force a court test of the validity of an order by the Securities and Exchange Commission postponing the annual meeting of Standard Gas.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- American realtors have saved the public millions of dollars by setting up a recommended schedule of commission fees that eliminate the once common practice of "charging all the traffic will bear" for brokerage services, C. Arinel Nutter, of Camden, regional vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, declared tonight.
GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- The strikes in France have given a serious but not so far fatal setback to the effort to meet the industrial and power targets underlying the European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of defense, stated today that military-planning must be put on a long-range basis over "a period of years" and freed from the uncertainties of year-toyear appropriations.

The Board of Estimate will have before it today a report by Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson recommending $36,320 in salary rises for seventeen high-ranking city officials, including nine commissioners. Favorable action on the report was indicated last night after it had been considered by the board in executive session.

CLARKSVILLB, N. J., Dec. 3 -- The first field exercise of the Metropolitan Feather Dusters Club was carried out today without single casualty among the members and with what might very well be termed a "minor decrease" in the pheasant population of June Murray's Deep Meadow pheasant preserve.

Articles 43 to 47 of the United Nations Charter provide for the creation of what would in effect be an International Police Force. Contrary to a widespread popular belief on this point, it was never intended by the authors of the Charter that this Police Force should be powerful enough to make war upon a great Power, if that Power should be guilty of aggression.
An Army transport was renamed here yesterday in honor of a Congressional Medal of Honor winner who gave his life while serving with the Army in France on June 9, 1944.
The campaign to enlist 10,000 citizen reserves from New York in the Marines was extended yesterday into all city departments Bind bureaus.

A seller's market for many important chemicals and chemical equipment lines will continue into 1948, exhibitors at the twenty-first exposition of the chemical industries, at Grand Central Palace, revealed here yesterday. Despite large scale increases of capacity at new plants throughout the country, shortages of materials exist extensively throughout the industry, they said.

Because scientific management has not been adequately applied to distribution, a bottleneck has developed in the past under "horseand-buggy methods" of marketing, A. Edwin Fein, general manager, Research Company of America, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follow: HOGS Salable hogs, 13,000 head; total 22,500. Market opened about steady on butchers, but trade later was very slow and mostly 25 cents lower than Tuesday's average, with an estimated 2,000 head unsold;

Traveler Headed North A fellow we know with the unlikely name of Balboa Prawn came by the other day wearing a parka and a look of determination. He had with him also a pair of snowshoes, several cans of pemmican, and a dozen tins of a certain British pipe tobacco guaranteed to remain fresh in any climate.

PARIS, Dec. 3 -- The report or Jean Monnet, Director of the Planning Commission, on the first six months of his program for French modernization and production, today noted important progress toward its" objectives and called attention to the grave drop in coal output since April. That was the last month of Communist participation in the Government.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 3 -- The nation's railroads asked Federal approval today of freight rate increases averaging 30 per cent over those in effect last July and designed to raise revenues more than $2,000,000,000 on the basis of 1947 traffic volume.

Ranch Mink Has 10% Advance Ranch mink had a top of $32 for Yukon darks and $34 for halfbloods at the first auction of new season pelts held yesterday by Lampaon, Fraser Huth. Prices were up 10 per cent over December, 1946, levels.

Opponents of the St. Lawrence Seaway believe their case has been strengthened by the report filed on Monday by Gov. J. C. Mehaffey of the Panama Canal Zone, advocating a sea-level system in Panama and declaring that a locksystem canal could be put out of operation perhaps permanently by a single atom bomb.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 -- Although the Poles took a parting shot at the United States as a "monopolistic warmonger," the General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation closed today with most of the delegates satisfied that peace could be promoted through their efforts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Notre Dame's undefeated, untied football warriors rolled out of rain-andsnow-swept Chicago tonight for Los Angeles to engage Southern California Saturday in what Coach Frank Leahy expects to be Notre Dame's toughest game of the 1947 campaign.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- The appointment of Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, director of the United Nations Trusteeship Division, to be chief of the secretariat accompanying the Palestine Commission was confirmed today by Trygve Lie, secretary general of the world organization.

If American families were actually to do their homes over twice in a lifetime, manufacturers of furniture and floor coverings would have to produce 40 per cent more units than they do at their peak today, T. Hart Anderson of Anderson, Davis Platte, Inc., advertising agency, declared yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer's radio talk tomorrow disclosing in detail his 1948 legislative program, including the plan for a fare rise on municipal transit lines, will be carried by eight stations, it was announced yesterday at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The National Advisory Council, which makes the Government's financial policy, has taken the position that Congress should not be asked to provide a $3,000,000,000 stabilization fund to support European currenotes under the Marshall plan.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 3 -- The assassination last night of Chang Duk Soo, 55-year-old leader of the moderate Right Democratic party, was carried out by two men dressed in metropolitan police uniforms, it was learned today. They were among a group that summoned Mr. Chang, a graduate of Columbia University, to his door and shot him down there.

Educating foreign manufacturers about their exporit opportunities in the United States has become one of the most important functions of American foreign field representatives, E. E. Schnellbacher, director of special services and intelligence branch of the Office of International Trade, Department of Commerce, revealed yesterday.

As much a part of Christmas as good St. Nick and his tiny reindeer are the star-shaped cookies, the steaming plum pudding and the rich fruit cake that, baking in the oven during the days before the festivities, fill the kitchen with such delightful aromas.

In the Milgrim collection .presented yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel the practical mingled with the glamorous. Suits and dresses were keyed to daily wear for the South, while evening dresses were designed for dining and dancing under warm skies and for formal holiday occasions in New York.

American Metal Products The American Metal Products Company declared an extra dividend of 25 cents and a regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents on, common, both payable Dec. 30. This makes a total of $2 for the year cpmpared with 60 cents in 1946.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Britain backed the French proposal for a settlement of the Soviet claims in Austria in the Council of Foreign Ministers today and disclaimed any special status for herself or her citizens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Treasury suggested today that Congress take away at least part of the tax exemption given officers of the armed services who are retired for disability.

A group of private citizens, concerned about the welfare of members of the police and fire departments who retired before 1940, got together yesterday to do something about increasing the pensions of these former city employes, who receive from $200 to $50O a year.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and, save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: There's many a trick with thrifty luncheon meat, as proved by today's Peace Plate. The main dish is a scalloped combination, bringing together luncheon meat and oysters, now in season and fine in quality.

Because of the fire that virtually destroyed the laboratories and museum of the George Washington Carver Foundation at Tuskegee Institute, Ala., last month, an effort will be made to raise at least $500,000 more than the $2,000,000 already fixed as the goal of an endowment campaign, it was announced here yesterday.

The high price of butter, moving toward the $1-a-pound mark in retail stores here, had even the wholesalers worried yesterday. The Department of Markets reported a price range of 89 to 97 cents in this city, with 93 cents the most general price.

THE ventilation system at Madison Square Garden probably has cleared the air of any lingering fumes from the LaMotta-Fox bout. But if any of them should remain, a gust of good, wholesome and clean air is due to sweep through the hall tomorrow. Joe Louis, as invigorating and refreshing as a cool breeze on a suitry summer's day, will whisk majestically into the arena for the twenty-fourth defense of his world heavy weight championship.

Market Situation Brokers generally hold to the opinion that on the basis of current earnings, many recent declines in individual stocks can hardly be justified. At this season, year-end tax selling, which frequently has little relation to investment values, can cause unusual recessions in fundamentally wellintrenched stocks.
After a poor start, the cotton futures market oil the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered all early losses and closed 10 to 25 points net higher.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 3 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Council started debate today on proposals for granting greater self-government to the residents of Western Samoa, now administered by New Zealand as a trust territory.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Dec. 3 -- The high priest of hyperbole has settled down in his old home town. Old rocking chair's got him.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- A new source of agitation arose today in Milan, which was the scene of serious disturbances last week. The local Steel Workers Federation and Chamber of Labor demanded that the Government take over three manufacturing companies on the ground that they had "deliberately sabotaged production."

On Nov. 4, 1941, the late Peter V. Cacchione, running in Brooklyn under the designation of Communist, won a seat in the City Council with 48,536 votes. On Nov. 2, 1943, again running as a Communist, he was re-elected with 69,149 votes, more ballots than were received by any other candidate in Brooklyn except Joseph T. Sharkey, Democrat.

Tennessee Williams has brought us a superb drama, "A Streetcar Named Desire," which was acted at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. And Jessica Tandy gives a superb performance as rueful heroine whose misery Mr. Williams is tenderly recording.

ATHENS, Dec. 3 -- Because he feels the United States mission and other United States officials with whom he has dealt here have failed to grasp the full extent and nature of Greece's peril and the urgent needs of her armed forces, Premier Themosticles Sophoulis is sending Sophocles Venizelos to the United States as his personal emissary.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Gulfstream Park's two days of enforced idleness was ended late today when President James Donn and some 200 horse owners reached a compromise agreement on the increase of minimum purses and daily distribution.

A Broadway revival at Marc Blitzstein's "The Cradle Will Rock"' was assured last night as the composer and the New Theatre settled their differences. Under the new arrangement, the play with music will be produced on the Main Stern by Michael Myerberg in association with the New Theatre.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Committee today threatened to withdraw all of this nation's teams from the 1948 winter games if the Swiss organizing committee adhered to its preference for the ice hockey entry of the "professional and commercial" Amateur Hockey Association, but that drastic step seemed unlikely in immediate reactions to the ultimatum.

Washington dispatches yesterday included two stories bearing on the wage aspects of the inflation problem. One told of a meeting of the vice presidents of the CIO at which it was decided that this group, with its 6,000,000 workers, would "lead labor's fight for a third round of wage increases since the end of the war."

MANILA, Dec. 3 -- The United States and Philippines delegations plumped for regional self-help among the Asiatic nations in a jointly sponsored resolution presented to the Economic Commission for the Far East and Asia at Baguio as a concomitant to any financial assistance that the United States might extend in what has been locally designated as a Marshall plan for Asia.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Par didn't mean a thing to the nation's top golfers today as they opened the winter season with the first round of the $10,000 Orlando open over the Dubsdread Country Club course.

A Case of Larceny Hezekiah Cobb said it was an old saying down in his part of the country that March steals days from April. What has happened in this year which defies all Robert's rules of order is that December has been stealing from November days that rogue of a month must have snitched in the first place from October.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor took the unprecedented action of today recommending that a voluntary fund of several million dollars be raised by its members to advance the cause of labor to the forthcoming political campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A number of influential officials and members of Congress in Washington are increasingly afraid that, despite all its efforts, the United States may lose the battle for production and recovery in western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Leakage of gasoline was blamed officially today for the fires which broke out recently on two DC-6 airplanes, causing one to crash near Bryce Canyon, Utah, and another to make a forced landing at Gallup, N.M.

WASHINGTON Dec. 4 -- The White House sent to the Senate today for confirmation the new temporary ranks of thirteen Air Force general officers assigned to high positions on Oct. 1 during the recess of Congress. The list included one four-star general, Hoyt S. Vandenberg, vice chief of staff; seven new lieutenant generals and two new major generals, and three brigadier generals.
The annual Holiday Fair at the Museum of Modern Art is open for boys and girls 4 to 8 years old.

PARIS, Friday, Dec. 5 -- While strikers held virtual possession of Nice and the first deaths from bullets in this strike wave were reported from Valence, the leaders of seven of the eleven federations of Government employes voted early today to call a two-day "warning strike" for Monday and Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The United States has requested the Soviet Government to facilitate the departure to this country of persons in Russia who claim American citizenship and of Russian women married to American citizens, but the request has been without result thus far, the State Department reported today.

President Truman will issue next week the proclamation putting the new United States tariff rates under the Geneva trade pacts into effect on Jan. 1, it was revealed yesterday by Winthrop G. Brown, Chief of the Division of Commercial Policy of the State Department, at a meeting here sponsored by the Commerce and Industry Association.

"The future of industry and investment is linked inseparably with what is happening to people and the business they produce," Donald B. Woodward, second vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

While emphasizing that Zionism was "neither communistic nor capitalistic," Rabbi Meyer Berlin of Jerusalem, president of the World Mizrachi Organization, religious wing of the World Zionist Organization, urged Soviet Russia yesterday to permit Jewish communities within that country to participate in the upbuilding of the newly created Jewish state.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ahmed Pasha Larawi, Director General of Foreign Affairs, was reported officially today to have apologized to the United States Charge d'Affaires for an attack by demonstrators on the United States Information Service office this morning.

The State Department's Voice of America broadcasts are heard by a "considerable" number of Czechs and should be continued on a larger scale, Laurence A. Steinhardt, United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, said here yesterday.
Extracts from the statement of the National Association of Manufacturers recommending a maximum Federal budget of $31,000,000,000 for the fiscal year 1948-49, made public yesterday, follow:

On the ground that a public hearing in the paternity trial of John W. Meyer, publicity man for Howard Hughes, would be harmful to the 10-months-old child involved, 250 spectators, witnesses and reporters were barred from the Court of Special Sessions as the case began yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WARSAW, Dec. 4 -- A Polish underground leader testified before a military tribunal today to the existence of an international underground organization dedicated to the overthrow of the Soviet Union. He said the group had branches extending within Russia herself.

The first positive prediction of the end of the current steel famine by a prominent official of the industry was made yesterday by Wilfred Sykes, president of the Inland Steel Company of Chicago, who said that the steel industry "will be able to balance supply and demand during 1948."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- The burst of rioting in Palestine may have its first echoes in the United Nations on Tuesday, when the problem of the Holy Land is formally placed before the Security Council.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 -- In the rioting of the last three days the Jewish Agency for Palestine has taken the first visible step toward the organization of the state that the Jews will have under partition by bringing into the open the Haganah defense organization.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Enough people have written me from the United States about the French Communists, so that I should like to correct what appears to be dangerous misunderstandings.

Twenty-seven years ago Rudolph J. Thomas came here from Orlando, Fla., at the age of 16 to visit relatives and to take a "temporary" summer job as elevator operator at the Harlem Y.M.C.A. branch, then at 181 West 135th Street.

A Federal budget ceiling of $31,000,000,000 for the fiscal year 1948-49 was proposed yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers. Its aim is to achieve thorough review and prudent reduction of departmental requests without skimping on needed national defense, foreign aid, veterans, tax reduction or debt retirement allowances.

GENEVA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Already faced with a possible lack of American competitors, the winter Olympic program was placed in jeopardy tonight as Mayor Carl Nater of St. Moritz threatened to withdraw the city's offer of hspitality if the United States Olympic Committee boycotted the games.

The Government of Premier Schuman scored an impressive political victory yesterday when the French National Assembly approved legislation directed against the incipient Communist insurrection by one of the biggest majorities seen in post-war France -- 413 to 183.

Thirty-two pieces of silver, reminiscent of pieces of eight in a bygone sailing era but of a different order, were awarded at a dinner last night at the New York Yacht Club as racing prizes in the organization's events last summer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 29, 1947, totaled 792,339 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 110,333 cars, or 12.2 per cent, fewer than for the preceding week; 131,428 cars, or 19.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 11,435 cars, or 1.4 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

VIENNA, Dec. 4 -- The Allied Council for Austria agreed today to the proposed Austrian currency conversion law. Approval was granted after learning that the Russian price for approving it approximated an exchange of slightly more than 500,000,000 old schillings on even terms instead of the 1,500,000,000 that had been feared.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- United States Secretary of State Marshall broke into the monotonous aria of Soviet propaganda at the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers today with the blunt charge that Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov was trying through his attacks to disrupt the European Recovery Program, which Secretary Marshall fathered.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 4 -- Protestantism can no longer afford to regard Christian education as a "penny-a-week affair" requiring a minimum of time, effort, and money, the Rev. Dr. Erwin L. Shaver of Chicago, director of Week-day Religious Education for the International Council of Religious Education, said here today.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Following is the text of a statement made today by Secretary of State Marshall at the meeting of the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A list of about ninety organizations of questioned loyalty to the United States, prepared under direction of Attorney General Tom C. Clark, was made public tonight by the special board now examining the loyalty of Federal Government employes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- President Truman's Cabinet Food Committee projected an intensified voluntary conservation program today and warned that better public understanding and support was needed to prevent inflated prices from climbing "beyond the reach of millions of American families."

The practiced hands of 1,500 unionized bartenders were restored to the beer taps in 800 Manhattan taverns last night following settlement of a three-day-old dispute between the Bartenders Union, Local 15, AFL, and the United Restaurant Liquor Dealers Association.

A plea for support of the Compton committee report on universal military training was made yesterday by Brig. Gen. Ogden J. Ross, commanding officer of the Fourth Division Heeadquarters of the First Army, at the annual meeting of the Sons of the Revolution in Fraunces Tavern, Broad and Pearl Streets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- State Department reports of "panic buying" in Russia were interpreted by several Senators tonight as meaning that the Soviet economic system might be facing serious trouble. Some other Senators, however, treated the reports with caution.

Stout Steve Owen came up with a new running back yesterday during the brisk Giant drill at the Polo Grounds. Art Faircloth, the tall young man who was brought up from Jersey City as a pass defender and passer, shared the ball-carrying assignments with Choo Choo Roberts.

The City Council approved yesterday a measure increasing the annual fee for pistol permits from $1.50 to $10. The measure came before the Council members as an amendment to the administrative code. It was adopted without discussion by a vote of 14 to 6.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- The troubles in Palestine and possible repercussions in the Middle East sent oil issues lower in the stock markets here today. Although losses were small, they were widespread.

MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 4 -- Troops were used today to clear away the barricades erected by strikers of the Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor in an attempt to cut off Marseille's auto and truck-borne food supplies.

New and luxurious drapery fabrics by Joseph Blumfield of California emphasize this rug designer's interest in rich textures. His handwoven fabrics were introduced yesterday during a showing of new rugs and fabrics held by Edward Fields, Inc., 509 Madison Avenue.
Verdi's overture to "Sicilian Vespers." Bartok's Dance Suite. Samuel Barber's cello concerto, with Raya Garbousova, 'cello soloist. Beethoven's Fifth Symphony.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The list of questionable groups submitted by Attorney General Clark today contained the names of forty-seven organizations or associations first disclosed on Feb. 5, 1943. Many of these have expired, but the original list also contained the following names:

The Supreme Court of the United States will be called upon to invoke the United Nations Charter against the practice of discrimination in the purchase and use of real estate, it was made known here yesterday.

Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, warned employers yesterday in an address before the National Association of Manufacturers not to make closed shop contracts to avoid strikes or slowdowns.
Ten members of the board of directors of United Service to China were decorated yesterday by the government that has benefited by their work.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial on the partition of Palestine is in at least one respect misleading, and in another perpetuates an invalid misgiving as to the theory behind the plan.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 -- Abitibi Sales Company, Ltd., tonight advised its Canadian and American customers by telegram that its contract price for standard newsprint paper is being increased $6 per ton on Jan. 1. This closely followed the announcement by Consolidated Paper Sales, Ltd., that it would maintain its present contract prices for the first two months of 1948, but after that, a substantial price increase seems unavoidable.

BASEBALL has begun to muscle its way back into the headlines but collegiate football will make one last frantic clutch at top billing on the morrow. Notre Dame will play Southern California before some 105,000 wild-eyed clients at Los Angeles in what promises to be a most intriguing struggle. Unlike most intrigues, however, this one is rather obvious.

An eight-point program of recommendations for educational aid to Puerto Rican children who have recently settled in New York was outlined yesterday by Dr. Clare C. Baldwin, assistant Superintendent of Schools in charge of Districts 10 and 11.

Praising the recent report of President Truman's Advisory Committee on the Merchant Marine, the board of directors of the Shipbuilders Council of America urged yesterday an early enactment of legislation, where necessary, to carry out its recommendations.

The well-being of the people of Brooklyn is being carefully guarded by the Brooklyn Chapter of the American Red Cross, it is fully apparent from the annual report of the chapter, just released. The report shows that while a large part of the Brooklyn unit's work still is with former servicemen and their families, the problems of veterans are becoming more and more like those of the rest of the civilian population.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 4 -- The Arab three-day strike ended today with bloodshed throughout Palestine.

ATHENS, Dec. 4 -- Minister of Public Order Costas Rendis announced today that 3,419 outlaws of the Left and 5,647 of the Right have surrendered to civil and military authorities during two months of the amnesty between Sept. 15 and Nov. 15.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Government banned further demonstrations today after police and frontier guards fought a street battle with a crowd of 15,000 protesting the partition of Palestine.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 4 -- The United States categorically opposes any United Nations investigation of atomic tests by this Government in the Pacific at this stage in history, but is prepared to report fully to the peace organization on the welfare of the natives of the Pacific islands involved.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 4 -- A United States military tribunal sentenced four former officials of the German Ministry of Justice to life imprisonment today, gave six prison terms and acquitted four others.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J,. Dec. 4 -- An unprecedented technical ruling this afternoon decided the national women's team championship in contract bridge, overshadowing the fact that the ultimate victors had displaced a team which had won this event for four consecutive years.
ST. LOUIS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Bob Rodenberg, Baltimore sportsman, today wound up his initial overtures toward purchase of the Browns and departed for the East without disclosing any particular progress.

Richard Strauss' most genial opera, "Der Rosenkavalier," was done with appealing freshness of spirit at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. There were a number of individual contributions of merit, but it was the teamwork of singers and orchestra pit that gave the performance its chief distinction.
Adams-Millis The Adams-Millis Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 23, making the year's total $4.50, compared with $6 distributed in 1946.

Tax selling became more persistent yesterday, stocks lost ground and prices went below the September resistence level. At the worst figures of the session the combined averages were close to the June mark and, on balance, the averages lost approximately 3/4 point, with the industrials off even more.

Construction of a branch store in Millburn, N.J., which will be opened in the fall of next year, was announced yesterday by Lord Taylor. The new branch, to be located at Wyoming and Millburn Avenues, Millburn, will be the company's third, the two others being in Manhasset, L.I., and East Chester, N.Y.

OMAHA, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Sentiment at the National Amateur Athletic Union convention tonight was that the delegates would turn down, for the second time, a proposal that no foreign athlete could be designated as a national American A.A.U. champion.

Last spring trout fishermen were looking through the downpour in a vain effort to locate a patch of blue sky to encourage them for the week-end fishing trip; for with the brief duck season on its second leg, the same men are trying to locate a dark cloud on the blue dome.

Among the many "firsts" of which this country can boast is the fact that we lead the world in the number of telephones in use. Last year our people carried on forty-two billion conversations over that instrument. This statistic, which has been supplied by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in a pamphlet it issued recently giving facts about telephones throughout the world, without a doubt establishes us as the "talkingest" nation in the world.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 4 (AP) -- Following a two - day blackout due to a squabble between the track and horsemen for increased purses, racing was resumed at Gulfstream Park today with 9,366 fans present.

They picked the best kitten yesterday at the opening of the thirty-first championship show of the Empire Cat Club at the Hotel McAlpin, but a "fairy tale" pussycat -- a blue-eyed, short-haired, alley species -- received the most attention.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Floor traders on the Board of Trade were more pessimistic concerning the outlook for prices than most other groups speculating in grains on Sept. 17, a study of a report of the Commodity Exchange Authority disclosed today.

By a vote of 67 to 40, the faculty of Queens College, Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, adopted a resolution yesterday reaffirming the ban imposed earlier this year on the chartering of the American Youth for Democracy as a campus organization.
Excursion boat companies using city piers were warned yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer that it would not take much to put them all out of business.

Atlantic and Gulf steamship employers yesterday turned back a request for wage increases asked by the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, representing engineers of forty-eight leading shipping lines.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- During the week ended Dec. 3, member bank reserve balances decreased $83,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

In an action of sweeping importance the National Labor Relations Board yesterday freed Remington-Rand, Inc., from any legal obligation to continue bargaining with a Congress of Industrial Organizations union that refused to file non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law.

The twenty-year gate receipts record for Madison Square Garden boxing will be shattered tonight when Joe Louis, world heavyweight champion, defends his title in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds against Jersey Joe Walcott, Camden challenger.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Warner Brothers is preparing a new film version of "Brother Rat," the Broadway comedy by Fred Finklehoffe and John Monks about life at the Virginia Military Institute, which the studio first filmed in 1938.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Creation of the motion-picture industry's first labor - management body for the consideration of joint interests loomed today as a possible outgrowth of the film producers' current activity against Communists.

New York talent gained an even break with basketball representatives of the Rocky Mountain Conference in a wild and woolly doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night. City College salvaged local pride by defeating Brigham Young, 61 -- 56, in overtime after St. John's had succumbed to Denver University, 54 -- 52.
HAVANA, Dec. 4 -- Walter Nash, chairman of New Zealand's delegation, told the United Nations Trade and Employment Conference today that there was "no reason for pessimism."

Formation of the Radio Servicemen's Association of New York to correct any of the alleged abuses attributed to radio repairmen was announced yesterday. Its officers are Max Leibowitz, president; Norman Jacobson, vice president; Jack Edel, treasurer and recording secretary, and Harry Anis, correspondent secretary.
An 18-year-old Netherlands girl who tended the grave of a Canadian soldier killed in action in 1945, arrived here yesterday with the deceased man's father, who has offered to adopt her.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ardent admirers of Southern California's Trojans, playing to the hilt their role of underdog in the approaching game with Notre Dame, got a word of encouragement -- unsolicited -- from, an erstwhile enemy source today.

PRAGUE, Dec. 4 -- The Czechoslovak-Soviet commercial treaty will account for 17 to 18 per cent of Czechoslovak foreign trade and amount to about $110,000,000 of exports and the sale value in imports annually.

YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Trusteeship Council Considered resolution according increasing self - government to Western Samoa and appointed drafting committee of Belgium, China, Iraq and Mexico to compose minor differences of opinion.

Organizations named in the Government's official list of "totalitarian, Fascist, Communist or subversive" groups replied last night with statements denying that they fitted any of the categories, according to The Associated Press.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 4 -- A dispute between the State Department and Army authorities over the disposition of surplus goods in Europe was reported here today by reliable sources. The difference of opinion involves the desirability of continuing to sell huge amounts of surplus vehicles, clothing and scrap at comparatively low prices, which some persons doubt will ever be paid, or to hand the goods over as gifts to the nations concerned.

NAM Ads to Continue The National Association of Manufacturers, now meeting here, expects to spend about $900,000 in continuing its public relations campaign through 1948, a spokesman said yesterday. The organization's long-range program of presenting the business man's "point of view" will be continued in magazines.

Collectors of American Art will make its 1947 distribution of original works of art to members on Tuesday evening at the Hotel Delmonico. The group is a non-profit membership organization that encourages the ownership of contemporary art in America.

Christmas carols that refer to the Nativity or have a religious significance may not be sung in twenty-three public schools of two Brooklyn school districts, according to an order issued by the assistant superintendent in charge, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Airtight guarantees that none of the emergency relief sought by President Truman would go to France, Italy or Austria if those countries fell under Communist control were demanded by some members of the Senate Appropriations Committee today.

Current political and economic conditions in Europe and the Middle East probably will increase in volume and intensity the problems already giving concern to American steamship companies and seamen, Louis S. Bershen, director of overseas operations for the United Seamen's Service, declared yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Felix Rondo's Camp's First, with Jockeys R. L. Baird up, hit the wire ahead of Boden's Pal at the Fair Grounds today to win the featured Lafayette Purse. Camp's First paid $8.60 for $2. Rodman Keenon finished third.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A nip-and-tuck battle with death is being waged by protective agencies throughout the country to keep highway fatalities this year below the 33,700 total of 1946, Sidney J. Williams, assistant to the president of the National Safety Council, said tonight at the Highway Research Board meeting here.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 4 -- Morgan L. Fitch of Chicago, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, today flatly rejected the proposal that the Government subsidize property owners under a renewed program of rent control, and excoriated public housing as being "an ill-designed forerunner of a nationalistic state."
After holding within a narrow range all day, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 to 19 points net lower.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 4 -- Over the opposition of the United States and the Soviet Union, the United Nations Commission on Human Rights voted today to proceed at once on drafting a convention of human rights to be binding on signatory governments.

Announcement of the 1948 Brooklyn Dodgers' manager may come from President Branch Rickey at any moment -- perhaps as soon as tomorrow -- and it appeared more certain than ever that his name is Leo Durocher.

New Applications of procaine by intravenous injection to relieve pain caused by a variety of injuries and chronic diseases were described yesterday at the second annual meeting of the American Society of Anestesiologists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Testimony conflicting with claims that speculation on commodity exchanges had no long-range effect on prices was presented to Congress today by a cotton broker.

Lack of interest on the part of business men in our schools and colleges and Government paternalism were cited yesterday by Henning W. Prentis Jr., president of the Armstrong Cork Company, as two of the basic factors which are undermining the American system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The House opened debate today on its bill to authorize $590,000,000 of winter relief for France, Italy, Austria and China. Repeatedly, however, the proposed emergency fund became caught -- and seemingly lost -- in crossfires of attack on American policy relating to Russia, the long-range European Recovery Program, and those accused of responsibility for high prices at home.

Steamship company committees organized to draft a code of minimum regulations for export packaging will seek the advice and cooperation of exporters and manufacturers of packaging materials in framing the new system of rules, it was learned yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Two United Airlines cargo pilots wrestled their four-engined DC-4 cargo liner to a safe landing last night with two engines bashed in and a wing ripped.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 4 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha. who presided over the tumultuous second session of the United Nations General Assembly, said tonight that he hoped and believed that the Soviet Union would agree to take part in the work of the "Little Assembly."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.4 per cent during the week ended Nov. 29, with advances in most major commodity groups, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau's comprehensive index of commodity prices in primary markets again reached a new post-war high, 159.8 per cent of the 1926 average, only about 4 per cent below the May, 1920, peak.

The interim aid bill which the House of Representatives took up yesterday is not quite the same as the one the Senate passed on Monday by a vote of 83 to 6. The Senate bill authorized the expenditure of the fun $597,000,000 asked by the Administration for Italy, France and Austria alone.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, ordered his division and bureau heads into the field to watch relief operations first-hand, as he proceeded yesterday with a general tightening-up of his department's administration.
BERLIN, Dec. 4 -- The United States Military Government has obtained from Washington an allocation of $4,000,000 for newsprint with which to print German school-books and anti-Communist material.
Henry A. Wallace, in a vigorous assault on American foreign policy, declared last night that the chief danger to American freedom "comes not from any foreign foe but from Americans."

Metropolitan skiing enthusiasts, awaiting the first succession of heavy snow to permit good sport on a wide scale, will have to remain patient. Reports from the North Country were far from inviting -- at the same time, normal for this time, of the season -- yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 29 were 10 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Grain markets were decidedly unsettled on the Board of Trade today. Wheat was weak and corn strong, the former breaking 3 3/4 to 6 cents a bushel and closing about the bottom while corn rose 1/2 to 1 3/4 cents, the May delivery selling within 1/4 cent of the seasonal peak.

Delayed a week as the result of internal ructions, "Caribbean Carnival" finally hovers into view tonight at the International. Behind the gay title lurks "the first Calypso musical ever presented," to quote the program.

New Treasury Call Acting to meet the scheduled redemption of $100,000,000 of its bills on Dec. 11, the United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks. The call, requiring 12 per cent of such deposits as of Dec. 3, is payable on the redemption date.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Marriner S. Eccles told Congress politely but plainly today that there would be no substantial retreat from the most disputed of the antiinflation measures recommended by the Federal Reserve Board.
LONDON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Russia has become a member of the International Amateur Athletic Federation and thus has taken a major step toward participation in the 1948 Olympic Games.

Declaring that the National Maritime Union, CIO, operating on a "spend, spend basis, with no reckoning," is now virtually "destitute," M. Hedley Stone, union treasurer, has recommended a drastic cut in personnel and a 10 per cent slash in all salaries, including those of top officials.

At record high levels, butter, now 93 cents a pound, and large Grade A eggs, 93 cents a dozen, are in the forefront of the general upward trend in food prices, Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz of the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A Republican anti-inflation program with heavy emphasis on voluntary measures and tax reduction was under preparation in Congress today. It will be outlined in detail, according to present plans, in a public "declaration of policy" to be issued soon in reply to President Truman's ten-point program.

Dissipating the appearances of a seasonal decline indicated in the previous weekly period, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $40,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi, who has been ill for a week, hopes to be well enough to preside over the Cabinet council on Saturday and to complete the Cabinet reshuffle within a few days.
An entire new slate of officers was elected at the annual meeting of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday at the Hotel Shelton.
YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Mr. Truman was vacationing at Key West.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- John Foster Dulles, arriving today on a three-day fact-finding visit on behalf of Secretary of State Marshall, told newspaper men who met him as he descended from the Golden Arrow at the Nord station:
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

The Council of The Authors League of America issued a protest yesterday against the recent Hollywood investigation by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, charging that it represented an "immoderate, uncontrolled and radically harmful form of censorship" against the entire profession of writing.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 4 -- President Truman had a day of complete relaxation today, his principal activities being eating, sun bathing and napping. But his breakfast took Florida by surprise.
Under the sponsorship of college leaders, a new educational organization, designed to bring the physical and social sciences closer together, was officially started yesterday.

Foreign chemical engineers visiting the twenty-first exposition of chemical industries in the Grand Central Palace have revealed plans for enlargement of foreign chemical, glass and food-packing plants, exhibitors revealed yesterday. Show officials also disclosed that total attendance during the first four days of the six-day schedule has passed the 50,000 mark, according to their estimates.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Tanners do not want nor are they responsible for high prices of hides, skins, leather and shoes, it was declared here today by Harold Connett, president of the Tanners' Council of America. Speaking at the thirty-first annual three-day meeting of the council in the Palmer House, he emphasized that tanners have "done more than increase production to the maximum limit of available raw materials.

The Board of Estimate rejected yesterday the City Planning Commission's recent zoning amendment under which doctors and dentists not living in multiple dwellings in residential districts could have maintained offices on either of the first two floors of such structures.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Virgil W. Peterson of the Chicago Crime Commission today urged race track executives to oppose legislation to legalize handbooks, declaring it would lead to legalization of "all forms of gambling."

A concert devoted to instrumental and vocal works by Carlo Stea, 44-year-old American composer of Italian parentage, was presented last night at Times Hall. Mr. Stea's compositions were performed by Joan Slessinger and Melvin Levine, pianists; Muriel Lane, soprano, and Paul Bernard, violinist.
The traditional Christmas tree in the Children's Village at Dobbs Ferry will not glow with lights this holiday season nor glitter with the tinsel and bright ornaments handed down year after year.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- The staff of the Securities and Exchange Commission's utility division disclosed today, as the elevenday hearing on the shake-up in the management of the Standard Gas and Electric Company drew to a close, that it considered the proxy material filed by the company to be "inadequate."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- A manufacturers' group recommended today a monthly salary of $250 as the dividing line between covered and exempt employes under the Wages and Hours Law, and a union spokesman said the figure should be at least $100 a week of $433 a month.

Communists must be permitted complete freedom of speech in this nation if the peoples of the United States are to understand and recognize the evils of the "communistic viewpoint," Dr. Noel D. Godfrey, Professor of General History at the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts, and Finance, declared last night.

The long services of Joseph M. Proskauer, former Justice of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, in behalf of civic, religious and philanthropic causes, were praised last night by Cardinal Spellman, John W. Davis, former Democratic candidate for President; former Govs. Herbert H. Lehman, Nathan L. Miller and others, at a testimonial dinner at the Hotel Plaza.

Wholesale prices of competitive lamp lines will rise from 10 to 20 per cent next month, a spokesman for a large lamp manufacturer predicted yesterday. He said that lamps retailing up to $25 will be affected and those above that figure will undergo little or no price changes.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 4 -- Willard K. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, told the convention of the Investment Bankers Association here today that the European Recovery Program (ERP) is not intended to provide ''rich-uncle support" for distressed peoples but to tide over, the war-torn lands Until the critical gap in their balance-of-payments positions can be closed.
