WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The annual conference of state and territorial health officers adopted a resolution today strongly supporting Surgeon General Thomas Parran's program for greatly accelerated training of physicians, dentists, nurses and other health personnel.

News yesterday that F. Beverly Kelley had retired at the age of 42 as chief publicity man for The Greatest Show on Earth and would settle down to the life of a small-town merchant in Ohio is hard to take. What are we to think now of all those songs he used to sing, come March, of the joyous, carefree, glamorous life of the circus?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The drive to put a third party in the field for the 1948 Presidential campaign will be abandoned if Henry A. Wallace does not announce by the first of the year that he will head the movement.

Howard Fast, novelist, has been barred from addressing a campus meeting of the Columbia University chapter of the Progressive Citizens of America that was scheduled for next Friday, the PCA announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It will probably be a service rendered to the American public to remind them that the unrestrained rejoicing of Zionists over the U.N. decision to partition Palestine and thus bring about a supposedly legal institution of a Jewish national entity does not by any means command unanimous support by Americans of the action taken, nor of the announced United States policy which lay back of the decision.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Recommendations for a $5,596,200,000 annual tax cut, including a $3,083,000,000 slash in individual income taxes, were submitted to the House Ways and Means Committee today by the taxation committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

George J. Haney asserted yesterday that some of the larger independent airlines are making money flying freight in spite of the opposition of the established scheduled airlines. Mr. Haney, regional vice president of California Eastern Airways, told the aviation section of the New York Board of Trade that his company "was willing to show the big certificated airlines how to fly freight at a profit."

"THINGS happen to people because of what they are. Even murder," said the dashingly handsome and magnetically sinister young man. The missionary's widow who gazed at him with such fascination was not even shocked. Murder no longer seemed so inconceivably remote to her as it once would have, not now that she was proving herself so accomplished a blackmailer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- In this space today an outline was published of several proposals to operate the European Recovery Program which are under discussion in official circles. On the choice of these mechanical details the fate of the project in Congress may depend; also its success or failure in actual practice.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 4 -- A recommendation that steps be taken at once to call to the attention of the Secretary of Defense, James V. Forrestal, the need for coordinating the aims of military and port officials in developing the country's port facilities was urged today upon the executive board of the American Association of Port Authorities.

Reversing his position of Oct. 25, when he flatly termed the condemnation by Cardinal Spellman and the National Legion of Decency of "Forever Amber" as "unfair and harsh," Spyros P. Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, producers of the film, announced yesterday that the picture had been revised.

A near riot that brought three police radio cars nearly broke up a meeting of the Board of Education yesterday when a number of persons voiced strenuous objections to the board's procedure in handling the case of a suspended teacher-picket.

New Yorkers have contributed $73,000 in cash, 21,023 cases of assorted canned and dried foods and 45,889 pounds of sugar, flour, macaroni, rice, dried vegetables and bran to the city's Friendship Food Train Committee.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 4 -- The American steamship industry is facing a trend toward the pre-war situation in which foreign ships were carrying their own commerce and 70 per cent of America's imports and exports as well, according to Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of Shipping.

A check for $50,000, honoring the fortieth anniversary of King Gustav V's ascension to the throne, was given yesterday by D.S. Gottesman on behalf of the D.S. and R.H. Gottesman Foundation to Uppsala University in Sweden. The donation will endow a series of lectures on the humanities by world figures for a five-year period.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 -- Sixteen of the twenty-one directors of the Miami Beach Hotel Owners Association and 100 hotels have signed an agreement to adhere strictly to the fair practices code of ethics for the winter season as recommended by Rudolph Pell Ellis, New York vacation agent.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- One person was killed and twenty-five were wounded this afternoon when police fired at rioters in Primavalle, a suburb of Rome.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- As the Council of Foreign Ministers got down to the crucial issue of economic principles today, United States Secretary of State Marshall launched an all-out effort to get definite action and to pin Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov down to precise facts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- One of the country's most influential bankers, Edward Eagle Brown, president of the Advisory Council to the Federal Reserve Board, advised Congress today against tax reductions.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 5 -- The suit brought by the Department of Justice against the Investment Bankers Association was denounced here today by the association's newly inducted president, Julien H. Collins of Chicago, as an "insulting" and "outrageous" imposition of litigation on the association's 700 members.

Attorney General Tom C. Clark has designated some ninety organizations in this country as "totalitarian, fascist, Communist or subversive." Membership in one or more of these organizations will be one factor in testing the fitness of federal employes under President Truman's loyalty order.

Leading industrialists called yesterday for a longer work week by temporary lifting of the work week standard in the wages and hours act as the only way to raise real wages while combating high prices at home and misery, economic stagnation and the spread of the "police state" abroad.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 5 -- Several recommendations and reports proposing far reaching changes in the relation of Protestantism to the American community were adopted today at the final session of a national conference on the community and religious education.
ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., veteran campaigner on the pro circuit, led the field by a stroke today at the halfway point of the $10,000 Orlando open golf tournament.

Ten stories by Charles Dickens that deal with Christimas have been selected by May Lamberton Becker to form a volume entitled "Christmas Tales." Mrs. Becker says in her foreward that although Dickens did not invent it, "he certainly did create the pattern, the picture by which the whole world recognizes an 'English Christmas.' "

After a century of exclusively feminine control, the Society for Seamen's Children, an organization devoted to the relief and protection of the destitute children of seafarers, voted yesterday to permit men to serve on the society's board of managers.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Anti-Jewish violence, breaking out in a new quarter of the disturbed Middle East, resulted in the killing of forty-four persons at Aden, the British colony and protectorate at the mouth of the Red Sea, the British Colonial Office announced today.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 5 (UP) -- A strike scheduled for next Tuesday by 2,800 uranium separation workers threatened tonight to interrupt the nation's output of atomic energy both for war and peacetime uses and emergency negotiations were under way to head it off.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The Council of Methodist Bishops protested today against dismissal of Government employes accused of having subversive views on charges based on "vague and unsubstantial assertions" or on their associating with so-called suspicious characters.
Strife in Europe had a disturbing influence on commodity markets yesterday and cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange finished 17 to 28 points net lower.

PEIPING, Dec. 4 (Delayed) -- A new aggressive type of warfare against the Communists was proclaimed by Gen. Fu Tso-yi, new commander of Government forces in North China, in an interview in Peiping today.

Increased cooperation of governmental agencies to expedite approvals of chemicals and equipment sales to foreign buyers from devastated European areas was stressed yesterday as a vital need at the chemical exposition at Grand Central Palace, which closes tonight.

Allied Chemical and Dye A special dividend of $3 a share in the common stock, payable on Dec. 27, was voted yesterday by the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation. This brings the total dividends for the year to $9 comared with $8 in 1946.

ATHENS, Dec. 5 -- The Ministry of Public Order tonight announced -- but the Ministry of War later denied -- that a band composed of regulars of the Bulgarian Army and Greek guerrillas yesterday entered Greece from Svilingrad and attacked the town of Spilaion six miles inside Greece.

Some Democratic votes, as well as some Republican votes, will doubtless be cast against the bill for emergency aid to Italy, France and Austria when it comes to a test next week in the House of Representatives. There are Democrats, as well as Republicans, who cannot see things clearly at a distance -- even large things, and at no great distance.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 5 -- Dr. Milton H. Hahn, director of psychological services at Syracuse University, said here today that not one school in 100 had an adequate guidance program that would enamble students to discover their weaknesses and their strong points.

Shortly before Joe Louis began the defense of his world heavyweight title in a scheduled fifteenround bout with Jersey Joe Walcott at Madison Square Garden last night, Ruby Goldstein was named to referee the match by the New York State Athletic Commission.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 -- Progress in the treatment of some advanced types of cancer by means of a 3,000,000-volt X-ray machine was described today by Dr. Richard Dresser of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Arsen Bonneyan, manager of the import division of A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., was elected president of the Oriental Rug Importers Association, Inc., at the annual luncheon meeting yesterday at the Hotel Martinique. Mr. Bonneyan, who previously served a term as president in 1945, succeeds Edwin G. Michaelian, president for the last two years.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Housing is preparing to make sweeping proposals to eliminate irregularities in the building material and construction field, to improve distribution methods and to bring the cost of homes down, Representative Frank L. Sundstrom of New Jersey, a member of the committee, said here today.

One of the largest glassware manufacturers in the country may raise prices on Jan. 1, a company representative revealed yesterday. The concern, along with its principal competitor and some others, has held its price line for several months, unlike many glassware producers who increased prices 5 to 17 per cent in September.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 5 -- A campaign by the people of this town to help residents of the French village of Marigny -- it eventually might lead to "adoption" -- got under way here tonight when a group of artists daubed wooden sand buckets at the home of Mrs. Howard Brubaker.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5 -- The contract bridge contest for the national team-of-four championship entered its final session here tonight with Peter Leventritt of New York, Bertram Lebhar Jr. of New Rochelle and Charles Solomon and Mrs. Benjamin Golder of Philadelphia leading the field of forty-seven teams by a narrow margin.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Violent winds, sweeping the coasts of Britain and Ireland today, wrecked the schooner Isallt with the probable loss of seven lives and sent Coast Guardsmen of many stations out on rescue missions.

LONDON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's first statement to the Foreign Ministers Council today: The Council of Foreign Ministers has now been in session for more than a week. According to the agenda, it has been debating two questions on Germany, frontiers and treaty procedure.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Greeted by one of Los Angeles' famous demonstrations of "unusual" weather, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame arrived today and their coach, Frank Leahy, matched the gloom of the skies in predicting the outcome of their annual football game with the University of Southern California.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- July and September corn dropped the limit of 8 cents a bushel in the late trading today on the Board of Trade. The market, however, had shown considerable strength early, May equaling the seasonal high price.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Encouraged by the first clear weather in a week, the United States Air Force in Europe put aloft today the largest aerial armada since the war in a desperate search for a United States Army plane missing seven days with twenty persons aboard.

WARSAW, Dec. 5 -- Mme. Maria Marynowska, former chief translator of the British Embassy's press office in Warsaw, admitted to a military tribunal today that she had arranged meetings of Polish underground leaders with British and United States Embassy aides.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today rejected applications by Transworld Airline and Pennsylvania-Central (Capital) Airlines seeking more than $16,000,000 in back mail pay.

OYSTFR BAY, L.I., Dec. 5 -- The theft of twelve pieces of jewelry valued at between $5,000 and $7,000 was reported to the Second Precinct, Nassau County police, on Tuesday by Mrs. Caja Hayes of 99 Orchard Street here, it was made known today.

Bible Sunday will be observed widely tomorrow. The sermons of many pastors will advocate a more regular daily reading of the Scriptures. The New York Bible Society will commemorate its 138th anniversary with a special service at 8 P.M. in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street.
One person was killed, another seriously injured and a third taken ill in three subway mishaps yesterday that tied up morning rush hour traffic on the IND and IRT lines.
John V.L. Hogan, president of radio station WQXR, received the Armstrong Medal of the Radio Club of America last night as inventor of the heterodyne receiver and for other pioneering radio work.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Gov. Earl Warren declared tonight that the United States must stay "spiritually and militarily strong" to keep its commitments for world peace in view of Communist infiltrations and aggressions.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES a while ago was story anent the low prices prevalend circa the year 1830. Apparently a publication of that year showed that laborer received $7.50 a week and, according to Harry V. Weiss of the New Jersey State Department of Agriculture, could do as well from the family budget standpoint as the $100 a wee man does today.

Profound changes in the markets for all iron and steel products may result from the new movement under way throughout the entire steel industry to retreat from remote to near-by customers, it was revealed here yesterday by Raymond L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders Society, Inc., Cleveland.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The estimated net income of Class I railroads in October was $48,000,000, compared with $58,000,000 in October, 1946, the Association of American Railroads said today. Class I roads are those doing $1,000,000 or more gross business annually.

NANKING, Dec. 5 -- A SinoAmerican agreement is scheduled to be signed here in a few days formally transferring 271 small United States naval craft to the Chinese Government. The transfer is being carried out under a United States law, passed in July, 1946, empowering the President to authorize the sale, lease or gift of surplus vessels to China.

Juvenile delinquency has grown to such proportions as a result of abnormal conditions during the war that the Federal Government, "which bears great responsibility for the welfare of its people," is compelled to join the fight against it, Representative Jacob K. Javits, Republican, of New York, said last night.

The advertising committee of the Radio Manufacturers Association has approved a 1948 appropriation "more than double that for 1947," Stanley H. Manson, advertising and public relations director of the Stromberg-Carlson Company and committee chairman, announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Twenty thousand Egyptians shouted today for a holy war to prevent the partitioning of Palestine and broke through police lines before the Al Azhar Mosque.
Tough Days for the Battery A friend of this department visited the Battery the other day to see how the work on the new tunnel was progressing. Battery Park, he found, no longer exists.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The House completed today nearly ten hours of general debate over the proposed authorization of nearly $600,000,000 of emergency relief to France, Italy, Austria and China. Then it squared off for the voting contests, to start Monday, over amendments that would alter the Administration's program materially.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- France's resistance to communism is more significant than that of any other European country, John Foster Dulles told a press conference here today. He said he felt that no fatal blow has yet been struck here to the Marshall plan.

Yara Bernette, Brazilian pianist, gave her third New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her program included two early Spanish sonatas by Mateo Albeniz and Padre Antonio Soler; Mozart's "Fantasie" in C minor (K. 396); the Bach-Liszt Prelude and Fugue in A minor; Brahms' Sonata in F minor, a Chopin group; Liszt's "Mephisto Valse," and items by Debussy, Villa-Lobos and Guarnieri.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 5 -- President Truman was commissioned a "qualified submariner" today, more or less without due process, at the naval submarine base here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee gave its sanction today to the preparation by House and Senate leaders of a Republican anti-inflation program.

Governor Dewey conferred for more than an hour yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel with officers of the Greater New York Hospital Association, representing ninetyseven voluntary nonprofit hospitals in this area. He outlined his plans for a state-wide program for adequate hospital facilities for all the people and expressed hope that the current local campaign to raise $2,400,000 for the United Hospital Fund will be "generously oversubscribed."

Despite turbulent civil conditions in India, burlap dealers in New York predicted yesterday that there will be a considerable easing of the supply after the first of the year, and that burlap prices will come down to a more reasonable level.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 5 -- Eight European governments and the three Western zones of Germany have agreed through the Economic Commission for Europe to permit for six months the international movement of highway trucks, it was learned today.
Representatives of organizations named on Thursday by Attorney General Tom C. Clark as of questioned loyalty to the United States issued statements yesterday denying the allegation.

ALBANY, Dec. 5 -- Robert W. Leavitt, new president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, urged at an inaugural luncheon today that Congress and the State Legislature terminate rent and other controls Which, he claimed, are prolonging the housing shortage.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States, Canada and the Netherlands signed in Brussels, Belgium, today, an "agreement relating to the resolution of conflicting claims to German enemy assets" designed to avoid long continued litigation and negotiations such as ensued after World War I.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The State Department announced today that the United States was discontinuing for the present the licensing of shipments of arms to the Middle East. The quantity sent there since the war ended has been small.

Savings Bank Efficiency Savings bankers here have begun a research project to develop methods of increasing efficiency and reducing costs in savings operations, and a committee, under the chairmanship of Everett J. Livesey, assistant controller of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, has been formed.

To become a member of La Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin one must demonstrate a thorough knowledge and appreciation of Burgundy wines by passing a rigid examination. This prerequisite, fortunately, was set aside for a tasting dinner at the Hotel Pierre that food editors were invited to attend this week.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Congress got word today that things are so bad in the fur industry that some fur farmers are ready to quit.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 -- Two men whose influence upon the automobile industry certainly equals that of any two other individuals met and chatted informally for an hour today like a pair of college chums.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The current strikes in France and Italy are a demonstration of the extension of Soviet foreign policy, Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett told the Senate Appropriations Committee today. Most of the committee members appeared to agree with Mr. Lovett's argument that the situation emphasized the need for the interim aid to the two countries and Austria, in behalf of which he was testifying.

TOKYO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Emperor Hirohito knew well in advance the general outline of his navy's plans for opening war with the United States by a carrier plane attack on Pearl Harbor, the International War Crimes Tribunal heard today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- More than 200 top leaders of the American Federation of Labor today unanimously and enthusiastically set up machinery to make a "grass roots" appeal to their nearly 8,000,000 members in support of their policy of fighting members of Congress who voted for the Taft-Hartley Act and to oppose other labor restrictive measures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Race covenants designed to prevent Negroes and other minority group from owning real estate must be held against the law, the Federal Government declared in a br filed in the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Appeals to American Federation of Labor unions to support the work of the Free Trade Union Committee of the AFL were voiced here tonight at a dinner arranged by the committee for 200 delegates who met earlier to implement labor's Educational and Political League.

TOKYO, Dec. 5 -- Reports that former Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Liberty party -- representing the majority of Japan's moderates -- would soon announce a new platform for the re-establishment of a free economy and the ending of large-scale Government controls that flourished before, during and since the war, are attracting considerable attention here today.

Complete planning for converting the peacetime American economy that turned the tide against the totalitarian forces in World War II into a war economy should an emergency occur is going forward rapidly, Thomas J. Hargrave, president of the Eastman Kodah Company and chairman of the Munitions Board, said yesterday in an address to the National Association of Manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Worthington Thompson of New York today became executive secretary of the National Security Committee, whose chairman is Owen J. Roberts, former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Bureau reassured corporations today that it would not punish them for withholding "reasonable amounts" from stockholders for use in their business. This season has been one of increased dividend declarations by many corporations.

Both dressing rooms looked like losers' quarters after the bout. Joe Louis was his usual, calm, unemotional self, but his retinue was hardly the joyful group generally expected in the winner's camp. They appeared glum and dissatisfied.

Isidore Labourace of 16-22 West 111th Street went to his home Wednesday night to find that not only had he been evicted, but his furniture had been taken to the borough storage yard. Yesterday he went to the office of Borough President Hugo E. Rogers and announced that he wanted the tin can that decorated a bureau in his three-room apartment.
OKAHA, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A twoman fight, with prospects of the later entry of a darkhorse, was under way today for the National Amateur Athletic Union presidency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The United States Treasury announced today authorization for Britain to resume drawing on the remaining $400,000,000 of her $3,750,000,000 credit from this country. The credit had been "frozen" since last August.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Announcement of the seizure as alien property of the Greenpoint Coal Docks, Inc., of 37 Commerce Street, Brooklyn, N.Y., was made here today by Attorney General Tom C. Clark.
The "new look" in newspapers, born of printers' labor disputes with publishers, spread to Allentown, Pa., yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 (AP) -- An attempt to block a three-way merger of oil companies was dismissed today in Federal Court.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- President Vincent Auriol tonight refused a request of the Communist-controlled executive committee of the Confederation of Labor that he hold up the application of the new law against incitement to strikes and sabotage to permit negotiations between the strike leaders and the Government.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- The best feature in otherwise quiet stock markets here today was the improvement in gilt-edge issues on small but steady buying. At the close all-around gains up to 1/2 point had been recorded.

CAMP KILMER, N.J., Dec. 5 -- When retreat sounded here tonight, 500 officers and enlisted men of the Organized Reserve Corps, most of whom had not set foot on an Army post since the end of the war, were gathering here to take part in the first large-scale postwar exercises by the reserves in this area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The United States has sounded out China about any possibility that Chinese troops could be made available, presumably as part of an international police force, in the event that serious fighting developed as a result of a partition of Palestine, it was learned tonight.

From all parts of the country, skiers converged on the Olympic Headquarters in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday. By nightfall, the squad of thirty-four, including coaches and managers, was almost ready for Monday's departure aboard the S.S. America for St. Moritz, scene of the Fifth Winter Olympic Games.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- For the second day running the Soviet delegation to the Council of Foreign Ministers, which previously had avoided contact with Western newspaper men, held a press conference tonight on the day's meeting.
World unrest in financial circles was translated yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange into the sharpest break in the market in two months.
BERLIN, Dec. 5 -- The "All-German People's Congress for Unity and a Just Peace" meets here tomorrow with everything being stage-managed by the Communists, who issued the invitation.

The Experimental Theatre, an adjunct of the American National Theatre and Academy, will launch its second season tomorrow evening at the Maxine Elliott Theatre with Charles Laughton in his own adaptation of Bertolt Brecht's play, "Galileo."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Lack of road-building equipment due chief y to the prevailing shortage of steel and potential demands for this type of machinery by the Marsha11 plan will reduce the scope of 1948 highway construction in this country by at least 30 per cent "when highways are so sorey needed," Charles M. Upham, engineer-director of the American Road Builders Association, said today.

Mayor O'Dwyer recommended last night an 8-cent fare on the municipal transit lines as an indispensable part of a comprehensive 1948 program of state and city legislation designed to meat the city's expense budget needs for 1948-49 and its capital project requirements for the next ten years or more.

THE trouble with a good many expert travelers is that they know just what they are going to find before they reach their destination. Their minds are made up, their books, are planned. All they need is a hatful of on-thespot corroborations. On their heads, as Mr. Eliot said in a slightly different connection, assurance sits like a silk hat on a Bradford millionaire.
MILAN, Italy, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Stocks slumped in Milan today, touching off a riot by a mob that stormed the Stock Exchange.
Random notes. The North Carolina waterfowl season will open Monday and late reports indicate plenty of geese but not an overabundance of ducks, at least in the coastal area.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- Paramount is planning production of a sequel to "Dear Ruth" under the title "Dear Wife" with as many members of the cast of the original picture as are available, it was learned today.

A new synthetic chemical called dibenamine, which acts as a nerveblocking agent, and if successful would eliminate the necessity for surgery of the sympathetic nervous system, was described here yesterday at a closing session of the annual meeting of the American Society of Anesthesiologists.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has ordered a copy of the minutes of yesterday's hearing before the State Labor Relations Board at which a kitchen hand had asserted that Sherman Billingsley, proprietor of the Stork Club, gave $600 to him over the last fortyeight hours for favorable testimony in his behalf.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- The minors' National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues quit juggling the convention's "hot potato" today and dumped it into the laps of the majors when they asked the big leagues to vote either "Yes" or "No" on the Pacific Coast League's resolution to become a third major league.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Piling up a much greater majority than in the general election of 1945, the Conservative candidate won yesterday's by-election at Epsom, home of the Derby.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Mrs. Bernice E. Gold Gollobith, 36 years old, married only three weeks, was found dead of strangulation at 1 o'clock this morning in the trunk of her own coupe off Route 10, not far from her Denville farm.
If there is any remaining mystery as to who will manage the Brooklyn Dodgers next year it will be dispelled at 11 o'clock this morning in the club's Montague Street offices.

RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Rebellious Burmese Communists, flouting the authority of Premier Thakin Nu's Government, have seized power in three districts north of Rangoon and established regimes of their own, it was announced officially today.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 5 -- An international organization of port authorities that could take the initiative in standardizing hemispheric port regulations was recommended today to the annual convention of the American Association of Port Authorities.

Mayor O'Dwyer reached a turning point in his administration and perhaps in his political career last night. He took the bold course, turned his back on the sacred "tradition" of the five-cent fare and launched out on an ambitious program that may, if he succeeds in getting what he asks, distinguish him in New York annals as the Mayor who was a builder.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Competition from substitute materials, plus rising costs for leather manufacturers, make it imperative that the tanning industry adopt a comprehensive and continuing research program, Clifford Roberts, vice president and director of research, United Shoe Machinery Corporation, warned here today.
GENEVA, Dec. 5 -- The Human Rights Commission broke up into working groups today to tackle simultaneously its three main problems.

In the midst of a furious controversy over an assistant superintendent's ban on the singing of religious Christmas carols in twenty-three Brooklyn public schools, harried officials of the Board of Education made no move yesterday to revoke the ban other than to insist that customary procedures would be followed.
Mrs. Joe Walcott, wife of the challenger who nearly jarred Joe Louis loose from the heavyweight crown, took her husband's defeat calmly last night -- but she thinks her Joe "actually won."

Ferdinand C. Smith, national secretary of the National Maritime Union, CIO, charged yesterday that M. Hedley Stone, union treasurer, had given a "false and unwarranted picture of the union's finances that serves only to mislead the membership."

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Committee will not seek mediation by the International Olympic Committee's executive council in the stalemate concerning America's ace hockey entry in the 1948 winter games, Chairman Avery Brundage of the United States group said today.

During the past year significant forward strides have been made in American education. Although the teacher shortage is still acute, there are signs that it is gradually easing. Many communities, particularly in the larger cities, are no longer forced to employ as many substandard teachers as they did in the past.

If talent always received its just reward, the "Caribbean Carnival," which was put on at the International last evening, would turn out to be a rousing show. For some of the dancing talent is remarkably accomplished and original, and several of the numbers first rate.

Reporting that the United States has become China's major source of supply, A. Guy Hope, United States consul at Shanghai, said yesterday that China could easily absorb a half billion dollars in American capital goods if it could get it.

Three plans instead of one will be presented next week by distilling groups to James A. Stillwell, a special assistant to the Secretary of State, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, carrying on the voluntary food conservation program, it was learned here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today redistributed service permits for the British Commonwealth and other overseas points among American radio telegraph companies.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- There are "no fundamental constitutional rifts" in Britain where Laborites, Liberals and Conservatives are all "equally united against the conception of Communist tyranny," Winston Churchill said today in ceiving the freedom of the city of Manchester.

An editorial published yesterday in The Columbia Daily Spectator, Columbia College newspaper, charged that Columbia University's barring of Howard Fast, novelist, from speaking on the campus was based on "invalid and dubious grounds."

The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Sturdy squash, now plentiful and always nutritious, holds the center of interest on Saturday's Peace Plate. Squash has a special affinity for fruit, which is another way of saying that this fruit-meat stuffing has a flavor all its own.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Senator John Sherman Cooper, Republican, of Kentucky, called upon the Administation today to tell the people "openly and plainly" that the current problem of prices and supply is connected closely with exports and the proposed European Recovery Plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Ten Hollywood figures who refused to tell a Congressional committee whether they were Communists were indicted today by a Federal grand jury for contempt of Congress. Under present plans, they will be arraigned Dec. 19 or Jan. 2.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The Association of American Railroads asked Congress today to permit the readjustment of war-time taxes paid by carriers on income later returned to the Government as refunds for overcharges.

The National Association of Manufacturers adopted unanimously yesterday a resolution calling for a concerted attack on the country's housing problem by modernization of the housing construction industry.

The biggest, single, human problem before the United Nations is the plight of the world's children. Of two billion people in the world, about 826 million are children under 18 years of age; and of these children one-third are living close to starvation. Does this fact strike terror into the hearts of the diplomats at Lake Success and into the hearts of adults of the wellfed nations?

JERUSALEM, Dec. 5 -- Shooting broke out again today on the border between Jaffa and Tel Aviv but Jerusalem remained entirely quiet through what was regarded as a critical day and this week's disorders here appeared at an end.

Following is the text of Mayor O'Dwyer's address on his fiscal and legislative program as broadcast last night from City Hall: Ladies and Gentlemen: When I took office in January, 1946, I found the facilities and services of our city depleted and run down, chiefly as the result of the long war years.

Samuel Moskowitz, dismissed on Nov. 26, as a. relief investigator, was released in $1,500 bail yesterday pending a hearing on Dec. 29 on five counts of petit larceny involving $70 and two counts of violating the State Social Welfare Law.

Fewer than 30 per cent of the 475 hotels and apartment hotels registered with the City Rent Commission have applied for rent increases, Paul L. Ross, commission chairman, said yesterday in a discussion of the grounds on which such increases may be granted.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 5 -- The Potomac Edison Company, Hagerstown, Md., asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to sell at competitive bidding $4,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage and collateral trust bonds and to issue and sell 50,000 shares of its common stock to its parent, the West Penn Electric Company, New York.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Dec. 4 -- Germany, once leader in the field of synthetic rubber, will soon be left without a synthetic rubber works, it was indicated today. As a first step in that direction the bizonal agencies have not renewed a contract with the Soviet zone for shipments of this commodity in 1948.

OTTAWA, Dec. 5 -- Parliament was opened today in special session by Governor General Viscount Alexander of Tunis. As soon as the customary ceremonial was over there was criticism of the Government's proposed measures to preserve and supplement Canada's reserves of United States dollars.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in a two-to-one decision ruled yesterday that the commission of a mercy slaying is evidence of the lack of "good moral character."

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- The Building Industry Employers of New York in annual convention here today proposed an increase in apprentices in the building trades to relieve the shortage of craftsmen, especially bricklayers and draftsmen.

Christmas Trade About Even Christmas retail trade here this week on the average showed little change from the comparable period of last year, according to estimates by store executives yesterday. Several stores went ahead, while others fell slightly behind.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 5 -- The city of Sao Paulo resumed normal conditions today following a hectic night. Last night the city resembled an armed camp as the mounted and foot forces of the crack state police succeeded in preventing the Communists from holding thirty scheduled meetings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- George Meany, secretary-treasurer of the American Federation of Labor, called tonight for swift Congressional approval of the European recovery program and declared that failure to carry it out would ultimately mean war.

Though Joe Louis retained his world heavyweight championship last night by defeating Joe Walcott in Madison Square Garden, the decision went to the wrong man, in the judgment of hundreds of indignant callers who flooded THE NEW YORK TIMES' switchboard immediately after the result was announced.

The Whitney Museum's 1947 annual exhibition of contemporary American painting opens today with work by 162 artists, a slightly smaller but quite as colorful an event as last year's survey. The installation takes up all the museum's gallery space and will continue through Jan. 25.

The American Broadcasting Company and the directors of the Boston Symphony are holding a series of discussions with a view to arranging cooperative sponsorship of the orchestra. The symphony currently is heard on a sustaining basis at 9:30 P.M. Tuesdays.

The maritime unity conference of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, held in New York last month, ended in disagreement, and further widened the split between CIO sea unions, according to accounts of the meeting in the National Maritime Union's newspaper, The Pilot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A colloidal suspension of asphalt for spraying on coal to form a coating by which the coal particles are rendered substantially dust-proof and impervious to moisture and oxidation, was one of 407 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

Saturday, Dec. 6, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Mr. Truman is vacationing at Key West. The Senate Not in session. Republican Policy Committee approves joint leadership conferences to prepare party's anti-inflation program.

The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, chief operating subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced yesterday a new scale of prices for nine tinmill products at mills in Pittsburgh and at Gary, Ind. The prices, the first set listed for the new year by a major mill, show increases ranging from 85 cents to $1.05 for base boxes of 100 pounds.

Joe Louis is still the world heavyweight champion today because he won a split, unpopular decision over Jersey Joe Walcott, Camden (N.J.) Negro challenger, last night in a fifteen-round battle in Madison Square Garden.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 5 -- Unanimous endorsement of New Zealand's program of increased self-government for its trust territory of Western Samoa was reached today in the United Nations Trusteeship Council.

HAVANA, Dec. 5 -- The divergence of views between economically developed and undeveloped countries at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today caused the appointment of a special subcommittee to study the proposal for an economic development committee in the proposed International Trade Organization.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A close finish came about in the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth American League Purse at Gulfstream Park today, with Brosnan Halley's Danny J. beating Mescara by a nose.

The one trouble about "Aida," performed last night in the Metropolitan Opera House, is that it will survive any performance, and, on the other hand, is such a masterpiece in grandeur and in detail that it deserves the degree of attention that it never receives in preparation, for the stage.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 5 -- Water treated with chemicals to increase its "wetness" has been tested successfully in fighting recent Westehester County woodland fires and should play an important part in fire-fighting in the future, two engineers told the American Society of Mechanical Engineers today during a final session of their meeting here.

THIS novel sings of illegitimate ladies and philandering men, and a long-winded, blowsy song it is. Covering three generations, it moves from a virtually unidentifiable England (remotely seventeenth century) to a convictfilled Australia of a slightly later date.

An occasion that communicated as it could not have been communicated under any other circumstances the genius of a masterpiece was the performance of Verdi's "Otello" given by the NBC Symphony Orchestra, with assisting soloists and choruses, under the direction of Arturo Toscanini, and broadcast to most of the world yesterday afternoon.
GENEVA, Dec. 6 -- Leap year day, Feb. 29, 1948, has been tentatively set as the day on which citizens of all United Nations will be asked to give a day's pay for aid of children.

IN the opinion of people who keep an eye on metrical matters, poetry really came into its own the other night at a dinner sponsored by the Academy of American Poets, which in turn is sponsored by -- among others -- Robert Frost, Marshall Field, Conrad Aiken, Walter de la Mare and Herbert Hoover, not all of whom write rondeaus.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 6 -- Charles Brinton of Philadelphia, national amateur squash racquets champion, was eliminated from the Gold Racquet tournament today as play started at the Rockaway Hunting Club.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- This island resort has welcomed so far in 1947 twice as many visitors as it had in the same period in 1946, and the Colony has opened what it expects will be its liveliest and longest winter season in years.
Competing in a field of twentyfive, Miss Madeline Dalton, representing Salle Santelli, captured the annual Anthony Greco Trophy competition at the Fencers Club yesterday.

In his annual report as president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael notes that our colleges and universities increasingly recognize the importance of international studies However, most colleges have a long way to go before they can establish a well-rounded program, in this difficult area.

Wall Street is digging in for its annual battle between management and labor. Union contracts on the New York Stock, Curb and Cotton Exchanges and several brokerage houses expire on Jan. 31, 1948, and the thrusts and parries of both, parties are being readied for the contract negotiations that are soon to come.

Dr. Luke D. Broughton, who had practiced medicine for more than sixty years in Brooklyn and was one of the oldest practicing physicians in that borough until his retirement several years ago, died on Friday in Brooklyn. His age was 88.

The Yuletide Ball, at which twenty-seven young women will be presented to society, will be held on the night of Dec. 26 in the ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, under the auspices of the Yuletide Committee of the Brooklyn Kindergarten Society.

The stock market paused yesterday after its sharp plunge of Friday and, in effect, took time out to appraise its current base of operations. Prices throughout the session on the Stock Exchange drifted within a narrow range to an irregularly lower close.

THIS is the time of year when home owners become alarmed at the browning of evergreens. They deluge tree experts with frantic calls for help. In most cases there is nothing to worry about, and a popular misconception should be debunked: "evergreens" are not ever green!

Compensation of wholesale soft goods salesmen during the last few months has been subjected to a serious "squeeze play," Ben Spindel, member of the advisory council of the National Association of Women's and Children's Apparel Salesmen, revealed in an interview last week.

TO Northerners the Caribbean is a stretch of water "somewhere down there" beyond the Florida Keys where tourists go for fun and a winter sun tan. The Caribbean is a big sea. An arm of the Atlantic Ocean, it is 1,500 miles long, 400 miles wide at its narrowest and 700 miles at its widest point.
OMAHA, Dec. 6 -- A group of global-thinking enthusiasts who met here this week presented convincing proof that interest in water and soil conservation is expanding rapidly, and on a world-wide basis.

MOTORISTS traveling on highways this winter should be overcautious. The perils of driving on roads in inclement weather will be multiplied because automobiles will be one year older and less perfect. A check-up is urged before setting forth on the nation's highways.

The former United States liner Washington, second largest Americanflag passenger vessel, will again fly the company's wellknown "Blue Goose" on North Atlantic sea lanes, returning to private service on Feb. 4, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO -- Early fall snows have set ski clubs of the Middle West to brushing their downhill slopes and oiling the pulleys of their rope tows in preparation for the biggest ski season since the war. The Central United States Ski Association currently has a record of seventy member clubs scattered from Minnesota to Ohio and as far south as the Great Smokies of Tennessee.

LEON KARP, who has achieved a considerable reputation in Philadelphia, his home, has been introduced last week to New York audiences in his first local one-man show at the Luyber Gallery. Karp paints portraits and still-life with a rare sensitivity to light and sensuous color in a manner that seems distilled from Manet and the early Cezanne.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 6 (AP) -- The New Jersey Congress of Industrial Organizations convention today crushed left-wing attempts to substitute the national CIO foreign policy statement for a strongly-worded endorsement of the Marshall plan and criticism of the Soviet Union.

IN simplest terms, fresco work is the painting of murals on wet mortar. That it is closely related to the building trade itself is emphasized by the fact that more than half of this lucid handbook on fresco painting is devoted to a detailed description of the techniques and problems connected with the laying of the fresco grounds.

BALLET THEATRE'S current season at the City Center may not be -- indeed, definitely is not -- the best it has given us. In apite of the substantial weight of genius in its top ranks, its ensemble, including the corps de ballet and most of the secondary soloists, is perhaps the weakest it has ever had, and the result has been a haphazard alternation of brilliant and, shall we say, infelicitous performances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- An outright embargo on all exports from the United States to Russia was proposed today by Representative Alvin F. Weichel, Republican, of Ohio, as "a last resort if necessary to stop supplying a potential enemy."

Public funds have been misspent in the city's administration of public welfare through failure to check eligibility adequately, failure to place recipients in categories receiving large Federal contributions, and by granting excessive assistance in some cases, the State Board of Social Welfare charged yesterday.

Everglades National Park, twentyeighth and newest in the United States, is a 1,000,000-acre expanse of cypress swamps, mangrove forest and tropical jungle on the southwest tip of Florida. Last July the state of Florida gave the Federal Government $2,000,000 to buy the last privately owned property in the area.

The battle to save the nation's natural beauties and resources has to be fought all over again every few years, as all who heard or read President Truman's speech yesterday at the dedication of the Everglades National Park must have been reminded. We certainly do have to "remain constantly vigilant to prevent raids by those who would selfishly exploit our common heritage for their private gain."

In previous seasons folk singers who have come into the regular concert halls have appeared in joint programs of at midnight events. But now their art has become more fully recognized, many are giving solo recitals of a more formal nature at regular hours.

Columbia experienced phenomenal growth during his long tenure. From 1902 to 1938 the roster of teachers rose from 407 to 3,325; that of students from 4,293 to 32,245. The annual budget increased from $1,380,924 to $15,039,212 and the value of the plant from $25,708,146 to $58,878,187.

NORTH BERGEN, N.J., Dec. 6 -- The police here arrested today two men who were said to have admitted responsibility for nearly a dozen robberies of doctors' and dentists' offices in Brooklyn in recent weeks. The prisoners related that they had robbed a doctor in Baltimore and were on their way back to Brooklyn to rob doctors' offices there, according to police.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today that more than 100 stable isotopes of twenty-nine elements were available for distribution to research laboratories in the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Diplomacy like politics, is an art, not a science. The very word diplomacy conjures up qualities like tactfulness, skillful management, dexterous handling of affairs, clever manipulation. A government has policies; a diplomat must put then into effect in his personal dealings with other diplomats pursuing other policies.

BUENOS AIRES -- This most remote metropolis of the western world is now 19 hours and 15 minutes from Miami by air. That is the newest and most dramatic travel fact in South America. The carioca-andtango continent still lacks adequat shipping facilities to satisfy the tourist accustomed to the broad range of pre-war cruises.

PANAMA, Dec. 6 -- The Government of Panama has agreed to lease the heavy bomber base at Rio Hato and thirteen other sites in the republic to the United States for ten years for the defense of the Panama Canal. The agreement contained a stipulation for an additional ten-year renewal of the lease.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The Florida West Coast is experiencing a building boom which approaches the boom of the Nineteen Twenties. This time it is not into the plush tourist hotels and clubs that most of the money has gone.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- John Foster Dulles, who was the object of a protest by enraged Communist Deputies in the Assembly for his "interference" in French internal affairs, met Charles de Gaulle today.
HlGHLIGHTS of this crowded week include "On Stage" with Michael Kidd as guest artist and the season's first "Undertow" at the ballet, and Kreutzberg's farewell at the aiegfeld. The schedule follows:

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Most of the country's leading contract bridge stars were among 166 pairs, the largest field ever to compete for a national bridge title, who began play this afternoon in a four-session contest for the national open pair championship.

FORT BELVOIR, Va., Dec. 6 -- The Fort Belvoir Engineers, football champions of the Second Army, ran rouglishod over a visiting Camp Kilmer (N.J.) squad here today in an inter-Army tilt played before an estimated 3,000 spectators. Halfback George Evans of New Orleans led the Engineers scoring parade as he racked up five touchdowns in the 41 to 7 rout.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The House Un-American Activities Committee, which has lately pinpointed its anti-Communist fire on Hollywood, will broaden its attack after the first of the year, Chairman J. Parnell Thomas promised this week.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: "The Great Victorians," edited by H.J. and Hugh Massingham, figuratively paraded across the spotlight of page one. Forty contemporaries chose forty Victorians to write about; among the chosen were William Morris, Wilfred Blunt, Cardinal Newman....

KAMLOOPS, B.C. -- Simon Fraser, the first westbound white man to surmount the Rockies and come down to tidewater in western Canada, found it a land of "long winters with vast amounts of snow, and mountains all about."

Reports of the issuance of an order that would prohibit the Maritime Commission from entering into any long-term operating subsidies are causing much concern in the maritime industry, it was learned yesterday.

WHILE railroad coach travel has improved through the arrival of much new equipment, the outlook for betterment in firstclass or sleeper travel continues to be clouded by the delay in delivery of new sleeping cars that have long been on order. Shortage of these cars explains why travelers are still having trouble obtaining reservations.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Winston Churchill predicted today that under socialism 12,000,000 Britons "will have to disappear in one way or another."

As it has done with consistent regularity in the last few seasons, the Columbia Broadcasting System once more has shown how the horizons of contemporary broadcasting may be extended through mature thought and care.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- About twenty rulers of Indian Princely States are meeting in New Delhi to form a tribunal for dynastic disputes and other matters of peculiar concern to the Princely order.

"SPEARHEAD," an anthology of poetry, fiction and drama, is a memorial to the first ten years of James Laughlin's publishing house, New Directions. A memorial is appropriate and Mr. Laughlin certainly has a special place in the literary history of this period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The national capital promises to be as quiet tomorrow as it was the last time Dec. 7 fell on a Sunday, as quiet as it was that day, in 1941, until in the early afternoon the fateful news was flashed of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the Philippines and Guam.

The conviction that the Arab masses do not want any conflict with the Jews was expressed by Moshe Shertok, director of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, at a service "of prayerful thanks for the Jewish state" in B'nai Jeshurun Synagogue, 257 West Eighty-eighth Street, yesterday.

THE horizon of world travel is steadily widening. The tourist who plans to circle the globe in 1948 will have no difficulty, at least so far as transportation is concerned. Whether le prefers ships or planes, the tourist will find what he seeks.

The theory of increased cooperation between parents and school officials was endorsed yesterday by representatives of both groups at the twenty-sixth annual meeting of the United Parents Associations in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

While Investment bankers were discussing in their convention in Florida last week how European aid should be administered and financed and as they blasted the Government for its suit against them accusing them of violating the anti-trust law, two large pieces of industrial financing went to institutional investors.

ATHENS, Dec. 6 -- John Q. American, who has put up the money, may be wondering why, with all the expenditure in Greece, a mere twenty thousand guerrillas have not been cleaned up and the country put back on its feet; why, on the contrary, guerrilla warfare keeps expanding, and why, as winter approaches, there are urgent cries for more money.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 -- The University of Kentucky football team parlayed power and deception into a one-two punch that ripped Villanova College of Philadelphia for an upset 24-to-14 victory in the first annual Great Lakes Bowl game in Municipal Stadium today.

It seems to have teen agreed upon that the special session of the Congress will not give consideration to any income tax legislation. Accepting this as authoritative, relief legislation must then be enacted early in the new year if we are to have reduction for the taxable year 1948; lack of time will preclude a broad revision of the Federal tax structure for 1948.

OF the Whitney Museum's 1947 annual of contemporary American painting, which opened yesterday, let it be said at the outset that it is a decidedly stimulating event, representing the cross-currents of art today from realism to nonobjectivism.

SKI trains, ski buses and ski planes are important parts of the winter transportation and holiday operation today though they date back only nineteen years to the first ski train, six years to the first ski bus, and nine years to the first ski plane.

WATERBURY, Conn., Dec. 6 -- Frederick Starkweather Chase of Middlebury, Conn., retired president of the Chase Brass and Copper Company here, died last night of a heart ailment in the Waterbury Hospital. His age was 85.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the current discussion of prospective austerity, price control, and rationing, there is danger that the fundamental economic issues may be buried under layers of political propaganda. In the first place, while it should be recognized that the European Recovery Plan adds an inflationary force to our economy, the publicity given to the "Marshall Plan" has impressed the public unduly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Usually informed sources expressed today the hope that Britain would use her influence with Bong Abdullah of Trans-Jordan to help bring about a partition of Palestine without an outbreak of serious fighting.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Take Wing, owned by Mrs. Clyde Troutt, came home fast after trailing his field to win the $5,000 Crescent City Handicap, feature of today's racing at the Fair Grounds.

The first Junior Assembly for this season was held last night in the ballroom suite of the RitzCarlton. Traditions which have surrounded the Assemblies since their establishment several decades ago were manifest last night with but one exception.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Despite organized opposition by realty men, builders and some other interests, Congress now is considered virtually certain to vote extension of Federal residential rent controls, according to opinions expressed here today.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Public Safety Director John B. Keenan of Newark wrote to Governor Alfred B. Driscoll today asking for state legislation embodying the features of the New York State Weights and Measures Law, particularly with respect to that section making it a misdeamnor to label goods falsely with an intent to defraud.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the cold war for Germany, which started in London on Nov. 26, Mr. Molotov has won the first battle. There is no man or woman in Germany who will not cheerfully approve what he said about the necessity to restore the country as an economic and political unit.

IN responding to his partner's opening bid, a bridge player is guided by several principles. Following one of these, he tends to bid his best suit; following another, to avoid raising the level of bidding when his hand is weak; and following a third, to consider whether his hand is worth only one or as many as two bids.

The opening of the hunting season in New York always was the signal for a bombardment of letters from hunters protesting the scarcity of "public" shooting grounds, but this season's volume has set a new high.
Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed ia the following table, which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:
VANCOUVER, Wash, Dec. 6 -- Indignation and 'chagrin over Canada's new "austerity" regulations seem virtually as prevalent in the State of Washington as on the neighboring soil of the dominion itself.

THIS highly authoritative story of a unique art was first published in a privately printed, limited edition. This new edition is identical with the original in both format and plates and is -- in itself -- a fine item for the book collector.

Taking a page from its experience in the last war, the Quartermaster Corps has made considerable progress in its industrial mobilization plan for food, textiles, clothing and equipage to bring manufacturers to peak production for the armed forces without costly delays and bottlenecks, it was learned last week.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 6 -- Down in the southern Appalachian Mountains the price of at least one commodity -- moonshine whisky -- has gone sharply downward, agents of the Federal Alcohol Tax Unit here report.

Five thousand visitors crowded the Holland-America's Hoboken pier and the refurbished liner Nieuw Amsterdam at the first postwar sailing of a big cruise liner at midnight Thursday. The gala scene familiar to cruise-goers and visitors in the era before the war was recreated and with a new angle.

TUCSON, Ariz. -- Ten years ago it was only the adventuresome tourist who decided upon Arizona for a winter vacation. But today Arizona ranks high among the nation's winter resort centers. Planes and trains Arizona-bound from wintry eastern climes are filled to capacity.

OMAHA, Dec. 6 -- The National Amateur Athletic Union today adopted a resolution urging United States withdrawal from the 1948 Olympic winter games unless the hockey team sanctioned by the United States Olympic Committee is recognized as the official American entry.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds today announced a thirty-nine-game schedule for their 1948 spring training season, including four games with the world champion New York Yankees.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- League-leading Arsenal, unbeaten up to last Saturday, stayed in the slump that has followers badly worried when soccer warfare was resumed throughout Britain today -- but the old label "Lucky Arsenal" stuck for a 1-1 draw with Manchester City.

In the 'Cold War' The key battle in the "cold war" between the United States and Soviet Russia is now being fought out in France. That fact was made increasingly clear last week by the course of events both inside and outside the Fourth Republic.

Christmas shopping spurred activity in all departments at retail stores last week, and the peak has not yet been reached, according to the survey prepared weekly especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Dress sections were reported as "active" with clearance "pulling," new holiday type fashions in demand and formal fashions selling.

HONOLULU -- The chances for a vacationist, wearing a lei and a coconut hat, to sit under a coconut tree and watch a hula, or ride the surf in an outrigger canoe at Waikiki are better this year than they were a year ago.

IN the days of which we write, when some of us who now are old were young, our winter sports were not promoted by special trains, and skiing had not been imported from Switzerland, or wherever -- or skijoring from Scandinavia.

PARIS (By Wireless). THE gray, sunless winter of northern Europe has descended upon Paris long before the city was prepared for it. The preparation, which had been well advanced as compared with previous postwar winters, has been checked by a combined political and labor crisis, deepening the uncertainty and fears for their future that have beset the French ever since their liberation from the German Army.

CARGO ships are wonderful things. They carry 100pound sacks of flour, automobiles, rubber and animals, and an amazing assortment of passengers -- including women with a spirit of adventure. So I recently discovered on a 22,000-mile trip to the Orient and back via the Atlantic route.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov successfully continued today his campaign to pin the Council of Foreign Ministers down to the shadowy realm of propaganda and away from the substance of the German problem.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The first positive move of the American Federation of Labor to rally non-Communist unions into a countermovement of the World Federation of Trade Unions will take place at Lima, Peru, next month.

Closer liaison between the Department of Commerce and retailers will get under way this week at a meeting between officers of the Retail Advisory Committee of the department and officials recently designated to undertake this work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- New Yorkers may have seen what looked like a depression nightmare this week when 4,000 men waited for hours in the cold to apply for 1,000 city day-laborer jobs. But placed against the background of the nation's best peacetime unemployment record, the bad dream dissolves into a line of men simply looking for more secure Jobs at better pay than the ones they already have.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Fighting between Netherlands and Indonesian forces has simmered into quiet as a result of conciliation by a three-nation committee of the United Nations Security Council, it was reported today.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 6 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea is expected to arrive early next month, Wiliam R. Langdon, United States State Department representative here, announced today.

Assembly of the giant steel magnet for what is to be the most powerful cyclotron (atom-smasher) in the world was completed yesterday at Columbia University's new nuclear physics research center at Nevis, Irvingtonon-Hudson, N.Y.

The newly completed memoirs of Cordell Hull, whose long service as Secretary of State illuminated a public career spanning the most critical and tumultuous period of the nation's history, will be published in this area by THE NEW YORK TIMES, beginning in mid-January.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Dec. 6 (UP) -- A 45-year-old Fort Worth housewife answered her telephone tonight, screamed "Martha Graham" and touched off a neighborhood celebration because she had identified "Miss Hush" and won a fortune in prizes.

The singing of religious Christmas carols in the public schools is a matter entirely up to the discretion of the individual school principals, teachers and children, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Fuel, particularly oil, is so tight that Americans are going to be asked soon to ration heat and adopt other conservation measures so that hardship and suffering may be avoided even if the country experiences as extraordinarily rigorous winter.

PORTLAND, Ore. -- The heaviest snows of the continental United States fall on the mountains and uplands of the Pacific Northwest, and already the ranges of this region lie beneath a deep covering of white. The high passes have been powdered with snow since Columbus Day; deer and elk have commenced to "yard" in swales and meadows where they can forage.

WQXQ, the frequency modulation affiliate of THE NEW YORK TIMES radio station, WQXR, has begun operation with a new antenna which increases the outlet's radiated power by fivefold, it was announced yesterday by Elliott M. Sanger, executive vice president of WQXR.

The "five-cent fare" has been a "tradition" in New York City politics for decades. Last week, for the first time, a Mayor -- William F. O'Dwyer -- directly told the people that the nickel transit fare would have to be abandoned. The step was regarded as a political risk.

THIS edition of Lanier's poems, printed sixty-three years after his death, is apparently directed to the gift-book trade; a trim and decorative volume, its lacy drawings are in remarkable harmony with the verse. The selection is ample enough for a full-bodied view of Lanier's poetry, the narrative fragment "The Jacquerie" and the dialect poems perhaps noticeable omissions.

THE founding of the Experimental Theatre a year ago was in itself an experiment. A movement without precedent in the professional Broadway theatre, each of its problems was brand new and had to be decided without benefit of experience.

Recently he asked an old Italian gentleman -- old in years, but young in spirit and rich in proverbial wisdom:

Victory Song, champion of Castleton Farms Stables, has been named the "Harness Horse of 1947," it was announced yesterday by E. Roland Harriman, president of the Trotting Horse Club of America. Fifty sports editors, harness racing writers and radio commentators comprised the committee that picked Victory Song.

YOU need to hear only a few phrases of Edith Piaf's singing to know that hers is a distinctive gift. If you listen to all six sides of the Vox album, La Rue Pigalle, in which La Piaf sings six of her repertory of French songs, you will come away with the conviction that she is an artist in her field.

CONSIDERING his lack of a formal education, Joe Louis has an amazing facility for expressing himself and many a conversational gem that he has dropped in most casual fashion has been widely quoted. The Brown Bomber added another to the collection on Friday night a short while after he'd gained a disputed decision over Jersey Joe Walcott in Madison Square Garden and thus retained his world heavyweight championship.

To the Screen Editor: WITH what searching yet beguilingly humorous commentaries did Ernst Lubitsch enrich our photoplays! Whether he was engaged in poking gentle fun at middle-class English conventions as in "Cluny Brown," or in satirizing collectivism in "Ninotchka," there was always the same adroitness, the same sure "touch."

ROME -- Italy is ready for its first full-fledged post-war, winter tourist season. The newly created Commissariat of Tourism soon will issue a "Calendar of Events" for 1947-48 featuring snow-sports contests in the mountain resorts of the north, celebrations and festivals in the south, and first-rate opera performance all over the peninsula.

ROCKPORT, Masa. A LOT of New Englanders and regular visitors to these parts don't like what's happening to church steeples hereabout. Every once in a while a fine old steeple disappears, a victim of fire, hurricane, lightning, termites, building inspectors, safety laws or persuasive members of wrecking firms.

Last week this department called attention to the work of the late Dr. William B. Coley in his use of mixed toxins of the streptococcus of erysipelas and bacillus prodigiosus in the treatment of malignant diseases. It also pointed out that the great progress made since Dr. Coley's day in bacteriology, biochemistry and related sciences opened the way for preparing Dr. Coley's toxins in a much purer form.

LOS ANGELES -- In his first important political talk since he announced himself a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, Gov. Earl Warren last night renounced the "non-partisanship" which has been both a boon and a problem to him in California.

Sixty-six residents of the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street have one topic of conversation today -- the home's seventyfifth anniversary next Sunday, and its celebration next Saturday.

Bryant High School's tall team experienced little difficulty in defeating Forest Hills, 56 to 32, as Madison Square Garden's thirteenth season of scholastic basketball was launched with a quadrupleheader yesterday. More than 5,000 spectators sat through the five-and-a-half-hour matinee program.

WARSAW, Dec. 6 -- The trial of the Polish Underground Coordination Committee took a new, sensational turn today when, for the first time in these processes, a defendant swore that the two Cardinals of the Polish Church had had direct knowledge of the underground's activities.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- Pennsylvania's mountain vacationland has spent a busy summer and fall enlarging its facilities for winter sports enthusiasts. New slopes have been cut through the hills and tows and mechanical lifts have been installed.

An incumbent slate, headed by Austin Hogan, was re-elected yesterday to head Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, for the next two years.

WARSAW, Dec. 4 (Delayed) (UP) -- The manner in which the United States handles the German question is the greatest test of United States friendship and understanding for Poland and Europe, Prime Minister Joseph Cyrankiewicz said in an interview today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Six years ago tomorrow the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor. Today the Veterans of Foreign Wars and the American Legion demanded continuing preparedness against any future attacks through universal military training.

In present circumstances should the Federal Reserve Board continue to support the market for Government-securities? That question was uppermost last week in financial circles, with the banking community divided and the pros and cons highlighted by statements by a top banking spokesman and by the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets hero by the United, States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 300 trend; total 6,000 (estimated). Compared with week ago; Barrows and gilts 75 cents to $1 higher; sows 50 to 75 cents higher.

THE Western Ocean, with its bitter winds and towering seas, has been the central stage of man's long battle with the sea since the days of the Vikings. On its roiled and restless waters wars, shipwrecks, victories, defeats have each succeeded each in endless drama.

HOLLYWOOD. THE problem of history and the Roman Catholic Church on the screen, which has been solved without violence to either one in Ingrid Bergman's current Joan of Arc film, has cropped up again in connection with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's projected remake of "The Three Musketeers."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Labor's demand for a third round of wage increases, combined with rising prices and soaring profits, appear to be heading up to form one of the most volatile issues of the 1948 political campaign.

TRENTON -- New Jersey needs only a good cold winter to prove to sports enthusiasts that it can offer an enticing variety of skiing, tobogganing, outdoor and indoor ice skating, ice boat racing and hunting. The state is not only hoping for that frigid, snowy winter; it is definitely planning for one.
MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Paul Herzog, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, appealed to labor today to give the Taft-Hartley Law "a fair trial."

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- As the strike of composing room employes against Chicago's six major daily newspapers nears the end of its second week, it appears the situation has reached a state of equilibrium which may last, barring legal, intervention by the National Labor Relations Board, at least until Jan. 2.

"I HOLD that it was wrong to have considered me a revolutionary," writes Igor Stravinsky. "When the 'Rite [of Spring]' appeared, many opinions were advanced concerning it. In the tumult of contradictions my friend Maurice Ravel intervened practically alone to set matters right.

COMMERCIAL airline travelers who have been kept busy adjusting themselves to one type of air transport after another since the end of the war have at least two more adjustments to make in the near future. The first adjustment will be to the Douglas DC-6, now temporarily and voluntarily grounded while the airlines and manufacturers work out some "bugs," and the second will be to the giant double-decker Boeing Stratocruiser.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- CIO workers at the Oak Ridge (Tenn.) atomic energy plant today received approval from their international union for a strike which they have authorized to be called if negotiations fail.

BANGOR, Me., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Two soldiers from the Dow Field Army air base were charged today with murder, Sheriff Herbert L. Pinkham of Lincoln County said, in the Killing on Thanksgiving eve of Bene Browne, 28 years old, a Rockland telephone worker, at Wiscasset.
