MONTREAL. THE exhibition branch of Canada's motion picture industry has been hard hit by the Government's dollar-saving measures, but the emergency decree, which tightly curbs imports of "luxury" products from the United States may, in the final analysis, prove to be a good thing for the producing end of the industry.

The United Jewish Appeal, now ending its current campaign for $170,000,000, win hold a five-day national conference at Atlantic City, beginning next Thursday. Jewish leaders from every large city in the United States will discuss the 1948 program for European relief and rehabilitation, immigration and settlement in Palestine and refugee aid in this country.

BUENOS AIRES. AN anonymous telephone call, but one carrying unmistakable official authority for all that, has suddenly put an end here to the successful run of the Italian motion picture, "Open City," which dramatizes resistance by partisans in Rome during the Nazi occupation.

LOS ANGELES -- California, never backward about tourism, will embark on a new era of receptiveness to the American traveler as the new year swings in. Nineteen forty-eight marks the one hundredth anniversary of the discovery of gold at Sutter's Mill, and hence the brightest highlight to date in a five-year observance of California's "centenary" due to culminate in its hundredth admission anniversary in 1950.

The Marshall plan for European Recovery is foredoomed to failure "unless we find some economic road of cooperation with Eastern Europe," James M. AN outstanding success of the New York theatrical season is a version by Robinson Jeffers of the tragedy "Medea," by Euripides, staged by John Gielgud and giving Judith Anderson the acting triumph of her distinguished career.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Johnny Palmer of Badin, N.C., and Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, sneaked up on Jimmy Demaret, the debonair Californian, to share with him the 54-hole lead of the $10,000 Orlando open golf tournament today with scores of 205.

THE Duchess of Wellwater -- nee Trottie True of the Gaiety Chorus -- startled but did not deceive fashionable Edwardian society when she appeared at the Trousseau Tea. Memories of her rollicking past underlined the delicious improprieties of the intriguing present.

HAVANA -- Cuba is looking forward to an excellent tourist season this winter although shortage of hotel space will prove a handicap during December and January.

Prompt action to save, Europe and to preserve our own economy was demanded yesterday by Robert F. Wagner Jr., chairman of the City Planning Commission and of the New York chapter of Americans for Democratic Action. IN 1940 in Boston a new play, "Battle of Angels," a production wearing the colors of the Theatre Guild and directed by Margaret Webster, opened lor a two-week tryout. At the tryout's end, it closed -- with an apology from the Guild to its subscribers.

The Episcopal Actors Guild has taken over the performance of "Angel in the Wings" on the evening of Dec. 17 at the Coronet Theatre as its twenty-fourth annual benefit. The proceeds will be devoted to a special relief program maintained by the guild to aid actors and actresses who are ill or in need of emergency help.

ATLANTA, Ga. -- The opening Jan. 1 of Jekyll Island, former playground of the rich off Georgia's coast, to the public as a park and resort center, will highlight the winter season for the South Atlantic States. Georgia is looking forward to the heavist winter tourist season ever.

ATLANTA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Georgia Tech's athletic director, W.A. Alexander, today lashed out at "bowl committees conducting games with little consideration for competing teams" and hinted that the National Collegiate Athletic Association may investigate the method of distribution of gate receipts and tickets.

Native Westchester fieldstone combined with Roman brick features the new Wallachs White Plains store on East Post Road and Mamaroneck Avenue, which will be formally opened tomorrow. Construction work on the store was begun in mid-September by Harold L. Fischer, Inc., builder of White Plains.

ENSENADA, Mexico -- This small, isolated fishing village (population 3,800) is just a dot on the map of Baja (Lower) California, 200 miles south of Los Angeles and seventyfive miles from San Diego. No Tijuana or Agua Caliente, border towns inexplicably attractive to tourists, Ensenada faces on one of the finest bays of the Pacific.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Planners of the projected world capital on Manhattan's East River are working on a new architectural scheme that would set off the central unit for the General Assembly as a monumental symbol of the United Nations, it was learned today.

TORONTO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- In the wildest scoring game this season, the Toronto Maple Leafs increased their National Hockey League lead when they swamped the last-place Chicago Black Hawks, 12 -- 5, before 13,471 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight.

THIS is for the parents of teen-age boys and girls who feel as one mother does: "Harassed, concerned, irritable and old-fashioned -- who am I? This is the era of the quiz program and this is the one-dollar question. No prompting, please! The answer is -- the mother of a 16-year-old girl, of course."

An all-star eleven from Dickinson and Lincoln High Schools of Jersey City ousted the Staten Island High School All-Stars, 26 -- 6, before 1,500 fans in Thompson's Stadium, Staten Island, yesterday. Lincoln fielded a team for the first and third quarters and Dickinson the second and fourth, while Staten Island had a composite team from Curtis, New Dorp and McKee.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 6 (AP) -- New Hampshire's eight-game winning streak was wrecked by a rugged Toledo Rocket eleven today, the willing but outweighed Wildcats dropping a 20-to-14 verdict in the second Glass Bowl contest before a crowd of 13,500.

BEAR MOUNTAIN -- The skitow at Silvermine Hill, less than five miles from Bear Mountain Inn, will operate daily this season. In the past, the tow, which services an intermediate and expert trail has been open only on week-ends and holidays.

PARIS -- The Mediterranean coast of France is preparing for its winter season after its most successful summer season since the war. This, if all goes well politically, will begin around Christmas and offer a refuge for the winter weary until the end of March.

NOTRE DAME -- Commerce Studies The University of Notre Dame's College of Commerce is expanding its use of visual education to give students a clearer and more graphic understanding of the various aspects of finance, marketing and industry. Films and slides will now be used in place of field trips whenever possible.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- The Boston Bruins and the New York Rangers played to a 5-5 National Hockey League tie before 13,000 fans at the Boston Garden tonight. Tony Leswick scored the visitors' equalizing goal one minute and 49 seconds before the final bell.

MRS. MICHIKO YAMAZAKI of Tokyo divorced her husband when he came home from the war with an Indonesian consort and two children, then ran against him in a House of Representatives election and won handily.

THIS volume on shells, by Mr. Morris, chief preparator at the Yale Peabody Museum, follows two guides on birds in the same series. It covers the marine snails and bivalves of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, touches on representative chitons, scaphopods and cephalopods, and includes a considerable number of deep-water species commonly secured only by dredging.

When the cornerstone of the annex to the Advertising Club of New York at 103 East Thirty-fifth Street is laid tomorrow afternoon it will contain prophecies as to What the world may be like in 2004. That year, the hundredth anniversary of the founding of the club, was selected as an appropriate time for the opening and reading of the predictions.

Ed Heusser, major league veteran righthander, whose most recent big-time service was with the Brooklyn Dodgers, emerged as the best percentage pitcher in the International League in 1947. He won nineteen games and lost three for .864.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Selling pressure in corn developed again today on the Board of Trade, and prices, after being ahead slightly in early dealings, slipped below the preceding close. The action of corn created a nervous market in other grains.

The Board of Foreign Scholarships, appointed last July by President Truman to administer the new Fulbright Law, will meet in Washington on Saturday under the auspices of the State Department. The law authorizes executive agreements with foreign governments under which such governments may pay in part for purchases of American war surplus by establishing scholarships for American students in their schools.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- New Mexico, a state which offers the attraction of Indian dances all the year around, is thought of by many Easterners as part of the hot Southwest where snow is seldom seen. That is the principal reason most Northerners came to New Mexico in the winter, time, to bask in the mild weather, ride the range of the dude ranches, see the Indian ceremonial dances.

EVER since the Miss Buncle books, and later the Mrs. Tim series, admirers of D.E. Stevenson's stories of English country life have looked forward with pleasure to the next in line. They are written with charm and ease, a knack for highlighting human foibles witii humor; they make England seem still the traditional happy isle, even under post-war rationing and austerity restrictions.

THE American dollar is today both a prized object and a glamorous symbol. At home and abroad, it is "almighty" and there are few people who feel they have enough. Yet, in essence, the dollar bill is only a rather complicated printing job.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr., lashing out at Communism, said tonight that America was the world's only hope of preventing totalitarian enslavement and the start of "another dark age."
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 -- More than 8,000,000 refugees crossed the India-Pakistan border in both directions up to Nov. 21, the Dominion of India press information bureau announced this week.

ESME DAVIS, who wrote about her cosmopolitan life as a dancer, circus performer and perfume manufacturer in "Esme of Paris," has fictionized the life of her gypsy grandmother, Lola Bazil, in "Seed of The Serpent." Grandmother was quite a person in her own right.

The American Automobile Association has made a survey of plans for automobile license plates for 1948. The results suggest that improvement could be made in present methods. There will be few brilliant colors on the 1948 plates. Seventeen states and Canadian provinces will use aluminum finishes and eighteen will use black backgrounds.

THE fifth annual Madison Square Garden Poultry Show will be held from Tuesday through Sunday. More than 6,000 entries have been made, about the same number but a more comprehensive showing than in previous years.

HEADLINES of late have compared our price spiral to the Twenties -- especially the peak pre-depression year of 1920. In those days butter reached 76 cents a pound, sirloin steak, 48. Milk cost 17 cents a quart, and a dozen "strictly fresh" eggs sold for 92 cents. There was no restraint on rents and clothing prices were so exorbitant that buyers' strikes were all the style.

The silence of December is upon us. There is no fly-buzz or bee-hum even on the midday air, no Insect whir or rasp when evening comes. The wind may rattle the oak's dry leaves, but the sibilant whisper through fullfoliaged trees is a midsummer memory. The dawn clamor of the crows no longer echoes, nor does the sweet matin song of the robin.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- What's going to happen to prices in the next six months ?

CAMP KILMER, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Staff personnel of the Seventyseventh Infantry Division, Organized Reserve Corps, and three other New York area reserve units ended tonight one phase of their first major training exercise since their reactivation.

IN February, 1942, Navy Secretary Knox called to Washington Edward Steichen, one of America's most distinguished photographers, gave him a commander's silver oak leaves for his collar and put him in charge of organizing naval aviation's photographic history of the war.

ALAMEDA, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Three hundred licensed officers and unlicensed seamen manned posts on a dry-land "ship" at Neptune Beach this week, training to increase their efficiency in the postwar American Merchant Marine.

The text of President Truman's speech as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Chairman Pennycamp, Mr. Secretary of the Interior, Governor Caldwell, Senator Holland, Senator Pepper, Distinguished Guests and Ladies and Gentlemen:

TO THE EDITOR: Brooks Atkinson's article "Faith, Not Fear, Must Move Us," is an excellent restatement of the late Franklin D. Roosevelt's "the only thing we have to fear is fear itself." However, it suffers from an omission from which the extension of Roosevelt's philosophy did not -- that is, a positive program offered to eliminate the cause of fear.

OSCAR WILLIAMS has collected from three of his books of poems ("The Golden Darkness," 1921; "The Man Coming Toward You," 1940, and "That's All That Matters," 1945) this series of apocalyptic visions of the disintegration of our civilization.

MIAMI -- The whole state of Florida is hopefully awaiting the tourist boom expected to result from the formal dedication yesterday of the Everglades National Park. The twenty-eighth and newest national park, it is hoped, will tap a new strata of tourists, bringing to Florida thousands of visitors attracted by the only tropical jungle within the continental United States and by the strange wild bird and animal life to be found within its borders.

NEW ORLEANS -- Undaunted by the autumn hurricane, resort towns and cities along the Gulf Coast have long since pulled themselves together and completed preparations for a big winter season. Not a single hotel was damaged in the big storm.

Princeton and the Squadron A Armory can well be proud of Paul Miller. The 26-year-old poloist turned in the top game of the season last night as he led the Squadron A Regulars to their second straight success over Al Lubash's Bermuda trio, 17 to 12, in the feature match of the double-header at Squadron A.

Jules Moch, Minister of the Interior, who is emerging as the strong man of France, declared yesterday: "The battle is won; I am master of the situation." It may be so. France was face to face with a Communist insurrection. It could have ended in revolution and the passing of an enslaved nation under Russian domination.

MONTREAL -- Most of the skiing in eastern Canada is done in the Laurentian Mountain area which begins about forty miles north of Montreal. Here, in a strip of hills some fifty miles long, lies the most intensely developed ski country on the North American Continent.

To the Music Editor: THANK you for printing Morton Estrin's letter in THE TIMES "Mail Pouch" of Nov. 16. It's high time somebody started raising hob about what goes on in the music teaching profession.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 6 -- The policy of the United States toward this country seems epitomized by Ambassador James Bruce's recent reference to President Juan Peron as "a great leader of a great nation." The comment came about six months after President Trumna had proclaimed that estrangement with Argentina was at an end.
It seems almost paradoxical that steel companies, in their present era of booming and profitable operations, should be selling out their businesses to consuming groups.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Dee. 6 -- The American Association of Port Authorities unanimously approved today a resolution urging Congress to adopt a statute "clearly providing that the master of a merchant marine vessel shall be in command of that vessel, and all the officers and crew thereof snail be subordinate to the lawful orders of the master."

MIAMI, Fla. -- This town, composed of almost equal parts of sun, beaches, palm trees and hotels, used to be the terminal point of a large percentage of Florida-bound vacationists. They came here to spend their holidays, and they stayed here.
HOUSTON, Texas, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said tonight that revising taxes affecting business should come ahead of a reduction in tax rates.
Circumstances have conspired so as to enable the Football Giants at last to creep out from under the shadow of the Football Yankees.

TOKYO, Dec. 6 -- The Japanese Cabinet voted tonight to pay a bonus of 220,000,000 yen to members of the Japan Federation of Mine Workers Unions. A nationwide coal mine strike had been scheduled for tomorrow midnight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The American Federation of Labor said today that it now required three-fourths of an hour's work to pay for a pound of butter.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Artillery, owned by the Rolling Hills Farm of Walter G. McCarty of Los Angeles and ridden by Herb Lindberg of Arcadia, today won the fifteenth running of the $60,300 Bay Meadows Handicap by five lengths before a crowd of 16,856 and equaled the track record of 1:49 for the mile and a furlong.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 -- The greatest legal battle in Australian history will take place in Federal High Court over the law recently enacted by the Parliament at Canberra authorizing nationalization of private banks.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- With an estimated $2,000,000 face-lifting nearing completion as the first and major part of its post-war rehabilitation, Bermuda looks forward to welcoming over 17,000 visitors -- perhaps up to 20,000 by the time Easter travel commences -- during this winter season.

NOW that the big wheels of the movies have publicly taken a stand against the employment of Communists in their business and have formally suspended five men who refrained from telling the House Committee on Un-American Activities what their politics are, a great deal of public misconception, indignation -- and maybe glee -- have been aroused.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 6 -- Embattled drivers of the Long Beach Bus Company, aided and abetted by the local police, were operating the city's bus routes today over the protests of the company, which wanted to put all of its equipment in its garage and padlock the door.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Oregon State College made up a 14-point deficit tonight to defeat Canisius, 50-48, in the first game of its Eastern basketball trip. Brigham Young topped Niagara, 54-53, in the opening game of the first Memorial Auditorium doubleheader of the season, played before 10,281 spectators.
PEIPING, Dec. 6 -- Nationalistheld areas in Manchuria have entered upon what may be the most miserable winter they have ever experienced.

THOUGH both of these novels have in common their devotion to the Roman Catholic Church and to the struggles of those in the poorer parishes, they are widely divergent as to their selection of material and their prose style.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The destruction of a huge counterfeiting ring, which has flooded the Midwest in recent months with bogus $10 and $20 bills, was announced today by Harry Anheier, chief of the Secret Service in Chicago.

BOSTON -- "The skiers are in the East -- but the snow is in the West." That condition, said a ski expert, expresses the potential and the hope as New England prepares for a winter sports season that is expected to attract a total of winter sports fans running into the millions.

After regional hearings throughout the country for almost three months, final hearings on the freight rate petitions of the railroads for an increase averaging about 30 per cent for the entire country are scheduled to open tomorrow in Washington.

First editions of note, autograph letters and manuscripts and books with fore-edge paintings collected by the late Col. John Bancker Gribbel of Media, Pa., will be auctioned tomorrow evening and Tuesday afternoon and evening at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.
Two-point margins decided both college basketball games at Madison Square Garden last night, with L.I.U. outscrambling Western Michigan, 48 -- 46, and N.Y.U, defeating St. Francis, 54 -- 52.

"LET nature take its course" is impractical advice so far as winter birds are concerned. When ice covers the trees, and heavy snow hides weed patches, birds are deprived of food supplies Every gardener knows they should not be allowed to go away.

At the 1916 convention Dr. Butler led a vain but valiant fight to obtain the Presidential nomination for Root. Perhaps inadvertently, he brought about the nomination of Charles E. Hughes as a compromise candidate. While the convention was deadlocked, George W. Perkins asked Dr. Butler to telephone Roosevelt at Oyster Bay.

Disgusted with the showing he made against Jersey Joe Walcott at Madison Square Garden Friday night in his twenty-fourth defense of the world heavyweight title, Joe Louis yesterday declared with emphasis that he will not retire from boxing.
OMAHA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Mayor James A. Rhodes of Columbus, Ohio, now a vice president of the National Amateur Athletic Union, tomorrow is slated to move up to the presidency of the group.

Under the auspices of the Pestalozzi Foundation of New York, and many persons prominent in educational, scientific, diplomatic and social circles, a dinner followed by motion pictures, will be given Friday at Sherry's.

THIS book by Ben Hur Lampman is a collection of meditative pieces of fiction mainly concerned with people of the Far Northwest and their relationship to universal myth. Mr. Lampman is associate editor of The Portland Oregonian, in which some of his writings first appeared -- indeed, his editorials have achieved recognition for their artistic merit -- and it is also true that his fiction reads, at times, like a very high-class Journalism.

AN attempt by Ansel Adams, West Coast photographer and lecturer, to redefine the types of photographic activity, precipitated a discussion at the Photo League last week, in which reportage was defended as a medium capable of interpretive treatment rather than mere recording.

The appearance tomorrow morning of a steam shovel at the north corner of Fifth Avenue and Sixtyeighth Street will signal the start of excavation work on one of the latest and largest apartment house developments designed to meet the demand for luxury type quarters on Manhattan's East Side.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, said last night that the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem "evidently enjoys powerful protection from very high, quarters, including, apparently, the British Foreign Office."

THE time is at hand for the annual departmental peek into the Christmas sock and buskin. Peeking back at us is the prospect of thirty-four plays and musicals that should give off an uncommon holiday glitter for their number, variety and quality.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Dec. 6 -- Manhattan College's basketball team turned on the heat for five minutes here tonight and defeated the Villanova quintet, 52 to 48, in the Villanova field house.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- An ultimatum expiring at midnight on Tuesday was delivered today to the Government by the Communistdominated Rome Chamber of Labor. It resulted from yesterday's riot at Primavalle, where the police fired on a crowd, killing one person and wounding others.

A revival of gang warfare in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn was indicated yesterday when a petty gambler was "taken for a ride" there. It was the first killing in the area linked to underworld rivalry since a major shift of detectives was made last summer to halt the many slayings.

MARSEILLE, Dec. 6 -- Two of Marseille's leading union officials sought orders recently from members of the Soviet Union's repatriation commission in a Marseille hotel it was learned today from official sources.

To the Drama Editor: IT has been lamented in your columns that 92 per cent of Actors Equity's members are out of employment. May a Broadway director be permitted an unanswerable question? How many competent members of Equity are out of work? * * *

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 6 -- Complete returns from, twentytwo of the largest Finnish cities showed tonight that the Communistdominated Popular Democrat party had lost twenty-three seats in city councils in this week's municipal elections.

ATHENS, Dec. 6 -- A decree prohibiting strikes in Greece "for the duration of the rebellion" was adopted by the Cabinet this afternoon and was put through a special session of Parliament tonight. It carries the death penalty for violations.

JOHN MARTIN, former Indiana newspaper man, now a free-lance writer in Chicago, is not the first writer to suggest that the golden mean of American life and thought is to be found in Indiana, long the center of the nation's population.

ATOMIC "ASHES" -- The frequency with which various fission products occur in the operation of an atomic furnace are being studied by Dr. Nathan Sugarman and Dr. Anthony Turkevich at the University of Chicago Institute for Nuclear Studies. They found that when a uranium atom splits in two, 6 times out of 100 the fission products are barium and krypton.

The State Department's reports of a buying spree in progress in Russia, because of signs that the ruble might be devalued, were beamed directly to the Soviet Union yesterday. The department's "Voice of America" radio broadcast a dispatch describing American reaction to the original reports Wednesday.
A Berliner, eager to follow the proceedings in the Council of Foreign Ministers in London, read these headlines last Tuesday in the leading newspapers of the four sectors of his city:

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 6 -- Say Blue, belonging to Mrs. Albert Sabath of Chicago, scored a hardearned victory in the seven-furlong Hollywood Handicap at Gulfstream Park today. Shriners' Day was celebrated and the 12,258 fans present wagered $605,934.

THE possibilities of setting up a postal administration as a United Nations agency and of printing special stamps are being inquired into by Secretary General Trygve Lie at the request of the U.N. General Assembly. The results of his studies will be reported to the Assembly's next session in September, 1948.

One hundred "luxury" type houses in the $50,000 to $60,000 price range are planned by Milton Adler for an "exclusive" Long Island colony in the Hewlett Neck Park and Hewlett Bay section of Nassau County. Two of the elaborate dwellings already are under construction and are scheduled for completion next March.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered all early losses yesterday and closed at net grains of 4 to 23 points. Most strength was displayed by the near months.

DENVER, Col. -- Less than a year ago, the common Eastern comment heard out here on Rocky Mountain skiing was, "The Rockies are terrific, but who wants to walk up an alp?" And then the tows came -- more than fifty of them. Many, like the sensational Aspen chair lift, ran part of last winter.

WASHINGTON -- New Yorkers fleeing winter in the North this time of year can find spring or fall in the mid-South, in North Carolina or southern Virginia, roughly halfway to summer in Florida. The climate in the mid-South is officially labeled mild in contrast to the semi-tropical languor farther South Virginia's Tidewater and North Carolina's Sandhills are popular resort areas in this belt.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- A definite split in the Christian Democratic Union, one of the two largest German parties, appeared probable today as prominent members defied their own leadership to participate in the Soviet-sponsored "all German" congress on the peace treaty.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- The highly centralized German film industry, one of the most effective propaganda outlets of the Nazis, will be completely broken up in the British and United States zones within the next few weeks, a Military Government official disclosed today.

ASTIN, Texas -- Motorists in Texas this winter will find the Texas highway system in its best condition since the war began. During the war, when construction was curtailed, the big Texas Highway Building Fund, derived from retail gasoline taxes, grew into many millions of dollars, and this has been matched by Federal road funds.

IGOR STRAVINSKY, who has not written an opera in twentyfive years, is planning one now. It will be in English and will hark back to Handel's London for its inspiration. Albert Goldberg broke the news in the Los Angeles Times.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 6 -- Sudden death and violence spread throughout Palestine again today as ArabJewish clashes continued.
GENEVA -- Arrangements are nearly complete for the fifth Olympic winter games to be held in San Moritz Jan. 30 to Feb. 8.

ATHENS. NEWCOMERS to Greece always ask, "Where is the front?" But there is no front, no line of battle, no fixed positions. In the mountainous regions, and most of Greece is mountainous, fighting between the guerrillas, alias the Andartes, and the Greek Army and its auxiliaries flares up anywhere, any time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations urged today prompt Senate approval of the inter-American treaty of reciprocal assistance that was concluded in Rio de Janeiro last summer, to demonstrate strong leadership of the United States for peace in a disordered world.

The site for the branch of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., at Bay Shore, L.I., was assembled by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., with Gladstone, Dasey Associates as co-brokers. Eight plots were involved, comprising nine stores, nine offices and five apartments at 1 to 3 West Main Street and 2 to 20 Fourth Avenue.

HOLIDAY trade is developing steadily towards the figures which will put the year's business several pegs above the $100 billion mark for the first time in history but there does not seem to be much enthusiasm about the thing.

NO other place on earth holds the wonders and treasures that may be found in New York City, nor the irresistible appeal which brings tourists and sightseers here wide-eyed and agog at every season, every day of the year. Very few of the visitors go home disappointed.

War veterans seeking financing for their newly acquired homes are faced with a "tightening" of the mortgage market in which the lenders are beginning to prove reluctant to invest in GI loans unless the new owners have a substantial equity at stake.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- The plumbing brass goods industry is among the first in the building lines to overcome post-war shortages, a spokesman for the plumbing and heating industries declared today. While all items in the industry's line are not equally available, the over-all situation indicates a return to a peacetime competitive position.

ALBANY -- The biggest news for New York State's wintersports enthusiasts this season is the report from Supervisor Arthur Draper that the $350,000 project at Marble Mountain, first step in the $3,000,000 ski development at Whiteface Mountain, near Wilmington in the Adirondacks, will be open for use soon after Jan. 15.

HAVING undertaken one of Shakespeare's most difficult plays, Katharine Cornell and her husband, Guthrie McClintic, have not been parsimonious with their skill, time or money. The play is "Antony and Cleopatra," much admired between covers but seldom on the stage.

American Aid to France, Inc., has been named a member of the Friendship Train Distribution Committee in France, it was announced yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 1757 Broadway. The committee is now working out plans for distribution of the first consignment of French supplies, which sails from New York today on the American Leader, renamed Freedom Ship for this voyage.

BERLIN, Dec. 6 -- Less than 50 per cent of the Germans living in the United States zones fell that a democratic government could be established in Germany today, according to a report on a United States Military Government survey issued today.

Europe must be reconstructed as a whole on the basis of economic rather than political lines, Oscar Lange, permanent Polish delegate to the United Nations and delegate to the Security Council of the United Nations, said yesterday at La Guardia Field before leaving for Poland by way of Paris.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur will have the support of Col. Robert R. McCormick, editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, for the Republican nomination for President in event of a deadlock among the leading candidates at the Philadelphia convention, Colonel McCormick announced here today on his return from a trip to the Orient.
GARRISON, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Paul Monroe, professor emeritus of education at Teachers College, Columbia University, died at his home here early today. He was in his seventy-ninth year.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 6 -- Gov. James L. McConaughy told more than 400 delegates to the annual state convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations here today that Connecticut has remained a pro-labor state "because the leaders of your group have tempered their judgment with intelligent appraisal of conditions and have been true to the responsibilities of their positions."

WHILE the Holy Land has long been a source of deep inspiration to artists, it has been only in the past four or five decades, after a journey to Palestine had ceased being a wearisome affair, that painters actually have been going there to create works of art on its soil, sacred to several creeds.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, with Goalie Bill Durnan in the star role, blanked the Detroit Red Wings, 4-0, at the Forum tonight and bolstered their fourth-place standing in the National Hockey League. It was Durnan's fourth shut-out of the season and he achieved it in a game replete with speed and close checking.
PRAGUE, Dec. 6 -- For political reasons and apprehensive of an economic crisis in the West, Czechoslovakia has forced a major change in her trade pattern just as trade was coming into equilibrium.

FOR THIS WEEK: If ground has frozen to a depth of about two inches, start coveringpeonies and other perennials planted this fall with a mulch of leaves or salt hay.... Break off the ragged tops of chrysanthemums to complete garden clean-up and pull out chickweed, sorrel and other weeds whose growth hasn't been halted by frosts.

THESE twenty-four anecdotal tales by Dr. Hewitt Ballowe, Louisiana physician, planter, naturalist, author, form something of a folk history of the Negro sugar-plantation worker. They touch on the customs and beliefs of that group from Africa and ante-bellum days to the present.

IT used to be growled that nothing was deader than a dead play, excepting a dead review of a dead play. But this pleasurable "Broadway Scrapbook" counters with proof that nothing can keep a good first-night more alive in a dozen years' memory than a good review of it by Brooks Atkinson.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- House Republican leaders are considering priorities to get three bills for war veterans through Congress before Christmas.

PANAMA -- Travelers to Central America will get a warm welcome this winter, partly because of the American dollars they will bring to countries greatly in need of dollar exchange. And in the tourist trade there are no complicated regulations.

IN spite of the gothic details that adorn the text and the fact that these are stories of torment and suffering even to death, these tales of Mr. Kolitz are not, as might be imagined, fantastic or horror tales. They are not even stories as we understand the term, for they lack that completeness and resolution that make the best short stories satisfying.

LAST spring when I learned that both the Metropolitan Opera and the San Francisco Opera Companies were scheduling a revival of "Louise," and that I was to sing the title role, I decided I would spend some time in the summer in France to study the part and, if at all possible, receive some coaching from the composer, Gustave Charpentier.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- The labor struggle in France calmed down considerably today, with little violence and less sabotage reported. It was doubted that many Government employes would take part even in the two-day warning strike voted by their leaders for Monday.

LONDON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- The Government returned oats and barley products and added more canned meat to its lengthening list of rationed foods today. Official sources said that not even the release of the last $400,000,000 of the United States loan could stave off further cuts in imported foods.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A Chamber of Deputies committee tonight approved a bill to remove all Communists remaining to public posts.

NO bulb for indoor culture can compete with the magnificent amaryllis for flower size and beauty. Mature bulbs may be purchased from fall to mid-April and they usually contain from one to six flower buds, according to their proportions.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, 85-year-old president emeritus of Columbia University and internationally known educator, died at 1:52 o'clock this morning in St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been under treatment for broncho-pneumonia that had set in Thursday.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Following are the texts of three proposals submitted to the Council of Foreign Ministers by Foreign Minister Molotov today (the translation of the first two is official and that of the third unofficial):

TWENTY-FIVE years ago in a lonely Egyptian valley a small group of excavators uncovered one of the most spectacular treasures of archaeology, the tomb of Tutankhamen, Here the boy king -- the last of the Eighteenth Dynasty pharaohs -- lay amid gold and alabaster, quartzite and semiprecious stones.

WHAT seemed like one of those wild hopes a few weeks back appeared on the verge of reality the other day with the disclosure that Louis J. Singer had taken a hand in the reactivation of the American Repertory Theatre.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 6 -- Samuel E. Darby Jr., a Democrat, who was elected Mayor of this predominantly Republican village last March under the non-partisan political system, died of a heart ailment last night in his home at 28 Oak Lane here, after an illness of two months.

Admission to this country of displaced persons from Europe, regardless of race or creed, was favored yesterday by junior high school pupils who took part in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR from Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

An unspecified number of fellowships and travel grants, designed to advance "research in problems which are clearly related to an understanding of the contemporary culture of a major area of the world," will be given to qualified graduate students, preferably in the field of the social sciences, by the Social Science Research Council for 1948, it was announced yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 6 -- The AngloAmerican Bipartite Control Office will present in a few days a Germandrawn law that, if approved, would represent the biggest step toward western German unity since the creation of the Bizonal Economic Council.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- With a population of 3,000,000 higher than its pre-war total and with organized criminals assertedly threatening an invasion of its fertile "pastures," California is witnessing the start of a crime study as comprehensive as any ever undertaken in the country.

MEXICO CITY -- Despite a disappointing summer and a fall season that got off to a slow start, Mexico expects a full and exciting winter and is preparing to entertain an even greater number of tourists from now until April than were entertained during the same period last year.

Christmas business last week reached a fast pace, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. Stocks generally, the report stated, were ample, but orders for fill-ins continued to arrive.

Two years ago, when this column was started, it was introduced by the statement that it would be devoted to "the needs and tasks of the millions of service men returning to civilian life." Since then, many of the problems of veterans' rehabilitation have been solved, and increasing attention is being given to the problems of America's far greater number of civilian handicapped.

THE schedule of competitive sports events for the coming season apparently will not be affected by the absence of leading American amateurs who will be in Switzerland for the Olympic Games. More than 100 skiing and ice-skating contests are listed in the winter sports calendar below.

Political leaders concentrated yesterday on a study of Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for an 8-cent fare on the municipal transit lines and new special taxes on taxicab fares, trucks and automobiles and liquor license fees At the same time real estate interests turned their attention to analysis of the Mayor's ambitious program to increase the city's taxing and borrowing power well beyond present constitutional limits.

Last week saw a number of significant developments in the field of atomic energy, with an outburst of activity on several fronts. Both Columbia and Harvard Universities announced near completion of their new giant cyclotrons. The one at Columbia, to be housed at its new nuclear physics research center at Nevis, Irvington-onHudson, N.Y., will be a mammoth synchro-cyclotron weighing 2,500 tons.

Columbia registered its second straight basketball victory of the season by beating Champlain College, 60 -- 31, at University Hall last night before 1,200 spectators. The Lions were never in trouble and led 31-9 at the half.
LOS ANGELES,Dec. 6 (AP) -- "I think," said Coach Frank Leahy, his hat pushed back and a grin spread across his big face, "that was perhaps the best single game a Notre Dame team ever played."

A NEW crop of little-known young New York painters predominates this week in a series of Christmas and other group shows that are remarkable mainly in evidence of technical ingenuities and broad eclecticism of influences.

ONCE in awhile along comes a perfectly wonderful idea for a work of fantasy. When the author fortunate enough to get such an idea also has the ability to tell it on a par with its quality, then we have another "Lady Into Fox" or "Animal Farm."

Rudolph Serkin, the pianist, and the Busch Quartet headed by Adolf Busch, gave the first of two subscription concerts yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program presented was devoted to two great masterpieces. It consisted of Beethoven's Quartet in B flat major, Op. 130, and Piano Quintet in F minor, Op. 34 of Brahms.

The area designated by the United Nations as the first Jewish state in 1,877 years is a pin-point of land at the hub of a vast and hostile Arab world. Under the U.N. plan, the state's total land area is 5,500 square miles; its Arab neighbors spread over 1,500,000 square miles of the Middle East.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Two weeks' experience of a strangely fluctuating strike movement in France has proved two things: (1) that the Communist party does not have complete control of the French laboring classes; (2) that it does have strength enough to cause a crippling disturbance in production.

ON Sunday night two weeks hence in the Waldorf-Astoria comes the annual big dinner of Bohemians, to which all musicians and music lovers who can get there hie themselves with a special anticipation and the certainty of brilliant entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- House managers of the Foreign Aid bill, in an effort to save the winter relief program from crippling restrictions, prepared today to make some concessions to forces supporting a sheaf of amendments that will be presented next week.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Dr. Daniel A. Poling, president and editor of the Christian Herald, said today that there could be no adequate program of national defense without universal military training.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Somewhere in rural America this week an electric light flashed on and the 2,000,000th customer was hooked to the Government's power lines.

HAVANA, Dec. 6 -- Undeveloped countries at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, which have reopened the commercial policy chapter of the Geneva draft charter for the proposed International Trade Organization, today centered their fight on a demand for the right to establish new regional systems of tariff preference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Wilson W. Wyatt, who quit the administration as Housing Expediter a year ago in a policy disagreement, will be in the front ranks supporting President Truman's 1948 election campaign as national chairman of the Jackson-Jefferson anniversary dinners, Democratic headquarters announced today.

TO THE EDITOR: The article, "A Land That Could Be Europe's Granary," by Thomas D. Campbell, and the accompanying photos give an inexact picture of North Africa. The grainfields there which are cultivated by Europeans with modern agricultural machinery give a higher yield than the grain fields of Montana.

For the thirty-sixth successive year THE TIMES this morning opens the doors of homes in which misery dwells and invites the interest and help of the good neighbor. The appeal of The Hundred Neediest Cases, which is stated in four pages of documented family histories in another section of this edition, has been made since 1912.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 6 -- Emerson High School of Union City captured the Hudson County Interscholastic A.A. football championship yesterday before 7,000 at Roosevelt Stadium, where it overpowered St. Peter's Prep., 26 -- 6, in a play-off contest.

THOSE who remember the New Opera Company's productions of Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte" and Verdi's "Macbeth" may have wondered what became of Hans Busch, who collaborated with his father, Fritz Busch, in presenting them.
CEDARHURST, L.I., Dec. 7 -- Stanley W. Pearson Jr. won the Gold Racquet for the second successive time today.
An American cargo ship slid from her pier on the North River at 12:30 P.M. yesterday with 4,000 tons of food, destined for France, as her principal freight.

Chances for thrifty purchases at the vegetable counter have narrowed considerably lately as fresh produce follows the higher price trend of other foods. Not to be overlooked, however, by the economically minded shopper are kale at 19 cents a pound, spinach at 12 cents and the elongated, white heads of celery cabbage that are so plentiful at present.
ROME, Dec. 7 -- The Communists gave a demonstration of their military strength by concentrating 20,000 Partisans in Rome and parading them this morning through the main streets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Boom conditions will continue next year in almost every American industry, the Department of Commerce reported today, but it added that the outlook is subject to upsets by the international situation. Department experts disclaimed any attempt to make a forecast for 1948 but on the whole their report on commodity trends was optimistic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Scoring two touchdowns apiece in a thrill-filled final period, the Buffalo Bills and the San Francisco Forty-niners battled to a 21-21 tie today in their wind-up football game of the All-America Conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Republicans were reported by a leading party member today as being ready to drive for a reduction of $5,300,000,000 in individual income taxes in 1948. This is $1,300,000,000 above the $4,000,000,000 sought in two bills vetoed earlier this year.

BOSTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- After going through seven straight National Hockey League games without victory, the Boston Bruins shut out the Montreal Canadiens, 1 -- 0, tonight before 13,900 fans at the Grarden. Pat Egan, defenseman, blasted in a thirty-footer during the fourth minute of the middle session.

VIENNA, Nov. 28 -- The war orphans in Austria who constitute a problem are those who are not only orphans but also displaced persons. These are either the children of slave laborers -- often illegitimate because their parents were not allowed to marry -- children brought to Austria to be nazified or children brought here for slave labor.

Satisfied that an 8-cent fare will keep the burden of municipal transit operating deficits out of the city's expense budget for the next few years, Mayor O'Dwyer is pressing for the earliest possible construction of a Second Avenue trunk line subway as insurance against any further fare rise, it was learned last night.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers clinched a tie for the Eastern Division title in the National Football League today by plowing through mud, rain and fog to a 17-7 victory over the Boston Yanks as 31,398 looked on in a game finished under floodlights.

Benjamin Fielding, Commissioner of Welfare, said yesterday he hoped to announce next Monday the appointment of a committee representing the private welfare agencies in the city to help him develop an integrated approach to the problems of social welfare in the community.

Comparatively few buyers were in the New York wholesale markets last week, so markets were quiet, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Winter coats in both better and medium price ranges were wanted, while some types of rayon piece goods were reordered.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 7 -- A Communist drive to get back full voting rights for all foreign students and the outlawing of the anti-Marxist students list of candidates at the Conservatory of Music and Dramatic Arts indicated the start, this week-end, of a Communist counteroffenslve against the recent defeats by the student opposition.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- While the strike wave in many parts of France appeared to be subsiding, the transport unions decided tonight to call a strike of Paris subway and bus workers for tomorrow and Tuesday. Several unions of Government employes have proclaimed a "warning strike" for those two days.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- According to child welfare experts who have visited all the Balkan states, Albanian children are in the greatest need.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- In two weeks the London Conference has developed into a kind of duel not so much of wits as of endurance between Mr. Marshall and Mr. Molotov. To watch these two men playing a four-handed game for the future of Europe is to see an epic clash of systems, ideals, backgrounds and aims embodied in two strong personalities.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 7 -- The Netherlands has entered, after two years, the final stages of its monetary purge, according to Finance Minister Dieter Lieftinck. This, however, probably will cover the next five years, by the end of which time all traces of freezing will have disappeared.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 7 -- Although the Long Beach Bus Company went out of business at midnight Friday, twenty drivers and nine maintenance men kept the vehicles rolling today for the second successive day. Long Beach police headquarters reported tonight that normal schedules were being maintained on the company's nine routes and no complaints had come from riders.

The standard of living of the peoples of Asia must be raised for the sake of economic stability, "without which we shall have no peace or security," former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman said yesterday. He declared that political unrest in Asia could be "heavy with menace for us."

Penn State, unbeaten and untied in nine games, led all other members of the Eastern College Athletic Conference in four out of seven departments of team statistics for the 1947 football campaign, according to the final figures issued by the E.I.F.A. yesterday.

As a direct result of effort at cooperation, labor-management relations on the whole were better in 1947 than in 1946 in the majority of 250 representative companies, the American Management Association disclosed over the weekend in reporting the preliminary findings of a year and a half study of employe participation in increasing industrial productivity.
GENEVA, Dec. 7 -- The approach of Europe's third post-war Christinas finds 20,000,000 children on this continent living in squalor and misery, in cold and in fear.

RED BANK, N. J., Dec. 7 -- Veteran skippers in the North Monmouth County area agreed yesterday that iceboat competition on the Shrewsbury River, which once rivaled in sports popularity its summertime opposite numbers--outboard motor and sailboat racing--on the same tributary, would have a comeback this winter, weather permitting.

The Child Care Centers Parent Association announced yesterday that a survey of 467 families with children in the city's child care centers showed that the fathers' weekly earnings ranged from $21 to $80, with most of them earning less than $50.

"Lucia di Lammermoor," "La Gioconda," "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will receive their first performances of the season during the Metropolitan Opera's sixth week, opening Dec. 15, it was announced yesterday. Lily Pons, Ferruccio Tagliavani, Bidu Sayao and Irra Petina will all return to the company during the week.

Beethoven's String Quartet, Op. 130, with both the finales Beethoven composed for it, was performed late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall by the Paganini Quartet at the New Friends of Music's sixth chamber music concert of the season.

NANKING, Dec. 7 -- China has reiterated her stand on the procedure to be followed in drafting the Japanese peace treaty in a new note to Russia. The contents of this note, which was a reply to a recent Soviet note to China, were revealed here today by Dr. George Yeh, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs.

A bronze memorial plaque in honor of forty-one members of Local 802, American Federation of Musicians, American Federation of Labor, who died in World War II was unveiled yesterday afternoon at the union's headquarters, 1267 Avenue of the Americas.

New York has become such a musical show window that it is only the occasional concert that is not marred by a sort of department-store glitter. But last night England's Griller Quartet gave a program at Town Hall that was completely free of it.
Major elements in the maritime industry are determined to resist demands of sea unions for another round of wage increases, they reported yesterday.

Carl W. Ackerman, dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism, announced yesterday that fourteen members of the American Society of Newspaper Editors would serve on Pulitzer Prize juries this year.

John J. McNamara, leader of the recent Railway Express Agency strike in this city, was re-elected yesterday to a new three-year term as secretary-treasurer of Local 808 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL.

Columbia experienced phenomenal growth during his long tenure. At the time he entered upon his executive duties in 1901, the total enrollment of students was 4,440 and the annual appropriation $1,039,797. Before World War II disrupted academic life, the number of resident students reached a peak of 31,411 and appropriations topped $15,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A group of Republican Senators lined up today behind a proposed limit on wheat exports which some lawmakers hope may prove an effective anti-inflation substitute for the controls and rationing authority sought by President Truman.

AFTER long months of soul-searching, conscience-probing and other inner conflicts which have not been matched since Daniel Webster wrestled the Devil, Branch Rickey has finally decided on the Dodger manager for next year. To the vast surprise of practically no one at all his choice turns out to be his unfrocked manager of last year, Leo Ernest Durocher in person.

On the eve of the departure of the United States ski team to the scene of the fifth Winter Olympic Games in Switzerland, President Roger Langley of the National Ski Association yesterday cabled Mayor Carl Nater of St. Moritz urging him to continue to support the United States Olympic Committee in its dispute with the Amateur Hockey Association.

Eliezer Kaplan, treasurer of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, declared last night that "we plan to bring at least 1,000,000 Jews to Palestine in the next ten years." He said the two states created by vote of the United Nations could be permanent only if "life and property are made safe for all inhabitants, Jews and Arabs alike."

Senator Capehart and Representative Grant of Indiana have proposed a revival of the wartime legislation to accelerate plant and machinery amortization over a period of five years. They point out that this legislation resulted in the investment "over a very short period" of $6,500,000,000.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The champion Cleveland Browns, tuning up for their All-America Football Conference title battle with the Yankees in New York next week, smothered the Baltimore Colts today, 42 -- 0, before 20,574 chilled fans in Municipal Stadium.

DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Thousands of Syrians flocked to the colors today after the Chamber of Deputies approved compulsory military service legislation. The bill drafts men over 19 for twelve months active service in peace; in war, the age limit is 17.
KEY WEST, Fla., Dec. 7 -- President Truman wound up a five-day vacation today, rested and refreshed for his return to the Capital tomorrow.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler was blessed with a long and many-sided life. He passes now on the ebbing tide of a former epoch, but no man left a deeper mark on his own time or erected a more solid monument of high achievement. He will occupy a unique niche in the memory of his countrymen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- An Army-Navy personnel board has recommended that all armed forces members who have been retired for physical disability be re-examined, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, advised President Truman today.
The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

The single novelty of the Ballet Theatre's week-end schedule at the City Center was the debut of Nora Kaye in the role of the Italian ballerina in Antony Tudor's "Gala Performance" on Saturday evening. Miss Kaye is a wonderful comedian, in addition to her other gifts, and it is not surprising that she played the part of the haughty goddess from Milano for all it is worth.

Walter Reese has been appointed vice president in charge of the Western departments of the Railway Express Agency to succeed Albert W. Hayes, who has retired. W.M. Smith has become a vice president and replaces Mr. Reese as general manager of the Mississippi Valley department.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Two of the Big Four powers, Britain and France, are believed to be favorably impressed with the Netherlands Government's claim to frontier rectifications and coal and potassium workings in Germany.

Samson Francois, the French pianist, who gave his first New York recital last night at Carnegie Hall, was first and foremost the virtuoso during the entire program ha presented. He disclosed a phenomenal technique, a remarkable control of dynamics, tone and color.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs added two points to their first-place margin in the National Hockey League tonight by defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2, before 16,491 fans. Thus the Leafs swept their week-end home-and-home series with the Hawks, who were beaten, 12 -- 5, at Toronto last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Russian alarm about the Marshall Plan appears in two lines of the propaganda which contradict each other. The Russians are telling Europeans (a) that the United States will not come through with help, and (b) that the United States will help Europe for its own imperialistic purposes.
Truancy starts gradually and, unless checked, will develop into chronic truancy, the Board of Education has learned in an intensive study of junior high school attendance in an east Harlem area.
MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 7 -- The Communist party in Marseille announced today that a series of meetings would be held throughout the city to "inform the people about the Marshall plan."

Results of the second annual Radio Awards of the American Schools and Colleges Association were announced yesterday by Kenneth J. Beebe, association president. The awards, which he said were established to encourage radio "to strive for public service and public enlightenment through intelligent programming," were determined by a poll of more than 150 educators and civic leaders throughout the country.
Their voices are silenced by sorrow through most of the year. Only at Christmas does the city hear their appeals for help.
J. Russel Sprague, one of the most important figures in the Republican party in New York State, is planning his gradual retirement from politics, it became known yesterday.

Col. William F. Heavey, New York District Engineer of the Army Corps of Engineers, will be appointed today by Mayor O'Dwyer to the newly created $12,000 post of Consulting Engineer to the Department of Marine and Aviation. The Mayor said yesterday that Colonel Heavey would take office immediately after retiring from the Army next Monday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Mrs. Wilkinson Wagar of Atlanta, Ga., and Mrs. Helen Sobel of New York, leading woman bridge master, last night won the national open pairs championship in the climactic four - session event of the American Contract Bridge League's eight-day winter tournament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The presidents of eighteen railroad brotherhoods organized "Railway Labor's Political League" today to inform their 1,250,000 members of each Congress member's record on labor issues and to get out the railroad vote in next year's general election.

New York's neediest were remembered yesterday by persons from various sections of the nation whose gifts helped to start the thirty-sixth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,946,969,307. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Seek Ad Facts for Tea An Initial budget of nearly a half million dollars is being spent by the Tea Bureau, Inc., on a research program that is expected to provide new ammunition for advertising campaigns on this product, it was learned over the week-end from a bureau spokesman.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Dec. 7 -- Post-war transitions in the American economy are reflected by a survey of summer work trends completed recently at the New Jersey College for Women by Miss Ethel G. Dawbarn, assistant director of the personnel bureau.
Many tenants are paying painting bills that are the landlord's responsibility under the Federal Rent Law, a survey disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Paris today forgot its strikes and political conflicts to pay tribute to Maj. Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc, hero of the capital's liberation, who was killed last week in a plane crash in North Africa.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- Tristan Bernard, French humorist, novelist and playwright, died in his home here today at the age of 81. He had been ill for several months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 7 -- Declaring that the "most effective political defense against the growth of communism in America is a fighting, liberal Democratic party," Chester Bowles told 400 delegates to the annual state convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today that "a Republican victory in 1948, on the other hand, would be right down their alley."

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 1 -- It is estimated there are in Belgium about 20,000 youngsters under the age of 16 orphaned as a result of the war. The great majority of them have long since shaken off ill effects of the wartime period with regard to nourishment and general health.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams erased a two-touchdown deficit today to defeat the Chicago Bears, 17 -- 14, snapping an eight-game winning streak for the Bears, who slipped into a first-place tie with the Chicago Cardinals in the Western Division of the National Football League.

A black miniature poodle, Champion Bric-a-Brac Blackbird, belonging to Mrs. P.H.B. Frelinghuysen of Morristown, N.J., took the best-in-show award at the revived Bronx County Kennel Club event in cavernous Kingsbridge Armory, the Bronx, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Dr. J. J. Dawson, secretary of the Joint Baptist Conference on Public Relations, told a congregation here today that religious education must be kept out of the schools in the interests of the traditional American church-state relationship.

Yesterday, six years to a day after the attack on Pearl Harbor, the Emperor Hirohito of Japan went to the city of Hiroshima to deliver a commemorative address. Like any public man in either country, he must have relived the episodes of Dec. 7, 1941, which in Japan ran over into Dec. 8.

WARSAW, Dec. 7 -- The Communists have bitten another large chunk out of the Socialist party's position in Poland by gaining' control of Spolem, the country's largest cooperative society and an important factor in her economy.

LAST October when Lionel Trilling's "The Middle of the Journey"* was published so many other new titles were also published that Mr. Trilling's was neglected, probably unjustly, in these pages. It isn't that "The Middle of the Journey" is an important or even a good novel. It isn't. But it is a sincere and ambitious one written by a sensitive and formidably intelligent man.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- Governor Dewey has no present intention of formally tossing his hat into the Presidential ring prior to the 1948 Republican National Convention, according to informed persons at the Capitol.

Last week's foreign exchange market had proceeded evenly enough to show no great disturbance in undertone or rates when, unexpectedly on Wednesday, there began a drying up of the demand for sterling "forwards" carried right up to the close on Friday to effect the sharpest setback in that market in many months, in fact, since mid-August when sterling convertibility was suspended.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 7 -- Arab-Jewish fighting flared in Germany over the week-end. Tonight, peace was believed restored after one Jew had been reported killed by stabbing, ten Jews had been stabbed or beaten, four of them seriously, and four Arabs had been stabbed or beaten.

CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Professional traders were aggressive on the buying side of corn most of last week in the Board of Trade, but the market became overbought later and prices broke. December corn at one time sold at $2.61 1/2 a bushel, or within 1/2 cent of the high record established the previous week.

Missing chances galore in a wild third period the New York Rovers were unable to match the speed of the Shawinigan Falls Cataracts and thereby dropped a 3-1 decision to the Dominion skaters in a Quebec Senior Hockey League tussle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Among the art exhibitions of this week are holiday group shows, a comprehensive annual of American painting at the Whitney Museum, and approximately twenty one-man shows, including work by well-known artists and newcomers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I cannot quarrel with the sentiment and the general tenor of the editorial in the times entitled "That City Council Seat" concerning the filling of the vacancy resulting from Peter V. Cacchione's death. However, you seem unaware of certain statutory provisions which would, if given due consideration, tend to alter your conclusions.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Going into the air for three of their five touchdowns, the Green Bay Packers scored in every period today to take a 35-to-14 National Football League victory over the Detroit Lions before a chilled crowd of 14,055 fans.

BERLIN, Dec. 7 -- The war on the Christian Democratic Union leadership implied at the opening session of the Communist-run allGerman congress yesterday, was openly declared today as that meeting closed.

YONKERS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- Plans for a year-long celebration during 1948 of the 150th anniversary of the building of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in Colonial Heights here were announced today by the Rev. W. Osborne Budd, rector.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Robert C. Goodwin, director of the United States, Employment Service, predicted today that employment in 1948 again will hit the "dream" mark of 60,000,000 jobs.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- In Prance there is no exclusive organization for the care and education of war orphans as a group. They are looked after by numerous independent organizations, including Assistance Publique, which is the government-operated institution for orphans, relief agencies in devastated areas, religious orders and numerous private institutions.

President Truman joined with leaders in all walks of life in paying tribute yesterday to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 7 -- Georgia's new building safety law, designed primarily to prevent loss of life in fires, became effective today on the first anniversary of the disastrous Winecoff Hotel fire here, in which 119 died.

Great Britain and the United States must cooperate closely to prevent another and more disastrous world war, Sir Norman Angell, winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1933, said yesterday at a special Anglo - American service held in cooperation with Common Cause, in St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 7 -- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer has acquired an option to buy the screen rights to "Across the Wide Missouri," a work by Bernard De Voto on the fur traders of the early nineteenth century. The studio plans to assign writers and a producer to prepare a photoplay from De Voto's book as a vehicle for Spencer Tracy.

Cotton prices in the domestic market moved irregularly last week. After a strong beginning, the market turned reactionary, with prices tending to back and fill in relatively moderate activity. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes ranging from an advance of 36 points to a decline of 8 points.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 7 -- President Romulo Betancourt today accused Rafael Caldera, Presidential candidate of the Copei party, of attempting to encourage a split in the Government between the military and the civil authorities.

Member of liberal Jewish congregations attended yesterday a Hanukkah synagogue conclave under the auspices of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues in the community house of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixtyfifth Street.

BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The problem of war orphans in Germany is a large one, but neither German nor Allied public welfare officials can say exactly how large it is. There are no accurate data on the numbers of children who lost their parents during the war; unofficial estimates put it at from 600,000 to 1,300,000.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 7 -- National registration of all Jewish youth for service and defense of their new state will begin tomorrow and be completed within a week, a Jewish Agency spokesman said tonight.
GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- Switzerland, whose children mirror the healthy, prosperous condition of their country, has taken on heavy burdens in helping the children of her less fortunate neighbors.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 7 -- A miniature war gripped the outskirts of Jaffa and Tel Aviv today although British troops moved into one part of the area early this morning.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Mayor James A. Rhodes of Columbus, Ohio, whose aim is to extend athletic privileges to underprivileged youth, took over leadership of the national Amateur Athletic Union today as the annual convention came to an end.

PATERSON, N.J., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Bethlehem Bulldogs won the American professional football league championship today with a 23-to-7 victory over the Paterson Panthers before a near-capacity crowd of 10,587 in Hinchliffe Stadium.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Two members of the Ryder Cup team, Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., and Herman Keiser of Akron, Ohio, and Wilmington, Del., Professional Dave Douglas tied at 274 for first place in the 72-hole Orlando Golf tournament today.

A salvage offering of $1,500,000 in obsolete machine tools and sealed bid sales of aircraft components, costing $1,300,000, were announced over the weekend by John R. Campbell, New York regional director of the War Assets Administration.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 7 -- Rightist followers in the Wisconsin State Industrial Council, state CIO body, scored a major victory today at the tenth annual convention when delegates gave a majority of about 5,000 votes to a constitutional amendment to reduce the executive board from twenty-six to thirteen members, including the president, vice president and secretary-treasurer.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals surged to six touchdowns in the second half today for a smashing 45-21 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles before 34,342 and threw both Eastern and Western Division races of the National Football League into a last-game scramble for the championships.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 7 -- Leopold, exiled King of the Belgians, has told a delegation visiting him at Pregny near Geneva that he was prepared to resume his constitutional duties, according to a communique issued by his secretariat here tonight.

The present Advent season should be a time of reconsideration of our responsibilities and stewardship "in a world that is both physically and morally sick," Col. Martin C. Poch of the Office of the Army Chief of Chaplains in Washington, declared yesterday in a sermon at St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-sixth Street.
TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 7 -- The "right wing" was dominant in the New Jersey Congress of Industrial Organizations tonight as its tenth annual convention concluded.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Several weeks ago I was interested to read in THE TIMES that a series of courses were to be given at the Hayden Planetarium of the American Museum of Natural History. What attracted my attention was a course on marline-spike seamanship.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 7 -- Production of steel ingots reached last week a new post-war peak, operations being raised 1 1/2 points to 98 per cent of theoretical capacity, or an annual rate that would reach or exceed the record in 1944, when 89,600,000 tons of ingots were produced.

With the friendly assistance of Charles Laughton, the Experimental Theatre has succeeded in putting on an experimental play. It is Bertolt Brecht's "Galileo," which had a fancy production at Maxine Elliott's last evening. Using Galileo's experience in science Mr. Brecht has told the age-old story of the conflict of truth with authority, for Galileo's epic struggle with the church epitomizes that part of human experience.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 7 -- The United Nations five-man commission may not leave for Palestine as soon as officials here originally had hoped, despite repeated warnings that the need for action has been made more urgent by Arab-Jewish violence, it was learned today.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Nov. 27 -- "The greatest wealth of a nation is its children," is a theme basic in the Bulgarian Government's internal policy. All former private institutions and enterprises for children are now state undertakings and three Ministries, those of Education, Health and Social Policy, provide large sums for children's care and coordinate their efforts for radical reforms in the bringing up of children.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York announced yesterday that its counsel would argue before the United States Supreme Court in Washington this week in support of its brief calling it a violation of the Federal Civil Rights Act to prevent Negroes, through restrictive covenants, from buying, selling or renting real estate.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dons closed their All-America Conference season today handing the Chicago Rockets a 34-14 pasting, an unpalatable going-away present for Coach Jim Crowley of the Windy City team.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- On the eve of the third week of the present session of the Council of Foreign Ministers, it can be stated only that nothing has been accomplished, nothing is expected to be accomplished and that United States, British and French tempers are frayed down to the last thread.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The long-range foreign policy of the present British Government seeks not only to foster the restoration of world peace and economic stability in cooperation with the United States but eventually, by the establishment of a firmly based Socialist system here, to make of Britain a bridge between capitalistic United States and the Soviet group, which might tend to facilitate global understanding.

If Christianity is to meet the challenge of materialistic philosophy there must be an end to Protestant denominationalism, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist area declared yesterday. He preached the morning sermon at the Riverside Church.

Remington Rand, Inc., announced last night that it was severing relations with the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, which has represented 10,000 workers in seven Remington Rand plants for periods ranging from one to six years.

VIENNA, Dec. 7 -- All prisoners of war who have returned to Austria and Germany from Russia in the last eighteen months were indoctrinated with communism during their confinement. The most suitable from the Soviet viewpoint received high school and university courses to fit them for service as Communist agents.

The Board of Higher Education has extended the experimental program of the Hunter College Elementary School, 695 Park Avenue, for three years, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Florence Brumbaugh, principal of the school.

NANKING, Dec. 7 -- Despite pressure from private concerns for less interference with business, the Central Government has found it necessary to tighten its grip on the economic system. Regulation of the distribution of cotton stud rice is being incorporated into the policy of "economic martial law."

The nation's leading stars in every entertainment medium will be sought for a vast fair in New York next November designed to raise $1,000,000 in ten days for the joint benefit of the Actors' Fund of America and the Motion Picture Relief Fund, two outstanding good samaritans of show business.

Funeral services for Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University and a figure of international renown in many fields, will be held tomorrow at 11 A.M. in St. Paul's Chapel on the university campus.

All reports from France agree that the attempt of the French sector of the Russian-dominated Communist International to stage an insurrection sparked by strikes, sabotage and violence has failed, and that the Schuman Government has remained master of the situation.

With his managerial problem finally solved, President Branch Rickey, along with all the other major league moguls, will plunge enthusiastically into baseball's big annual meeting, which, officially opens at the Waldorf-Astoria here tomorrow.

CAIRO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- High Arab sources said tonight that the Arab states intended to inform Britain that they planned to enter Palestine "with the full consent of Palestine Arabs" as soon as British troops withdrew.

Many additional tributes to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University, were received yesterday at the university. Among them were the following Dr. JAMES B.
