CONANT, president of Harvard University President Butler contributed to Columbia University and to education as a philosopher and statesman and his services to the country as a citizen of the world place him among the relatively few in each generation whose names are long remembered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Hazel K. Stiebeling, chief of the Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics, in an annual report, said that the rapid upward trend in prices during recent months meant that many families were laving difficulties in making ends meet, even though incomes and wage rates tended to be high compared with those of pre-war years.

Characterizing the procedure of the Thomas Committee on UnAmerican activities as "silly," Morris L. Ernst, an attorney and a member of the President's Committee on Civil Rights, urged last night in an address at London Terrace. 405 West Twenty-third Street, that all subversive groups be forced out into the open.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 8 (AP) -- The University of Illinois, displaying a well-balanced attack, came from behind in a last half surge tonight to upset highly rated Notre Dame, 40 -- 38, for the Illini's second consecutive basketball victory of the new campaign.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- French fears over the future disposition of the Ruhr's industrial production and the establishment of a highly centralized state in Western Germany were quieted by John Foster Dulles during his pilgrimage to Paris, it was learned tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad today to increase its basic one-way interstate passenger fares in coaches by 15 per cent, or to about 2.875 cents a mile, with a minimum one-way fare of 17 cents.

CHICAGO. Dec. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 17.000 head, total 38.000; market fairly active; general trade 25 to 50 cents lower on all weights including sows: most good and choice 180 to 300 pound butchers

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Total dollar volume of manufacturing production in the Chicago industrial area if current production rates continue through this month will approximate $11,500,000,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago estimated today.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, filed today denial that it was engaging in unfair labor practices as charged by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United, Gas, Coke and Chemical Workers Union, CIO, today postponed the strike of 2,800 employes at the Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic energy plant, scheduled for tomorrow night. The action followed an appeal by Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

A dog named Wonder, a second cousin of the bull terrier family accused in the death last July 1 of 11-year-old Stanley Balaban of 1142 Elder Avenue, the Bronx, was put on the witness stand in Bronx County Court yesterday in defense of their master, Sven O. Sandgren, who is being tried on a second degree manslaughter charge.
BATAVTA, Java, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Dutch and Indonesian representatives began direct negotiations today to settle their conflict in Indonesia.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- The statue of St. Frances Xavier Cabrini, the first of a United States citizen to be placed in St. Peter's Basilica, was unveiled today by Federico Cardinal Tedeschini.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a strange way, the Russian-American agreement on Palestine confirms the Russian-American disagreement on most other subjects. In practically every crucial problem Russian acceptance of the United States viewpoint would result in a recession of Soviet power.

A total of $2,114,682 has been raised toward the $2,383,877 goal of the United Hospital Fund's sixty-ninth annual campaign, William H. Jackson, chairman, announced yesterday at a Manhattan-Bronx women's division report meeting in the Hotel St. Regis.

Forecasting that the paper manufacturing Industry, with the exception of newsprint, will achieve a balance of supply and demand by mid-1948, Harry E. Gould, president of Reinhold-Gould, Inc., fine paper merchants, said yesterday that big plants and distributors should begin now to build bettertrained sales forces and plan promotion and advertising campaigns superior to pre-war standards.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Hundreds of Jews in Tel Aviv responded today to cries of motorcycle couriers who raced through the streets shouting: "Hatikvah is in danger. Send help." One courier halted a motion-picture performance with his alarm and sent hundreds of persons in the audience hurrying to the embattled quarter.
Support of Mayor O'Dwyer'a program for modernizing city hospitals was urged yesterday by Commissioner of Hospitals Edward M. Bernecker.

Women Rule on Air Travel Women have the final word on whether their husbands or other members of their families shall travel by air, according to the results of a special study. Accordingly, at least one large airline is considering a special advertising campaign appealing to this decisive element of the traveling public.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 8 -- The world's economic predicament calls for the transfer as soon as possible of some 150,000,000 of the world's 800,000,000 gainfully employed from agricultural pursuits to industry, trade and service enterprises, the Institute of World Affairs was told at the opening session of its twenty-fourth conference last night.

To those who have become accustomed to the exotic flavor of crystalized ginger, there probably is news of interest in the fact that the first sizable shipment of ginger to arrive here from Hong Kong since 1940 has just come in.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- The tax collectors are on strike and Japan's already weakened economy is wabbling precariously. In the first seven months of this fiscal year collections aggregated only 32,000,000,000 yen against the year's projected 132,000,000,000 yen total.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Although conditions generally were firm in the stock markets here today, uncertainties on outcome of the Big Four conference helped to keep business in check.

In the nineteen years they have been playing here as a two-piano team, Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson have given a great deal of pleasure. Last night they added to the store with the recital they gave at Town Hall.
Tuesday, Dec. 8, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Trusteeship Council Heard representative of all-Ewe conference present oral petition for unification of Togoland.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 8 -- The Arab League announced tonight that it was taking "immediate measures" for military and other action to prevent the creation of a Jewish state in Palestine.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 -- Fighting between Arabs and Jews in the Tel Aviv-Jaffa border area flared again tonight as Arabs set fire to houses in the oriental Jewish quarter and Jews fled in panic to the town of Tel Aviv.

Our correspondent in India, Robert Trumbull, reports that the new Dominions of the Indian Union and Pakistan have reached an agreement for dividing financial assets of the old government of India. At the same time, prospects seem brighter for an easing of the tension between the two nations.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- Motion picture distribution has been put back on a competitive basis in the United States zone of Germany by the licensing of ten distributing agencies, the Military Government announced today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 -- Baptist churches across the country will carry their crusade for Christ into factories, office buildings and stores in a drive to add 400,000 new members to the church roll by May, 1950, Dr. G. Pitt Beers of New York, executive secretary of the Baptist Home Missions Society, stated today at the mid-year meeting of the Northern Baptist convention.

Duly accredited advertising men who happen to be around East Thirty-fifth Street and Park Avenue in the year 2004 may decide to remove the cornerstone of the New York Advertising Club's annex, which was laid yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- In sad contrast to the thriving Chicago Bears and Cardinals of the National Football League, the Chicago Rockets of the All-America Conference today licked gaping financial wounds as they optimistically hunted a new coach and fresh promotional gold.

Store Sales Here Up 1% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 1 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New Tork.

Jose Mercado, dishwasher at the Stork Club, who last Friday told a state unfair labor practice hearing that Sherman Billingsley, manager of the club, tried to influence his testimony with a $600 gift, testified yesterday for two hours before the Grand Jury.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The State Department last week became a competitor with the vehicles of public information which are operated under the guarantee of the Constitution by the daily and periodical press and, through government license, by the radio.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Supreme Court refused today to enter the legal fight of the Traffic Telephone Workers' Federation of Sew Jersey against that state's 'utility anti-strike law."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Sylvanus B. Olympic, representative of the Ewe tribes of West Central Africa, took a seat at the United Nations trusteeship council table today to plead for unification of the Ewe lands.
Blue Ridge The Blue Ridge Corporation declared a dividend of 30 cents on its common stock. In August 10 cents was paid. In 1946 the only payment was 43 cents in December.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just returned from a visit to Funk Caserne and Prien, two displaced children's camps In and around Munich. These orphans, aged 14 to 18, of different nationalities and creeds, await emigration to the States. Although they have been screened and selected, most of them, because of immigration law strictures, remain at the camps months and months on this last lap of their terrible journey.

New York's four city colleges will ask for a total of 5525,00 annually for extra-budgetary needs, a report made public by the Administrative Council of the Schools indicated yesterday. The council is composed of the presidents of the four colleges, Dr. Harry N. Wright of City College, Dr. George N. Shuster of Hunter, Dr. Harry I. Gideonse of Brooklyn and Acting President Margaret V. Kiely of Queens.

As the baseball clans descended upon New York yesterday for the annual three-day major league conclaves that open in the WaldorfAstoria today, it remained for the Dodgers to hold their familiar position right in the center of the spotlight.
A new Lentheric salon will open today at 673 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-third Street. Designed by Harrison Abramovitz, architects, it was decorated by Ruby Ross Wood and lighted by Feder.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen, discussing our relations with Russia, asserted here tonight that he was "optimistic that we can win through for expanding freedom for ourselves and others without the tragedy of a third World War."

Acting with gratifying speed and virtual unanimity, the Senate yesterday ratified a treaty which acquires special significance in view of the Russo-Communist efforts to overthrow the European democracies by a combination of insurrection and indirect aggression.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The railroads presented their arguments today at the final hearing before the Interstate Commerce Commission on their twice-revised petition for increased freight rates. The original petition, filed in July, asked increases of 25 percent in freight rates in the North-east and between that and other sections of the country, and 15 per cent in and between the other sections.

GENEVA, Dec. 8 -- A new high of 19,899 refugees and displaced persons were resettled under the auspices of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization during October, it was announced here today.

NANKING, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Chinese Government Army paper Peace Daily reported today that at least two divisions of Gen. Liu Po-cheng's Communist troops had burst westward from their Tapieh mountain hideouts as strong Government forces knifed into the mountains behind them.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 8 -- The Venezuelan Presidential campaign went into its final week today as the candidates wound up their tours prior to the election this Sunday.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 8 -- In the partly filled main courtroom of the Palace of Justice here, an American prosecuting staff headed by Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor opened today the war crimes case against a group of men who antedated and anticipated Adolf Hitler as the spearhead of German aggression in World War II.

The lifting yesterday of tax selling pressure invited moderate bidding on the stock market, bringing a rally which added 1 to 2 points to prices of some of the key issues and raised the combined averages by 0.76 point on the day. The advance, however, was considered purely technical by financial observers.

Mankind is standing on the threshold of "one of the greatest spiritual revivals in the history of civilization," Archbishop Richard J. Gushing of Boston declared last night at the fifth annual Jesuit Mission Benefit Dinner held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Commodore.

RONNE ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Dec. 4 (Delayed) -- After being grounded for five days by winter overcast, this expedition carried out another mapping flight today. We extended the known depth of Ronne Bay by more than twenty miles, discovered a mountain and a mountain range on Alexander Island, but again failed to photograph elusive Charcot Island.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Yorkshire Farm's Flying Fort defeated Mrs. T. Christopher's Donna's Ace, the favorite, in the mile-and-a-furlong Arthur Murray purse, sixth and feature event of today's Gulfstream Park racing.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- Army authorities announced today that they had escored quiet to Ulm and NeyUlm, on the Danube River in the United States zone, where over the week-end Moslem-Jewish fighting broke out.
Some vital city services, paricularly garbage collection, are lot keeping pace with the unusually rapid population growth of Queens, it was disclosed yesterday.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Belgian Government will explain its position on King Leopold III in Parliament tomorrow, it was learned on reliable authority tonight.

The Asia Institute has opened to the public the galleries of its spacious new home at 7 East Seventieth Street. The southeast Asia Institute has joined the group of organizations including the School for Asiatic Studies, the Institute of Asiatic Economics, the Iranian Institute and the India Institute.

HAVANA, Dec. 8 -- The United States delegation appeared today to be losing its fight for a weighted voting system. This proposal would give the United States a voting power in the proposed International Trade Organization that would conform to the nation's world economic leadership.

Stockholders of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company at a special meeting held here yesterday approved the purchase and retirement of 1,923,447 of its common shares at a price not in excess of $25 each. Shareholders also approved financing the purchase through the sale of not more than $50,000,000 of twenty-five year 2.8 per cent debentures.

Russia joined the United States in approving the United Nations plan for the partition of Palestine because, being checked in Greece, it wanted to establish a military base in the eastern Mediterranean area, Emir Feisal al-Saud of Saudi Arabia said yesterday as he left La Guardia field for Cairo to attend the meetings of the Arab League.

Steps toward improving local living conditions not only help to solve vital domestic problems, but also contribute to the power of the United States abroad by demonstrating that democracy works, Miss Doris Herrick Cochran, division of public liaison, Department of State, told 150 women yesterday at the National Women's Conference of the American Ethical Union, meeting at 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

The New York City Rent Advisory Board voted unanimously yesterday to recommend that Federal rent controls be continued in the city and in Nassau and Suffolk Counties until the housing shortage is eased. The group made no suggestion concerning a possible general increase or lowering of rents here, but will act on that question soon.

The New York Knickerbockers, who amassed a record-shattering total of 114 points in their last outing against Providence, counted only 71 against the St. Louis Bombers last night at Madison Square Garden. Yet the Knicks won with plenty to spare, recording a 71-56 victory before 10,296 fans.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Four old National Football League records lay smashed today and two others, already broken this season, reached new highs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Congress was asked today to establish a permanent national rubber program under which the Government could continue controlling the use of rubber supplies and could sell or lease to private industry some of its $700,000,000 worth of synthetic plants.

TOKYO, Dec. 8 -- The Katayama Government's controversial bill for state control of the coal mines became law tonight, when it passed the upper house of the Diet by a vote of 132 to 79, with thirty-nine members absent or abstaining. The enforcement of the new measure, by which it is hoped to expand the nation's flagging production, begins on April 1.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Warren R. Austin, chief United States delegate to the United Nations, tonight called Russia's plan for control of the atomic bomb "a fraud on the peoples of the entire world." He laid it might take years to bring together the United States and the Soviet Union on atomic and other world issues.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The joint Mexican-United States Foot and Mouth Disease Commission heard recommendations today that rigid quarantine lines be set up to keep the Mexican, livestock epidemic inside its present boundaries.

Senator Robert A. Taft, speaking here yesterday at Town Hall, predicted that Congress would continue rent controls for at least another year, and all but predicted that meat rationing would start next April. Meat rationing, he indicated, would be without price controls.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 8 -- After having kept ten buses of the "defunct" Long Beach Bus Company running on schedule for the third successive day, twenty drivers and nine maintenance men suffered a setback this afternoon when three of the buses were seized in a replevin action.

Thirty skiers, accompanied by Managers Alice Kiaer and Cortlandt Hill and Co-coaches Alf Engen and Walter Prager, departed yesterday aboard the S.S. America for the Fifth Winter Olympic Games at St. Moritz, Switzerland, after" a program that concluded four days of processing and fetes in New York City.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- In the first case of its kind, the United States Military Government began legal proceedings today to break up the large German firm of Askania Werke, which, contrary to the Four Power Control law, allegedly manufactured war materials for "an unnamed power."

Two holiday television programs, on which stars of stage, screen and radio will offer special entertainment designed for hospitalized veterans, are to be presented on Christmas Day and New Year's Eve over the National Broadcasting Company's video outlet, WNBT.

Notre Dame -- unbeaten, untied and virtually unchallenged -- has been selected as the outstandingcollege football team of 1947, winning the honor for the second straight year in the final poll conducted by The Associated Press.

VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- Two occurrences here this week-end have been interpreted as indicating that the Russians are preparing to put the screws on Austria as they recently have on every other Danubian country they control.

The mysterious disappearance of the victim's widow, described as a "most important" prosecution witness, caused a 24-hour adjournment in the opening yesterday of the first-degree murder trial of three men accused of having shot a boss stevedore to gain control over the hiring and firing of dock workers.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Britain has recommended to the United Nations that she terminate the Palestine mandate May 15 and that independent Jewish and Arab states come into formal existence two weeks later, Government sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Army disclosed today that private contractors have been ordered during the last year to transfer some ninety employes from secret Army projects because they were "bad security risks."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The last-minute filing of requests here tonight by two Arab nations, Egypt and Lebanon, to appear before the United Nations Security Council to discuss Palestine assures a full-dress debate on the Arab-Jewish flare-ups before the powerful eleven-nation organ for the first time tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- A request by Thomascolor, Inc., Los Angeles, for acceleration of the effectiveness of its amended registration statement, covering a proposed public offering of 1,000,000 shares of $5 par value common stock at $10 a share, was granted today by a three-to-two vote of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Protests have been registered by the managements of "Antony and Cleopatra" and "A Streetcar Named Desire" against what they consider arbitrary rulings made by Local 802 of the musicians union that both productions are dramas with music.

ORLANDO, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- His ninth one-putt green for a birdie 3 on the nineteenth hole gave 29-year-old Dave Douglas of Wilmington, Del., a one-stroke victory over Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., in a play-off for the third annual Orlando open golf title today.
Three hundred theatrical folk bad to forego luncheon at Sardi's yesterday as the result of a fire in the kitchen chimney of the celebrated restaurant at 234 West Forty-fourth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- Further postponement of Standard 3as and Electric Company's annual stockholders' meeting "will be inevitable," the Securities and Exchange Commission said today as it handed down a memorandum opinion outlining the next steps of procedure in its investigation of the facts surrounding the meeting and election of the board of directors.

The greatest post-war resilience of any major industry in the British Isles has been shown by the travel industry, it was said last night by John G. Bridges, directorgeneral of the Travel Association of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. He spoke at a meeting of tourist and transportation officials in the St. Regis Hotel.

THE All-America Conference moves serenely into its championship play-off between the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Browns at the Stadium next Sunday, while the National Football League is in the throes of its usual snafu. The rough translation of that war-coined word is "Situation normal, all fouled up."

Freddie Fitzsimmons, former big league pitching star, who managed the Phillies from 1943 to 1945, returned to baseball yesterday as a coach for the Braves under Manager Billy Southworth. He has resigned as general manager of the Brooklyn Football Dodgers to assume his new duties, according to John Quinn, general manager of the Braves.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- Mayor O'Dwyer's request for an additional $84,000,000 in state aid for New York City as a budget balancing medium was virtually rejected today at a six-hour conference on state budget problems attended by Governor Dewey, Republican legislative leaders and State Controller Frank C. Moore.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The creation of an Economic Commission for Latin America was recommended today by a subcommission of the "United Nations Economic and Social Council. The purpose of the commission would be to promote the development of industry, agriculture, transportation and communications in under-developed areas.

Flashing a fighting style that knew no restraint until his rival crumpled, Paddy DeMarco, sturdy Brooklyn welterweight, last night halted Joey Carkido of Youngstown, Ohio, in the seventh round of the scheduled eight-round feature at the St. Nicholas Arena.

Taking cognizance of the current practice of reselling dyes for export at exorbitant prices, the Calco Chemical Division. American Cyanamid Company, has notified it customers that it will discontinue sales to those who divert good into the "black market," it was learned yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 8 -- Prohibition times were recalled recently by fishermen from near by Wickford when they hauled in their nets and found a number of bottles of twenty-year old Scotch and other potables.
YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Returned to the White House after a brief Florida holiday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- Dr. Rolling Adams Emerson, a widely-known geneticist and head of the department of plant breeding at Cornell from 1914 to 1942, died this morning in Tompkins County Memorial Hospital after a long illness. His age was 74.
Instead of sending a gift to a friend who is ill, a donor yesterday gave $5 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund to aid a man stricken by sickness.

The National Maritime Union, CIO, presented a demand for a 25 per cent increase in basic wages and overtime rates to representatives of ship-owners and agents at a meeting yesterday at the office of the American Mercnant Marine Institute, 11 Broadway.
The barrel cost of crude oil was up 50 cents throughout the midcontinent area today with all indications pointing to an early general rise in the prices of gasoline at the filling station pump.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace announced today the election of a new secretary, Elwood N. Thompson, an official of the State Department.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Rome resumed its normal appearance today, the greater part of the 20,000 Communist Partisans who descended upon the city yesterday having left during the night as suddenly and as quietly as they had come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, told the Senate today that an American diplomat recently was searched at gunpoint by the police in Communistdominated Rumania and that the homes and automobiles of other Americans there had been searched.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Senate approved today, 72 to 1, the inter-American defense treaty, designed to bring the full force of Western Hemisphere nations to the defense of any one of them that may be attacked.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Yugoslavia's Marshal Tito forged the third link today in a projected four-power Danubian defense chain by signing a mutual aid treaty with Hungary. He commented that such action "may hinder capitalistic imperalistic states from fishing in troubled waters."

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 8 -- In a step to reorganize New Jersey's judicial system at the highest level, Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll named seven justices today to constitute the new Supreme Court, authorized under the revised state constitution to replace the Court of Errors and Appeals. The list is beaded by Arthur T. Vanderbilt of Short Hills.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 8 -- There is no area in the United States 'adequately served by convalescent facilities for poliomyelitis patients," a national infantile paralysis conference was told here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- "The Turquoise," a novel by Anya Seton of adventure in the American Southwest in the Eighteen Nineties to which Warner Brothers acquired the screen rights two years ago, will be filmed as an Errol Flynn vehicle, the studio announced today.

George H. Earle, former Governor of Pennsylvania, made public yesterday a letter to him from the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, which, Mr. Earle charged, was an order tantamount to "political exile" in the South Pacific.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 -- Leaders of the Soviet film world called today on their American counterparts to fight Hollywood's efforts at "propagandizing the notorious Truman Doctrine and so-called Marshall plan, programs of beastly malice and hatred toward humanity and the stronghold of peace, the Soviet Union."

Warning that the city schools are in a critical condition, the Public Education Association issued yesterday the findings of a two-year study, calling for the drastic overhauling of the system here at an additional cost of $140,000,000.

Mayor O'Dwyer swore in sixteen appointees to city positions and judicial posts yesterday at a ceremony in the Board of Estimate room at City Hall attended by 250 city officials and relatives and friends of those appointed. The new job holders are:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Rocky Graziano won a narrow squeak, split decision today in a poll of state boxing commissioners who were asked whether the world's middleweight champion should be allowed to fight again.
Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, reiterated yesterday the belief of the bi-state agency that harbor installations were a regional problem.

As additional tributes to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler arrived yesterday in large numbers, preparations were completed for the funeral of the distinguished educator, which will be held at 11 A.M. today in St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.
ATHENS, Dec. 8 -- The United States Mission for Aid to Greece was not consulted or informed in advance about the Greek Government's decree prohibiting strikes of any kind, it was learned today.

There is a growing suspicion that City College has the best basketball team in town and local fans will have another opportunity to see Nat Holman's Beavers in action tonight at Madison Square Garden. Unbeaten C.C.N.Y, will oppose Oregon State in the curtainraiser of the twin bill that will present St. John's against Loyola of Chicago in the afterpiece.

Gus Lesnevich, world lightheavyweight champion, yesterday was named to receive the ninth individual award of the Edward J. Neil Memorial Trophy, as the outstanding boxer of 1947. At the same time James A. Farley, former chairman of the State Athletic Commission, was voted an award which in future shall be known as the James J. Walker Memorial, for long and meritorious service to boxing down through the years.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of Soviet Foreign minister Molotov's statement today to the Council of Foreign Ministers, as released by the Russian delegation: On Dec. 6, the Council of Foreign Ministers was unable to begin consideration of economic questions relating to Germany because no agreement was reached as to the procedure for discussion.

The amount of money to be spent by the United States for European recovery is secondary to the development of a "sound, workable" plan, Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, said last night. He declared that in conjunction with the plan an anti-inflation program would have to be worked out to protect the domestic economy, but strongly opposed reimposition of widespread price controls at this time.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A Champaign, Ill., plan for religious teaching in public schools was under the close scrutiny of the Supreme Court today as justices took up the final appeal of an atheist mother seeking to ban the classes on grounds of religious freedom.

The National City Bank of New York will head the group of banks participating in the credit plan which would provide cotton fort Japan, now under negotiation as part of the British-American loan to finance Japan's foreign trade, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Bernard J. Gillroy, City Commissioner of Housing and Buildings, made known yesterday that he was revising departmental procedure for the handling of complaints from tenants, which were expected to number at least 130,000 this year.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 8 -- Josef Grossxnann, ablest of the Communist student leaders, has appeared at a meeting of the board considering applications of Czechoslovak students to go on exchange scholarships to America to examine the candidates on their former political background.

Some appliance distributors are by-passing neighborhood appliance stores and shipping "unfair amounts" of scarce traffic appliances like automatic mixers and toasters to large furniture and department stores, independent retailers charged yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton crop totals 11,694,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, an increase of 189,000 bales over its forecast of a month earlier. The crop is about 3,000,000 bales larger than last year's unusually small one, but 700,000 bales less than the 1936-45 average.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to ''save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Today's Peace Plate is planned around solid satisfaction, from hearty Dinner Chowder through salad and old-time apple pie, blessed with cinnamon and served hot for those who like it.

"The Gentleman from Athens," a new comedy by Emmet Lavery, who wrote "The First Legion" and "The Magnificent Yankee," opens this evening at 8:30 at the Mansfield Theatre Martin Gosch is producer of the offering in association with Eunice Healey. Sam Wana maker, who gave a good account of himself last year in "Joan of Lorraine," has attended to the direction and Ralph Alswang has supplied the scenery and arranged the lighting.

As a means of relieving pressure on wheat prices, a group of Republican leaders in Congress is reported to be advocating the "stock-piling" of that food grain. These members suggest the enactment of legislation which would require a minimum carry-over of wheat at the end of the crop year of somewhere between 125,000,000 and 250,000,000 bushels.
The Taft-Hartley Law was invoked yesterday to protect the city's holiday liquor supply.

The contrast between the good fortune most families enjoy and the appalling: ill-luck which dogs others, equally deserving, is something no philosophy can explain. Fate strikes like the lightning where it listeth. Yet it is not simply a harsh fact we must supinely accept.

The State Athletic Commission yesterday rejected the request of Jersey Joe Walcott for a reversal of the decision which enabled Joe Louis to, retain his world heavyweight title in last Friday night's controversial bout in Madison Square Garden.

From New Books to Old Nowadays, when we From read about an old book in a new book, many of us proceed to read the old book. The reason for this is a wish to learn what impression the latter will make on a mind subjected constantly to the impact of the literary standards of the present age, so different from those of the age in which the old book was written.

First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co., underwriting managers, yesterday made public offering of 80,987 shares of $10 par value capital stock of Springfield Fire Marine Insurance Company, representing that part of an issue of 200,000 shares not subscribed during a preferential offering to stock-holders.

STRATFORD, Conn., Dec. 8 -- While Tom Marshall and H.W. Riley of Fairfield whistled vainly for the 30-mile-an-hour wind which was scheduled but did not develop, we crouched in a duckboat on the Nels Island marsh and watched an occasional blackduck circle the island and glide down to join his friends in the Sound.

NEW YORK Miss Lily Lodge, daughter of Representative and Mrs. John Davis Lodge of Washington, D.C., and Westport, Conn., will be guest of honor at a tea dance to be given by Mrs. Edward Bragg Paine and her debutante daughter, Miss Natalie Wales Winslow, on Saturday in their home at 1175 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- On the ground that Negroes had been excluded from the jury which convicted him of murdering a white man, the Supreme Court today saved Eddie (Buster) Patton, Mississippi Negro, from the electric chair, and ordered a new trial.

Nursing no more than the normal number of aches and bruises that accrue in a hard and winning campaign, the New York Yankees of the All-America Football Conference are looking forward to Sunday. On that day Ray Flaherty's crew of huskies will line up against the Cleveland Browns at the Yankee Stadium in a game that will decide the championship of the junior pro loop.

PARIS, Dec. 8 -- After strike orders had completely failed to halt the Paris subway and buses, and had largely failed to bring out the Government employes, the Schuman Cabinet issued tonight a virtual ultimatum to the strikers.
GENEVA, Dec. 8 -- The United Nations Human Rights Commission heard the charge today that the United States condones Slavery. The accusation was made by A.S. Stepanenke of White Russia.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 8 -- Haganah, Zionist defense force has accused the Palestine police of sympathy with the Arabs and is consdering issuing an ultimatum saying that unless the police provide adequate protection on roads it will put armed guards on buses with orders to fire on anyone, including the police, who tries to disarm them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The debate in the House today on aid to Europe was decidedly waspish. Like most disputes in the lower chamber, it was less a reasoned discussion than a series of disconnected exhortations in the old Chautauqua manner.

MOSCOW, Dec. 8 (AP) -- An information official of the United States Embassy said today that the Voice of America program of Saturday was heard here, but that reception was only fair. Reception of the program throughout last week was fair to poor.

ROME, Dec. 8 -- Pope Pius today urged all young Catholics to form a "solid and compact bloc" in the defense of Catholic principles and religion. He made it clear that their purpose in uniting should not be offensive but purely defensive.
VIENNA, Dec. 8 -- Thanks to the victorious outcome of the battle of the posters, the Austrian people now are aware that 60 per cent of their food supply comes from the United States.

Creeping advances are continuing in the third round of price changes now taking place, industrial supply, distributors revealed here yesterday. Announcements of increases are coming in daily, they said, and standard lines such as chucks and flexible shafts, both increased about 10 per cent yesterday, are typical of the lines in which advances are occurring.

Yale University will receive $300,000 and six other institutions will share a similar amount under the will of Mrs. Helen Jewett Hunt, who died Feb. 13, 1946, leaving a net estate of $2,214,704, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Charles W. Ferry, deputy Estate Tax Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Democrats and a sharply split Republican majority in the House rescued the emergency foreign relief program today from strongly supported restrictions which concededly would have rendered it impotent.

OTTAWA, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's reserve of gold and United States dollars which started the year at $1,244,900,000, had been reduced to $480,200,000 by Nov. 30, according to a return tabled in the House of Commons today by Finance Minister D.C. Abbott.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Congresional action before the Christmas holidays on three or four aspects of a Republican-sponsored program against inflation was in prospect today.

Sweden has just observed the fortieth anniversary of the reign of King Gustaf V. Few rulers have gained such profound love from their subjects or such world-wide respect as has the present King of Sweden, and only one other Swedish king in that nation's more than 1,000 years' history even approached the number of years that Gustaf V has been on the throne.

NANKING, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Preliminary planning is under way both in Nanking and Washington for the manifold expansion of the United. States military advisory groups in China in the event that large-scale American military assistance is granted to President Cihiang Kai-shek's armies.

CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 8 -- Additional import cuts from, dollar countries, embracing gasoline, tobacco, newsprint and automobile chassis, and restrictions on film royalties and travel allowances were announced by the Australian Government today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Truman will ask funds for the economic revival of Germany as an integral part of the European Recovery Program (Marshall plan), the Senate Appropriations Committee heard today from Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall.

Mayor O'Dwyer indicated yesterday that he intended to present his legislative program, designed to give the city increased revenues and borrowing power, to the Legislature intact as he outlined it to the public in a broadcast Friday night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Immediate repatriation of nearly 2,500,000 World War II prisoners was urged today by the board of governors of the American Red Cross.

A two-day concentration of competitive sales intended to raise $65,000,000 in new capital for public utility enterprises got off to a start here yesterday with Central Maine Power Company selling $4,000,000 of thirty-year 3 1/4 per cent bonds at a premium, but rejecting the only bid submitted for 160,000 shares of new common stock.

Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island will make his first visit to New York today as chairman of the Democratic National Committee. He is to be guest tonight at one of a series of private dinners arranged by the Democratic State Committee. Leading party figures will address Democratic party contributors.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The annual public budget hearing of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors adjourned after forty-five minutes here tonight when only eighty-five persons turned up and only five speakers asked to be heard.

New York and other cities would oppose an attempt by the Federal Government to take over the pension field for local government employes, according to the annual report of the New York City Employes' Retirement System, made public yesterday. New York has pioneered in "well-regulated, carefully financed pension systems on a sound reserve Basis," the report said.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Going over the books for the first year of professional football in Baltimore, Bob Rodenberg, president of the All-America Conference Colts, concluded cheerfully today that "We're here to stay."

Commemorating century of the Communist Manifesto, the Jefferson School of Social Science presented last night before 1,000 persons at Manhattan Center a program entitled "A World to Win," with William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party of America, as the principal speaker.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 8 -- The wholesale cost of buildingmaterials in the United States has risen 92 per cent since 1937, according to a new table in the latest issue of the United Nations Statisical Bulletin, to be published tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Grains closed strong on the Board of Trade today, with wheat rallying around 5 1/2 cents a bushel and corn 4 1/2 cents from the early low, the former finishing at net gains of 2 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents and the latter up 2 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday that he saw no reason why the State Board of Social Welfare should carry out its implied threat to withdraw state relief reimbursement, as he issued a reply to last Sunday's state report calling for improvement in relief administration.

Occupational harzards of dentistry range from flat feet to stomach ulcers from worrying about taxes, according to two medical doctors who spoke yesterday afternoon at the Greater New York Dental Meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Marketability? Wall Street men admitted yesterday that the bidding on 160,000 new shares of Central Maine Power Company common stock could hardly be pointed to as a testimonial to the liquidity of public security markets.

Benno Moiseiwitsch, who gave a piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has been absent from this country since 1934, but judging by the size and disposition of his audience, he has not been forgotten. When he came out upon the stage at the beginning of the program, he was greeted with the kind of sustained applause that audiences reserve for artists they have taken to their hearts.

THE first Anglo-Chinese war, generally known as the opium war, was one of the least glorious in the long history of the British Empire. It arose out of a series of misunderstandings, errors, bluffs and mistakes which would have been comic if they had not been so ultimately tied up with traffic in a "noxious" and "deleterious" drug.

The showing that Russeks Fifth Avenue brought at the luncheon hour yesterday to the Iridium Room of the St. Regis Hotel was designed to fill the spectators with a spirit of "wanderlust." There were coats to keep one cozy and warm on ship or plane, dresses for shopping in the market places of the Caribbean or the main streets of Hamilton, Bermuda.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- The names of deceased Army personnel will be given to eight ships assigned to the San Francisco Port of Embarkation. Four transports of the P-2 Class are to be renamed for distinguished general officers of World War II and four Victory Class cargo ships will carry the names of Medal-of-Honor soldiers.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Eighteen college soccer stars from Maryland and North Carolina have been chosen as an Olympic trial squad from those who played here on Saturday.

BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- Although half the residents in the United States zone believe they now have a free press, two-thirds of the population believes that that freedom is limited and that German editors are not allowed to print everything they believe correct, a Military Government survey showed today.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The Council, of Foreign Ministers got its second wind today when Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov submitted proposals on economic principles for inclusion in any German peace treaty. On the strength of this, the Foreign Ministers agreed on the basis of one paragraph of the combined British and Soviet drafts and the paragraph now goes to a drafting committee for restatement.

First flurries of snow should not be needed to make us realize that we are entering the most hazardous season on the roads and streets. The Committee on Winter Travel Hazards of the National Safety Council has been conducting a continuing study of the special dangers which slippery surfaces and reduced visibility bring in their train.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that a new regulation under the Commodity Exchange Act had been drawn up to end "held open" accounts that avoid income taxes.

Hits Media Promotion Claims "Egotistical, outmoded and inane" media promotion material aimed at space and time buyers was assailed as wasted money yesterday by Harry Singer, publisher of Media Buyer, in a talk to the marketing research group of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.

The board of directors of the Western Electric Company increased the total of dividend disbursements this year to $3.12 1/2 cents a share from $2 distributed in 1946, with the declaration yesterday of a year-end dividend of $1 a share.

The Department of Justice filed a civil suit in Federal Court yesterday accusing seven corporations of a conspiracy to create a monopoly in the manufacture and sale of braking equipment on automobiles, trucks and industrial equipment.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Speedy approval of the Marshall recovery program and encouragement of the center and non-Communist left in European politics were urged today in a report by Americans for Democratic Action proposing the broad outlines of a liberal foreign policy for the United States.
City College has barred Arnold Johnson, legislative director for the Communist party from speaking tomorrow on its main center campus at Convent Avenue and 139th Street.

Awards were announced yesterday for the sixth annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists, which is being held this year at the galleries of the National Academy. A preview reception will be held tomorrow evening and the exhibition will be open to the public begining Friday and until Dec. 30.

Further wage increases to pottery labor in 1948 will force dinnerware prices higher and restrict production, G.D. Agnew, head of Universal Potteries, Inc., Cambridge, Ohio, and president of the United States Potters Association, warned yesterday.
Five young war orphans from England, Belgium, The Netherlands and Italy arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field for a nine-day visit.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York urged last night the adoption of an amendment to the Federal Constitution making anyone appointed to the United States Supreme Court in the future permanently ineligible for the office of President or Vice President.

The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Short ribs of beef, always a dish for the hungry man, are doubly welcome served with a fine-flavored vegetable gravy, as suggested for today's Peace Plate.

Further gains of a selective nature were registered yesterday by the stock market. Exaggerated advances again were made by some of the high-price issues but, in the main, the gains were of major fractions. The combined averages rose 0.57 point on the day.

Nearly three million American workers have passed their sixtyfifth year and industry rates them as more loyal, absent less and as productive as their juniors, according to a study made by the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging.

An audience of 3,500 people filled the Metropolitan Opera House last night for a program of Hebrew liturgical music presented by the Jewish Ministers Cantors Association of America and Canada to celebrate the association's fiftieth anniversary and to raise funds for a training school for cantors in the United States.
Herbert O. (Fritz) Crisler of Michigan was selected as "Coach of the Year" in the annual poll conducted by The New York WorldTelegram.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- The situation in Rome, which, had been tense since last Saturday, when the local Chamber of Labor handed the Government an ultimatum that was to have expired at midnight tonight, eased somewhat today when the Chamber agreed to wait another twenty-four hours for the Government's final reply.

Successive rises in piece goods prices which have been followed by increases in dress prices have reached a point where the house dress manufacturer is pricing himself out of his field, J.M. Biberman of L'Aiglon Apparel, Inc., warned yesterday.
Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan appraised yesterday the nation's ability to enforce its foreign policy and declared that "perhaps we have gone too far" in shrinking our defenses.
A check of restaurants in several parts of the city showed yesterday that many waiters served bread and rolls to customers who do not specially request them.

The race relations department of the American Missionary Association declared yesterday that the Civil Rights Act and the Constitution could protect minority groups against unfair treatment in housing, but might not be applied.

Contracts are being drawn for Arthur Hopkins to produce "The Waiting Game" as quickly as possible. Based on a timely subject, the action takes place in an army general hospital, with most of the principal characters being paraplegics.

Mrs. Eugene Pitou of 1010 Fifth Avenue and Southampton, L.I., will give a luncheon on Saturday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton for Miss Jeanne Marie Crawley, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Eugene Crawley of 800 Park Avenue and Southampton.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Vitamin D can be a dangerous preparation in the hands of untrained persons, physicians attending the annual meeting of the American Academy of Dermatology and Syphilology explained today.

BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The Communists today began a war of nerves against Jakob Kaiser, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union in the Soviet Zone and an outstanding leader of Christian parties throughout Germany, with the suggestion he might soon "disappear."

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 9 -- Seven hundred members and guests of the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair heard a spirited discussion today on the question, "Does Europe Need a Revived Germany?" by members of a panel of THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy's direction, played Haydn's G major Symphony, numbered 88, presented Menahem Presser, the 19-year-old pianist of Palestine in the Schumann Concerto, and gave its first performance in New York of Samuel Barber's "Medea" Suite last night in Carnegie Hall.

The hearing of the National Maritime Union's challenge of the validity of that provision of the Taft-Hartley Act which calls for the filing of non-Communist affidavits will be held on December 19, in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, it was announced yesterday by William L. Standard, counsel for the CIO-affiliated union.

James A. Farley declared last ight that the late James J. Walker was more typical of New York than any person he had ever known. The former Cabinet member was the principal speaker at the unveiling of a plaque in honor of the late Mayor at the clubhouse of the Grand Street Boys Association, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.
Wednesday, Dec. 10, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Security Council Adopted resolution containing revised texts on admission of new members.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Spokesmen for the National Industrial Traffic League, representing large and small shippers throughout the country, told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that the railroads were entitled to increased freight rates.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec, 9 (AP) -- Proposals to ban post - season games and to make more explicit the rules on athletic professionalism have been offered members of the Southern Conference for consideration at their annual meeting Friday and Saturday at Roanoke, Va.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The House interrupted its debate on foreign aid for a few minutes today to rush to the Senate a $2,000,000 aid bill for the Navajo and Hopi Indians.

HAVANA, Dec. 9 -- Erik Colban of Norway, chairman of the organization committee, announced today that thirty-five of fifty-eight delegations attending the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment had made statements in first reading stage of the debate favoring the one country, one vote system for the proposed International Trade Organization.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Barring an unlikely Russian concession, all hope of agreement on essential questions of the future German economy at this session of the Council of Foreign Ministers seemed to vanish today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The vital role of state labor commissioners in building world labor standards was stressed here today by Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach at the opening session of the fourteenth National Conference on Labor Legislation.
A veteran who returned from World War II unscathed physically and emotionally gave $5 yesterday to the Hundred Needles Cases Fund to help another veteran not as lucky as he.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- French and British colonial officials today came out in opposition to the unification of Ewe tribal lands in West Central Africa. The United Nations Trusteeship Council continued discussion of petitions from Ewe tribesmen asking that artificial barriers erected between their people be ended.

CAIRO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- An Arab informant predicted today that pending the departure of British troops from the Holy Land the Arab nations would concentrate on forming a volunteer "People's Army" to aid the Palestine Arabs in the fight against creation of a Jewish state.
RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Tax reductions at this time were condemned at the Institute of World Affairs today as "political demagoguery menacing the welfare of the United States."

WEST NEW YORK, N.J., Dec. 9 -- A former combat soldier who signed up for peacetime training in the National Guard was released by the police today in custody of a veterans administration counsel after his arrest on a military warrant charging him with failure to attend weekly drill sessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett defended vigorously the cut in tariff rates at the recent Geneva conference as in the best interests of the United States and essential to the European recovery program in a letter given out by the State Department today to Arthur Besse of New York, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.
The Eastern College Athletic Conference mapped out its 1948sports program and elected officers during a two-day meeting which closed here last night.

A policy of caution in taking a position in the fur market because of high prices and uncertainty prevailing throughout the trade was recommended last night by William Weinstein, retiring president of the American Fur Merchants Association, at the annual meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOSTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Playing with more skill than ast season, when they won the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship, the Holy Cross Crusaders tonight thrilled 7,581 Boston Garden fans by trouncing the Valparaiso University Crusaders 80 -- 45.

Every year an American returns to Salerno or Anzio or Omaha Beach to find children playing in their fancy with the wreckage of war and softening the steel of landing craft with moss and seaweed. The battles are done, the dead laid. He treads the beach in sad memory of comrades lost, or in grim wonder at his own survival.
Sharp increases in city wharfage rates may lead to higher fares on local excursion boats next summer, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- The United Fuel Gas Company's proposal to sell to its parent, Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, $6,400,000 of 3 1/4 per cent notes, due in equal installments on Aug. 15 each year from 1950 to 1974, inclusive, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Robert Moses, Park Commissioner, detailed yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer how his department had spent $14,443,000 in the last two years, in large part reconstructing and rehabilitating parks, parkways and recreational facilities neglected during the war.

Tooth pastes and powders containing alkaline substances may help start tooth decay in young persons at an age when the development of dental caries is already active and "most treacherous," Dr. Charles F. Bodecker told a session of the Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel here last night.

Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower will assume the presidency of Columbia University on June 7, it was announced yesterday by Frederick Coykendall, chairman of the university's trustees. General Eisenhower will come to New York about May 1, Mr. Coykendall said.

Out of the swarm of rumors and counter-rumors that flew around the major league meetings at the Waldorf Astoria yesterday there emerged only one confirmed player deal -- the trade of Johnny Berardino by the Browns to the Indians for George Metkovich and a substantial but undisclosed amount of cash.

PARIS, Dec. 9 -- French-Soviet relations took a sharp turn toward tension today as Moscow expelled the French repatriation mission and broke off trade negotiations involving a proposal for the emergency delivery of wheat to this country.

Having his heart in the right place, Emmet Lavery has written a popular homily about integrity in politics, "The Gentleman from Athens," which was acted at the Mansfield last evening. This is the Mr. Lavery who wrote a highminded play about Justice Holmes a few seasons ago, and who startled the unAmerican Activities Committee a few weeks ago by answering when they were probing into his politics.

YORK, England, Dec. 9 (AP) -- William Woodward, United States thoroughbred owner, tonight renewed his appeal for world recognition of the American stud book, declaring that race horses bred in the United States were "equal to any in the world."
MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Syl Apps, captain and veteran playmaker of the Toronto Maple Leafs, has regained first place in the National Hockey League's individual scoring derby.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 9 -- A breakdown of the bus system servicing this community of 12,000 was indicated here today as mechanical and legal complications beset the twenty drivers and nine mechanics who have been operating the vehicles over the lines dropped at Friday midnight by the Long Beach Bus Company.

Initiating the practice of reporting quarterly on operations of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., Jack I. Straus, president, informed stockholders in the statement mailed yesterday that sales for the thirteen weeks ended on Nov. 1 were $75,568,000, or 17 1/2 per cent more than the $62,348,000 volume for the corresponding period of last year.

Buyers' Total Higher Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,127, compared with 1,091 last week and 1,115 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Dec. 9 -- Enticed by an incentive program that offered them, in addition to extra food and clothing rations, a share in export proceeds, Ruhr miners have built up a credit of $5,000,000 as a reward for boosting coal production to a post-war record, Heinrich Kost, general director of the German Coal management, disclosed today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -- Screen versions of six operas will be produced in Italy by Gregor Rabinovitch for Columbia release after he completes "The Eternal Melody," the studio announced today. Rabinovitch's present picture, in which Jan Kiepura and Marta Eggerth are appearing, is also an adaptation of an opera, being based on Puccini's "La Boheme."

JERUSALEM, Dec. 9 -- Jews turned on the British police in an open attack today for the first time since the announcement of the United Nations decision to partition Palestine. They burned two police armored cars with "Molotov cocktails" and attacked six others in the Jaffa-Tel Aviv area and shot at one in Haifa, northern Palestine.

The economic fabric of the world is interwoven so closely today that the countries of the Western Hemisphere must support the Marshall plan if the world is to be preserved from communism, Norman Armour, Assistant Secretary of State, said last night.
Tuesday, Dec. 9, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Received the new Swedish Ambassador, Herman Eriksson.

The Citizens Union made public yesterday a letter to the Port of New York Authority requesting that body to include in its study of the city's dock and pier development the question of relocating Washington Market.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- On Trust, leading 3-year-old California-bred speedster, came within one-fifth second of the track record for six furlongs in capturing the $3,000 feature race at Bay Meadows today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Poland is making rapid strides toward economic recovery, largely with the help of supplies from the now defunct United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, the Foreign Policy Association reported today.

Bowing to a government ultimatum, the French Communist leaders have called off their insurrectionary campaign of strikes, sabotage and violence, and have ordered all strikers to return to work today. This action, which is tantamount to an unconditional Communist surrender, represents a decisive victory for the French Government and the French Republic.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- The strikes in France were called off tonight by the Communist leaders within the Confederation of Labor who had instigated them a month previously.

A millinery event of unusual interest took place yesterday afternoon in the grand, ballroom of the Hotel Pierre -- the showing to a large audience of a collection of hats representing four fashion centers, California, London, Paris and New York.

The 25-cent recording fee for dog show entries, abandoned by the American Kennel Club a year ago because the club's finances were in a particularly healthy condition, will be reinstated early in 1948, it was announced yesterday at the A.K.C. delegates' meeting at the Hotel Commodore.

Dr. Harold J. Parker, whose controversial one-year appointment as City College football coach ended last month, will lead the Beaver eleven again in 1948, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that authority for the railroads to increase freight rates by 30 per cent would "complicate the nation's effort to check the course of inflation." Louis H. Dean, its economist, appeared before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the carriers' application tot higher rates and urged caution in the light of current economic conditions.

The danger of a pre-Christmas tie-up of telegraph service grew yesterday when it became known that American Federation of Labor unions representing 50,000 Western Union workers had called local leaders to a meeting in Washington Sunday to fix a national strike date.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The second issue of the magazine of the new Communist Information Bureau disclosed today that the Russian Communist party faces sweeping changes and that the Government intends to end food rationing by Dec. 31.

A brief rest for Spec Sanders New York Yankee ground gaining ace, was ordered by the team physician yesterday. The order cam from Dr. S.S. Gayner, who advise Sanders "to stay off his feet for two days" before reporting back for a workout tomorrow.

Three Men in Wall Street A recent visitor to this town -- one of two who came from a far country -- was interested, they say, in a number on the south side of Wall Street, between Broad and William -- the figure, 33.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Filippo Del Giudice, who for the last decade has been one of the most colorful and provocative personalities in British motion pictures, will remove his newest company, Pilgrim Productions, to the United States unless British financiers provide him with the operating funds before Jan. 1, he declared today.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 9 -- Officials of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration expressed resentment tonight over the "failure of the Chinese Government" to curb a Governmentregulated monopoly that has been restricting Shanghai's food.

Federated Metals Division of American Smelting and Refining Company increased prices on various grades of brass ingots by a half to a cent a pound yesterday, Thomas Hammer, director of sales, announced. This increase was caused by scrap dealers withholding deliveries of scrap brass and increasing their prices, trade members said, also disclosing that other brass ingot makers are expected to follow the upward revision.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- Ralph A. Harry, representative of Australia, today launched a new attempt to achieve some basic United Nations progress on disarmament before 1948.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- A "small increase" in the Federal Reserve rediscount rate on bank credits was proposed to Congress today by a Chicago banker as a possible check on inflationary trends.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed yesterday in a 2-to-1 decision the conviction of Leon Josephson on charges of having refused to be sworn and testify last March 5 before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Government has lost $281,972,000 making and selling synthetic rubber, Reconstruction Finance Corporation executive G.B. Hadlock reported to a Congressional committee today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (UP) -- International Harvester Company, which nine months ago cut its prices in an attempt to combat inflation, announced price increases averaging 5 per cent today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Representative Ross Rizley, Republican, of Oklahoma, said today he was going to "make certain" that $17,000,000 of machinery manufactured for Russia and now in" the hands of the War Assets Administration "doesn't get to the Communists."
BOSTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A $4,000,000 former Navy tanker split in half at an East Boston repair slip today, injuring fourteen workmen.

Despite increased operating costs, several leading banks here have scheduled payment of Christmas bonuses to their staffs, it was learned yesterday. The bonus policy which some of the banks resumed last season after a lapse of nearly ten years, resembles the pattern of 1946, and while in some cases the maximum payment has been reduced, elsewhere it has been increased.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Counting- at least 124 killed in Aden and four in Syria, The Associated Press tally of dead throughout the Middle East since the United Nations decision to partition Palestine mounted to 240.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Stockholders of Pacific Western Oil Corporation met today and adjourned their annual meeting until 2 P.M. Thursday without acting on the proposed merger of Pacific and Mission Oil Corporation of Nevada into Sunray Oil Corporation.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- State Controller Frank C. Moore said today that the state-mandated 2 per cent tax limit on local real estate was full of loopholes and did not offer the protection "real estate people think it does."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The decision of the United Nations to bring to a realization the historic aspirations of the Jewish people for statehood in Palestine has by no means lessened the interest of Jews everywhere in the meeting of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights which opened in Geneva on Dec. 1.

Reorganization of the city's $142,000,000 relief administration moved into the constructive phase yesterday, when Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, and Benjamin Fielding, the city's Welfare Commissioner, announced that they would meet for the first time at noon tomorrow to discuss relief on a mutual state-city basis.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The first step toward establishment of a football shrine and hall of fame that will be national in scope was taken today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- The Economic Commission for Latin America that has just been recommended by a United Nations subcommission will be in working operation by next April or May, it was predicted here today by Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz, Chilean delegate, who proposed creation of the regional organization.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "Congress' Number Two Job," in the issue of Nov. 30, interested me very much. Your reference to the "fuzzy thinking among opponents of military training" reminds me of the trite saying about the pot calling the kettle black.

The growing popularity of "Chinoiserie" in decorative design was evident yesterday in a showing of new wallpapers at the Renverne Corporation's decorator showroom, 515 Madison Avenue. A new scenic by James Seeman and two by Albert Van Luit represented varied interpretations of the, Chinese theme.

President Truman, who already had paid tribute to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler in a statement last Sunday, sent to Mrs. Butler a message of condolence that was made public yesterday through Columbia University.

The century-old Spanish silversmith company of Luis Espunes which is showing its flatware and hollow ware here for the first time, seems to have thought of eating and serving utensils for every type of food that might be found on the menu.

THINGS just won't be the same at Ebbets Field any more. Dixie Walker has been traded to the Pirates and gloom hangs thickly over Flatbush. "I sure love those Brooklyn people," drawled Dixie in his farewell address. You said it, Dixie. And the feeling has been entirely mutual.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A trainload of 629 representatives of nineteen consumer, tenant and trade union organizations returned to New York tonight after a day of lobbying here for return of price and rent controls and a roll-back of prices to levels of June, 1946.

The prospect of a trip South was made even more attractive yesterday by the colorful and prettily feminine resort fashions presented by Zachary Bogert's Cotton Shop at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel. Glimpsed were exciting new beachwear with short coats, casual cottons made feminine with swirling skirts, cabana and evening costumes and clothes to wear on train or plane.

ON the banks of the Wabash far away, in Muncie, which is "Middletown," where the glass jars and the sociological statistics come from, and in Indianapolis, which was "the best place" for an American to live in "the best time," the Eighteen Nineties, all is not well. The great state of Indiana, the most average, typical, representative state in America, is in a bad way.

MARSEILLE, France, Dec. 9 -- This city, where France's labor disorders began, received the news of the end of the strikes with weary relief tonight. At 11 P.M., the Government took over the telephone service and Marseillev -- still strike-bound in spite of the capitulation of the Comniunist-controlled General Confederation of Labor -- found itself without means of obtaining details of the terms upon which the walk-out was settled.

HALLANTDALE, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Roi Rouge, belonging to L.J. Hollenbach and winner of his last two starts at Churchill Downs, made his Florida winter bow an auspicious one today when he won the seven-furlong Southeastern Association of State Highway Officials Purse, feature at Gulfstream Park.

The completed manuscript of "The Memoirs of Cordell Hull" has been turned over to Macmillan and scheduled for publication in May. The story, which starts with Mr. Hull's childhood in Tennessee and ends with his retirement as Secretary of State, deals at some length with the first two years of his Secretaryship, when he initiated several important policies, such as his trade-treaty policy and the good-neighbor program in Latin America.

A funeral service for Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University, was held yesterday in St. Paul's Chapel, on the Morningside Heights campus. It was attended by a large number of friends and admirers of the distinguished educator and worker for world peace.
The natio'n a comic strips are being subjected to an antt-Communist loyalty purge, The Daily Worker complained yesterday.

Jewish trade union leaders pledged their support last night to Histadrut, the Jewish federation of labor in Palestine, at a testimonial dinner to Dr. Chaim Weizmann, scientist and Zionist leader, at the Astor Hotel.

Although the expansion of baseball's present major league set-up to two ten-club circuits by the inclusion of the four principal franchises on the Pacific Coast League is still very much, in a nebulous state and may never get beyond it, the idea has something more than Commissioner A.B. Chandler's official blessing.

The Radio Directors Guild, an AFL affiliate, announced yesterday that its executive council had been authorized to call a strike against NBC, CBS, ABC and Mutual's New York outlet, WOR. The guild's contract with the chains expires on Jan. 1.

Emissaries from heaven are not conspicuously exceptional on the screen, the movies having coyly incarnated any number of these supernatural types, ordained by their fanciful creators to right the wrongs of this world (not to mention the bookkeeping errors that seem to occur up above).

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Lew Worsham of Oakmont, Pa., national open champion, fired a fourunder-par 66 over the Miami Springs Golf Club course today in a warm-up test for the twentyfourth $10,000 Miami Open golf tournament which begins Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Some Senators complained today that the Greek Government had refused to furnish lists of the Greek Army's losses in fighting guerrilla raiders.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- William Green, American Federation at Labor president, said tonight that 1948 Congressional candidates must advocate lower prices as well as repeal of the Taft-Hartley law to win endorsement by the AFL's new political league.

A permanent exhibition of books to acquaint Americans with new French literature was opened yesterday afternoon with a reception at the French Institute in the United States, 22 East Sixtieth Street. Rene de Messieres, cultural counselor of the French Embassy, opened the exhibit, which includes 300 volumes by twenty French publishers.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- An interesting feature of the Council of Foreign Ministers is the presence of Grerman reporters at the news-briefing given daily by the four delegations. Then are ten of them, two each from the American, French and Soviet zones and four from the British.

The first shipment of 800 food and clothing pacKages for displaced persons in Cyprus under Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE) auspices left last night aboard the Exford, American Export Lines vessel.

Random notes. Although the chances are a black duck wouldn't know an isobar from a hip-roofed barn, the redlegs apparently decided that in spite of a lot of black lines on a weather map it was too cold in the North for comfort, and they have been arriving in greater numbers in Long Island Sound and the Long Island bays.
Hempstead Village, L.I., announced yesterday that it would receive on Dec. 18 bids on $366,000 of general improvement bonds dated Jan. 1, 1948, and due on Jan. 1, 1949 to 1965.
In an atmosphere that went back to the inception of boxing in 1719 plans yesterday were announced for a, James J. Walker Memorial which will serve the interests of juveniles.

With almost unprecedented speed and unity, leading civic, parent, educational and labor groups pledged their support yesterday to the Public Education Association's campaign to "Save the Schools." They urged that immediate steps be taken to improve the local school system and wipe out "educational slums."

This Christmas season finds the city's confectioneries supplied with candy of all sorts in quantities and varieties that exceed any year since the holidays of 1941, which was just before sugar rationing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee began a search today for any policy-making officials or employes of the Federal Government who might be speculating in the grain and commodity markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- A compromise under which purchases for the emergency foreign relief program, would be controlled to minimize impacts on American resources and prices was adopted today by the House of Representatives.

Senator J. Howard McGrath, paying his first visit to New York as Democratic national chairman, said yesterday that the Democrats wanted "no traffic" with organizations dominated by Communists or so regarded in the public mind but would welcome the backing of Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President.

Dresser Industries, Inc., manufacturers of oil and gas equipment, reported yesterday in a statement covering the fiscal year ended with October, a net profit of $4,400,000 after all charges, equal to $3.81 a common share. In the previous fiscal year the company's net amounted to $1,037,235, or 74 cents a share of common.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- If the rest of the winter is bleak and bad there will be fuel oil shortages in the North Atlantic states that will be uncomfortable at all events and perhaps rather worse than that in some localities, Congress was told today.
