CAIRO, Dec. 9 (Reuters) -- The Egyptian Arabic newspaper Al Mokattam said today the object of the present Arab League Council session in Cairo was "to harmonize the efforts of member states for feeding internal revolt in Palestine."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 9 -- Complete agreement has been reached between India and Pakistan on all issues relating to partition and the Kashmir question is proceeding toward an amicable solution, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Deputy Prime Minister of India, told the Dominion of India Legislative Assembly today.

Bad Debt Guide The Commissioner of Internal Revenue is preparing a guide for his agents designed to assist them in interpreting current regulations with respect to setting up by banks of annual reserves for bad debts, the New York State Bankers Association points out in a bulletin to members.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Addition of Lousiana State University features the 1948 University of North Carolina football schedule, announced today by Director of Athletics R.A. Fetzer. L.S.U. replaces the University of Florida.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 9 -- The unfair labor practice case of the American Newspaper Publishers Association against the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, went to trial today but the proceedings broke down in a disagreement over some final legal points before testimony began.

CHICAGO. Dec. 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 15.000 head: total. 21.000. Early butcher hog market steady but trade closed dull, mostly 25 cents lower: sows generally 50 cents lower: top, S26.2S; bulk of

The city will intervene in support of an application before the Federal Power Commission for construction of a natural gas pipeline between Texas and the Hudson River at 132d Street, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 9 -- An Arab attempt to get the Unites Nations Security Council to take up early discussion of the partition of Palestine was rebuffed today. The eleven-nation peace organ, rather gingerly agreeing only to place the item on the agenda, indefinitely adjourned any further talk on the explosive subject.

TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- Stars and Stripes, Army newspaper, denied tonight charges in The New York Daily Worker that it had been transformed by Gen. Douglas MacArthur into "one of the worst warmongering newspapers."
Louis Ranhofer got the award of the Lawn Tennis Writers Association of America yesterday for the most valuable contribution to the game in 1947.

Representatives of the arts, society, museums and dealers jammed the Knoedler Art Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, until early this morning at the charity art auction on behalf of the United Hospital Fund of New York. Receipts totaled $21,870.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Although the stock market here today was generally quiet most sections were cheerful and firm.

A funeral service was held yesterday for W. Axel Warn, retired state political editor and legislative correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, at the Williams Funeral Parlor, 41-39 149th Place, Flushing, Queens. Mr. Warn died on Sunday at 79.

New York quintets could earn no better than a split fast night at Madison Square Garden. There, before 18,189 fans, C.C.N.Y. overcame Oregon State, 58 -- 51, but St. John's of Brooklyn bowed to Loyola of Chicago, 61 -- 43. Both winners increased their unbeaten strings, City College to four and Loyola to eight.

The New York Rangers, currently one of the hottest sextets in the National Hockey League, clash with the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden tonight. Since these teams meet again tomorrow night at Montreal, fourthplace in the standings will be effected.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Another important step in the fight on leprosy was brought to public attention here today with the announcement that a large research station for study of the sulfone treatment would be established in Nigeria.

We believe that New York City's financial problems, the nature of some of Mayor O'Dwyer's criticisms of present state aid, the social purposes of the city's construction program and the sacrifices the Mayor is willing to exact from his own constituents deserve the earnest and open-minded attention of Governor Dewey.

If there is any question under the sun which one might think the Soviet Government would deal with gingerly, in an international conference, it is the subject of slave labor. The Soviet Government thrives on slave labor. It is an integral and indispensable part of the Soviet economic system.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 -- The South Carolina Public Service Authority charged today that the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation had violated the Public Utility Holding Company Act with respect to the proposed sale of all outstanding common stock of the latter's subsidiary, the South Carolina Power Company, to the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company for $10,200,000.

ATHENS, Dec. 9 -- A report from Salonika said a special investigation team, the first of its kind to be formed, had left for Epirus and the Albanian border this morning by air. At the Greek Government's instance, this small offshoot of the United Nations Special Commission on the Balkans will examine charges of violation of the frontier by a guerrilla formation now being engaged by the Greek regular forces.

Nickel consumption in the United States in 1947 will reach the highest peacetime rate in history, T. H. Wickenden, manager, the development and research division, International Nickel Company, revealed here yesterday during an interview at their national conference of more than 60 engineers and metallurgists at the Commodore Hotel.

Ever since the President, on Nov. 17, outlined to Congress his ideas for an anti-inflation campaign the Administration has been under criticism from the political opposition for its failure to back those recommendations up with a concrete program of legislation. Yesterday the Administration moved to remedy this deficiency.
BERLIN, Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to ship goods and raw materials in payment for reparations received from the western zones of Germany.

A head bookkeeper for the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, who had started with the company in 1927 as a messenger, was arraigned yesterday in General Sessions on a charge of swindling his employer of almost $50,000 in a nine-month period.

Legal action will be taken by United Artists to compel its affiliated independent motion-picture producers to comply with contractual commitments, it was announced yesterday by Gradwell L. Sears, president of the film distributing corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The trait in Senator Robert A. Taft that impels him to say whatever is pertinent to the subject he is discussing explains why he told a New York audience yesterday that meat rationing "may" start next April, thereby confusing the strategy of many of his fellowRepublicans in Congress.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Buying of wheat futures by mills that were removing hedges against sales of flour to the Government estimated at 2,000,000 sacks lifted prices sharply today on the Board of Trade with December in the lead. The latter developed congestion in the last few minutes of trading and soared 5 1/4 cents to $3.10 a bushel and closed at the top.

UTICA, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A truck line operator testifies in the United States District Court today that he was told by AFL union officials he would have to put union drivers on trucks he had leased to a Connecticut firm.

Many important plant expansions in chemical and process industries now held back by shortages of plates, strip, sheet steel and pipe will continue their slow progress next year unless equipment manufacturers can obtain new sources of supplies soon, equipment manufacturing officials revealed here yesterday.

The disclosure yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Marriner S. Eccles, that the rediscount rate will be increased in the near future from 1 per cent to probably 1 1/4 per cent aroused some wonder and uncertainty in banking circles yesterday as to the chairman's motives.

The Zionist Organization of America urged the United States Government yesterday "to make available the necessary ships and facilities for the transportation of large number of Jews to Palestine for the resettlement of the Jewish state" and "to facilitate the acquisition by the Jewish Agency for Palestine of adequate military equipment for defense and security uses in Palestine."

Peter J. McCabe, assistant to the vice president and general sales manager, has also been named manager of household refrigeration sales by the Times Appliance Company, Inc., Westinghouse distributor for metropolitan New York.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Britain is not going to alter the Palestine immigration quota of 1,500 per month, a Government spokesman said today.

Presiding Justice David W. Peck of the Appellate Division, Supreme Court, First Department, pleaded yesterday that citizens not avoid service on petit and grand juries because "jury service is the stuff of which democracy is made."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Robert L. Pine, Dayton, Ohio, real estate dealer, today appeared as a surprise witness before a Federal grand jury which is ending its investigation into the wartime business deals of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers.

Appointment by the Board of Education of a full-time director of safety education for the public schools was urged yesterday in the annual report of Frank L Jones, president of the Greater New York Safety Council.

A year ago the General Assembly of the United Nations established an International Children's Emergency Fund which symbolized by its international character the fact that children were above political considerations, that their plight cut across geographical boundaries, that the arithmetic of their tragedy was the concern of everyone, calling for a bold offensive on their enemies -- hunger and disease.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, guest of honor last night at the annual dinner of the New York County Lawyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel denied that there was any danger of attempted domination of this nation by its military men.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -- More than 5,000 men, many of them soldiers of the first and second World Wars, have sent cables and letters from various parts of the British Empire, the United States and Europe to Arab League headquarters here offering to fight for the Arab cause in Palestine, it was stated today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In quite a few of the articles appearing in the press, including editorials, there seems to be a lot of confusion concerning the issues arising out of the refusal of the ten Hollywood writers to answer the simple question as to whether or not each of them is or is not a Communist.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 10 -- Palestine lived through another day of bloodshed and murder today with eighteen deaths listed despite reports from Tel Aviv of an Arab-Jewish truce. Nine Jews, eight Arabs and one British soldier were killed.

Despite all its difficulties, the United Nations "today stands stronger than ever," Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, said last night. He scoffed at those who have spent the last two years predicting its speedy collapse.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of State Marshall's Statement to the Council of Foreign Ministers today:

Santa Claus lent George Herman (Babe) Ruth his red suit and white beard, gave him a sleighful of toys and sent him to the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation party yesterday at the Hotel Astor. Lined up to greet him were forty young poliomyelitis victims from New York and New Jersey, all of whom had been treated by the Kenny method.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 10 -- The fortunes of King Leopold suffered a setback here this afternoon. After a violent debate, the Belgian Chamber of Deputies voted confidence in the Government of Premier Paul-Henri Spaak on a motion arising out of the monarchial question.

Further elaboration of inter-European payments as worked out by the Benelux countries, whereby each nation could offset debits against credits, would do much to stimulate European production and aid in making the Marshall plan successful, Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Henry A. Wallace made the flat assertion today that there will be a third Presidential ticket in the field next year unless the foreign policy being followed by the Democratic national administration is changed.

It has well been said that charity is a virtue of the heart, that it stems from an inner goodness that lies within all of us. No one can read the stories of the Hundred Neediest Cases without a feeling of concern for those less fortunate than we are. Where can these troubled souls turn?

Reorganization of the city's Department of Commerce as a working unit with a paid expert staff was announced at City Hall yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. The department will function under the direction pf Commissioner Edward C. Maguire, who will continue to serve without salary, but will have a paid director and statistician-economist as well as a salaried secretary and a clerical staff.

The Board of Education ended its 1947 building program on schedule yesterday when ground was broken for two new schools in the Flushing section of Queens. The units, seventeenth and eighteenth of the year, will cost a total of $3,950,000.
Johnny Lujack, quarterback of the unbeaten Notre Dame football team, received the Heisman Memorial Trophy last night at the Downtown Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today a change in export licensing requirements that will give it control over what countries get building materials, brass, bronze, copper and zinc materials.

Homemakers may soon have phonographs housed in low-cost paper boxes, fluorescents that light up quickly, and all-rubber cords for pressing irons if tests being conducted by the Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., indicate these products are safe from fire and accident hazards.

First reports of a major new trend in industrial packaging methods have shown large economies obtained through increased buying of high price stainless steel containers, formerly considered prohibitive in cost, it was learned yesterday.

What the immediate future has in store for the Pacific Coast League in its determined bid to have its entire circuit elevated to the status of a major league should be determined not later than noon today.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. Raymond Marquie, head of the French repatriation mission in Russia which the Soviet Government has ordered expelled, charged his own Government tonight with a "systematically malicious attitude" toward the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- When Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. of Massachusetts was in Europe this summer he had two conversations that annoyed and impressed him.
The United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, was under pressure from two sources yesterday to reconsider its refusal to file non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law.

The New Jersey special deer season for archers will close today, and the hunters with shotguns and buckshot will take to the pine barrens tomorrow. Then for five days the woods will echo to the shouts, whistles and noisemakers of the drives.

Declaring that one of the prime goals of the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulation "will be to ascertain if a monopoly exists in all or any branches of the industry within this state," State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo outlined yesterday the plans of the committee.

Gasoline stocks in the United States increased 649,000 barrels last week, bringing the total of the week-end to 86,968,000 from 86,319,000 the week before, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. On Dec, 7,1940 the nation's gasoline stock amounted to 88,086,000 barrels.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Governor Dewey said today that 94,810 State companies soon would receive unemployment insurance tax credit amounting to a record $148,560,179, the first "rebate" under the controversial Young-Demo "merit rating" law.

Efforts to provide haven in Canada for one of three groups of Baltic refugees who have come to the United States from Europe on small fishing vessels in the last three months were described here yesterday by a representative of the National Lutheran Council.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A big White House Christmas celebration, combined with their daughter Margaret's Constitution Hall concert, will be held by the President and Mrs. Truman this year, their first holiday season to be spent in the Executive Mansion.
The first issue of The New Colophon, a book collectors' quarterly, is being distributed to the bookstores, Philip C. Duschnes announced yesterday.
MARSEILLE, Dec. 10 -- Dockers, seamen and others resumed work here today after the twenty-day strike.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two colorful backfield aces -- Johnny Lujack of Notre Dame and Herman Wedemeyer of St. Mary's -- will face each other New Year's Day in the annual Shrine East-West football game.

What was to have been the season's first presentation of the pas de deux from "Don Quixote" by the Ballet Theatre at the City Center last night did not take place because of a leg injury from which John Kriza has been suffering for some time which makes certain movements impossible for him.

Joana and Louise Leschin, duopianists, were heard in their first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The youthful sisters had arranged an unusual program consisting of the Respighi-Messina "Toccata," Mozart's Rondo (K. 386), reconstructed by Einstein, Liszt's "Reminiscences of Don Juan," the Bach-Leschin "Jesu Christus, Son of God," the Zipoli-Simon "Suite," which like the "Bailecito" and "Gato" of Guastavino received a first performance, and items by Infante, Bloch and Tausig-Gobbi.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 10 -- The Democratic leaders of twelve Midwestern states demanded today a unit voice in the party's 1948 platform. This action was looked upon as a concerted effort to woo the farm vote which the Democrats have lost in the last two national elections.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Unexpectedly rapid and harmonious agreement appeared to have been reached in the United Nations Trusteeship Council today regarding petitions by Ewe tribesmen of West Africa for unification of their lands.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Premier Ahmed Ghavam failed tonight to win sufficient votes in the Iranian Majlis (Parliament) in a test of confidence and, in accord with constitutional procedure, his resignation became mandatory. The Teheran radio announced that he had resigned.

Thirteen was the lucky number yesterday in the fourteenth annual "little sister" beauty contest at the Boys Club of New York, 287 East Tenth Street. It won the tittle of "beauty queen" and "Miss Boys Club of 1948" for Christina Stauchowicz of 260 East Tenth Street.

Members of the Child Care Center Parents Association said yesterday they would stage a demonstration with their children today before the headquarters of the State Youth Commission at 205 East Forty-second Street in protest against a new formula tentatively devised by the Welfare Department to adjust fees for child care.

Rayon yarn producers will give careful consideration to the proposition of raising prices in line with the increase announced by the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., according to officials of other leading companies in the field, yesterday.

Alan Ladd will be featured in "Box 13," an adventure series slated to become a regular WOR feature in January. The title refers to a postoffice address where Mr. Ladd, as Dan Holiday, receives replies to his newspaper notice: "Adventure wanted.

Never seriously threatened, Fordham easily won a 62-47 victory from Wagner in a wide-open basketball contest staged before 1,500 last night at the Rose Hill Gymnasium. John Bach and Gerry Smith split scoring honors for the Rams with 21 points apiece.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The House decided tentatively today, in three voting tests, to authorize $590,000,000 of emergency relief for France, Italy, Austria and China. It also voted to make this aid available without the formality of appropriations.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 -- Robert R. Young, board chairman of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, today issued a statement after the filing of an ICC examiner's report recommending against the seating of Mr. Young and Robert J. Bowman, president of the C. O., as directors of the New York Central and the right to vote C. O.'s holding of 400,000 shares of New York Central's stock.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Union and company negotiators have reached a settlement of the wage dispute at the atomic energy plant in Oak Ridge, Tenn., it was announced here early today.

Ruby Mercer, soprano, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Miss Mercer, who made two appearances with the Metropolitan Opera Association in leading roles during its spring season of 1937, and subsequently sang with other opera, companies, has been active in musical shows and radio broadcasts.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Mission Oil Corporation sought today before the United States Circuit Court of Appeals to have a Nevada Federal court injunction set aside to permit a $200,000,000 merger of Mission Oil and the Pacific Western Oil Corporation into the Sunray Oil Corporation.
Discovery of a hitherto unpublished manuscript by Maimonides, twelfth century Jewish philosopher and codifier of ancient Jewish law, was hailed yesterday as a major event in Jewish learning.

Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday to the international leadership of two labor unions to cooperate in settling a jurisdictional dispute that has brought to a standstill work on the city's low-cost housing project at Astoria, Queens, and threatens to affect other municipal housing project.

The Medal for Merit, the highest award for a civilian performing a notable service during the war, was presented yesterday to Irving Geist, philanthropist, manufacturer and leader of an inter-faith movement in this city.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 10 -- A vast conspiracy of treachery by which German militarists and industrialists made a mockery of the Allied victory in World War I within two years after the armistice was charged today during the trial of Krupp officials in the Palace of Justice here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Powerful Republicans in the House of Representatives are conferring in determination to end the reciprocal trade program as it is now known and operated.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 10 -- Col. Milton B. Ochs, 83-year-old veteran newspaper man of Tennessee, has been chosen by the Kiwanis Club of Chattanooga to receive their 1947 award as the person whose service to the community was considered outstanding.

Because of increased costs in running the school system, a substantially higher budget will be sought in 1948-49 than the present record sum, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said yesterday.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Headed by the Calumet Farm champion Armed, making his second try for the fat purse, 116 candidates are nominated for the eleventh running of the $100,000 Santa Anita Handicap on Feb. 28.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Hypnotism is all very well but it will not ever replace the old-fashioned straight left, according to the experience of Boxer Eric Boon.

WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., Dec. 10 -- A big Air Transport Command plane crashed in midnight darkness with, twenty-nine military men aboard in Labrador's icy wilderness just north of Goose Bay, but flares sighted near the wreckage today through a snowstorm gave hope of survivors.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP) -- A program calling for nearly doubling the foreign missionary staff of the Methodist Church as well as the present financial aid of the church for missionary purposed was presented today to the Board of Missions and Church Extension.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- A considerable increase in United States investment in raw materials and capital goods for German industry is envisaged for the Western zones of occupation in Germany by United States officials.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Coming from behind twice in a brisk-checking, rough National Hockey League game that flared so hot at one stage four players were sent to the penalty box together to serve major penalties for fighting, the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs earned a 2-all tie with the Detroit Red Wings tonight before a crowd of 12,505 fans.
MILAN, Italy, Dec. 10 -- The fear of Communist-fomented disorders has prompted the Italian Government to concentrate three Army divisions in this city, it was learned today.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- A great trial of strength, perhaps the final showdown between the Communist-dominated labor unions and the Government, began today when the Chamber of Labor called a general strike in the city and province of Rome to start at 6 o'clock tomorrow morning.

TEHERAN, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Mr. Ghavam's Cabinet quit several days ago over his failure to carry out domestic reform measures. At that time he turned down Opposition Deputies who informed him he no longer had a majority in Parliament and therefore should resign.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

PINE CAMP, N.Y., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Fire of undetermined origin raged through a two-story wooden barracks at this military reservation today, taking the lives of four Army officers assigned to "Exercise Snowdrop."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A resolution applying strict reciprocity, in numbers and treatment, to Soviet Russians seeking visa entrance into the United States was introduced today by Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Grain prices moved up sharply on the Board of Trade today, with, corn leading. The December corn contract was up 7 1/2 cents a bushel at one time to $2.65, coming within 1/2 cent of the daily limit, setting a new seasonal peak, and within 3/4 cent of the record high for any future.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 10 -- The Argentine press is up in arms again over criticism in the United States.

CALCUTTA, India, Dec. 10 -- One person was killed and nineteen injured today when police fired in Calcutta to disperse political demonstrators who attempted to prevent members from attending the meeting of the Legislative assembly.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Reports to Air Force headquarters here, relayed from a B-17 circling over the wreckage in Labrador, said that the entire airplane apparently had been burned except for a section of the tail in which no one would have ridden.

SECAUCUS, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Alexander Kahan, 29 years old, of 315 West Ninety-fourth Street, New York, pilot of a small sea-plane, was arrested here early today on two police charges of vehicular manslaughter as the result of an aerial collision yesterday in which two men were killed.

Some highly interesting and constructive ideas appear among the seventy-two prize-winning suggestions for economy and efficiency in the city government for which Mayor O'Dwyer made the awards yesterday. This contest, sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission, brought forth 728 economy proposals from 440 city employes, as against 600 suggestions in a like contest in 1939 and 310 last year.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Brown Hotel Stables' Tidy Sum won the featured Biloxi Purse today at the Fair Grounds. Tidy Sum finished three lengths ahead of Mrs. E.W. Hawkins' My Pop to pay $8.80 for $2 in the six-furlong race. W.H. Bishop's May Fly was third.

Columbia finally subdued Rutgers, 50 -- 44, for its third straight basketball victory at University Hall last night, but not before both teams had thrilled 1,200 spectators with a fiercely waged defensive struggle that had Rutgers on top for a considerable stretch.

A $1,200,000 cooperative economic experiment, in which more than 2,600 employes of the Thomas A. Edison Industries will share the benefits, was started yesterday by Theodore M. Edison, son of the late Thomas A. Edison, with announcement of a fifteen-man employe board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A breakdown of the Foreign Ministers Conference in London on the economic unity of Germany will mean the end of reparations transfers from Western Germany to the Soviet Union and its satellites, it was strongly intimated to the Senate Appropriations Committee today.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Nine movie writers, producers and directors surrendered today to the United States Marshal on a Federal warrant charging them with contempt of Congress for refusing to tell the House Un-American Activities Committee if they were Communists.

Ads to Give Gray Iron Data Details of the first national advertising campaign of the entire gray iron foundry industry were revealed here yesterday by R.L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders' Society, Cleveland.

Though the variety of fruit cake and plum puddings now prominently on display for Christmas is far too great to allow for a sampling of each kind individually, ten cakes and eight puddings from some of the leading manufacturers were chosen for a blindfold asting conducted yesterday in THE NEW YORK TIMES test kitchen.

The first exhibition of oils, water-colors, pastels, etchings, drawings, wood-carvings and jewelry by employes ("Sunday painters") of the Combustion Engineering Company, members of the C-E Art Guild, has opened on the twentieth floor of the company's building, 200 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Republicans put their answer to President Truman's ten-point anti-inflation program before Congress late today in the form of a joint resolution granting two of his requests and disposing of three others by authorizing voluntary measures.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The fourteenth annual Conference on Labor Legislation today advocated repeal of restrictive labor laws by the various states.
New issues of public utility bonds totaling $30,000,000 will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers, as follows:

To replace over-age machinery, buildings and equipment, the cotton textile industry must spend 500 million dollars more than it has been able to accumulate in its reserves, according to a survey by the Textile Information Service, released yesterday.

Results of a two-part study on newspaper readership and analysis of the effect of frequency and continuity in newspaper advertising on audience turnover and on total unduplicated audience were revealed yesterday by the American Newspaper Advertising Network, Inc.

TETERBORO, N.J., Dec. 10 -- An idea born over morning coffee more than a year ago ended in success here today when George W. Truman and Clifford V. Evans Jr., landed their Piper Cub airplanes to terminate a 25,162-mile world-girdling flight that probably never will be duplicated.

WARSAW, Dec. 10 -- The arrests of three Polish women employes of foreign embassies in Warsaw, including an American consular clerk, were disclosed today in the midst of what one diplomat described as "a crude campaign to terrorize" Poles from associating with foreigners.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member tanks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 3:
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- After a quiet opening in stock markets here today some sections livened up during the afternoon as business broadened.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The Central Ohio Light and Power Company, Findlay, Ohio, informed the Securities and Exchange Commission today that it plans to bid tomorrow on seven Ohio electric subsidiaries of the United Public Utilities Corporation that are to be sold at competitive bidding.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, informed Congress today that the board soon would raise the rediscount rate on bank loans.

The first citizens' advisory board for the Salvation Army to be organized in the Bronx was set up yesterday afternoon with forty-four members at a luncheon at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Grand Concourse and East 161st Street.

"Angel in the Wings" will check into the Coronet Theatre tonight bringing the comedy team of Paul and Grace Hartman. A song and dance show, sponsored by Marjorie and Sherman Ewing, it is described as an "intimate musical revue." The production, though, is hardly an inexpensive one, the financial outlay reported to be more than $100,000.

At a special meeting yesterday of the League of New York Theatres' board, the league interjected itself into the controversy now raging between Local 802 of the Musicians Union and two attractions, "Antony and Cleopatra" and "A Streetcar Named Desire," which have filed protests against the union's classification that each is a drama with music and must employ a minimum of eight musicians to play incidental music.

After a stormy crossing in which her speed was halved as she encountered gales of 60-knot velocity, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary arrived here yesterday, one day behind schedule, from Southampton. The ship docked at 9:45 A.M. at Pier 90, North River, with 1,925 passengers.

The American President Lines does not want responsibility for the construction of five proposed liners without assurance of long-term aid from the Government, according to a statement made in San Francisco by George Killion, president of the shipping concern.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The lowly Chicago Black Hawks tonight again found the usually stubborn Goalie Frankie Brimsek an especially porous individual and whipped the Boston Bruins, 6 to 5, before 15,682 in a National Hockey League game. In their last three starts against the Bruins, the Hawks have won two, tied one and have hit Brimsek for 15 goals.

Production of steel during November by the domestic industry was at a peacetime record level for that month and shipments of finished steel during October were at a peak for any month, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

The rich Red Sox became richer yesterday, and Manager Joe McCarthy, on the trail of another pennant to add to his impressive string, was wearing the smile of the cat that had just depopulated the bird cage.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Dec. 10 -- An investigation into allegedly heavy trading in wheat and other food commodities by Edwin W. Pauley, an assistant to the Secretary of the Army, was demanded in a speech here tonight by Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican nomination for the Presidency.
YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Proclaimed Dec. 15 as Bill of Rights Day. Presented Victory Medal to members of the White House Police Force and Secret Service who served in armed forces.

Theatre-size motion pictures comparable in quality with ordinary newsreel films, made in sixty-six seconds by aiming a film camera at the screen of a television receiver, were demonstrated yesterday at the annual "clinic" of the Television Broadcasters Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THE baseball meetings never seem to change from year to year. Nor does anyone in the cast of characters appear to get one day older. Perhaps that sedentary life keeps them young because they are the darnedest collection of lobby sitters you ever did see. They were parked by the scores in the lobby of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, punching the conversational bag with an adroitness born of decades of practice.

C.E. Marshall of the Yale Club led the way last night into the second round of the National Squash Tennis Association's scratch tournament on the courts of the Columbia University Club. Marshall had to come from behind in order to win from a home player, F.E. Kilgore, 12 -- 15, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 9.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- France today rejected the Soviet Union's note after a Cabinet discussion had concluded that its terms were "unacceptable."

Deluged with inquiries for sheets, the Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it has been forced to suspend acceptance of orders on that product until early next year because the company's capacity can not fill the current demand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Text of the Republican Anti-Inflation Bill follows: JOINT RESOLUTION To aid in the stabilization of commodity prices, to aid in further stabilizing the economy of the United States, and for other purposes.

It was all uphill for the New York Rangers in their National Hockey League game with the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night. As play went into its closing moments it looked as if the New Yorkers would just fail to make the grade, and it appeared that the Flying Frenchmen were about to break the jinx held over them all season by the Blue Shirts.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- The Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association denied today a statement made on behalf of the Chicago Typographical Union, Local 16, that the publishers had offered to operate their composing rooms without a contract, provided the union would waive a wage increase, before 1,500 printers walked out Nov. 24.
Mayor O'Dwyer publicly acknowledged yesterday his debt to the Citizens Budget Commission for "excellent" advice on efficiency and economy in city government.

Increased use of animation and colored lights and more open arrangement of merchandise designed to stimulate sales will be featured in store and window displays next year. These forecasts were made yesterday by representatives of seventy-eight members of the National Association of Display Industries participating in a spring pre-view exhibition at the Hotel New Yorker.

New Definition Needed? There was a time when a pedestrian was simply a person who journeyed or moved from place to place on foot, hence a walker. More recently we wheel-mad creatures have come to think of "pedestrian" more particularly in connection with someone who has been hit by an automobile.

The question of American-flag shipping service is no longer one of commercial enterprise, it is definitely a question of national policy of the highest consequence, Richard Parkhurst, member of the United States Maritime Commission, declared yesterday.

Sales of leading mail-order and chain-store companies increased 17.2 per cent in November, compared with the corresponding month in 1946, according to a compilation covering forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase in October was 17.7.

Charging that the Rumanian Government had hampered the delivery of American food and textile packages in Rumania, even to the extent of subjecting beneficiaries to questioning, CARE (the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc.), announced yesterday that it was ending operations in that country.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray of New York and Ilex House, Southampton, L.I., will give a supper dance on Dec. 29 at their home, 11 East Ninetieth Street, to introduce to society their youngest daughter. Miss Judith Bradley Murray.

City Bonds Municipal bond dealers are "getting by" in recent sessions with their newly bid-in issues of tax-exempt obligations, but the secondary market for the so-called "dollar bonds" of local governments is still sweating out an agonizing suspense passage.

Plans for the centennial year of the Community Service Society were announced by the organization yesterday at the annual meeting of its board of trustees, held at the society's headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A new campaign for the sale of United States Savings Bonds as a thrust against inflation was started here today.

LAKE SUCCESS N.Y., Dec. 10 -- A United Nations subsidiary group, drawing up plans for an international regime for Jerusalem as part of the partition program for Palestine, agreed today on measures aimed at guaranteeing the holy city's neutrality during any Palestine disturbance.

The controversy over whether Communists or persons under sentence should be permitted to speak on New York college campuses was intensified yesterday at Columbia University and City College and spread to Brooklyn College.

President Truman and former President Herbert Hoover joined in paying tribute last night to Jesse H. Jones for his work as chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the depression and the war. A letter from the President was read by Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder at a dinner in Mr. Jones's honor at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, attended by 300 former and present members and workers in the RFC.

Date Set for Summer Openings Members of the Sportswear Guild will open their summer lines beginning Monday, Feb. 2, it was announced yesterday by a spokesman for the group. Guild members include Adler Adler, Inc., Davidow; David M. Goodstein, Inc., Kane-Weill; Mutual-Rosenbloom Co.; Charles W. Nudelman, Inc., Zoltan Rosenberg; Sport-Craft, Inc., and Star-Maid Dresses, Inc.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 10 -- Secretary General Trygvie Lie will call the first meeting of the United Nations Little Assembly -- the new and controversial year-round committee of the General Assembly -- to order on Jan. 5, it was announced here today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- The $10,000 Miami open golf tournament will get under way tomorrow with the defending champion Sammy Snead, national open title holder Lew Worsham and Jimmy Demaret, the year's leading money winner, favored in the bulky cast of 232 players.
HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Forward March, owned and trained by Don M. Gilkey, sprung a mild surprise when he led all the way to win the mile-and-a-furlong feature at Gulfstream Park today.

Long Island University, which remains a question mark after its narrow triumph over Western Michigan last Saturday night, will run into topflight opposition at Madison Square Garden tonight. In the nightcap of a double-header that opens with New York University opposing Arkansas, the Blackbirds will face Oklahoma A. and M.
A donor to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund confessed yesterday that she had fulfilled a lifelong ambition in being able to send a gift to help the distressed families of the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, Philadelphia Eagles, Chicago Cardinals and Green Bay Packers, principals in key National Football League games next Sunday, are the team statistical leaders, too.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I dissent from your editorial "A Third Round" ? Try as I may, it is just impossible for me to accept any analysis of the present wage-price-profit picture that makes it seem that labor and business have enjoyed comparable increases in real income.

For the third successive session, the stock market yesterday extended its gains irregularly, with the rail shares showing the greatest strength. Sales were the largest in a week at 1,120,000, compared with 1,070,000 on Tuesday.

HAVANA, Dec. 10 -- Eric Wyndham-White, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, revealed in a news conference today that some 800 amendments had been submitted to the Charter drafted by the eighteen-nation Preparatory Committee in Geneva.

Coach Ray Flaherty of the football Yankees is giving away no secrets. He was asked yesterday whether his defensive strategy for Sunday's All-America Conference championship play-off would be to rush Otto Graham, Cleveland's great passer, or to jam Mac Speedie and Dante Lavelli, brilliant receivers for the Browns.

Dr. Leonard Cavello, principal of Benjamin Franklin High School, East 114th Street and East River Drive, praised Puerto Rican community organizations in East Harlem last night for taking a new interest in the problems of their community.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 10 (AP) -- As powerful Michigan began preparation today for its Rose Bowl game against Southern California, the Wolverines' hard-pressed ticket office set up a formula for distribution of Michigan's limited allotment of ducats for the New Year's day football classic.
An initial liquidating dividend of $5.25 a share was voted yesterday by the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation for payment to stockholders on Dec. 24.
Losing part of the early grains, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 14 points higher to 3 points lower on the day.

OSLO, Norway, Dec. 10 (UP) -- American and British Quakers who for 300 years have offered organized resistance to fighting in any form accepted the Nobel Peace Prize for 1947 today with an appeal for peaceful relations between the United States and Russia.

The 1948 Alexander Hamilton Medal, awarded annually for "distinguished service and accomplishment in any field of human endeavor" by Columbia College alumni, will be given to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia, Frank S. Hogan.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Dec. 10 -- Uncertainty as to continuance of bus transportation on the East End, West End and Point Lookout routes -- the three basic ones in this city -- ended tonight when the Long Beach City Council, at an emergency session, granted David Greenfield, bus operator, of 2260 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, New York, temporary consent to operate for at least sixty days.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- If the Council of Foreign Ministers fails to reach an agreement on German economic unity and reparations, as seems almost certain the dismantling of German factories in the Western zones for reparations will be stopped, it was learned here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- In this space last week two dispatches were devoted to listing the major mechanical problems in setting up a European Recovery Program. These issues must be decided by the administration before it can present a draft of the ERP to Congress, and by Congress before it can legislate a plan.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- "No Son of Mine," a forthcoming novel by G.B. Stern, British author, has been acquired for the screen by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer under a long-term option, the studio announced today. The story, which will be published early next year, deals with a relationship of a respectable citizen and a rascal who poses as his son.
The military sectors of the "cold war" between Russia and the United States were broadened this week.

The expulsion of the French repatriation mission from Russia, with the similar action taken by France against the corresponding Russian mission, calls attention again to a situation that has become a dark blot on our victory and our civilization. Behind the innocuous and even appealing term of "repatriation" there lurk the horror and the agony of a modern slave system and of the most extensiye and ruthless dislodgment of populations known to history.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- An agreement under which Panama will lease fourteen sites just outside the Canal Zone to the United States for the defense of the Canal was signed in Panama City today by Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, the United States Ambassador, and Francisco A. Filos, Acting Foreign Minister of Panama.

An issue of $1,500,000 of rural school bonds of Davidson County, Tenn., maturing Jan. 1, 1949 to 1973, was bought yesterday by an investment banking group headed by Equitable Securities Corporation at a bid of 101.09 for 2.70s, an interest cost of 2.629 per cent.

ATLANTA, Dec. 10 (U.P.) -- Basil O'Connor, head of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, said tonight that in the organization's "decade of progress" it had spent $35,000,000 in medical care for poliomyelitis victims and $13,000,000 for research in the disease.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- President Truman wants Congress to think it over carefully before taking any action to prohibit shipments of oil abroad. Otherwise, he says, the country "may suffer."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- Two citizens of the United States, one Argentine, two British scientists and one French author received Nobel Prize diplomas and money here tonight from Swedish King Gustaf.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Secretary of State Marshall accused the Soviet Union today of taking German assets at the rate of more than $500,000,000 annually from its occupation zone in Germany. He called for the cessation of that and other practices.
YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Trusteeship Council Completed discussion on petition of Ewe tribes of West Africa for unification of their lands.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the board, and Robert J. Bowman, president, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, will not be permitted to hold directorships in the New York Central if the Interstate Commerce Commission follows recommendations made to it today by C.E. Boles, assistant director of the ICC's bureau of finance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The State Department said today that it was retaining the right to discharge or transfer an employe as a "bad security risk," even though he had been cleared of disloyalty by President Truman's Review Board.

LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Under heavy parliamentary pressure, the Government withdrew tonight its specific references to the press and news agencies from a motion regarding the disclosure and publication of confidential information on Parliamentary matters.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Saying that "the republic has just undergone a severe assault, and our workers defended it magnificently," Premier Robert Schuman in a broadcast tonight called on all classes to emulate "the great majority" of wage earners by cooperating to raise France's standard of living.

Zadel Skolovsky, who appeared in recital at Carnegie Hall last night, has an affinity for the piano. His aptitude where mechanical aspects of playing the instrument are concerned is astonishing, even in a day when keyboard technicians are to be found in abundance.
ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 10 -- Employment of Negro police by the city of Atlanta was temporarily restrained today by the Fulton County (Atlanta) Superior Court.

Paper industry executives are watching inventory, production and consumption reports with special interest now because some fear a break in the paper market late in 1948 if inventories outside of mills increase too rapidly, trade spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- John D. Goodloe, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, said today the RFC had authorized a $15,500,000 loan to a prefabricated housing company in Chicago that "from a credit standpoint was not what you could call a sound loan."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Republicans' anti-inflation resolution was approved today by the House Banking and Currency Committee, 14 -- 9, after being rescued from certain defeat by the help of Democrats. The measure, which substitutes voluntary methods for mandatory allocation, priority and several other powers requested by President Truman, thus narrowly passed its first legislative test.

Retail merchandisers and resident buyers expect general merchandise prices to remain strong at least until Easter, according to comments here yesterday. No break was seen in staple goods prices, with the contrary view expressed that some lines may show further advances before peak levels are reached.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- Advance of nationalism in the Far East and the slow defeat of communism in Europe were outlined today at the twelfth annual luncheon given by THE NEW YORK TIMES for automotive and industrial executives here.

Ike Williams, his lightweight championship of the world not at stake, will collide with Tony Pellone, Greenwich Village welterweight, in the feature ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The Trenton (N.J.) titleholder is expected to scale about 136 pounds, but Pellone will come into the ring weighing closer to 145.

The statement made to the London conference by Secretary Marshall cuts through the rival claims, divergent policies and rival propaganda that have hitherto obscured the issue. This issue is so fundamental and so urgent that Mr. Marshall has felt justified in demanding an immediate showdown on it, in order to determine whether there is still any hope of Big Four agreement.

Hail End of Extra Commissions The decision of Philippines publishers to decline payment of an extra 15 per cent commission to local representatives of United States advertising agencies was termed a return to pre-war normalcy yesterday by the New York representative of a large Manila newspaper publishing company.

Contrary to popular belief, home freezer units have proven a boon to locker plants and owners of the community freezers have done a big job in selling the home units, it was pointed out yesterday by speakers at a luncheon meeting of the Eastern Frosted Food Association in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The International Monetary Fund approved tonight the Canadian Government's proposal to subsidize the mining of gold as a step toward improving its dollar position for world trade.

Daroff Announces $2 Advance A price increase of $2 at wholesale on spring Botany-Daroff worsted and gabardine clothing ranges was announced yesterday by H. Daroff Sons. The advance, effective next Monday, raises the present wholesale level to $36.25, with the established retail price going from $55 to $60.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York was quoted tonight as saying that President Truman's handling of domestic affairs had convinced him that he was "not competent to use the powers that have been given him."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine today appealed to Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations for permission to appear before the Security Council and participate in the debates on the Palestine case.

What ails the Neediest ? Poverty, illness, unemployment, yes -- but most of all, the feeling that misfortune is as resistless as the tide. Where talent, intelligence, self-confidence are so shaken as in Peggy of Case 73, it is not alone the service of supply that will cure.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.8 per cent during the week ended Dec. 6, as most major commodity groups reached new post-war highs, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- After a day of anxious negotiations in which the Government made some further slight concessions to the workers, the Chamber of Labor decided tonight to continue the general strike it declared yesterday in the city and Province of Rome.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The long-planned Moscow Information Center of the United Nations will be opened late in January, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 11 -- Informed sources here believe that the Arabs will confine their wholehearted opposition to the creation of a Jewish state to the encouragement of guerrilla warfare and will take no official or concerted action against Palestine Jews until after the British mandate ends next May.

Lieut. Gen. George F. Stratemeyer, commanding general of the Air Defense Command, told a group of Brooklyn business men and civic leaders yesterday that until the United Nations worked out a plan for world peace "there will be no peace, just an armistice -- a "time out" -- in the deadly game of war."

Directors of the Sinclair Oil Corporation declared yesterday an extra dividend of 25 cents a share in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents, both for payment to stockholders on Feb. 14. No comparable extra dividend was voted last year.

ESSEN, Germany, Dec. 11 -- The Ruhr coal mines, turning out coal these days as never before since the end of the war, face a real and imminent danger of being forced to close, at least partly, because of inadequate transport, Harry L. Collins, British chairman of the bipartite coal control group, said in an interview here today.

Demands for better enforcement of the police regulations aimed at easing traffic congestion and many "able" proposals for improving conditions have been received by the Traffic Action Committee, it was disclosed yesterday by Walter D. Binger, chairman.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Dec. 11 -- Dr. W.V. Wibell of Cherry Valley was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association tonight at the annual meeting in the Garden City Hotel. O.M. Lamberaon of North Hempstead was named vice president, Robert M. Johnke of Hempstead, secretary, and Campbell B. Carmichael of Sewane Harbor, treasurer.

Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, postponed his scheduled meeting yesterday with Benjamin Fielding, City Welfare Commissioner, until noon on Monday in the state offices at 205 East Forty-second Street.

The first performance in America of Mahler's Sixth Symphony was given by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra last night In Carnegie Hall. This performance brought cheers and long-sustained applause in its wake. Mr. Mitropoulos kept returning to the stage, bowing graciously, at last gesturing to the orchestra to rise and bow with him.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 11 -- Communists hold fourteen posts in the new Cabinet of the Fatherland Front Government announced today by Premier Georgi Dimitrov. The new Government, which was sworn in before the National Assembly, also contains five members of the Agrarian party and two each of the Zveno Union and the Social Democratic party. It includes five Vice Premiers.

Last Christmas 7-year-old Phyllis Turiansky, instead of spending her time wondering what Santa Claus would bring her, was busy during the pre-holiday season making potholders. These she sold and then contributed the proceeds to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Truman took personal command of the Administration's drive on high living costs today. He demanded that Congress carry out his ten-point anti-inflation program to the letter and forget about substitute plans which he said were inadequate to do the job.

A man, who had $4,100 in his pocket when arrested and admitted he was a home relief recipient, appeared yesterday in General Sessions in connection with the alleged theft of $5,445 from various banks, but pleading to an indictment was adjourned until next Thursday.
A rise of 15 per cent in the rents of about 1,700,000 Federally controlled dwelling units in the city and Nassau and Suffolk Counties was demanded yesterday by the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee.

Purchase of Ware's Department Store in New Rochelle was announced yesterday by Bloomingdale's, the New York unit of Federated Department Stores, Inc., which said it would take over the actual management of its new enterprise early next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The House, by a voice vote, passed its $590,000,000 emergency relief bill for France, Italy, Austria and China today. The roar of "ayes" indicated support by an overwhelming majority. Democrats complained that the gavel of Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. had banged too fast for them to demand that the House go on record, member by member.

As evidence of the progressive spirit of the age, Paul and Grace Hartman have been promoted. They are head folks in an extremely pleasant musical revue, "Angel in the Wings," put on at the Coronet last evening. For years the Hartmans have been making serious dancing totally unnecessary in this town with their inspired parodies.

Comets are not now widely regarded with superstitious awe. We know too much about them. We know that they are largely composed of gas. We know that their so-called tails are so tenuous as to be repelled by light. We know that most of them are regular in their habits, so that Halley's, which was seen by millions of naked eyes in 1910, will be around again in 1986.

After more than a month of discussion, the Board of Superintendents of the New York public school system, has dropped a teachers' in-service course dealing with the Soviet Union and sponsored by the American-Russian Institute, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Mrs. M.E. Tilley, of Atlanta, Ga., a member of the president's committee on civil rights, told the women's national press club today that she hoped human rights would be a campaign issue in 1948, and that "both political parties will be back of it."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- Studies of nerve axon structure under an electron microscope, which magnifies 100,000 times, may solve many of the mysteries of the central core of human nerve fibers and reveal how nerves work, the Electron Microscope Society of America was told today at the opening session of its three-day, fifth annual convention in Franklin Institute.

Scenes of the annual lighting of the Christmas trees on Park Avenue this year will be put on the air by WNBT, through a pick-up Sunday from 6 to 7 P.M. by one of NBC's mobile television units. The electronic cameras will take up a vantage point outside the Brick Presbyterian Church at Ninety-first Street and Park Avenue, where the ceremony will be conducted under the auspices of the Park Avenue Association.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today closed a deal with Al Jolson giving the studio the right to produce a sequel to "The Jolson Story," which Columbia made in 1946. The new project has been assigned to Edwin Knopf for production, and Jolson will work with him on the preparation of a photoplay dealing with the aspects of the singer's life not covered by the Columbia film.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Dec. 6, 1947, totaled 178,588 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 86,249 cars, or 40.9 per cent more that, for the preceding week; 149,504 cars, or 20.5 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 102,212 cars, or 13.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- An amended plan for the liquidation and dissolution of the International Hydro-Electric System of Boston was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by Bartholomew A. Brickley, trustee for the system.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- British steel production in November at the annual rate of 14,174,000 tons was the highest ever recorded for that month but slightly lower than in October, the British Iron and Steel Federation reported tonight.

ABERDEEN, Md., Dec. 11 -- Various types of "mathematical brains," automatic machines for handling information by electronic or electrical relay circuits, are in the blueprint or production stage which promise not only to open up vast areas of the fields of science to research but to revolutionize the handling of information in business.

A market for about 9,000,000 cars exists in the United States and it won't be met until at least 1950, Ray A. Robinson, research director of the Crowell-Collier Publishing Company, declared yesterday. He spoke at the annual meeting of the Automobile Merchants Association of New York in the Park Central Hotel.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The twelve-point anti-inflation program recently offered by the National Association of Manufacturers "in the public interest" is a most extraordinary document.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Senators heard today that shortages of pig iron and scrap metal are threatening to drive many foundries out of business, cause widespread unemployment and affect the construction of new housing.

The existence of a "brand-new" comet in the universe was confirmed yesterday by Dr. Leland E. Cunningham of the University of California in Berkeley, one of the world's leading authorities on comets and their paths.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 11 -- The North Korean Communist Government late last week confiscated all currency in the Soviet zone. This sudden move touched off a wild buying spree.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- In the most vigorous radio speech yet made in the series on "Freedom Versus Totalitarianism," addressed to Germans in the Soviet zone, Richard M. Scammon, expert on elections and political parties of the United States Military Government, today drew a sharp contrast between the roles of parties in a democracy and under a dictatorship.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 11 -- In ever-widening, infinitesimal detail, Deputy Prosecutor Joseph Kaufman continued today the presentation of evidence of the extensive German rearmament prior to the Hitler era, in the trial here of twelve officials of the Krupp munitions combine.

Heads of special steamship company committees working on proposed regulations for export-packaging revealed yesterday their plans for putting teeth in the projected code and announced that efforts would now be speeded up to get it into operation early next year.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday the payment of a year-end bonus of one week's salary to all employes with one year or more of service. Employes with less than one year's service will receive bonuses based upon the length of employment.

The Port of New York Authority gave its approval yesterday to Austin J. Tobin, its executive director, to appear before the Civil Aeronautics Board in support of the issuance of temporary certificates of operation for short-haul passenger service by helicopter in the New York area.

The use of city-wide benefit assessments and pay-as-you-go contributions from proceeds of an increased transit fare were recommended to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday as a method of getting an early start on construction of a Second Avenue subway line.

Extension of tax privileges enjoyed by subsidized operators under the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 to include unsubsidized operators was recommended yesterday by the Association of American Ship Owners.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The State Department has sent a political adviser from Seoul to confer with United Nations officials on paving the way for entry into Korea of the special United Nations Commission, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense today foreswore any Presidential or Vice Presidential aspirations in 1948 by quoting the now historic statement in the same vein made last January by George C. Marshall, then the newly-appointed Secretary of State.

Strict attention to sales promotion and the use of planned advertising were stressed by Stanley J. Cummings, executive secretary of the National Association of Uniform Manufacturers, at the association's sixteenth annual convention meeting yesterday afternoon at 112 East Nineteenth Street.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

John Reed Kilpatrick, president of Madison Square Garden and admittedly a No. 1 hockey fan, yesterday deplored "the squabble" regarding the selection of a hockey team to represent the United States in the winter Olympic games.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Efforts of the occupation forces to impose a statemanaged-and state-financed economy upon Japan have run into a snag. The Government simply cannot raise the necessary money, and unless some way out of the difficulties can be found within the next two or three months a firstrate crisis is certain.

Friday, Dec. 12, 1947 YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Security Council Committee of Experts -- Continued discussion on question of Council's functions in relation to strategic trust territory of former Japanese-mandated islands in Pacific.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The FrenchSoviet diplomatic controversy was featured today by a charge by the Government that French citizens had been transferred to the Soviet Union through the Beauregard repatriation camp here without the knowledge of French authorities.

A son of an assistant football coach, who started the season as a benchwarmer, finished as the nation's 1947 leader in total offense with the second highest mark in collegiate football history, The Associated Press revealed yesterday.

Thousands of lights will sparkle on the sixty-five-foot Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center for the first time today at 5 P.M. Skaters cutting graceful turns on the pond will make this a gay holiday scene.

WESTOVER FIELD, Chicopee, Mass., Dec. 11 -- Twenty-three persons died in the crash just after midnight, Tuesday, of the United States Air Transport Command C-54 plane near Goose Bay, Labrador, Air Force officials reported here late today.

The Rev. Dr. Frank Hamilton, a former official of the Navy Department in Washington, said by those who knew him to have been "the greatest living authority on the topography of Palestine," died yesterday at the home of Dr. Charles Fama, a physician, at 216 Sutherland Street, City Island, the Bronx.

The techniques by which Christmas shoppers can deal with thieves, pickpockets and holiday racketeers were laid down yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. In a list of "don'ts" the Commissioner advised shoppers to frustrate the underworld by not making friends too quickly with strangers and not leaving notes announcing the time of return home in a door bell.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the closing hours of the U.N. Assembly "debate" on Palestine a suggestion was made by the Arab delegates that Palestine should be set up as a federated state.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Princess Elizabeth and her consort, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, will receive from the British Government allowances amounting to L50,000 ($200,000) a year if recommendations published today by the House of Commons Select Committee are approved by Parliament.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, retiring on Monday from command of the Navy to "baby-sitting," received today the official farewell of President Truman and the leaders of the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Communist expansion in western Europe has reached its outer limits, barring a clear and present possibility of a "violent strike for power" by way of civil war, Congress was informed today in a first-hand study.

The National and American Leagues, in joint session before Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler in the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, once again turned a deaf ear to the fervent pleas of the Pacific Coast League for recognition as a third major circuit.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The President alone should have responsibility for administering the Marshall plan, and this administration should be by a new operating agency, not a corporation, the National Planning Association declared today.

Random notes. The New York waterfowl season will close tomorrow, and despite the bad shooting weather that has generally prevailed during the second phase of the season, the reports indicate better shooting than last year.

The contemporary approach to the fusion of sculpture and architecture was discussed by critics last night at a dinner and preview in the Architectural League, 115 East Fortieth Street, of a nineman show of recent works by prominent sculptors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Truman announced today that he is preparing an extensive plan for reorganizing Government departments which he will send to Congress for action in January.

The oil industry has been called upon for immediate mobilization of all its public relations, advertising and promotional organizations behind a concentrated campaign to gain public cooperation on conservation and obtain better understanding of the industry's efforts to meet current high demand, the American Petroleum Institute announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- A statement issued here today outlining the proposal of Odeon Theatres to take over shares of the General Cinema Finance Corporation revealed that the latter incurred losses of more than L2,000,000 ($8,000,000) on movie production during the last three years.
LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Firmness of industrials and a further setback in gilt-edge issues were the features in stock markets here today.

OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 11 -- Topranking Army officers held an allday "off-the-record" conference on national defense and industrial preparedness with nearly 600 Midwest industrialists and businessmen today.

The owners of the Long Island Sound group of International Class racing yachts gathered last night for their annual winter dinner-meeting in the New York Yacht Club, with their crews as guests, and reports were made that all twenty-three of the sloops would be out next summer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs, 13,000 head: total, 23,000. Market slow, generally 25 to 40 cents lower on barrows and gilts; sows around 25 cents off: bulk of good and choice 180-300 pound butchers

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, despite seasonal influences, rose again last week, advancing $24,000,000 to another new high of $5,317,000,000 at "the close of the reporting period ended on Wednesday.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman defended yesterday the state's public housing program as the best in the country and criticized "a leading public figure from the Middle West" who recently came out against subsidized public housing.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 11 -- In an unusual community experiment that will be studied as the possible working projection of President Truman's appeal for guardianship of civil rights, this town of 45,000 has "audited" itself to find out where it stands in offering its citizens equality of opportunity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 6 were 7 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from periods of 1946:

An Old Hand on the Job From his place of retirement out of the hurly-burly of the city, a ninety-three-year-old newspaper man has written this corner a letter. Naturally he is interested in the New York which was the scene of his active service and his daily goings and comings.

The principle of emergency aid to France, Italy and Austria has now been accepted by both Houses of Congress: by the Senate on Dec. 1 by a vote of 83 to 6; by the lower House yesterday by a voice vote. The Senate accepted as "substantially accurate" the President's estimate of $597,000,000 as urgently needed between now and April 1.
MONTREAL, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The New York Rangers plastered a 4-2 lacing on the Canadiens at the Forum tonight and moved into a fourth-place tie with Montreal in the National Hockey League race.
Thousands of fathers, nephews and brothers are going to receive one tie less than usual this Christmas morning -- and most of them already know it.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Great Britain and the Soviet Union have reached a basis of agreement on trade that will bring not only immediate benefits in food for Britain and machinery for Russia, but will also form the foundation for a longterm trade pact.
Two Navy icebreakers, now nearing the icebergs south of New Zealand, will attempt a feat unique in polar exploration, it was learned yesterday.

Urging the United States to pursue a constructive policy abroad that does not "play into the hands of reaction," Frank Rosenblum, vice president of the World Federation of Trade Unions, said yesterday that such a policy would enable democratic elements in Europe to triumph over both communism and fascism.

Alighting from the Merchants Limited train in Grand Central Terminal yesterday, 67-year-old Fred Wright was greeted by executives of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad who presented him with a gold pin commemorating the Pullman car porter's fifty-five years of service.

During the debate yesterday on the bill for emergency aid to Europe, Republican leader Halleck of the House of Representatives asserted that the Democratic Administration has terribly mismanaged the foreign policy of the United States and that additional funds for aid to Europe are necessary at this time only because of such mismanagement.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A two-man committee representing Pittsburgh Steeler players today asked the club management for "stand-by pay" until their status in the National Football League play-offs is determined.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Corn futures, after being buoyant yesterday, turned downward today on the Board of Trade and closed 2 1/2 to 4 1/4 cents a bushel lower, with December finishing about at the bottom, although a car of No. 2 yellow sold in the cash market at $2.71, a new record.

ONCE upon a time there were two Irishmen. One was named Joe Cronin and the other was named Joe McCarthy. And that's no joke, son. The two Joes have been very busy in the past few weeks fastening the 1948 American League pennant to the flagpole at Fenway Park. They haven't been using nails. They've been using rivets.

After drifting narrowly lower, stock prices in the final hour yesterday recovered moderately and closed mixed on the New York Stock Exchange. Led by American Telephone and the oil shares, activity increased near the close with the tape in the final minutes of trading lagging behind the market.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- Henry A. Wallace, continuing his criticism of the bipartisan foreign policy, took Governor Thomas E. Dewey to task tonight for his support of universal military training, aid to China and his local tax plan.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 11 -- Establishment of a Federal agency to survey "war disabled" American cities and "find means for their rehabilitation" was advocated today by Goveror Sari Warren of California.

Unable to penetrate the tight zone defense of the Oklahoma Aggies. Long Island University's basketball team dropped from the unbeaten circle last night at Madison Square Garden. The Brooklyn Blackbirds succumbed, 52-37, after N.Y.U., in its best showing of the campaign, had romped to an 85-62 victory over Arkansas.

L.J. Dieber, sales promotion manager of Butler Brothers, Chicago, has been named general sales manager, succeeding L.R. Maxwell who has resigned. Carl V. Haecker, formerly of W.T. Grant Company, becomes sales promotion manager of Butler Brothers.

This week butter prices passed the all-time peak of 95 cents a pound, attained last year, and reached the disconcerting level of 97 cents. The City Department of Markets, in reporting that this was the most common cost in stores in low and medium income neighborhoods, said the general range was 93 cents to $1.06 a pound.

After more than three years of research, scientists of the New York Medical College, Metropolitan Research Unit, have perfected an extremely low calory "survival" diet that may have broad value in the event of an atom war.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 11 (AP) -- American business interests contracted today to buy $30,000,000 worth of scrap steel from China, bringing to light the fact that the Chinese Government is selling vast quantities of United States war surplus materials received in a settlement of wartime accounts between the two countries.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers agreed today to set the German level of steel production at 11,500,000 ingot tons annually. It also agreed to several other paragraphs of the British draft on economic principles. Thus, after many weary days of disagreement, some cheer was brought to the gloomy delegates.
