HAVANA, Dec. 11 -- Steps were taken today to speed up the work of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment to prevent its materially running beyond the scheduled Jan. 15 deadline or of being compelled to recess because of the heavy load of amendments to the Geneva draft charter of the proposed International Trade Organization.

Just when it appeared that the Red Sox had stolen all the trading thunder of the major league meetings, concluded yesterday, the Yankees made the eleventh-hour announcement that they had acquired Pitcher Charles (Red) Embree from the Indians in a straight player deal for Outfielder Allie Clark.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 11 -- Palestine's death toll reached a new high today in the current disorders. Eleven Jews and nine Arabs were killed and forty-six Arabs and fourteen Jews injured in a long series of bombings, shootings and stabbings.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned sluggish yesterday and closed 9 to 30 points net lower.

Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley said yesterday that although the nation that gave the most attention to education would "write the history of the future," the school system here was endangered by "false ideas of economy." He said our nation must "respond to the needs of the times" by producing educated citizens and civil leaders.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 -- Jakob Kaiser's political fate hung in the balance tonight after the party board of the Christian Democratic Union for the Soviet zone had debated nearly ten hours whether to force him to resign. The board finally quit without a decision, and, in effect, passed the question to the Soviet military administration.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 11 -- A total of $158,032,729 has been expended this year by the three agencies of the United Jewish Appeal for overseas relief and rehabilitation, settlement and reconstruction of Palestine and aid to refugees in the United States, it was reported tonight by Henry Morgenthau Jr., general chairman of the United Jewish Appeal.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 11 -- The ten Hollywood producers, directors and writers charged with contempt of the House Un-American Activities Committee Started today a hovel legal maneuver to escape trial.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 11 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, addressing the quarterly New Jersey Traffic Court conference today, sharply condemned those who feel that through "influence" they can "fix traffic tickets" and escape consequences of their infractions of highway-safety regulations.

The granting of long-term operating differential subsidies to American-flag steamship companies by the Maritime Commission, a practice which is currently under attack from the Bureau of the Budget, is authorized under the Merchant Marine Act of 1936 and subsequent legislation was not intended to interfere with such grants, according to Judge John J. Burns, general counsel of the American Merchant Marine Institute.

Limited skiing may be enjoyed in several places in upper New York State and New England as enthusiasm continues to run high in Eastern ski circles -- thanks to early snow which permitted running as early as Thanksgiving Day this season.

A dentist should make a psychiatric evaluation of each patient on the spot and assume approach tactics calculated to suit each personality type to relieve some of the dread patients associate with a visit to his office, two doctors told the Greater New York Dental Meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today announced a reorganization of the company's leading studio executive personnel and the abandonment of the executive producer system, which has been in effect at Metro for more than ten years.

NANKING, Dec. 11 -- Continued sweeping successes were claimed today in Government reports here dealing with the offensive against the Communists in the HupehAnhwei-Honan border region, a hundred miles north of Hankow.
New York's meat wholesaler were accused yesterday by Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz of holding back heavy stocks in anticipation of higher prices. The charge was denied by industry spokesmen.

The power of the State Supreme Court to rule on the recent action of the Board of Education, in which that body refused to prohibit allegedly subversive groups from meeting in public schools, was questioned yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Charles W. Froessel in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- During the week ended Dec. 10, member bank reserve balances increased $94,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- The House of Commons listened in deep gloom today as the Government closed a "tragic chapter" in British history by confirming that on May 15 next year Britain planned to lay down her Palestine mandate.
The President Held a news conference. Told reporters Congress should carry out his anti-inflation program to the letter.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : Congressman Herter has played a praiseworthy part in obtaining Congressional consideration of the Marshall Plan. But his bill, H.R. 4579, proposes a plan of organization that would prove costly in operation and spells delay, confusion and inefficiency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Testimony alleging careless handling of "March of Dimes" funds and possible illegal political activity involving employes of the Boston Internal Revenue office was turned over today by a House subcommittee to the Justice Department for "appropriate action."

With the return to action yesterday of Spec Sanders, the indispensable man of their backfield, the football Yankees tackled their training chores for Sunday's AllAmerica Conference championship play-off, against the Cleveland Browns with renewed vigor.

Paul Windels has been in the front lines of the battle for a self-sustaining transit fare for a long time. It was in 1940 that he became chairman of the Committee of Fifteen, which was interested in transit problems. Since 1943 he has been chairman of the Citizens' Transit Committee.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 11 -- Four Canadian missionaries en route to take up duties in Africa underwent a harrowing experience when the 10,000-ton British freighter Empire Wallace, on which they were traveling, encountered a violent storm on the way from Montreal and was given up for lost by her master.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of New York today urged the Methodist Church to take a more active part in formulating this country's foreign policies by "providing competent men to represent the moral opinion of the world at the places where decisions are made."

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The Communists moved rapidly today to obtain the strongest possible representation on the Rules Committee of the Assembly of the French Union, the newly formed forum provided by the French Constitution for France's overseas spheres of influence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee decided today to summon Edwin W. Pauley, Special Assistant to the Secretary of the Army, to testify tomorrow morning about his trading in wheat and other food commodities during 1947.

BERLIN, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Mr. Scammon said in his speech that Russian-dominated European states never dared speak out in favor of the Marshall plan or any other move by the Western powers to aid Europe, because these nations were afraid to speak against communism.

Anglo-Chilean Nitrate Corporation -- Twelve months to June 30: Distributable net profits of L759,292, compared with L757,989 for preceding twelve months period. Horance R. Graham, president, states that all future earnings of the company will be available for corporate purposes including distribution of dividends to the shareholders.

PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The passage of the stop-gap aid bill by the United States House of Representatives has greatly reassured the French Government, which is concentrating its efforts upon the importation of wheat, meat, fats, fodder and fertilizer to insure that French urban workers will be well fed this winter and afterward.

The State of Louisiana sold yesterday a new issue of $3,000,000 of institutional bonds, maturing Dec. 1 from 1969 to 1973, to the state's teachers' retirement system at an interest cost of 2.69 per cent. The state rejected bids submitted for $7,000,000 of bonds to mature Dec. 1 from 1952 to 1968.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- The popular Belair Stud racing banner was carried to victory in the Miccosukee Purse at Gulfstream Park today by Catana, who beat five 3-year-old opponents over the mile and a sixteenth route.

The Bureau of Internal Revenue does not regard as "unreasonable accumulations" funds held back from this year's earnings and reserved for future advertising, particularly in view of increased advertising costs necessary to meet competition, it was said last night by W.A. Sutherland, Washington attorney.

The settlement of the recent disturbances in French industry was characterized yesterday by Georges Villiers, president of the National Council of French Employers and the French Association for Free Enterprise, as "the unset of a political interference" in her internal affairs that cannot prevent France from regaining her former place among the free nations of the world.

John R. Macomber, chairman of the board of directors of First Boston Corporation, and Allan M. Pope, president, will retire on Dec. 31, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Macomber will be succeeded by Harry M. Addinsell, chairman of the executive committee, and Colonel Pope, by James Coggeshall Jr., executive vice president.

"The Gentleman from Athens" is paying the Mansfield one of those fleeting visits. On Tuesday night the Emmet Lavery comedy -- produced by Martin Gosch, in association with Eunice Healey -- had its premiere there. Tomorrow night it will make its exit after a span of seven performances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Stealing a march on the Republicans, a Democratic Representative from Michigan, John D. Dingell, introduced a bill today to reduce taxes by $5,500,000,000. He said the measure offered "an equitable system of tax reduction."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council should establish an economic commission for Latin America, it was decided unanimously here today by an ad hoc study committee.

Although banned from speaking at Brooklyn College next Monday, Howard Fast, who is awaiting sentence for contempt of a Congressional investigating committee, will address a rally Thursday night at Midwood High School, adjacent to the college, it was learned yesterday.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 11 -- A new price policy announced by the apparatus department of the General Electric Company provides for a limitation of 20 per cent on price increases and simultaneously permits the company on new orders to adjust prices within this ceiling to those in effect at time of shipment, officials revealed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Officials saw nothing irregular today in the sale by the Chinese Government to the Bethlehem Steel Corporation of 2,000,000 tons of scrap iron on Pacific islands for re-importation into this country after it had been sold by the United States Government to China.

In an attempt to get more money for the public schools, educational leaders are now preparing a bill to be introduced in Albany early in the session that will seek an additional $100,000,000 in state aid, Dr. Arvie Eldred, executive secretary of the New York State Teachers Association, announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Fred Haas Jr. of New Orleans, former national intercollegiate champion, one-putted nine greens today to take a one-stroke lead with a fiveunder-par 65 at the end of eighteen holes of play in the twenty-fourth annual $10,000 Miami open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Dec. 11 (Religious News Service) -- Washington Jefferson College, identified with the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America since the Eighteen Seventies, announced here that it has broken off with the church for trying to "usurp" its authority.

A group of stockholders of the Alleghany Corporation is organizing an independent advisory council, of which Daniel W. Blumenthal will act as honorary chairman, it was announced yesterday. The principal aim of the group will be to take the fight of Robert R. Young and Robert J. Bowman, chairman and president, respectively, of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, to become directors of the New York Central directly to the stockholders of both companies.

Her pre-Christmas departure marked by numerous cabin parties, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed from West Fiftieth Street yesterday with 1,685 passengers bound for nearly every country in Europe and the Mediterranean area.

Toward Stabilization? The market for prime corporate securities is beginning to show definite signs of stabilization, bond men were bold enough to assert yesterday. Their hunch is based on a new "feel" which they are getting out of the secondary market, which suddenly has begun to broaden.
Miss Nannie Ochs died early yesterday morning in her home in the Volney Hotel, 23 East Seventyfourth Street. She would have been 88 years old next month. She had been ill for several months.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Demands that the United States Military Government preserve a "beachhead of free enterprise" in Western Germany came from some members of the Senate Appropriations Committee today. They were addressed to Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The first trial examiner's report on Taft-Hartley Law issue's tossed out unfair labor practice charges against a union today and ruled that a strike during the term of a contract did not necessarily constitute restraint and coercion of employes who might be opposed to the walk-out.

Speedy enactment of the Marshall plan was urged last night by Louis Hollander, president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations and national vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers.

The President Conferred with General Eisenhower on Army problems. White House announced he would see Congressional leaders Monday morning concerning European aid. Nominated fifty Reserve and National Guard officers to be major or brigadier generals.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Only a "consistent and persistent" foreign policy inflexibly protecting the legitimate foreign interests of American oil operators can assure the national security against a somber outlook in the supply position, Congress was told today.
ROME, Dec. 12 -- The general strike in Rome was called off today by the Chamber of Labor after lasting for two days. The strike was ended when the Government made further concessions.

Production of Eastern Canadian softwoods, particularly spruce, will probably be reduced 50 per cent as a result of failure of British buyers to place orders, a wellknown local lumber wholesaler with Canadian interests predicted yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Following is the text of the statement by Foreign Minister Molotov to the Council of Foreign Ministers today as distributed in English by Tass, Soviet news agency: The day before yesterday Mr. Marshall made a statement on behalf of the United States Government designed to stop immediate reparation deliveries to the Soviet Union from Germany.

Christmas Trade Active Here Christmas trade continued active here this week. Gains over a year ago were somewhat larger than earlier in the month, but nevertheless were spotty as between stores. Volume next week is expected to be particularly heavy.

Two wage-reopening meetings held yesterday by a committee representing Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipowners with the Marine Engineers Benefical Association and the National Martime Union, both CIO affiliates, made little or no progress and the entire matter probably will be made the subject of arbitration.
TOKYO, Dec. 12 -- Once again an occupation attempt to control prices without controlling wages has failed. Not only has it failed but it is creating conditions bordering upon economic chaos.

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, said today that "neither the Wagner Act nor the Taft-Hartley law compels the signing of contracts unless two conditions are established."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Edwin W. Pauley defended his trading in futures in the commodity markets as a normal, prudent "hedge" against depreciation of the dollar as he testified today before the Senate Appropriations Committee. He said he had engaged in such trading for about ten years.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 -- Hirohito has recently displayed concern lest the testimony to be given by Japan's wartime dictator, Gen. Hideki Tojo, in his own defence in the closing stages of Tokyo's wartime trials, will again raise the question of imperial responsibility for the war, this correspondent has learned.

Officials of Hunter College and the Board of Education took steps yesterday to prevent Howara Fast from addressing student groups, but New York University reluctantly granted permission for a student meeting at which he is scheduled to speak.

This Christmas New Yorkers might borrow an idea from smalltown life, one that's been current in this country since the first log cabins went up on the Plymouth shore. We're referring to the home-kitchen gift, mentioned here earlier this season, that may be elaborated on at length.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, the Polish Peasant leader and former Premier who arrived in the United States recently from Britain after having fled from his country, expressed the hope today that this country would furnish economic assistance to Poland notwithstanding its domination by the Soviet Union.

ROANOKE, Va., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Sixty coaches, athletic directors and athletic council members debated at length today on measures designed to "strengthen" the rules of the Southern Conference on the subject of the length of time students may participate in Conference athletic programs.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary of State Marshall, answering a long and insulting tirade by Foreign Minister Molotov against the Western Powers on German reparations, today said that "such a method of procedure makes it rather difficult to inspire respect for the dignity of the Soviet Government."

Powerful natural economic forces are now working for higher interest rates and lower bond prices, but they are no match for the power of our Government to regulate the money market, Joseph Stagg Lawrence, vice president of the Empire Trust Company, said yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Municipal Forum at the Lawyers Club.

Liquor dealers will be asked to back up the Marshall plan by buying more imported wines and spirits, thus providing more American dollars to European countries through regular trade channels, it was learned here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hope it will not seem to you petulant if I quarrel with certain statements in the biographical note on General LeClerc which followed the news service report of his death in a plane crash.

Delayed four days by Atlantic storms, the Marine Flasher, operated by the United States Lines, arrived here from Bremerhaven yesterday with 632 passengers, among them a 7-year-old boy who does not remember his name, his parents or his nationality.

WSHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- An expansion of the cultural exchange program, to double the number of foreign students now in this country, was recommended here today by Dr. Francis J. Colligan, acting chief of the State Department's Division of International Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, paid what was to be a secret visit to the White House and discussed what were described as professional military problems of the Army with President Truman today.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The London County Council, chief local authority for a large part of the metropolitan area, presented today a scheme to extend individual medical advice and health services to the more than 3,000,000 persons in its jurisdiction before the end of March, 1949.

Oil Product Prices The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., apparently has adopted a new policy with respect to adjusting prices of products to offset change in prices of petroleum. Heretofore, the policy has been to pass on to the public the full increase in prices of crude oil without taking into consideration the petroleum produced by the company.

A new gloves merchandising tie-up with Valentine Day will be launched about Feb. 1 by way of an advertising and sales promotion package sent by the National Association of Glove Manufacturers to 1,500 of its members, an association spokesman disclosed yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, told today how representatives from the United States, Great Britain, France, China and the Netherlands won out in a move to carry details of the Marshall plan to workers in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The following list of the twent three men who died in the cra of the ATC plane at Goose Ba Labrador, at midnight Tuesday was made public tonight by t Air Force:

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Austria will appeal for material help beyond that in the United States interim aid bill if the Council of Foreign Ministers fails to reach agreement on an Austrian peace treaty, Foreign Minister Karl Gruber said today.

BRIDGEPORT, Dec. 12 -- A new administration has taken over control of Bridgeport's largest industrial union local composed of more than 6,000 employes of the General Electric Company by unseating officers who directed the ousting of twenty-four alleged Communists and fellow travelers last year.

PANAMA, Dec. 12 -- Protesting crowds of students battled police in the center of the city today as the National Assembly received from President Enrique Adolfo Jimenez the newly signed agreement for Panama's lease of canal defense bases to the United States.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., nervous as an amateur poker player with four aces but rolling out the birdies, shot a six-under-par 64 in the second round of the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today to take a two stroke lead at 132.

Lumber producers are prepared to reduce -- perhaps by as much as 25 per cent -- prices now averaging 221 per cent more than the 1939 level, and Congress will act, if necessary, to legalize an industryvide agreement to effect such a reduction, Representative Ralph A. Gamble, chairman of the Congressional Joint Committee on Housing, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Concern is beginning to be felt here among some United Nations officials over the continued delay in establishing the Palestine Commission that is to take over interim administration of the Holy Land when the British relinquish their mandate.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Senate and House managers agreed today -- in a move to speed the emergency foreign relief program into operation as soon as possible -- to an authorization of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to advance money until actual appropriations are made.

The announcement by CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc.) of the end of its operations in Rumania was withheld until it succeeded in getting its representative out of that country alive, it became known yesterday.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 12 -- Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, Deputy Prime Minister of India, revealed details of the financial agreements between India and Pakistan in a statement to the India Legislative Assembly today. Commenting that the comparatively simple separation of Burma from India required five years to complete, Sardar Patel termed the completion of Indian partition in six months a "miracle of concentrated effort and consummate ability."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 12 -- Six farming and engineering experts are being sent to Cairo, Egypt, by the United Nations to meet the request of Arab states for international help in stepping up agricultural production, it was announced today.

HAVANA, Dec. 12 -- William L. Clayton, chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, today received a report from Clair Wilcox, vice chairman, on the impasse that threatens the proposed International Trade Organization.

WASHINGTON,Dec. 12 -- An amendment to the interim foreign aid bill may make it possible for this country to count contributions of all Governments in matching funds for the International Children's Emergency Fund, officials of the fund said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- With his message to Congress on the European recovery program nearing completion, President Truman will hold a conference with Congressional leaders on Monday morning in which the whole European relief problem will be reviewed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Republican majority House leaders moved today to get quick action on President Truman's request for $29,375,000 to continue work on four Western reclamation projects threatened with suspension by lack of money.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a temporary injunction granted in Nevada that forbids completion of the proposed merger of Mission Oil Corporation with Pacific Western Oil Corporation into the Sunray Oil Corporation.

The faithful of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York will be asked at all masses and vesper services in every church tomorrow to stand up and renew their pledge to the Legion of Decency. At the same time Catholics in all the other dioceses of the United States will renew this pledge, it was announced yesterday at the Chancery office, 477 Madison Avenue.

Following is a chronological report issued last night by CARE (Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe, Inc.) of events leading to its decision to end delivery of parcels to Rumania, and incidents related by Tucker P.E. Gougelmann, CARE's Rumanian representative who returned recently to the United States:

With Fleet Admiral William F. Halsey, USN, retired, as the principal guest of honor, the New York Southern Society held its sixtysecond annual dinner dance last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldbrf-Astoria. Groupings of flags of various Southern states, offset by a profusion of autumn flowers, provided a colorful decor I for the fete, a traditional reunion of Southerners residing1 here or temporarily visiting in this city.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 12 -- The unprecedentedly high sum of $395,367,000 will be needed by the United Jewish Appeal during 1948, it was announced here today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 11,000 head: total, 21,500. General market on barrows and gilts steady to 25 cents lower: close fairly active, mostly steady: sows 25 to 50 cents lower: bulk of

Charpentier's "Louise," which remains an unusual and enchanting opera of Paris and its proletariat, and the cause of working girls leaving home, made its return to the Metropolitan repertory last night and presented Dorothy Kirsten for the first time here in the title role.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 12 (AP) -- Chairman Alvin F. Weichel of the House Merchant Marine Committee said today that two Russianoperated American-owned ships left United States ports with vital cargoes for Russia within the last month.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Now that the orators on both sides of the United States-U.S.S.R. controversy have exhausted their choicest epithets, the time has come for an end to forensic oratory and the beginning of action to bring about a state of dependable peace.

In this great city many of us do not know our neighbors. The faces one sees in an apartment elevator may be vaguely familiar, without ever becoming connected with names or personalities. The jostling crowds in the subways, the impatient shoppers in the corner stores, the man who bumps you as you struggle down the hall with an armful of Christmas bundles -- all these are strangers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- On the theory that they might be liable to criminal prosecution in case of "a catastrophe," Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, sought today to place in the record of the Senate Appropriations Committee, of which he is chairman, the names of all officials responsible for recent exports to the Soviet Union.

LAC BEAUPORT, P.Q., Dec. 12 -- The staccato orders of alert instructors mingled with the hilarity, of recreational enthusiasts today at Lac Beauport, northeast of Quebec City, where thirteen inches of new snow made for unusually good early-season skiing.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- The difference between Britain's socialist economy and United States capitalism offers "no serious difficulties" to continued development of "close and even fraternal relationship" between the two countries, Secretary of State Marshall declared tonight.
HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- A long run of losing favorites failed to be checked when the H. S. Stable's Syntet won the Kissimmee Purse at Gulfstream Park today.

Thousands of tons of food and other commodities contributed or pledged by the people of New England for the needy of Scotland and delayed in delivery because of the reluctance of the Federal Government and American private operators to provide free shipping will be transported in British vessels, it became known yesterday.

Commercial banking interests headed by the Chase National Bank are continuing their efforts to participate in the financing of shipments of cotton to Germany despite a series of setbacks, it was learned yesterday. The original program, under which private banking sources would become active in handling German imports for the first time since the war, involved about $20,000,000.

Expressing optimism over prospects for adoption of the charter of the International Trade Organization at the world conference now being held at Havana, Arthur Guinness, president of the International Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday he expected the conference to be concluded by the end of January or mid-February.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- A blunt warning to Jews not to provoke trouble by unauthorized immigration that might lead to war in Palestine came today from Foreign Secretary Bevin at the conclusion of a two-day debate on the British withdrawal from the Holy Land.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A sound-producing mechanism for aircraft to assure more dependable control in flight, happier landings in cases of emergency and reduction of hazards in general has been patented (No. 2,432,078) by Charles Adler Jr. of Baltimore, Md.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The United Mine Workers of America today abruptly severed its connection with the American Federation of Labor. In a curt "chit" that scarcely concealed its contemptuous implications, John L. Lewis announced the momentous step.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Rene Mayer, Minister of Finance, consulted leaders of labor and management today to receive their suggestions regarding the drastic economic measures that the Government expects to take within a fortnight to check inflation and to reduce the hardships of urban wage-earners.

City College, most impressive of the metropolitan court squads until New York University put on its great show against Arkansas, will attempt to recapture the spotlight tonight. Nat Holman's busy Beavers will tackle Bowling Green's high-scoring quintet in the finale of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.

The organization of a National Catholic Resettlement Council "to help bring about legislation in Congress to open the door to a substantial number of displaced persons," was announced yesterday following a two-day meeting of representatives of national Roman Catholic groups at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

ABERDEEN, Md., Dec. 12 -- Eniac, the only electronic computer among the four "mathematical brains" now in use, is being converted so that it can handle without resetting all types of mathematical problems to which it is adapted, it was disclosed at the Aberdeen Proving Ground today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The secretary of the National Canners Association said today that the canning industry had solved its own inflationary problem by increasing production to meet demand and forcing a drop in prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Administration's bill for stand-by price-control powers was submitted to an unreceptive Republican Congress today in the midst of extraordinary preparations by leaders for quick House passage of the Republicans' own anti-inflation resolution.

In his thoughtful speech last night at the Pilgrims' dinner in London, Secretary Marshall touched upon two points that are of particular interest to an Anglo-American audience at this time. He noted first that those (he could have mentioned the Russians here) who see the close and even fraternal relationship between Britain and the United States as "evidence of calculated political combinations" are confusing cause and effect.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Champaign School Board asserted today that Interpretation of the Federal Constitution to prhibit the use of public school buildings for religious education "is to commit religion in every form of its expression to a state of anarchy."

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Secretary Marshall was fully informed by Sir Stafford Cripps of the progress of the negotiations that have resulted in agreement in principle on terms of the comprehensive Anglo-Soviet Trade Treaty.

Full accord on the need for compulsory motor vehicle inspection in New York State with, opinion divided sharply as to its administration was voiced yesterday at a public hearing before the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems.
Despite a clearing in the skies yesterday, the comet discovered earlier in the week at various points in the Southern Hemisphere remained invisible to observers in the United States.

Edward E. Rhatigan, former Welfare Commissioner, disclosed last night that the Office of Military Government had withdrawn suddenly its offer to him of a $10,000 post as Deputy Chief of its Public Welfare Division in Germany.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 12 -- The practical experience gained by German technicians through the device of the dummy concern "IVS," set up near Rotterdam, the Netherlands, in 1921 saved two to four years for the German Navy in its reconstruction prior to World War II.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were less active yesterday than in any previous sessions this week and closed 4 points lower to 16 points higher than the day before.

In the mistaken belief that because he was heavier he would be stronger. Tony Pellone, Greenwich Village welterweight, last night undertook a ten-round bout with Ike Williams, Trenton (N.J.) Negro who is the undisputed world lightweight champion.

The control of a West Side pier "shape-up," at which a boss stevedore each day selected several hundred longshoremen for work, was cited yesterday by the prosecution as the motive behind the fatal shooting of Anthony Hintz last Jan. 8 as three men went on trial on first-degree murder charges.

Purchasing agents have started resisting efforts by manufacturers to expand the use of escalator principles in selling materials and equipment, industrial spokesmen revealed here yesterday. They said that changing sales terms to a basis of "prices in effect at the time of delivery" is the first step toward reviving escalator clauses generally.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 12 Questions implying grave charges maladministration by the Union South Africa in its mandate of South-West Africa were posed today in the United Nations Trustee Council by representatives of na, Iraq, Mexico and the United States for submission to the South African Government.

VIENNA, Dec. 12 -- The United States protested today at a meeting of the Allied Council for Austria against a Soviet order to the Austrian General Directorate of Railways to send seventy-five Austrian -owned locomotives to Yugoslavia.

The New York City Rent Commission, 500 Park Avenue, heard arguments yesterday for and against eviction of fifty-six families in the Washington Square area to make room for a $3,500,000 multiple apartment project.

HONOLULU, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Fifteen members of the Hawaiian Warriors, Pacific Coast League championship football team, were charged today with "betting on an athletic contest" and were released on bail for District Court hearing tomorrow.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 12 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California tonight pictured the Far West as having a growing "appetite" for full development of its resources to make it "still more useful to the world." He warned, however, that these resources were not "inexhaustible."

The hero of a long list of Mexican motion pictures and of two American films produced in Mexico was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison on a charge of dodging the draft.The defendant, Walter Henry Ward Jr., who adopted the film name of Alfonso Ortega, was found guilty by a Federal Court jury Thursday night.
Three players from the National Football League, all linemen, repeated on The Associated Press 1947 All-Pro team announced yesterday.

It is a little difficult to render a fair and conclusive judgment on a legislative program while it is still in process of unfolding. And that, it appears, is the present state of the Republican anti-inflation program. We have been permitted to see one reel of the picture; the showing of reel two has been reserved for sometime after Jan. 1, when the second regular session of Congress convenes.

Reinvestment demand and further activity in the petroleum section provided yesterday a fresh argument for an extension of the week's recovery of stocks on the Stock Exchange. Prices finished at the best levels of the current recovery, although encumbered in some respects by irregular movements at the opening in several of the major groups.
Canada has agreed to lift a little of the "iron curtain" that threatened to keep Saint Nick and his gifts from crossing the border, it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Fifty civilians who distinguished themselves as officers in the recent war were nominated by President Truman today to be generals in the Officers Reserve Corps and the National Guard.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Defense Plant Corporation, which built and equipped 10 to 12 per cent of this country's war-time production capacity, was criticized today for its bookkeeping methods.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 -- Henry A. Wallace, on the last lap of an upstate speaking tour to sound out third-party sentiment, said tonight he was playing a game of "make believe" when he told reporters he would vote for Senator Robert A. Taft, Ohio Republican, in preference to President Truman next year.

NANKING, Dec. 12 -- The State Council decided today on an indefinite postponement of the National Assembly, which had been scheduled to convene Dec. 25, The original plans called for China's new Constitution to become effective with the opening of the Assembly session.

The millinery industry has set its sights on a goal of 120,000,000 units annually, which can be reached in two or three years, according to Sam Finkelstein, executive administrator of Millinery Promotions, Inc., in an interview yesterday. This will represent an increase of 50 per cent over current volume, he said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Legislation to force Federal agencies to dispose of surpluses made of steel and iron was suggested to the Senate Small Business Committee today as a "solution" to the nation's pig iron and scrap shortage.

Jean Watson, Canadian contralio, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. As at her previous appearances in this city, the youthful artist's voice proved enthralling, with its unusual power and gorgeous timbre, its firmness, and its freedom of emission, throughout a wide range of evenly matched tones.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- William Bowers and Robert Arthur have been assigned to prepare a new photoplay for production next year at Universal-International under the title, "The Western Story," giving three interpretations of a single incident in the history of the Western pioneer.

Two hundred dentists with experience in treating cerebral palsy victims put their names on a list during the Greater New York Dental Meeting, which ended yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, to be consulted by parents seeking dental care for children who suffer from the affliction.

WARSAW, Dec. 12 -- The Polish Government affirmed today that it had no objection to Polish nationals working for foreign nations in Poland and declared there was no intention of restricting ordinary contact between Poles and foreigners.
Lunchrooms in city schools have resumed using margarine instead of butter for sandwiches as an economy measure, it was disclosed yesterday.

A group headed by the National City Bank was high bidder yesterday for $5,004,000 of bonds of the Independent School District of Houston, Tex., at 1.00.619 for 1 1/4s and 2s, an interest cost of 1.9588 per cent.

Eight of fifteen major projects to speed commercial, as well as passenger, traffic through the city are under way, only a year and a half after the start of the fiveyear, $200,000,000 program of extending arterial highways laid down by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.

In a scintillating struggle that saw lona make up a 9-point deficit in the final minutes, the Brooklyn College basketball team dropped its first game of the season, 52 -- 48, to the New Rochelle quintet last night before an overflow crowd at the Flatbush court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board, refereeing a jurisdictional fight between John L. Lewis and David Dubinsky, ruled today that a West Virginia employer must pay back all the dues, deducted from employes' pay checks for Mr. Dubinsky's union since June, 1946.

The Board of Superintendents of the New York public school system is postponing all courses in its program of intercultural education for teachers and will "survey the whole problem," Dr. Jacob Greenberg, associate superintendent in charge of the in-service courses, announced yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 12 -- Terming cities the "bottlenecks" in the existing state highway system, Charles H. Selis, superintendent of the New York State Department of Public Works, today proposed construction of a system of arterial highways for Poughkeepsie City and the Town of Poughkeepsie, Dutchess County.

Alfred Hennen Morris, only surviving charter member of The Jockey Club which was founded in 1894, resigned as an officer, it was announced yesterday, and his place as vice chairman was taken by George D. Widener.
Farewell to Santa's Sleigh? The problem of inducing Santa Claus to do a guest appearance at the inauguration of the Christmas season has always tickled the imagery of department store staffs.

HANKOW, China, Dec. 12 -- Central China's rich merchants and well-established companies, including foreign concerns, are being taxed for fortifications and for the raising of the People's Militia to combat the Communists. The levy is designed primarily to finance a program that the impoverished local governments cannot afford to carry out.

More than 600 needy children will find toys in their Christmas stockings this year as a result of the efforts of students at the New York University Industrial Arts Department who have organized a miniature "mass-production" toy factory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Russia was reported today to be threatening a deadlock on reparations from Japan. Diplomatic informants said the Soviet delegate had served notice on the eleven-nation Far Eastern Commission, that a United States proposal, which would trim down Russia's share of any war indemnity from Japan, was unacceptable to Moscow.

Opposition to the proposed sale of the Empire Steel Corporation of Mansfield, Ohio, to the Studebaker Corporation, manufacturer of automobiles, arose yesterday with the solicitation of proxies by a group headed by Peter Beasley of New York, a consulting engineer and former president of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Memorial Hospital in New York, headed by Dr. C.P. Rhoads, today received the largest aggregation of Federal cancer grants ever given to one institution, a total of $142,550 for six projects.
PARIS, Dec. 12 -- Approval of the French policy in rejecting a note from the Soviet Union was voted by the National Assembly today, 411 against a solid Communist opposition of 183.

Mayor O'Dwyer will have rounded out two years in office and be at the half-way mark of his term when he returns from vacation. Last Jan. 1 we mentioned three major goals which, if accomplished, would make 1947 a year of achievement for the Mayor.

John Orr Young, former member of the advertising concern of Young Rubicam, has started what is expected to be an extensive advertising campaign to bring about the nomination of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for President by the Republican party.
CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Athletic officials of the Big Nine will invite presidents of the Conference's schools "mutually to discuss problems and get suggestions" on athletic policies.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, assigned one-third of his staff of 6,000 yesterday to a comprehensive review of eligibility for all classes of public assistance except veterans' relief. The action was in accordance with the State Board of Social Welfare's demand for an up-to-the-minute picture.
Gus Lesnevich, world lightheavyweight champion, yesterday entered the heavyweight boxing picture as a possible June opponent for Champion Joe Louis in the titleholder's last fight.

"A ceremony celebrating the first issue of a new national magazine designed to spread information on diabetes to sufferers in areas where treatment now is "not good," was held yesterday by the American Diabetes Association, Inc., at the Russell Hotel, Thirtyseventh Street and Park Avenue.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 -- Today's official death toll in Palestine was twenty-eight, with eight more missing and believed dead. This list, comprising nineteen Arabs, seven Jews, one British soldier and one Czech, covers the deaths confirmed until late tonight and not previously reported by this correspondent.

A disturbing picture of New York's public school system is presented by the Public Education Association in making available the results of its twoyear study. Conducted by Dr. Paul R. Mort and other school experts, the report indicates that this city has far to go before it can provide the children with an adequate education.

Year-end changes in brokerage firms which are members of the New York Stock Exchange were announced yesterday. According to the weekly bulletin of the Exchange, the firms of Newburger Hano and Paul S. Zuckerman Co. will be dissolved on Dec. 31.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Scattered liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, wheat being off over 4 cents a bushel at one time, but short-covering developed and a good rally followed.

A proposed local law calling for the licensing of "amusement devices" and fixing a schedule of license fees has been introduced in the City Council at Mayor O'Dwyer's request, it was learned yesterday. The measure is now in the hands of the Council's General Welfare Committee.

Attorney General Tom Clark has completed his study of the disputed sale of tankers to foreign interests and has reported on his findings to the White House, New York shipping men were Informed yesterday by their Washington representatives.

The Robert J. Collier Trophy, one of aviation's chief awards, has been given this year to one of the hard-working engineers of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, Lewis A. Rodert, for "his pioneering research and guidance in the development and practical application of the thermal iceprevention system for aircraft."

The Girl Scouts in the United States have announced the establishment of a new proficiency badge designed to give 615,000 intermediate scouts "the basis for intelligent radio listening which will be useful to them all their lives."

GENEVA, Dec. 12 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights approved today a Chinese proposal that advocacy of racial, religious and national discrimination that tends to incite to violence should be forbidden by law. A clause containing this provision was included in the draft convention on human rights aiteivthe rejection of a Russian proposal to make a list of similar actions for inclusion in the draft declaration as a crime punishable by law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The text of the price-control bill submitted to Congress today by Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach was as follows: STATUTORY STANDARDS Section A -- The application of this act shall be limited to the following commodities:
MILAN, Italy, Dec, 12 -- Fortyfour thousand Milan workers today donated one hour's pay to their French brethren, Armando Cosciutto, secretary of the local Communist party, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Congressional Aviation Policy Board will recommend that the Government undertake "greatly increased expenditures" to bolster the air defenses of this country. This unanimous decision of the board was announced today in an interim report issued by Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, chairman of the group charged by the Congress with making an over-all study of air policy for the future.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- British movie box office receipts fell about 25 per cent in November, and the decrease is largely attributed by industry authorities here to the embargo by Hollywood producers on sending new films to this country.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The State Board of Canvassers completed an official count today and found that the people voted overwhelmingly in favor of the $400,000,000 veterans' bonus in the Nov. 4 referendum. New York City voters approved it 1,209,689 to 388,748. The up-state margin was 1,012,111 to 417,078.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I be permitted to comment on Dr. J. Arthur Myers' remark, as printed in your Notes on Science, Oct. 12, that "BCG and similar vaccines will defeat efforts to wipe out tuberculosis and block the chances of streptomycin or other chemical conquests of it..."

The prospects of the New York Yankees against the Cleveland Browns in tomorrow's play-off for the All-America Football Conference championship at the Yankee Stadium received another boost yesterday. For the first time in almost a month, Bruce Alford, the local team's brilliant right end, worked without a brace on his left arm.

With the northern shooting drawing to a close, a number of hunters are looking southward and many plan to put in a Christmas week vacation in the Carolinas which offer varied sport for both big game and upland birds.
Columbia won its fourth consecutive basketball game at University Hall last night, stopping Pratt Institute, 68 -- 51, despite some stubborn resistance by the visitors in the second half.
Football coaches and players are pretty much 'satisfied with the rules as they are, Lou Little said yesterday after studying approximately 1,000 letters and cards.

Muriel Smith, young contralto of many attainments, including star parts in "Carmen Jones" and "Our Lan' ", gave a Town Hall recital, yesterday afternoon. Greeted by prolonged applause as she stepped on the stage, she charmed the audience with her personable appearance and voice of quality.

A three-man mediation panel was named yesterday by the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service to handle the pre-Christmas strike threatened against Western Union by three AFL communications unions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- A country-wide program, both longrange and emergency, to raise the standards of the teaching profession was started by the National Education Association here today in the first of a series of regional conferences.

Agreement has been reached on the basic provisions to be included in a uniform order blank for purchase of women's and children's apparel, it was announced yesterday in a joint statement by the vendor relations committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and an inter-association committee of twelve apparel trade groups.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Key House Republicans were reported near agreement tonight on a bill for a $5,250,000,000 reduction in personal income taxes to be introduced probably next week for Congressional action in January.

As the last of the baseball clans that had gathered here for the annual major league conclaves evacuated the city yesterday, they seemed to leave New York's three entries harboring a mingled assortment of feelings. None of the three had been able to close the number of deals it had hoped to make, but only one was greatly perturbed about it.

A one-volume version of Ralph Barton Perry's study of William James will be issued by Harvard University Press under the title "The Briefer Version of the Thought and Character of William James." The book, originally published as a 1,600-page, two-volume addition, received the Pulitzer Prize in Biography in 1935.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Photographs showing a tiny virus invading and actually killing a living cell were presented today to the Electron Microscope Society of America.
A citizen of Argentina studying in this country sent $5 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday with the explanation that, "I believe that charity should be international."

Nine hundred members of Acuors' Equity turned out for the association's second quarterly meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor. The session was said to have been devoid of the usual fireworks provided by heated discussions from the floor.

Glazed and fragrant comes Spiced Meat and Glazed Yams to table on today's Peace Plate. Home economists are looking out for appetizing flavor-as well as economy and convenience-in combining apple juice, luncheon meat and yams or sweet potatoes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The Department of Justice was asked today by the House Labor Committee to determine "whether or not the monopolistic practices of James Caesar Petrillo and the American Federation of Musicians" were subject to prosecution under the anti-trust laws.
A citizen of Argentina studying in this country sent $5 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday with the explanation that, "I believe that charity should be international."

Nine hundred members of Acuors' Equity turned out for the association's second quarterly meeting yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Astor. The session was said to have been devoid of the usual fireworks provided by heated discussions from the floor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- After thirty years of agitation San Francisco is hoping to have a foreign trade zone on its waterfront. Its application for such a zone has been approved by the Foreign Trade Zone Board in Washington and final approval by the Secretaries of Commerce, Treasury and Army is expected.

National League hitters went all out in 1947 in the business of breaking records and performing feats for the first time in the history of the old loop, it is revealed in the compilation of statistics just released.
Boxing receipts for Madison Square Garden this year will aggregate in the neighborhood of 52,000,000, an altogether satisfactory return in the light of existing circumstances.

The proposed granting of income tax credits for accelerating amortization of mortgages has won the support of Lee Thompson Smith, president of the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York, who views the plan as a means of encouraging builders to invest in new rental housing.

Speakers at the first day's session of the Catholic Film and Radio Forum objected yesterday to announced plans of the large motion picture companies in Hollywood to produce educational and religious films.

IT isn't every Christmas that a real Christmas picture comes along, full of snow and bells and Christmas music and sentiments of good-will toward men. Last year we had a lawful entry in "It's a Wonderful Life," but the nearest thing before that was "A Christmas Carol" in 1938.

The black or "gray" market in basic and finished steel, disclaimed and minimized by the producers and fabricators of the vital industrial commodity, is no small enterprise. It is a gigantic business whose center is situated in New York City and which controls millions of tons of steel in various forms throughout the nation.

FREDERIC REMINGTON -- like his friends Theodore Roosevelt and Richard Harding Davis -- seems to sum up and explain an era. If such men had not existed it would have been necessary to invent them. They worshiped energy, both physical and mental.

The franchise of the Chicago Rockets, one of the weak links in the All-America Football Conference, reverted to the league yesterday, on the eve of the championship play-off. Further developments, probably a new ownership, are expected, and until then the conference will hold the franchise and all player contracts.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- A galaxy of French and American notables will go to Le Havre Wednesday to welcome the American Leader, rechristened the Friend Ship. The vessel is bringing to France, at the start of winter's hardships, the first load of foodstuffs spontanerously piled by the people of the United States on the Friendship Train to relieve the suffering in France.

"CHRISTMAS EVE, just that one evening that with the mind of a child I saw in all its festive glory, when it seemed that I must see the Christmas tree, rejoice in the joy of children and see their elders become children once more.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Deliveries of raw materials, parts and finished goods to industry have improved to a point where they might be considered normal for most commodities, P.C. Patch, head of a survey committee for the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago, declared today.

MANY of our voters were too young in 1929 to have had any intelligent idea of what happened then; and many older voters either never knew or have forgotten why it happened. But since there are some startling similarities between the situation now and that of twenty years ago, perhaps an examination of the 1929 disaster may help us to avoid a repetition of it.

HOLLYWOOD. IT'S all right for Samuel Goldwyn, with several million steelengraved Lincoln portraits and many outstanding pictures behind him, to stand up and say that Hollywood ought to make more distinctive pictures.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- SenateHouse conferees agreed today on a compromise foreign aid bill authorizing $597,000,000 of winter relief to France, Italy, Austria and China.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 13 (AP) -- In three major moves, the Missouri Valley Conference today voted to strengthen its eligibility rules and at the same time end all "racial discrimination" at its member schools.

ZLIN, Czechoslovakia. HIS name is Pan Prokouk, which is Czech for Mr. Snooper. He is a middleaged, goofy-looking little chap with a bald head, round goggling eyes peering down a turnip nose with a reddish tinge at the end, and a bristlebrush mustache.

The Administrative Council of the city colleges has asked the Board of Higher Education to establish a five-year teacher-training program in the four schools, it was learned yesterday. The council is composed of the presidents of the colleges, including Dr. Harry N. Wright of City College, Dr. George Shuster of Hunter, Dr. Harry D. Gideoiise of Brooklyn and Acting President Margaret V. Kiely of Queens.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Truman announced tonight that the United States would consider "appropriate" measures if the independence of Italy was threatened "directly or indirectly."

(Well-Known Actress and Teacher at the American Theatre Wing) AT the request of some veterans who had been impressed by the acting of the Old Vie company and John Gielgud's troupe last spring, the American Theatre Wing instigated a new course at its school of the theatre this fall, one which the Wing chose to call "a class in classic acting."

ROME, Dec. 13 -- Less than twenty-four hours after the Rome general strike had been called off, Premier Alcide de Gasperi won his most brilliant victory in the Constituent Assembly this afternoon. An anti-Government motion was rejected by a vote of 216 to 111, with four abstentions.

For wild-and-woolly, uninhibited basketball, Madison Square Garden never has seen the equal of that produced in last night's double-header as City College's five-game winning streak was snapped by Bowling Green, 72 -- 68, and Georgetown conquered St. John's, 61 -- 58, in overtime.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- Military government officials in charge of education disclosed this week the launching of a publication program that would provide during the first quarter of the new year elmost as many textbooks as had been published in the United States zone in the two and a half years of occupation.

TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- The Soviet Government is now stepping up its previously somewhat sporadic campaign to indoctrinate hundreds of thousands of Japanese war prisoners still remaining in Russia with the principles of Marxism, according to stories told by the most recent repatriates to both official and unofficial investigators here.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Blizzards of arctic intensity are being manufactured by engineers in the climatic test chambers of the Signal Corps Engineering Laboratories here, it was announced today. This development of actual snow in a sufficient quantity to test military equipment under simulated arctic climatic conditions is believed to be the first accomplishment of its kind.

Jack Kramer, the national champion from Los Angeles and mainstay of America's victorious Davis Cup squad, who recently turned professional, again has been placed at the head of the list of the United States Lawn Tennis Association's rankings, it was announced yesterday.

TWENTY-FOUR carloads of Christmas trees rolled into the New Haver. Railroad's Mott Haven Yards nine days ago, the vanguard of an estimated five hundred cars that will be coming into the city within the next week.

A REVOLUTIONARY change in the pattern of winter transatlantic travel has followed the rapid expansion of air service to Europe, Charles L. Gallo, director of international traffic for Trans World Airlines, reports after a tour of twelve countries served by TWA.

In an expansion move that is due eventually to change shopping facilities in the Plaza district; Bergdorf Goodman has extended its realty holdings to include the west blockfront on Fifth Avenue between Fifty-seventh and Fiftyeighth Streets, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Mexico, in a new effort to cope with a dollar shortage, has ordered a tariff revision on imports largely raising rates on shipments from the United States to 1942 levels, the State Department said today.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Chaffey Junior College of California unleashed a brilliant passing game in the last half today and trounced the favored Cameron College Aggies of Oklahoma, 39 to 26, before an estimated 55,000 fans in the second annual Little Rose Bowl game.
"THE French -- they are a funny race." Or so the song says. In this country that statement has usually been interpreted to mean that the French are funny-peculiar rather than funny-ha-ha.

The New York State soldier bonus will be payable after Jan. 1 but application blanks will not be distributed until Dec. 31, the Veterans Bonus Bureau announced yesterday. Blanks are being held up because applications executed before the bonus law is operative will not be valid and by deferring distribution the bureau can avoid receiving illegal applications with the consequent confusion.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 13 -- Over all the Jewish rejoicing at the impending fulfillment of their dream of a national state hangs the sword of repeated Arab threats to thwart the establishment of that state or destroy it in infancy.

TO THE EDITOR: In your article, "Sensitive and Angry Man," it is stated that Sigmund Freud refused to leave Vienna for more than a year after the Anschluss. It may be corrected by the fact that Freud realized the necessity to emigrate even before the annexation of Austria, when he was warned of forthcoming events by British and American friends.

The National Maritime Union is planning for the regular January session of Congress a campaign against further disposal of American ship tonnage to foreign interests, Joseph Curran, president, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- A daring gunman raided the Interstate Express of the New York Central tonight as it was running from Englewood station, a secondary stop in Chicago, to the La Salle Street terminal, and escaped with $500 in cash, as well as jewelry and furs.

ABILENE, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Missouri Valley College's Vikings came from behind twice today to hand McMurry College a 20-13 licking in the first annual Boys Ranch Bowl game. The victory ran the Marshall, Mo., eleven's winning streak to thirty-two straight games.

ATHENS, Dec. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Yannis Tsamakos, a reserve officer who took part with the Eam-Elas forces in the civil strife of December. 1944, appealed today to the Government to be allowed back into, the army with other former insurgents to fight the present gruarrillas.

"SHY flocks of small bananagreen parrots," Mr. Bates begins, "had begun to come back to the pipal trees about the bombed pagoda. But across the rice fields, scorched and barren now from the long dry season, only a few white egrets stepped daintily like ghostly cranes about the yellow dust in the heat haze.
To the Drama Editor: THE cynicism which marked Cheryl Crawford's article last week justifying the policies of the Experimental Theatre shocked at least one reader. * * *

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Declaring that a cold war, like a hot one, could not be won with a good defense and nothing else, Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota urged today that this country try to regain the initiative in the United Nations and also stop being "apologetic about our free, capitalist economy -- the best yet devised."

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal to establish an 8-cent fare on the municipal transit lines to lift from the city's expense budget the heavy load of their operating deficits will be the focal point of a free-swinging political fight in the 1948 Legislature. The battle lines are being formed, with the Mayor, the Board of Estimate and the Democratic legislative delegation on one side, and Governor Dewey and the Republican majority at Albany on the other.

In 1901 Columbia University had just moved from Madison Avenue at Fortieth Street to Morningside Heights. It was short of funds; it operated in temporary buildings, lacked even a dormitory. The university had 4,440 students, 459 teachers, a budget of $1,039,797.

CARTOON fanciers familiar with the work of Abner Dean, and readers of his earlier book, "It's a Long Way to Heaven," will know a little what to expect in "What Am I Doing Here?" In eighty-eight deft drawings, Mr. Dean runs a hopeful and hapless specimen of contemporary man through a gamut of minor frustrations, nightmares, bafflements and wishthinking.

LONDON. Scrapbook technique is creeping more and more into the British Broadcasting Corporation programs. The original Scrapbook idea was to string together a series of incidents, illustrated by music, or where possible by voices of famous personalities, to give a sound picture of a given year.
Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, finished yesterday his organizational plan for the complete review of the 180,000 cases on home relief required by order of the State Board of Social Welfare.

THE talented Otto Graham of the Cleveland Browns plays the piano, violin, French horn, cornet and football. He plays them all remarkably well. The deft T-formation quarterback has music in his soul and rhythm in his body. Nor is the connection between music and football especially far-fetched since proficiency in each bespeaks an innate sense of cadence, coordination and timing.

THOSE widely circulated reports last summer that had Charlie Chaplin packing his bags to leave these shores forever have been borne out somewhat by Mr. Chaplin himself in I an article titled, "I Have Had Enough of Hollywood," published in London on Dec. 7 by Reynolds News.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Soviet Sports, a Russian publication, today accused the United States of exercising the power of "veto" in international sports.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- The occupation of Germany by the Big Four is costing the Germans during this fiscal year approximately 8,000,000,000 reichsmarks, or a little more than one-quarter of the entire public income from taxes, according to estimates by German economists.

WASHINGTON. A VISITOR to Air Force Headquarters in the Pentagon finds himself faced continually with copies of a particular map. It is a projection of the world and it is tacked on the walls of almost every office.

JUST seventeen years ago this week in this Review: "Andree's Story. The Complete Records of His Polar Flight," was reviewed on page one by Walter B. Hayward, who wrote that the adventure was "a tragic tale, but one of courage and fortitude."

AS a compassionate individual who observed the pitiful and harmful effects of stammering on a member of his family -- and as a professional teacher who points to the amazing statistic of a United States with more than 1,000,000 stammerers, 350,000 of whom are children -- Charles Pellman has a justifiable axe to grind.

ABERDEEN, Md., Dec. 13 -- The fastest automatic computer or "mathematical brain" in use works only a two-hour week, mathematicians on the staff of the ballistic research laboratories at Aberdeen Proving Ground reported today.

The United Negro College Fund, c., of 38 East Fifty-seventh Street, announced yesterday as the 1947 drive drew to a close that ty-seven communities had raised 1,018,000. The amount was close enough to the goal set to call the campaign a "success," executives the fund said.

BALLET THEATRE, which was to have closed tonight at the City Center, has extended its engagement until Wednesday. A last-night novelty Win be Ruth Ann Koesun's first appearance as the youngest sister in "Pillar of Fire."

TORONTO, Dec. 13 -- Backed by Sugar Jim Henry's superlative goal tending, the New York Rangers came from behind tonight and scored three goals in the last period to gain a 4-1 National Hockey League victory over firstplace Toronto at Maple Leaf Gardens before 13,454 fans.

BERLIN, Dec. 13 -- Whether the Russians will be able to revive the one-party system in their zone of occupation in Germany may be determined next week. If they do so and the Western Allies do nothing to prevent it, it will mean that they have brought Eastern Germany into the company of Soviet satellites, at least politically.

The historic performance, by Mr. Toscanini, the NBC Symphony Orchestra and assisting soloists, of Verdi's "Otello," of which the last two acts were performed and broadcast from Studio 8-H in Radio City, came to an end yesterday afternoon.
The marriage of a 15-year-old boy on probation to the Children's Court for juvenile delinquency does not change his status and thus remove him from that jurisdiction, it was ruled yesterday.

TELEVISION kept up its forward pace last week, unveiling a spirited and intelligent quiz show which made the unseen "Information Please" of radio seem sadly outdated. The piece, going by the title of "Americana Quiz," has John Mason Brown, the wry and ebullient official of the Drama Critics Circle, in the moderator's chair.

THE 1947 performance record of the 202 persons who accepted Bert Parks' challenge to "Break the Bank," has been treated to statistical attention. The more or less significant point is that the men walked off with more cash booty than the women, while couples outdrew either sex at the pay-off window. The average for each group is put at $374.74 for couples, $299.41 for men and $107.55 for women.

High costs of building and fear that rent control will be renewed are factors in delaying the erection of new rental housing throughout the country, according to the National Association of Real Estate Boards, which yesterday reported the results of its semi-annual survey of the realty market.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 13 -- The Manhattan basketball team held Dartmouth scoreless for the last six minutes tonight, scoring 6 points in the interim to notch its sixth consecutive triumph, 57 -- 53.

TODAY legislators are speculating to a greater extent than ever before in recent history on the possibility of easing taxpayers' burdens and meeting budgetary deficits by Governmentsponsored lotteries.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The British people's effort in the economic crisis "is now taking them around the recovery corner," Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council and Prime Minister Attlee's deputy, said in a broadcast tonight.

Adolf Busch and Rudolf Serkin appeared in the second of two subscription chamber music concerts at Town Hall yesterday afternoon. Only this time, instead of playing with the other three members of the Busch Quartet as they did last week, they appeared as a sonata team.

GENEVA, Dec. 13 -- The United Nations Commission on Human Rights will complete in its current session a declaration of rights and a convention of human rights, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, chairman of the group, predicted today.

For many sportsmen the closing of the waterfowl season will mean the end of shooting but those who do not want to put their guns away may find plenty of sport during the months to come hunting crows and foxes.

Gasoline sales to transient motorists were limited to a ration of five gallons yesterday at scattered service stations in various parts of the metropolitan area as dealers found their supplies getting low.

Despite clearcut signs that further increases will mean a reduction of volume, the price trend of textiles and apparel continues upward, it was pointed out in the trade last week. All appeals for a halt in price rises are given little heed, a summary of developments revealed.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 13 -- More than 1,500,000 Venezuelans will go to the polls tomorrow to elect their first constitutional president since the revolution of October, 1945, which overthrew the Medina regime and replaced it with a "de facto" government headed by Romulo Betancourt.

It will be the Eagles against the Packers at Philadelphia and the Bears against the Cardinals at Chicago today in the key game as the National Football League's twenty-eighth season reaches the end of its regular schedule. The races in both divisions, still undecided, hinge on the results of these contests.

Rumania's government-controlled radio, in a broadcast beamed to its home listeners, asserted Friday that "many" Rumanian children were taken ill after eating "adulterated Yankee maize" imported from the United States.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. I3 -- Early disclosure of full details of the Marshall plan was urged today by Gov. Earl Warren of California, who said that up to now the program for aid to western Europe "could be called a principle instead of a plan."

Plans of the Long Island College of Medicine for a new $16,000,000 medical center in Brooklyn include a family health maintenance program and a regional health program for the rural parts of Long Island, according to a 100-page book "Bringing Medicine to the People," made public by the college yesterday.

The following appears in a pamphlet of the New York City Committee on Mental Hygiene, "When a Child Uses Bad Language:" "Sometimes you might try playing with the word. For instance, if he says 'lousy', you say 'bowzy, dowzy, rowzy,' until the word loses its original significance.

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 13 -- The names of forty-eight Rhodes scholars selected by the eight district committees in the nation to enter Oxford University next fall for two years of study were announced tonight by Dr. Frank Aydelotte, American secretary to the Rhodes trustees.

THE Turner Construction Company, one of the leading scene builders for the Broadway theatre, is on the block. The way this department hears it, a deal almost was consummated the other day whereby a group sought control of the plant with the idea of developing it into a unit capable of contributing more to a production than just set building.

LODI, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Led by their Little All-America quarterback, Eddie Le Baron, the College of Pacific Tigers defeated the Utah State Aggies, 35 to 21, today in Lodi's first annual Grape Bowl football game.

RAILROAD men and bankers who hailed the establishment Sept. 1 of the travel loan plan permitting deferred payment for vacations as a great boon to vacationists are now frankly puzzled by the apparent lack of interest shown to date by holidayers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 13 -- Five months after its signature, the United States aid program of Turkey is progressing slowly but smoothly. The biggest result to date is the establishment of what is described here by both sides as the "perfect understanding between the various Turkish and American military and civilian teams assigned to its implementation.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 13 -- Tennessee's political pot was boiling furiously today as the result of two rapid-fire announcements this week which appear at this stage to have presented Edward H. Crump, famed Memphis political boss, with a major test for control of the state.

IF anyone gets more fun out of the art world than Alexander Calder he has yet to be called to our attention. Do not be frightened away from his current show at the Buchholz Gallery by the news that Jean-Paul Sartre of existentialist fame has written the introduction to the catalogue.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 13 -- Admiral William F. Halsey, chairman of the University of Virginia Development Fund, announced today that Edward R. Stettinius Jr., rector of the university, had made a gift to the university of cash and securities independently valued in excess of $100,000.
Riding hard throughout and making their drives count, the Squadron A Regulars defeated the New York Athletic Club polo trio last night, 9 to 8, in the Squadron A Armory.

The annual opera benefit under the auspices ot the Free Milk Fund for Babies, Inc., will take place Tuesday night at the performance of "Lucia di Lammermoor" at the Metropolitan Opera House. The benefit is under the sponsorship of many members of society.

The Pennsylvania Community Property Law had a short life; its effective date was Sept. 1, 1947, and on Nov. 26, by a unanimous opinion of the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, Western District, the act was held unconstitutional and "wholly invalid."

ON display in the galleries of the American Academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters is a plastic history of the world during the last forty years. There in bronze, marble, terra cotta and plaster are men and women who have shaped the destinies of almost every land, all the work of one artist who has turned out not plastic effigies but psychological biographies in tangible form.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A new knife that whirls at 800, miles an hour could slice an invisible ham sandwich just fourmillionths of an inch thick.

In a sale of precious-stone jewelry tomorrow and Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, several centuryold objects will be offered.
