They include a gold snuff box, Circa 1825, enameled with Mediterranean landscapes and enorusted with diamonds and rubies, and a musical box of tortoise shell, enameled and mounted in gold and fitted with a diorama containing a magician.

THE period 1917-1941, which is covered in its economic aspects in these two books, is "our times" to those who are now middle-aged. The complicated story of those years, so well told by Messrs. Soule and Mitchell, is here presented in terms of economics, statistics, institutional developments in both private and governmental fields, and public and private economic policies.

THE successful completion last week of the round-the-world flight of George W. Truman and Clifford V. Evans Jr. in 100-horsepower Piper Cubs left few, if any, worlds for the sturdy little plane to conquer. As one onlooker put it: "Until it gets a jet engine, there's nothing new for it to do."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, asked Secretary of State Marshall today for his views on a proposal to subsidize the sending of American newspapers and magazines abroad by air to spread "the truth about America."

OSCAR BERGER has assembled forty "human frailties" -- running alphabetically from "ambition" to "zeal" -- which he has illustrated graphically with line drawings and verbally with more than 600 apposite quotations.

INDISPUTABLE facts about Shakespeare's life remain skeletal, though some have turned up in the last twenty years, and Sir Edmund Chambers sifted elaborately the truth in the legends spawned after Shakespeare's death.

A model home has been opened in the first section of seventy-five houses under construction by Paisley Homes in Raritan Township, near New Brunswick, N.J., where eventually there will be 300 units on a tract of sixty acres. The new dwellings are rising on ten acres of land fronting on Plainfield Avenue, between Routes 25 and 27.

With an eye on the foreign situation, the financial community last week followed closely the threeway race in Washington to halt inflation. Monetary ideas on how to control it through the Federal Reserve System, the Administration's plan and the Republican program all will undoubtedly undergo many changes before a final agreement is reached.
TOKYO, Dec. 13 -- Premier Tetsu Katayama has turned down the bid of the Left Wing of his own Socialist party to obtain representation in the Cabinet.

DR. KATHARINE WHITESIDE TAYLOR says that "the first rules of wholesome child guidance are to know what to expect at successive stages and of your own child as an individual." Children will give us the clues if we let them.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 -- Great Lakes vessels set new peacetime records for the shipment of iron ore and bituminous coal this season and also transported huge quantities of grain, iron and steel, scrap iron, pulpwood, oil and gasoline, stone, sand, and lumber.

ALBANY, Dec. 13 -- Governor Dewey announced today that unless Congress and President Truman acted in 1948 to permit married couples in New York and other non-community-property states to divide their income for Federal income-tax purposes the state would be "forced to modify its laws to protect its citizens as best it can from the present discriminatory situation."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 13 -- Navy opened its basketball season today with a 67-32 victory over Johns Hopkins of Baltimore before a crowd of 3,000.

ONE of the many hackneyed bridge maxims is to plan the play of the entire hand before playing from dummy to the opening lead. This is not always possible and not always necessary, but occasionally there arises a striking case in which it pays to follow the rule.

The Pennsylvania Society Gold Medal for Distinguished Achievement was presented to Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower last night at the forty-ninth annual dinner of the society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Senator Edward Martin of Pennsylvania made the presentation.

LONDON, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Britain's soccer spotlight turned today to the Footfball Association Cup with lower-category clubs fighting for the right to enter the third round with the first and second division squads, exempt from competition to that point.

Retail trade should continue on a consistently high level through the spring of 1948, according to a survey of retailers' views just completed by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., one of the largest resident buying firms in the local market. The survey, which covered 200 merchants from coast to coast, showed department stores in general expect to beat 1947 figures in the first quarter, while specialty stores are not quite as optimistic.

IN the past few weeks students have been at work among the newly opened papers of Abraham Lincoln in the Library of Congress. What they have found is a rich collection, with fresh material that is highly valuable from the historian's point of view. For these voluminous documents throw new light upon Lincoln and his associates and add greater depth to the picture of the man and the problems that beset him.

THE sixth annual exhibition of the Audubon Artists in the galleries of the National Academy gives the visitor reason to believe that thin yearly event has gone a long way toward replacing the old Independent annuals.

The only comparable undertaking in recent times was the construction of the $1,000,000 Baker Library in 1928.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (AP) -- A Tass dispatch from London said today that sessions of the Foreign Ministers have shown that the Americans had decided beforehand to divide Germany.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: High on the agenda of the Congress at its next regular session is an organic act for the government of the Trust Territory of the Pacific, the former Japanese mandated islands which were recently entrusted to this country by the United Nations.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Auchincloss, Mr. and Mrs. John W. Hanes and Mr. and Mrs. G. Herbert Semler gave a supper dance last night in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis for three debutantes, the Misses Rosamond Saltonstall Lee, granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Auchincloss; Ormsby M. Hanes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hanes, and Gay Parker Semler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Semler.

LONDON. AT our municipal elections early last month something happened for which we have been waiting for many months. Ordinary men and women in Britain at last showed that they were not content to sit around and watch the twilight of freedom deepen into a totalitarian night.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 13 -- Rumanian authorities have prohibited exhibitions of forty new and old American motion pictures. They had been under review by the Censorship Bureau.

In the two weeks since the United Nations General Assembly voted to partition Palestine into separate Arab and Jewish States, about 215 persons have been Killed in rioting and fighting in the Holy Land. The fighting is a foretaste -- on a small, disorganized and sporadic scale -- of what might happen when the actual partition goes into effect.
To offset the recent increase of 50 cents a barrel in the price of crude oil, refiners have marked up the prices of gasoline and other petroleum products east of the Rocky Mountains.

THE picture of untutored and primitive man pitted tragically against sophisticated woman is frequent enough on every level of writing. In "Sligo," where approach and technique are pedestrian, this eternal situation is once again aired and polished off.

The 450 members of the crew of the liner Washington, which is soon to re-enter private service under charter to the United States Lines, will get intensive refresher training prior to joining the vessel.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The text of a Senate Republican Policy Committee statement, approved by the Republican conference, on a cost of living program follows: We are deeply concerned over the steadily rising prices. Already these prices impose great hardship and suffering on many families.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Maj. Gen. John H. Hilldring, U.S.A. retired, former Assistant Secretary of State and a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations, predicted tonight a quick end to the violence to Palestine.

THE American quarterly, Foreign Affairs, is now 25 years old. To celebrate this anniversary, the editor, Hamilton Fish Armstrong, has selected from it a group of twenty-nine articles for publication in book form. The resulting Foreign Affairs Reader provides an illuminating review of the inter-war period and a useful background for an understanding of the contemporary crisis.

The Railroad Federal Savings Association has $20,000,000 to lend on 100 per cent GI home loans, which meet the association's requirements as to soundness, it was announced by George L. Bliss, president of the association.

United States troops were scheduled to complete their withdrawal from Italy today, but from 600,000 to 700,000 Americans in the uniforms of the armed forces were still "on guard" in many areas throughout the world.

WHERE lesser novelists contrive to get their messages across in trilogies or tetralogies, Neil H. Swanson is currently embarked on a series of no fewer than thirty related novels. If his lifetime fountain pen holds out, Mr. Swanson will ultimately have produced "one continuous narrative of the advance of the American frontier from the Atlantic to the Mississippi."

DETROIT, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The automobile industry continued to roll out passenger cars and trucks at top post-war levels this week and has scheduled assemblies for the remainder of the year that will bring the 1947 total to only a few units under 4,800,000.

Miss Evelyn West Hughan of 27 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, retired head of the foreign department of Ginn Co., textbook publishers, and for many years active in the Socialist party and pacifist movement, died Friday in the Wood Nursing Home, Brooklyn, at the age of 76.

LOS ANGELES. IT'S too bad that Rip Van Winkle belongs to the Catskills and that there's no West Coast Irving to tell the tale of an old prospector stumbling down from the San Bernardinos to rub his eyes at the glossy mirage called Palm Springs. It was a ghost town in 1908 with the bones of its buildings bleaching in the desert sun and tumbleweeds rolling like vagrant headstones along the cemeteries of its streets.

THIS novel is written in a rich and creamy style, altogether suited to its narrative of a sensitive boy's growth to maturity. It is sprinkled with apt figures of speech. "His name sounded smooth and thin like a peeled stick."

First snow should be a damp, clinging snow dropped from the skies with little wind; and it should come in the night. Then we waken to a world properly dressed for winter, with the white accents everywhere but without a muffling blanket of white. That should come later.

A society columnist called Knickerbocker, or Raisinseed, or some such name, came out last week with a list of the ten worstdressed men in America. On seeing it, the tailors of the country rose to their feet as one and commissioned your correspondent to draw up a list of the ten bestdressed men in America as an antidote to Knickerbocker's list.

To the Music Editor: MORTON ESTRIN'S letter of Nov. 16 and Adrienne Anderson's of Dec. 7 have encouraged me to write on behalf of voice teaching. There is great urgency to expose the quackery practiced in that branch of the music profession.

GOOD prose is hard to write. Clarity and richness do not easily mingle. Our best modern styles preserve the first quality at the expense of the second, so that a writer who strives for complex effects sounds ancient or esoteric.

WHEN the history of music in the twentieth century comes to be written, an institution that will have an honorable and important place is the American college. Not only has it taught music on an increasingly wide scale, but it has fostered composition by sponsoring festivals and giving shelter and sustenance to European and native composers.
For those who have not yet completed their gift shopping, the Hundred Neediest Cases offer big bargains in genuine Christmas values.

KEEP this out of the hands of children. For adults only -- and just those hardy enough to court the chaos of escorting a child to the theatre -- the following is a report on the Christmas season's theatricals for tots.
TYLER, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Compton (Calif.) Junior College staved off a last-quarter rally by Tyler (Tex.) Junior College today to win the first annual Texas Rose Bowl game, 20 -- 19.

Henry L. Stoddard, former editor and controlling stockholder of The Evening Mail, died yesterday afternoon in Misericordia Hospital, to which he was removed Friday night after suffering a heart attack in his home, The Murray, at 66 Park Avenue. His age was 86.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The faculty committee of the Southwest Conference today established a rigid standard of aid to athletes.

GEORGE BALANCHINE'S new ballet, "Theme and Variations," is the first work by this gifted choreographer which has compelled the present reviewer to sit back and enjoy it with whole-hearted delight. "Sit back" is perhaps an inaccurate phrase to describe one's response to so brilliant, stimulating and beautiful a ballet, but it implies at least that easy pleasure which attends a work toward which one feels no reservations, no strains, no subcutaneous antagonisms.

LAST week was the most crowded of the art season thus far with between forty and fifty exhibitions opening. They included the annual of the Audubon Artists at the Academy, which seems destined numerically to be quite the biggest show of the season.

SINCE there are always people who want to know how to get into this business (of writing for a living), consider the route taken by John Durant, whose excellent baseball book is noted over on P. 22. Well, there was Mr. Durant, down in Wall Street a few years back and with no more idea of writing a baseball book than, say, Mr. Vishinsky has evidenced.

The British Government was criticized for its attitude toward Palestinian Jews in sermons by rabbis here yesterday in Hanukkah, the Jewish Feast of Lights, commemorating the religious revolt of the Maccabees in 165 B.C., which led to a period of freedom for Judea.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 13 -- Kansas' largest city has put its housing problem on the operating table. The X-ray report was brought in last week with the publication of an analysis based on what is believed to be one of the most comprehensive housing surveys made in this country since the end of the war.

"A GOOD potograph of an interesting subject of the times in which the photographer lives" is the description of modern photography offered by Samuel Grierson in an address last week at the Manhattan Camera Club.

Stocks extended their gains in the short session yesterday and final prices were at the best levels of the week as the rail shares joined the industrial group in the upward movement. Gains on the Stock Exchange ranged from fractions to 2 points generally.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The need, in the next three months, for more dollar-financed imports and for a drastic increase in state revenues to fill the inflationary gap will be emphasized in a report of France's balance sheet commission to be published Monday.

THIS first novel is a rather wistful footnote on the books of Fitzgerald, O'Hara and one or two other writers. Mr. Smith is not yet much of a craftsman, but he puts down what he knows modestly and without any fuss.

HOLLYWOOD. IT has become almost traditional in this country to associate the professional theatre with the Broadway show-shops. In fact, when one declares that he is "from the theatre" the derivative reference is exclusively to New York.

A solemn mass of requiem for Gen. Jacques-Philippe Leclerc, Inspector General of the French armed forces in North Africa, was celebrated yesterday morning by the Rev. Etienne Galtier in St. Vincent de Paul's Roman Catholic Church, West Twenty-third Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues.
For dramatic beauty of both foliage and flowers, few winter house plants can compete with the regal calla lily. Best known is the classic white, but other kinds and colors are equally beautiful.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- A very Brundage, chairman of the United
Excerpts from a recent address by Dr. Gregg, Director of Medical Research, the Rockefeller Foundation, before the National Committee for Mental Hygiene.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers scheduled for today was postponed. The Ministers will not meet again until Monday.

THE title of Mr. Norman's novel of contemporary China is derived from those foreigners, the "Hai Shang shuo-mang jen," who, having lived in pre-war China, have returned and found themselves unable to adjust to the new post-war country.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Baron Rayleigh, eminent scientist who since the late Twenties has occupied the highest positions in most of the British scientific societies, died today at his home near Witham, Essex, after a heart attack. His age was 72.

TWO surprise stamps from Spain add to philately's gallery the portraits of Manual de Falla, composer who belonged to the contemporary national Spanish school, and Ignacio Zuloaga y Zabaleta, who was one of the foremost Spanish painters.

EDGEWATER PARK, Miss., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Southeastern Conference delegates, in an unprecedented action, recessed their annual meeting for an indefinite time today, but not until after an unscheduled session, centering on a regulation which limits athletic scholarships to seventy-five.

HAD this book been written in 1910 (which is about when its rambling action mercifully closes) some of its nebulous philosophies would have been understandable. Its oriflamme of "one big- union" could have been a banner to be followed by men who remembered the Haymarket riots and the Colorado strikes; men who believed-and not unreasonably -- that the great corporations were created for but one purpose:
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : This letter, which might offer a suggestion helpful to world peace and security, proposes a radio "town meeting" of the world.

Ten men conferred Friday and yesterday around a huge oval table in a committee room on Capitol Hill. They were "managers" -- five from each House of Congress -- named to work out differences between House and Senate versions of the first major legislation of the special Congressional session that convened on Nov. 17 -- legislation for interim foreign aid.

Four long months of bumps and bruises in exhibitions, practice and actual competition, more them 120 days and numerous nights of toil and turmoil; one-third of a year devoted exclusively to football will be rewarded today at the Stadium. For there, in the majestic House That Ruth Built ostensibly for baseball -- the gridiron Goliaths of the All-America Conference, the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Browns, will vie for top honors.

The secondary bank reserve proposal of Marriner S. Eccles, the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, suffered a direct knockout last week. After staggering around the Congressional-hearing arena for some two weeks, and then being virtually disowned by its mentor, the Eccles proposal was effectively laid to rest by the testimony of Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

When the first annual Christmas Seal sale of the National Tuberculosis Association was held fortyone years ago, the death rate for tuberculosis in the United States was 202 to 100,000 of the population. The vast majority of those deaths occurred between the ages of 20 and 45, the most productive and generally useful period of life.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Britain has notified both the Russian and Chinese Governments that she will oppose the use of the veto power in preparing the peace treaty with Japan, it was announced today.

On a wooded, sloping site of sight acres in the Riverdale section of the Bronx overlooking the Hudson River, a new group of four twelve-story apartment buildings is planned to accommodate 600 war veterans and their families on a tenant-ownership basis.
Eighteen deaf-blind employes of the Industrial Home for the Blind visited an American Airlines hangar at La Guardia Field yesterday and had their first contact with airplanes.
IN this holiday season there a much outward joy -- gifts and heartiness and other evidence of good fellowship. These are friendly acts toward neighbors whom we know, done in the Christmas brightness.

BIMINI ISLAND -- The announcement of a tuna-fishing tournament to be held here in January gives further evidence of the growing popularity of this little island among sportsmen. At the gateway to the Bahamas, Bimini, a British possession, is just thirty air-travel minutes from Miami.

The suggestion of Surgeon General Parran that a system of awarding federal scholarships to medical students be established, in order to insure that future government needs for physicians will be met, serves to dramatize the shortage of doctors that is in some areas of the nation already acute.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- An errand of revenge on the part of three small-time hoodlums set off a chain of cold-blooded Killing's late last night and early this morning which in motive and violence recalled the gangland vendettas of the Capone era.

IN explaining the principle on which her has composed this interpretation of the history of the American people, Henry Barmford Parkes, Professor of History at New York University, is refreshingly frank. As long as the writings of Americans are approached, he says, "on the superficial level at the ideas they consciously inculcate, and are judged by their political beliefs," they do not yield up a "common pattern."

SINCE the first Americanmade gasoline-powered automobile chugged down the pike about fifty-five years ago, more than 2,200 different makes of cars have appeared on the market in this country alone. Few have withstood the test of the years, for of the 2,200 manufacturers listed by the Automobile Manufacturers Association, only twenty-one continue today in actual production of passenger cars in the United States.

EVERYONE seems to agree that the Christmas scene this year should have the new look, that is, the new oldfashioned look of feminine fashions. When ladies are wearing short basque waists and long billowing skirts, the traditional Yuletide settings of red and green and holly and mistletoe play the same theme, while sleek concoctions of chartreuse, cerise and synthetic glitter seem oddly out of key.

MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 13 -- Reversing the result of their meeting in the final round of the national championship last season, Ogden Phipps and Alastair Bradley Martin defeated William E. Lingelbach and E.M. (Ted) Edwards of Philadelphia, 6--1, 6--2, today as New York and Boston qualified for the final round of the Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament.

FOR THIS WEEK: Mulch all plants newly set this fall, and erect a windbreak for tender shrubs and evergreens that might be windburned.... Water evergreens in outdoor window boxes once a fortnight, if it does not rain or snow during that period.... Supply moisture to the soil of African violets daily by the use of water at room temperature.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 13 -- The Korean Legislative Assembly today marked its first anniversary. It was created last year by the United States occupation authorities to give the Koreans experience in self-government, but this Legislature has been threatening for the last several weeks to dissolve itself because of the "excessive exercise of the veto" on its acts by the American Military Governor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Plans for the selection of exchange students and teachers were approved today by the President's Board of Foreign Scholarships at a meeting held under the auspices of the State Department.

The Wolf, a bay gelding belonging to Mrs. T.F. Gussenhoven, won the jumper championship of the Brooklyn Winter Horse Show at the Teevan Riding Academy last night. Ridden by Miss Peggy Johnson, the gelding from New Rochelle failed to take first in any of the three events that counted for championship points, but was in the ribbons in all three.

STABLE ISOTOPES -- More than a hundred stable isotopes of twenty-nine different elements have been made available by the Atomic Energy Commission for scientific research, it was announced last week. The stable isotopes do not give off radiations, and can be used in studies for which the radioactive isotopes are not suitable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- E.I. du Pont de Nemours, Inc., of Wilmington, Del., was charged with unlawfully monopolizing the cellophane industry in the United States in an anti-trust suit filed today by Attorney General Tom C. Clark in the United States District Court here.

John L. Lewis, as expected, has stalked out of the A.F. of L. carrying his United Mine Workers with him in his coat pocket. As expected, too, his action was as majestic and dramatic as he could make it, announced in two brief words, "We disaffiliate" scrawled in crayon on a scrap of paper addressed to William Green.

ISLAM today commands the steadfast allegiance of more than 300 million people. Its adherents occupy an all but unbroken belt stretching from westernmost Africa to the East Indies and the interior of China. Within this Islamic belt are found some of the world's most strategic spots:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Marshal Feng Yu-hsiang, former Deputy Generalissimo of China's Nationalist armies, today vigorously opposed any new United States loans to China as long as Chiang Kai-shek remains in power.

A phenomenon in the conduct of Soviet foreign affairs is the insistence of Moscow's spokesmen on making propaganda speeches. At the recent meeting of the United Nations Assembly, Mr. Vishinsky kept it up long after it was apparent he was having no effect at all at Flushing Meadow so far as the other delegates were concerned and no effect at all on American public opinion. Yet he kept it up until he sailed.

The nickels, pennies and dimes that students of Hunter College have contributed in the past toward bouquets for their professors at Christmas have been diverted, since the end of the war, to providing food and clothing for needy persons in foreign lands.
"The family is one of nature's masterpieces."-- George Santayana.

Although the demand for winter coats continued, the markets generally were quiet last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

THE road to a flourishing winter greenhouse is, it seems, usually paved with good intentions and little else. Unless plans were laid well in advance, blooms are now few and far between. The chrysanthemums are gone, leaving the benches bare, and although the fault is ours, we readily excuse ourselves on several counts.
Although the volume of trading on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday was smaller than in previous sessions last week, closing prices were 12 points higher to 5 points lower than the day before.

VALCARTIER, Que., Dec. 13 -- Thomas Dennie of nearby Lac Beauport flashed narrow hickory wings to the dominion's best in winning the first of two races today to determine the cross-country skier who will represent Canada in the winter Olympic games in Switzerland.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The stubbornness of both East and West upon the fundamental problems of Germany's future political and economic structure, plus Mr. Molotov's use of the Council of Foreign Ministers as a forum for propaganda, has plunged that body into a morass of verbiage from which it is unlikely to emerge with any basic agreements.

Paul Loyonnet, French pianist, who gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, imbued his performances with important attributes usually found solely in those of first rate keyboard artists. But in spite of the virtuosic approach, the power, and the control of coloring he brought to his work, results were disappointing.

Bruce MacFadden of the New York A.C. defeated Paul Girdes of Yale by a length in the 100-yard free-style invitational event, feature of the monthly swimming meet at the Winged Foot Club last night. MacFadden, metropolitan 100-yard champion, covered the distance in 0:52.2.

More than 40 per cent of the electrical supply and equipment lines handled by electrical wholesalers remain in critical or scarce supply, and only about 20 per cent of the lines are plentiful, it was revealed here yesterday after a careful check of the latest reports from leading wholesalers.

WASHINGTON. IT is only natural that the imagination of the American people has been captured by the now accepted fact that pellets of dry ice -- solidified carbon dioxide -- can make it rain or snow if they are strewn from an airplane into the proper kind of cloud. Not only does the process offer the possibility of modifying the weather but already it has brought up grave economic and legal questions.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Big Nine faculty representatives today deferred action on the questioned eligibility of the star Halfback Chalmers (Bump) Elliott of Michigan for the 1948 football season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Senate Republican Conference approved today a statement specifying increased production and curtailment of unnecessary spending as the best methods for curbing inflation.

The Carpet Institute, Inc., representing virtually all soft surface floor covering manufacturers, will begin an intensive retail sales training program in the first quarter of 1948, Merrill A. Watson, president, disclosed in an interview last week.

LONDON. BRITISH video is bringing the great and stirring story of Hamlet, the Prince of Denmark, into thousands of homes in one of the most ambitious presentations yet televised. The hopes of George Moore O'Farrell, the producer, and his company were well realized in Part I of the tragedy which was sent out last Sunday and Monday nights.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 300 head; total, 7,300 (estimated). Compared with week ago, barrows and gilts 50 cents to mostly 75 cents lower: sows $1 to $1.25 lower.

CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Only minor price changes were recorded today in prices of grains on the Board of Trade. Opening quotations on wheat and corn were lower than yesterday's final figures, and prices slipped a few cents during early dealings.

SINCE autobiography is the writer's life as he himself sees it, Zola's definition also applies that "art is a bit of nature seen through a temperament." Whether the result becomes a chronicle of external excitements or an itinerary of intimacies depends on how the particular life and its narrator meet up on paper.
LIMESTONE, Me., Dec. 13 -- Construction of the nation's huge air base here is moving along rapidly as Army Engineers and contractural workers by the hundreds dig in for their first winter.

A PENCIL of light swinging close above a sheet of bromide paper on a doublejointed pendulum creates unpredictable and unrepeatable "wobble" patterns. In this new picture idea, introduced by Arthur Palme of Pittsfield, Mass., the light is furnished by an electric bulb attached to the bottom of the pendulum and completely shaded with a metal cone.
Awards to an outstanding player and a coach were features of the first day's meeting of the U.S. Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

EUROPEAN stop-gap aid has been voted and now Congress must start wrestling in earnest with the antiinflation problem. The Administration finally submitted its draft of a bill last week and the Republican leadership introduced its own legislation in the House.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Creation of a central office for the Big Six Conference, officially the Missouri Valley Intercollegiate Athletic Association, to be headed by Reaves peters of Kansas City, was announced today by Sam B. Shirky, secretary of the faculty representatives.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The severe tension that has existed for the past several days between the French and Soviet Governments remained unabated today, with each side making protests against the other over the issue of the expulsion of Soviet citizens.

A combination garden apartment colony for 400 families and a streamlined shopping center eventually to contain fourteen large stores is under construction on a thirty-acre site at the intersection of Route 4, Main Street and Bogert Road in the River Edge district of North Hackensack, N.J.

High school students admitted the influence of the movies on their behavior but said that bad effects be offset by proper cultural influences, in a discussion of this topic yesterday at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

Virginia O'Hanlon, the puzzled little girl whose question in 1897, "Is there a Santa Claus?" was answered in a now famous editorial, told yesterday how she in turn was trying to teach the answer to that question to her 670 pupils.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 13 -- Texasborn Jimmy Demaret, his golf matching the smoothness of his dress, widened his lead in the $10,000 Miami golf tournament today when he fired a 66 for a 12under-par total of 198 for 54 holes. He had led by two strokes after the second round yesterday.

By common consent, the finest new play on the boards just now is Tennessee Williams' "A Streetcar Named Desire." As a tribute to the good taste of this community, it is also a smash hit. This combination at fine quality and commercial success is an interesting phenomenon.

NEW garden books, and old ones as good as new, occupy the gardener's mind during the long winter evenings when he has time to read them at leisure. The Christmasgift buyer will have a pleasant task, for there is a generous diversity of subjects.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Details of the Russian-Czech trade agreement, signed two days ago have been made public along with the announcement of a short-term Credit to Czechoslovakia.

HAVANA, Dec. 13 -- The General Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment tightened up on the press coverage of the conference tonight by limiting news released to the public by the United Nations Department of Public Information on closed subcommittee meetings to communiques approved by the subcommittee chairmen.

JAY MONAGHAN, state historian of Illinois and former Westerner, has given us a well-written book about the Trail which was "the pattern for all emigrant roads -- the symbol of pioneer America." It is comprehensive, a product of prodigious research; and within his definiton of intent, it is accurate.

Dr. Henry Noble MacCracKen, general secretary of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, anounced yesterday a selection of leaders in education, religion and other fields to head committees to enlist support for American Brotherhood Week, sponsored annually by the conference.

Beaten severely by a group of irate citizens, "a clumsy holdup suspect" was in Kings County hospital prison ward yesterday after attacking a couple walking to their home in the Columbia Heights section of Brooklyn at 2 A.M.

ATHENS, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The United States Mission to Aid Greece said tonight that the United States has given the Greek Army enough equipment to enable it to wage a "successful" campaign against the Communist-led guerrillas if the Greek people support the government's operations in the civil war.

Editor New York Times Book Review: IN my recent book, "Our Vichy Gamble," I devoted considerable space to a description of the background of the American invasion of North Africa. In this connection I paid full tribute to the contribution of the French resistance group and particularly to the part played by M. LemaigreDubreuil.

The Christmas period of entertaining for younger members of society again will include a familiar feature, the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, which will be given on Dec, 22 in the grand ballroom suite of the WaldorfAstoria, Sponsored by Coty, Inc., as a benefit for the New York Infirmary, the event is under distinguished patronage.

AMONG oriental surroundings it is necessary to hold trustingly to your author's hand even if the author is telling you a clear English-thinking tale with Chinese trimmings. In the case of "Miss Jill," Emily Hahn's latest close-up of China in the raw, there is even more need for implicit confidence.
HONOLULU, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Magistrate Griffith Wight disclosed today that the Warrior players recovered half their $6,700 pot by threatening to beat up the bookies.

WHETHER they are growing in the garden or in their natural surroundings, most of the ferns shrivel and turn brown after the first frost. A few hardy kinds are exceptions and stay green through the coldest winter, even if well buried in snow.

The consumer service section of prepared ideas to "save wheat, save" are its recommendations for today: Two favorite foods share the oven preparation that builds a Sunday dinner of substance and satisfaction for today's Peace Plate. Pork chops, richly browned, then baked slowly to delicious tenderness in milk, come to the table with their oven companion, scalloped potatoes.
ST. MORTTZ, Switzerland, Sunday, Dec. 14 -- The Swiss Olympic committee decided early today to stage the Winter Olympic Games here whether the United States teams compete or not.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Chairman Harold Knutson of the House Ways and Means Committee said today he would introduce a bill to reduce income taxes an estimated $5,000,000,000 a year.

Vistas for the eventual conquest of mental disease by chemical means have been opened by a new method for exploring the interior constitution of single cells, developed at the Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, by Prof. Torbjoern Caspersson and his associates at the institute's department of cell research.

Mr. Molotov in London on Friday was "not asking but demanding" that the German reparations question, and presumably all other questions on which there is disagreement among the Big Four, be settled by a Russian formula. But the strong words which provoked hot replies from Secretary Marshall, Foreign Secretary Bevin and Foreign Minister Bidault came from no new strength in Russia's diplomatic position.

MANILA, Dec. 13 -- The Philippine Government is thoroughly alarmed at reports from Havana where the United Nations Conference to discuss the charter for the International Trade Organization is meeting. It is understood here that there is a tendency toward scrapping or modifying the preferential trade arrangements among nations and that this may be applied to the Phillippine Trade Act of 1946.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 13 -- Three bombing incidents, attributed to the Jewish underground Irgun Zvai Leumi, killed today sixteen Arabs and wounded sixty-seven of whom three are expected to die. These attacks confirm the recent impression that Irgun Zvai Leumi has rejected the Jewish Agency's policy of strict legality and is carrying the fight to the Arabs.

At a protein symposium at the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn yesterday Prof. Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, Nobel Prize winner in medicine, presented a resume of the important researches on the mechanism of muscle contraction which he carried on during the war at the University of Szeged, Hungary, and more recently at the Marine Biological Laboratory at Woods Hole, Mass. Following are some of the highlights:

GLEN COVE, L.I., Dec. 13 -- Tom Iannicelli and George Pendergast of Short Hills led the way into the semi-final round of the fifth pro-amateur invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

HONOLULU, Dec. 13 -- Fourteen members of the Hawaiian Warriors professional football squad of the Pacific Coast League and one former player pleaded guilty in District Court today to gambling on themselves to win last Sunday's league title game with the Los Angeles Bulldogs.

AL MORTON of Salt Lake City, Utah, has won the Hiram Percy Maxim Memorial Award for his 16mm Kodachrome film, "Adventure on the Colorado," according to an announcement by Movie Makers, publication of the Amateur Cinema League.

THE score of Sergei Rachmaninoff's First Symphony, which has been discovered in the archives of the Leningrad Conservatory, has been printed by the Music Division of the State Publishing Company of the U.S.S.R., has reached America, and will be performed for the first time in this country under the auspices of the Rachmaninoff Fund, at a date to be announced in the early spring.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- There was a time not long ago when the countries of the Middle East were merely way stations on the British route to India and the path of Russia to the open waters of the Persian Gulf. But today these countries lying between Egypt and Afghanistan -- Iran, Iraq, Syria, Saudi Arabia and the small sheikdoms tied by treaty with Britain -- have assumed a new importance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Presidential candidates faced the growing boom of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower as they sat among the 550 guests at the winter dinner of the Gridiron Club at the Hotel Statler tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- As this strikers in France go back to their work after the most widespread labor revolt since the liberation, there is a tendency in certain quarters, and especially outside France, to celebrate a victory over communism. Yet nobody in authority here believes that the Communists have been definitely defeated.

CONSTANT radio listeners probably know all about Lucille Fletcher's little thriller, Sorry, Wrong Number. Under William Spier's supervision and with Agnes Moorehead in the principal role, it was produced for the first time over CBS in 1943.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 13 -- The Yale University quintet scored its third consecutive victory before a capacity crowd of 2,400 in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight, defeating Pennsylvania, 63 -- 42. It was the first Eastern Intercollegiate League contest of the season and Penn's initial setback.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- American President Lines will accept delivery of the 23,500-ton luxury liner, President Cleveland, largest commercial vessel ever built on this coast, on Monday, officials announced today.

A long-term boom in sales of papermill equipment to new mills in Southern States is expected by leading American heavy machinery manufacturers, based upon new developments in converting southern pine into pulp and improved processes for making newsprint, spokesmen for machinery manufacturers revealed here yesterday.

CHRISTMAS is almost at hand, and this time is bringing with it a facsimile of one of the most glorious of Christmas works, "The Rose and the Ring" by William Makepeace Thackeray. Profound gratitude is in order for the book's publishers (The Pierpont Morgan Library), the book's distributors (H. Bittner Co.), the book's editor (Gordon N. Ray, editor of "The Letters and Private Papers of William Makepeace Thackeray") and, of course, the book's creator.
One-third of the country's potential automobile buyers have been priced out of the 1948 new

ATHENS, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The United States mission's report today said more than $23,000,000 worth of relief supplies and 74,000 tons of military supplies were delivered during the program's first five months. A total of 57,000,000 worth of reconstruction is under way.

BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight listed the following winter sports forecasts and skiing conditions: MAINE -- Fair, cold, temperatures near zero tonight. Fair Sunday morning. Increasing cloudiness Sunday afternoon with light snow likely Sunday night.

OF the four items listed above, the first three are designed especially for the Hot Stove League, which went into session at the end of the world series and will remain there until the first batteries go south in the late winter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- During 1947 the United States has had the most destructive series of major disasters in history, the American National Red Cross reported today as the year neared its end. Up to Dec. 1 there were 267 disasters requiring Red Cross aid.

DENVER -- Radio Training A radio training program, designed to prepare students to qualify for positions involving technical knowledge and experience, has been established by the University of Denver. The program first requires a sound education in either the liberal arts or business administration, then a thorough knowledge of the various aspects of the radio industry.

An up-state Lake Ontario marlinspike skipper and manufacturer, F. Ritter Shumway of Rochester, is slated to become national chief commander of the United States Power Squadrons to succeed Charles F. Chapman of New York at the annual election Jan. 10.

Future debutantes and young men of "prep" school and early college age will be feted at many traditional subscription dances during the Christmas-New Year's holiday period. The Colony Dances, comprising one of the long-established series of parties for juniors, will be continued with a dance on the night of Dec. 26 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 -- Granted that the question of seriously impaired civil rights tends to dominate any analysis of what the Peron regime means to Argentina, it is only fair to record that, to thousands of Peronistas, this is no flaw at all.

New records are being set in the amount of money advanced to finance homes throughout the country. Lately the figures have reflected rising prices of dwellings, however, rather than a sharp gain in the number of mortgages.

IT is surprising that Christopher Isherwood's delightful "Lions and Shadows," published in England quite some time ago, should only now have found its way to the American public. On the surface it tells how, in the London of the Twenties, a young man made himself into a writer.

THE job of putting science on the air starts with the word "science" itself. To the average person, science means elaborate Greek-letter formulas, dull abstruse technical details, and a succession of ten-dollar terms. Radio, of course, must put this jargon into familiar English.

A warning that personality changes might result from frontal obotomy, the comparatively new brain operation that relieves pain, was voiced yesterday before 700 doctors here by Dr. Gosta Rylander of the Royal Caroline Institute, Stockholm.

Boys High School's smaller quintet put up a stirring battle yesterday before going down to a 41-38 setback at the hands of Thomas Jefferson. The contest featured a quadruple-header at Madison Square Garden witnessed by 6,000 spectators.

Ides of December When the year had arrived at the Ides of December the Roman felt that the time had come for a celebration. Four days later, on Dec. 17, the streets and squares of Rome began to echo to the shouts of "To Saturnalia!" Business stopped, and for a solid week the people whose boast it was that they ruled the world gave themselves up to the maddest and wildest excesses.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 13 -- Helene K. Haggerty's good 5-yearold mare Rampart took the Biscayne Bay Handicap and set a new track record of 1:43 1/5 for one mile and a sixteenth at Gulfstream Park today.

THIS department has just received a letter from two young men in Philadelphia who are peddling an idea. In the perennial manner of thoughtful young men the world over, they are concerned about the contemporary situation in the arts and are zealous to do something about it.
OTTAWA, Dec. 13 -- All week the Canadian Parliament has been debating in the dark and has arrived nowhere, in the opinion of a great many of its members.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 13 -- Robert Hervey Cabell, who was president of Armour Co., of Chicago, meat packers, from 1935 until his retirement in January, 1940, died here last night at his home 212 Sunset Avenue, at the age of 78.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Mrs. John Payson Adams' Grandpere, California's hope in the Kentucky Derby, today won the $10,000 added Salinas Handicap for 2-year-olds on the final day of the Bay Meadows meeting.

JOSEPH SHEARING fans -- and there are many -- have come to expect a carefully wrought period piece of simmering passions, slow poison, hypnotic suspense. The stories are generally fictionalized versions of actual murder cases which inflamed the British courts during the nineteenth century: the writer dresses each tale in exquisite atmospheric detail, dripping with lamplight, rustling taffetas, clodding bombazines, blushing ladies, sneering servants and ornate furniture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Interest in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination is as keen today as if the party's nations convention were being held six days instead of six months from now.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The House of Representatives passed the bill for interim aid to France, Italy and Austria (plus China) Thursday by what some newspaper accounts described as a "rousing" voice vote.
A Salvation Army band and chorus and Donald McMillan, head of the army's eastern territory, began yesterday distribution of 20,000 Christmas packages to patients in eight New York hospitals.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 13 -- Secret talks among Arab military leaders, appointed by the Arab League to work out plans regarding action in Palestine, have been held during the last few days in Cairo where the Arab League Council is now meeting in private.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- White House advisers see further inflationary hazard in labor's "third-round" wage increases which, it now appears, may average around 10 cents an hour.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Will Fyffe, amous Scottish character comelian, died early today in hospital it Saint Andrews, Scotland, from injuries he suffered yesterday in a twenty-foot fall from a hotel window. His age was 62.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 14 -- Talks on trade which will be most important to the Netherlands will open tomorrow in London when Dutch and British representatives will discuss reciprocal business relations for 1948 and will try to hammer out an actual trade pact.

BRESLAU, Dec. 14 -- Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka carried the Communist fight for Polish workers unity straight into the opening session of the Socialist party's congress today with the frank declaration that it was the Communist policy to hasten the inevitable merger of the two parties.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- News of the imminent conversion of the ruble caused no surprise in London financial circles tonight. The action was described as "an essential corollary" to the abolition of rationing.

Use of "the old trickery of separation of church and state" to set up a godless totalitarian state, abuse of the word tolerance and "glorification of so-called humanitarianism" were denounced yesterday by the Rev. Edward L. Murphy of the Weston Jesuit College, Weston, Mass., as the three "greatest deceits of secularism" being practiced in this country.

NANKING, Dec. 14 -- Communist Gen. Chen Yi has launched an attack on Kaifeng in a move to relieve the pressure of Government forces against the troops of Gen. Liu Po-cheng, Red leader in the Honan-Anhwei-Hupeh border area.

Warning that lack of an adequate convention and exposition hall was causing the city to lose millions of dollars each year, twelve business and civic groups endorsed yesterday the proposal for a new Madison Square Garden as the one that could provide this sorely needed facility in the shortest possible time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A statement by the Treasury tonight gave substance to reports that the Government supported the market price of its long-term bonds in November by buying them itself.

HANKOW, China, Dec. 14 -- Without having recovered from the war with Japan the three siste cities, Hankow, Wuchang and Hanyang, are encountering greater difficulties as a consequence of the civil war and inflation.

Winner and still champion -- the Cleveland Browns! Minus the thrills and frills that many had anticipated, the All-America Football Conference title play-off between the Brownies and the New York Yankees at the Stadium yesterday was neither a romp nor a rout, though it resulted in a convincing 14-3 victory for the defending rulers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- The leading roles in Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer's projected version of "The Three Musketeers" will be played by Gene Kelly, Lana Turner, Van Heflin, Sidney Greenstreet, June Allyson and Keenan Wynn, the studio announced this weekend.

The Todd Shipyards Corporation has completed a two-year expansion program at the Union Industrial Shipyard in Barranquilla, Columbia, the company announced here yesterday. The New York organization took over management of the yard after acquiring an ownership interest.

A new engineering process has been developed which may solve the problem of world-wide short-ages of vegetable fatty acid oils, now being studied by representatives of 23 nations, it was learned over the week-end.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 -- Palestine fighting took a new and serious turn today when troops of the Trans-Jordan Army, the Arab Legion, killed fourteen Jews and wounded nine Jews, two British soldiers, and an Arab civilian in an attack on a bus convoy near Tel Aviv.

GENEVA, Dec. 14 -- The Economic Commission for Europe is now able, in a. number of specific cases, to advise member Governments, including the United States, how great a saving in Europe's need for dollars can be made during the period of the European Recovery Program (the Marshall plan).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- With newspapers in at least eight cities hit by printers' strikes, and others threatened, the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board was reported preparing today to appeal to the courts for temporary restraints against the AFL International Typographical Union.

As the result of a rebuilding project that is expected to set the pattern for other East Side properties, the Bank for Savings will open a branch today at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Seventy-second Street, where it reconstructed eight buildings into one unit containing modern offices and garden apartments for fortyfive veterans and their families.

A nation-wide radio appeal for support of the Marshall plan to aid Europe was made yesterday on the basis that a stable, healthy economy for Europe was necessary to insure peace in the world and prosperity for the United States.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Dec. 14 -- Confronted by the warning that lack of funds may force America's most northern college to close its doors before the end of the school year, members of the Associated Students of the University of Alaska resolved in a mass meeting to write letters of protest to Congress and the Alaska Legislature.

Reduced current business has caused dress manufacturers in the bow-end and medium price fields to run below their minimum gross bookings for showing a profit, it was learned last week. Until cuttings for spring lines get under way in earnest, manufacturers said, production activity will be exceedingly light.
One donor who has contributed to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund since its inception thirty-six years ago and one giving for the first time were among those whose gifts were received yesterday.

Foreign Language Study It is not surprising that there has been, as reported recently, a marked decrease in the number of students applying themselves to foreign language study in New York City's public schools.

After an absence of three years from the local concert stage, Dorothy Maynor gave a recital last night at Town Hall which attracted a large and extremely enthusiastic gathering. It would be a pleasure to report that Miss Maynor's voice, which earlier in her career had a beauty of timber equaled by few sopranos of the day, Still retained its former luster.

Replies to its patents and research committee's questionnaire show an increase of 270 per cent in anticipated expenditures for industrial research during 1947, the National Association of Manufacturers announced over the weekend.

Fulfilling the peace treaty with Italy to the letter, all American, and therewith Allied, occupation troops have now left that country, and the American flag which has flown over Italian soil as a symbol of our victory ever since that stirring morning of July 10, 1943, when it was planted on the shores of Sicily, has been hauled down.

Following the national pattern, manufacturing employment in New York and New Jersey continues to remain well above prewar levels, although it is still somewhat below the level reached at the height of the wartime industrial expansion, the New York Regional Office of the United States Department of Commerce reported yesterday in a year-end summary of economic conditions in this area.

VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- Austria's semi-official and highly conservative Institute for Economic Research has issued a report on the Hungarian Government's victory over inflation through price control. It represents the conviction, now predominant in the Ministries of Finance and of Economics, that only through price and wage control can the new Austrian devaluation of money by two-thirds be made to work.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- A program for scattering "sparks of truth" behind the iron curtain and in countries where ideological warfare is raging was advocated today by William I. Nichols, editor of This Week magazine.

Pierre Luboshutz and Genia Nemenoff, duo-pianists, again displayed the extraordinary rapport and musicianship which has placed them among the finest artists of our day, in their concert at Carnegie Hall, last night. Not only did they play with unusual accuracy, but they also reached a high level of unity in tempo and dynamics with no observable effort.

Terry Tullos, 3-year-old poliomyelitis victim from Laurel, Miss., has been chosen as the poster child for the 1948 March of Dimes campaign, it was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, 120 Broadway.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Dec. 14 -- Jesse A. Knight, prominent textile-mill builder and operator during twenty years of New Bedford's active textile expansion, died today at his home after a long illness. His age was 81.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The United States Olympic Committee announced today that final tryouts for the 11-man water polo team will be held July 7-9 in St. Louis.

Federal welfare authorities may direct the State Board of Social Welfare to extend its investigation of home relief administration here to include the three categories in which Federal funds are involved -- old age assistance, aid to the blind and aid to dependent children -- it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations reported today that Philip Murray, president, had been questioned again by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation about his deliberate challenge of the Taft-Hartley Law ban on union political activity.

ROME, Dec. 14 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi announced today that he had formed his fifth Cabinet. Republicans and right-wing Socialists will strengthen his Parliamentary position with their seventy-six votes and each party will be represented by one Vice Premier and two Ministers.

The Madison House "gang" had a reunion yesterday in its club-house at 226 Madison Street. The party, one of a series of events marking the settlement's fiftieth year, attracted more than 600 alumni, their children and, in some cases, their children's children.

A decline in net profits after taxes to 3.9 per cent on sales for the nine months ended Oct. 31 from 6.5 per cent in the like period of 1946 has been reported by a representative group of department and specialty stores, according to announcement over the week-end by the controllers congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

ROME, Dec. 14 -- Italians' reaction to President Truman's promise to help them if their freedom or independence are threatened was varied according to their political convictions. Leftists were partly alarmed, partly angered. Rightists were elated.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 -- On the fortieth anniversary of the discovery of oil in southeastern Argentina, President Juan D. Peron declared last night that he had decided "radically to change" the nation's oil policy with a view to stepping up production.

Whether it's an uncle with a penchant for Russian caviar or a housewife with practical ideas about food for whom a suitable Christmas gift must be found, delicacy shops and grocery sections of department stores are ready with an abundance of clever and useful suggestions.

Solveig Lunde, gifted young pianist, was heard in a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The program she presented comprised Scarlotti's Sonata in F major; Clementi's Toccata in B-flat major; Beethoven's Sonata in F major, Op. 10, No. 2; Prokofieff's Sonata No. 8; Debussy's "Voiles" and "L'Isle joyeuse," and a Chopin group.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

An unprecedented long-range demand for trained engineers exists as a result of war-time developments in engineering and industry, James Kip Finch, dean of Columbia University's School of Engineering, declared yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- J.B. Priestley, novelist and playwright, recently visited New York for the first time in nine years. After brooding about what he saw there, he went on the air tonight to tell a British radio audience that our town "is not really a place but a state of mind."

Two impending revisions in the cooperatively sponsored Abbott and Costello show have been announced as the replacement of the Les Baxter singers by Matty Malneck's orchestra and the addition of Tom Brown of the films to the regular cast.
The threat of a New Year's Day strike of 2,500 cable and radio workers was added last night to are danger of a Pre-Christmas tie-up of domestic telegraph services.
More persons are employed in this state now than on V-J Day, according to estimates made public yesterday by the division of placement and unemployment insurance of the State Labor Department.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- A degree of excitement and activity was worked up in the stock markets here last week, which surprised but did not altogether please everybody. There had been solid grounds for this revival, but there also were influences that must prove to be of a purely temporary character.

VALCARTIER, Que., Dec. 14 -- Canada's newest skiland, being completed on the fourth range hills of the parish of St. Gabriel-De Valearlier, twenty-two miles north-west of historic Quebec City, will rank among the finest winter areas in North America by the time spring rolls around.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- A good deal of soul searching has been going on during the week-end over the import and the effects of the impasse in the Foreign Ministers' Council. This applies to the Western delegations. Nobody knows what goes on in the soul of Mr. Molotov or whether he has a soul apart from the composite organ that animates the Politburo.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The inspired Chicago Cardinals scored on an 80-yard touchdown play the first time they got the ball today to touch off a drive that carried them to a 30-21 triumph over the Chicago Bears and to their first Western Division pennant in the history of the National Football League.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Earl Baldwin of Bewdley, three times Prime Minister of Great Britain, died in his sleep last night at the age of 80.
Philip A. Snyder has been made general sales manager and Charles E. Horne general superintendent of the new specialties division of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 -- Many of the policies of the occupation authority are having and will have results the authors never intended. Perhaps the strangest of these unforeseen by-products of American efforts to democratize Japan is the strengthening of a bureaucracy already heavily leftist.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Government and Baltimore printing concerns asked tonight for a decree against a closed shop, "featherbedding" and other restrictions sought by the Internaitonal Typographical Union. They said such restrictions would mean complete "revocation" of the collective bargaining policy of the ITU.

Government officials will begin this week, under a White House directive, a study of the proposed reorganization of the Maritime Commission as recommended to President Truman by his merchant marine advisory committee.

ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- A memorandum submitted to the Ministry of National Economy by the Merchants Association in Piraeus has led to the discovery of additional large quantities of imported and hitherto unaccounted for food stocks in Government warehouses at Piraeus.

A petition urging that voluntary euthanasia, or "mercy death" for an incurable sufferer, be permitted by law has been signed by 1,000 physicians in the state and sent to every member of the Legislature. This was announced yesterday by the Committee of 1776 Physicians for Legalization of Voluntary Euthanasia in New York State and the Euthanasia Society of America.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The upturn in prices of cash corn and corn futures last week on the Board of Trade reflected an actual scarcity of available grain for consumptive needs, and buyers were forced to bid up the price to attract offerings.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 14 -- Belgium, a realistic little country with a tradition of being overrun in European conflicts, takes an unequivocal attitude in the "cold war" between the United States and the Soviet Union. That is, in simplicity:

The features of Christmas week at the Metropolitan Opera will be two special performances of "Hansel and Gretel," the first "Rigoletto" of the season and the debut of Pia Tassinari, Italian soprano, who will sing the title role of "Tosca" opposite her husband, Ferrucio Tagliavini, who joined the company last season.

Three leaders of an anti-Communist local of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, were ordered yesterday to appear before the union's district executive board to answer charges that they were "secretly plotting" to destroy the local.

The chances of American-flag steamship companies receiving a 50 per cent construction-differential subsidy, which was recommended in the recent report by President Truman's Advisory Committee on the Merchant Marine, appear very slim, informed maritime industry sources said yesterday.

Large producers of pet foods have made tentative plans to increase use of glass containers, rather than resume wartime dehydration practices, to meet the Department of Commerce's proposed curb on use of tin cans by this and other industries, spokesmen for leading pet food concerns said over the week-end.

When the Children's World Theatre progressed to a performance of "Many Moons" at the Barbizon-Plaza Saturday afternoon, THE TIMES' battery of impartial critics reassembled on time and in good order. "Many Moons" is Charlotte B. Chorpenning's dramatization of a fairy-story by James Thurber, a celebrated writer for tiny tots when he is out of the bistros.

The Greater New York Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations has drafted plans for a "flying squad picket line" of union volunteers to augment pickets in any local strike, Saul Mills, secretary of the council, announced yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Ojai, Calif., won the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament today, tying the seventy-two-hole record of the Miami Springs course with a 13-under-par 267 and increasing his earnings for the year to $26,556.

The Automobile Club of New York exists to serve the Interests of its members. We applaud its success on numerous constructive measures. We are inclined to differ with it, however, on the demand recently made upon the Port of New York Authority to reduce its tolls on the George Washington Bridge and the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels.

In a pre-holiday burst of activity some thirty art exhibitions are in prospect for this week. New group shows opening today include water-colors by contemporary Americans at Macbeth's; painting and sculpture by a dozen contemporary artists at the gallery of Georgette Passedoit; water-colors and small oils by members of the group at the Kootz Gallery, and modern Haitian pictures at Jacques Seligmann's.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- An announcement from Indo-China today said that 15,000 persons had taken part in a demonstration at Hanoi in favor of Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Maurice Thorez. Communist leader in France, declared today that by the Geneva economic agreements and the decisions of the Havana conference the French Government was delivering French agriculture into the hands of United States competition.

Warning that the American people can no longer afford to permit their views on tolerance to become "muddled and confused," the Rev, Dr. Robert James McCracken, pastor of Riverside Church, declared yesterday in his sermon that while tolerance is a "Christmas and a Christian virtue it is not as passive as it is often made out."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is encouraging to those wrestling with the difficult and perplexing problem of crime to note the action taken on Dec. 3 by Eric Johnston and his associates of the Motion Picture Association of America to amend their regulations and codes and to halt the production of those pictures glorifying the criminal.

With competition set to begin Saturday, six top indoor teams will ride in the 1947-48 Metropolitan League highgoal tournament, according to the schedule announced yesterday by John Clements, chairman of the committee. This season's play will run sixteen weeks.
After thirty years of encouraging, advising and cheering for Lewisohn Stadium performers, from City College football players to Jose Iturbi, George McCormick is retiring.

The Institute of Rehabilitation, a unit of the projected $15,575,000 New York University-Bellevue Hospital Medical Center, will establish ''interim headquarters" in the five-story building at 325-327 East Thirty-eighth Street, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, Chancellor of N.Y.U., announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Administration has been concerned for some time about what would happen in Italy when the United States troops withdrew from that country, as they did today.
In these bleak times, when suffering is nearly universal elsewhere in the world, there are several factors affecting the Neediest which must give this richest of cities pause.

To THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I, as an American citizen long interested in India, endorse every word of the letter you published Dec. 3 from an Indian concerning American neglect and misunderstanding of India and restating India's claims on our effective assistance.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- A busy week for Congress will begin at 10 A.M. today when leaders of both parties will go to the White House for a conference with President Truman on all aspects of the European Relief Program.

In spite of considerable liquidation following the unexpected increase shown in the official crop report issued on Monday, cotton prices in the domestic market last week reached new seasonal highs for virtually all futures contracts. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 35 to 67 points.

Although advertised to give two performances yesterday, "Caribbean Carnival," said to have been the first Calypso musical ever presented, abruptly terminated a brief run Saturday night at the International. The decision to throw in the towel was made early that evening, despite assurances given on Thursday by Max Jelin, lessee of the house, that the show would hang on this week, at least, for the simple reason that the rent had been paid in advance.

A great third-period spurt saw the New York Rovers notch three goals to down the high-flying Ottawa Senators, 3 to 1, in a Quebec Senior League struggle that featured the hockey double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Navy and Marine Corps planes will begin using facilities of the Air Force's flight communication system in the continental United States about Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday at Third Naval District Headquarters here. Aircraft of both services now use the airways communication system of the Civil Aeronautics Administration.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- All three Western powers have decided over the week-end that unless Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov brings some very unexpected concessions to tomorrow's meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers there win be no use going on.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet decree on devaluation of the ruble and the abolition of rationing, broadcast in Russian by the Moscow radio and translated in London by the Soviet Monitor:

THE traditional red ball did not fly over the Yankee Stadium yesterday in recognition of the fact that the ice was frozen fast and the skating was fine. This oversight caught the gridiron heroes unawares and unprepared. So the Cleveland Browns skated to a solidly earned 14-3 victory over the New York Yankees and thus retained their championship of the All-America Conference.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Glenn L. Martin Company announced today it has discarded production plans for its 303 pressurized twin airliner, in favor of carrying on with its 202 ship which has been in production for several months.

On the theory that Santa Claus does not live at 1310 Lohengrin Place, the Bronx, detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad booked five prisoners arrested earlier at that address, on charges of criminally receiving stolen property, and took $26,000 in merchandise yesterday afternoon.

Week Ended Dec. 12, 1947. It was an unsettled and uncertain week in the foreign exchange market. While special incidents explained away the irregularity of the Canadian free dollar, it is to be expected that as the year draws to its close adjustment of accounts by commercial and fiscal institutions will produce an ebb and flow in values.

The four city colleges are over-crowded and understaffed and need $37,000,000 for additional buildings and a bigger budget appropriation for more teachers, according to the annual financial report of the Board of Higher Education, made public yesterday.

At this time of year it apparently is easier to sell football tickets than to give them away. The noticeable gaps in the stands at the Yankee Stadium yesterday in the All-America Conference cham pionship play-off between the New York Yankees and the Cleveland Browns were in the bleacher sections.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- German sources said today that Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor in Germany, and Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, Military Governor in the British zone, were expected here sometime during the coming week-end.

Retail store notions, commercial chemical and plastic products, printers' ink, harware and electrical items are among the products being offered by the War Assets Administration, it was announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, New York regional director of the WAA.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Officials tonight described Russia's plan for devaluing her inflated currency as "interesting" and perhaps drastic, but not unorthodox.

Former United States Senator Arthur Walsh of New Jersey, a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority and executive vice president of Thomas A. Edison, Inc., of West Orange, N.J., died here Saturday night in Memorial Hospital, where he had undergone an operation.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 14 -- Rededication ceremonies, marking the second time in its 300-year history that the First Presbyterian Church here had been forced to rebuild after a fire, were held today in the presence of 1,000 members of the congregation and several distinguished guests.

BOSTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Playing without Syl Apps, their premier center, the Toronto Maple Leafs were held to a 1-1 tie by the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game before 13,907 fans tonight at the Boston Garden. It was the fourteenth consecutive time that the Maple Leafs have been denied a victory on Boston ice since March 6, 1945.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- The North Hudson All-Stars, coached by Sam Monaco of Emerson, mentor of Hudson County's first official titleholder in the H.C.I.A.A., defeated the South Hudson All-Star football team, 19 to 0, before a chilled crowd of 2,500 at Roosevelt Stadium today in the third annual post-season classic sponsored by the Paul Revere Boys Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- At a special closed meeting next Wednesday the United Nations Security Council will revive its sporadic, year-long search for a Governor of the Free Territory of Trieste.

With retailers concentrating their entire activity on selling, wholesale market activity marked time last week, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Trading in grain futures continues to be featured by excessive price changes. Wheat had a range of around 13 cents a bushel and corn 15 cents on the Board of Trade last week. This reflected rapid changes in the character of the news from Washington regarding price control, rationing and the big demand for foodstuffs for shipment to Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Steve Van Buren scored three touchdowns and set a new National Football League ground-gaining record today to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 28-to-14 victory over the Green Bay Packers and a tie for the Eastern division title with the Pittsburgh Steelers.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams closed their National Football League campaign today by smearing the New York Giants, 34 to 10, before 24,050 spectators.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 14 -- The Boston Terrier Club of Westchester, making the first move toward its proposed specialty for all non-sporting breeds, held its eleventh annual competition at the Westchester County Center today, with the Bulldog Club of America joining to make it a combined event.

Most of us think of our Bill of Rights as having been crystallized in the first ten amendments to the Constitution adopted by Congress 156 years ago yesterday. As a matter of fact, it is a living body of law, like the 700-yearold Magna Carta, which has been growing and expanding ever since.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The fading out of what promised a few weeks ago to become a strong bull movement in Wall Street is arousing comment and conjecture in financial circles here. It is fairly obvious to London market observers that the reaction was due to great uncertainty concerning future levels of prices, wages and profits in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The War Assets Administration today called for bids for the purchase of ten Army ordnance works which originally cost the Government $500,000,000. The plants are at Point Pleasant, W.Va.; Sandusky, Ohio; Paducah, Ky.; Pryor, Okla.; Weldon Springs, Mo.; Baldwinsville, N.Y.; Youngstown, Ohio; Rosemont, Minn.; Baraboo, Wis., and Meadville, Pa.

Plans for a Second Avenue trunk line subway and related connections, designed to eliminate rapid transit bottlenecks in Manhattan and thus greatly increase the capacities of lines in the other boroughs, were made public yesterday by the Board of Transportation.
