The Transport Workers Union of America, CIO, which says it represents a substantial majority of the 33,000 employes on the municipal transit lines, is prepared to endorse Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for an 8-cent fare on the city system, it was reported last night.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 -- Despite a continuation of shortages of material and problems of production, the steel industry was able last week to maintain for the second consecutive week the post-war peak level of operations at 98 per cent of practical capacity.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 14 -- More than 1,000,000 Venezuelan citizens went to the polls today to choose between Romulo Gallegos and Rafael Caldera as their new President. The city of Caracas was quiet; never before had it been so orderly in an election.

Russia's drastic revaluation of the ruble, announced yesterday over the Moscow radio, is an authoritarian remedy for what strangely resembles a capitalistic disease. The official explanation that went along with the bitter pill of conversion presented an almost classic picture of wartime inflation in any country.

Tea major points are being stressed in the national drive to improve distribution of industrial supply and machinery products among manufacturers and distributors alike, W. W. Kemphert, chairman of the Sales Methods Committee of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers Association, Pittsburgh, revealed here yesterday.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it had expressed strong opposition to the recent decision of top film executives to suspend or discharge employes refusing to testify before the House Un-American Activities Committee.
MANHASSET, L.I., Dec. 14 -- The court tennis team representing New York won the Payne Whitney Memorial intercity doubles today for the first time since 1936.

Three colleges, Colgate, the University of Virginia and Kenyon College of Gambier, Ohio, were admitted to membership as the annual three-day convention of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association came to a close yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Washington Redskins came up with a one-two punch today -- Sammy Baugh's magnificent passing and Jim Castiglia's line-crashing -- to end a dismal season with an easy 40-13 victory over the Boston Yanks.

Until there is widespread recognition of the sovereignty of God, man will not succeed in breaking down the walls that separate him from his fellow men, the Rev. Dr. George J. Russell, chaplain of the Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, said yesterday.

Joint Campaign Planned Pillsbury Mills, Inc. and the California Cling Peach Advisory Board will concentrate forces in a newspaper and magazine advertising campaign during January and February, it was announced over the week-end.
The annual Yuletide tree-lighting ceremony in Park Avenue was held last evening outside the Brick Presbyterian Church, at Ninety-first Street.

Earl Baldwin of Bewdley and Viscount Corvedale of Corvedale were the titles which a grateful empire bestowed upon him toward the end of his seventieth year, but it was as plain Stanley Baldwin that the short, stocky, ruddy man who was thrice Great Britain's Prime Minister was known to the world at large.

Dr. I. Ogden Woodruff, president of the Health Council of Greater New York, Inc., announced yesterday plans for the "first comprehensive health survey of New York City in twenty years." He said the survey would be undertaken this month as a joint venture of the group he heads and the Public Health Relations Committee of the New York Academy of Medicine.

The American Communications Association, CIO, has announced that its marine radio officers will begin balloting today on a proposal that they affiliate with 'tha Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO.

In January, 1946, Robert Warren of the Institute for Advanced Studies read a paper before a Round Table of the National Industrial Conference Board here which aroused spirited discussion at the time and which was subsequently to prove painfully prophetic.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Claude R. Wickard, Rural Electrification Administrator, warned today that the United States is not producing enough electricity and said the utility industry has refused to admit a shortage exists.

Reporting on operations of Swift Co. for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 1, John Holmes, president, informed more than 64,000 stockholders in the statement released today, that sales and earnings were the largest in the sixty-two year history of the company.

The annual appearance of The Old Farmer's Almanac has a stabilizing influence on contemporary goings-on. There is something comforting and comfortable in the Old Farmer's philosophy. When he states that the "only predictable thing about March is its unpredictability" one appreciates the validity of the assertion.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 14 -- A minimum goal of $250,000,000 was set today by the United Jewish Appeal for the resettlement and reconstruction of Palestine, overseas relief and rehabilitation and for aid to refugees in the United States during the coming year.
CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 14 -- In the largest political demonstration ever held in Egypt, about 100,000 persons packed Opera Square this afternoon and called for action against the partition of Palestine.

LEGHORN, Italy, Dec. 14 -- The last 1,357 soldiers and ninety-seven officers of a United States Army that once exceeded 500,000 men sailed from Leghorn at 2 P.M. today aboard the transport Admiral Sims. They 'ara expected to arrive in Brooklyn just before Christmas.

LONDON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's reply, made available by the United States delegation to the Conference of Foreign Ministers, to Soviet charges on Friday concerning United States activities in Germany:

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadians scored three goals in the last half of the third period tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 3, in a National Hockey League game before 16,459 fans.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is important to distinguish between the cases commingled on your front page of Dec. 11, re Howard Fast free speech, Communists, and colleges

VIENNA, Dec. 14 -- The official organ of the majority Austrian political party, the People's party, stated today that Russia had only two interests in postponing the Austrian treaty -- to increase the sale price and to contribute to the maintenance of continued chaotic conditions in Europe.

Anyone doubting that Beethoven was a great composer should have gone to Town Hall late yesterday afternoon and heard Rudolf Serkin and the two Busch brothers play the last of that master's piano trios.

Erna Schlueter, German soprano, who made her debut three weeks ago as Isolde, assumed her second major role at the Metropolitan Opera last night when she sang the Marschallin in the season's second production of Richard Strauss' "Der Rosenkavalier."

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The U.S. Olympic Committee announced today it would file "a very strong protest" with the International Olympic Committee and the Swiss Organizing Committee over the latter's vote against the American committee-sponsored ice hockey team in the 1948 winter games.

Uncertainty regarding the international situation and Washington political developments brought about wide-scale liquidation in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices at the finish were 15 to 48 points lower than Saturday's close, with the weakness in the near months.

Mild profit-taking in the late afternoon stemmed a further forward push by the stock market yesterday, but left a sprinkling of gains in representative sections. While the number of issues showing improvement outnumbered those to show losses at the close, the combined averages only edged ahead 0.03 point on the day due to softness in some of the important components.

Beginning last night at 8:30 o'clock it became possible, for the first time since 1939, for a traveler to board a sleeper at Victoria Station, London, and proceed therein, without change of cars, to Paris, via Dover and Dunkerque. There were train ferries on this run before the war; they have been restored.

Ohio State's 7 -- 6 victory over Northwestern, engineered some three minutes after the final gun, was considered the principal oddity j of the 1947 football season by coaches, athletic directors and writers answering an Associated Press poll.
DAVOS, Switzerland, Dec. 15 (AP) -- With at least eighty participants entered, competition in the world figure skating championships here Feb. 11-15 is likely to be sharper than the Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Re-examination of the status of factory foremen in view of the existence of the Taft-Hartley Law was commanded by the Supreme Court today. The action made it virtually certain that the Supreme Court must eventually rule on the matter.

BETHPAGB, L.I., Dec. 15 -- A sleek jet fighter plane capable of a top speed of more than 600 miles an hour, yet able to take off from and land on an aircraft carrier deck, made its first public appearance here today under the auspices of the Navy.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- William Green chided John L. Lewis today for taking his 600,000 miners out of the American Federation of Labor. Mr. Green left the door open to their return.

Cardinal Spellman spent an hour yesterday in the warehouse of the War Relief Services-National Catholic Welfare Conference, inspecting the more than 2,500,000 pounds of canned foods assembled in a nation-wide Thanksgiving Food Collection for Europe's hungry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 --The production and conservation of food to assure world peace dominates the annual meeting of the American Farm Bureau Federation. In a series of conferences today on various phases of agriculture preceding the formal opening of the meeting tomorrow, farm leaders and experts stressed the need for better farm and marketing' practices to supply food that "fights" to win the peace.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Faced with changing economic conditions that can force the garment industry back to the unstable conditions existing before the war, coat and suit manufacturers were warned here today that they must fight to keep the gains achieved in recent years.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- The 200,000,000 citizens of the Soviet Union found out today what they would have to pay for food, drink and clothing with the new paper rubles their government was to issue in its currency reform program for battling speculation and inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Counsel for Schine Chain Theatres, Inc., which operates nearly 100 motion picture houses in six Eastern States, argued before the Supreme Court today that a lower court was unjust and "improvident" in a 1946 decree that the company break up in the interests of competition.

The arrival on Broadway of Gertrude Lawrence in Noel Coward's collection of one-act plays "Tonight at 8:30," now on torn will be sooner than originally anticipated. Reliable reports, which could not be confirmed last night, have it that the anthology of bright, short plays will be put on at the Plymouth Theatre arround Feb. 23, or a month earlier than previously planned.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 (AP) --The following table gives the new price schedule for articles in Zone 1. [The ruble is converted here at the official exchange rate of 19 cents. There has been no free exchange, but diplomats will get 8 rubles for $1. Economists in the United States have estimated the actual purchasing power of the ruble at three cents. One one-hundredth of a ruble is a kopeck, as in column three below.]

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 15 -- Princeton's varsity hockey team notched its second triumph of the season tonight, downing the St. Nicholas Hockey Club of New York by a 6-2 count in a hard-fought match in Baker Rink.

THE Puritan settlers of Massachusetts contributed something to American civilization; but just what it was is difficult to know, so many and conflicting are the various verdicts. At one time every school boy knew that they braved the dangers of a howling wilderness to find religious freedom and to experiment in democracy at a safe distance from the divine right of kings.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 15 -- In secret meetings that are still going on the Arab League has decided that no member state shall send its army against Palestine's Jews, it was learned tonight from a reliable source. It is understood that this decision was influenced by the United States and Britain.

Alexander S. Panyushkin, newly appointed Russian Ambassador to the United States, not only "took a walk" but almost ran from the unusually large group of reporters who met him yesterday on his arrival here aboard the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A solid Democratic minority in the House of Representatives blocked an effort of the Republicans today to pass an anti-inflation substitute for the program recommended by President Truman. The Democrats showed a unanimity which had not been seen at the capital since the early days of the New Deal.

A proposed theme song for the 1948 Greater New York March of Dimes Campaign was heard yesterday by 120 guests at a luncheon of the Federal Employes Division of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis in the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Plans for the organization on a broader basis of activities in support of the establishment of a sanctuary for lost European children on the Island of Nevis, B. W. I., have been announced by Representative Sam Hobbs of Alabama.

Americans who want to aid the African people "must learn to go the slow way and not make bad matters worse," Sir Alan Burns, former Governor of Accra, British Gold Coast, West Africa, told a group of church representatives and businessmen here yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The other morning our friend Fulton Oursler, riding uptown with Arthur Garfield Hays, happened to mention a Christmas plan which my husband and I are following this year. Mr. Hays said: "That settled my Christmas problem. I'm going to do the same thing."

Benny Goodman, who proved years ago that he knew his way around a concerto as well as a stomp, has not been out in public lately with the long-haired set. As if to make up for this over-sight, he played the clarinet in two works at last night's Town Hall concert of the Little Orchestra Society under the direction of Thomas K. Scherman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz retired from naval service today after a career that embraced command of the Pacific Fleet in the recent war and afterward the highest post open to a member of the commissioned service, Chief of Naval Operations.

The chestnuts that provide such a meaty, delicious stuffing' for turkey or chicken are selling for about 33 cents a pound in stores throughout the city. Last season they were as much as 60 cents a pound. The drop in price is owing to the greatly increased quantities that have appeared on the market this fall, plus -- to a smaller extent -- an unenthusiastic demand that derives from the weather.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- The proportions of the problem of inflation in France were defined today in a report of the National Balance Sheet Commission. It said that in 1948 the excess of purchasing power in the hands of the people over the volume of purchasable goods would be at least 365,000,000 francs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Allegations that both Negroes and white persons were arbitrarily and systematically barred from a jury system under which nine Negroes were convicted in North Carolina will be reviewed by the Supreme Court.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Excerpts from the first report of President Truman's Commission on Higher Education for American Democracy follow:

NORRISTOWN, Pa., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Forty-three striking typesetters returned to their jobs at The Norristown Times-Herald today on what management said were "company terms" -- including an open shop and the absence of a new signed contract.

TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- The guilt or innocence of Shigenori Togo, Foreign Minister in the wartime Cabinet of Premier Hideke Tojo was at issue today. He is under fire for not having served a formal declaration of war on Great Britain on tiec. 7, 1941, and for his belated notification to the United States of the breakdown of negotiations, served after the bombs had already begun to fall on Pearl Harbor.

More than 5,000 Santa Claus letters have poured into the main Post Office at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday. It is 25 per cent heavier than last year, he added.

Made homeless by a three-alarm fire that wrecked the five-story tenement at 229 West Sixteenth Street last Wednesday, ten families face the prospect of a cheerless Christmas, it was learned yesterday. Many have been left with only the clothing on their backs.
The ways in which gifts to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund have helped the stricken men, women and children of New York were described yesterday by two of the private agencies that attest the cases.

Promoter Sol Strauss, directing the Twentieth Century Sporting Club's activities during the illness of Mike Jacobs, announced yesterday he would usher in boxing at Madison Square Garden for 1948 with an all-heavyweight card featuring three ten-round bouts.

Economists who expect a recession early in 1948 will be mistaken, Sumner H. Slichter, Lament Professor at Harvard University, told more than 500 members attending opening sessions of the two-day production conference of the American Management Association which began yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

NANKING, Dec. 15 (AP) --Chinese Communist forces closely threatened the important cities of Kaifeng and Chenghsien in Honan Province today. Pro-Government reports said fighting was general over a wide area of central China.
OTTAWA, Dec. 15 -- All indications are that the British-Canadian food contracts will be renewed and that an announcement to that effect will be made within the next twenty-four hours.

BERLIN, Dec. 15 -- An attempt to create a liberal atmosphere at Heidelberg University has failed. The ancient seat of learning io rapidly coming again under the control of the old reactionary elements.
LONDON, Tuesday, Dec. 16 -- The Moscow radio announced late last night that Russian troops had completed the evacuation of Bulgaria on Sunday in accordance with the German satellite peace treaties.

LONDON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Following are the texts of statements made at the Foreign Ministers' meeting today by Secretary of State Marshall, as given out by the United States delegation, and an incomplete text of a statement by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, as distributed by the Soviet Embassy:
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The Council of Foreign Ministers adjourned indefinitely this evening at Secretary of State Marshall's suggestion without having accomplished anything.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Congress approved today a bill authorizing $2,000,000 for emergency relief to needy Navajo and Hopi Indians. The measure has gone to the White House.

Currency inflation has long been regarded as one of the favored instruments of Communist revolutionary strategy for the overthrow of the bourgeois state. Two Communist writers, Bukharin and Preobrazhensky, even dedicated a book to the printing press in appreciation of the havoc it has created at various times and places in history in capitalist economies.

Atlanta Gas Light A common dividend of 60 cents a share, payable on Dec. 31, was voted by the Atlanta Gas Light Company. The stock is now being distributed to holders of preferred stock of Consolidated Electric Gas Company under terms of the latter's recapitalization plan.

The country should alter its financial policy by curtailing Government spending and reducing taxes to allow more money for capital investment before resorting to price controls in an effort to curb inflation. So said James L. Rogers, president of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association, at the opening session of a three-day meeting of the association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Honolulu, Hawaii, announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on Dec. 23 an issue of $2,300,000 of park bonds and $1,500,000 of sewer bonds. The park issue is to be dated Dec. 1, 1947, and is to come due on each Dec. 1 from 1952 to 1977; the sewer bonds are to be dated Dec. 15, 1947, and are to mature on each Dec. 15 from 1952 to 1977.
Legalized off-the-track betting at state-owned establishments using the part - mutuel track system was recommended yesterday by a Kings County grand jury.

PANAMA, Dec. 15 -- Teachers and students called a general strike today in protest against the arrest of twenty-five persons Friday during a clash with police who were trying to prevent a march on the National Assembly. The demonstration was called to demand dejection of the agreement to lease defense sites in Panama to the United States.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The working population in Britain increased by 70,000 in October, the first month in which the National Control of Engagements Order was in effect, George Isaac, Minister of Labor, said today.
The National Collegiate Athletic Bureau isn't prepared to say that colleges are using a rabbit football, a development some suspected of baseball last season.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, spoke today at the dedication of Canisius College's Delavan annex in this city. In touching upon the state's decision to give financial aid to denominational institutions he said that their inclusion had been necessary to provide full educational opportunities for veterans at colleges of their own choice.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 15 -- J. Russel Sprague summoned newspaper men to his office here today to characterize as "ridiculous" a report that he was planning his gradual retirement from politics. Mr. Sprague is National Republican Committeeman from New York as well as county leader and county executive, and is second only to Governor Dewey in state Republican politics.

Justice Meier Steinbrink of the Appellate Term of Supreme Court, who challenged theconstitutionality of a major provision of the city's rent control law three weeks ago, has since made similar rulings n three cases, it was found yesterday.

Members of the Congregation Emanu-El went on record unanimously last night as opposed to the plan for the Union of American Hebrew Congregations to affiliate with an organization that would represent Jews in the United States on all matters of domestic and foreign policy.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- End Frank Ivy, who suffered a shoulder separation, was the only Chicago Cardinal casualty as the South-Side Red Birds dumped the North-Side Bears, 30 -- 21, yesterday for the Western Division title of the National Football League.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Spurred by rising commodity prices and a post-war boom in speculative activity, the nation's futures markets did a $33,546,000,000 volume of business during the fiscal year ended last June 30.
The United States Maritime Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the sale of all remaining available Government tankers.

BRESLAU, Dec. 15 -- The congress of the Polish Socialist party answered a decisive "no" today to the Communist request for a merger of the two parties. The reply was made in a resounding spontaneous demonstration for Premier ' Joseph Cyrankiewicz's declaration that Poland needed the Socialist party.

The committee for thirty-two Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipowners and agents rejected yesterday a demand by the American Communications Association for a 25 per cent wage increase and other benefits, submitted under a contract wage-reopening clause.

HONOLULU, Dec. 15 -- Four members of the Hawaiian Warriors' squad of the Pacific Coast League were expelled from professional football for life today. Ten others received indefinite suspensions as the aftermath of their ill-fated betting pool on the league championship game with the Los Angeles Bulldogs here Dec. 7.

Retail Ad Methods Lauded Greater readership and sales results were credited to retail promotional advertising in a talk last night by Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association's sales promotion division, before the advertising and selling course of the New York Advertising Club at the Engineers' Club.

RONNE ANTARCTIC RESEARCH EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Dec. 9 (Delayed) -- The Joint British-American Weddell Coast sledge party reached Mount Tricorn on Sunday, Dec. 7. It has taken the men since Oct. 10 to travel the 500 miles from this base, averaging sixteen miles a day by dog sledge on every day on which travel was possible.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 -- West Coast longshoremen affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations won a wage rise of eight cents an hour today and the promise of an additional increase on Feb. 10, when Department of Labor computations of living costs for the current quarter will be available.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Rumanian Government today took over management of the two biggest British oil companies here, Astra-Romana and Unirea, after having charged their owners with "bad will, deficient production and theft of oil from Government subsoil."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Rep. Chenoweth, Republican, of Colorado, said today he will oppose any attempt next year to extend the State Department's authority to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Sammy Baugh, at 33, has just wound up his eleventh year as the pass master of the Washington Redskins. And the records show the thin man from Texas was never better.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- With two of the overnight field scratched, only four started in the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth Winter Haven purse, sixth race at Gulfstream Park today. The winner was Respingo, owned by Gustave Ring of Washington.
Highlights of spring fashion picture were enumerated yesterday by Miss Kay Sullivan, president of the Fashion Group, at the Hotel Biltmore at the group's ready-to-wear division luncheon meeting.

Two new issues or public utility preferred stock aggregating $8,000,000 in par value were offered at competitive sale yesterday. An issue of 40,000 shares of Indianapolis Power and Light Company preferred with a 2 1/2 per cent sinking fund was sold to investment bankers at a net dividend cost of 5.12 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that exports increased during October in all classes of commodities except crude foodstuffs, notably wheat, while imports increased in all classes except crude materials. An earlier bureau report showed exports rose from $1,089,000,000 in September to $1,208,700,000 in October, while imports rose from $480,400,000 to $504,700,000.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 15 -- The prospect that Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halback may be left without legal counsel in the event the United States Military Tribunal here denies a renewed request for permission to retain the law firm of Thomas Foley and Earl J. Carroll of Hayward, Calif., appeared in today's proceedings.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Arthur Machen, the novelist, whose works were characterized by an unusual vein of rich fantasy, died today at a private hospital in Beaconsfield. His age was 84.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The members of the President's Commission on Higher Education are as follows:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Eleven Senators, headed by H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of New Jersey, filed a joint resolution today authorizing the President to set aside in a special fund all further payments on the Finnish war debt. The money would be used to educate Finnish youth in the United States.

CAMDEN, N.Y., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Jeannette Delahunt, 14 years old, appeared for classes at Camden Central High School wearing slacks today, but returned home when school authorities ruled that in such attire she would be "segregated" from classmates.

Mrs. Maybelle Sheppard Hintz testified yesterday in General Sessions that after her husband, Anthony, had been waylaid in the hallway of their home and wounded six times he told her that John M. Dunn was the man who shot him.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 -- Monopoly in production of shoe-making machinery was charged against the United Shoe Machinery Corporation of Boston today in a civil anti-trust suit filed in United States District Court here

A hearing on charges by The Nassau Daily Review-Star against the International Typographical Union, AFL, opened yesterday in the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board, 120 Wall Street.

A recently-appointed special subcommittee of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will make a world-wide survey of industrial design protection or lack of it in various countries next year, Francois Hepp, French design expert attached to UNESCO, disclosed yesterday.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Alpine combination, consisting of the downhill race and slalom, will tie one of the most popular events at the Winter Olympics here Jan. 30-Feb. 8, if a tabulation of preliminary entries is indicative.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- Two companies asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today for permission to withdraw registration statements covering 423,306 shares of common stock.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 -- Inflated prices have caused retail sales to consumers to fall off at a faster rate than can be compensated for by higher prices, Roger L. Slater, vice president and general merchandise manager of Scruggs-Van-dervoort and Barney, asserted tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Presiden Truman sent to the Senate for confirmation today a list of more than 200 generals for promotion, including seventy-six major generals and ninety-two brigadier generals for permanent rank in the Regular Army.

With yesterday's action on the $597,000,000 interim foreign aid program, Congress has nearly fulfilled the purpose for which President Truman called it into special session a month ago. Under the authorization bill now sent to the White House the Government can borrow $150,000,000 from the RFC and begin sending food, seed, fertilizer, fuel, medical necessities and other supplies to France, Italy and Austria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Negro firemen on thirteen, southeastern railroads won a victory when the Supreme Court today refused to review a lower court ruling that the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen must not discriminate against them in the matter of promotions.

The four-game winning streak of the New York Knickerbockers was ended last night at Madison Square Garden, where the Philadelphia Warriors came from behind to record a thrill-jammed 74-71 victory. A crowd of 13,476 fans saw the champion Warriors overcome an early 8-point deficit against the current pace-setters in the Eastern Division of the Basketball Association of America.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Publication in your columns of Jonathan B. Bingham's letter on NAM's twelve-point anti-inflation program gives an importance to his criticisms which we feel should not go unanswered.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- The leaders of the Social Democratic party and the Christian Democratic Union, the two biggest parties in Western Germany, are working toward agreement on a single set of proposals to the United States and British Military Governments for the charter of a provisional Western. German Government, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The text of the emergency foreign-aid bill as sent to President Truman today follows:

Shortage Rumor Revived Confusion characterized the general reaction yesterday to the statement of Claude R. Wickard, Rural Electrification Administrator, who charged on Sunday that the utility industry has refused to admit a shortage of electric power exists.
YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES The President Conferred with Congressional leaders on adjournment plans.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- "The Gay Nineties," a film musical comedy, which Alien Boretz is writing at Warner Brothers, has been scheduled by Michael Curtiz for February production to replace his shelved project, "Forever and Always," it was learned today.

Health Department officials denied yesterday a frequent assertion made recently by landlords that it was permissible to turn off heat in apartment houses for a few hours in mid-afternoon. The department and newspapers heard from numerous tenants that landlords had given that excuse in reply to complaints about cold radiators between noon and 4 P. M. on weekdays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A coast-to-coast strike of 50,000 Western Union employes, excepting those in New York City, was set for Dec. 23 at 6 A.M., Eastern standard time, by three American Federation of Labor unions today.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Business in the stock markets here today was on a small scale and a number of leading industrials were lower on some profit-taking. Exceptions were shipping and brewery issues. The gilt-edge group lost 1/16 to 1/2 point.

Thirteen illuminated manuscripts, the patient work of monks ou the fourteenth, fifteenth and sixteenth centuries, were placed on exhibition yesterday in the main hall of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

After three weeks of futile debate, the London meeting of the Foreign Ministers Council has adjourned indefinitely. The Ministers' deputies are still supposed to meet today to explore the possibility of agreement on a treaty for Austria. But even in that matter it seems most unlikely that the deputies can succeed where their chiefs have failed, and unless a last-minute miracle takes place the London conference may be considered at an end.

Arrangements for a special Christmas Rosary program, entitled "The Joyful Hour," have been completed by the Rev. Patrick Peyton, national director of the Family Rosary Crusade. The program will be broadcast at 9 P.M. on Saturday over the Mutual network and WOR.

Mutual pledges of cooperation were given yesterday by Robert T. Lansdale, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, and Benjamin Fielding, city Welfare Commissioner, after their first meeting on city-state relief relationships since Mr. Fielding took office on Oct. 25.

The manuscript of "The United Nations," by Herbert Vere Evatt, has been received by the Harvard University Press. Mr. Evatt, Australian Foreign Minister, discusses the problems facing the United Nations. The book will be published in late January or early February.
CHICAGO. Dec 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Sauthern Methodist's football brain trust already knows that its Gotten Bowl opponent -- Benn State -- set an all-time defense record against rushing this year and turned in the best total defense mark since 1937.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A sharply cut price schedule for Japanese war silk, effective Jan. 1, was announced today by the Army Department.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Dec. 15 -- Romulo Gallegos, the Democratic Action party candidate for President, won a sweeping victory in the elections yesterday. The Copei party candidate, Rafael Caldera, was defeated by an unexpectedly wide margin.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, who was closely associated with Columbia University for sixty-nine of his eighty-five years, made that institution the residuary legatee under his will, which was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 15 (AP) -- At least fifty persons died when the Pauna bridge over the River Miner o in Boyaca Department collapsed Saturday, an eye-witness said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The Italian Republic and two of its institutions filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering $131,971,700 of sinking fund bonds. At the same time, the SEC announced that it intends to withdraw its request that American brokers and dealers "refrain from making a market in Italian securities."

HAVANA, Dec. 15 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today accepted the one-country-one-vote principle and abandoned weighted voting for the proposed International Trads Organization.

An annual net profit of 17 per cent must be realized by American business as a whole during the decade between 1950 and 1960 if production goals and over-all national income for the period envisaged in the recent report of the Twentieth Century Fund, entitled "America's Needs and Resources" are to be realized, Elliott I. Petersen, vice president for manufacturing, Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Jacob Aronson, vice president and general counsel of the New York Central Railroad, today told the Interstate Commission and members of state regulatory bodies sitting with it, that they should "raise their sights" in considering the current request of the railroads for increased freight rates.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Congress completed authorization today of up to $597,000,000 of emergency winter relief for France, Italy, Austria and China and sent its bill to the White House.

Nearly 25,000 children, the number brought to Palestine through the Hadassah Youth Aliyah immigration movement since its inception thirteen years ago, will enter Palestine in the coming year, Dr. Vera Weizmann, wife of Dr. Chaim Weizmann, scientist and Zionist leader, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Australia disclosed today that she planned the permanent union of her Trust Territory of New Guinea and her adjacent colony of Papua into a single administrative unit to be known as the "Territory of Papua and New Guinea."

Admiral Jonas Ingram, commissioner of the All-America Football Conference, yesterday set at rest rumors having to do with the question, "Is Brooklyn still in the league?" Taking time out from a closed meeting of owners of clubs in the Conference, Ingram went on record as positively asserting that the Brooklyn franchise was to remain an integral part of the Conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Leaders of both parties, who conferred with President Truman at the White House this morning, said they had had no advance intimation that Secretary of State Marshall was getting ready to call it quits in London and come home, but they indicated that they had expected an early break-up.

New York University's baske ball team, which flashed the form expected of it, while routing Arkansas, 85-62, last week, will seek its fourth straight victory the season tonight at Madiso Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- An agreement between the United States and Britain that will give this country virtual economic and financial control over the combined British and United States occupation zones in Germany will probably be reached within a day or two, it was learned tonight.

Striving to make December a record production month, the domestic steel industry this week Will operate at 97.8 per cent of ingot capacity, a new post-war high, and the highest weekly schedule since the week of April 24, 1944. The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Adoption of 1948 Westchester gross budgets of $23,228,955 as proposed on Nov. 13 by County Executive Herbert C. Gerlach was recommended today by the Budget and Appropriations Committee of the Board of Supervisors.

At the two-day hearing on a transit-fare rise test February before the Mayor and the Board of Estimate, Saul Mills, speaking for the CIO, declared that "the CIO, which represents the City of New York's 600,000 working people organized in some 300 local unions, is unalterably opposed to any increase in the five-cent fare."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 -- India and Pakistan are holding Government sponsored conferences of leading industrialists in their respective Dominions this week. From these meetings, it is expected, both short and long term economic policies will emerge for the two Dominions.

Six Christmas cards being distributed by the Progressive Citizens of America with a message from Henry A. Wallace were attacked yesterday by a spokesman for the Knights of Columbus as "obscene," "blasphemous" and "sacrilegious" and defended by the PCA as capturing the holiday spirit and pleading for tolerance and brotherly love.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The trend of Congressional comment today on the sudden breaking up of the London Foreign Ministers' conference was that this country should go ahead with Great Britain and France on stabilizing Western Europe without Russia's aid.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Conditions in the Soviet zone of occupation and Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's unwillingness to reduce Russia's claims to German reparations will be the principal ammunition in a new United States propaganda campaign In Germany.
Stevedoring companies in the Port of New York have joined in a drive to oppose "overtime on overtime" pay for longshoremen, it was announced here yesterday.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 15 (AP) -- J.F. Ahearne, general secretary of the International Ice Hockey Federation, said today that Europe is "closed" to the hockey team of the United States Amateur Athletic Union.

By following a policy which has permitted loans without restrictions or designated end uses, the Government has made it possible for a virtually bankrupt Europe to outbid the solvent United States in world wool markets, it was charged yesterday by Curt E. Forstmann, president of the Forstmann Woolen Company.

The prefabricated home industry, which in the last two years has sold 70,000 new permanent dwellings, was described yesterday as "the strongest bulwark against the encroachment of socialized housing."

HONG KONG, Dec. 15 (AP) -- China Sea pirates with a yen for occidental hats swarmed over the Netherland passenger ship Van Heutz, kidnapped six passengers and escaped today in commandeered junks. A ship's officer valued the pirates' loot at a half-million United States dollars.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 15 -- The tension between the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the British police in the Holy Land has become so serious that the United Nations Security Council may be asked to act on the matter, an Agency spokesman said today.

With the pace of gift buying rapidly gathering headway, retail stores here are now entering the peak period of Christmas shopping. Barring a blizzard or other weather handicap, new high records for volume increases are now anticipated.

MILFORD, Conn., Dec. 15 -- With the waterfowl season for Connecticut ending tomorrow, it is believed that the total bag for the entire Sound shore will be considerably under that of last year, although almost every experienced shooter contends that black duck and broadbill, as well as scoters, were more plentiful this season.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld the right of Indiana to regulate sales of natural gas by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company to large industrial users in that State.

Arnold Johnson, legislative director of the Communist party, to whom permission to address a meeting of the Marxist Cultural Society at City College was denied last week, will be allowed to speak at Columbia University at a forthcoming meeting of the Marxist Study Group, it was announced officially last night.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Henry Cotton, former British open champion and present French open champion, believes American golfers are the "best chippers and putters."
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Dutch West Indies, Dec. 15 (Aneta) -- Four dead and fifty-two survivors, five of them seriously injured, had been brought ashore this evening from two oil tankers that collided and caught fire near here early this morning.
GENEVA, Dec. 15 -- A full-scale Russian attack on any effort by the United Nations to implement by enforcement a bill of human rights developed during today's meeting of the Human Rights Commission.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 15 -- Dr. J. Howard Ralbag, chairman of the Justice for Palestine Committee, Inc., proposed today that the United Nations Security Council take emergency measures to safeguard the lives and property of 800,000 Jewish residents of the Arab states.

Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the International Conference of Christians and Jews, returning yesterday from ten weeks in Europe, expressed pessimism over the spiritual let-down of Europeans, in the seven countries he visited, including the United States zone in Germany, he found, however, a strong wish to organize councils of Protestants, Catholics and Jews.

Acting upon a recommendation of the Administrative Council of the municipal colleges, the Board of Higher Education, meeting last night at Hunter College, authorized each of the four citl colleges to establish a fifth year of teacher training, to begin next September.

Claudio Arrau gave the first of three piano recitals "featuring highlights of piano literature" last night, before a big and interested audience in Carnegie Hall. This audience listened and approved. Its members knew, as the event showed, that they could at least expect interpretations of a musician of high intelligence and uncompromising sincerity, who would place before them, without intrusion or exaltation of self, great creations of piano music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Drastic reorganization of America's system of higher education was recommended in a report of the President's Commission on Higher Education made public here today. Reforms which may shake the educational system to its very foundations were proposed for the nation's 1,700 colleges, universities and professional schools.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- The development of a western German state in three stages and the proclamation of an "all-German Government" are predicted for western and eastern Germany, respectively, by highly placed members of the United States delegation in consequence of the breakdown today of the Council of Foreign Ministers.
TOKYO, Dec. 15 -- The Japanese Government today abandoned its four-and-a-half-month battle to maintain its "1,800-yen monthly standard wage."

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Grain markets turned downward today after an early advance of more than 3 cents a bushel in wheat and corn. The close on the Board of Trade was irregular, with wheat 1 1/4 cents a bushel lower to 1/4 cent higher on the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- An event which brings to Washington many Presidential aspirants and their followers, and a number of other persons with public influence, who are as yet unpledged, gives off a kind of light that indicates the shape, if not the features, of the political future.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A refusal by Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, to disclose to Congress the names of persons speculating in commodities, including Government officials, if any are involved, was indicated tonight.

ROME, Dec. 15 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fifth Cabinet came officially into being late this afternoon when the provisional President of the Republic, Enrico de Nicola, swore in five new members of the Government.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 15 -- The United Jewish Appeal closed its national conference here today with a plea to all Americans to support its 1948 campaign to raise $250,000,000 for the building and defense of the Jewish stata in Palestine, for relief of European Jews and for refugee needs in the United States.

Even in the face of rising costs for labor and materials, responsible business is obligated to explore all possibilities for the reduction of unit costs before it increases prices, it was declared last night by William Blackie, vice president of the Caterpillar Tractor Company.

The Democratic high command in the state has embarked on an aggressive policy in dealing with the Dewey state administration, it was indicated yesterday. The intention, it was said, is to answer Mr. Dewey at every turn, and to call attention to the timing of his declarations.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Both the British and United States delegations were saying grimly tonight that if the Council of Foreign Ministers met again, it must be under changed conditions that precluded a repetition of the present resounding failure.

Store Sales Here Up 6% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 6 per cent over the like week of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
The American Red Cross has sent a protest to the Rumanian Legation in Washington over the use in this country of the Red Cross name and emblem by the Rumanian Red Cross, it was learned yesterday.

GLEN ROCK, N. J., Dee. 15 -- American Housewives Organized, Inc., formed a year ago to fight the black market and inflation, begins its second year this week with Its 25,000 members as determined as ever to do their bit, even though the inflationary trend continues.

Polacolor, a new process for printing motion pictures in color, developed at the laboratories of the Polaroid Corporation in Cambridge, Mass., was demonstrated for the first time yesterday at the Preview Theatre, 1600 Broadway, with the first commercial film released using that process, titled, "The Circus Comes to Clown," a one-reel cartoon produced by Paramount Pictures.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN Germany, Dec. 16 -- The steering committee of the German Bi-zonal Economic Council drafted today a politically nonpartisan program for a drastic revision of the present Council, creation of a representative body similar to the United States Senate and creation of three new Ministries.

Reconversion work on the Moore-McCormack liner Argentina will be completed Dec. 30 and the ship will return to private service with her initial post-war departure from here on Jan. 15, Albert V. Moore, president of the steamship company, announced yesterday.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation, will install a minimum of 30,000 automatic electric washers in self-service coin-operated laundry units throughout the country in 1948, I. Frank Brownson, manager of the laundry equipment department, disclosed in an interview yesterday.

FREDERIC MORTON'S "The Hound"* Is a novel of astonishing precocity. It falls a good way short of being completely successful and it is flawed with serious faults; but, nevertheless, it reveals an authentic talent and a vaulting ambition.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Grain markets made a strong finish on the Board of Trade today after a tame start. Short-covering, some support from cash interests and commission house buying disclosed a lack of pressure in both wheat and corn, and the former grain closed at the top, with net gains of 2 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel on the day.

Of the five National League pitchers who topped the 20-game mark in victories, the Boston Braves boasted two during the 1947 season, Warren Spahn and Johnny Sain, with Spahn gaining the most coveted leadership, the earned run average crown.

All tankers of the Maritime Commission's wartime design known as the T-2 type will have to be strengthened under safety regulations issued on Monday by the United States Coast Guard, it became known here yesterday.

The distilling industry wants one million more bushels of grain per month thaan the Department of Agriculture wants to allow them. Consequently they will reject, today, the proposaal of Secretary Anderson that only 2,500,000 bushels monthly be used during the next six months, it was learned yesterday.

The end of the London conference has inevitably been succeeded by conferences among the Three Western Powers, now confronted by a situation that imposes on them new responsibilities but also presents them with new opportunities.

Henry Ford 2d has changed the Ford factory from overhead conveyor systems for delivery of parts to assembly lines and now uses a new material handling system known as "palletized unit loads," Ezra W. Clark, business counselor, Battle Creek, Mich., told almost 1,000 members of the annual production conference of the American Management Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

Distinguished alumni of the New York Law School gathered yesterday at its new location at 244 William Street, formerly the Brace News Boys' Home, to pay tribute to the institution on the fiftieth anniversary of its incorporation by the State Legislature.

In a twenty-five-mile wind near the sand dune of Kill Devil Hill forty-four years ago today the persistence and the courage of Wilbur and Orville Wright brought powered flight to man and set in motion a train of events which have been among the most revolutionary in our time.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Miss Allena Gilbert Pardee, honorary president of the Corporation of Yaddo, close friend of the late Spencer and Katrina Trask of Saratoga Springs and New York, died here last night at her home on the Yaddo estate.
Cotton futures were moderately active yesterday, with final prices on the New York Cotton Exchange 16 to 25 points net higher than the day before.

Counsel for fifty families completed their case before the City Rent Commission yesterday, in their fight against eviction from apartments in Washington Square's "House of Genius" and six other buildings in that neighborhood. Briefs are yet to be filed with William L. Messing, assistant counsel who conducted the hearing at 500 Park Avenue, but it is expected that the evidence and argument will be ready for consideration at the commission's meeting next Tuesday.

The acrobatic, shoestring catch which Bill Swiacki, Columbia's All-America flankman, made of a Gene Rossides pass in the endzone early in the fourth period of the Army game was both the most decisive and most spectacular single play of the 1947 college football season, in the minds of the men who report the games, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Senate confirmed today President Truman's appointees to the National Labor Relations Board, Abe Murdock of Utah and J. Copeland. Gray of New York, and the appointment of its new general counsel, Robert N. Denham, Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican, of Utah, who succeeded Mr. Murdock, a New Deal Democrat, in the Senate, declared himself dissatisfied with his predecessor because he had demonstrated a "strong prolabor bias."

ROME, Dec. 16 -- The Ambassadors of the United States, Great Britain, France and Russia this morning informed the Foreign Ministry that their Governments had waived rigid application of Article 49, Paragraph C of the peace treaty and would allow Italy to scrap instead of sink the submarines remaining to her at the end of the war.

The Columbia Broadcasting System advanced further yesterday its plans for a national television network, filing an application with the Federal Communications Commission in Washington for a new video station in Boston. CBS, which operates WCBS-TV in New York, previously filed an application for a Chicago outlet.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the editorial "The New Slavery" in THE TIMES of Dec. 10, which I read with great interest, I came across the mention of Belgium with regard to the "hundreds of thousands of war prisoners who are still employed as slave laborers throughout Europe."

Postmaster Albert Goldman, in replying to critics, denied yesterday that there had been any "noticeable slow-down" in city mail deliveries despite an unprecedented increase in the annual volume of business handled, which will reach $135,000,000 by the end of the year.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 16 -- The Arab League conference ended here tonight without publicizing its decisions. It is believed, however, that with the possible exception of Trans-Jordan and Saudi Arabia all the states agreed to establish recruiting centers for unrelenting guerrilla war against the new Jewish state in Palestine.

Except for transit fare legislation, Mayor O'Dwyer's legislative program for the city faces tough sledding at Albany, Oswald D. Heck, Speaker of the Republican-controlled Assembly, indicated yesterday. But he left the door slightly ajar for granting some parts of the city proposals if "politics" are eliminated from them.

YESTERDAY'S ACTIVITIES Trusteeship Council Adopted fifty questions to be transmitted to Union of South Africa on administration of South-West Africa; approved resolution on relations with Security Council and recessed until mid-February.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A "modest but currently adequate" American standard of living, the result of a two-year study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on Congressional orders, was presented today by Ewan Clague, B.L.S. Commissioner, before the Joint Economic Committee.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- Unless there is a deliberate plan to plunge the world into a third war, the failure of the London conference of the Big Four leaves open one last dim possibility to preserve peace, Count Giuseppe Dalla Torre, editor of l'Osservatore Romano, says in an editorial today.

ROME, Dec. 16 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi presented his new Cabinet to the Constituent Assembly this afternoon in a turbulent session. There was a heated debate between the Premier and the Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The California Supreme Court today sided against Cecil B. de Mille in his four-year battle with the American Federation of Radio Artists over a $1 union political assessment.

The Bencor Limited Corporation 92 Liberty Street, which has been using the Red Cross name and symbol in its solicitation of gift packages sent to Rumania for distribution by the Rumanian Red Cross, agreed yesterday to discontinue the practice.

VIENNA, Dec. 16 -- The Austrian Government, through its Ministry of Transport and Communications, has requested the Allied Commission for Austria to return all broadcasting facilities to Austrian management. The reason for this request -- of which Allied authorities take a dim view -- is national pride and a desire for freedom from outside influences.

A banking group headed by the First National Bank of Chicago bought yesterday at competitive sale two issues of school bonds of Hinsdale districts in Du Page and Cook Counties, Ill. For $1,700,000 of building bonds of Hinsdale Township High School District 86, due from 1949 to 1967, the banking group bid 100.0667 for 2 1/4s and 2 1/2s, an interest cost of 2.40 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The House received from its Appropriations Committee today a bill which would slash $88,000,000 from the $597,000,000 which Congress authorized yesterday for emergency winter relief for France, Italy, Austria and China.

The stock market was unable yesterday to improve the price level established during the two preceding sessions. Much of the strength exhibited last week waned when interest diminished in the oil section and quotations, for the most part, drifted narrowly throughout the session to an irregularly lower close.

Members of the trucking industry agreed yesterday to meet tomorrow with Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander at Police Headquarters to discuss night trucking as a method of easing traffic conditions. They pledged full cooperation.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Helena in the Farkcheste district of the Bronx completed arrangements yesterday for a benefit basketball game for a Jewish family and for a Protestant family, survivors of two city firemen who died in a burning warehouse in East Ninety-eighth Street on Nov. 28.
Five offerings embracing more than $28,000,000 of common and preferred stock were announced yesterday by syndicate managers, as follows:

Forty-five New York scenes from the Nathan M. Ohrbach collection of paintings were put on exhibition last night in the Community House of the Central Synagogue, 35 East Sixty-second Street. The opening of the exhibit was planned in conjunction with the synagogue's 102d annual meeting and the dedication of the Julius and Hilda Loeb Memorial Room.

Immigration legislation in this country should be revised to make our system work on a humane basis, Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, declared yesterday. He recommended that Congress study the possibility of a five to ten year plan designed to "straighten out the injustices" caused by the present quota system of immigration.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Intensive efforts to have Premier Robert Schuman's anti-inflation measures ready to submit to the National Assembly on Friday were reported to be straining the cohesion between its various factions as the Socialist party's national council today started to debate the question of its support of the Government.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The French Government had expected little of the London conference of the Big Four and therefore was not greatly surprised when it collapsed, according to well informed opinion expressed here today. No expression of the official viewpoint was forthcoming, other than statements made by Foreign Minister Bidault in interviews in London.

A total of 127 Protestant and Orthodox church bodies in thirty-nine countries has joined the World Council of Churches to date, it was reported yesterday at the annual meeting of the Friends of the World Council of Churches, Inc., held at Calvary House, 61 Gramercy Park.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- The Potomac Edison Company of Hagerstown, Md., and the McColl-Frontenac Oil Company, Ltd., of Montreal, Canada, filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The United States, Britain, France and Italy today signed a protocol permitting Italy to participate in the distribution of monetary gold looted by Germany.
Only 2,770 workers are on strike in New York State, the lowest number in fifty years. State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi reported yesterday.

Sometime during the past year every man and woman has thought of doing some act of kindness that, somehow, never was performed. It was thought of from time to time; it was put off because other matters were more pressing; yet it would crop up, always at an inopportune moment; finally, the urgency of it passed, the opportunity stopped knocking.

Gus Lesnevich's next defense of his world light-heavyweight title will be against the challenger he last knocked out in championship fray, if present plans materialize. Announcement was made yesterday by Sol Strauss of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club that he was about to close a return bout between Lesnevich and Billy Fox, Philadelphia Negro, at Madison Square Garden on March 5.

Savings Bond Savings The cost to the United States Treasury in selling a half billion dollars' worth of United States Savings Bonds to the people, of New York State in the first six months of 1947 was but 15 1/2 cents on each $1,000, Robert W. Coyne, newly appointed vice chairman of the New York division's advisory committee, stated yesterday.
As an emergency aid, the Associated Hospital Service has decided to pay supplementary grants totalling $1,300,000 to its 260 affiliated hospitals, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The plan of Senator Robert A. Taft, announced today, to bring before the Senate certain anti-inflation measures, and pass them by the week-end if possible, can hardly cancel the blunder of the House Republican leaders yesterday in this same legislative area, even if Mr. Taft should get his program through the Senate.

Designed for a gay holiday whirl North and South were the youthful fashions presented yesterday at Bonwit Teller's seventh floor. For young folk home from school, a fitted coat of holly red had lilting grace in its swirling skirt and deep rounded collar while a loose gray coat looked chic with its navy collar and cuffs banded with gray.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The removal of Charles E. (Gus) Dorais as coach of the Detroit Lions, of the National Football League, was disclosed tonight. Owner Fred Mandel made known Dorais' removal and at the same time indicated he would sell the Lions, in whom an investment of nearly a half-million dollars has gone sour over the seven years of his ownership.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- John L. Lewis has demanded that the bituminous coal operators agree to pension all miners at the age of sixty after twenty years of service. The annuity would be $1,200.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- Paramount Chief Frederick Mahareru, exiled head of the Herero tribe of South-West Africa, may come to Lake Success in February to try to get a hearing in the United Nations Trusteeship Council the Rev. Michael Scott said today.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Breakdown of the Four-Power Conference, although generally expected in the city, put an end to all but essential business in early dealings in the stock markers today.

HAVANA, Dec. 16 -- Dr. Diego Luis Molinari, chairman of the Argentine delegation here, said in a press conference tonight that Argentina was prepared to grant $5,000,000,000 in "graduated and compensated credits" to needy nations.

DETROIT, Dec. 16 -- A new drug to aid persons afflicted by both functional and organic diseases of the blood vessels was revealed today by Parke, Davis Co. It is called etamon chloride and company officials said it had given good clinical results by blocking nerve impulses controlling the diameter of blood vessels.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The trading and exchange division of the Securities and Exchange Commission is making an extensive study of increased commission rates on the New York Stock Exchange, James A, Treanor Jr., division director, said today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issues of Dec. 4 and 5, Arthur Krock used the modest term "mechanical details" to set forth very clearly some fundamental choices which will have to be made by Congress when it finally enacts the legislation to implement the long-term European Recovery Program.

If an opportunity should arrive for a large scale planning program to be put into effect, the United States might not be in a position to take advantage of it, F.J. Osborne, British planner, declared yesterday at the annual meeting off the Regional Plan Association.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin again charged tonight that the Soviet Union had taken "considerably more than seven billion dollars" worth of reparations out of its zone of occupation in Germany.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today assigned Jo Swerling to write the screen adaptation of Maritta M. Wolff's novel, "About Lyddy Thomas," as a vehicle for Lana Turner. Leon Gordon will produce the film after Miss Turner completes "The Three Musketeers," which will go before the cameras next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- President Truman has approved a plan of administration for the $16,000,000,000 European Recovery Program vesting discretionary authority in an Economic Cooperation Administrator to make grants of cash or credit on his own responsibility or to certify loans to the sixteen participating nations reviewable only by the National Advisory Council.

Jimmy Warren, 136 1/2, Brooklyn, scored a technical knockout over Jimmy Joyce, 136 3/4, Gary, Ind., in 1:30 of the fifth of the main bout scheduled for eight rounds at the Broadway Arena in Brooklyn last night. A crowd of 4,300 saw Referee Ruby Goldstein halt proceedings to save the loser unnecessary punishment.

Dr. Walton Martin, distinguished surgeon, put all the power of his 78 years into a right uppercut last night and routed two hold-up men, one of whom was armed, from his luxuriously furnished home at 228 East Forty-ninth Street. Dr. Martin formerly was on the staff of St. Luke's Hospital, where his patients included the late President Theodore Roosevelt and Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler.

There have been occasions this season at the Metropolitan Opera when the applause was tame; but not last night, for both Lily Pons and Ferruccio Tagliavini appeared for the first time this fall in the season's first production of "Lucia di Lammermoor."

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 576, against 1,127 last week and 642 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 211 arrivals yesterday, compared with 493 last Tuesday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 16 (AP) -- When Graymar Bonnie and Airsis won the first and second races, respectively, today, the daily double pay-off was $1,635.00 for $2, second largest in the history of Gulfstream Park. The record is $1,795.40, set last March 14 by Brave Bid and Abrego.

An exhibition of oils Toy Shirley Moskowitz has opened in the Council Room of the Belt Makers Union, Local 40, ILGWU, 125 West Thirty-third Street, to continue until Jan. 3. The artist won first prize in 1945 for oils at the annual exhibition at the Musuem of Fine Arts of Houston, Tex., and in 1946 received a one-man show at the Alien Memorial Art Museum, Oberlin, Ohio.

Adolf A. Berle Jr., former Assistant Secretary of State, charged last night that the Soviet Union's opposition to the Marshall plan stemmed from a Kremlin decision in 1944 aimed at a political dictatorship over Europe and Asia by the Communist Internationale.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee unanimously approved today a Republican anti-inflation resolution similar to that rejected yesterday by the House, reviving to some extent the prospects of Congressional action this session.

THE three local baseball teams, which would be the Yankees, Dodgers and Giants, were hosts to the press at the Hotel Commodore yesterday for a preview showing of the motion pictures of the 1947 world series. It's a quite stirring presentation with proper emphasis on the moments of high drama but enlivened occasionally by a few comic touches.

Something along the lines of the Marshall plan is needed for the countries of Asia, particularly India, if they are to make industrial and technological headway, Dr. K. S. Shelvankar, member of the Indian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday in an address at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Threats posed by retailers' collective buying projects and combines are merely in a state of suspension during the current merchandise shortage, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Coat, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, of New York, warned here today.

Holy Cross, proud owner of the N.C.A.A. basketball championship and a twenty-six-game winning streak, plays its only regularseason college game in the metropolitan area tonight when it meets Columbia for the first time.
A general wage increase of $4.50 a week, retroactive to Feb. 1, 1947, for most of the 8,500 persons employed in the three New York stores of R.H. Macy Co. was announced yesterday.

Until the New York Yankees responded to the importunities of the news-hungry press and laid their cards on the table, face up, for all to see, there was not much of a story to the annual player draft meeting of the All-America Football Conference yesterday.

After an administrative mixup, City College narrowly prevented a speech in its main building last night by Howard Fast, who was barred from the college by Dr. John J. Theobald, dean of administration.

MANASQUAN, N.J., Dec. 16 -- Four men were drowned, three were missing and nine others were rescued from icy, gale-swept seas shortly after noon today when the party fishingboat Paramount V, bound for Brielle, N.J., capsized off the Manasquan River Inlet.

The New York Rangers, who trail the third-place Boston Bruins by a single point in the National Hockey League race, will have an opportunity to displace the Hub sextet when the teams clash at Madison Square Garden tonight. Victory would send Frank Boucher's skaters into the third slot.

Cunningham Drug Stores Cunningham Drug Stores, Inc., voted an initial dividend of 25 cents a share on the increased common stock, following payment of 100 per cent stock dividend on Oct. 24. The cash dividend is payable Jan. 20 and corresponds with the 50-cent disbursement on Oct. 20 prior to the stock split.

New York University remained unbeaten and Long Island University resumed its winning ways in the basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden last night. The Violets finished strongly to defeat, 68 -- 55, a Connecticut quintet that had won sixteen in a row since last season.

"The continued failure of New York to provide for a state university, including medical and dental colleges, is unjust to the residents of this state," the special council committee investigating complaints of racial and religious discrimination in the city's professional schools reported yesterday to the City Council.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 ()AP -- Bradley University's undefeated Braves won their seventh successive basketball game of the season tonight when they downed Harvard, 68 -- 62, in the second game of a collegiate double-header before 2,672 fans at Boston Garden.

ATHENS, Dec. 16 -- The Greek Communist party's secretary general, Nicholas Zachariades, has declared that "the establishment of a 'Free Greek' Government is a matter of only a few days," according to a Belgrade, Yugoslavia, radio broadcast.

GENEVA, Dec. 16 -- Fifteen European nations and representatives of the British-United States zones of Germany, working through the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, have agreed to establish an international exchange system for railway freight cars, it was announced today.

BOSTON, Dec. 16 -- Indictment of the Boston Fruit and Produce Exchange and twelve wholesale egg dealers on charges of conspiracy to fix and stabilize prices throughout New England was returned today by a Federal grand jury.
The holiday season was celebrated yesterday by several organizations here. Others announced plans for festivities.

The President's Commission on Higher Education has prepared a significant study that may bring about sweeping changes in the academic world. Many of the suggestions proposed by the twenty-eight prominent civic and school leaders who comprised the commission are designed to modernize the country's 1,700 colleges, universities and professional schools.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The next step in the melancholy progress of the Big Four disagreement is a plan for the immediate future of Germany. Whether the Foreign Ministers will ever meet again is problematical. An obituary mood hangs over the delegations today, lightened only by the glimmer of satisfaction among the "Westerners" that the dreary business ended on their initiative Secretary Marshall brought the conference to a close.

More than $45,000 was realized in the three-week Christmas sale of articles made by the blind that closed yesterday at 1 East Forty-fourth Street, Mrs. Blanche P. Gilman, Commissioner of the New York State Commission of the Blind, sponsoring the sale, announced.

CAMDEN, N.Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The "battle of the slacks" flared anew today in this village of 2,000 as Gertrude Ackley, aged 14, a student of the Camden Central School, was barred from her classes because she wore slacks.

Without any dilly-dallying, the new producing firm of James Russo and Michael Ellis quickly secured a haven for its initial offering, "A Friend of the Family." Tuesday night, Jan. 27, will see it installed at the Belasco after a Philadelphia tryout, Jan. 8-24.

GRIMSTAD, Norway, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Pale, deaf and defiant, Knut Hamsun, Nobel prize-winning author, faced a jury of his neighbors today in defending himself against a $100,000 damage suit for his literary activities in favor of the Nazis during the German occupation.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Complying with a request submitted by counsel for the Standard Gas and Electric Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission granted today to all parties an additional week, ending Dec. 23, for consideration of relevant issues.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it will readmit to trading Italian dollar bonds covered by the registration statement filed with the Securities Exchange Commission on Monday, when that registration becomes effective, which is expected to be about Dec. 22.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Railway Express Agency to publish an increase of 10 per cent in first-class express rates above those authorized in September and to publish second-class rates and charges equal to 75 per cent of the increased first-class rates. About 85 per cent of the agency's income is derived from these two types of traffic.
The National Civil Service League reported yesterday that twenty-eight states and thousands of municipalities throughout the country were operating without sound personnel procedures.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall is expected to return here from London on Friday morning and to report to the American people in a twenty-minute radio address that evening on the failure of the meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the Big Four.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16 -- With the current ski season off to a recordbreaking early start and the expenditure of nearly $3,000,000 for improvements, Quebec's Laurentian Mountains are anticipating a winter that should be the best in snow activities since 1934.

Criticizing the Federal Reserve Board for undue restrictions on credit for trading in listed securities, Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday congratulated J.M. Mehl, administrator of the Commodity Exchange Authority, for pointing out the diversion of trading into commodities which, he said, is a direct result of the Reserve Board's stand.

Home Title Guaranty The Home Title Guaranty Company, following its custom, has made an additional Christmas compensation to all members of its staff representing 6 per cent of their annual salaries, Henry J. Davenport, president, announced yesterday.

The Committee for the Companies and Agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts agreed yesterday to accept arbitration of the wage review issues of its negotiations with the National Maritime Union, CIO. Arbitration was suggested last week by the NMU when a deadlock resulted from previous talks.
A 16-year-old boy and two men were held in Felony Court yesterday on grand larceny charges growing out of what police called a fake hold-up.

Italy now has the strongest Government achieved since the war's end. Premier de Gasperi's fifth Cabinet is virtually a coalition of national union, excluding only the Fascist remnant and the disruptive elements of the extreme Left. It can look forward to the decisive spring elections, now being set, assured that it will not be destroyed by sabotage from within and hopeful that it can resist any menace from without.

Representatives from forty-three colleges attending the first annual meeting of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday took initial steps toward stricter eligibility for college athletes participating in summer baseball or in other sports outside of the current college curriculum.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Amir Sjahriffudin, Premier of the Indonesian Republic, asserted today that Dutch troops were concentrating on Java perimeters "in sufficient numbers possibly to threaten the Republican capital of Jogjakarta."
