RCA Institutes, Inc., the radio and television school division of the Radio Corporation of America, has leased the entire second and third floors of the nine-story business building at 350 West Fourth Street from Jack D. Weiler and William Kaufman.

LONDON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Walter Dew, retired chief inspector of Scotland Yard, who won fame for his 3,000-mile successful pursuit of one of England's most famous killers, Dr. Hawley Harvey Crippen, nearly forty years ago, died today. His age was 84.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The United States has formally notified Hungary of its compliance with the Hungarian peace treaty by the withdrawal of all American military forces from the country, it was learned today.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- British industrialists find nothing inconsistent in cooperating with a Socialist Government, Sir Frederick Bain, president of the Federation, of British Industries, told the American Chamber of Commerce in London today.

The birth rate in New York is falling now after a year in which a record number of births were recorded here, according to the bulletin of the Hospital Council of Greater New York, made public yesterday.

The candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President on a third-party ticket in 1948 appeared yesterday to have passed from the possible to the probable stage, as the most important group of his supporters, the Progressive Citizens of America, announced here that it was urging Mr. Wallace to make the race.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- Russia is failing in her efforts to sabotage European recovery, Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, told the annual meeting of the American Farm Bureau Federation today.
BOSTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued the following ski forecasts and conditions:

OTTAWA, Dec. 16 -- Finance Minister Douglas Abbott today defended before the House of Commons his recently announced measures for United States dollar conservation, now incorporated in "The Emergency Exchange Conservation Bill." He declared:
BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- There will be no United States retreat from Berlin unless the Russians force it, and that is not expected, according to informed sources here today.
An employe of the city's Public Welfare Department gave $5 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. The donation was accompanied by a letter that explained:
Macy's, these shopping days, has an inflation problem that neither a miracle nor Congress is going to settle.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Very Rev. Hewlett Johnson, Dean of Canterbury Cathedral, who has been known for years as "the Red Dean," was rebuked today by the Most Rev. Geoffrey Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury. The Archbishop dissociated himself and the cathedral from the pro-Soviet, pro-Communist opinions of Dr. Johnson.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- A possibility that reconversion of the Matson liners Monterey and Mariposa for the Australia run might be completed on the East Coast developed today with the disclosure that shipbuilding concerns on both coasts had been invited to submit bids.

Two proposals aimed at driving ineligibles off the city relief rolls were under serious consideration by the Welfare Department's policy committee yesterday, with every likelihood that they would be put in practice.

Plans for establishing a foundation to finance medical research in the increasing problem of caring for the ailments of an aging population were reported last night at a dinner of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 16 (AP) -- N.L. Raffeman's Tiny's Choice won the feature race at the Fair Grounds today, paying $3.40 for $2. Tiny's Choice was ridden by George Porch.

Robert Mann, top-seeded player from the Dartmouth Club, was among the second-round victors in the Metropolitan Class C invitation squash racquets tournament at the New York Athletic Club last night. Mann defeated Carl Hoffmann of the home club, 15 -- 10, 15 -- 11, 15 -- 7.

Patricia Travers, who played the violin at Carnegie Hall last night, was 19 twelve days ago. To one who heard her last night and remembered her debut at the Lewisohn Stadium at the age of 10 it was clear that she was one of those rare musicians who realize on their promises of precocious childhood.

Color-slide projections, used as backgrounds for fashions, offered a new and dramatic setting for costumes by some of New York's leading designers in a showing yesterday in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton. The novel venture was introduced by Al Ostrander, well-known scenic designer and head of the newly organized Merchandising Shows, Inc.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Victor A. Kravehenko, former Soviet official in Washington who has publicly renounced communism, today won the first round in his fight against deportation to Russia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- The United Nations plans to install in its future world capital a telephone switchboard that will be the largest in the state and specially-equipped to handle the multilingual calls of the fifty-seven member nations.

A second defendant among three men charged with slaying Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, was placed at the scene of the shooting by the victim's brother, William, who walked to the defense table yesterday in General Sessions and pointed to Daniel Gentile as the man he saw "running from the house the morning my brother was shot."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- In one of the few prosecutions of its kind in the country, a New York automobile driver was indicted here today by a Westchester County grand jury on a charge of culpable, criminal negligence because he "fell asleep at the wheel."

Barbara Holmquest, promising young pianist, deserves credit for ignoring the standard repertoire in her Town Hall debut, last night, even though the predominance of short pieces made for over-all lack of contrast. It is encouraging to find a performer who dares to play the music she presumably likes best.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board has issued eleven complaints of unfair labor practices under the Taft-Hartley law, ten of which have been directed against unions. Four of the ten name the International Typographical Union, AFL, as respondent.

Thomas Perkins Durell, former New York financier and treasurer of the New York State Democratic Committee from 1941 to 1944, killed himself yesterday with a 12-gauge shotgun in his suite at the Hotel Fairfax, 116 East Fifty-sixth Street, the police of the East Fifty-first Street station reported.

Not so many years ago a big round orange bulging in his Christmas stocking was a delightful surprise for a Yankee youngster. To day the fruit is as abundant in the Northeast as New York state apples or Maine potatoes. Even so it may once again be considered something of a rarity, because it is one of the few foods that is not one bit higher in price than it was in 1946.

Passenger travel statistics made available by the principal steamship companies and the Civil Aeronautics Board indicate for 1947 a combined total of 625,000 sea-air travelers between Europe and the Mediterranean ports and the United States and Canada.
GENEVA, Dec. 16 -- The United Nations Commission on Human rights adopted its report on a "Declaration of Rights" today by thirteen votes to none, with four abstentions.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Soviet citizens went to the banks today to exchange their old rubles for new ones, under the currency reform program, then toured the stores to buy food, clothing and other items, some featured at lower prices with the end of rationing, others at the same, or higher costs.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson formally declined today to furnish to the Senate Appropriations Committee a list of speculators on the commodity exchanges of the country. He made public a letter to this effect he sent to Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, chairman of the committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- The "United Nations disarmament work for 1947 came to a complete dead end today, and Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko laid the blame at the door of the United States and Britain.

The proposal to legalize "mercy deaths," as suggested in a petition signed by 1,000 New York State physicians and published on Monday, was characterized yesterday as "un-American" in a statement issued by the Catholic War Veterans through its state commander, Paul L. Murphy.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- A conference between representatives of the United States film interests seeking some modification of Britain's 75 per cent tax on foreign earnings and government officials has been set for tomorrow. Fay Allport, representing the American Motion Picture Producers Export Association, will open talks with treasury officials.

Help British Ad Men to Dine Gift food packages, sent to the Thirty Club of London by the Advertising Club of New York, have arrived in England and will provide a special Christmas dinner today for members of the British advertising men's association, Eugene S. Thomas, president of the New York Club, was informed yesterday.

Dividends totaling $2,953,675 will be paid on Feb. 2, 1948, to holders of the three preferred stock issues of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the company's board of directors.

BERLIN, Dec. 16 -- British-American authorities have scaled down the cost of German participation in the Marshall plan approximately 25 per cent. The deficit of $5,512,000,000 originally estimated as the cost of making the British-American zones self-sufficient by 1952 has been revised to $4,025,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 16 -- Another Government effort to head off a threatened nation-wide strike of 50,000 Western Union employes, scheduled to start at 6 A.M. Dec. 23, ended in failure here tonight when the union rejected a company offer as "insulting."

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- With a unanimous vote, including the Communists, the French National Assembly today hailed the arrival of the Friendship cargo of relief foodstuffs and thanked the American people for this generosity.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 16 -- While Palestine enjoyed a comparative lull in Arab-Jewish violence today, all sentries here watched tonight for a "phantom" armored car that reported to have taken part in shootings here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A group of Senate Republicans is preparing a tactical plan intended to outmaneuver a formidable Democratic minority, and force an investigation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark after the first of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A call for a conference of all veterans' organizations to reconcile their varying views on public housing was sent out today by five younger former service men who favor enactment of the Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill.

From a legislative standpoint the program of aid to Europe is trilateral. Stop-gap aid for France, Italy and Austria represents one side; the second is the sixteen-nation long-term plan for the recovery and reconstruction of war-torn Europe; the third is a domestic anti-inflation policy to insulate the economy of the United States against any upward pressure on prices that might result from action on the relief aspects of the problem.

Leo Durocher will manage the National League's team in the 1948 All-Star baseball game, to be played in St. Louis on July 13, if he elects to assume the responsibility. In the event Durocher decides to step aside, the honor will go to Burt Shotton, who piloted the Dodgers to the senior circuit pennant last season during the suspension of Durocher.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 16 -- One phase of economic policy of the United Nations was suggested today by the Subcommission on Economic Development at the completion of its first session, which commenced Nov. 17.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The formation of a "Free Greek" provisional government in the rebel-held areas of northern Greece and its recognition, at least by Soviet satellite states, is regarded by diplomatic sources as imminent.

Random notes. The Brookhaven Game Protective Association of Long Island will hold another of its combination field trials and pheasant shoots on Sunday at the trial grounds, East Islip. There will be classes for pointers and setters as well as for spaniels.

Only 46 per cent of the $350,000 needed by the Girl Scouts in this city for 1948 has been raised in the current campaign, Mrs. Howard Phipps, president, announced yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York.

The Bank for Sayings in the City of New York announces that the office of the bank, which has been at Third Avenue and Seventieth Street, wilj open for business in Its new quarters at Third Avenue and Seventy-second Street on next Monday.

The West Side Association of Commerce has appealed to the Board of Estimate to hold in abeyance the city's plan for increases in pier rentals on city-owned water -front terminals, James W. Danahy, vice president of the association, announced yesterday.

Just before Ghnstmas, Doth budget and busy budgeteer are ready for first-aid, which comes in the form of a thrifty meal-in-one dish for today's Peace Plate. Lemon and tomato juice add zest and tenderness to lamb neck slices, that have been browned and simmered gently to succulent tenderness. Plenty of rich gravy is part of this menu planning.

Randolph Hokanson, young American pianist, was heard in his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. In a schedule which ranged from Bach to Szymanowski, Mr. Hokanson, who received his training in England and this country, disclosed a carefully schooled technique.

For its final performance at the City Center last night the Ballet Theatre brought forth two more novelties. One was the official debut of George Balanchine as orchestra conductor, after a "sneak preview" at last Saturday's matinee. Mr. Balanchine led the men in the pit through a brisk and I spirited playing" of the Tchaikovsky score for his new ballet.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- A formal campaign designed to oust the Communists from control of the General Confederation of Labor, the most powerful implement of Communist influence in France, will begin tomorrow.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 (AP) -- A smooth-working Navy basketball team smothered Catholic University today, 59 -- 34.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Unity of forces in the United States fighting for Polish freedom from Communist domination has been achieved here at a two-day meeting between officials of the PolishAmerican Congress and Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, Polish Peasant party leader who recently escaped from Poland, it was announced today by the congress.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- The food cargo sent to the French people in donations to the Friendship Train that crossed the American continent was brought into Le Havre today, exciting interest throughout France.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 17 -- Founding of the American Jewish archives for the gathering and study of important American Jewish historical materials was announced here today by Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of the Hebrew Union College.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- Pope Pius XII today deplored the epidemic of strikes fostered by the Left Wing parties in Italy and warned that if the internal peace were disturbed he would cancel present plans to proclaim 1950 as a holy year.

The State of New Jersey announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Jan. 8 on $15,000,000 of series C veterans' emergency housing bonds. The issue is to consist of serials maturing in three to fifteen years, with the long maturities callable in ten years.

Detective John T. O'Connor of the West Twentieth Street station was acquitted yesterday after a two-day trial in Special Sessions of a third-degree assault charge made by Peter Trian, 26-year-old wounded war veteran, of 244 West Fifteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An industry drive to smash a gray market in nails through increased production and improved distribution was announced today by Senator Flanders, Republican, of New Hampshire.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- In a starthing change of attitude the Soviet Union made two important concessions on Austria today and at the same time demonstrated the Russion intention to continue using the Council of Foreign Ministers as an instrument for negotiation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Although the Government's final estimate on the 1947 grain crops issued late today showed decreases of about 43,000,000 bushels of wheat, 47,000,000 of corn and 16,000,000 of oats, compared with the last previous return, the reduction of corn was not so large as traders had expected.
Michigan's unbeaten and untied Wolverines topped the nation in home attendance as college football enjoyed another successful year with a per game average increase of 5 per cent over 1946.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Saved from early deportation to their native China despite loss of a $25,000 fund that was to have paid for a good-will tour of America, three musical prodigies began celebrating today the "happiest Christmas" of their lives.

ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- Employes of the State Bonus Bureau, starting an intensive two-week training course, received from Governor Dewey today an appeal for "complete teamwork" and "close coordination" in administering the bonus.

HAVANA, Dec. 17-The United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today seemed to be losing its fight on the method to be used in determining the composition of the executive board of the proposed International Trade Organization.

St Paul's School of Concord, N.H., routed Andover Academy, 14 -- 0, in the former's annual Christmas week benefit hockey contest at Madison Square Garden yesterday. A crowd of 2,500 saw the Massachusetts team suffer its worst beating in the six-year rivalry between the two prep schools.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 17 -- The Arab League leaders ended tonight a series of secret conferences on Palestine and issued a cryptic communique calling on the Arabs "to prepare for the struggle." They held that "all doors have been shut before justice and right."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- The Government yesterday charged the Abrasive Grain Association and five of its member corporations with fixing prices in violation of the anti-trust Jaws and demanded that the association be dissolved.

Albert Edward De Palma, a former Brooklyn automobile salesman who, according to Federal authorities, set up a brokerage office in Toronto, Canada, and made nearly $1,500,000 through the sale of stocks in this country, was arrested here early yesterday morning.
Despite the threat of a Western Union strike, parents, wives and sweethearts of service men will be able to send Christmas messages to camps in this country and overseas, it was announced yesterday.

Athletic directors, attending the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday recognized television as a "new problem" that colleges must face in considering their aports -- more particularly their football -- programs.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within narrow limits yesterday, closing 15 to 25 points net lower than the day before.

A Christmas tree may look pretty beside the fireplace, but it shouldn't be there, even if the mantel is resplendent with stockings and gifts for the kiddies. This was the advice given yesterday by W. Graham Cole, head of the Metropolitan Life Insurance safety bureau, 1 Madison Avenue. As for the traditional candle-lit tree, that's out, too, if one wants to avoid fires. "Lighted candles should never be used on Christmas trees," Mr. Cole declared.

Ground was broken yesterday for what is viewed as "possibly the greatest electronic research project" ever to rise in Greater New York. On a fifty-seven-acre site in Queens, 'facing Long Island Sound, it eventually will house all the farflung laboratory activities of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., to "extend man's basic knowledge in television, lighting, frequencymodulation radio and radar."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, was having drafted late today a stop-gap under which Congress would reimpose wartime controls of grains to distillers from the end of the voluntary grain-saving holiday on Dec. 25 to Jan. 31. He said he hoped for action on it in the special session and for longrange action in the regular session next month.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization cpmposed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public .and private elementary and high schools; recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pibtures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

NANKING, Dec. 17 -- The implementation of the provisions of the Fulbright Act in respect to China was formally launched here today with the conclusion of the first meetings of the board of directors of the United States Education Foundation to operate the Fulbright bill program in this country.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 17 -- Carrying out a proposal announced two months ago, the Securities and Exchange Commission adopted today revised proxy rules, composing Regulation X-14, under Section 14A of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- After four hours of spirited debate, during which a majority of the Labor members defied their own governmental leadership, the House of Commons approved tonight a grant to Princess Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh of u50,000 [$200,000] a year.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 17 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, in a statement to the Korean press today warned: "We may expect a great increase in Communist propaganda and activity in Korea against the great United Nations organizations and against the United States and their representatives here both in quantity, mendacity and bitterness."
POUGHKEEPSIE, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Elliott Roosevelt said today that he intended to "make Christians out of Christmas tree dealers."

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 17 -- A long-range expansion and modernization program, for its department store estimated to cost $7,000,000 will be started next spring by L. Bamberger Co., it was announced today by John C. Williams, president.

Successful use of a bacterial product to prevent recurrence of malaria was announced last night at the annual meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences at the Hotel Astor. The results, it was said, probably represent "the first successful attempts to inhibit multiplication of protozoan parasites by stimulation of immunity mechanisms through a bacterial product"

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The British Cabinet, which meets tomorrow morning, will commence the great task of reconstructing and perhaps reorienting Britain's foreign policy. This has been made inevitable by the breakdown of the conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers.

A program blending diplomatic, economic and military means but stressing "unquestioned superiority" in the air was advanced here last night by John S. Knight, newspaper publisher, as ''logical steps in our endeavor to prevent war."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Secretary of State Marshall is expected to make a forthright address Friday night on the failure of the London conference of Foreign Ministers and the implications for the future. Not only would this be in line with the direct statements he made during the conference to Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov, but it also would conform to a newly announced policy of the State Department.

Bond Ad Increase Expected Recent setting up of a new advisory committee of twenty-three industrialists to aid the Treasury Department sale of United States Savings Bonds is expected to bring an increase in the amount of public service advertising produced by the Advertising Council in its regular campaign on this subject, it was learned yesterday.
The weather seems to be getting better every day for the fox-hunters and, according to reports received from the Catskill area and eastern Connecticut, there is no shortage of foxes this year.

Arrival of the first shipment of the American Friendship Train at Le Havre has evoked a spontaneous outburst of gratitude in France. The French people know about this demonstration of our interest in them, and rejoice in it. Even the Communists were shamed into joining the unanimous Assembly resolution of national gratitude.

Year-end bonuses amounting to more than $500,000 have been distributed by the Industrial Rayon Corporation to its hourly and salaried employes in Cleveland and in Painesville, Ohio, and Covington, Va., it was announced yesterday by Hiram S. Rivitz, president.
TRENTON. N.J., Dec. 17 -- Petitions were circulated today by New Jersey members of the American Legion and its auxiliary to gain support of citizens of the state for universal military training.

The approach of the Dec. 3: deadline, after which tenants will not be permitted to grant voluntary rent rises to their landlords, has" failed to increase the flow oF such ' agreements, figures at the Office of Rent Control Indicated yesterday. During the first five months in which such agreements were authorized, however, about 194,000 were made.

Golf instruction by members of the Professional Golfers Association will be provided for youngsters in a program that the organization intends to sponsor next year, Maynard G. Fessenden, chairman of the P.G.A.'s tournament advisory committee and head of the Western Golf Association, announced yesterday.

To the editor of the new york times: As in the autumn of 1916 it fell to me, in the Arab, Jewish and Allied interests, to initiate the negotiations which resulted in the Balfour Declaration of November, 1917, and the subsequent British mandate for Palestine, I should like to be permitted now to offer some suggestions which may conceivably contribute to the solution of the tragic Arab-Jewish conflict in the Holy Land.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Izvestia, the Government newspaper, declaring that "the consumer is boss" now in the Soviet Union, today reported continued wide-scale buying throughout the country with the end of rationing and issuance of the new currency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- An organized Democratic drive to give President Truman power to allocate scarce materials stirred a dispute that prevented Senate action today on the Republicans anti-inflation resolution.

LONDON, Dec, 17 -- Sir Bernard Spilsbury, the most famous British pathologist of modern times, was found dead tonight in a gas-filled room of his laboratory in the department of pharmacology of University College, London. He was 70 years old.

THE HOODED HAWK,"* by D.B. Wyndham Lewis, is a salty, witty and incisive biography of the immortal Mr. Boswell, biographer, of the consequently immortal Dr. Johnson. Mr. Lewis, like Mr. Boswell, is a pleasure to read. He writes like a duelist in defense of Boswell, and many a donnish head bites the dust before he has given the detractors their justly earned damnation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, lost today most of the legal ground it had gained in the unfair labor practice case brought by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 -- The power of minor royalty in India is gradually decaying. This week thirty-seven of India's 562 Princely rulers voluntarily merged their territories with the surrounding or adjoining provinces of the Indian dominion.

We are indebted to Speaker Heck of the State Assembly for the first fulllength statement of Albany's attitude toward the city's financial needs since Mayor O'Dwyer carried his proposed legislative program to the people by radio on Dec. 5. Mr. Heck is a Republican from Schenectady County.

ATHENS, Dec. 17 -- In a Joint statement issued today Demetrios Helmis, Minister of Finance, and Stefano Stefanopoulos, Minister of Coordination, replied to criticism leveled at home and abroad against the Government for negligence.

WARSAW, Dec. 17 -- The Polish Foreign Office spokesman, Gen. Victor Grosz, commenting on the break-up of the London Foreign Ministers' Conference, said today, "The American decision to adjourn was decided by elements unwilling to see a unification of Germany, elements which want to split Europe."

With silk prices brought to their lowest point since the beginning of World War II, the principal obstacle to large-scale consumption of the fiber nas been removed, it was pointed out yesterday in the trade. Weavers and knitters indicated, however, that they would proceed cautiously in fabricating silk products as the result of their experience in the last eighteen months.

If Eddie Stanky, sometimes Known as The Bellicose Brat of Brooklyn, needs confirmation of his recent contention that he was too good a second baseman to lose his job overnight to Jackie Robinson, Eddie can find it in the National League fielding averages, released today.

Jake LaMotta got his money yesterday, but the Bronx middleweight is still under suspension in this state. Eddie Eagan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, in a communication to Sol Strauss, acting head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, requested that the sum of $23,910 be turned over to LaMotta who was suspended indefinitely on Nov. 21 following his four-round knockout by Billy Fox of Philadelphia at Madison Square Garden.

Generally speaking, it is not news, and it is not cause for gratification, when things go higher in these inflationary days. But there are exceptions to this rule, as there are to most others, and such an exception was recorded yesterday in dispatches from Washington with reference to the 19471948 budget.

The stock market snapped back yesterday on the recovery side when the rails gave further confirmation of the recent strength in the industrials. A few of the key issues managed to show substantial increases, but gains generally were limited to fractions, with the composite rate raised 0.50 point on the day.

Counsel for the State Labor Relations Board completed yesterday its presentation of alleged unfair labor practices by Sherman Billingsley, proprietor of the Stork Club. The hearing was at board headquarters, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street.

PANAMA, Dec. 17 -- Big Jim Newberry, Birmingham Barons pitcher playing in the Panama Professional League here, staged a one-man war at the National, Stadium yesterday untill he was rescued and subdued by mounted police.

Although never behind after the opening seconds, Fordham had to stave off a last-minute rally by Brooklyn College last night to achieve its fourth straight basketball victory, 59 -- 56, at the Rose Hill gymnasium in the Bronx. The Rams held a 34-23 advantage at the intermission.

Though London reports a "startling," and perhaps mercurial, change of attitude on the part of the Soviet Union regarding an Austrian settlement, we are faced with the fact that discussions of the much more important question of Germany have broken down completely, and that for practical purposes the Big Four has now become the Big Three.

LONDON, Dec., 17 -- The brightest group in generally cheerful stock markets here today were tin shares. The increase of u73 a ton to the record of u510 a ton in the domestic price of the metal, announced late yesterday, brought buyers in.

Maple living room suites of the type usually ponfined.to porch, sun room and occasional use are now providing serious competition to orthodox living room lines, manufacturers' representatives reported yesterday. They attributed the trend to price upgrading of virtually all lines by regular living room producers.
ROME, Dec. 17 -- Pietro Nenni, left-wing Socialist leader, opened the attack by his own party and the Communists on Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fifth Cabinet in the Constituent Assembly tonight.

Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said yesterday that the people of' Russia, while disappointed with the United Nations so far, believed it could become "an effective instrument in the struggle for preservation of international peace and security."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd today advocated amendment of the United Nations Charter to change the right of veto and concurrently the maintenance of a strong United States to implement the Charter.
Sidney R. Langer, credit manager of the Herbert Manufacturing Company, Inc., converters of Loomskill fabrics and Bona Fide linings, also has been appointed controller.

RONNE ANTARCTIC RESEARCH EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Dec. 14 (Delayed) -- At 5:20 A.M. local time on Dec. 12 Pilot James Lassiter, Aerial Photographer William Latady and I took off in the Ed Sweeney plane from Mount Tricorn on the last major flight of this expedition's exploratory program.

President Truman's proclamation putting into effect on Jan. 1 the bulk of the United States tariff concessions negotiated at Geneva was about in line with expectations, comment in foreign trade circles here yesterday indicated.

BRESLAU, Dec. 17 -- The Polish Socialist party, having asserted plainly its will to remain an indepen'dent organization, staged a demonstration today in this city [called Wroclaw by the Poles] in support of the other half of its platform -- whole hearted cooperation with the Communists on terms of equality and mutual respect.

With Christmas only one week away, festivities reached an accelerated pace here yesterday. From morning through the evening hours, carols were sung, Yule logs lighted, and refreshments passed that ranged from hard candy to the traditional Wassail bowl.

Steel Company Acquisitions Selling of steel companies to industrial concerns or syndicates has become a trend that may be broadened considerably in the next two months. At the present time three automotive companies, which have not been receiving sufficient steel to permit operations at a level greater than 65 per cent of capacity, have opened negotiations with medium-sized steel companies looking toward outright purchase of the latters' plants.

Purchasing methods geared to past efficiencies will not be sufficient to meet production problems of the drug industry during the next six to twelve months, Francis A. Wandell, director of purchases for E.R. Squibb Sons, told a session of the American Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association meeting yesterday at the Waldorf -Astoria Hotel.

NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 17 -- The case of an Italian who is said to have entered this country last October on an Italian diplomatic passport and visa and took employment in East Orange, as a garbage collector is under investigation by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Secretary of Agriculture recommended today that the Interstate Commerce Commission grant to the railroads of the country a 15 per cent "straight across-the-board increase" on all commodities, although he mentioned for possible exception, from the full increase "depressed" commodities, such as livestock, fish, apples, citrus fruits and wool.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- In a rehearing order issued today the Federal Communications Commission set aside its October grants for five new FM radio stations in the New York area, and announced that it would reopen the case for presentation of further oral argument beginning Jan. 12.

To the casual sports follower the controversy in high Olympic circles over which group shall represent the United States in hockey at St. Moritz seems quite unimportant, a mere tempest in a teapot. Most of them undoubtedly remark disdainfully, "There goes Avery Brundage popping off again" -- and forget about it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The trial in the Philadelphia Dock Street case will serve as a test of whether the Federal anti-racketeering law should be strengthened, the House Committee on Executive Expenditures said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Foreign countries, to pay for their purchases over here, relied more on loans and grants from the United States and sold off less of

Irra Petina, who has been absent from the company for several seasons, returned to the Metropolitan Opera last night as Carmen, as enticing a role as there is in the repertory. She had sung Carmen at the Metropolitan in the past, mostly as a last-minute replacement; her lot otherwise was secondary roles, some of them amusing and striking, but not the hind out of which stars are born.
Dr. Chaim Weizpnann, former president of the Jewish Agency in Palestine, was among 911 passengers who sailed for England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Mauritania.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Royal Aeronautical Society of Great Britain, presented the Wakefield Gold Medal today to Edwin A. Link for his past and continued development of the training machine which simulates for student pilots every condition of actual flight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Following are a series of recommendations made by the Senate-House Joint Committee on the Economic Report on Administration proposals for inflation control: Resolutions dealing with certain of the President's recommendations adopted Dec. 15, 1947:

Representatives of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths paid tribute last night to Postmaster Albert Goldman of New York for the service he has rendered in the field of inter-racial and religious cooperation. Mr. Goldman received the Interfaith in Action Gold Medal at the dinner at the Hotel Astor, which was sponsored by the Garment Center Congregation and Community House.

Columbia, rising to inspired heights every time it was challenged, scored a stunning 60-to-53 basketball triumph over Holy Cross last night before 2,500 vociferous partisans, who filled every available inch of space in the bandbox Morningside Heights gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The House, by a voice vote, passed today a money bill which would limit to $509,000,000 American expenditures for emergency foreign relief this winter. This sum was $88,000,000 under the $597,000,000 which the whole Congress approved on Monday as a maximum in a bill of | authorization.

Five wreaths were placed at the base of the equestrian statute of Simon Bolivar in Central Park at Eighty-fourth Street and Central Park West yesterday morning, the 117th anniversary of the death of the South American liberator.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- The world's mightiest crane, which was three years under construction and was put to its biggest test today, lifted a 630-ton metal and concrete block and set it down so gently on a hen's egg that the shell did not break.

ALBANY, Dec. 17. (AP) -- State Comptroller Frank C. Moore finds that fifty-two New York cities are taxing real estate beyond the constitutional 2 per cent ceiling through legal "devices." He met yesterday with his sixteen-member citizens' committee to study possible revision of the limit on levies for operating revenue and other financial problems of local governments.

This is the time to take down the punch bowl, polish the silver tea pot, brush up on eggnog recipes. It is the season when plans are laid for gatherings of friends from ages 3 to 80 (or more). The pleasantest party, hostesses seem agreed, is the afternoon or evening festivity when hospitality consists of offering a cup that cheers (anything from tea to fruit punch to hot buttered rum) with suitable little savories.

Texas, Southwestern Conference champion, and Washington State, one of the top contenders for the Pacific Coast Conference's northern division title, will be tonight's visitors in a college basketball double -header at Madison Square Garden.

Traffic conditions in this city will be surveyed during the second program of WOR's documentary series on civic problems next Tuesday from 9:30 to 10 P.M. "Name Your Poison" has been retained as the general title of the series, the first presentation of which dealt with sanitary conditions in the kitchens of New York restaurants.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Farm leaders disagreed strongly today with a poll, published by a farm magazine, which showed that 52 per cent of the nation's farmers had not heard of the Marshall plan.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 17 -- Municipal heads of six cities in the United States and British zones, as well as an unofficial representative from Berlin, asked the German Bi-zonal Economic Council today to permit them to participate more directly in future efforts toward the economic revival of Western Germany.

What do needy children use as barometers of hope for a happy and presentful Christmas? We grown-ups read about sales of department stores, about records being broken and broken again on succeeding Saturdays. Wartime advances in technique make their appearance in new and ingenious gadgets for the greater comfort of morning, noon and night.

LONDON, Dec.17 -- In a report to the House of Commons on the progress of European economic cooperation since the Paris conference on the Marshall plan, Foreign Secretary Bevin said today that Great Britain's coal exports in early 1948 would put her ahead of the timetable in the Paris report.

Two deathbed statements made by Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore who was shot last Jan. 8, were read into the record in a General Sessions courtroom yesterday. In these statements the victim accused John M. Dunn of being his slayer and then implicated Dunn's co-defendants, Andrew Sheridan and Daniel Gentile, as taking part in the attack.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am sorry that you did not mention, in your editorial on auto license plates, something about owners who cover the figures with glass, making it impossible to read the plates at certain angles because of the reflection, the glass acting as a mirror.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The 7,912 fans at Gulfstream Park today witnessed a highly interesting finish in the feature race, with Wheatley Stable's Athlete getting a nose decision over L. Gerngross Noble Hero.

A Congress of Industrial Organizations union representing 7,000 Western Union telegraph workers in this city proposed last night that American Federation of Labor groups representing 50,000 wire workers in the rest of the country coordinate strike plans with the CIO under an "all for one and one for all pact."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 10: Increases of $103,000,000 in commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans and $162,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, a decrease of $134,000,000 in United States Government bonds and an Increase of $323,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Detroit's Red Wings defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 7 to 1, for the sixth straight time this season before 15,785 spectators at the Stadium tonight. Detroit moved within a point of the first-place Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League.

What union leaders hailed as a new era of good feeling in relations between the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and the Board of Transportation was ushered in yesterday at a. cordial meeting between executives of the two groups at the board offices, 250 Hudson Street.

Offerings of securities valued at more than $32,000,000 were announced yesterday by underwriting managers as follows: New York Central Railroad -- $12,800,000 of equipment trust certificates maturing Jan. 15 from 1949 to 1958 at prices to yield from 1.50 per cent to 2.95 per cent, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salabe hogs, 12,000 head: total, 18,500. Market slow and steady after moderately active opening on all weights of butchers hogs: all early advance lost bulls of good and choice

CAMDEN, N.Y., Dec. 17 (U.P.) -- Everyone was talking about slacks today, but whether girls should wear them to school was something that Judge Walter Abbott of Onei'da County Children's Court might be called on to decide.

The nation's light fuel oil stocks declined last week 3,209,000 barrels, according to the weekly report of the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 55,032,000 barrels, compared with 58,241,000 a week earlier and 64,046,000 a year ago.

In a move to support its stand against motion-picture censorship, the' National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, Inc. is inviting citizens throughout the country to become members of the organization, the National Board of Review's board of directors announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee, on "advice" of the Republican leadership, served a subpoena on Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, today, ordering him to come forward at 9:30 A. M. tomorrow with all his records on speculators in grains and other commodities.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Westchester's 1948 tax equalization table was filed here today by the County Tax Commission, showing revised rates for nineteen of the twenty-four towns and cities. The commission explained, however, that the table struck a balance that would cause little shift in tax burdens.

Pay rises for twenty-five more high-rank city officials, ranging from $500 to $2,500 a year and totaling $36,110 annually, were approved informally yesterday at an executive meeting of the Board of Estimate. The increases are scheduled for formal approval at the board's regular meeting in City Hall this morning.

LONDON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Nahum Goldman, of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said in an interview today that Jewish legal experts, working on a draft constitution for the projected Jewish Palestine state -- which may be named Judea -- have included a clause binding the country to neutrality on the Swiss model in any future world conflicts.

Three National Football League records for team offense were sur passed during the past campaign according to the final statistics released yesterday. The Chicago Bears gained 5,052 yards from scrimmage, the Washington Redskins advanced 3.336 yards by passing and the Bears made 263 first downs for the new marks.
A little Brooklyn girt of fairytale age received a wishbone from a princess yesterday.

Thirteen Bronx young people from 15 to 21 years old, including four teen-age girls, were rounded up by detectives yesterday and charged with engineering seventy-five burglaries of apartments, stores and bars. The burglaries -- which allegedly netted them $5,000 -- took place during the last three months.

The New York Rangers made up for the past when they skated into the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night. Previously the Blue Shirts had been unable to down their hub rivals all season, but they more than atoned for that with a convincing 5-to-2 triumph at Madison Square Garden before 14,919 fans.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The announcement in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Nov. 27 that the Department of the Interior is opposed to all of the bills in Congress that are designed to force the removal of virgin forest from the Olympic National Park is a welcome clarification of a confused problem.

Until the United States demonstrates that it has no political or "capitalistic" designs on India, the people of that country will continue to fear America as much as they fear Russia, the Rev. K. Mathew Simon of the Syrian Orthodox Church of India declared yesterday.

Plans for an academy to serve as an advanced training center of the Russian Orthodox Church in North America for priests of that faith and other interested scholars were announced yesterday at a reception at Union Theological Seminary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- Warner Brothers' 1938 film, "Four Daughters," which introduced John Garfield to She acreen, will be remade next year by United States Pictures, an independent Warner producing company headed by Milton Sperling, the studio disclosed today.

St. Barnabas House, a temporary shelter for women and children of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society, will be the beneficiary of a double-bill performance of "Cavalleria Rusticana" ana "Pagllacci" on the night of Jan. 21 at the Metropolitan Opera House.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- In a conversation here with French diplomats prior to their departure for the Continent, Marshal Vassily Sokolovsky. Commander in Chief of the Russian Army of Occupation and Soviet representative on the Berlin Control Council, used telling sentences to express his countrymen's resentment at the American and British attitude toward German reparations.
Wednesday, Dec. 17, 1947 The President Announced the resignation of James J. Caffery as SEC chairman. Presented Collier Trophy to Lewis A. Rodert.
Business is going back on a "negotiated price" basis in 1948 in many equipment and heavy goods lines, it was learned here yesterday.

To the editor of the new york times: The most rational way to safeguard against abuses in job insurance, such as those recently described in THE NEW YORK TIMES, is to combine unemployment compensation with old-age pension benefits.

Travel Without Locomotion One must never forget, said a friend of this department, that foreign travel is not solely a matter of transferring one's body to foreign lands, but can be also something else possessing merit of a high order, viz: stationary travel, or journeying in foreign parts with the aid of the mind alone.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer urged the Senate Appropriations Committee today to extend all possible aid, including military supplies to the Government of President Chiang Kai-shek as part of a world-wide plan to contair Communist expansion.
The employes of the New York Directed Operations Office of the United States Atomic Energy Commission sent $250 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17(AP) -- James J. Caffrey resigned today as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a letter to President Truman, Mr. Caffrey said he was resigning because of "family responsibility which I can no longer ignore." He will enter private practice of law in New York.

Dr. Bernhard J. Stern, Columbia University lecturer on sociology, declared yesterday that the action of the Board of Superintendents in canceling his course in intercultural education for teachers was an abrogation of "basic democratic principles."

The Theatre Guild further advanced its production plans yesterday on Bernard Shaw's comedy, "You Never Can Tell," by signing "Leo G. Carroll for a leading role and by concluding arrangements whereby Tom Helmore will be borrowed from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to depict the part.of Valentine, the dentist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee today asked the State Department to make available FEC-230 -- a controversial and secret document outlining the Administration's economic policy for Japan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- By his insistence on bringing before the Senate what he frankly labeled a "stop-gap" program to halt inflation, until later and fundamental correctives can be worked out, Senator Taft has once again displayed the intelligent and responsible qualities of leadership for which he is not always given due credit.
City, state and Federal relief officials joined forces yesterday in a drive to rid the city's relief rolls of persons ineligible for relief under current laws and regulations.

Gen. A.G.L. McNaughton, Canada's chief atomic spokesman, told the United States yesterday that it could count on atomic supremacy for "some decades" but that in the meantime it should increase its leadership in the field by every method at its command.

Two more ClO-affiliated maritime unions agreed yesterday to arbitration of their wage reviews, bringing to a close for the time being, at least, negotiations between the committee representing shipowners and agents on the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued the following ski forecasts and conditions: Maine-Considerable cloudiness tonight with light snow ending tomorrow. One to two inches light powder snow probable.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Crop production this year turned out to be the fourth largest on record despite a severe drought that cut the corn harvest to the smallest since 1936, the Government's final production report of the year showed today.

TOKYO, Dec. 17 -- Shigenori Togo, Foreign Minister in Japan's Pearl Harbor Cabinet, took the vitness stand before the International Military Tribunal this afternoon. He testified that no declaration of war was necessary before the Japanese sneak attack on Pearl Harbor since Japan's fight was one of self-defense provoked by the note of Secretary of State Cordell Hull, which he called an "ultimatum," of Nov. 26, 1941.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 -- Beirut will become the political canter and Damascus, Syria, the military center where decision taken by the Arab League in Cairo this week will be elaborated in further meetings and carried out according to informed Arab sources here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Joint Committee on Labor-Management Relations today invited complaints of specific inequities resulting from operation of the Taft-Hartley law.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 17 -- The political background of the Palestine crisis was more interesting today than any of the day's events. Jewish hostility to the British is rapidly intensifying, with a press campaign accusing the British of complicity with the Arabs to defeat the partition plan.
A hundred persons turned out yesterday to hear Arnold Johnson, legislative director of the. Communist party, speak at a special meeting of the Marxist Study Group at Columbia University.

The annual report of the General Shoe Corporation, for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, mailed to stockholders yesterday, shows net sales of $78,142,458, an increase of 28 per cent over the $61,133,798 volume transacted in the previous year.

Need for much improvement in display techniques employed in average grocery advertisements was brought out yesterday in the color slide presentation by the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, of its More Power in Newspaper Ads, Part 2," before 100 representatives of leading1 advertising organizations at the Hotel Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Diversion of some steel provided for export under the Marshall plan in order to build up an American merchant marine was advocated here today by the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17-The United States agreed today to finance virtually the entire cost of the -British-American occupation of Western Germany, assuming an additional $400,000,000 liability heretofore paid by the British, in return for a controlling voice in the economic affairs of the area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 17 -- Moshe Shertok, chief of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, charged today that the implementation of the United Nations partition plan was being imperiled by the attitude of the British administration in Palestine.

The Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America turned thumbs down yesterday on the proposal of the Progressive Citizens of America to nominate Henry A. Wallace for President. Jacob S. Potofsky, its president, announced that the Amalgamated was opposed to the formation of a national third party in 1948.

Holding that the word "union" in the title of the Tool Owners Union was misleading, Supreme Court Justice Samuel Null denied yesterday an application by the organization to compel the Board of Standards and Appeals of the State Department of Labor to approve a certificate of incorporation to enable operation in this state.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 17 -- Beirut will become the political canter and Damascus, Syria, the military center where decision taken by the Arab League in Cairo this week will be elaborated in further meetings and carried out according to informed Arab sources here.
The Spider and the Fly For mid-Manhattanites there is a mental hazard about going to Brooklyn. It is one to which even our agile city scout is subject, though, long ago, he lived in Brooklyn.

IN Hertfordshire near the town of Hitchin lives a country lawyer of singular wit and charm and pleasant eccentricity. For forty-four years he has practiced law in Hitchin, for the first thirty-five of them with the honorable firm of Messers, Hawkins Co., which was first established in 1591, when good Queen Bess sat on the throne of England.

Ralph H. Tapscott, president of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that the company had completed arrangements with a group of fifteen New Fork banks for a $70,000,000 credit, available until December, 1948.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES May I say a few words in the discussion around the filling of the vacancy caused by the untimely death of my good colleague, Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist?

In the first official report on the London conference, Foreign Secretary Bevin declared yesterday before the House of Commons that the breakdown of Big Four collaboration confronts the Western democracies with grave decisions. "We cannot go on as we have been going on."

DETROIT, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Representative Thomas L. Owens, Republican, of Illinois, was named today to head a House subcommittee to investigate the labor dispute between a number of newspaper publishers and the International Typographical Union.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Truman Doctrine of resisting totalitarianism does not preclude a peace discussion between the President and Premier Stalin, but President Truman said today that such a conference would have to be held in Washington.

Maintaining their contraseasonal advance for more than a month, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the New York City reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System gained $49,000,000 last week to reach another new high of $5,366,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- A brief setting forth the advantages of New Jersey's first parkway, State Route No. 4, in relieving north-south traffic congestion from urban areas of Passaic, Essex and Union Counties, was presented today to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll and legislators by Spencer Miller Jr., State Highway Commissioner.

A hint from a London pal to check a report that Alfred H. Tamarin would make his man-agerial debut with no less ambitious an offering than Sean O'Casey's play, "Red Roses for Me," was confirmed in New York yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A resolution to send all Jewish displaced persons in United States camps in Germany to Palestine before Oct. 1, 1948, was introduced in the House today by Representative Hugh D. Scott Jr., Republican, of Massachusetts, and Representative Andrew L. Somers, Democrat, of New York.
ROME, Dec. 18 -- The United States policy toward Italy was the center of the Constituent Assembly's debate today on Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fifth government.

An undisclosed number of American seamen appeared before a Congressional committee on Tuesday to offer information on Communist efforts to gain control of maritime labor. The session was disclosed here yesterday by some of the seamen, and Representative Willis W. Bradley of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, verified the report in his office in Washington.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Leon Jouhaux, veteran Liberal labor leader, today launched a movement to oust the Communists from power in the General Confederation of Labor. He warned the newly formed anti-Communist labor faction, however, against permitting the issue to split the CGT ranks, which claim 6,000,000 French workers.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Trailing by the score of 38 -- 35 at the end of the first half, the New York Knickerbockers put on a 36-point spurt in the third quarter while holding the Philadelphia Warriors to 10 and defeated Philadelphia, 99-71, in a Basketball Association of America game tonight before 4,018.

Mrs. Harriet Gardiner Lynch Coogan, one of the most important landholders on Manhattan Island, widow of Manhattan's first Borough President, died early yesterday in her suite in the Hotel Biltmore, where she had lived in seclusion the last thirty-two years.

The People's Voice, a Harlem weekly published also as PV, at 210 West 125th Street, was accused yesterday by The Daily Worker of playing the role of "Uncle Tom" to the foes of the Negro people, and of following a policy that would mean one thing -- "that PV is cowering before the witchhunters."

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- British Foreign Secretary Bevin spoke of "taking a grave decision in the face of the world and the future" this afternoon in reporting to Parliament on the breakdown of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- The search for a Governor of Trieste was passed on to Italy and Yugoslavia today. After a three-hour meeting behind closed doors the eleven-nation Security Council decided it had exhausted its list of candidates without agreement and put it up to Italy and Yugoslavia to see whether they could pick a man by Jan. 5.

"Castles in the Air" might well have been the title of the decorative fabric design for which Anne Jarosak of Brooklyn, 18-year-old student at Washington Irving High School, received a $250 scholarship fund from Franco Scalamandre, president of Scalamandre Silks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- With further increases in most major commodity groups, average primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended on Dec. 13, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. At 161.4 per cent of the 1926 average, the bureau's comprehensive index of commodity prices in primary markets was 1.8 per cent above the level of four weeks earlier and 15.5 per cent above a year ago.
Some of the mysterious denizens of the sea will have no more privacy than a household goldfish if current plans of the American Museum of Natural History are carried through.

Charlie Chaplin's production of "Monsieur Verdoux," which was lukewarmly received by most professional critics and the movie-going public, has been voted the best picture of the year in the twenty - second annual poll conducted by the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures, it was announced yesterday.

Plan Drive on Cosmetic Line An aggressive six-month "come-back" campaign, expending an estimated $500,000, will be launched in March for Associated Products, Inc., Chicago, on Chen Yu nail lacquer and lipstick and Cloud Silk cake makeup, it was announced yesterday.
Boston announced yesterday that it would receive bids Monday on $4,000,000 of temporary loan notes dated Dec. 30, 1947, and due Oct. 1, 1948.

Erasmus Hall High School's old academy building, said to be the first secondary school chartered by New York State, will be restored as a museum under an appropriation approved by the Board of Education yesterday in a special meeting.
Three separate delegations called on Henry A. Wallace yesterday in his editorial otfice at the New Republic, 40 East Forty-ninth Street, to urge him to run for President on a third party ticket.

Penny-wise New Yorkers will find bargains in Christmas trees this year if they happen to live on the lower West Side or in the Bronx. Prices for Christmas greenery in other parts of the city vary with a neighborhood's social standing, except in Harlem, where stores are charging all they can get.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial comment "Not Forgetting China," which appeared in your Nov. 25 issue, fails to point out some pertinent facts that should bear considerable weight in making loans to China.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 18 -- The Arabs have again become the aggressive element in Palestine and British troops went into action against them for the first time in a clash reported today.

The so-called "purity code" of strict amateurism for college athletics, adopted in principle by the National Collegiate Athletic. Association a year ago, is doomed to failure, in the opinion of a majority of football writers and coaches participating in the annual season-end Associated Press poll.

The House of Representatives was not supposed to kill interim aid for France, Italy and Austria, and it did not. But a majority of the House members seem to have felt that if interim aid went through unscathed some of their dignity would be lost. They whittled $67,000,000 off the Administration's estimates, which the Senate Republicans had accepted as "substantially accurate."
LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Although brokers found business in the stock markets here today on the small side it was enough to strengthen most sections.
Howard Fast, who had been banned from speaking at four local colleges, finally found a forum yesterday at New York University.

SINYANG, Southern Honan, China, Dec. 18 -- Two-thirds of agriculturally rich Honan, with a total population of 26,000,000 and an area comparable in size to the state of Missouri, is now dominated by Chinese Communists.

Alfred Rheinsteln, former city buildings commissioner, was honored last night with a scroll for distinguished service in engineering by the New York Society of Engineers at a meeting in the auditorium of the Health Building at 125 Worth Street.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18 -- Angered by United States support for the partition of Palestine, the Syrian Parliament is holding up ratification of the agreement for transit rights for an American oil pipeline.

Christinas is the traditional time for reunions of families who for the rest of the year must frequently live with their members widely separated. Sometimes the annual get-together brings back to the family homestead sons and daughters who have grown up, married, and established homes of their own.

A ruling that may enable thousands of small businesses to invoke the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Law has given a small Connecticut beer distributor access to the regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board in this city, it was learned yesterday.

A 28-year-old woman was dead and her 30-year-old husband, a policeman, was in "critical condition in Roosevelt Hospital last night after they had been hit by a passenger bus on Broadway between Forty-fifth and Forty-sixth Streets.

HAVANA, Dec. 18 -- S.L. Holmes, acting chairman of the British delegation at the international conference on trade and employment, denied charges today that the proposed Tariff Committee would be "an exclusive club" that would act as "a sort of ruling oligarchy" of the trade organization that fifty-eight countries are trying to establish here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Members of Congress awaited today disclosure of President Truman's own design for the European Recovery Program which the President is expected to send to the Capitol at noon tomorrow. It will be a voluminous message that will be formally presented to the Senate and House by their respective reading clerks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The value of exports to every continent rose in October as the total value of United States shipments abroad moved up to $1,225,700,000 compared with $1,099,900,000 in September, the Census Bureau reported today.

Employers of workers whose unions have refused to file non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley law received yesterday an amplification of the views of Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, on what their obligations and immunities are under the law.

Plain talk and full praise were in order at the weekly meeting of the New York Hockey Writers Association at Leone's yesterday. The praise was handed out by Lester Patrick, vice president of Madison Square Garden, and the plain talk came from Frank Boucher, who holds the reins as manager of the New York Rangers, the current surprise of the National Hockey League.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Hugh Dalton, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, who resigned Nov. 13 after secret budget information in his possession had appeared in a British newspaper, was in effect cleared today by a Parliamentary Select Committee of premeditated wrongdoing.

A slowing up in the demand for cotton and cotton goods induced a greater amount of liquidation in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, with the result that final prices were off 13 to 37 points.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The United States appeared virtually assured today of a far-above-average wheat crop next year despite drought conditions that handicapped some fall sowing.

The stock market was unable yesterday to make any new gains. A lack of support permitted moderate selling to produce an easier tone. Price changes were confined to fractions, with a few exceptions, and the combined averages fell 0.04 point on the day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Representative Harold Knutson, Republican of Minnesota, introduced today a $5,600,000,000 individual income tax reduction bill, and President Truman almost immediately indicated that he would probably oppose it.

George Szell made his first appearance of the season as guest conductor of the Philharmonic Symphony last night in Carnegie Hall, and he arranged his program in a novel and courageous fashion. For he began with the Third Symphony of Aaron Copland, and ended with the First, by one Johannes Brahms.

"World Communism Today," by Martin Ebon, has been scheduled for Jan. 26 publication by Whittlesey House to coincide "with the 100th anniversary of the publication of Karl Marx's original Communist Manifesto in 1848. The book is a country-by-country survey of Communist parties, including historical background, an analysis of the current aims and policies of world communism and biographical sketches of all important living Communist leaders.

A "National Radio Meeting of the Democratic Party" will be carried by means of transcription over WOR at 11:30 P.M. on Jan. 2 before the opening of Congress. The speakers are scheduled to include Senators Warren Magnuson and Theodore Green;

Stating that Canada's dollar difficulties are not a result of any weakness in her internal economic position, but a reflection of the difficulties of Western Europe in particular, Douglas Abbott, Minister of Finance of Canada, suggested yesterday the production of parts by Canada's automobile industry for sale to America as a possible remedy for the Dominion's dollar shortage.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 18 -- Argentina's proposed aid to the Marshall plan to the amount of $5,000,000,000, as announced by Dr. Diego Luis Molinari in Havana Tuesday, created considerable puzzlement in government and financial circles today.

AUBURN, Ala., Dec. 18 -- A scientific vista in which atomic energy developments, would assist in an unparalleled enrichment of soil for a world now suffering from depleted farmlands and the undernourishment of millions of people was outlined here today by scientists.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- The American Light and Traction Company, a subsidiary of the United Light and Railways Company, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a supplemental application-declaration outlining the terms and conditions upon which it proposes to sell 450,000 shares of common stock of the De troit Edison Company.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 18 -- Senior military officers of four Arab states have left the country on a mission to purchase arms and ammunition as part of the Arab League plan to prevent the inception of the embryonic Jewish state in Palestine. They will visit six countries where they believe weapons are available.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The list of names of the larger speculators in food commodities over the last two years will soon be made public, and for this thanks are due first to Harold E. Stassen and second to the Republican leaders in Congress who cornered the quarry after he uttered his view halloo.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation of "gray market" operations was voted unanimously by the House today to stamp out or expose "conspiratorial practices which seriously undermine and threaten the national economy."

The transfer of Anthony Hintz to Post-Graduate Hospital 303 East Twentieth Street, five days before the boas stevedore died from gunshot wounds, was sharply criticized by a surgical director of St. Vincents Hospital in a letter offered in evidence yesterday during the General' Sessions trial of three men accused of the murder.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Here is the roll-call vote by which the Senate passed, seventy-seven to ten, the Republican anti-inflation bill and sent it to the House:

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Michigan's undefeated Wolerines, Western Conference football champions, were Rose Bowl-ound today for the first time since the late Fielding H. Yost cook a fifteen-man squad-West to defeat Stanford, 49 -- 0, in the 1902 Tournament of Roses.

Aluminum cookware producers will probably follow the lead of Wear-Ever Aluminum Cooking Utensil Company which recently raised prices 5 to 10 per cent on about half of the 100-odd items comprising its line, buyers predicted yesterday.

Voluntary hospitals in Greater New York can cut their operating costs $300,000 a year if permitted to substitute margarine for butter, Dr. John Connorton, executive director of the Greater New York Hospital Association, estimated yesterday.

Hechalutz, the American arm of Histadrut (the Jewish Federation of Labor in Palestine) issued an appeal yesterday for more American youth to go to the Holy Land as pioneers in the new Jewish national state.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Senate adopted unanimously tonight a joint resolution specifically authorizing Clinton P. Anderson, the Secretary of Agriculture, to give to Congress and the public the names of all speculators in grain and other commodities.

Enlargement of the powers of the Port of New York Authority and elimination of multiple inspection of dairy farms were discussed yesterday by Govs. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, Alfred E. Driscoll of New Jersey and James L. McConnaughy of Connecticut at a conference in Mr. Dewey's suite at the Roosevelt Hotel.
ATHENS, Dec, 18 (UP) -- Twenty-one persons convicted of subversive acts were executed today, ten at Salonika and eleven at Volos.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec. 18 -- A giant all-metal glider, which the Army Ground Forces plan to use as a carrier of assault troops or cargo, took to the air here today for the first time. Despite a stiff wind that swept across Mercer Field, at times reaching a velocity of forty miles an hour, the craft handled well both on the ground and in the air.

The postman rings twice this year for those wishing to send holiday messages abroad in time for Christmas, it was announced yesterday. Those who missed the straight mails on holiday messages overseas now have a second opportunity to send them via air mail and have them delivered in ample time, Postmaster Albert Goldman said.

Impact of lower tariffs on wool goods will be felt in the domestic market shortly after the first of the year, it was predicted yesterday. Manufacturers of both men's and women's apparel, making preparations to order fabrics for fall, will have one eye cocked on foreign sources of supply, wool fabric suppliers said, particularly for better grades of woolens and worsteds.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- By agreement with the United States, temporary headquarters of the United Nations here at Lake Success and the General Assembly building at Flushing Meadow received tonight the same extraterritorial freedoms, privileges and rights that have been allotted to the permanent site in mid-Manhattan.

The Board of Estimate sent back to the City Council for reconsideration yesterday a proposed local law passed by that body last week increasing from $1.50 to $10 the annual fee for pistol permits. The measure was sent back after Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn had indicated displeasure with the council's procedure.

When the Silver Jubilee of the City of New York was celebrated in 1923 the only building available, the Grand Central Palace, was considered wholly inadequate for the exposition. Twenty-five years later it is still the only structure of the right type, and is even more inadequate for the proposed Golden Jubilee.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 18 -- A special Federal grand jury indicted ten more persons today as it ended its inquiry into 1946 Kansas City vote frauds. It also handed up a report stating that Roger C. Slaughter, then a member of Congress, did not lose in his bid for renomination because of irregularities at the polls.

The recent purchase of eleven T-2 type tankers from the Maritime Commission by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) was confirmed here yesterday by M.G. Gamble, manager of the company's marine department.

Squadron runs of the New York Yacht Club fleet next summer were announced last night by Commodore De Coursey Fales at the organization's annual meeting, held in the clubhouse, 37 West Forty-fourth Street.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- There is "far more hope" for an Austrian peace settlement as a result of Russian concessions at the meeting of the Foreign Ministers' deputies yesterday, Dr. Karl Gruber, Austrian Foreign Minister, declared today.

Ponchielli's "La Gioconda," which had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is a work of the second or third rank that can be redeemed only when all the principal singers are of the first rank.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Following is a comparison of Federal income tax payments under present law and under the $5,600,000,000 tax reduction bill introduced by Representative Harold Knutson:

Abandonment of many of the restrictive trading procedures of the United Kingdom, except in temporary emergencies, was urged yesterday by the National Foreign Trade Council, as essential to world recovery and continued high economic productivity.

In a letter to Henry H. Curran, former Justice of the Court of Special Sessions,: made public last right, Bishop William T. Manning re-emphasized his opposition to the building of the projected $3,000,000 New York University Law Center on a site facing Washington Square Park.
Nobody had heard of John, Bruce of William and Maryls Southern Conference football champions as a contender for national pass-interception honor's -- until after his last game of the season.

William L. Clayton said yesterday that the United States could restore the economy of western Europe by devoting from 2 to 2 1/2 per cent of its gross national product to the purpose for the next four years. At the same time, he added, Americans could live better than they did before the war.

The two-story loft building at 37-09 Thirty-sixth Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, has been sold by the 37-07 Thirty-sixth Avenue Corporation to the Biro-Wehde Associates, Inc., manufacturer of Flashograph moving message signs.

Cardinal Spellman appealed for funds yesterday to make up the operating deficit of the New York Foundling Hospital as he presided over the annual Christmas party for the hospital in the grand ball-room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. More than 1,000 persons attended.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- The nation's 26,000 high schools should be consolidated into about one-third as many so they could offer broader curriculums to larger groups of students, John W. Studebaker, United States Education Commissioner, asserted today.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Billy Herman, former major league second baseman and manager last season of the Pirates, today announced his retirement from baseball.
