LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 18. The first meeting of the United Nations Palestine Commission has been called for Jan. 7 at Lake Success, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.

Random notes. Gun cranks, smallbore shooters and others interested in rifle and pistol shooting in this general area will be pleased to learn of a new monthly news bulletin which is being published by the Vermont State Rifle and Pistol Association.

The Civil Service Forum delivered yesterday a 600-page accumulation of data to the Welfare Department alleging that the department was Communist-dominated through the influence of the United Public Workers Union, CIO.

The Brooklyn Trust Company will pay a bonus of 6 per cent of salaries received in 1947 to all present employes excepting officers, branch managers and assistant manager, George V. McLaughlin, president announced yesterday.
C. Barry Mead, architect, died yesterday in his home, 25 East Eighty-sixth Street. He was 65 years old on Wednesday.

The acquisition of the building at 30 West Forty-fourth Street for use as a center for Manhattan units of the Organized Reserve Corps of the Army was announced yesterday by Col. S.L. Kiser, acting officer-in-charge of the New York-New Jersey-Delaware Military District of First Army.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for toddy:

The price housewives will pay for Christinas turkeys has yet to be announced, but the cost of the other foods that will play important roles in holiday meals is expected to be the same next week as it is today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Truman made public today Charles Luckman's final report on the work of the Citizens Food Committee, setting its grain-savings at a 95,000,000-bushel minimum and a 121,000,000-bushel maximum.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Department, store sales in the week ended Dec. 13 were 10 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Refusal of the United States to accept offers of the Greek Leftist Partisans for a peaceful settlement within their country "has forced the Greek people into civil war, according to an Interview purported to have been given by Gen. Markos Vatiades, guerrilla leader, which is to be published tomorrow by Humanite, French Communist newspaper.

Governor Dewey declared yesterday that the people of Italy "shook off the brutal yoke of Fascist totalitarianism only to find themselves menaced by the forces of Communist totalitarianism." He predicted, however, that Communist intrigues will be defeated.
New Yorkers can expect no help from the Weather Man this winter in taking the sting out of fuel-short days and nights.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- During the week ended Dec. 17 member bank reserve balances increased $449,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Negotiations between Washington newspaper publishers and the Columbia Typographical Union were reported at a critical stage today, with the next move up to the printers who have scheduled a meeting for Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The House vote today ordering an investigation of commodity market speculation came under a resolution sponsored by Representative August H. Andresen, Republican, of Minnesota, to deal with all Government operations in commodity markets and with the activities of individuals "in connection with the purchase or sale of commodities."

The recovery of $80,000 worth at merchandise, which was stolen from aten-ton truck early Tuesday morning, and the arrest of eight men on charges of grarid larceny in connection with the theft was announced yesterday by the Safe and Loft Squad at Manhattan Police Headquarters.

"Deck the Halls," "Silent Night" and other Christmas carols will be sung by the Glee Club of Public School 60 at a concert for young people at Town Hall tomorrow at 11 A.M. Leon Barzin will conduct the New York Philharmonic Symphony in a program which will include demonstrations of stringed instruments.

Bobby Riggs, world professional tennis champion, regards Jack Kramer, top-ranking amateur of 1947 and his opponent in the exhibition tour that gets under way at Madison Square Garden, Dec. 26, as a greater player than Don Budge.
CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The 1,500 striking members of the Chicago Local of the International Typographical Union have been denied unemployment compensation.

Three members of the bench in the Second Judicial District doff their robes at the end of this month in compliance with the constitutional edict that none may serve past the year in which he attains the age of 70. Two are Supreme Court Justices, Edwin L. Garvin and Charles C. Lockwood.

A sharp but apparently seasonal decline in the number of dwelling units put under construction by private builders in the city during November was reported yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- The Bi - zonal Economic Council, by a vote of 49 to 2, refused today to rule out future participation in the creation of a West German state, although it adopted a resolution by the same vote emphatically denying that any effort in that direction had been made by its members thus far.

THE All-America Conference has concluded its draft of college seniors for future delivery and the National Football League will go through the same operation at Pittsburgh today. Then the battle will begin in earnest. It will be a battle of dollars as each circuit attempts to woo its draft choices by flashing large and attractive wads of bills in front of their eager young faces.

Americans of Jewish faith were urged last night by former Governor, Herbert Lehman to take the leadership in helping to make the new Jewish state in Palestine "economically and spiritually self-sufficient."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There was an interesting editorial in THE TIMES not long ago on the desirability of having more trees in our city. The editorial expressed the hope that the builders of large apartment communities would not neglect the opportunity to plant both trees and flowering shrubs.

Skiing remains limited, although good for this time of the season, in the North Country where reports yesterday indicated that preparations are being made for a record influx of enthusiasts during the Christmas holiday period.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- National Guard Army units soon will receive large increases in assigned equipment, in relation to their growth since post-war reorganization of the guard, it was announced here today by Maj. Gen. Kenneth F. Cramer, Chief of the National Guard Bureau.

Four New Yorkers who no doubt long ago were sure that Santa Claus never existed had their confidence shaken yesterday, when Mr. Claus, through Police Property Clerk Frank Leuci, handed them various items ranging from a diamond ring to $700 in cash.

ROME, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Ten persons were reported wounded in a gun battle in front of Palermo's city hall tonight in the first major violence in Sicilian city general strikes. At the same time, a nation-wide walkout of 300,000 food workers was ordered to begin five days before Christmas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Senate passed a slightly revised Republican anti-inflation resolution today, seventy-seven to ten, and sent it to the House where leaders immediately undertook extraordinary measures to complete action before the Christmas adjournment tomorrow night.

Coming up with a conservative spring training program reminiscent of the days when Ed Barrow and Joe McCarthy directed the affairs of the establishment, the Yankees yesterday announced a thirty-nine-game exhibition schedule for 1948 that includes none of the global gyrations of the MacPhailian era.
In the last six weeks a new scheme for relieving the austerity of life in the British Isles has been adopted by thousands of families here, a survey showed yesterday.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 18 (AP) -- El Mono, belonging to D. Lament, made his Florida debut in the featured Ojus Purse at Gulfstream Park today and stepped six furlongs in the clever time of 1:10 3-5 to beat eight rivals.

A "heavy" welterweight will fight a middleweight at Madison Square Garden tonight, but the affair does not promise to be a mismatch at all. Tommy Bell of Youngstown, Ohio, is the welter-weight and his opponent will be Steve Belloise, the Bronx gladiator who has been the perennial challenger for the world 160-pound title for more years than he cares to admit.
Laxity in enforcing the daytime ban on the parking of passenger automobiles in midtown Manhattan is contributing markedly to the city's traffic woes, a survey showed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Edmund Beloin is writing a photo-play at Paramount under the title "Diamond in the Haystack" as a vehicle for Bing Crosby and Barry Fitzgerald, the studio disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The weakest point in German occupation by United States forces is the belief prevalent in Europe that this country will not remain there long enough to finish its job, in the unanimous view of twelve editors who returned here today from a tour of the occupied areas.

A round of holiday festivities started in the city yesterday. They ranged from parties for underprivileged and handicapped youngsters to Yuletide celebrations for disabled veterans. The pre-Christmas parties were focused primarily on those who might have had no seasonal joy were it not for the spirit of good-will that made individuals and organizations alike remember those less fortunate.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 18 -- Defense attorneys in the trial of I.G. Farben executives here moved vigorously to the offensive today, in their opening statements on behalf of their clients. One of the most striking claims made was an assertion by Dr. Gustave Siemers, representing Georg von Schnitzler, that the trials of German industrialists were not directed against individuals but fundamentally against the whole German capitalism and economy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A suggestion of rapprochement between organized labor and the Congress which passed the Taft-Hartley law appeared today when a committee chairman and a labor leader announced cooperative measures to produce more houses.

American Machine Metals American Machine and Metals, Inc. announced yesterday that the board took no action on a common dividend. The only payment this year was 25 cents in June, while in 1946 25 cents was disbursed in each quarter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Attorney General Clark has included the name of the Jefferson School, as well as those of other sincerely democratic organizations, in his list of "subversives." To answer his "name-calling" only by our denials would merely put our word against his.

ALBANY, Dec. 18 -- Appointment of Eugene L. Brisach, Republican, of the Bronx, assistant New York City corporation counsel, as a justice of the Supreme Court, First Judicial District, was announced today by Governor Dewey.

Vina Barnden, Australian pianist, made her American debut in a recital given last night at Times Hall. The youthful artist, who has concertized extensively in her own country and England, was heard in a program which featured the "Tobruk" Sonata by her compatriot, Miriam Hyde, and also included works by Beethoven, Chopin, Ravel, Debussy, Granados and de Falla.

A funeral service for Gen. Edward J. Higgins, who was international commander of the Salvation Army from 1929 to 1934, was held yesterday morning at the Centennial Memorial Temple, 120 West Fourteenth Street. The general died Sunday in Summit, N.J.

A proposal by the New York Life Insurance Company to construct a 1,400 to 2,000-car parking garage to occupy the entire block just south of a nineteen-story garden apartment building it plans to erect in the Yorkville section of Manhattan was submitted yesterday to the Board of Estimate.
An Englishman visiting in this country sent a donation of $260 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund to cover Case 104.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Club owners of the National Football League will meet here tomorrow for their annual player draft but the confab may air problems more vexing than building for next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Federal taxes on passenger fares and freight rates, adopted as a wartime measure, are likely to have some harmful effects in the future, a Treasury study said tonight.

OTTAWA, Dec. 18 -- After nearly a month of hard negotiation, the renewal of the Canadian-United Kingdom food contracts, with neccseary adjustments, was announced today by Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- As soon as Foreign Minister Bidault returned from the London conference today, the French Foreign Office started putting the brakes on the merger of the three western zones of Germany.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, CIO, today repudiated Henry Wallace as an independent candidate for President in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Thomas Jefferson Coolidge of Boston, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, will head a committee to study "overlaps in administration, taxation and grants in aid between Federal and state Government" for the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government, headed by Herbert Hoover.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Truman appointed today the personnel of the National Labor-Management Panel created by the Taft-Hartley Law.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- The fear of a collapse in farm prices such as the country's farmers suffered after World War I was evident today as the American Farm Bureau Federation outlined a comprehensive farm program at the conclusion of its twenty-ninth annual meeting.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Grain traders generally placed a bullish construction on a Department of Agriculture estimate issued today that only 838,705,000 bushels of winter wheat would be harvested next year, based on conditions prevailing on Dec. 1, or about 230,000,000 bushels under the record crop grown last summer.
PARIS, Dec. 18 -- In the name of the people of France, President Vincent Auriol thanked the people of the United States today for their Friendship Train gifts of food.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 -- Scientists exploring human endurance at the University of California have survived fourteen and onehalf minutes' exposure to temperatures up to 250 degrees Fahrenheit, 38 degrees above boiling, it was disclosed today.

Harold Borg has been elected president-treasurer of the Rainseth Umbrella Company, Inc. Until recently he was president-secretary of the King Novelty Company, Inc., and secretary-treasurer of King Plastics Corporation.

HONOLULU, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The 7,176-ton freighter Simon Benson, which struggled through a stormy night in the North Pacific with plates split and water pouring Into her cargo of swelling rice, was proceeding slowly toward Honolulu late today with everything under control.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- The improvements in Britain's economic position in recent months were cited to the House of Common's today by Sir Stafford Cripps in the opening of debate on the Government's program for curbing expenditures on capital investments.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 18 -- This is the first major city to rebuild and to try to make itself depression-proof, fifteen leading executives in civic, industrial, research, mining, banking and retailing revealed here today at a luncheon meeting at the Duquesne Club.

Guerrilla warfare in Greece could be stopped in ninety days by the simple expedient of arming Greek civilians, William Helis, president of the Greek War Relief Association, declared on his arrival here yesterday on the Italian liner Vulcania.

The Federal Government will make a new effort this afternoon to avert a strike of 50,000 Western Union telegraph workers. Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, will meet in Washington with representatives of the company and three American Federation of Labor unions, which have scheduled a strike for 6 A. M. Tuesday.
WASHINGTON Dec 18 (AP) -- A plea for an end to "back scratching and porkbarreling" in building homes for veterans was made today by James F. O'Neil, national commander of the American Legion.
Charles Stewart has been appointed to aid in the supervision and coordination of production activities by the National Fastener Corporation, makers of National Slide Fasteners.

BERLIN, Dec. 18 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, returned from London tonight, determined to make the bi-zonal merger work, as an object lesson to both the Germans and the Russians. He was equally determined that there should he no partitioning of Germany so far as United States initiative went.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee voted late tonight to recommend that Congress approve $570,000,000 to finance the emergency foreign relief program. This total included $20,000,000 for China. The rest would go to France, Italy and Austria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 18 -- Despite Soviet objections, the working committee of the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission agreed today that a separate group, the control committee, should go ahead with its work on the structure of the proposed international atomic control agency when it reconvenes next January.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 18 -- Students of Seton Hall College heard a talk on the new fashions today given by Miss Virginia Pope, fashion editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. The meeting in the auditorium, attended by 400 men students, was arranged by Frank McNally, editor in chief of the undergraduate paper.

Official observance of the Christmas holiday season in the city began yesterday at 5 P.M. when 5-year-old Rory O'Dwyer, nephew of Mayor O'Dwyer and son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul O'Dwyer, threw the switch that lighted the sixty-foot tree in City Hall Park.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Evidence that a prompt cure of undulant fever was obtained through the combined use of streptomycin and sulfadiazine -- after each proved ineffectual alone -- was reported today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

LONDON, Saturday, Dec. 20 -- Admiration and gratitude for the European Recovery Program presented by President Truman are expressed today by editorials in British newspapers. With the President's message has begun what the independent London Times calls a "new page in American and world history" and the liberal News Chronicle "one of the most important and ambitious schemes in history."

A campaign to raise $500,000 in New York for a program of education and research in the diseases of the heart, number one killer of mankind, was announced yesterday at the New York Academy of Medicine by the New York Heart Association.

PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Ten days after the end of the Communist-promoted strikes, Leon Jouhaux, veteran anti-Communist labor leader, split France's organized labor ranks wide open today by resigning from the General Confederation of Labor, of which he was secretary general for thirty-seven years.

The stock market resumed the advance yesterday and, with gains of 1 to 3 points in some key issues, closed at the best levels of the session. The best volume was in the final hour. President Truman's announcement of the long-range Marshall plan coincided with the closing spurt.

The Educational Testing Service, a new corporation to promote research and further development of scientific educational measurement and appraisal, received an absolute charter yesterday by the State Board of Regents meeting in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The House briskly passed the Senateapproved anti-inflation resolution without change today and sent it to the White House. The vote was 281 -- 73.

The text of Secretary of State Marshall's broadcast to the nation last night from Washington on the results of the meeting in London of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, as transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES: The result of the recent meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in London was disappointing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Demolition work on the site of the future capital of the United Nations has been abruptly curtailed as a result of court action instituted by two East River tenants seeking a stay of eviction.
Without handing down an opinion, the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court upheld yesterday the contention of an automobile owner that the State Commercial Rent Control laws apply, to private garages.

For sixty-one years, ever since 1886, the sale of margarine has been conducted under the handicap of restrictive and discriminatory law. Dairy and farm interests, affecting a tearful and altruistic concern for the consumer's welfare, have managed to block at almost every step the efforts made through the years to lift this yoke laid down in federal and state law.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 19 -- The United States military tribunal today again denied the application of Alfred Krupp to engage as his defense counsel the services of Earl J. Carroll of Hayward, Calit. Mr. Carroll will fly to Washington next week to initiate a test in the courts there of the validity of the military tribunals now operating in Nuremberg.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- An improved apparatus to locate submarines was one of 483 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Shanghai Newspaper Guild today ordered ruinous cuts in paper supplies for the American-owned PostMercury and the British-owned North China Daily News, which have been sharply critical of the Central Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In publishing my letter on Soviet foreign policy in your Nov. 30 issue, for which I am truly thankful, some editorial cutting seems to have been necessary for reasons of space. Unfortunately, it made my argument a bit incoherent toward the end.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- J. Arthur Rank, Britain's leading film producer, faced stockholders of his Odeon Theatre chain today and won their unanimous approval of a proposal to purchase the General Cinema Finance Corporation, in which he also is a heavy stockholder.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered all the early losses yesterday and closed at about the best levels of the day, or 22 to 29 points net higher.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has notified advertisers of two major changes in its contracts so that the network itself may be assured of the final voice in determining the pattern of its program structure. The first change provides for withdrawal of the provision for automatic renewal of contracts.

PASCAGOULA, Miss., Dec. 19 -- Miss Arrol Elaine Wright, daughter of Gov. Fielding Wright, popped a bottle of champagne over the bow of the Loide-Venezuela here this afternoon to send the hundredth ship built by the Ingalls Shipbuilding Corporation down the ways.
A 38-year-old father of six children was arrainged yesterday in mid-Manhattan Court on a charge of obtaining relief from the Department of Welfare by fraud.

St. John's, which finally entered the winner's circle by defeating Iona College at its home gymnasium the other night, draws a strong opponent tonight in the feature of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

DETROIT, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, working with confidence and precision, scored a technical knockout over challenger Chuck Taylor of Coalport, Pa., at 2 minutes and 7 seconds of the sixth round at Olympia Stadium tonight.

The average American citizen still loves to watch the ponies run but he either has turned a bit conservative when it comes to parting with his cash or it just isn't as plentiful as it once was, 1947 figures from the nation's leading race tracks showed yesterday.

Prices of almost all high tinbearing bronze ingots were raised 1/2 cent to 3 cents a pound above recent levels, pending on tin content, metal refiners reported here yesterday. This action reflects the recent rise in price of British tin to 93 cents a pound and the United States Metal Reserve Corporation tin price of 94 cents a pound for sales here by this agency, industry members declared.

Capturing firsts in five of the eight events, Evander Childs retained its city P.S.A.L. dual meet swimming crown by defeating Richmond Hill, 43 to 24, in the Brooklyn Tech pool yesterday. The teams are co-holders of the city P.S.A.L. individual crown.

Harry Pechter, vice president of the Pechter Baking Company, Inc., and two attorneys were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of extortion arising from a transaction with an employe of the company.
Friday, Dec. 19, 1947 The President Sent a message recommending $17,000,000,000 European Recovery Program to Congress.

A complete overhauling of the State military law to enable the National Guard to make adequate plans to cope with a major disaster and to put such plans into effect should occasion arise is needed urgently in the opinion of a special National Guard committee that has studied the subject, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Authority for United States Government underwriting of private American investments in European production facilities was proposed today in an Administration draft of proposed legislation accompanying President Truman's request for $17,000,000,000 to finance the Marshall plan.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Congress approved today and President Truman immediately signed a measure directing Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, to stand ready to supply the names of "all traders" on the commodities exchanges.

Police Commissioner Wallander is to be commended for calling into conference representatives of trucking organizations and labor leaders, to enlist their cooperation in the traffic problem, which steadily becomes more serious in this city. It is encouraging to learn that the conferees were openminded with regard to two of the Commissioner's proposals -- namely, the establishment of transfer depots outside of congested areas and the use of smaller trucks within those areas.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The American Federation of Labor's foreign policy was discussed with President Truman today by a committee of its leaders. They described efforts being made to enlist support of the trade unions in the sixteen countries which would benefit from the European Recovery Program.

Barrie Stavis' new play, "Lamp at Midnight," will be given tomorrow night at 8 o'clock in the New Stages Theatre at 159 Bleecker Street. It will be the first bill of New Stages, Inc., a producing outit organized by almost one hundred theatre professionals to put on works that do not fall into the conventional Broadway pattern.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- Britain has saved herself an outlay of $120,000,000 and relieved the strain on United States food resources through the conclusion of a wheat deal with Australia, John Strachey. Minister of Food, told the House of Commons today.
ROME, Dec. 19 -- The Constituent Assembly showed its confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fifth government tonight by a vote of 303 to 118, with fourteen abstentions.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Political emphasis has switched quickly in London from the failure of the peacemakers to the European Recovery Program. There has been more talk about the Marshall Plan since the Conference ended, before and since the last of the Foreign Ministers departed, than in months before.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The State Department announced today that at the request of the United Kingdom a section dealing with rubber of the general agreement on trade and tariffs that was recently negotiated at Geneva, Switzerland, was being suspended pending renegotiation.
As has been their custom for many years, a group of students of Horace Mann School for Boys visited THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday to offer their annual gift to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Here is an itemized list of commodities which the United States would send abroad under the Marshall plan:

SEOUL, Korea, Dec 19 -- Growing resentment among the people of Northern Korea was reported here today over the Soviet authorities' confiscation of money and the failure of the puppet Government to inform the 9,000,000 inhabitants of the Soviet occupation zone as to the exchange rate of the old currency for the new.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Deputy Police Chief Frank O'Neil, in command of the Newark Detective Bureau, said tonight that an eightstate teletype alarm has been sent out for Ralph Cordasco, 50 years old, wanted here in connection with the murder of his estranged wife, Mrs. Rose Cordasco, 38, of 7 Clifton Avenue.

Venezuela, one of the nearest neighbors of the United States in Latin America, was long notorious for bloody and destructive civil wars, for "peace" so precarious as to be hardly distinguishable from anarchy, for irresponsible dictatorships that lived and perished by the sword.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore, in a move to provide for early payment of state veterans' bonuses, today invited subscriptions for $100,000,000 in war bonus notes bearing interest at the rate of eight-tenths of 1 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The resolution of the United Nations General Assembly condemning genocide was a real revolution in international law, in that it tries to reconcile the interests of all human beings everywhere with the principle of sovereignty, Dr. Rafael Lemkin, United Nations adviser on genocide, said today.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 19 -- Seton Hall's basketball team, enjoying what appeared to be a fairly comfortable advantage at half time, was forced to go all out tonight before administering a 60 to 52 setback to Loyola of Baltimore.

PANAMA, Dec. 19 -- The special committee of the National Assembly acting on the agreement of the United States and Panama for use of defense bases for protection of the Panama Canal, reported tonight in favor of reservations that are considered in some quarters equivalent to calling for rejection of the pact.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- By a 9-to-2 vote, the Soviet Union today lost an attempt to prevent debate on a possible veto modification conference between the United Nations Security Council and the new "Little Assembly." The vote came in the Council and found only Poland supporting the Soviet Union.

Speaking of Beverages He said he had been reminded by the current price of drinks of a time when the sale of such things was forbidden by law and people were invited to consume, instead, other things politely described as beverages.

Since the Soviet Government operates on the theory that if an idea is repeated often enough it will ultimately gain acceptance, however thin its merits, it is necessary to point once more to the real responsibility for failure in the United Nations to reach agreement in the immensely important question of control of atomic energy.

Spotty Trend in Gift Buying Several larger department stores here continued to report excellent holiday trade this week. Others were disappointed with both dollar and unit volume. Estimates of average gains for the city ranged from 10 to 25 per cent over the like week of last year.

Robert E. McCormick of 1 Beekman Place gave a supper dance last night at the River Club for his debutante daughter, Miss Shirley McCormick. The debutante, a provisional member of the Junior League, attended the Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, Conn., and the Garrison Forest School in Maryland, and is studying at the Garland School in Boston.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Truman, as Commander-inChief of the Armed Forces, today headed a long list of ranking military personages who sent Christmas greetings to the members of the services at home and overseas.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, reported a net drop of 2,313 in the city's relief caseload yesterday as he made public his first comprehensive report covering the period between Nov. 1 and Dec. 6.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Debt reduction by the Federal Government of more than $11,000,000,000 in the last fiscal year, ended on June 30, brought about the first drop in general public debt in many years despite some sharp increases in 1947 in debts contracted by the states, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The House today voted $25,000 to finance an investigation of the so-called "gray market" in scarce materials.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Advice to the housewife on how to keep a maid has been outlined from a Women's Bureau study o household employment programs in nineteen cities.

For more than sixty of his seventyeight years Ludolf Buhr has barbered in this city, but yesterday it became apparent he would have to take a test to stay in business. Furthermore, to qualify for the test he must report on Monday with a tonsorial guinea pig -- a man with full head of hair and beard, willing to submit to anything Mr. Buhr's examiners decide must be done.

In a message to Congress yesterday which will take its place among the historic papers of the United States, President Truman submitted the fullfledged Marshall Plan to Congress and dealt with its implications in terms of security and freedom. "The next two years," he declared, "can determine whether the free countries of Europe will be able to preserve their heritage of freedom.

ALL critics and columnists are immensely grateful to Brooks Atkinson of this paper for his development of the Atkinsonian Gambit. He uses it just about once a year. It consists, of course, in writing a full Sunday column explaining in guileless and wildly persuasive detail just why there will not be a column that day.

Poultry of all sorts is being offered for the holidays, everything from a lowly stewing hen to a proud -- and very expensive -- pheasant. Geese are abundant for the first time in several seasons; if unavailable locally they may be ordered readily through a dealer.

The police of eight states were asked yesterday to be on the lookout for a 17-year-old Queens high school student who rode away on his pet horse on Wednesday because he preferred to give more of his attention to the animal than to his homework in chemistry.

HAVANA, Dec. 19 -- Charging that the original list had been stacked against them, the economically undeveloped countries that form the numerical majority of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today forced changes in the composition of a subcommittee on new preferential tariff arrangements.

ATHENS, Dec. 19 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis told Parliament tonight that the "darts hurled against the coalition Government are made of paper." This was his way of announcing that no Cabinet crisis was imminent and that all was well with a government that is known to be divided on vital issues.

The Liquid Carbonic Corporation reported yesterday in its annual statement to stockholders a consolidated net profit for the year ended on Sept. 30 or $2,002,830 after all charges, including $1,200,000 provision for taxes.
The following are among the special programs of Christmas music arranged by the city's churches for tomorrow, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day:

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Establishment of tripartite "development councils" for consumer goods industries is under consideration by the British Government, Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, told a press conference today.

Westchester County's Charter, adopted ten years ago after comprehensive study, requires that a public hearing on the county budget be conducted each winter by the Board of Supervisors before adoption of the budget. The phraseology makes clear an intent to establish a democratic process that would permit taxpayers to discuss all fiscal operations with the officials.
Tommy Bell stepped out of his class last night in the year's final boxing show in Madison Square Garden, and bit off more than he could chew.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Truman turned the arrival of Secretary of State Marshall at the National Airport today into a demonstration of solidarity and endorsement of the course he had followed at the London Conference of Foreign Ministers.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 19 -- "The Saintly Miss Peters," a screen comedy by William Roberts which Metro-Goldwin-Mayer purchased last September as a vehicle for Katharine Hepburn, has been switched to Greer Garson's schedule, the studio announced today.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Saturday, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Martial law was declared here today as Communist troops infiltrated to within twentyone miles of this Nationalist stronghold and put it under a virtual state of siege.

An effort to chop down the high price of Christmas trees was undertaken locally yesterday by the Laundry Workers Joint Board with the sale of several hundred Vermontgrown trees to union members at $1.10.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Congress adjourned tonight with President Truman's European Recovery Program officially in its custody. It will be high on the agenda when the next regular session convenes at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Hearings will begin before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on Jan. 7.

TOKYO, Dec. 19 -- Shigenori Togo, Foreign Minister in Japan's Pearl Harbor Cabinet, testified today before the International Military Tribunal that he had been threatened by one of his twentyfour fellow defendants in an attempt to persuade him to suppress evidence that the Japanese Navy favored an attack on Hawaii in December, 1941, without warning to the United States.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- In a reversal of policy, the Westchester County Realty Board went on record today in favor of continuance of rent control in Westchester for a year after the scheduled expiration on Feb. 29. This in opposition to most real estate board theory elsewhere.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Although trading in the stock markets here today was on a small scale, most groups continued firm.

WASHINGTON, Dec., 19 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board granted about $391,000 additional mail pay to All American Aviation, Inc., today, but coupled it with an expression of "grave concern" over the rising coat of the service in relation to public benefit.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 19 -- Sources close to Fawzi el Kawukji, commander of the Arab "People's Army," said at Damascus today that the first of the guerrilla units now being formed would be sent across the frontier into Palestine soon after Christmas.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- Rodman Keenon, owned by F.J. DeMary, won the featured Toy Bowl Purse at the Fair Grounds today. Second in the mile-and-sixteenth race was Big Brother, with Russian Valor third. The victor paid $6.20 for $2.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- German officials of the United States-British combined zones of occupation would like a West German state set up, although they would not call it that, but they are trying to avoid the responsibility entailed in its development.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, AFL, claimed a legal victory yesterday in its efforts to bring the Harold Levinsohn Corporation, manufacturers of women's suits, before Sol A. Rosenblatt, impartial arbitrator of the industry, on a charge of contract violation.

A more cautious tendency in bidding on cotton textiles, noted in the primary markets during the last few days, is attributed to a normal pre-Christmas letdown and not to any marked falling off of demand, according to Worth Street sources yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Showing good mud-running ability, Valley View Farm's Superwolf was up to beat six rivals in the Indian River Purse at Gulfstream Park today.
While several department stores here are doing the largest Christmas volume in their history, spottiness has nevertheless marked holiday shopping this week.

The Chinese people under Communist domination probably have better food, clothing and shelter than they do in the Nationalist areas, two American women medical workers, who have just returned from China, said at the office of the China Aid Council here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- President Truman asked Congress today to authorize a 1948-51 European Recovery Program costing $17,000,000,000 to halt the march of "selfish totalitarian aggression" and to maintain a civilization in which the American way of life is rooted.
MILLBURN, N.J., Dec. 19 -- A Christmas party was combined with the cornerstone placing ceremony this evening at the Lord Taylor branch store under construction at Millburn and Wyoming Avenues here.

A suit to bar the City Rent Commission from acting on an application for rent increases at the Marcy Hotel, 720 West End Avenue, was filed in Federal Court yesterday by a group of tenants. The suit contended that the rooms occupied by the plaintiffs were subject to Federal rent controls, and could not therefore come within the commission's jurisdiction.

HANKOW, China, Dec. 19 -- Traffic along the entire 725 miles of the Peiping-Hankow line, China's most important railway, has been completely disrupted by the spread of the civil war from the Yellow River into the Yangtze Valley.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 19 -- The signing of a treaty of friendship, collaboration and mutual assistance between Yugoslavia and Rumania was announced today before a cheering, flag-waving crowd of more than 100,000 who stood in a heavy snowstorm to salute Marshal Tito, Yugoslav Premier.
Springfield, Mass., sold yesterday $1,600,000 of veterans' housing bonds due Dec. 1 from 1948 to 1957 to Whiting, Weeks Stubbs and associates at a bid of 101.08 for 1 1/2 s.

DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 19 -- The barking of a dog and the meowing of a cat were credited by the police here today with saving the lives of nine persons overcome by leaking sewer gas while they slept here in a two-family house at 14 Main Street.

AUBURN, Ala., Dec. 19 -- A bellringing rose, phosphorous-filled rabbit and a sleek greyhound whose delight at receiving radioactive injections induced furious tail-wagging all brought laughter and interest today to 250 scientists discussing atomic energy.
ITHACA, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Cornell launched its Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League schedule by defeating Yale, 52 -- 46, before a crowd of 6,000 tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 -- The nature of the Federal inquiry into possible vote frauds in three Eastern Missouri counties will probably become known next month when the regular session of the Federal Grand Jury convenes, but authorities today refused comment.

SYDNEY, Australia Dec. 19 (AP) -- Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister of External Affairs, called today for the settlement of the German question by the democratic methods of the United Nations General Assembly.

ALBANY, Dec. 19 -- State Superintendent of Public Works Charles H. Sells announced today plans for a $20,600,000 network of state-financed urban arterial highways and connections in Binghamton and the triple cities area.
PARIS, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- President Truman's message to Congress asking for approval of the European Recovery Program was warmly welcomed today in responsible quarters here.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Vigorous opposition to increases in freight rates that would be greater in the Northeastern section of the country than in the other sections was expressed today by Parker McCollester, representing the Associated Industries of the State of New York and others.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Here is the House vote passing the voluntary price curb bill:

Jerome C. Mayer, New York operator, has acquired from the Elda Realty Corporation for cash over a mortgage of $35,000 the apartment and store structures at 68-74 Main Street and 4-10 Greenwood Avenue, northeast corner of Main Street and Greenwood Avenue, East Orange, N.J.

Gift-laden youngsters hurrying home from parties were as plentiful yesterday as gift-laden shoppers, as the last week-end before Christmas began. The sick and needy, the blind, the handicapped, the hospitalized -- all these found their names on Christmas present and party lists.

Christmas carols began chiming out at noon yesterday over the metropolitan area from what is believed to be the most powerful musical instrument in the world, situated on the eighty-sixth floor of the Empire State Building.

The New York Giants of 1947 produced a new addition of "Artists and Models" -- slugging artists with Louisville Slugger model bats -- when five of Mel Ott's heavy swingers emerged from the pennant race with a total of 1,300 bases.

Football's unlimited substitution rule, after a year's trial, has earned a 2-to-1 favoring vote from writers, coaches and athletic directors answering the annual seasonend poll conducted by The Associated Press.
Merry Christmas Land, an exposition of Yuletide attractions including exhibits, rides and stage and circus shows, opens today at the Grand Central Palace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Congress approved tonight, as its last act of the reconvened session, a $540,000,000 appropriation for emergency, communism-combating relief abroad.

The United States Conference of Mayors is planning to endow a chair in municipal government in the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University as a memorial to the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 -- The Department of Agriculture's estimate of the winter wheat crop to be harvested next summer, issued late yesterday, showed a yield well above what many operators anticipated and led to general selling today at the opening on the Chicago Board of Trade.

Contract negotiations between towboat owners and workers over the last few weeks have been unproductive and the possibility of a harbor-crippling tug strike on Jan. 1 is causing considerable concern in the shipping industry, it was learned yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- High incomes and the profits of farmers and merchants would be hit by the Schuman Cabinet's anti-inflation program set before the National Assembly today.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 19 -- Ten Arabs, reported to include five small children, were killed and five injured during the night in a Haganah reprisal raid which, it was feared today, would start a new wave of bloodshed in Palestine.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 (AP) -- New communal rioting has broken out in India, with sixty-five persons killed in the city of Ajmer and three killed and more than fifteen injured in the old city of Delhi, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- Three American Federation of Labor unions late tonight abruptly changed the date of the scheduled Christmas-season telegraph strike and ordered their 50,000 members to be ready to walk out "at any time," Federal Labor officials said.

"American Foreign Service," by J. Rives Childs, our present Minister to Saudi Arabia, has been scheduled for publication on Jan. 19 by Henry Holt. Mr. Childs, who has been in the consular service since 1925, traces the service from its beginnings under Benjamin Franklin, John Adams and John Jay up to the present.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- Panama and Denmark today named their representatives on the United Nations Palestine Commission, which is to help carry out the partition of the Holy Land.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- An embargo on fuel oil exports or at least their sharp curtailment until domestic shortages are met was recommended unanimously today by the House Commerce Committee.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Official reports show Kentucky burley tobacco growers have hit a jackpot in pre-Christmas sales ending today in sharp contrast with last December's auctions. Final pre-holiday sales today with a money return like that reported for yesterday would give the state's burley growers a total preChristmas income approaching $100,000,000.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 19 -- To the surprise of no one, the New York Giants designated a halfback as their first choice in the National Football League draft tonight: Because of their last-place standing, the Giants, following Washington's "bonus pick," had first choice and selected Tony Minisi of the University of Pennsylvania.

Sherman Billingsley, proprietor of the Stork Club, voluntarily appeared yesterday before the Grand Jury to give his version of a charge that he had paid one of his dishwashers $600 to offer testimony in his behalf before a state unfair labor practice hearing.

WHITMAN, Mass., Dec. 19 -- The 632 employes of the Regal Shoe Company plant, members of the Brotherhood of Shoe and Allied Craftsmen, an independent union, voted today to go on strike Monday as a result of a company announcement of open-shop operations.

Members of the New York City Council now are awakening to the fact that they stirred up a real hornet's nest when they approved the measure calling for an increase in the pistol permit fee from $1.50 to $10.

An educational campaign aimed at curbing rising freight damage claims against railroads will be started early next year by the Shipping Container Institute, E.J. Gross, institute managing director, disclosed yesterday. The project is an outgrowth of a recent institute study on the causes of damage to packaged goods in transit, findings of which indicate faulty loading by shippers of fiber-board containers to be the chief loss factor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 19 -- This country's wartime surplus of oil tankers, which numbered 481 when the fighting ended, has been disposed of despite the fact that nine months ago tankers were a drug on the market, it was revealed here today by Vice Admiral W.W. Smith, chairman of the Maritime Commission.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The message sent by President Truman to Congress on the Marshall plan read as follows:

Regulation of the insurance industry by enactment of "antimonopoly" legislation within the states is deemed contrary to the public interest by Edward L. Williams, president of the Insurance Executives Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19 -- The Middle West Corporation's application for authority to sell all outstanding capital stock of the Oklahoma Power and Water Company, a subsidiary, to the Public Service Company of Oklahoma was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers and a former associate who turned on him were indicted today on charges of giving false testimony at a recent Senate inquiry into General Meyers' wartime activities as an Air Force purchasing officer.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 19 -- This Mountain College Town, renowned because of its skiing, was throbbing with excitement today as preparations were being made to give the Dartmouth team a rousing send-off tomorrow when the Big Green squad departs for Sun Valley, Idaho, to seek intercollegiate honors against the nation's best on Dec. 28-31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Secretary of State Marshall declared in a broadcast tonight that the failure of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers had demonstrated that peace was impossible without the creation of stable conditions that would provide a firm basis for it.

Representatives of the World Festivals for Friendships, Inc., met yesterday with manufacturers and representatives from the garment industries to plan a drive to collect 25,000 pieces of clothing to be sent to orphanages in Italy.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 -- The first indication that the Soviet Government might attempt to obtain the withdrawal of Allied occupation forces from this city was given today by the Soviet-sponsored press. The overt Soviet organ Taegliche Rundschau published an editorial containing an obvious suggestion that if the Western Allies chose to form a capital of a triple zone at Frankfort on the Main they would have no place in Berlin.
The motorist of the future may ask for two different grades of gasoline every time he pulls into a filling station, it was predicted yesterday.

TOPEKA, Kan., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Sam Francis bowed out today as Kansas State College football coach and Ralph Graham, Kansas State alumnus, who now is varsity coach at Wichita University, was considered top favorite to succeed him.

Anthracite Campaign Opened The Anthracite Institute will launch an immediate campaign, expending approximately $650,000 for 1948, to inform anthracite users in the northeastern part of the country on the product's availability during the current winter, Frank W. Earnest Jr., institute president, announced yesterday.

Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation will market in February a new ten-inch direct view table model television receiver to list at $275 or less, Benjamin Abrams, president, revealed in an interview yesterday. The new model will replace the company's present similar television receiver which retails at $375, he said.

Anthony (Tough Tony) Tischon, twice-convicted felon, testified yesterday in the General Sessions murder trial of three men that one defendant, John M. Dunn, told him in the Tombs: "I wouldn't be here if it wasn't for Sheridan; the bum didn't go through with his part of the bargain."
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 19 -- Gov. Thomas J. Herbert of Ohio will marry Miss Mildred Helen Stevenson of this city on Jan. 3, it was announced today.

A delegation from New Jersey called yesterday on Henry A. Wallace at his New Republic editorial offices, 40 East Forty-ninth Street, and urged him to run for President on a third party ticket. Other delegations are expected to see him next week.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Indian dances performed by Jemez pueblo tribesmen afforded a typical dash of Southwestern color today as Michigan's Rose Bowl-bound Wolverines broke, their long rail trip to the Pacific Coast with a half-hour stop in Albuquerque.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander admitted inferentially yesterday that enforcement of anti-parking rules had lagged when he said that the traffic division would get the bulk of the new recruits now coming into the Police Department.

Christmas Sunday will be celebrated in city churches tomorrow in preparation for the observance of the Feast of the Nativity on Christmas Eve, Wednesday, and Christmas Day, Thursday. Sermons based on the Christmas theme will be preached tomorrow morning.

CARLISLE, Pa., Dec. 19 -- The undefeated Columbia University basketball team tonight made it six in a row for the season by lasting just long enough to score a 48-to-46 victory over Dickinson College before an overflow crowd of 1,500.

LONDON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- A Conservative member told the House of Commons today that Britain made a "considerable blunder" at the Geneva trade negotiations by agreeing to reduce imperial preference tariffs in the Colonies in return for a proposed limitation on the use of synthetic rubber in the United States.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 19 -- The Republic of Indonesia charged formally today that the Netherlands had violated orders of the United Nations Security Council by occupying the island of Madura.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The welfare of the peoples of Western Europe and the peace of the world for a long time to come may depend upon the Marshall Plan. The United States must, therefore, explore every road that may make its European, aid program more effective.

The Hunter College Faculty Council approved at its monthly meeting last night a report of the Faculty-Student Committee on Student Affairs saying that the American Youth for Democracy on the campus had incurred no serious violation of regulations.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi, Jewish Underground organization, has extended its propaganda campaign in Britain by circularizing municipal councils.

Directors of Automatic Steel Products, Inc., formerly known as the Automatic Products Corporation, declared yesterday a dividend of one share of Majestic Radio and Television for each share of Automatic Steel Products held. It is payable on Jan. 12.

Trapped by fire and smoke pouring into a rear, top-floor Harlem apartment, five small children were rescued yesterday by a fireman lowered by rope from the roof. Meanwhile the police and firemen led to safety members of five other families, including a number of children, from the four-story tenement at 54 West 119th Street.
PARIS, Dec. 19 -- Capt. Allan Smithies of the American Leader [The Friendship] today handed a message from Mayor O'Dwyer of New York to President Vincent Auriol.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The Roosevelt household in the White House had its Fala and now the Trumans are to have a dog. His name is Feller and he will arrive tomorrow.

New Capital Market The lively succession of marketing deals that kept underwriters' offices humming this week evidently was the final work spasm of the 1947 market. Except for a calendar of nominal municipal sales totaling $24,921,000, the holiday week beginning on Monday will be devoid of major deals.
OF all the needs of man, the greatest is ease of mind. There may be food and clothing and shelter, but if there is not freedom from fear, then there is no real living.

CUTTING CHRISTMAS TREES -- The Forest Service of the United States Department of Agricuture does not discourage Christmas tree cutting. In fact, the national forests supply about 750,000 trees a year. Christmas tree cutting under Forest Service supervision improves forests by thinning surplus trees.
MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Communist newspaper Pravda printed today a letter from Russia's oil workers pledging to fulfill within four years the production quota set in the five-year plan.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Michigan's mighty Wolverines rolled into the Rose Bowl city today and immediately began limbering up their artillery for the Jan. 1 game with Southern California's Trojans.

HOLLYWOOD. SIERRA PICTURES last week invited the press to attend the burning of Ingrid Bergman at the stake at eight o'clock in the morning, in connection with the cinematic life of Joan of Arc, which Walter Wanger is producing for RKO release.
Relief by next summer for commuters who squeeze aboard local trains of the IRT lines was promised yesterday by officials of the Board of Transportation.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The United States Embassy announced today that negotiations between American and Czech film representatives had collapsed following a Czech demand that revenue from their pictures shown in the United States must equal the income of American pictures here.

Anti-inflation legislation came too late to stop the "third round of price increases," according to industrial executives interviewed yesterday. Instead, they expressed fears that the Government effort may have just the opposite effect and spur higher prices and large-scale buying.

JOPLIN, Mo., Dec. 20 -- The Atomic Medical Commission plans a study of the case of Ted T. Clark, 40, Joplin man who a year after leaving the Oak Ridge, Tenn., atomic energy plant, where he was employed, lost his lower left leg from what pathological reports at St. John's Hospital here indicate were isotopic burns from radioactivity.
Scholarship students in this country representing five Latin American nations sent a gift of $38 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as a gesture of international good-will.
ELKTON, Md., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Fire destroyed six adjoining building's in the center of this famed Gretna Green's Main Street business district today.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Jakob Kaiser was as nearly removed from the leadership of the Christian Democratic Union tonight as the Russians could go without kidnapping him. If the latest maneuver is successful the Soviet occupation zone will become, to all intents and purposes, a one-party region.

An elaborate landscaping and garden program eventually to cost about $5500,000 has been started by the Gross-Morton Company at Glen Oaks Village, 3,800-family apartment community at Union Turnpike and 247th Street, in Queens.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Mrs. K. Maxwell's Fleetridge won the mile-and-sixteenth Pelican Handicap by a harrow margin before 7,000 at the Fair Grounds today.

THE steam locomotive is on its way out to the transportation boneyard, there to lie down with the Concord coach, the river packet and the canal-boat. No doubt we shall regret for decades its gradual passing, as we have for decades regretted the passing of the inland river steamboat.

Miss A. Louise Brough of Beverly Hills, Calif., Who captured the national tennis championship last September after having been upset in the semi-finals at Wimbledon, has been named as the nation's No. 1 woman performer. This was announced yesterday as the United States Lawn Tennis Association released its rankings for 1947 in women's and veterans' competition.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Congressional circles forecast today a thorough examination of President Truman's $17,000,000,000 four-year European Recovery Program, but experienced members expressed the belief that in the end, and notwithstanding some strong attacks on it at the outset, it would be approved substantially as it was submitted in the Chief Executive's message.

Formation of a building syndicate, known as the Afghan Corporation, to build medium-priced homes in developed areas of lower Westchester County, has been announced by Hubert M. Finnerty, president of the corporation and head of Finnerty's Real Estate of Pelham.

The President's Commission on Higher Education, in its long-awaited report made public last week, offered far-reaching suggestions that are expected to have a profound influence on America's system of education.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- A reduction in the sugar allocations to brewers has forced a cut in beer production equaling nine pints out of every barrel according to a statement today by the Brewers Society. The cut will become effective Jan. 1, next.

ALTHOUGH some airlines insisted almost to the end that they would not seek an increase in passenger fare rates, a 10 per cent rise in the air traveler's ticket cost is now in effect, or likely to be soon, on most domestic airlines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Secretary of State Marshall's report on the London conference and President Truman's official European Recovery Program have been received on Capitol Hill as a definition of the Soviet problem and an answer to that problem.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- A new line of Dodge "job-rated" trucks, including 248 basic chassis models, ranging from 4,250 to 23,000 pounds gross vehicle weight, was announced today by L.F. Van Nortwick, director of truck sales, Dodge division, Chrysler Corporation.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 -- Haganah, unofficial Palestine defense force, carried out a three-hour attack on the Arab village of Qazaza early today. Casualties were one Arab killed and two wounded, according to the police, but a Haganah source said tonight that the Arab losses had been "much greater."

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Revaluation of the ruble by the Soviet Government and termination of the rationing system represents the culmination of a series of measures ordained by Moscow to turn the national economic system to more normal forms from the warped and strained structure brought about by war.

HOLLYWOOD. IN the several weeks since the Thomas committee suddenly folded its tent with the promise of probing further into Hollywood at a later date, repercussions from the hearings in Washington have been felt in the ranks of the screen writers with increasing intensity.

WHEN the 3-cent purple stamp honoring George Washington Carver, scientist and agriculturist, has its first-day. sale at Tuskegee Institute, Ala., on Jan. 5, fifth anniversary of the Negro chemurgist's death, the Carver Seal Committee, Inc., a non-profit organization, will sponsor an initial-date cachet cover.
OMAHA, Neb., Dec. 20 -- A proposal to resettle agricultural workers among Europe's displaced persons on American farms has been gaining converts steadily in the Middle West.

BUFFALO, Dec. 20 -- J. Francis Harter of Eggertsville, N.Y., an attorney here for almost thirty years and a former member of the House of Representatives, died today at the age of 50. He also had been Amherst Town Attorney and counsel for the State Association of Town Superintendents of Highways.

To the Drama Editor: REGINALD DENHAM, in his letter Dec. 7, asks what he considers an unanswerable question: "How many competent members of Equity are out of work?" It can be answered. If Mr. Denham had before him a list of the unemployed Equity membership, he would be amazed at the number of competent and extremely talented people whose names he would instantly recognize.
PHTLADELiPHIA, Dec. 20 -- William F. Haiiny, well-known newspaper cartoonist and contributor to humor magazines, died last night at his home in suburban Swarthmore. His age was 65.

TO THE EDITOR: YOUR article "The Little Pharoah That Stirred the World" and the brief mention in it of the role THE NEW YORK TIMES played in presenting the story stirs memories in one who worked on it as a reporter twenty-five years ago.

And so one accepts with gratitude what is accomplished, and need not emphasize what is poorly done, or not even attempted, in the volume which comes on the market in the month of the composer's eighty-second birthday (Dec. 8th), "The Music of Jean Sibelius," published by W.W. Norton.

HAVANA, Dec. 20 -- Striking at the heart of the United States' position on the proposed world trade charter, the undeveloped nations today stepped up the tempo of their attack on requirement of prior approval by the International Trade Organization before any country can use import quotas and other quantitative restrictions on trade for development purposes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Representative Edward H. Rees, Republican, of Kansas, said today that evidence submitted to a House committee showed the taxpayer was paying for entertainment and other special favors which he asserted individual airlines used in getting local support before the Civil Aeronauties Board.
Despite the disturbing international influence on American industry, earnings of the nation's industrial manufacturers were at record levels for the first nine months of this year.

Manhattan Transfer The last important addition to New York City's subway service was the IND division's Sixth Avenue line, opened in 1940. The subways and els then carried 6,130,000 passengers on a normal day. They now carry as many as 6,800,000.

Mr. Copland, one of this country's leading composers, gave twenty-eight lectures and sixteen radio talks during his recent South American tour. He also took part in five concerts, conducting orchestras in Buenos Aires and Montevideo.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 20 -- Gustave Ring's Respingo won the Broward County Purse at Gulf-stream Park today, surviving a claim of foul lodged by Hedley Woodhouse, who rode Iodine, second horse in the field of eight.

With Congress acting to extend export controls until Feb. 28, 1949, price will now become a critical factor in the granting of export licenses, comment in foreign trade circles here last week indicated.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 20 -- Development of a "Little TVA" is under way in west Florida and south Georgia. It is a project for navigation, electric power, flood control and recreation facilities on the Apalachicola River and its principal tributaries, the Chattahoochee and Flint Rivers.

The shortage of stenographers in New York has become so acute that the State Employment Service will make an intensive recruiting drive throughout the metropolitan area during the next two weeks, M. Joseph Tierney, metropolitan director, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The French version of the failure of the Council of Foreign Ministers in London, as given to the Foreign Affairs Commission of the National Assembly today by Foreign Minister Bidault, put the blame for the breakdown on the Soviet Union.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The designing of passenger automobiles is one of the car industry's most time-consuming operations, and to make continued production possible the men who shape and style the vehicles must be two and three models ahead of the assembly lines at all times.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The little towns along the Maine coast, and the islands offshore, which tourists know so well as bustling summer communities, can become lonely outposts once the vacationists have packed up and winter has set in.

THE story of Anna Collett (who turns out to be something of a latter-day Anna Karenina) might be interpreted as a novel about Catholicism if it were not clear that Miss Lucas has no such intention. Nowhere in the novel is Catholicism raised as an issue.

Acceleration of the war-checked development of color printing ii daily newspapers was forecast in an interview last week by Joseph L. Auer, president of R. Hoe Co., Inc., manufacturer of printing presses. Unless unforeseeable material shortages intervene, color advertisements, photographs and editorial features will become commonplace in all large dailies and many smaller ones within the next three years, Mr. Auer declared.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 -- The University of Illinois won its fourth straight game and Pennsylvania lost its third in a row in the Quakers' first basketball matinee at the Palestra today. The score was 70-44.

AMONG the half-dozen inspired lyric poets writing today in English, Richard Eberhart deserves to be better known in America. His neglect here may be traced in part to the circumstances that he was educated at Cambridge, published by Oxford, and wrongly identified in the early Thirties with the Auden-Spender-MacNeice group.

Some of our universities and colleges have concluded that science is taught within their walls in what is probably the wrong way, so far as liberal arts students are concerned. The professor of biology lectures to sixty young men and women as if they were all potential Darwins and Huxleys, yet he knows that not one in a hundred will become professional zoologists, botanists, physicians or biochemists.

FRANCONIA, N.H., Dec. 20 -- Blond-haired Silas Dunklee, agricultural-student at the University of New Hampshire, demonstrated once again that he is one of the country's foremost cross country ski runners by outlasting a field of sixty-five, the, largest in the history of the sport here, in the opening half of the Franconia Ski Club's tenth annual competition today.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 20 -- Kansas, one of the last strongholds of rock-ribbed isolationism and the rugged Republican individualist, has become the first state with a permanent "grass roots" UNESCO commission devoted to the propagation of world understanding at community level.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -- Refugee children brought into India when their parents fled from communal rioting are dying from pneumonia brought on through lack of shelter in the bitter north Indian winter, Dr. Gopichand Bhargava, Prime Minister of East Punjab Province, declared today.

THE talents of John Steinbeck and Burgess Meredith may be allied in two film projects if present plans jell, it was learned last week. Included on this agenda are "Cannery Row," the Steinbeck novel dealing with some citizens of the slums of Monterey and a property that has been contemplated by movie makers since January, 1945, and "Nothing So Monstrous," the Steinbeck short story culled from the anthology, "Pastures of Heaven."

BUDAPEST, Dec. 20 -- An indictment against Carl Payer, moderate Socialist leader who fled from Hungary, was published today. Mr. Peyer is charged with asking for material help from the United States to influence Hungarian public opinion according to the version published in the paper Villages Szag.

As the biggest Christinas trade on record was rung up by cash registers throughout the country last week, Congress passed its version of a cure for inflation and the long-term European aid program was put before the national legislators by President Truman.

PLENTY of dancing looms ahead between now and the end of the holidays. ASPEN, Colo. -- The Aspen chair lift is rapidly becoming one of the major tourist attractions of this section of the Rocky Mountains, an all-year thrill to visitors though it was built originally to carry skiers up a mountain so the could come down again.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Reports of black-market and smuggling operations by United States personnel in Germany will prove to be "largely without basis," according to Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 20 -- The State Health Department today started an investigation to determine whether the typoid fever infection that on Friday night killed Dr. Kenneth M. Wheeler, state micro-biologist, might have been contracted in his laboratory.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet Union should be called upon by the United States and Britain to join now in a plan for international, atomic control or take the consequences, it was suggested today in a statement by eleven prominent Britons.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio charged President Truman today with the responsibility of stopping inflation by using the powers granted by Congress in the session just ended in conjunction with those which were already at his disposal.

WHITMAN, Mass.; Dec. 20 -- Intercession of Francis Cardinal Spellman, a native of Whitman, who became Archbishop of New York; was sought today in settling an impending strike of 632 workers at the plant of the Regal Shoe Company here.

BERLIN, Dec. 19 (Delayed) -- Some branches of the Military Government are seeking to repeal German business licensing laws in the United States zone which so severely restrict free enterprise as virtually to elminate it.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Many tips that government officials and other public figures have been speculating on the grain market were reported arriving at the Capitol today as committees of the Senate and House made ready for broad investigations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The decision of the State Department to combat Russian propaganda against the United States with prompt statements of the actual facts is expected to restore the Voice of America, the department's foreign broadcasting organization, not only to its original position but to expand it to a status beyond any that it had before Congress months ago curtailed its operations.

The stock market extended its gains in yesterday's brief session and final prices on the Stock Exchange were at the best level since November. The rail shares joined the steel and oil groups in the upward movement, which was most pronounced in the last hour of trading.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Federal conciliators held negotiators from both sides in sessions through the day and far into tonight in last-minute efforts to avert a strike by employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company. Recess to tomorrow was taken just before midnight.

Growth of the coat and suit industry on the West Coast has more than kept pace with the increase in population in that area in recent years, it was pointed out last week by management and labor representatives attending the annual meeting of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board in Chicago.

Preservation of the rare old trees and shrubbery on the Whitlock estate property on North Broad Street, in Newark, N.J., is being undertaken in an elaborate transplanting operation coincident with the development of the property for the Templeton Arms 104-family garden apartment project.

Both Congress and the present Administration can extend an important service to the home buying public by encouraging general adoption of modular coordination and the industry-engineered housing program, according to Douglas Whitlock, chairman of the Building Products Institute.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A field goal by Nelson Bobb with ninety seconds to play shattered the myth of Kentucky basketball invincibility tonight as inspired Temple University whipped the Wildcats, 60 to 59, before an amazed crowd of 8,623 at Convention Hall.

A SMALL show at the Metropolitan Museum of woodcuts and engravings from the fifteenth and early sixteenth centuries in Germany and the Netherlands supplements, somewhat the contemporary French Gothic tapestries in the museum's current loan exhibition.

HANKOW, China, Dec. 20 -- Twelve-year-old Chu Wen-mei, one of the 1,200 Communist prisoners being "reindoctrinated" at the Government's "peace and patriotism camp" here, is a quick, bright-eyed little shaver from Manchuria. Dressed in a quilted gray military uniform, he looked like a precocious sixth grader made up for a school play.

Mrs. Emma Phaler of Columbus, Ohio, secretary of the Women's International Bowling Congress, Inc., announces that starting on Jan. 1 she will accept entries and reservations for the thirty-first annual W.L.B.C. tournament which opens in Dallas, Tex., on April 8.

The Trapp Family Singers' pleasant custom of annual Christmas concerts was continued late yesterday afternoon in a well-filled Town Hall. In Tyrolean costume, six daughters and one son of the late Baron von Trapp, together with Franz Wasner, their conductor, sang music of the season from many lands.

Radio has a marked influence upon youth and programs should be supervised and improved so that benefits would outweigh faults, according to pupils of junior high schools, public and parochial, who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Plans to spend about $20,000,000 for increasing this port's cargo handling capacity by 50 per cent were disclosed this week by J. Alexander Crothers, port director, in a detailed survey submitted to the Legislature.

OTTAWA, Dec. 20. -- Although little was accomplished during the two-week session of Parliament that adjourned last evening until Jan. 26 it is generally conceded that it was not entirely lost time.

North Carolina State, faltering and uncertain, at the start but truly devastating when it settle into stride, blasted St. John's off the court in the second half at Madison Square Garden last night. The hard-driven Wolfpack quintet rolled up 49 points after an intermission deadlock to defeat the Redmen, 76 to 56.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Some spirited bidding for the cream of the 1947 college crop was Indicated today as the National Football League concluded its annual draft, laying claim to practically the same galaxy of stars already selected by the rival All-America Conference.
