It also has been aggravated by the decline in European coal production, which has amounted since 1939 to the equivalent of 1,700,000 barrels of oil daily.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A statement that printers employed by newspapers have conducted "slowdowns" came up again today in the unfair labor practice case brought by the American Newspaper Publishers Association against the AFL International Typographical Union.

The mailing of premium lists for the Westminster Kennel Club show last week prompted that organization to answer some questions to clarify the new conditions for entry. The show will be on Feb. 11 and 12 in Madison Square Garden.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Phoenix is now trying to establish itself as a week-end center for people from New York who are willing to spend $300 (and up) for a couple of days in the sun 2,000 miles from home. This is what the public relations counselors Out here describe as a "Quickie Holiday."

Many stores last week showed satisfactory increases in gross dollar volume as a result of the late buying spurt which brought Christmas business up sharply, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

Arthur Rank.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 20 -- Argentine claims to Antarctica were re-emphasized stridently this week as the result of a British announcement of a scientific expedition to be based on the Falkland Islands. The expedition left Britain yesterday on the ship John Biscoe.

A NEW color printing process for motion pictures called Polacolor was demonstrated here last week by Polaroid Corporation, in whose Cambridge research laboratories the process was developed. First use of Polacolor has been in the production of a one-reel 35mm cartoon film, "The Circus Comes to Clown," which will soon, be shown in theatres throughout the country.

A twelve-point program for conservative business management for 1948, taking into consideration all of the foreseeable factors which would tend to affect the nation's economy, was presented yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men.

Moderate improvement in the lowered earnings of New York City banks may be expected during the months ahead, according to informed observers here. Despite the rise in operating costs other than taxes based on income, which continued to advance during the year at a strong rate, and the drop in investment income as redemptions proceeded and holdings contracted, the decline in net current operating earnings has now been arrested.

THE automobile industry was acutely interested last week in two related predictions: another rise in the retail prices of passenger cars by next spring, and more extensive use of aluminum. Increases in costs of labor and material were given as the principal factors in the prospective automobile price rise, while the predicted increase in the use of aluminum was based on the lack of steel and the expected higher steel prices.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The office of Inspector General of the United States Air Force was established today by W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, under Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Knerr, wartime commander of the Air Service Command and Secretary General of the Air Board since February, 1946.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Twenty-one former German diplomats and officials pleaded innocent today when arraigned before a United States Military Tribunal on charges that they had committed crimes against peace and humanity.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Scientific researchers, as well as industrial inventors, draw freely upon the Greek language for names for the product of their discoveries or inventions. In the new scientific discoveries names are usually very aptly chosen, with due regard for the Greek etymology.

Although the failure of the Council of Foreign Ministers to reach an agreement was a disappointment last week to the financial community, the event had no repercussions in the security markets. Last-minute Congressional action, before adjournment, coupled with President Truman's message, sent stocks to the highest levels in about a month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The machinery proposed to Congress by the President for the administration of the European Recovery Plan is designed from a model which became the symbol of inefficiency and waste during World War II, and its base is the ambition of an executive branch of the Government. Both concepts will be strongly challenged in the forthcoming debates at the Capitol.

The venture of the Knickerbockers into afternoon basketball proved an unqualified success yesterday. Not only did New York's entry in the Basketball Association of America race sweep to an impressive 70-to-58 triumph over the Boston-Celtics but it did so before the second largest crowd ever to see the Knicks play at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- President Truman declared that Italy stood with the other freedomloving nations "in the defense of liberty and democracy everywhere," in an exchange of messages with Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian Premier, on the occasion of the departure of the last of the American troops from Italy this week.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Dec. 20 -- The Dutch are pleased with the inclusion of Germany in the program for European aid. It was learned today that they were prepared to revive their demands for reparations in the form of territorial claims and economic clauses.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- A petition by the Chicago Loop Cooperative Association to install a central heating, air conditioning and electrical system in the Loop is being heard by the City Council Subcommittee on Utilities, which last week deferred further hearings until this week.
MANILA, Dec. 20 -- Bantam-weight Champion Manuel Ortiz decisively, defeated the game but inexperienced challenger, Tirso Del Rosario, in a savage fifteen-round title fight at Rizal Stadium tonight.

With carols sounding throughout the city -- from atop the Empire State Building and from churches in all the boroughs -- with trees being bought and holiday menus planned, the Christmas spirit by yesterday was carrying with it even the Scrooges.

FIVE albums of folk music are at hand, and they cover widely flung sections of the earth. To add to its ambitious and valuable "Ethnic Series," Disc Company has released American Indian Songs and Dances (six ten-inch disks) and Folk Music of Ethiopia (four ten-inch disks).

JUST thirteen years ago this week in this Review: "South Street" (Maritime History of New York), by Richard C. McKay, was deemed most worthy of the week's books and took the Page 1 spotlight. And the reviewer: "It is not unnatural to think of a city in terms of its streets.

FRANCES TYSEN NUTT is on home grounds in her first novel, which chronicles the ordeal by war of a colonial family. The setting of "Three Fields to Cross" is Staten Island, where she was born and now lives; much of her material is derived from family documents.

Squadron A's unbeaten regulars routed the Jockey Hollow Polo Club of Morristown, N.J., 17 to 10, as play in the New York division of the Metropolitan High Goal League began last night at the Squadron A Armory. If the 11-goal Regulars continue to display such fine teamwork, then the Squadron A No. 1 trio most certainly will be a top contender for the title won last season by the New York Athletic Club.

THE Dance Notation Bureau has taken a new lease on life. Having carried on with wonderful fidelity and ingenuity through the years of international isolation and absorption at home in war activities, it has pulled its forces together and set in motion a lively and substantial program for the future.

GADGETS simplify growing of plants indoors, a hobby that gains momentum during winter months. They are relatively low in cost and encourage the giving of much-needed care. Although many house plants thrive on just regular watering, others soon wilt and fade unless they receive a certain amount of special attention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Republicans laid the basis this week, in an atmosphere of harsh, intense partisanship, for investigations of alleged "insider" speculation in food commodities that may have profound political effects in the Presidential year 1948.

The best measure of the average man's well-being in any country is how much work he has to do to get the things he needs and wants. Work and goods are the realities of which money is merely a symbol. In an article published in another section of this newspaper today Will Lissner employs this principle to make a comparison between conditions in the United States and in Russia since the devaluation of the ruble.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Exhibiting a passing attack that at times was as bewildering to the 11,395 fans as to their opponents, Holy Cross tonight vanquished Dartmouth, 75-61, in the closing game of a college basketball double-header at the Boston Garden.

Next month's National Motor Boat Show is beginning to take real shape in the mind of its impresario, Ira Hand, secretary of the National Association of Engine and Boat Manufacturers, who yesterday discovered he had allotted space for more craft than last year.

IOWA STATE -- Placements Requests for teachers received by the Teacher Placement Office of Iowa State College totaled 2,205 for the year ended Oct. 1, a 20 per cent increase over the previous year. The highest percentage of placements was in agriculture and home economics, with 123 positions filled.

THE Federated Garden Clubs of New York State will hold its sixteenth annual judging school at the Savoy-Plaza Hotel Jan. 13 through the 16th. Intended primarily to train show judges, it is open also to anyone interested in gardening and flower arrangement.

The second concert of the season presented by the National Association of American Composers and Conductors last night at Times Hall commemorated the birthday of the late Henry Hadley, founder of the organization. Participants included the NAACC Singers, conducted by Dolf Swing, with Sigrid Swing as accompanist; Thomas Richner and Frederick Marantz, pianists; Frances Blaisdell, flute; Leopold Teraspulsky, 'cello, and an ensemble composed of Carolyn Beebe, pianist, and the Kraeuter String Quartet.

BY legendary association as well as by its Christinastree form and fragrance the herb rosemary seems a most fitting plant for the holiday season. A good-sized specimen of this lovely evergreen, with its narrow, needle-like leaves, even makes the handsomest kind of table tree.
LONDON, Sunday, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Moscow radio today accused the United States Government's Voice of America of "lying" about Russia's economic situation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- American consumers will have this week the biggest holiday meat supply available in history, but meals will be the most expensive on record for both Christmas and New Year's Day. Meat costs have declined substantially from the 1947 highs of last summer, a seasonal trend, but current levels are setting new winter records.

Experiments made by a team of entomologists of the United States Department, of Agriculture indicate that disease-carrying insects can be killed by feeding their animal hosts with certain chemicals that will make the blood deadly. The principle has not been sufficiently developed to justify its practical application in the protection of human or animal health.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The war-inspired boom in farm land prices continues to grow, but at a somewhat reduced pace, the Agriculture Department reports.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- Full diplomatic immunities, including the right to import scotch whisky tax-free, about $1.50 a bottle, were granted by the United States today to the permanent representatives to the United Nations.

A WANDERER from this bailiwick found himself the other day in the offices of Talking Books, a sort of subsidiary of the American Foundation for the Blind, and came away with a history and a fistful of statistics. In a sense the statistics were the history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -- With the disclosure that the Matson Navigation Company planned to go ahead with reconversion of the luxury liners Monterey and Mariposa for the Australia run, the West Coast looked forward this week to the prospect of passenger fleets in the Pacific equal to those of the pre-war era.

THERE has been so much activity among the designers of decorative fabrics that anyone who tried to define all of the so-called "new trends" would soon be whirling around like a weather vane in a hurricance.

The first ten-year program for country-wide improvement and development of a major American industry has been laid before executives of the two-billion-dollar gray iron foundry industry in all leading manufacturing centers. Aimed at bettering working conditions, eliminating losses and waste, improving productive efficiency, controlling costs and advancing industrial relations as well as technical research, the plan was prepared by Raymond L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders' Society, Inc., Cleveland.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Screen Writers Guild last Monday voiced the first organized opposition to the recent decision of the motionpicture producers to employ no known Communists and to fire those employes who refused, last October, to answer the questions of a Congressional committee regarding their alleged affiliation with the Communist party.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Referee Johnny Weber denied today that any illegal punching by Welter-weight Champion Sugar Ray Robinson caused a kidney injury that hospitalized challenger Chuck Taylor for twelve Hours after their title fight here last night.

TOKYO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Japanese militarists sought at the time of surrender to "buy the people's good-will and to prepare for an eventual comeback" by distributing throughout the country war stocks worth hundreds of billions of yen, Kanju Kato, chairman of a Diet investigating committee, declared today.

THIS is a book which we warmly commend to all idealists, young and old, who have any notion of trying to translate their high-mindedness into national legislation. We particularly suggest it to those who have it in mind themselves to go to Congress.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Strength in December contracts, in which trading will cease at the close of business on Monday, featured a general advance in all cereals on the Board of Trade today. Several new seasonal high records were made.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Development of a chain of parks since 1921 by the Union County Park Commission, involving transformation of swamps, ash dumps and run-down farm tracts into recreation areas that attracted 10,912,539 visitors last year, is recounted in a twenty-five-year report issued today by the five-man commission.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Only forty-eight fighter planes of Jagdkorps II, the Luftwaffe (German Air Force) unit closest to the Normandy invasion area, were available for combat on D-day in 1944, and all movement behind the German lines had been "completely paralyzed."
Featured by late week-end short covering, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed irregular, 8 points lower to 12 points higher than on Friday.

AS editor, Robert Payne first decided which of China's numberless poems from the dawn of the written word should be included. Then he arranged that the translation of each poem should be entrusted to that Chinese scholar who considered himself most sympathetically endowed for the work of translation.
NOW is the time to plan a trip to South Africa. January, February and March are their summer months aid the dry season.

AUBURN, Ala., Dec. 20 -- Optimistic reports on the use of radioisotopes in bringing about chemical and biological solutions to problems involving plant-killing chlorosis, soil fertility and the nutritive deficiencies of cattle marked today's final session of the first conference on the application of atomic energy to the field of agricultural research.

CHOSEN from "stacks of prints totaling a greater height than a four-story building," the winners In the $5,000 1947 Graflex Photo Contest were announced last week. Awards were made according to the photographers' status, as follows: Teen-agers, first prize, $250, to Bob Schafer, Lansdowne, Pa.; second, $150, to Alfred Regan, San Francisco; third, $100, to Mervyn Lew, Los Angeles.

Experimental research by the Reynolds Metals Company, aimed at producing an aluminum can that would compete with and even excel the long-established "tin" steel can, will achieve half its objective -- a sealed, aluminum drypack container -- "within a year," a company spokesman disclosed yesterday.

THE thriving art center at Port-au-Prince, Haiti, has been well represented in New York in the last year or two. The group show at the Jacques Seligmann Gallery includes oils and water-colors high in key and a group of quite striking black-and-white drawings by an artist named Lucien Price -- some of them representational landscapes, others semi-abstract compositions which would make admirable print designs.

Many of those who are planning a Florida fishing trip during the next few months have announced their intention of making their first bonefish excursion, which undoubtedly will result in the extension of a number of vacations.

Clifford Curzon, English pianist, who gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, must be reckoned among the greatest keyboard artists of the time. When previously heard in the same auditorium at his American debut in 1939, Mr. Curzon had made an unusually deep impression, and his performances at this second recital fully established him as an unexcelled technician and interpreter.

GENERATIONS before America produced, a professional writer, professional painters were expressing our colonial civilization with an awkward, stark beauty and a slowly growing maturity. This fact, usually ignored even by the best of our historians, is the basis for this excellent volume.

ROME, Dec. 20 -- Gravely perturbed by strikes and other social disturbances Pope Pius published today an encyclical, "Optatissima Pax ("Most Desired Peace"), urging that class hatred be replaced by collaboration, concord and peaceful work.

To the Radio Editor: I WAS very much interested in Paul R. Milton's article, "Against the Taboos," in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 7. I regret very much that before he wrote the article he apparently did not read what I had to say on the subject of motion pictures, radio broadcasting and comic strips in relation to the administration of justice, or that he read my remarks without adequate consideration thereof.

TORONTO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Left-winger Vic Lynn of Toronto fired a goal with seven seconds left tonight to tie the Detroit Red Wings, 4-4, before 13,284 persons at Maple Leaf Garden. The result kept the Leafs in first place in the National Hockey League, one point margin ahead of the Wings.
The Air Force hopes to recruit two-thirds of its future pilots from the United States Military Academy and the United States Naval Academy, Secretary of the Air Force Symington revealed last week.

ALL the networks and many of the independent stations will carry the annual ceremonies at the lighting of the national Christmas tree on the White House lawn and President Truman's greetings to the nation on Wednesday, from 5 to 5:30 P.M.

MONTREAL, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Boston's Bruins took third place in the National Hockey League, displacing the idle New York Rangers, by administering a convincing 4-2 defeat to Montreal's Canadiens before 10,952 persons at the Forum tonight.

THIS is the time of the year when the observers of the sports scene are required by precedent to take a backward look, like Lot's wife, at what's been left behind. Since this corner is much too timid ever to flout precedent-well, leave us go.

GREYHOUND KEY, Fla. -- A new experiment in tourist accommodations is being made with the opening of the Greyhound Post House here, midway between Miami and Key West. Partially completed at a cost of $100,000, this will be the first in Greyhound's expanding coast-to-coast system of post houses.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 20 -- Louis D. Oliveros, commander of the Louis L. Battey Post of the American Legion, called on the Army today to make "an immediate investigation" of the disclipinary barracks at Camp Gordon. His telegram was based on Information he said he obtained yesterday in an unofficial investigation of the installation in company with a clergyman and a newspaper man.

INJURY to trees in winter can, at the very least, retard their development and pave the way for insect and disease attacks. Not only are specimens set out this fall endangered but also any that were planted within the last year.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- The anti-Communists in the international labor movement hope to make France's new Force Ouvriere the spearhead of their attack on the Communist-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions, it was indicated hero today.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, Newburgh Republican, said today that he would introduce in the Legislature next month two proposed constitutional amendments designed to improve the standards of selecting judges.

Though this department views much of what passes for cancer research with a skeptical eye and regards it as unscientific cut-and-try tinkering that is not likely to produce anything of importance, it calls attention to an announcement in Science which comes from Dr. George F. Watson of Kitchener, Ont.; Dr. Irene Corey Diller of the Institute of Cancer Research, Philadelphia, and Dr. N. Volney Ludwick of Hahnemann Medical College and Hospital.

PARIS, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Questioned in the Foreign Affairs Commission's session about prospects of a three-power alliance between the United States, Britain and France, as suggested by Charles de Gaulle, M. Bidault said nobody had talked to him about it, "but I do not say I would refuse such an arrangement."

The music of Handel's "Messiah" is so overwhelmingly wonderful that, after the consecutive first part, telling of the birth of Christ, few listeners have questioned whether the rest of it makes sense. But it does, as was proved last night when the Oratorio Society of New York, to celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary, presented the masterwork at Carnegie Hall with all the usual cuts restored.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Dec. 20 (UP) -- A 24-year-old Marine Corps veteran described from a hospital bed today the eight horror-filled days and nights he spent sealed in a box car between Wells, Nev., and Fort Smith.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Despite apprehension among Germans and many non-Germans, it is considered highly unlikely that any quick and dire consequences will flow from the failure of the Council of Foreign Ministers at London.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Coming to life in the second half, during which they scored three touchdowns, the Quantico (Va.) Marines defeated the Alameda (Calif.) Naval Air Station Hellcats, 26 to 0, to capture the all-Navy football championship before 20,000 fans in Balboa Stadium today.

PRE-HOLIDAY activities in the art world included a number of events and publications with sculpture and graphic art in the ascendant. Since the Sculptors Guild annual exhibitions ceased, the Whitney annual and sections of various annual group shows such as the current one of the Audubon Artists at the Academy, have provided the principal opportunities for surveys.

Leon Barzin and the National Orchestral Association presented a Christmas pageant, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall similar to the one presented three Christmases ago by Leopold Stokowski and the New York City Symphony Orchestra at the City Centre.

IF you ever played Aunty-IOver you will understand how Dickie found the hole in the roof and solved the mystery of the noises in the night. He and Jean were spending two weeks in the country with two aunts who were not used to children and especially impatient with boys.

The Dodero Lines, Argentine-flag shipping company, has bought three large American-built freighters of the C-3 class for operation in the Atlantic Coast-South American route, it was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- British workmen suddenly seem to be producing more than they were a few months ago. They are doing this with the same machinery, with approximately the sames numbers of workers and without any marked technological or administrative improvements.

MINEOLA, L.I., Dec. 20 -- Robert Norton, 17 years old, of 144-46 Farmers Boulevard, Laurelton, Queens, for whom an eight-state alarm had been sent out on Wednesday, was taken back to his home today by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. George Norton.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 -- Unless one is willing to pay ten times the face value, not a single seat is available for tomorrow's National Football League Eastern Division championship play-off between the Philadelphia Eagles and the Pittsburgh Steelers at Forbes Field. Nothing may be had at the boxoffice, except standing room, but scalpers around town are demanding $40 for a $4 ticket -- and, in some instances, the asking price is being met.
The tennis match they have talked about for two years comes into Madison Square Garden this week. It's the world amateur champion against the world professional champion.

CHRISTMAS comes to bridge players, as to everyone else, only once a year; but Santa Claus, in the form, of opponents who accommodatingly make mistakes, is likely to appear any day in any season.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 -- Bavarian agencies have become so uncooperative with the Military Govrnment that an investigation has been ordered to ascertain whether there is a campaign of passive resistance against the American occupation authorities, it was learned today.

Russia's Rubles In Soviet Russia there is a phrase: "Control by the ruble." It refers to the part played by "managed" currency and credit in the U.S.S.R.'s socialist planned economy. The central bank, Gosbank, with 4,100 branches, is the only agency that issues money.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, and a member of the American Section of the Jewish Agency Executive, announced yesterday that he had called a special meeting of Zionist leaders of Greater New York for next Tuesday night at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel to review the latest developments in Palestine.

COFFEE cakes, which please palates the year round, become even more important at Christmas to many people. The Swedes bake julkaka, a circular cake spiced with cardamon and full of citron and raisins; Austrians like stollen; Italians demand the puffy panettone.

Prices Politics Besides interim foreign aid, the only other major item on the agenda of the Eightieth Congress' extra session was domestic inflation control. As the session ended last Friday, both Democrats and Republicans agreed that the inflation problem had barely been touched.

HOLIDAY travel out of New York City, according to late reports, will run from 15 to 20 per cent heavier than last year. All available carriers are being pressed into service, and from present indications more Could be used if they were available.

MACON, Ga., Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. W.B. Burke, who spent more than fifty years as a missionary in China and was the subject of a book, "My Father in China," written by his son, James, died here yesterday at the age of 83.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 20 -- This Christmas about 2,500,000 children in eight of Europe's poorest countries will get one meal from the United Nations. Throughout the rest of the winter, a total of 3,715,000 out of an estimated 31,600,000 needy children and nursing and pregnant mothers in twelve countries will get one meal daily and some medical care from an organization most of them have never even heard about.

In spite of President Truman's successful defeat, by the exercise of his veto power, of two tax-reduction bills this year, a third bill, having similar purposes, was introduced in the House by Representative Harold Knutson, Chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, last Thursday.

THE unique and distinctive capabilities of television seldom have been more effectively demonstrated than they were last Sunday evening by the American National Theatre and Academy and the National Broadcasting Company in the joint production of "The Purple Door Knob."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Whatever else Congress accomplished in the session it brought to a close last night, it succeeded in establishing the cost of living, or inflation, as it is usually called these days, as the outstanding issues of the general elections next year.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The official Central News Agency reported today that the vanguard of Communist forces attacking Mukden from four sides had fought into the suburbs, ten miles from the center of the city.

PARIS (By Wireless). A FEW days before Robert Schuman became Premier of France, one of the most distinguished and experience politicians assured this reporter that it was out of the question for any member of the Popular Republican Movement to head a Government because of the severe setback which that Catholic party had suffered at the municipal elections in October when Charles de Gaulle captured a large part of its votes.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Debate was opened in the National Assembly today on the French austerity program prepared by Premier Robert Schuman's Cabinet to pave the way for economic stabilization.

ALBANY, Dec. 20 -- Governor Dewey's office said today that the Chief Executive was "gravely concerned" about the fuel-oil situation in New York State this winter and that he was working on a program which might include an appeal for voluntary rationing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 20 -- The 60-year-old Inter-Parliamentary Union, a world-wide organization of "unpledged" representatives from the legislatures of twenty-six countries, is undertaking a program of active collaboration with the United Nations.

HOLLYWOOD. COMES Wednesday, the day before Christmas, when the average man is filled with good-will and cheer, Lionel Barrymore will be gruff, grumpy and waspish. The fact that Barrymore is no average man is not the cause of this individuality; his ill humor will be his preparation for the role of Scrooge in which he will be heard that evening on ABC.

To the Screen Editor: RECENTLY I attended a showing of the British film "Nicholas Nickleby" at the Little Carnegie. The J. Arthur Rank Prestige Film as it is now being shown in New York is not the complete British production.

Leading all the way, Frank Efinger, formerly of De Witt Clinton High and now representing Andover Academy, Massachusetts, captured the feature event of the opening interscholastic indoor track and field meet of the season last night, the forty-first Stuyvesant H.S. Games, at the Third Engineers Armory before 4,500 persons.

Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., has taken two major steps to strengthen its fifteen-year-old employe educational refund program, Sterling W. Mudge, supervisor of training, disclosed in an interview last week. First, maximum monetary contributions of the company toward employe educational expenses have been increased 50 per cent, and second, administration of the program has been decentralized completely, he reported.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. -- The holiday habits of 2,700 United Nations workers, who have now been long enough, settled in their headquarters to start vacation traveling, are turning out to be considerably less diversified than experts predicted, considering the fifty-seven countries represented here.

Outwardly unworried over the six-count indictment for perjury and suborning perjury returned against him on Friday by a Federal grand jury in Washington, Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers said yesterday he welcomed the opportunity to lay his own side of the case before a court and jury.

The largest single family booking on the records of the United States Lines was set down in the company books last week on application of an agent in Chicago. An unidentified, man planning a trip to Ireland next July with his family asked for reservations for fifteen persons on the liner Washington, which is how being rebuilt as a one-class ship.

Salmon have been marked in Scottish, Norwegian, Baltic and Canadian haunts to find out how, when and whither they migrate. From studies made by J.W. Menzies it seems that European and Canadian salmon have a common feeding ground in the North Atlantic near Iceland.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- Three goals by talented Tommy Lawton as he led Notts County to a 4-1 victory over Stockton in a second-round cup replay highlighted British soccer today -- but perhaps the most significant score was that notched by the Welsh international, Bryn Jones, enabling league-leading Arsenal to tie Sunderland 1--1.

HIS may be no time for mentioning it -- what with Christmas almost on us, that is, and with everybody trying postpone unpleasant thoughts-- But the "take" of domestic movie business has been dropping uncomfortably of late and the general quality of movies has been of an order most kindly described as low.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec; 20 -- Thirteen, regional chairmen have been appointed in the United States and abroad to aid the Bowdoin College Sesquicentennial Fund, it was announced at a meeting of the executive committee held yesterday at campaign headquarters here.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Russian citizens were told today that a foreign intelligence campaign against the Soviet Union has persisted for thirty years, and that they should be on constant guard against "imperialist" spies.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 20 -- Residents of Utah and Colorado are feuding once again, but not over rustled cattle, jumped claims, irrigation rights, or even the presumed locale of a Western movie.

GENEVA, Dec. 20 -- If Foreign Minister Molotov intends to follow up the Council of Foreign Ministers' fiasco by trying to force the eastern European countries into closer economic union with the Soviet Union, he is going to have some tough nuts to crack, in the opinion of economic experts here from both eastern and western countries.

THREE photographers in search of a way to interpret Yehudi Menuhin arrive at three separate answers in pictures exhibited at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fiftythird Street, through Feb. 23, under the heading, "Music and Musicians."

The Refrigerated Steamship Line, a subsidary of the United Fruit Company, has decided defer resumption of its New York-Florida coastwise service until the start of the new shipping season in October of next year, it was made known yesterday by Ralph Keating, president.

Alex Hetzek, University of Michigan sophomore, seeded No. 1, had too many guns for Byron Brown, a Brooklyn lad who attends Manual Training High, yesterday when the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships began at Nick's courts in the 369th Regiment Armory.

THE Royal Opera of Stockholm, one of the finest companies in Europe, is making plans to visit the United States next October with its own orchestra, chorus and ballet, a large cast of singers and enough scenery and costumes for ten operas. Earlier this month H.E. Linden, Swedish -- American engineer from Los Angeles, returned from Sweden and said he was empowered to make contacts in this country to further the project.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., Dec. 20 -- Charles Elwood Dull, supervisor of science instruction in the junior and senior high schools of Newark, when he retired in 1944, died at Orange Memorial Hospital last night after a brief illness. He lived at 106 South Harrison Street, here.

CAIRO, Dec. 20 -- There is one thing that grows more certain as each day passes, and that is that the Arabs are not bluffing. Aside from the fact that they believe a little chunk of the Arab world is being taken from them by chicanery and high-pressure methods, they are deeply hurt by certain statements from America that their threats of reprisal are all talk.

Wall Street investment houses are writing off to "experience" the year now ending, but they admit that the period's record of great ado and little, profit has raised more questions than it has answered. Suddenly brought to prominence by the end of the bull market in bonds, such questions, moreover, seem to bring into conflict the thinking fashions of yesterday with the economic, needs of today.

THE post-war period has seen a notable rise in the number of hardy souls who head for public camping grounds during the Christmas season. There has always been, of course, a tight little knot of semi-professionals -- Educators and students mostly -- who have considered the winter "long vacation" an ideal time for communing with nature.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- A Christmas story came true today for the school children of Paris. They saw with their own eyes dozens and dozens of big trucks drive up filled with gifts of food for them from the Friendship Train.

DECORATING the home for Christmas should be a personal matter. If the wreaths, garlands, table centerpieces and other ornaments axe made from branches, berries and cones growing in the garden, the results will have far more personal meaning tljan "storeboughten" decorations can ever have.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- William K. Divers of Ohio, first assistant administrator of the Home Loan Bank Board, received a recess appointment by President Truman today as a member and chairman of the board. He succeeds John H. Fahey of Boston, whose resignation was accepted.

ROME, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Fifteen persons were injured in new outbreaks of fighting in Italy's labor disorders today. Italians faced the possibility of a spaghetti-less Christmas as a result of a Communist-led national strike of 300,000 food workers.

The 9,000-ton freighter Seattle, the first of five new vessels of exceptional speed now under construction for the Pacific-European service of the Johnson Line, is scheduled to arrive in Seattle Saturday after her maiden voyage from Gothenburg, Sweden, it was announced here yesterday by Axel Johnson Jr., director of the company.

The fundamentally new approach to the problem of peace developed by American foreign policy during the past year has now been given frank and official expression in President Truman's message to Congress on the European Recovery Program and in Secretary of State Marshall's report on the failure of the London conference.

A Novel by a President One who likes to read books in Spanish took down from a shelf the other day a novel which, written some years ago by a Latin-American man of letters, immediately brought him enormous renown wherever Spanish is spoken; and, promptly translated into several other languages, greatly enhanced that renown among numerous readers elsewhere who were unable to enjoy it in the original.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 22 (AP) --The Moscow Radio, making its first comment early today on President Truman's message to Congress Friday, said "the essence" of the Marshall plan is "war."

HAVANA, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Patricia ("Satira") Schmidt was sentenced today to fifteen years in prison for the yacht slaying of her lover, John Lester Mee, and she indicated tonight, her lawyer said, that she might seek a pardon from President Ramon Grau san Martin.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21--Prospective legislation looms large as a major influence in shaping the trend of the grain markets, according to views expressed last week by brokers on the Board of Trade. However, despite the passage of anti-inflation legislation, the wheat market averaged somewhat higher, as did corn and oats.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21 (AP)-- The mechanical eye of television was focused today for the first time in the Eastern United States on a solemn high mass which was telecast from the Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul.
The Russian peasant bore the brunt of the confiscation of savings that attended the recent conversion of the Soviet Union's currency, according to data that became available yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Reporting on the improvement of the privately owned electric utility industry in its financial condition between the end of 1937 and the conclusion of last year, the Federal Power Commission pointed out today that the plant investment of the industry had risen in the nine-year period from $13,852,000,000 to $14,952,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21-- "The Jinx," a screen story by Harry Ruskin and William Ludwig, has been acquired by MetroGoldwyn-Mayer as a future vehicle for Red Skelton, to follow "The Southern Yankee" on the comedian's schedule.

Walter Soltow of Manhattan College, former P.S.A.L. mile and cross-country titleholder while at New Utrecht High and later an A.A.U. champion in the steeplechase and distance events, will compete in the two-mile limited handicap feature of the Metropolitan A.A.U. open track and field meet at the Twenty-second Regiment Armory on Jan. 3.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- To keep the United States to the forefront in the weapons race, the Research and Development Board has been ordered by Secretary of Defense Forrestal to submit at least once a year a new master plan for military research.

The annual meeting of the National Highway Research Board has put its finger squarely on two of the most important elements which aggravate the parking situation in American cities. The first is the desire of motorists, understandable but under the conditions of today unattainable, to drive their vehicles directly to their destination in the city's heart and park them there.

The eighty-first military review of the Reserve Officers Training Corps Regiment of Xavier High School was held yesterday afternoon in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory of the New York State Guard in honor of Thomas J. Curran, Secretary of State of New York.

Some time ago Chairman David E. Lilienthal of the United States Atomic Energy Commission made the somewhat startling assertion that "the entire investment in the atomic energy subject--now nearly two and a half million dollars--may be more than repaid by the benefits to agriculture and to human nutrition alone."

Assemblyman Bernard Austin of Brooklyn predicted yesterday that a ban on discrimination in education in New York State "will become a reality in the 1948 session of the Legislature." He was co-sponsor of the Austin-Mahoney Bill, which failed of adoption earlier this year.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Dutch Army communique said today that 150 Indonesian "terrorists" were "liquidated" Dec. 9 in operations in the Krawang area, forty-three miles east of Batavia.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 21--For all its talk about self-sufficiency and its continuous preachings to the Germans in its zone about the evils of dollars, the Soviet Military Government, no less than the United States and British Military Governments, has designed its export program on a strictly dollar basis.

Five-Minute Steak Sandwiches carry their own time guarantee, without clocking the eating satisfaction of this surprisingly economical main dish. Recipes that go lightly on time, energy and the burget are extra-welcome Christmas week.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 21 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine through a spokesman gave official approval today to reprisal raids by Haganah, the Zionist militia, on Arab villages. The Haganah raids marked a policy of self defense "to root out nests of brigands," the Jewish Agency said, adding it was "very unfortunate" that five small children were killed in the raid on the village of Khisas Thursday night.

LONDON, Dec. 21--By the middle of July, 1944, Field Marshals Erwin Rommel and Guenther von Kluge, the German commanders in Western Europe, knew they were beaten but Adolf Hitler's inability to accept facts kept his armies fighting under adverse conditions in Normandy and contributed to the great disaster that overtook them in August and September.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, predicted yesterday that the college would reach its full quota of professors, on a par with other institutions of higher education, within the next two years.

NANKING, Dec. 21 (AP)--Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, in a Christmas message broadcast over the Shanghai radio, said today: "When we look at the present world situation through the lens of Christian faith, much which is obscure and confused becomes clearer.

Paul Draper and Larry Adler, who have become almost as much a part of Christmas hereabouts as good King Wenceslas, opened their annual series of children's matinees at the City Center yesterday. Before a houseful of incredibly small and extremely vocal youngsters, they presented themselves in tap dances and harmonica solos and acted as masters of ceremony for their associates, who consisted of the magician, Prince Mendes, the ventriloquist, Paul Winchell and Salici puppets.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 21 (AP)--Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, retired, wartime commander of the Flying Tigers and the United States Fourteenth Air Force, married Miss Anna Chan, 24, reporter for the Chinese Central News Agency, today. He is 57.

ATHENS, Dec. 22--Communist party members said tonight that the formation of the "Democratic Government of Free Greece" had not yet been announced because the Governments of Greece's northern neighbors [Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Albania] were withholding full support.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 21-- Boulder Brook Club's threesome won a thriller from New York's Squadron A trio, 17 to 16, in the feature of this afternoon's indoor polo program at the Boulder Brook Club.

Fritz Busch, Metropolitan Opera conductor, whose illness forced him to cancel all appearances during the first seven weeks of the season, will return to the company on Jan. 3 to conduct "Tristan und Isolde." Lauritz Melchior and Helen Traubel also will appear for the first time this season, singing the name parts in the performance he conducts.

PARIS, Dec. 21--Dazzling, imaginative and new is the display at Cartier's in celebration of the company's one hundredth anniversary. Gone are the heavy gold rings, bracelets and necklaces of the war period, when a large part of the value of a piece was in the metal.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 21 --A special train has been chartered to bring 176 members of the United Nations secretariat on Christmas Eve to Binghamton, Johnson City and Endicott for an old-fashioned Christmas celebration lasting four days.

Despite the opposition of other units in the Greater New York CIO Council, the Transport Workers Union will stick to its position in favor of Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for an eight-cent fare on the municipal transit lines, it was predicted last night.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 21 --Young King Michael returned to Rumania today to fight for the retention of his throne and for Communist permission to marry the woman he loves. He has been away since Nov. 12.

LONDON, Dec. 21--This was the first sunny day of the month in London. At noon church bells all over the town broke out in a chorus of Christmas carols. They didn't play the same tunes and some of the chimes were a little cracked and warworn like the face of London, but the effect of the medley was both solemn and merry-- the authentic voice of Christmas.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 21 -- Press reports said today that former Premier Ahmad Ghavam was arrested yesterday and his passport confiscated as he was about to depart by plane for the United States.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 22 -- All operational units of the Indian Army will be under the command of Indian officers by Jan. 1, 1948, and an Indian officer will be appointed Commander in Chief, taking over on April 1, Sardar Baldev Singh, Defense Minister, announced today.

The necessity for a separation of church and state in the field of public education was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Moshe Davis, dean of the Teachers Institute and College of Jewish Studies of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, at the second annual Rabbinical Assembly conference on Jewish education.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 21 (AP)-- Collegiate football rules are all right, Marquette Coach Frank J. Murray said today, but a little more liberalization as regards substitutions and tightening up on enforcement in general are in order.

Oregon University, third of the Pacific Coast Conference fives to invade Madison Square Garden this season, matches shots with Long Island University in the second game of the collegiate basketball twin-showing booked for the Eighth Avenue arena tonight.

Rises in cotton yarns have affected hosiery pricing to a greater extent than any other type of yarn used in the industry, according to a study made by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. The sharp rises in cotton, it was pointed out, are in contrast to the very moderate increase in rayon yarn and 47 per cent decrease in nylon yarn prices during the last seven years.

Although he looks as if he were sculptured in ice for a winter carnival, the rolypoly snow man that Jane Parker bakery departments of A. P. stores now sell especially for Christmastide is fashioned of golden layer cake and boiled frosting.

'Time' Tops S.A. Survey Time Magazine's international edition leads as "first choice publication" among key businessmen in Latin America, according to the findings of a special survey conducted for the magazine by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP)--The Cudahy Packing Company, meat packers, reported today net income of $7,121,707 in the fiscal year ended Nov. 1, 1947, compared with net income of $6,720,585 in the preceding fiscal year. Net income this year was equal to $4.32 a share on the common stock against $4.06 in the previous year.

Although polls have shown that wage earners believe their employers retain 10c to 25c or more of the sales dollar, corporate profits in 1946, after taxes, represented slightly less than 5c per dollar of sales, or well over a cent less per dollar of sales than in 1939 or 1941.

Harold Bogin, pianist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Times Hall. The program contained a Marcello-Vivaldi-Bach Adagio; three Scarlatti sonatas; the Bach-Busoni "Chacpnne"; Beethoven's; Sonata, Op. 110; a Chopin group; "Two Pieces for Piano," by Stefan Wolpe; Gene Forrell's "Abstraction," which received its first performance, and Prokofieff's Sonata, No. 7.

HAVANA, Dec. 22 -- With the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment past the scheduled half-way mark, it is still impossible to tell whether it will be a success or failure. But a crisis has developed over "QR" -- that is, quantitative restrictions such as import quotas -- that could wreek the whole idea of international economic cooperation for world peace and prosperity.

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 (AP)--Pravda, the official Communist party newspaper, today described as a "dismal failure" the United States State Department's Voice of America broadcast of Dec. 3, which it quoted as being to the effect that the Soviet Union was facing an economic crisis and "increased prices."

LONDON, Dec. 22--The determination of owners and editors of British daily newspapers and news weeklies to defend their independence and to run their own affairs is expressed in evidence submitted to the Royal Commission on the Press and issued today.

IN spite of Thomas De Quincey's immortal dissertation "On Murder Considered as One of the Fine Arts" appreciation of murder remains an acquired taste. Some people do acquire it, of course, and never tire of rehashing the story of Lizzie Borden and her "forty whacks," or the grizzly details of a hundred other murders and murderers.

HANKOW, China, Dec. 21--Recent developments in central China, where the Communists have established three major bases, support the findings of Gen. George C. Marshall and Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer that it would be difficult to defeat the Chinese Communists by military means alone.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21--There was every indication last week that the steel industry would chalk up one of the best peacetime records in its history by Jan. 1. Even if the 85,000,000-ton mark was not reached, it was apparent that he figure would be approached closely.
PARIS, Dec. 21--In a notable speech in the National Assembly's debate on France's austerity bills today, Pierre Mendes-France, former Finance Minister, gave his support to the Government program.

Two bright new members of the producing fraternity, Robert Whitehead and Oliver Rea, who were thrilled at shattering precedent when they struck a gold mine in "Medea," are extending their foray in a difficult field with another somber drama, "Crime and Punishment," a Broadway failure twelve years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9--Argentina's six universities will begin one of the most critical phases of their troubled existence on Jan. 1, When the new university law, originally laid down by President Juan Peron as part of his five-year plan, goes into effect.

Aided by an $8,000,000 investment in plant development, ceramic wall and floor tile manufacturers are geared to cut-produce in 1948 any previous year by a wide margin, it was said over the week-end by D. Parry Frost, chairman of the Tile Council of America.
There is nothing quite like a boom or a depression to stimulate improvisation in the field of economic and financial theory.

The Police Department announced yesterday awards to 270 members of the force for meritorious conduct in line of duty in 1947. The awards included seven honorable mentions, ten citations for exceptional merit, 100 commendations, 103 citations for meritorious police duty and fifty citations for excellent police duty.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Dec. 21-- Through eight sailing races, the largest number held this season off the Larchmont Yacht Club, Corny Shields with his boat Dainty and Jack Sutphen in his craft Rum Dum tied for the lead today. One point below them was Bob deCoppet with his Zotom.

Robert W. Atkins of 375 Park Avenue, president of the Hat Corporation of America, 417 Fifth Avenue, and a director of many other companies, died yesterday afternoon in St. Luke's Hospital, after a brief illness, at the age of 58.

"Sex-besotted and sex-inflamed," scornful of the responsibilities of family life, America has been weakened to a point that has made it "an easy prey for its enemies and a fit object for the visitation of God's judgment," the Rev. Edward L. Murphy declared yesterday in the third of a series of Advent sermons at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- An eight-man mission will go to Germany this month to hunt iron and steel scrap that can be brought back to relieve a bottleneck in steel production in the United States. Secretary of Commerce Harriman announced today the industry-Government mission, to sail from New York Dec. 30, will:

Although mankind is "bitter, baffled and resentful" as Christmas approaches, those who sincerely believe in the church and all that it stands for will find again a source of confidence and courage for what lies ahead, the Right Rev. Charles K. Gilbert, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, said yesterday.

Two "great ideological battle lines" are forming throughout the world, Wilbur La Roe Jr., moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, declared last night. Mr. La Roe, Washington attorney and associate counsel for the Port of New York Authority, spoke at a special Christmas service in the Hollis Presbyterian Church, Hollis, Queens.

The contest-minded Ralph Edwards will follow up his recently concluded "Miss Hush" venture with another stake calling on contestants to settle a matter of identity, this one to be known as "The Walking Man." In announcing the contest over the week-end during his NBC feature, "Truth or Consequences," Mr. Edwards described the new unknown "as a person too famous to give hints to listeners by use of his voice."

"Northwest Harvest: A Regional Stock-taking," will be brought out by Macmillan on Jan. 20. It is a collection of fifteen speeches made at the Writers' Conference on the Northwest held in 1946 in Portland, Ore. The book was edited by V.L.O. Chittick.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A move is under way to commit 1,000,000 railroad workers to demand a work week of forty hours with pay equivalent to the present work week of forty-eight hours. This would mean an increase of 20 per cent in current wage rates.

The morale of Europe's displaced persons is "low and getting lower," and the United States should act promptly if it plans to "do anything at all" about absorbing some of the 1,000,000 or more homeless persons in camps in Austria, Germany and Italy, Ugo Carusi, former Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner, declared yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock's admirable summary of various proposals for operating the European Recovery Program which are under discussion in official circles includes this comment: "* * * the proposal for specific earmarking has gained small approval in the executive quarters where the President's outline for the ERP is being prepared."
Eight thousand assistants to Santa Claus will shoulder their bags starting at 7:15 A.M. today to begin their rounds, delivering parcels and messages of good cheer to residents of the city.

American aid to Europe is a "magnificent gesture, which, if inspired by the proper motive, may prove a turning point in these troubled times," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman said yesterday in his sermon at Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.

FRANCONIA, N.H., Dec. 21-- Two youngsters from the Eastern Slope region of New Hampshire, 18-year-old Brooks Dodge of Pinkham Notch and 17-year-old Billy Patch of North Conway, gave polished performances in the open giant slalom today on Cannon Mountain.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 21 -- The United States, in an effort to break the deadlock in the United Nations Military Staff Committee, has offered to scale down its estimate of the ground and air strength required for the proposed international police force, it was learned today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21--With Tommy Thompson tossing touchdown passes to Steve Van Buren and Jack Ferrante and Bosh Pritchard galloping 79 yards to score with a punt return, the Philadelphia Eagles today won their first Eastern Division championship in the National Football League.

BOSTON, Dec. 21 (AP)--Rookies Jim McFadden and Rod Morrison each scored twice as the Detroit Red Wings gained their fourth straight National Hockey League triumph over the Boston Bruins, 6--5, tonight before 13,900 fans at the Garden.

WARSAW, Dec. 21--The Polish Government believes that espionage for foreign powers, meaning mainly the United States and Britain, is increasing in this country, it was stated authoritatively today. It was indicated that the government would ask the British and United States Embassies to remove diplomats suspected of organizing espionage by Poles.

Paul Bellam, violinist, who spent the last three years making music for the Army in the Pacific, gave his first Town Hall recital late yesterday afternoon. Among the finer aspects of his abilities, the first to impress was a tone of unusual opulence and color, which he produced unpretentiously, and with apparent ease.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- An experimental rocket plane, the Bell XS-1, has flown faster than the speed of sound a number of times recently, Aviation Week reports in an issue to be released tomorrow.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The British Council, which is roughly the equivalent of the United States Information Service, has staffs at work in 50 countries, according to its annual report, issued today. It receives an annual Parliamentary grant of u3,000,000, about $12,000,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21-- The eight-cents-an-hour wage rise granted last week to dock workers on the West Coast will be increased three to six cents on Feb. 10, if expectations of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union materialize.

Jose Limon and his company gave their first performance of the season at the City Center last night, and a tremendous performance it was. Mr. Limon is not only a superb dancer, but he has also the great good judgment and good fortune to have Doris Humphrey as his artistic director and choreographer -in-chief.

A large bid sale of surplus supplies in Buffalo today, another in Maspeth, Queens, tomorrow, and fourteen new mail-order bid sales of an additional $4,000,000 in goods were announced over the weekend by John R. Campbell, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 21-- Prompted by a continuous drain of gold and foreign exchange resulting from the substantial increase in the deficit on the balance of trade throughout 1947, the National Bank of Switzerland announced last week that greater opportunities for making transfers of capital from the United States would be provided after Jan. 1.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 21 (AP)-- "Champs at last" and "Bring on those Cardinals."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--An official summary of the recommendations embodied in the second report of the President's Commission on Higher Education follows: "1. The first condition toward equality of opportunity for a college education can only be satisfied when every qualified young person, irrespective of race, creed, color, sex, national origin, or economic status is assured of the opportunity for a good high school education in an accredited institution.

A 50-year-old partner of a jewelry concern was held up by three men, two of them armed, in the deserted looby of 595 Fifth Avenue at Forty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon and robbed of jewelry and watches that he valued at $100,000.

After drawing even in the third period, the New York Rovers yielded a tally late in that stanza to drop a 4-3 decision to the Boston Olympics in an Eastern Hockey League battle before 11,417 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

Ozan Marsh, young pianist last heard here almost two years ago, appeared in Times Hall last night. At his command are all the requisite techniques of the accomplished pianist: fine shadings from whispering softness to fortissimo, from smooth, clean legato to a staccato which makes even the piano's lowest notes sound clearly.
TEHERAN, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Iranian Parliament tonight nominated two men, Ibrahim Hakimi, who twice before was Premier, and

ALTOONA, Pa., Dec. 21 (AP)-- Unbeaten and untied Penn State College's football eleven, primed for its New Year's Day engagement with Southern Methodist in the Cotton Bowl, left tonight for Dallas, Tex.
The President Released second annual report of his Council of Economic Advisers. Attended Constitution Hall concert by daughter, Margaret.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP)--Toronto protected its slim National Hockey League lead before 16,741 fans in Chicago Stadium tonight with a 3-to-1 victory over the last-place Black Hawks.

TOKYO, Dec. 21--The Left Wingers, forced into the background last spring by the compromises leading to the formation of the present coalition Government, are now making a strong drive to take control of the Socialist Party.

The Marine Falcon docked here yesterday morning with 616 passengers, including sixteen war brides and their twelve children, after an extremely rough voyage from Southampton, England. The Government - owned "emergency class" passenger vessel, which is operated by the United States Lines, was delayed two days in arriving after encountering heavy seas and strong westerly gales that were said to have reached fifty miles an hour.

Sound travels just as fast as molecules of air can be moved smoothly. The speed of sound has been set as the limit in speed for aircraft of known design because above this speed, air cannot get out of the way of the airplane. The plane would be moving faster than the molecules of nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide and other gases in the air could easily get out of its way.

The Philadelphia Americans, champions of the American Soccer League, gained the verdict over the Brooklyn Hisnanos at Hawthorne Field, yesterday, 8 to 3, latter leading at the interval by 3--0. The League champions chalked up 7 goals before Hispano began to score.

Buyers remained at home last week to attend to holiday needs at the store and the wholesale markets therefore generally were quiet, except for a few reorders on fill-in items, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The construction and expansion program envisioned by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for the next four years will cost $280,000,000, Ralph H. Tapscott, president, announced yesterday. Early in 1947 the company reported that its five-year post-war program would involve the expenditure of $250,000,000.

ROME, Dec. 21(AP)--A nationwide strike of 300,000 food workers was settled tonight, less than forty-eight hours after it had begun, assuring Italians that food stores would be open for Christmas provisioning.

B.W. Dyer Co. Year-end bonuses have been granted to employes of B.W. Dyer Co., sugar economists and brokers, based on individual productivity, company profits, and length of service.

Instead of constituting a spur to inflation, tax reductions would aid in fighting it, the National Association of Manufacturers declared over the week-end. This is true, it pointed out, because whereas the Government spends all it receives in ways which create demand for consumer goods, private citizens would save some of the money left them by the tax reduction.

Meredith Nicholson was the last leaf on a famous literary tree that grew in Indiana. It was a sturdy tree, pleasant and shady, watered in the American tradition with its roots deep in the soil of the state. In its day it was one of the outstanding features of our literary landscape.

The construction and expansion program envisioned by Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for the next four years will cost $280,000,000, Ralph H. Tapscott, president, announced yesterday. Early in 1947 the company reported that its five-year post-war program would involve the expenditure of $250,000,000.

ROME, Dec. 21(AP)--A nationwide strike of 300,000 food workers was settled tonight, less than forty-eight hours after it had begun, assuring Italians that food stores would be open for Christmas provisioning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--In anticipation of a difficult fight over several aspects of the Administration's European Recovery Program, Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, has sent out a call to influential interested persons to "offer to testify on the bill or be subpoenaed."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--The State Department has been kept informed of all developments of the case of Nikolas Kyriazidis, Greek newspaper man now being detained at Ellis Island, by the Immigration and Naturalization Service of the Department of Justice, a Department spokesman said tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 21 (AP)--New York farmers produced $355,935,000 worth of fruits, vegetables and grain products in 1947, three per cent less than last year, the State Agriculture Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21--A national scholarship program for colleges and universities, with an immediate outlay of $135,000,000, was advocated by the President's Commission on Higher Education in a report made public here today, the second of six.

The Eightieth Congress showed that its majorities had a strong sense of our international obligations, but it went home without doing the simple thing it might have done to help Europe's Displaced Persons. Why this strange blindness to the needs of individuals when our responsibility for the needs of nations is freely admitted?

NEW DELHI, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Indian Defense Ministry said tonight Indian troops had killed 140 trans-border raiders and wounded eighty-five in the past two days in the towns of Poonch and Jhangar in Kashmir State.

Final plans for construction of an underpass at Kew Gardens, Queens, to end one of the borough's most serious traffic bottlenecks, will be submitted soon to the Board of Estimate, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP)-- Records of the Department of Justice show that 3.707 Russian Government officials are in the United States on various missions, Senator Millard E. Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, revealed today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21--Aboveaverage prices for corn will continue for a considerable time, according to traders, as the result of an actual scarcity of the grain in the states that ship most of the commercial corn that enters into interstate commerce.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The threat of a nation-wide strike of Western Union employes was postponed apparently for a matter of weeks as the company and unions reached an agreement tonight to submit to a fact-finding board the determination of technical differences that have impeded collective bargaining.

The Canadiens of Montreal finally managed to defeat the New York Rangers. Unsuccessful in four previous attempts, the Flying Frenchmen enjoyed their first victory of the campaign over the local crew last night, when they beat Frank Boucher's skaters at Madison Square Garden by the score of 4 to 3.
Boyce Tuten has been named manager of the chemical department of the United States Foreign Corporation. He formerly was with Dayton Price Co.

LONDON, Dec. 21--Several events in the last few days have helped inspire a more hopeful spirit in financial markets and business circles generally. Almost all these developments will contribute directly and indirectly toward stimulation of Britain's export trade and in saving dollars.

After pondering other subjects for an entire fortnight, the theatre has returned to Galileo. Barrie Stavis' "Lamp at Midnight" was produced by New Stages in a reformed motion-picture theatre at 159 Bleecker Street last evening. It is a deeply moving play with a passionate theme and a resolute point of view.

GENEVA, Dec. 21--The indications that President Truman may name as head of the United States delegation to the Economic Commission for Europe the person who will also head the European Recovery Program's administration in Europe have caused considerable excitement here.
The city began yesterday to assume its full holiday garb, as doorways bloomed with holly wreaths and churches were more crowded than usual in preparation for Christmas.

A return to the pre-war practice of moderately priced all-expense tours to Europe on medium-speed ships is possible soon, Arnold Bernstein, president of the steamship company bearing his name, declared yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 21 (UP) --The University of Michigan football team went sight-seeing today before getting down to hard work for the New Year's Day Rose Bowl game, while the opposing University of Southern California squad set up training quarters in Santa Barbara.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)-- Governors of twenty-eight states today were asked by Senator Charles W. Tobey, Republican, of New Hampshire, to consider appointment of local emergency fuel coordinators as one step toward overcoming fuel oil shortages in their areas.

VIENNA, Dec. 21--Austria, under the pressure of the Marshall plan and the Export-Import Bank system of granting loans for rehabilitation, finally appears to be setting up active, coordinated central state economic planning.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (AP) --Head Coach Don Faurot, Missouri's contribution to the New Year's Day East-West Shrine football game, after sizing up his West squad gave out these impressions today:

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 21--Labor leaders in Germany's western zones are looking forward to increased organizing activity after Jan. 1. It is believed that the occupying powers will make clear their intentions toward political unification at that time.

PARIS, Dec. 21--France's new anti-Communist Force Ouvriere labor group today began its campaign to win the vast nonpolitical labor masses that it must control if it is to supersede the Communist -dominated General Confederation of Labor.

BERLIN, Dec. 21--American plans to proceed swiftly with the decartelization of German industry in the United States-British zones is being seriously delayed by the British Control Commission, American Military Government officers said today.

ROME, Dec. 21--An attempt to mobilize agricultural workers in support of communism at the next general election was begun this morning in Bologna. The Constituent Assembly of the Land was inaugurated under Communist sponsorship by 5,000 peasant delegates from all parts of Italy.

Twenty years ago the first lowrent housing in the heart of the lower East Side--the Lavanburg Foundation development at 132 Baruch Place--accepted its first tenant. Last night at an anniversary party in the central recreation room many of the original tenants were present.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The White House and State Department are evidently not too happy about the attention given to the foreign policy pronouncements of President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall last Friday.

Henry A. Wallace continued yesterday to maintain complete silence on the "Draft Wallace for President" movement being carried on by the Progressive Citizens of America, with which the former Vice President is closely associated.
LONDON, Dec. 22 (UP)--Premier Stalin has been elected to the Moscow City Soviet by the unanimous vote of all 1,617 voters registered in his district, the Moscow radio said today.
ROME, Dec. 22--By 453 votes to 62. the Constituent Assembly this afternoon approved the new Constitution of the Italian Republic. The definitive draft was received with great enthusiasm.
Without an opinion, the Appellate Division, Second Department, upheld upanimpusly yesterday a restrictive covenant that bars the sale of property to a Negro.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 22-- All operational units of the Indian Army will be under the command of Indian officers by Jan. 1, 1948, and an Indian officer will be appointed Commander in Chief, taking over on April 1, Sardar Baldev Singh, Defense Minister, announced today.

Store Sales Here Up 8% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 8 per cent for the week ended Dec. 20, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Electric ceiling panel heating is featured in the prefabricated model house at Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street, which will be opened today as the temporary headquarters for the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service during the drive for funds to finance the organization's child charity work.

THIS reporter is now a crushed and broken man, his spirit irrevocably shattered. Never again dare he raise his voice on a controversial issue and never, never, never can he say one unkind word about the Russians. Alas and alack, the most dreadful thing has happened. This column has been violently attacked by The Daily Worker.

Opposition to the proposed affiliation of the marine department of the American Communications Association, CIO, with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, CIO, was expressed by the Radio Officers Union, AFL, in a letter to the MEBA made public here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP)--Charlie Conacher of Toronto, former member of the Maple Leafs' famed "kid line," and Vine of three hockey famous brothers, today was appointed coach of the struggling Chicago Black Hawks, succeeding Johnny Gottselig, who was "kicked upstairs" as general manager of the Hawks' farm system.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP)-- Secretary of Commerce W. Averel Harriman summoned today fifteen top steel executives to meet in Washington Jan. 8 to draft voluntary agreements for increasing production and channeling scarc steel to the most essential users.

Sworn in as a probationary patrolman on Friday and married on Saturday, Patrolman Emanuel Hauser made his first arrest on Sunday and was commended by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Reports have reached here of serious discussions in industrial circles of voluntary measures to halt inflation, and the capital would not be surprised if one materializes rather soon. The immediate proposal--that an important segment of industry offer to reduce prices by about 5 per cent if its organized labor agrees to seek no general wage increases while the plan is being tried-- was under consideration before Congress passed the Taft anti-inflation bill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP)-- The lists of large traders in the commodity markets released today by the Agriculture Department follow: (The list shows whether the traders reported they were long or short in the market and whether their dealings were for "hedging" or were "speculative or spreading.")

A Christmas exchange between the Netherlands and this country was unfolded yesterday in two announcements. While 5,000 pounds of lilac blooms arrived here aboard a Royal Dutch Airlines plane from Amsterdam, news came simultaneously from the Cooperative for American Remittances to Europe (CARE) of a new program designed to supply 5,000 families in Holland with American coal to help relieve a fuel shortage.

Any day now Helen Hayes will affix her signature to contracts binding her to appear in the Theatre Guild production of "My Favorite Blonde." This is S. N. Behrman's version of the Marcel Achard play now running in Paris under the name of "Aupres Ma Blonde," with Yvonne Printemps.

PARIS, Dec. 22--Mickey Mouse shared the highest honors of stardom today with clowns and performing animals at the second annual Christmas party for the orphan children of Paris sponsored by United States residents in the French capital.

There was a tremendous snipping and scraping yesterday at the Moler School of Barbering, 154 East Twenty-third Street, as 400 barbers demonstrated their proficiency with scissors and razor. The State of New York, through its Division of License, was testing -- somewhat belatedly -- the qualifications of barbers for a license, required under a law signed by Gov. Dewey on April 16, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The Council of Economic Advisers declared in its second annual report to President Truman today that industrial prices and profits would have to be reduced and "gross imbalances" in the wage structure rectified if the economy was to be stabilized.

ROME, Dec. 22 (AP)--On the Swisslike snowfields of Selva Di Val Gardena in the Dolomites Alps, Italy's skiers are training for the winter Olympics at St. Moritz but only a few names have been added to the Italian line-up which competed at Garmisch-Partenkirchen, Germany, in 1936.

There will be only standing room available at Madison Square Garden tonight for the college basketball double-header there. Obviously, then, a sell-out crowd of more than 18,000 will witness the twin bill, in which Kentucky faces St. John's and N. Y. U. engages Cornell.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Frontiers facing Palestine were virtually closed tonight to all nonArabs. Consulates here flatly refused visas to Americans seeking to travel in the Middle East outside Palestine except on direct appeal to the various capitals of the Arab countries.

LONDON, Dec. 22--The determination of owners and editors of British daily newspapers and news weeklies to defend their independence and to run their own affairs is expressed in evidence submitted to the Royal Commission on the Press and issued today.
Boyce Tuten has been named manager of the chemical department of the United States Foreign Corporation. He formerly was with Dayton Price Co.
