LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Dec. 22--Plans for a world children's congress, intended to dramatize collection of funds for child relief, were flatly and surprisingly rejected tonight by a seven-nation subcommittee of the United Nations Economic and Social Council.
Upsets marked play yesterday it the Eastern junior and boys' indoor tennis championships on the courts of the Metropolitan Tennis Glut at the 369th Regiment Armory.

After three rounds, which Were not completed, Harvard's players still held a slender lead last night in the annual tournament of the H. Y. P. D. Chess League for the Belden-Stephens Trophy at the Marshall Club.

The necessity for a separation of church and state in the field of public education was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Moshe Davis, dean of the Teachers Institute and College of Jewish Studies of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, at the second annual Rabbinical Assembly conference on Jewish education.
BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 22 (AP)-- A Dutch Army communique said today that 150 Indonesian "terrorists" were "liquidated" Dec. 9 in operations in the Krawang area, forty-three miles east of Batavia.

The 1948 RCA-Victor television line now on the market will remain unchanged through next year, Irving Sarnoff, vice president of Bruno-New York, Inc., metropolitan area distributors of radio and television products for the RCA-Victor division of the Radio Corporation of America, declared in an interview yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22-- Three public utility companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering an aggregate of $26,000,000 of bonds.
New York State was asked yesterday by Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, to increase its contribution toward the city's child day-care centers from 33 to 50 per cent.

For centuries it has been the custom in England to serve plum pudding at Christmastime. Yuletide feasting in Italy calls for panettone and fried eels, and in France for the buche de noel, a chocolate-frosted cake in the shape of a log.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 22--Friedrich Flick, the first to industrialist to be arraigned on war crimes charges, was found guilty today on three of four counts by a United States Military tribunal headed by Judge Charles B. Sears of Buffalo, N. Y. He was sentenced to serve seven years, dating from his imprisonment on June 13, 1945.

Admitting that plumbing facilities at Public School 54, 104th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, were antiquated, Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, said plans and funds for their renovation had been approved and that the work would start soon.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP)--Yankee Hill, flying the Amsterdam, N. Y., silks of poloplayer Laddie Sanford, improved considerably off one previous effort here to capture today's featured Ocala Purse, before a crowd of 8,328 at Gulfstream Park.
Two more steps in the accelerated campaign to ease traffic congestion were taken yesterday.

The National Draft Eisenhower for President League, was reorganized yesterday, with Stuart Scheftel, publisher of Young America, a weekly magazine, succeeding Winston H. Thornburg, advertising executive, as its chairman.

The Macmillan Company has contracted with the American Council of Learned Societies for the publication of a series of translations of Russian books that are standard in their various fields in the Soviet Union. The volumes have been edited by a board under the direction of W. Chapin Huntington, editor of the Russian Translation Project of the Council.

The New York City Rent Advisory Board announced yesterday that it would conduct a three-hour public hearing on Jan. 12 for proponents of a general rent increase in the city and Long Island, and a similar hearing on Jan. 19 for those opposing an increase or requesting a decrease.

LONDON, Dec. 22--Foreign Secretary Bevin urged the Russians today to stop the conflict over the United States' European Recovery Program. He spoke after a luncheon held by the Association of American Correspondents in London.

The last remaining space in the taxpayer containing five stores being erected by Sam Minskoff Sons at 193-197 East Post Road, White Plains, N. Y., has been leased for ten years by Mannie H. Poster and Etta Greengold. The lessees will occupy the premises as the Green Post, retailing women's wearing apparel, lingerie and cosmetics.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Dollar stocks were marked up substantially on Wall Street advices in a generally bright stock market here today. Under the lead of Bethlehem Steel, which advanced 7 1/2 points, other dollar issues were as much as 2 1/2 points better.

Time Magazine's international edition leads as "first choice publication" among key businessmen in Latin America, according to the findings of a special survey conducted for the magazine by Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and made public yesterday.

Kirsten Flagstad, former leading Wagnerian soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, who has been the subject of political discussion and demonstrations at her recent recitals throughout the country, was picketed outside and cheered inside Carnegie Hall last night.

OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Dec. 22 (AP)--Youth and competitive spirit may combine to give the United States one of its better Olympic speed skating teams this year, but the European racing style probably will prove too much again, Coach Peter J. Miller of Chicago conceded today.

TOKYO, Dec. 22--Japanese Government employes are continuing their battle for higher wages. Today a large number of members of the Finance Ministry's Workers Union didn't report for work, following an announcement of their intention to take an indefinite holiday.

Homer L. Ferguson, who headed the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company in Virginia for thirty-two years, and his second in command, Roger Williams, will retire from active participation in the affairs of the major shipyard on Dec. 31, it was announced last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Three men and three organizations charged with racketeering in the $125,000,000 - a - year Dock Street produce market entered pleas of innocent today in Federal District Court.

WHITE PLAINS. N. Y., Dec. 22 --Although criticized by some civic organizations and picketed by a Santa Claus hired by taxpayers, the Westchester County Board of Supervisors adopted record budgets of $23,228,955 for 1948 today and arranged to adopt next Monday a number of salary increases permissible under vague headings in the compilations.
Four hundred and twenty-three local hospitals and health and welfare agencies are sharing today a $3,200,000 Christmas gift sent out yesterday by the Greater New York Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Edwin W. Pauley admitted tonight that he had asked to be relieved as Democratic National Committeeman from California.

The third December grand jury voted yesterday that there were no grounds for subornation of perjury charges against Sherman Billingsley, proprietor of the Stork Club, in connection with an allegation that he paid $600 to a kitchen hand for favorable testimony in his behalf before a state unfair labor practice hearing.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 22 (UP)-- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, appointed pro-British Dr. Ibrahim Hakimi as Premier of Iran today as authorities discussed the fate of former Premier Ahmad Ghavam, deposed Dec. 10 and reported jailed Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Connie Mack, 85 years old tomorrow, says his Philadelphia Athletics would be a 1948 American League pennant contender "if I had new second and third basemen who could hit hard and run fast."

BERLIN, Dec. 22--Germans living in the United States zone again have expressed an overwhelming preference for national socialism over communism, according to a Military Government survey made available today. Asked which of the two forms of government they would choose if they had a choice, 31 per cent of the native Germans interviewed said they would rather have nazism, as against 4 per cent who would try communism.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (AP)--Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, declared today that criticism of Britain's control system was "ill-informed."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Two men sentenced to die within the next three weeks for the slaying of a New York honor detective in the Bronx on Dec. 13, 1946, today received a stay of execution from the Supreme Court, which will review their case.

PARIS, Dec. 22--An estimated 500,000 organized Government employes are ready to quit the old General Confederation of Labor (CGT) and join the new antiCommunist CGT--Force Ouvriere (Workers' Force), it was said at its headquarters tonight.

VIENNA, Dec. 22--The Austrian income from the sale of free deliveries of food and similar necessities from United States Army relief and the aid designed to follow the closing of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration is now approaching the total income from the sale of UNRRA goods.

With a sales volume of more than 57,100,000, Macy's Herald Square store last week beat its own previous record to set a new mark for a single week's sales, Macy officials announced yesterday. Total volume for Macy's New York (including the Parkchester and Jamaica branch stores) was slightly in excess of $8,000,000.

The Musicians' Gulld, which gave the first concert of Its second season at Times Hall last night, has cause to be proud this morning. It has been the inspiration of a new work of immense charm, Bohuslav Martinu's Three Madrigals for Violin and Viola, which had its first performance last night.

PARIS, Dec. 22--Premier Robert Schuman's coalition of Centrist parties consolidating its strength in the long-drawn debate over the austerity bills, today repulsed a frontal attack from supporters of Charles de Gaulle.
The Christmas garden at The Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum's medieval branch in Fort Trypn Park, received yesterday its finishing touches for the holiday season.

An offer of a general wage increase of 56 a week, retroactive to Aug. 1, and a rise in the minimum hiring wage from $26 to $30 was unanimously accepted by 3,500 workers of Gimbels and Saks Thirty-fourth Street department stores last night.
BALTIMORE, Dec. 22--The Right Rev. Edward T. Helfenstein, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Maryland from 1929 to 1943 died of a heart ailment this morning in his home here at the age of 82.

Rises in cotton yarns have affected hosiery pricing to a greater extent than any other type of yarn used in the industry, according to a study made by the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. The sharp rises in cotton, it was pointed out, are in contrast to the very moderate increase in rayon yarn and 47 per cent decrease in nylon yarn prices during the last seven years.

The Gold Cup, international horse race, run for the first time last summer, again will serve as one of the turf's feature attractions in the metropolitan area next year, it was announced yesterday by the Empire City Racing Association. The second running of the $100,000 added event will take place at Belmont Park on Saturday, Oct. 16.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22-- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today completed arrangements to borrow Gregory Peck from Twentieth Century-Fox for the leading role of "The Story of Monte Stratton," which Guy Trosper is writing. The photoplay deals with the career of the Chicago White Sox pitcher who continued to play baseball after losing his leg.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation of New York has added another property to its holdings in Philadelphia, where it has purchased the twenty-two-story Mitten Building at Broad and Locust Streets from the Transit Investment Corporation.

Those who appreciate the art of book binding should not miss the collection of masterpieces of original French Modern Bindings from 1880 to 1947, now on exhibition at the French Office of Cultural Affairs, 934 Fifth Avenue. The exhibit can be seen every day in the week until Jan. 17.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with interest the dispatch from Jerusalem of Dec. 13 by your correspondent, Sam Brewer. What caught my attention is his valuation of the trend of events. I have in mind the following words: "Observers here are virtually unanimous in the belief that the chances of serious and prolonged fighting in Palestine have been dangerously underrated in America and elsewhere.

SHANGHAI, Dec. 22 (Reuters) --Fighting raged twenty miles south of Mukden, big Manchurian city, today as Chinese Communist troops, continuing their advance, met with stiffer resistance from Government forces.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 22 (AP) --It was rugged double duty today for both the Michigan Wolverines, training at Brookside Park here, and for the Southern California Trojans, working out 100 miles to the north at Santa Barbara for the Jan. 1 Rose Bowl game.

From ten-cent store counters and subway stands to shops on Park Avenue, flower sellers agreed yesterday that this Christmas would be as busy for them as any during the war. Flowers and blossoming plants of many kinds are in good supply.

WARSAW, Dec. 22--After a three-hour speech that was more of a political harangue than a summation of evidence, the prosecutor in the trial of the Polish underground coordination committee demanded today death sentences for three of the seven accused Poles.

Hunter College students and faculty members described yesterday their impressions of academic freedom at a rally on civil liberties at the Hunter College playhouse for which the Student Council was sponsor.

High bids totaling $151,750 were received for eight business properties at 2-30 Broadway comprising the blockfront on the west side of Broadway from Board Street to Seventh Avenue, Newark, N. J., at the auction sale held by Joseph P. Day, Inc., last Friday in the Robert Treat Hotel in Newark.
An appraisal of $750,000 yesterday was placed by General Manager George Weiss on the sixteen ball players the Yankees will bring up next year to strengthen the American League club.

Nine former luxury liners and two old freighters recently offered for sale by the Maritime Commission will wind up in scrap yards unless bought by foreign-flag companies, the Steamship Historical Society of America reported yesterday. All eleven ships saw war service as transports or hospital craft.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission received two requests today to reopen the reorganization proceedings of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company for further consideration.
Seattle, Wash., announced yesterday it would receive bids Jan. 12 on $5,500,000 of public safety building bonds dated Feb. 1, 1948, due in from two to twenty years and callable in five years.

Post-holiday markdowns and January white sale promotions will be limited in scope by higher replacement costs and a continued tight supply situation in, most goods, it was reported here yesterday. As a general rule, larger metropolitan stores which have been, conserving stocks of white goods for the traditional January events will be in a better position to feature these goods than most medium and smaller stores.

GHICAGO, Dec. 22--Liquidation developed in December grain contracts on the Board of Trade today. General selling developed late in the session after December corn had shown strength early, and the finish was about at the bottom, with December wheat off 4 3/4 to 5 3/4 ts a bushel.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Vegetable Rarebit is the meatsaving Peace Plate suggested for today's dinnner. It is to be served hot over left-over or fresh-cooked peas, snap beans, broccoli, carrots or corn, or over baked potatoes broken open and sprinkled with salt and pepper.

BERLIN, Dec. 22--The firm determination not to take any "irrevocable" steps toward--a split in Germany was expressed by both the American and British Military Governors today. Both voiced the intention to do nothing calculated to break up the Allied regime in Berlin.

HAVANA, Dec. 22 (AP)--Patricia ("Satira") Schmidt was sentenced today to fifteen years in prison for the yacht slaying of her lover, John Lester Mee, and she indicated tonight, her lawyer said, that she might seek a pardon from President Ramon Grau san Martin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Reporting on the improvement of the privately owned electric utility industry in its financial condition between the end of 1937 and the conclusion, of last year, the Federal Power Commission pointed out today that the plant investment of the industry had risen in the nine-year period from $13,852,000,000 to $14,952,000,000.

Nine newspaper editors and publishers have accepted invitations to participate in NBC's annual year-end news review and forecast for the coming year. The round-up of editorial opinion is scheduled for Sunday from 4:30 to 5 P. M. As announced by NBC, the list will include:
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 22 (AP)--The Olympic ski leap here has undergone a face-lifting job in preparation for the winter games, but the profile has not been changed.
New Year's Eve will bring a country-wide showdown between the International Typographical Union, AFL, and the commercial printing industry over the union's "no contract" policy.

The city administration is preparing legislation that would remove the state prohibition against use of oleomargarine instead of butter in city hospitals and other public Institutions, it was disclosed yesterday by Harold L. Herzstein, legislative representative for Mayor O'Dwyer.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP)--The two adopted children of Mrs. Muriel McCormick Hubbard, in a conference with reporters supervised by Superior Judge John A. Sbarbaro, declared today that the wealthy heiress had administered severe punishments to them and that they did not love her.

Three city agencies and two large corporations spent all day yesterday in an unsuccessful attempt to find the source of the gasoline leak into the IRT subway station at Lexington Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 22 (UP)--The American Newspaper Publishers Association and the International Printing Pressmen's Union, AFL, today announced renewal for another five-year period of their international arbitration agreement, which was first signed forty years ago.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 22--The Argentine General Labor Confederation, which is wholly dominated by the Government, will not send a delegation to the Inter-American labor meeting in Lima, 'Peru, next month, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--As Christmas decorations were put up at the White House today, Mrs. Truman's secretaries announced the Christmas dinner menu.
A Christmas Fable A correspondent has sent this corner a cutting from a newspaper. He has written below the picture--which is all there is on that scrap of paper: "Christmas at Hezekiah Cobb's."

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP)--Today's report at the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Saiable hogs 12,000 head, total 14,500; market active, generally half a dollar higher than Friday all weights butchers and sows; good and choice 170 to 250 pound weights, mostly $27.25 to $27.50; practical top $27.50; around one load at $27.75.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 22--A shipload of 800 Jews trying to enter Palestine without permits was intercepted off the coast tonight by the British Navy.

The six-story office building at 45 to 51 East Thirty-third Street has been sold by Charles R. Maxwell, the Mayson Realty Corporation and others to investment clients of Cyrus Gordon. The building is occupied by Harper Brothers, publishers, who have taken an additional lease for twenty -one years at a rental aggregating about $1,000,000.
NEWARK, N. J., Dec. 22 -- A strike of 3,000 ironworkers impeded progress today on $50,000,000 in North Jersey industrial construction projects.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The Interstate Commerce Commission today issued notice it would investigate the reasonableness of the share of revenue received by northeastern railroads on traffic they receive from railroads in the South and Southwest.

David Nadien. violinist, who gave his third New York recital last night it Town Hall, has come a long way since his debut almost eight years ago. His first appearance was as a 14-year-old prodigy at a children's concert of the New York Philharmonic - Symphony, whereas last year he played with the same orchestra at a regular concert as an adult soloist, his reward for winning the seventh annual Leventritt award.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The steady accumulation and mounting of foreign problems and programs are threatening Congress with a serious bottleneck in international affairs. This was disclosed today by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. This committee is the point of the logjam.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Increasing the amount of personal and dependents' exemptions, now $500, allowed in determination of Federal income taxes would "tend to dampen demands for wage rate increases," the Treasury Department said in a report on such exemptions made public today.

Oil Merger Abandoned The proposed merger of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation and the Mission Corporation into the Sunray Oil Corporation has been abandoned. Recently, the proposal was blocked by a legal action instituted by William G. Skelly, president of Skelly Oil Company and a director of Mission, which resulted in a United States Court in Nevada forbidding a special meeting of Mission stockholders.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 22-- The partition of Palestine was all but forgotten in Syria and Lebanon today in fright over the outbreak of cholera in the Syrian villages of Mouhajje and Kounaye, where fifty --three cases and fifteen deaths have been reported officially thus far.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22--Illinois lawenforcement officials, judges and other members of the legal profession today hailed the United States Supreme Court decision reversing the murder conviction of Tony Marino, 41 years old, who has been incarcerated in the state's prisons since April, 1925.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Edward A. Alexander on Dec. 11 discussed in THE TIMES the Thomas Committee hearings on communism. He believes that a Congressional committee has every right to obtain information so that the Congress may frame laws.
The President Released second annual report of his Council of Economic Advisers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Legislation to direct the Interstate Commerce Commission to investigate Western freight rates has been placed in charge of a Senate Commerce subcommittee.
Fresh as the green isle itself is the Irish collection of resort clothes now to be found at Peck Peck's.
The celebration of Christmas in the churches of the city will begin tomorrow noon with a traditional carol service in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church at Broadway and Wall Street.

HAVANA, Dec. 22--With the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment past the scheduled half-way mark, it is still impossible to tell whether it will be a success or failure. But a crisis has developed over "QR"--that is, quantitative restrictions such as import quotas--that could wreck the whole idea of international economic cooperation for world peace and prosperity.

Wholesale prices of hand-woven Persian rugs will rise from 15 to 20 per cent after the first of the year, a department store Oriental rug buyer predicted yesterday. He said the increases will be over and above those in the last few weeks, which range from 10 to 15 percent.

LONDON, Dec. 22--Large-scale plans to modernize Great Britain's mines, to increase mechanical equipment in the pits and improve the quantity and quality of coal were disclosed today by Lord Hyndley, chairman of the National Coal Board, in a review of 1947 and a forecast of prospects for 1948.

By putting his head together with Dostoyevsky's, Rodney Ackland has conjured up an imaginative and flaring drama that needs a perfectly-trained company. It is a dramatization of "Crime and Punishment." With distinguished actors in the chief parts, it was staged by Komisarjevsky at the National last evening.

The police of the West Fiftyfourth Street station announced late last night the arrest of a 26year-old Army corporal who, they said, had admitted he had held up thirty-two delicatessen, liquor, hardware and drug stores in the West Side area during the last two and a half months.

Little more than a minute before time ran out, Nat Miller of L. I. U. scooped up a loose ball and curled in the lay-up that enabled the Brooklyn Blackbirds to defeat Oregon University, 49--47, at Madison Square Garden last night. L. I. U.'s thrill-packed triumph followed a top-heavy 82-46 City College rout of Utah State.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22--University of Chicago astronomers reported today that the new comet, which turned up in the southern skies of this hemisphere Dec. 14, had been observed as it broke in two on the evening of Dec. 18.

Employes of Russeks Fifth Avenue, Inc., in the New York, Brooklyn and Chicago stores, had their Christmas brightened this year with bonuses and gifts totaling approximately $150,000, Max Weinstein, chairman of the board, and David Nemerov, president, announced jointly yesterday.

The speed of sound marks a threshold in aerodynamics. As it is approached, wings no longer part the air with ease. Shock waves batter and try to twist and rend the plane. Streamlining is no help. In fact, the noses of fuselages must be as pointed as artillery shells, wings as thin and sharp as knives.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP) --Richer by nearly one hundred million dollars after three weeks of burley tobacco auctions, Kentucky leaf producers joined growers in the rest of the burley belt today in beginning a Christmas holiday period which will extend until Jan. 5.

General Sessions Judge John A. Mullen reserved decision yesterday on a motion for a special panel of 150 jurors from which to select a jury for the forthcoming trial of Mrs. Doris Coppola, wife of Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola, and her father, David T. Lehman, on charges of first-degree perjury in connection with the slaying of Joseph R. Seottoriggio.

FRANCONIA, N. H., Dec. 22-- Having played host to more than 200 competitive skiers--a recordbreaking field--in the first major meet of the 1947-48 season the past week-end, this peaceful New England village was looking forward tonight to another recordbreaking throng, this time by the recreational devotees, for the holiday period.

Leading Southern educators yesterday voiced their opposition to the recommendation of the President's Commission on Higher Education that the dual system of schools, now in effect in seventeen states, be eliminated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP)--A group of atomic scientists and a military team of admirals and generals were assigned today to organize and staff the new proving ground for atomic weapons at Eniwetok, in the Far Pacific.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP)--Bob Feller of the Cleveland Indians today said he anticipates no salary trouble next season in face of reports that the Tribe plans to cut down the attendance bonus which gave him a reported $85,000 this year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The Administration, not waiting for Congress to reassemble and begin its promised grand-scale investigations of alleged "insiders" in speculation, made public today a list of large traders in grain and other commodities.

Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang, more widely known as China's "Christian General," declared yesterday he would refuse to comply with orders from Generalissimo Chiang Kai-Shek's Nanking government to return home before the end of the year.
Santa Claus made a streamlined entrance here yesterday, arriving by helicopter instead of down the chimney to usher in Christmas week festivities.

Although, final figures on the deer kill during the recent season in Pennsylvania are incomplete, the State Game Commission estimates that a minimum of 80,000 were taken legally, in addition to the 3,000 illegal deer. The illegal kill, according to the commission, was a result of honest mistakes, carelessness and deliberate violations.

ATHENS, Dec. 22--Communist party members said tonight that the formation of the "Democratic Government of Free Greece" had not yet been announced because the Governments of Greece's northern neighbors [Yugoslavia, Bulgaria, Albania] were withholding full support.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Counsel for the International Typographical Union refused today to comply with a subpoena of the National Labor Relations Board, thereby inviting a court test of a collateral issue in the unfair-laborpractice case brought by the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--The Administration's caution in approaching the question of aid to China, as manifested in last week's hearings before the Senate Appropriations Committee is based on two principal considerations, according to informed sources today.

NANKING, Dec. 22 (AP)--Reports from Central China said today that Chinese Communists apparently were operating under instructions to arrest United States missionaries and other Americans because of United States support of President Chiang Kai-shek's Government.

Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, wartime purchasing officer for the Air Force, appeared yesterday in the Federal District Court, Brooklyn, for arraignment on two indictments charging perjury and subornation of perjury returned against him last Friday in Washington.

The city's fiscal year began on July 1. Its transit system has now reported income and outlay for the first three months of that fiscal year, operating as usual on the five-cent fare. The result was an operating loss of $8,119,164 for the three months. To this should properly be added the expenditure for debt service, which amounts to $14,250,000 for three months.

LONDON, Dec. 22--Christmas shoppers were still crowding London stores today and milling goodnaturedly before well - stocked counters. The holiday spirit along Oxford and Regent Streets and on Piccadilly is high, as are prices, but Londoners are finding in limited quantities the toys and consumer goods they had gone without for eight long years.
The cotton futures market closed 15 to 38 points net lower yesterday, with operations on the New York Cotton Exchange on a reduced scale.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Dec. 22--Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, acting on news of the detention at Ellis Island of a Greek Communist correspondent accredited to the international organization, today formally called the attention of the United States to provisions of the United Nations Headquarters agreement under which the United States grants special status to accredited reporters.
LONDON, Dec. 22--British Communists hotly denied today charges by the Labor party that Communist -inspired attempts to foment discontent among workers could be expected.

A gay Yuletide fete entitled the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball was given last night in the grand ballroom of the WaldorfAstoria. One hundred and thirty debutantes of this season assembled at the party, many of them making their formal debuts there.
HAIFA, Palestine, Dec. 22 (AP)-- Arabs and Jews still work here side by side on the docks, at oil companies and refineries and in shipping the Palestine citrus crop.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 22--Unless the Germans collect more food now from indigenous sources, they face a crisis next spring equal if not greater than that of last April, which resulted in wide-scale unrest, official sources disclosed today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22--Hearings into the strike started Nov. 24 against this city's six major daily newspapers by Local 16 of the International Typographical Union, AFL, were opened today by a subcommittee of the House Committee on Education and Labor, headed by Representative Thomas L. Owens, Republican, of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Three Supreme Court justices took Illinois to task today for making a hopeless legal "merry-go-round" for prisoners claiming they were convicted in violation of their constitutional rights.

More than two and a half years after the victory in Europe the long voyage home for American troops in Italy ended at 5:15 P. M. yesterday with the docking at Pier 11, Stapleton, Staten Island, of the 17,000-ton Army Transport Admiral William S. Sims.
A spirit of sacrifice marked the gifts that came yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, three days before Christmas.

The stock market lost its forward motion yesterday after making some gains in the morning and inal prices were generally lower. There were only a few major price changes, except, in the oil section, and the combined averages fell 0.56 point on the day.

Further upward price revisions to take effect after January 1 were received by industrial purchasing agents here yesterday. Increases from 5 to 10 per cent were scheduled for a complete line of drill presses and drill heads. Purchasing agents said it was significant in that there were no promises of improved deliveries.

A New York State Public Service Commission employe told Commissioner George A. Arkwright yesterday that only nine Manhattan -bound Long Island Rail Road trains had arrived on time during the morning rush-hour periods last July.

Sometimes we think of "charity" as a right, to be exercised or denied. Philanthropy has often meant a willingness to be magnanimous after one has met his obligations to himself and to society. But the biblical and classical history of "charity" is that of a virtue as hard in its self-imposition as it is kindly toward the object of its affection.

Dennis Pat Brady, Hartford lightweight, gave Johnny Dell, rugged Brooklynite, a boxing lesson in six of the ten rounds they fought last night at the St. Nicholas Arena and his reward was to hear the decision announced in favor of his rival.

The morale of Europe's displaced persons is "low and getting lower," and the United States should act promptly if it plans to "do anything at all" about absorbing some of the 1,000,000 or more homeless persons in camps in Austria, Germany and Italy, Ugo Carusi, former Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Here are some definitions of the "trade terminology" which the Agriculture Department used in making public its first list of commodity market traders: Hedging -- A standard business transaction in which a trader protects himself against possible price changes.

Nineteen girls and women were graduated yesterday afternoon from the first course in "baby sitting" given by the Health Department, the Health Council of Greater New York, and the Quaker Emergency Service.

Agreements between Lloyd's, Britain's historic insurance organization, and eighteen or twenty major American insurance companies have resulted "in some instances" in higher costs for insurance to the American public.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22--Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower has restated that he has "absolutely no political ambitions or intentions."

Today the Second Annual Report of the President's Council of Economic Advisers makes its appearance. The product of a year's study of the American economy at work, this review might fairly be expected to deal with the actual events of that period--to indicate where the stresses and strains of the post-war boom were manifesting themselves, what the basic causes seemed to be, and what specific course of remedial or preventive action was called for.

Governor Dewey was applauded by 225 underprivileged boys and girls of mid-Manhattan yesterday at a Christmas party in the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street. The club sponsored the event in conjunction with the Coordinating Councils in four police precincts.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A report published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 3, and referring to the Dec. 2 "What's On Your Mind" forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES, states that I was among those who agreed that "although American policy in Greece had not yet restored peace and democracy, it was on the right track."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)-- Members of Congress proposed today that the nation draw up plans for a new Atlantic-Pacific canal following Panama's rejection of a lease agreement covering United States defense installations.
One of the chilliest relations between landlord and tenants anywhere in the city is scheduled to be talked out Friday morning in Upper Manhattan Magistrate's Court.

Fourteen issues of pre-war Italian Government and public utility company dollar bonds were restored yesterday to trading privileges on the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange. Few transactions took place because of the scarcity of old bonds.

A wage bonus of $1,000,000 will be shared among 10,000 employes of Bond Stores, Inc., next March, it was announced yesterday by Barney S. Ruben, president. The bonus, it was added, would be the largest distribution in the clothing concern's history.

An easy oven dish for Christmas Eve supper is this peace plate of scalloped oysters, prefaced with chilled tomato juice, seasoned with lemon juice and horse-radish. Accompany the oysters with a big bowl of holiday slaw--crisp shredded cabbage tossed with sliced stuffed olives and French dressing.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--The State Department said today through an official spokesman that the United States intended to continue with the deportation proceeding's of the Immigration Service in New York against Nicolas Kyriazidis.

A whole concept of the function of government is involved in the question of the continuation of child-care centers. In the situation in its simplest form, the mother is the sole parent in the home, there are no adult relatives to take care of the child, the mother must earn a living for the home, and she cannot earn enough to hire a servant to take care of the child.
With dollar sales volume rising to new record heights, Christmas trade in this city will top last year's peak by 10 per cent, according to a survey made yesterday.

NANKING, Dec. 23--With China's new Constitution scheduled for promulgation Thursday, the Legislative Yuan today voted procedural regulations that in effect will delay full implementation of the Constitution until next year.

The City Council approved without change yesterday the 1948 capital budget adopted by the Board of Estimate on Nov. 25, although the proposal in the budget to use $15,692,324 in housing funds outside the city's general debt limit for schools and playgrounds adjacent to housing projects was sharply attacked as unconstitutional and highly improper.

TRIESTE, Dec. 23 (AP)--Tension mounted today in Trieste after twelve persons were injured in two separate bombing incidents in the last two days. The disorders occurred amid Italian-Yugoslav negotiations over the naming of a candidate for civilian governor of the Free Territory.

Should any further proof be needed that pitching, despite a mild epidemic of sore arms, played a prominent role in putting the Yankees over the top in the 1947 American League pennant race, it is more than amply supplied by the circuit's official hurling records announced yesterday.

BERLIN, Dec. 23--The United States Military Government announced today that inter-Allied inspection commissions would again visit all four zones of Germany to check on the progress being made in liquidation of the German war potential.
Debutantes participating in one of the gayest winter seasons of the post-war years were honored yesterday at many parties ranging from luncheons to late night dances.

Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, predicted yesterday that 1,200, New Yorkers would die or be injured permanently as a result of accidents in the Christmas-New Year holiday season. His prediction was based upon previous holiday statistics.

An alert conductor brought an uptown local Eighth Avenue IND subway train to a halt at the Fifty-ninth Street station yesterday after the train had failed to stop at Times Square and Fiftieth Street because the motorman had suffered a stroke. The motorman was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where his condition was found to be serious.

PARIS, Dec. 23--The French Cabinet today approved negotiations with Bao Dai, former Emperor of Annam, to end the Viet Nam conflict in Indo-China. Whether it is planned to ask Bao Dai to head a new state created to include the present Viet Nam territory or whether he will simply be asked to act as an intermediary in FrenchViet Nam negotiations was not disclosed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23--Suppliers today reported heavy demand for all types of materials used in the photo engraving process. Not only have Chicago newspapers substantially increased their orders to build up reserve stocks because of increased needs resulting from the printers' strike, but newspapers in other cities are calling upon suppliers for large quantities of materials in anticipation of possible walkouts by other printers' locals, suppliers said.

In the latest report of a series on taxation which it has been transmitting to Congress the Treasury raises the question whether the demand for wage increases might not be "dampened" by increasing personal exemptions and exemptions of dependents under the income tax law from the present $500 level.

What Are "Europe-Minded Americans"? Speaking the other day in Brussels, France's Foreign Minister, Georges Bidault, called Secretary of State Marshall "European-minded." That remark by the French statesman provides food for thought.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Dec. 23 (AP)--Thousands of chests of machine -gun ammunition, consigned to the Chinese Air Force, remained piled up on a dock tonight after the officers and crew of tire Canadian freighter Islandside had signed off the ship, leaving it without steam for loading.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--The United States Government announced today that it was evacuating all its military bases in the Republic of Panama, outside the Canal Zone.

Holiday dollar volume in housewares is running from 5 to 20 per cent ahead of last year but unit sales are equal for only a trifle greater, buyers reported yesterday. They attributed the situation to higher unit prices.

A demonstration by persons grouped together in parts of the auditorium interrupted a meeting of Americans for Haganah, Inc., in Manhattan Center last night, but did not halt the proceedings. Order was restored by the police, and the program continued.

LONDON, Dec. 23--A morning spent in food queues with housewives of a middle-class neighborhood gives a better idea of everyday life in England than any number of statistical reports or conversations with Cabinet Ministers. The latter, indeed, absorbed in their arduous bookkeeping, working out their great experiment under most unfavorable conditions, often give a rather abstract view of how it operates on kitchen level.

A debut of unusual distinction was made by the Juilliard String Quartet when it bowed at Town Hall last night. Not only was there ensemble playing of the highest order, but the program offered one of the definitive works in the medium to come from the modern school of composers, the Lyric Suite of Alban Berg, composed in the twelve-tone system.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23--The Toledo, Peoria Western Railroad is operating on a profitable basis after its close-down, due to labor troubles, J. Russel Coulter, its new president, said today. He came here "to ring doorbells," his own way of expressing his search for new business.

Market Closings Commodity markets throughout the United States will lengthen the Christmas and New Year holidays by operating only a half session preceding each day. The various markets handling staples will shut down at noon today, a practice which the Chicago Board of Trade also will follow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)-- The Brazilian naval training ship Almirante Saldanha is scheduled to remain in Philadelphia for ten days before leaving for Havana, New Orleans and various LatinAmerican ports on her way to Brazil.

Winding up with a total score of 8 1/2--3 1/2 after three adjourned games were played off at the Marshall Chess Club, Harvard's chess players yesterday finished in first place in the annual tournament for the championship of the H.Y.P.D. College Chess League.

CARL HUBBELL never was a particularly talkative person when he was wheeling in that tantalizing screwball for the Giants. But he perked up considerably in the conversation department since he's taken charge of the New York farm system and, as you might expect, there's always a lot of sense in what he says.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After reading Hyman Bookbinder's letter on wages and profits, and your editorial of Dec. 11, "Profits Versus Wages," I wonder if the public isn't in danger of getting a serious dose of statistical poisoning.

While two seeded players were toppled from the tournament, Sidney Schwartz, University of Miami star and defending champion, moved, into the semi-final bracket of the Eastern junior indoor tennis championship yesterday on the Metropolitan Tennis Club courts at the 369th Regiment Armory.

GLENDALE, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Twelve members of Glendale Post 127 of the American Legion and a former newspaper publisher were fined in Glendale Justice Court today for attempting to break up a meeting of the La Crescenta-La Canada Democratic Club in a private home in nearby La Crescenta Nov. 14.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 23 (AP)-- Former All-America football star Glenn Davis disclosed today he has requested permission to resign from the Army. The husky, good looking 25-year-old Californian, one of the most brilliant halfback in West Point grid history, said he has made application through customary Army channels "in the same manner as any other officer who desires to be separated from the service."

HARTSDALE, N.Y., Dec. 23-- Although suffering from illness after a speaking tour in the autumn, Gen. Evangeline Cory Booth, retired international commander of the Salvation Army, was up again today at her home here and was preparing for her eighty-second birthday on Christmas Day.

ESOPUS, N.Y., Dec. 23--Eighty boys, 8 to 12 years old, paid rapt tribute here today to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt by remaining silent for one hour during her reading of Charles Dickens' Christmas Carol. When Mrs. Roosevelt finally closed the book, she said:

With some teachers' organizations still concerned over the official attitude of the public school system toward intercultural courses, the Board of Superintendents approved yesterday a new study program for teachers that will be presented in cooperation with the department of public information of the United Nations.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 23 (AP)-- Axel Wenner-Gren's new Telefonos de Mexico S.A., formally closed negotiations today for taking over all properties of the Mexican Ericsson Telephone Company, with a book value of 190,000,000 pesos ($38,000,000).

CHICAGO, Dec. 23--Members of the International Typographical Union, AFL, are attempting to evade the law in seeking ageements that will include the outlawed closed shop, according to Representative Charles J. Kersten, Republican, of Wisconsin.

HAVANA, Dec. 23--Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, warned today that the United States might have to abandon the International Trade Organization project and adopt retaliatory measures if economically undeveloped countries insisted on freedom to use import quotas and other quantitative restrictions on world trade.

Selective improvement took place yesterday on the stock market, with best price mark-ups in the rails, steels and oils. Some gains were exaggerated, in relation to the general trend, for the combined averages only rose 0.40 point on the day.

Nicolas Kyriazidis, Greek Communist correspondent covering the United Nations, was released yesterday at the order of the Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization. The correspondent had been held for six days at Ellis Island as an alien illegally in the United States.

PEIPING, Dec. 23--All gateways to Mukden were under attack today in the Communists' seventh Manchurian offensive. One of the two railroads to the south was cut and fighting along the other may have left it useless.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--In attacking today what he termed the "inexcusable delay of the Administration in reporting the operations of insiders in the commodity markets during 1947, Harold E. Stassen mentioned the "heavy governmental buying" in these markets last September when wheat shot up 27 2/8 cents in ten days.

NANKING, Dec. 23--More than 100,000 Communists are reported to be concentrating for the attack on Sinmin, key Government defense anchor northwest of Mukden. Seven Red columns are poised for the attack along an arc north of Sinmin, the Central News Agency said.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson today received a delegation of distillers to discuss grain allocations after the close of the sixty-day whisky-making holiday on Christmas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--The Interstate Commerce Commission granted to 216 railroads today a 25 per cent increase in the rate of pay for carrying mail.

The Mayor's Committee on Unity yesterday entered the dispute between Harlem merchants of the West 125th Street area and pickets representing community groups alleging price and quality discrimination in neighborhood stores. A meeting at the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, brought an arbitration plan.
ROME, Dec. 23--The slight cold that Pope Pius XII caught last week has developed into bronchitis with a fairly high fever.

Italy has taken a long step toward stability in adopting a new and vigorous constitution. The Assembly vote, 453 to 62, was overwhelmingly favorable. The basic law becomes effective with the beginning of the new year, in full time to be tested before the spring elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 23--The screen actors, directors and writers whose support the motion picture producers have been wooing in Hollywood's current ferment over elimination of Communists from film production, have agreed to participate with the producers in a joint committee on presentation of the industry's problems to the public.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Harold E. Stassen charged tonight that huge amounts of food are being held off the market for higher prices, and proposed a system of "inventory controls" to check hoarding and reduce the cost of living.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 23 -- Far from their homelands, 3,000 members of the United Nations staff began celebrating Christmas early here this afternoon. It was the second Christmas that the international organization had spent in its temporary headquarters at Lake Success.

Residential construction here is approaching a pace that gradually will ease the pressure of the housing shortage, Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, said yesterday. He and other local and state officials welcomed the first tenants admitted to three low-rent housing developments, which when completed will accommodate 3,680 families.

Broadway's four-a-day vaudeville lost its last stronghold last night when the Loew's State Theatre at Broadway and Forty-fifth Street took its daily variety show off its boards for the first time in its twenty-six years of existence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Among the strange gifts which people like to present to the President of the United States count the radio which the National Bureau of Standards gave to Mr. Truman today.

The sale of the Atlantic Basin Iron Works, in Brooklyn, to Blair Co., Inc., investment tankers of 44 Wall Street, was announced yesterday by Bernard A. Moran, former president of the shipyard company. E. J. Crofoot, a director and vice president of the Blair organization, has succeeded Mr. Moran as president.

PARIS, Wednesday, Dec. 24-- The Government's bill for a forced loan was passed by the National Assembly early today by a vote of 351 to 189. Just before midnight, the Cabinet's "exceptional levy to fight inflation" also was passed, 300 to 268.

Many a benefactor of the Neediest writes that he gives because he can't forget the supreme sacrifice of a loved one in battle. For the airmen of Fame's Favored Few, for the lieutenant killed at Le Plessis, Normandy, for the son who disappeared with the "Sunny Star" in the North Atlantic, for the infantryman "killed on the forgotten front of Italy"--the list is a montage ground in the molars of war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Studies of the unification program of the armed services in Congressional quarters led to a conclusion today that possibly one-third and certainly one-tenth could be cut from operational expenses as compared with the old separate budget system.

The Giant Portland Cement Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Jan. 7 in Wilmington, Del., to vote on an increase in the authorized capital stock from 300,000 shares of $1 par value to 1,200,000 shares to raise $1,000,000.

A rate increase of $10,515,000, effective Jan. 1, was announced yesterday by the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company. The new schedule of intrastate rates, which are exclusive of Federal taxes, was approved by the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners recently, following the company's request for increases amounting to $16,152,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23-- RKO today announced the purchase of "Follow Me Quietly," a screen story by Francis Rosenwald and Anthony Mann. Marty Rackin has been engaged by the studio to write a photoplay from the Rosenwald-Mann story, which so described as a murder meloirama laid in contemporary San Francisco.

Industrial and metal distributors in the New York area want their interests fully protected before the Department of Commerce allocations conferences are held with steel mill executives early in January, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. They are taking action now to prepare formal recommendations on allocation policies to prevent future cutbacks in quantities of materials delivered here, they explained.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--The White House announced today that President Truman will nominate Mark Edwin Andrews, a Houston lawyer and oil man, to be Assistant Secretary of the Navy when Congress convenes in January.

PARIS, Dec. 23--Delicate diplomatic negotiations now are going on between France and the United States designed to draw up an agreed text for a bilateral treaty that would cover the operations of the interim program of American aid.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Harold E. Stassen, a Republican Presidential aspirant, by implication brought the White House today into his accusations that "Administration insiders" had improperly profited in the commodities markets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--A Christmas gift of a full pardon, restoring all political and civil rights, was granted by President Truman today to 1,523 men who were convicted during the war of violating the Selective Service Act.

Seventy-eight Russian women, all residents of displaced persons camps in Germany, have sent an appeal to the women of America for aid in establishing homes and careers in this country, it was learned, yesterday.

When Bach's "Christmas Oratorio" came to a close last night at Carnegie Hall, the 2,700-capacity audience applauded unbrokenly for five minutes. There were redoubled bursts of clapping as different performers were singled out--the Collegiate Chorale, the orchestra of thirty-eight players, and the vocal and instrumental soloists.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 23 --Emil Bodnaras, the "tough guy" and political technician of Premier Fetru Groza's Government, was named Minister of War tonight, succeeding Gen. Mihail Lascar.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 23 (AP)-- The United Nations Good Offices Committee announced today details of its Dec. 3 plan for a demilitarized zone to give effect to the United Nations cease-fire order in the Indonesian Republic's conflict with the Dutch.

The driver of a sound truck chartered by the Park Avenue Association to play Christmas carols appeared yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court on a summons charging him with operating the vehicle and its apparatus without a permit.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23--Grain markets broke sharply in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after showing strength early. Corn led the decline, futures losing 1 1/2 to 1 7/8 cents a bushel. Wheat was off 1/4 to 3/4 cent and oats finished 1 5/8 cents lower to 1/8 cent higher, the former on May.
DANBURY, Conn., Dec. 23-- William Horace Cable of Danbury, Corporation Counsel, who was a lawyer here for fifty-one years, died today in his home. His age Was 71.

ATHENS, Dec. 23 (AP)--Contrary to Premier Themistocles Sophoulis' orders, the publisher and Editor of the Liberal party newspaper, Vima, were brought before an army court martial and questioned for more than an hour today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Administration plans to ask Congress to pay the costs of sending American newspapers and magazines abroad by air, Robert A. Lovett, Under-Secretary of State, said today.

This is the month of thin sounds. Winds whip up suddenly and subside abruptly. For the most part December's sounds are in keeping with the spirit of oncoming winter. Among the scrub oaks above the maple sugar grove the brittle bleached leaves rustle as the west wind passes by.
Hundreds of children lined up in the cold and snow yesterday in front of the East Sixty-seventh Street station house waiting for the Christmas party to begin.

At a special meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation approved a proposal to split the common stock three shares for one and voted to increase the presently authorized 5,000,000 common shares to 20,000,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Dec. 23 (AP) --The Right Rev. Msgr. William F. Bergan, chancellor of the Rochester Roman Catholic Diocese, died today in St. Mary's Hospital after an illness of two weeks. His age was 57.

BERLIN, Dec. 23--Jakob Kaiser, ousted by the Russians as chairman of the Christian Democratic Union in the Soviet zone, began operating today as a "government in exile" in the British sector of Berlin. Associated with him there are his deputy, Ernst Lemmer, and leading members of the party's executive committee.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Connie Mack blew out a batch of candles today--and bought a hat.
Paul Hilton, long active in the tie fabric field in Brussels, Belgium, has been appointed general manager of the Raxon Western Hemisphere Corporation.

VIENNA, Dec. 23--Col. Gen. L. V. Kurassov, Soviet commander in Austria, refused to say at today's meeting of the Allied Council that Austria had been demilitarized. The general, who had returned from Moscow after a six-week visit, asserted that the military potential of Austria was higher now than her total industrial potential in 1938, and argued that a significant part of this might be used for the production of armaments.

NEWPORT, R.I., Dec. 23--Newport, the largest city in the country without railroad service, virtually was cut off from the outside world by bus connections early today when 125 drivers and mechanics of Short Line, Inc., went on strike.
occupied areas. To provide winter relief and combat communism in France, Italy and Austria the bill carried $522,000,000. The request was $597,000,000.

For the third time since the end of the greatest war in history, a large part of the world is preparing again to lay aside for a moment the burden of its daily cares and to surrender itself gladly to the magic of the Christmas spirit, with its eternal message of peace on earth to men of good will.

Faced with the task of clearing dry goods inventories this coming spring at prices considerably above those of last year, wholesalers will be forced to intensify their selling efforts, it was pointed out yesterday in the trade. Salesmen have been called to home offices during the week between Christmas and New Year's Day for pep talks and selling pointers to overcome anticipated price resistance.

Coal gas escaping from a defective furnace flue in a four-story dwelling at 1480 Thirty-eighth Street, Brooklyn, caused the death early yesterday of an elderly man and would have resulted in additional casualties but for the involuntary assistance of a cat.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Dec. 23 --In an effort to save her two little sons from drowning in the waters of Beaver Dam Lake, Mill Neck, about noon today, Mrs. Pauline Klipp Eschrich, postmistress of the East Norwich Post Office, was drowned, along with her younger boy, Warren, 2 years old.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP)-- Following is the text of the State Department statement on evacuation of defense sites in Panama: According to official reports the National Assembly of Panama has rejected the ratification of the defense sites agreement signed on Dec. 10, 1947 by the Governments of the Republic of Panama and the United States of America.

A sharp upturn in construction awards during November served to offset a setback during the second quarter of the year and gives indication that projects in the thirtyseven states east of the Rocky Mountains this year will top the mark of 1946, the F. W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday.

In the mad scramble by producers to book what few local houses are available, Lee Shubert, who controls a good many theatres, observes the hustle and bustle with almost Olympian detachment. His motto always has been that a good show will never go homeless.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP)--Although Warren Wright's Calumet Farm failed to chalk up its 100th victory of 1947 today, it did zoom its record earnings for one season to $1,400,011 when Hail Victory ran a close second to L. J. Hollenbach's consistent Roi Rouge in the featured Fernandina Purse at Gulfstream Park.

Herble Kronowitz, 158 1/4, Cone Island, outpointed Jimmy Mangia 158, East Side, in the main attraction of eight rounds at the Broad way Arena in Brooklyn last night A crowd of 3,500 saw Kronowitz triumph. In the eight-round semifinal, Sid Haber, 143 1/2, Browns ville, defeated George Estrada, 143 Cuba.

A 14-year-old schoolgirl, stepdaughter of John M. Dunn, one of three men accused of having fatally shot Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, testified yesterday in General Sessions that her stepfather was at home in Corona, Queens, at the time of the attack.

Today, Christmas Eve, 500 employes of the E. W. Bliss Company of Brooklyn, manufacturers of rolling mill equipment, presses and other machinery, will be discharged by the company. The announcement of the mass lay-off was made originally in September and confirmed again yesterday.

The Maritime Commission announced last night that eight more tankers moved out of lay-up anchorages to repair yards yesterday, and that all remaining tankers of the T-2 class that were in lay-up prior to the current sales program would be in repair yards within the next ten days.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP)-- The text of President Truman's proclamation today granting Christmas pardons to violators of the Selective Service Act and the accompanying report of President's amnesty board follow: Granting Pardon to Certain Persons Convicted of Violating the Selective Training and Service Act of 1940 as Amended by the President of the United States of America.

Amicable settlement of the controversy between Clendenin J. Ryan, former secretary to the late Mayor La Guardia, and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation approached a climax yesterday when Col. Sosthenes Behn, chairman and president of I.T. and T., announced that he had extended an invitation to Mr. Ryan and two of his associates to be candidates for election to the board at a meeting scheduled for Dec. 29.

A committee to study the problems involved in an extension of trucking hours as a means of spreading deliveries and thereby relieving traffic congestion was appointed yesterday at a meeting of trucking operators and union leaders.
With Christmas but a matter of hours away, gifts arrived yesterday in a steady stream from all over the nation as donors rushed to help the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund by Christmas Day.

Leading American educators deplored yesterday the steps taken by President Juan Peron to place the six universities of Argentina under political control, and called upon the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to make a thorough investigation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)-- Industrial production increased during November to the highest point in peacetime history, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23-- Coosa River Newsprint Company, organized in Alabama on March 18, 1946, to erect and operate a mill for the manufacture of newsprint from Southern pine, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 238,829 shares of $50 par value common stock.

Reorders already coming through on some early spring merchandise from stores in the South buttress forecasts of active spring consumer demand in other sections of the country, merchandisers here reported yesterday. Customers were said to be "nibbling" at the new styles, particularly women's suits.

According to the Soviet magazine Ogonyok, as reported yesterday on the sports pages, the grasping, imperialistic -minded United States Olympic officials are going to force a lot of capitalist food on the underfed athletes of other countries at the Olympic Games in London this summer.
A 4-year-old boy and his grandmother who had wandered in midtown Manhattan for thirteen hours were found early yesterday morning.

On the eve of his departure today for his first vacation in five years, Sol Strauss, directing boxing affairs for the Twentieth Century Sporting Club during the convalescence of Promoter Mike Jacobs, yesterday signed a middleweight bout of unmistakable appeal as an attraction for Madison Square Garden on Jan. 16.

One bowl, one hour, one cup of water and one package of Pillsbury's hot roll mix are all that's required to turn out twelve to eighteen delectable raised rolls that would take three or four times as long and many more utensils if one put them together from scratch.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP)-- The Agriculture Department today set aside 13,200,000 pounds of meat and meat products for commercial export during the first three months of 1948. This quantity was said to be equivalent to about onefourth of one per cent of this country's expected production for that period.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP)--The lastplace Chicago Black Hawks played their best hockey of the National League season before 15,323 tonight as they downed the recently red-hot New York Rangers, 7 to 1. It was the final home appearance of Johnny Gottselig as manager of the Hawks for on Sunday, after games at Boston Thursday and at Montreal Saturday, Charlie Conacher will take over the leadership.

ALBANY, Dec. 23--State Controller Frank C. Moore announced today that banks had oversubscribed by $65,830,000 the issue of $100,000,000 in war bonds notes issued to provide prompt payment of veterans' bonuses in January.

DALLAS, Dec. 23 (AP)--Penn State's massive Nittany Lions rolled into town today for their New Year's date with Southern Methodist in the Cotton Bowl with Coach Bob Higgins hoping for "a little luck" when his boys battle the Southwest's standard bearers.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 23 -- David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, was in a convoy that was attacked today on the Jerusalem -Tel Aviv road. Some persons, were wounded, but Mr. Ben-Gurion came out unscathed, thanks to a bulletproof car.

Prolong Fall Apparel Cutting Demand for cold-weather garments which retailers feel can be sold through February has caused some manufacturers to cut and manufacture women's coats and suits to a limited extent, according to trade sources yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP)--Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 11,000 head, total 17,500; market active and 50 cents higher on butchers under 250 pounds; weights over 250 pounds uneven, 25 to 50 cents higher, but these

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The revaluation of the Russian ruble is aimed at limitation of purchasing power of the population. This has been rightly observed in your editorial of Dec. 16. it seems important, however, to stress that this is probably only one purpose of this much discussed move which has been inadequately interpreted by many commentators as "anti-inflationary."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a New Yorker traveling for the first time in the West, I was appalled at the standard of living among the Indians on the reservations. I learned things that I had not known, although I am not ill-informed. I did not know that Indians in the pueblos have no vote.

The Right Rev. Henry K. Sherrill issued yesterday his first Christmas message as the Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church. He took office last Jan. 1, succeeding Bishop Henry St. George Tucker, who retired.

LONDON, Dec. 23--London is preparing to celebrate its gayest Christmas since 1938. Throughout the city cheerful crowds hurry to complete their Christmas shopping, and both the sight and sound of thousands of children on holiday add new warmth and a note of festivity to the holiday preparations.

Cooperative effort to carry out resolutions adopted at the second annual Rabbinical Assembly conference on Jewish education was urged yesterday at the final session of the two-day meeting in the Jewish Theological Seminary, 3080 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23--Plans for authorizing department stores and other qualified retailers to use the "last-in-first-out" method of valuing inventories for income tax purposes was announced today by George J. Schoeneman, Commissioner of Internal Revenue.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP)--The United States Circuit Court of Appeals denied today an appeal by Cargill, Inc., of Minneapolis, a leading grain-trading company, for damages of $10,624,867 from the Chicago Board of Trade. Cargill charged that price-fixing resulted from a board order restricting futures trading in the Chicago pits.

While food prices rose in 1947, grocers generally have stepped up the efficiency of their operations in an effort to restrain the upward trend and the industry as a whole will place major emphasis on economy and service during 1948, it was declared yesterday by John A. Hartford, president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company.

Give Views on Media Services National advertisers, reporting in a survey conducted by Deutsch Shea, Inc., to learn their opinions of media merchandising assistance, listed personal calls on distributors and dealers by media representatives as the most important.

Undefeated New York University won its fifth straight game by blasting out a 61-to-48 victory over Cornell last night. The Violet success, coming after St. John's had lost to Kentucky, 52 to 40, kept the season's book balanced for Madison Square Garden competition between local and out-of-town quintets.

Tomorrow will find plenty of fishing tackle weighing down the stockings, but the shotgun, rifle and ammunition market could not hope to offer enough items to bulge the pack of the old man with the full white beard.
The last-minute pre-Christmas party, travel and mail rush was in full swing yesterday as the approach of Christmas Eve tonight heralded an accelerated tempo of all Yuletide activities.

An informal federation of the alumnae groups of seven women's colleges has been formed to promote their common interests, it was announced yesterday. The Committee of the Seven Women's College Clubs of New York City, a plan originated last spring by Mrs. Harrison Tweed, president of the Smith College Club, became a reality last month with approval of the idea by the boards of directors of the individual groups.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 23 (UP)--A group of American Olympic ski officials, headed by Coach Walter Prager, arrived here today to study the skiing grounds for the coming winter games and to arrange housing accommodations for the athletes.
LONDON, Dec. 23--Apart from British funds, most sections in the stock markets here today were cheerful despite the slowness of business.

After a shooting chase by three policemen, all war veterans and former schoolmates, a robbery suspect, wounded eight times, jumped last night from a kitchen window on the third floor of an apartment building at 3 East 101st Street, off Fifth Avenue, and plunged four stories to his death in a basement areaway.

BAD HOMBURG, Germany, Dec. 23--Germany's national debt is estimated at 685,000,000,000 reichsmarks, exclusive of the capital equipment being dismantled, reparations from current production in the Soviet zone and future reparation demands.

BOSTON, Dec. 23--Hope that at least $55,000 would be realized from the Silent Guest plan for feeding needy Europeans was expressed today by William Brewster, treasurer of the organization. The drive, which was opened just before Thanksgiving by Gov. Robert E. Bradford of Massachusetts, closes on Christmas.
After considerable year-end evening-up, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged yesterday to 8 points higher than on Monday.

Nathan M. Ohrbach was sworn in yesterday at City Hall as Deputy Commissioner of Commerce by Judge Albert Conway of the Court of Appeals. Mr. Ohrbach is chairman of the board of Ohrbach's, Inc., a vice president of Montefiore Hospital and chairman of the citywide campaign of the Boy Scouts of America.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Dec. 23-- Drucie Snyder, daughter of John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, who took over as news commentator of radio station WBCC in Bethesda two weeks ago, today put on her first guest of honor, Miss Margaret Truman.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 23-- Conflicting reports, emanating mainly from official United States sources have created doubt in the public mind as to whether sound preparations have been made to implement the $100,000,000 American aid to this country.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 23 --The Christmas season has sent Swedes on a record spending spree. Ignoring the Government's antiinflationary appeal to keep gift shopping at a minimum, crowds eager to buy everything in sight, regardless of price, have been storming shops in Stockholm and the provinces.

Victor Moore has been signed as a permanent member of the cast for the Jimmy Durante show at 10:30 P.M. Wednesdays over NBC, beginning next week. His engagement as a foil for Jimmy means that the program will discontinue its guest star policy, except for the previously scheduled appearance of Fred Allen on Jan. 28.

Bond issues amounting to $5,560,000 will be offered for sale on Jan. 15 by East Baton Rouge Parish, La., for Sewer Districts 6, 6A and 8. One issue will consist of $2,125,000 ad valorem tax-secured bands dated Oct. 1, 1947, and due Oct. 1, 1948 to 1977.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23--The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled unanimously today that it would not approve the dissolution plan of the Northern States Power Company (Delaware) unless it is amended within fifteen days to provide, among other things, for increased participation by common stockholders.

Frank W. Efinger Jr., ace schoolboy miler who formerly ran for De Witt Clinton High School and now is a student at Andover, will compete in his specialty at the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s junior championships Saturday night in the Twenty-second Regiment Armory on West 168th Street.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals hope to get going "fustest with the mostest" in a counter offensive against the running of Philadelphia's champion ball-carrier, Steve Van Buren.

BETHLEHEM, Palestine, Thursday, Dec. 25 -- Christian pilgrims had to run the gantlet of rifle fire to reach Bethlehem last night for the commemoration of Christ's birth here, but the actual ceremonies passed off without incident.
A message of good will and friendship was sent to five leaders of the Protestant and Roman Catholic faiths yesterday by the Synagogue Council of America.

PARIS, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- In mild weather that offered little hope of a white Christmas, lastminute French shoppers thronged the big department stores on the main boulevards. The temperature this afternoon was 48.2 Fahrenheit.

Light fuel oil stocks in the United States last week dropped an additional 3,530,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 51,502,000 barrels, compared with 55,032,000 a week earlier and 62,239,000 on Dec. 21, 1946.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Rene Mayer, Minister of Finance, today asked the Finance Committee of the Council of the Republic to reconsider the amendment adopted by the National Assembly yesterday exempting some 800,000 peasants from the special anti-inflation tax.
An English woman who has been blind since childhood arrived here yesterday to help similarly handicapped persons on both sides of the Atlantic.

A group of Negro youth, for years under the care of the Riverdale Children's Association, 223 East Thirtieth Street, was reported yesterday by Mrs. Audre Delany, executive secretary of the association, to have found a goal in life through enlistment in the armed forces.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles will be seeking a fitting climax to the "Thompson" story Sunday when they meet the Chicago Cardinals for the National Football League championship at Comiskey Park in the Windy City.

New York's Knickerbockers, upset on Tuesday night in Providence by the Steamrollers, face the same team tonight in a Basketball Association of America game that will be the feature of a twin bill in Madison Square Garden.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest the account by Elizur Yale Smith in THE TIMES of Dec. 14 of the writing and adoption of our Bill of Rights, particularly the first Amendments. However, he has omitted mention of a famous man who had as much to do with this foundation structure of our Government as any American.
Price is expected to be a major factor in the allocation of exchange and granting of licenses for imports into India for the first half of next year, according to foreign traders here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -- Vah Heflin, Angela Lansbury and Marshall Thompson were named today by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading roles in the screen version of John P. Marquand's novel, "So Little Time," to which Metro acquired the rights from David O. Selznick in 1946.

DAVOS DORF, Switzerland, Dec. 24 (AP) -- With about five feet of snow on the heights above this Alpine village, a white Christmas was assured today for the United States ski squad training for the Winter Olympic games, Jan. 30 to Feb. 8.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the final steps for reorganization of the Chicago Rock Island Pacific Railway Company. The agency authorized the railroad and the Peoria Terminal Company to take over certain properties.
One of the nation's leading sports figures gave $100 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund in memory of another sportsman who during his life was a stanch friend of the needy.

HAVANA, Dec. 24 -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment remained deadlocked tonight despite an all-day meeting of the delegation heads in an attempt to solve the crisis that threatens to wreck the United States long-range plans for the International Trade Organization.
