CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Liquidation by holders of grain futures developed in the late trading on the Board of Trade today after a brief showing of strength early. Closing trades were about the bottom as support was lacking on the way down.

The most precious Christmas gift that skiers in this part of the country could expect -- deep powder snow on firm bases -- will be found today at most of the popular skilands. The recent heavy snows came at an appropriate time, assuring the army of hickory riders, who have been converging on the North Country in record number, of the finest period of sport in many a year for the holiday period.
The Transport Workers Union, CIO, demanded yesterday a wage increase of 30 cents an hour for 2,100 bus drivers and maintenance employes of the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest Topics of The Times on Dec. 15. As a soldier in the A.E.F. in the last war I served sixteen months in France. During most of the period of hostilities there was not much time to pick up the French language.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- A craft union which has been submerged by large industrial unions in many plants successfully invoked protective provisions of the Taft-Hartley law today.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- The Communist party organ Unita in an editorial published this morning indicated that agitations and disturbances are to cease during the holiday season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (U.P.) -- All efforts to settle the dispute between the United States Olympic Committee and the Amateur Hockey Association, which may keep American teams out of the winter games at St. Moritz, failed despite two weeks of negotiations between officials of the organizations, it was learned today.
The animal world had its share of Christmas Eve cheer yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rizzuto Sr. of 115-56 203d Street, St. Albans, Queens, are experiencing a turnabout of holidays today, celebrating in spirit a day of Thanksgiving, having held their Christmas party on Thanksgiving day.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The United States is producing about four times as many fishing boats as before the war, but fish production is much the same, the Fish and Wildlife Service said today.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 24 -- He was a ragged little urchin in dirty galabia [wide outer garment]. How he got so dirty or how his feet became so calloused in only ten years was a mystery. I tried to pass him by but he grabbed my hand, looked up at me and with sincerity that seemed strange said, "Merry Christmas, sir."

MOSCOW, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A Brussels dispatch to Pravda, Communist party newspaper, said today that the Vatican, inspired by United military authorities in Rome, was plotting revolutions in Italy and France.

President Truman's Christmas amnesty proclamation restoring political and civil rights to only 1,523 World War II draft violators brought a half dozen protests yesterday from New York groups which had fought for pardons for thousands of others.

A new musical program featuring Gordon MacRae, Evelyn Knight and Victor Young's orchestra, will be offered at 9:30 P.M. Sundays over CBS under the sponsorship of the Texas Company. The series will make its bow on Jan. 4. Meanwhile, the Texaco Star Theatre, which had occupied the Sunday time, will be shifted to 10:30 P.M. Wednesdays on the ABC chain, beginning Dec. 31.

ATHENS, Dec. 24 -- Communist Miltiades Porphyrogenis announced today over the "Democratic Army's" broadcasting station that the "First Provisional Democratic Government of Free Greece" had been established.
BERLIN, Dec. 24 -- Substantial improvement in the nutritional level in the United States zone of Germany over that of a year ago was reported today as a result of monthly weight samplings.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 24 -- Heavy sniping amounting almost to guerrilla warfare killed four Arabs and two Jews and wounded at least twenty-six other persons in Haifa during the last twenty-four hours, it was reported tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 24 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district, after seasonal allowance, declined about 2 per cent last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index last week was 201 per cent of the 1935-39 average; it was 205.1 in the week ended Dec. 13, and 206.6 in the week ended Dec. 6.

Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President and Secretary of Commerce, will "state his own views on the 1948 election" in a Coast-toCoast broadcast Monday night. It is expected that Mr. Wallace will announce his willingness to run for President on a third party ticket, probably under specified conditions.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- El Mono, a 3-year-old colt that would make a splendid Christmas present to any horseman, added to his reputation as a gem of consistency at Gulfstream Park today when he easily registered for the fourth straight time in the featured Lochloosa Purse.

Backstage at the Adelphi Theatre, where Henry Duffy's musical production, "Music in My Heart," is playing, the closing notice, to become effective Saturday evening, Jan. 3, has gone up. The musical, based on a romantic but unhappy incident in the life of Tchaikovsky, made its local debut on Oct. 2.

Drive to Promote Jewelry The Jewelry Council will begin sending out next week the first of eleven special advertising and promotion packages for a campaign to increase sales in 1948. First of the kits, which will go to 10,000 members, will contain material for Valentine's Day, including copy for local newspaper advertising, radio commercials, window and counter display.

The seventh Communist offensive to drive Chiang Kai-shek's forces from Manchuria is in full swing. It appears to be better organized, better led and generally more formidable than any of the others. Mukden, key city of Manchuria and gateway to the north, is already surrounded in a great encircling arc and in spots the attackers have forced their way close to the city walls.

Reimposition of price controls on lumber must be applied at the mill level to be really effective because both wholesalers and retail distribution yards are now taking lower mark-ups than the 30 to 40 per cent permitted by the Office of Price Administration, a leading Northeastern lumber wholesaler with substaantial yard interests declared yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 24 -- The Adjutant General released the following orders today: NYNG Officers Assigned Capt. R.F. Dutcher, FA, 170th FA Bn., to service battery as battery comdr. Capt. A.D. Ackerson, FA, 170th FA Bn., to Battery A as battery comdr. Capt. G. Witschief, FA, 170th FA Bn., to Battery C as battery comdr.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 24 -- Utter bewilderment prevails among bankers, stock brokers and investors in Switzerland at their predicament caused by action of the authorities in Holland in connection with the new capital issue of Royal Dutch Shell.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Dec. 24 -- Most industrial and mining enterprises in Bulgaria, with the exception of those owned by foreign states, were nationalized today. Action came on a bill introduced in the National Assembly last night by the Minister for Industry, Prof. Petko Kunin; it was adopted without opposition.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., Dec. 24 -- Strict regulation of commercial buildings, signs, billboards and other eyesores and the zoning of land adjacent to new highways were urged today in a new fifteenpoint program for highway safety and improvement by the New Jersey Roadside Council.

Seventy-two Polish war orphans in Gdynia, Poland, whose faith in things material and mythical was shattered during the war, have learned that Santa Claus is a real person even if he does look like an American seaman. They will receive final proof today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- There are several strong objections to President Truman's proposal that Congress, if it embarks on the European Recovery Program, shall make a four-year commitment, and active resistance to this recommendation can be expected. But, if Congress can be shown a persuasive precedent, some advocates of the proposal with experience at the Capitol hope the objections can be overcome.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The announcement by the Communist Balkan radio chain of the establishment of a "Free Greek" Government is evidently the first move of a series that will shift the emphasis of the Soviet attack on United States policy from Western Europe to the Mediterranean.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Michigan's football warriors engaged in a knockdown scrimmage today, their hardest workout since they began readying themselves for the Rose Bowl game with Southern California.

A plea for "big business" executives to reduce prices and improve deliveries of raw materials to "small businesses" was sent to all their suppliers by Benjamin Foster Company, paint manufacturer, Philadelphia, Benjamin Foster, president, revealed in a statement yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Overlapping seasonal planning will absorb efforts of manufacturers of coats and suits during the normal lull between Christmas and New Year's Day, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday.

VATICAN CITY, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The official English-language text of the Pope's Christmas Eve message to the world follows: The feast of Christmas and the New Year close at hand bring with them certain signs which point a warning finger toward the days to come.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Secretary of Labor L.B. Schwellenbach appointed Frederick R. Livingston today as arbitrator in the dispute between the Atlantic and Gulf Coast shipping companies and the CIO National Maritime Union, American Communications Association and Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.
AKRON, Ohio, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Tires designed to cut down skidding by means of wire coils in the treads are rolling out of plants of several of the nation's leading rubber companies.

Only one-third of the governmentowned war surplus forge and foundry plants remains to be sold and forty-two out of a total of sixty-three have been either leased or sold, War Assets Administration officials declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- From President Truman on this Christmas Eve went forth a message of hope and a pledge of further aid to the needy people of Europe and Asia. In a brief speech which he delivered in a ceremony on the White House lawn, the Chief Executive said this country was inspiring the return of hope in people abroad who were left desolate by war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24--The text of the statement issued by President Truman in connection with the issuance of an executive order creating an, Interdepartmental Committee on Scientific Research and Development, and the text of the executive order follow:
The cotton market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose yesterday, closing 5 to 11 points net higher.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (ONA) -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov was largely to blame for the breakdown here of the Council of Foreign Ministers this month, Prof. Harold J. Laski, former chairman of the Executive Committee of the British Labor party, charged today in an article written for the Overseas News Agency.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 24 -- A train full of people lonely in a foreign land at Christmas left Jersey City early this afternoon. It pulled into Binghamton four hours later and by that time it was the gayest train on the Erie run.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Argentine Ambassador today accused Summer Welles, former Under-Secretary of State, of being a "sponsor" of a pamphlet "insulting" Argentine President Juan D. Peron. Mr. Welles flatly denied it.

This morning, as has become our custom on Christmas Day, we make an accounting of stewardship on the Hundred Neediest Cases. We are happy to report that, in a time of many distractions, with uneasiness invading many homes, in the face of high living costs and many large and worthy demands on generosity, the Neediest Cases have been well remembered by their friends this year.

New York State spends only $2 a day for each of the 100,000 patients in state mental institutions in comparison with the $10 a day spent by nearly all other hospitals, the Association for the Improvement of Mental Hospitals, Inc., asserted yesterday.
All Markets Closed Security and commodity markets throughout the world will be closed today in observance of Christmas.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Glenn Davis has decided to sign with the Los Angeles Rams if the army permits him to resign and if the Rams match other professional football offers, it was learned today.

The market for shares received yesterday a minor jolt when the Federal Reserve lowered its support level for Government bonds, but the session on the Stock Exchange generally proved a typical pre-holiday affair. Firmness in the early trading gave way to a shift to the easier side in the afternoon and final quotations were irregularly lower than on Tuesday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American Friends Service Committee invites you to share its concern, that traditional American generosity, always heightened at the Christmas season, may this year be directed toward sharing our plenty with those for whom acute privation has long been the only daily experience.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 24 -- There are 30,000,000 homeless and breadless Russians in the Soviet Republic, the former Brazilian Ambassador to Russia, Dr. Mario de Pimentel Brandao, declared today.
There are several thousand hunters and fishermen who, after removing the wrappings and ribbon this morning, will roll both eyes upward and ask why there is no sportsman's exchange shop in the city.

YOU know how it goes, don't you? " 'Twas the night before Christmas and all through the house. * * *" In other words Santa Claus has come and gone. And how did the jolly old elf treat you? Well, we trust. If you've been wondering what the apple-cheeked gentleman left under the trees of the members of the sports fraternity, here's approximately what we hope was found.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial commendation of the great public service rendered by Justice Charles C. Lockwood is richly deserved. It does not detract from your approval of his work in condemnation cases or from the many fine things accomplished by the La Guardia administration to point out that your are mistaken in the statement in the editorial that the La Guardia administration ended the condemnation racket.

PANAMA, Dec. 24 -- President Enrique A. Jimenez, referring today to the controversy over defense sites with the United States and the withdrawal of American troops from Panama, said: "I accept the responsibility; I have complied with my duty."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- A new Atlantic-Pacific canal across the waistline of Mexico was proposed by Senator Dennis Chavez, Democrat, of New Mexico, today as the United States began pulling 2,000 troops out of strategic defense sites flanking the Panama Canal.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- Members of Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, who have been on strike against Chicago's six daily newspapers since Nov. 24, received an increase in strike benefits from the International Typographical Union, AFL, it was revealed when the strikers received their fourth weekly benefit checks today.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- Pope Pius XII rose from his sickbed today to issue the most outspoken and scathing condemnation of Soviet policy he had uttered since the beginning of his reign.

Though literary critics still quibble over the authorship of "A Visit From St. Nicholas," 300 children and adults made the thirtyseventh annual pilgrimage yesterday to the grave of Dr. Clement Clarke Moore. Firmly believing that he wrote the jolly Christmas poem, they gathered with lanterns held high in Trinity Church Cemetery to sing "Come All Ye Faithful."

An officer of the Stork Club and brother-in-law of owner Sherman Billingsley told a state unfair labor practices hearing yesterday that it was a common practice for Mr. Billingsley to lend money to employes without getting a receipt.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 24 -- With only Memphis and Birmingham, dissenting, the big Southern cities in the main have abandoned "Jim Crowism" to allow citizens of all races, creeds and colors to welcome the Freedom Train together as it rolls through Dixie carrying some of the world's most treasured documents.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 24 -- Declaring that the city's racial segregation law was not a mantle to be put aside at the request of any visitor to the city, Birmingham authorities today banned the proposed visit of the Freedom Train here next Monday.

LONDON, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- Railway stations were crowded, shopping centers jammed with last-minute gift hunters and taverns merry with early celebrants as Britons prepared tonight for a Christmas that for the first time in many years showed signs of returning to pre-war festivity.

IT happened a long time ago. The Indians at the Mission of San Gabriel in California were putting on the annual Nativity play under the cheerful guidance of Father Juan, and Father Serra was expected to arrive in time for the occasion.

Joseph Bonavita, whose carefree liberality in distributing $1,000 among unfortunates on the Bowery last Christmas caused him to be whisked off to Bellevue Hospital for a test of his mental balance, returned to the Bowery yesterday, handing out money right and left to the tune of $700.

John Foster Dulles, chief adviser to Secretary George C. Marshall at the London meeting of the Foreign Ministers, declared here yesterday that while the recent conference "did not produce a pact of peace," there was no reason for "hysteria or thinking in terms of war."
On Christmas Day the thirtysixth annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES stands at $280,040.95 given by 8,765 donors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Negotiations with France, Italy and Austria for a further lowering of their estimates of emergency winter relief requirements are under way at the State Department.
The birth of the Christ-child was commemorated last night as thousands of New Yorkers crowded the churches of their choice to usher in the traditional festival with prayer and song.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The Republic of Nicaragua through its highest leaders tonight offered to cooperate to the fullest with the United States if it is decided to build a canal through Nicaragua as an aftermath of its current difficulty in Panama.
The development of lightweight boxers is one objective Sol Strauss, acting head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, will undertake upon his return from a visit to Promoter Mike Jacobs in Florida.

The report of the President's Amnesty Board, headed by former Justice Owen J. Roberts, is an illuminating discussion of the rights and duties of citizenship in a democracy. It should do much to clarify public thinking about those 15,805 persons who were convicted of violation of the wartime Selective Service Act.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- With the good coal production figures to back them up, jobbers in stock markets here today had no difficulty in giving to most sections a firm appearance.

New Motor Price Lists Loom New list prices on electric motor lines will be announced soon, motor distributors here revealed yesterday. They said they expect larger motor manufacturers will announce the new schedules soon after Jan. 1, to bring list prices more into line with selling prices.

Harold B. Stassen calls for the establishment of inventory controls over certain basic foods to discourage hoarding and prevent rising prices. His proposal stems, he says, from the fact that huge amounts of food are being held in storage, and he singles out meat as a conspicuous example.
Today the liquor business is looking for a Santa Claus who hasn't yet shown up.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Miss Margaret Truman found today that an unknown performer can "mug a scene," even from the daughter of the President.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The State Department announced today that it would ask the United Nations for an early conference looking to "a drastic revision" of the United Nations system of accreditation of alien newspaper correspondents.

PRAGUE, Dec. 24 (UP) -- Textile sales by factories and wholesalers throughout Czechoslovakia were suspended indefinitely today in the first move of a drastic Government fight to stamp out the black market.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The J.A. Kinard colors made a clean sweep of feature races at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Following is the text of the speech by President Truman at the lighting of the Christmas tree today: My fellow countrymen: We are met on the south lawn of the White House. Above the barren treetops rises the towering shaft of the Washington Monument.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- President Truman may sign the Republican Anti-Inflation Bill "any day after Christmas," the White House said today. He will accompany it with a statement which is expected to attack it as inadequate to curb living costs.
PEIPING, China, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Troops of the North China Command were flown to Mukden today to meet the shock of the Communists' seventh Manchurian offensive, rolling up on all sides of the city.

VIENNA, Dec. 24 -- The ground for Russia's objections to the American supervision of relief in Austria, employed by the Soviet Union all during the past half year and at the London Conference as a political weapon, will to a great extent be eliminated under a new agreement to be signed here.

BOSTON, Dec. 24 -- Bell-ringing carolers ushered in Boston's Christmas in traditional fashion tonight as New England continued digging out of the ten-inch snowstorm that mantied the area in white for the holiday.
Christmas dawned today on a nation that had manifested the Yuletide spirit for nearly a month in a series of festivities and deeds of good-will toward other nations less fortunate than itself.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 -- Governor Dewey, in his traditional Christmas pardons, granted freedom today to three prisoners, two of them convicted murderers, and reduced the sentence of another.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- The Force Ouvriere [Workers For a], the new French anti-Communist labor confederation, now can count on about 1,000,000 adherents, Leon Jouhaux, veteran labor leader and principal figure in the new movement, said today.

The market for United States Government bonds, in the most sweeping daily price movement since Pearl Harbor, declined sharply yesterday when official support levels set up tentatively last month were lowered.

Within twenty-four hours after the National Assembly of Panama had repudiated a signed agreement leasing to the United States fourteen bases for the defense of the Panama Canal, all American troops stationed at these bases had received orders to evacuate them immediately and to withdraw to the Panama Canal zone, which remains in United States hands.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Signing of a new contract by Trans World Airline and the Air Line Pilots Association, covering wages and working conditions for 1,000 pilots and co-pilots, was announced today by Robert H. Biron Jr., T.W.A.'s vice president of industrial relations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- President Truman announced today the formation of the Interdepartmental Committee for Scientific Research and Development, with his assistant, John R. Steelman at its hub, to coordinate Federal scientific activities.
New York newspaper funds received more than $650,000 up to Christmas Eve for the aid of needy individuals, underprivileged children and hospitalized veterans, they reported yesterday.

All the authorities agree that some sort of holiday was celebrated at about this time of year in all Western countries long before there was any reason to call it Christmas. The mistletoe is as pagan as can be, though this need not worry any young man who catches his sweetheart under a sprig of it.

Following the pattern he set two days ago, Daniel Rivkind of Brooklyn continued to upset the favorites yesterday as he advanced into the final round of the Eastern junior indoor tennis championships on the courts of the Metropolitan Tennis Club at the 369th Regiment Armory.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Nine American merchant seamen lost their lives in a Christmas Eve shipwreck when the United States freighter Park Victory went aground and broke in two in a blinding snowstorm off the rocky coast of southwest Finland, authorities announced tonight.
A resolution endorsing the city's day care program for pre-school children has been approved unanimously by the board of directors of the Welfare Council of New York City, it was announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 25 -- Cathy O'Donnell and Lynn Bari will play the leading roles with Turhan Bey in Eagle-Lion's "The Spiritualist," which is scheduled for the cameras on Jan. 5. The photoplay, written by Muriel Roy Bolton from a screen story by Crane Wilbur, deals with society blackmail by means of spiritualistic fraud.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The absence from the capital of most members of Congress during the Christmas season has softened for a time the note of political controversy that dominates the news from Washington, particularly when one party controls the executive department and the other the legislative.

The struggle of man's higher self against secularism in celebrating the birth of Christ has reached a point where the spiritual content of the message of Christmas is being overlooked, it was emphasized in Christmas sermons here yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- World food production will have to be more than doubled within the next twenty-five years to prevent the "direst calamities," Sir John Boyd Orr, director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, warned in a report made public here today.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation, which, like other bus companies in New York, has been wondering how long it can continue operating on the five-cent fare, has had a study made of transit fares in the United States in cities of 100,000 population and over.

Refusal of the State Department to publish the name of each country with which the United States negotiated tariff concessions at Geneva deprives Congress and the domestic producer of information of vital importance, the American Tariff League declared today in a letter to Winthrop G. Brown, Acting Deputy Director, Office, of International Policy, Department of State.

BOSTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- "Hat trick" scoring Doug Bentley figured in all but the last goal as his Chicago Black Hawks subjected the Boston Bruins to a 6-1 set-back, their most humiliating defeat of the current National Hockey League season, before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden tonight.

Paul Draper and Larry Adler, who are running a series of children's matinees at the City Center these days, last night began an evening series for adults at the same house, with Josh White joining the show to replace the strictly juvenile numbers on the matinee series.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- French race horses were on strike today against the high price of oats.

The Military Order of the Purple Heart, Greater New York Chapter, has intensified its rehabilitation program among the 15,000 convalescent wounded confined in veterans' hospitals to help fill the gap made by the closing down of the United Service Organizations and American Women's Volunteer Service at the end of this year.

Actual operation of released public school time for religious education has not met to any appreciable extent the problem of growing religious illiteracy among American youth, Leo Pfeffer, assistant director of the Commission on Law and Social Action, says in a pamphlet on "Religion and the Public Schools," being issued today by the Office of Jewish Information, American Jewish Congress.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 25 (AP) -- United States Senator J. Howard McGrath, Democrat, of Rhode Island, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today the Administration would welcome Henry Wallace's support in the 1948 election, but will not change its policies to win it.

It may seem like rushing things a bit to talk about preparations for a New Year's Eve party the day after Christmas. But the time is short in which to plan and procure what is to be served on that occasion, so we are going to suggest a few ideas now.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 25 -- Although the G I tide "apparently has reached its peak" and freshman classes, veteran and non-veteran, are smaller this year, the 1,592,389 full-time and 585,868 part-time students in 716 approved universities and four-year colleges reporting to him this autumn constitute a record total on the country's campuses, accoording to Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati.
The third Christmas Day since the end of World War II still found most of the world hungry, ill clad, racked with dissension; with peace on earth still beyond mankind's ken.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Shooting's, bombing's, armed robberies and other violence swept over Palestine on Christmas Day, increasing to 336 the number of dead since the United Nations decided to divide the Holy Land between the Jews and Arabs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Missing a collision with a comet is not the only pleasant thing that happened to the earth in 1947, at least to the United States.

A total of 16 fielding records were set or tied in 1947 in the American League, according to the official averages released for publication today, with the entire loop, as a unit, setting a new major league percentage high of .977. The previous mark was .974 set by the National League in 1946.

On a special green canvas court at Madison Square Garden tonight, Bobby Riggs, world's professional tennis champion, will meet a new threat in the pay-for-play ranks, Jack Kramer, whose successes at Wimbledon, Forest Hills and in the Davis Cup tests brought him international fame as an amateur player.
The ragged, the tattered, the sadeyed, moved through Iatticed elevated-railroad shadow yesterday toward Christmas Dinner at Sammy Fuchs, restaurant operator and locality mayor, at 267 The Bowery.
Every remaining United Service Organizations club -- 200 compared with a wartime peak of 4,000 -- will close its doors today.

Passenger operations of the Alcoa Steamship Company during 1947 surpassed any previous year in the company's history and advance bookings give every indication that the coming year will bring bigger passenger business, according to an annual review released here by the company yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 26 -- Gen. Hideki Tojo, Japan's war Premier, whose guilt Allied prosecutors charge equaled that of Hitler and Mussolini in the Axis effort to dominate the world, took the witness stand before the International Military Tribunal here today.

STOCKHOIM, Sweden, Dec. 25 -- The outgoing Italian Minister in Stockholm, Alberto Bellardi Ricci, Was stabbed to death in the legation today by an insane countryman during the Minister's Christimas and farewell party for his staff.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At a recent meeting of the New York County Medical Society a group of doctors, many of them members of the Physicians Forum, endeavored to pass a resolution deploring the application of the President's loyalty test to doctors employed by the Federal Government.
ATHENS, Dec. 25 -- The Athens police force was ordered to stand by today to block any attempt by sympathizers here with the newly formed "Government of Free Greece" to provoke disorders.

In his talk from the south lawn of the White House on Christmas Eve, President Truman did not mention $522,000,000, or $6,800,000,000, or $17,000,000,000, or any other sum of money. He quoted St. Paul's reference to faith, hope and charity, and he agreed with St. Paul that "the greatest of these is' charity."
The Citizens Union made public yesterday its program of proposed legislation for 1948 covering many aspects of city finance, housing and the election law.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- Small as well as large-scale speculators will be named tomorrow in the Agriculture Department's second list of traders on the commodity markets. J.M. Mehl, Administrator of the Commodity Exchange Authority, said the list would include anyone who dealt on the Chicago Board of Trade April 30 in 1,000 or more bushels of wheat for future delivery.

NANKING, Dec. 25 -- Statements by the Government publicity organs proclaimed the "enforcement" of Nationalist China's new Constitution as from today. Flags were displayed by Government buildings and commercial, establishments but no formal Government announcement marked the event and no commemorative ceremonies were held.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- In the technical fields of international cooperation -- from the granting of reconstruction loans to the repatriation of refugees -- the United Nations made business-like progress during 1947.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Marshall plan, the $17,000,000,000 European Recovery Program proposed by President Truman and the Secretary of State George C. Marshall, ran into renewed Republican misgivings today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The country's largest producer of blended whisky, Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., today ordered its plants to continue closed for the time being, although the industry-wide voluntary "holiday" officially ended last midnight.
The dollar volume of construction work to be recorded for 1947 will exceed any previous year, according to Engineering News-Record.
For a time last-night it appeared that the New York Knickerbockers were going to spoil Coach Joe Lapchick's Christmas by dropping their second straight decision to the Providence Steam Rollers.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The United States Public Health Service offered proof today that science can produce a cold, that such colds are infectious and that the infectious agent causing them can be grown in eggs.

The 100th presentation of "The Theatre Guild on the Air" since its inception in September, 1945, will be an adaptation of Lillian Hellman's "The Little Foxes." The bitter drama of a Southern family will be broadcast at 9:30 o'clock Sunday night, Jan. 4, over the WJZ-ABC network.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- A half year of planning went into the Government's efforts today to make this a Merry Christmas for the disabled war veterans under its care.

ROME, Dec. 25 -- Virtually recovered from his attack of bronchitis, Pope Pius XII spent a quiet, restfull Christmas day. This morning he rose as usual at 7 o'clock and shortly afterward said mass in his private chapel.
It was a frigid Christmas yesterday for tenants in the six-story apartment house at 916-26 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx.

IN "The Pleasures of Peacock" Ben Ray Redman has erected a pious monument to the memory of one of the great English literary eccentrics. Today a number of initiates know and delight in the novels of Thomas Love Peacock, but, Mr. Redman laments, they are too few. To ameliorate so deplorable a situation he has compiled this book, which contains two of Peacock's seven novels complete and the remaining five in neatly condensed versions.

The personnel of the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn -- sailors and officers -- didn't overlook a single item yesterday to assure a Christmas Day of joy for some 150 orphans and underprivileged children.

Fourteen new appointees are included among the thirty 1948 national committee chairmen announced yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States. The selections were revealed by Mayor James A. Rhodes of Columbus, Ohio, new president of the National A.A.U., after consultation with the other elected officers.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 25 -- Two British soldiers were killed and at least three more were wounded tonight when Stern Band gunmen fired on a group of Tommies who were celebrating Christmas in a Tel Aviv cafe.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 25 -- The leading Istanbul newspapers today launched a criticism of the United States aid program to Turkey. The criticism, the first to be formulated on the subject, appears to be coordinated.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 25 -- Some 25,000 Soviet troops, including tactical forces ranging from tank crews to fighter pilots, still were on Hungarian soil today although, the formal peace was signed 100 days ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- There has been a strange dip in demands on the mint for new pennies, nickels, dimes, quarters and even half dollars, and officials are puzzled, it was learned today. Usually the call has been for more and more coins in periods of booming business, and let-ups in the demand have come only when sales were sliding.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Today much is being said, and rightly, concerning" the "American democratic system -- the importance of individual, freedom and the desirability of full opportunity for the free play of individual initiative "under a capitalistic business ecdnomy.

ANOTHER amateur tennis star, who has had his fill of glory but not of cash, will make public repentance tonight for his previous grave disrespect for the almighty dollar when Jack Kramer hits the sawdust trail in Madison Square Garden. But that sawdust will be flecked with gold for Big Jake as he makes his professional debut against Bobby Riggs, the acknowledged ruler for the play-for-pay brigade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, challenged Democrats today to make an issue of compulsory health insurance in 1948. He asserted that he would seek Congressional approval for an alternative plan for government grants to states for medical care.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:
A donor celebrated his first day as an American citizen by sending a $100 gift yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. In a typewritten message he said:

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Trojans of U.S.C. will have an added incentive for hard work when they buckle down at Santa Barbara tomorrow in resumed practice for their Rose Bowl game with Michigan on New Year's Day.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- In Binghamton's first ward, where factory workers live, the Czech head of the United Nations atomic sta spent Christmas today above the sparkling bake-shop of a man who came from a town near Prague twenty-five years ago.

PEIPING, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Today's fighting waxed hottest in sub-zero Manchuria. The Government said 200,000 Communist troops were menacing the Mukden garrison on a perimeter within a forty-five-mile radius of the windswept city. Neutral observers here consider this figure exaggerated, but it is clear from Government reports that the Communists are astride the main-stem railway north of Mukden and threaten its connection with the rest of China at Sinmin, forty miles to the west.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Ted Schroeder of Glendale, Calif., Davis Cup star and the nation's third ranking player, was seeded No. 1 today in the annual Sugar Bowl tennis tournament which starts next Sunday, Tourney Chairman Douglas Watters announced.

In an interim report to the stockholders the board of directors of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad Company announced yesterday that negotiations have been completed with the Pennsylvania Railroad for participation in passenger fare increases on a proportional basis, amounting to an additional annual revenue for H. M. of about $160,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The scheduled airlines reported record business today in several fields of operations, but a year-end SUrvey showed a noticeable increase in the fatality rate and losses exceeding the $7,000,000 deficit of 1946.

Manhattan College, which set three meet records in sweeping the relay races last winter, will try to duplicate this triple triumph in the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior indoor track and field championships at the Twenty-Second Regiment Armory tomorrow night.

The seventh annual survey of public opinion on American railroads, made for the Association of American Railroads, shows that the percentage of the people favoring public ownership of the railroads has been reduced considerably since 1941.

Two small freighters, both former Army cargo vessels, made their appearance in New York harbor early this month, reconverted to peace-time use and now employed in the transportation of frozen fish between New York and Newfoundland.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- A prediction that the "Free Government" of Markos Vafiades, proclaimed yesterday by the Communist-led rebels in Greece, would be recognized by Greece's neighbors of the Soviet bloc was made today by the diplomatic correspondent of the French Communist newspaper Humanite in a first page article.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Corporations in the United States paid out 20 per cent more in dividends during the three months ending on Nov 30 than they did in the same three months of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

For the second time in recent weeks a controversy has developed between the United Nations and the State Department over the accreditation of newspaper correspondents. On this occasion Trygve Lie has sent a "reminder" to Mr. Austin, as our chief delegate to the U.N., of the special status which this country agreed to grant to correspondents accredited to that organization.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Chester Bowles, chairman of the international advisory committee of the United Nations Appeal for Children, will leave on Jan. 2 for a five-week tour abroad in an effort to speed child-relief champaigns in European countries, it was announced today.

Anything that smacks of novelty is Michael Myerberg's bait. That accounts for the producer and owner of the Mansfield bringing "The Cradle Will Rock" from the City Center, where it was revived recently before enthusiastic audiences, to his own house tonight.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- The United Nations is making plans to convene four seminars on social welfare next year in different parts of the world, it was learned here today.

Those planning a trip to Florida involving any quail shooting would be well advised to get advance information on the quail situation in the area in which they plan to shoot, for reports from a large number of popular East Coast sections indicate poor shooting prospects.

The United States Navy will benefit as much as the American merchant marine when the new American President liner, President Cleveland, enters service tomorrow. The new vessel has been equipped as a potential wartime auxiliary, as well as an efficient passenger-cargo carrier, company officials said yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 25 -- The French will have a difficult task fitting their reorganized armed forces into the restricted budget, according to French military opinion expressed today.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (Reuters) -- Top places in all divisions of Britian's soccer leagues were maintained today as the heavy three-Day Christmas program started.

MADRID, Spain, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Generalissimo ,Francisco Franco is expected to take action, at a Cabinet meeting tomorrow in a political crisis that has developed because his Minister of Industry and Commerce, Juan Antonio Suances, was loudly hissed in Parliament Monday.

George Szell, with Erica Morini as assisting soloist, gave his Philharmonic-Symphony audience a Christmas present last night at the concert in Carnegie Hall for which fee will long retain their gratitude. The present was an exceptional series of Beethoven performances.
LONDON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Following is the text of King George VI's Christmas message to the Commonwealth and the British Empire:

WASHINGTON. Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Wineland that the Icelandic Vikings told in their sagas of finding on the North American Continent five centuries before Columbus possibly was at the mouth of the Merrimack River in northern Massachusetts, Dr. John R. Swanton, Smithsonian Institution collaborator, stated today.

A real festive atmosphere prevailed in the North Country as thousands of skiing enthusiasts took advantage of unusually good snow conditions for Christmas Day. According to wires received yesterday, favorable sport is enjoyed at most of the popular regions, deep powder surfaces being gradually packed by the constant running of hickory board devotees.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 25 -- All beaches in Natal are filled with vacationists for Christimas in. what is described as "the greatest spending orgy since before the war." Reports from resorts in Cape Province tell the same story.

The City Planning Commission and the Board of Estimate were criticized sharply yesterday by James A. Burke, Borough President of Queens, for approving a private parking garage in Manhattan but vetoing a similar project for Queens.

NANKING, China, Dec. 25 -- A series of small but potentially important Communist bases has sprung up almost unnoticed below the Yangtze River in the provinces denuded of regular Nationalist troops. Nuclear guerrilla units have intensified their activities in six southern provinces, especially Kwangtung, which the Communist timetable has scheduled for conquest by 1949.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The United States Air Force announced today that it had attained its year-end goal of 335,000 officers and men. On the basis of its past recruiting record it expressed confidence that a planned strength of 401,000 would toe reached by June 30.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The public is probably not fully apprised that American labor has embarked upon a new political program and that its program in effect, if not in purpose, constitutes an attempt to form a political bloc. The occasion is the opposition of most labor leaders to the Taft-Hartley Act.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- The Department of Justice has been investigating lobbying intensively and expects to begin criminal prosecution soon of unlawful efforts to influence Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Chicago landlords are not entitled to a 15 per cent increase in rents on the basis of information available in Washington, Tighe E. Woods, housing expediter, told the Chicago Rent Advisory Board today.
MANILA, Friday, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Manila was paralyzed today by an 80 - mile - an - hour typhoon that ripped through this war-scarred capital at sunup, twelve hours ahead of schedule.

The present situation in New York State with regard to post-high school educational opportunities is critical and likely to grow worse, the college committee of the Public Education Association declared yesterday in a letter to Owen D. Young, chairman of the Temporary Commission on the Need for a State University.

Although New York City's police reported few accidents yesterday in connection with the Christmas Day observance, 226 deaths were listed throughout the nation, a majority of them the result of traffic mishaps.

A four-point program for Federal tax reduction, based on the use of a substantial portion of the national surplus for debt retirement and the remainder for cuts in assessments has been adopted by the executive committee of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., it was announced over the holiday.

More than half a million people are expected to pay in excess of $2,000,000 to witness this year's cluster of football bowl games -- a giant octopus of an enterprise that now has tentacles stretching to every part of the country, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 25 -- The most formidable challenge to the control by President Juan Peron of Argentine universities in May, 1946, was laid down yesterday, when a group of scientists, intellectuals and former educators founded the Free University.

Twenty-three street corner Santa Clauses forgot the rigors of pre-Christmas fund-raising and relaxed yesterday at luncheons given for them by Rosoff's Restaurant, 147 West Forty-third Street, and in the Marine Grill of the McAlpin Hotel.
MONTREAL, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs conquered the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 0, before 11,109 fans in a bruising National Hockey League game here tonight.

A whopping big batch, of facts and figures, with a few opinions thrown in for good measure, was the Christmas present from the State Racing Commission yesterday. It was a copy of the three-man board's annual report to the Secretary of State, summarizing the happenings in New York racing during 1947 and making a prediction or two about the future.

After six months of preparation, the Communist command of the guerrillas in northern Greece has now made its long-expected move and proclaimed a rival "government" in opposition to the established Greek Government, which is recognized by all nations, including Soviet Russia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 25 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, acknowledged today that the work of the organization had been greatly handicapped by the lack of understanding among the great powers, but he expressed hope that in 1948 there would be "a change in the tide of disagreement."

LONDON, Dec. 25 -- King George VI appealed to his people in his annual Christmas broadcast today to remain steadfast in their quest for "true peace" in the world despite the disappointment suffered in the two and a half years since military victory was achieved.
Neighbors dramatically rescued yesterday a grandmother, a mother and her infant as flames swept a Brooklyn apartment while a Christmas dinner was being prepared.

The Metropolitan Opera evidently found under its Christmas tree what it badly needed -- a performance worthy of its reputation. Last night's "Rigoletto" was done the way all -- well, nearly all -- productions at the Metropolitan should be done.

MANILA, Dec. 26 -- The worst sea disaster since the war has developed from the wreck of the 10,000ton Danish freighter Kina off the bleak rocky coast of northern Samar in the central Philippines, with the probable loss of fiftyseven persons, including United States women and children, in the midst of a Pacific typhoon this morning.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Back in 1925, when the National Football League was a 2-team circuit, the championship went to the Chicago Cardinals, then coached by Dr. Eddie Anderson. On Sunday, under the tutelage of Dr. James Conzelman, the Cardinals hope to regain the glorious heights of yesteryear.

Impervious to the weather, as usual, the drama kept open house at the Mansfield last evening with a blistering revival of Marc Blitzstein's "The Cradle Will Rock." Despite the storm a full audience was on hand to salute it. For Mr. Blitzstein's "play in music," as he calls it, is the most vivid proletarian drama ever written in this country.
HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Lightly regarded Cardigan, owned by Dave Zakoor, upset the Calumet Farm's highly favored Balanced today in the Apalachicola Purse at Gulfstream Park.

Alice Ribeiro, Brazilian soprano, who made her local debut a year ago, gave her second New York recital last night at Town Hall. With Luis Borbolla at the piano, Miss Ribeiro presented a program featuring a group of songs by her compatriots, Siqeira, Ovalle, Guarnieri, Mignone and Villa-Lobos, and also containing arias by Mozart and Gretry; French lyrics by Faure, Debussy and Bachelet, and Spanish songs by de Falla, Granados and Turina.

MANILA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- At least seven other vessels experienced storm damage, the business district of war-ravaged Tacloban was reported 70 per cent burned by a wind-driven fire, and ten persons were listed as dead or missing in Manila and elsewhere ashore.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 26 (AP) -- State police tonight were rescuing women and children from hundreds of storm-stalled cars along the Merritt Parkway, where snow had drifted to five feet in many spots.
ATHENS, Dec. 26 -- About 2,000 heavily armed rebels were trying today to capture the Epirus town of Konitsa, ten miles from the Albanian border. They were engaged by Greek regular army forces.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The University of Maryland football squad arrived here today aboard a chartered plane from Washington, D.C., and prepared to resume practice tomorrow for its New Year's Day game with the University of Georgia in the Gator Bowl.

With the Board of Education preparing to issue its proposed budget for 1948-49 next month, the Teachers Union, CIO, suggested yesterday that the school officials draw plans calling for an increase of $50,000,000 in expenditures.

Heavy Treasury Call The United States Treasury issued yesterday a 75 per cent call on its "War Loan" accounts with the A and B banks. The call is based on balances as of Dec. 24, payable on Jan. 2. For the A banks here the amount involved is $10,780,700, while for the banks throughout the country, it is $98,589,800.
With a professional game scheduled for the afternoon and a college double-header on at night, more than 30,000 basketball fans will throng to Madison Square Garden today.

After working almost an hour Yesterday afternoon, police and fire rescue crews released a man pinned to the sidewalk in front of the St. Marks motion picture theatre, 133 Second Avenue, by the house marquee. The latter had crashed to the ground because of too heavy a snow burden.

The Royal Observatory at Greenwich -- by whose clock most of the world fixes its time -- has begun a move to new, more efficient quarters at Hurstmonceux Castle, twenty miles east of the prime meridian of longitude. But the world will be little affected by the change, and men will still set their watches and clocks by Greenwich Mean Time.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- A prediction that West Coast longshoremen might have to refuse to load materiel for some "reactionary right wing" governments, just as they did a decade ago when scrap iron was being sent to Japan, was made today by Harry R. Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Four major automobile manufacturers now are actively participating in the steel industry in an effort to assure themselves of a continuous flow of steel sheets to keep new cars rolling off assembly lines.

One of the points raised by those who oppose granting the Administration new economic controls is that the latter has not fully employed the powers which it already has at its disposal. There is a good deal to be said for this view. The Federal Reserve System has now offered at least a partial reply to this charge, however, by bringing one of these latent powers into play.

Both sides rested yesterday in the first-degree murder trial of three men accused of the shooting last Jan. 8 of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore. This came after a onehour session in which Assistant District Attorney George P. Monaghan briefly recalled two prosecution witnesses.
RONNE ANTARCTIC RESEARCH EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Marguerite Bay, Dec. 24 (Delayed) -- We have just completed two new trimetrogon mapping flights in the Antarctic.

LONDON, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- The race for leadership of the English Soccer League's first division tightened today as Preston North End avenged a Christmas Day defeat by Burnley, leaving only five points between the first three teams in the official standings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Appointment of a fact-finding board of three members to consider certain aspects of the wage negotiations between the Western Union Telegraph Company and three labor unions was announced today by Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

Brooklyn literally was brought to a standstill by yesterday's snowstorm. Surface cars crawled sporadically, automobiles were abandoned in mid-street, ambulances got stuck. Police radio cars "rushed" the sick, injured and seven maternity cases to hospitals.

As the domestic steel industry rushes in the final ten days of 1947 to cap the year's record production for a peacetime year with peak weekly output there is growing sentiment in the industry that there is an excellent possibility of ending the severe post-war steel famine some time in the next twelve months.

A new aluminum, zinc and magnesium alloy has been developed with physical properties which enable it to substitute for scarce iron parts in machinery and hardware, metallurgists of the Federated Metals Division of American Smelting and Refining Company revealed here yesterday.
The Cunard White Star Line will observe tomorrow its 100th anniversary of transatlantic passenger service between New York and Europe.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Fourteen-year-old Miss Laura Lou Jahn of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Belmar, N.J., upheld her top seeding by gaining the third round of the 1948 girls' national indoor tennis championship tournament without losing a game today at Longwood.

WESTOVER FIELD, Mass., Dec. 26 (UP) -- Bucking howling headwinds of growing Arctic storms, a United States Army plane from Goose Bay, Labrador, tonight rescued nine Americans whose B-17 was forced down on a frozen northern lake on Christmas Eve.
ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Nine candidates were named today for the feature race as Santa Anita starts its annual merry-goround of horse racing tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (Science Service) -- A helicopter, in which torque is overcome without the use of the familiar little auxiliary propeller that keeps pushing the tail sidewise, is the subject of Patent 2,433,251, just issued to Carter S. Whiting of Tarzana, Calif.

Department stores and many business establishments in the city and metropolitan area closed their doors early yesterday afternoon to enable their employes to get home. Closing hours were staggered so as not to overtax the storm-harassed transportation systems.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- A split rail, believed snapped by a sharp drop in temperature during the night was held responsible for the collision of a Florida East Coast passenger train and a freight here early today. Four crewmen were hurt.

Directors of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company declared yesterday a 50-cent dividend on the common stock, payable Dec. 31. Similar amounts were paid on March 31 and Sept. 30, but the payment for the second quarter was omitted.
LONDON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Moscow broadcast today a bitter attack on Premier-Designate Hakimi by Pravda, newspaper of the Russian Communist party.

The President's creation of an Interdepartmental Committee for Scientific Research and Development follows the advice given by the Scientific Research Board, of which John R. Steelman is chairman. But it would be a mistake to believe that the coordination of fifty overlapping and decentralized government bureaus is to be the major task of the Committee.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 26 (AP) -- After a week of practice sessions devoted largely to passing and pass defense, selected all-stars from Dixie and Yankeeland don the blue and gray here tomorrow for the annual North-South pigskin classic.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Mrs. George Sevey is a "mighty mad" woman and she says Senator Robert A. Taft had better quit dealing in "imponderables" and do something about it before she gets madder.

Vincent A. Lupiano, who as a justice of the Municipal Court receives an annual salary of $12,000, bowed yesterday to the efforts of public and private officials who are trying to get high-income tenants out of Knickerbocker Village, the East Side housing project where monthly rentals of $12.50 a room are made possible by part exemption from taxation.

The New Year will be the topic of sermons to be preached in virtually every church in the city tomorrow. "Holy hour" and "watch night" services will be held Wednesday night. Special services to welcome the New Year will be held Thursday morning.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Articles of incorporation for the Detroit Football Company, which plans to set up shop in the pro field here, were filed with the State Securities Commission today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- An improvement in highway lights was one of 349 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

New York of 1947 at last has something big enough to command respect from the memorable Blizzard Men of 1888. "I never-saw so much snow in the air at one time!" said Mr. Parry, ur contemporary meteorologist, in some astonishment. In his Thursday morning forecast for yesterday the weather man had said something like "cloudy and warmer."

Departing from its usual policy of musical revival presentations, the New Opera Company, of which Yolanda Mero-Irion is general manager, will put on tonight at the Morosco Theatre the Marcel PagnolBenn W. Levy comedy, "Topaze," first done in New York at the Music Box back in 1930, with Frank Morgan in the title role.

Duke Ellington and his orchestra gave their sixth annual concert in Carnegie Hall last night, before a remarkably large audience considering the state of the weather. Listing twenty-two numbers, the program was devoted largely to music composed by Mr. Ellington or by his arranger, Billy Strayhorn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The foreign world, especially Britain and Western Europe, is so short of dollars as to necessitate the Marshall Plan for its relief. It is universally agreed that it would be infinitely better that foreigners should earn the dollars rather than receive them as charity, or even as a loan.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- A five-year agreement for developing the growing of southern Rhodesian tobacco to fill part of the gap in the British market left by the stopping of purchases from the United States was announced today by the Board of Trade.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today, corn showing a heavy undertone from the start and at one time was off around 11 cents a bushel from the high point of the week. Wheat and oats eased at one tune in sympathy with corn but showed resistance to pressure later and rallied quickly.

The powerfully organized National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, an American Federation of Labor union of deck officers, plan to set up picket lines in every port of the nation in an effort to stop the proposed transfer of American ship tonnage to foreign nations, it was announced yesterday.

The five high-school seniors who won the $1,200 cash scholarships offered by the "Quiz Kids" radio program were announced yesterday. They are Graham Stanley Finney of the Greenwich (Conn.) High School ; Hugh F. Houston of the Rocky Mount (N.C.) High School; Louis Shelton of the Kirkwood Township (Ill.) High School; Barbara Flaherty of the Lincoln High School, San Francisco, Calif., and Ralph Shangraw, of the Rutland (Vt.) High School.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: THE TIMES has performed a signa service to the people of this state b its Dec. 19 editorial advocating wag increases for state employes. Salary scales in the State Civil Service are of concern not only, or even primarily, to state employes.

Trading at the new lower officialsupport levels continued in volume yesterday in the market for United States Government bonds, while heaviness persisted in high-grade corporate and municipal obligations.

Twenty months in advance of maturity, a loan of $12,000,000 made by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association last February to the KaiserFrazer Corporation was repaid in full yesterday, according to an announcement by Henry J. Kaiser and Joseph W. Frazer, chairman and president, respectively, of the automotive manufacturing company.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- The United Nations in the person of 175 staff workers who have been spending the Christmas holiday here -- decided today to make a gift to the people of an American town.

Henry L. Stimson has recorded in his official biography his belief that the United States war effort suffered losses at times as a result of the determination of President Franklin D. Roosevelt to "keep all the threads in his own hands."

With many traders literally snowed under, the stock market yesterday drifted lower and prices at the close were down fractions to 2 points. Trading was quieter than in recent sessions and the volume in the Stock Exchange fell to 930,000 shares after nine consecutive full sessions of more than a million shares each.

A proposal to extend the normal "daytime" trucking hours from ten to fifteen hours will be discussed it a traffic conference during the week of Jan. 11, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The AFL International Typographical Union today demanded the names, dates, places and other particulars of the unfair labor practices which the union is charged with committing against members of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Yesterday's snow storm brought shipping activity in the Port of New York almost to a standstill as seventy-three freighters were forced to suspend loading or unloading operations, mail and passenger vessel departures were delayed or postponed and ferryboats operated three to ten minutes behind schedule.

PARIS, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The National Assembly, after a brief holiday "breather," today groped through the complicated maze of a 100,000,000,000 franc (about $840,000,000) budget for 1948 in what looked like the start of a protracted debate.
William J. Powell, commissioner of sanitation, directed an army of workers last night in the enormous job of getting enough snow off city streets to enable operation of traffic over the week-end.
The city's suburbs were staggering last night from the full fury of the record-breaking snowfall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- During the week ended Dec. 24, member bank reserve balances decreased $304,000,000, the federal Reserve Board reported today.

ONE of the most interesting art books of the year is Robert Goldwater's "Rufino Tamayo," a study of the distinguished Mexican painter. It is illustrated with eight color plates, ten times as many collotype reproductions and nearly two dozen additional text illustrations. And like most of the new art books it is rather staggeringly expensive, too.

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- The State Board of Law Examiners announced today that 274 of the 662 applicants for admission to the bar had passed the October examination. Two hundred twenty of them live in the New York City area.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Armed and King Ranch's Assault head the list of 34 eligibles from three continents for the eleventh running of Hialeah Park's $50,000 added Widener Handicap on Feb. 21, it was disclosed today by Racing Secretary Charles J. McLennan.

Problem in Engineering An acquaintance who moved recently to the hinterland and who now has a small house all to himself reports that he has been compelled to renew contact with an old adversary, namely, a furnace.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 26 -- Offices of the United Nations were closed at 3 P.M. today to permit members of the secretariat to get home before transportation was paralyzed by snow.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Dec. 26 -- The Hungarian Foreign Ministry denounced tonight as "a gross lie" what it said was an assertion by The Associated Press that Soviet troops were still in Hungary at the invitation of the Hungarian Government.
Various ways devised by the young people of the city to raise money for the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund were described yesterday as many sent in their gifts.
TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Usually reliable sources said today that the Soviet Ambassador, Ivan C. Sadchikov, had left Iran with part of his staff and that the rest would leave soon.

Although apprehensive of business conditions in the coming year, rayon textile suppliers are confident of a record dollar volume of business in the first quarter of 1948, according to trade sources yesterday. Any feeling about a possible recession in soft goods lines projects itself somewhere toward the middle of the year, textile men said, while prospects are bright for movement of merchandise at better than the current rate in the immediate future.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -- In a New Year's message circulated today to all national Red Cross Societies, Basil O'Connor, chairman of the Board of Governors of the League of Red Cross Societies, cited 1947 as a year in which "new vigor and enthusiasm" marked Red Cross work.

Commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System overcame seasonal influences again last week, advancing $47,000,000 to another new high total of $5,413,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- After a brief appearance this afternoon of Gen. Hideki Tojo on the witness stand of the International Military Tribunal, his trial and those of twentyfour others of accused war crimes were adjourned over the week-end. The Japanese press tomorrow will feature the former Premier's plea as probably the biggest news event of this year.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- More than 500,000 French children and 100,000 aged persons will receive supplementary rations for six weeks to two months from the Friendship Train food sent by the people of the United States.

It started to rain in New York on Sunday evening, March 11, 1888. The temperature dropped and the rain changed to sleet and snow. By Monday morning the city was covered with snow and it was still falling.

With forty-six players representing twenty colleges, the tournament for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League, sponsored by the United States Chess Federation, was off to a good start yesterday at John Jay Hall, Columbia University.

BERLIN, Dec. 26 -- An attempt to eliminate small plants and make industrial concentration a formal policy in the bizonal area was recently thwarted by combined action of the British and American Decartelization Branches.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 26 (AP) -- The University of Kansas football team arrived here from Lawrence, Kan., aboard a chartered airliner tonight for their New Year's Day contest with Georgia Tech in the Orange Bowl.

City Magistrate Peter A. Abeles issued some strong words yesterday morning on the subject of landlords who "alibi" their failure to provide apartment dwellers with the amount of heat required by law. He also laid down a course of action for tenants who get nowhere banging on the radiators.

For small fry whose parents had planned a visit to the Metropolitan Opera yesterday afternoon to see "Hansel and Gretel," the counterattraction of all that snow to throw and roll in must have had a powerful pull. But those youngsters of all ages who managed to reach the Opera House for "Hansel" behaved as though it had been worth the trip.
Quaker leaders and clergymen of other faiths will gather today to honor the signers of what Flushing residents consider America's first great document of religious freedom.

Sanitation Commissioner William J. Powell made public yesterday a tabulation showing the amount of snowfall and the cost of removal for each of the nineteen years from 1928-29 to 1946-47, inclusive. In each instance the figures cover the entire snow removal season, from November to April, inclusive.

To eliminate confusion with other oil companies, the SoconyVacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that after Jan. 1 it no longer will use the word "Standard" on any of its products, plants or properties in New York and New England.

With more than 600 athletes slated to compete for the fifteen titles at stake, the pre-Olympic indoor track and field campaign will be launched tonight with the Metropolitan A.A.U. junior championships at the Twenty-Second Regiment Armory, on West 168th Street near Broadway.

A total of 771 record and transcription companies are scheduled to be affected next Wednesday midnight by the ban of the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, on the further manufacture of disks containing music, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Administration, making public a second list of traders in commodities futures, simultaneously opened today a sworn census to bring forth the names of those venturing on the markets who had any connection with Government, Federal, state or local.

Production of titanium dioxide is now at an all-time high, seventyfive times as great as in 1927, it was revealed here yesterday by officials of National Lead Company, 111 Broadway, who disclosed that a further expansion program of plant facilities is under way.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Wayne Coy, radio director of The Washington Post, was appointed chairman of the Federal Communications Commission today by President Truman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Questionnaires are on the way today to 2,953 Army and Navy officers asking details about the disabilities for which they were retired with tax-free incomes.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 26 (AP) -- Southern Methodist's Mustangs resumed practice after a four-day vacation and Penn State's Lions held another hard scrimmage today as they entered the final week of preparations for the New Year's Day Cotton Bowl game.

To an already worthy schedule of holiday entertainment for youngsters, the Theatre Arts program of the Walt Whitman School added another yesterday with its presentation of "Tom Sawyer -- Ballad of the Mississippi." With the arrival of yesterday's snow, which should be good for a week's sleighing, at-least, plus the choice of almost half-dozen in-the-flesh entertainments, this should be a merry vacation from books and thing's.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 26 -- Dr. Alan Gregg, director of the Division of Medical Sciences of the Rockefeller Foundation, has recommended rejection of a proposal that Virginia's two medical schools be merged under one board. He suggested, however, three other steps that might reduce their operating deficits.

Most of you had some difficulty in getting around to the stores to lay in supplies to supplement the cold Christmas turkey, but if you think that was difficult, picture the problems faced by the birds and small game.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- President Truman formally started the interim European aid program today, delegating all his authority over it to the Secretary of State George C. Marshall, and transfering the $522,000,000 authorized for winter relief to the State Department.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Two small Dominican ships were completing today the loading of an unrevealed quantity of Brazilian armaments sold to the Dominican Republic despite Venezuelan diplomatic efforts to block the deal.

The thinning line of lightweight Championship possibilities suffered a major reduction yesterday with the retirement of Bob Montgomery, Philadelphia Negro who formerly was recognized here as world champion.

So popular is the new program of the Girl Scouts to help clothe children around the world that fourteen New York troops reported yesterday that they had filled quotas given them for the coming year. The organization hopes to ship a million garments abroad, during 1948, on the basis of two or three clothing kits from each troop in the country.

Except for one player sidetracked by the weather, all the favored entrants in the junior division won without too much trouble as play began in the national junior and boys' tennis singles championships yesterday on the courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory.

Another round of parties was given yesterday for debutantes of the season and their young friends who are at home for the holidays. One of the largest was the supper dance given by Mrs. Haywood D. Newbold of 817 Fifth Avenue, and Southampton, L.I., in the St. Regis Roof to present her daughtter, Miss Betsy Newbold.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Production is expected to rise to new peaks in 1948 and there is "a distinct possibility" that inflation wil slow down, Edwin G. Nourse, Federal economist and adviser, said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 -- The American people have been getting "too many confusing and pessimistic stories from the Far East," Mr. Davis, Consul General in Shanghai, said here today en route to Washington to spend several weeks on the State Department's senior selection board.

A sweeping investigation of amateur boxing in this district by the Metropolitan A.A.U., last night was forecast when the governing amateur body ruled against issuance of further sanctions for amateur tournaments for an indefinite period.
The city is "well-stocked" with food, so no serious hardship is likely to result from the storm, Commissioner of Markets Eugene G. Schulz said yesterday afternoon.

Before a great tennis gathering at Madison Square Garden last night, Bobby Riggs, world's champion in the play-for-pay, tennis ranks, spoiled the premiere of the latest professional newcomer, Jack Kramer.

Storm Cuts Retail Gain Because of heavy eleventh-hour Christmas shopping, retail trade here will show an increase this week. The size of the gain, however, will be appreciably affected by the blizzard which closed New York and Brooklyn department stores at an early hour yesterday afternoon.

HAVANA, Dec. 26 -- Sergio I. Clark of Cuba, president of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, said tonight that it would require "time, patience and good-will" to resolve the conflicting views that had caused a stalemate in the conference.

To help meet the challenge of the great diseases that have not yet been conquered, such as cancer, heart disease and arthritis, the Long Island College of Medicine has announced a broad program of medical research, training of doctors, better health protection and care of the sick through its services to a network of associated hospitals and agencies.

The maintenance of city services at present levels will be "extremely difficult" during the fiscal year starting July 1 unless Mayor O'Dwyer is successful in obtaining "a very substantial portion" of his 1948 legislative program. Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson declared yesterday.

Furniture buyers from department and home furnishings stores will be limited by management policy to ninety-day forward purchasing in virtually all items except better bedroom and dining room furniture at the Chicago markets next month, a leading retailer revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Department of Justice announced today that its division charged with investigating registrations under the Lobbying Act had "conferred" recently with representatives of the CIO. The outcome of these talks was not disclosed by the department, which referred further inquiries to Lee Pressman, general counsel for the CIO.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: To use up the last of the holiday bird with a flourish, chicken or turkey pie is suggested for Saturday night's supper. Served with glazed or buttered onions and a salad of crisp red cabbage and celery, this is a hearty dish that combines thrift with good eating.

$3,000,000 for Gas Campaign Nearly $3,000,000 will be expended on advertising in 1948 by the American Gas Association, thirteen appliance manufacturers and approximately 600 utility companies for a continuing campaign promoting ranges and other gasconsuming fixtures, it was disclosed yesterday by an association spokesman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 20 totaled 832,130 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
