ATHENS, Dec. 26 (AP) -- At Konitsa late today, the Greek Army garrison beat back the third violent rebel assault in two days. Authoritative sources said the rebels' fire power was vastly greater than the Army's.

New York City and its environs wore last night a snow mantle 25.8 inches deep, dropped on the area by the greatest snowfall in the city's recorded history. The storm started at 5:25 A.M. The 25.8 inches was measured at midnight, with light snow flurries continuing.

DUBLIN, Dec. 26 -- Eire today is among the few fortunate countries that are not making headlines. To most of Europe this once turbulent and hungry land looks like an island of tranquillity and plenty. From England especially its green pastures beckon to feasts of milk and butter, eggs and bacon.
The New York City Housing Authority yesterday filed plans for its Sheepshead Bay Houses in Brooklyn to accommodate 1,056 families and cost $8,235,990.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Senate Civil Service Committee has started an investigation, Senator Clyde M. Reed of Kansas said today, to determine whether Kansas Democratic leaders had violated the Hatch act in connection with campaign fund solicitations or Federal job appointments.

PANAMA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Ricardo J. Alfaro, former Foreign Minister, said today the State Department of the United States had committed certain "fundamental errors" in negotiations for the defensebase agreement that the Panama National Assembly rejected last Monday.

TOKYO, Dec. 26 -- Intimidating tactics, it has been revealed, have returned to the Japanese labor scene. On Tuesday night four Communist Diet members, accompanied by leaders of various railway workers, united in what amounted to an effort to force Transportation Minister Tokutaro Kitamura to grant concessions beyond those that the Government had promised.

General Tojo, it turns out, has the same idea about Pearl Harbor that some of our own extreme isolationists have expressed on the floor of Congress. This idea is that Japan was "forced" to attack Hawaii, in sheer self-defense, because of an American "ultimatum."
Reinstatement of work relief as part of the city's welfare program was among the proposals discussed yesterday at a conference between Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, and his staff.

Two unions of cable employes, one independent, the other an affiliate of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday they had asked for joint negotiations with the three cable subsidiaries of the International Telephone Telegraph Company.
New York City's transportation systems suffered a creeping paralysis that became more and more acute yesterday as the snowfall piled higher and higher.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec., 26 -- "Doctors on Horseback," a work by Robert Thoeren about Ephraim MacDowell, frontier surgeon of the early Nineteenth Century, which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has owned since 1940, has been revived by the studio as a vehicle for Wallace Beery and Van Heflin.

Some reached for ski poles, thousands of others for the long stick on the working end of a shovel, but Caryl Beckwith wandered through the storm all day carrying a long, slim cedar rod marked in tenths of an inch. Miss Beckwith's job is to take the official snowfall readings for the Weather Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Life insurance companies are entitled by law to deductions that will entirely exempt most of them from 1947 Federal income taxes, a situation which calls for "the immediate attention" of Congress, John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, announced today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- All the meteorites that have landed and still are landing on earth are the shattered fragments of an ancient planet that revolved around the sun between Mars and Jupiter several hundred million years ago, which exploded in space for reasons unknown.

NANKING, Dec. 26 -- Rigid military censorship was clamped today on all press dispatches from Mukden, Manchuria's leading city whose 1,000,000 population is undergoing extreme winter hardship as a result of the Communist blockade.
A temporary spurt in the number of heatless homes in and around the city was predicted yesterday.

Arriving in New York during the heaviest snow storm in the city's history, a doughty band of Canadian skiers bound for the Winter Olympics in Switzerland, literally "schussed" and "slalomed" its way to the Queen Mary of the Cunard White Star Line yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday recovered all early losses and closed steady, 4 to 9 points net higher.

JERUSALEM, Saturday, Dec. 27 -- An immigration official of the Jewish Agency for Palestine was shot dead yesterday by Arabs in an attack on a convoy in which Mrs. Golda Meyerson, acting head of the Agency's Political Department, was traveling. Mrs. Meyerson was unhurt.

FAIRFIELD, Iowa, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Roy P. Porter, former Associated Press correspondent in Europe, died unexpectedly this morning. He was 40 years old. Mr. Porter and his wife had come here from New York to attend the funeral of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Jack Ireland.

Editor New York Times Book Review: WHEN a reviewer avoids the basic issues of a book and resorts to ridicule and misrepresentation of its author he is, I think, revealing his inability to make a more coldly logical attack. There is no coldly logical attack on my research methods in Dr. B.F. Skinner's recent review of my book, "The Reach of the Mind."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The text of Loyalty Review Board Chairman Seth W. Richardson's statement on board aims and procedures:

The construction materials industry is winding up its greatest year of production, with the physical volume of goods running 2 per cent ahead of the previous peak year of 1925, and much higher in dollar value.
MY name is Nunnally Johnson. N-u-n-n-a-l-l-y, Nunnally. I was born Dec. 5, 1897, in Columbus, Ga., of white Methodist parents.

FOR hundreds of thousands of radio listeners the name of Milton J. Cross is virtually synonymous with the Metropolitan Opera; and so it was inevitable, I suppose, that sooner or later the amiable announcer-commentator of the Metropolitan's Saturday afternoon broadcasts should give us in book form his versions of opera plots, however glutted the market might be with other volumes on the same subject.

Commercial bankers in this state, now becoming aware of the specialized technique of public-relations activity, are planning to set up a special school in that field, it was learned yesterday. The project, sponsored by the New York State Bankers Association, under the direction of Syracuse University, is still in the "top-secret" stage, but it has been established definitely that the association's council of administration has given its formal approval to the plan.

The American merchant marine, occupied throughout 1947 with problems of reconversion and adjustment from war status, declined appreciably in size during the year, Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, reported in a year-end review made public yesterday.

OTTAWA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Canadian Trade Minister J.A. MacKinnon, in a year-end review of Canada's growth as a trading nation, said today that decisions taken in 1947 "will lead to changes which we hope will work toward a better balance in Canada's trade with foreign countries."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The question whether the closed shop is to survive as an institution of American labor may turn on the outcome of the charges brought by the American Newspaper Publishers Association against the International Typographical Union, AFL, under the Taft-Hartley Law.

CHARLESTON, which has somewhat Jagged behind other historic, picturesque American cities of late in receiving literary attention, is put back in the running and receives an affectionate, understanding, overall presentation in this newest volume of the Century City Series.
BILOXI, Miss., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Alabama's Crimson Tide, thirty-eight strong, arrived this afternoon and immediately began practice for the Sugar Bowl game against the University of Texas.
Fuel oil distributors were operating yesterday at about 50 per cent of efficiency, slowed down primarily by heavy uncleared snowdrifts in side streets and driveways.

NANKING, Dec. 27 -- New attacks against weakly defended towns on the Yangtze River, the Chinese Government's most important economic lifeline, have been launched on both sides of Hankow by Communist troops based north of the river.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee will consider further anti-inflation proposals, along with many other issues when it meets next month, Senator Robert A. Taft, its chairman, said today.

ARCHITECTURE and sculpture may be sister arts, but in recent generations there has been a serious falling out in the family. The latest attempt at reconciliation is the exhibition of sculpture now at the Architectural League, arranged by a committee of sculptor members to show what has been going on.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- During the second quarter of 1947, the net income of all manufacturing corporations in this country, after taxes, amounted to $2,500,000,000, compared with $2,700,000,000 in the first three months, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission reported today in a joint statistical release.

THE year just drawing to a close has been crowded with flower shows. Varying from small informal events to elaborate exhibitions lasting several days, they have been more numerous than for several years. To anyone who has followed them fairly consistently," at least in the New York area, it is apparent that just as styles change in automobiles or women's hats, certain trends are developing in the field of flower arrangement.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Coaches of the East team in the annual East-West Football Game at Kezar Stadium got a scare today when Tony Minisi hard-running back from the University of Pennsylvania, sprained an ankle in scrimmage.

A WRITER of mystery tales, Mitchell Wilson departs from that robust domain to investigate character and emotion in "The Kimballs." He withstands the more perilous lures of literary ambition by limiting his cast, confining scenery and eschewing plot complications.

THE annual scramble, and a mad one it is, for Pullman space to Miami for the high season on Florida's East Coast is now under way. In good times it has always been a battle royal with sun followers, travel agents and other vendors of transportation as the principal contenders, and the railroads and their reservation clerks as the bystanders who frequently get pulled into the ring.

Within an hour after arriving back at City Hall last night by plane from California to assume personal charge of snow clearance, Mayor O'Dwyer announced that he would request by radio today that all private cars except funeral groups and all trucks except those hauling food, fuel and other essentials stay off the streets tomorrow.

Representatives of nearly 300 National Collegiate Athletic Association member universities will gather at the Hotel New Yorker for their forty-second convention Jan. 9 and 10 to take final action on the proposed amendments to the association's constitution.
This seems to be the reflection period, when anglers and hunters, individually and in groups, are thinking over the sport of the past year and planning for the year to come.

THE hobby of clock collecting is but one of many aspects of the much more general hobby of antique collecting, but nevertheless, it has in recent years developed into a $5,000,000-a-year business. This volume serves as a primer for the incipient clock collector, as well as a comprehensive handbook for the seasoned one.

Additional automobiles for 1948 is one of the major needs of the Visiting Nurse Association of Brooklyn, according to the December report to the board of directors issued yesterday by Miss Marie M. Knowles, executive director.

After several futile attempts by the police, an unidentified young sailor rescued yesterday afternoon a 50-year old bridge operator who had been trapped in a snow-covered automobile for twenty-one hours a half mile away from, the Mill Basin Bridge, Brooklyn.

New assurance and new uneasiness came into the market for prime securities over the Christmas holiday as the Federal Reserve Bank System lowered the level at which it would support prices of Government bonds and at the same time changed from a reluctant to a willing buyer.

Continuing his clean sweep of batting laurels in the American League 1947 campaign, Ted Williams, long range clouter of the Red Sox, topped his circuit both in slugging percentage and runs batted in, according to the official figures announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 27 -- Steamship travel to the Orient, on a luxury basis, was resumed today, after six years of interruption, when the 23,500 -- ton President Cleveland headed westward through the Golden Gate with 550 passengers.

To guard the Panama Canal -- the strategic American-owned waterway linking the Atlantic to the Pacific -- the United States has relied upon an elaborate, three-zone defense system. The outer zone is a series of air and naval, bases strung around the Caribbean from San Juan, Puerto Rico, across the West Indies, and west to the Galapagos Island in the Pacific.
There is no cause for alarm about depletion of the city's food supplies early in the week, Eugene G. Schulz, Commissioner of Markets, insisted yesterday.

THE final entries in the brief chronology at the end of this well-executed cooperative study are Sixth symphony, 1923; Seventh symphony, 1924; and "Tapiola," 1925. (The legendary Eighth symphony remains a legend here.) At the age of 60 the composer effectively fell silent.

The top of the business upswing which began in August was reached in November, and December reports show a falling off in the number of companies reporting increased sales and production, it was revealed in a summary of the composite opinion of purchasing agents who comprise the National Association of Purchasing Agents business survey committee.

THIS department's 1947 researches began with the subject of kindergartens. Looking back, we see that we failed to report one historic objection to this form of early childhood education. Guess what? In 1893 people said the kindergarten was just a place for mothers to park their children.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Official opinion in the Department of State is crystallizing gradually in favor of increasing United States military assistance to Greece.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The new Loyalty Review Board laid down today its standards for testing the loyalty of employes of the Government and promised that ''the program shall not degenerate into a witch-hunt."

There may have been a time when the Giants did not look upon the development of vast farming systems in baseball with favor. John McGraw frankly did not like it at all, chiefly, perhaps, because he was shrewd enough to see in it a direct challenge to his own matchless genius which, singlehandedly, had kept his club on top so long.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Dec. 27 -- Buried under a blanket of snow that ranged from twenty-seven inches at the playground to thirty-two at the popular towserviced Silver Mine Hill, Bear Mountain Park, gem of the Hudson highland, is anticipating a winter sports season that will surpass any since ice and snow were accepted as assets back in 1926.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The unending quest for speed as a prime characteristic of military aircraft was emphasized by the Department of the Air Force today in releasing a year-end summary of the new airplanes it has ordered. Of the seventeen new types ordered during the year, however, sixteen are purely experimental and may never be produced in volume.
BOSTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued these winter sports forecasts and ski conditions:
Stock prices in the brief session yesterday displayed slightly lower tendencies. Trading on the Stock Exchange was unusually slow and price changes were narrow.

BELVA LOCKWOOD was 54 years old when, in 1884, she ran for President as the candidate of the National Equal Rights party of the Pacific Coast. Behind that unprecedented act lay a record of many years service in the fight for equal rights for women.

THE unveiling of Spanish mysteries for Anglo-Saxon readers is difficult. When attempted by an Englishman or American, the analysis is often too cool, too Protestant -- there is not enough churrigueresque in the spiritual architecture of Oxford or Chicago.
LONDON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Russia claimed, today to be "graining the upper hand in peaceful competition" with, the Western powers' "capitalistic system" for economic supremacy.

MANILA, Dec 27 (AP) -- The toll of dead and missings -- including those lost on the sunk motorship Kina--stood at forty-nine tonight as the Philippines mopped up after its worst December typhoon in three decades.
Benjamin Parry, chief meteorologist of the Weather Bureau, suggested "yesterday, that more attention to meteorological research might be in order.

CONTRACT bridge winds up 1947 in a blaze of glory: a Gallup poll has found bridge to be America's favorite card game. Meanwhile, the bridge authorities, those who write the books and run the tournaments, find their pleasure mixed with some degree of apprehension.

For the first time in the history of New York University its three largest religious organizations, the Christian Association, the Newman Club and the Jewish Culture Foundation, will be housed in one building at 2 Washington Square North, Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university, announced yesterday.
TRURO, Mass., Dec. 27 -- Cape Cod fishermen, kept ashore by mountainous waves, today were taking a rather smug pleasure in the plight of snowbound New York City.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 27 -- Geographers from all over the United States and from several foreign lands attending the meeting of the Association of American Geographers, the National Council of Geography Teachers and the American Society for Professional Geographers, heard many appeals today for greater study of their specialty, including one by Edward R. Stettinius Jr. former Secretary of State.

EVERY week more than seventy-five actors and actresses come into my office asking for a radio audition. Most of them have had little or no professional experience. In addition, I receive dozens of letters a week from every state in the Union, asking how to get an acting job in radio.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Temple University unloosed a barrage of baskets in the final ten minutes tonight to wallop a scrappy but outclassed Dartmouth College quintet, 73 to 54, before 3,500 Convention Hall fans.

A lively version" of "Hansel aid Gretel" is having a week's run of daytime performances at the tiny Greenwich Mews Playhouse The Lemonade Opera Company, which included the work in its successful season there last summer, again gives the work the enthusiasm of youthful performers and the fast pace made possible by judicious cutting.

With Christmas now behind and New Year's Eve soon past, the yachtsman, who usually beaches' himself for the fall months, is nearly ready for his second busiest part of the year. Instead of hibernating, he considers January, February and March almost as important as his cruising weeks next summer.

TWO recent art publications deserve especial attention at this time. One of these, "Rufino Tarnayo, by the scholarly Robert Gold-water, the publication being synchronous with the exhibition of work by the Mexican artist, current this month at the Pierre Matisse Gallery.

ANKARA, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The demonstration here today capped a week-long anti-Conttnunist campaign in the Ankara newspapers. The dismissal of four allegedly communistic Ankara University Professors has resulted.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Congressional investigators, expressing dissatisfaction with Administration efforts to uncover "Government insiders" In commodity speculation, increased pressure today for early independent checks on all aspects of Government buying for foreign countries.

POST-HOLIDAY cruises, discontinued during the war years, are again becoming a feature of the winter travel season. Demands for cruise reservations are brisk; travelers snap up tickets as quickly as ships are assigned to favorite cruise runs.

WHEN 1947 began, the objective for the record makers was to catch up with the vast, accumulated demand for all manner of disks. Considerable progress was made during the year. A lot of new recordings were released, and not all-though too many-were duplications of standard repertory.

IF you are shopping for furniture during the next few months and should happen to notice some dining-room and bed-room pieces with a "different" look, they will probably be the introductory samples of substantial shipments due here shortly from Sweden.

The Public Service Corporation of New Jersey one of the country's largest utility system, whose plan of corporate simplification is pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission, increased last week its system-wide generating capacity to 1,211,150 kilowatts.

OF all the great musical figures of the nineteenth century, perhaps none has been so curiously and consistently misrepresented as Musorgskyy. Many composers of the past have suffered at the hands of their biographers, but usually posterity has been able to evaluate them more or less accurately by the music they wrote.
The following indicates the extent to which various means of transportation had conquered the effects of Friday's record-breaking snowstorm:
BERLIN, Dec. 27 -- The Soviet Military Administration has prescribed the compulsory study of the Russian Constitution for all residents of the Soviet occupation zone, it was disclosed today.
In year-end statements issued for publication today, representatives of the steel industry discuss the outlook for 1948.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Reserve Officers Association said today it had submitted to Congress a plan for national security, made necessary because "the admirals and generals of the top level staff have been impervious to new concepts of preparedness."

All of the larger department stores in Manhattan, Brooklyn and in the suburbs opened at their usual time yesterday morning. However, they, closed from one to two hours earlier, permitting their employes ample time to get home in the face of transportation difficulties.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 -- By ones and twos, outstanding golfers of the nation, and a few from abroad, are assembling here for the $10,000 Los Angeles open, initial tournament of the 1948 money trail. The Los Angeles event will get under way Friday.

World War II veterans have a slight but definite edge" over non-veterans as effective salesmen, Harry R. White, executive secretary of the Sales Executives Club of New York, declared in an interview last week. Mr. White based his contention oil a recently completed club survey covering several top business organizations which sought to determine whether or not veterans employed as salesmen since the end of the war are succeeding.

GRASSE, France. IN all France there are only twenty Noses. They belong to -- or more properly, they arc -- those masters of the olfactory sense who create perfumes designed to induce "Un Reve," "Mystery" or "Wild Abandon" in perfume users and/or their escorts the world over.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 27 -- The series of anti-Comnmnis demonstrations since announcement was made that the state of siege in Istanbul and five other provinces would be lifted took a violent turn today.

Thousands of Long Island and Westchester commuters spent Friday night in cold, stalled trains between Manhattan and their homes. Trains on both the Long Island and New York Central railroads were as much as twelve hours, late on runs that usually take less than an hour.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Thoroughbred racing returned to Santa Anita Park with a flourish today as a record opening-day crowd of 64,000 saw Call Bell ring out a victory in the $50,000 added California Breeders Champion Stakes at one mile.
ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Olympic ski jumpers from the United States, Italy and Switzerland will meet tomorrow in the St. Moritz Christmas jumping championships on Olympic Hill.

LONDON. JUST twenty years ago the Gilbert and Sullivan Society in London invited me to appear before it and argue in debate that Gilbert's part of the work was growing so out of date in its references and so old fashioned in its style that it would have to be rewritten soon or the operas would lose their grip and become meaningless to the public.

THE year drawing to a close set a new record for dollar volume of retail trade, but it was also accompanied by a decline in unit sales of major significance. The old saw about "the higher the fewer" is once more proving itself and this will inevitably have considerable bearing on retail prospects for 1948.

NOW comes that happy moment when the occupant of this corner can cut loose and concentrate his geniality upon the best pictures of the year. For twelve months we sit in solemn judgment upon the passing parade of films, wincng in pain at some of them and swelling with satisfaction at a precious few.

WHEN, a few months ago, the League of Composers announced that it planned, as part of its twenty-fifth anniversary celebration, to sponsor a band concert on Jan. 3 in Carnegie Hall, many a reader of the music pages must have received a mild shock or been led to suspect that a misprint was somewhere involved.

For Americans and most Europeans the twelvemonth that begins this Thursday is Anno Domini 1948. For the Japanese it is the twenty-third year of Showa, dating to Hirohito's accession. For the Chinese the new year -- the Thirty-eighth of the Republic -- will not begin until Feb. 10.

MONTREAL, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadians, backed by the sharp goal-tending of Bill Durnan, advanced into a fourth-place tie with Boston in the National Hockey League tonight by shading the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 -- 1, before 11,144, the season's largest Forum crowd.

A SHORT while back the P.E.N. Club threw a swank dinner during which various individuals were supposed to take off their high hats and silk ties and get down to some rough and tumble on the subject of the book clubs.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- A Government construction expert predicts that building costs will remain at 1947 levels next year.

WHERE art is disposed to grapple with the raw, topical realities of our day, it usually turns to expressionism; where the facts-remain undigested technically or are used to bypass the search for a living language of painting, as demonstrated in the work of three expressionists currently on view, expressionist painting is liable to crack under the strain and fall off into a ruck of sentimentality.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Final preparations completed, there were no Ieventh-hour developments today to cause a switch or change in the odds for tomorrow's National football League championship play-off between the Philadelphia Eagles and Chicago Cardinals at Comiskey Park.
THIS was a year for a diversity of events. Record high prices were reached for many products. Staples that had been imported before the war (coconut, tapioca) returned to stores.

IT is a pleasure indeed to pick up a book of contemporary verse and to recognize instantly its excellence. For verse today has its difficulties. Some of the best of our modern poets are "difficult": Wallace Steveiw, Marianne Moore, W.H. Auden are examples.

The United States Weather Bureau forecast for Friday, Dec. 26, said: "New York City and vicinity, cloudy with occasional snow ending during the afternoon." It probably was the greatest understatement in Weather Bureau history.

MARGARET CAMPBELL BARNES, a lady from Surrey, is an old hand at historical novels. She has already done up the England of Richard Coeur de Lion and Henry VIII, and in her latest book, "Within the Hollow Crown," Richard II has his innings.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 27 -- The United States Military Government boldly charged tonight that "freedom of speech is being suppressed through a one-party political system" in the Soviet zone.

THIS is the second collection of Haldane's essays to appear within the last several months. Like its predecessor, "Science Advances," it is made up chiefly of articles which Haldane wrote for The London Daily Worker. A review written for the American counterpart of that newspaper would certainly award this book its gold medal, both for the high standard of scientific exposition and for the political and social point of view.

HERE is a book you could have had in installments, for thfe price of eighty-one postcards. For this is a collection of talks given over the radio during intermissions of the Sunday afternoon Philharmonic - Symphony concerts. While the musicians-rested, the scientists spoke.

The year runs out. A few more days and the chart we call the calendar begins a new cycle, another sequence of days to add up into weeks and months and, in the end, another year. Thus we mark it off, for man must count his hours and days and bring mathematical order, at least, into his life.

In the longest match of the day, Gilbert Bogley of Chevy Chase, Md., second-seeded player, rallied to win from Daniel Rivkind, Brooklyn College sophomore, in the second round of the national junior indoor tennis championships at the Seventh Regiment Armory yesterday, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 10 -- 8.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The greatest problem for United States foreign policy strategists in 1948 can be summed up in one question, the answer to which they cannot know for certain: What will the Soviet Union do next and where and how ?

NANKING, Dec. 27 -- Communists are harassing isolated Mukden with increasing boldness and food riots have broken out in that shivering Manchurian city, reports seeping through the newly-established censorship said today.

PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Two fires, one of which threatened to explode stored chemicals, destroyed a big waterfront coal plant and a 250-foot stockyard stable today in a northeast storm. Four fishing vessels tied up alongside the Randall McAllister Coal Company's wharf were damaged when a blazing, 400-ton loading tower crashed on them.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- Adoption by the National Assembly this week of a modified form of the Government's special anti-inflation levy marked what may be called the second battle of the moderate forces to justify their claim to govern France.
Members of the Army Medical Center at Port Totten, Bayside, Queens, and other military personnel rescued more than 100 civilians marooned or endangered by the snow storm Friday night and yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 26 (Delayed) -- A purge to eliminate wavering members of the Communist party in the Netherlands will be undertaken on orders of Paul de Groot, executive secretary, he made clear here today at the biennial congress of the party.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- John Bialas of Ithaca College and Anthony Callipaire of the Rochester Skating Club won the men's senior 220-yard and 880-yard races, respectively, as the Northern New York Skating Association program opened today.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- There's plenty of snow up-state this week-end, and slopes and trails are in "fair to excellent" condition for skiing.

In business it long has been the custom at New Year's to take inventory and stock of the gains and losses made during the preceding year. Applying the bookkeeper's standards to activities in rehabilitation and services to the handicapped, there usually has been in past years a modest total on the credit side of the ledger.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec 27 -- Sixth for half the trip of a mile and a sixteenth, the Bermill Farm's Bug Juice staged a strong finish to capture the $10,000 added Fort Lauderdale Handicap at Gulf-stream Park today.
Cotton futures were rather quiet yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange where attendance was reduced by the storm. Final prices were 2 points lower to 7 points higher than on Friday.
The writer of the following letter is a member of the faculty of New York University Graduate School of Arts and Science. He was adviser to the German Ministry of Economics under the Weimar Republic.
A donor who, saw the human misery in France last summer sent a gift of $10 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund in memory of his son who died in the war.

FOR nearly a full century, from 1847 to 1937, the Fall River Line's luxurious side-wheel steamers covered the. route between New York and Fall River in Massachusetts. It was a service that aroused admiration and affection among the millions of passengers, and in all that time the queen of those fine ships was the matchless Priscilla.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates of the National League will play thirty-nine exhibition games in their 1948 spring training schedule -- thirty-one of them against major opposition.

BOSTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- With little Bruce Mather, star of last season's great Dartmouth team, performing the three-goal trick, the United States Olympic hockey team made its public debut by defeating the strong University of Toronto sextet, 7 -- 4, before a crowd of 5,900 tonight at the Arena.

TWELVE months ago the travel industry hailed 1947 as the first honest-to-goodness post-war travel year. The world seemed to be simultaneously opening up and settling down. Tourist outfits were back in business again, and they were busy taking wartime austerity conditions out of travel, restoring luxury and glamour to the private citizen's holiday.

PROBABLY the most important developments of the year now closing are those still fairly nebulous ones which deal with basic post-war readjustment in the dance world. They are as yet more symptomatic than factual, however, and are felt rather than objectively seen.

THE old saying, "Good things come in small packages," might well be applied to dwarf fruit trees, which are once more available in greater quantities. The discovery in England of the famous Mailing understocks for apples some years before the war gave great impetus to the cultivation of these smaller forms.

STATISTICALLY speaking -- and otherwise -- the theatre, as usual, insists on being different. Here it is the end of the year, the time when lists and such are being dispensed and the theatre is, according to the records, in mid-stream.

MANY strange things have been attributed to the walls of the Museum of Modern Art, but they will now be accused of having ears. So surreptitious was the note-taking of the gallery lecturers that the public was surely unaware of the painstaking way in which its taste, reactions and questions have been recorded.

With a new state charter duly en acted and about to take effect, Governor Driscoll of New Jersey faces the second year of his three-year term with a review and possible revision of one of the state's local administrative setups, the commission form of municipal government.
TORONTO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The world champion Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Boston Bruins, 2 -- 1, to increase their National Hockey League lead to five points tonight before 14,157 fans.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Utah's "Cinderella" team, national invitation basketball tournament champion, opened its Eastern invasion tonight by conquering Canisius, 41 -- 36. A Memorial Auditorium crowd of 10,619 also watched.

Editor New York Times Book Review: I WAS not reviewing' the experiments to which Dr. Rhine's book refers and should, of course, do so only in a technical journal. It was a book for the non-technical reader and I reviewed it as such.

New York City's transportation systems began to get themselves out of the snow yesterday, the railroads and subways achieving full operation though subject to delays, but surface transportation was still badly crippled and offering at best only shadowy service.

Like a giant stunned by a sudden blow, New York began yesterday to shake off the numbing effects of the greatest snowfall on record here. It marshaled its vast resources, threw its reserves of men and machines into action, and by nightfall the life stream of the metropolis was once again beginning to pump through its great arteries of communication to the metropolitan area and the rest of the country.

WHEN in the fullness of time historians look back on the year 1948 they will say of it: "That was the decisive year of the twentieth century. In it the most powerful nation the world has ever seen -- the American nation -- came face to face with the problem of its world responsibility.

THE outstanding fact of photography in 1947 was that photographers were more than ever more conscious of their equipment than of subject-matter. Despite this concern with the tools of the photographic medium, which was reflected in an astonishing flood of mediocre work, there were a few signs that things will be better in 1948.

THIS may come as a shock to the thousands of Americans who tried, without success, to buy a new automobile this year: during 1947 the industry produced about five million units and tie American purchasers received eighteen out of every twenty cars that left the assembly lines.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Glenn Davis was denied permission to resign from the Army by the Department of the Army today, marking the second time the All-America halfback's plea to enter professional football was rejected in six months.

THE New York Botattical Garden has a series of Saturday afternoon lectures starting on Jan. 3. These programs, which have been given for fifty years, include talks on practical gardening designed for people who live near New York,. and also on more general nature subjects.

THIS study of the origins and evolution of scientific fiction by Mr. J.O. Bailey, professor at the University of North Carolina, fills a definite gap in any library concerned with the varieties of literary creation. How important this gap should be considered must depend primarily on the reader's own predilections and also on how susceptible he may be to Mr. Bailey's skillfully unobtrusive presentation.

IN a Reuters dispatch from Frankfort, Allan Dreyfuss reports that stamp dealers in the American zone of Germany are "rejoicing in the fact that Hitler's face has become their fortune" by virtue of an Allied Control Council decree last April forbidding purchase, exhibition, sale "or even existence" of postal paper bearing the Fuehrer's portrait.
ATHENS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Markos Vafiades, guerrilla chieftain who has proclaimed a Communist state in northern Greece, is a convert to communism who has made a career of violent political agitation.

In a meeting that paired the Western and Eastern division leaders of the Basketball Association of America, Chicago's Stags downed New York's Knickerbockers, 79 to 70, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
The safest way of passing holidays is to sit and yawn your head off. -- Voltaire.

WHILE the art world does not change overnight, one season does perceptibly differ from another. At the end of last season several of the art writers met quite by accident on Fifty-seventh Street and were joined by one or two other habitual gallery visitors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- How the late Fiorello La Guardia changed his mind on the question of universal military training was disclosed here today by Gen. Peyton C. March, retired, Chief of Staff of the War Department in World War.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The holiday interlude may enable members of Congress to assess "the state of the nation" in the light of its most important domestic problem -- the ever-continuing pursuit of wages and prices.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:
The Chamber of Commerce of Binghamton, N.Y., was reliably reported yesterday to be toying with the idea of billing the town as the unofficial capital of the United Nations.

THE railroads made a good beginning during 1947 on their broad program, for the improvement of passenger service which, was seriously weakened by wartime operations. New equipment on order, especially sleeping cars, was not delivered in anywhere near the quantity desired or needed.

Years are like people: there is so much good in the worst of them, so much bad in the best of them. In these waning days of 1947 we may like to remember that this year did not arrive in an atmosphere of buoyant optimism. In fact, most persons' fears, whether or not they cared to express them in public, must have outweighed their hopes.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- A discussion of music school curricula and standards of requirements for graduate music schools, today opened the four-day annual meeting of the National Association of Schools of Music.

ESCAPE from humdrum existence was the unflagging vocation of Cyrus LeRoy Baldridge. From his birth on an upstate New York farm through a precocious boyhood with his itinerant mother, he later came to see and to be with, the great and famous in distant parts of the world.

AS the union pooh-bah of musicland, James C. Petrillo is a man of provocative, if peculiar, distinction. A scratch of his pen on the bottom of a one-paragraph letter -- his most recent memo outlaws the making of records and transcriptions after next Wednesday -- usually has reverberations from the recesses of Tin Pan Alley to the halls of Congress.

ONE HUNDRED years ago, on the western coast of Africa, a Negro republic was founded without benefit of League of Nations or internecine strife. This was the birth of the Land of the Free -- Liberia, as the Rev. Ralph Gurley, one of the founding fathers, named it.

Sales of property reported through the multiple listing bureau of the Salt Lake City Real Estate Board amounted to $3,500,000 last month, and represent an increase of 30.3 per cent over the corresponding month last year. The November total was slightly lower than that for October, however, according to figures furnished to the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

A the only annual attempting to give a comprehensive picture of the year's photography in this country, "U.S. Camera 1948" (New York: U.S. Camera Publishers, $5.95) performs a useful service. If the effort of Tom Maloney, the editor, is not uniformly successful, at least it is a good try.

Back in winning stride after dropping a game to each of the tail-end teams in the National Hockey League, the New York Rangers will skate against the loop-leading Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden tonight. With the New Yorkers showing a vast improvement over Ranger teams of the past four years, it is almost certain that Frank Boucher's stick-handlers will play before a capacity crowd when they oppose the Leafs.

New York University came on with a thunderous drive late in the game to register its sixth straight basketball triumph last night. The undefeated Violets downed Missouri, 70 to 63, after St. Francis had snapped the five-game winning streak of Arizona, 79 to 70, in the first game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.

DENVER, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The second annual Denver open golf tournament, with prize money reduced from $15,000 to $12,500, has been tentatively scheduled for next Aug. 19-22 at the Wellshire Municipal Course.

A special educational program, designed to provide better facilities for truant and delinquent children, is to be Introduced next term by the New York City school system. Twelve schools, in various parts of the city, will be established for the treatment of emotionally maladjusted pupils or for those who need remedial disciplinary attention.

HOLLYWOOD is awaiting the arrival of the new year with serious mien and with a minimum of cheerful bell ringing if persistent reports and fairly well founded alarums are taken into account. Losses from foreign markets, and an anticipatecl reduction in domestic revenues are giving the studio heads plenty to worry about.

After two rounds in the tournament for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, six of the original list of forty-six had scores of 2-0 to their credit last night.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Dewey told New York City officials today that all possible facilities of the state were at their disposal to help dig the metropolis out of the worst snowfall in its history.

Even without the benefit of any championship boxing matches and the Army-Notre Dame game, sports fans thronged to the Yankee Stadium in greater numbers than ever before in 1947. Total attendance, at all events staged in the celebrated House That Ruth Built set a new all-time high of 3,415,957.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The aviation manufacturing industry will end 1947 with a record of notable technological advances and the worst financial losses suffered in its history, it was reported today in a year-end review issued by Gen. Oliver P. Echols, retired, president of the Aircraft Industries Association.

BOSTON, Dec. 27 -- New England tonight struggled out from under an uneven snow cover that ranged from a scant trace of fresh flakes in northern New Hampshire to deep, wind-driven drifts in Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island.

Last-minute Christmas-rusi buying tapered off at the finish after holding up at the beginning of last week, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Resort shops both in the North and South were steadily active while dress departments were reported only fairly active with emphasis on formal wear.

BETWEEN the covers of a book these twenty brief sketches of John Espey's boyhood in China, take on fresh perspective. Many appeared first in The New. Yorker, giving vivid x fragmentary impressions of a pre-Chiang China often forgotten today.

THE fountainhead of our democracy, elementary and secondary school education, is drying up at the source. Many states and local communities cannot provide the funds to support their schools anywhere near adequately. In recent years, our schools would not have been able to meet the demands of even a static enrollment; the war and post-war upsurge in birth rate has left American schools in a tragic dilemma.

RADIO in 1947 enjoyed a year of mixed blessings. If the over-all programming picture continued to suffer from the curse of sameness, here and there throughout the twelve months there were encouraging signs of a more mature and imaginative use of the medium.

THE Germans have a proverb: "In America the hour has forty minutes." We make things fast in America, even our folk heroes. The first known appearance of Paul Bunyan in print took place in 1910. Today, less than forty years later, he is a full-fledged saga, sitting shoulder to shoulder with Pecos Bill and John Henry in the gallery of American folk heroes.

Financial markets were at crosscurrents during this past week, with the Christmas holiday cutting activity and interest in securities. The second annual report of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, and the action of the Federal Reserve Board in lowering its support "peg" for government securities, were the center of attention.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Maryland's football team today went through its first scrimmage session since Dec. 19 and its last before the Terrapins' Jan. 1 game with Georgia in the Gator Bowl.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Dewey, urging continuation of Federal rent control for another year, announced today that he would recommend to the 1948 Legislature that the state residential and commercial rent-control laws also be continued into 1949.

The Big Four split, which had widened month by month since the war's end, was officially acknowledged in 1947. The world "divided into two camps-one led by the United States of America, the other by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. That was the essence of the year's history.

NOW is the time of year when all properly disciplined members of the night-watch constabulary prepare lists of the ten best productions of the year. A natural skeptic of dogmatism, I find that my list of ten includes fourteen.
OMAHA, Dec. 27 -- In this region during 1948 the new look will be for old remains. Bones, that is.
BERNARD SHAW. By Eric Bentley. 242 pp. New York: New Directions, 500 Fifth Avenue. $2.

Construction work is scheduled to start this week on the ninety-four-family garden-type apartment project adjacent to Warinanco Park in Roselle, N.J. The development, to be known as Oak Tree Village, will be on a plot of about four and one-half acres.

Funds invested in insured savings and loan associations increased almost, a billion dollars, or more than 15 per cent, during 1947, according to William H. Husband, general manager of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

The Maritime Commission is undertaking a "fresh study" of tramp shipping under American-flag operation and has named a special committee to conduct such a study, commission spokesmen said yesterday. There has been considerable agitation in the past for Government assistance in support of tramp, or cross trade, operation by United States companies.

FOR the scheduled commercial airlines of the United States, 1947 was a painful paradox. During the year the air carriers flew more passengers, freight and express farther and at a greater dollar profit than ever before, yet the combined losses on the year will probably set a new record.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Truman today signed the bill that amends the National Housing Act to increase by $750,000,000 the Federal Housing Administration's authority to insure new home mortgages.

Fifteen thousand Department of Sanitation men, employes of the five Borough Presidents and other city departments and emergency workers, struggled yesterday on an 11-hour shift with twenty minutes out for lunch to clear the main city thoroughfares of snow.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: No thoughtful person will disagree with, the opinions expressed by university heads of Southern institutions, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 23, that the application of the principles of equality in admission to Southern colleges and schools must be worked out by the Southern people, "within the established patterns of social relationships" in the South.
A MAN behind a set of weird magnifying eyeglasses, the lexicographer behind the new "American College Dictionary," Clarence L. Barnhart blinked tired eyes and talked about his book.

WHILE the ten most treasured cinematic memories of the year are being recalled with appropriate ceremony elsewhere in this section, it becomes this recorder's doleful duty to toll the bells once again for an equally select number of pictures which fell ignobly under critical examination.

Two earnings reports covering the period of the sharp price rise this year confirm the previous evidence that profiteering in cost-of-living items has not been a significant factor in this rise. Swift Co. reports that in the year ending Nov. 1, the company's sales exceeded $2,200,000,000 and that its earnings were equal to 1 cent for every dollar of sales.

ATHENS, Dec. 27 -- The rebel forces outside Konitsa late today held two important heights between that Epirus town and the Albanian border. They are the Hill of the Prophet Elias, north of the town, and another dominating height known as Hill 915, about four miles to the northwest.

Completion of a wholesale repackaging project by the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, involving 6,000 units in ten major hardware lines, will be climaxed next month when the company starts full-volume production on all of its "new look" products, Meade Johnson, general sales manager of the Stamford Division, disclosed yesterday.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J. Dec. 27 -- The Setbn Hall basketball team registered its, fifth successive victory tonight, defeating Rutgers, 46 to 43, for the mythical college supremacy of New Jersey.

THE man who does the effective sleuthing in this story is Jerry Benedict, an editorial cartoonist temporarily functioning as a reporter. His cartoons have made Jerry unpopular with the city administration, including the police, who are not disposed to give him any help in his investigation of the murder of a local gangster.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- George Babin's Dockstader won the $10,000 added Louisiana Handicap at the Pair Grounds today, leading all the way and staging a driving finish to ward off Mrs. K.T. Maxwell's Fleetridge by a neck.

The signatories to the following letter are, respectively, former member of the OSS Mission for Germany; former Acting Director, Division of Cartels and External Assets of the Office of Military Government, and former chief and deputy chief of the Financial Intelligence Branch of the Finance Division of the Office of Military Government.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 27 -- General developments in recent weeks suggest that the groundwork is being laid for a more positive anti-Communist policy in Argentina. The Leftist League for the Rights of Man charged today that "illegal" arrests had risen sharply.

PLAINF1ELD, N.J., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Thomas Mills Day, New York lawyer and son of Thomas M. Day, for many years editor and a proprieter, of The Hartford (Conn.) Courant, died tonight at his home near here. He was 83 years old.

THE music educators are descending on Boston in droves this week. Six different groups are holding their annual meetings there. Composers and musical authorities, too, are going to the city to read papers and give speeches at the various sessions.
The city's streets became one huge playground yesterday as holidaying children took over with almost no interference from autos and trucks.

Much of the good work in medicine during the year was done not by physicians but by chemists. This is necessarily true of the anti-biotics, of which over a dozen new ones appeared. Some of them are effective against viruses, which penicillin is not.

DESPITE two years of high national income since the end of the war, government -- federal, state and local -- is burdened with a vast relief problem. That problem is growing more complicated; moreover, the cost of relief and social security is steadily increasing and relief techniques are changing as government assumes more responsibility for those in need.

Turning in a splendidly paced effort, Frank W. Efinger Jr., Andoyer Academy student running unattached, captured the one-mile race that served as one of the features of the junior indoor track and field championship conducted by the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. last night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Grains staged a rally in the latter part of the session on the Board of Trade today, moving above preceding closing prices. The upturn was led by new-crop wheat contracts as the May delivery continued to lag. Strength in wheat was reflected in other cereals.

PARIS, Dec. 27 -- The National Council of Premier Robert Schuman's party, the Popular Republican Movement, formally allied itself tonight with the "third force." In its resolution, the council welcomed this "grouping of democratic and social forces" in the country, and it directed its executive committee to cooperate With "this third force."

ELLIOTT CHAZE says that Cole, Wilson, Wagman, Williams, Boydkin and Trotts, the six paratroopers of his hilarious, grim, bawdy book about the Japanese occupation, are not real persons but only composites of many men that he knew in the Army.
THE advent of 1948 will be observed by the world of radio with appropriate festivities on Wednesday evening and early Thursday morning.

PRAGUE, Dec. 27 -- Hungary's advancement as a junior member of the Eastern bloc may bring about a revision of Czechoslovakia's foreign policy. Dissatisfaction with the results of Czechoslovak foreign affairs has been felt, and party leaders feel more and more that there must be a change.

In Article TV of the Headquarters Treaty between the United Nations and the United States, the United States agree not to "institute proceeding's * * * to require any [foreign correspondents attached to the U.N.] to leave the United States except with the prior approval of the Secretary of State * * * after consultation * * * with the Secretary General."
FOR THIS WEEK: Inspect windbreaks around the evergreens, and also muIch them, especially those planted in fall..... Spread manure over the rose beds, if it is available.
The continuing bloodshed in Palestine emphasizes the need of establishing an international police force for the United Nations.

The new peacetime duties of the Coast Guard Auxiliary, a group of amateur yachtsmen, were discussed at the convention of the Coast Guard Auxiliary of the Third Coast Guard District in the Hotel Astor yesterday. The emphasis was on safety in small-boat operation and what the organization was doing to promote it through education and a new inspection service.

"If we are going to do anything, we should do it promptly. * * * The next step to be taken is legislation by Congress." The crucial word in this statement, by Ugo Carusi, former Immigration Commissioner, who has just completed a survey of, the DP camps of Europe, is the word "if."

IN THE little greenhouse continuous bloom all winter is a tantalizing goal. From the beginning of November until tulip time, it is quite a trick to avoid periods of all work and no flowers. I have a system, however, worked out by a long process of trial and error, and it gives me masses of blossoms from late fall to spring.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 27 -- Flashing a well-balanced attack and taking advantage of its opportunities, a hand-picked Southern eleven defeated a similar team from above the Mason-Dixon line here today, 33 -- 6, in the tenth renewal of the Blue-Gray football game.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Coach Bobby Dodd and his Georgia Tech squad arrived today for the Orange Bowl contest with Kansas on New Year's Day and promptly declared that he didn't see his team a "14-point-favorite."
PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Written into the records of the Rose Bowl are many surprises and upsets, shining examples of where the "impossible" happened.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- A short-term trade accord between Britain and the Soviet Union was signed in Moscow tonight, the British Board of Trade announced. Details of the agreement were not made public, but it was authoritatively said that the pact embodied the principles recently agreed upon in Moscow by Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, and Anastas Mikoyan, Soviet Minister for Foreign Trade.

THERE are at least two excellent reasons for not missing this book, aside from the undeniable fact that it is captivating in itself. If you happen to live in Maine or to have your roots there, you will hasten to read it, for it is an unsurpassed picture of that unique and incomparable State and will evoke gratitude or homesickness as the case may be.

JUST eleven years ago this week in this Review: Rounding out the year the Review devoted Page One to the second volume of Charles M. Andrew's "The Colonial Period of American History." "The crowning work of his scholarly career," said the reviewer. . . .

MOST of the muttering about the quality of our post-war writing has been directed at the novelists. We seem incorrigibly to crave the semblance of something new, preferably a manner that hits us like a knockout punch.

The New York Dress Institute will spearhead the drive to bolster faltering sales of popular price dresses, Julius Hochman, general manager of the Joint Board of Dress and Waistmakers Union of Greater New York, said last week.

Robert H. Armstrong, economist and member of Armstrong Associates, yesterday made public his seventeenth annual list of the ten "best" books published this year on realty topics. He pointed out that in the past many of the books dealt with theoretical phases of realty, but this year most of them, have related to the practical side of the business.
Independent steel distributors are asking a say in any future decisions of industry conferences in Washington which affect their allocations, it was learned here yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The Moscow radio today accused the American press, especially THE NEW YORK TIMES, of having given a "distorted picture" of the Soviet currency reform and renewed its prediction that the United States was heading toward a ruinous crash in 1948.

Human Equality ON the level of the human spirit an equal, a companion, an understanding heart is one who can share a man's point of view. What this means we all know. Friends, companions, lovers, are those who treat us in terms of our unlimited worth to ourselves.
"A good intention clothes itself with sudden power." -- Ralph Waldo Emerson.

A training school where students can take subjects ranging from farming and foundry work to dietetics and dental mechanics is being established at the Farmingdale Agricultural and Technical Institute on Long Island under the auspices of the New York State Department of Education.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 27 (AP) Dr. Harmon W. Caldwell, president of the University of Georgia, and head football coach Wallace Butts today took issue with State Auditor B.E. Thrasher's report last Saturday criticizing the University of Georgia Tech Athletic Association for operating with a deficit for the past fiscal year.

BY a welcome coincidence, both of this week's arrivals on Broadway are institutions in the theatre -- the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company and Ruth Draper. Miss Draper, with whom this roll of the drums is concerned, is the one-woman show that has been brightening the stages of most of the world's large cities for a quarter of a century, frustrating stagehands and delighting audiences.

As the steel industry rushes in the final few days of 1947 to cap the year's record production for a peacetime year with peak weekly output, there is growing sentiment in the industry that there is an excellent possibility of ending the severe post-war steel famine some time in the next twelve months.

All the wholesale markets last week were inactive as a result of buyers remaining at home during the holiday rush, according to a weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- President James Bryant Conant of Harvard University told a meeting of the country's leading scientists here tonight that scholars studying man and his society might well join together and issue a proclamation, similar to the doctors' hippocratic oath, setting forth their ideals and goals for American society.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 27 -- Moderate Indian elements in this Province, represented by the Natal Indian Organization, decided today to convene a meeting here on Jan. 11 to see whether it is possible to reach a compromise in regard to the status of Indian nationals in South Africa.

ATHENS, Ga., Dec. 27 (AP) Dr. Harmon W. Caldwell, president of the University of Georgia, and head football coach Wallace Butts today took issue with State Auditor B.E. Thrasher's report last Saturday criticizing the University of Georgia Tech Athletic Association for operating with a deficit for the past fiscal year.

As the steel industry rushes in the final few days of 1947 to cap the year's record production for a peacetime year with peak weekly output, there is growing sentiment in the industry that there is an excellent possibility of ending the severe post-war steel famine some time in the next twelve months.

All the wholesale markets last week were inactive as a result of buyers remaining at home during the holiday rush, according to a weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- President James Bryant Conant of Harvard University told a meeting of the country's leading scientists here tonight that scholars studying man and his society might well join together and issue a proclamation, similar to the doctors' hippocratic oath, setting forth their ideals and goals for American society.

DURBAN, South Africa, Dec. 27 -- Moderate Indian elements in this Province, represented by the Natal Indian Organization, decided today to convene a meeting here on Jan. 11 to see whether it is possible to reach a compromise in regard to the status of Indian nationals in South Africa.

JOHN BAKELESS, lecturer at New York University and biographer of such diverse figures as Christopher Marlowe and Daniel Boone, has written the first full-scale joint biography of two of the most remarkable of Americans.

The Lefrak Construction Corporation has obtained from a savings bank a mortgage loan of $750,000 at 4 per cent interest for ten years on the first apartment building of a four-unit. development under construction on the east blockfront of Ninety-ninth Street, between Sixty-third Road and Sixty-fourth Avenue in the Forest Hills West section of Queens.

The sled became the lifeline of Westchester County yesterday. By the thousands, in long winding columns, the housewives of Westchester trudged into town dragging sleds on which to load food for their families.

WARSAW, Dec. 27 - Two of the seven Poles accused of haying organized a spy ring for the British and United States Embassies in Warsaw received death sentences today at the close of the trial of the Polish Underground Coordination Committee.

On the day before Christmas last week radio monitors in Europe picked up a broadcast from an unidentified station somewhere in the Balkans. Communications engineers thought it came from Yugoslavia or Albania. The broadcast, sometimes so weak that listeners in Athens had a hard time catching the words, was imortant.

VANISHED PLANET -- Dr. Carl A. Bauer (University of Michigan) proposed to the American Association for the Advancement of Science last week the theory that meteorites, which are burned up by mere friction in great numbers as they plow through the atmosphere, once comprised a planet smaller than the earth but larger than the moon What caused the disruption of the hypothetical planet Dr. Bauer does not profess to know.

WHEN it comes to herbs, it is hard to find more appealing kinds than lemon verbena and rose geralium. These two, favorites in the Nineties, have never gone out of style. Fragrance is probably their most appreciated characteristic, But they are also liked for their attractive foliage, usefulness in the garden and a sentimental charm they have acquired over the years.

LONDON, Dec. 27 (Reuters) -- The sharp promotion struggle in the northern half of the English League's third division stole the spotlight today as Britain's vital holiday soccer schedule reached the halfway mark and seven teams remained within 3 points of one another.

Editor New York Times Book Review: RICARDA HUCH, who recently died near sanatorium near Frankfort on the Main at the age of 83, was Germany's leading woman writer and unquestionably one of the noblest figures of modern German literature.

MARJORIE CORYN has followed her "Marriage of Josephine" with another fulllength episode called "Alone Among Men." The episode covers a period of one month, Oct. 11-Nov. 12, 1799, and moves Napoleon from exile in Egypt through his well-arranged coup d'etat of that year.

To the Drama Editor: LET Richard Rohman [in his letter of Dec. 14] and others stop calling Cheryl Crawford names and examine for a few minutes the economic realities of the Experimental Theatre. Last season five plays were done without "name" actors to draw the public, and though none of the productions cost over $4,000 (I believe), the project as a whole ended In the red for the season.

PANAMA, Dec. 27 -- Rejection by the National Assembly of Panama of the agreement for leasing defense bases to the United States cannot be attributed entirely to local political reasons, nor to the lack of a desire on the part of the Government and people of Panama to cooperate in the defense of the Panama Canal and this hemisphere.

The city's ambulance services, taxed to the limit by the storm, barely held their own yesterday. With, a number of vehicles out of commission and replacements scarce, the Department of Hospitals and other agencies appealed to the public to summon ambulances only in extreme cases lest the seriously ill be deprived of transportation to hospitals.

WISCONSIN -- World Problems A course dealing with the study of world problems will be available to senior students at the University of Wisconsin next semester. The course will survey contemporary trends in modern civilization, placing particular emphasis on the need or world peace and the use of atomic energy for peacetime purposes.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 27 -- The intensity of the communal strife is continuing to mount in Palestine. Troops had to be used this afternoon to end a six-hour battle between Jews and Arabs near Tulkarm.
Dissension has broken out on the staff of The New Republic over the position the magazine would take if Henry A. Wallace announces his candidacy for President, it was learned last night.

Six hundred and fifty-five essservice men and their families now are occupying modern living quarters in various parts of the city as the result of completion of work on two major housing conversion jobs under State auspices.

AFTER twelve years of successful performances abroad and in South, America, Honegger's dramatic oratorio, "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher" (Joan of Arc at the Stake), will have its premiere in this country when Charles Munch conducts it with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Thursday, Friday and Sunday.

While some 10,000 firemen continued yesterday on an emergency footing because of the snowstorm, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle appealed to all former members of the old Fire Department Auxiliary Corps to report for duty at their nearest firehouse "to assist in the removal of snow from vicinities of fire hydrants during this emergency period."
THE week which divides the music season proper and ends the year makes possible a perspective of what that year, though not the current season as a whole, has brought us in music.

United Nations in Action One of the few important questions the United Nations has been able to unite on is the question of Palestine. Going back in history about 800 years we find the nations of Europe similarly united.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- President Truman in his salary requests for the three top officials to administer the European recovery program pointed up one of the executive problems that has perplexed him most -- finding high-caliber men willing to take important Government posts.

Estimating gains in retail dollar volume for the first half of next year ranging up to 8 per cent, retailers foresee in 1948 a continuation of many of the trends which marked the record sales year about to close, according to a survey made last week by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Britain is on the verge of what Foreign Secretary Bevin in the House of Commons last week called "grave decisions." He did not go into details and he will not do so until he reports back to Parliament after the Christmas recess, but everybody knows that those decisions refer particularly to Germany and in general to Britain's relations with the Soviet Union.
No doubt important discoveries were made in 1947 about the structure and behavior of the atom, but if they were the military authorities forbade any announcement. Such are the fears of an atomic age.

ATHENS. Dec. 27 (AP) -- Greek Army reinforcements destroyed more than half a dozen guerrilla strong points tonight in a drive to open the road to besieged Konitsa. Front-line dispatches reported 44,000 refugees had sought shelter within the Army-held area from the fire of the Communist 66-mm. guns.

ATTEMPTING to forecast the course of the American theatre during the coming year would provide a dubious holiday occupation for one who loves it, were that one not an incorrigible optimist. In a similar undertaking in these columns twelve months ago I related unmerrily that the honeymoon between public and box office, which kept the country's Broadways so joyous through the war years, was at an end and bleaker days were ahead.
The city's waterfront stirred to action yesterday after nearly twenty-four hours of virtual immobility under a blanket of snow.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 27 -- A falsified news report of his signature on a condemnation of the Marshall plan, which was widely published in newspapers of the Soviet zone in Germany, was one of the motivating reasons for his flight in September from his position as Minister President [Premier] of Thuringia, Dr. Rudolf Paul disclosed here today.

An example of fallacious argument on the effect of the impact of income taxes upon individual effort is contained in a release of the Division of Tax Research of the Treasury Department. We are told that increased income taxes are conducive of greater incentive to individual effort, and that tax reduction tends to make taxpayers relax in their efforts to earn income.

The small arms, helmets and binoculars that were sent to England early in the war to help the British defend themselves, when many had little more than pikes, are being returned to this country, in part, it became known yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 27 (UP) Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang, so-called "Christian General" of China, who has been sharply critical of President Chiang Kai-shek, said today he would not return to China because he would be killed if he did so.

A veteran gave $25 yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund "in memory of my comrades of World War II." He asked that the contribution be used to help Case 115, "Crippled Young Man," the tragic story of John S., who at 19 is deprived of use of his arms and legs because of an incurable nervous disorder.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 28-- In a memorial address at a service for the war dead of the national fraternity, Delta Kappa Epsilon, held in Dwight Chapel of Yale University today, Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, declared that "strength and preparedness are the way to peace."

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP)--While the Chicago Cardinals celebrated their first national football league title triumph since 1925, the crestfallen Philadelphia Eagles bitterly bemoaned their 28-21 "tennis shoe" defeat on the cement-like Cominsky Park gridiron today.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Two of four seeded performers were eliminated from the Sugar Bowl invitation tennis tournament in the first-round and quarter -finals play today.

Television Is likely "to do more to revolutionize politics than sound broadcasting did," with its first effects noticeable during next Steals Presidential campaign, Brig. Gen. David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, declared yesterday in his annual year-end statement.
TOKYO, Dec. 28--For the second time the Central Screening Committee has voted that Rikizo Hirano, president of the National Farmers' Union and former Agriculture Minister, need not be purged.

Only two boxing champions are considered far enough ahead of their respective classes to gain individual recognition as leaders in the eight standard ring divisions in the annual ratings of The Ring Magazine released today.
The city's waterfront returned nearer to normal yesterday, with one liner, the Spanish vessel Habana, and seven mail freighters leaving port between noon and midnight.

Three vice presidents of the Calumet and Hecla Consolidated Copper Company to be elected to office next Thursday are A. E. Petermann, general counsel; A. H. Wohlrab, general manager of the Calumet division, and H. Y. Bassett, general manager of the Wolverine Tube division.

An operating loss of $9,982,371 for the four months ended Oct. 31 was incurred by the municipal transit system, according to a report filed yesterday with the Board of Estimate by William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation. The loss for October was reported as $1,863,206.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Dec. 28 (AP)--American ski jumpers leaped for long distances today, but the first two places in the initial test of jumping power among contestants preparing for the Winter Olympics went to the Swiss.

Seventeen years ago Marcel Pagnol's "Topaze" seemed much funnier than it did last Saturday evening with Oscar Karlweis in the chief part at the Morosco. Possibly the natural depravity of man was a gayer topic then, or gallic cynicism was more enjoyable.

THE New York State Racing Commission issued its annual report the other day and it was a most imposing document. But that's no way to get a proper slant on what happened at the hoss pavilions during the past year. The correct procedure is to corral one of those rugged individualists who buck the machines day after day, a Fugitive from Jamaica, for instance.
Canon Bernard ladings Bell, consultant on education to the Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of Chicago, preached yesterday morning at Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street.
The Bronx Zoo had its troubles, but, nevertheless, got off quite easily in the storm, William Bridges, publicity director for the New York Zoological Society, reported yesterday afternoon.

Plans to rebuild the University. of Nijmegen, Holland, as a memorial to the 800 men of the Eightysecond Airborne Division who gave their lives at Nijmegen, were announced yesterday by Hugh Gibson, former United States Ambassador to Belgium.
That was the promise made by postal authorities last night as they marshalled Army trucks and hundreds of extra employes for a task even more formidable than the Christmas rush.

ROME, Dec. 28--Left Wing Socialist leader Pietro Nenni clearly differentiates his awn from the Communist attitude toward the Marshall plan in a report on the Socialist policy that he will read at his party's twenty-sixth Congress in the second half of January.

King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy will go down in history as a shadowy ruler who paid the inevitable price of defeat and became the scapegoat for his nation's Fascist adventure. Scion of the once powerful House of Savoy, he reigned but never governed. During his forty-six years on the throne his subjects fought two major wars and two minor ones.

Fern Helscher's holiday dance series at Times Hall got under way in spite of the weather on Saturday evening with a performance by La Meri and her Exotic Ballet, and continued last night according to schedule with a program by Valerie Bettis and her company, including Duncan Noble.

Hope that the Marshall plan for the economic recovery of western Europe will make 1948 a better year than 1947 was expressed last night by nine newspaper editors and publishers in the annual news review and forecast of the National Broadcasting Company.
Central. Park looked a shade like take Placid yesterday as skiers took to the slopes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--President Truman, announcing he would sign the Republican-sponsored antiinflation bill, declared today he would be shirking responsibility if he did not let the public know that the measure was "pitifully inadequate as a weapon against the high cost of living."

Last week this space was devoted to a discussion of how mass emotion and the popular attitude of the day tended to distort current thinking in the field of finance and economics.
