But waves and cycles of popular hysteria, it hardly need be pointed out, are by no means confined to such matters as speculation and to the narrow geographical confines of the speculative community.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 28 (AP)--Fourteen-year-old Laura Lou Jahn of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Adrianne Goldberg of Baltimore today won their way into the final round of the 1948 national girls' indoor tennis championships.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 28--Former King Victor Emmanuel III of Italy died of lung congestion at 2:20 o'clock this afternoon in Alexandria at the age of 78. He had been seriously ill in Moassat Hospital for a fortnight under the care of his own physician, Dr. Peta Macciorino, and doctors supplied by King Farouk I of Egypt.

Slightly more than 60 per cent of the executives surveyed by the National Industrial Conference Board on the business outlook anticipate increases in sales in the first half of 1948, compared with the corresponding period of 1947, the board announced over the week-end. Nearly 22 per cent saw little or no change and slightly less than 17 per cent expected a decrease in sales volume.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In debating the machinery for administering ERP, consideration should be given to the experience gained in administering lead-lease.

After several years of study, the United States Golf Association has adopted a handicap system designed for nationwide use, one of the most important decisions it has made concerning the playing of the royal and ancient game, was disclosed yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 28--Moshe Sneh, one of the outstanding executive members of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, resigned today in a move believed to indicate a fundamental split on the question of Zionist relations with the Soviet Union.

Informed last night of pricegouging on milk and bread in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, Eugene Schulz, Markets Commissioner, said he had received a few complaints of the same nature but added that his department exercised no control over retail prices.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP)-- Strengthening of the Anti-Trust Laws to protect the "little man" from unfair trade practices may be recommended by the House Committee on Small Business.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Nov. 6 Delbert Clark published an article in the NEW YORK TIMES expressing various accusations and insituations against myself. Among other things I was said to have pleaded at a secret meeting of Social Democratic leaders in Berlin for the partitioning of Germany and a separate peace with Western Germany.

Surface transportation, hit hardest by the week-end snowfall, struggled back toward normal last night, with a majority of the city's bus lines hoping to restore nearnormal service in time for the rushhour crowds this morning.

A musical event of more than routine interest took place last night when Elly Kassman performed the solo part of Stravinsky's Concerto for Piano and Wind Orchestra in her Town Hall recital. The work, which is reported to have been heard only twice here since it was composed in 1924, was ably conducted by Robert L. Craft.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Dec. 28-- The largest unauthorized transport of Jewish refugees to attempt to reach Palestine sailed through the Bosporus today.

Snow removal progressed faster yesterday as an increased force of 19,247 men, with the aid of 2,344 trucks, plows, snow loaders, bulldozers and other pieces of equipment again assailed the banks and piles of snow in the main thoroughfares and began to dig into side streets in business sections.

The text of Mayor O'Dwyer's broadcast on the snow-removal situation follows, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TlMES: Ladies and Gentlemen: This city is facing the most colossal task in its history.

Tours of inspection and interviews with officials in each of the five boroughs of New York depicted similar scenes of feverish around-the-clock activity to remove the paralyzing effects of Friday's record-breaking snowfall.

In Ms report on the London conference, Secretary Marshall rightly declared that the fundamental reason for the failure of our efforts to make progress toward a settlement has been the fact that the war has shattered Europe and created a political vacuum which must be filled before a realistic peace can come to the world.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 28 --State troopers of the Hawthorne Barracks became snow troopers today. Wearing snowshoes, they hauled toboggans loaded with milk, bread and other foods to marooned residents of the northern areas of Westchester County.

A sneak-thief entered the Plaza Hotel apartment of Hildegarde, the night club singer, early yesterday morning, and walked off with her jewels and a full-length Russian stone marten fur coat. The theft occurred between 12:30 and 1:30 A. M., while the victim was singing in the hotel's Persian Room for the late show.

In the future when certain veterans begin talking about how tough things were in Europe or the Pacific, their wives may sneer and remind them of the Battle of Ulmer Park, which went into its third day yesterday.

PRAGUE, Dec. 28--Czechoslovakia is expected to seek during the coming year an increase in her generally recognized limited influence within the Eastern bloc by a more active collaboration with Poland.

Few kings left behind them fewer regrets than Victor Emmanuel III when he bowed to the inevitable on May 9, 1946 and, after a reign of forty-five years and nine months, abdicated in favor of his son, who became King Humbert II until he in turn was ousted in the plebiscite of June, 1946.

Mayor Israel Rokach of Tel Aviv, the principal modern city in Palestine, arrived in the United States yesterday to arrange to raise funds for the purchase of 1,000,000 dunama (250,000 acres) of uncultivated land in his country.

Although outlying communities suffered shortages of fuel and food, most of suburban New York reported yesterday that main roads and transportation facilities were clear of last Friday's choking snowfall. Commuter services, meanwhile, announced that schedules would be at near normal this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- The United Stated should go ahead with plans for helping Europe regardless of a "Soviet campaign of calumny and blistering abuse," Francis B. Sayre, president of the United Nations Trusteeship Council, urged today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28--There was a temporary decline in steel ingot output last week because of the Christmas holiday. Practically all of this drop, however, will be eliminated this Week as mills rush operations back to normal.

In a radio appeal to the public, broadcast last night from City Hall, Mayor O'Dwyer predicted early victory in the fight to remove the city's 99,000,000-ton blanket of snow if full cooperation was given to public officials by individuals, business and trucking interests, and motorists.
MATTAFOISETT, Mass., Dec. 28--Everett F. Buffington, widely Known in the cotton industry, died here today in his home after a year's illness. His age was 65.

Blasting the Dominion skaters' cage five times in the third period, the New York Rovers downed the Valleyfield Braves, 9 to 5, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League battle before 10,700 fans at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

ATHENS, Dec. 28--Greek Army forces in Epirus, bolstered by fresh troops rushed from western Macedonia and new heavy arms, launched an offensive today aimed at smashing guerrilla attempts to carve out a piece of northwestern Greece for a separate Communist state.

HAVANA, Dec. 28--The United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment still hopes to win the support of enough countries to establish the projected International Trade Organization as an effective working body, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Federal ownership of forty-five corporations "controlling some $30,000,000,000" came under fire by a (Congressional committee today as an "alarming expansion of the powers of Government vitally affecting private business."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Procedures for testing the loyalty of Government employes announced yesterday by the new Loyalty Review Board drew the criticism tonight that they raised "serious problems" in the safeguarding of constitutional liberties.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--Never behind, but ever in jeopardy of a tie and an enforced "sudden death" overtime, the Chicago Cardinals conquered the Philadelphia Eagles, 28--21, today at Comiskey Park and annexed the National Football League championship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Following is President Truman's statement on signing the Republican anti-inflation bill: I am signing Senate Joint Resolution 167 with a sense of deep disappointment that the Congress has seen fit to take such feeble steps toward the control of inflation.
ALBANY, Dec. 28--Gov. Thomas E. Dewey announced a sweeping state-wide oil conservation program today with the appointment of the State Superintendent of Public Works as fuel coordinator.

AMSTERDAM, Dec. 28--A warning by Jan Mansholt, Minister for Agriculture, that without the European Recovery Program the Netherlands would "run aground within one year" has made a great impression here.

Suppose only two cups of cooked meat remain from Sunday. And suppose it's pork or chicken, veal or lamb. What's to be done? Special seasonings and oven treatment create a scalloped hash for today's peace plate, with these added suggestions for Adapting the meat or fowl on hand.

HACKENSACK, N. J. Dec. 28-- Luther A. Campbell, who retired as Chancellor of New Jersey on Oct. 14, 1946 after fourteen years in the state's highest judicial office, died at 6:40 o'clock this evening in the Hackensack Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered yesterday in his home at 254 Union Street.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28-- Fanned by strong wind, flames swept five brick building's in downtown Philadelphia's warehouse and wholesale district this morning and caused damage estimated officially at more than $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--The air lines of the United States reached new peaks of passenger traffic in both domestic and international services in this year, carrying an estimated total of 15,700,000 passengers. These figures were reported today by the Civil Aeronautics Administration and represented an increase of 18.5 per cent over 1946.

Indications were last night that most forms of transportation would be approaching normal schedules today. A summary of conditions to be expected follows: AIRLINES Only ninety flights left La Guardia Field yesterday but individual airlines predicted near normal schedules today as more runways are cleared. Newark Airport was shut down yesterday but some flights may be resumed today.

On the third day of exhausting efforts, New York wrenched itself loose yesterday from the shackles imposed by the record snowfall of Friday. The real test of freeing itself entirely was expected today with the start of the business week and with thousands returning to the city after Christinas visits out of town.

The artificial gaiety of many New Year's Eve celebrations represents a form of escapism while something deep within the revelers is calling them to "a little period of quiet, of meditation, of spiritual stock-taking, of prayer," the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell said yesterday in his morning sermon at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue at Fiftyfifth Street.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 (UP)--Russia has agreed to supply Great Britain with 750,000 tons of coarse grain between February and September, 1948, under the major trade agreement signed last night, it was announced today. The price for the grain was not disclosed.

LONDON, Dec. 28--Christmas week is scarcely a period where stock-market activity could be expected, but a surprisingly good turnover has been experienced The upward trend of prices, too has been maintained in keeping partly with the cheerful sentimen typical of the season.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Topics of The Times seems to be taking a tinge of things historical History is dramatic, a truth not universally recognized. Reading last week of the peregrinations of the voice broadcasting the Topics, one learned, or rather heard, of State Street off Bowling Green, of old houses at Nos. 7 and 9, where "Our Lady of the Rosary" is housed.

DUBLIN, Dec. 28--Nothing in the changing prospect of this oddly remote and lovely island is more interesting than a close view of the effect on a little nation of the working partnership in a great international enterprise like the Marshall Plan. Even in the European recovery project Ireland is divided.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 28 (UP)-- Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, has issued stern orders for a new drive to combat venereal disease among Army men, including provisions for the discharge of any officer whose moral habits set a bad example for enlisted men, it was disclosed today.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 28-- The leading Protestant denominations of America were scored here tonight by Dr. John R. Mott, "elder statesman of Protestantism," for failing to raise as much money for current relief and reconstruction needs as some of them had raised for church extension purposes after the first World War.

After five years in the ministry of a country church, a clergyman might feel he had done his job and be tempted to move on, but In New York this period of time is just enough to qualify him to start serving his congregation in earnest, the Rev. Dr. Harold C. DeWindt declared yesterday.

Some new records were set last week with the wind-up in a rush of Christmas business at retail stores, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. The wholesale markets, however, were quiet, since buyers stayed at home to take care of the holiday rush.

The ten-story loft building at 9 and 11 East Nineteenth Street, between Broadway and Fifth Avenue, has been resold by Henry Goelet, operator, to the S. M. Furman Manufacturing Company in a transaction negotiated by William C. Walker's Sons.

Members of the American Guild of Musical Artists, who often have made appearances to benefit others, last night gathered in force at the Metropolitan Opera House to sing and play on their own behalf. For the proceeds of their "Christmas Party" were earmarked for the guild's maintenance and welfare fund.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday year-end changes in the personnel of its regular member firms.

undefeated after four rounds in the tournament for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League of the United States Chess Federation, three of the forty-six competitors Were tied for first place hut night at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, Where play Will Continue at 10 A. M. today.

PARIS, Dec. 28--A law forbidding strikes by the national security police was officially announced today as part of a nationwide "purge" of certain law-enforcing agencies, where Communist influence is considered strong.

Two West Coast quintets, the University of California at Los Angeles and Santa Clara, invade Madison Square Garden tonight to battle Long Island University and City College in a collegiate doubleheader. The L. I. U.-U. C. L. A. test opens the program at 8 o'clock.

The United States Bureau of Labor Statistics has published a comprehensive study which estimates the total cost of a budget for a family of four. In describing this budget the bureau says, "It is not a subsistence budget; it is not a 'minimum' budget in the sense in which that term is ordinarily used, but it is far from a luxury budget.

The Maritime Commission and the Treasury Department will consider soon extension of privileges of subsidized steamship companies to American-flag lines operating without Government aid, it was learned yesterday. The subsidy itself would be excluded.

THE revival in popularity of the works of Anthony Trollope, which has been spreading across the English-speaking world during the last few years, is rather mysterious. It has not been inspired by a barrage of highbrow criticism, as has that of Henry James. It has not been confined to the solemnly intellectual, as were, the revivals of John Donne and Gerard Manley Hopkins.

Joseph Posner, baritone, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. In a program of Italian, German, French, Jewish and English offerings, the serious and musicianly artist could be commended for the intensity and depth of feeling which marked his work.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 29-- The Superior Labor Court has decided a $35,000 suit against Avianca Airlines, a Pan Air subsidiary, against the complainant, Capt. Enrique Concha Vanegas, a member of the Colombian Civil Aeronautics Department.
ATHENS, Dec. 28--The battle of Epirus, developing from the guerrilla attack on Konitsa, has taken on proportions greater than was originally deemed here as likely, a military spokesman said tonight.
It was a fight all the way down to the final whistle as the Rangers and the Toronto Maple Leafs, skated to a 1-1 tie in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Another twenty-four hours should see New York City well dug out of the heaviest snowfall in the recorded history of metropolitan weather. The city should be almost back to normal if everyone, and especially private car owners and truckers in non-essential industries, will stay off the streets and out of the city today to allow an uninterrupted clearing of the snow that still is blocking many side avenues and even some essential main roads.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--Discovery of one of nature's key substances and providing the first definite clue to the process of photosynthesis, the mechanism that enables plants to synthesize food out of carbon dioxide and water with the energy of sunlight, was announced here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $52,035,736,084. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows: 1948.

The responsibility for the protection of tenants in this city against eviction rests with Governor Dewey and the State Legislature, Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman and majority leader of the City Council, declared yesterday in a statement stressing the necessity for the continuation of eviction and rent control.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week held within a narrow range, closing the period at only moderate net changes. At the close on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net changes ranging from a decline of 8 points to an advance of 2 points.

ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Dec. 28 (UP)--By order of King Farouk, the Egyptian court went into seven days of mourning. Official sources said Farouk would order a state funeral. Farouk's grandfather, the former Khedive of Ismail, took refuge in Italy many years ago.

The trend toward rapidly accelerating use of automatic control devices in home and industry was more pronounced in 1947 than in any of the preceding 100 years of the controls industry, it was said in Minneapolis over the weekend by Harold W. Sweatt, president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.
GLENS FALLS, N. Y., See, 28 (AP)=Anthony Callipare of the Rochester Skating Club won the senior men's plaque today, in the finals of the two-day Northern New York Skating Association meet.

The Rev. Dr. Samuel H. Goldenson, rabbi of Congregation EmanuEl for the last fourteen years, who retires next Wednesday, delivered his farewell message last night at special services in his honor in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.

Twenty-one students from Denmark, Norway, Sweden and Finland, ranging from 16 to 19 years of age, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday to spend ten weeks in the United States. During this stay, they will live at the homes of American students and visit points of interest.

Renowned the world over for an almost fanatical devotion to the Gilbert Sullivan tradition, the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company has been imported from England with the blessings of the Shuberts. The famous aggregation's fourth visit to these shores (1939 was the last time they were here) will commence at 8:30 this evening at the Century, a Shubert house, with the ever popular "Mikado."
GENEVA, Dec. 28--Nine major European countries will begin operation of the first phase of the multilateral Foreign Exchange Clearing Union early in January, it was learned today.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 28 (AP)--The American Historical Association today elected Dr. Kenneth Scott LaTourette of Yale University president. It awarded the Albert J. Beveridge Memorial Fellowship prize for the year's best manuscript on the history of the United States, Canada or Latin America to Dr. Lewis Hanke of Washington.

The failure of the United States to take the lead in the implementation of "pious international pledges" to end discrimination against minorities is a result of our "tenuous moral position" and a "lack of courage in high places," Walter White, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, declared yesterday.
FRESNO, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP)-- Western cotton is booming; so much so that cotton no longer is a monopoly of the Deep South.

NANKING, Dec. 28--Striking to bar Government troops in Hopeh Province from giving diversionary aid to the hard-pressed Nationalist forces in Manchuria, Communist raiding units have cut three railway lines leading into Peiping.

The newestt way to feed a Baby is the oldest and simplest way. The United States Children's Bureau's latest folder, "Breast Feeding," issued today, reflects a move in pediatric practice to get baby off a bottle and back to this mother.

New York's "Pinafore" Craze Confronted with yet another revival of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas on Broadway, one of those rabid G. S. fanatics--whose number, everybody knows, is as the sands of the sea--resolved to ferret out the facts about a sensational record established by one of the said classics of light entertainment--a record not only never equaled but never even approached in the history of the drama in this city.

Another chapter in the book of infamy recording the efforts of the Communist-dominated regimes of eastern Europe to crush all opposition, including all those who dare to maintain any kind of contacts with the Western democracies, has just been written in Poland.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 28-- Thomas A. Barry, industrial adviser, lawyer and former All-America football player at Brown University, died in his home here yesterday. His age was 68.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--The only way to slow up the inflationary wage-price spiral is "a hard way," self-discipline for organized labour and business management, Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont declared tonight.

A series of projects seeking to raise standards and efficiency in the packaging industry are scheduled to be set up during the coming year under sponsorship of the Packaging Institute, Inc., according to plans now being worked out by Dr. Laurence V. Burton, new executive director of the institute.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--While President Truman was announcing he would sign reluctantly the Republican - sponsored anti - inflation bill, Representative Charles A. Halleck, House majority leader, acclaimed the measure as an affirmation of the "American voluntary way of life."
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Four records fell as Big Bill Hulse and Jerry Thompson, the University of Texas distance mite, won feature events of the annual Sugar Bowl track meet today.
Arrangements are being completed for combining the publishing house of Reynal Hitchcock with Harcourt, Brace Co., Inc., as of Friday, it was announced yesterday.

Although ship activities in the Port of New York increased during 1947, customs duties and other payments declined, according to year-end figures made "public yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port.

Handling of the greatest peacetime traffic in history during 1947 pointed up the two great problems of the railroad industry in the years ahead, William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said in his annual review.

ALBANY, Dec. 28--A program extended to provide "a measure of protection" for all children placed in foster homes will be submitted to the Legislature next month by the Special Committee on Social Welfare and Relief of the Ostertag Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

A distinct characteristic of the white collar worker in New York City is "sticking to one job," according to a general study of pesonnel practices by employers in the Metropolitan Area by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., released over the week-end by Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28--Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, today called upon Representative August Andresen to "put up or shut up" on his charges that 200 Federal workers in Chicago having inside information, were involved in commodity speculation.

The Moore-McCormack liner Argentina, second largest American vessel afloat, will leave the Bethlehem Steel Company's Brooklyn shipyard, where she has been undergoing reconversion, tomorrow morning for her final sea trials.

A three-point "closeout" program for 1948 to dispose of surplus goods worth about $500,000,000 in cost value, drop branch warehouses and reduce its staff for final completion of its job is planned by the War Assets Administration in this region, it was announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP)--With Goalie Harry Lumley marking up his second shutout of the season, the Detroit Red Wings beat the Boston Bruins for the fifth straight time this season, 3 to 0, before 13,256 fans in a National Hookey League contest tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP)-- Sumner Welles, who was linked by the Argentine Ambassador with an "insult" to President Peron, issued a denial today. He observed too, that the people of all the Americas do not like "interference" by foreign diplomats in their personal or political affairs.

ALBANY, Dec. 28--A program extended to provide "a measure of protection" for all children placed in foster homes will be submitted to the Legislature next month by the Special Committee on Social Welfare and Relief of the Ostertag Committee on Interstate Cooperation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28--Little change was shown last week in the wheat situation, although prices were reduced sharply by liquidation by longs and operations to establish profits and losses for income tax purposes. Part of the pressure on the market came from a belief that farmers will sell cash wheat much more freely, early next year, and rotessional operators were inclined to even up their positions pending developments in this respect.

Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President and Secretary of Commerce, is expected to announce tonight his willingness to run for President on a third party ticket, particularly if the Truman Administration continues what he regards as a war policy in its relations with Soviet Russia.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Dec. 28--The song of the ski echoed throughout the snow-blanked mountainside as this alpine-like winter sports playground, less than fifty miles from Times Square bulged with enthusiasts this crisp sunny Sabbath day.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 28--ArabJewish incidents were reported from all over the country today. Jerusalem had the heaviest death toll of any day since the beginning of the violence following the United Nations' partition decision at the end of November.

CHICAGO, Dec, 28--Liquidation of long accounts by commission houses carried prices of corn down rapidly last week on the Board of Trade. A slow demand for No. 3 yellow corn delievered on December contracts and fears that movement of the grain from farms would increase after the turn of the year helped the decline.

One thousand educators from all over the country gathered here yesterday for the annual joint meeting of five learned societies; the American Sociological Society, the American Statistical Association, the Institute of Mathematical Statistics, the Sociometric Institute and the Biometric Society.

PARIS, Dec. 28--In addressing the national committee of his Popular Republican party, Premier Robert Schuman declared today that France, by overcoming the recent strikes, had "done a service to the world" and possibly had averted a war.

To judge by the audience at the Empire last evening, Ruth Draper was a success. In another one of her programs of original character sketches she had only to bounce her genteel slapstick over the empty head of a dowager to draw a shriek of laughter and a round of applause.

Dr. Joseph X. Healy, associate professor of public speaking at City College and holder of administrative and teaching posts there for the last thirty-four years, died Thursday night in Knickerbocker Hospital at the age of 55. His home was at 644 Riverside Drive.

MANILA, Monday, Dec. 29-- Several intermittent earthquakes and a tidal wave struck Eastern Luzon simultaneously with the Christmas typhoon, it was disclosed today through appeals for assistance reaching President Manuel A. Roxas.

Future commercial relations between the Philippines and the United States are of "tremendous importance" and now is the time for the development of sound relations with the new republic, it was declared over the week-end by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the Philippine-America Trade Council, a recently established division of the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28--An all-Negro police squad, the first such unit in the country when it was organized four years ago, was credited today with a 1947 record of 1,537 arrests, 92 percent of which resulted in convictions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28-- Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer has announced that Deborah Kerr, Robert Taylor and Lana Turner will play the leading roles in the screen version of Esther Forbes' forthcoming novel, "The Running of the Tide," to which the company acquired screen rights earlier this year in its semi-annual novel competition.

The persecution of the Holy Innocents by Herod was merely the first in a series of attempts by tyrants down through the ages to remove Christ from human hearts, the Rev. Thomas F. Maher of St. Patrick's Cathedral declared there yesterday morning.

Council to Open Bond Drive Display of 72,000 copies of anew car card, stressing the value of United States Savings Bonds, will be made in January by transit advertising companies throughout the country as the beginning of the Advertising Council's 1948 campaign to promote bond sales through the payroll savings plan, it was announced over the weekend.

NOME, Alaska, Dec. 28 (UP)-- Arctic storms balked tonight efforts to rescue the four known survivors of a B:29 in northern Alaska, but paratroopers reached the wreckage with medical aid. The survivors have been marooned for six days in sub-zero weather.
ROME, Dec. 28--The Italian radio this evening announced the death of former King Victor Emmanuel III in six words: "Victor Emmanuel of Savoy died today."

Five performances of the Budapest String Quartet's series next spring in the Library of Congress will be broadcast over the Columbia network, of which WCBS is the local outlet. The group will be heard Saturdays during the hour beginning at 5 P. M., from April 17 to May 15, inclusive.

The Christmas stocking of the food news department was fat and knobby with all sorts of entrancing delicacies. There were old friends and some products so new to our acquaintance they are just beginning to appear in shops around the city.
CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Government Bonds Government bonds continued to be offered for sale to the Federal Reserve System in volume yesterday, but evidently not to the same xtent as last Friday. The partially tax-exempt issue continued to lose ground, with the 2 3/4s of 1965-60 selling down to 108 16/32 bid, a drop of 20/32 of a point.
EVANSTON, Ill., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Yale's touring basketball team downed Northwestern by 60-50 tonight in a closely fought contest which was deadlocked eleven times.

Dr. Abba Hillel Silver of Cleveland, chairman of the American Section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, called on the United States Government last night to help equip the militia in the new Jewish state in Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A swiftly worsening situation for Europe's children was reported today by Donald A. Sabin on his return from setting up international children's emergency fund programs in Czechoslovakia, France, Greece, Italy and Poland.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: All New Yorkers interested in the education of their children welcomed the forthright and graphic report recently released by the Public Education Association. Its courageous analysis of unsatisfactory conditions in our schools and its intelligent suggestions for their improvement will, I am certain, do much, to arouse public opinion, and eventually eliminate many of the defects that are cited.

NANKING, Dec. 29 -- The Communist radio asserted tonight that Gen. Lin Piao's Manchurian Red Army had overwhelmed the Government's Forty-ninth Division and had captured Changwu, strategic communications center sixty miles northwest of Mukden.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio made the following comment today when he was told that General Graham was listed among Government officials who had speculated in grain.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Argentina tonight stated that the Anglo-Argentine trade agreement of September 1946 had been rendered ineffective, and she claimed full freedom of action with regard to the disposal of future exportable meat surplus.

CAIRO, Egypt, Dec. 29 -- Plans for the funeral of former King Victor Emmanuel III, who died In Alexandria yesterday, are being held in abeyance pending the arrival of his son, Humbert, whose flight from Portugal had been held up by bad weather.

The European Recovery Program contemplates a serious depletion of the maritime strength of the United States for a small saving in dollar transportation costs, the National Federation of American Shipping declared yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The French Foreign Ministry said today that Soviet occupation authorities in Germany had made available for the first time almost 60,000 tons of wheat, wood and motor fuel in reparations from eastern Germany.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The teaching of languages, treated in Topics of the Times on Dec. 15 and discussed by one of your readers in the Dec. 25 issue, is being woefully neglected in this country at a time when our present world leadership makes it almost a duty for us to know foreign languages.

A large group of Government officials and maritime industry leaders is expected to attend a demonstration of three newly developed cargo-handling devices at Akron, Ohio, during the week of Jan. 12, it was announced yesterday.

LAST Friday, with my customary forethought and presence of mind, I took the 3:32 P.M. train out of Grand Central so that I would not be held up unduly by the storm. Quite a few other persons had the same idea, so I was lucky to get a seat. Stamford, theoretically, was less than an hour away. And the run up the branch line from Stamford to my town takes less than fifteen minutes.

NOME, Alaska, Dec. 29 (U.P.) -- Six survivors of the B-29 crash in the Arctic wastelands were rescued tonight by daring Alaskan bush pilots and the two others of the crew, who left to seek aid, were being sought near the wreckage.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Despite the bad travel conditions, forty of the forty-five Westchester supervisors came here today from all parts of the county's 448 square miles to attend their final meeting of the year and to order, by divided vote, higher 1948 compensation for themselves, nine other officials and 2,000 employes.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 10 an editorial entitled "An Albany Brush-Off?" quotes indirectly from a report on State-Local Relations issued by the Council of State Governments.

Hundreds of homes and apartment houses in New York were without fuel yesterday and thousands more were nearing the exhaustion of their supplies. Widespread suffering was threatened as snow-choked streets continued to hamper deliveries.

Penguins that live in similar houses should put numbers on them and learn to read. If that precaution had been taken at the Bronx Zoo one penguin might not have been slain by another some time Sunday night.

HAVANA, Dec. 29 -- Another crisis, this one on the preferential tariff arrangements, seemed to be developing in the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today, with last week's crisis on quantitative restrictions still unsettled.

After digging stalled cabs out of the snow, taxicab operators yesterday were limiting their trips to main thoroughfares and open side streets. Passengers for most side streets had to pile out at the nearest main roadway and go the remaining distance to their destination on foot.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- With further increases in most non-agricultural commodity groups, average primary market prices increased 0.7 per cent in the week ended Dec. 20, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 29 -- Soviet participation in the efforts of the United Nations temporary commission to set up an all-Korea Government is held highly improbable here today. Pessimism arises from a broadcast by the Russian-controlled North Korean radio station at Pyongyang, which declared that the United Nations commission would be "the kind of commission of which the American imperialists are very fond."

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Grains made a tame start and a strong finish on the Board of Trade today. Early sellers of grain found offerings light when they tried to cover, and the finish on the nearby months was about the top. Wheat gained 1/2 to 1 cent.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Although open to traffic, business streets and through highways in Westchester County were still so clogged with snow today that trucks, buses and private automobiles frequently became stalled. Many residential streets and most country roads were completely blocked by drifts and stalled vehicles.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 29 -- Forty years ago the first evidence was obtained of the existence of clouds of dust and gas in the spaces between the stars comprising our Milky Way galaxy, and since that time the interstellar matter has caused drastic changes in our concepts of the nature of the universe and the origin of stars, which may be born from the dust in space.

With Congress having demonstrated its distaste for imposing strong governmental controls to combat inflation, business has been given its last clear chance for true voluntary action in reducing prices, Robert Nathan, economist, warned yesterday.

Third act trouble has afflicted the incoming Florence Ryerson-Colin Clements play, "Strange Bedfellows," which deals with the problem of woman suffrage. After the show opened in Philadelphia's Locust Street last Saturday, it was decided to make some extensive revisions.

A strong effort to agree on the long-term stabilization of wages in the construction industry will be made today, when officials of the Building and Construction Trades Council, AFL, meet with leaders of the Building Trades Employers Association.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read in the Dec. 28 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES an editorial entitled "Argentina's Universities" in which you comment on the article written by Virginia Warren, your correspondent in Buenos Aires, who, as all your former correspondents in Argentina, is evidently following the line of your paper to discredit Argentina in the United States.

ROME, Dec. 29 -- Communist attacks against the Marshall plan were renewed today in the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Constituent Assembly, where Communist leader Palmiro Togliatti reaffirmed that he and his party continued to oppose any American "intervention" in Europe.

ATHENS, Dec. 29 -- Fresh guerrilla battalions fought their way into the outskirts of Konitsa tonight and re-established their siege, Government sources said, after Greek Army troops had broken open the rebel lines long enough to rush a brigade of reinforcements into the battered city.

Random notes. The past week-end seems to have been good fox hunting weather for those who could "take it" and had snowshoes. Three Connecticut hunters reported one of the best mornings of the season on Saturday, despite rather heavy going for both hunters and hounds.

TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- In one of the most remarkable linguistic efforts since the war's end, the League of Koreans Residing in Japan appears to have expressed a hope that the United Nations Commission will not succeed in establishing a single peninsular government for Korea.
The question over the management of the National League team in baseball's All-Star game to be played next July in St. Louis yesterday was definitely settled.

LAKE SUCCESS, Dec. 29 -- Nikolas Kyriazidis, former United Nations correspondent for two suppressed Communist newspapers in Greece, protested today that his arrest pending a deportation hearing was worse than the treatment accorded foreign correspondents by Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany.

Plans were filed yesterday for an eighteen-story and penthouse apartment building on the site of the former historic Temple Beth-El at Fifth Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street. The new building, at 945-947 Fifth Avenue and 204 East Seventy-sixth Street, will accommodate 113 families.
A twenty-four-hour delay was announced last night in plans for a strike of 3,000 workers in four international radio and cable companies.
After a slow start, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange developed strength yesterday and closed at or near the best levels of the day, 19 to 40 points net higher.

Despite difficulties of travel, more than 1,000 buyers of children's and infants' wear in the metropolitan area attended the first two days' showing of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart in the Hotel New Yorker. Buying among the 180 manufacturers who displayed spring lines was brisk, a survey showed, with dollar volume above that of a year ago, although unit volume was down somewhat.

Irving (Moon) Mondschein of New York University, three-time national decathlon champion, holder of several major high-jumping titles and one of this country's foremost Olympic hopes, yesterday received the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s eighth annual "Meritorious Performance" Award.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham, President Truman's personal physician, was speculating in wheat to the extent of 50,000 bushels on Sept. 17, seventeen days before the President denounced "the greed of speculators" in grain.

Howard (Jake) Cann, coach of New York University's unbeaten basketball Violets, said yesterday he deplored the "bad feeling and lack of sportsmanship from the bench" which he stated was displayed by Missouri against N.Y.U. here last Saturday.

Stroud Jordan, industrial chemist in charge of the manufacturers service division of the American Sugar Refining Company, died on Sunday at his home in Miami, Fla., according to word received here. His age was 62.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Big Brother, owned by Mack Brothers Jr., and ridden by W. Saunders won handily in the $1,500 Pass Christian Purse at the Fair Grounds today. He paid $13, $5.60 and $3.20.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Henry Agard Wallace, backed by the Progressive Citizens of America and the liberal groups throughout he country, announced tonight that he would be a candidate for President in 1948 on a third-party ticket, pledged to "a positive peace program of abundance and security, not scarcity and war."

No advanced instruction in Gilbert and Sullivan having been conducted for nine years, classes reconvened last evening at the New Century, where the D'Oyly Carte Company is settling down for the winter term. They opened the course with a revival of "The Mikado."
The status of public school education in the United States at the present time, in contrast wit its status a year ago, as show regionally in a nation-wide survey by THE NEW YORK TIMES, follows:

Another meeting between representatives of local tugboat owners and workers is scheduled for this afternoon in the New York Tow Boat Exchange, 17 Battery Place, in an effort to head off the threatened tie-up of harbor craft. The contract between the owners and Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, expires tomorrow at midnight.

The city appeared to have achieved a partial victory in the battle against the snow yesterday, the first full business day since Friday's record fall, when it received with a foreboding shudder the weather forecast for today and tomorrow.

Antonio De Raco, gifted Argentinian pianist, made his 'recital debut in this country at Carnegie Hall, last night. Besides a fine technique, he displayed an ability to sway his listeners with the power, of his interpretation of Beethoven's Sonata Op. 10, No. 3, and glittering evocations of the moods and colors of Debussy and Ravel.

OTTAWA, Dec. 29 -- There still are immense oil fields to be discovered between the Arctic Circle and Guatemala, and in Labrador there still are huge reserves of iron ore, the Geological Society of America was assured here today by speakers who addressed the society's sixtieth annual meeting.
From neighborhood groceries to large wholesale markets, the city's food industry functioned yesterday in surprisingly normal fashion, several surveys showed.

BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 29 -- What may be the beginning of a plan to move the United States air defenses into the outer reaches of the defense perimeter of the Panama Canal will start early next month 'with the transfer of the Ninety-first Long Range Reconnaissance Squadron from France Field, in the Canal Zone, to Waller Field, in Trinidad.

Industrial supply and equipment manufacturers have no plans at this time for taking advantage of anti-inflation privileges under legislation due to be signed by President Truman, spokesmen for more than 600 companies revealed here yesterday.

Henry A. Wallace's declaration of his intention to run for President in 1948 on an independent ticket had become sc increasingly certain, in the past two weeks that the political reaction it would produce was definitely forecast in advance by leaders of both major parties.

Col. Sosthenes Behn, chairman and president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, announced yesterday the election of seven new directors to fill vacancies on the twenty-three-man board.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Southern Methodist University's Mustangs hit peak condition today while its Cotton Bowl opponent, Perm State, gloomily announced the possible loss through illness of Co-Captain John Potsklan for the New Year's Day game.

Neither the wisdom of age nor the desires of youth will change the pattern of love followed by college students, according to speakers yesterday at the Interfaith College Conference on Love, Courtship and Marriage.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The Greek Government brought before the United Nations today a charge that Yugoslavia had violated two General Assembly resolutions: those against aiding the Greek guerrillas and against warmongering.

A mother and father yesterday gave $50 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund in memory of their son who died in battle and who had been a constant contributor to the fund ever since his school days at Horace Mann School for Boys.
The following prepaid message from Dmitry Shisheyev, chief engineer of the Ordjonikidze machine tool plant in Moscow, was received last night by THE NEW YORK TIMES from the Soviet capital:
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The next step in Greece is up to the United States, it is felt here, and talks about it are going on in Washington between the British and Americans, it was learned today.

The Richmond County grand jury completed yesterday afternoon an investigation into complaints of unsafe conditions and inadequate service on the main municipal ferry line between the Battery and St. George. No indictments were handed up and no presentment was made.
A heavy influx of buyers into the wholesale markets here is expected next month, but opinions were divided yesterday on whether new peaks would be set in the number of store representatives expected.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- Individuals in this country set aside $2,900,000,000 of liquid savings during the third quarter of this year, compared with $2,400,000,000 in the preceding quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Raoul Jobin, French-Canadian tenor, has been a mainstay pf the French wing of the Metropolitan Opera ever since he made his debut there in February, 1940, but his recital last night at Town Hall was the first one he has given in this city.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 -- A strong denial that the Methodist Federation for Social Action was in any way in support of communism was made today by the group in a resolution adopted at the last session of a three-day meeting here.
Transportation systems in the city still were staggering yesterday from the blow dealt by last Friday's snowstorm. Travel was a gamble, with no certainty of reaching a destination on schedule.

For a meatless meal that will satisfy your family's appetites and supply adequate nutritional values, too, this baked casserole of vegetables is accompanied by raw beet and peanut salad. Chilled butterscotch pudding, sprinkled with toasted coconut, is the suggested dessert.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, now thirteen and one-half years old, can put 1947 down as its greatest year of accomplishment in administering the Public Utility Holding Company Act, the "death sentence" law for sprawling, empire-size utility holding companies.
A swift return to normal by retailers and manufacturers here was indicated yesterday as the city wrestled with the problem of snow removal in the major traffic arteries.

The major American motion picture companies, as represented by the Motion Picture Export Association, have notified authorities in Washington and government and occupation heads in Germany and Japan, that they will be forced to withdraw the idstribution of American films in those countries unless there are assurances of sufficient revenue in dollars to offset actual costs, it was revealed yesterday by Irving A. Maas, vice president and general manager of the MPEA.

The immediate "sense of deep disappointment" with which the President will sign the Republican version of the anti-inflation legislation is certain to be widely shared. The degree to which that disappointment proves justified by events, however, will depend upon whether or not the majority party acts to strengthen its decidedly sketchy program at the regular session of Congress.

Young women from Baltimore, Washington, Boston and Philadelphia augmented the gatherings at the many parties held here yesterday in private homes and hotels for debutantes and their young friends. One of the largest of the entertainments was the supper dance given by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bradley Murray in their residence at 11 East Ninetieth Street, to introduce their youngest daughter, Miss Judith Bradley Murray.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark was called on today to investigate an alleged putting of political pressure on Federal employes in Kansas for contributions of 10 per cent of a month salary to the 1946 Democratic campaigns.
Thousands of plants, many of them rare, were in danger at the Bronx Botanical Gardens after the glass roof of the main conservatory began collapsing under the weight of snow on Sunday.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, accused President Truman today of "playing all the politics he can with high prices."

After U.C.L.A. had struck a How for Pacific Coast basketball by downing Long Island University. 66 to 64, in overtime, City College upheld New York prestige by turning back Santa Clara, 56 to 47, in the finale of a doubleheader at Madison Square Garden last night.

As the force of snow removal workers increased by 10,000 yesterday to a total of 30,083 and more trucks and bulldozers were thrown into action, the city administration moved to coordinate and speed the task of clearing the streets.

While sociologists debated zealously the moral and ethical questions they deemed in urgent need of solution to save civilization, economists and statisticians grappled yesterday with the intricacies of the European Recovery Program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Republican anti-inflation bill, product of dispute and compromise, and roundly denounced by President Truman yesterday, has vanished in mystery-book fashion from the White House.

Leaders clashed yesterday in the fifth round of the tournament for the Individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League at John Jay Hall Columbia University, where play will continue today at 10:30 A.M.

Store Sales Up 9% Here Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 9 per cent last week over the like period of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Wise, witty and kind, Frank Crowninshield played an important role in the cultural life of his city, and indeed of the nation. As editor, prophet of modern art, and discoverer and encourager of young literary talent he was arbiter elegantiarum in every field that his ceaseless and urbane activity touched.

Six hours of legal argument were marked by charges and denials yesterday in General Sessions that the prosecution's case against three men, on trial for the fatal shooting of a boss stevedore last Jan. 8, is a "frame-up."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Sam Bischoff has borrowed Lizabeth Scott from Hal Wallis for the leading feminine role opposite Dick Powell in "Pitfall," Bischoff's next production for United Artists release. The photoplay, a melodrama with a Los Angeles setting, based on a 1946 novel by Jay Dratler, will go before the cameras late in January with Andre de Toth directing.

Separation to some extent of business English courses from the general English departments of the nation's colleges and universities was recommended yesterday by Edward J. Kilduff, associate dean of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, in an address at the opening session of the tenth annual two-day convention of the American Business Writing Association at Hotel New Yorker.

Mr. and Mrs. John J. Casey hit the telephone jackpot yesterday when the 4,000,000th instrument to be installed in this state by the New York Telephone Company was placed in their apartment at 243 East Thirty-eighth Street.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Much of the furor caused by fantastic prices asked for used automobiles in the post-war market has subsided but prices generally still are above the highest pre-war levels and demand has eased only because of seasonal influences.

As the third event in Fern Helscher's holiday. dance series at Times Hall last night Reginald and Gladys Laubin made their formal New York debut in a program of authentic dances of the American Indians of the plains and woodlands, and a perfectly delightful evening it was.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Michigan State rallied to sink three field goals in the last two minutes of an overtime period tonight to register a 53-to-47 basketball victory over a touring Harvard University Five.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- On the basis of reports collated just before "General" Markos Vafiades established his "Free Greek Government," and fully anticipating this event, the United States Government is said to remain optimistic concerning the long-range success of the Truman Doctrine.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- The alternate plan for the recapitalization of the Interstate Power Company, involving the issuance of $29,700,000 of new securities, was approved today "as fair and equitable" by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey has decided to oppose any increases in state taxes this year in the belief that they would stimulate inflationary pressures by cutting production. He also believes additional imposts would impair New York's competitive position.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- Fifty standout skiers from ten invited colleges were busy tonight putting finishing touches to hickory boards in preparation for the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' twenty-seventh annual college week competition.

First shipments of the new International Haryester Company refrigerators to dealers Greater New York, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk counties will be made by Jan. 15, Gerald O. Kaye, general sales manager, Bruno-New York, Inc., metropolitan area distributors, revealed yesterday.

The New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street felt the impact of the snow-storm three days after it happened, with 10,000 persons visiting the building yesterday, a new record since its opening thirty-six years ago.

An acre of corn exposes about two acres of leaf to sunlight. If on that one acre a hundred bushels are grown, all those leaves produce with the aid of sunlight about seven tons of material, including three tons of carbon, which was made by taking eleven tons of carbon dioxide out of the air.

HYDERABAD, Dec. 29 -- Armed raids on villages in southeastern Hyderabad, the only independent Princely State in India, are said by state officials and others to be led by Communists from Madras Province, stronghold of that party.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Although business was small, when the stock markets here resumed today after the Christmas holiday, most sections were cheerful.

Conveying the city's greetings yesterday to Mayor Israel Rokach of Tel Aviv, Palestine, Mayor O'Dwyer expressed the hope that the Jewish community there would find peace and happiness as a result of the recent partition of Palestine by the United Nations.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 29 (UP) -- J. Howard McGrath, Democratic National Chairman, said tonight that Henry A. Wallace's announcement as an independent candidate for President "will clear the atmosphere in the coming campaign."

NAPLES, Italy, Dec. 29 -- The first shipment of food that the people of the United States sent Italian people as a gift through the Friendship Train was officially turned over to the special committee that will supervise its distribution.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Warren Wright's Calumet Farm stable finally won its 100th race of 1947 today, and ironically enough, it was probably the cheapest horse in the famous barn that turned the trick -- a maiden 3-year-old named Great Spirit.

Watch night services, most of them ending with the celebration of holy communion, will be held in virtually all the leading Protestant churches of Manhattan through the dying hours of 1947 tomorrow and extending into the new year, as bells peal a welcome to 1948.

The New York Film Critics held their thirteenth annual conclave yesterday to determine the motion-picture "bests" of the year and picked a Hollywood production, "Gentleman's Agreement," over a close-running English contribution, "Great Expectations," as the outstanding picture exhibited in New York during 1947.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The announcement by Henry A. Wallace that he would be a candidate for President on an independent ticket in 1948 caused a stir in official Washington tonight.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Dec. 29 -- The discovery of a Constantinian chapel by archaeologists excavating in the church of San Lorenzo fuori le Mura in Rome was announced today by authorities of Vassar College. The chapel, described as built into the catacombs under the church, was said to contain numerous tombs and inscriptions dating from the fourth century.

The painted horns, paper hats and bright balloons for New Year's Eve celebrations here tomorrow began to arrive yesterday at hotels and night clubs. The East Side night spots began rolling out their bright red carpets, the doormen to polish their uniform buttons and the orchestras to rehearse their rumbas and special arrangements of Auld Lang Syne.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, and of its Chicago local, is to go into action on two fronts in a few days in his campaign against "canned music," an institution which, in its present form and functioning, he regards as a threat to the livelihood of the 225,000 members of his union in the United States and Canada.

Despite a slight improvement in the past year, the nation's schools are confronted with a serious teacher shortage on both the elementary and high school levels. At present 110,000 teachers, or just about one of every eight in the country, are serving on substandard or emergency certificates, with the result that 3,000,000 children are being deprived of an adequate education.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft injected into his speech to the Missouri Republican Club tonight a statement that "even Henry A. Wallace, without the support of the CIO, is going to go a long distance" in the direction of ending Democratic party control of the country.

Thoughts Between Holidays As this between-holidays week was getting into its stride and everybody was settling down to looking backward to Christmas-time, with its tumult and shopping, its beauty and joy, and forward to New Year's Day, with its good resolutions and eager scannings of the horizon for signs that might justify bright New Year's hopes, we heard a friend remark that his post-Christmas and pre-New Year's reflections were largely concerned with envy and revenge.

Hollywood's Robert Montgomery has been signed by CBS as permanent star for "Suspense," the weekly series of mystery plays to be restored on the network Saturday, Jan. 3, at 8 P.M. John Dickson Carr's "The Black Turk" will be the motion-picture player's first vehicle in the series, which is being expanded to a fifty-five-minute production, after an intermittent run on CBS since July, 1942, as a half-hour show.

New York University will put its six-game winning streak on the line against once-defeated Temple, which accounted for one of the season's biggest upsets in downing Kentucky recently, in the feature contest of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Observers at the offices of the State Labor Relations Board, 250 West Fifty-seventh Street, were taken orally behind the scenes of the Stork Club yesterday and shown a few tricks of the night club trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- Registration statements covering $3,000,000 of bonds, 284,682 shares of preferred and 220,643 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

Life insurance companies and savings banks in this state have reached an agreement whereby they will jointly support new legislation liberalizing the sale of such insurance by the banks, it was disclosed here yesterday. A proposal of the banks, narrowly defeated at the last session of the State Legislature, was designed to increase the limits of individual policies written by savings banks from $3,000 to $5,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department today made public the following names of local, state and federal employes, who held positions in wheat futures in a September, 1947, fourday period on the Chicago Board of Trade, and said their positions and dealings as reported by brokers were:

JERUSALEM, Dec. 29 -- A bomb thrown by the Jewish terrorist organization Irgun Zvai Leumi from a speeding taxi today killed eleven Arabs and two British policemen and wounded at least thirty-two Arabs by the Jerusalem Damascus Gate, the same place where a similar bombing took place sixteen days ago.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The threat of The British Musicians Union to ban all direct broadcasts of theatre or music hall performances relayed over the British Broadcasting Corporation networks unless its demands for higher pay are met by the end of year sent entertainment circles here into a sharp flurry of negotiations today.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 -- Prof. T. Moody Campbell of Northwestern University, retiring president of the Modern Language Association of America, assailed "overspecialization" by teachers of English in American colleges and universities tonight.

A partial embargo on freight for this city, Long Island and several New Jersey cities was declared yesterday by five railroads serving the metropolitan area Food, fuel, medicine and other emergency items were exempted.
The following is the text of Henry A. Wallace's address as recorded and transcribed THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WARSAW, Poland, Dec. 29 -- Augustus Cardinal Hlond, Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, left Warsaw by train today for Rome. This gave more strength to reports that new efforts were being made to reopen negotiations between the Polish Government and the Church.

As a result of a series of telegraphic reports from power systems throughout the country, the Edison Electric Institute issued yesterday a sharp denial of "dope stories of an impending power famine" with a compilation of electric power consumption figures which it said showed that the private power companies have met the greatest power demand in history successfully.

New Hair-Scalp Preparations A new line of scalp and hair preparations will be launched under the name "Regime," early next month, it was announced yesterday by Waldo Zimmerman, specialist in advertising and sales promotion for toilet and cosmetic goods.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- President Truman's Air Policy Commission has completed and will send to the White House this week one of the most solemn reports on the defense of the United States ever prepared in time of peace.

VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- Relations between the Austrian Government and the Russian occupation authorities have become severely strained as a result of a sharp Russian denial that they are blocking food distribution in Austria, as alleged by Food Minister Otto Sagmeister recently, and the Russian accusation that industries seized by the Soviet Government under the Potsdam agreement are being starved for electric power by the Austrian Government.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- The question of fixing a new exchange rate for French currency was believed in financial circles today to have been rendered more urgent by the suspension of imports from Belgium because of the necessity to pay for them in gold.
Only one upset was recorded as play entered the quarter-final round in the national junior indoor singles championships yesterday at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A Dutch spokesman disclosed today the formation of the first Dutch-approved State in Netherlands Indies territory over which the Netherlands had recognized the authority of the Indonesian Republic under the Cheribon Agreement.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Statistical analysis of the effects of the encouragement of bank credit deflation by the Federal Reserve Board indicates clearly that the board is never actually in control of the issuance of credit by the banks, Dr. Charles F. Roos, president-elect of the Econometric Society, reported here today.

IF the snowstorm did nothing else it certainly demonstrated what a hardy breed the sports fan is. Inasmuch as fan is merely an abbreviation of fanatic, it took true fanatics to brave the snow and the drifts to witness the week-end offerings at Madison Square Garden, the most remarkable turnouts that the historic arena ever has produced.

Consolidated net sales of the John B. Stetson Company, Philadelphia, increased $8,913,085, or 43 per cent, to $29,336,257 the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, last, from the $20,423,172 volume for the previous year, David H. Harshaw, president, reported yesterday in the annual statement to stockholders.

Three fires started within twenty minutes late yesterday afternoon in six-story Harlem tenements between West 140th and 154th Streets. Two families were displaced from their homes, an elderly woman was burned seriously and five persons received minor injuries.

LONDON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Bao Dai, exiled former Emperor of Annam, arrived in England today from Hong Kong aboard a British plane on a mission apparently aimed at settling a dispute with the French over the future of Indo-China.

YOKOHAMA, Dec. 29 -- The first American tourists to set foot in Japan in seven years sailed today for Shanghai after a twenty-four hour "visit" More than three-quarters of their time here they spent on their luxury ship, the President Monroe of the American President Lines, with a fine view of Yokohama's longest pier but little else.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- A warning that a chemical widely used to bleach white flour, which has been found to produce convulsions and fits in dogs, may also produce subclinical symptoms in human beings that may manifest themselves as alcoholism or some other form of personality disturbance, was sounded here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
Such familiar spring notes as navy and gray, and bolero suits were welcomed yesterday at Saks-Thirty-fourth at a showing of new junior fashions for wear now and during the coming season.

Non-union employes of the Rockaway News Company of Valley Stream, L.I., to whom membership in the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union of New York had been denied, received permission yesterday from the Appellate Division in Brooklyn to make a legal challenge of the union's closed shop agreement.

About a year and a half ago, speaking at the tenth anniversary dinner of the American Labor party in this city, Henry A. Wallace warned against the formation of a national third party on the ground that this would split the progressive vote. Mr. Wallace is now ready to ignore his own warning.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- British Government sources have been receiving accounts of grave disorganization and shortages in the Soviet Union following the end of rationing and the devaluation of the ruble on Dec. 16, it was learned today.

Patrons of two Bronx theatres turned their attention from cinema thrills to drama in the audience yesterday when altercations in the rear of the houses resulted in gunplay and the Wounding of three youths.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Robert C. Bassett, spokesman for the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association, told a Congressional subcommitte today that the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, in fearing the Taft-Hartley Law, has "in a sense dreamed up a bogey man" as far as the law concerns union printers in Chicago.

The stock market indicated again yesterday that it was either not ready or able to embark on the traditional late December rally. Prices backed down further under only slightly enlarged offerings. With selected rails and steels the softest, reductions ranged from fractions to about a point, while the combined averages slipped 0.62 point.

Play in the University Club annual invitation intercollegiat squash racquets tournament go under way yesterday with a total of thirty-eight players listed of the draw. Of these, only two failed to appear, with the result that the program produced virtually a full measure of competition.

Although the counter space occupied by Alperts Cheese Corner in the City Department of Markets' First Avenue store at 230 East Tenth Street is scarcely more than sixteen feet in length, the wares displayed there represent just about every country in the world.

With 10,000 motor vehicles still snowbound on the city's thoroughfares yesterday, those motorists who refused to cooperate in getting their cars out of main lines of travel shared in a white Christmas flurry of "snow summonses."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Whether or not the Kremlin and its Communist supporters in Greece "planned it that way," the problems raised for the United States Government by the guerrilla regime set up under General Vifiades include a threat to the European Recovery Program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association, after a twenty-one-month heavy-weight hunt, finally has found a logical contender for the title owned by Joe Louis.

Readers of Samuel Pepys will remember that it was that gentleman's habit of New Year's Eve to go home and add up his accounts. To do this he would leave a royal party at Whitehall and not mind missing one at Mrs. Pierce's. But the famous diarist was exceptional.

Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia University, paid tribute yesterday to the late Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler as a great man who had greatly strengthened the spirit of the university.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 30 -- A vote for Henry A. Wallace for President under the terms of the announcement of his candidacy would be a vote for the things for which Stalin, Molotov and Vishinsky stand, and Mr. Wallace must know it.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- The trial of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, and of its Chicago local, on the United States Government charge that he has violated the Lea Act opened today before Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy with the testimony of nine Government witnesses.

As the old year draws to a close it is increasingly clear that one major problem confronts us -- the problem of the relations between the United States and Soviet Russia. This problem has already superseded what seemed to be the great issue of 1947 -- namely, the settlement with Germany.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The first diplomatic reports from the Balkans since Gen. Markos Vafiades created his "First Provisional Democratic Government of Free Greece" are beginning to trickle out. In a nutshell, they indicate: (1) That Belgrade is preparing the Yugoslav people for the dangerous step of according diplomatic recognition to the rebels but has not yet entirely determined to do so.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- New construction in the United States increased 30 per cent over the total for 1947 and cost more than $12,800,000,000, it was estimated today by the construction division of the Department of Commerce.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- A resolution condemning the arrest by United States authorities of two United Nations correspondents, Syed Sibtay Hasan and Nicholas Kyriazidis, was adopted unanimously today by the Standing Committee of United Nations Correspondents.

Three years ago during the Battle of the Bulge in December, 1944, Lieut. Col. John D. Hanlon borrowed 500 white sheets from the people of Hemroulle, Belgium, to camouflage his men while they fought to stem the German advance toward the sea.
Gregory Pavlides, Stork Club captain and right-hand man to Sherman Billingsley, denied yesterday that the night club owner paid kitchen employes who voted against a union last May.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today a joint plan of the United Light and Railways Company and American Light and Traction Company, assuring construction of a $104,000,000 pipe line to feed natural gas into Michigan and Wisconsin.

The City of New York has borrowed $40,000,000 from a group of twenty-six local banks on 1 per cent tax anticipation notes dated Dec. 29, 1947, and due April 21, 1948, Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday. The notes were sold on an allotment basis to banks as follows:

HAVANA, Dec. 30 -- Representatives Jacob K. Javits of New York and James G. Fulton of Pennsylvania, Republicans, warned in a joint statement tonight that failure of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment would have an adverse effect upon United States participation in the world's economic recovery.
BERLIN, Dec. 30 -- The longawaited reform of this city's schools system was again delayed today when the four powers instructed German officials to revise their proposed program.

The stock market made a show of strength yesterday which Wall Street interpreted as a belated year-end rally. While the scope of the upturn was limited to certain sections, many industrials recently under pressure came to the front and there were gains of 1 to 3 points at the close.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A passport misunderstanding between the State Department and the Amateur Hockey Association's Olympic players appeared to have been settled tonight.

The restless spirit that prompted North Atlantic coastal pioneers to find out what lay beyond the horizon lives today with the American motorist. Statistics show that while the average car owner was content to cover 5,000 miles a year in pre-war times, now that total has doubled and about 10,000 miles annually is registered on the dashboard.

LONDON, Wednesday, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov has said that the United States delegation disrupted "the entire work" of the London conference of Big Four Foreign Ministers, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today from Moscow.
BOSTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued this winter sports bulletin: Maine Fair and cold, brisk northwesterly winds tomorrow and New Year's Day.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30 (AP) -- White primaries were declared illegal in South Carolina by the Fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today in a decision which, if upheld by the United States Supreme Court, may have far-reaching effects upon the political and economic structure of the Southern states.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The American Internee Committee asks your aid to help publicize the appalling tragedy of thousands of American civilian ex-prisoners of war who suffered more than three years in Japanese prison camps in the Far East.

The shipbuilding industry of this country distinguished itself during the last year principally by the fact that it completed and delivered all but one vessel remaining of the World War II merchant ship construction program, marking the end of the greatest shipBuilding program in history, according to the annual report of H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, issued yesterday.

Whatever became of that threatened booking jam? Like magic, it evaporated into thin air. More and more Broadway houses are becoming available so the congestion has eased up considerably. On top of that many of the shows trying out aren't ready for the supreme test.

Reporting on operations of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, Harvey S. Firestone Jr., president, informs shareholders in the statement issued yesterday for publication today, that sales reached $638,447,166, exceeding by 10 per cent the peacetime record of $577,833,422 set a year earlier.

Three women have been appointed to a commission charged with carrying out the global trip for the One World Committee that the late Fiorella H. La Guardia was unable to undertake, it was announced yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Referring to Sidney Gruson's article, "Polish Socialists Spurn Tie to Reds, which appeared in THE TIMES on Dec. 16, I wish to make certain corrections for the benefit of your readers.
