RANGOON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A special Burmese tribunal today held that U Saw, leader of the opposition Myochit party, was the brains behind the plot in which five assassins burst into the Ministers' Council Chamber on July 19 and sprayed it with machine-gun bullets.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today approved reorganization of the Public Service Corporation of (Newark) New Jersey by the transfer of all of its assets to its principal operating subsidiary.

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened last night in the threatened strike of harbor towboat workers after another meeting in a long series of negotiation sessions failed to bring the operators and their employes together.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Bob (Ace) McCann, a mite among giants, field generated undefeated La Salle College of Philadelphia to its seventh straight victory tonight, 61 to 48, over Southern California in the second game of a Convention Hall basketball doubleheader before 3,706.

Some improvement in New York's transportation system was made yesterday -- the fourth day since the record snowstorm -- but bus service deteriorated instead of improved in Brooklyn and Queens because of the number of private cars that tried to use the streets and then stalled.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Senator Glen H. Taylor, Democrat, of Idaho, awaited here today, without commitment, a formal invitation to take second place on the ticket to be headed by Henry A. Wallace.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Dec. 30 -- A seven-point "Wallace plan" to replace the Marshall plan for the recovery of Europe and calling, among other things, for the placing of Germany's Ruhr valley under control of the Big Four, was proposed by Henry A. Wallace, third party Presidential candidate, in a speech here tonight.

For fourteen years after she was stricken with poliomyelitis, Alice Helwig spent all of her time in bed or in a wheelchair. She began last year to take rehabilitation training at Bellevue Hospital and now walks with the aid of crutches and braces, lives alone, has a job and supports herself.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- British Government stocks and home rails were the main attraction in the stock markets here today, with holders switching to industrials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Continued Republican control of Congress, regardless of the outcome of the Presidential election, was predicted today as a result of Henry Wallace's announcement that he would lead a third party movement in 1948.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Coach Jimmy Littlejohn's scrappy St. Lawrence University ski team appeared to be well on its way to its second victory in the annual Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' collegeweek tournament following the opening two events of the three-day competition today at Mount Whitney.

New York City faces the prospect of a beerless New Year's Eve as an aftermath of last week's storm and Mayor O'Dwyer's ban on non-essential trucking while the city shovels its way out. At least 90 per cent of the city's taverns were reported "out of beer" last night and remaining kegs in the others were expected to be emptied by this morning.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Administrator of the Federal Works Agency, informed President Truman today that the states would need public works costing about $75,000,000,000 in "the next few years."
PEIPING, China, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Communist regulars in force have hammered to within six miles of Mukden, censored press dispatches reported today.

An agreement to stabilize wages and working conditions for 70 per cent of the 250,000 construction workers in the city and adjoining New York counties was announced last night by the Building Trades Employers Association and the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, AFL.

St. John's, playing sound, heady basketball, fashioned a major upset by turning back Utah, last season's national invitation tournament winner, before 18,482 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. The 49-44 conquest by the Redmen was followed by a 64-41 New York University rout of Temple, extending the undefeated Violet string to seven.

In a brief summing up of past, present and future Soviet policy on Palestine, Andrei A. Gromyko issued a warning last night against any effort by "foreign monopolies" to influence the future economies of the newly create Arab and Jewish states. The occasion was a "U.S.A., U.S.S.R., Palestine friendship dinner."

NUREMBERG, Germany, Dec. 30 -- Fourteen top-ranking members of the land, sea and air arms of Germany's shattered military forces were arraigned this morning as defendants in the final case that will be tried by Nuremberg military tribunals.
Frank R. Milliken has been appointed plant manager of the MacIntyre Development, titanium Division, National Lead Company, Tahawus, N.Y., effective tomorrow.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey today promised representatives of major farm organizations and others interested in rural education that he will recommend a "substantial" increase in state aid for education. He declined to estimate the dollar amount of the increase.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 30 -- Our huge wheel-shaped system of stars Known as the Milky Way galaxy is apparently composed of two vast aggregations of stars which differ from each other in their motions and physical characteristics, so that astronomers are now assigning celestial bodies to one of two groups which they call Population I and Population II.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Distribution of applications for the state bonus to war veterans, which the voters approved at a referendum last fall, starts tomorrow at 6,000 local outlets in various parts of the state, Leo V. Lanning, Bonus Bureau Director, said today.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- Traffic conditions and food supplies improved today in Westchester County with the removal of more snow from the highways, but the delivery of fuel oil after tomorrow midnight was threatened when the Westchester Fuel Oil Trade Association and Local 456 of the Teamsters Union, AFL, failed to agree on a new contract.

A lull before the storm of New Year's Eve merriment pervaded the city yesterday. Yet behind-thescenes preparations were in full swing. The Police and Fire Departments formulated their plans to make the occasion safe and sane for celebrants, and hotels and restaurants decorated their chandeliers with various versions of the seasonal phrase, "Happy New Year."

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 30 -- The Communist-led Colombian Federation of Labor will not send delegates to the International Labor Convention in Lima, Peru, next month, according to an official communication signed by its president, Victor Julio Silva, Socialist member of Congress.

New Year's Eve, traditional hockey night at Madison Square Garden, will find the New York Rangers trying to tighten their third-place grip in a National Hockey League clash with the Boston Bruins tonight. This encounter will be the first of four for the Rangers within five nights.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The abdication of King Michael of Rumania came as no surprise to the British Foreign Office and there is nothing to be done about it, according to an official spokesman.

British authorities in this country have declined to clear the shipment of a carload of Aroostook County, Me., potatoes, contributed as part of a project for which New England is sponsor, to aid the needy of Scotland, it became known yesterday.

Plans for erecting a rayon yarn and staple mill in Palestine, currently scheduled for completion by the end of 1949, will bring about a real expansion of the textile industry in the new Jewish state it was pointed out yesterday by officials of the newly formed Palestine Rayon Corporation.

PARIS, Dec. 30 -- The Cabinet authorized Foreign Minister Georges Bidault today to sign an agreement with the United States regarding the use to be made of the stop-gap aid voted by Congress for France. Officials said the signature might take place tomorrow.

Holiday Low for Buyers Visiting buyers registered, in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 180, compared with 292 last week and 62 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board, governing body of United States commercial aviation, will lose its chairman tomorrow night with the expiration of the term of James M. Landis, head of the CAB for the last eighteen months.

NEWARK, N.J., Dec. 30 -- Representative Fred A. Hartley, coauthor of the Taft-Hartley labor law, is expected to seek his eleventh term as a member of Congress from the Tenth District, it was indicated today. While campaigning two years ago, Mr. Hartley said repeatedly that he would not be a candidate again.

DETROIT, Dec. 30 -- The study of American literature is elective in all but 5 per cent of 700 colleges and universities investigated by a special committee of the National Council of Teachers of English, it was reported here tonight.

The first foreign film to receive its American, premiere through television will be the French-made "African Diary," which NBC will put on the air tomorrow night at 9:15 o'clock over its four-city video network. Outlets will be at WNBT, New York, the program's origination point; WNBW, Washington; WPTZ, Philadelphia, and WRGB, Schenectady.

A General Sessions blue ribbon jury, which received at 1:45 P.M. yesterday the case of three men accused of murder in the shooting of Anthony Hintz, boss stevedore, in the hallway of his Greenwich Village apartment house last Jan. 8, still was deliberating early this morning, more than eleven hours after it had retired from the courtroom.

What this city of nearly eight million people would have done without its subways during and after the tremendous snowfall of last Friday is something best left to the imagination. Certainly it seems a fair assumption that many lives might have been lost and great hardship suffered if we had not had the underground to rely on.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 30 -- Col. Milton B. Ochs, who for years has held an influential position in the affairs of Chattanooga, next Tuesday will receive the highest honor of the Chattanooga Kiwanis Club, "the man of the year."

A bronze memorial plaque was unveiled in Trinity Churchyard yesterday afternoon in memory of Francis Lewis, the only signer of the Declaration of Independence buried in Manhattan. Mr. Lewis, who was a member of the vestry of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street, died 144 years ago at the age of 90.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, withdrew a nomination to a $12,000-a-year post on the Board of Examiners yesterday after learning that a majority of the Board of Education would not support his choice for the job.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The possibility that Britain would begin realizing the benefits of her newly signed trade pact with the Soviet Union early next month in advance of schedule was seen here today as further details of the shortterm pact became known.

Bedding production during the first quarter of 1948 will drop 25 per cent compared with the last quarter of this year, Irving Weisglass, president of Eclipse Sleep Products, Inc., said yesterday. He said the drop will result from a 25 per cent cut in supplies of steel wire, vital component in innerspring and box mattresses, dual purpose sleeping equipment and virtually all other bedding items.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- First-seeded Ted Schroeder, of Glendale, Calif., and Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, of Los Angeles, literally pulled their semi-final matches out of the fire today to qualify for tomorrow's championship battle in the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 30 -- A move to "disassociate" the North American Student Conference on Christian Frontiers from recen public utterances by its chairman Representative Walter H. Judd of Minnesota, was started here to night by a group of student delegates.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Holy Cross, National Collegiate A.A. champion, defeated North Carolina State in overtime, 56 -- 51, on the annual Sugar Bowl basketball program tonight. The score was 50 -- 50 at the end of regulation time.

Shortage of tire chains and reported profiteering in them added yesterday to the troubles of motorists. Chains were quoted at $30 a set, compared with the normal retail price of $8.50, according to the Automobile Club of New York.

The year just ending has been the safest in the city's history for having a baby, the Maternity Center Association, 654 Madison Avenue, reported yesterday. With a provisional maternal death rate for the year of only 1.05 for each thousand live births, New York ranks high among the cities of the world, Miss Hazel Corbin, director of the association since 1923, declared.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Alabama's Crimson tide and Texas' Orange wave will sweep into this sports mad Southern metropolis to keep a red letter date in the Sugar Bowl, with the weather gods wearing huge grins. The Mid-Winter Sports Association smiled from ear of there as Government forecasters promised ideal weather for the fourteenth annual football classic Thursday, predicting possible showers tomorow but no rain on the big day.

Most of the groups that habitually backed Franklin D. Roosevelt in New York State independently of the Democratic party organizations hurled a barrage of denunciation yesterday at the announced third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, arrived here today for a two-day investigation of the United States and British industry dismantling program, which he said would come up for examination in connection with hearings on the European Recovery Program.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The powerful Trades Union Congress, which is the mainstay of the Government in the labor union field, disappointed Government leaders today by coming out firmly against wage controls. In an "interim report on the economic situation" the TUC passes the buck on this vital issue back to the Labor Government.

BEFORE Christmas gets too far away entirely and the spirit of the season is lost for another year, it's just as well to skim through the mail which arrived during the Yuletide period from various thoughtful persons. The cards always are appreciated and they come from all quarters. One constant source of satisfaction is to receive missives from you and you and you, the readers who keep this column in business.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- An order which will end fourteen years of bankruptcy for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad at 12:01 A.M., Jan. 1, was signed today under "protest" by Federal Judge Michael L. Igoe.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A final message to the Chinese Government from Maj. Gen. Lowell W. Rooks, Director General of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, today was the last release to be issued by the UNRRA information office.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission increased freight rates 20 per cent today until June 30, 1948, for railroads, water carriers and freight forwarders.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Even Break, an English-bred gray gelding flying Helene K. Haggerty's silks, sprang a mild upset before 11,581 fans at Gulfstream Park today when he defeated seven other fast sprinters in the featured Tarpon Springs Purse.

Foreign Dollar Bonds The market supply of old Italian dollar bonds exchangeable into the new trio of conversion loans seems to be picking up a bit, despite the general year-end standstill in the securities markets. No bonds have yet come in from foreign sources, however.

Shortly after being installed as president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, Shepard Barnes of the Baltusrol Golf Club, Springfield, N.J., warned the delegates attending the fiftieth meeting of the organization at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday that the body would try to stamp out "semi-professionalism" in the game.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30 -- In registration statements filed today with, the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Telephone Company listed $60,000,000 of thirty-year refunding mortgage bonds, Series E, and three other companies listed 630,788 shares of common stock.
NOME, Alaska, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The bodies of two parachutists who leaped into an Alaskan blizzard four days ago were found tonight near the wreckage of the B-29 they were attempting to reach.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A Department of Commerce analysis tonight pictured 1947 as a record year when production, consumption and prices rose -- especially prices.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec. 30 -- A local Freedom Week observance fashioned after the national tour of the Freedom Train was proclaimed here today by Mayor George K. Batt.

Sales of non-jewelry items became of marked importance to credit Jewelers this year and helped pull dollar volume up to 1946 levels, it was reported yesterday by William Wagner, executive director of the National Association of Credit Jewelers.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- A clash between New York City and up-state members of the Legislature is expected to develop during the coming session over the problem of determining what the pay of the 150 Assemblymen and fifty-six Senators shall be.

The form charts were upheld as the field in the national indoor junior singles tennis championships being conducted on the boards of the Seventh Regiment Armory was narrowed down to four men yesterday. The quartet which gained the semi-final round comprises the first four seeded entrants in the tournament.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Paul Henreid and Steven Sekeley disclosed today that they expect to go to Paris next year to produce an English-language film based on William Herzog's unpublished novel, "Cartouche," to which Henreid owns the screen rights.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The United Nations Security Council held its last 1947 meeting here today in a moderately optimistic spirit as the delegates of Australia, Brazil and Poland, terminating their two-year tenures on the Council, joined in hearty wishes for a more prosperous and peaceful 1948.

Delivery dates of some formerly scarce industrial and electrical supply items have improved so much that some suppliers are expecting to hold firm price policies through the first quarter of 1948, purchasing agents revealed here yesterday.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 -- A controversy centered today on the Argentine threat to cut off, for the second time within less than four months, the shipment of tinned beef to Britain.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Koppers, Inc., will devote a considerable amount of research during 1948 to development of processes for making synthetic liquid fuels and other chemicals from coal, the company said in a yearend report today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 30 -- The Greek situation is being watched with considerable concern by several United Nations delegations. They expect Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria to accord at least belligerent rights to the "First Provisional Democratic Government of Free Greece" if the guerrillas capture Konitsa.

Russia will be the major issue in the 1948 election because Henry A. Wallace "side-stepped direct mention of Russia" in his speech Monday, Louis Fisher, author and lecturer, predicted here yesterday. Mr. Fisher spoke to 175 persons attending a luncheon meeting of the International Platform Association, held in Columbia's Men's Faculty Club, 400 West 117th Street.

ATHENS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Greek Army forces lunged tonight to within light-artillery range of guerrillas who were besieging Konitsa, near Albania, after Athens Government commando units had knocked insurgent fighters off heights dominating the strategic Borozani Bridge, eleven miles west of Konitsa.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Dr. Charles O. Hardy, economist of the Joint Congressional Committee on the Economic Report, disputed today in an address before the American Economic Association here the Administration doctrine that any Government surplus must be used for debt reduction rather than tax reduction in the interest of countering inflation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- UnderSecretary of State Robert A. Lovett warned in a statement today that recognition by any countries of the so-called provisional government that has been proclaimed by guerrillas in northern Greece "would have serious implications."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Dec. 30 -- Prague's central organs of the major political parties opposed to communism warned today that the Communists were again trying to break down the compromise on which post-war Czechoslovakia has been erected and to bring trade under the control of the state.

Mr. and Mrs. William P. Hunt Of 1035 Fifth Avenue and Greenwich, Conn., gave a supper dance last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza to introduce their daughter, Miss June Hunt. The ballroom was decorated with simulated trees comprised of boughs of white balloons reaching to the ceiling.

BOSTON, Dec. 30 -- Music has become big business instead of an art form, Dr. Howard Hanson, dean of the Eastman School of Music, Rochester, N.Y., said today. He also charged that educators had done a bad job of developing an understanding of music in students, in an address before the twenty-fourth annual convention of the National Association of Schools of Music.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 -- A processional in which seven bishops in vestments marched down the center aisle with a robed choir of 125 voices tonight officially opened the Methodist Youth Conference which has brought representatives from every state in the country as well as delegates from Cuba, Hawaii, Canada, Spain, Brazil and other countries.

It may be possible to find clothes at reduced prices in the afterChristmas sales now going on in department stores, but in groceries the situation is just the opposite. Prices for many kinds of meat, vegetables and poultry are higher than they were before the holiday.

MANILA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Some of the passengers of the typhoonwrecked Danish motorship Kina, flown here from Masbate Island, today criticized the action of Capt. Vlademar Hjernum for taking the vessel into the treacherous Samar Sea in the face of typhoon warnings.
Washington, Dec. 30 -- The Department of Agriculture issued today for Republican Congressional investigators a fourth list of 2,914 speculators in wheat as of Feb. 28, 1947.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Michigan's role of favorite over Southern California in the Rose Bowl on Thursday reached landslide proportions today, much to the joy of Trojan Coach Jeff Cravath and the discomfort of the Wolverine's Fritz Crisler as they swapped banter at the annual kickoff luncheon before some 2,000 guests.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Ski enthusiasts will find good sport in New York State this New Year's holiday.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The text of King Michael's abdication proclamation: Michael I, by God's grace and the national will King of Rumania, to all, present and future good health.

Snow in the Bronx began producing curious reactions yesterday in some sections. As a result there emerged two new types in the, already varied population of this semi-glacial area. First there was the geographical isolationist. Second, the Republican with the persecution complex.

No soldiers will have a nobler monument than the 800 Americans of the Eighty-second Airborne Division who died in the fighting around the Nijmegen Bridge in Holland in September, 1944. Before the Second World War the buildings of the University of Nijmegen stood near this spot.

ONE of the most ambitious and also one of the most peculiar novels of 1947 was nearly overlooked by this conscientious department. Six days a week aren't enough in which to pay tribute to all the ambitious and peculiar books which are published each year, but Vincent McHugh's "The Victory"* is unusual enough to deserve careful attention.
The cotton futures market closed 15 to 32 points net higher yesterday, following a day of moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

The publishing firm of Grosset Dunlap has withdrawn from sale the first printing of a new children's edition of "Arabian Nights" following protests from organizations and individuals that some of the content was anti-Semitic, it became known yesterday.

The latest report on the waterfowl situation on the Canadian nesting grounds during the past season has been issued by Ducks Unlimited, and is compiled from reports made by observers in 329 district's.

Diehl Mateer Jr., 19-year-old sophomore from Haverford College, Pa., and Russ C. Ball, West Point first classman, who hails from Winwood, Pa. advanced to the final of the annual intercollegiate squash racquets invitation tournament at the University Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Republican anti-inflation bill became law today when President Truman signed it and soon afterward Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, restricted the use of grain in the manufacture of liquor.

Robert Byrne, 19-year-old Yale freshman, and member of the Manhattan Chess Club, was declared the winner last night for the individual championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League after seven rounds of the schedule under the Swiss system had been completed at John Jay Hall, Columbia University.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The reaction in British official and press circles today to Henry Wallace's announcement that he would run independently for President of the United States in 1948 ranged from clear-cut disapproval by The Times of London to what might be called sorrowful headshaking by a prominent, left-wing Labor member of Parliament.
Two hospitals patients sent their gifts yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund through intermediaries.

Further examination of the family as the source of social development and personality planning is required to make it function adequately in a democratic society, speakers said yesterday at the closing session of the forty-second annual meeting of the American Sociological Society in the Commodore Hotel.

Because the right of citizenship by birth in this country might be "forever lost," Supreme Court Justice J. Edward Lumbard Jr. refused yesterday to direct two childcaring institutions to release the three children of Hamportzoon Choolokian, 48-year-old shoemaker, so that they might join him in Soviet Armenia under a repatriation agreement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A world wheat summary issued today by the Department of Agriculture showed that in order to export 450,000,000 bushels by June 30, which would be the largest United States wheat export for one crop year, 109,000,000 bushels still would have to be bought for export.
MADRID, Spain, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Two Communist leaders, found guilty of illegal underground activity, were executed yesterday by a firing squad, the Spanish Government announced today.

Anti-Bias Drive to Start The Advertising Council's, newest public service campaign, the "United America" drive against racial and religious intolerance, will be launched about the middle of January, it was announced yesterday by Edward Royal, council account executive on the campaign.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A new export license policy, designed to permit wider competition in the export trade and aid importing nations in conserving scarce dollar exchange, will become effective Jan. 2, 1948, the Department of Commerce announced today.

Touching the Manly Art This corner is not directly concerned either with Art or with Sports -- although, like King Charles' head, what happens about the horses comes up for mention every now and then.

Roberts Mander Corporation yesterday exhibited its 1948 lin of gas and electric cooking are heating appliances, a kitchen sin and cabinet "package" and automatic built-in exhaust fan in special advance showing in the New York showroom, 1 Park Avenue.

The Community Service Society will mark the completion in 1948 of one hundred years during which it has given individual aid to three million persons in this city. At the same time it has given notable leadership in developing welfare and health programs and in improving social and living conditions for the community as a whole.

BATAVIA, Java, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Dutch announced today they would transfer the responsibility for the security of those now under Dutch protection only to a Federal Government of Indonesia "that can guarantee that same security and liberty."
Maritime labor and industry representatives in the Joint Committee for the American Merchant Marine will meet in Washington next week to adopt final plans for a coordinated program for the industry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Experiments in genetics invalidating many of its present basic concepts and promising to lead to revolutionary developments in the breeding of new species of plants and animals, as well as of human beings, were described here today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The Radio Directors Guild, AFL, and the radio networks failed to, reconcile their differences yesterday in a meeting before the State Mediation Board at 270 Broadway, as the contracts between them are scheduled to expire tonight at midnight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The standards for testing the loyalty of Government employes, and their discretion in act and speech (with security in mind), which have been laid down by the board headed by Seth W. Richardson reveal that the formula of decision whether such employes shall be dismissed, stated in 1892 by the late Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes, remains in full force.
The fuel oil delivery snarl caused by Friday's record snowfall was reported yesterday to be growing worse instead of improving.

An order barring all non-essential vehicular traffic from the city's streets was issued last night by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander to speed snow removal. The order became effective at midnight and will remain in force until further notice.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Administration economists and members of Congress of both parties tonight hailed the price reductions announced by the General Electric Company as a significant contribution to the fight against inflation.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- John J. Pilch, president of Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, AFL, told a meeting of printers on strike against six Chicago daily newspapers today that "beginning the first of the year, we really are going to put the heat on."

A record amount of life insurance was purchased this year by Americans, according to Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance. Life insurance purchases totaled $21,700,000,000, of which $14,500,000,000 was ordinary insurance, $4,200,000,000 industrial life insurance and $3,000,000,000 group life insurance.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor of Germany, suggested "informally" to his French counterpart today that they eliminate trade and travel barriers between the United States and French zones.
Fascism's resurgence on a worldwide scale and creation of the Cominform were listed yesterday by the Friends of Democracy as two of ten serious setbacks sustained by democracy in 1947.

Gustavus T. Kirby, president emeritus of the United States Olympic Committee, yesterday appealed directly to the International Olympic Committee president to proclaim that no team could represent a nation unless it had the approval of the national committee -- an action that if taken would rule out the Amateur Hockey Association team.

Fifteen well-upholstered bobsledders, three trim figure skaters and nine superbly conditioned speed skaters, all hoping to gain honors for the United States at the Fifth Olympic Winter Games at St. Moritz, were among the passengers yesterday when the United States Lines' flagship America headed for Europe.

Price reductions of 3 to 10 per cent on a wide range of electrical products such as refrigerators, stoves, radios and television receivers were announced here yesterday by Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company.

Economists and statisticians, forecasting major economic developments of 1948, predicted yesterday the greatest upswing in peacetime production, along with increases in the cost of living. One of them prophesied that the Marshall plan would be scaled down substantially by Congress.

When King Michael of Rumania observed his name day last Nov. 8, reports from Bucharest indicated that he had but small cause for rejoicing. For Michael (Mihai in his own country) was described as a young man on a hot seat with the temperature steadily rising.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 30 -- Forty-one Jews and six Arabs were killed today in a fight in Haifa provoked by a bombing by Irgun Zvai Leumi, Jewish terrorist organization. Forty-eight Jews and forty-two Arabs were wounded in the clash.

"Insufficient attention" has been given to the numerous phases of existing Government policy that tend to intensify the upward pressure on prices, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York suggests in its monthly review of business and financial conditions, issued today.

PANAMA, Dec. 30 (AP) -- President Enrique Adolfo Jimenez, who appointed a new Cabinet today, told a news conference that he did not believe it was a propitious time to initiate new negotiations for an agreement on United States military bases on Panama soil.

The "British Concert Hall," a series of the British Broadcasting Corporation, will be brought to American listeners through recordings by WINS, beginning Sunday at 5 P.M. The one-hour programs, to be heard for thirteen consecutive Sundays, will feature the BBC Symphony, London Symphony and Royal Philharmonic, under the batons of Sir Thomas Beecham, Sir Malcolm Sargent and Clarence Raybould.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Dodge Sloane's Music, breaking loose from an extended jinx, today wound up her 4-yearold campaign with her gamest effort of the year to score a nose triumph in the featured Canaveral Purse before 10,249 fans at Gulftstream Park.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- A freakish, violent tornado that did little damage elsewhere, although it ripped a swath 100 miles long from Louisiana into Arkansas, struck the oil and farming town of Cotton Valley twice in succession this afternoon, destroying more than 100 buildings.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -With the versatile Robert (Rainbow) Wright, former mountain trooper from Glen Ridge, N.J., again showing the way, the St. Lawrence University Larries from Canton, N.Y., added to their lead for the team honors in the twenty-seventh Lake Placid Club Snowbirds' college week ski competition as the cross-country was contested today under ideal conditions.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The combined British and American zones had an unfavorable trade balance of more than a quarter of a billion dollars in the first ten months of 1947. Exports, including coal and timber, amounted in value to about 58 per cent of imports.

In regard to our foreign policy, as the new year opens, we are being shown the largest possible application of the parable of the Good Samaritan ever offered. It is lifted beyond what is merely individual, into national and international experience.

Many household appliance producers will reduce prices of some of their products "almost immediately" as a direct result of price cuts announced on Monday by General Electric Company, an executive of a large national appliance distributing organization predicted yesterday.
Jefferson City, Mo., will offer $435,000 of bridge and park bonds on Jan. 5. Bidders will name the rate on the issue, which is dated Feb. 1, and which will fall due July 1, 1949 to 1968.
Veterans by the thousands stood in line yesterday to pick up application forms for the collection of the bonuses of $50, $150 or $250 to be paid by New York State.

VIENNA, Dec. 31 Despite Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's unyielding front in London, it is believed in Vienna that the Russians still want to negotiate an Austrian treaty and that their terms may not necessarily prove entirely unacceptable to Austria or the western occupation powers.

Averting the threat of a serious tugboat tie-up in New York Harbor, representatives of Local 333, United Marine Division, International Longshoremen's Association, A.F. of L., and officials representing tugboat operators agreed on a new contract at 1 o'clock this morning, one hour after their 1947 contract had expired.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Truman stressed the necessity of mutual good-will and confidence in international relations for the solving of post-war problems in receiving today Alexander S. Panyushkin as Soviet Ambassador to the United States.

Thirteen-year-old Janice Samuels of 264 Fort Washington Avenue and Troop 3-171 of the Girl Scouts, was one of the proudest youngsters in America yesterday. She was the first of the nation's million Girl Scouts to read the letter from Princess Elizabeth thanking the organization for its wedding present.

The most vital problem before the nation in 1948 is that the purchasing power of the dollar should not decline further. This can be achieved by increasing production on the farm and factory. The Secretary of Agriculture recommended an increase in the cotton acreage of 3 per cent.
The New Year got an early start yesterday for forty-seven young families as they settled into the first completed apartments in two new low-rent developments of the New York City Housing Authority.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- A new approach to the problem of estimating national income in areas of the world that are "statistically poor" because standard data are not gathered or are not made public was reported here today before a joint session of the American Economic Association, the economic and engineering sections of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and the Academy of World Economics.
The year 1948 opens with United States' armed forces strong and definitely on the "upgrade" after two destructive years of post-war demobilization and reorganization.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 31 -Ginger Rogers' association with Enterprise Productions will be terminated by mutual consent, it was learned today from Enterprise, "because of subordinate contractural terms and conditions which could not be worked out."

The nation's gasoline stocks last week rose 4,213,000 barrels, the largest weekly increase in recent years, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekendh)0*0*0*ithey amounted to 91,269,000 barrels, compared with 87,056,000 a week earlier and 91,851,000 on Dec. 28, 1946.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Masterful net-minding by Goalie Harry Lumley in his second straight shutout triumph enabled the Detroit Red Wings to extend their jinx string to seven straight victories over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight, 4 to 0, in a National Hockey League game.

PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 31 (AP) - Bradley's basketball team jumped back into the victory column tonight, winning its twelfth game in thirteen starts by overwhelming Yale, 91 to 56. South Dakota handed the Braves their first defeat last night, 54 to 51.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 A policy of reinvesting earnings from the sale of electric power in new generating and distributing facilities was recommended by the management of the Tennessee Valley Authority in its annual report, made public today, listing gains in most of its fields.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation, which is scheduled to continue its activities in controlling railway transportation under the antiinflation bill recently signed by President Truman, reviewed today the year's activities of the organization and took a look at 1948.
LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Creation of four new peers, twenty-nine knights and six members of the Privy Council was announced here today in the New Year's Honors List.

With 3,000 workers in four large international communications companies scheduled to go on strike at midnight tonight, the first signs of hope for a peaceful settlement were reported last night by John A. Daly, acting regional director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Year-end evening up resulted in irregular changes in grain prices on the Board of Trade today. Wheat futures closed unchanged to 1 3/4 cents higher, the former on May which was around 28 cents a bushel over-July at the finish, compared with 30 1/2 cents at one time in the early trading.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -If the weather man knows his stuff, Alabama's Harry Gilmer and Texas Bobby Layne won't be able to show much of theirs tomorrow in the fourteenth annual Sugar Bowl game.

Entering second weeks today are "The Fugitive," at the Victoria; "Captain From Castile," at the Rivoli; "The Voice of the Turtle," at the Warner; "High Wall," at the Capitol; "The Exile," at the Winter Garden; "Tycoon," at the Palace; "The Fabulous Texan," at the Gotham, and "Shakuntala," the Indian-made drama at the Art on East Eighth Street.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 1 -Britons, after welcoming 1948 with as much traditional revelry as was possible in these austere times, faced the New Year with a quiet confidence.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The Department of Agriculture, contending that only "heartache" toh)0*0*0*ilawful persons was being accomplished, challenged Republicans in Congress today to stop the publication of the names of private speculators in commodities.

Following the custom that we observe each year, we present today the four recipes printed in this column during 1947 that proved most popular with our readers. A tally of the number of comments and requests for additional copies reveals that the formula for cheese cake that appeared last January not only heads the list for this year but has aroused greater interest than any other recipe we have ever offered.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 - Individual saving is America's "most potent weapon in combating inflation," John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, said today in a New Year's message to the country in which he urged every American who can do so to "set a goal of substantial savings for 1948."

In a few weeks the United Nations Appeal for Children will open its drive to "give one day's pay" -- or the equivalent in profits, professional earnings or agricultural crops -- to help feed and clothe the least guilty of persons who have suffered the most in war and peace.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- France, Italy and Austria have accepted all the conditions laid down by Congress in the Foreign (Interim) Aid Act of 1947 and will sign bilateral agreements with the United States on Friday, it was learned today.

A resolution calling for an investigation of charges that academic freedom has been violated in Argentina was adopted unanimously yesterday by the eastern division of the American Philosophical Association at a meeting in Columbia University.

Both output and earnings of the Chain Belt Company for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31 were the largest in the company's peacetime history, J. C. Merwin, president, reported in the annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

New bond flotations in December totaled $157,835,000, representing thirty-three issues, the smallest offering of bonds in the year. The total compared with $180,340,000 for forty-one issues in the preceding month and with $269,642,000 for twenty-four issues in December, 1946.

In observance of the New Year, all domestic, financial and commodity markets will be closed today. Most commodity markets were open yesterday only to noonh) 0*0*0*ifor business, the exception being the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, which was open for a full session.

Students at the New York University School of Law will have an opportunity to get needed practical experience in the offices of N.Y.U. alumni through a new onthe-job training program that will be set up today. The program is an extension of an experiment started at the Law School last January.

Devotion as well as revelry marked the passing of the old year and the advent of the new here last night as residents and visitors attended special religious services throughout the city. Despite travel and transportation difficulties, large crowds were present at Watch Night and other observances.
CAMDEN, N.Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -A 14-year-old eighth grade girl today won the "battle of the slacks" at Camden Central School.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Tomorrow's 'Gator Bowl football game is a publicity man's dream -- in a state where publicity men's dreams are colossal.

A study of the development of Japan's international role by Helen Mears will be published next summer by Houghton Mifflin under the title "Fit the Crime." Miss Mears is the author of "The Year of the Wild Boar," also about Japan.

Those partial to solemn and admonitory quotations like sic transit gloria can find rich inspiration in the fact that this new year marks the fiftieth anniversary of the final disappearance of one of the greatest conglomerations of people andh)0*0*0*iterritory ever brought under the rule of a single nation -- the Spanish Empire in the Americas.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Joseph Rhoden, chairman of the newspaper wage scale committee of Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, AFL, acknowledged before a Congressional subcommittee here today that the real reason the union insisted on a sixty-day cancellation clause in any contract it might sign with Chicago newspaper publishers was to permit enforcement of conditions banned by the Taft-Hartley labor law.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The first step toward revaluation of the French currency is under consideration by the Schuman Government, which is understood to have consulted Washington and to have found there a sympathetic reaction.
Trading in stocks in 1947 ended yesterday with prices almost on a level with the composite rate of Dec. 31, 1946.

In the fashion world, 1947 will be known for having introduced the "new look." Certainly in modern times no change has caused so much comment, favorable and unfavorable. It was the suddenness with which it burst upon an unprepared world that caused the excitement.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- At midnight tonight, Britain's vast railway system becomes public property. Tomorrow is "vesting day," when the Transport Act nationalizing railways, the London Passenger Transport Board, many canals and other adjuncts of the railroad system takes effect.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Charges that reduced working hours in Britain's shipyards have cut output by 33 per cent and increased absenteeism were made at Birkenhead yesterday by Sir Robert Johnson, chairman of Cammell Laird's, leading British shipbuilders.

The last commercial master phonograph recordings made with members of James C. Petrillo's American Federation of Musicians were impressed in wax yesterday up to within a few minutes before the contract between the union and 771 recording companies ended with the passing of 1947, at midnight.

A pair of goals that came within eleven seconds of each other in the third period gave the New York Rangers a comfortable margin of insurance in their National Hockey League game with the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night.

Although it was the largest in three months, the total of bonds called before maturity for payment in December was the smallest for the month since 1939. Last month's prepayments of $95,278,000, compared with $48,045,000 in the preceding month and $104,106,000 in December, 1946.

TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- Wartime Premier Hideke Tojo yesterday underwent his first two hours of cross examination at the hands of the Allied prosecution in his war crimes trial. By his answers from the witness stand he tried to draw this picture of himself:

More than 4,000 licensed and unlicensed members of three independent tanker unions have received 5 per cent cost-of-living wage increases from the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), it was announced here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 24:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg dispatched a letter tonight to Republican leaders of Michigan urging them not to boom him as the state's favorite son candidate for the Presidential nomination.

The Mendelson Kleinman Realty Corporation sold the five-story apartment building, also containing three stores, at 2327 Webster Avenue and 385 East 184th Street, the Bronx, to the 500 West 173d Street Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $56,000 and occupies a plot about 122 by 35 feet.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The Russians are planning the creation of a de facto government for all Germany, according to outstanding German politicians in close touch with the Soviet military administration. In the hope of accomplishing this coup d'etat, they do not intend to form a separate government in their own zone, it is said.

On Nov. 4 the voters of this state approved by a respectable margin a constitutional amendment permitting members of the Legislature to fix their own salaries. The vote was yes, 1,431,636, no 901,023. For many years the salary has been set by the Constitution at $2,500, a ridiculous anachronism under today's conditions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -The Reconstruction Finance Corporation reported to the President and Congress today that it would show a loss of $8,632,714,519 on its $9,313,736,531 outlay for defense and war programs.

The Central Greyhound Lines, Inc., of New York has purchased the entire block in Long Island City, Queens, bounded by Fortythird Avenue, Twelfth and Thirteenth Streets and Forty-third Road for use as a bus terminal. The Interstate Land Holding Company was the seller and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
Loading operations on New York piers were curtailed sharply yesterday as a result of Mayor O'Dwyer's edict on Tuesday thath)0*0*0*icleared the streets of nonessential commercial trucking.

LONDON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Britain will maintain the prices fixed for Empire tin, in the face of strong representations by Malayan producers that the increased levels announced a fortnight ago still were "too low," an informed Whitehall (Government) source reported tonight.

Volume sales in 1947 of gem diamonds were almost up to the 1946 peak, but stiffening sales resistance was shown to stones of threequarters carat and larger, according to results of a telegraphic survey made public yesterday by Baumgold Brothers, Inc., diamond cutters, 62 West Forty-seventh Street.
Gifts in memory of men and women killed by the Nazis were received yesterday by the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

John B. Kelly Jr., who attained rowing's equivalent of the "triple crown" by sweeping single sculls honors in the United States and Canadian championships and England's famed Henley regatta, yesterday was named as the 1947 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

The pace has been growing slower in the last twelve months for Mrs. Martha Hains Shepherd, a former slave of the British West Indies who prepared yesterday at the home of her daughter at 145 West 143d Street to celebrate today her 102d birthday.

Thirty-five hundred vehicles of all sorts were still marooned in snow-clogged side streets in the five boroughs, a police report showed yesterday. The condition, officials said, still hampered snowclearing forces as they began concentrating on side streets and isolated sections.

HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- A plenary session of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment voted today to cancel all meetings scheduled for tomorrow. The vote was taken over the strong protest of Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation.

Almost double the average snowfall occurred in this city in 1947, with the aid of the recent record snowstorm, the local Weather Bureau reported yesterday. During the year two new rainfall intensity records were set, new maximum temperatures were reached on ten days, and October was the warmest in the city's weather history.

For whatever else it may be worth recalling, 1947 was the year in which the United States broke all peacetime records for production. Income in terms of goods and services had a market value of $230 billions. Income of individuals and corporations also set a new peak for the twelve months at more than $200 billions.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The two Jewish immigrant ships, Pan Crescent and Pan York, which the British are going to intercept, are full of potential "fifth columnists," according to an authoritative source here. The 12,000 visaless Jews sailed from Varna, Bulgaria, it is believed here, and they are mostly hand-picked Communists or fellow travelers, with links to the Stern Gang.

Plans for expanding their wellknown restaurant business in the Times Square area were announced yesterday by Eugene and Celestine Leone, owners of Leone's at 239 West Forty-eighth Street, who have purchased for the purpose the adjoining Union Methodist Church and two houses at 227 to 237 West Forty-eighth Street.

Basement sections of department stores are showing steady increases in sales, largely reflecting the inflationary price trend. In recent months, these sections in some instances have shown larger percentage increases than the upstairs store.

NANKING, Dec. 31 President Chiang Kai-shek in his annual "State of the Nation" New Year's Eve address tonight stressed the necessity for redoubling efforts to suppress the Communists. He declared that the main Red forces must be annihilated within one year and admitted that it would take years more to wipe out the remnants.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 -Brought into line with requirements stipulated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the amended dissolution plan of Northh) 0*0*0*iWest Utilities, a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, was approved today by the commission.

A bit of sweet revenge came to Diehl Mateer Jr. at the University Club yesterday when he swept through three straight games against Russ C. Ball, West Point first classman, to become the tenth winner of the annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament.

The nine-story Knights of Columbus clubhouse at 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, has been purchased by the Friends of Columbus Council, Inc., from Hunter L. Delatour, referee. A mortgage loan of $300,000 was obtained from the East New York Savings Bank.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The grounds for the divorce of the United Mine Workers from the American Federation of Labor was incompatibility, according to the official explanation made public today.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Undefeated and untied Michigan, striving to make it two straight victories for the Western Conference over the Pacific Coast Conference, was poised -- as a 15point favorite -- for its Rose Bowl battle with Southern California's once-beaten, once-tied Trojans tomorrow.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Dec. 31 -- Rumania's newly proclaimed People's Republic passed its first day without visible disorder today, but it was becoming increasingly clear that what had been announced as the voluntary abdication of young King Michael was in fact a cold-blooded, Communistdictated coup d'etat against the monarchy.

A greatly intensified United States savings bond drive, tentatively scheduled to be launched in April, will be supported nationally by nearly $20,000,000 worth of newspaper, magazine and radio advertising over a three-month period, Philip Light, New York State director of the Treasury Department's Savings Bond division, stated yesterday.

Nathaniel Spector, manager of the Millinery Workers Union and labor member of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, announced yesterday that he would urge the establishment in the commission of a separate division to promote children's and teens' hats. By failing to exert such an effort heretofore, he said, the industry is faced with a tendency toward "hatlessness" on the part of future customers between the ages of 9 and 18.

The controversy over United States representation in ice hockey at the 1948 Winter Olympics, in which the United States Olympic Committee and the Amateur Athletic Union are aligned against the Amateur Hockey Association, continued yesterday.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Dec. 31 -The modern missionary is as much an expert in engineering, medicine, nutrition and education as he is a preacher, the Rev. Dr. Winburn Thomas, general secretary of the Student Volunteer Movement, told the North American Student Conference on Christian Frontiers tonight.

KALIBAKI, Greece, Dec. 31 -- A Greek rebel force that struck from the Albanian border in the early hours of Christmas Day was still pushing at the gates of this small but tactically important town today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A stupendous budget-slashing task appeared today to be shaping up for Congress in the new year if Republican pledges to cut individual income taxes were to be redeemed.h) 0*0*0*iO

There is a character in one of Gogol's novels who is harassed by this question: If elephants laid eggs what would be the color of their eggs? It is by asking such seemingly mad questions that the mathematical physicist of today arrives at valid conclusions about the universe and about atoms.

No review of Important Events of the Old Year would be complete without a mention of the flying saucers. At the time they made their appearance, more or less everywhere at once, it was hot enough to melt some of the mountains of snow behind which New York is hiding (and would that it was that hot again, if only for a day or two!).
BOSTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued these winter sports conditions and ski forecasts:

The first effort of the self-styled Greek Communist "government" to capture a capital and carve out a "state" for itself, and thereby provide some substance behind its shadow, appears to have suffered a major setback on both the military and the diplomatic fronts.

Despite the city's ban on nonessential traffic, deliveries of fuel oil were scarcely better than 30 per cent of normal yesterday. The cumulative effect of the slowdown caused by Friday's record snow was being felt in every borough.

If the facts about any given year, such as 1948, are compared with what optimists say on Jan. 1, there is almost always some discrepancy. But this is no reason why we should abolish optimistsh)0*0*0*ior why optimists should not be allowed the freedom of speech that is guaranteed to all citizens under the First Amendment to the Constitution of the United States.

Reading in Topics of the Times the glowing tribute to Romulo Gallegos President-elect of Venezuela, and his novel "Dona Barbara," I felt more than ever how applicable to acts of incomplete comprehension are the biblical words, "These things ought ye to have done, and not to have left the others undone!"

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Dec. 31 (AP) The president of the American Locomotive Company predicted today a record amount of railroad equipment would be produced in 1948 if manufacturers were "permitted to operate in a favorable economic climate."

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Dec. 31 (AP) -- An Air Force B-29 Superfortress, which appeared to be engulfed in "a blinding flash" two minutes after a take-off at 12:11 A.M., added nine more names today to Alaska's roll of missing airmen for the year's final week.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned easier yesterday and closed 1 point higher to 27 points net lowerh)0*0*0*ithan on Tuesday.

ATHENS, Dec. 31 -- The attempt by Greek Communists to seize Konitsa as a capital for their newly proclaimed "free state" has been beaten back by Greek Army troops, the Ministry of War announced today. Two columns of relief troops moved toward the embattled garrison before diminishing resistance.
DETROIT, Dec. 31 -- The Modern Language Association, with more than 2,000 members in attendance, reverted today to Shakespeare for the closing note of its sixty-second annual convention.

First degree murder convictions were returned yesterday against the three men accused of shooting Anthony Hintz, 43-year-old boss stevedore, in the hallway of his Greenwich Village apartment house last Jan. 8.

Substantial tax reductions are possible "only if Congress is willing to review periodically its major programs with a view toward contracting them as conditions change and the necessity no longer exists," The New York Trust Company states in its quarterly publication.

The annual tournament of the National Intercollegiate Chess League was concluded yesterday at John Jay Hall, Columbia University. An unfinished game from the seventh round of the individual championship was ended and an exhibition of simultaneous play by Herbert Seidman, ex-champion of the Marshall Chess Club, was put On.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach said today that the country's workers would rather have their real wages increased by means of lowered living costs rather than have a money increase "that soon will be wiped out by higher prices"

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Middlebury College swept three of the top six places in jumping contests today to win Sun Valley's annual national intercollegiate ski meet and displace the University of Utah as champion.

The liner Argentina was formally returned to Moore-McCormack Lines by the Maritime Commission last night for resumed operation between New York and the east coast of South America, marking final "separation" for the vessel from military service.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Harold Keller, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Commerce, predicted in a year-end statement today that 1948 would be "another prosperous year, tempered only by unpredictable inflationary influences which are countrywide."
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec, 31 (AP) -- The American Association of Geographers announced yesterday the election of Richard Joel Russell of Louisana State University as president for 1948.
Svend A. Schellenberg has been appointed sales manager for domestic sales of all products of American Apothecaries Company.

A few years ago we resolved to relate no more "unusual" hunting stories unless we were present to witness the circumstances, but one came across the table at a luncheon meeting of the Feather Dusters Club that seems too good to keep.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 31 - Micro-wave astronomy is being developed as an aftermath of advances in radar and radio reception techniques achieved during the war. At Cornell University a program is being set up specifically to carry on astronomical observations from thirty meters to three centimeters wave length, that is from low to high frequencies in the region of short wave radio.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The University of Kansas Jayhawkers and the Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets, who meet tomorrow in the fourteenth annual Orange Bowl football game before an estimated 60,000 fans, declared themselves physically and mentally prepared today for the battle ahead.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -Ted Schroeder, Davis Cup star from Glendale, Calif., deftly stroked to a dual singles and doubles title in the eleventh Sugar Bowl tennis tournament today, with a four-set victory over Richard (Pancho) Gonzales an a doubles triumph parred with Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, Fla.

Commercial truckers will be allowed to resume operations in the city's streets tomorrow at 7 A.M., but the ban on private automobiles "must continue until a later date," Mayor O'Dwyer announced late yesterday.

As most of the transportation systems serving the city made further gains yesterday in overcoming problems of the record snowstorm, J. Russel Sprague, Nassau County Executive, demanded a governmental investigation of the Long Island Rail Road.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The new account which started in the stock markets here today opened cheerfully with industrials showing allround strength as a result of reinvestment orders from sales of home rail stocks.

Thermionic, Inc., of which Victor O. Allen is president, has purchased the Park Instrument Company's plant at 76 Interhaven Avenue, North Plainfield, N.J. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker. The buying concern manufactures filaments for radio and television tubes.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Truman will carry his fight on high living costs to the coming session of Congress in a special economic message on Jan. 9, renewing his demand for revival of consumer rationing of staples in short supply and authority to fix price and wage ceilings.
Births in New York were at a record high in 1947, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard reported yesterday in his department's New Year's Eve summary of the year just ended.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Warren R. Austin, United States representative to the United Nations, announced today that no further proceedings would be taken against two United Nations correspondents, Syed Sibtay Hasan and Nicholas Kyriazidis, without consultation with Secretary General Trygve Lie.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31 - Reports received at the Veterans Bonus Bureau today from all over the state showed a "terrific rush" by veterans to obtain application forms for the bonus.

Requiring 46 moves to gain the success, Laszlo Szabo of Budapest recorded his third straight triumph in the international chess masters tournament by defeating Sir George Thomas, according to wordh)0*0*0*ireceived from Hastings, England, yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 The Democratic and Republican parties are locked in an all-out battle to capture the 14,000,000 war-veteran votes that can be cast in 1948 and, as the old year tolls out, it appears that the Republicans have made greater headway from an organizational viewpoint.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 31 (AP) -Southern Methodist University's explosive Mustangs pit their aerial circus against Penn State's stubborn Nittany Lions tomorrow in the twelfth annual Cotton Bowl classic.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 31 -While President Peron, his wife and the pro-Peron press tonight generally hailed Argentina's prospects for 1948, the Central Bank, which controls the nation's business and financial life, reported in some detail on the year's accomplishments and the principles whichh)0*0*0*ihad motivated them.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, received yesterday from the New York State Youth Commission a letter rebuking him for tactics said to have been employed by him in seeking additional state funds to maintain and expand the city's child-care center program.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- A report in this space last week of "serious discussions in industrial circles of voluntary measures to halt inflation" added that one such discussion might soon materialize in an announcement by a large corporation. It did yesterday when Mr. C. E. Wilson, president of General Electric, announced reductions of 3 to 10 per cent in the prices of electrical products in wide demand.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The presentation of evidence was completed today in the Federal Court trial here of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, accused by the government in a criminal information of violating the Lea Act. Mr. Petrillo did not testify.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 31 -- Killing in Palestine will mount to unpredictable pitch unless the British balk the United Nations partition decision, Emile Ghory, the most active leader of Arab nationalism inside Palestine said today during comparative lull in the Arab-Jewish clashes.
ALBANY, N.Y., Dec. 31 (AP) -New York's ski slopes were in good condition tonight for the New Year's holiday, but the weather forecast was none too promising.

RIP VAN-WINKLE once became entangled with bowls and it took him twenty years to extricate himself from his predicament. It could be a lesson to you. But New Year's Day is a pretty rugged day for learning lessons. So perhaps it's better to skip the entire idea. Let's merely establish the fact that this is the time when the football season either begins or ends -depending on which side of the telescope you're peering through.

New York University and Long Island Unversity will meet visitors from afar in tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The Violets, undefeated in seven games, will oppose Colorado in the curtainraiser at 8 P.M., with the Blackbirds facing Southern California in the nightcap.

WARSAW, Dec. 31 The Polish Parliament today passed its 1948 budget after a three-day debate in which unexpected opposition to the Government's economic, religious and educational programs was voiced by representatives of the Catholic and Democratic parties.

Women's apparel sales before and immediately following Christmas have held up exceptionally well despite predictions that the ratio of soft lines to total sales would show a sharp drop, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday.

It is now definite that "Power Without Glory," the London thriller which John C. Wilson and the Messrs. Shubert are sponsoring, will make its local debut at the Booth Theatre on Tuesday evening, Jan. 13. The play, written by Michael Clayton Hutton, began a two-week engagement at Boston's Wilbur Theatre last Tuesday.
ROME, Dec. 31 -- Pope Pius XII predicted today that 1948 would mark a turning point in the history of the world, and warned that "peace is indivisible."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Truman reaffirmed in a New Year's message today his belief that the world will achieve lasting peace and that the United Nations will insure it ultimately.

ROME, Dec. 31 -- The Communists suffered a setback today when Left-Wing Socialist labor representatives forced the adoption of a motion that grants the right to unions to decide individually whether they should support strikes called by the executive committee of General Federation of Labor (CGIL).

Joseph H. Schwartz has been granted extensions on three mortgage loans involving $1,575,000 at 3 1/2 per cent interest for five years on three properties that he controls. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank extended the loan of $800,000 on the twenty-three-story loft building at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Thirtyeighth Street, and the loan of $125,000 on the six-story loft building at 249-55 West Seventeenth Street and 242-48 West Eighteenth Street.

WASHINGTON. Dec. 31 -- James M. Landis today left the chairmanship of the Civil Aeronautics Board to become associated with Joseph P. Kennedy, financier, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James and, a decade ago, fellow member with Mr. Landis on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In a hockey match that provided good fun for players and spectators -- and furnished funds for a couple of camps for underprivileged boys -- St. Mark's School of Southborough, Mass., downed Choate School of Wallingford, Conn., 5 to 0, at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- During the period Dec. 25-30, member bank reserve balances increased $604,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

A New Year and its promise were greeted joyously last night by millions throughout the land. Into warm handclasps and exchanges, of greetings were packed a "good riddance" to a year of disappointment and a heartfelt wish for something better.

Henry A. Wallace, who announced that he would run for President on a third party ticket in a radio speech in Chicago Monday night, returned late yesterday afternoon from Milwaukee. He will go to his country home in South Salem, N.Y., to rest for a month before resuming his campaign.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 31 -Clarifying the announcement made yesterday that retailers would be protected against the 3 to 10 per cent price reduction in General Electric appliances, C. R. Pritchard, manager of marketing of the company's appliance and merchandise department today announced that price protection would be given only on major appliances, household vacuum cleaners and Automatic blankets.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Chester Bowles, chairman of the international advisory committee of the United Nations Appeal for Children, today urged Secretary General Trygve Lie to go ahead with the proposal for a world children congress.
CAIRO, Dec. 31 Former King Victor Emmanuel of Italy was buried today in Saint Catherine's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Alexandria after an impressive military funeral.

Joseph H. Schwartz has been granted extensions on three mortgage loans involving $1,575,000 at 3 1/2 per cent interest for five years on three properties that he controls. The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank extended the loan of $800,000 on the twenty-three-story loft building at the northwest corner of Eighth Avenue and Thirtyeighth Street, and the loan of $125,000 on the six-story loft building at 249-55 West Seventeenth Street and 242-48 West Eighteenth Street.

Henry A. Wallace, who announced that he would run for President on a third party ticket in a radio speech in Chicago Monday night, returned late yesterday afternoon from Milwaukee. He will go to his country home in South Salem, N.Y., to rest for a month before resuming his campaign.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 31 -Clarifying the announcement made yesterday that retailers would be protected against the 3 to 10 per cent price reduction in General Electric appliances, C. R. Pritchard, manager of marketing of the company's appliance and merchandise department today announced that price protection would be given only on major appliances, household vacuum cleaners and Automatic blankets.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Chester Bowles, chairman of the international advisory committee of the United Nations Appeal for Children, today urged Secretary General Trygve Lie to go ahead with the proposal for a world children congress.
CAIRO, Dec. 31 Former King Victor Emmanuel of Italy was buried today in Saint Catherine's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Alexandria after an impressive military funeral.
American industry, by almost doubling pre-war production, has taken the pinch out of high prices, the incoming president of the National Association of Manufacturers declared over the holiday.
Second in a series of articles giving the views of leading designers to the changing fashion picture and the outlook for 1948:

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 1 -- Even snow removal can be overdone, it has been discovered in Ottawa, which prides itself on the way it keeps its streets clean during the winter. Recently the city purchased new equipment and has been using it enthusiastically.

A sustained level of activity throughout 1948, bulwarked by the high level of the national income, is envisioned by leaders in the women's and children's coat and suit manufacturing field, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Operating under Government scrutiny and the unrelenting pressure of unprecedented industrial demand, the domestic steel industry in 1947 answered the trying challenge with its most notable peacetime performance. Not only were production records shattered, but steel-making facilities were so improved and expanded that the new year brings promise of even greater achievement.

ROANOKE, Va., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Federal Judge John Paul has ruled that a public carrier has the right to establish its own rules providing for the separate seating of white and Negro passengers where such separation is in line with local custom.

The New York Telephone Company concluded its most trying and successful year in 1947. Surpassing all records of its fifty-one years of existence, the company, which serves New York City and most of New York State, added 410,000 telephones.

In the first full year of production following the end of Government controls, producers of rayon and other synthetic fabrics attained new high levels of production, it was pointed out by Irene Blunt, secretary of the National Federation of Textiles in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The University of Mississippi came from behind with two great touchdown passes today to defeat Texas Christian, 13 to 9, and write a story-book finish to the first Delta Bowl game before some 28,800 spectators.
The year 1947 brought to the market for prime securities confirmation of what its predecessor had hinted -- that the depression-born bull market in bonds at least had come to an end.

A concert in memory of Bessie Smith, celebrated Negro blues singer, was presented by the Friends of Jazz last night at Town Hall for the benefit of the United Negro and Allied Veterans of America. Many noted jazz players and singers, some of whom appeared with Miss Smith in clubs and on records. took part in the program, which was given under the direction of Bernard Katz.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Thirty-two United States seamen, survivors of the 7,607-ton United States ship Park Victory which sank in the Gulf of Finland on Christmas morning, left London airport in a Pan American Clipper for New York tonight.
SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Twenty persons were dead, scores injured and hunderds homeless tonight, victims of tornadoes which skipped furiously over five Southern states yesterday and today.

The year 1947 will go down in financial history as one in which a verbal battle raged between two opposing schools of thought over the presence of a "bull" or "bear" market. Neither force was able to claim victory at the year's close, although THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty combined stocks had indicated on two distinct occasions that the market had reached its limit.
A preliminary estimate by the National Lumber Manufacturers Association places 1947 lumber production at 34,000,000,000 board feet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The final report of President Truman's Air Safety Board recommends that all airlines be required to have a full time safety director subject only to the highest company official, it was learned today.

Business activity in 1947 was the greatest in the peacetime history of the United States, according to The Associated Press review. Following are the year's statistical highlights, all peacetime records:

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 1 -- New Year's Day in India -- the first that this country has experienced as an independent nation -- dawned on a somber situation. The new Dominions of India and Pakistan are again approaching the edge of war after a short period when it seemed that their differences might be settled around the conference table.

ROME, Jan. 1 -- The new Constitution of the Italian Republic went into effect today. At the end of an extraordinary Cabinet meeting, the Italian Government announced it had selected the Quirinal Palace, which had belonged to the House of Savoy, as the official residence of the President of the Republic.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Senate inquiry into oil exports, centering around reports that military supplies are being diverted to foreign aid programs, is due to open Monday.
LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Declaring today that 1948 would be "a year of test for the British people," Sir Stafford Cripps said he retained his faith in their capacity to work out their own salvation.

Despite setting of record peacetime high output levels in chemical industries, some industry members inclined toward a pessimistic view of 1948 as the year ended, spokesmen said. The 1947 production of chemicals reached a rate estimated to be about 150 per cent above the pre-war average while chemical exports were reported at about three times the total for 1941, the last peacetime year.
