Machine tool builders are entering the new year with sales on an upward trend after operating during 1947 at the rate of about $300,000,000 per year, roughly half of the industry capacity, Tell Berna, general manager, the National Machine Tool Builders Association, Cleveland, revealed here yesterday in a statement to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins broke a five-game losing streak by toppling the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, as they hit the halfway mark of their sixty-game National Hockey League schedule tonight before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

With all the current discussion by the gray-bearded sportsmen concerning the "good old days," it was rather refreshing to get a letter from Roy S. Tinney of Brielle, N.J., enclosing a quotation on the hunting of "yesterday."

YANINA, Greece, Jan. 1 -- News that Konitsa, attacked by the rebels on Christmas Day and since then under siege, had been relieved by a Greek Regular Army column, was announced here late last night about the time people were seeing in the New Year.

NANKING, Jan. 1 -- A "Cominform" for the Far East was proposed by Mao Tse-tung, chairman of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, in a Christmas Day report to a meeting of the Central Committee somewhere in North China.

DETROIT, Jan. 1 -- Immediate delivery on new automobiles in all but the lower priced bracket is one of the cheering prospects for 1948. Manufacturers still report the demand is far ahead of the industry's ability to produce, but dealers in both new and used cars anticipate that the buyer's market will return by midsummer.

While low-priced stocks in 1947 as in recent years, were the mediums of large-scale trading, it was noticeable that the level of prices was slightly higher than in former years in the list of twenty most active issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

TOKYO, Jan. 1 -- For the first time in Japanese history about 200,000 commoners were permitted today to cross celebrated "double" bridge and enter the precincts of the Imperial Palace to pay New Year's respects to Emperor Hirohito -- a privilege formerly reserved to the highest-ranking Japanese officials.

ATHENS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Greek General Staff communique tonight said the column of troops that relieved the Konitsa garrison entered the town about 8 o'clock last night. A second Regular Army relief column still was held up by rebel fire at the Borozani Bridge eleven miles west of Konitsa and close to the Albanian border.

A three-year program of French exploration in polar regions at the top and bottom of the earth was outlined yesterday by Paul-Emile Victor, head of the projects, who is visiting this country to obtain American help in his ventures.

Confidence that retail trade will continue strong during the first half of 1948 marks the opening of the new year. Consumer purchasing is expected to remain at high levels in this period, buttressed by peak employment, utilization of savings and further expansion in retail credit. Many merchants, however, feel that sales may level off later in the year.

SEDALIA, Mo., Jan. 1 -- Fourteen holiday travelers, including a family of five persons, were killed today when a Missouri Pacific mail and express train rammed into the rear sleeping car of a passenger train during a blinding snowstorm fifteen miles east of here today.

Zionist leaders here were quick to deny yesterday charges made by a British spokesman in London on Wednesday that the two Jewish immigrant ships, the Pan York and the Pan Crescent, on their way to Palestine from Bulgaria, were full of potential "fifth columnists."

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Western democracies were warned against the spread of communism in Asia by Gen. Ho Ying-chin, wartime Chief of Staff of the Chinese Army, in an address to the Moral Rearmament Assembly here this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A field goal by Bob McKillop in the final 30 seconds climaxed a rally by Santa Clara University that washed out a 13-point Temple University lead and gave the Galloping Broncos a 62-to-60 victory tonight in the second game of a basketball double-header at Convention Hall before 5,673.

Manufacturers of farm equipment had highly successful production in 1947, according to Joseph W. Frazer, chairman and president of the Graham-Paige Motors Corporation. However, he said, the domestic and foreign demand for American agricultural machinery is so great that the market for these products will be only partly satisfied, even if output reaches capacity in 1948.
Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., stressed the need for lower prices in a year-end statement made public over the holiday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- An alert Texas team, led by the versatile Bobby Layne, completely outclassed Alabama here today in the fourteenth annual Sugar Bowl football classic to rack up a decisive 27-7 victory.

Fibber McGee and Molly are presently enjoying top favor among listeners to evening radio entertainment, according to the latest computations of the C.E. Hooper organization. The risible pair have unseated Jack Benny from the lead in this particular evaluation of popularity, sending him to second place.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Arkansas Razorbacks came from behind twice to win a 21-19 decision over William and Mary's Southern Conference champions in the inaugural Dixie Bowl football game before a crowd of 21,000 today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Now that Henry A. Wallace has retired for a month of goldfish privacy and comment on his independent candidacy for President has slackened temporarily, it seems to this correspondent that several points which deserve mention have been slighted.

The Tennessee Valley Authority's annual report, made public on the last day of the old year, continues a story of material progress that the bitterest enemies of public power systems cannot question. Fifteen years ago the Valley people's average per capita income was only 40 per cent of the national average -- now it is 58 per cent.
MOSCOW, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Moscow newspapers predicted new victories during 1948 for countries and peoples of the "anti-imperialist camp" in their New Year articles today.

RONNE ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION BASE, STONINGTON ISLAND, Marguerite Bay, Dec. 29 (Delayed) -- The Ronne geological sledge party returned to this base three days ago after a ninety-day trail journey, twenty-two full days of which were spent entirely on geological research.

Improvement in the supply of steel to small users through services of independent steel distributors is a major problem carried over from 1947 to 1948, Morris Rosoff, general counsel for the Association of Steel Distributors, Inc., revealed here this week.

Two outstanding factors will shape American foreign trade in 1948 -- the Marshall plan, which will give a "shot-in-the arm" to exports, and the favorable influence on imports of tariff reductions ranging up to 50 per cent which became effective yesterday under the Geneva reciprocal trade pacts.

With business activity in most major lines expected to continue at a high level although the future is clouded by uncertainty of prices and the international situation, New York City's manufacturers view the outlook for 1948 as "fair" to "very good."
Excerpts from the report of the research staff of the Temporary Commission on the Need for a State University follow:

Domestic bituminous coal production achieved a new peacetime high in 1947 when the total should approximate 615,000,000 net tons after final figures have been tabulated, John D. Battle, executive secretary of the National Coal Association, revealed in his review of the year's output.

Production capacity of paperboard and paper, other than newsprint, will be adequate in 1948 to make over 22,000,000 tons "should that be the level of demand," according to a forecast by Dr. Louis T. Stevenson, economist of the American Paper and Pulp Association.

For the first time in decades, the wool industry in 1947 experienced a demand for worsteds diametrically opposed to that for woolens, according to a summation of the outstanding developments of the industry prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 1 -- Elmer H. Wene, State Senator from Cumberland County and former member of Congress, is the choice of former Mayor Frank Hague, State Democratic chairman, as the Democratic Gubernatorial candidate in 1949.

The inflationary tendencies evident in our national economy continue unabated, Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., says in a statement reviewing 1948 retail prospects. The company operates stores in New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Milwaukee, Saks 34th Street and Saks Fifth Avenue, with branches in Chicago, Detroit, Miami Beach, Palm Beach and Beverly Hills.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Government officials are perturbed by London fears that many of the persons on board the Pan Crescent and the Pan York are actual and potential "fifth columnists."

A happy-go-lucky lot, showmen are plagued the year round by various problems, not the least of which is the financial one. Of course, they are inured to a hazardous game depending on the whims of a fickle public and a no less temperamental Dame Fortune.
Heralding the New Year, donors sent gifts yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Fund. With a $1 donation came the greeting:
There were fifteen angry prospective bridegrooms in the city last night.

Confusion and contrast marked the year 1947. Where a recession in industrial activity had been predicted, record-breaking production took place. There was more industrial peace -- and more inflation. The stock market, usually a good barometer of business, failed for the most part to reflect the exceptionally favorable earnings and dividend payments by corporations. Politics -- national and international -- were dominating influences on public thinking.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A gaily attired holiday crowd of 15,863 was on hand to witness the annual morning racing program at Gulfstream Park today and saw Alfred Klee's King Midas drive to a length triumph in the Singing Tower Handicap.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 1 -- A customs tariff agreement linking the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg came into being today after twenty years of effort to draw this important bloc of 18,000,000 persons into the initial stage of full economic union.

The dark clouds that poured their wrath into the Blizzard of 1947 are beginning to disclose at least one silver lining. Our storm should discourage the annual orgy of chill fact and nostalgic mythology concerning the Blizzard of 1888. What can survivors of that earlier mishap, each by his own account a Paul Bunyan in those mighty drifts, possibly say to top our 25.8-inch fall of snow?

Unit production by the radio industry in 1948, with the exception of television and FM-AM receivers, is expected to experience a decrease compared with 1947, according to Max F. Balcom, president of the Radio Manufacturers Association.

The first American performance of Arthur Honegger's "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher" (Joan of Arc at the Stake) took place last night in Carnegie Hall. It is a brilliant score, and it was brilliantly presented. What is the work to be called? It is a musico-dramatic form which Honegger has especially cultivated, and which, at the suggestion of the dancer, Ida Rubinstein, he no doubt outlined to the poet, Paul Claudel.

GENEVA, Jan. 1 -- Some 1,600 Russian Mennonite refugees, descendants of a people who have been wanderers for 400 years, will be moved from German camps to Paraguay early this year by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization.

That 1948 advertising budgets will show a substantial increase over 1947 -- an estimated average of 10 per cent -- is a matter of cause-and-effect in the light of undimmed business prospects, according to a year-end survey of advertiser and agency representatives. Dominant question in the new year of advertising, one that is perturbing those executives who dole out return per high-cost-of-advertising the dollars, is how to get a greater dollar.

Although curtailment of buying of knitted outerwear in the early half of the year did not produce the results that buyers hoped for, it enabled the industry to liquidate a substantial portion of its inventories, Sidney S. Korzenik, executive director and counsel of the National Knitted Outerwear Association, pointed out in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

New York City and its suburbs, finally on the road to recovery yesterday from last Friday's record snowfall, were once more in serious straits last night and early today as a severe ice storm swept the area.

Carpet production figures for 1947 will range between 66,000,000 and 68,000,000 yards, an increase of approximately 30 per cent over the 52,000,000 yards produced in 1946, according to Merrill A. Watson, president of the Carpet Institute, Inc.

HOT SULPHUR SPRINGS, Col., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A Denver motorist was shot and killed today by a hitchhiker who was believed, during a chase lasting several hours, to be James Sherbondy, 29-year-old mountain murderer and the last of twelve hardened criminals who escaped from the Colorado State Prison on Tuesday.

Preliminary estimates by many industry leaders place over-all 1947 homefurnishings volume at between $6,000,000,000 and $9,000,000,000, an all-time record. Several spokesmen described the latter figure as somewhat high, but all agreed that the previous peak of $6,000,000,000 in 1946 has been exceeded.

Records featured developments in the petroleum industry last year. In virtually every division new high levels of activity were reached. Crude oil production was at a peak both here and abroad. Demand reached unprecedented heights, exceeding those of the war, when some 1,600,000 barrels daily of petroleum products were being sent to the armed forces.
DALLAS, Tex., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Penn State's Nittany Lions spotted Southern Methodist two touchdowns, then fought doggedly for a 13-13 tie here today in the twelfth annual Cotton Bowl football game.

Although final figures are not yet in, it is relatively safe to state that 1947 has proved a record year in the men's and boys' shirt and pajama industry, both in volume of unit production and in dollar sales, M. J. Lovell, director of the National Association of Shirt and Pajama Manufacturers, states in a review prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Although $164,500,000 of new foreign dollar bonds were floated in this market during 1947 by Australia, Netherlands, Sydney County Council, and Norway, repatriation and purchases from abroad have more than halved the market supply of pre-war years.

HAVANA, Jan. 1 -- Despite the deadlock on the issue of quantitative restrictions on trade and other difficult problems posed by economically undeveloped countries seeking special protection for their industrialization programs, the United Nations' conference on trade and employment is making progress in some directions.
Snow-covered Central Park is a winter playground with outdoor sports in full swing. Boys and girls are coasting down Pilgrim Hill and Boat House Hill at Seventy-second Street and East Drive.
Service in and out of Grand Central Terminal was disrupted for several hours yesterday morning when the power failed in the third-rail feeder system of the tunnels.
LAWRENCE, Kan., Jan. 1 -- The modern Christian missionary must carry the teachings of Christ into every field of human endeavor, from international politics to the lowliest vocation.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Autocrat, a 24-1 long shot, owned by Bert Baroni and Tony Battilana of Arcadia, won the $50,000 added San Carlos Handicap, feature race at Santa Anita today.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 1 -- Soviet Army troops stationed in North Korea are undergoing an intensified training and "toughening up" program, according to evidence accumulated by highly qualified observers here.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 1 -- Delegates to the Methodist Youth Conference were urged today to study the facts about alcohol and to talk, think and live total abstinence.

Office equipment industry members expect that their future sales volume will continue on a much higher basis than before the war, John A. Zellers, vice president of Remington Rand, Inc. disclosed here over the holiday. The final figures of production and sales for 1947 are likely to show that this has been the best year for office equipment in the history of the industry, he said.

TAUNGS, Cape Province, South Africa, Dec. 21 -- The discovery of fossil remains of three new types of extinct human beings, together with crude artifacts that reveal knowledge of their ancient culture, was announced here today by Prof. Charles L. Camp, head of the University of California South African Expedition.
The year 1948 will be a testing period for the nation as a whole and for the industrial and financial segments in particular.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 (AP) -- With their greatest display of cheers, back-slapping, hugging and yelling of the year, the mighty men of Michigan expressed their joy today after their superb exhibition of football. It was an exhibition which wrote a new page in Rose Bowl history and left Southern California bewildered.

A harbor strike that would cut off 90 per cent of the city's fuel oil supplies continued last night as a possibility despite an agreement reached early yesterday between tugboat operators and union spokesmen at City Hall.

As 1948 begins, the monetary authorities, both Government and private, continue their uncertain efforts to control the inflationary spiral. Formal consideration of the problem has produced nothing more than an intensification of the program initiated earlier in the year and the more radical proposals have produced little concrete action, bogging down on questions of method and degree.

Although production of primary aluminum last year exceeded the billion-pound mark for the first time since 1944, the industry still is hard pressed to meet the demand, Donald M. White, secretary of the Aluminum Association, stated in his year-end review.

For the first time since the Securities Act and the Securities Exchange Act went into effect in the Thirties, underwriting houses in 1947 endeavored, with the acquiescence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to use the distributive machinery of their business to place stock with investors concurrently with preferential offering of the same issue to shareholders of the issuing company.
I have read with great interest your editorial of Dec. 25 on the Panama Canal, the final paragraph of which is the most significant.

Following a year of significant production and price trends, the outlook for 1948 is viewed with critical concern by tanners and shoe manufacturers. According to Irving R. Glass, executive vice president of the Tanners' Council of America, the immediate problems of these industries are directed toward consumer acceptance of retail shoe prices.

Office management executives throughout the country began in 1947 a comprehensive program aimed at greater efficiency in production and improving morale of rank-and-file office personnel, by setting up more pleasant working conditions.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- St. Lawrence University of Canton, N.Y., which became the first New York State school to carry off Lake Placid Club Sno Birds' tournament honors in twenty-six years last season, repeated today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- Senate investigators fixed today an unofficial deadline of next Monday for Edwin W. Pauley to produce his personal records on commodity market speculation.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Holders of shares in the British railway systems that became nationalized today will receive in exchange a British Transport 3 per cent guaranteed stock, to mature 1978 to 1988, issued at par and redeemable at par, the Treasury announced tonight.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 (AP) -- A mass attempt to break the Palestine blockade partly succeeded today when between 500 and 700 Jewish immigrants waded ashore from a beached ship while the British were busy herding more than 11,000 passengers from two other vessels into Cyprus detention camps.

When the United States signs today bilateral agreements with France, Italy and Austria granting $522,000,000 in interim emergency aid to help them through a crucial winter, it will initiate an undertaking which, when carried through to its logical conclusion, should stand out as one of the finest examples of enlightened statesmanship in history.

Shattering all previous records, earnings of the nation's industrial manufacturers climbed last year to unprecedented levels. Production and business volumes in a few industries will expand somewhat, but a contraction in profits generally is anticipated for 1948. Capacity operations in most industries, together with such factors as inventory profits and carry-back tax credits, which contributed substantially to the striking results, will not figure in this year's account.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that time-study men were professional employes and were entitled to union recognition and Government protection as provided by the Taft-Hartley Law.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Dr. Luis Padilla Nervo, Mexican representative to the United Nations, is the leading candidate for chairman of the Little Assembly, which will convene here next Monday, it was learned today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Medical researchers and the pharmaceutical industry have teamed up to search for cures for the diseases which still baffle medical science.

Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange, in 1947, amounted to 253,623,894 shares, the smallest total since 1942. In the preceding year, the volume was 363,709,312 shares and, in the record year of 1929, it was 1,124,990,980 shares.

PEORIA, Ill., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Bradley University's basketball team won its thirteenth game in fourteen starts and completed a victory-sweep of the Ivy League tonight by defeating Princeton, 64 to 41. The Braves previously had defeated Harvard and Yale.

A correspondent from the region of Chesapeake Bay reminds us that, though the shooting war is suspended so far as the United States and their possessions are concerned, one port within our continental limits is still blockaded by armed forces.

The Port of New York Authority filed a brief yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington protesting the inclusion of export, import, coastwise and intercoastal traffic in the proposed increase in railroad freight rates in less-than-carload lots in the Central, Middle Atlantic and New England States.

Bing Crosby has been voted the top money-making star of moviedom for the fourth consecutive year in the annual poll of motion-picture theatre owners and operators conducted by The Motion Picture Herald, trade publication. Crosby thus becomes the all-time box-office champion among male stars and equals the unique record established by Shirley Temple at the height of her popularity as a child star.
Two years of transition from a wartime to a peacetime economy have brought to Wall Street the realization that economic normalcy is still several years away.

The toilet goods industry has reached the year's end in appreciably better condition than it entered 1947, S.L. Mayham, executive director of the Toilet Goods Association, reports in a review prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. The industry, he said, looks forward to 1948 with great confidence.

Eight important forward steps were taken by industrial management executives during 1947, Alvin E. Dodd, president, the American Management Association, 330 West Forty-second Street, revealed here yesterday. These tend to reduce the "time-lag" between important scientific discoveries and their practical application by business, he explained.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 1 -- Albert D. Cash, an attorney, was elected Mayor of Cincinnati by the City Council today for the term ending Dec. 31, 1949. He is the first Democrat to head the city government in thirty-five years and the first member of the Charter party to be Mayor since 1933.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Appellate Division, Fourth Department, yesterday ordered transferred to the Third Department an appeal by a Buffalo taxpayer of a State Supreme Court decision upholding the constitutionality of a $128,000 state housing grant to a sectarian college.

Changes in the liquor industry in 1947 have resulted in the year becoming "a major turning-point" for the industry, Arthur D. Schulte, president of Park Tilford, Inc., pointed out in a year-end review. The year's most significant changes, he said were a deepening of brand consciousness among consumers, resulting in an acceleration of the trend toward nationally advertised brands and a revival of intense competition among distillers.

BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- Members of Local No. 25 of the Teamsters Union, American Federation of Labor, ignoring pleas of union officials, voted today to go on strike immediately. The action affects 6,000 men.
The city's fuel distributors fought a losing battle yesterday in an effort to catch up with the backlog of shortages and orders from apartment houses and homes.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- One lynching and "six borderline cases" during 1947 were listed by Tuskegee Institute today in its annual report.

Disturbed by the third-party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace, right-wing elements in the State Congress of Industrial Organizations plan to quit the American Labor party and form a state branch of the CIO Political Action Committee, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Active volunteer participation by the people in the communities throughout the United States in a program to explain American Democracy to Communist-threatened Europe will be recommended to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee as it resumes consideration of the "Voice of America" bill early this month.

As 1947 ended representative manufacturers of men's suits had sold up their production solidly on an allotment basis through June of 1948, according to the review of the men's clothing industry prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Jerome I. Udell of Max Udell, Sons Co.

NANKING, Jan. 1 -- The American-trained and equipped New First and New Sixth Armies, which once were rated as the best Chinese field forces, have been broken up by the Nationalist command in Manchuria, it was learned today.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- On the heels of the ban by the Musicians' Union on playing for performances relayed over the British Broadcasting Corporation's network unless the fees are raised, British Equity, the actors' trade union, came out today with a demand that BBC should pay more for broadcasts direct from theatres.

The outlook for 1948 indicates continuance of the inflation which has led to prices higher than the public and retailers like, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said in a year-end statement. He added: Apparently, the fact that inflation primarily springs from the policies of government, and not from business, is coming into wider recognition.
VIENNA, Dec. 23 -- Two and a half years after the war's end the wounds of Europe are still festering hate and draining refugees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Congress action on the Marshall plan may be delayed two months beyond the Administration's April 1 deadline, Chairman Charles A. Eaton of the House Foreign Affairs Committee predicted today.

A social study of America by Prof. Harold J. Laski, British economist and leader in the Labor party, will be published by Viking in April. The 800-page book has been titled "The American Commonwealth.

Except in the matter of profits, last year was a period of conspicuous achievement for the nation's airlines. Passenger and Cargo traffic spurted ate new peaks and the industry's seat capacity jumped to a new record level.

BANGKOK, Siam, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Siamese Defense Ministry ended today the state of emergency that has existed since Field Marshal Pibul Songgram, wartime dictator during the Japanese occupation, overthrew the existing Government last Nov. 9.

A "vast reservoir" of private investment capital exists that can be tapped for industrial development and expansion in European countries and elsewhere if conditions are created which will encourage the investment of such capital, the National Foreign Trade Council said in a statement issued for publication today.

A strong defense of the Long Island Rail Road, which he said had made "a remarkable record" in the aftermath of the record snowstorm, was advanced last night by A. F. McIntyre, general manager of the road.
PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Nevada spotted North Texas State six points then cut loose with its passing attack to win the first annual Salad Bowl football game, 13 to 6, before 12,500 fans today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 1 -- Alan H. Posner, New York broker, and Walter Compton and Samuel X. Abarbanel, motion-picture publicists, have established a new independent film-producing company under the name Eronal and have contracted with Film Classics for the distribution of their first venture, "The Argyle Album."

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The immigrants packed into two 4,500-ton ships offered no resistance to unarmed British marines who boarded the vessels when their five-day voyage from the Black Sea port of Burgas ended today at Famagusta.

Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, has issued a plea to Congressional investigating committees to call a halt to the publication of the names of individuals speculating in commodities. The proceedings against which he protests stem from charges that Administration "insiders" have been profiting from their knowledge of the Government's buying plans, particularly with respect to wheat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- American labor has just completed a year of full employment, but with little gain in real wages or in living standards, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today in a summary of 1947 developments.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Army Chief of Staff, is reported by close associates to be on the verge of closing a deal for his wartime memoirs for an amount "in excess of $500,000."

CANNELTON, Ind., Jan. 1 (AP) -- The Indiana-Kentucky "sorghum feud" ended today in a tie. Five judges who witnessed the contest between disputing newspaper editors from Perry County. Ind., and Hancock County, Ky., announced this decision:

Despite a record year of production and distribution in durable goods in 1947, manufacturers of machinery, tools, metal products, industrial equipment and construction equipment reported individually that 1948 would bring increased sales competition in almost all lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Gift to the Philadelphia Board of Education of the nationally known Widener Memorial School for Crippled Children, on the southeast corner of Broad Street and Olney Avenue, was viewed today by city officials as providing space for a "much-needed and much-discussed city college."

JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 -- The Palestine Government now considers it in the best general interest that the mandate should end sooner than May 15, provided that the United Nations commission agrees, and it is possible that the date may be advanced by about six weeks.

Preliminary steps taken to develop a flow of suitable immigration into Canada should be included in any survey of the 1947 achievements of the Canadian Pacific Railway, W. M. Neal, chairman and president of the company, said in his annual year-end statement, issued yesterday.

Continued scarcities and large demand marked metal markets at the close of the year, with extremely active buying from both foreign and domestic sources pushing prices toward upward revisions in both ferrous and non-ferrous lines, trade sources revealed. But supplies had improved over January, 1947.

The nation's railroads last year moved the greatest volume of freight for any equal peacetime period. However, increased costs of operation absorbed the benefits that normally would have accrued from such record traffic, with the result that net earnings for the second year in succession generally were unsatisfactory.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 1 -- City Hall here is the scene of a huge reception each New Year's Day, as city job and contract holders and members of their families line up to shake the hands of the City Commissioners and be remembered among the faithful.

Allow me to answer the lengthy cable from Dmitry Shisheyev, chief engineer of the Ordjonikidze Machine Tool Plant, Moscow, U.S.S.R., branding your recent article on income and expenditures by Soviet citizens as misleading and inaccurate.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Alexander W. Weddell were en route to Tucson, Ariz., where they planned to stay for "several months" on doctor's orders. Friends of the family said Mrs. Weddell, a native of Edina, Mo., had been in ill health for some time.

Entering 1948, the outstanding question before the American food industry is: How much higher can prices go? With butter at a dollar a pound or better, eggs nearing a dime apiece., and beefsteak a mere memory to many persons, the question is one that affects not only every consumer but more directly the fourteen million among the sixty million employed persons who are engaged directly with the growing, processing and distribution of food.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- This year will be the turning point in the German economic recovery with certain currency reform and bizonal exports twice as great as in 1947, according to Don R. Humphrey, deputy director of the economics division of the United States Military Government.

TOLEDO, Jan. 1 -- Seton Hall bested the University of Toledo tonight in a duel between undefeated basketball teams. The Pirates, registering their seventh straight triumph, ended the nine-game winning streak of the Rockets by a 54-43 score.

Laszlo Szabo of Budapest scored his fourth consecutive victory in the international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to a report from Hastings, England, yesterday.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Missouri Valley College powered its way to a 26-7 victory over West Chester (Pa.) State Teachers College in the second annual Cigar Bowl football game today.

Few citizens remembered the golden anniversary of Greater New York yesterday. On the eve of Jan. 1, 1898, thousands jammed City Hall Park as a flag was run up to mark the consolidation of the five boroughs into what was then the second largest city on earth.

Since Jersey Joe Walcott came so close to dethroning Joe Louis, interest in the younger crop of heavyweights has been extraordinarily high. So high, in fact, that the Twentieth Century S.C. has arranged an all-heavyweight boxing program for Madison Square Garden tonight.

A vastly expanded system of higher education for New York State, to include facilities for doubling the student body, is recommended by the research staff of the Temporary Commission on the Need for a State University. State-supported medical, dental, nursing and graduate schools are proposed, it became known yesterday.

America's economic position, industrially, is more vulnerable than it was a year ago, George A. Renard, executive secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, revealed here yesterday in a review of 1947 industrial purchasing developments.

In a novel approach to the requirements of the Taft-Hartley Law, Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes International Union, AFL, announced yesterday that it would ask for union-shop elections before negotiating with Manhattan building owners for higher wages and other contract improvements.

Casting two more votes in favor of eastern basketball, N.Y.U. and L.I.U. took the measure of Colorado and Southern California, respectively, in the holiday twin bill before 18,115 fans at Madison Square Garden last night. The Violets, boosting their season's unbeaten string to eight, downed the Golden Buffaloes, 59 -- 46, while the Brooklyn Blackbirds fashioned a 44-41 victory over the Trojans.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Georgia Tech's Engineers beat the Kansas Jayhawkers, 20 -- 14, in the Orange Bowl here today as the Jayhawkers tossed their golden opportunity out of the window in the final two minutes of play.

Sidney Schwartz, University of Miami freshman, bade a fond farewell to junior tennis competition yesterday by capturing the national indoor singles title at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Schwartz registered a victory over Grant Golden of Chicago and Northwestern by 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, in the final.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Princess Anne of Bourbon-Parma said in an interview today that she was completely in love with Michael, who abdicated as King of Rumania, and "wherever he goes, I will follow him."

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A great Maryland football team outfought Georgia for three periods in the Gator Bowl today -- but settled for a 20-to-20 tie against a bulldog comeback that all but won the game.

The majority vote in business as the New Year begins is that the light will stay green for at least the first half of 1948. This is in distinct contrast to the vote of a year ago when there was so much talk of a possible recession. So business thinking is bolder and, possibly, because the forecasts of last year went wrong except to a minor degree.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Putting on a last-minute surge, the Wilberforce Green Wave defeated the Grambling Tigers, 27 to 21, in the seventh annual Vulcan Bowl game today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Owen J. Roberts, former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, proposes that the United States organize a transatlantic union of the democracies in a program for peace and recovery.

Though there is probably enough left over of the New Year's ham to supply all of this meat that will be wanted for the next few days, those who were particularly fond of the Polish ham that used to be available here before the war will be pleased to know that Macy's and Altman's have just received the first shipment to arrive in this country in several years.

To what extent the Government will attempt to control and regulate credit is the question uppermost in the minds of business executives at present, according to Henry H. Heimann, executive manager, National Association of Credit Men.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Despite a drenching rain, which thinned their ranks and weighed down their carnival capes, nearly 5,000 mummers marched up Broad Street today in their traditional New Year's Day parade before 250,000 spectators.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- A freezing rainstorm accompanied by wind gusts of 50 and 60 miles an hour today paralyzed traffic and communications, wrecked radio towers and store windows, uprooted trees and brought about seven automobile deaths and hundreds of accidents.

Looking back on the unresolved business problems of 1947, Theodore R. Gamble, president of the Theatre Owners of America, declared in a statement released yesterday that motion-picture exhibitors "face one of the most critical periods in their history" this year, but expressed confidence that the issues would be met and solved "in a spirit of intelligent cooperation."

The textile and garment industries have closed their books on 1947 in the knowledge that all previous yearly peacetime dollar-volume records have been exceeded. Beset by problems of distorted distribution which have not been resolved in a full year of production without Government controls, the soft goods industries came through scarred in the struggle to maintain supply on a parity with demand, and showing exceptionally high profits.
MOBILE, Ala., Jan. 1 (AP) -- Purchase of nine additional C-2 type cargo vessels from the United States Maritime Commission was announced yesterday by the Waterman Steamship Corporation.
EL PASO, Tex., Jan. 1 (UP) -- Miami University of Ohio showed Texas Tech some tricky plays today to score a 13-to-12 victory before a crowd of 18,000 in the annual Sun Bowl football game.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 1 -- The University of Michigan's dazzling football machine capped an all-victorious season today by slashing almost at will up and down the Rose Bowl greensward to defeat the University of Southern California, 49 to 0.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- The Boston Weather Bureau today issued the following winter sports reports and forecast:

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- All-America Johnny Lujack closed out his college football career in brilliant fashion today when he pitched and engineered the East to a 40 to 9 victory over the West in the twenty-third charity game between gridiron stars gathered from all parts of the country.

Despite the scarcity of materials and high building costs, the savings banks of New York State in the two years since the end of the war have loaned or made commitments totaling $372,750,000 on new residential construction to house approximately 200,000 persons, according to a year-end statement by John Adikes, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York.

The office personnel shortage, with some temporary alleviation at the beginning of the year and toward the end of spring, continued acute through all of 1947, according to Ernest De La Ossa, chairman of the New York Personnel Management Association and personnel director of the National Broadcasting Company.

An encouraging economic and social revival among Europe's Jews during 1947 was noted yesterday by Edward M.M. Warburg, chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee in making public a year-end review of the agency's activities in aiding distressed Jewish people abroad.

The $13,000,000,000 private electric utility industry closed 1947 with a sigh of relief as demands for power, unprecedented in its sixty-nine-year history, were complied with in all but a few minor, isolated spots.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Jan. 1 -- In a New Year's Day ceremony that packed City Hall to overflowing in spite of difficult traveling, Mayor Luke A. Mercadante, the first Democratic head of the City Council in six years, was installed this morning By Richard C. Patterson, former Ambassador to Yugoslavia and an Under-Secretary of Commerce in the Administration of the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 1 -- Jews carried out a series of attacks on Arabs today. These raids apparently were counter-reprisals for the massacre of forty-one Jews in Haifa on Tuesday after a bomb had been thrown among Arab workmen.
The United Jewish Appeal in a year-end report yesterday said 60,000 homeless European Jews had been aided by the agency in finding new homes in Palestine, this country and elsewhere in 1947.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- The central Viet Nam Government in a directive has told its political commissars with the Viet Nam field armies that the United States and Britain plan to send arms and money to aid the French in Indo-China, according to information obtained here from official circles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A new committee has been established within the research and development board of the national military establishment to study basic physical sciences as pertaining to research and development activities in the latter unit, it was announced today by Dr. Vannevar Bush, board chairman.

ATHENS, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- The report received from General An tonopoulos, commanding the Greek Eighth Division on the Konitsa operations, said "yesterday at 20:00 hours (8 P.M.), detachments of the National Army entered Konitsa, despite torrential rain, overthrowing the enemy with great loss to him."
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Reuters) -- Arsenal scored a 1-0 victory over the Bolton Wanderers today for a 5-point lead in the first division of the English Football League.

For the first time since the end of the war, freighters in the inter-coastal service are turning in profitable voyage returns but the black ledger entries are destined to be short-lived, operators reported yesterday.

Investment banking had rough going in 1947, with the prospect of more breakers ahead. With the stock market effectually quarantined from the post-war price-and profit boom, there was little encouragement for the raising of new capital through new junior equity flotations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1 -- Contracts covering 3,600 printers in Chicago's 400 commercial printing shops expired at midnight last night, and contracts covering mailers in Chicago's newspapers expire tomorrow night at midnight.

The New York State Chapter of Americans for Democratic Action announced yesterday that it would support a state legislative program in 1948 that calls for the establishment of a state university system, increased state aid to education, expansion of the state low-cost housing program, extension of the rent-control law, liberalization of unemployment insurance benefits and passage of a fair educational practices bill.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- The Schuman Government may stake its existence upon the passage by the National Assembly of the extraordinary tax to check inflation when the parliamentary battle enters its final stage tomorrow. This was indicated after a conference of Premier Robert Schuman and his advisers tonight.

The cotton textile industry enters the new year in the strongest position in its history, Claudius T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, declared in a statement prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mills have in hand enough orders to assure continuance of the present high rate of production for the first six months of the year and some mills have sold goods for third and fourth quarter delivery, he said.

Electrical manufacturing during 1947 reached a record rate 50 per cent above 1946 and 40 per cent above the pre-war peak year of 1941, W.J. Donald, managing director of the National Electrical Manufacturers' Association, reported in summarizing the status of the industry in a year-end report.

One quality accepted as a fact regarding the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development at the beginning of 1948 is that it is not moribund, but active, eager and anxious to fulfill the ends for which it was created. Although its policies and activities have been placed in suspension pending implementation of the Marshall plan, the bank has been readying itself to supplement the economic aid to be provided under that program.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press) -- The fifth Lily Bowl football game between the United States Navy and Air Force teams stationed in Bermuda -- in which the main attraction took second place to several sideshows -- ended in a 12-12 tie today.

Purchase of the controlling stock in the Brooklyn Football Dodgers by the Brooklyn Baseball Club may be expected "any day now," it was learned last night. The deal, long rumored to be in the making, undoubtedly will go through before Jan. 10.

Traffic courts, the only legal tribunals that many of our people are ever called upon to visit, have long been neglected places. Often they are set up in any old building in which cities and towns can find space for them, and almost as often they are presided over by persons none too qualified for such jobs.

BUFFALO, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The University of California at Los Angeles basketball team completed an all-victorious swing through the East tonight by defeating Cornell, 50 -- 47, in two overtime periods before 5,934 persons at Memorial Auditorium.

The nation's mutual savings banks now are serving nearly 18,500,000 depositors, a gain of more than 1,500,000 accounts since V-J Day, and the total of these deposits is approaching $18,000,000,000, the highest point in the banks' 131 years of service, Earl B. Schwulst, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, points out in a year-end statement.

Greater merchandising efforts to consolidate gains in retail and industrial markets, a production high of 1,500,000,000 pounds, and continuing plant and facilities expansion totaling at least $175,000,000 will be the chief objectives of the plastics industry for 1948, according to George H. Clark, president of the Society of the Plastics Industry.

Industrial supply and equipment manufacturers are the first organized group of industrialists to take steps to back up the Marshall plan with a plan of specific cooperation, officials of the American Supply and Machinery Manufacturers Association revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- The international speed record and four other international air records were broken by pilots of the United States Air Force during 1947, the Department of Air Force reported today in a summation of its achievements during the last year.

GENEVA, Jan. 1 -- Eighty-seven per cent of the displaced persons under the care of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization are men and women under 45 whose productive years lie ahead, the organization announced yesterday.
Two thousand cable and radio workers quit work at 12:01 A.M. today, cutting off one-third of the normal facilities for commercial communication between the United States and the rest of the world.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Premier Robert Schuman submitted to the Assembly today a compromise proposal for an anti-inflationary levy, which he said was the Government's last word. He told the Assembly that the Cabinet would stake its existence on the new measure by making it a question of confidence.

If recently published census data reveal an increase of 21 per cent in the incidence of insanity in the American population in the years from 1940 to 1945, they cannot with equal accuracy show the tremendous development of psychiatry which took place during the war years.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- The Treasury had to intervene in the stock market here today to hold the Transport stock of the newly nationalized railways steady above 97. Securities were issued at par to cover well over 1,000,000,000 in value and such a huge transaction inevitably brought nervousness and preliminary selling.

The second and final Junior Assembly of the season was held last night in the ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. The majority of the debutantes of the winter were in attendance, many of them making their formal debuts at the dance and others at prefatory dinner parties.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee decided today to subpoena the brokerage account records of Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham, President Truman's personal physician, after learning that copies had been turned over to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Henry A. Wallace's announcement that he will run as an independent candidate for President of the United States in 1948 was enthusiastically greeted tonight by the Soviet commentator, Mikhail Mikhailov, in an English language broadcast over the Moscow radio.

The Austin Motor Company, Ltd. (England), will open a newspaper campaign to announce its 1948 line of automobiles with full pages in two New York papers and a half-page in a Brooklyn paper tomorrow, it was announced yesterday. Initial newspaper announcements outside New York will start a week later.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 2 -- The Methodist Youth Conference concluded its four-day meeting today with a solemn dedication service at which more than 10,000 young persons pledged themselves anew to the service of Christ and the church.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- Nowhere is the prospect of the opening year more clouded than in France. And nowhere, not even in England, is the future of Europe so visibly hanging in the balance as in the weary struggle going on in this so-called holiday season in the Chamber of Deputies.

The slow and painful process of seeing that all Americans receive the equal justice that is guaranteed them by the Constitution and by our common law made progress in 1947. The Tuskegee Institute, in its annual report on lynchings, records that last year there was only one clear-cut case of the invocation of Lynch Law in the South.

A city law should be enacted making it the house-owner's obligation to clear the snow in front of his house. He would have to clear it from the sidewalk and from the road up to the middle of the street; the snow to be piled up at the curb. From there trucks of the Department of Sanitation would remove it at leisure, or it could be left there to thaw in time.

Burning foam rubber exploded just after 7 o'clock yesterday morning in a four-story plant at 230 West Fifty-eighth Street, east of Broadway, and for three hours smoke obscured the neighborhood from Columbus Circle to Fifty-sixth Street, and from Eighth Avenue to Seventh Avenue.

Rose Slatkovitz, violinist, who made her local debut a year ago, gave her second New York recital last night at Times Hall. With Elsa Fiedler at the piano, the gifted young artist presented a program having as its chief offerings Beethoven's Sonata in C minor, Op. 30, No. 2; Bach's "Chaconne," the Concerto in B minor of Saint-Saens and Ravel's "Tzigane."

Supervisory employes, working around the clock, sought yesterday to keep traffic moving in the cable systems of Western Union and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, affected by a strike at 12:01 A.M. Friday by members of the American Communications Association, CIO.

Neither the elements, an overtaxed transportation system nor the aftermath of New Year's Eve could keep thousands more World War II veterans from seeking application blanks yesterday for the New York State veterans' bonus.
Prices of cotton futures were somewhat erratic yesterday due to several conflicting influences. Final prices were 4 to 19 points net lower.
BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau today issued the following winter sports reports and forecasts:

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Chairman Thomas L. Owens of a House subcommittee investigating the walkout of 1,500 printers against six Chicago daily newspapers said today that it appears "at first blush" that the strikers' union, Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, AFL, was being used as a "guinea pig" to attack the Taft-Hartley law on behalf of all labor.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The speedy St. Louis Billikens won their seventh straight basketball victory without a defeat tonight as they outclassed the Holy Cross Crusaders, N.C.A.A. champions, 61 to 46, before 11,000 spectators in Kiel Auditorium.

In a New Year's Day letter dispatched to 17,500 party officials and workers throughout the country, Mr. Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, asserts that the record of the Eightieth Congress will probably be the most important factor in determining the success or failure of the G.O.P. in this year's national elections.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 2 -- A drive to get arms from the United States for a fight with the Arabs over partition is the main topic of a conference of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine that is now going on in Tel Aviv, it was believed in well-informed Jewish circles here today.
The rain and the sleet made for uneasy travel on foot and dangerous vehicular movement throughout the city yesterday, with the police reporting a score of accidents of all types. None was serious.

There may be too much whistle blowing at college basketball games but the fault lies not with the officials, as has been charged by court mentors, but with the coaches themselves, Matty Begovich, a leading Eastern referee, declared yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Michigan's all-conquering Wolverines, the plaudits of Rose Bowl observers still ringing in their ears, boarded a noon train today taking them back to their Ann Arbor lair.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Britain shipped $142,820,981 worth of gold to this country in November. This was more than half of the $267,300,832 worth received from all countries that month, the Commerce Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Congress' responsibility for assisting European recovery was formally accepted today by the Republicans' top policy makers. But they agreed that the amount of aid and the administrative machinery for providing it were unsettled questions of major proportions.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Lester B. Pearson, chairman of the General Assembly committee that drafted the plans for the United Nations Little Assembly, will be Canada's first delegate to the Security Council, it was announced today.

Douglas Stewart, who coached soccer at the University of Pennsylvania from 1910 until 1942, when he retired, last night received the 1948 "Oscar" of the National Soccer Coaches Association of America, that organization's annual award to the person who has done the most for the game.

NANKING, Jan. 2 -- Communist forces were reported tonight to have broken into the western suburbs of Paoting, capital of Hopeh Province, as groups of Gen. Fu Tso-yi's Nationalist cavalry tried to break up a Communist attack on the southwest corner of the Peiping-Tientsin-Paoting triangle.
Many of the nation's security markets have suspended operations for today because of the severe weather conditions throughout the country. Some commodity markets also will be closed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Eighty-five railroads, operating in the western section of the country, today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to authorize them to increase basic one-way coach fares by 13.63 per cent, on five-days' notice.

TOKYO, Jan. 2 -- Fear that the United States would enter the European war and thus bring on a "convulsion in the Pacific animated Japan to change her international policy as early as the middle of 1940, Gen. Hideki Tojo testified before the International Military Tribunal today.

BERLIN, Jan. 2 -- The foreign trade of Eastern Germany will be diverted almost entirely to Eastern and Southeastern Europe, according to Josef Orlopp, President of the Central Administration for Foreign Trade. Such trade will be almost entirely on a barter basis, it was understood.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 2 -- The building of a happier family life was described here today as a keystone of world recovery as delegates to the world assembly of Moral Rearmament turned to a third theme of their ten-day conference.

Icing conditions aloft and runways and taxi strips slick with sleet and slush combined yesterday to bring air transport almost to a dead stop in the metropolitan area. Forecasts from Newark Airport and LaGuardia Field last night indicated the weather would improve slowly and operations would be almost normal today.

Despite a slow start, the fur manufacturing industry enjoyed a relatively good year in 1947 and if 1948 is approached with caution there is not likely to be much change from the present situation, according to Sol Rosenberg, president of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., 393 Seventh Avenue, whose membership comprises 750 of the world's leading fur manufacturers.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Some 20,000 persons, including many social and financial celebrities who winter in this area, are expected to watch the rowing regatta tomorrow between Yale and Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Union of eight different interdenominational organizations under a proposed National Council of the Churches of Christ in America is being explored at a conference being held at Washington Cathedral here.

With a large comeback contingent joining the athletic parade, the Olympic year of track and field competition will begin tonight with the Metropolitan A.A.U.'s inaugural open meet at the Twenty-Second Regiment Armory, on West 168th Street. An entry totaling 930 has been received for the seventeen-event program, which will get under way at 7:15 P.M.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the agreement, signed in Paris today, under which France accepts United States conditions for emergency aid:
LONDON, Jan. 2 -- For the first hour of business in the stock markets here today, dealings in the new 3 per cent Government Transport stock monopolized attention.
A total of 8,674 New Yorkers appeared yesterday in six traffic courts throughout the city to pay fines amounting to $52,748 for illegal parking of cars hampering snow removal and other violations.

The stock market limped yesterday into the new year with only a moderate show of the late December recovery movement. With wire and transportation services hampered by the weather elements and attendance in Wall Street even smaller than the aftermath of the post-Christmas storm, some further progress was made with the best gains registered near the close of the session.

An intense and widespread storm -- possibly the worst of this century -- roared across sixteen states yesterday, affecting 60,000,000 persons and resulting in millions of dollars of property damage. From Iowa to New England the people combated snow, sleet, rain, ice and high winds as they prepared to meet a cold wave scheduled to follow the storm.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The interim aid agreement by which France receives immediate shipments of food, fuel, fertilizers and other needed items from the United States was signed at 6 P.M. today in the French Foreign Ministry by French Foreign Minister Georges Bidault and United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- The Admiral Corporation today introduced its new "optional television" line at a special press preview in the American Furniture Mart here. Marking the company's entrance into the television field, it showed a ten-inch direct view receiver in a twenty-eight tube chassis which may be purchased independently of the FM-AM radio and automatic phonograph combination.

"The Eternal Return," a modernized version of the Tristan and Isolde legend, written by Jean Cocteau and directed by Jean Delannoy, will open an engagement today at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse. This new French film, carrying English dialogue titles, stars Jean Marais as Tristan and Madeleine Sologne, who is making her American debut, as Isolde.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Calumet Farm sent its 1947 champion, Armed, out for his 1948 debut in a six-furlong event at Gulfstream Park today and was rewarded with victory and a $2,200 check which pushed the thoroughbred's all-time winnings to $763, 700, leaving him $52,360 behind first-place Stymie on the world money winning list.

The Nine Pins of Europe is the name being irreverently applied by a friend of this corner to nine European monarchs who, in the period since the outbreak of the First World War, have been toppled over in nine European countries, along with the monarchical form of government they represented, by anti-royalist bowlers in the bowling alley of European international politics.

The CBS Documentary Unit has completed a detailed two-month survey of the educational facilities of an American city and will present its findings on Wednesday, Jan. 14, at 10 P.M. in a one-hour broadcast entitled "Report Card."

A volunteer force "should be mobilized immediately" to help implement the United Nations decision on Palestine, Bartley C. Crum national chairman of Americans for Haganah, declared yesterday at the Hotel St. Regis. The former member of the Anglo-American Committee on Palestine visualized this force as recruited from member nations of the United Nations that would accompany the United Nations Committee on Palestine there in February.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Carl R. Gray Jr., Veterans Administrator, said today that former President Herbert Hoover was arranging for a committee of insurance experts, to investigate the veterans' insurance program.
The writer is an alumnus of the City College, class of 1923, and has been a member of two college faculties.

New York and its suburbs, hard hit by Thursday night's ice storm, were buffeted anew by a combination of rain, sleet and snow yesterday, but the precipitation ended in the city officially at 8:15 o'clock last night.

"EAGLE AT MY EYES,"* by Norman Katkov, is, in its essentials, a tough Romeo and Juliet story, told with unsparing candor, about the realities of religious prejudice and bigotry. The Romeo here is Joe, a young Jewish newspaper man, desperately in love, desperately troubled. The Juliet is Mary, who loves him just as much and wants to make their life together a success.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 2 -- Gig Young, former Warner contract actor, has been signed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer to play Porthos in "The Three Musketeers," which Pandro S. Berman is producing. Cesar Romero, who was borrowed by Metro from Twentieth Century-Fox for the role, will appear in "Julia Misbehaves," with Greer Garson.

The Controller of the Currency issued yesterday in Washington a call for a statement of the condition of all national banks at the close of business on Dec. 31. The Federal Reserve Board called for statements on the condition of banks in its system as of the same date, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation issued a similar call on FDIC-insured banks which are not Federal Reserve members.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 2 -- New prices on General Electric Company's appliances under the 3 to 10 per cent reduction policy announced recently by Charles E. Wilson, president, come to as much as $20 on refrigerators and electric ranges, the company disclosed here today. The average reduction for all affected lines runs to 5 per cent.

VIENNA, Jan. 2 -- After having[ heard from Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes that "there are no stipula-I tions, secret or-otherwise, w l!i'ch 'm] any way limit the authority or infringe upon the independence of the Austrian Government," Chancellor Leopold Figl today signed the Austrian interim aid agreeI ment under the United States foreign aid progrsxn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Wheat showed a heavy undertone from the start on the Board of Trade today. Prices at one time were down 6 cents a bushel as the result of general selling based on expectations of much larger sales of cash grain by producers and also heavy snow in parts of the West and Southwest.
Third in a series of articles giving the views of leading designers on the changing fashion picture and the outlook for 1948:

One of Long Island's largest post-war apartment projects -- the group of five buildings recently completed by Sol Atlas in Great Neck -- has been purchased by the Co-Al Realty Corporation, a syndicate represented by Paul P. Zinner, Inc.

The "C's" have it. Cluett Peabody (CLU on the tape) was the first stock traded on the New York Stock Exchange in 1948, opening at 35 1/2, off 1/8 point from the closing price in 1947. Capital Administration Company, Ltd., class A (CAD, the ticker symbol) was the issue that closed transactions in 1947, finishing at 12 1/2, compared with 14 1/2 at the end of 1946.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Paperboy, W.L. Ranch's 10-year-old gelding, romped home a length winner today in the $5,000 seven-furlong sprint feature at Santa Anita Park before an estimated 32,500 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 27 were 27 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Railroad service into New York City, wobbling from the effects of last week's snow storm and Thursday's rain and sleet, was further disrupted yesterday by derailments of freight trains on the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads.
BOLOGNA, Italy, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Even Communist officials in northern Italy gave a warm welcome today to the first United States Friendship train with its gift of food to the Italians.

ALBANY, Jan 2 -- John E. Burton, State Budget Director, has transmitted an "alternative draft" of recommendations to the thirty members of the New York State University Commission, urging that an existing university -- preferably Syracuse University -- be acquired for the establishment of a state university.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- An air pick-up and delivery system and a telescopic arm for use with any system or apparatus for picking up grounded loads by an aircraft in flight were among the 495 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office. An unusually high number.

Branching out from its production of herbs, sauces and vinegars, Twin Tree Gardens, Inc., of Lynbrook is making a number of specialties for the cocktail hour. The new items cover about everything needed for such an occasion, except the liquor.
The sailfishing at Stuart, Fla., seems to be improving every day, and, according to the late report from the Stuart Sailfish Club, the anglers have been consistently successful during the past week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont said today following a conference with the Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson, that he would introduce a bill to ration meat if he could "get convinced of a satisfactory way of doing it."

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 2 -- India told the United Nations today that she might send troops into Pakistan unless the sister Dominion stopped aiding Moslem raiders in Kashmir. The Security Council was immediately called into session for Tuesday afternoon to hear both sides.

The posthumous volume of John O'Hara Cosgrave's personal philosophy, "Man: A Citizen of the Universe," will be published by Farrar, Straus on Jan. 14. It is a briefer statement of his first book, "Academy for Souls," which appeared in 1931.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy said today that he would give his decision on Jan. 14 in the case of James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, accused by the Federal Government of violating the Lea Act.
After a heavy snowfall in any large city it is imperative to clear the streets quickly. The utilization of every means, despite heavy expense, is desirable and necessary.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (Reuters) -- Shipping movements to and from North America declined in November, the official British Board of Trade Journal reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Petroleum products for export have been limited to 12,000,000 barrels for the first quarter of 1948, 200,000 barrels below the quota for the last quarter of 1947, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The spirit of cooperation engendered among the personnel of the city departments and the extra help, during the snow removal job, is something for which the citizens of New York may be proud. It is the spirit of true Americanism at work. Whenever an emergency arises the American people pitch in and help overcome the difficulty, not because they must, but because they want to.

FAIRLAWN, N.J., Jan. 2 -- DuMont and Burlington Mills figured in Fairlawn expansion moves announced today by N.J. Leigh, president of Fairlawn Industries and chairman of the board of Einson-Freeman Company, lithographers.
One thousand seamen manning harbor oil barges and self-propelled tankers will walk out at midnight tonight unless an agreement is reached with their employers at City Hall today.

As the fuel oil crisis created by the shortage of transportation and by the repeated storms worsened yesterday, rumors grew that a black market in fuel oil had developed. The Board of Transportation admitted that it had been the first victim of "gouging."

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 (Delayed) (UP) -- The Leningrad newspaper Pravda, in an admonition to greedy consumers, told today of a hoarder who came to grief after he had bought everything he could, from bug poison to tombstones, in an attempt to beat the ruble revaluation decree.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A sharp-shooting Seton Hall quintet rallied in the third quarter tonight to shatter the seven-game winning streak of the Baldwin-Wallace Yellow Jackets, 63-54, at the Arena.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- Gay H. Brown, Grand Master of Masons of the State of New York, announced today that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey had issued the following statement:

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- New apparatus which, flown to high altitude, can "weigh" cosmic-ray mesotron particles and further pierce the mystery of the atom was described today at a meeting of the American Physical Society.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals, in a caustic decision, unanimously affirmed yesterday the conviction of Joseph Forman, former Democratic chairman of Ulster County, two other individuals and the Pure Rock Mineral Springs Corporation of Ellenville, N.Y.

The ice storm of yesterday and Thursday night destroyed at least 100 street trees and damaged thousands of others, as well as valuable shrubbery, not only on city streets but in parks and along landscaped parkways as well, the Parks Department reported yesterday.
Sharp increases in the price of bunker fuel oil for ships threaten to cause the withdrawal of more American tonnage from foreign trades, it was reported here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.3 per cent during the week ended on Dec. 27, mainly because of advances for commodities other than farm products and foods, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The heavyweight boxing carnival that placed 2,772 odd pounds of ambitious youth on exhibition before 9,284 fans last night in Madison Square Garden, left the onlookers with the conviction that Joe Louis has no immediate worries.

DETROIT, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Yale University's high-scoring basketball team came from behind in the last minute and a half with eight points tonight for a hard-earned 70-to-65 victory over Wayne University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Inspired by the efforts of a Connecticut beer dealer to get help from the National Labor Relations Board the Chamber of Commerce of the United States cautioned small business men today against looking to the Federal Government for the solution of their labor-management problems.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today he had "definite assurances" from Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, Republican, of Michigan, that the latter "will insist" that a measure authorizing the St. Lawrence seaway be placed before the Senate this month for "final consideration."

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Jan. 2 (AP) -- The directors of the Berkey Gay Furniture Company have authorized the filing of a petition for reorganization under Chapter 10 of the National Bankruptcy Act, a spokesman for the concern confirmed today.

The new headquarters of Church World Service, Inc., at 214 East Twenty-first Street, East of Third Avenue, will be dedicated Tuesday at 4 P.M. The offices have been at 37 East Thirty-sixth Street since the Organization set itself up a year and a half ago after a consolidation of three Protestant overseas relief agencies.
A strike by the Radio Directors Guild, AFL, against the nation's four leading networks that would have cut coast-to-coast radio entertainment drastically appeared averted yesterday.

Engineers and trainmen of the Long Island Rail Road issued a joint statement last night denying reports that they had not lived up to their responsibilities during last week's record snowstorm, and declaring that they had "worked around the clock" in a "heroic effort to serve the public."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 -- Gov. Earl Warren today appealed to the people of California to fill a ship with contributions of preserved milk as a gift of friendship from the state to the undernourished children of France, Italy and Greece.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands (Aneta) -- There will be continued danger from mines along the entire Dutch coast for at least another eight years, according to a Dutch minesweeping expert quoted by the newspaper Dagblad.

TAUNGS, Cape Province, South Africa, Dec. 22 -- Prof. Charles L. Camp and Dr. Frank Peabody of the University of California's scientific expedition announced today that they had unearthed traces of an ancient carnivore previously unknown to science.

Tons of swirling water from a broken forty-eight-inch water main at Eighty-ninth Street and Amsterdam Avenue swept over a quarter-mile area yesterday, causing widespread damage and discomfort. Traffic on the Seventh Avenue IRT line from Times Square to Ninety-sixth Street was blocked from8:06 A.M. to 12:51 P.M. while the water was being pumped from the flooded roadbed.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- The General Committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment adopted tonight a plan to expedite progress. Beginning Monday there will be twenty subcommittee meetings daily, with morning, afternoon and night sessions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Far Eastern Commission, in a policy decision announced today, has directed Gen. Douglas MacArthur to insure that the Japanese Government take the necessary measures to attain the maximum production of indigenous food to relieve the food shortage.

PARIS, Jan. 2 -- The Quai d'Orsay salvaged considerable French pride by minor face-saving changes in the bilateral treaty signed with the United States today governing the conditions of interim aid. The State Department submitted the initial draft of the proposed treaty text to the French Embassy in Washington Dec. 17, two days after the Foreign Aid Act of 1947 had been approved by Congress.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The preliminary screening of the first 16,000 applications turned up the Veteran Bonus Bureau's first big headache today. One-third of the applications, Director Leo V. Lanning said, will have to be sent back either because of omissions or because the forms were executed before Jan. 1.

SEDALIA, Mo., Jan. 2 -- Salvage workers at the scene of the wreck of two Missouri Pacific trains today found jewelry valued at $200,000 to $250,000, the property of former Ambassador and Mrs. Alexander W. Weddell, who were among the fourteen victims of the accident.

Falling trees and branches, weighted down by a combination of wind and heavy, frozen sleet, ripped innumerable power lines apart Friday night and early yesterday, leaving large sections of the metropolitan area without light.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- The text of the agreement between the United States and Italian Governments on interim aid to Italy was delivered this morning to the Foreign Office by Walter Newbold Walmsley, commercial attache of the United States Embassy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Some building materials may continue in short supply in 1948, the Commerce Department said today, if construction is at a predicted $15,200,000,000 record high dollar volume. Construction last year was estimated at $12,878,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The State Department announced today that the United States was prepared to pay for seventeen Finnish ships seized here during the war.

Eighteen fiancees of former American service men, detained at Ellis Island because their visas had expired before they arrived here Thursday by airliner from Rome, were released under bond yesterday pending final decision on their immigration status.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Many recommendations for reducing the hazards of air travel, including safety directors for air lines, changes in technique and equipment for fire-fighting, and better pay and working conditions for pilots, were urged today by the President's Air Safety Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The daily average value of manufacturers' shipments in November was 5 per cent above the October rate, reflecting an increased flow of goods and a continued rise in prices, the Office of Business Economics, Department of Commerce, reported today.
