A note in THE TIMES of Dec. 19 states that at its last meeting in Mexico City UNESCO formally approved a resolution making Spanish an official language of its deliberations on the same footing as English and French. As a matter of fact, the motion proposed by Mexico which would have made Spanish an official working language of UNESCO in future conferences was postponed.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Jack Harden, 33-year-old ex-GI from El Paso, Tex., fired a sub-par 67 to take the lead today in the first round of the annual $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.
Donors expressed the wish that 1948 would prove a happier year for the unfortunate families and individuals of New York as they sent their gifts yesterday to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- On the eve of reconvening for its second regular session, the Eightieth Congress was urged today to take full advantage of the Reorganization Act to improve its utility and strength. Each member received a letter to this effect from the National Committee for Strengthening the Congress.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today that some individuals in the State Department were hobbling the CIO's efforts to sell the European Recovery Program, the Marshall Plan, to workers abroad through the World Federation of Trade Unions.

Although outright relief still is the principal need of Europe's Jews, it is encouraging to learn from the year-end review by Edward M.M. Warburg as chairman of the Joint Distribution Committee that the committee's assistance programs throughout the world are gradually, but certainly, moving from relief to reconstruction.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- A hearing examiner of the National Labor Relations Board decided in a report today that the AFL Carpenters' Union violated the secondary boycott clause of the Taft-Hartley Law by requiring its members to stop working on a project with non-union employes of a decorating firm.

Harassed by the record snow and sleet storms which followed, retail trade here this week failed to show any gain over last year. More department stores showed decreases than increases, with changes in night opening schedules being somewhat of a factor.

HAVANA, Jan. 2 -- Cuba's sugar mills were not working today, the date for milling of the new crop, as owners met to discuss the recent Presidential decree fixing minimum wages at the maximum level of 1947.

Registering the first contraction after twenty-three consecutive weeks of expansion, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System were reduced $77,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.
OCRACOKE, N.C., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Coast Guardsmen working against heavy seas early today rescued twenty-one men from a fishing steamer driven aground at Ocracoke Island shortly before midnight.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 2 (AP) -- An AFL teamsters' union was enjoined today from forcing an employer to pay for services not performed, commonly known as "feather-bedding," in the first decision of its kind under the Taft-Hartley labor law.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. listed individual income tax reduction today as "one of the very first" items on the agenda of the House when Congress convenes next Tuesday.

The Admiral Realty Corporation has purchased for investment the five-story apartment house occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 2680-84 Broadway, northeast corner of 102d Street, from the Courtney Realty Corporation in a transaction reported yesterday by Byrne, Bowman Forshay, the brokers.

Under the auspices of the American National Theatre and Academy, the Experimental Theatre, Inc., will present Jan de Hartog's new play, "Skipper Next to God," at Maxine Elliott's Theatre tomorrow evening. John Garfield of the films will take the leading role in the play which is to be given for six performances only.

Housewives were out shopping yesterday in greater force than on any day since the previous Friday. They bought food to replace reserves used up during the week, and as much more as they could carry home.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- James M. Landis, former chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, disclosed today that he had recently received personal assurances from President Truman of reappointment to the agency.

The first of a series of legal moves slated to resolve the controversy between the judges of the judges of the Kings County Court and the District Attorney over control of the court's calendar was taken yesterday by Miles F. McDonald, the Brooklyn prosecutor.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 2 -- India would be "justified in self-defense" in attacking bases in Pakistan where raiders were being trained and armed for an invasion of Kashmir, Prime Minister Nehru declared tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Truman has definitely decided to have a porch at the White House, and construction of it will begin in two or three weeks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- An earnest plea for Congressional approval of the Marshall Plan was made by Senator Albert W. Barkley, Democratic leader of the Senate, as he and other Democrats in political and private life spoke over a nation-wide broadcast tonight.

PEIPING, Jan. 2 (UP) -- A Chinese Communist force estimated at 1,000 invaded Changchun, pre-war capital of Manchuria, today and fought a seven-hour battle with the Nationalist garrison within the city's walls, semi-official dispatches from Changchun reported.

Madison Square Garden, which has crammed more basketball into this holiday period than ever before, will present another matinee and evening program today. In the afternoon the professional New York Knickerbockers will oppose the Baltimore Bullets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Enough marines to restore the normal complement on an aircraft carrier and three light cruisers in the Mediterranean will be dispatched from the United States next Tuesday, the Navy Department announced today.
The new biting turn in the weather yesterday slid the suburbs, particularly those in New Jersey and Long Island, back into last week's chaos.

YANINA, Greece, Jan. 2 -- The guerrilla forces of Gen. Markos Vafiades assailed Konsita once again today. The attack went in Before dawn, the rebel infantry advancing single file. The Greek Army garrison was far stronger now, since arrival of the relief column that augmented it New Year's Eve, and it drove off the attackers.

LONDON, Jan. 2 -- Mrs. Winston Churchill, accompanied by Lord Moran, Mr. Churchill's personal physician, and Lady Moran, left England by chartered plane today to join Britain's wartime Prime Minister at Marrakesh, Morocco.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department listed good conditions today at eighteen ski centers.

An unidentified gunman, shot and killed a 15-year-old youth who had pursued him on foot, overtaken and grappled with him after the boy had caught the thug in the act of trying to steal an automobile parked in front of 2,980 Park Avenue, the Bronx.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association, reputed to be the world's largest bank, in its year-end statement reports records in deposits, resources, loans and earnings during 1947.

Despite a civil war that threatens its integrity and absorbs most of its energies at the moment, the biggest nation on earth, China, comprising more than 450,000,000 people, is continuing the difficult process of converting itself from an archaic, feudal and patriarchal autocracy into a modern democracy.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Donald Allan was removed today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll from his position as Superintendent of Registration and Elections in Hudson County on charges of over-expending his budget.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Seven industrial firms have joined with the University of Chicago's atomic scientists to form a link between pure research and its commonplace applications, it was announced here today.
Arnold C. Martinelli, formerly sales manager for the thermoplastic division of Monsanto Chemical Company, has been named general manager of the Rogers Plastic Corporation, North Wilbraham, Mass.

The possibility of a strike that would cripple an important part of Westchester County deliveries of coal, fuel oil, gasoline and petroleum products grew yesterday. Negotiators for the Westchester Allied Trade Association and Local 456 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, failed to reach any agreement.

ROME, Jan. 2 -- The Italian Government has designated Gen. Henri Guisan, former wartime Commander-in-Chief of the Swiss Army, and Belgian Senator Auguste Buisseret, former Minister of the Interior and Public Instruction, as its candidates for the governorship of the Trieste Free State.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans is giving serious study to the possibility of recommending an emergency session of the General Assembly, in the event that one of the pro-Soviet Balkan nations establishes relations with Gen. Markos Vafiades' rebel Greek Government, it was made known here today.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 2 -- Speaking to the Off-the-Record Club today, K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said "on the record" that the diversion of American raw materials through the operation of the Marshall Plan could have a substantial effect upon the productive capacity of the automobile industry in 1948.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 2 -- Speaking to the Off-the-Record Club today, K.T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, said "on the record" that the diversion of American raw materials through the operation of the Marshall Plan could have a substantial effect upon the productive capacity of the automobile industry in 1948.

OTTAWA, Jan. 2 -- Britain has agreed to purchase Canada's surplus of beef, bacon, eggs and cheese for the years 1948 and 1949 at prices that have been agreed to for 1948 and will be negotiated before the beginning of 1949.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores increased 8 per cent in December over the same period of 1946, marking the largest Christmas trade in their history, according to the monthly survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The Joy Manufacturing Company, manufacturer of mining machinery and equipment for use in coal mines, construction, petroleum and other industries, yesterday reported a net income of $5,705,824 after all charges, for the year ended on last Sept. 30.

Survival of the lace industry in the face of Government action which does not afford tariff protection for high labor standards will depend upon ability to increase efficiency to the point where consumers will demand American laces, according to Gilbert R. Bodell, president of the American Lace Manufacturers Association, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Representative Keating, Republican, of New York, charged today in a complaint filed with the Federal Trade Commission that the Ford Motor Company "is engaging in unfair trade practices and competition to injure small businesses."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 (UP) -- Latin-American countries can increase their economic cooperation with each other and the rest of the world if the United States will provide them with financial and echnical assistance to develop their natural resources, in the opinion of Dr. Carlos Sanz de Santamaria, former Colombian Minister of Economy and of War.

The Yankees and their star performer, Joe DiMaggio, have opened negotiations on the amount of salary that Jolting Joe is to receive in 1948. How far apart they are in their estimates, or what those estimates actually are, is something where one fellow's guess is about as good as the next.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Indianapolis Motor Speedway announced today a change in a long-established rule which will permit assistance for cars stalled in next May's Memorial Day 500- mile race because of engine trouble.

After gaining four victories in succession in the international masters tournament at the annual congress sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, Laszlo Szabo of Budapest sustained a partial setback in the fifth round, according to reports from England yesterday.

The National Labor Relations Board issued yesterday a complaint against the International Typographical Union and five of its locals in this city, Detroit, Chicago and Pittsburgh charging violation of the Taft-Hartley law in dealings with approximately 500 commercial printing concerns.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- While the eyes of the winter sports world will be focused at St. Moritz, Switzerland, scene of the Olympic Games, starting the end of this month, a talented array of combined ski jumpers and instructors from Norway, mother of the sport, will invade the eastern United States on a comprehensive good-will tour, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Dec. 27, 1947, totaled 599,357 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 232,773 cars, or 28 per cent fewer than the preceding week, 28,610 cars, or 4.6 per cent fewer than the corresponding week last year, and 93,380 cars, or 18.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

In a rescue witnessed by scores of subway passengers, Patrolman Timothy Long subdued a man who tried yesterday afternoon to kill himself in the IRT station at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street, the police reported.

Large steel users in materials handling and industrial equipment industries, representing several billion dollar fields, will take action to protest plans of the Department of Commerce to agree to steel allocations without going more thoroughly into domestic requirements, industrial leaders revealed here yesterday.

Highlights of the spring fashion picture were well summarized in the collection presented by B. Altman Co. yesterday on their third floor. Romantic femininity, the key to the whole panorama, was reflected in the small tapered waists, the petticoats rustling beneath full skirts, the little suits and picturesque gowns for after-dark.
Under present conditions the candidacy of Henry A. Wallace on a third-party ticket seems to assure the forty-seven electoral votes of New York State for the Republican nominee for President.

Athletic officials and coaches from more than 300 colleges will gather here this week for the forty-second convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the yearly meetings of numerous other bodies concerned with the administration of college athletics.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The highly secret operations at Sandia Base, New Mexico, were reformed to for the first time by the Army today as a "guided-missiles project."
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Jimmy Demaret of Houston Tex., and Ojai, Calif., won the Vardon Trophy for 1947, the Professional Golfers Association of America announced today.

JACQUES MARITAIN exerts a public attraction rare indeed for a metaphysician. The reason is that his writing usually deals with concerns, questions and worries which the public experiences. Also, nearly all his work contains passages of a really high rhetoric, expressing loftily some feeling and sense which the well-disposed public shares.

" RHEINGOLD," the first opera of the newly staged "Ring" cycle, the sets by Lee Simonson, the stage direction by Dr. Herbert Graf, with Fritz Stiedry conducting, will be presented next Wednesday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House.

WASHINGTON. IF there is any single focus where the troubles of the world seem to converge in one crushing impact, it is the sedate oval office of the White House. Into it pour in a ceaseless tide the toughest and most insistent problems of a bewildered mankind.

It is appropriate that a chair in municipal government should be endowed as a memorial to the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University, as is now planned. And it is especially appropriate that the endowment should come from the United States Conference of Mayors, whose president Mr. La Guardia was for several years.

JANUARY seems an apt time for the legumes, the dried peas and beans and lentils, which provide the sort of robust dishes the appetite seeks when the wind whistles. Higher in cost than they ever have been, perhaps, they yet are inexpensive in comparison with other foods, and especially with meat, for which they are a good protein substitute.

JUST fourteen years ago this week in this review: A novel received the Page One notice: Sean O'Faolain's "A Nest of Simple Folk." "He has the poet's vision and the realist's eye," said the reviewer. . . . On Page Two a short survey and assessment of Australian writing with the name of Henry Handel Richardson ("The Fortunes of Richard Mahoney") leading all the rest.

LEGISLATIVE ideas about how to deal with price inflation were brought up short last week by action in industry. The General Electric Company apparently decided that the way to reduce prices was to reduce them.
Gov. Luther W. Youngdahl of Minnesota predicted yesterday that former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of that State would win the Republican nomination for President and would be elected.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Harvard's basketball team ended a holiday trip on a victorious note before 3,000 spectators tonight, defeating the University of Rochester, 57 to 47, to end a three-game losing string.
MILAN, Italy, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The United States Friendship Train experienced the thinnest welcome yet in Italy when the "Treno dell-'Amicizia" pulled in here this morning.

THIS is a good time of year to consider coldframes and hotbeds, and to install these ever-useful garden accessories. Although styles change and new kinds appear, they remain the same in their essentials. A coldframe is simply a bottomless box with a transparent, removable top.

A reliable taximan furnishes a note on the Age of Relativity, Sub-Period: Television. He says he saw the first round of a recent Madison Square Garden boxing match in the Avenue of the Americas at Fourth Street; the ninth round near Lexington and Ninety-eighth and the fifteenth in 116th Street, close to Lenox Avenue.

Aiming for a second consecutive 4,000,000-car year, the nation's automotive industry in 1948 will be aiming to erase another substantial volume of the deficit of vehicle transportation piled up during the war years, Powel Crosley Jr., president of Crosley Motors, Inc., declared in his year-end statement.

VARIOUS attempts have been made to capture in book form the tremendous appeal that comics have for children. While one or two have met with a measure of success, others have failed signally. "Three Tall Tales" is in the latter group.

IOWA CITY, Ia., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The University of Iowa defeated Princeton tonight, 52 to 40, to stretch its string of home non-conference basketball victories to thirty-two. It was the Hawkeyes' sixth triumph in a row this season.

Frederick R. Livingston, recently appointed arbitrator in the wage reviews between representatives of Atlantic and Gulf Coast steamship operators and three CIO maritime unions, announced yesterday that the first of three arbitration meetings would be held on Friday.

Baltimore's Bullets, largely by means of a pair of nine-point runs in the third quarter, downed the New York Knickerbockers in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon, 79 to 70, and advanced one notch to second place in the Western Division of the Basketball Association of America.

WMCA will open its campaign to induce Mayor O'Dwyer to call an open hearing on the city's critical housing shortage tomorrow night when the station offers the premiere broadcast of "A Home To Live In," from 10:03 to 10:30 o'clock.

THERE are those who think that when the curtain goes up at the City Center of Music and Drama this Thursday a new era will have begun in the legitimate theatre. Then there are those who are equally sure that the debut of the New York City Theatre Company will mean very little for Equity's children, certainly much less than did the Group Theatre or the Federal Theatre.

After defeating H. Golombek, the British champion, in their adjourned match from the fifth round in 62 moves, M. Raizman of Paris faced Laszlo Szabo of Budapest in the sixth round of the international masters' tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to reports received from Hastings yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The outcome of the debate on the European Recovery Program, which starts in Congress next week, will probably be determined by the level on which it is fought by the Administration and the supporters of the Marshall Plan in Congress.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- United Nations delegations began discussing today the possibility of setting up a new international commission to find an on-the-spot solution to India's dispute with Pakistan over Kashmir.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 3 -- If Louisiana citizens are concerned about the Marshall Plan, they're not telling their Congressmen about it.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Three contests offering cash awards to composers and instrumentalists have been announced by the National Federation of Music Clubs, to take place this spring. Requirements and addresses for obtaining further information follow:

IF some of the new wallpaper designs Seem startling, it is not because the designers have all gone mad. In the last few years wallpaper has been playing a role as different from its old one as a mural painting is from a miniature.

BECAUSE the Metropolitan Opera Guild raised the money for the four new "Ring" productions, its members were given first crack at the seats for the matinee cycle of the Wagner music dramas. Having an enormous appetite for opera, they snapped up all but a few seats in the balcony and family circle.

The Zionist Organization of America announced yesterday the enrollment of 100,000 members for the three-month period ending Jan. 2, pointing out that this represents an increase of 65 per cent over the same period of last year.
These dates are ringed on the 1948 calendars of the professional politicians:

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- Those New Englanders who have discussed the Marshall Plan with their Congressmen agree that some sound, long-range platform for helping Europe regain its feet is needed. They are inclined, however, to believe incentive and good administration are more important than merely spending billions of dollars.

THE bells which ring out this old year and ring in the new ought by rights to have a muffled sound, symptomatic of the anguished, throbbing heartbeats of The Industry, as it looks at its rapidly emptying film vaults and considers what in tunket it is going to do.

DAVOS, Switzerland, Jan. 3 -- European experts agreed today that the American Olympic ski team has shown a marked improvement over its first showings here and expressed the opinion that George Macomber of West Newton, Mass., was the Yanks' biggest threat for the forthcoming events at St. Moritz.

MARRAKECH, where Winston Churchill is spending six weeks combining a holiday with work on his memoirs, has long been a favorite stopping place for vacationists on the Mediterranean circuit, particularly during the late winter and spring.

If the textile industry is to arrive at a comparatively simple formula for obtaining voluntary price reductions under the new anti-inflation bill signed last week by the President, it will focus its principal effort in the matter of allocating raw and finished materials, leaders of the industry pointed out.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Higher prices and allocation of merchandise in many lines will greet buyers attending the International Home Furnishings Market opening Monday at the Merchandise Mart and at the American Furniture Mart, officials said today.

Attacking Governor Dewey and the Republican members of the Legislature for hoarding a $700,000,000 state surplus and taking money away from the municipalities, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, made public yesterday the Democratic legislative program.
" IF I had nothing to read but the mere dry lists of what they do, I should read them with pleasure."

A large number of high school students cannot correctly spell the words they are expected to know before graduation from elementary school. This is the conclusion reached by the New York State Department of Education, which recently made a state-wide survey of the spelling ability of third-and fourth-year high school students.

OTTAWA, Jan. 3 -- Nearly all of 1947's problems will be carried over into 1948, in some cases in a more acute form, and undoubtedly 1948 will develop new problems of its own. But most Canadians are clinging to the hope that the new year will at least retain the good features of the old.

Gross revenues of the aircraft manufacturing industry in 1947 amounted to more than $1,150,000,000 following similar volume of the preceding year, but many of the industry's companies failed to place their operations on a profitable basis.

In Harold Helfer's "Money Matters" there is one item which has me wondering. Mr. Helfer states that a judge in Washington, D.C., "decided that a man should pay $250 for forcibly kissing a woman." Is this a ruling on one particular case, or has it been made an ordinance? Also last, but not least -- who gets the $250?

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 3 -- Indications in Pakistan's press and elsewhere are that the Moslem Dominion will insist that the United Nations Security Council's inquiry into the Kashmir question be extended to all other points of difference between Pakistan and India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Warning that a grave school crisis confronts the United States, the National Education Association called today for immediate passage of a $300,000,000 bill for Federal aid to education.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- Representative Everett M. Dirksen, Republican, of Pekin, who "frankly favors the Marshall Plan in principle," asserted that "a campaign of education is necessary to bring home to the people what the plan is and what its objectives are."

THE riots provoked by the United Nations' decision in favor of partition and the establishment of a Jewish State have not deterred theatrical and musical organizations from fulfilling their schedule. The Palestine Philharmonic Orchestra continues to play to capacity halls, and its subscription concerts are now presented seven times each in succession.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 (AP) -- A threat by the Motion Picture Export Association to stop providing American movies for showing in Germany unless income from the films is unfrozen brought a reply from American Military Government officials today that Hollywood producers would receive an opportunity to recover their net export costs by a limited use of German services.

During the new year the American people should resolve to bring the world closer to peace and not to war, Rabbi Israel Goldstein said yesterday in a sermon in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street near Broadway.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The University of Colorado, a seemingly beaten team throughout the game in which it trailed by as much as 14 points, rallied in the final ten minutes tonight to whip Temple University, 50 to 45, in the second game of a basketball double-header at Convention Hall before 4,196.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- The third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace has occasioned jubilation among the Republicans and mixed feelings among Democrats here.

White sales and "return gifts" were the center of last week's activity, according to the weekly survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Stores were busy in spite of the adverse weather and there were signs of "bargain hunting" in response to clearance advertising, the report said.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 3 -- The Bluegrass hoisted a mint julep to Whirlaway today and proclaimed him its new favorite thoroughbred son to succeed the deceased Man o' War.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- A State Department official said tonight that shipment of any arms or ammunition of United States origin to any place in the Middle East was officially forbidden on Dec. 5.

HOUSTON, Tex., Jan. 3 -- In a strongly worded statement Bishop A. Frank Smith, titular head of three Methodist Church Conferences in North and East Texas, declared today that the Methodist Federation for Social Action was not an agency of the Methodist Church.

I have read the Fair Share Plan and the criticism of the plan in your columns. It seems to me the criticism misses the point of the plan. The Fair Share Plan is a program of rationing without a black market and without any curtailment of our economic liberties.

The slack period that preceded the holidays in the auction galleries is over, and this week begins a return to the normal complement of sales. At the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, a two-session sale, tomorrow and Tuesday, will disperse the library of the late Harry M. Brower of Gloversville, N.Y.

THE Federal Republic of Austria, shaped by the Treaty Saint Germain, comprised an area slightly larger than that of South Carolina and a population of less than 7,000,000 people. It was the scene of a remarkable, if futile, political experiment.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3 -- Congressmen in this industrial section have been receiving a series of communications from their constituents which appears to be pro-Administration on the Marshall Plan.

DEAR Kenneth C. Ross: Congratulations on your appointment as director of the long-rumored Modern Institute of Art in Beverly Hills. Prior to its opening late this month, while policies are still being formulated, we would like to ask some of the questions and make some of the comments which come to the mind of those of us in the East who have witnessed the inauguration of several of the predecessors.

THERE were, one discovers, many points of interest in Harriet Beecher Stowe's life besides the fact that she wrote a book which shook the nation. Quiet, pensive, almost plain, this sixth child in one of America's most famous families of divines knew the plain living and high thinking of a country minister's crowded household.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Russian news agency Tass charged today that United States military police in the American zone of Germany threatened to "beat up" Maria Borkowicz, a Polish diplomatic courier from Berne, Switzerland, while they were detaining her and trying to take her diplomatic pouch. Poland is protesting to Washington.

Financial markets ended the old year and began the new with a show of strength. While the "dying" days of 1947 were marked by some final tax selling on the New York Stock Exchange a stronger tone developed under the leadership of the rails.

PERHAPS the most interesting event on the week's schedule is the meeting which is to be held tomorrow evening at the Museum of Modern Art to consider the serious need for organizing the American dancers. This has nothing to do with unions, but with promotion.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 3 -- The people of Virginia are familiar with the name of the "Marshall Plan," but they are not familiar with its details. They believe in reasonable aid to Europe, aimed at preventing the spread of communism, but they want American aid pretty well circumscribed to prevent its abuse.

WHATEVER happens in the diplomatic relations of the record companies and the American Federation of Musicians in the next few months, there will be plenty of new disks on the market for a long time to come.

THAT'S exactly what it was, "The World's Greatest Hit." Here's the story of the play that has had the longest run in theatrical history, over ninety years, and more than one million performances. The play, of course, is "Uncle Tom's Cabin."

TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- Although currency and price inflation is advancing more rapidly than at any time since the surrender, although the scanty stockpiles are nearing exhaustion, and although the next two or three months promise mounting labor troubles, Japan is facing the New Year with hope.
BUDAPEST, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Hungary will be represented at the winter Olympic Games at St. Moritz, but Magyar contestants will be "underdogs" alongside the veteran champions of more wintry nations.

Shortages of scrap metal, which restrained the steel industry last year from capitalizing on its full production potential, should be alleviated somewhat during 1948, according to authorities of the scrap and steel industries.

Representatives of the cable division of the Western Union Telegraph Company and the American Communications Association, CIO, agreed yesterday to meet at 2 P.M. tomorrow under the auspices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in a new effort to settle the Western Union phase of the strike affecting two-thirds of American foreign communications.

An influx of buyers, the greatest in years, is expected in the New York wholesale market this week and next, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

ALL-AMERICA Selections, the annual list of prize-winning new flowers and vegetables, has been announced for 1948. Three flowers and eight vegetables have been chosen from among the sixty-six entries tested for this year.
DENVER, Jan. 3 -- The attitude of Coloradoans toward the Marshall Plan, as seen through the eyes of their Congressmen, is still one of uncertainty.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Lennart Strand, Sweden's middle-distance runner, was recognized officially today as co-holder of the world record for 1,500 meters, the metric mile.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Cornell held Canisius to one field goal in the second half tonight to overcome a 29-17 deficit and win a 41-37 basketball victory before a Memorial Auditorium double-header crowd of 9,151 fans. Delaware defeated the University of Buffalo, 46 -- 43, in the first game.

John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, was ordered yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer to start an immediate inquiry into reports of excessive prices for kerosene and fuel oil and of "racketeering" by some terminal operators and distributors.

Raymond Daniell's evaluation of present conditions in Berlin in "Are We Making Headway in Germany?" is faulty in several respects. For instance, he plays up the fact that most Germans appear well dressed, and from this he draws various conclusions.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Governor Dewey, in his annual message to the opening session of the 1948 Legislature next week, will recommend enactment of a law barring discrimination on racial or religious grounds in admission to colleges and professional schools, it was learned today.

Representatives of Local 138 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and the Greater New York Wholesale Grocers Association conferred for four hours yesterday without settling a dispute that prompted fifty food warehouses to close Friday.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 3 -- Congressional mailbags in this area are not very loaded these days with communications about the Marshall Plan, a survey among Tennessee members of the Eightieth Congress reveals.

Industrial construction, especially in the chemical industries, will continue at a high level during the coming year, according to a survey of executives of the H.K. Ferguson Company, industrial engineers and builders, of Cleveland, New York, Cincinnati and Houston.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 3 -- Henry A. Wallace's decision to run as a third party candidate for President has disturbed leaders of an already badly disunited Democratic party in California and reassured Republican strategists looking to the 1948 Presidential primary.

The Metropolitan has been having some bad luck with its singers and conductors through illness, and there have been other causes which have militated in the earlier part of the season against good performances. Yesterday everything seemed to be in the Opera Association's favor; the result was one of the finest "Tristan" performances that we have seen in years.
NANKING, Jan. 3 -- The military position of the Central Government has worsened to the point where the Nationalist Army appears to have lost the initiative on all major war fronts.

Foreign demand for dollars to pay for needed imports from this country lifted the monetary gold stock of the United States in 1947 by more than $2,000,000,000, the largest gain in seven years. With holdings of the metal thus raised to within striking distance of the record figure reached in 1941, virtually all the gold lost in recent years has been recovered.

HAVANA, Jan. 3 -- George Hakim of Lebanon proposed today what some delegates regarded as a promising formula for a compromise solution of the controversial issue of new preferential tariff agreements under the proposed International Trade Organization.

We, the undersigned members of the Board of Trustees of the World Peace Foundation, wish to register our conviction that the United States must advance sufficient funds to the countries of Western Europe to enable them effectively to rehabilitate their economic life.
MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Armed and King Ranch's Assault will duel under top weight of 130 pounds in the $50,000 added Widener Handicap at Hialeah Park Feb. 21.

The National Sportsmen's Show is scheduled to open at Grand Central Palace on Feb. 14 for a ten-day run, and according to the sponsors this year's event will be the largest and most varied in the history of the exposition.

On Dec. 19, the day Congress adjourned for the Christmas holidays, President Truman presented to Congress and the country the Administration's version of the European Recovery Program. On Tuesday, Jan. 6, Congress will reconvene, and one of its most important and urgent problems will be consideration of this $17 billion program for long-term aid to Europe.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The "most profound gratitude" of the Hessian people for American food that nourished their school children during 1947 was expressed to President Truman and the American people in a letter received by Mr. Truman and given out by the White House today.
The All-America team of 1947 was named yesterday by the National Soccer Coaches Association of America, which concluded its annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins battled Montreal to a 2-2 tie before 11,159 fans tonight to retain their two-point edge over the Canadiens in the fight for fourth place in the National Hockey League standing.
THE best time to open a singleton, according to the rule, is when the leader has a trump holding such as A-x-x or K-x-x, with which he may hope to regain the lead before all the trumps can be drawn.

MORE and more home gardeners are learning to look for something intriguingly different to use in window gardens between the last burst of fall glory in the borders and the first bulbs of spring. No group of plants offers more than do the succulents.

For its annual benefit, the Carroll Club, Inc. has taken over seats at the evening performance of the Sonja Henie Hollywood Ice Revue on Jan. 26. A meeting to perfect plans for the benefit will be held tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Basil Harris, 36 East Seventy-second Street, president of the club.

Unconscious thirty hours after inhaling gas in her home, Mrs. Grace Kelsey, a 32-year-old Brooklyn mother, started to draw a few natural breaths yesterday afternoon in Kings County Hospital and doctors used the respirator only intermittently.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Harmonica, representing the estate of John J. Watts, flashed to victory in today's $10,000 added Hallandale Handicap and established a new Gulfstream Park mile and a furlong track record of 1:48 4/5.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Prices of wheat dropped sharply today in active dealings on the Board of Trade following reports from Kansas City that farmers were selling large quantities of the cash grain now that the new year has started. Corn and oats, steady early, joined wheat in the decline.
Three youths who met on the baseball diamond of an orphan asylum were in jail last night. One was charged with homicide; the others with a series of hold-up and automobile larcenies.

IN "Day on Earth" Doris Humphrey has achieved one of her greatest works. It is becoming increasingly clear that though we glibly and automatically rate her high among choreographers, we have not begun to realize her true stature.

STANISLAVSKY was a man of exceptional talents, an excellent actor, an inspired director and probably the finest teacher in the modern theatre. As director of the Moscow Art Theatre he had the opportunity of using gifts with which nature had endowed him and experimenting with ideas for the improvement of the theatre in general and acting in particular.

WILLIAM AUERBACH-LEVY on caricature has the same indisputable authority as Freud on sex, Tilden on tennis, or Fanny Farmer on cookery. There are only two or three other living caricaturists who are to be mentioned in the same breath.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- Capt. Hugh V. Blair, 42 years old, was sentenced today to ninety days in the Rockland County Jail at New City by Justice of the Peace John H. Borger after pleading guilty to beating his 8 1/2-month-old daughter Susanne.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- Rotherham United, by defeating lowly Hartlepools United, 3-2, retained its one-point lead in the third division northern section of the English Football League today with the sharp promotion race in that division continuing to overshadow other developments in the soccer picture.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- More than half a million visitors, representing practically every state and many foreign countries, are expected to view the thirty-second annual Pennsylvania Farm Show, opening here a week from tomorrow and continuing through Friday, Jan. 16.
On this final Sunday of the thirty-sixth annual Christmas appeal conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund totals $340,720.30.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 3 -- A new inter-American labor federation will be formed next week in Lima, Peru, where delegates from at least seventeen countries will meet beginning next Saturday.

Backing sufficient quantities of sheet and strip steel, the automotive industry fell short of its production goals during 1947 as the shortages held operations to 65 per cent of the industry's manufacturing capacity. Nevertheless, output approached the creditable level 5,000,000 vehicles -- an annual total surpassed only thrice previously.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- This winter playland in New York City's back yard resounded with the crashing impact of triple-grooved skis as a brilliant array of "skyriders" tested the Bear Mountain 50-meter hill in preparation for tomorrow's Torger Tokle Memorial Jump, one of the nation's foremost events.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 (UP) -- Two jet-propelled P-80 "Shooting Stars" recently streaked across Japan at ground speeds in excess of 775 miles an hour by taking advantage of strong tail winds, the United States Fifth Air Force announced today.
Some 40,000 persons will die of carcinoma of the stomach in the United States this year. Of all the patients who are examined at the Mayo Clinic with X-rays, 2.4 per cent have gastric carcinoma.

Among the measures Congress will have to deal with in its new session is a concurrent resolution for establishment of a Joint Committee of Senate and House to undertake a thorough study of the Trusteed Islands of the Pacific and make recommendations for their governance.

Drs. W.F. Libby and E.C. Anderson of the University of Chicago point out that all living matter accumulates traces of radioactive carbon 14. The fossil remains of any plant or animal that was alive 30,000 years ago are slightly radioactive. Since this radioactivity can be detected and measured, it is now possible to determine the ages of various carbon-containing materials.
SINAIA, Rumania, Jan. 3 -- Former King Michael, who was forced to abdicate Tuesday in a Communist coup, left with his mother, Queen Helen, at 8:25 o'clock tonight for a life in exile.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- Liaqat Ali Khan, Pakistan Premier, declared tonight that "India is out to destroy Pakistan, which Indian leaders still persist in regarding as a part of India itself."

The closing of entries for the Westminster Kennel Club show in Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12 is imminent. Friday morning the Foley Dog Show Organization in Philadelphia had received 1,600 entries. The rate they were coming in indicated that the fewer than 1,000 more to fill the limit of 2,500 would arrive with the mails of tomorrow or the next day.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- The Communist party in Rome has announced a further increase of its membership. The increase is modest, however; indeed, so modest that it marks the failure of the campaign launched by the Communists in midsummer to increase their registered members to 2,500,000.

Representatives of the New York Athletic Club captured eight national championships in individual competition and three national team titles in 1947, it was revealed yesterday in the annual report of Edward M. Swinburne, the former half-miler who serves as chairman of Winged Foot organization's committee on athletics.

ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- Members of the Dewey Administration expressed the belief today that the Legislature would accept the administration's proposal that the state take over Syracuse University and operate it as a state university.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- The third New Year's holiday season since the surrender has been marked by a large-scale return on the part of the Japanese people to the traditional custom of paying devout homage at the Shinto shrines and sites dedicated to the imperial family and imperial ancestors, according to figures available today.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Convinced that Americans and British are making fabulous profits from their bizonal export and import business, the Russians are striving to their utmost to make their zone of occupation as prosperous as they imagine the bizonal area to be.

The entire utility industry -- electric, gas, telephone and transit -- is waiting with optimism for the opening session of hearings in the Wisconsin Supreme Court on an appeal from one of the sharpest reversal decisions in the annals of rate case hearings in a circuit court.

AFTER the confusion of directions and manners in the major contemporary exhibitions it is a relief to look at the drawings of Thomas Rowlandson in this book. The Englishman was, as Arthur W. Heintzelman writes in his commentary, "a profound student of humanity" as well as an explorer in the arts of other countries moved by a wide diversity of interests.
In the wild mountains of northern Greece an important turn came last week in the civil strife that last Greek against Greek for more than three years.

Last Friday's food-buying rush tapered off yesterday with Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz issuing a warning that there is no necessity for housewives to buy in huge quantities. He said foodstuffs to meet normal demands were reaching the city, including meats and produce.

A FEW weeks before the end of the war, sometime in April, 1945, the First Army's Ninth Division captured three or four chateaux in the Harz Mountains of central Germany. From a military point of view that conquest was unimportant.
HE is a veteran publisher who has had good years and bad, and among the bad ones was the late and not overly lamented season that has just passed. But in his eye, as it faced 1948, was hope.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A minimum of 1,245,000 tons of oil country goods, steel casing, tubing and drill pipe, will be needed during 1948 if the oil industry is to meet the demand for oil products in the United States, the Independent Petroleum Association of America reported today.
The tangled controversy over commodity speculation now is engaging these units of Government:

Imports under the lower United States tariff rates of the Geneva trade agreements got off to an active start as the new year opened. To date, there have been 1,475 withdrawals of merchandise from bonded warehouses, it was reported yesterday by Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port of New York.

Five deaf mutes, who allegedly attacked a policeman when he tried to stop them from fighting with a man who had irritated them, were held yesterday in $500 bail each in Brooklyn Felony Court on a charge of felonious assault.

THE fox was only one thing that Roger discovered on his father's Connecticut farm. But it was the thing in which Roger was most interested. Seth, the hired man, told him about the fox and where he lived. Roger wanted to see it and show Seth that he wasn't just "a city boy."

NO round-up of the movie year, such as began in this section last Sunday, would be complete without a few paragraphs devoted to the high-jinks of the industry's drumbeaters. So, herewith some of the more fanciful exhibits of unblushing press agentry which 1947 witnessed.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- A Cornell University scientist, Dr. F.A. Long, asserted today that "cut rates" were increasing research in numerous scientific fields. The member of the department of chemistry added that radioactive isotopes had recently entered a reasonable price range.

THE past five or six years in France have seen a notable revival of interest in the great modern writer, Charles Peguy. Since 1941 many studies of him have appeared, the best being those by Roger Secretain, Andre Rousseaux, and Romain Rolland.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Premier Robert Schuman issued an ultimatum to the National Assembly tonight by rejecting amendments on five major parts of his anti-inflationary tax and loan bill. He made each the subject of a vote of confidence in the Government. The vote will take place Monday.

THE first Stuyvesant Peabody Memorial Award "for outstanding work in and service to pictorialism" has been made to John R. Hogan of Philadelphia, the Photographic Society of America announces. The award, which will be made annually, was established by Patrick Peabody of San Jose, Calif., in memory of his father, a Fellow and vice president of the society.

In the eight days from Dec. 26 through Jan. 2 the residents of New York lost any illusions they may have had about their winter clime. First they were hit by the kind of weather that makes Saint Bernard dogs happy. On Dec. 26 a record snowfall of 25.8 inches covered the city. Then they were hit by weather that makes no one happy.

People's Songs presented another of its well-attended concerts of folk music at Town Hall last night, when Betty Sanders and Tom Glazer sang, in solo and duet, with their own guitar accompaniment. An informal setting was established when the lights went down, the audience moving into the few vacant front seats, and continued with the performers' relaxed comments and their easy rendition of the songs.

Despite salary increases, the nation faces an acute teacher shortage which is endangering the education received by millions of children. Virtually every state in the Union reports that it is impossible to get qualified elementary or high school teachers needed to operate an efficient school program.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va. -- The Mariner's Museum near here, a popular side-trip for vacationists, traces the entire history of man's conquest of the seas. Its displays range from a Vancouver Indian racing canoe to a Japanese World War II suicide submarine; from a Venetian gondola's gilt and crimson lamp to giant reflectors and lenses from modern light-houses.

CAN there be such a thing as a perfect murder? Dr. Clive Riordan thinks there can. He plans to kill his wife's lover in such a way that no one will ever know that the man is dead. Bill Kronin is to disappear, but he is not to die immediately -- not until the hue and cry over his disappearance has abated.

IT all began when Harold Davis, stuffy bibliophile, presented a copy of Tennyson's "Enoch Arden" to his young wife. Neat craftsman that Rufus King is, he leaves nothing to chance. Clara meets a young woman who might be mistaken for her twin.

WHEN Dr. Luther E. Woodward talks to prospective fathers he says that the "sustaining affection" they give to their wives is very, very important for the expected baby. Much of a wife's attitude toward her husband -- and later toward the baby -- depends on the husband's attitude toward her during pregnancy.

STRESS was placed in these columns last week on the number of American artists who had learned much from various phases of the modern movement without being sidetracked in blind alleys and minor arms.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- The Royal Navy, one of the foundations of the British Empire, is being reduced so drastically that many an Englishman who has refused up to now to accept the fact of Britain's waning power finds himself gloomily admitting it.

ROME, Jan. 3 -- The interim aid agreement with the United States was signed this evening by Premier Alcide de Gasperi and Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza for Italy and Ambassador James C. Dunn for the United States.

Continuing the superb teamwork that has brought them six triumphs this season, the Squadron A Regulars trounced the Squadron A Falcons, 17 to 2, in the Metropolitan High Goal League match featuring the indoor polo twin-showing at the Squadron A Armory last night.

THE first returns from college editors and freshman humorists of the current academic year are in, and they reveal that that hallowed undergraduate institution -- the college comic or funny magazine -- is the same as ever. The same cigarette ads, the same parody issues, even largely the same jokes.

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- If Greece were an island, or a sub-continent like Australia, there would be no Greek problem before the world The Greek Government, inept as it is, and the Greek Army, chaotic as it has been, would be able to deal with guerrilla forces and the Communist Markos "government."

ACCORDING to Pudd'nhead Wilson, "it were not beat that we should all think alike," else (as he sensibly put it) there'd be no point in horse-races. There would also be no point in people reviewing films -- nor in the New York Film Critics voting on the best screen achievements of the year.

THE first subject on the Hollywood agenda after the holidays is always the Academy of Motion Arts and Sciences award nominations, a local tribal rite in which motion-picture makers participate with superstitious reverence.

DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 3 -- General, chestnut gelding owned by Mr. and Mrs. J.A. Hale of Greenwich, won the jumper championship in the sixteenth annual indoor horse show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club tonight. Reserve went to the Hutchinson Farms' Peg's Pride.

THIS book is a detailed account of German re-education, as planned and implemented by the American Military Government. An insider has written it: Marshall Knappen, in civilian life a historian and political scientist at Michigan State College, was not only on the staff of the original planning unit, but after Germany's defeat continued to serve in a leading position.

UPON her arrival at the home of Aunt Daisy Hander, Marcella Bradley finds the household wrought up over the disappearance of Lucille Logan. It is feared that Lucille has been drowned. Actually she has been murdered.
IF it isn't too soon after the holiday uproar to take a furtive look at 1948, here are some entries due in what remains of the first month of the new semester:

A Rhode Island State basketball team, which refused to succumb even when confronted thrice by 14-point deficits, staged a nerve-tingling second-half rally that carried Frank Keaney's Rams to a 63-59 victory over St. John's of Brooklyn last night at Madison Square Garden.

MONROE, Ga., Jan. 3 (AP) -- The white residents of Walton County today scheduled a mass meeting at the court house here next Friday to raise funds for the reconstruction of two Negro churches at Logansville, recently burned.

DURING 1947 the scheduled airlines of the United States apparently realized the great possibilities of air cargo. The gains they made in air freight and express were impressive but will probably be as nothing compared with the figures for this year.

THE critical lack of parking space continues to be New York City's major traffic problem. Countless recommendations, suggestions and plans have been put forward in an effort to solve it; several schemes have been tried. But the situation has shown no improvement and in the new year all signs point toward even more congested conditions.

BOSTON, Jan. 3 -- The Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace may well become the deciding factor in carrying Massachusetts for the Republican party in a national election for the first time since 1924. Conservative Democrats, nevertheless, are considerably relieved.

SPOKANE, Wash., Jan. 3 (AP) -- A new series of motion pictures designed "to encourage the application of religious principles to great contemporary problems" was announced today by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America.

The new Swedish motorliner Stockholm will start her maiden voyage from Goeteborg to New York on Feb. 21, G.H. Lundbeck Jr., managing director of the Swedish American Line, announced yesterday. The Stockholm is scheduled to arrive here on March 1 and will start the return leg of the voyage on March 6.

THIS is a study of four political "architects" (Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln and Franklin D. Roosevelt), of their characters and personalities, and the main ideas they embodied or expressed. The author is a clergyman and news commentator, a friend of liberal and humane causes, who has read American history with discernment. He retells important bits of it here with freshness, but this is no authoritative work of information. It is a book of interpretation.

BEHIND ivy-covered walls and electronically operated gates, in a nine-room converted playhouse adjoining the Brentwood mansion her fabulous earnings bought, lives a phenomenon of motion pictures that never again may be matched.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The Department of Justice asked the Federal District Court today for immediate judgment in the civil anti-trust suit against the National Association of Real Estate Boards, the Washington Real Estate Board, the executive vice president of the national association and fifteen members of the Washington board.

THE Chinese Republic celebrated its new constitution by issuing on Constitution Day, Dec. 25, three commemorative stamps. The design shows a bound copy of the constitution. Values and colors are: $2,000 red orange, $3,000 blue and $5,000 green.

NANKING, Jan. 3 -- A fiscal accounting, made today by Finance Minister O.K. Yui to a committee of the People's Political Council revealed that the Chinese Government ended the year 1947 with a budgetary deficit of 26,400,000,000,000 Chinese dollars.

ATHENS, Jan. 3 -- While fighting continued north and west of Konitsa the rebel forces of Gen. Markos Vafiades developed another attack late yesterday in the Philiates area of Epirus, near the coast at Corfu Strait.

AN inquiry into best-selling reproductions at selected galleries, museums and department stores gives evidence of no startling recent departures in popular taste. If anything, public taste today seems characterized by its lack of insistence on any particular types of painting, its genial accommodation to whatever publishers have made available.

THE dispersal of one of the smallest but most distinguished American private collections of old masters was completed this week when seven paintings formerly in the possession of the late Henry Goldman were purchased by Wildenstein Co. Mr. Goldman, who died in 1937 and had been senior partner of Goldman, Sachs Co. until his retirement in 1917, began collecting in about 1912.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 3 -- Whether as another stratagem in the present war of nerves with British commercial negotiators or as the beginning of an entirely new policy toward cattle raisers, the Government referred again last night to the possible "eventual suspension of meat shipments to Britain."

THE author of this book was chief investigator for the United States Senate Subcommittee on Health and Education of several years ago, better known as the Pepper Committee. This committee conducted an extensive study of medical care in the United States.

LAST week-end's historic snowstorm offered photographers the challenge of documenting a unique event -- the greatest snowstorm in the history of New York City -- rather than just another snowfall. Most cameras were aimed at snow-covered automobiles, streets, trees, doorsteps, housetops and similar subjects.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3 -- Yale's eight-oared varsity crew defeated Pennsylvania by three feet in a thrilling race over the 2,000-meter Olympic distance on Lake Worth before an estimated 20,000 persons today.

PRAGUE, Jan. 3 -- Hubert Ripka, Czechoslovak Minister of Foreign Trade, said today that the Marshall Plan definitely would benefit non-participating European states such as Czechoslovakia. He also indicated that Czechoslovakia would materially contribute to the success of the Marshall program.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Browning Ross, 22-year-old Navy veteran and Villanova sophomore, ran away from some more highly advertised track stars tonight to win the featured mile in The Washington Evening Star games.

In the light of the United Nations decision establishing an independent Jewish state in Palestine, the United Palestine Appeal and its constituent agencies will require $283,156,000 to carry on their work during 1948, Dr. Israel Goldstein, chairman, announced yesterday.

THIS book will be as useful as a spare tire. You can get along without it, but it's mighty handy to have around. Its double columns are packed with the information the average traveler needs about historic sites, scenic views, national parks, monuments, art galleries and general points of interest in the forty-eight states.

LIEUT. BILL WEIGAND is looking for his wife, who disappeared soon after she almost witnessed a murder. Perhaps she saw something that she was not intended to see. Pam North thinks so, and so does Bill, who knows that Pam's mind works faster than her tongue, which is going some.

Today the New Year is only four days old. But had it not been for the blizzard that almost totally curtailed traffic and experience had repeated itself, accidents would have already taken the lives of nearly fifty New Yorkers, have seriously injured another 5,000 and have cost over three million dollars.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand -- It has been years since the American pleasure traveler visited this land way down under, and the renewal, finally, of tourist traffic is being welcomed here enthusiastically.

SALT LAKE CITY, Jan. 3 -- If comments in that typically American forum, the Pullman lounge, are an accurate index to thought hereabouts, interest in European aid is virtually non-existent. Business men, ranchers and salesmen aboard the overnight Denver-Salt Lake Prospector discuss prices, taxes, sports and weather in that order, but unsolicited comment on the Marshall Plan is absent.

THE TIMES of Dec. 28 carried a letter signed by four former officials connected with our activities in Germany. In essence, this letter is an argument for the disastrous Roosevelt-Morgenthau-Henry White pastoralization scheme for Germany. Fortunately, the large contingent of American Senators and Representatives who visited Europe this summer furnish a bulwark against a recurrence of such fallacies and schemes.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- Little Ben Hogan, repeating his performance of a year ago, took charge of the twenty-second annual Los Angeles open golf tournament at the midway point today as 10,000 spectators turned out under ideal weather conditions at the Riviera Country Club.
THE literary developments of the last century were measured by every twenty years -- the Forties, the Sixties and Eighties. Every ten years, at the least, of this century marks some new development.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (UP) -- The House Labor Committee today put a "rush" label on a measure aimed at breaking James C. Petrillo's ban on musical recordings.
Senator Francis J. Myers of Pennsylvania called last night for a return to "a measure of economic restraint" to check current inflation.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 3 (AP) -- Lou Rowan's Mrs. Rabbit, a 6-to-1 shot, today won the $50,000 added Santa Susana Stakes, a seven-furlong dash for 3-year-old fillies. Brookfield Farms' Itsabet was second, with Candy Kane third.

ST. GEORGE, Grenada -- Grenada, "The Spice Island of the West," should rank, before this season is over, with Barbados, Montego Bay and Ciudad Trujillo as a well-equipped vacation center. Its ambitious citizens, prosperous from the growing of cocoa and spices, recently formed a corporation to build the Santa Maria de la Concepcion Hotel.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 3 -- Increased riding comfort and safety are emphasized in new "super balloon tires" announced today by the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company here. They will be utilized on many 1948 automobiles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman transferred the chairmanship of the Cabinet Air Coordinating Committee from the State to the Commerce Department today in view of the emphasis expected soon to be put on domestic aviation.

In a year-end statement Roy K. Ferguson, president of the St. Regis Paper Company, predicted continued strong demand for the company's products in 1948. He estimated that the new year's sales may exceed the 1947 volume of $140,000,000 by 15 per cent.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 3 -- The flag of South African Union has been hoisted on unoccupied islands of the Prince Edward group in the remote Southern Indian Ocean where an air base will be established, it became known today.

Why are leaves green and roses red? Why are fruits sweet? How does grain produce starch? There is no profounder mystery than all this. A seed is planted and up springs an oak, an elm or one of a million different kinds of plants. All vegetation is carbon in the form of cellulose and much in the form of sugar and starch.

WHAT you are about to read is going to make a lot of actors angry. I think experience is a prerequisite of performance. I don't mean so many years at drama school and so many seasons in stock and so many weeks on "Ma Perkins."

TAUNGS, South Africa, Dec. 23 -- This town in Cape Province, the site of paleontological excavations by University of California scientists, has been visited by few South Africans. Even fewer Americans have heard of it.

DURING the year just ended more than 2,400 major and minor varieties of postal stamps were issued. The figure recorded to date is 2,416, contributed by 139 Governments. This is a minimum total and is certain to be augmented by stamps which some countries released during the year's final fortnight but which have not yet reached New York.

All of us who have watched the events of the past two years have become alarmingly aware of the steady move "toward reaction on the right." The liberal, progressive forces of this great nation, consisting of a sizable leadership and a real following of persons all over the country, have been paralyzed and immobilized by fear.
BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- A three-cornered stalemate over what makes fit reading for Berlin students has brought about a halt in the approval of textbooks for the city's schools.

REGINALD DENHAM is right [in his letter Dec. 7] when he says many actors "cannot read. They cannot pronounce the simplest words correctly." The men he speaks of have no idea of verse, no inkling of the fact that versification was invented for stage speaking purposes, nor the slightest curiosity as to general knowledge.

A graduate program for elementary teachers leading to the degree of Master of Science in Education will be offered during the 1948 summer session at the New Jersey State Teachers Colleges at Newark and Trenton. Of the thirty-two semester hours required for the degree, approximately twenty hours will be spent in three selected areas of study: language arts, social studies, mathematics, science, creative arts or health, physical education and safety.

RANGOON, Burma, Sunday, Jan. 4 -- Burma, the second great Asiatic area to become independent of the United Kingdom in six months, became an independent republic at 4:20 A.M. today (5:20 P.M., Saturday, EST), at the hour and minute that Buddhist astrologers had picked as the most favorable for its birth as an independent nation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman through an executive order established the machinery today for carrying out the provisions of the Republican-sponsored anti-inflation law by delegating authority for its administration to Federal agencies most closely connected to the commodities concerned.

New York yesterday had virtually won its fight to shake loose from the paralyzing effects of the Dec. 26 record-breaking snowstorm and the New Year's Day aftermath of sleet. Mayor O'Dwyer announced in the morning that every street in the city was passable and every fire hydrant accessible.

AGAINST the backdrop of grazing land and mountain ranges, and caught up in the suspicions and thought patterns of the country, the personalities of this novel work out a story of jealousy and pride. After twelve years of happy married life, the MacFarlans are propelled toward disaster by Mac's bitter recriminations after the death of his father.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Senator Irving S. Ives, Republican, of New York, will marry his secretary, Mrs. Marion Mead Crain, on a date yet to be determined, according to plans revealed here today. Their engagement was announced by Mr. and Mrs. Orin W. Mead of Bradford, Pa., Mrs. Crain's parents.

A research worker who is studying diseases, for example, diphtheria, bovine tuberculosis in cattle or apple scab, often requires authentic cultures either to help him in identifying the organisms he has isolated or to test new drugs or treatments. If he is trying to find means for preventing micro-biological attack which will rot sandbags or timber, or if he is studying tropic-proofing of packed stores, he may also need standard strains of the destructive organisms.
WASHINGTON -- The United States Travel Bureau, which became a war casualty shortly after its birth in 1940, has been revived to help more tourists see more of America all the year around.

In Frank Nugent's "Who Makes the Movie -- Writer or Director?" I note with no small interest that the question of the actor's possible contribution is not raised. I gather then that, in the Hollywood scheme of things, actors rate only slightly above tailors' dummies and couturiers' mannequins.

IN the annals of American politics there are few narratives which match that of the LaFollettes for courage, persistence, integrity and drama. The LaFollette story is an inherent part of our political history for the past fifty years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Edwin W. Pauley sent the records of his speculative dealings on commodity markets to Washington today in response to demands of the Senate Appropriations Committee.

PALESTINE, Jan. 3 -- Fear and grief are both growing in Palestine as Zionists and Arabs kill each other in a struggle that hardly can be dignified with the name of war because it is more like a great mass vendetta.

A drop of 25 per cent last year is the amount of money paid as unemployment insurance to residents of New York State was reported yesterday by the State Division of Placement and Unemployment Insurance. In 1947, the report said, $274,871,434 was spent, whereas in 1946 the figure was 372,117,447.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall said today that whatever justification there was for complaints about tax-free disability payments to retired military officers was traceable principally to the law and not to its administration. He added that the law should be changed.
NANKING, Jan. 3 -- Government counter-attacks have apparently disrupted Communist threats for the time being on several major battle fronts in Manchuria, North China and Central China.
STAMFORD, Conn., Jan. 3 -- Atomic Energy Week will be observed here from Jan. 4 to 11 with schools, churches, civic organizations and local and national scientific groups participating.

" GARDEN Setting for Your Home," the 1948 series of four programs by garden experts, will be presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES on four consecutive Wednesdays starting on Jan. 21. The meetings will be held at 2:30 and 8 P.M. in Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

When the Eightieth Congress reassembles on the day after tomorrow its term will be half over. No doubt many members will be thinking of that fact. No doubt many will be wondering whether they will again be in their accustomed seats when the Eighty-first Congress organizes, one year from yesterday.

A SYMPHONY orchestra's chief excuse for being is its devotion to art. When it plays tile finest music of the past and our own time, as most of the nation's ensembles are doing, now that the season is under full sway, it is discharging its duty to the community and it is honored as a shining ornament of our civilization.

Johnny Lujack, Notre Dame quarterback, will receive the Dr. Matthew G. Golden Memorial Trophy as the outstanding Catholic football player in the United States on Saturday. The presentation will take place at the fourth annual sports dinner sponsored by the Fathers Guild and Alumni of Brooklyn Prep at the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

FOR 5, 6 and 7 year olds Lena Barksdale has filled an imaginary bag full to overflowing with stories and poems until every child will feel rich in reading treasure. There are old familiar fairy stories, folk tales from other lands, tales of everyday life.

With three pages of agile casuistry, Chester Bowles would persuade us that the way to save "democracy" is to adopt a sweeping socialism. He wants credit controls, rent controls, price controls and allocation controls, all in the sacred name of democracy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3 -- Former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer of New York, national president of the American Jewish Committee, said tonight that the present low status of organized anti-Semitism affords "a precious opportunity" for a tactical shift by the foes of bigotry.

Magistrate Morris Rothenberg, president of the Jewish National Fund of America, asserted yesterday that the disorders created by Arab bands "are directed not only against the Jews of Palestine but are principally aimed at the authority of the United Nations."
JERUSALEM, Jan. 3 -- The British authorities cracked down seriously today on the Arabs for the first time since Arab-Jewish disorders began here with the United Nations partition vote.
OTTAWA, Jan. 3 -- Finance Minister Douglas C. Abbott is planning to visit Washington and probably also New York next week for a series of information-seeking conversations.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- The previously announced resignation on Dec. 22 of Edwin W. Pauley as Democratic National Committeeman from California was formally recognized tonight in a statement made by J. Howard McGrath, chairman of the National Committee.

Janus must have been the strangest of immortals, for the back of his head was exactly like the front. The Romans pictured him as a dignified old gentleman with two nicely trimmed beards, looking out over the world with two calm, steady gazes.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 3 (UP) -- A merchant ship captain whose hobby is watching skilled surgeons at work successfully performed his first operation by flashlight at sea to save the life of a crew member who had been stabbed twelve times, it was learned today.

In another of those heart-tingling finishes on which he holds the exclusive patent, gangling Reggie Pearman of New York University got up in the last few strides to defeat Roscoe Browne of the Pioneer Club in the John J. Deignan Memorial 600 last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- In an effort to persuade the Soviet Union to renounce its boycott of the United Nations Little Assembly, which will convene here Monday for the first time, the United States plans to sidestep at first any major issue that might further antagonize Russia, it was disclosed today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The effectiveness of the Soviet Union's new de-rationed trading system was indicated today as the state announced the institution of an eight-hour day in ordinary food stores, where a full assortment of goods appeared to be on sale and few customer queues were noted.

THE plastic age has produced three soft, smooth-textured sturdy picture books for the very youngest of the family to chew, tug at, float in the bathtub, or just look at. The publishers dare you to put them through the washing machine.

After nearly ten years' absence, the British novelist-playwright, J.B. Priestley, recently passed through New York to and from the UNESCO conference in Mexico City. On his return to England he gave his impressions of the city revisited in a broadcast over the BBC.

CHARLES WISNER BARRELL, secretary to the Shakespeare Fellowship, expresses surprise in his letter Dec. 21, that so many reviewers of my novel and the Maurice Schwartz play, "Shylock and His Daughter," are unfamiliar with the Roth and Sisson research which indicates that Jews were living in England at the time of Shakespeare.
President Truman praised the Joint Distribution Committee yesterday on its completion of a third of a century of help to distressed Jews abroad.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- On the eve of the proclamation of full independence by Burma the first country to secede fully and formally from the British Commonwealth since the American colonies, Foreign Secretary Bevin sent a message of congratulations to his Burmese opposite.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- Remarkable findings on the results of atom-smashing by the University of California's cyclotron at Berkeley were reported today. The papers were read at the final session of a two-day meeting of the American Physical Society.

There was another round of parties last night for debutantes. Mr. and Mrs. Frank Delaney gave a supper dance at their home, 4 East Sixty-sixth Street, for Miss Virginia Leigh, daughter of the hostess. For the event the apartment was transformed into a summer setting with pink flowers.
More than 124,000,000 visits were made by New Yorkers to their parks and playgrounds during 1947, according to a Parks Department estimate yesterday. It was a new record.

If official reports from Athens, sometimes unreliable in the past, are correct, the Communist attempt to establish a "free state" on Greek soil has definitely failed. The siege of Konitsa has been lifted and General Markos' Red government still lacks even a mailing address unless it is somewhere in Yugoslavia or Bulgaria.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Violent fighting erupted in Jerusalem's old walled city tonight and informants said that Jews and Arabs in that sacred area were locked in "an all-out" fight for control of the ancient streets.
