Recent publicity given to the prevalence of trading in commodities has furnished new impetus to the study of reform measures leading not only to restrictions upon such transactions, but also to correction of certain practices in avoidance of the income tax resorted to in reporting profits and losses thereon.

TORONTO, Jan. 3 -- World champion Toronto came from behind twice before 13,972 fans at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight to earn a 5-5 tie with the New York Rangers and increase their National Hockey League lead to three points over the idle Detroit Red Wings.

Just why the Snowbird should be called a Junco nobody seems to know; but Junco is the scientific name and is more and more used as the common name. Even the ornithologists hesitate before they say that the Latin word for seed is "juncus"; the Snowbird eats quantities of weed seed, therefore Junco is a logical name.

IT has become evident that the colonial era of American civilization, small as was the theatre of operations, offers to the reflective analyst the prefiguration of a more stupendous drama. Much of the best work achieved by American scholars over the last three decades has been consciously inspired by a desire to formulate, out of the colonial laboratory, generalizations that may be fruitful in a wider application.

AN important new agency of the United Nations is about to meet for the first time It is technically known as the Interim Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. It is popularly called the "Little Assembly." The creation of this body was one of the major acts of the General Assembly which met last fall.

STRATFORD, Conn., Jan. 3 -- Roger Ross, 18 years old, of Pittsburgh, was arrested for murder here last night on a tip inadvertently given to the police by his mother, Mrs. Bernice Ross, who was in near-by Bridgeport visiting friends for the holidays.

Penrock's Promotion, a solid black cocker spaniel belonging to Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Whitehouse, N.J., launched his ring career with a noteworthy victory yesterday by taking the Futurity Stake at the opening of the American Spaniel Club's specialty at Hotel Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- The Maritime Commission has disapproved of measures to amend the Jones Act to permit Canadian vessels to carry passengers and freight among Alaskan ports.

IRA WOLFERT, author and newspaper man, whose report on the sea battles off Guadalcanal won him the Pulitzer Prize in 1943, has sold the film rights to his novel, "Tucker's People" to John Garfield and Bob Roberts, producer and star of the currently successful "Body and Soul," it was learned last week.

The Brooklyn College basketball team defeated the Brooklyn Poly quintet on the loser's court last night, 74 to 59. The game was close in the first half, which ended with the Kingsmen in front, 36 to 29, but the visitors were clearly the superior toward the end.
OMAHA, Jan. 3 -- There is strong Marshall plan support in this region.

I read with interest Alma Denny's compilation of quotes entitled "Never Again!" which presumably is offered as counsel for all New Year's resolutions-makers. May I postscript a note of consolation for the resolutions-breakers? It is a quote from Emerson which condones all aberrations: "A foolish consistency is the hobgoblin of little minds."

EACH year 1,000,000 square miles of sea ice breaks from the Arctic cap and drifts south to menace the crowded steamship lanes of the North Atlantic. This "white terror" is as frightening a reality to the loran and radar seamen of today as it was to John and Sebastian Cabot.

INDIANS -- genuine redskins -- a band of fifty-three right off the reservation, descended on a local radio station here recently, and in a few minutes war-whoops resounded from loudspeakers throughout Utah. All was peaceful in most respects, however, since the Uintah and Ouray tribesmen ranged from 6 to 16 years in age and were accompanied by a squadron of teachers from the Whiterocks Indian School at Fort Duchesne.

Staving off a mild second-half rally by the visitors, the City College basketball team scored its seventh victory in nine starts by defeating Moravian College, 74 -- 60, last night at the C.C.N.Y. gymnasium.

KODIAK, Alaska, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Navy headquarters today reported word from a search plane that the cannery tender Spencer was broken on the rocky coast near Kanatak, opposite Kodiak Island, but that six survivors were seen moving about on the beach.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Prime Minister Attlee accused the Soviet Union and her satellite states tonight of threatening the rest of Europe with a "new imperialism," which he defined as "ideological, economic and strategic."

Accordion recitals are rare, but New York has now heard two within a week, both by 13-year-old boys. Joseph Pizzi gave one last Sunday at Town Hall and Charles Amato gave the other last night at Times Hall.
An estimated 65,000 pounds of TNT were found accidentally yesterday in cases marked "used industrial machinery" that were being loaded aboard a Palestine-bound freighter at a Jersey City pier.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- President Truman sent a message of congratulation today to the Sawbwa of Yawnghwe, President of the Union of Burma, on the occasion of the coming into being of the Union tomorrow.

In the closing months of 1947 several large New York banks, after watching the Treasury break its rigid pattern of interest rates adopted during the war, acted to raise their own minimum rates on prime commercial loans from 1 1/2 per cent to 1 3/4 per cent.

ACROSS this department's desk last week came two clippings which relate to what long has been a serious void in New York radio. That void has been the lack of any machinery by which the thoughtful and interested citizen may play an active role by encouraging what is good in radio, disapproving of what is shoddy and, at all events, learning more about the medium which plays such an important part in everyday life.

JENNIFER CALDWELL is worried because her employer, David Cartwright, has declared his intention of leaving her a legacy of $100,000 in the new will he is about to draw up. Jennifer is afraid that her husband will not like it and she knows that Cartwright's relatives will be furious.

IN this volume the former United States Minister to Hungary has brought together much pertinent information about Hungary's reluctant association with Hitler's Germany and her subsequent devastation by Soviet Russia.

LONDON, Sunday, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Russia's view that the Council of Foreign Ministers of Britain, the United States, Russia and China should prepare the Japanese peace treaty has been reiterated in a note to China by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov on Dec. 30, the Moscow radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Officials of eight major steel companies were asked by a Congressional investigating committee today to testify Monday on alleged "black market" operations in steel involving an estimated $1,000,000,000 a year.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Dr. Elis Berven, famed Swedish cancer specialist, left for Moscow today after a call that his son described as "fantastically mysterious." The Swedish press speculated that his patient might be Premier Stalin but cited no foundation for its guesses.

AS men of good-will and perception, Dr. Castiglioni and Dr. Krumbhaar -- University of Pennsylvania pathologist and the noted medical historian who served as his translator-editor -- realized that while man was rapidly destroying himself during the last war years he also was creating at, perhaps, an equal pace.

Revival of NRA schemes of self-regulation of business through partial suspension of anti-trust laws is expected to emerge from recently enacted anti-inflation legislation, legal experts on business problems revealed here yesterday.

FROM Plato and Aristotle to the present day some of the finest minds mankind has produced have devoted all or much of their thought to the problems of human conduct. For a Buddha in his Eightfold Path it was seemingly a simple thing to lay down the principle of "right conduct" and virtually leave it at that.

Flotillas of power and sail craft, assortments of marine engines, accessories and other equipment are converging on New York by rail, truck and waterway from many sections of the country for the National Motor Boat Show, which will open for the thirty-eighth time Friday night at Grand Central Palace.

Union leaders early today postponed for one week a threatened strike of oil barge and tanker workers after Mayor O'Dwyer had urged them to defer the walk-out because of the fuel and food shortage faced by the city.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3 -- Congressmen from this area are getting little comment from their constituents on the Marshall Plan.

PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 3 -- Fear that actual operation of the Marshall Plan may boost food prices still higher in the United States seems to dominate the communications which Pacific Northwest members of Congress are receiving from the folks at home.
MONTREAL, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Unemployment in most countries during the latter half of 1947 fell below the levels of the 1946 period, the International Labor Office said today.

The nation's aluminum industry, now entering its sixtieth year, exceeded all previous peacetime production records in 1947 with an output of about 1,140,000,000 pounds, according to a year-end statement by Roy A. Hunt, president of the Aluminum Company of America.

MELCHIOR LENGYEL of Beverly Hills, Calif., erstwhile of Budapest, Hungary, and occasionally of London and New York, has a niche all to himself in Hollywood's mnemonic hall of fame. He is the man "who made Garbo laugh." In 1939 the assignment to make the great Garbo laugh was indeed an assignment! It turned out so well, however, that he was nominated by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for his efforts.

The United Fruit Company will complete the building of eighteen all-refrigerated vessels with the launching of the Morazan on Thursday at the Bethlehem-Sparrows Point Shipyard, Baltimore, Md. The ship will be sponsored by Mrs. Thomas. D. Cabot of Boston, wife of one of the fruit company's directors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- The frank statement of Chairman Seth W. Richardson last week has left the strongest impression that the Loyalty Review Board will carry out its task of screening disloyal employes from government service in a manner as careful as it is thorough.

BERLIN, Jan. 3 -- Labor organizations from all countries participating in the Marshall Plan will hold the first of a series of conferences early this spring to determine how they can best aid the industrial recovery of Europe, Irving Brown, European representative of the American Federation of Labor said today.
Meatless Tuesdays and eggless Thursdays will be dropped this week by most restaurants that have not already abandoned them, it was indicated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Eightieth Congress opens its second session Tuesday with momentous foreign and domestic decisions before it. These decisions will be more difficult because of the supercharged atmosphere of a Presidential election year.

A group of operators represented by Seymour Herzog, attorney, resold the five-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 100 feet at 649 West 184th Street, adjoining Broadway, to William Wolf, who bought the house last month through Nehring Bros., the brokers in the resale.
Fourth in a series of articles giving the views of leading designers on the changing fashion picture and the outlook for 1948.

RANGOON, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- Sir Hubert Rance, last British Governor in Burma, sailed downriver from Rangoon in the Royal Naval cruiser Birmingham early today, cheered by thousands of Burmese citizens who lined the wharfs and river banks to bid farewell to the last representative of British rule in Burma.

HAVANA, Jan. 4 -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment decided last night to refer to a subcommittee, the new issue of voting power created by a debate on Australian and New Zealand amendments to a provision in the proposed charter for the International Trade Organization on cooperation between the trade organization and the International Monetary Fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Army has developed a new 1,000-horsepower vehicle capable of hauling some of its biggest weapons back and forth on the battlefield at high speed, it was disclosed today.

The snow and sleet of the past week proved more of a factor in slowing down the business of the foreign exchange market than conditions usually operative at a holiday or a year-end period. The battle of the elements kept many a banker and dealer away from his desk or on abbreviated time, so that but passing interest was given to making of new commitments. Fortunately, evened accounts helped in meeting the situation.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Jan. 4 -- Fifty members of the Long Island Division of the National League of Masonic Clubs, headed by Samuel F. Kaiser of Rosedale, made a pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt in Youngs Memorial Cemetery this afternoon.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Britain said good-by to Burma today in graceful and friendly fashion as that former colony became independent.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Details became known today of a Conservative scheme of reform of the House of Lords, in which the hereditary principle of membership would be severely limited.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 -- The steel industry brought its ingot operating rate up 9 points last week from the week before to 97 per cent of rated capacity. This was only 1 point below the activity prevailing in the week before the Christmas holiday.

In a wholly non-political sense, experience of life indicates that man has to deal not with one world but with two, the Rev. Dr. Theodore Cuyler Speers, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

Withdrawal of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America from the American Labor party in disapproval of the third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President is expected this week, it was learned yesterday. The resignation of Hyman Blumberg, executive vice president of the Amalgamated, as state chairman of the Labor party also is understood to be scheduled.

PEIPING, China, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Chinese Government dispatches said today the Communists had blown up a big railroad bridge across the Liuku River in southwest Manchuria, delaying for many weeks any prospect of restoring rail traffic between Peiping and Mukden.

DETROIT, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Red Wings rode their fourth straight National Hockey League victory to within a single point of the lead tonight by defeating the Canadiens, 6 to 2, before a crowd of 13,365.

ABOARD THE RUMANIAN ROYAL TRAIN, Jan. 4 -- The special train bearing former King Michael of Rumania into exile crossed the Enns River in the United States zone of Austria at 9:30 o'clock tonight. As the United States occupied area was reached a member of the King's suite said: "Now we are on the sunny side of the street."

A ten-year land program in the future Jewish state in Palestine, involving expenditure of $880,000, 000 for the purchase and reclamation of 3,000,000 dunams (660,000 acres) of land, was adopted yesterday at a leaders' conference of the Jewish National Fund in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The world this week welcomed a new nation into the great global family. Free Burma has broken completely away from the bonds of the British Empire. But unlike our own secession, in 1776, the break was achieved by peaceful negotiation instead of war. Yet by yielding Britain does not lose all in Burma.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 4 (Reuters) -- The formation of an Interim Federal Government in preparation for a sovereign United States of Indonesia is to begin immediately, a communique from the Netherlands East Indies Government announced today.

PRAGUE, Jan. 4 -- An increasing desire here to see the Marshall Plan succeed and open resentment against the anti-Marshall Plan program of the Communist Information Bureau are now explained by men directly responsible for the success of this country's nationalized economy in terms of foreign trade.

Nick Mickoski supplied a hair-raising finish to the Eastern Hockey League battle at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon. Hitting the cords with six seconds of the game left, Mickoski enabled the New York Rovers to tie the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 6 -- 6, before 11,722 on lookers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- W. T. Faricy, president of the Asso ciation of American Railroads, said tonight that Robert R. Young is the slow man in passenger equipment modernization and is trying to make up for it by "vociferations."
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

The Rev. Louis W. Pitt Jr. conducted a communion service for the first time yesterday at the Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, where he was ordained and where his father, the Rev. Dr. Louis W. Pitt, has been rector since 1940.

The wintry winds that blow down from the Alps give the resourceful Swiss plenty of inspiration for concocting dishes like neuchatel fondue, which is warming as well as appetizing. Combining two of the country's most famous products, cheese and a white cherry brandy known as kirsch, the fondue is really an extra-rich welsh rabbit.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Anthony Callipare of Rochester won the Northeastern speed skating championship today by a wide margin.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Charles de Gaulle, addressing the miners and other workers in the industrial center of St. Etienne, today made his first out-and-out appeal for support from the working classes of France.

The National City Bank of New York, largest bank on the Atlantic Coast, issued for publication today its annual statement as of Dec. 31. The figures showed an increase in resources to $5,203,284,028 from $4,957,416,117 at the close of September, and $4,977,735,667 on Dec. 31, 1946.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Two members of Yale University's crew squad, returning from a regatta at West Palm Beach, Fla., were injured early today, one critically, when their automobile overturned.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 4 -- Preparations for the liquidation of two top governing bodies of the United States and British zones may be initiated this week so that a vastly strengthened Bizonal Economic Council may assume broadened and more direct authority, it was learned today.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 4 -- Ten children, all of Archbold, Ohio, were killed and two seriously injured this afternoon when a New York Central passenger train, No. 59, the Chicagoan, running west to Chicago, struck a combination farm utility sleigh, drawn by a tractor, at Rupp crossing, one mile east of this community.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, State Health Commissioner, today announced the appointment of Dr. William A. Brumfield of Delmar as deputy commissioner to succeed Dr. James E. Perkins. The appointment, effective immediately carries a salary of $11,286 annually.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 4 -- Under the wing of the Communist party, an organizational meeting of about seventy-five Bavarians took place today in a Munich beer hall. Other political parties, boycotted the session.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The financial event of the past week has been, of course, the announcement of the issue of Government stock to holders of securities of British railways as compensation for the state's acquisition of the properties, which took place on the first day of this year.

The recent "re-pegging" of the support level for United States government bonds "did not represent a step in a retreat from a policy of supporting the Treasury bond market, but had been decided upon in lieu of a gradual recession in support prices over an extended period," the Federal Reserve Bank of New York states in its Monthly Review, just published.
On the basis of an announcement yesterday it seemed that the bridge players of the New York Central's Harlem Division had something for which to look forward.
Two new films are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

TOKYO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Japanese Government is preparing a five-year economic program based on the hope that Japan can begin exporting more than a billion dollars worth of goods a year by 1951. This is four times the present exports.

Conference that will bring together leaders in medicine, psychiatry, the social sciences, public health and education will highlight the centennial observance of the Community Service Society this year, it was made known yesterday.

Gertrude R. Rather, buyer of blouses, sweaters, skirts and sportswear for Gimbel Brothers, Pittsburgh, upon her return from the California markets will join Saks-34th in a similar capacity, succeeding Lucille Glazer, resigned.

HAVANA, Jan. 4 -- The third Pan-American Congress of Ophthalmology opened tonight in the House of Representatives chamber. Some 800 delegates of Pan-American nations and scientists from other nations were present, as well as diplomatic representatives and Cuban professional men.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Norwegians dominated the first major ski jump of the season, the third annual Torger Tokle Memorial event, witnessed by an enthusiastic gathering of several thousand who huddled along the snow-packed Bear Mountain 50-meter hill today.

Perhaps they underestimated the worth of their rivals. Or perhaps they were too tired after their gruelling struggle in Toronto on Saturday night. At any rate, the New York Rangers bowed to the cellar-dwelling Chicago Black Hawks in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

Greater state aid to cities, increased salaries for teachers and state employes, establishment of a state university and expenditure of an additional $500,000,000 for low-rent housing were urged yesterday by Max Bloom, chairman of the state legislative commission of the Liberal party, and Ben Davidson, its executive director, in making public the party's legislative program.

Americans, in their desire for freedom, have mistakenly interpreted the doctrine of separation of church and state, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in his sermon at Christ Methodist Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The statement of condition of the Guaranty Trust Company as of Dec. 31, 1947, shows total resources of $2,848,543,557, compared with $2,869,596,711 at the end of September, and resources of $2,893,376,869 on Dec. 31, 1946. Deposits at the end of 1947 totaled $2,451,659,286, a decline of $23,442,121 for the quarter and $49,854,172 for the year.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 4 (AP) -- For Champion Jockey Johnny Longden, the next seventy-seven victories will be the hardest -- certainly the most important.

Six standout speedsters are scheduled to compete in the Great American sprint series, one of the feature events of the sixteenth annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, indoor track meet at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn Saturday night.

Conflicting opinions on the proposed organic union of the Congregational-Christian Church and the Evangelical and Reformed Church were presented in three sermons in the metropolitan area yesterday. The merger, if approved, would affect nearly 2,000,000 members of the two Protestant groups throughout the country.

NANKING, Jan. 4 -- The wind-up this week of the activities in China of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration points up the controversy over the effectiveness of the UNRRA operations that has existed throughout the life of the international relief program in this country.
New York escaped last night what might have proved to be a heavy snowfall when a storm forming off Cape Hatteras veered to the east and away from the city.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Lack of country offerings of corn, combined with limited receipts and an advance in cash corn premiums, helped that grain to make fair net gains last week, there being a lack of hedging pressure. Professional sentiment also was inclined to the bull side.

The heaviest holiday travel since the Twenties was reported yesterday by the New York Central Railroad. The spacious Grand Central Terminal war jammed most of the day as solidly as the Times Square subway platforms during rush hours.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 -- Justice Meier Steinbrink of New York, national chairman of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, urged the Jews of this country tonight to subordinate activities directed exclusively at anti-Semitism to a broad effort in behalf of every democratic ideal.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 (AP) -- De Paul University handed Holy Cross, N.C.A.A. champion, its third defeat in thirty-one starts, 47 -- 40, as the Crusaders displayed their customary fine passing, but poor shooting form before 10,000 fans at Chicago Stadium tonight.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 4 -- Fourteen Arabs were killed and ninety-eight wounded today when a bomb planted by Jews next to the local Arab Higher Committee's offices exploded and shook the whole Arab city of Jaffa. Many casualties are believed to be still unreported and a number of bodies are thought to be still buried in the ruined buildings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Like two rival theatrical companies vieing for headline talent, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House and the Foreign Relations Committee of the Senate are now engaged in a quiet contest for prominent witnesses or the European Recovery Program bill.

JERUSALEM, Monday, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Semiramis Hotel in Jerusalem, believed to be a transit headquarters for Arab leaders, was wrecked early today by a heavy explosion. Police said the blast had killed at least twenty Arabs and wounded twelve others.

Satisfaction with present television programs was expressed by only 45 per cent of the 9,341 video set owners in New York, Philadelphia and Chicago and adjacent areas questioned in a survey conducted by William Bethke, general education director of LaSalle Extension University in Chicago.

Dr. Walter Gropius probably had tongue slightly in cheek when he suggested in an article in the Army newspaper Weekend that history could be shaped by architecture. The opposite probably is more accurate. It was not the massive Reich Chancellory that shaped Nazi thinking, but the other way around.

The church must become spritually minded and shake itself free of all materialism and secularism that has weakened its power, the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher, pastor of St. Luke's Evangelical Lutheran Church, 308 West Forty-Sixth Street, declared yesterday at the morning service.

A plan for voluntary action on the part of the nation's 15,000 banks to avoid excessive or inflationary increases in the use of bank credit was announced yesterday by Joseph M. Dodge, president of the American Bankers Association. Under the plan, a seven-man "team" of banking executives headed by Mr. Dodge will begin soon a tour of the nation's banking centers, conducting "pilot" meetings to arouse the industry to the need for caution.

An appeal to aid the suffering children in our own city as well as in the rest of the world was made yesterday by Canon Edward N. West, Sacrist of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, preaching at the morning service.

LONDON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The 6,103-ton United States Lines freighter Pioneer Cove was reported making for London tonight under her own power after having struck a mine early today in the North Sea off the Netherlands coast.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 (AP) -- New York's divorce laws are so rigid they have given rise to a "system of fraud" amounting to a "public scandal," the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York State said today in a statement advocating revision of the statutes.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- Under weather and sailing conditions which severely tested the fortitude of even the most hardy winter skipper, the Larchmont Yacht Club got its mid-winter frostbite championship dinghy series under way this afternoon, with a fleet of twenty-one braving the elements for the regatta.

The sense of Khalil Totah's suggestion, in your issue of Dec. 23, is that having given "verbal support" to the partition of Palestine into two independent states, the American Government should now disinterest itself completely in further events in and around Palestine.

A consolidated net income of $1,667,175 for the fiscal year ended with last September was reported by the Hayes Manufacturing Corporation, in its thirty-seventh annual statement mailed to stockholders yesterday. Exceeding the combined earnings for the four preceding years, the income compared with $213,739 reported for the year ended on Sept. 30, 1946.

In an effort to develop a health plan in which all the city's health agencies will be invited to participate, the Health Council of Greater New York, Inc., and the Public Health Relations Committee of the New York Academy of Medicine are cooperating to make a comprehensive health survey of New York City.

The last twelve months proved to be the most successful passenger year in the history of the Grace Line, with 130 passenger sailings, which provided a total of 13,500 accommodations, inadequate to handle the demands for space, according to an annual review released yesterday by the company.

Cheerfulness, courage and charity should be presented to Christ, just as the wise men presented three gifts to Him, the Rev. Edwin B. Broderick of St. Patrick's Cathedral said yesterday. He delivered the sermon at the 10 A.M. mass.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ed Jeremiah, Dartmouth hockey coach, said tonight four of his players and two Colgate hockey men had been invited to play in the coming Olympics on a sextet sponsored by the Amateur Athletic Union.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 4 -- A three-cornered tie in Class B resulted after two races today in the light shifting northeasterly breeze which prevailed for the opening regatta of the winter dinghy series sponsored by the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Britain has narrowed the gap between visible imports and exports in recent weeks, H.A. Marquand, Paymaster-General in the Labor Government, told an audience at Cardiff today. He stressed, however, that the nation still had a "long way to go," and he called for still greater effort on farms, in mines, in factories and in what he termed every kind of useful activity.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- The wheat market celebrated the turn of the year by a sharp decline in prices due in part to increased hedging pressure incident to enlarged sales of storage grain by producers and to prospects that Congress would delay action on the Marshall Plan for some time.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The railroads' Pullman fleet never will be modernized under present methods, Robert R. Young, chairman of the Federation for Railway Progress, asserts in the current issue of the Federation's monthly magazine, Railway Progress.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 4 (UP) -- After today's bombing of the crowded headquarters of the Arab Higher Committee in Jaffa, the British said that many of the victims were Arab refugees, including a heavy proportion of children, who had been sheltered temporarily in the building for lack of safe homes elsewhere.

In partnership with the Jewish Agency and major civic and health groups in Palestine, Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, has started a $500,000 emergency medical defense program, it was announced yesterday. The group also will extend its services for immigrants to care for recent arrivals.

LAWRENCE, L.I., Jan. 4 -- A 10-year-old boy and his 75-year-old grandfather combined to balk an attempted hold-up last night in the home of Sason Zacharia, New York underwear manufacturer, at 2 Regent Drive here. One alleged participant was under arrest here today and the police were searching for another.

WARSAW, Jan. 4 -- A pastoral letter consecrating Poland to the Sacred Heart of Jesus was read in all Polish Roman Catholic churches today, fulfilling a secret vow taken by the Polish Bishops in 1943 during the German occupation. The Bishops vowed then to make this consecration after Poland was freed from the Nazis.
RANGOON, Burma, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Burmese Parliament today Overrode Communist opposition and ratified a treaty with Britain in its first act as a sovereign assembly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (AP) -- State and local public works contracts awarded during the first nine months of 1947 were 35 per cent higher in value than for the same period of 1946, the Federal Works Agency announced today.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Penn State's unbeaten Nittany Lions came home to a joyous welcome today as the town turned out to pay homage to Coach Bob Higgins' Cotton Bowl football team.

The record snowstorm and the lull of a post-holiday period combined to continue the quiet in the wholesale markets last week, according to weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Formation of the American Parents Committee, Inc., as a means of promoting child health and welfare in all the states was announced here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Plans for filming three photoplays which Mark Hellinger had in preparation before his death on Dec. 21 are being made by Morgan Maree, secretary-treasurer of the Hellinger Producing Company, and David O. Selznick and Daniel O'Shea of the Selznick organization, which will distribute the films, it was learned from Mr. Maree.

A new collection of luxurious upholstery fabrics indicates that power looms can produce the rich nubby materials usually associated with hand weaving. As a result, the modern weaves may be used in decorating schemes where budgets, while not severely limited, are not boundless.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., continued his mastery of the field and the Riviera Country Club course today as he fired his third sub-par round in a row to remain in the lead at the end of 54 holes of the annual $10,000 Los Angeles open golf tournament.

If there are fuel dealers in this city who have been profiteering in the public's dire necessity we should know who they are; if they have violated the law they should be prosecuted; and if no existing law permits prosecution we should have one that does. This is the position taken by Mayor O'Dwyer in ordering his Commissioner of Investigation, John M. Murtagh, to go into action today.

Through the efforts of the Civil Air Patrol and with the cooperation of the State Quartermaster General's office, New Jersey has gone well over the top in passing its quota of twenty-nine air markers installed for transient and private pilots. The markers are large chrome yellow and black billboards on open flat roofs identifying towns, giving map coordinates and indicating the direction of true north. Fifteen of the markers are on National Guard armories.

The addition of eleven stage personalities to those taking part in the American National Theatre and Academy Benefit at the Ziegfeld Theatre Sunday night, Jan. 18, was announced yesterday by Oscar Serlin.

Lauritz Melchior will be the Siegmund; Rose Bampton, the Sieglinde; Helen Traubel, the Bruennhilde, and Herbert Janssen, the Wotan in the performance of "Die Walkuere," which will be presented Tuesday afternoon, Jan. 13, at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was announced yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 4 -- A strike by 11,000 timber cutters for a 28 1/2 per cent wage increase has stopped delivery of props, crossbars, supports and other wood products to hundreds of soft-coal mines and steel mills in the Pittsburgh district.

A request to major fuel oil companies to join in the construction of a pipeline into the city from a key point on the New Jersey side of the harbor is being considered by Mayor O'Dwyer, it was reported yesterday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 4 -- Engineers at the University of California announced today that they had put into operation "the world's first low-pressure supersonic wind tunnel, duplicating pressure conditions up to an altitude of 250,000 feet."

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- State aid for New York City and other local governments and the liberalization of social welfare laws are expected to furnish the major controversies of the new legislative session opening here on Wednesday.

THE football coaches will be meeting in our town this week and that means the rules will be discussed at considerable length. However, the coaches cannot do more than recommend changes to the ultra-conservative Rules Committee, which is, by tradition and habit, opposed to most of them. That is as it should be, though.

DALLAS, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Matty Bell, the football coach whose team won the Southwest Conference championship by the margin of a point after touchdown, will renew his fight for its abolition this week when the National Football Coaches Association meets in New York.

If there is one complaint received more frequently than any other by the person who writes regularly on matters concerned with economics, it is the complaint that the subject matter is too technical for "the layman" reader.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Price reductions ranging from 3 to 10 per cent were announced today by Hotpoint, Inc., effective at once. James J. Nance, president, said that the lower prices affect refrigerators, electric ranges and Disposalls.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it will open hearings here Jan. 12 on its charge that the nation's steel producers had agreed in an "unlawful conspiracy" to fix prices and throttle competition.

A campaign to arouse the public to the threat of rheumatic fever will be part of the 1948 drive by Irvington House to meet the largest budget in its history, $202,000. The institution, which cares for children with heart disease, is located at Irvington-on-Hudson.
The proposal of the Dewey Administration to convert Syracuse University into a state university was criticized as inadequate yesterday by Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman.

To honor Edwin Franko Goldman on his seventieth birthday, a program of contemporary works was performed by the Goldman Band Saturday night at Carnegie Hall, under the auspices of the League of Composers. The elaborate series of offerings, which consisted entirely of compositions written especially for band, was directed by Walter Hendl, as guest conductor.

Most people (the very young excepted) will agree that snow should not fall on a big city. There is, unfortunately, little room in the city for snow. Perhaps, if it could be arranged, it would be all right for snow to fall in Central Park, but nowhere else on Manhattan.

Study of opinion surveys and statistical reports made in connection with the brand names project held in Greenfield, Mass., last Oct. 20 through Nov. 5 reveal the pioneering educational campaign was more successful than anticipated, it was announced over the week-end by Henry E. Abt, president of Brand Names Foundation, Inc.

Dispatches from Prague during the past two days tell a dramatic story of Communist policies running up against Czech stubborness and the hard economic facts of life. The Czechs, as Albion Ross reports to this newspaper, are by no means satisfied with a "Molotov Plan" which makes them the indentured servants of Russia, and the Czech liberals deeply resent Communist efforts to wreck the Marshall Plan.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Clothes-hungry women were already queuing up outside London stores tonight for tomorrow's post-holiday sales. Retailers caught with excess stocks of women's clothes have slashed their prices and are thus allowed to halve coupon requirements to clear their surplus.

Champion The Dream Boy of Chalburn, a solid black cocker spaniel belonging to Mr. and Mrs. W. Chalmers Burns of Ridgefield, Conn., climaxed the two days of the American Spaniel Club's annual national specialty by taking best in show at the Hotel Roosevelt last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The flag of the Republic of Burma was unfurled by Ambassador U So Nyun at a colorful ceremony on the lawn before the Burmese Embassy here at 11 o'clock this morning as the country emerged into full independence. Lord Inverchapel, the British Ambassador, State Department officials and chiefs of diplomatic missions of many other countries attended.

A travel boom in the first half of this year was forecast yesterday by the American Express Company, which quoted "seasoned observers" as estimating that the number of passengers traveling for pleasure would be up to 20 per cent above last year's totals.

KODIAK, Alaska, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Nine or ten gale-buffeted castaways clung today to a rocky point of the bleak Alaska peninsula, opposite Kodiak Island, awaiting rescue by a Navy tug and Coast Guard clipper, which have been unable to put boats ashore in the 60-mile-an-hour storm.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week turned easier in late dealings to lose part of earlier gains. At Friday's close, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 14 to 43 points for the week. The Exchange was closed on Saturday because of bad weather.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Michigan's victorious Rose Bowl championship football team stepped off the train at Ann Arbor tonight amid the din of cheering students and townspeople.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 24 -- For those who like their mystery stories steeped in the ages, we present a plot that may be 1,000,000 years old: "Who bashed the baboons of ancient Africa, and how?"

Opening a new series of Government sales in the new York and Northern New Jersey region to reduce warehousing space and costs, two large local sales of about $5,000,000 worth of surplus consumer goods will begin this month, it was announced over the weekend by John R. Campbell, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

Reports from Washington foreshadow serious opposition to the President's European Recovery Program when Congress meets. The reasons appear to be that we cannot afford to do so much without grave risk to our own economy, and that we cannot be sure of success.

More than 250,000 active individual customer accounts covering practically every line of manufacturing and distribution in the United States, both nation-wide and world-wide, are included in the second quarterly survey of the Chicago Association of Credit Men, it was announced over the week-end.

LONDON, Jan. 5 (Reuters) -- The Daily Mail correspondent, Cecil Wilson, said today that Filippo del Giudice, "top producer" for Arthur Rank, British film financier, is on his way to New York "to clinch a deal for restoration of the flow of Hollywood pictures to Britain."

The lull of Christmas week in the world of art events will be succeeded this week by a renewed burst of gallery activity. Approximately fifty exhibitions of work by familiar and unfamiliar artists are scheduled in this, the busiest week of the current season.
In one of your editorials of Dec. 25 you wrote:

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- Boulder Brook Club's two indoor polo teams emerged victorious today at the club's arena. In the feature game, the Boulder Brook Greens led by Tommy Glynn, back, outpointed Zenas Colt's Pittsfield (Mass.) Polo Club, 12 to 7, after the Boulder Brook Whites got past the Albany Polo Club, 16 to 12.
Despite expanded picket lines, four international communications companies reported last night that they were receiving and transmitting all messages on a normal basis.

Whatever its merit may be, Jan De Hartog's "Skipper Next to God" deserves to be produced. With the quixotic assistance of John Garfield, the Experimental Theatre produced it last evening at Maxine Elliott's and did itself considerable honor.

Andres Segovia, the Spanish guitar virtuoso, who is currently celebrating the twentieth anniversary of his American debut, was heard in his first New York recital of the season, last night at Town Hall. An artist who can always be banked on to give his best, Mr. Segovia regaled his enthusiastic audience with another of those displays of skill and artistry which have come to be expected of him.

BOSTON, Jan. 4 -- Full financial support from the $18,000,000 treasury of the AFL International Brotherhood of Teamsters was promised to 4,500 striking members of Local 25 in a telegram from Daniel J. Tobin, international president, today.

The two major present interests of the Carnegie Corporation of New York are "an enlargement of the nation's understanding of its international responsibilities and an increase in the supply of knowledge and training in the practice of government," Devereux C. Josephs, its president, said in his annual report, released yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 4 -- An attack by rebels in the Philiates area of Western Epirus near Corfu Strait, which yesterday seemed to be taking dangerous proportions, appeared today to be petering out, Athens military sources said.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Three policemen were injured trying to control a milling throng in the Place de la Republique today when movie fans broke through police lines formed to protect film stars marching in a demonstration against that part of the Blum-Byrnes accord the French believe discriminates against French films.

The town of Charmes, France, which was laid waste by Nazis when underground fighters sought to open a path for American troops, will receive medical aid under a plan announced yesterday by a group of New Yorkers, including business men and ex-GI's.
A small boy sent $5, part of his allowance, to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, writing.

ROME, Jan. 4 -- The Foreign Ministry has instructed the Italian Ambassador in Washington, Alberto Tarchiani, to request clarification from the United States Government of the exact meaning and implications of its decision to send more marines to the Mediterranean.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Terms of the $50,000 international competition for the design of low-cost furniture, sponsored by the Museum of Modern Art of New York City and Museum Design Project, Inc., were made public here today. The competition, announced a few months ago in New York by Nelson Rockefeller, president of the museum, will open officially tomorrow and close at midnight, Oct. 31.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Catholic Archdiocese went on record today against universal peacetime military training on the ground that it would endanger the morality of the nation's youth.

Five important new management engineering advances have been made by Meehanite process foundries during the past year, and further developments of expanded uses of foundry products are expected during 1948, C.R. Austin, chief metallurgist of the Meehanite Metal Corporation, New Rochelle, N.Y., revealed over the week-end.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Price increases of 10 to 15 per cent will be announced tomorrow by many furniture manufacturers at the opening of the International Winter Homefurnishings Market in the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart, it was learned here today.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 4 -- A navigational error due to "fantastically inaccurate" maps used by the Air Force in Alaska was held to blame by Brig. Gen. Frank F. Everest for the crash of a B-29 ninety-five miles north of Nome on Dec. 29. The plane hit a mountain.

A four-alarm fire virtually destroyed a Brooklyn synagogue early yesterday morning, but firemen saved the holy scrolls. Shortly after firemen were ordered from the blazing building the roof collapsed.

Seasonal price weakening of lumber at the mill level has not occurred so far this winter and little change in the situation can be expected in the first quarter, R. E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, declared in an interview last week.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Jan. 4 -- Before she was 48 hours old tonight, Olga Anna Hrycaj had already traveled by road, rail, air and sea.

Advertising support of its public relations program, adopted by the industry three years ago, has been increased 300 per cent over the pre-war budget, according to a thirty-six page outline report on the progress of the carpet industry during the past three years released over the week-end to 20,000 retailers by the Carpet Institute Inc.

Full production and greater efficiency in promotion, permitting reduction in costs, will insure continuing prosperity in 1948, according to leaders of American business and foreign trade who contributed to the annual symposium on the outlook for the New Year released for publication today by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc.

The lighter bearing a cargo of 65,000 pounds of TNT taken on Saturday from a Palestine-bound freighter rode at anchor last night, flying from its masthead the red swallow-tail flag of the international signal code that signifies "Explosives -- Keep Clear."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Representative Walter G. Andrews, New York, Republican, said today that he would seek clearance for floor debate of the Universal Military Training bill.

Unity between Great Britain and the United States was the theme of the annual British Epiphany Festival Service held yesterday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street.

Putting up a game battle for existence, "Music in My Heart" has survived a crisis. It didn't close Saturday night at the Adelphi after all. The Tchaikovsky musical is very much alive. On competent authority we are told that the engagement is to be resumed tomorrow night, after a day's hiatus, with Sunday afternoon and evening performances added to the schedule next week.

HAVANA, Jan. 4 -- The highly technical and complicated discussions at the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment have tended to obscure the fundamental importance of the proposed world trade charter in terms of the things that the people of the United States and of other countries will eat, wear and use in the long-term future.
ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Dewey, in a proclamation designating this week as Universal Military Training Week, reiterated today his endorsement of such training.

Herman Robins bought for investment three two-family brownstone dwellings on a plot 60 by 85 feet at 356-58-60 Tompkins Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Frank H. Harper family through the Bulkley Horton Company, brokers, who also sold a two-story building containing a store and six apartments on a lot 30 by 100 feet at 1342-44-46 St. Marks Avenue for Harold Schwartz to the White Estates for investment.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 4 -- The United Nations Little Assembly will meet for the first time here tomorrow with almost every member country represented at the historic session except the six nations of the Soviet bloc.

The need for large-scale programs for the relief of displaced Jews abroad is greater than ever, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman and other speakers declared yesterday before the Joint Distribution Committee at the closing session of its thirty-third annual meeting, held in the Commodore Hotel.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- How little French politics changes! France has a new Constitution, a new form of republic, a new alignment of political forces. The country itself has altered more in the last few years than in the historic upheaval of 1789. Today it is not even the France of the Liberation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Here is the tentative timetable for the convening of the second session of the Eightieth Congress (all time Eastern standard):

The city's investigation of alleged profiteering and racketeering in the sale of fuel oil and kerosene during the period of storm distress will begin today. John M. Murtagh, Commissioner of Investigation, will question consumers and retailers who will appear voluntarily with complaints.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The true underlying reasons for the recent Soviet monetary reforms are bound up with financing the world revolutionary movement, in the opinion of a man who for a number of years held various responsible economic posts in Russia, notably in the Soviet gold industry.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- This city's army of shopping housewives was resting tonight after a hysterical day of battles for bargains in which all post-war sales records -- to say nothing of at least one display window and no end of tempers -- were shattered.

TUSKEGEE, Ala., Jan. 5 (AP) The great and the humble joined in tribute today to a frail, slave born Negro, George Washington Carver, who rose to international fame as a scientist, educator and humanitarian.

The rally which developed last week on the stock market failed yesterday to gain further momentum as selling aimed at pivotal industrials and rails reduced prices by 1 to 2 points. A few cores of resistance were found at the close but these appeared mostly in groups not participating in the recent upturn, and the combined averages at the finish were off slightly more than a point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Secretary of Defense James Forrestal took positive steps today toward complete unification of the medical services of the Army and Navy. He laid down policy studies for a special board headed by Dr. Paul R. Hawley, retired chief medical director of the Veterans Administration.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Mme. Marie Helen Lefaucheux, French delegate, was elected chairman of the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women today by a secret ballot of elevenh)0*0*0*iaffirmative votes. She succeeded Mrs. Bodil Begtrup, Danish delegate.

Prince Peter and Princess Irene of Greece were among the 103 passengers who arrived here yesterday from Rotterdam on the Holland America liner Westerdam. The ship docked at 2:45 P.M. at the Fifth Street pier, Hoboken.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- The Long Island Lighting Company's proposal to sell $3,000,000 of promissory notes to three commercial banks was sanctioned today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

" Cloudy, with occasional snow ending during the afternoon," the city read in its daily paper on Friday morning, Dec. 26. The "occasional snow" proved to be a record fall for the city. Happily for us, the prognostication for last Sunday was just as wrong; for a storm that was to have deposited from four to six inches of snow spared the city.

The National Committee of the American Communist party asserted here last night that the State Department had refused to issue a passport to one of its leading members seeking to attend the sixth national convention of the Communist party of Italy.

A special evening cycle of Wagner's "Der Ring des Nibelungen" has been announced by Edward Johnson, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Association. "Das Rheingold" will take place on Friday, Feb. 6, "Die Walkuere" on Tuesday, Feb. 10; "Siegfried" on Wednesday, Feb. 18, and "Gotterdaemmerung' on Tuesday, Feb. 24.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- Pressures from American cotton states which want Japan to buy only American cotton, and from American cotton goods manufacturers who want Japan to sell none of its finished products in the United States, continue to dominate Japan's recovery picture.

A net profit of $4,708,969 after taxes and all charges was reported yesterday by the MinneapolisMoline Power Implement Company and its subsidiaries in a statement covering the fiscal year ended with last October.

Money Market Easy The money market was fairly easy yesterday and short-term securities again were in good demand. The New York City banks which reported excess reserves of $450,000,000 on last Tuesday night, lost a substantial portion of this total on Wednesday, when their reserves dropped to $290,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Civilian employment in the executive agencies of the Federal Government dropped during November to below 2,000,000 for the first time since 1941, the Joint Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Expenditures told Congress today.

The Board of Education was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Isaac R. Swezey in Brooklyn to show cause why a meeting of a branch of the Communist party in a borough public school should not be barred.h)

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP) -Jimmy Demaret of Texas and California, in addition to winning the Harry Vardon Trophy for the best golf scoring average in 1947 also walked away With top-money winning laurels for the year.

The Port of New York Authority, in a brief filed yesterday with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington, opposed pleas by railroads for increases in water rail rates from Eastern ports to the Southwest. The roads are seeking charges to equal or exceed allrailh)0*0*0*irates.

An unusually large number of the city's emergency units converged quickly on a four-story brick apartment house at 731 East Eight Street, Brooklyn, last night after thirteen persons, eight of them children, were sickened by coal gas from the furnace, according to the police.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 5 (AP) -- United States military authorities today denied a Polish protest that Miss Maria Borkowicz, a diplomatic courier, was roughly handled by military police while traveling through the United States zone of Germany.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- All during the winter months hundreds of thousands of persons needlessly submit themselves to the dangers of fresh air poisoning by spending countless hours on snowy slopes. It seemed serious enough to merit investigation by this reporter, a hothouse plant by nature. So at great personal risk the job was done over the week-end.

Loans by the Chase National Bank oustanding on Dec. 31, 1947, amounted to $1,324,264,034, the largest loan total by any New York bank at the year end, the bank reported in its statement of condition as of the December date, issued for publication today.

The National Baseball League enters 1948 in the finest financial condition of its long career after having drawn more than 10,000,000 fans last year, and with a flag race coming up that should curl the hair, says President Ford Frick with undisputed pleasure.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Pravda, Communist party organ, declared today that Secretary of State Marshall and French Foreign Minister Bidault had lingered in London after the official closing of the Council of Foreign Ministers last month to hold a conference of their own with British Foreign Secretary Bevin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The momentous second session of the Eightieth Congress will convene tomorrow with planning already well under way for putting it steadily at work -- on its floors as well as in committees -- as soon as possible.
One of the main cogs of the Yankee's pennant machine slipped into place yesterday with the announcement that Tommy Henrich, sometimes known as "Tommy the Clutch," has signed his 1948 contract.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- The Joint British-American Export-Import Agency disclosed in its monthly report, issued today, that the bizonal area had delivered $194,091,300 worth of products to sixty-five purchasing nations during the first eleven months of 1947.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A complete stalemate on the distribution of reparations from Japan was reported at the State Department today. It is caused by the rejection by the Soviet Union of every proposal the United States has submitted to the Far Eastern Commission.

Fifty thousand Negroes have been added to the voting rolls in Richmond, Va., and adjacent territory in recent months and they are "going to vote in spite of the poll tax," according to a report presented yesterday at the annual meeting of the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- As the Securities and Exchange Commission began moving its headquarters back to Washington today, it was the consensus here that the field of candidates for the position of chairman of the agency had been narrowed to two men.

" Missouri Waltz," by Maurice Milligan, will be brought out in April by Scribners. In it Mr. Milligan, who was the district attorney in the Prendergast case, tells the history of the Prendergast regime and how it is tied in with current Missouri politics in connection with the proposed investigation by Attorney General Tom C. Clark of the 1946 Democratic primary in Jackson County, Mo.
h)0*0*0*iCotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday 12 points lower to 4 points higher than the previous day.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Striking printers, members of Chicago Typographical Union Local 16, voiced protests today against a decision of the union's executive committee to increase the hours of picketing from one to two, effective tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Grains made a weak start and a strong finish today on the Board of Trade, with short covering combined with aggressive buying by professional traders and commission houses disclosing a lack of pressure after the early selling had been absorbed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- The new United Nations headquarters advisory committee will hold its first meeting tomorrow to discuss design changes that must be made in the projected world capital to offset increased construction costs, it was learned today.
ATHENS, Jan. 5 -- In a statement issued late tonight, the Greek Government said that by agreement with the United States Government it had decided to augment the Greek fighting forces.

The importance of having as many Freedom Gardens as possible in the United States this year was emphasized yesterday by Paul Stark at the New York State Nurserymen's Association's annual convention at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Because of a sudden drying up of business in the stock markets here today, most sections started the week on a dull note.

A voice of great natural beauty was presented last night when Magdalena Nicol, Brazilian mezzosoprano, made her New York recital debut at Times Hall. It was, however, an occasion of questionableh)0*0*0*ivalue from either the singer's or audience's point of view, for Miss Nicol suffered from a severe head cold and often seemed less than fully prepared to sing the music she had chosen.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Administration agreed today to withdraw President Truman's request for $17,000,000,000 for European recovery over a period of four years and to rely on Congress for a determination of annual appropriations for Marshall Plan operations.

h)0*0*0*iOA return to 1939 price levels in the radio industry was envisaged yesterday by S. W. Gross, president, Tele-tone Radio Corporation, in an interview at the St. Regis Hotel at which a new superheterodyne table model priced at $9.95 was described.
The threat to the city's fuel oil supply system, posed by the inability of oil barge and tanker operators and their employes to reach agreement on a new contract, remained unchanged yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A proposal to eliminate the point after touchdown and invoke the "sudden death" method of settling a tie game will be presented to the Rules Committee of the National Football League at its meeting on Jan. 14 in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The American Red Cross announced today that it would seek $75,000,000 in its annual March campaign to continue its present services, replenish its disaster relief fund, develop a new blood program, and meet the "higher cost of meeting human needs."

The formula for the oatmeal cookies that are mixed up in one bowl in approximately two minutes evidently charmed cooks. Since it appeared in this column, with pictures, about six week ago, requests for additional recipes like it have come in.

Rent-gouging by landlords against tavern owners and other small retailers seeking renewal of their leases has reached "vicious proportions" and relief will be sought through legislative "tightening" of the commercial rent law, Arthur V. Selig, general counsel of the Joint Retailers Rent Action Committee, said yesterday.
A strike against 2,000 retail meat markets in Brooklyn, Queens, Richmond and Long Island, was voted last night by Local 342 of the Amalgamated Meat Cuttersh)0*0*0*iUnion, AFL.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week dropped 5 per cent below the corresponding week last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The loss was attributed to the effects of the snowstorm and to bad weather the latter part of last week.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 6 (AP) - Answering with a show of reluctance, wartime Premier Hideki Tojo told the International War Crimes Tribunal today that he "believed" that Japan's High Command had informed the Emperor beforehand of their plans to attack Pearl Harbor.

BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- Despite widespread circulation of the Soviet viewpoint on the recent London conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers by Soviet-sponsored newspapers, four out of ten inhabitants of this city blame the Russians for the break-up of the meeting, according to an official survey by the United States Military Government.

The Chesapeake Ohio Railway announced yesterday that it will open a central reservation bureau this month in Huntington, W.Va., through which it hopes that reservations of space on its trains may be made easier. When established, a nickel telephone call from Newh)0*0*0*iYork, Cleveland and from any of the principal cities on its line will connect the caller directly with the reservation bureau, the company explained.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- Egypt took a new lease on her economic life today with the signing of an agreement with Britain releasing to this country, from its blocked holdings of sterling, 21,000,000 (about $84,000,000). Britain also has agreed to sell to Egypt, which is not a member of the sterling area, $25,000,000 to enable her to trade with the hard-currency countries.

Police Commissioner Wallander's recent edict barring private cars from New York's streets during the Alpine emergency has reminded a man who lives in the suburbs of a resolution he made a little ahead of the New Year -- one which has gone the way of so many New Year's resolutions of orthodox date.

Leslie MacMitchell, top pre-war miler, is the latest entry for the Conklin two-mile run, one of the invitation scratch events listed for the sixteenth annual Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, track meet at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn Saturday night.

" Advertising people have a big job to do right now, helping business to recover our selling way of life; the tough, though healthy, way of progress," Allen T. Preyer, chairman of the Advertising Federation of America and chairman of the board of Morris International, Inc., told the luncheon meeting of the Advertising Men's Post 209, American Legion, yesterday at The Hotel Lexington.

Thomas K. Scherman's heart is so consistently in the right place as far as the best interests of music are concerned that one can condone an occasional mistake in judgment. In his sixth program with the Little Orchestra Society at the Town Hall last night, he paid his respects to the memory of his teacher, Hans Weisse, by directing the first public performance of Mr. Weisse's Octet.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A steel industry executive testified today that his company called in the FBI in an effort to track down "fly-by-night" operators alleged to be offering steel at exorbitant prices.

TOKYO, Jan. 5 -- Joseph B. Keenan, chief American prosecutor, attempted to bring out in cross examination today that former Premier Hideki Tojo, then chief of staff of Japan's Kwantung Army, came from Manchuria to Japan in 1940 to become War Minister with his mind clearly made up to fight an aggressive war against the United States.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Bob Higgins, Penn State football coach, admitted today that his players were "unhappy" about being quartered at the Dallas (Texas) Naval Air Station for their Cotton Bowl game on New Year's Day but he flatly denied reports of team dissension.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 Governor Dewey's annual message to the Legislature at its opening session Wednesday will concern itself chiefly with inflation and measures that the state can adopt to help combat its effects.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 (AP) -Ben Hogan, conquering a dense fog and a belated challenge by former national open champion Lloyd Mangrum, captured the $10,000 Los Angeles open today.

When the Little Assembly of the United Nations met yesterday for the first time at Lake Success there were six noteworthy absentees. They were Russia, White Russia, the Ukraine, Poland, Yugoslavia and Czechoslovakia. This completes the roster of the "Russian bloc."
Good reports on the fox hunting continue to arrive both from southern New York and Connecticut and several hunters commented on the large size of the grays they have killed during the past two weeks.

The mystery of the subways' "phantom cars," those unlighted, unused units attached to most trains on IRT, BMT and IND linesfor the last ten days, was solved yesterday afternoon by the Board of Transportation, which announced cryptically that "it had to be that way."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Supreme Court today, by 7 to 2, upseth)0*0*0*ithe conviction of a Buffalo man who had been arrested and searched without a warrant when found riding in an automobile with a person suspected of holding counterfeit gasoline ration coupons.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Yugoslav Government has presented a new demand for the release by the United States of Yugoslav funds totaling $60,000,000 to $70,000,000, including $56,000,000 in gold, Ambassador Sava N. Kosanovitch announced today.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 5 -- The "outright opposition" of the Soviet Government to the Marshall Plan "cannot and will not prevent this great effort from going forward," Charles E. Bohlen, counselor to the State Department, declared here today.

The city's problem of fuel oil deliveries was eased yesterday as many small dealers who had run out got new supplies for their customers and companies generally began to catch up on their backlog of orders.

In what is believed to be the first case of its kind here, the Board of Education yesterday permitted a retired teacher to work one day to enable her to apply for a higher pension. The board's action was taken to correct an error made twenty-one years ago in the pension application of Miss Therese Kessel, who retired last February as an art instructor at George Washington High School after thirty-five years in the system.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) The Government rolled up a surplus of $1,658,190,000 in the first half of the current fiscal year, during which officials expect revenue to exceed spending by the greatest margin in history.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The terms of the financial agreement with Egypt took London's financial district by surprise. The consensus was that Britain's releases ofh)0*0*0*ifunds to Egypt this year were much more generous than had been expected.

The custom collection of bridal gowns shown yesterday afternoon by Jay Thorpe must have been stimulated by the pageantry of the recent royal wedding. For each of the eight gowns presented was done in yards of heavy satins, nylon tulle, silk taffeta or marquisette, nearly all embroidered with twinkling crystalline beads on rare laces like point de Venise or chantilly.

In an expansion move, the Tavernon Photo-Engraving Company has purchased the industrial property at 27-31 First Avenue, Paterson, N.J., from the Metalsalt Corporation of Nevada. The building contains 15,000 square feet ofh)0*0*0*ispace and there is an additional four acres of land.

WHEN Johnny Somers went to the little Alabama town of Pineboro in September, 1936, to teach history in the high school he was as self-conscious, apprehensive and unsure of himself as was ever a young man of 23 fresh out of college and bound for his first job. Johnny was intelligent and likable, but he was afraid.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 5 (AP) -Notre Dame recorded its thirtyfifth successive home floor basketball victory tonight by defeating Georgetown of Washington, D.C., 77 to 69. Notre Dame had a 12point lead with a little over a minute to go, but the stubborn Georgetown five picked up four quick poins.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Charles de Gaulle's proposal for solving the social problem by the abolition of trade unions and the "association" of all elements in productive activity was greeted today with protests of "fascism" from the Communists and was received withh)0*0*0*icoolness by the Center and the Right.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 5 -- Haganah took the responsibility today for the bomb that killed at least seven persons in the Semiramis Hotel here earlier in the day. A total of thirty-four persons were killed in this attack and in one yesterday on the Palestine Arab headquarters in Jaffa.

In ten rounds of slugging that set a season record for sustained action here, Johnny Williams, Montgomery, Ala., welterweight, hammered out a decision over Roman Alvarez, East Sider, in the feature attraction at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

The Westchester Lighting Company asked yesterday for a temporary increase in its gas rates, at a hearing before Public Serviceh)0*0*0*iCommissioner George A. Arkwright, Colley Williams, the company's counsel, said the temporary increase would give the company an additional annual revenue of $2,100,000.

Modern examples of glassware chosen for beauty and usefulness by museum experts were highlighted in an exhibit previewed yesterday at the Copper Union Museum, Cooper Square. The show will open to the public next Tuesday after a private showing Monday.

Repair crews from five statesh)0*0*0*iwere assisting New Jersey utility company crews yesterday to restore electric and telephone service to the North Jersey communities suffering from last week's sleet storm. Substantial progress was made during the day, aided by temperatures above freezing, but it will be the end of the week before some areas receive full service.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:
Your lead editorial on Henry Wallace commented that "To the best of his ability he is ready to split the progressive vote."

Old favorites and more recent prize-winning motion pictures newly acquired by the film library of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will be shown, at the museum, which beganh)0*0*0*iyesterday its film program for the first half of 1948.

CLEVELAND, Jan, 5 -- The medical profession must face reality and be prepared for atomic bombardment of large American cities in which there would be mass casualties, Dr. Edward L. Bortz of Philadelphia warned members of the American Medical Association House of Delegates today.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Premier Robert Schuman won a notable victory for his anti-inflation program today when, after having given him five different votes of confidence on the challenged sections of his tax bill, the National Assembly passed that measure by 315 to 268 votes.

HAVANA, Jan. 5 -- Switzerland refused today to join the proposed International Trade Organization unless countries not experiencing balance-of-payments difficulties were allowed to use import quotas and other quantitative restrictions on trade for "the protection of economic stability, particularly in the fields of agriculture and employment."

The session of the Eightieth Congress which begins today will be remembered as the one which had to dealh)0*0*0*iwith the European Recovery Plan. It will take up other problems, most of them affected by or related to the ERP, but ERP will be the core of this session's apple. The immediate future i of parties and personalities is involved in this issue.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 5 (UP) -- Chinese Communists struck suddenly at Yangtze River communications today, attacking two towns west of Hankow and threatening the rich "rice bowl" of South China for the first time in ten years, semiofficial reports from Hankow said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- President Truman heartily endorsed today the voluntary anti-inflation program of the American Bankers Association, declaring it was "vitally important to the country."
Construction of another low-rent housing development by the New York City Housing Authority with funds borrowed from the state was started yesterday at Wyckoff and Bond Streets, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Grain exports by the United States in this crop year will nearly equal exports from all other nations, the Department of Agriculture estimated today. The crop year runs from July 1, 1947, to June 30, 1948.

Carnegie Hall, which long ago embraced "classical jazz," then swing in nearly all its variations, has widened its musical scope again. Come May and the musical temple on West Fifty-seventh Street will take barbershop quartets under its wing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation of the major oil companies for possible anti-trust violations was proposed by Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat, of South Carolina, today because, he said, there's apparently "a squeeze play going on to hurt the small independent dealers."
A gift in memory of former Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia arrived yesterday as one donor's contribution to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund. He wrote:

MOREHEAD CITY, N.C., Jan. 5 (AP) -- Two big Navy transports, carrying approximately 1,000 marines with full combat equipment, slipped quietly out of this North Carolina port today for the Mediterranean. A silence remindful of wartime secrecy cloaked the movement of the men, each a specialist in amphibious operations.
An official end of eggless Thursdays after this week was announced yesterday by the Federal Government, which urged, however, that all patriotic Americans continue observance of meatless Tuesdays.

Siritzky International Pictures have leased the former ABC Radio Theatre on Fifty-eighth Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, for a period of ten years, it was announced yesterday. The 595-seat house will be used as a showcase for French films owned or distributed by Siritzky, with "Fanny," a film by Marcel Pagnol, starring the late Raimu, slated to open the theatre on Wednesday evening, Jan. 28.

Contending that the mere threat of refusing to handle "hot copy" constituted a secondary boycott, three of the four international communications companies struck on Friday by the American Communications Association took last night the unprecedented step of asking the National Labor Relations Board to seek a court injunctions against refusal of copy by a non-striking ACA local.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Mrs. Robert A. Taft, wife of the Presidential candidate, today predicted a Republican inauguration in January, 1949.

Curtain and drapery buyers are placing orders with apparent confidence in the current price structure, according to exhibitors at the New York Curtain and Drapery Show in the Hotel New Yorkerh)0*0*0*iyesterday. The show, which opened Sunday, and will continue through Jan. 9, showed a registration of more than 500 buyers for the first two days.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 5 A movement among Germans in the Bizonal Economic Council to seek permission from the United States and British Military Governments for convening a national constitutional assembly became known today.
The text of the address delivered yesterday by Harold E. Stassen before the New York Young Republican Club in Town Hall follows:

Harold E. Stassen, in a major address here on foreign affairs, proposed yesterday that the United States initiate now a United Nations convention to be held in 1950, for the purpose of amending and rewriting the United Nations Charter.
