Olle Tandberg, Swedish heavyweight, is not averse to facing Joe Louis for the world heavyweight title, and plans to seek additional American ring engagements if he is successful in his ten-round bout against Joey Maxim, Clevelander, in Madison Square Garden Friday night.

One of the season's most attractive college basketball doubleheaders is listed for tonight at Madison Square Garden, where C.C.N.Y. engages St. John's and Long Island University opposes unbeaten Kansas State. A standing-room crowd is a certainty.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Two former generals of the German Army at present aiding the United States Army's Historical Division will be tried by a German denazification tribunal in Neustadt this month, the European Command announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Harold E. Stassen, a Republican Presidential aspirant, was called today to testify Thursday before a Senate investigating committee as it prepared a public inquiry into commodity speculations, including those of Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham, President Truman's personal physician.

Reviving a pre-war service, the Weather Bureau plans to send accurate weather forecasts twice daily to vessels operating from New York to European and African ports in order to help shipmasters avoid damaging and sometimes dangerous storms, it was learned yesterday.

Twelve plants closed as a result of the largest grain restriction orders were cited yesterday by Seton Porter, president of National Distillers Products Corporation, as one of five reasons why he has objected to the recent retroactive directive issued by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson, last week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A chronology of events leading up to the Congressional debate on the European Recovery Program, as presented to members of Congress by the staffs of the House Foreign Affairs and Senate Foreign Relations Committees, is as follows:

The board of directors of the National Department Stores Corporation, meeting yesterday, authorized for payment on Jan. 15, an extra dividend of 50 cents and the regular quarterly of 25 cents a share on the $5 par common stock.

I should like to correct a piece of misinformation contained in the dispatch of Commander Finn Ronne, Antarctic expedition leader, released in the Nov. 30 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES. In this he announced that his wife, Edith Ronne, is the "first woman ever to set foot on the Antarctic Continent.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- A considerable degree of concern has been caused in official circles here by reports from Washington that long-term United States aid to Europe may be delayed until June.
RAMAPO, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Maggie Gannon was alone tonight on Half-Moon Mountain, shut in by winter silence with the snow drifted five feet high against her cabin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Coal exports for February were set at 3,825,000 tons today by the United States Coal Operating Committee, it was announced by the Department of Commerce. This is 325,000 tons more than the January quota.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 5 -- The opening of the observance of the centennial of Wisconsin's statehood was marked here today by receipt of a congratulatory telegram from General of the Army Douglas MacArthur which was interpreted by his supporters as an announcement of his availability for the Republican Presidential nomination.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Prospects of putting an end to the conflict with Viet Nam were discussed at length in a Government conference held today. This discussion was prior to the departure of Emile Bollaert, French High Commissioner, to Indo-China for new conversations with the former Emperor of Annam, who is now in Geneva.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- With the six members of the Soviet bloc apparently determined to remain absent, the Little Assembly of the United Nations cut short its opening session today and postponed until Friday a decision on whether it should defer discussion of the controversial veto question for ten weeks.

The largest public school budget in history was predicted yesterday at the Board of Education, where Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, and his aides have been rushing to get the proposed expenditures for 1948-49 lined up.

Any quivers of excitement running through the town this morning can probably be traced to the fact that the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company is in fine fettle. After opening the season with an undistinguished "Mikado" last week, it sang "The Pirates of Penzance" and "Trial by Jury" brilliantly at the New Century last evening.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- Only lately has it been possible to talk with the numerous refugees from the Soviet Union who are in Paris. They were always afraid, and their suspicion grew when they surmised that extracts of their conversation might appear in the press.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- By a margin of three to two, the state executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations called on all CIO unions tonight to quit the American Labor party if it endorses Henry A. Wallace as a third-party candidate for President.

Paper-thin crisp straws and the lightest of colors were combined by Gustav Brandt to give charm and delicacy to his spring millinery collection, presented yesterday at Stein Blaine. Contributing also were flaring choux of taffeta and clusters of carnations as trim.
HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Jayess Stable's Cencerro turned in one of his gamest efforts to capture today's featured Chumuckla Purse before a crowd of 11,523 at Gulfstream Park.

A drive by professional dental societies against unscrupulous dentalh) 0*0*0*imechanics and others guilty of "bootleg dentistry" was urged last night by Dr. Sidney E. Riesner in his inaugural address as president of the First District Dental Society at the society's annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Although commercial banks reduced the volume of their loans on securities in the year ended on last Oct. 6, this liquidation was more than offset by a rise of $720,000,000 in outstanding loans for commercial and industrial purposes, Elliott V. Bell, Superintendent of Banks, stated in his annual report to the Governor and Legislature, released yesterday for publication today.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- The British Foreign Office received from Moscow today a copy of the Soviet Union's note to China reiterating the Russian view that the Council of Foreign Ministers should take the preliminary steps in preparing a peace treaty for Japan.

Two designers who contribute constructively to New York's fashions are foreign-born. They are Bruno Stehli, a Swiss, called Bruno in the professional field, and Pauline Trigere, Parisianborn. Both passed through the school of the French couture before coming to this country.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Haganah, Zionist defense force, announced tonight the dynamiting of three houses in villages around Safad, north of the Sea of Galilee. Eight Arabs were killed in one house, five in another and one in the third, Haganah said.

Democratic leaders in the stateh)0*0*0*iare mapping a vigorous campaign against the suggested plan to convert Syracuse University into a state institution, it became known yesterday. They declared that the Dewey administration proposals would not provide sufficient facilities for students either on the undergraduate or the professional school levels.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Joint Committee for the American Merchant Marine took the position informally today that the ship transfer provision of the European Recovery Program would be detrimental to the future of American shipping.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Opposition to the proposal to make Syracuse University a state institution is mounting rapidly within the New York State University Commission, headed by Owen D. Young, even though the plan is reputed to have the backing of Governor Dewey and Republican leaders.

President Truman is said to want a back porch where he can get "a breath of fresh air," screened from public view. Drawings from the design of even so distinguished an architect as Williamh)0*0*0*iA. Delano hardly reveal how he can be screened on an open balcony guarded by a three-foot iron railing.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Buyer attendance at the opening here today of the winter international home furnishings market in the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart shattered all previous records but higher prices in furniture lines and the general lack of really new products in most fields disappointed a great number of retailers.

Essential services in 116 hospitals and health and welfare institutions affiliated with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies face curtailment unless $3,910,000 additional is raised in the next month to meet the 1948 quota of $15,000,000, Victor S. Riesenfeld, city-wide appeal chairman, declared yesterday.

The Theatre Guild is trying to close a deal whereby it would take over for immediate Broadway production the Experimental Theatre presentation of "Skipper Next to God." Written by Jan de Hartog, the play is now being done at Maxine Elliott's Theatre for six performances, with John Garfield in the leading role.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -- The Coast Guard received last night a penciled appeal for help dated Nov. 24 and signed by five persons who said they were stranded on "Bones Island." Theh)0*0*0*imessage was found in a bottle floating in San Francisco Bay.
A total of $13,000,000 in two new public utility bond issues was awarded to banking groups at competitive bidding yesterday, as follows:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, Jan. 5 -"The Boy With Green Hair," an anti-war film, which has been kept in abeyance at RKO by its producer, Adrian Scott, who was dismissed by the studio for refusing to tell a congressional committee whether or not he was a Communist, has been reactivated and assigned to Stephen Ames for production in February, RKO disclosed today.

With reports from Albany indicating that almost a third of the early bonus applications had been filed incorrectly, state and local officials were busy yesterday attempting to clarify misunderstandings that have existed in filling out the blanks.

ARMONK, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Deer and birds suffering from food shortages because of icy snow blanketing the ground found manna falling from the heavens today in Westchester County as sportsmen distributed by plane two tons of hay and nearly a ton of grain.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The State Department said tonight it had taken no final action on a passport application by Max Weiss, member of the national committee of the Communist party in New York, despite a "twentyfour-hour ultimatum" from the applicant last week to the chief of its passport division.

In an editorial entitled "Mr. Wallace's Candidacy" you say: "Mr. Wallace's formula for keeping the peace seems to us to be essentially the formula which Mr. Chamberlain employes in the hope of keeping peace with Germany. It is to purchase a temporary good-will at the price of a sacrifice of both principle and position."

Six traffic courts in the city opened their doors at 8 A.M. yesterday, an hour earlier than usual, and by the time they closed at 3 P.M., 8,271 car owners had paidh)0*0*0*ifines amounting to $34,888 for hampering snow removal operations.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation assumed active command yesterday of the inquiries going on since Saturday morning to determine the identity of the person or group responsible for the attempt to ship 65,000 pounds of TNT to Palestine aboard the American Export liner Executor.

The new year finds the Camp Fire Girls newly housed in their own newh)0*0*0*ihome at 16 East Forty-eighth Street, where they moved in the closing days of 1947. Purchase of the new quarters has meant much work and effort on the part of some 360,000 girls, aged 7 to 18, throughout the country who have been raising money in many different ways to achieve their share of Camp Fire's $225,000 building fund.

Walt Disney Productions, producers of motion pictures, yesterday reported that gross income for the fiscal year ended on last Sept. 27 amounted to $6,619,912, the highest in its history. In the precedingh)0*0*0*ifiscal year gross income was $4,097,700.

Henry A. Wallace, in a statement issued last night through the Progressive Citizens of America, which is supporting his independent candidacy for President, reiterated his opposition to universal military training, and called it a decisive step "in conditioning the American people to the inevitability and imminence of war."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Arthur Leff, trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, today directed Robert N. Denham, the board's general counsel, to name the newspapers and furnish a bill of particulars stating how the International Typographical Union had sought to force them to violate the Taft-Hartley Act.

Coaches and athletic officials from more than 300 of the nation's colleges began drifting into the city yesterday for the forty-h)0*0*0*isecond annual meeting of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which begins gradually today and will extend through the remainder of the week.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- With all six members of the Soviet bloc absent from the first meeting of the Little Assembly, Michael Parisot, one of the United Nations' skilled simultaneous interpreters, spent some of the morning talking into a "dead" microphone.

Henry A. Wallace, in a statement issued last night through the Progressive Citizens of America, which is supporting his independent candidacy for President, reiterated his opposition to universal military training, and called it a decisive step "in conditioning the American people to the inevitability and imminence of war."

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 5 -- Following the course set by the Federal Reserve Bank some weeks ago in connection with United States Government securities, the Bank of Canada withdrew today its quotations on Dominion of Canada bonds, making no bids although open to offers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, asserting that prices were "almost stable when Congress was in session in 1947," asserted tonight that more New Deal policies have "started them up again."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 5 -- Pleading for adoption of universal military training, Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall warned today against deriving "a false sense of security" from the presence of great numbers of World War II veterans in the population.

Winning his adjourned game from the sixth round with M. Raizman of Paris in 57 moves, then scoring a draw against C. H. O'D. Alexander, former British champion, in the seventh, Laszlo Szabo of Budapest retained the lead in the international chess masters tournament at the Hastings and St. Leonards club, according to a report received from Hastings, England, yesterday.

ROME, Jan. 5 -- The Italian Government announced today that Yugoslavia had rejected Gen. Henri Guisan of Switzerland and Senator Auguste Buisseret of Belgium as candidates for the Governorship of the Free Territory of Trieste.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 5 -- The University of California African expedition exploring the Sinai Peninsula has discovered evidence that Moses and the Israelites may not have made their exodus from Egypt across the Red Sea as believed by some biblical scholars, but crossed a shallow body of water much farther north, according to Wendell Phillips, leader of the expedition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company today elected John D. Farrington of Chicago as its president. The company tookh)0*0*0*iover the property of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company on Jan. 1.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 5 -The ninth Pan American Child Congress opened here today with President Romulo Betancourt officiating. The congress the first since the war, has delegations from all nations in this hemisphere.

Manufacturers of better grade shoes are maintaining current prices on spring and summer shoe's now being shown for March and April delivery, according to Irving E. Grossman, president of the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers. Some manufacturers are raisingprices on new models, he said,but the average increase will notexceed 25 cents a pair.

In agreement or disagreement, the American people owe Henry A. Wallace a debt of gratitude. Our parties and politicians have in their campaign so equivocated, deceived and cheated that the very honorable name of politics, the art of citizenship, has become disreputable.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 5 -- Top secret documents of the German Army and Navy, dated September and October, 1933, were introduced today in the trial of Alfred Krupp and his co-defendants to indicate the deliberation with which these units violated the prohibitions against rearmament in the Versailles Treaty.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -- Senator J. Howard McGrath, the Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that California Democrats would agree upon a single slate of delegates, pledged to President Truman, for the June 4 Presidential primary ballot.

" Of Men and Books," which has been off the air since September, will return to the CBS network at 6:15 P.M. on Thursday. Russell Maloney, book critic, gag writer and erstwhile contributor to The New Yorker, will be the featured principal on the initial two broadcasts.

KODIAK, Alaska, Jan. 5 (AP) All thirteen persons marooned for days in near-zero weather on an icy point of the Alaska Peninsula were rescued today by the Navy and Coast Guard as gale winds and towering seas subsided and permitted the rescue.

Operators of local oil barges and self-propelled tankers and union representatives appeared yesterday to be deadlocked in a contract dispute that for the third successive year threatens the city's supply of fuel oil and other petroleum products.
Mrs. Linda E. Fleischer, 73-year-old great-grandmother from Seattle, Wash., is in the metropolitan area this week, ready to start the last leg of her trip around the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Truman may recommend a general increase of income taxes on corporation profits, but has definitely barred the re-establishment of the wartime excess profits tax, it was learned tonight.

In an effort to offset some of the spiraling costs involved in constructing the United Nations capital along the East River architects consider converting the Manhattan Building, now standing on the debris-filled site, into a permanent international library.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The second session of the Eightieth Congress convened at noon today, went through its formal opening routines and adjourned to await the personal delivery by President Truman of his annual message on the state of the Union at 1:30 P.M. tomorrow.

The first-place teams in the Eastern and Western Divisions of the Basketball Association of America will clash at Madison Square Garden tonight, with the New York Knickerbockers engaging the Chicago Stags.
Congress convened yesterday to find some 1,000 marines with full combat equipment on the high seas en route to the Mediterranean.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Vincent J. Butera, 31-year-old Purple Heart holder from Schenectady, received the first payment from New York State's $400,000,000 bonus for World War II veterans today.

The one great problem that may cause the downfall of India and Pakistan is the dispute over possession of Kashmir, Dr. Henry F. Grady, United States Ambassador to India, declared here last night. He spoke at the tenth anniversary meeting of the India League of America in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Dame May Whitty has been assigned to one of the top roles in "Julia Misbehaves," a forthcoming adaptation of the Margery Sharp novel, "The Nutmeg Tree," which Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will produce starring Greer Garson and Walter Pidgeon. . . .
Dr. Leo Baeck, president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism, expressed his appreciation yesterday to Mayor O'Dwyer for the Mayor's work for refugees as wartime head of the War Refugee Board.

NANKING, Jan. 6 -- About 1,250,000 Government combat troops are now committed against 700,000 Communist regulars in the major war areas north of the Yangtze River, according to the most reliable figures available here.

A five-month investigation into grain speculation by two bottling company salesmen resulted yesterday in the indictment of the two men and a commodity margin clerk for a brokearge house on charges that they swindled the Wall Street firm out of $69,160.
There is actually a surplus of anthracite coal at present, Frank W. Earnest, president of the Anthracite Institute, said yesterday.

No Congress has had to consider more vital issues affecting the United States Merchant Marine than the Eightieth Congress, which convened in Washington yesterday, in the opinion of representatives of the maritime industry in New York.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries reported yesterday, in the annual statement mailed to stockholders, a net profit of $22,094,979 for the fiscal year ended on last Aug. 31, compared with $19,424,650 earned in the preceding fiscal year.

The report in your edition of Jan. 4 that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey will recommend to the session of the New York State Legislature opening this week the enactment of a fair educational practice bill is extremely important and encouraging news to those who have for years been concerned with ending racial and religious discrimination in nonsectarian institutions of higher learning.

Having managed to defer to Jan. 15 his departure for Australia, in whose national championships he will compete later this month, Herbert McKenley has accepted an invitation to run in the Columbus 500 here on Saturday night. This race is one of the scratch features of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, meet at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

PARIS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Fifteen persons, including three Americans, died tonight when a Paris-bound Air France DC-4 airliner from Brussels crashed and burned while coming in for a landing at Le Bourget Airfield.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- The American homemaker may well become confused when she goes shopping for modern furniture, according to Alfred Auerbach, homefurnishings consultant. The designers, manufacturers and retailers themselves are in a jungle of confusion.

Harold E. Stassen opened an Eastern states campaign headquarters at the Hotel Sheraton yesterday and announced plans for expanded activities in the next three months in behalf of his Presidential campaign.

Two years ago today, on the eve of our departure for the States, we stood knee-deep in water and chest-deep in tules and watched several thousand mallards and teal sweep over and around us on the Gaeta Marshes in Italy.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The development most worth watching in France today is the progress of the anti-Communist labor movement. The main force of the French Communist party lay in its control of the General Federation of Labor (CGT), which had eighty-two per cent of the voting strength in the Trades Union Congress.

After a hearing lasting two hours and a half, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals reserved decision yesterday on a plea by Serge M. Rubinstein, international financier, and Allen Gordon Foster, his former business associate, for reversal of their convictions last April on charges of violating the Selective Service Act of 1940.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Convinced that the British Government has no intention of resuming negotiations for modification of the 75 per cent film tax until later this year, the American film industry has abandoned hopes of an early resumption of film shipments into the British market, it was learned today.

Edward E. Rhatigan, former Welfare Commissioner, severed his last connection with that department yesterday in a ten-word letter to Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding giving up his civil service post of Director of Public Assistance.
LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Brokers were blaming Greek political uncertainties for the further decline in business in the stock markets here today.

Buying activity in the New York apparel markets win approach record proportions this month judging from orders placed in the first six days, a survey showed yesterday. With the biggest influx of buyers yet to come within the next two weeks, manufacturers expressed confidence that business for spring and summer will exceed that of last year.

Murray Roth has sold the three two-story factory buildings at 511, 513 and 515 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, to the Koder Corporation through Harry Zirinsky, broker. Irving M. Levine was attorney for the seller and Lawrence Zirinsky represented the purchaser.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a treble damage award of $375,000 to the William Goldman Theatres, Inc., from Warner Brothers and ten other motion picture producing and distributing companies.
MOSCOW, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Thousands of worshipers thronged Moscow's Cathedral of the Resurrection tonight for the Orthodox Christmas Eve service led by Patriarch Alexius of Moscow and all Russia.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Jan. 6 -- Four hundred fifty persons, many of them high school students, attended the 111th forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES series of broadcasts on "What's on Your Mind?" this afternoon at the Woman's Club of Great Neck.

When we pause to reckon how completely world reconstruction depends on a wise distribution of food supply, and how gravely Europe's own share in her recovery will be jeopardized if her people do not have enough food to maintain the strength to produce, then the breakdown of our voluntary food conservation program in this country must be a source of great concern.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Bleriot H. Lamarre, who was president of the Aviation Electric Corporation set up by Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, pleaded guilty today to three charges of perjury. The arraignment was in the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia.

The increase of business debt relative to equity money has not yet been carried to the point of endangering the position of mark business concerns, "but it is a tendency which will need careful watching," according to the 1947 annual report of the National City Bank of New York, mailed to shareholders today.

Underwriting houses that bid for public utility bond issues on I Monday and yesterday are sensing, if only spasmodically thus far, a recurrence of the old assurance that dominated the bull market in bonds. With partly tax-exempt and i other bank-eligible bends in the! TreasUry list continuing to gain ground, the scrutiny of prime corporate credit continued, .too, to relax some of its recent severity.
MILWAUKEE, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The "Big Three" of the brewing industry here -- Schlitz, Blatz and Pabst -- were at sharp variance today of prices.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- "I feel that I committed no wrong. I feel I did what was right and true." With these words today Japan's wartime Premier, Hideki Tojo, ended his lengthy cross-examination at the hands of the American chief prosecutor, Joseph B. Keenan.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Purchasing at the winter international home furnishings market in the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts has definitely assumed "a normal character for the first time since before the war," manufacturers and buyers agreed here today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 6 -- United California Productions, in which Eugene Frenke, Robert Cummings and Philip Yordan are partners, has closed a deal with Eagle Lion for production facilities and distribution for "Let's Live A Little," a comedy in which Hedy Lamarr will play opposite Cummings, Eagle Lion announced today.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The mushrooming growth of the world's civil aviation networks is shown in tables of the United Nations Statistical Bulletin's latest issue, to be released tomorrow.
Stanley C. Gillett has been appointed regional sales manager of the Middle Atlantic States for the Phillips-Jones Corporation.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Jan. 6 -- A packed house attended the first performance by the Theatre of San Antonio, Lily Cahill's new stock company venture, featuring Peggy Wood in Sidney Howard's Theatre Guild comedy, "Ned McCobb's Daughter."

Whenever financial statements appear on the stationery or in a report of an independent certified public accountant there should be a clear-cut indication of the character of the examination, if any, made by the accountant in relation to the statement, it is recommended by the committee on auditing procedure of the American Institute of Accountants.

The Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday the schedule of its Spring tour, which will be the lengthiest one the company has undertaken in forty-three years. Denver, Lincoln, Neb., and Richmond, Va., will be included in addition to the already announced season in Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, speaking as an individual, declared today his opposition to Henry Wallace as an independent candidate for President of the United States.

"Is it --h ----,,w luk-- ' ? i rather like to refer to it as the feminine look, for femininity is the very esseffce of fashion for 1948,"- This was the comment of .Maurice Rentner in response to a ,request for his opinion of the chned sUouette.

The mental hygiene clinic that the Health Department hopes to open this month in Brooklyn will be an experiment and the first public clinic of the kind in this city, it was explained yesterday. For that reason, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard has nicknamed the project a "pilot plant."

HONOLULU, Jan. 6 -- The International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union sugar workers' "unity" conference in Hilo, Hawaii, neared adjournment late yesterday with the recent revolt in the rank and file over charges of communism within the union still the chief issue and apparently an unsettled one.

American gray iron foundries have asked the Department of Commerce to restudy the effects of the Hyde Park financial agreement upon American manufacturers, R.L. Collier, executive vice president of the Gray Iron Founders' Society, Inc., Cleveland, revealed here yesterday.

The New York Central System this year will completely re-equip twenty-eight of its key passenger trains with streamlined cars, virtually completing a $75,000,000 passenger equipment program, G. Metzman, president, announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 6 -- A Palestine Government statement, issued today on the subject of the blasting of the Semiramis Hotel yesterday, said the Government was "carefully considering the situation created by Haganah in publicly claiming credit for this dastardly and wholesale murder of innocent people."

In spite of present strength of the textile industry, it is advisable that its members adopt a cautious policy for this year, it was declared last night by Dr. Marcus Nadler, professor of finance at the New York University School of Business Administration.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 6 (UP) -- Five 'teen-aged youths confessed today that they wrecked about twenty-five automobiles over the week-end for a "thrill."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- President Truman soon will lose his personal pilot, Lieut. Col. Henry T. Myers, who has flown presidential planes and their famous passengers thousands of miles without mishap.

BROOKFIELD, Conn., Jan. 6 -- Night clubs and taverns, and little shops and stores in this Fairfield County town of 1,300 residents were displaying today little glass jars with the legend, "A Little Girl Needs a Hand."
Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander rewarded yesterday two detectives who wounded and captured a hold-up suspect. He promoted them at the scene within a short time of the occurrence.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 7 -- The United States today asked Russia for information regarding reports that Japanese army equipment captured in Manchuria by Soviet forces was now in the hands of Chinese Communists.
MONTREAL, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Buddy O'Connor is leading the hockey scorers for the first time in his seven-year National Hockey League career.

Private enterprise can play a vital role in helping to shape and carry out the Marshall Plan, Allen Welsh Dulles of Sullivan Cromwell and legal consultant to the Herter Committee, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer reserved decision yesterday in a suit brought by trustees of the will of Samuel L. Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, to restrain the publication of a detective story written by the author in 1876 on the ground that it would injure his "fame and reputation."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- Seventy persons were killed here today when a crowd stormed into a Sikh temple in which 250 Sikh men, women and children evacuees from upper Sind Province were housed for transit and afterward set it on fire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A Senate committee investigating commodity speculation by alleged "insiders" completed today in closed session its preliminary case involving President Truman's personal physician, Brig. Gen. Wallace H. Graham.

Asserting that price cuts put into effect last week by the General Electric Company were too limited to ease the pressure of rising living costs, the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, announced yesterday that it would seek a third round of post-war wage increases for 300,000 members employed by the Big Three of the electrical manufacturing industry -- GE, Westinghouse and the electrical division of General Motors.

St. John's did it again! The upset kings of the East, who surprised against Utah and came close to taking the measure of Kentucky and Rhode Island State, outsmarted and outhustled the C.C.N.Y. basketball team and recorded another startling victory at Madison Square Garden last night, in the season's lowest-scoring game on the Eighth Avenue hardwood.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, under Eugene Ormandy, played the Honegger "Symphony for Strings" (with trumpet solo) for the first time at its New York concert series last night in Carnegie Hall. No greater contrast than the one that exists between this intense and profoundly sincere music and the inflated bombast of the same composer's "Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher," heard in the same hall the previous week, can be imagined.

Total assets of the United States Trust Company of New York, on Dec. 31, 1947, amounted to $157,809,988, compared with $165,067,967, at the close of 1946, reflecting the withdrawal by the Government of funds from its War Loan Deposit Account, Benjamin Strong, president, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- With President Truman as the ranking guest, the Capitol celebrated today the birthday of Representative Sam Rayburn of Texas, former Speaker of the House and now minority leader. He was 66 years old.

The stock market lost more ground yesterday although a late rally enabled prices to end the day well above the worst marks of the session. Selling was directed again against the rails and pivotal industrials while the aircrafts made a new advance, apparently on expectations of a renewal of Government orders.

Sol Strauss, directing the Twentieth Century Sporting Club in the absence of the ailing promoter Mike Jacobs, yesterday announced definitely that Joe Louis would defend his world heavyweight title under the auspices of his club, preferably at the Yankee Stadium or Polo Grounds in June and probably against Jersey Joe Walcott.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 6 (AP) -- The long and short of it at Gulf-stream Park today was that favorite followers had a long wait before Eb, a long-striding horse with a short name and short odds, came to their rescue in the featured Useppa Purse.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 2,185, against 180 last week and 2,147 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. There were 1,945 arrivals yesterday compared with 142 last Tuesday.

Caswell Motors Company has bought from the Manhattan Terrazzo Brass Strip Company the garage building on a plot 50 by 200 feet at 613-15 West 129th Street, to be used as a Ford service station. The property is assessed at $60,000.

The passing of Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, widow of our twenty-third President, carries us back to an era that now seems even more remote than its dates would indicate. Mrs. Harrison did not marry the former President until he had left office and was never mistress of the White House.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 6 -- Behind the scenes of their conference with the leading German officials of the bizonal area, Gen. Lucius P. Clay and Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson plan to work out tomorrow and Thursday a complete reorganization and integration of the United States and British Military Governments in Germany, it was learned from an official source tonight.

Plans for the movie industry's participation in American Brotherhood Week were outlined yesterday at a luncheon of the amusements division for the observance, which will start Feb. 22. Spyros P. Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox and chairman of the motion picture division, presided at the meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The American Labor party, formed in 1936 to back the second term candidacy of Franklin D. Roosevelt, is scheduled to fall apart this morning at a special meeting of its state executive committee called because of the independent candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 6 -- Discrimination against the American Indian can be dissipated only through a reversal of public attitudes and by his gradual assimilation into the urban and industrial life of this country, William E. Warne, Assistant Secretary of the Interior, asserted here tonight.

More individualistic design of packages, plus more frequent change of the promotional and informative material printed on them, was advocated yesterday by Jim Nash, packaging designer, as a necessary tool for the coming job of competitive selling.

HELSINKI, Finland, Jan. 6 -- The Finnish Government is trying to obtain new foreign loans, Onni A. Hiltunen, Minister of Finance, declared in an interview tonight; however, he did not disclose the government or governments approached.
Beating the city's latest snow flurry by a matter of a few hours, winter baseball broke out on two fronts in the metropolitan area yesterday.

The Marshall Plan was described last night as "the greatest rehabilitation program in history" by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson at the Metropolitan Opera House. He made the chief speech at a concert by the Boston Symphony Orchestra opening the Salvation Army's 1948 campaign for $1,000,000 for its maintenance fund.

The winners of the 1947 competition for the Edwin Austin Abbey Memorial Scholarship Fund for Mural Painting in the United States have been announced. They are Joseph Lasker of New York (winner in the 1946 competition) $2,000; Clarence Eugene Van Duzer Jr. of Cleveland, $2,000, and Sante Graziani of New Haven, Conn., $2,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- A new half dollar of regular issue, bearing a likeness of Benjamin Franklin and a representation of the Liberty Bell, has been approved and is expected to be ready for distribution in about three months, it was announced today by John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury.

CAMDEN, N.J., Jan. 6 (UP) -- Felix Bocchicchio, Camden promoter who has exclusive call on Jersey Joe Walcott's services, said tonight he would not consider 20 per cent of the gross gate for his fighter to meet Joe Louis in New York next June.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 6 -- Britain and Argentina resume their trade negotiations tomorrow. Although Argentina's halting of permits for exporting meat to the United Kingdom highlights the upper hand held by Miguel Miranda, head of the National Economic Council, the situation is far from being as serious as it appears.

Under the impact of the increased aggressiveness of the Greek Communist guerrillas and the increased aid extended to them by Russia's Balkan satellites, the United States has again adjusted its Greek aid program to enable the Greek Government to increase its own military effectiveness.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 6 -- Mexico's oil reserves are estimated at slightly more than 1,000,000,000 barrels, according to a report released by Petroleos Mexicanos (Pemex), Government oil monopoly.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- The State Legislature may take action at its coming session to protect New York City automobile owners from exorbitant garage rents. It is expected also to enact a bill deterring rent increases in cases where housing is decontrolled under the Federal rent law.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- As Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg explained, the elimination of the overall dollar commitment ($17 billions) for the long-range European Recovery Program does not withdraw the request of the Administration for "continuing authorization" of the project by Congress over the proposed period of four years and a half.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 6 -- Development of a self-sufficient, democratic Japan, able to stand as a "deterrent" to any future "totalitarian war threats" in the Far East, was described as the American goal by Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, in an address today to the Commonwealth Club.

The first reading of the sky riders competing at Bear Mountain was like a leap back to pre-war ski-jumping. Another Tokle has arrived in this country from Norway -- Arthur, brother of Torger, the greatest jumper the sport has known. Torger Tokle was killed in Italy with the Tenth Mountain Division, the "Ski" Division.

CAIRO, Jan. 6 -- Premier Mahmoud Fahmy Nokrashy Pasha indicated in a speech before Parliament today that Egypt was prepared to take a strong stand when the Anglo-Egyptian treaty negotiations were resumed and would insist on the immediate evacuation of British troops from this country.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 6 -- Sardonically designated by Brig. Gen. Telford Taylor, chief of counsel, as "the gentlemen from Wilhelmstrasse" twenty-one Nazi diplomats, bankers and economists went on trial today in the main courtroom of the Palace of Justice here.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- The Government's special tax to fight inflation became a law tonight when the National Assembly passed it quickly by a show of hands after its adoption by the Council of the Republic.

DETROIT, Jan. 6 -- Assailing Democrats and Republicans alike for failure to curb inflation, Walter P. Reuther, president, and the Wage Policy Committee of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, stated tonight that the union, with almost 1,000,000 members, would "demand and win wage increases" early this year.

Expressing doubts that the new anti-inflation bill directly can effectuate price reductions in the apparel field, Erwin Feldman, director-counsel of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers, declared yesterday that the measure likewise did not make clear what could be done to reduce textile prices.

BOSTON, Jan. 6 -- Harvard's gallant bid to repeat last year's upset of Columbia's Eastern Inter-collegiate League basketball champions went for nought tonight despite a stirring effort that extended through two overtime periods before the Lions emerged on top, 55 -- 53.

OIL CITY, Pa., Jan. 6 (AP) -- A group of petroleum refiners operating in Pennsylvania fields announced today that it had obtained control of the National Transit Company's pipelines by the purchase of about one-third of 504,499 shares of National Transit's outstanding stock from two holders of the stock in New York City.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- British and Danish representatives began today a series of financial and trade talks, the outcome of which will largely influence the success of Britain's struggle to restore the pound sterling to its position as major international currency.

HAVANA, Jan. 6 -- A proposal for the creation of a special fund out of taxes paid by sugar producers to be used as part payment of workers' wages on this year's crop was presented to President Ramon Grau San Martin today by Dr. Arturo Manas, secretary of the National Sugar Institute.

CHICAGO, Jan. 6 -- Heavy profit-taking attracted by a rally of 9 cents a bushel in wheat, 7 1/4 cents in corn and 5 1/8 cents in oats from yesterday's low marks caused a sharp setback in grain prices on the Board of Trade today after an early advance.
An altruistic move was made yesterday by Blevins Davis to extend the run of the Experimental Theatre's production of "Skipper Next to God," in which John Garfield is appearing at Maxine Elliott's.
A spectacular five-alarm fire destroyed last night Pier 8, Furman Street near the foot of Orange, in the heart of the Brooklyn dock area.

PARIS, Jan. 6 -- Statistics issued today by the French Ministry of Health indicate the greatest reduction in the history of the French death rate, making it one of the world's lowest in 1946. The drop from 1945 was from 16.8 per thousand to 13.4.

The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation yesterday formally opened .its new quarters in the modernized building at 16 East Fifty-sixth Street with a reception and preview of its products, of which more than a score have been incorporated in the five-story structure.

It's love that makes the world go 'round, says the proverb -- but those who know England are inclined to believe that, in so far as the portion of the world inhabited by the English is concerned, what keeps things revolving is not love but tea.

The seventy-first annual report of A.G. Spalding Bros., Inc., issued yesterday to stockholders by Charles F. Bobbins, president, disclosed consolidated net earnings amounting to $2,178,902 for the fiscal year ended with last October.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Information Subcommittee of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided to day to urge early debate by the Senate of the Government's entire foreign information service.
TEANECK, N.J., Jan. 6 -- On court order, three former GI's started today to tear down the $11,000 dry-cleaning plant at 297 Cedar Lane that they had built with their own hands eighteen months ago.
BERLIN, Jan. 6 -- The United States Military Government will charge that justice as it is known in the Western democracies does not exist in the Soviet zone of Germany, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6 -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation of Willow Run, Mich., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 1,500,000 additional shares of $1 par value common stock.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The United Nations Security Council agreed today to take up India's complaint that Pakistan is supporting raids into the state of Kashmir. However, consideration of the case was postponed until next week to allow the Foreign Minister of Pakistan, Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, to arrive here from Karachi to take part in the discussions.

TOKYO, Jan. 6 -- Japanese politicians have decided that the present Cabinet has no future and the parties backing the government of Premier Tetsu Katayama are slowly disintegrating. Sixteen Socialists, under the leadership of Rikizo Hirano, former Minister of Agriculture, quit their party yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 6 -- John Howard, deputy to Dwight P. Griswold, head of the United States Aid Mission, announced tonight an additional $15,000,000 of aid funds would be allocated to the Greek Army and National Guard.
In behalf of his comrades shot down at sea during World War II an Air Force veteran sent yesterday his gift of $10 to the Hundred Neediest Cases Fund.

Edward C. Werle, a partner in Johnson Wood, has been nominated for the office of chairman of the board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange for another term, it was announced yesterday. Nomination is tantamount to election.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Prices paid by consumers for all foods, with the exception of meat and eggs, advanced 0.5 per cent between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- The services of Senora Eva Peron, first lady of Argentina, have been offered to help the United Nations collect funds in South America for needy children abroad, it was learned today. The Argentine Government has further proposed to assist the child relief campaign by contributing $10,000,000.

A light snowfall, part of a storm that swept through to the Eastern seaboard from the Midwest, struck New York yesterday afternoon and the prediction was that it would continue through the night. About an inch of snow had fallen by early morning.

I have served on a jury and I am ready to do it again. I think every citizen should do his civic duty. The city paid me three dollars a day for my time. The other jurors were paid the same amount. But a strange situation developed.

Long Island is in the midst of a home-building boom with Nassau County "one of the fastest growing suburban areas in the country," according to a survey released yesterday by the Long Island Association.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 6 -- The Indian Army's forward position in Kashmir at Naoshera was attacked by "about 4,000" hostile forces this morning, according to an Indian Army communique. This was the first daylight attack made on an Indian encampment since the Kashmir fighting began in October.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Repeal of the Condon-Wadlin Act outlawing strikes by public employes and the establishment of a state university are advocated in the legislative program of the New York State Congress of Industrial Organizations, Louis Hollander, state CIO president, announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders of Vermont disclosed tonight that the stand-by meat rationing bill he was drafting would be introduced under bipartisan sponsorship. He declined to name the Democrats who would have their names on the bill, asserting that he was waiting until the bill was in more complete form before talking to them.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll said today that he expected a pattern of government for New Jersey, condensing nearly 100 existing bureaus and agencies into fewer than twenty on strict functional lines, would be ready to offer to the Legislature next Tuesday.
Mayor O'Dwyer endeavored yesterday to prevent the threatened strike of 3,000 butchers in 2,000 retail meat markets in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island and Long Island.

ROME, Jan. 6 -- The decision to send United States marines to the Mediterranean was taken by the Navy Department in a routine manner without previously consulting the State Department and was devoid of any political significance, according to information officially supplied to the Italian Ambassador in Washington by the State Department.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- A. McKnight's Miss Busy Bee won the $1,300 Pointe Coupee Purse, feature race at the Fair Grounds today.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 6 -- The United States Steel Corporation reported today that seven production records were established in 1947 at three plants here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- President Truman waited ten minutes backstage for Jose Iturbi tonight, then helped the embarrassed pianist recall a number the first family wished to hear at a recital in Constitution Hall.

The hats shown by Florence Reichman yesterday in her salon at 1 West Fifty-seventh Street brought such remarks from spectators as "pretty," "wearable," "women will like them." Mrs. Reichman, taking the present-day styles into consideration, geared her headlines to meet them.

Meetings of affiliated bodies preliminary to the forty-third annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association produced a swirl of activity in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday as hundreds of college athletic officials and coaches made the rounds from gathering to gathering.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- The development of plans for a large-scale Greek Army offensive next spring was indicated strongly by the State Department today. The suggestion came in a statement explaining United States support of an increase in the Greek Government's armed forces and revealing the diversion of $15,000,000 in American aid from civilian to military purposes to finance the increase.

HONOLULU, Jan. 6 -- Strong support of statehood for Hawaii was given today as Circuit Judge Carl E. Wimberly, of Oregon, a special investigator for a Senate subcommittee on Territories, began taking testimony on the issue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Red Cross chapters in Birmingham, Ala., and El Paso, Tex., have protested that the 1948 national fundraising goal of $75,000,000 is too high, but headquarters of the American Red Cross here said the protests do not represent a "revolt."

Close bidding marked the competition of investment-banking syndicates yesterday for awards of public utility securities valued at more than $16,000,000. Less than 10 cents per $1,000 bond separated the highest of ten bids for $8,000,000 of thirty-year first mortgage bonds of the Dayton Power and Light Company -- that of Lehman Brothers -- from a second high bid submitted by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

Henry Morgan is slated for an early return to the WJZ-ABC network, his services as a humorist having attracted new sponsorship. He is to resume broadcasting Thursday, Jan. 29, in an offering which will be heard from 7:30 to 8 P.M. in the different time zones across the country.

Laszlo Szabo of Budapest, after drawing his eighth-round game with M.H. Muehring of Amsterdam, a King's Indian defense lasting twenty moves, was declared victor of the annual international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to reports received yesterday from Hastings, England.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 6 -- The health of 15,000,000 Americans engaged in hazardous occupations is the direct responsibility of the medical profession. This was emphasized today by Dr. R.L. Sensenich of South Bend, Ind., president-elect of the A.M.A., in an address at the congress on industrial health of the American Medical Association.

The nation's sports writers gave the final answer yesterday to the raging controversy on relative strength of the Notre Dame and Michigan football teams, and it was the Wolverines over the Irish by almost two to one -- including those who saw both powerhouses perform.

HAVANA, Jan. 6 -- William L. Clayton, chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, returned here today from Washington, where he has been working on the Marshall Plan.

The arrest yesterday of six men by the Federal Bureau of Investigation disclosed an intensive inquiry by the Civil Aeronautics Administration into credentials held by airplane mechanics employed by the major airlines in the metropolitan area.

Naval officials here attempted yesterday to clear up some of the confusion that has surrounded applications by former naval, marine, and coast guard officers and enlisted men for the $250 veterans' bonus for overseas service.
New headquarters for Church World Service on five floors of a seven-story building at 214 East Twenty-first Street were dedicated yesterday afternoon.

President Truman pledged his fullest cooperation in support of the 1948 March of Dimes campaign in a letter to Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, which was released yesterday from the headquarters of that organization at 120 Broadway.

Tribute was paid yesterday to the memory of the scientist and educator, George Washington Carver, the "peanut wizard" of Tuskegee Institute in whose honor a 3-cent commemorative stamp was released locally. Friends and admirers gathered in the Harlem Branch of the Y.W.C.A. under the auspices of the National Alliance of Postal Employes to take part in the tribute.

Federal authorities acted yesterday to seize as contraband the twenty-six cases believed to contain 65,000 pounds of TNT and the fifty-one cases suspected of containing munitions-making machinery that had been removed on Saturday from a Palestine-bound freighter.

HAVANA, Jan. 6 -- The creation of a central office for the exchange of information and the promotion of activities for the prevention of blindness in the Western Hemisphere was approved by the Pan-American Council of Ophthalmology at the third Pan-American Congress of Ophthalmology, here.

Cocking a weather eye yesterday on what looked like another approaching layer of snow for already stricken New York, the Elco people of Bayonne, N. J., sent by barge to an East Thirtieth Street pier and then by dray to Lexington Avenue and East Forty-eighth Street the three cruisers for their display in the National Motor Boat Show which will open Friday night in Grand Central Palace.

Directors of Textron, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of one share of capital stock of $1 par value of Dorset Fabrics, Inc., on each share of Textron common, payable March 1 to holders of record Jan. 17. In announcing the dividend, Royal Little, president, said directors do not plan to consider further dividend action on the common stock of Textron until the latter part of the year.

The report in THE TIMES on Dec. 16 of Sir Alan Burns' remarks at a luncheon the day before suffered from two grave defects. First, it picked certain phrases to publish without setting them in the sentences in which they were spoken.

One thousand men were lined up at 4 P.M. yesterday outside the Park Department building at 533 West Fifty-ninth Street to apply for 300 civil service positions as cleaners. The first applicant had arrived twelve hours earlier.

JOSEPH PAUL DIMAGGIO has finally solved the problem of the high cost of living. No longer does he have to go along on a hand-to-mouth basis, struggling to keep the wolf off the doorstep at a paltry $43,750 a year. The Jolter now is in the chips at a handsome $70,000 or so per season. More power to him, though; it couldn't happen to a nicer guy -- or greater ball player.

The six-story apartment building at 3951-3957 Gouverneur Avenue, in the Bronx, has been sold by the Fourex Realty Corporation to the Gouverneur Realty Corporation in a transaction negotiated by Farber-Wittman, Inc., as broker.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 6 -- The Rumanian Government is reported to have ordered the remnants of the country's royalty to follow King Michael into exile, even though the two principal remaining representatives -- Princesses Elizabetha and Ileana -- collaborated so closely with the Russians that they became known as the King's "Red aunts."
Like Shakespeare, Glorifried Ham 'n Eggs seems to be something for everybody.

Many passengers among the 600 who arrived here yesterday from Poland on the American ship Ernie Pyle brought spiced meats and other foods because they thought there was a food shortage in the United States, according to ship officers.

A distinguished program of contemporary sonatas for violin and piano was presented by the League of Composers at Times Hall last night. The league was fortunate in having the services of two excellent performers so familiar with the medium as Angel Reyes, Cuban violinist, and Jacques de Menasce, composer and pianist. They did a bang-up job on sonatas by Hindemith, Thomson, Copland and Bartok.

An investing client of Samuel W. Brodsky, attorney, was the purchaser of the twelve-story apartment building at 120 West Eighty-sixth Street from the Stonehouse Realty Corporation. A previous report of the deal in these columns a few days ago erroneously listed the buyer as a client of Irving Brodsky.

New York is due to get only 60 per cent of its minimum requirements of fuel oil in the next three months, Mayor O'Dwyer declared in a telegram sent last night to the United States Maritime Commission appealing for twenty more tankers to service the area in January and February.

The Brooklyn Dodgers of the All-America Football Conference have been taken over by the baseball organization of the same i name, Branch Rickey, president, announced yesterday. The franchise, which the Brooklm club "inherited" without responsibility i for any previous indebtedness, will be operated by Rickey.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- The Navy holds such complete control of the seas that it can establish floating air bases off any shores from which to launch devastating attacks on inland targets, asserts Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, who retired last month as chief of naval operations.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Faced with a host of problems arising out of increased prices, the 171st regular session of the Legislature meets at noon tomorrow to hear Governor Thomas E. Dewey's annual message and recommendations for legislative action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Those recommendations in the President's message to Congress today which did not deal with policies and projects in the foreign field growing out of World War II further certified the political decision he made last year to go the whole route with the New Deal and union labor allies of the Roosevelt Administration.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Mayor Carl Nates of St. Moritz, champion of American participation in the Winter Olympic Games starting Jan. 30, today resumed active charge of preparations for the games with the approval of the Swiss Olympic Organizing Committee.
Ernest T. Williams has been appointed executive assistant to the president of the Railway Express Agency. He suceeds J. R. Marra, appointed general manager, eastern lakes department.

No one could know more about the change from wartime to postwar fashions than Philip Mangone, whose coats and suits are renowned throughout the country. He was one of those called to Washington to discuss with the Government details of the L-85 regulation.

HARRISON, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- A master plan for modernization and development of Harrison, the township that some United Nations delegates once sought to make the capital of the world, was submitted today to taxpayers by Supervisor Alfred F. Sulla Jr. and the Town Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Here is a comparison of taxes under the present law, as they would be under legislation proposed by President Truman, and under a measure introduced by Representative Knutson, Republican, of Missouri:

The hubbub and fanfare attendant upon the signing of Joe DiMaggio having subsided, the Yankees returned to their quiet daily routine in their Squibb Tower offices yesterday. But that by no means prevented George M. Weiss, the efficiently operating general manager, from bringing another frontline player into the fold for the 1948 campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, was a speculator in corn to the extent of 195,000 bushels on June 30 of last year, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature was criticized today by Democrats as a blatant appeal for the Republican Presidential nomination. They said that it was devoid of constructive recommendations for meeting state problems and reflected "the Hoover philosophy of fear."

" The Paradine Case," produced by David O. Selznick and directed by Alfred Hitchcock, which arrives at the Radio City Music Hall, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Heading the cast of the melodrama are Gregory Peck, Ann Todd, British acress; Alida Valli, Italian actress; Louis Jourdan, French actor; Charles Laughton, Ethel Barrymore, Charles Coburn, Leo G. Carroll and Joan Tetzel.
Truman Gordon Case, who retired last week from the New York Central Railroad, said yesterday that he "still would like to putter around" in the job he held for fifty-two years.

Chicago's Stags again were move than a bit too good for New York's Knickerbockers in their Basketball Association of America engagement at Madison Square Garden last night. Despite a riproaring rally by the home forces in the last quarter, the lads from the Windy City gained a 79-to-74 decision, their third straight over the Knicks this season.

" Nosegays are my signature for the season," Mago Hayes said yesterday in presenting a collection of hats in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. Bouquets shot straight up at the front or back of bretons and small sailors.

Roosters felt they had something to crow about yesterday when the seventeenth annual New York Poultry Exposition opened for four days at the Ninth Infantry Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street. The cackling of 1,700 barnyard specimens, comprising the entries of 229 exhibitors throughout the country, bore out the contention of Paul H. Kuhl of Flemington, N.J., president of the exposition, that this was their best poultry show since before the war.

In his spring hat collection shown yesterday at 1 West Fiftyseventh Street, Laddie Northridge emphasized two basic silhouettes -the bonnet and the sailor. With them he used, with restraint and excitement, imported flowers, moire taffeta ribbons, sweeping bird plumes and gilt miniature hands.

Demonstrating the high degree of fashion consciousness engendered in the so-called daytime frock, fifty-one manufacturers of dresses in the by-dozen category presented their annual showing of spring and summer styles last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Mr. Truman's tax plan, put forward yesterday in his message on the State of the Union, seems to us to be an attempt to play both sides of the political street. It is an attempt by the Administration to seize the initiative from the majority party in this area of electionyear political maneuvering, and to do this while continuing at the same time to pose as the "anti-inflation" party.

In THE TIMES of Dec. 26 is a picture of a group of men picketing the White House on Christmas Day. Dressed in striped prison garb, they are shown demonstrating in behalf of a general amnesty for violators of the Selective Service Act.

The Communists and consistent followers of their party line took control of the American Laborh)0*0*0*iparty yesterday when Hyman Blumberg, executive vice-chairman of the Amalgamated Clothing workers of America, resigned as state chairman. Representative Vito Marcantonio, New York County Chairman of the party, was elected to succeed him.

The national economic and social goals advocated by President Truman yesterday drew a surprisingly small amount of criticism from industrial leaders in the first canvass of comments made among New York industrialists yesterday afternoon.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- A Holywood star, an unemployed worker and an American family of five have joined in giving a preinaugural start to the United Nations international collection of funds for needy children.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The occasion for a report on the state of the Union, a tradition established by George Washington, afforded to foreign observers today the nearest example of pomp and circumstance in the American republic.

Ever-wider growth of the selfservice supermart, laundermats and vending machines will produce within a few years stores entirely devoted to mechanical merchandising devices, an official of the Telecoin Corporation predicted yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 7 -Princeton's varsity basketball quintet opened its 1948 Eastern League campaign with a 50-48 conquest of Pennsylvania in the new Dillon gym tonight by coming from behind with a second-half rally which kept 2,500 persons in a constant uproar.

Headquarters of the police department safe and loft squad at 400 Broome Street took on the aspect of a loft preparing for an auction sale last night as detectives carried in truckloads of silks, linens, woolens and other goods of an estimated total value of $100,000, and stacked the bolts in lots for inspection by persons who have reported truck robberies during the last six months.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- There are abundant indications that British foreign policy, as it will begin to emerge at a Cabinet meeting tomorrow, will be as firm and unequivocal toward Communist intentions in Europe as is the policyh)0*0*0*iof the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- A bill to authorize the State Department to carry on an information service to foreign countries and to stimulate the exchange of students and technicians was favorably reported to the Senate by the Foreign Relations Committee today.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York is now offering its memberh) 0*0*0*ibanks a daily summary of news and "outside" opinions of a financial and fiscal nature, prepared by its reference library. In a notice just sent to the member banks, the bank explained that the summary was started some years ago, primarily for the information of its officers and directors, although it has been distributed also among its staff and others in the system.

The Lawyers Trust Company reported as of Dec. 31, 1947, total deposits of $78,505,601 and total assets of $84,856,144, compared, respectively, with $75,876,508 and $82,216,951 on June 30, 1947. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $22,333,887, against $20,059,023, holdings of United States Government securities to $45,068,398, against $45,135,323, and loans and discounts to $14,236,824, against $13,327,417.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Armour Co., meat packers and food processors, today reported net earnings of $30,950,269 for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 1, last, compared with $28,026,342 in the preceding year.

Governor Dewey's annual message to the Legislature will naturally be read first of all this year for its political overtones. Such readers will find what they are looking for. The message is, in fact, two messages. In one Governor Dewey, as an unannounced candidate for President, deplores what he regards as a mismanagement of our national economy, which has, throughout the nation, produced an "inflationary whirlwind."

TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur's headquarters has refused to give the Soviet Union a special study covering Japanese disarmament and demilitarization, the Allied Council for Japan was told at today's session.

The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that the State Department had revoked a military permit to visit Japan granted to John Haynes Holmes, chairman of the union's board of directors and minister of the Community Church, 10 Park Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- Opening an intensive, ninety-day drive in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, Harold E. Stassen declared today that Congress could slash taxes by $3,000,000,000, meet the financial requirements of the Marshall Plan in full and still have a balanced budget, with a reserve of between one and two billion dollars.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Congress gave President Truman's annual message on the state of the Union a chilly reception today. It had been heralded as "a slugging message."h) 0*0*0*iO
Stockings in faint tones were presented yesterday by the Gotham Hosiery Company at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics made public today preliminary figures showing there were fewer strikes in 1947 than in 1946. Besides, the strikes affected fewer workers and cost fewer man-days than in 1946.
LONDON, Jan. 7 -- As developments in Washington in connection with the Marshall Aid Plan were not known in time to affect the stock markets here today, most sections were dull.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for an 8-cent fare on the municipal transit lines was endorsed yesterday by Local 100, Transport Workers of America, the CIO union that says it represents most of the 33,000 employes of the city system.

Random notes:h)0*0*0*iIce fishermen, the warm-blooded and hardy members of the brotherhood, are having a field day on some of the lakes, but a few of them have written to complain that the deep snow on the ice has made things both complicated and difficult.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Here, briefly, are President Truman's recommendations on major issues in his message on the state of the Union:
PROVIDENCE, Jan. 7 -- Columbia made Brown its eighth straight basketball victim of the season at the Marvel Gymnasium tonight by its largest margin of the campaign, 73 -- 41.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 7 -Army had to stave off a spirited last-half rally to defeat Swarthmore College, 41 to 39, in the cadets' inaugural basketball game of the season in the Field House today. The game also marked the debut of Coach John W. Mauer, former Tennessee mentor, at the military academy.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to prohibit segregation of Negro and white students in public education systems.

Representatives of industry were urged yesterday to support the program sponsored by American Overseas Aid and the United Nations Appeal for Children in the campaign for $60,000,000 endorsed by President Truman last November.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -Trailing by 5 points with two minutes left to play, unbeaten Fordham staged a dramatic rally to notch its fifth straight basketball victory by a 77-75 count as the expense of Yale tonight. A crowd of 2,000 saw the game in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium.

Count Richard Coudenhove-Kalergi, founder and secretary general of the European Parliamentary Union, declared on his arrival here yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania that if the Marshall Plan is to to succeed Europe must federate.
Seven years of controversy over the offspring of two miniature poodles has been settled with the award of $100 claims that totaled $7,000, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers pleaded not guilty today to charges that he perjured himself before Senate investigators inquiring into his wartime private deals and that he caused another to swear falsely also.

DETROIT, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings rode a five-game winning streak into first place in the National Hockey League tonight as they trounced the thirdplace New York Rangers, 6 to 0, before 12,556 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Church organizations received permission today from the Atomic Energy Commission to use Governmentowned land at principal atomic installations for sites for the construction of churches and church schools.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Presidential speeches, particularly on the state of the Union, are usually put together like a grandmother's quilt -- a few bits from each of the government departments, a few contributions from the Cabinet, and a few bright patches from the White House staff, all tacked together by some expert craftsman.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday that as of Dec. 31, last, its net asset value was $95,451,720, equal to $49.03 a share, compared with $47.73 at the end of the previous quarter. Its fiscal year ends on June 30. For the first half of the present fiscal year, on up to Dec. 31, it reported a net ordinary income of $2,105,584, compared with $1,837,797 in the corresponding period in the previous fiscal year.

Earl Bunting, chairman of the board of the National Association of Manufacturers, yesterday attacked President Truman's message to Congress as "the greatest appeal ever made for more inflation, longer inflation and the kind of inflation that will hurt every citizen in the land."

h)0*0*0*iOSAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 7 (AP) -- A chartered twin-engined passenger plane crashed into a Savannah River marsh and burned today, killing seventeen of the twenty-six persons aboard. Nine others were injured.

Mary Goodfellow's spring millinery shown yesterday at the Sherry-Netherland Hotel featured pastel colors and "petticoat" frills. Beneath one bonnet brim taffeta was draped and tied in the manner of the old-fashioned bathing bandana.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 7 -- In an amendment filed today, the Northern States Power Company of Delaware brought its dissolution plan into line with findings of the Securities and Exchange Commission by providing for increased participation of common stockholders.

The City Board of Transportationh)0*0*0*iyesterday filed plans for the erection of a thirteen-story office building at 368-98 Jay Street, in Brooklyn. The plans were drawn by William E. Haugaard, architect, who estimated the cost at $6,930,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- The United States will take the initiative to bring about Big Five talks on moderating the use of the veto in the United Nations Security Council, it was reported today.h)0*0*0*iO

ROME, Jan. 7 -- The Communist party organ Unita and the Left Wing Socialist organ Avanti gave prominence today to demonstrations staged yesterday and the day before by soldiers in more than one Italian city against the Government's decision to keep them under arms until after the general election in April.
Many Eastern Orthodox Churches that follow the Julian calendar celebrated Christmas yesterday with masses in the morning. Services were also conducted on Christmas Eve.

The Greater New York Boy Scouts Council started yesterday a $1,000,000 finance campaign for 1948 at a "dawn patrol" breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The occasion also was marked by the induction of the 475,000th city Scout.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The United States Maritime Commission and Officials of fifteen of the country's leading oil companies were unable, at a meeting here today, to make any specific recommendations with regard to Mayor William O'Dwyer's request for twenty more tankers to supply fuel oil to the New York area.

Fuel oil deliveries by the twentynine members of the Westchesterh) 0*0*0*iAllied Trades Association who had stopped operations Tuesday because of a drivers' strike against one of their members will be in full swing this morning.

Washington, Jan. 7 -- President Truman's "cost-of-living" tax adjustment plan appeared today to be headed toward a Congressional pigeonhole even before its details had been spelled out. From the private and public comments of conservative Democrats as well as Republicans, it became immediately evident that the most Administration supporters could hope would be to use the proposal as a rallying point for opponents of the Knutson Bill to reduce individual income taxes $5,600,000,000.

MOSCOW, Jan. 7 -- The commercial director of Mostorg, Moscow's largest department store, criticized various Russian factories today for producing inferior products and demanded improvement in the quality and quantity of goods available to the Soviet consumer.h)0*0*0*iO
The stock market's reaction yesterday to President Truman's message to Congress was negative.

0*0*0*iOSTUART, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- One person was drowned and nine others rescued early today after their 45-foot fishing boat capsized on St. Lucie Inlet reef in heavy seas. The party included nine New Yorkers on a vacation and the boat captain.

Laszlo Szabo of Hungary, whose claim to first place was decided in the semi-final round, finished his schedule by defeating G. Abrahams of London in the international masters tournament sponsored by the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club, according to reports received from Hastings, England, yesterday.
LONDON, Thursday, Jan. 8 -British newspapers today greeted President Truman's message to Congress with appreciation mixed with sober caution.

ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Governor Dewey today made the charge that President Truman was responsible for touching off the wageprice-profit spiral which he said had wrecked inflation control "and brought about the present exorbitant scale of living costs."
WARSAW, Jan. 7 -- The Communist party of Poland, now firmly in the saddle, has put the brake on its two-year mass recruiting drive and has started a purge of "alien and superfluous" elements.
