WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman urged Congress today to grant every income taxpayer a $40-cost-of-living credit with an additional $40 credit for each of his dependents, and proposed the recapture of the consequent loss of $3,200,000,000 in Federal revenue by raising taxes on corporation profits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Top officers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations are strongly opposed to the third-party movement headed by Henry A. Wallace and will make their sentiments known later this month.

Discriminatory admissions practices against minority racial and religious groups by institutions of higher learning are criticized by a committee of the Association of American Colleges in a report that will be discussed at the association's annual meeting in Cincinnati next week.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 7 -- Because the Government organization known as South African Railways and Harbors has a long memory -- as well as a monopoly -- three-score American merchant seamen are stranded here indefinitely, or at least until the United States Consul General can obtain aid.
You and other newspapers publish the fact that Governor Dewey has proclaimed this week as "Universal Military Training Week."

" The Pursuit of Robert Emmet," by Helen Landreth, will be published by Whittlesey House on Jan. 30. It is a history of Ireland's early fight for freedom as well as a biography of the Irish patriot. Miss Landreth, author of "Dear Dark Head: An Intimate Story of Ireland," spent eight years in England and Ireland uncovering facts about Emmet's uprising.

The important part that fine fabrics play in good fashions was illustrated yesterday at the Hampshire House, where John Walther fabrics were presented in new spring models by various designers. Such highlights in the fabrich)0*0*0*istory for the coming season as iridescent gabardines, new weights and color combinations in tweeds and companion patterns in crisp worsteds contributed to the chic of the costumes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- Argument before the Interstate Commerce Commission today renewed the tug-of-war between the Atlantic Coast Line Railroad and the St. Joe Paper Company, acting for the Alfred I. du Pont estate, for control of the Florida East Coast Railway Company, which, under a reorganization plan approved by the ICC, is to be merged with the Atlantic Coast Line.

BOSTON, Jan. 7 -- Gov. Robert F. Bradford asked the Massachusetts Legislature today to grant citizens of Boston the authority to vote this year on adoption of the Plan E, the City Manager form of government, or some other new charter.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- Validation of New York City rent laws, which require that eviction proceedings be approved by the City Rent Commission before they can be started, was assured today.

Holcombe Ward, president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association since 1937, received the Sportsmandship Award for 1947 last night at the dinner of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood in the Hotel Commodore.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The text of the message presented to the Legislature today by Gov. Thomas E. Dewey follows:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -Class 1 railroads had an estimated net income of $44,000,000 in November, compared with $39,600,000 in November, 1946, the Association of American Railroads has reported.

" War nerves," adduced on several recent occasions as the basis of crimes by ex-service men, were cited yesterday in Felony Court to explain the alleged hold-up career of a woman, who said she was ah)0*0*0*iformer Wac lieutenant.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 7 -- With the books just closed on a year that saw tremendous increases in coal and iron movement over its Toledo trackage, Chesapeake Ohio Railroad officials announced today that the company would spend $2,000,000 on improvements at its Walbridge Yards and Presque Isle docks here.
As the 1947 appeal for the Neediest Cases draws to a close, a recapitulation shows that the 1946 Fund brought help to 1,436 cases.

Last fall the Safeway stores sold meat that was graded "U.S. Good" and, for as much as 10 cents less a pound, the same cuts of "U. S. Commercial." About two weeks ago they discontinued this practice. Why? Because there was practically no demand for the cheaper product.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week increased a further 2,830,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 94,099,000 barrels, compared with 91,269,000 a week earlier and 93,447,000 on Jan. 4, 1947.

The boys' apparel industry may be the first organized group to take industry-wide steps on a national basis to combat inflation under an integrated program carrying back from retail stores to textile mills, it was disclosed yesterday. Members of the trade revealed plans for the program following a price panel discussion heard by more than 1,000 executives during their annual convention at the Astor Hotel.
The number of trolley lines in the city continued to dwindle yesterday when the Third Avenue Transit Corporation announced it would replace with buses two more trolley lines in the Bronx.

The Board of Higher Education has been ordered by Lewis A. Wilson,h)0*0*0*iacting commissioner of the State Department of Education, to reinstate Francis J. Thompson, dismissed as an instructor of public speaking at City College in September, 1941, accused of being a member of the Communist party.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 7 New York City constitutes the greatest missionary challenge of any city or territory in the world, the Rev. Dr. Mark A. Dawber, executive secretary of the Home Missions Council of North America, asserted here today in a report to the organization's annual meeting.

The radio premiere of the short dramatic opera, "The Monastery," by the American composer, Paul Hastings Allen, will be offered by WHOM Sunday from 5 to 6 P.M. Mr. Allen will be guest conductor. The lyrics, in Italian, were written by S. di Giacomo.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 7 -The medical profession was called upon tonight by Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, to take constructive action to improve rural medical care while farm income was high and a friendly national administration had a definite interest in meeting the problem.

An underwriting group headedh)0*0*0*iby Lehman Brothers announced yesterday that it has completed the sale of $8,000,000 of thirtyyear 3 per cent bonds of the Dayton Power and Light Company for which the syndicate bid successfully on Tuesday. The bonds were marketed at 100 3/4, to yield about 2.96 per cent.

PARIS, Jan. 7 -- Precautions for the event of renewed outbreaks of social or political disorders throughout the country were discussed at today's Cabinet meeting, and a number of measures were approved with the aim of preventing further disturbances.

Retail tire stores here reported a new tire buying rush of consumers purchasing new low-pressure tires for replacement of older tires, based on the idea that the new lowpressure lines are underpriced in relation to other tire lines. Some sizes are now out of stock, they said, and other sizes are selling rapidly.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The Public Service Commission asked the state Legislature today for emergency legislation strengthening the commission's powers to prevent hardship during periods of shortages.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- With the St. Lawrence seaway, scheduled for priority action in the Senate, the opposition today attacked the proposed power project as a potential danger, rather than an asset, to the national defense.

Emetia (Joe Pledge) Polizio, the Astoria, Queens, gambler whose charges of police protection to bookmakers touched off last summer's investigation, was convicted of bookmaking last evening in Queens County Court, Long Island City.

Sidney Foster gave a piano recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The program he presented before an enthusiastic gathering was composed of Mozart's Variations in A. major (K. 137, Appendix); Beethoven's' "Pathetique" Sonata; a Chopin group; Prokofieff's Sonata, No. 7; Debussy's "La terrasse des audiences du clair deh)0*0*0*ilune" and "La vent dans la plaine," and Liszt's "Valse oubliee" and "Hungarian Rhapsody," No. 15.

BERLIN, Jan. 7 -- A violent attack on the military governments of the three Western zones was delivered last Sunday at a political convention in Erlangen, Bavaria, by Dr. Johannes Semmler, bizonal economics chief. Dr. Semmler accused the Allies of looting the German economy and, in effect, advocated a sit-down strike.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 7 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, Leftist leader, was expelled today from the Mexican Federation of Labor [CTM], which he founded in 1936. Three other leaders also were ousted during a stormy session of the federation's national council.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 7 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General ofh)0*0*0*ithe United Nations, has sounded out a number of smaller countries over the last ten days on the question of whether they would be willing to send troops to Palestine if more serious fighting developed over the partition plan, it was learned tonight.

PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 7 Yearend pledges of more than $400,000 to the Sesquicentennial Fund of Bowdoin College, by all members of the governing boards, has secured a conditional gift of $100,000 offered by Harvey Dow Gibson, president of the Manufacturersh) 0*0*0*iTrust Company of New York City, according to an announcement made today by Maj. Gen. Wallace C. Philoon (retired), general chairman of the fund.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads said today that notwithstanding the post-war car shortage the railroads set a new record for moving coal in 1947.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 7 (AP) Eight former Navy athletes are here to review the Naval Academy's athletic policy, and reports indicate that most of their attention will be devoted to football.

PRAGUE, Jan. 7 -- The Communists and Left Wing Socialists today succeeded in making a fairly serious breach in the compromise between the state and private enterprise principles that were the foundation of the present Czechoslovak economy and society.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Snapping loose from an extended losing streak, Bordeaux carried the Knollwood Stable's blue and silver racing livery to a length-and-a-half triumph in the Astatula Purse, chief offering witnessed by 10,922 fans at Gulfstream Park today.

Delegates and officials to the fortysecond annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association and affiliated bodies waded through a mass of detail at the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. Much was accomplished of weighty consequence to the parties concerned; little evolved of great interest to the general public.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 7 -- Indian Army mobile patrols have encountered large bands of raiders that entered Jammu Province of the embattled State of Kashmir from the direction of the Sialkot District of Pakistan, Indian military sources declared tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- Buyer attendance at the winter international home furnishings market in the American Furniture and Merchandise Marts dropped sharply here today compared with the first two days. Many buyers, who placed all orders possible in view of inventories, prices and pre-market commitments on Monday and yesterday, left town to attend the Grand Rapids market or to return home.

CAMP CARSON, Colo, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Five enlisted men and two officers of the Thirty-eighth Regimentalh) 0*0*0*iCombat ski team of the Second Division will represent the United States Army in the Winter Olympic Games. They will leave tomorrow night for Westover Field, Mass., then fly to St. Moritz.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- United States diplomatic representatives have orally communicated to the Governments of Bulgaria and Yugoslavia a warning against recognition of the Communist regime of Gen. Markos Vafiades in northern Greece, the State Department said today.

Gar Wood Jr. of Tulsa, Okla., son of the more famous speedboat racing fox of Detroit, yesterday gave a demonstration of how the mechanical age of today differs from the early eons of boating when Polynesian aborigines paddled hollowed-out tree trunks.
TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Two seeded entrants were knocked out of the Dixie tennis tournament today, Sidney Schwartz falling before Enrique Buse and Tom Burke being upset by Steve Colson.
ALBANY, Jan. 7 -- The major recommendations made by Governor Dewey in his annual message to the Legislature were:

Our mid-Manhattan friend who boasts that he enjoys the freedom of the city no less because it has not been conferred upon him in a formal ceremony at the City Hall has been listening to what the denizens of the outlying boroughs and the suburbs have to say about the conditions of life which have been theirs since the Great Snow fell.

A six-hour session at the Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday ended with the announcement that State Athletic Commission contracts binding Joe Louis to defend his world heavyweight title at the Yankee Stadium in June likely would be signed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 31:

CHICAGO, Jan. 7 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board enlarged his complaint against the International Typographical Union, AFL, today to cover the union's demand for a sixty-day cancellation clause in its contracts with newspaper publishers.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 7 -- A bill canceling the mandates of Communists holding elective offices was passed tonight by the Chamber of Deputies, 181 votes to 74, after a tumultuous session.

READING, Pa., Jan. 7 (AP) -- A stainless steel with high acid resisting qualities and available in wrought forms is the newest of the super alloys to come from metallurgy's laboratories and rolling mills.

LONDON, Jan. 7 -- The gravity of Britain's dollar position and the inevitability of a fall in her standard of living unless United States help was forthcoming were stressed by Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, at a press conference today.
About thirty tons of TNT were found yesterday by the Navy in ten of the seventy-seven Palestineconsigned cases that were seized Saturday as they were being baded on a ship in Jersey City.

A new duo-piano team made its New York concert debut last night when Arthur Ferrante and Louis Teicher gave a program at Town Hall. They were greeted by an audience of 1,400, for the young men have already scored a success playing over the radio.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 -- President Truman today reminded a Congress yet to be sold on theh)0*0*0*imerits of his European Recovery Program that "this vital measure of our foreign policy" required prompt action and a $6,800,000,000 appropriation if operations were to begin on schedule on April 1.
Cotton futures on the New Yorkh) 0*0*0*iCotton Exchange recovered all their early losses yesterday, and closed at about the best levels of the day, 23 to 44 points net higher.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 7 (AP) -- Ewell Blackwell, whose whiplike arm made him the best right-hand pitcher in baseball last year, today signed a contract with the Reds for 1948.

City Councilman S. Samuel Di Falco introduced at yesterday's Council session a resolution calling for a 10 P.M. curfew for unchaperoned teen-agers in the theatre areas of the city. The resolution was referred to the committee on city affairs.

The Welfare Council of Newh)0*0*0*iYork City has suggested to the State Board of Social Welfare that the board "clarify its position concerning the housing of relief clients," it was made known yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 7 -- In his annual report to Yale alumni for the academic year 1946-47, President Charles Seymour announced today that a University Council of twenty-five alumni from all parts of the country was being established to develop plans for constant improvement of the academic and administrative affairs of the university.

As William J. Powell, Sanitation Commissioner, continued his efforts yesterday to clear all highways in the city, Controller Lazarus Joseph approved the first temporary snow removal payroll, amounting to $1,614,152. Previously the Board of Estimate had appropriated $3,000,000, but the cost for the Dec. 26 snowstorm is expected to reach $7,000,000.

An issue of $1,500,000 of bonds of South San Francisco unified school district, San Mateo County, Calif., will be offered publicly today by a banking group headed by Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association. The bonds, bearing interest of 2 3/4 per cent and 3 per cent, will be datedh)0*0*0*iJan. 1, 1948, and will become due on each Jan. 1 from 1954 through 1973.

TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 8 (AP) -Decks of the sinking Russian ship Dvina were awash, but efforts of two rescue ships to remove her 780 passengers had thus far been futile, an American airman radioed from the scene off northeast Japan early today.

To write a three-act opera is no mean accomplishment; to get it produced is a feat, indeed. Anders Emile, Norwegian-born composer, made it on both counts when his "King Herald," which has a librettoh) 0*0*0*iby Pearl Cleveland Wilson, had its premiere in the Hunter College Playhouse last night.
A committee was formed yesterday to work for a reduction in tolls charged for motor travel between New York and New Jersey.

Restrictions have been placed by the Cuban Government on relations between foreign companies and their agents in Cuba, the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce announced yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 7 -Lucille Ball announced today through a press representative that she had signed a seven-year contract with Columbia calling for her to appear in one picture annually for the studio. Miss Ball's first vehicle under the new deal, according to her spokesman, will be "Pink Lady," a comedy which Virginia Van Upp has written and will produce at Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -- In connection with the listing of traders in commodities today officials said that a Des Moines company in which former Vice President Henry A. Wallace has a financial interest was among traders in the corn market on April 30, 1946.

Veteran airline mechanics, who suspected the abilities of the men who held forged Civil Aeronautics Administration certificates, turned in the first information that led on Tuesday to the arrest by the Federal Bureau of Investigation of the alleged perpetrator of the forgeries and a half dozen of his dupes.

Drafts of two bills to create a Board of Traffic Control and a Parking Authority were approved yesterday by the executive board of the Traffic Action Committee at a meeting at the Women's City Club, Hotel New Weston. Walter D. Binger, chairman, will present the bills next week to the entire committee.
Following is the text of President Truman's state of the Union message to Congress yesterday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

A strong campaign abroad to combat Russia's anti-United States propaganda -- possibly under sponsorship of the Advertising Council --- was urged yesterday by A. O. Buckingham, vice president of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., and a director of the Advertising Council.

In the treatment of child victims of rheumatic heart disease it is as important for the physician to listen to the worries of the mother as it is for him to listen to the child's heart, it was emphasized last night at the quarterly scientific session of the New Yorkh)0*0*0*iHeart Association by Dr. Carl Binger, associate professor of clinical psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Jan. 7 (AP) -- Members of four building trades unions of the American Federation of Labor today ended a five-day-old walkout that had slowed work on projects valued at about $30,000,000.

PARIS, Jan. 7 (UP) -- The nine man United States speed skating team, the fifteen-man bobsled team and the contingents of the figureskating squad, beaming with confidence, left Paris today for St. Moritz, Switzerland, and the winter Olympic Games.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

HAVANA, Jan. 7 -- Donald D. Kennedy of the United States delegation told the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today that the United States did not intend to use "predatory export subsidies" on agricultural products but objected to having its subsidies subjected to penalties not imposed on other types that "may be just as harmful.

TOKYO, Jan. 7 -- The saner section of Japanese thought has apparently begun to crystallize around the idea that a dictated peace is the best that the nation can expect. This is regardless of the outcome of present negotiations among the Allied powers regarding means of formulating the treaty's ultimate provisions.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 7 -- The MinisterPresidents of eight German states in the United States and British zones, and the chief officials of the Bizonal Economic Council were asked by the United States and British Military Governments today to form an economic government consisting of a two-house legislature, a nine-man supreme court and an executive who would choose a six-man Cabinet.
Eggless Thursday will get a premature burial today under an avalanche of fried, poached and boiled eggs, hotel and restaurant men let it be known yesterday.
Twenty-two personal commendations for excellent police duty were presented yesterday by Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander at police headquarters.

Appointment of Hazel E. Tice to the new position of chief clerk of the New York State Bankers Association has been approved by that group's council of administration, it has been announced. Miss Tice has been with the organization since January, 1940.

HERBERT ORRIN CRISLER of the University of Michigan will be formally installed as the "Coach of the Year" at The World Telegram party tonight. But perhaps that's a misstatement. Fritz Crisler, it would seem, personally attended to that bit of business in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day, when his juggernaut whacked the bewhatsis out of Southern California by the tidy little count of 49 to 0.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 7 -- Eighteen persons were killed and forty-one wounded this afternoon in a double bombing here, carried out by five members of Irgun Zvai Leumi. The attackers were driving a stolen police armored car and at least one of them was disguised as a policeman.

Ben Jonson's "Volpone" will be revived tonight at the City Center, the civic playhouse, as the first of three productions by the newly established New York City Theatre Company. The occasion will mark the final execution of a long-cherished plan by the City Center to place beside the opera, symphony and ballet companies its own resident troupe.
New York University vs. Duke and West Virginia vs. Manhattan are the pairings in tonight's basketball double-header in Madison Square Garden. Play will start at 8 o'clock.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- Three of the Hollywood figures charged with contempt of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee and subsequently laid off by their respective studios, today filed damage suits against the studios aggregating more than $3,000,000.

The newly mounted "Ring" of the matinee subscription series began yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House: new scenery by Lee Simonson; stage direction, Herbert Graf; musical direction, Fritz Stedry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 (AP) -Democratic headquarters is heading into the Presidential campaign with $315,367 in its treasury, while the Republicans report that they came through 1947 with contributions of $28,575 above expenses.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 7 -- Eighteen persons were killed and forty-one wounded this afternoon in a double bombing here, carried out by five members of Irgun Zvai Leumi. The attackers were driving a stolen police armored car and at least one of them was disguised as a policeman.

Ben Jonson's "Volpone" will be revived tonight at the City Center, the civic playhouse, as the first of three productions by the newly established New York City Theatre Company. The occasion will mark the final execution of a long-cherished plan by the City Center to place beside the opera, symphony and ballet companies its own resident troupe.
New York University vs. Duke and West Virginia vs. Manhattan are the pairings in tonight's basketball double-header in Madison Square Garden. Play will start at 8 o'clock.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 7 -- Three of the Hollywood figures charged with contempt of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee and subsequently laid off by their respective studios, today filed damage suits against the studios aggregating more than $3,000,000.

The newly mounted "Ring" of the matinee subscription series began yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House: new scenery by Lee Simonson; stage direction, Herbert Graf; musical direction, Fritz Stedry.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Without ceremony Republicans buried President Truman's cost-of-living tax adjustment plan today and shaped plans for fashioning a vetoproof bill of their own.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California asserted today that deficit financing must be ended, the national debt reduced and Government expenditures curtailed in conjunction with any move toward tax reduction.

KINGSTON, N.J. Jan. 8 -- There are all kinds of pheasant shooting, and according to the official log of the Feather Duster's Club the members who participated today in the second field expedition of the club "encountered every kind, with obstacles."

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The National Council of Farmer Cooperatives today adopted a resolution calling on both major political parties to reaffirm their platform pledges supporting the farmer cooperative movement, and denouncing persons in either party who in violation of these pledges have displayed hostility to cooperatives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Congress, still reacting sharply and with pronounce partisanship to the legislative recommendations made by President Truman yesterday, settled down to work today.

A glowing picture meets the eye as one turns into the long hall where the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art is holding its exhibition of costumes of the Eastern world, entitled "From Casablanca to Calcutta." The exhibit, which was previewed last night, will open today and continue through April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that refusal by the United States to help rebuild Europe's economy would plunge the whole Continent into "the dictatorshiph) 0*0*0*iof police states" and reduce this land of the free to a "regulated and controlled armed camp."

Msgr. Patrick A. O'Boyle, formerh)executive director of War Relief Services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, will be consecrated as the first Archbishop of Washington, D. C., at 10 A.M., next Wednesday at St. Patrick's Cathedral, Fifth Avenue and Fiftieth Street, here.

The State of New Jersey sold yesterday $15,000,000 of veterans' emergency housing bonds maturing from 1951 to 1962 to a syndicate of banking houses headed by Lehman Brothers at an interest cost of 1.6764 per cent. Reoffered to investors at prices to yield from 1.05 per cent to about 1.78 per cent, the offering of bonds was oversubscribed within three hours, the syndicate reported.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Reaction to the Marshall Aid Plan in the stock markets here today showed that speculators were not taking too much for granted. An additional factor, was the grim warning by Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Stafford Cripps that Britain is faced with intense trading difficulties.

Directors of Universal Pictures Company, Inc., yesterday authorized the payment on Jan. 30 of a 25-cent dividend. Shareholders had received 50 cents quarterly for several years. Explaining the reduction, the company said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Sharp increases in farm products and foods were mainly responsible for the increase of 0.9 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Jan. 3, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.
Prince Peter of Greece said yesterday that he hoped complete freedom of expression would be permitted in his country when the present "emergency" ends.
ATHENS, Jan. 8 -- Maj. Gen. William G. Livesay, chief of the military group of the United States Mission for Aid to Greece, told American correspondents here today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- An agreement providing for a $300,000,000 loan to Canada by the Export-Import Bank was signed today by Douglas C. Abbott, Canadian Finance Minister, and William McC. Martin Jr., chairman of the board of the bank.

Although declining for the second consecutive time, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System fell only $4,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. According to the data released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the reduction sent the new total of such loans outstanding to $5,332,000,000.

The grand sport that has prevailed the past fortnight in the North Country, extending from the Pennsylvania Poconos to the Laurentians of eastern Canada, continues with the result that ski enthusiasts will be out in greater number than ever cutting tracks starting this afternoon.

A shipment of almost 50,000 pounds of explosives known as M-3 was uncovered yesterday when operatives of the Federal Bureau of Investigation closed in on a well-organized group in this country that, officials assert, has been supplying the sinews of war for the undeclared battle of Palestine.

Dr. John C. Whitehorn, director of the Department of Psychiatry at Johns Hopkins University, and one of the country's foremost psychiatrists, chided the psychiatric profession last night or paying too little attention to the good points of patients and concentrating, instead, on picking the patients to pieces.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Continuing strong buyer resistance to overpriced low-end case goods led today to the partial breakdown of the quota distribution system at the Winter International Homefurnishings Market here. The breakdown, geographical in character, extended to several other types of low-end furniture also overpriced.

That number is. fixed'as the maximum, but ~nundisclosed number over thatround figure will be accepted asusual.

OTTUMUA, Iowa, Jan. 8 (AP) - John Morrell Co., meat packers, reported today a net income of $2,889,017, equal to $3.61 a share of common stock, in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 1. In the previous year net income was $2,104,398 or $2.63 a common share.

Today's events: "Der Rosenkavalier," Metropolitan Opera House, 8 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, 2:30; Jacques Abram, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:20; The English Duo (Viola Morris, soprano, and Victoria Anderson, contralto), Town Hall, 8:30; Bernice Kamsler, folk songs, Times Hall, 8:30; Juilliard Training Orchestra, Juilliard Concert Hall, 8:30; "King Harald," Hunter College Playhouse, 8:30.

Olle Tandberg, Sweden's hope for heavyweight honors, will make hid American debut as a professional when he faces Joey Maxim, Cleveland battler, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Net profit of Dresser Industries, Inc., for the fiscal year ended with October reached a new high of $4,439,189, equal to $3.85 a share on the 1,095,137 shares of common stock outstanding, according to the annual report of H. N. Mallon, president, issued for publication today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- Grain marketsh)0*0*0*iclosed higher on the Board of Trade today after a midday break had carried wheat off about 2 cents a bushel from Wednesday's finish. Closing trades on wheat were about the top with May leading the upturn, final sales being 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents higher.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- full-scale drive for state legislation barring the employment in public office of members of the Communist party and members of other "subversive" organizations was foreshadowed here today. With the legislative session only two days old, four bills have already been introduced to require loyalty oaths and to withhold funds from schools where anti-Democratic doctrines are taught.

Bohuslav Martinu's Third Symphony, played by the PhilharmonicSymphony Society under the direction of Charles Munch lasth)0*0*0*inight in Carnegie Hall, was designated on the program as being presented for the "first time by the society."

The Cruising Club of America, an organization of deep-water sailing men, set the Newport-toBermuda ocean race to begin on June 19, awarded its Blue Water Medal to an Argentine, Ernesto Uriburu of his country's diplomatic corps, and re-elected Thorvald S. Ross of Manchester, Mass., as commodore at its annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club last night.

Hens laid a record number of eggs yesterday to celebrate the lifting of the ban on eggless Thursday at the seventeenth annual New York Poultry Exposition at the Ninth Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.

A second indictment, following one last December in which a head bookkeeper for the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, was accused of swindling the bank of almost $50,000, resulted yesterday in the arraignment in General Sessions of three persons alleged to have reaped most of the gain from the fraudulent transactions.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The meeting of the International Olympic Committee just prior to the winter games may serve as "a court of last resort" in the ice hockey dispute which has threatened to provoke an American boycott of theh) 0*0*0*igames.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today, which will mark the end of this series:

CLEVELAND, Jan. 8 -- Clashes in the RH factor of their blood no longer make it impossible for parents to have two or more normal children, doctors attending the mid-winter meeting of the American Medical Association were told at the final sessions today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 - Gen. George C. Marshall finished his first year as Secretary of State today, looking even more relaxed and self-possessed than he did when he returned from China.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- Commenting on a Swiss newspaper report of Premier Stalin's death, Vladimir Pavlov, counselor of the Soviet Embassy in London and former interpreter for the Russian Premier, declared today:

HOBOKEN, N.J., Jan. 8 -- A general alarm was turned in this evening for a fire that swept the top floor of a four-story loft building at 1007 to 1011 Grand Street here, about six blocks from the Weehawken entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- Pope Pius XII, said today that the Catholic church could give its most efficient contribution to the defense of Christian civilization against what he indicated was the current antiChristian offensive only if three conditions were met by the lay governments.

Board of Education by-laws stipulate that when a teacher in New York City's schools is not present for classroom duty an amount equal to the pay of a substitute teacher shall be deducted from his salary check. If the absence is because of illness, presentation afterward of a doctor's certificate will restore the deducted pay.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- The mathematical wizards of the United Nations have sat down and figured out just what European cities will have to supply to bid for the 1948 session of the General Assembly -- everything from 11,500 chairs to eating facilities for 300 workers assigned to the night shift.

The great debate on the European Recovery Program got its real start yesterday when Secretary Marshall, looking across the table at the formidableh)0*0*0*iarray of talent and prestige which confronted him, bluntly told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee: "Either undertake to meet the requirements of this problem or don't undertake it at all."

The five-story store and loft building at 262 Fifth Avenue, betweenh) 0*0*0*iTwenty-eighth and Twentyninth Streets, was sold by David S. Meister, operator, to the Morhym Realty Corporation for cash over mortgages amounting to $60,000 in a transaction reported yesterday by the Charmill Realty Company, brokers.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- Fresh fuel was added today to the anti-American fury of the extreme Left Wing press by the statement attributed to Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, who quoted as saying in San Francisco that the United States was planning to equip its fleet in the Mediterranean to act as a floating base for planes that would, in case of need, drop atomic bombs.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- Governor Dewey has appointed a committee of three to manage his preconvention campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination, virtually destroying the threadbare fiction that he is not a candidate, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Bendix Aviation Corporation, Detroit, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering 399.990 shares of $5 par value common stock. The shares are being sold by the General Motors Corporation and Bendix Aviation will receive no part of the proceeds.

THERE has been considerable boxing news in the papers for the last week but most of it has been about Joe Louis and Joe Walcott. Hence tonight's fight at the Garden between Olle Tandberg of Sweden and Joey Maxim of Cleveland has developed into one of the better kept secrets of the trade. Perhaps it even should stay that way.

CHICAGO, Jan. -- 8 The average industrial worker in England produces only about one-third as much as the average American, it was said here today by William J. Kelly, president of the Machinery and Allied Products Institute.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Premier Marshal Tito dismissed three cabinet ministers today and gave four others new posts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Republican Congress will go ahead with its foreign and domestic program with little regard for the recommendations President Truman made yesterday in his message on the state of the Union, it was predicted tonight by Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, chairman of the majority policy committee of the Senate.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- The urgency of implementing United States aid to Europe, as provided both in the interim act of Congress and the Marshall Plan is seen in the fact that the Communists and de Gaullists in France appear convinced that this country faces a serious collapse late this winter or in the coming spring.

After an early sell-off the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday and closed steady, 3 to 22 points net higher. Most strength was shown in the March and May positions.

A diversity of themes wa brought together in the spring an summer showing of Braagaar seen yesterday at 17 West Fifty seventh Street. This designer preference for scarf drapes and profile line was accentuated.

The Porto Rico Line's Borinquen yesterday became the thirtieth unit of the American Merchant Marine to receive the Naval Reserve Pennant in a ceremony aboard the vessel at her dock, Pier 92, North River. Twentytwo of the total thus honored were from the Third Naval District.

Four four-story apartment houses occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 730-36 Eleventh Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-second Street, were sold by the Beth Realty Corporation to William J. Fitzgerald, investment They contain seven stores and thirty-two apartments and were sold for cash over a mortgage of $22,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota, still withholding a final decision on whether he will challenge Senator Robert A. Taft in the Ohio Presidential primary, will send a crew of workers into the state next week to line up a slate of delegates pledged to him.

You are literally in clover if you get to see Sally Victor's new spring and summer millinery collection. In clover because it is good, in clover because the fourcornered shape of the good-luck symbol is used in hats large and small. She presented her collection yesterday in her showroom at 18 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Attorneys for the United Steel Workers Union, CIO, and two large steel companies today pleaded with the National Labor Relations Board to refrain from "carving" small craft units out of the plant-wide industrial units.

The long drawn-out negotiations between American financial interestsh) 0*0*0*iheaded by the National City Bank and representatives of the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers to make available $60,000,000 for the purchase of cotton for Japanese textile mills have now moved into a final stage, it was learned yesterday.

A combined investigation by members of the rackets bureau of the District Attorney's office and the Police Department safe and loft squad has uncovered "an organized hijacking combination operating on a large scale," Assistant District Attorney Vincent G. O'Connor declared yesterday in Felony Court at the arraignment of two alleged criminal receivers.

ROME, Jan. 8 -- The Sindacati Unici, which are pro-Yugoslav Communist-controlled labor unions, called a general strike in Trieste this morning in protest against the arrest last Sunday by the BritishAmerican military authorities of former Yugoslav Partisans accused of having participated in an illegal demonstration.

WORCESTER, Mass., Jan. 8 (AP) -- Selection of Bullet Bill Osmanski as head football coach at Holy Cross for "a considerable number of years" was announced today by the Very Rev. William J. Healy, S.J., college president.

Although the Japanese are falling short of a motor car and truck production goal of 300,000 vehicles in the next four years. American exporters of vehicles and parts cannot enter that market because of lack of dollars and failure of occupying authorities to establish an exchange rate, it was pointed out yesterday by W. A. Rawmsley of Muller Phipps Asia, Ltd.

Those who had faith in prolonging the engagement of "Music in My Heart" deserve the highest commendation. After a week's suspension the Tchaikovsky musical will reopen Sunday afternoon at the Adelphi. This is official now.

In anticipation of favorable action by the membership on the "sanity code" constitutional revisions that will be voted on tomorrow, the executive committee of the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday drafted executive regulations for enforcing the provisions against athletic scholarships and recruiting.
More confusion was added to the lot of the already snow-bewildered motorist by changes in city traffic regulations reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Owner Fred L. Mandel Jr. of the Detroit Lions made a key move today that suggested he might retain his National Football League holdings in Detroit, sought for the last month by a seven-man syndicate incorporated as the Detroit Football Company.

" Springtime British-madeh)0*0*0*imusical, starring Carol Raye and Peter Graves, will have its premiere on Monday at the Skouras Academy of Music in Manhattan and at the Crotona and Park Plaza in the Bronx, it was announced by Skouras Theatres yesterday.

A Bronx woman real estate operator was ordered yesterday to serve a ten-day sentence in the Women's House of Detention as the result of repeated failure on her part to furnish heat in a threefamily house in the Bronx of which she is co-owner.

Snowmen and animals of every size and shape will dot the Mall at Central Park Sunday when boys and girls gather for a snow sculpture contest at 10 A.M. The contest will be staged by groups; children under 12, boys and girls 12 to 17, and others over seventeen.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 8 -- A more effective handling of the problems of inflation and price control in China is being achieved through the application of the new economic regulations that went into force last month.

On the theory that it is never too early to begin the subject of social studies, the Board of Education is testing concepts of democratic living among New York public school children in the kindergarten to Grade 2 levels.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 8 -Arriving in the State Capital today from a series of meetings in Philadelphia yesterday, Harold E. Stassen made a bid for support from Pennsylvania's Republican leaders.

If trucks and cars could wear bells it would not be so bad. A generation ago the sound of bells was an integral part of the cold months. There were, of course, the year-round bells. Many farms had a bell on a cedar post in the yard or hanging from a framework in the ell or woodshed.

PEIPING, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Chinese Communists, after a short lull in their midwinter offensive, have resumed attacks twenty to twenty-h) 0*0*0*ifive miles north, west and south of Mukden, Nationalist dispatches reported today from Manchuria.
More than 120 educators and students met yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Hotel at a luncheon in honor of Dr. Richard Courant, chairman of the New York University Department of Mathematics.
Arthur C. Link has been appointed manager of Organization Planning, a new division of the Western Electric Company, effective Feb. 1.

George Ricci, 'cellist, who had been heard in this city previously as soloist with orchestras, gave his first local recital last night at Town Hall. For his offerings he had chosen the Mozart-Piatigorsky Sonatina in A major, Brahms' Sonata in E minor, Tchaikovsky's "Variations on a Rococo Theme," Reger's unaccompanied Suite in G major, and a group of shorter pieces by Frescobaldi, Wieniawski, Shulman and Popper.

R. S. Rothschild of the Downtown A.C., metropolitan champion, scored in his opening-round match in the New York State squash racquets championship last night, defeating a visiting British player, Capt. G. O. Jamieson of the Rockaway Hunt Club, 15 -- 10, 17 -- 15, 11 -- 15, 15 -- 10.

The Rockefeller Foundation has awarded $31,500 to Columbia University to continue an investigation started in 1945 "of the interaction of hereditary and environmental factors in relation to problems of age," Dr. Willard C. Rappleye, Dean of Columbia's Faculty of Medicine, announced yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- German officials of the bizonal area accepted today the United States and British offerh)0*0*0*ito assume the responsibility for forming a new bizonal economic government, which will be officially titled the Bizonal Economic Administration.

The Richard P. Strong palladium medal for distinguished service to tropical medicine was presented last night to Dr. Neil P. Macphail, medical superintendent of the United Fruit Company at Quirigua, Guatemala, from 1908 to 1948.

TOKYO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Improving weather off the east coast of Hokkaido led American military authorities tonight to express belief that the waterlogged Russian ship Dvina might yet reach safety with her 780 passengers.

As matters stand at the moment, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and the four networks are not expected to resume their negotiations until the last week of this month. The union leader has to be in court in Chicago on Jan. 14 to hear the decision in his trial under the Lea Act.

A recent news item indicated that the advent of the electronic microscope has permitted observation not only of bacteria but also of viruses which heretofore have been invisible even to the most skilled expert. The viruses have been seen to surround the bacteria, pierce them, arrange themselves in criss-cross pattern inside them, and then cause them to "explode" or burst open.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- In a special message to the legislature, Governor Dewey today requested immediate action on a bill making a $26,220,250 deficiency appropriation to cover increases in relief payments and institutional costs occasioned by rising prices.

Price declines have occurred on a few items in grocery stores since a week ago, but not to a degree that will make any difference in the amount of money that must be spent for this week-end's food. A general increase in the tariffs of most meats and poultry is the big handicap in saving pennies.
The following is the text of the radio speech by Senator Robert A. Taft, last night, replying to the message of President Truman, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Taking his ease at an old chophouse in midtown Manhattan, which has changed little from what it was when he first knew it, a New Yorker of ingrained gastronomic adventurousness fell to musing recently on the large number of eating-anddrinking places that have vanished, leaving no trace, since the beginning, many years ago, of his exhaustive local investigations in the alluring realm of dining-away-from-home.

DUBLIN, Jan. 8 -- Irish newspapers today editorially, hailed the Marshall Plan allocations for this country with praise for the United States' generous gesture. But they temper their comment with a warning to the Irish people that receipt of such help must be repaid by hard work to expand Ireland's agricultural output as a positive contribution to European recovery.

A highly profitable scheme for counterfeiting domestic and foreign postage stamps so as to increase their value to philatelists was uncovered yesterday by inspectors of the Post Office Department and the Auto and Forgery Squad of the Police Department.

It seems to me that the City Fathers may well learn one striking and significant lesson from New York's experience with the recent record snowfall. The temporary emergency exclusion of private automobiles from the central sections of the city has proven, in practice, under very unfavorable conditions, a simple, obvious and entirely adequate solution to theh)0*0*0*icity's critical problem of traffic congestion.

Although general operating expenses of the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company are likely to be higher this year than in 1947, there is a prospect that higher loan income may offset this increase, William S. Gray Jr., the bank's president, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday.

Dr. Stephen B. L. Penrose Jr., special adviser on budgetary matters in the office of the Secretary of National Defense, will succeed Dr. Bayard Dodge as president of the American University of Beirut, Lebanon. Harold B. Hoskins, president of the board of trustees, announced yesterday at the offices of the Near East College Association, 46 Cedar Street.
The Chase National Bank is planning one of its largest branchesh)0*0*0*iat Fifty-seventh Street and Madison Avenue, it became known last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The Schenley Distillers Corporation New York City, filed today two suits in United States District Court here to enjoin Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson from carrying out the grand-allocation program to distillers under the Taft anti-inflation act.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 8 (AP) -The adverse balance of trade with the United States, which indicates the amount by which Canada is short of U.S. dollars in purchases from her southern neighbor, took another great leap forward during November and now appears to have shot over the $900,000,000 mark for 1947.

Backed by a $100,000 research program now being started by the Battelle Memorial Institute, Columbus, Ohio, a three-year project of research and development in the steel container field was undertaken yesterday, it was revealed by L. B. Keplinger, president of the Steel Shipping Container Institute, following an industry research conference at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, yesterday issued a short prepared statement answering The Campus, C.C.N.Y. undergraduate weekly, which had declared editorially on Wednesday that Madison Square Garden was an "unwholesome influence" on intercollegiate basketball and had asked that the Beaver team cease play there as soon as contractual obligations were completed.

Two British statesmen, representing opposing political beliefs, painted an optimistic picture of conditions in England after arriving here yesterday from Southampton on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth. The ship docked at 8:45 A.M. at Pier 90, North River, with 1,643 passengers after having been away from this port for two months while undergoing routine repairs.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 8 (AP) - There are no immediate dangers of war with the Soviet Union, but there are "dangers of war if you and I do not rise to the occasion that confronts us," Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman declared tonight in a plea for support of the Marshall Plan.

Countering demands of garage workers for a 25 per cent wage increase, operators of 900 Manhattan and Bronx garages asked yesterday that the workers' union assume financial responsibility for damage caused to customers' cars by its members.

PARIS, Jan. 8 (Reuters) -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine is now asking governments to assist them as far as possible in obtaining arms for self-defense in Palestine, Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the Agency's United States section and of the American Zionist Emergency Council, said here tonight.

Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced yesterday the allocation of $1,188,785 in grants for polio research and training projects in universities andh)0*0*0*ihospitals throughout the United States and Canada.

Since many people at the City Center were laughing and applauding last evening, the horseplay "Volpone" now visible there must have its points. The two chiefh)0*0*0*ipoints are Jose Ferrer and Richard Whorf, who do not like underplaying.

Seemingly working on the theory that a contract a day will keep the holdouts away, the Yankees yesterday bobbed up with another signer, their fourth in as many days. He was, to repeat Manager Bucky Harris' own popular toast which he sang right up to the close of the world series: "Gentlemen -- Joe Page!"

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 8 -- In quick reaction to an almost plaintive German reminder that the food situation was critical and strikes spreading throughout the Ruhr, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, warned German leaders today they would do better to improve the job of raising their own food and distributing it equally.

Loans and investments under current conditions "must be made cautiously, and conservatively," Harvey D. Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, states in his annual report, now being mailed to stockholders in advance of their annual meeting on next Wednesday.

Three group shows on view this week include work of American, Dutch and British old masters from three centuries, and a selection of work by modern print makers offer a more than ordinary appeal to gallery goers and include first-rate works by Washington Allston and John Constable.

BOSTON, Jan. 8 -- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union purchased from the Massachusetts General Hospital today an eight-story building on Harrison Avenue, in the heart of the garment district. Officials of the union said the structure would house a health center and a frequencymodulation radio station.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today the quantities of sugar which various domestic, offshore and foreign producing areas will be allowed to supply the United States this year under a renewed quota system.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 8 -James H. R. Cromwell, former United States Minister to Canada, obtained an absolute decree of divorce today from the former Doris Duke, now Mrs. Porfirio Rubirosa, whose Nevada divorce from Mr. Cromwell in 1943 was never recognized by the New Jersey Chancery Court.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Sydney G. Dobson, president of the Royal Bank of Canada, the Dominion's largest bank, said today Canada's present dollar problem contains "an element of danger to the stability of the United States."

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Ministry of Health's recent announcement of the conditions and pay for medical practitioners under the National Health Service brought reiteration today from the powerful British Medical Association that the plan should be rejected by doctors.

Governor Dewey's message to the Legislature was assailed yesterday by the Teachers Union, CIO, as expounding economy "at the expense of the school children, the poor, the indigent, the aged and the ill." The Teachers Guild, AFL, said the message constituted "a clear bid for the Presidential nomination."

There is no immediate prospect of ending the embargo by the American motion-picture industry on film shipments to England since preliminary negotiations toward a readjustment of the 75 per cent tax imposed by Britain last August have met with failure, it was announced yesterday by Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Export Association.

LONDON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- High diplomatic authorities said here today that they believed Europe's "Red belt" states were preparing to establish relations with Markos Vafiades' Communist Greek "state" and declared that Britain and the United States were broadly agreed upon their policy in that eventuality.

A profit for its first year in the air terminal field and prospects for a sound future as it expands into bus terminals, and possibly into harbor and pier development, were reported yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, chairman, to the annual meeting of the Commissioners of the Port of New York Authority.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 8--Sources close to the Lebanese and Syrian Governments said today that the Syrian Parliament was likely to ratify an agreement giving the American Trans-Arabian Pipeline Company the right to lay pipe through Syria.

Four copper plates from which naval charts of the American coast were printed for the British Navy during the Revolutionary War were presented yesterday to the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, by the British Admiralty.
Somewhere in the files of the United Nations at Lake Success lies a convention on genocide -- the extermination of entire human groups by governments, through physical, biological, or cultural means.
A woman who was in the hospital at the start of this year's Hundred Neediest Cases Fund sent yesterday her gift of $25 to the appeal. She wrote from Canada:
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 8 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea arrived in this capital at 6 o'clock tonight by plane from Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- The text of Secretary Marshall's testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today in support of the Administration's European Recovery Program follows:

Increased facilities for handling adoptions and legislation to end irregularities in the field were recommended in the report of the New York City Committee on Adoptions, made public yesterday. Appointed by the Welfare Council of New York City, the United Hospital Fund and the New York Academy of Medicine, the committee studied services available to unmarried parents and children placed for adoption outside their own family circle.

Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the City College administrative committee of the Board of Higher Education, accused Lewis A. Wilson, acting State Commissioner of Education, yesterday of establishing a "bridgehead in our schools for the Communist revolutionary movement" by his decision that membership in the Communist party is not ground for dismissing a teacher.

TSINGTAO, China, Jan. 8 (AP) -The Chinese Government garrison commander reported today that Communists had killed one and captured four United States Marines on a Christmas Day hunting trip on the Shantung Peninsula.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 8 -Nineteen Communists were jailed and ten were injured in a clash today between the police and personnel of the Communist newspaper Tribuna Popular.

" The Collected Tales of A. E. Coppard" has been scheduled for publication on Feb. 9 by Knopf. Thirty-eight of the 200 tales Mr. Coppard wrote between 1921 and 1938 have been chosen for this volume. Included in the selection are "Adam and Eve and Pinch Me," "Clorinda Walks in Heaven," "The Black Dog" and "Fishmonger's Fiddle."
I was much interested in your timely editorial on the Junco, or snowbird, in THE TIMES of Jan. 4.
CHICAGO, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The American League, with Bob Feller, Joe DiMaggio, Ted Williams and other old and new stars in the cast, contemplates a great show in 1948.

Joe Louis signed yesterday for what the Brown Bomber still insisted would be his last fight. After a lengthy session in which he and his representatives conferred with Sol Strauss, acting director of the Twentieth Century sporting Club, Louis agreed to terms calling for him to risk his heavyweight championship of the world in New York next June.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Truman today chose Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter, one of the younger general officers of the Air Force and a West Point graduate, to serve as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. He announced that the appointment was conditional on passage of a special law to preserve General Kuter's military status while exempting him from any form of control by military superiors.

The city's effort to avert a threatened strike on oil-carrying barges and tankers at the weekend was intensified last night when Mayor O'Dwyer summoned the disputing employes and operators to City Hall. Another joint session of the two groups began on the upper floor of City Hall after the mayor delivered a speech to the committees and left for dinner.
In a cash deal, the nine-room house at 107 Eastchester Road, New Rochelle, in Westchester County, was sold by Grace Schmidt to Dr. Daniel J. McAuliffe of New York City, through John J. Reynolds, Inc.

An amazing exhibition of longrange set-shooting by Don Forman featured unbeaten New York University's ninth victory of the season last night at Madison Square Garden. Forman, smallest man on the squad, became the biggest man in N.Y.U. basketball history as he scored 35 points and paced his team to a 77-56 victory over Duke.

The team selected and sponsored by the Amateur Hockey Association of the United States to represent this country in the winter Olympic Games at St. Moritz, Switzerland, starting Jan. 30, was the guest of the New York Hockey Writers Association at dinner in Leone's yesterday.

The arrival of the Friendship Trains at their European destinations suggests another project that might be a happy ending to an old dispute. Why not an up-to-date Boston Tea Party - in reverse? The English people need tea, and don't have enough of it. Returned travelers and letters from Britain tell us that many families save their small quota for their elderly folk, to whom the cheer and warmth have become necessary.

The stock market recouped yesterday more of the ground recently surrendered and, although the rally proved the best of the new year, gains ranged only to about a point. A few pivotal issues managed to go beyond the gain made by the composite rate, which was 0.64 point on the day.

OWASHINGTON, Jan. 8 (AP) -- Attorneys for the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company filed a bill of exceptions with the Interstate Commerce Commission today objecting to an ICC examiner's recommendation that the two top officials of the C. O. be denied directorships on the New York Central.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Jan. 8 -- The Protestant churches of the South are making "significant" progress in their efforts to cope with racial problems, the Rev. Dr. Harry V. Richardson, director of the training program for the Negro rural ministry at Tuskegee Institute, Alabama, declared here tonight.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 8 (AP) - Master, a 4-year-old Calumet Farm colt that had been away from the winner's circle since last April 17 at Keeneland, ended a long losing streak today by breezing home to a three-length victory in the featured sixth race at Gulf stream Park.

Sharp but guarded resentmenthwas expressed yesterday by some of the utility companies involved in the request by the Public Service Commission to the State Legislature on Wednesday for emergency legislation that would give that agency authority to determine how gas and electricity should be distributed by utilities in this state during times of shortage of such fuels.

Warning of needless diphtheria cases and deaths in 1947, Health Commissioner Harry S. Mustard announced yesterday that his department's campaign to have every New York child immunized against the disease would be, intensified this year.

PEIPING, Jan. 8 (UP) -- Gen. Li Tsung-Jen, 57 years old, commander of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's Peiping headquarters, announced today his candidacy for Vice President of China on a platform that included friendlier relations with the Soviet Union.

A new upsurge in retail prices has increased the cost of meat to New York housewives 4 to 10 cents a pound in the last two weeks, Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz reported yesterday. Most of the new prices are 20 to 38 per cent higher than a year ago.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- French official reaction to the reports of United States and British proposals to set up a German economic government in the bizonal area was marked today by concern that the proposed program might compromise the French fundamental thesis against the creation of a strong central German government.

The annual Memorial Concert in honor of Franklin D. Roosevelt will be given on Jan. 30 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, it was announced Yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis. The concert, in which eminent artists, to be announced later, will participate, will mark the sixtysixth anniversary of Mr. Roosevelt's birth.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 8 -- Free emergency medical advice can be obtained by ships at sea from the Health Department of the Panama Canal on radio request from the master sent through the Naval Radio Station at Balboa, addressed "Govt. Medico, Pancanal," according to a joint circular issued by Marine Superintendent P. G. Nichols and the Chief Health Officer, S. D. Avery.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 8 (AP) -Several areas of Kentucky and adjoining states were excited today over reports of a "flying saucer" which led to the death of one National Guard flier and fruitless chases by several other pilots.

The Advertising Council announced yesterday its selection of American Overseas Aid for a campaign of public service advertising. The campaign, approved by the U.N., will be in cooperation withh) 0*0*0*ithe United Nations Appeal for children.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- President Truman announced today that he would nominate George V. Allen, a career diplomat who is now Ambassador to Iran, as Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

On Wednesday in this space we were writing of the absence of realism in the new year's first fiction. Never was realism more thoroughly spurned than in "The Well of the Unicorn,"* by George U. Fletcher. For this, ladies and gentleman, is romance with a capital R, romance liberally mixed with political allegory and all manner of lordly trimmings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Henry J. Kaiser, West Coast industrialist, "jumped the gun" on representatives of the steel industry today when he urged the creation of an impartial steel anti-inflation commission and demanded "goldfish bowl" hearings for any proposed allocations of steel.

HAVANA, Jan. 8 -- William L. Clayton, chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, said in an interview today that it was highly important that the world trade charter should contain "provisions of a character which will stimulate rather than discourage the flow of private capital to countries needing development."

Larry Ellis, the New York University freshman who emerged as a contender for mile honors by doing 4:16.9 around an unwieldy handicap field last Saturday, will have another chance to press his case tomorrow night. The precocious Violet cub will start from the back mark again in the handicap mile at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, meet at the Twenty-Third Regiment Armory, Brooklyn.

BERLIN, Jan. 8 -- The United States and British zones of Germany are expected to receive this year approximately 500,000 tons of steel from the Saar if the Marshall Plan becomes operative, United States Military Government officials disclosed today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- The United Nations Palestine Commission will hold its first meeting at 11 A.M. tomorrow amid growing uncertainty over the question whether outside military force can be provided if Arab opposition to partition should result in serious fighting.

The quick and unanimous action of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in reporting out a bill to authorize an information program overseas, and predictions that money will be appropriated for an expanded service, are welcome indications that Congress at last is aware of the necessity of telling abroad the "American story."

GENEVA, Jan. 8 (AP) -- An agreement "in principle" for an independent state of Annam, French Indo-China, within the French Union was reported tonight by Henry Thingh, secretary to former Emperor Bao Dai of Annam.

CHICAGO, Jan. 8 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, prosecuting the International Typographical Union, AFL, on unfair labor practice charges, circumvented the ITU president's refusal to produce union documents by summoning an antagonist of the union leadership who identified the required papers today.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 8 -- Subscriptions have been canceled and circulation barred to the weekly liberal magazine The Nation in four high schools here as the result of a series of allegedly anti-Catholic articles in thc publication last November, it was disclosed today.

The New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office at 111 East Sixteenth Street will request bids in the near future for substantial quantities of wool serge cloth, cotton uniform twills, sateens and oxfords, it was announced yesterday by Col. L. O. Grice, QMC, commanding officer.

Herbert Orrin (Fritz) Crisler of Michigan, named coach of the year in a nation-wide poll of college football coaches conducted by The World-Telegram and other ScrippsHoward newspapers, was honored last night at dinner in Leone's restaurant.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 8 -- The first shipload of a million-ton purchase of "demilitarized" war equipment from the Chinese Government arrived here today for the Patapsco Scrap Corporation, a Bethlehem Steel subsidiary.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Establishment of headquarters here for the Fifty-second Fighter Wing of the Air National Guard in its new plan for wartime defense of New York state, New Jersey and Delaware was announced tonight at a review of wing units in the state armory.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 8 -- Arabs, Jews and Britons fired thousands of rounds of ammunition here this afternoon as Jews and Arabs shot at each other while police armored cars tried to silence snipers and machine-gunners endangering passersby.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 8 -Universal-International has acquired screen rights to "The Wonderful Race at Rimrock," a magazine story by D. D. Beauchamp, as a vehicle for Marjorie Main, Donald O'Connor and Percy Kilbride.

Though fully expecting to be hanged, Ex-Premier Tojo has concluded his testimony before the Tokyo War Crimes Tribunal with the defiant and unrepentant declaration that he was conscious of no wrong, that what he had done was "right and true," and that his only regret was that he had lost the war.

MONTREAL, Jan. 8 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens and Detroit Red Wings battled to a 11 stalemate tonight in a National Hockey League game that left the topplace Red Wings and fifth-place Canadiens unchanged in their positions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, will be asked to give a Senate investigating committee further information concerning his trading in grain, it was announced today by the chairman, Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan.
A suit for $2,000 in damages was filed yesterday against the Long Island Rail Road by a commuter who claimed that he had been "wrongfully imprisoned" on a snowbound train.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Of all the unhappy situations in which public men find themselves, the most painful is that created when a Cabinet officer, having fought and lost a battle of principle on an issue directly involving his own particular responsibility in government, is given the task of defending the course he opposed.

The Greater New York CIO Council voted last night at a closed meeting in the Manhattan Center West Thirty-fourth Street, to oppose Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for an eight-cent fare on the municipal transit lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, in his annual report for 1947, declared today that "our greatest need, from the standpoint of continued prosperity for the individual wage-earners and the whole economy is to bring about a more stable balance between prices and wages."

A resolution urging the United States to furnish "adequate" aid to China was adopted yesterday by the Far East-America Council of Commerce and Industry, it was announced by Arthur B. Foye, partner in Haskins Sells, who was re-elected president.

Harry Ferguson, Irish-born industrialist and inventor of farm machinery, filed suit in Federal Court yesterday for $251,100,000 in damages from the Ford Motor Company, three other concerns and eight individuals, including Henry Ford 2d.

The six-story fifty-three family apartment house at 860 Fairmount Place, the Bronx has been purchased by Sam Roth and others from Sylvia Reich of Beverly Hills, Calif. The property is assessed at $180,000 and was sold for cash subject to a first mortgage of $122,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- Policy decisions on the trend that the voluntary food conservation program will take under the Taft anti inflation act are expected very soon by the Cabinet Food Committee, it was learned today.

PARIS, Jan. 8 -- Replying to critics of the new tax bill in a broadcast tonight Rene Mayer, Minister of Finance, said it marked the turning point in the recovery of France from the "poison" of inflation that otherwise would ruin her currency.

Denial of fare increases, both for single trips or commutation, that might apply to the Rockaway Beach and Far Rockaway divisions of the Long Island Rail Road was asked yesterday by residents of those areas at a hearing before the Public Service Commission, 233 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, Jan. S~.Depart-In/ent Store sales in the w. eek,(.e_ndedlJan./3 were 9 per ce ni;' above ~alesin the corresponding w.eek-.of.',lastIyear,' the Federal Reserve .BoardIrepprted today. The folio'wing lists]percentage changes from lj~.ke pe- Iriods a year ago:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 8 -- During the week ended Jan. 7, member bank reserve balanced decreased $396,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 8 -- Leaders of ten church, labor and educational organizations conferred here today on mobilizing sentiment against President Truman's plan for Congressional approval of universal military training.

The President told Congress Wednesday in his state of the Union message that the nation needs "accurate and comprehensive knowledge of our mineral resources"h)0*0*0*iand that we must develop "new supplies" and acquire stockpiles.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The British Government has reached a firm decision to use any aid it may receive under the European Recovery Program entirely for restoring and improving the country's productive capacity, it was learned today.

Weighing anchor tonight with a four-hour preview, starting at 7 o'clock at Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue, the annual mid winter excitement that brings yachtsmen out of their hibernation and known as the National Motor Boat Show will be held for the thirty-eighth time during the coming nine days.

The recommendations of the President's Committee on Higher Education, calling for scholarship funds, seemed fine on casual reading. On more careful analysis a serious flaw is revealed. This is the restriction of the scholarships to needy students.

LONDON, Jan. 8 -- The Middle East, and especially the Eurasian land bridge from Greece to Iraq, is believed to have received a considerable share of the Cabinet's attention today when it met to review the basis of British foreign policy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 8 -- Miss Susan B. Anthony 2d, grandniece of the famous feminist, today charged before the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women that the United States Embassy in Paris had refused a visa to Mme. Francois Leclerc, accredited representative of the Women's International Democratic Federation.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad has acquired a substantial common-stock interest in the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad, William White, president of the Lackawanna, announced last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 8 -- On the ground that the testimony of a witness was incompetent, the Court of Appeals today ordered a new trial for Martin J. Parkinson of Yonkers, a labor leader, on one count in an indictment charging an attempt to extort money from two concerns engaged in construction of the Delaware Aqueduct for the New York City Board of Water Supply.

DEL MONTE, Calif., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Former United States open champion Lloyd Mangrum, one of a handful to conquer the sandflanked Cypress Point course today, shared in a three-way lead in the first round of the 54-hole Bing Crosby $10,000 pro-amateur golf tournament.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming will complete fifteen years as rector of Trinity Parish on Thursday. When elected by the vestry of Trinity Parish, Dr. FIeming was vicar of its Chapel of the Intercession, Broadway and 155th Street, where he had served two years.

In a cash transaction the seven-story apartment house containing stores and fifty-three suites at 320 St. Nicholas Avenue, southeast corner of 126th Street, has been purchased by Lostrom, Inc., real estate operators headed by Mortimer F. Harman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--A truce on partisan politics in the working out of the country's anti-inflation and foreign recovery programs was urged upon the Senate today.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Qualifying nicely for the $25,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap on next Thursday's getaway program, Jule Fink's Wide Wing routed five rivals as expected in today's feature of a mile and a sixteenth.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, defending itself against charges of coercing its members into an illegal collective bargaining policy, showed today that its Akron, Ohio, local negotiated an agreement without interference or reprisal by the international union.

Establishment of a Jewish state in Palestine will not reduce the need for bringing displaced persons into this country in 1948, Edwin Rosenberg, president of United Service for New Americans, declared yesterday at its headquarters, 15 Park Row.
Olle Tandberg's prospects as a heavyweight title threat evaporated last night at Madison Square Garden in his tiresome ten-round bout with Joey Maxim, Jack Kearns' protege from Cleveland.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has transferred to the United States Treasury $18,368,000 out of net earnings in 1947 of $24,558,000, it was disclosed yesterday in the bank's thirty-third annual statement. According to the report, signed by Allan Sproul, president, the bank last year, before expenses, earned $38,907,000, compared with $37,443,000 in 1946.
