A resolution asking the Legislature to amend the state Constitution to permit the city to conduct for one year a lottery to raise funds for hospital rehabilitation and medical research was approved yesterday by the City Council's Committee on State Legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9--The United States Government is delivering to Turkey four large modern submarines, the Navy Department announced today. This was the major step in a series of new moves, including the transfer of eleven other naval vessels to Turkey and additional Greek civilian assistance.

WASHINGTON, San. 9 -- What promises to be a bitter battle over the future tariff policy of the United States started today when the House Ways and Means Committee demanded that the State Department explain before March 1 the manner in which it negotiated the eighteen-power trade agreement which went into effect at the first of the year.

In Lawrence Fernsworth's letter, published Dec. 22, concerning the liberties established by the Bill of Rights, and recent cases which point toward a shrinking of these liberties by judicial decisions, he states that "absent from our Bill of Rights is the * * * writ of habeas corpus.

Per capita consumption of paper products will resume its upward trend during the coming year, based upon greater appreciation by the public during the war of the usefulness of paper packaging, and research developing new products, Alexander Calder, president of the Union Bag and Paper Corporation, forecast today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Joint Congressional Housing Committee received indications today that lumber prices may have passed their peak and that a general reduction of around 10 per cent may be felt by next spring. Some lumber prices, the committee was told, are already off 5 per cent from their high point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Peace and inflation will be the two most important factors affecting American retailing in 1948, Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board of R.H. Macy, Inc., New York, declared today as he set forth a four-point anti-inflation program for retailers.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday that net income for the eleven months to Nov. 30, 1947, amounted to $7,895,347, compared with a net loss of $11,573,084 in the same period of 1946.

Roger Vernon Terry, 50 years old, of James River Drive, Hilton Village, Warwick County, Va., was found dead of a heart attack at 7:30 A.M. yesterday in his berth aboard a Pennsylvania Railroad train as it pulled into Pennsylvania Station. Gerald Moorehouse of Old Point Comfort, Va., Mr. Terry's traveling companion, made the discovery when he tried to awaken him.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- Figures released by the State Department of Taxation and Finance indicated today that the income of the State Government would reach a new peak by the end of the current fiscal year, March 31.
A marked increase in measles cases among New York children has appeared already in this "measles year," Deputy Health Commissioner Samuel Frant warned yesterday.

Recently Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, upon her return from Europe, mentioned that one of the questions most often asked, concerning the United Nations, was why its sessions were not opened with prayer. That same question has frequently come up among our own people.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9--The Little Assembly adopted tonight a United States resolution giving members of the United Nations until March 15 to present suggestions on modifications in the great powers' veto. The vote was 39 to 1, with the Peruvian delegate, Dr. Alberto Ulloa, casting the only negative vote.

The George Washington Bridge, linking New York and New Jersey over the Hudson River, was closed several hours yesterday when large pieces of melting ice crashed from cables to the roadways. As a result, there was considerable traffic congestion on both sides of the bridge.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- In a move aimed at curbing bank credit, the Federal Reserve Board today approved action of nine of the twelve Federal Reserve banks in raising the "rediscount rate" from 1 to 1 1/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- John P. Frey, head of the AFL Metal Trades Department, said today that all shipyard employers and unions are free to make their own contracts in the future because the Government's wartime area agreements have been abandoned by mutual consent.

Business and industrial leaders joined here yesterday in forming a volunteer committee to promote the sale of Government Savings Bonds in response to President Truman's recent proposal to use this means to curb rising prices.

Westchester County shooters who have been wondering what happened to a lot of the pheasants they had hoped to gather in last season might find a partial answer by scouting around within the city limits. E.A. McCormick of the Consolidated Shipbuilding Corporation has sent an interesting note on the pheasant population near City Island.

A thirty-day term in jail was imposed yesterday on a landlord who had exacted a $400 bonus for the use of a Bronx apartment renting for $26 a month. The sentence was given in Bronx Special Sessions to Chester V. Brown, 26-year-old owner of the tenement at 1480 Washington Avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Business booked by manufacturers of quality furniture during the first week of the winter international home furnishings market here was substantial but spotty, three top retailers representing mail-order houses, department stores and buying syndicates reported today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Tass, the official Russian news agency, said today that President Truman's state of the Union address to Congress Tuesday "directly recognized an approaching economic crisis in the United States, whose population presently is suffering from inflation.''

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan paid a tribute to the State Department today. Although he criticized the department's proposal for administering the European Recovery Program, he said the foreign aid measure was backed by more hard work and careful research than almost any other bill to come before Congress.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 -- As the Gubernatorial primary election campaign moves into its final fortnight indications are that Sam Houston Jones, Louisiana's wartime chief Executive and apostle of a "new economy" for the South, is the front runner in a contest that seems virtually certain to require a run-off primary between the two top contestants.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Ten new or improved devices for aircraft were among the 415 inventions for which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

Today's events: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Series, Rudolph Ganz, conductor; Guila Bustabo, violin, Carnegie Hall, 11 A.M.; "Louise," Metropolitan Opera Company, 2 P.M.; American, Youth Orchestra, Dean Dixon, conductor, Needle Trades High School, 2; Efrem Zimbalist, violin, Town Hall, 5:30; "Rigoletto," Metropolitan Opera Company, 8:30; American Opera Company Concert, Manhattan Paul, singer, Carnegie Hall, 8; Monica Mais, soprano, Town Hall, 8:40; Vinaver Chorus, Times Hall, 8:30.

A GOOD many of the light verses and sketches in A.P. Herbert's new book, "Leave My Old Morale Alone,"* are more felicitous than the title. Well, humorists are apt to have trouble with their titles and the funnier they are the worse their choices of names for books -- as witness Robert Benchley, for example. However, there is a lot of entertaining material here,

A Brooklyn section of the communist party was ordered yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court to disavow the alleged principle of revolution by force as a condition to representation at a hearing on an order to show cause why it should not be barred from meeting in a borough public school.

Basketballs are due to soar and bounce all over the Eastern seaboard this afternoon and tonight, with the greater activity centered in Madison Square Garden, where a scholastic quadruple-header is to supply the matinee entertainment and a college twin bill the evening's excitement.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., JAN. 9 -- Dmitri Z. Manuilsky, Vice Premier of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, and one of the most colorful figures in the United Nations, has been appointed to represent the Ukraine on the United Nations Security Council, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.
By way of breaking the monotony, the Yankees yesterday signed a ball player who admittedly will not receive $20,000 or more for his services next summer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Three bold bandits -- tossing smoke-bombs to cover their getaway -- held up a big department store just across from the Harvard Yard today and escaped with $50,000 in cash.

The stock market was unable yesterday to extend a recovery which developed in the morning and, as a result, prices tended to an irregularly lower close. The list leaned slightly to the lower side in terms of the number of issues to show losses on the day, and, while a few selected stocks strengthened, the combined averages sagged 0.42 point.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- A sharp rise in the cost of newsprint here has imposed an additional burden, estimated at 85,500 ($342,000) a week, on the British newspaper industry.

HAVANA, Jan. 9 -- The Trade Committee on Employment and Economic Activity of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment completed its work today with the adoption of a draft resolution on employment recommended for submission by the conference to the Economic and Social Council.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 9 -- Argentina will have the funds with which to aid the Marshall Plan if she decides to cooperate.

E.M. Rampey, weather forecaster, sailed yesterday on the Government-owned transport liner Marine Marlin, carrying weather apparatus and reading instruments for use in the voyage to Southampton. He will instruct the ship's crew, hold weather conferences with the captain and other officers, and make observations that will aid the weather bureau here.
Ernest G. Schmidt has been appointed general sales manager of the American Map Company, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The question whether the Florida East Coast Railway, long in bankruptcy, shall be merged with the Atlantic Coast Line System or be operated independently by the Alfred I. du Pont estate was placed before the Interstate Commerce Commission today for its final decision.

The Guaranty Trust Company, in its report for 1947, issued yesterday in advance of the annual meeting later this month, showed that its capital funds at the end of the year amounted to $360,666,666, said to be the largest of any bank in the United States and indicating a ratio of $1 of capital funds to $7 of deposits.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The United Mine Workers of America feels that "there has been a lot of chiseling" by bituminous coal operators on the contract signed last July 7, it was reported today. Just how the union plans to Handle its grievances other than through the machinery provided by the contract was not disclosed.

The nation's rubber manufacturing industry in 1947 consumed a record 1,100,000 long tons of new rubber, of which 556,000 was natural and 554,000 synthetic, the Rubber Manufacturers Association, Inc., reported in its year-end review.

Reading in THE TIMES of Jan. 1 the New Year's message of Treasury Secretary John W. Snyder that individual saving is America's "most potent weapon in combating inflation," found myself intrigued but nonplused. For I knew that today, with an insurance premium, several bills, and an income tax installment coming due, I would have to draw upon what savings I had already accumulated.

ALBANY, Jan. 9 -- A bill to outlaw restrictive covenants in real estate instruments, and seven other bills designed for the protection of civil liberties, were introduced today in the State Legislature by Assemblyman Bernard Austin, Democrat, of Brooklyn.

Paul Blanshard, writer of three articles on the Roman Catholic Church in The Nation that led to a ban on the magazine in the Newark, N.J., high schools, charged yesterday that the action was "an unjustifiable curtailment of intellectual freedom."

The threat of a retail meat store strike in Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island, and Nassau and Suffolk Counties appeared to have vanished yesterday as 240 stores signed contracts with Local 342 of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters, AFL.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that the Commodity Credit Corporation will enter into special contracts with tobacco companies designated by the French Tobacco Monopoly to procure 1947-crop tobacco, possibly to the amount of $3,500,000.
Butter prices dropped again yesterday in wholesale trading here. As a result, many retailers promised a pleasant surprise for shoppers this morning.

The household of Herbst invites you for pastry and coffee. The little patisseries are fresh from the oven and the coffee covered, a la Viennese, with a puff of unsweetened whipped cream. Blue muslin curtains hang at a window, blue uniforms dress up the waitresses and gay murals of old Hungary ornament the walls.

A new two-year contract, featured by a $13 weekly pay increase and job rules conforming in every particular with the Taft-Hartley Act, was announced yesterday by the Publishers Association of New York City and Local 2 of the International Printing Pressmen's and Assistants, Union of North America, AFL.

Completion of deliveries of fail fabrics for men's clothing by woolen and worsted mills not later than August next is vital to restoration of a normal production and delivery pattern in the industry, Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers of the United States of America, said here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- With the jobs of 6,000 soup-makers in jeopardy, Federal Judge Guy K. Bard issued a temporary order today restraining two Montgomery County farmers from selling their 1947 carrot crop to anyone except the Campbell Soup Company of Camden, N.J.

The method by which several of the rarer elements have been used to rehabilitate torn nerves and other human tissues was described here last night by Dr. Clarence W. Balke, Director Emeritus of Research of the Fansteel Metallurgical Corporation, North Chicago, Ill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The life-sized portrait of Margaret Truman just completed by Greta Kempton will be presented to the Truman family "by a group of friends," according to information given out today at an informal press showing attended by both the artist and her subject.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall was accused before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today of using "propaganda methods" in his all-or-nothing presentation yesterday of the Administration's European Recovery Program.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- Following is the text of the statement made today by Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, at the opening meeting of the Palestine Commission:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The spiraling expenditures of the Veterans Administration reached a total of $7,805,355,201 in the fiscal year ended last June 30, more than twelve times the pre-war rate, administrator Carl R. Gray Jr. reported to Congress today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 -- About 100 recently dismissed employes of the American Transarabian Pipeline Company demonstrated today in front of the offices of the company and then marched to the offices of the Lebanese President and Prime Minister.

Fordham's undefeated basketball team raced to a 71-54 victory over Williams College last night before a crowd of 3,500 at the Rams' court. George Detmar of the visitors took scoring honors with 23 points, while Johnny Bach was high for the Rams, with 21.

Five invitation events feature the schedule at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus track meet tonight in the Twenty-third Regiment Armory at Bedford and Atlantic Avenues in Brooklyn. More than 900 athletes, including the young season's biggest assembly of top-flight performers, will compete in the eighteen-event program, which starts at 8 P. M.
The city prepared yesterday to meet an additional fuel crisis if 1,000 seamen on harbor craft walk out tonight at midnight, as they threaten.
Mediation of one phase of the eight-day-old international cable strike will be resumed at 10 A.M. today in the offices of the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service.
I should appreciate an opportunity to thank Berwyn Fragner publicly for calling the attention of the branch libraries to what is surely a fault if he found them too noisy as places in which to study.

NANKING, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Censored pro-Government dispatches from Manchuria today said the renewed Communist offensive had brought fighting within eight miles northwest of Mukden and that more distant heavy artillery fire was audible within the city.

ATLANTA, Jan. 9 (AP) -- After fifteen years with the Senators, Shortstop Cecil Travis is quitting baseball to take up farming. Travis was placed on the inactive list so quietly that only his closest friends were advised of his decision.

Retail trade here snapped back sharply this week from the poor volume last week in the wake of the snowstorm. Department stores here had increases ranging up to 10 per cent over the heavy gains noted in the 1947 period.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 9 -- At the request of West Coast steamship operators, the Federal Conciliation Service today entered a dispute involving the tie-up of five ships, one at Baltimore and four on this coast, by the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union, CIO.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- British Government stocks were outstanding today in otherwise quiet and easier stock markets here. Jobbers had to deal with a steady flow of buying orders, and with supplies none too plentiful prices went ahead throughout the list, rises finally ranging from 1/8 to 3/4 point.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan.9 -- The Arab Higher Committee Delegation issued a statement here tonight expressing gratitude to American authorities for impounding the TNT and other explosives which, the statement said, "were destined to go into the hands of Zionist terrorists to blow up the dwellings of innocent Arabs."

Since airport operation is a new venture for the Port Authority, Howard S. Cullman's statement as chairman at the annual meeting of commissioners will be studied first of all, probably, for its balance sheet on La Guardia Airport. The Authority took over on June 1. Revenues in seven months amount to $952,552.

LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, chairman of the German Social Democratic party, arrived by air tonight in preparation for a conference of the Committee of International Socialist Parties to be held in London over the week-end.

The third annual La Tausca competition exhibition of paintings by contemporary American artists opens today at the Riverside Museum. There are sixty-two entries this year and five prizes totaling $6,750 have been announced.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 9 -- Walter Wanger and David O. Selznick are discussing a deal whereby Wanger's property, "The Ballad and the Source," may be produced for distribution by the Selznick releasing organization, Wanger disclosed today.

The biggest annual meeting of the American Horse Shows Association at the Waldorf Astoria yesterday established that the National Horse Show Association had requested eight days again for the nation's blue-ribbon equestrian fixture in November. Business transacted included re-election of all officers, with Adrian Van Sinderen president, review of recent rule changes and adoption of one new rule providing for classes of small hunters.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The New York State Vegetable Growers Association and the Empire State Potato Club, Inc., went on record today in favor of a 1948 state fair.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Jan. 9 -- The long-forecast direct Communist attack on Germany's role in the European Recovery Plan has begun, responsible officials here were sure today. Although fewer than 12,000 workers demonstrated during a five-hour work stoppage in Essen and only 3,500 took part in another demonstration in near-by Solingen, Communist ability to cause an estimated 60,000 workers to lay down their tools for varying periods during a week was noted.

NANKING, Jan. 9 -- A record budget calling for expenditure of ninety-six trillion Chinese dollars during the first half of 1948 was announced by the Government tonight. Dr. Hollington K. Tong, Nanking spokesman, said the Finance Ministry expected an income of fifty-eight trillion Chinese dollars in that period.

The arbitration of wage review issues between a committee representing ship owners and operators on the Atlantic and Gulf coasts and three CIO maritime unions opened yesterday before Frederick R. Livingston, who was named arbitrator by Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach following a petition from both parties.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 9 (AP) -- Week-end skiing conditions in up-State New York were reported "generally good" today.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 9 -- Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang's attacks on Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Chinese Central Government apparently have not endeared him to the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, said today that new spending programs proposed by President Truman would add $19,300,000,000 annually to the cost of government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Broadcasting of both Senate and House Committee hearings on the Marshall Plan under the same new technique used for the Un-American Activities Committee was urged today by the American Association of University Women.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- Coal production costs in Britain have risen since the nation took the fields from private owners, the National Coal Board said today.

A replica of the Statue of Our Lady of Fatima in Portugal will be exposed for veneration tomorrow evening in the Monastery Church of the Immaculate Conception, 178th Street and Wexford Terrace, Jamaica, Queens, it was announced yesterday.

Callers at the information booth in the main lobby of Manhattan Police Headquarters on Center Street will henceforth have their questions answered by four of the department's youngest, slimmest and most intelligent patrolmen.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 9 -- As Indian troops took the offensive in Kashmir state and thrust an armored column deep into raider territory, the Prime Ministers of India and Pakistan planned today to meet on Sunday at Lahore with the Indo-Pakistan Joint Defense Council under the chairmanship of India's Governor General Earl Mountbatten.
PRAGUE, Jan. 9 -- "Political terror is again on the program in factories,'' the Socialist party's central newspaper reported today.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 9 -- With the slaughter and burial of 278 head of infected animals in the Macuspana area within the last two days the State of Tabasco is now free of any known hoof-and-mouth infection, the United States-Mexican commission for the eradication of the disease announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Highly authoritative sources said today the Malayan tin producers were expected to request a further increase in prices for their tin which, if granted by the United Kingdom, may precipitate another wave of rises all over the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The Wolf Dessauer Company, operator of a department store in Fort Wayne, Ind., filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering 75,712 shares of $1 par value common stock that will be offered publicly.

Establishment of special courts to deal with alcoholics is recommended by Dr. Lyman C. Duryea, medical director of the Research Council on Problems of Alcohol, in a report submitted yesterday to the Committee on Medical Jurisprudence of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

In presenting their case for a general 15 per cent rent rise in New York City and Long Island, landlords' representatives appearing before the New York City Rent Advisory Board will offer a mass of statistical data and financial information, it was learned yesterday.

Along about the second or third week in January, the amateur mechanic-carpenter-handyman usually gets smothered by requests to fix the dolls, toys and gadgets that survived the rigors of Christmas Week, but not much more.

The Toni Company, manufacturer of home permanent wave kits and shampoo recently purchased by the Gillette Safety Razor Company, will spend $6,000,000 for advertising and merchandising during 1948, it was announced yesterday.

Despite an increase in net sales to $13,203,150 from the $10,364,725 volume of the previous year, the net profit of Adolf Gobel, Inc., for the fifty-two weeks ended on Nov. 1, declined to $17,461 or 3 cents a common share, from the $327,520 or 50 cents a share earned in the fifty-three weeks ended on Nov. 2, 1946, the annual report disclosed yesterday.

GRINDELWALD, Switzerland, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Celina Seghi, 27-year-old Italian star, made two faultless runs down a steep alpine slope today to win the slalom event, opening feature of the international women's ski races.

Working with Lee De Forest and Alexander Graham Bell on wireless experiments at the turn of the century, Frank E. Butler, who died this week in Ohio, played an important role in the development of the present-day radio. He participated in 1907 in the first "broadcast" from the scene of action when he joined Dr. De Forest in reporting by wireless telephone from ship to shore the results of yacht races on Lake Erie.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman granted an "honorable discharge" today to the United Service Organization and expressed the nation's gratitude for its camp shows and many other services in behalf of millions of soldiers, sailors and marines.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 9 -- A demonstration against the Inter-American Labor Conference, backed by the American Federation of Labor, backfired here tonight as mounted police rode down large pro-conference crowds, which vastly outnumbered the opposing demonstrators.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 9 -- An invasion force of about 1,000 Arab volunteers of the "People's Army" crossed the frontier into Palestine to seize and dynamite the Jewish colonies Metulla and Tiskheby this morning, sources close to the Arab commander, Fawzi el-Ka-wukji, announced here tonight.

E.C. Oelsner of the University Club, defending titleholder, gained the quarter-final round of the New York State squash racquets championship at the Downtown A.C. last night by defeating D.M. Frame of the Harvard Club, 15 -- 6, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 17, 15 -- 11.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 9 (AP) -- The poor health which led to Richard Cresson Harlow's retirement from the Navy in 1945 today forced him to resign as football coach at Harvard University, where spokesmen said no immediate attempt would be made to select a new mentor.

Douglas C. Abbott, Canadian Finance Minister, predicted yesterday that the present Canadian ban on the importation of American automobiles would be relaxed soon. He also forecast that the Marshall Plan to help rebuild Europe's economy would become effective and that Canada undoubtedly would benefit by its provisions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The ten Hollywood movie writers and producers who are facing charges of contempt of Congress pleaded not guilty in the Federal District Court today and were ordered to stand trial separately, beginning Feb. 9.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 9 -- Republican strategy to counter President Truman's tax adjustment program was illuminated further tonight in a major pre-campaign address here by Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., Speaker of the House.
LONDON, Jan. 9 -- The Arab Office in London expressed tonight the "gravest possible objection" to any British acquiescence to a dispatch of United States marines to Palestine.

As a first step toward enabling Western Germany to play that important and essential role which the Marshall Plan assigns to it, the American and British Military Governments are now establishing a German Economic Administration to mobilize the dormant productive capacities of their two merged zones.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- Trygve Lie, Secretary General of the United Nations, told the organization's Palestine commission today that it had a right to be confident that the Security Council, if necessary, would assume its full responsibility for carrying out the General Assembly's resolution on partition of the Holy Land.

ROME, Jan. 9 -- The Italian Minister of the Budget, Luigi Einaudi, informed the Cabinet today that the state's revenue was greater than foreseen but that expenditures had increased even more rapidly. He said that the foreseen budget deficit at the close of the fiscal year would exceed the forecasts.

Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, plainly angered by a state education commissioner's reversal of a City College instructor's dismissal for alleged subversive activities, demanded yesterday support by "the bar of public opinion."

The Holland America liner Nieuw Amsterdam docked in Hoboken yesterday with 964 passengers. Among them was Dr. Herman B. Baruch, United States Ambassador to the Netherlands, who said he would report to the State Department, but was here primarily for a reunion with his three brothers.

Reductions on imported fabrics resulting from lower duties in effect since the first of the year are being passed on to consumers, according to textile importers yesterday. The reductions are presently being computed, they said, both on goods already landed and those expected in the near future.
It blew hot and cold for enforcement agents of the Customs service yesterday, but at 6 P.M. they had a narcotics case.

An operatic series entitled "Let's Go to the Met" will make its bow at 4:30 P.M. next Friday over the ABC network and WJZ. The weekly half-hour program will be designed to familiarize listeners with the Metropolitan Opera performance to be broadcast the following Saturday afternoon over the chain.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- The Executive Committee of the American Association for the United Nations urged the United States to do everything possible, through the United Nations, "without sacrificing principle and without appeasement," to come to an understanding with the Soviet Union.

CHICAGO, Jan. 9 -- Grain markets closed strong today on the Board of Trade with March oats at $1.32 1/4, cash oats at $1.48 1/2 and March soy beans at $4.28 1/2 at record high prices. May and July corn went to a new seasonal peak as did May, September and December oats and the deferred deliveries of soy beans.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 9 -- The Belgian Government authorized Premier Paul-Henri Spaak today to resume royal negotiations that may result in the elevation to the throne of Prince Baudouin, 17-year-old son of exiled King Leopold III.

Thomas J. Patterson, budget director, predicted yesterday that the city would have considerable difficulty balancing its expense budget for the 1948-49 fiscal year unless state aid would be forthcoming for the O'Dwyer administration.

The New York State CIO has sent letters to all its local union affiliates, notifying them that the American Labor party is no longer the "political arm" of the state CIO and that its executive board has repudiated the candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President on a third party ticket.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Harold E. Stassen charged under oath today that "Administration insiders," numbering altogether "about eleven," had profited by $4,000,000 in speculating in the commodity food markets.

The Rev. James W. Hyde, formerly rector of St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church, Delaware, Ohio, will preach his first sermon tomorrow at the 4 o'clock evensong as a member of the staff of St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street.

Supporters of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower for the Republican nomination for President pushed his candidacy out into the open yesterday when they filed a complete slate of candidates for delegates to the Republican National Convention in New Hampshire.

Passengers aboard the Queen Elizabeth when that Cunard White Star liner sailed for Southampton yesterday included (1) the Amateur Hockey Association's Olympic-bound squad of seventeen; (2) the Canadian Olympic hockey outfit, eighteen of its twenty members in Royal Canadian Air Force uniforms, and (3) a United States Table Tennis Association team that will ping and pong in the world championships in London next month.

New York's surest harbinger that sun, fun, salt spray and yachting will come in a few more months to help it forget winter gloom arrived last night for its annual visit to Grand Central Palace. It was, of course, the thirty-eighth annual National Motor Boat Show, newly streamlined as befits 1948, gorgeous, gaudy, shiny, spic-and-span.

An oil painting of the late former Mayor James J. Walker was officially accepted yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer at ceremonies held in the City Hall rotunda. The painting, showing Mr. Walker seated in a characteristic pose, was unveiled by his sister, Mrs. Nan Walker Burke of Bayside, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- President Truman's use of the phrase "universal training" -- omitting the word "military" -- in his state of the Union message has no other significance than that he believes such training would be beneficial to the nation's youth in many ways, a White House spokesman said today.
ATHENS, Jan. 9 (UP)--Greek Government leaders clashed tonight with American aid officials over financial policy for the rehabilitation of the country.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- President Truman today formally nominated George V. Allen, now Ambassador to Iran, to be Assistant Secretary of State.

Two books by Albert Schweitzer, author of "Quest of the Historical Jesus" who has been in French Equatorial Africa for more than thirty-five years as a medical missionary, have been scheduled for March publication by The Beacon Press. One will be "Psychiatric

The Neediest Cases Fund went over the $350,000 mark yesterday. The contributions of eighty-six donors amounting to $2,603.56 raised the total in the thirty-sixth annual appeal conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES to $351,639.14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 3 were 682,038 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 82,681 cars or 13.8 per cent more than for the preceding week, 5,390 cars or 0.8 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 29,060 or 4.5 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Two young women who allegedly robbed and pummeled Mrs. Jean Berkowitz, 41 years old, and her father, Isaac Heitel, 68, in their apartment at 1424 East Second Street, Brooklyn, were captured yesterday by radio Patrolman Michael Tellone.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 9 -- An organized Arab force from Syria attacked two Jewish settlements in northern Palestine today. British armored forces, with a Royal Air Force fighter unit in support, aided the Jews in repelling the attack.

Donaldson Brown has been elected a director of the Safe Deposit and Trust Company, it was announced yesterday by Thomas B. Butler, president. Mr. Brown was formerly vice chairman of the board of General Motors Corporation.
Eugene A. McKeever has joined the brokerage department of the Houghton Company.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9 -- Final transactions proposed in the plan of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., now in process of liquidation, were approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 Buying of Series E Government savings bonds topped cash-ins by $155,298,000 in 1947, final Treasury figures, for the year disclosed today. As a result, the public holdings of these bonds -- formerly known as War Bonds -- reached a high record of $30,996,938,000 on Dec. 31.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Retail prices of goods and services in the moderate income family groups in large cities rose 0.7 per cent from mid-October to mid-November, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. This increase lifted the "consumers' price index" for November to 164.9 per cent of the 1935-39 average -- a new record high.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated yesterday in a narrower range than during recent sessions, and final prices were 16 points higher to 3 points net lower than the day before.

LONDON, Jan. 9 (UP) -- Sir Henry French, director general of the British Film Producers Association, offered today to let American producers keep the profits earned by British films in the United States, if export of American pictures to England resumed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- The possibility of sending American marines or other "guards" to protect the United States consulate general in Jerusalem has been discussed informally by the consulate with the Palestine Government, but no decision has been reached, the State Department said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 -- Prompt removal of United States armed forces from the thirteen bases in Panama has produced a good psychological effect in Latin America and throughout the world, Representative Mike Mansfield, Democrat, of Montana, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today.

TOKYO, Jan. 9 (AP) -- A Russian patrol craft was reported tonight to have made a line fast to the floundering Russian ship Dvina, in distress in heavy seas about 100 miles off the east coast of Hokkaido.

Ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace," prepared by the consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee, will be continued in its present form through Thursday, Jan. 15. The series was described inaccurately as terminating yesterday. Here are the recommendations for today:

Although raising of the Federal Reserve banks' rediscount rate had seemingly been "discounted" in financial circles, word of the imminent rise to 1 1/4 per cent was effective yesterday in writing finis to the week's exploratory attempt at a rally in the Government bond market.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The biggest bank robbery in years netted five bandits about $130,000 today, but before the sun had set three men were in jail and about half of the loot was recovered.

Notices of allocations of steel which have been received by metal- working plants here foretell a continuation of critical ferrous scarcities through the entire year, it was revealed yesterday by purchasing agents who have conducted a canvass of the metal inventory situation.

Syed S. Hasan, United Nations correspondent for The People's Age, Communist newspaper of Bombay, India, said yesterday that his arrest by immigration authorities was "an insult not only to my person but to the press as a whole."

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 9 -- Wing walking, speed races, delayed parachute drops, a balloon ascension, aerobatics and the first public demonstration of the pick-up of a human being by an airplane marked the opening here today of the sixteenth annual All-American Air Maneuvers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 9 -- Miss Mary Sutherland, United Kingdom representative on the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, accused the Soviet Union today of having violated a basic family right by refusing to allow the Russian wives of fifteen British soldiers to leave the Soviet Union and rejoin their husbands in Britain.

WARSAW, Jan. 9 -- An eight-point outline of Polish foreign policy for 1948 was set forth today by Brig. Gen. Victor Grosz, Director of Information of the Foreign Ministry. The outline was headed by a resolution to "extend and strengthen" relations with the other Slav states and may presage broader treaties between Poland and those countries.
BOSTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- The Boston Weather Bureau tonight issued these forecasts and ski conditions:

ATHENS, Jan. 9 -- Comdr. Morton Sunderland of the United States naval attache's staff here announced today that the United States Mediterranean Fleet under command of Vice Admiral B.H. Bieri is now holding training exercises in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Ionian Sea off southwestern Greece.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. Jan. 9 -- Speedy aid to millions of needy Chinese children was mapped out today by the program committee of the International Children's Emergency Fund of the United Nations, which now for the first time begins operations outside of Europe.

MOSCOW, Jan. 9 (UP) -- The Government in a sweeping decree moved today to break up the "home labor" system under which, it has been complained, industrial profiteers have been able to exploit workers.

Four attractions of varying success will retire from the Main Stem over the week-end. Three will call it quits after tonight's performance, while the fourth will take leave tomorrow night. The resultant gap -- theatregoers may be heartened to know -- will be filled next week by six incoming shows.

TOKYO, Jan. 9 -- The occupation authorities are finding evidence that certain Shinto priests are turning to gangsterism to supplement their fading revenues, it was disclosed today. Already Hanni Ito, leader of the sect that preaches the "new orientalism" has run afoul of the police for his collection methods.
ALBANY, Jan. 9 (AP) -- John L. Considine of The United Press is the new president of the Legislative Correspondents Association of the State of New York.

ABOARD A B-17, above the Dvina, Jan. 9 (AP) -- United States airmen are fighting snow and ice in the most comprehensive air-sea rescue operation of the occupation to maintain constant precautionary patrols over the stricken Soviet ship Dvina.

The United States Maritime Commission, through Vice Admiral W.W. Smith, told Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday it was using "all of its authority and available facilities" to alleviate the east coast fuel oil shortage. The Commission's telegram, sent from Washington, was in reply to Mayor O'Dwyer's appeal Jan. 6 for twenty more tankers to serve east coast areas through January and February.

BUCK HILLS FALLS, Pa., Jan. 9 -- A resolution urging Congress and the Federal Administration to consider the rights and desires of American Indians before drafting a bill to end Federal supervision of some of their territories was adopted here today at the annual meeting of the Home Missions Council of North America.
The failure of the Council of Foreign Ministers to reach agreement on a common program for post-war Germany must not be allowed to become the occasion for German rejoicing.

President Branch Rickey of the Dodgers, contributing to discussions on cleaning up college sports at the forty-second annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, yesterday assured college athletic leaders that "if you don't make your men professionals, we won't either."
Utica, N.Y., announced yesterday it would receive bids Tuesday on $1,700,000 of notes dated Jan. 14 and due July 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP) -- Prospects for the 1948 wheat crop, which last month was officially forecast at more than a billion bushels, have improved in recent weeks, the Agriculture Department reported today.

An embargo was placed by the War Assets Administration on all undelivered orders of surplus explosives late yesterday after the seizure up-state of three tractor trailers loaded with sixty-nine tons of M-3, an explosive described as slightly more powerful than TNT.

PARIS, Jan. 9 -- About 137,000 German prisoners of war working in France have elected to remain as free civilian laborers for at least a year, according to statistics published by the newspaper Monde today.

The English Duo: composed of Viola Morris, soprano, and Victoria Anderson, contralto, presented a carefully devised and interesting program last night at Town Hall. As at their local debut in 1940, the two Australian singers, who received their musical training in England, each sang a group of solos in addition to the duets which formed the chief part of the schedule.

The President's nomination of Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter to be chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board is an excellent choice. One can imagine General Kuter approaching the task with some regret, if not with trepidation, for the trouble is plentiful and complicated.

Although confident of generally good business in 1948, SKF Industries, Inc., manufacturer of ball and roller bearings, faces a year in which the determination of many users of anti-friction bearings to reduce inventories and to procure materials on shorter notice will call for greater flexibility in production and over-all management planning, according to William L. Batt, president.

ATHENS, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Bank of Greece, acting on authority from the United States Aid Mission, began selling gold sovereigns on the free market today and stemmed sharp depreciation of the drachma.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Jan. 10 (UP) -- The FBI said today that it was investigating the theft of about 10,000 rounds of small-arms ammunition from Borinquen Field.
As a new citizen of the United States of European origin, I ask for space in your column to present a point of view common among Europeans, and with which the United States must be prepared to deal.

IN a possible attempt to gain privacy or to illustrate that movies can originate in areas other than Hollywood, Director Lewis Milestone and Scenarist Arnold Manoff have been quietly whipping "an original idea" into shape in the confines of a local hostelry.

I'm not clairvoyant. But it's my guess that every important Gold Cup class speedboat record in the books will be smashed during 1948. That includes my two Gold Cup records of 70.88 m.p.h. for the 30-mile heat and 68.07 m.p.h. for the 90-mile event; Gar Wood's 124.92 m.p.h. American mile-straightaway mark, and possibly Sir Malcolm Campbell's world mile-straightaway record of 141.74 m.p.h.

IN recent years we have witnessed new interpretations and assessments of almost every aspect of American intellectual, cultural and social history. Among them, however, studies of the development of American science are conspicuously absent.

This department has been leafing through the literature of the common cold, only to reach the gloomy conclusion that doctors know vary little more about it than they did in 1928. In that year Dr. A. Raymond Dochez of Columbia University proved that the cause of the common cold was not a bacterium, as the medical world thought, but a virus.

IN January, 1942, a Negro was brutally lynched in a small town in Missouri. Within forty-eight hours German and Japanese short-wave radios were broadcasting the ugly news. The sordid details were relayed to the Dutch East Indies and India to break down resistance morale just before the fall of Java; it was "evidence" of how "democracies," when they have the opportunity, treat the colored races.

Both the President and Secretary of the Treasury Snyder have given their hearty endorsement to the voluntary anti-inflation program just announced by the American Bankers Association. This program represents a constructive plan of action which, if adhered to by the 15,000 member banks of that organization, can exercise a far-reaching effect upon the price and cost of living problem.

A SIX-CENT spurt in the price of hamburger a few weeks ago was particularly unwelcome to Martha Andrews. Martha is a 28-year-old housewife with a husband, Ted, aged 34, and three mall children -- Ted, Jr., aged 8; Jane, 2, and Robert, 7 months. While Ted was off fighting in Europe with General Patron's Third Army his mouth watered for Martha's baked hams and veal roasts.

The purchase of a pig in a poke is a gilt-edge speculation compared to the purchase of a hunting dog by mail, a fact that is sharply emphasized by many of the stories that have reached this desk during the past few months.

AT the dinner recently given him by the Bohemians in this city, Dr. Koussevitzky made some particularly timely remarks upon the position of the artist in the society of today. The keynote of his argument lay in the statement that whereas the artist in the nineteenth century could exist outside the social, political, and economic concerns of his age, the artist in the twentieth could not, and should not do so.

Mrs. Freund, in a recent letter, disagrees with Bosley Crowther's evaluation of "Mourning Becomes Electra," although nowhere does she document her defense of the film. She recoils with horror from the laughter of the audience during that "great play."

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Jan. 10 (AP) -- An aide of Michael, former King of Rumania, said today that Michael's expected marriage to Princess Anne of Bourbon-Parma was off, at least for the immediate future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A group of industrial leaders who had broad experience in dealing with the basic problems of resources mobilization in the second World War have been invited by Arthur M. Hill, chairman of the National Security Resources Board, to meet with him Wednesday to give advice on the scope and content of the general program of the board.

The state committee of the Liberal party formally rejected yesterday the third party candidacy of Henry A. Wallace for President, approved President Truman's message to Congress on the state of the Union, his program to combat inflation and the Marshall Plan.

IT is the peculiar role of the statistician to funnel innumerable facts through a mathematical mill and thereby to evolve gleaming summaries and conclusions. The classical grist for this mill has often sounded like the title of a doctorate thesis -- "the Cephalic Indices of 500 Tasmanian Bushmen," or other natural phenomena.
HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 10 -- Dartmouth's undefeated hockey team ran its victory streak to seven tonight by trouncing an aggressive Princeton sextet, 6 -- 2.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- More than 300 New York City residents, augmented by smaller up-state groups, conducted a "Citizens Legislative Conference" today at which Governor Dewey and the 1948 Legislature were asked to enact legislation that would virtually double the annual cost of state government.

THROUGHOUT the Eastern snowbelt operators of winter sports centers are gazing bug-eyed at their slopes, lifts and tows and at the tremendous throngs waiting in line to use them. This is something they have long dreamed of -- the biggest turnout of snowbirds this country has ever had in the comparatively short history of American skiing.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- One of the basic European aspects of Soviet foreign policy seems to be the encouragement of a federation of the Balkan and Danubian states. How far Moscow would like to go in this direction can by no means be ascertained. The extent would depend to a considerable degree upon how far it would be possible to go with the highly independent and inflammable material at hand.

The Government is understating its responsibility for high prices and its ability to control the price level with its present powers. It is overstating the case for the reimposition and extension of controls.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan 10 (AP) -- Sharpshooting Nelson Bobb hit the cords for 26 points to lead Temple University to a 58-to-54 victory over Duke tonight and break a three-game Owl losing streak in a basketball doubleheader at Convention Hall.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Howard Crossett, a lumberjack from Sutton, N.H., and his brakeman, Bill Trombley of Lake Placid, today won the Elizabeth Linney two-man bobsled trophy, clocking a total of two minutes, 21.65 seconds in four half-mile trips.

A threatened strike of employes of fuel carriers in this port was called off last night a half hour before the midnight deadline, when an agreement was reached at the Municipal Building between the operators and union representatives.

Donald William Dresden, writing of "The Twenty 'Noses' of France," fails to say that their occupation, like that of tea and wine tasters, prevents them from smoking pipes. I wish to remind you that this cruel disability is traditionally shared by professional baseball players under the direction of the distinguished Joseph McCarthy, late manager of the New York Yankees, current manager of the Boston Red Sox.

SENATOR LISTER HILL of Alabama has been nurturing a legislative baby for a long time. It was christened with the drab name of S-73 more than a year ago, and has been incubating ever since in the Senate Committee on Agriculture and Forestry.

DAVID GOODIS has decorated another cops-and-robbers story with the New Look. There is much Freud in the air, much Faulkner in the sentence, much Hemingway in the talk. But any way you slice it, it's the old chase again.

The wholesale markets last week were more active with a considerable number of out-of-town buyers in attendance, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

CARLOTTA IVES has confessed that she murdered her Aunt Sophie Willingham, under whose domination she has lived most unhappily since the age of 10. The only question seems to be whether Carlotta is mentally and morally responsible for what she says she has done.

MUCH has been written about the financially unsuccessful painter who constructed a simple but workable telegraph instrument that laid the foundation for an entire industry. Little, however, has been told about the details of the process by which the gifted, persevering Samuel F.B. Morse and his eager associates transformed the "magic wire," as contemporaries called it, into a going business concern.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Outplayed in the first half, Pitt's basketball team caught fire in the second session and chalked up its fourth straight victory by nosing out Army, 42 -- 41, in the big West Point Field House today.

ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Sounding a challenge for the coming $100,000 Santa Anit Maturity for 4-year-olds, On Trust whipped six rival California-breds today to win the $50,000 added Santa Catalina Handicap before a turnout of 51,500 fans.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 10 -- President Truman's message to Congress has a strong political taste to Democrats of this area, some of whom favor the Republican tax-cut program. Here were some typical expressions:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- City governments, with revenue collections and spending both on the upswing, reduced their total debt to $7,164,000,000 in 1946, the Census Bureau reports.

JERUSALEM (By wireless). As a dream nearly 2,000 years old nears fulfillment, the Palestine Jew makes light of the formidable obstacles ahead and sees only the imminent achievement of his national state, which to him means the end of the age-long wandering of his people.

MR. CONROY has contrived a chronological sampler of the humor that flourished in the Midwest or was written by persons born or brought up in that region. A good deal of it is of more historical than literary value, but there is enough in the book to remember and to cherish.

President Truman's message on the State of the Union was hailed yesterday for its "genuine optimism and faith in the future of America" by Rabbi Joseph Zeitlin in a sermon in Temple Ansche Chesed, 100th Street and West End Avenue.
WHILE the snow and the barometer dropped, the editor in charge of literary excerpts from English periodicals went right ahead with his work, and, the storm over, trudged in with a couple of items.
DETROIT, Jan. 10 -- Citizens here in general seem to have adopted a Missourian attitude toward the principles espoused by President Truman in his annual message to Congress.

Contract signing continues to be the fashion of the hour in major league baseball circles and yesterday saw both New York clubs weigh in with another batch of supposedly contented players who have accepted terms for 1948.

The Truman Administration strongly endorses the proposal embodied in bills before Congress providing for the admission of 400,000 refugees into the United States at the rate of 100,000 annually for four years, Charles E. Saltzman, Assistant Secretary of State for Occupied Areas, declared in an address here last night.

HAVANA, Jan. 10 -- The committee on restrictive business practices of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment today received a subcommittee report that somewhat weakened the authority of the proposed International Trade Organization over international cartels.

With leadership of division I in the Manhattan P.S.A.L. hinging on the result, Stuyvesant High School snatched victory from Seward Park, 40 to 38, in the thriller-diller finale to Madison Square Garden's four-game, six-hour schoolboy basketball matinee yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Air Force and the Navy are still using twenty-seven types of planes which no longer are being built, the Aircraft Industries Association reported today in a survey covering seventy-nine major varieties of aircraft and showing only twelve types both in use and in production.

CERTAINLY one of the most haunting and disturbing events of the season is Tchelitchew's show at the Durlacher Gallery, covering the period of his most impressive achievement, 1925-33, an achievement comparable to and deriving from the same sources of poetic melancholy as Picasso's "Blue" period.

The man who buys a boat must necessarily have a place to berth her. Those not members of yacht clubs very likely will make marinas the home ports of their vessels, so the marina becomes a matter of concern to many of the visitors at the Motor Boat Show.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Harold E. Stassen shaped up his Missouri organization today at the outset of a Western tour through ten States in the interest of his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination.

After its name had been brought before the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the quantity of M-3 explosive found near Asbury Park, N.J., last Thursday, the Jewish Agency for Palestine declared through a spokesman here last night that it believed the material to be legally purchased and awaiting legitimate shipment.
Herbert McKenley, the world's premier quarter-miler, dispelled a five-year-old jinx last night by winning an indoor race in this capital of board track competition for the first time.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 10 -- Less than five months after the constituting of a free India in the form of two dominions -- Moslem Pakistan and Hindu India -- the two countries are on the verge of war over the issue of Kashmir, a Princely State that adjoins the northern borders of both nations.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 10 -- Rupert C. Thompson Jr., president of the Providence National Bank, believes the President's message was colored by and was an answer to Henry A. Wallace's announcement that he planned to run for President.

Peruvian bonds which are being issued in exchange for those long in default are expected to be traded on the New York Curb Exchange before the end of the month. The new bonds, carrying a lower rate of interest than the original issue, are in process of registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MONTREAL, Jan. 10 -- The New York Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens fought to a 1-all tie tonight, both teams picking up a point in the National Hockey League standings in a game that was rugged, ragged and interspersed With bursts of good hockey despite close checking.

THERE is a disturbing tendency to consider atomic energy as if it were none of the American public's business. It is said that the subject is too "technical" -- that it is "over the heads" of the public; that "national security" requires that the public be kept in the dark, even on discussions of broad policy; or that the steps to be considered are such strong meat that all these matters must be withheld.

IN the world-wide contest between the United States and Soviet Russia, the nations of Latin America are becoming increasingly important. Notwithstanding repressive measures taken recently against the Communists in Brazil and Chile, the Communist movement in Latin America remains aggressively active.

SEVERAL readers have written to give parallels or to suggest possible sources for the famous phrase about fear which President Roosevelt used so effectively in his First Inaugural. Curiously, however, none has corrected this department's rendering of the phrase, which was set down from memory. It appeared here as "We have nothing to fear but fear itself.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- The United Nations celebrated its second anniversary as a going concern today -- it was on Jan. 10, 1945, that it set itself up in London, nearly a year after the Charter was signed in San Francisco.

MIAMI, Jan. 10 -- Airplane racing was given back to the spectator, the home-workshop designer and the pilot of limited means today when ten tiny "backyard" airplanes fought it out in two heats of the semi-finals of the Continental Trophy race of the All American Air Maneuvers.

Motor boat racing activities reached a new post-war peak in 1947. The American Power Boat Association sanctioned 143 regattas during the year, covering every section of the United States and reaching into both Canada and Mexico, from Lake L'Achigan, north of Montreal to Acapulco, Mexico and from Coos Bay, Oregon.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 10 -- Although Wisconsin is the Dairy State, its residents don't get any milk or butter bargains. The wholesale price of butter for this area is set by traders on the Chicago butter market.

Fellowships in biochemistry have been announced by Dr. Ellice McDonald, director of the Biochemical Research Foundation, and Dr. William A. Mosher, chairman of the Department of Chemistry, University of Delaware. The fellows will conduct independent research on the regular problems of the foundation under the direction of senior staff members of the two institutions and pursue courses at the university, which will lead to the Ph. D. degree on satisfactory completion.

Modesto Farolan, Philippine consul general at Honolulu, who is in New York on business, issued a reply her yesterday to James C. Needles, commander of the Hawaii Department of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, who had asked for Mr. Farolan's recall. The reply read:
Frigid weather closed in on the Northeast yesterday after two days of comparatively mild temperatures.

Ralph M. Arkush, general counsel of the Russian Orthodox Church of North America, said here yesterday that the rift in the church was due to the refusal of American clergy to pledge allegiance to the Russian Government.

HOW have the mixed peoples of Hawaii, with their widely divergent cultural heritages, been molded into a comparatively homogeneous American community? The answer given here by Dr. Burrows, a former Honolulu newspaper man turned anthropologist, is, briefly, this: the white man, largely by his technological superiority, early established dominance over the Polynesian natives of Hawaii .

The fourth annual in-service course for teachers, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES in cooperation with the Board of Education, is scheduled to begin Tuesday afternoon, Feb. 17. A series of nine weekly lectures, to be followed by five workshops, will be given.

GREENWICH, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Charles Brinton, national singles champion, and Stanley Pearson Jr., co-holder of the national doubles crown, moved into the semi-final round of the annual invitation squash racquets doubles tournament at the Greenwich Country Club and the Field Club of Greenwich as play started today.

ROME, Jan. 10 -- The Communist offensive against Premier Alcide de Gasperi's fifth Government, which was interrupted during the holiday season, was in full swing again today. While the nationwide bank strike still continued, general strikes were called or announced in four cities.

The old Hippodrome site -- one of the largest and most valuable vacant plots in the midtown business district of Manhattan -- has been purchased for erection of a parking garage to accommodate several thousand automobiles.

FROM her work to date, it is clear that Miss Babette Rosmond is a young and moderately traveled Woman-about-New York. Her first book, "The Dewy, Dewy Eyes," was duly noted and acclaimed a feminine version of "The Hucksters," written not without venom, and full of the particularized knowledge that comes of experiencing much of the material treated.
THE Rev. Peter Marshall, D.D., native of Coat-bridge, Scotland, and citizen of Washington, D.C., has been chaplain of the United States Senate only since last January, when his appointment was made.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 10 -- The Villanova basketball team routed Navy, 61 -- 39, today, handing the Middies their first setback of the season.

YOUNGEST sisters who are trying hard to catch up with the rest of the family will have an especially friendly feeling for Lisbeth Holly, who wasn't quite 10 and a trifle sensitive about being the baby of the family. But no matter what their rank in age, girls of 8 to 11 will enter whole-heartedly into the Holly children's good times during a summer on the shores of Lake Michigan forty years ago.

LORUS and Margery Milne are two young biologists, husband and wife, with a passion for facts. They have studied deeply, traveled a good deal and observed diligently. Out of their experience has grown this book which is packed with facts set down with enthusiasm and in readable detail.

IF the preparation of the United States draft plan for German reparations was as haphazard as both stated and implied in this book, one can only be amazed. Unfortunately, there is no reason to assume otherwise. The authors are economists, both of Duke University.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 10 -- The Inter-American Labor Conference opened here today after last night's conclusive demonstration that the combined opposition of the extreme Right and the extreme Left was insufficient to affect the project seriously.

The troubles of Palestine were emphasized last week by events that took place 5,800 miles apart. In New York's metropolitan area there were discoveries of illicit shipments of explosives destined for Jews in the Holy Land. In Palestine there was violent guerrilla warfare between Arab and Jew.

When France was liberated, the health of the French people became a matter of deep concern not only for the French themselves and their immediate neighbors but for the entire world. For the people of the largest nation that had endured Nazi occupation were undernourished and were living under tragic conditions of devastation wrought by bomb and shell.
The points advocated by Dr. Rufus S. Tucker in "What Danger of Another 1929?" as measures to combat inflation may have been applicable in some dead world, but will not serve today.

THIS is among the first books published in the new year, but the remainder of 1948 is not likely to produce a stranger, more arresting, more passionately intellectual novel. It gets under way as though it meant to become a Kansas version of Henry Bellaman's "Kings Row."

AT the opening performance of the D'Oyly Carte "The Pirates of Penzance" the other evening two schoolboys, properly chaperoned by their mothers, were sitting a little sheepishly in the row ahead. Now and then they were roused to admiration by a clever song or piece of humorous acting like Martyn Green's incomparable singing of the modern major-general tongue-twister and Richard Walker's pawky lament about the policeman's lot in the scheme of things.

Greater New York, with its unsurpassed connecting waterways, offers an ideal field for the development of pleasure boating. Motor boats based at New York can range up the magnificent Hudson to Albany and thence by canal to Lake Champlain and Canada or through the State Barge Canal to the Great Lakes.
The United States Coast Guard Auxiliary is the civilian component of the United States Coast Guard.

A GENERAL rise in the price of Defender enlarging photographic papers averaging an increase of 15 per cent is announced by the Du Pont Company, effective immediately. "Costs of materials and labor have been rising steadily both during and since the war, making this price increase necessary," the company announcement said.

BOMBAY, India, Jan. 10 -- The Indian Union will be compelled to attack tribal raiders in their Pakistan bases if a negative action results or procedural differences deadlock India's reference to the Security Council of the Kashmir issue, Shiekh Mohammed Abdullah, head of the Kashmir Emergency Government and Indian delegate to the United Nations, asserted today.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 -- Two concurrent conferences, a dramatized presentation of handling equipment, and continuous exhibition of what is said to be the largest and most recent collection of motion pictures on materials handling subjects will feature the opening of the Second National Materials Handling Exhibition at the Public Auditorium here on Monday.
An ex-convict who fled to Italy nine months ago and dodged detectives waiting on the pier when he returned here in November was seized yesterday as the fence a $100,000 textile theft.

WILLIE and Ham were Just a couple of average, small-town boys. That there was nothing ordinary about this particular summer was the result of their search for buried treasure. Everyone in the village knew there was treasure hidden near the old haunted house, and the boys decided to purchase a divining rod to find it.

A TREASURY of reading for yachtsmen is a peculiarly eclectic matter and its compilation calls for specialized knowledge as well as acceptable editorial judgment. As a specialist Critchell Rimington undoubtedly qualifies, for he has written much about the sea, is an editor of the magazine Yachting and knows both the sport and its literature.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 10 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission for the Establishment of a Korean Government will begin work here on Monday, it was announced today.

The Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court handed down a three-to-two decision against the Public Service Commission last Wednesday which may pose a new challenge to that agency's regulatory powers over utilities in the state, if the PSC decides to seek an appeal from the decision in the Court of Appeals.

Breaking loose in the second period and continuing to pour it on in the next three chukkers, the Jockey Hollow Polo Club's Johnson brothers trounced the Squadron A Falcons, 17 to 6, in a Metropolitan League high-goal match that featured the indoor double-header at the Squadron A Armory last night.

Olle Tandberg read himself right out of the heavyweight party last Friday night in Madison Square Garden as he flopped in his first American ring engagement as a professional. When Joey Maxim, outweighed twenty-nine pounds, handicapped proportionately in the matter of height and reach, gave the towering Swede a thorough going-over in ten listless rounds, Olle's usefulness as a heavyweight title potential ended before getting started.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- When New York's veterans of the second World War began last week to fill out forms to collect bonuses for their military service, a total of nine states as well as the territory of Alaska had provided for cash compensation for such service without qualification as to need.

MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 10 -- In the Ninth district for the four weeks ended Jan. 3, dollar volume was 14 per cent ahead of the comparable period a year ago, a gain of four points over the Dec. 27 figure. Customers' response to pre-inventory and clearance sales during the first full week in January indicated a continuance of the high level.

Ruins of once beautiful cities in Europe, correspondents tell us, are among the saddest and most depressing reminders of the World War. Yet just across the Mediterranean, on the northern rim of Africa, discerning correspondents are viewing ruins of once splendid cities with wonder and delight.

An Upper East Side apartment house superintendent and an undertaker were arraigned in Felony Court yesterday charged with first degree forgery and allegedly scheming to share the major part of a quarter of a million dollar estate of an 81-year-old spinster who died last June 30.
The police were questioning last night a 30-year-old man captured in an apartment house elevator and accused of having stolen $60 from a Lexington Avenue bookstore.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 10 -- The discovery of a big cargo of arms explosives in New York intended for shipment to Palestine has raised the question here of what other shipments may have gone through without discovery.

MAGGIE TEYTE does not appear often enough on records to suit the tastes of those who admire her musicianship and grasp of style. It is pleasant, therefore, to report this morning that a new album, all too thin, of her singing has been made available.

While the nation's public transit lines will offer improved equipment, safety and courtesy to their 67,000,000 patrons in 1948, higher fares appear to be an inevitable corollary, according to the American Transit Association.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Gardner Larned won a straight set victory over defending champion Bitsy Grant, in the semi-finals of the twenty-first Dixie tennis tournament today. Richard Gonzales was forced to five sets to beat Buddy Behrens.

THE scene of action alternates between Laredo, Tex., and Nuevo Laredo. Mexico. Larry Winter has come to these places to clear himself of a charge for which he has already served a prison term and to find a million dollars worth of jewels which he was accused of having looted from a castle in Germany.

THE meager, unsavory food in the Soviet slave-labor camp where "Prisoners of the Night" is laid "had not changed since the time of Catherine the Great." Little else has changed either, there in the Russian arctic.

CATALOGUES for 1948 have long lists of domestic and imported tuberous-rooted begonias. Plentiful foreign stocks, particularly from Belgium, have been added to the many thousands of bulbs now being grown in California.

THE well-upholstered gentlemen who direct the destinies of the nation's football teams have been milling around hotel lobbies for the past week like a herd of elephants. They kicked the conversational ball endlessly and enjoyed themselves to the full. One night they even had Governor Dewey and Mayor O'Dwyer in their midst but still they didn't veer away from their favorite topic.

NANKING, Jan. 10 -- A primitive kind of night bombing has been adopted by the Chinese Air Force in an attempt to break up Communist troop concentrations, it was learned today. Bomb crews are simply shoving missiles through the doors of low-flying transport planes over areas in which the Reds are believed to be concentrating for hit-and-run night raids.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 10 -- What appears to be a concerted campaign against the Zionists in Egypt was launched last night when the police searched fifty houses and hotels in Cairo and arrested a number of persons suspected of subversive activities. Among them were three young girls who were raising funds for the Zionist cause.

THE star dressing room at the Coronet Theatre has two comfortable chairs and, at the moment, two Christmas trees. When the holiday season finally is tucked away, if it ever is, the trees no doubt will be replaced by two boxes of spring flowers, then by two tennis racquets.

THE use of speed lights for portraiture was advocated by Jay Florian Mitchell, photographer, during a lecture-demonstration at the Miniature Camera Club last week. The new lights are revolutionizing photographic lighting, Mr. Mitchell claims.

FOLK music has come to town. Large, enthusiastic audiences patronize frequent performances in concert halls and night clubs, and buy up the enormous output of the record companies. So many newcomers are entering the field that there is said to be a shortage of guitars and zithers.

TRIESTE, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Allied Military Government informed Communists today it would enforce rigidly the law forbidding unauthorized demonstrations and the wearing of partisan uniforms in the United States-British zone.
More than 1,000,000 good turns by the Boy Scouts of New York last year were recognized yesterday when Deputy Mayor John J. Bennett gave a certificate of appreciation to the Scouts at City Hall.

ON the day after Independence Day, 1935, the Congress of the United States, which rather reluctantly had been passing out funds for the turbulent Federal Theatre, made obeisance to private enterprise and granted a charter -- but no funds -- to the American National Theatre and Academy.

BY realism in painting we mean two things: the subject matter is concrete, actual, credible and drawn from the world around us: and the artist is willing to let emotion or expression of an idea come as a by-product of more or less faithful representation.

APPARENTLY one of the more magnanimous persons on Broadway, Joshua Logan has taken the actor unemployment situation rather seriously. Now engaged in directing Henry Fonda and some thirty other players in "Mister Roberts," Mr. Logan had let it be known that he would not deal exclusively with agents and that anyone who applied would be seen and possibly heard for a role.

HERE are the Army amphibian engineers who had the safe job of coming up to the D-Day, H-Hour shore, and being a few hundred feet from the enemy instead of at his throat like the riflemen. Or was it safe? There was one school of battle thought that figured it was more dangerous being a little way back than right on top of the enemy.

In your Sunday Magazine an American, Anne O'Hare McCormick, writes cleverly and at length complimenting the English on their Spartan pluck. In the same Magazine an Englishman, J.B. Priestley, vehemently pans America, saying: "All that is wrong with our age, even when at its most prosperous, is shown here in sharp focus."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 10 -- Acting at the request of a permanent committee of the Arab League in Cairo, Egypt, the Government press directors of Syria and Lebanon asked local newspapers today to cooperate in a voluntary censorship.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 10 -- The man-in-the-street here apparently is more concerned with his personal affairs than in the State of the Union. A. sidewalk sampling of opinion showed that most persons were aware of the President's message to Congress, but not many with its contents beyond the proposed $40 cut in income taxes.
WENGEN, Switzerland, Jan. 10 -- Italy loomed as a genuine threat in the approaching winter Olympics today after taking the top honors in important preliminary tests.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Just as inevitably as high tide follows low tide, speculation rose today over a successor to the ailing Dick Harlow, who resigned yesterday as Harvard football coach.

An alternative report, calling for the immediate establishment of a state university, together with medical, dental and nursing schools, will be presented to the Commission for the Need of a University when it meets in Albany tomorrow.

COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY next Thursday will award the Alexander Hamilton Medal for "distinguished service and accomplishment" to one of its alumni. It is the second award; last year the medal was bestowed upon Nicholas Murray Butler. This year at a dinner at the Waldorf the alumni will honor the man who has served as president of Columbia for two years and has devoted his life to his alma mater.

AN opening bid of six in a suit has a conventional meaning, given in any bridge book that cares to go so far into the rarities of the game. The bid shows a hand that cannot lose a trick except to a missing ace, king or queen of trumps.
ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Governor Dewey made public today a State Food Commission report warning that food prices would remain at their present high levels for some time to come.

An entirely new procedure for obtaining legal sanctions to industry-wide trade agreements is being studied by management executives here.
