It is based upon invoking Section 6 of the recently enacted Anti-Inflation Act, under which Congress will approve industry-wide regulatory measures proposed by an Administration official following proof of necessity before a Congressional hearing.

ROCKLAND LAKE, N.Y. -- Every year about this time skate sails reappear on Rockland Lake and on its big sister, Greenwood. Skate sailing is perhaps the most rapid independent locomotion available to man. In airplanes, in automobiles, in iceboats, humans have certainly traveled much faster than the forty to fifty miles an hour achieved by the skate sailor.

IT looked like a thin summer vacation for Betsy Carr, who was going to stay home while her best friend, Ann, went to camp. But then Betsy found Chris, the puppy, and between them they took over the fenced-in yard around the proud house, thanks to Mr. Zukor, who had put the house up for sale.

IN choosing a title for this collection of notes and letters John McDonald undoubtedly was influenced by the title selected by Izaak Walton almost 300 years ago. To Walton as to Gordon, fishing was a "contemplative recreation," but one that demanded concentration, study and practice.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Drastic revision of the Administration's European Recovery Program by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee appeared certain today as Democratic members insisted on a more clearly defined administrative organization and challenged some basic specifications of the proposal.

As an addendum to your correspondence from Palestine published last Sunday, may I remark that several noted Palestinian musicians are now on a visit to our shores. Among the composers our guests are: Joachim Stuchevsky, who is also a concert 'cellist and lecturer; Solomon Rosowsky, equally known as a musicologist, and Jedidia Gorochov, an able song writer.

The National Student Association, representing 361 colleges and 2,000,000 university students in the United States, announced yesterday its support of President Truman's recent message to Congress urging extended authority for the Maritime Commission. The announcement is in line with the association's program for foreign travel and exchange projects for American students next summer.

The students of the Riverdale Country School, Riverdale-on-Hudson, sent $1,000 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund, the largest of their annual gifts to the appeal. Frank S. Hackett, headmaster, wrote in a letter that accompanied the gift:
LONDON, Jan. 10 -- A treaty of alliance between Britain and Iraq was concluded today. It replaces the pact signed in 1930.

POSTMASTER GENERAL JESSE M. DONALDSON announced last week that the stamp commemorating the discovery of gold in California a century ago will be a 3-cent purple of horizontal format for release on Jan. 24 with first-day sale in Coloma, Calif.

MR. WILBUR has not decided, or circumstances have not decided for him, whether to be a confessional or a projectional poet; whether to express personal frustrations or fulfillments, or whether impersonally to objectify phenomena, which is what I intend by the term projectional.

ALFRED HITCHCOCK, who has made a profession of frightening people who go to movies, has gathered together twenty-seven examples of "suspense'': twenty-five short stories of mayhem, mystery, and madness, one radio play, and one factual account of a great disaster.

THE moral of this story is: if you must have honey don't get caught snatching it! An easily absorbed and sympathetic lesson for the younger reader who operates personally on the same gratification principle as the big brown bear of this book.

Governor Dewey has been asked to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the assassination of Carlo Tresca, liberal editor, five years ago today. This was disclosed yesterday by Norman Thomas, Socialist party leader, in a speech at the Rand School, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Congress is scheduled to decide this winter what to do with the Government's synthetic rubber industry -- a healthy war baby that can produce almost all the rubber this country needs. There are these four possible solutions:

The decision of the Administration to drop the original $17 billion demand for a four and a half year European recovery program and seek annual appropriations instead is all to the good. It shows President Truman and his advisers responsive to growing public and Congressional resistance to long-term foreign commitments and to the statesman-like objections set forth by Senator Vandenberg.

GWYN THOMAS' fantasy is confined to a delightful turn of speech. His stories are made of bleak reality; his philosophy based on a wisdom bred of unremitting calamity. His setting is a Welsh mining community. The Terraces, hemmed in by tall blue hills and taller man-made towers of unemployment, starvation and despair.

NANCY is 12, quite old enough to take over the housekeeping in mother's absence, if only she knew how. This is a "how" book, charmingly disguised as the cheerful story of an eager little girl and her understanding mother. We follow Nancy step by step as she learns to cook, to clean, to shop for food, to acquire all the homemaking skills.

KINGSTON, N. Y., Jan. 10 -- Although possessing close to two feet of snow, more than they have had in many years at this time of the winter, the popular skilands of the Catskills forming a semi-arch north, west and southwest of this county, seat city were covered with gloom tonight.

The Italian liner Saturnia left here shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday some thirteen hours behind schedule, after being the subject of an intensive all-day search by Customs Officers on Friday. An extra detail of forty men was assigned to the vessel following the arrest of a member of her engine room crew on a narcotics charge.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- In the questioning of Ambassador Douglas, Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican of New Jersey, said he had heard complaints that the British loan was "wasted."

HALLAENDALE, Fla., Jan. 10 -- Buzfuz, one of the turf's true story book horses, carried the Miami-owned Sunshine Stable silks of Dan Chappell and Mose Rauzin to a scintillating triumph in today's $10,000 added Suwannee River Handicap at Gulfstream Park, witnessed by the waning meeting's second largest crowd of 16,138.

A seminar dealing with contemporary social problems arising from the "Great Issues of Today" will be inaugurated at the University of Denver with the beginning of the winter quarter this week. Similar to the Great Issues course introduced at Dartmouth College, the seminar will study the "Role of America in the Post-War World."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reports that total payrolls of Federal, state, city and county governments rose to a record monthly high of $1,180,600,000 in October.

Nine years ago Dr. Normal R.F. Maier made psychiatric history by announcing at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science that he could make rats so "nervous" that they broke down. His work was important because it made possible an experimental study of mental conflict and its consequences.

UNIONTOWN, Pa., Jan. 10 (AP) -- About 11,000 striking timbermen and sawyers in parts of Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Maryland today won the wage increase they had demanded. Their union leader said, however, they will not go back to work until the customers of their employers agree to higher prices.

PROFESSOR BARON appears to have two objects in this book. First, having found no comprehensive study "in any language" of the interrelations between nationalism and religion, he would, by this initial outline, stimulate further work in this field; and second, by revealing the intimacy of those relations, he would call on the religions of the Western World "to help create that large-scale climate of public opinion requisite for the creation of a constructive world order."
Although the market met increased liquidation of March and May cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday it finished 12 points higher to 4 points lower than on Friday.

Public opinion and emphasis in education against prejudice toward minority groups were cited as important factors in support of civil rights throughout the nation by high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.

Representative Frederic R. Coudert Jr., New York Republican, called upon the State Legislature yesterday to enable school boards to remove communist teachers if there were no reversal of the State Department of Education ruling that membership in the Communist party was not ground for dismissal.

A new record of 10,581 miles for regularly scheduled direct radiophoto transmission has been established between Washington and the U.S.S. Burton Island, headquarters ship of the present Navy Antarctic Expedition off the Shackleton Ice Shelf of the Antarctic Continent, it was announced yesterday by Navy headquarters in New York.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- State bonus payments amounting to $1,909,050 have been mailed during the first four payment days to 8,327 New York veterans of World War II, Leo V. Lanning, bonus director, announced today. More than 700,000 applications have been received so far.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- The conservative banker and the leftist labor leader in this metropolitan area shared the same view toward President Truman's message to Congress. They called it "political," and said the tax recommendations were impossible of passage in the Senate and House.

The United States Coast Guard has, for many years, been that agency of the Government charged with the enforcement of the Federal navigation laws. As a consequence, the Coast Guard has exercised not only a legal interest but has endeavored to maintain a weather eye to the safety of the pleasure boatman.

PATRICK WHITE'S third novel is a brilliant, original and highly intelligent piece of work. It is also, thank heaven, gay and witty -- as well as tragic, sometimes profound. Mr. White has the remarkable gift of adapting his prose according to climate, both geographical and human.

PRESENTED as the case history of a standard homosexual, this novel adds little that is new to a groaning shelf. Mr. Vidal's approach is coldly clinical: there is no real attempt to involve the reader's emotions, as the author sets down Jimmie's life story -- his first experience during his high school days, his life as a cabin boy, a tennis bum, his adventures in Hollywood and points East.

OCCASIONALLY the poison used so frequently in this story is supplemented by other lethal agencies such as blunt instruments and the like, but the arch-villain's chief reliance is on arsenic, of which there appears to be an abundant supply.

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Declaring that the cities and villages of New York face their most serious financial crisis in decades, the New York State Conference of Mayors today submitted to Governor Dewey and the Legislative a program designed to divert millions of dollars from the state to local treasuries.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 10 -- Having placed on the record their disavowal of a political state, the Germans turned today to the political possibilities in the new Bizonal Economic Administration. Right-Wing Christian Democrats appeared to be the dominant force by a slight edge over the Left-Wing Social Democrats with either a Christian Democrat or a Centrist as the probable Cabinet chief.

IT was quite a meeting the dancers staged at the Museum of Modern Art last Monday. Ever since last summer when an opportunity presented itself for the American dance to be represented at the Youth Festival in Prague and went by default because there was no organization of American dancers to take it up and push it through, there has been a feeling that something should be done to alter this situation.

THIS book is written out of the author's love for what he calls "Gothic England," that period extending in English history from 1300 to 1550. Like most people who write about the past, Mr. Harvey, English architect who has practiced in the restoration of medieval buildings, has an axe to grind.

THE present monograph is the first in the new "Direction'' series, published, naturally enough, by New Directions, as successor to its earlier imprint "Pharos." Issues of "Direction" will appear quarterly (four volumes on a subscription basis, $2), and the publishers announced "each number will be devoted to the work of a single writer, or to writings on one theme."
There is no accurate way of determining the increase of boating on the New Jersey inland waterways since the end of the war. Spot checks indicate anywhere from 10 to 100 per cent increase.
The fourth annual discussion of audio-visual aids to education was held yesterday in the American Museum of Natural History.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower was expected today to make an early statement on the move to press his nomination for the Republican candidacy for President in view of the filing of a complete slate of candidates for delegates pledged to him in New Hampshire.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Bobby Jahn of Cresskill, N.J., took the lead today in the sixteenth annual Eastern states speed skating championship when he won the 880-yard men's senior event.

The blueprints for America's course on the fateful year 1948 began to merge last week. With them there name the certainty that politics will revise these charts in many and drastic ways before they are translated into legislation.
I AM surprised and disappointed in the kind of criticisms your paper allows to be published.

The Rexall Drug Company's repackaging program, probably the largest ever attempted in the drug industry, is now rapidly nearing completion, Roland L. Baum, Rexall art director, announced last week. The project was started four years ago and called for redesigning of packages on 5,000 items in twenty different lines, ranging from pharmaceuticals, drugs and sick room supplies to nylons, golf balls and cosmetics.
Chimpanzees can detect odors imperceptible to man, but only when the odors are strange. Familiar odors are taken for granted just as by human beings.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- The Russian Orthodox Church has decided to try at a Court of Bishops the American Metropolitan Theophilus, leader of groups in the American branch who have discontinued communion with the mother church, Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported today.

DEL MONTE, Calif., Jan. 10 -- Slim Lloyd Mangrum, former United States open champion who hits his golfing stride with a bang every so often, took undisputed lead of the Bing Crosby $10,000 pro-amateur tournament today. He has a two-round thirty-six-hole total of 137 -- six under par.

" GARDEN SETTING FOR YOUR HOME," a series of talks to be presented at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, on four Wednesdays beginning Jan. 21, will cover some of the basic plantings on small properties.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 10 -- By a vote of 4 to 2 the Supreme Electoral Tribunal has approved the constitutionality of the law passed by Congress Wednesday night canceling the mandates of Communists holding elective office.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:
Columbia's favored basketball team revealed a dazzling passing game to subdue the Dartmouth quintet in an Eastern Intercollegiate League encounter on the Columbia court last night.

A FEW years ago Dola de Jong, of Holland birth, gave us a moving story of a Dutch family just prior to and during the Nazi invasion. Now we enter the Van Oordt household again, two years after the close of the war, and see in microcosm how many European families are striving to rebuild their lives.

A dash of yachting literature, a touch of cartoon comedy and a great deal of practical matter in text and scale drawings are blended into a small book that recently has appeared. It's The First Book of Boats by William and John Atkin, planned as a series "published as often as practical and possible, each featuring the designs of boats of yesterday, today and tomorrow."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 10 -- The ninth Pan-American Child Congress closed today with Dr. Gustavo Machado, its president, officiating.
Stanley M. Isaacs, president of United Neighborhood Houses, has requested a state hearing on the child care program in New York City, it was learned yesterday.
THE man who is looking for votes is Zachary Terrell, a Texas oil tycoon who is being groomed for the Presidential nomination Just as the nomination appears to be in the bag.

THERE was something noble in the grand illusion of Hegel that Reason is the force which rules the world. But by making it a quality of existence rather than of the way we think about existence, be claimed far too much for it.

Why was there an increased incidence of poliomyelitis among American troops in Japan during the past polio season? And why, generally speaking, is there such an increase wherever Western European adults go into such hygienically backward countries as Japan, India and North Africa, without a parallel increase in the native population?

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Jan. 10 -- Natural reportorial talents and skills acquired by experience make members of the Washington newspaper corps wise chroniclers of current history, Luther A. Huston, manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES Washington bureau, declared here today.

THE nurse asked her young patient. "Want to Lie down now, Gary?" The 6-year-old said, "I'd rather sit up." The nurse tried again: "But it is much easier if you lie down." This time the child said, "Oh, all right," and he lay down.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- New Englanders think President Truman started something with his state of the Union message, but they are not sure just what. They are inclined to believe it will lead to some tax reduction, and with that they are in accord.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 10 -- Prof. Edmund W. Sinnott, Dean of the Sheffield Scientific School and director of the Yale University Division of Sciences, will assume office next Thursday as president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

LONDON, Jan. 10 -- Now that Congress is considering the Marshall Plan for European recovery, it has been suggested that the committee of sixteen nations which last summer formulated the report of Europe's needs might reconvene. The purpose would be to draw up a report on the "self-help" aspects of the program.

-- Old Dobbin continues to give way to mechanical power. The total number of horses and mules on United States farms, a recent Government survey shows, has declined from a peak of 26,700,000 head in 1918 to 9,000,000. The number of tractors on farms today is nearly 3,000,000, or about twice the total in Use as recently as 1940.

IVA KITCHELL heads the week's calendar with her recital at the Ziegfeld tonight. Among her burlesques and satires are three new numbers: "The Tale of a Bird," which sounds a little as if it might be the saga of Swan Lake; "Portrait of a Hostess," and "Bacchanale," which comes direct from the opera house -- any opera house, perhaps, but don't be surprised if you recognize some particular one.
Several important decisions as well as the naming of the 1948 women's Curtis Cup team marked the United States Golf Association's fifty-fourth annual meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Twice a year, regular as clockwork, Florida's East Coast hotel men get the jitters. The first epidemic sets in early in November and it lasts until the December holiday trade comes booming in.

LAKE, SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- Its membership at last complete, the United Nations Palestine Commission began today a preliminary review of the work involved in the recommended partition of Palestine.

More even than the President's message on the State of the Union, the hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have begun to reveal the forces which will determine next November's election. The Republican party, whose latest President went out of office in 1933, has a real opportunity this year to win the White House and to enlarge its majorities in the Senate and House of Representatives.
The United States Power Squadrons look forward to the year just beginning as one of the most interesting and active in their thirty-four-year history.

JUST fifteen years ago this week in this Review: "The Biography of a British Statesman With American Principles" was the page one headline for the "Life of Joseph Chamberlain," by J.L Garvin -- the springboard for the headline possibly being the following: "The output of screws in England had been 70,000 gross a week.
PARIS, Jan. 10 -- Premier Schuman's success in inducing Parliament this week to adopt his drastic tax to combat inflation was noteworthy for several reasons.

THE tale of Paul Gauguin's life as an artist is a constant reiteration of financial crises. Raymond Cogniat writes in his delightfully illustrated life of this important precursor of modern art, "The most moving heroes are in real life the most deeply suffering victims."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Dr. Paul R. Hawley, former medical director of the Veterans Administration, was named chief executive officer tonight of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield prepaid health service plans.

New York Power Squadron faces 1948 confidently with a full slate in view; confidently because just astern is the memory of the largest advanced grades class in our history, the new course in seamanship which induced more than 100 to sit for the examination.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- The French Cabinet approved today a proposal to the former Emperor of Annam Bao Dai, calling for special conference of Viet Nam officials who have not taken up arms against France. This conference would seek conditions under which peace could be re-established in Indo-China.

NOT many knew it, but when Leonard Bernstein completed his season with the New York City Symphony in November with an exciting performance of Marc Blitzstein's "The Cradle Will Rock," the three-year-old association between conductor and orchestra was close to ending in a blaze of glory.

THOSE who remember Mary Jane Ward's study of private lunacy, "The Snake Pit," will expect clean writing and keen observation from her. In those respects, at any rate, her new study of a lunacy at once more public and more subtle will not disappoint them.

DURING the late war The New Yorker magazine's Talk of the Town department apparently began to sense a reader interest that broke out of past boundaries. Eugene Kinkead and Russell Maloney of its staff (the latter since resigned) were assigned to deal with this frightening new phenomenon.

THE Warner Brothers last week issued a film product announcement for 1948 which was significant because it omitted any mention of "Up Until Now," the anti-Communist picture which the studio announced with great fanfare last March.

The SOS (Supplies for Overseas Survivors) Collection of the Joint Distribution Committee announced yesterday that 9,114,000 pounds of canned foods, clothing and other relief supplies were donated to the SOS in 1947.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (Reuters) -- Charlton, winner of last season's Football Association Cup competition, advanced today to the fourth round of the current series when it beat Newcastle United, 2 -- 1, but Burnley, the other 1947 Cup finalist, lost unexpectedly to Swindon Town, 2 -- 0.

Savings bankers, hampered in their operations by the continuing shortage of suitable mortgage investments in this area, are planning an aggressive campaign to obtain legislative authority to make such investments anywhere in the United States.
LISTENERS on both sides of the Atlantic apparently have strong feelings about studio audiences and the uses to which they are put by some comedians.

WHY is it that press agents -- some press agents, in Hollywood and out -- try to invent pretty stories when the truth is the better yarn? Take the "official biography" of Alida Valli, as a Selznick Studio handout recalls it.
WHEN last I wrote in this column I hinted that my subject for today would probably be the Old Vic Company's production of Shaw's "Saint Joan" with Celia Johnson as the maid, and so it turns out.

The New York State Legislature last Wednesday opened its 171st session -- the sixth under the Governorship of Thomas E. Dewey. The Governor and his fellow Republicans were in strong command -- forty-one against fourteen Democrats in the Senate, D. against forty Democrats in the Assembly.

SOME shrubs are expendable; some are not. An expensive colorful shrub like an azalea, for example, will not solve the problems that arise on the north side of the house which gets little sun and moisture but plenty of wind.

MISS EARLY writes brightly, breezily, once-over lightly. Her vacation in the Creole city is a chatty affair, like the conversation of an easy-humored lady over gin-fizzes on a French Quarter gallery. Miss Early is out to pass on us, to see what catches the eye, what looks good and doesn't, what smells nice and doesn't, in this odd and often elusive metropolis by the Mississippi.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- Of all the proposals contained in President Truman's address on the State of the Union, his $40 cost-of-living income tax credit attracted the most interest among workers here.

When the members of the commission on the need of a state university meet tomorrow in Albany they will face momentous issues that will determine the future role of higher education in New York for many years to come. It is believed that the final report will be approved, establishing some form of a state-operated system of colleges and professional schools.
BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- A train derailment in the Back Bay station of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad today injured or shook up seventy-one of the 300 passengers.

Lured into Grand Central Palace on Lexington Avenue by the fluttering signal code flags outside on halyards, thousands of shore-anchored landlubbers yesterday joined thousands of salty old skippers with sea water in their veins for the first full day of the thirty-eighth annual National Motor Boat Show.

That structure was wrecked by two global wars and a devastating depression, and we now have to make a conscious effort to replace it.

The progress of recreational boating can well be dramatized by a comparison of the first National Motor Boat Show in 1905 and the thirty-eighth repeat performance of this exposition now in progress at Grand Central Palace.

On Friday, over the vehement protests of Dr. Ulloa of Peru, and with Colombia, El Salvador, Iraq and Saudi Arabia abstaining, the interim agency accepted a United States resolution postponing consideration of the matter until March 15.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 10 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, has cleaned house of "nonbelievers" at the union's regional office here, but he still must tread softly in Flint.

With more than 200,000 members in the Outboard Boating Club of America, and with a nation-wide organizational structure recently completed by the election of officers, the opening month of 1948 marks the emergence of O.B.C. as the largest and best-integrated boating club in the world.

THIS is R.P. Blackmur's third book of poems. Since the publication of his first, "From Jordan's Delight," ten years ago, he has been maneuvering himself steadily and insistently away from that book's relatively simple lyricism toward poems marked by great seriousness and considerable individuality -- muscular, intricate, devious, crafty, recalcitrant, and among the most curious of the time.

Financial markets, in the first full week of the new year, pursued an irregular course. There was a smaller reinvestment demand for stocks than had been anticipated as traders awaited President Truman's message to Congress on the state of the Union.

IF this season is to be judged by its beginning, food for birds and shelter while they eat are gong to be essential for their survival. The deep snow covering a great part of this section completely wiped out natural sources of food, such as weed heads and grasses, and even those normally offered by smaller berried shrubs.

NANKING, Jan. 10 (AP) -- A Government statement that it had inflicted 40,000 casualties on the Communists in southern Manchuria in a major victory highlighted far-flung reports of the Chinese civil war tonight.

HOW much longer are we Americans going to play the role of provincial suckers? How much longer are we going to endure the impositions practiced upon us by the various impresarios, directors and conductors, native and foreign? When are we going to insist that, when a foreign composition to a text is presented to us, it be presented to us in English?

With a minimum of opposition and surprisingly little discussion, the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday closed its forty-second annual convention by adopting the "principles for the conduct of intercollegiate athletics" that are popularly referred to as the "sanity code."

The Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Series gave itself a twenty-fifth anniversary party during its concert at Carnegie Hall yesterday morning. The hall was filled with children to partake of the music, slide pictures, speech making and gift giving, all presided over by Rudolph Ganz, conductor for the series.

TOKYO, Jan 10 -- Official figures fail to support Allied headquarters' claim that Christianity is staging a great revival in Japan. The rebuilding of war-damaged religious installations is proceeding slowly, although fourteen of the hundred Quonset churches planned for 1947-48 are now in use.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 -- Five guideposts for those in the selling profession were suggested here today by Alfred Schindler, former Under-Secretary of Commerce, at the Ninth New England Sales Management Conference in the Hotel Statler.

ONE difference between the two, major, English-speaking democracies is that Parliament sometimes turns up an intentional humorist, whereas Congress tends toward humor by inadvertence. Credit A.P. Herbert to the British.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- A woman believed to be the wife of Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, was named tonight on a list of 2,006 persons who were trading on the New York Cotton Exchange seventeen months ago.

Monica Mais, coloratura soprano, who made a successful debut two years ago, proved again last night at her second Town Hall recital that she is a skillful, attractive and artistic singer. Her voice was fresh and true, her diction clear and her manner gracious.

NANKING, Jan. 10 -- Government sources here believe that the Communist, hoping to achieve a complete defeat of the Government armies in Manchuria this year, are making plans for an autonomous Manchurian Government to take control of the whole of China's northeast Provinces.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 10 -- Arab attacks in the last two days have assumed a scale and organization net seen before, suggesting that they are part of a general plan.

PARIS, Jan. 10 -- It is expected here that Britain and France will summon a meeting in Paris in February of the Cooperation or Steering Committee of the European Economic Conference created in response to the Marshall proposal.

Even under an overcast sky, a snow-covered night is not a night of darkness. It is a night of black and white and gray, all faintly aglow; and once the human eye has accustomed itself to it, there is much to be seen and even more to be sensed. But it is seen and sensed in different terms than by daylight.

NOW that Reginald Denham and P.W.T. Ross have both raked our actors across the coals, especially our "youngsters," I'd like to have a word. I don't in the least disagree with their claim that many actors can't even read and are out solely to get a job, whether they are fitted for it or not.

THE great commercial sailing vessel and the line-of-battle ship have gone from our seas. To remind us of centuries of sailing history there remain only the small cargo and fitting craft of the world's out-of-the-way ports, and the modern yacht.
I COULDN'T help but feel somewhat nonplussed on reading William N. Robson's discussion, "A Casting Formula," in THE TIMES of Jan. 4.
" OPERA FOR COLLEGE" is ready for the road. Moritz Bomhard and Adolph Anderson who conceived the project, have modified their original plans, but they have found their basic idea was workable.

Administrators in the field of education were urged yesterday to adopt some of the methods employed by industry in establishing a wider public appeal for their accomplishments, in an address by Glenn Griswold, editor of Public Relations News, at the close of the Eastern district conference of the American College Public Relations Association.

JEAN COCTEAU, one-time enfant terrible of Paris arts and letters, has reappeared in the film world with all his old creative agility. His highly individual films, "La Belle et la Bete" ("Beauty and the Beast") and "L'Eternel Retour" ("The Eternal Return"), are successfully on display in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Senator Styles Bridges, Republican, of New Hampshire, disclosed today that President Truman had rejected a request which he made last Dec. 10 for preparation of the President's message on the Federal budget along traditional lines this year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The Republican-sponsored constitutional amendment limiting future Presidents to two full terms has no chance of ratification in 1948 because not enough state legislatures will be in session.

Challenge may be undertaken in the Cuban courts of the constitutionality of the Presidential decree placing restrictions on relations between foreign concerns and their agents in Cuba, it was reported here last week. Meanwhile, numerous protests regarding the action have been or will be made to the State Department by American concerns on several grounds, notably discrimination.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 10 -- The state of the Union is of surprisingly little concern to a majority of Greater Clevelanders if a "man in the street" poll taken here today is a criterion.

IN his criticism of "Antony and Cleopatra," in which Katharine Cornell has "returned as Cleopatra in one of her most decorative and regal performances," your critic says of the playwright, Shakespeare: "He was no scholar but a poet and dramatist."

AMERICAN ignorance of things American is not, as seems generally supposed, a product of sheer stupidity. It is rather more the product of a surfeit of provincialism and traditionalism. Any intersectional curiosity we may feel is usually satisfied by the stereotyped caricatures: our knowledge of other sections is too often -- and the spelling should be noted -- dialectal.

When it became apparent in the 1930's that the League of Nations was not able to meet its primary objective of preventing war, in the minds of most citizens the League was a failure. The scores of activities in government, labor, education, health and social welfare in which the League made notable contributions were so far overshadowed by the importance of this primary objective that they went virtually unnoticed.

WITHOUT waiting for the Federal Communication Commission's scheduled review on March 1 of its ban on partisan editorializing by a radio station, Nathan Straus, owner of WMCA, has decided to employ his own outlet's facilities to champion a plan for self-supporting public housing.

AS usual, this corner has been treated to the favor of some rather tart dissents on its recently published opinions of the best pictures and the best achievements of the past year. And, as usual, this writer has been grateful for the interest and the spirit they expressed.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan 10 -- A prediction that construction would start in a week or ten days on five round-the-world passenger-cargo ships for American President Lines, at a cost of about $50,000,000, was made today by George Killon, president of the lines.

TOKYO, Jan. 10 -- The Japanese Government's program of collecting grain from farmers at prices far below the open market to provide low-cost rations to the hungry city populations appears this year to be meeting with considerable success.

ANOTHER step in the development of the Caribbean area for the tourist trade is the opening of the Gauna Island Club to the public. Some twenty-five miles from St. Thomas, the island of Guana was not on the ship and air routes until quite recently.

A BRICK house built in 1832 in the Yorkville section of Manhattan was the raw material from which designer Harold M. Schwartz created three duplex "professional" apartments, each equipped with that old-fashioned feature, "an office in the house." While many a remnant of early Victorian architecture survived the remodeling, the choice of new materials was straightforwardly modern.

During the Coast and Geodetic Survey published new editions of seven nautical charts covering the water approaches to New York. The new editions are based on modern hydrographic and topographic surveys and incorporate the latest, available information required for safe navigation in these waters.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- Florida's West Coast tourists are experiencing, for a change, a partial buyer's market, but not one that will save them much money this winter. Nor does it show any signs yet of affecting the amount of business the resort operators expect to do this season.

THE phrasemaker who first named a certain layer-cake "Washington pie" must have had the city in mind rather than the squire of Mount Vernon. More than any other city, Washington is a superimposition of layers -- official and unofficial layers; Army layer and Navy layer (despite unification); Congress layer and Administration layer; secretaries to Congressmen layer and Government clerk layer, and among Washington's colored population there's a layer-cake in miniature.

Concert audiences of this city have not been as fortunate as the gathering that assembled in Studio H-8 and the much vaster audience of the air which heard Erich Kleiber conduct a program with the NBC Symphony Orchestra yesterday afternoon in Radio City.

MAY I, as a young, native actor, answer P.W.T. Ross (writing on Jan. 4), who agrees with Reginald Denham that many actors "cannot read," and who poses the question "When shall we have native actors, and young ones at that, of the Gielgud, Olivier and Wolfit type?" * * *

Retail trade here last week staged a good recovery after the unsettlement of the previous week caused by effects of the bad weather. Increases for department stores ranged up to 10 per cent, the gains being on top of the sharp sales upswing a year ago.

AFTER a retirement lasting eight years "The Colophon" emerges with little change in manner or spirit. The same editors who guided it before the blitz are back on the job, the original format has been retained, and the quondam typographical excellence has been upheld.

W.E. Farbstein's listing of unusual obituaries of 1947 in the New Year's issue of THE TIMES Magazine naturally was limited to humans. Without disrespect, it should also be noted, however, that certain prominent animals died that year.

ATHENS, Jan. 10 (UP) -- The Greek Army has launched an offensive against a large force of Gen. Markos Vafiades' guerrillas at Philiates, in Epirus near the west coast and about five miles from the Albanian border, military authorities announced today.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- Political life under Soviet rule is scarcely distinguishable from that under Adolf Hitler, Jakob Kaiser, ousted chairman of the Soviet zone Christian Democratic Union, declared today. He said his party crisis was a matter of concern for the entire world.

In the summer of 1722 the editor of The New England Courant, published in Boston, was in jail. He had, it seems, printed a story which wasn't true. His name was James Franklin. His younger brother, Benjamin, who was also his apprentice, continued to get out The Courant, and while James was still behind bars Benjamin wrote a defense of a basic right.

Speakers for the annual Alexander Hamilton dinner, which will honor Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia University at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel next Thursday, were announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, general chairman of arrangements.

PRAGUE, Jan. 10 -- The police in Bratislava suppressed yesterday the early edition of today's issue of the newspaper Cas, organ of the majority Slovak Democratic party, for charging the police with using Gestapo methods to obtain confessions from persons allegedly connected with a "conspiracy."

ALBANY, Jan. 10 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey's drive to win the Republican nomination for Presidents a second time entered a new phase this week as the Senate Legislature, both branches of which are Republican-controlled, started its 171st regular session.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The slight tremor felt on Capitol Hill at approximately 1:30 P.M. Wednesday was occasioned by the sudden dropping of a percentage point in the popularity rating of President Truman with the membership of the Eightieth Congress, second session.

The United States must be prepared to back its commitments in Greece with force or face a "tremendous setback" of the European Recovery Plan, Paul Porter, chief of Washington's former Economic Mission to Greece, declared yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Indian Army troops supported by planes smashed Moslem forces in the Naoshera area of Kashmir and forced them to flee, leaving large quantities of ammunition, an Indian communique announced tonight.

THIS first of a series on the peoples whose national stock and cultures have gone into the making of the United States is a somewhat uneven effort to comply with the enlightened point of view set forth in the foreword by the editor of the series, Louis Adamic.

WASHINGTON, Jan 10 -- Intent on putting through a veto-proof tax reduction bill of their own, Republicans cast hardly a passing glance at President Truman's cost-of-living tax adjustment scheme when he presented it to Congress this week.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN'S ten-year plan which he put before the opening of Congress last week in his state of the Union message is not likely to do much better than the ten-point program he placed before the session he called in mid-November. That was the inference to be drawn from comment by the Republican leadership which called the costs too high and was particularly critical of his tax proposal.

BERLIN, Jan. 10 -- Price control in the United States and British zones faces one of the severest crisis since the beginning of the occupation, Military Government officials disclosed today. The legal division of the Military Government has supported a decision by a German court that approximately 125 price-control ordinances put into effect in the last two years are not legally binding over German manufacturers or retailers.

AT the Macbeth Gallery Clay Bartlett's paintings reveal him to be working out a style which combines somewhat primitive approach with abstract and expressionist elements, especially in two studies of buildings in a state of demolition.

AS any fairly conducted Gallup poll will show, the average American heart leaps up when it beholds a new book by Ogden Nash. Few of our national bards, past or present, have so consistently, with so light and sure a touch, illuminated the inconsistencies and capriciousness of contemporary life.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP) -- The State Department estimated today that Great Britain needed $5,348,000,000 in outside financial help under the Marshall Plan -- almost twice as much as any of the other participating countries.

The gas industry recorded unprecedented expansions during 1947, particularly in the natural gas branch, where capacity of the nation's pipeline system increased by nearly two billion cubic feet a day. This is the equivalent of 80,000 tons of coal. Involved in that growth were 5,370 additional miles of pipelines, bringing the network up to 229,000 miles, or the same mileage as trunk line railroad tracks in the country.

Eleven months before the Japanese began dropping their bombs on Pearl Harbor, six private service organizations that already were rapidly expanding their activities to take care of the increasing demands from new military camps and war production centers decided to pool their resources and their brains to meet the emergencies that were clearly visible ahead.

In his message on the state of the Union, President Truman recommends that every individual taxpayer be given a cost-of-living tax credit of $40 and a like credit for each dependent. He says that "Government revenues must not be reduced" and proposes that the loss of revenue resulting from the tax credit be made up by increased taxes on corporations.
Such articles as "The Twenty 'Noses' of France," by Donald W. Dresden, are the cause of much indignation in certain households in our community.

Richard A. Knight, the disbarred lawyer, whose many eccentricities, including standing on his head in the foyer at a Metropolitan Opera performance, gained him wide publicity in recent years, was found dead at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon in his home at 7 East Ninety-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 -- Business men interviewed on Chicago's streets and in offices for opinions on President Truman's State-of-the-Union message were highly critical in their remarks, while laboring men were mostly praiseful and the banker and farmer voiced both approval and criticism.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 10 -- Those "ham and eggs" and "thirty dollars every Thursday" movements which from time to time in the last decade have colored the California economic scene are seeking the spotlight again.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 10 -- Reaction in the deep south to President Truman's message to Congress appears to have been very mild. Politicians and leading business men seemed eager to discuss its significance. But the man-in-the-street generally remarked that it was a Presidential year and added:

NEARLY 50,000 official documents containing uncounted millions of words -- background papers, reports, press releases, ambitious plans disguised in heavy technical language, agendas and minutes of meetings -- have poured from the presses of the United Nations since it moved to this country in March last year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- Statisticians in the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics have prepared a critical analysis of the comparison published in THE NEW YORK TIMES last Dec. 21 of the new Soviet price schedule with prevailing United States prices.

THE steamship lines are beginning to catch up in their race to get enough ships on the seas to meet the demands of both the pleasure traveler who wants to take a cruise, and of the business traveler. One by one, ships long delayed in re-conversion from war duty are returning to the type of service they performed before hostilities.

BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 10 -- The voting public in this Northwestern state is profoundly interested in the possibility that Idaho's senior United States Senator, 43-year-old Glen H. Taylor, may run for Vice President on the third-party ticket headed by Henry A. Wallace.

THE principal contacts that the casual visitor to Hawaii has with Hawaiians, are with the beach boys at the Outrigger Club, the Royal Hawaiian, the Halekulani or one of the other Waikiki hotels; or with the hula dancers at Queens Surf.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The State Department clamped down on exports of war surplus radar equipment tonight after Representative Ross Rizley, Republican, of Oklahoma, protested that some such supplies were going to Russia.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 10 -- With Capt. Bob Gale and Ed Peterson scoring 18 points apiece, Cornell remained undefeated in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by overwhelming Harvard, 57 -- 45, before 7,500 fans here tonight.

Lack of Federal attention to the Long Island inlets and waterways during the period of the war has brought about the pressing need for immediate improvements to the easterly channels extending into Mill Basin in Jamaica Bay and the stabilization of Jones Inlet, Fire Island Inlet, Moriches and Shinnecock Inlets.

Retail store activity in all departments last week was termed "good" in the weekly survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Continuing activity was reported in North Shops, housedress departments and lingerie departments. Home furnishings were good and "white events" were drawing crowds to linen departments.

BACK in the early days of commercial aviation the airlines knew that the majority of their passengers came from a relatively small group of people who used the airplane repeatedly in the course of a year. They tried to enlarge this basic group, but at the same time they had a feeling that air travelers would always be a comparatively small group.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 10 (AP) -- Sidetracking of a campaign to end promotional pay increases for teachers in favor of a drive for immediate salary rises was advocated today by the Executive Committee of the State Teachers' Association.

Form in basketball means as much as it does in any other sport, except when intracity rivals cross paths. Then facts and figures fall by the wayside just as they did last night at Madison Square Garden, where C.C.N.Y. toppled Manhattan College, 46 -- 43. Nat Holman's Beavers were favored and came through, but the margin was hardly convincing.

RECENTLY Filippo del Giudice, self-classified "impresario" of films, announced that he would take his Pilgrim Pictures producing organization to America if England wouldn't give him sufficient financial backing.

A full week of sales dispersing books, furniture and art objects at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, will begin tomorrow with a two-day auction of books on armor, arms, art, French and German literature and other literary property collected by the late George L. Shearer and others.

LAST week the post-holiday floodgates opened and some sixty exhibitions poured into local show places. Work in every phase of contemporary art and in all media made its appearance. Anyone who wishes to survey the various aspects of modernism may do so to his heart's content.

Dr. Joseph G. Hamilton and Dorothy Axelrod of the University of California have devised an ingenious technique for studying the biological action of the radioactive elements with which engineers who design and run atomic power plants must reckon. What are called "radioautographs" are taken of slices of bones removed from animals that have received an injection of a radioactive element.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Signing of a $7,000,000 steel and coal contract with the Japanese Board of Trade was announced today by a Los Angeles import-export firm which interpreted the transaction as signaling re-establishment of large-scale world trade by Japan.

ENGINEERING data ranging from developments in the production of smaller and lighter automobiles to research for cutting costs of motor fuel will be presented at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers which opens today in Detroit.

FROM Odysseus to Nimitz man has struggled to define -- in saga, story, chantey and yarn -- the unusual interplay of forces between those nautical sibilants, seas, shores, sailors and ships. After Pearl Harbor we began to get books like "Beachhead on the Wind," depicting the dirty hardships of the Coast Guard; books like "The Ship," wherein the personality of the vessel is the sum total of its personnel.

ROME, Jan. 10 (UP) -- Italy's third major political movement, the National Bloc, was created formally by Independents, Liberals and Rightists. Preliminary announcement of the new bloc came early this week. It will strive to win power for the middle-class in Parliament in the April general elections.

CHICAGO, Jan. 10 (AP) -- Grains failed to move far in either direction today on the Board of Trade, although the undertone was firm and most contracts held on to small fractional gains made in early dealings.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 10 -- After tossing away a lead that reached 12 points at one stage, Penn's basketball team came back in the final moments to score a 59-56 decision over Yale in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game here today before 2,000 fans.

ONE of the cultural wars Hitler didn't win was his Kampf against the gypsies. Although very considerable numbers of the polyglot people who call themselves "Romany" were put to death in the process of "race purification," gypsy music and gypsy dancing, best known of the gypsy arts, have carried on.

GENEVA -- The Winter Olympic Games to be held at St. Moritz from Jan. 30 to Feb. 8 are expected to bring many visitors who will remain after the Games to visit Switzerland's other winter resorts and to travel in this country whose life appears practically untouched by the effects of World War II.

A complete crew for the converted one-class liner Washington will be in school at the Maritime Commission training center at Sheepshead Bay tomorrow, preparing to take over the ship at the end of the week and place her in service.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- The party division in Congress is such that, if the Republicans divide evenly on the main points of the European Recovery Program the basic project probably would still have majority support. This prospect is fixed by the expectation that the Democrats will reveal no large percentage of dissenters on the plan as it is finally legislated.

A sharp increase in the cash position of leading banks here and a further reduction in holdings of Government securities in the final quarter of 1947 were made known in a survey of the statements of condition of the fifteen largest banks in New York.

PRIVATE detective John Marshall and his wife Suzy, are accused of murder by indirection. They are said to have caused the police to raid the apartment occupied by Chester McFarland, who was killed when he attempted to escape.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -Representative John McDowell, Republican, of Pennsylvania, said today the United States consular official who issued a visa to Ferenc Vajta, alleged former Nazi official of Hungary, will be summoned from Madrid to explain his action.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -Edwin W. Pauley said tonight he had made $932,703.10 in commodity trading in the last three years, but had done it without benefit of inside Government information.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The first mammoth blueprint for an international program of research and development in the 2,600,000-square-mile "subcontinent" of the Amazon jungle will be completed by the United Nations this week, it was learned today.

Citation, the Calumet Farm colt that seems certain to be the winter book favorite for the Kentucky Derby, and Bewitch, the Calumet filly that bewitched the opposition in her first eight starts last year, share top-of-the-roster honors in John Blanks Campbell's Experimental Handicap weights, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Sample copies of the new check-size personal income tax form which persons required to file returns for the state income tax may use at their option were made public today by Alger B. Chapman, president of the State Tax Commission.

Much has been said, and truly, about the terrific burden of the Presidency. Something might be said also about the terrific burden which is nowadays laid on Congress. The two houses now have before them the recommendations made by President Truman in his message on the State of the Union, touching on taxation, the fight against inflation and the broadening of social welfare.

" The Steep Places," an analysis of world politics by Norman Angell, has been scheduled for publication on Jan. 21 by Harper. Mr. Angell is the author of "The Great Illusion" and "Let the People Know" and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1934.
A $25 gift "in honor of all those who have done their share to alleiate the sufferings of others" was among the twenty-two contributions received yesterday by the Neediest Cases Fund.

Increased production will not of itself solve the problem of rising prices and rising living costs in the United States. It will not solve that problem because production, broadly speaking, results in a balanced equation. For every dollar's worth of goods or services produced, a dollar in new purchasing power is created.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 11 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine has informed Secretary General Trygve Lie that Moshe Shertok, head of its political department, will serve with the United Nations Palestine commission.
ROME, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Italian tax collectors will go on strike tomorrow in support of the twelve-dayold walkout of the country's bank workers, it was announced tonight.

DEVON, Pa., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Mrs. Marion Churchman Newbold, 29, of Babylon, N.Y., member of a socially prominent family of the Philadelphia area, was injured critically today when an automobile in which she was riding crashed with another car near here, pinning her under the wreckage.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that he would move speedily to obtain grand jury indictments against two men seized Saturday on charges of plotting to obtain the bulk of the $250,000 estate of Miss Mathilde Molsberger through a forged will.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 11 -Boulder Brook Club won a pair of polo games for the second successive week this afternoon at the local arena. The Boulder Brook Whites romped over a threesome from New York Squadron A, 13-8, in the first game while the Boulder Brook Greens eked out a 14 to 13 verdict from the Pittsfield (Mass.) Polo Club.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- The mind of Western Europe has been more concerned with the Marshall Plan during the last few days than at any time since the sixteen-nation committee met in Paris last September. Sir Edmund Hall-Patch, economic adviser of the British Foreign Office, has been here discussing technical details of the recovery program, and tomorrow M. Herve Alphand, his French opposite number, goes to London to arrange for reconvening the Paris conference.
Municipal issues of securities coming up for sale this week aggregate $64,999,434, compared with $51,801,810 last week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer.

A news report from Geneva, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 9, informs us that 19,899 displaced persons were resettled during the month of October, 1947, under the auspices of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The upheaval caused in the stock markets by the vast issue of Government stock following the nationalization of railways at the beginning of the new year has subsided largely, but its influence on the investment policy will remain for some time to come.

Police officials declared yesterday that they had smashed one of the biggest policy rings in the city. The announcement came after twenty plainclothes men had completed four raids in Brooklyn, during which ten men were arrested for possessing policy slips and conspiring to operate a lottery.

OLD POINT COMFORT, Va., Jan. 11 -- A three-day southern conference on conservation, sponsored by the Southern Association of Science and Industry, opened here tonight with a panel discussion on the "Conservation Implications of Atomic Energy."

Two hundred men, women and children made a symbolic "journey to Bethlehem" yesterday at the afternoon service in the Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street. Representing guilds of St. Augustine's chapel, Henry and Scammel Streets, and Trinity Mission House, 211 Fulton Street, as well as the women's auxiliary of Trinity Church, the group marched through the aisles in an Epiphany procession to a manger in the north aisle, where special prayers were said.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Anthony Callipare of Rochester won his third successive skating championship here today when he topped the men's division of the Eastern States speed competition.

Mayor O'Dwyer is strongly opposed to the $500,000,000 St. Lawrence Seaway project regardless of what support it may have in other quarters, it was learned yesterday. It was predicted that the Mayor -if he has not already done so -would soon put his opposition on record in Washington where the project is due for early consideration in the Senate under a priority obtained by Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan.

Dean Cromwell of Southern California, who has produced more Olympic champions than any other coach in this country, yesterday was named head coach of the 1948 United States Olympic track and field squad.

WARSAW, Jan. 11 -- The Polish and Czechoslovak Governments are considering a project for partial integration of their industries, it was learned today. The first phase of the project -- for building a jointly owned electric power plant on Polish soil -- already has been approved by technicians of both countries.

The liberation of India offers a great opportunity for Christianity to advance in that country because it removes completely the basis of the old charge that it acted as a tool of British imperialism, the Very Rev. S. Nazir Talibuddin asserted yesterday at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Net profit of the International Shoe Company for the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30 was $14,002,017, equal to $4.11 a share, according to the annual report mailed yesterday to 11,000 stockholders. The earnings, which represent 4.6 per cent of the total value of products manufactured by the company, compare with $5,448,781 earned in the preceding fiscal year.

Countrymen respect the gadgets and wavy-lined graphs of scientists who plot the complicated weather maps. Farmers conscientiously read the reports in the paper and listen to the voices on the wireless, although they wish the prognosticators would dispense with so many qualifying statements.

Half a dozen openings have been crowded into the season's busiest week on Broadway. Two of them will be presented tonight. They are "Harvest of Years" at the Hudson (an interim booking there until "Man and Superman" is transferred into that house Feb. 16 from the Alvin), and "Iolanthe" at the Century.

PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Finance Minister Rene Mayer's speech broadcasted on last Thursday was considered a frank and energetic answer to the demonstrations organized by industrial, commercial and agricultural unions and by unionized members of the liberal professions.

Republican enrollment in 1947 dropped sharply in twenty-six upstate counties while the Democratic enrollment increased, Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, said yesterday and added that this indicated that New York State would be in the Democratic column in next November's Presidential election.

When in June, 1945, statesmen signed a charter pledging "We, the peoples of the United Nations, determined to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war," the clear and obvious pledge was to save children. But that pledge has never been kept. Millions of children throughout the world can attest to the broken pledge -- with their broken bodies, hunger edemas, homelessness, sickness of spirit and their graves.
ELGIN, Ill., Jan. 11 (AP) -- West Allis, Wis., won the team championship of the Tri-State open skating derby today, following up its victory in the Western open yesterday.

Twelve new sealed-bid catalogue sales, offering about $4,000,000 worth of supplies and merchandise from centers in Long Island City and Newark and a $2,000,000 spot-bid clearance sale at the Newark center on Jan. 22 were announced over the week-end by John R. Campbell, regional director of the War Assets Administration.

Nathan Wilson bought and resoldthe five-story building on a lot 24by 55 feet at the northwest cornerof Third Avenue and Thirty-fourthStreet in a deal negotiated byEmanuel Kreisel and Louis Sill ofBrett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton.,.Inc. The new owner is David Levti,who will occupy most of the structure.

New sets for serving breakfast in bed are now available in varied designs calculated to suit different room settings or individual morning personalities. Services, including egg cups, small coffee or tea pots and covered dishes, are made in modern designs as well as provincial patterns and traditional floral-decorated china.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 11 -- A period of intense activity in practical matters, such as making room for agencies and personnel involved in the new economic government, and of watchful waiting on high policy involving political reaction to the Frankfort conference, has begun here.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- More than 250 fishing boats of all sizes took to the open water today in the face of warnings to small craft to start the thirteenth annual metropolitan Miami fishing tournament.

To judge by the bedlam and pandemonium at the BarbizonPlaza Saturday afternoon, "Little Red Riding Hood" is fundamentally sound. It is Charlotte B. Chorpenning's dramatization of the ancient fable, and the Children's World Theatre company was performing it before an audience of squirming, screaming savages.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -Personal income of Americans rose in November to an annual rate of $204,900,000,000 compared with $204,400,000,000 in October, the Department of Commerce reported today.
PARIS, Jan. 11 -- Pierre Pflimlin, Minister of Agriculture, said in a broadcast to French farmers tonight that the fate of the nation's economy was in their hands.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -Printers employed on Washington's four daily newspapers agreed today to accept a weekly wage increase of $8 offered by the publishers. The rise is retroactive to Nov. 11, the date on which the old contract expired.

Charles Edward McDonnell, Donal P. McDonnell, Robert E. McDonnell Jr., T. Murray McDonnell and William P. O'Connor Jr., have been admitted to partnership in the firm of McDonnell Co., regular members of the New York Curb Exchange.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- An interesting event last week was the reduction in the fiduciary note issue of the Bank of England by 50,000,000 (about $200,000.000). This was the first time since the war that a reduction had been made, while during the war, the fiduciary issue was nearly trebled.

Renaming ceremonies are scheduled to be held aboard the Army transport Wabash Victory Friday, in accordance with a program of redesignating Army Transportation Corps cargo vessels to honor war heroes, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall will take his European Recovery Program across the crest of Capitol Hill tomorrow morning to the House of Representatives, where the legislators have so far restrained their enthusiasm for additional large recovery appropriations.

Dr. Oscar Ivanissevich, the Argentine Ambassador, in his letter of Dec. 30 argues that Virginia Lee Warren's articles on the Argentine universities and your editorial of Dec. 23 follow "the line of your paper to discredit Argentina in the United States." I believe it unnecessary to answer in detail his legalistic view that Peron, having been legally elected President, acted under the Argentine Constitution in seizing the universities of the country.

The resumption of a French port of call for the HollandAmerica liner Nieuw Amsterdam, effective with her departure from here on Feb. 3, was announced yesterday by Peter van den Toorn, managing director of the company.

The Southernaires quartet, whose sixteen years of radio broadcasting have made their renditions of spirituals and work songs famous, gave a concert in Town Hall last night. They entertained their audience not only with Negro songs, but with folk songs of England and Russia, a medley of Sigmund Romberg songs, featuring their pianist and arranger Spencer Odom, and arrangements of popular music in a manner notable for its smooth and varied professionalism.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Owen D. Young, retired industrialist, said tonight that he was "highly pleased" over recent developments in the controversy over creation of a state university since, in his opinion, it has committed both major parties to the establishment of such an institution.

Famous classics from the world of literature will be the subject matter of a new series of dramatizations, originating in Hollywood, scheduled to start over the Columbia Broadcasting System next Sunday from 1:30 to 2 P.M. CBS as yet has not chosen a title for the series.

KANSAS CITY, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Dr. F. C. (Phog) Allen, basketball coach at the University of Kansas, says he has written two letters to Kansas State College athletic officials "questioning the eligibility of a Kansas State player."

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein reported today that New York State had made substantial progress during the past year in eliminating racial and religious discrimination in hotels, resorts, restaurants and other places of public accommodation.

Under snow conditions it takes a day to get your paper, a day to read it, a day to write a letter to you, a day to mail it, and, I suppose, a day for you to receive it So there better not be any hurry.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- A mandatory referendum on any proposal to increase transit fares in New York City and an almost complete reversal of the state's fiscal policies are demanded in the Communist party's 1948 legislative program made public here today.

Stuart Scheftel, chairman of the National Draft Eisenhower League, said yesterday that there had been a favorable reaction to Senator Charles W. Tobey's acceptance of membership on the league's board of directors and the decision to run a full slate of Eisenhower candidates for Republican National Convention delegates in New Hampshire.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The Soviet Government has never indicated to the United States that it wished the Western powers to withdraw from Berlin, and the United States has no plan to do so, informed officials in Washington said tonight.

Prince Peter of Greece was present at a high mass at noon yesterday in Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral, 319 East Seventyfourth Street. The ceremony was conducted by the Rev. George Papadeas of the cathedral staff as a tribute to the visiting member of the Greek royal family.
LONDON, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Some of the London critics were angry today that American film stars like Mickey Rooney can get around $10,000 every week they play the English music halls.
Three new films, including an importation from Mexico, are slated to open in midtown theatres this week. The programs follow:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 11 (AP) -- A four-man team driven by Clarence Preston, 40-year-old Oneonta automobile dealer, won the novice race for the Joseph R. Linney trophy today over the half-mile course of the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic bobsled run.

Returning to show competition after a two-year retirement, Champion Jai Son Fu of Orchard Hill, owned and handled by Mrs. Richard S. Quigley of Lock Haven, Pa., took the best of breed prize in the sixty-first specialty fixture of the Pekingese Club of America last night at the Hotel Belvedere.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 -- Ten business men on a round-the-world flight to survey business conditions in foreign countries will leave here Tuesday morning aboard the "Flying Salesroom" of the Atlas Supply Company of Newark. The trip will take about one hundred days.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 11 -Using thirty strains of virulent cholera, including those of the recent outbreak in Egypt and the present one in Syria, the hospital of the American University in Beirut has produced the most complete and effective cholera serum known to science, Archie S. Crawford, acting president of the university, said today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -A "radical reduction" in Government spending headed eighteen steps recommended by fifty-three economists today as a means of combatting inflation.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, called on the Soviet Union tonight to "discard provocative policies" that were "running the risk of war at some time" and "impeding the economic recovery and progress of mankind."
About 50,000 bales of raw cotton will be purchased by the United States, through the New York Quartermaster Purchasing Office, for shipment to Japan, it was announced yesterday.

RONNE, ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION BASE, Stonington Island, Marguerite Bay, Jan. 8 (Delayed) -- We have just finished more than eight hours of cosmic-ray investigation at high altitudes over Antarctica in the Norseman plane Nana.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- The memory of Haym Salomon, Revolutionary War patriot, was honored today at ceremonies in the historic Mikveh Israel Cemetery.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- A clear indication that the Russians will attempt to force the Western Allies to leave this city was given today by the Soviet Army paper Taegliche Rundschau.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, 19-year-old Los Angeles sensation, spotted Gardner Larned two sets then uncorked a tremendous service and a smashing net game to win the twenty-first annual Dixie tennis tournament, 2 -- 6, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, here today.

An autopsy showed yesterday that the death of Richard A. Knight, eccentric disbarred lawyer, apparently was due to "general visceral congestion." Mr. Knight was found dead Saturday afternoon in his home at 7 East Ninety-sixth Street.

A deep moral issue is involved in the succession to the seat of the late Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, Brooklyn Communist. He died on Nov. 6 last, and his duly designated successor, Simon W. Gerson, has as yet not been seated.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, offered today to disclose all his personal records on commodity-market holdings and other investments to prove that he had not taken advantage of "inside information" to speculate for profit.

Vincent Tusa, operator for thelast si:/teen years of the gasolineand service station at the southeast corner of Stillwell Avenueand Eighty-sixth Street, one ofthe largest on the Bensonhurstsection of Brooklyn, has leasedthe property for fifteen years tothe Belzer Holding Corporationand will retire to his estate inRhinebeek, 1. Y.

Sales of gas to ultimate consumers during the twelve months to Nov. 30, rose 10 per cent to 28,854,835,000 therms, compared with 26,089,726,000 therms in the preceding comparable period, the American Gas Association announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 11 -- A political innovation capturing the attention of many voters in Louisiana who are accustomed to more flamboyant campaigns is the state's first all-veteran ticket that is entered in the current Democratic primary contest for Governor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Thirtythree prominent Americans, protesting what they called inadequate safeguards in current loyalty tests joined in a letter, made public today, urging the Federal Employes Loyalty Review Board to use its influence to cut down the "danger of injustices inherent in the present wholesale check-up."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Formation of the National Conference of State Retail Associations as a constituent body of the American Retail Federation was announced here today. The action, joining the federation's thirty-three member state retail associations into a formal body, was completed yesterday after the close of ARF's annual meeting.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 11 -- Jews tonight wrecked a bridge over the River Jordan on the main road from Palestine to Syria in an area where Arab invaders attacked two settlements last Friday.

With Cardinal Spellman presiding in the sanctuary, the seventh annual vespers service for the dead of the Holy Name Societies in the New York Archdiocese was held yesterday afternoon in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 11 -- The new Inter-American Confederation of Labor, intended to supplant the Latin-American Labor Confederation, took shape here today, and it will be established formally Tuesday night.

After declining in early dealings last week, cotton prices in the domestic market recovered most of their losses. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 19 points to up 14 points for the week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Congress will get two messages from President Truman this week. Tomorrow it will receive the budget, authoritatively reported as calling for expenditures of about $39,500,000,000. On Wednesday it will receive the President's second annual economic report.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins suffered a double setback tonight, losing a National Hockey League contest to the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, and the services of their recently purchased star center, Johnny Quilty, who was injured and will be out an indefinite period.

John McAuliffe, former president and now a director of the Isthmian Steamship Company, has been elected chairman of the board of the American Eastern Corporation, its directors announced yesterday. Marcel E. Wagner, the president, also reported plans for expansion of the organization's world-wide shipping, trading and development enterprises.

The Moore-McCormack Lines' "new" Argentina, fresh from an eight-month reconversion and renovation job, will be the scene of considerable ceremony before starting her first post-war voyage to South America at 5 P.M. Thursday from Pier 32, North River, company officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- The argument that Alexander Hamilton's plan of 1790 for restoring the credit of the United States, if applied to Europe today, would restore private enterprise there and deal a "devastating" blow to communism was advanced today.

This morning at 11 o'clock, following the Sabbath's shut-down and the week-end preliminaries, the National Motor Boat Show will get squared away in earnest for a full week at Grand Central Palace, closing each night at 11 P.M.
BERLIN, Jan. 11 -- A Soviet sentry fired at a United States major and his wife today following an apparent misunderstanding at a Soviet Army barrier on the highway to Berlin.

It was no feat to glide into the new year from the old so far as this event was accompanied by an increased turnover or substantial price variations in the market for foreign exchanges. The lull of the last fortnight originating out of the holidays and the inclement weather was still maintained. Price changes while modest pointed to a firm undertone.

FREEPORT, L.I., Jan. 11 -- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Pakenham and their six children escaped without injury from their burning home early today, with Patrolman William Duncan doing yeoman service in aiding to safety Mrs. Pakenham and five of the children.

After a three-week holiday recess, the New Friends of Music resumed their 5:30 Sunday afternoon concerts yesterday at Town Hall. The artists were the four members of the Budapest Quartet, making the first of two appearances with the organization.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 11 -Development of a "flash heating" process which some scientists believe may revolutionize the canning of foods, especially of the liquid or semi-liquid types, was announced recently at a food processors' conference at the University of California.

International rather than national sovereignty, based on the moral principles of the church, is the only road to lasting peace, Herbert A. Mowat, assistant to Sir Ellsworth Flavelle, chairman of the World Committee for Palestine, declared yesterday.
