MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 11 -- Despite high winds that buffeted his light plane, Bill Brennand, 20-year-old pilot from Oshkosh, Wis., flew away from five competitors here today and won the Continental Motors Corporation trophy race. The Oshkosh pilot whipped the "Backyard Special," designed and built by S. J. Wittman, around twelve laps of the two-mile course at a speed of 166.473 miles an hour.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN; Germany, Jan. 11 (AP) -- United States informants here said today more than 400,000,000 United States cigarettes and 35,000,000 cigars were pouring into Western Germany to spur workers to greater efforts in rebuilding their country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (AP) -Members of Congress, their families and their staffs filled 500 reserved seats in Washington National Cathedral today and were assured that, as "faith in God has made us great, if we cling to it we shall be greater."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 11 -- John S. Sutphen's Rum Dum from Larchmont finished with 169 points to take the over-all prize in the sixteenth annual Frost Bite Regatta at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club today, Arthur Knapp's Agony was second with 166 and Ed Raymond's Snort, both from Larchmont, was third with 163.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Three British former Indian Army officers left here by air last night to fight with the Arabs in Palestine, it was learned today. Their precise destination was not disclosed, but it was believed to be Paris, en route to Syria.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 11 (AP) -- J. B. Pilcher, acting United States Consul General in Shanghai, said today that he had received confirmation of the deaths of three Evangelical Covenant missionaries in the Laohokow area, northwest of Hankow.

Forty-one youth organizations convened yesterday a Youth Affairs Congress at Madison House, 226 Madison Street. The session adopted resolutions opposing universal military training, and supporting the United Nations decision to partition Palestine, Government measures to increase the economic welfare of young people, and the move to establish a state university in New York.

A gardener advises this corner that he is convinced the publishers of spring seed catalogues are in cahoots with the weather man. How else could it be, he argues, that the new year's assortment of superlatives (illustrated in full color) invariably arrives on a January day cold and gray inside and out?

Ferenc Molnar, internationally known playwright, will observe his seventieth birthday today. Asked if he was planning anything special to commemorate the event, he replied: "I'm always working because it's an old habit of mine."

The detailed story of the purchase of 200 tons of the explosive M-3, which the Jewish Agency for Palestine late Saturday night acknowledged it had paid for in a legitimate transaction, was told yesterday by the man who negotiated the purchase.

The New York Rovers were in form yesterday at Madison Square Garden. With 11,625 fans rooting home their favorites, the Red Shirts humbled the pace-setting Shawinigan Falls Cataracts, 7 to 1, in a Quebec Senior Hockey League contest.

MONTREAL, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Toe Blake, Montreal Canadiens' veteran who is within striking distance of the all-time scoring record in the National Hockey League, will be lost to his team for at least two months as the result of an ankle fracture suffered Saturday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- An official summary of the recommendations embodied in the third report of the President's Commission on Higher Education follows:

PEESKILL, N.Y., Jan. 11 -John N. Schneider, Democratic Mayor of this city, whose officials have been unable to agree as to the powers of the Mayor, announced today that another attempt would be made Tuesday night to organize the Council.

Columbia University's Teachers College will offer a program of leadership training and intensive research in intergroup and intercultural education next autumn, Dr. Hollis L. Caswell, associate dean, announced yesterday. A grant of $125,000 from the National Conference of Christians and Jews will support the program for five years.

Leaders in the campaign to expedite city action on traffic and parking problems have been invited to present their views to the Joint Legislative Committee on Motor Vehicle Problems, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Development of a series of two-year community colleges throughout the country, to provide free education for all who want to go beyond high school is proposed by the President's Commission on Higher Education in the third volume of its report, made public here today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Although there was a marked increase in country offerings of cash corn late last week, due to higher prices and restoration of electric power lines to country elevators, the price moved upward steadily. The top figure on the Board of Trade was reached in the early trading yesterday, May selling within a few cents of the record of $2.65 3/4 a bushel, made by the September delivery.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -Radio servicing as a business has grown rapidly with the increase in radio set ownership, together with the progress of FM and television broadcasting and expanding uses of radio equipment, Max F. Balcom, president of the Radio Manufacturers Association, said here tonight at the opening session of the Town Meeting of Radio Technicians at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel.

Close to 8,000 merchants from all sections of the country are expected to attend the thirty-seventh annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association which opens tonight at the Hotel Pennsylvania. This figure compares with an attendance of 6,000 a year ago.
George Franklin Heuston, third assistant engineer of the Grace liner Santa Paula, will open an exhibition of his water-colors today at the Ferargil Galleries. The show will continue through Jan. 26.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Robert E. Wilson of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), Chicago, today was appointed chairman of a committee to help the Government carry out provisions of the new anti-inflation bill as they apply to the oil industry.

A pair of goals by Phil Watson in the second period gave the New York Rangers the edge that they needed to make their superiority over the Montreal Canadiens a proper circumstance. The New Yorkers yielded a tally to the Habitants within the first minute of play of last night's game at Madison Square Garden and then came on to contrive a 3-to-1 triumph over the visitors from across the border.

DEL MONTE, Calif., Jan. 11 (AP) -- Slender Lloyd Mangrum, former United States open champion, flashed home with a four-underpar 68 today to win the Bing Crosby $10,000 pro-amateur golf tournament with a fifty-four-hole total of 205.

The Robin Kirk, reconverted former escort aircraft carrier, will begin her maiden voyage to South and East Africa under the Robin Line's house flag on Wednesday, according to word from Arthur R. Lewis Jr., president of the steamship company.

The only basis for "one world" is our acknowledgment in the Fatherhood of God, the Rev. Dr. Ernest R. Palen, pastor of the Middle Collegiate Reformed Church, Second Avenue and Seventh Street, said in his sermon yesterday.

Buyers' attendance in the wholesale markets last week was high, and as a result activity in nearly all fields was brisk, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, summarizing findings made in a national housing poll, declared today that the "very great majority of those carrying important official and civic responsibilities in our states and cities" favored enactment of the Wagner-EllenderTaft bill.

ALBANY, Jan. 11 -- Democratic legislative leaders announced today their support of a recommendation of the State Conference of Mayors that the Constitution be amended to require the state to bear the full cost of any additional expenditures it requires municipalities to make.
United States policy in Greece and the Mediterranean took an important turn last week.

Twenty former service men waiting outside the War Assets Administration Disposal Center No. 5 in the Bronx for a sale at 9 A.M. today were advised early last night by a WAA official that the disposal would be on a lottery basis, instead of a first-come, first-served basis as had been previously advertised.

Among the exhibitions in prospect this week are the third annual of contemporary American drawings at the National Academy and the showing of twenty-five recent acquisitions of painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, which will also show paintings by French children.

ZURICH, Jan. 11 -- More than 100,000 bank employees in Italy have been on strike since Dec. 31. Pickets prevent anyone except managers and board members from entering banks and business in Italy is almost at a standstill. Turnover on the Bourse has shriveled because orders cannot be placed through the banks.

DETROIT, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs and the Detroit Red Wings played a bruising 2-to-2 National Hockey League tie here tonight that left them where they started, deadlocked for the league lead. The crowd, 15,219, was the biggest in Detroit hockey history.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Jan. 11 -- An enthusiastic throng of 15,000 that packed every vantage point along the 50-meter Bear Mountain hill today saw a ski jumping competition that kept them on tenterhooks for close to two and one-half hours.
E. G. Gerbic has been appointed director of merchandising for Johnson Johnson to succeed H. J. Henry, now president of Tek Hughes, Inc., a Johnson Johnson affiliate.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $57,326,411,950. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Miriam Solovieff, violinist, was heard in a recital at Carnegie Hall last night. In spite of her youth, Miss Solovieff already has a well established reputation as a talented artist, and her performances at this latest appearance again had much to commend them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Prices of lard moved up rapidly last week on the Board of Trade. Strength came largely from sympathy with other fats and oils, especially cottonseed oil. Trade reports indicate that soap manufacturers were among the leading buyers of the deferred deliveries, lard being cheaper than many oils.

The Greater New York CIO Council has sent to each member of the 1948 Legislature a letter declaring its opposition to any increase in the present five-cent fare on the municipal transit lines, Saul Mills, secretary of the organization, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11 -- Gen. Clifton B. Cates Commandant of the Marine Corps, said today that no marines were being sent to Palestine and that the recent assignment of about 1,000 "leathernecks" to Mediterranean fleet units was purely routine.

Set Svanholm, Swedish tenor, will sing the title role in the season's first performance of Wagner's "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday afternoon, Jan. 21. Subscribers to the series, which is sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, will also hear Helen Traubel as Bruennhilde and see the new settings designed by Lee Simonson.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 11 -David O. Selznick will produce his screen adaptation of Henrik Ibsen's "A Doll's House" in Norway and Sweden as the first in a series of European film projects he has in view, the producer has announced.
TOKYO, Jan. 11 -- Developments in the world outside its temple gates are pressing in upon Buddhism, Japan's principal religion, and forcing it to get into tune with the times.

Sam Goldwyn's production, "The Best Years of Our Lives," directed by William Wyler from a scenario by Robert E. Sherwood and a story by MacKinlay Kantor, was voted the best picture of 1947 in the twenty-sixth annual poll of film critics of the nation's newspapers, magazines, syndicates, wire services and radio stations conducted the trade publication, The Film Daily.

Rabbi William F. Rosenblum, president of the Synagogue Council of America, deplored yesterday the recent embargo on shipment of surplus explosives as "a tragic shortsightedness" and emphasized the right of Palestinian Jews to defend themselves against attacks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Business has reached a high state of activity and probably will continue in an upward trend this year, but the rate of improvement has been declining and now stands at the lowest mark in several months, P. C. Patch, chairman of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago, declared today in revealing the results of a survey as of Dec. 31, 1947.

With 70 per cent of the city's construction workers covered by a two-and-a-half-year stabilization agreement, Mayor O'Dwyer urged yesterday that all holdout groups sign the master pact by Feb. 1. As an incentive for prompt action, the Mayor promised that the city would start many important projects" within thirty days after the agreement was signed.
LONDON, Jan. 11 -- Britain is determined that her occupation forces shall remain in Berlin whatever the Russians try to do, it was stated on high authority tonight.

Myron C. Taylor, President Truman's representative at the Vatican, and a member of the vestry of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, will attend the consecration of Msgr. Patrick A. O'Boyle on Wednesday as the first Archbishop of the newly established Archdiocese of Washington, D.C.

Fifteen hundred persons attended services last night in the Roman Catholic Monastery Church of the Immaculate Conception, 178th Street and Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, in connection with the enthronement of a replica of the statue of Our Lady of Fatima.
John T. Stanley Company, Inc., makers of shave cream and lotion, to the New York office of Brisacher, Van Norden Staff, Inc.

LONDON, Jan. 11 -- The primary purpose of marriage, Bernard Cardinal Griffin, Archbishop of Westminster, said in an address here today, "is the procreation of children and their subsequent education."
A report yesterday by a committee of the United Parents Associations described most of the city's playgrounds and recreation centers as "poor" in terms of sufficient personnel and equipment.

If wages are stabilized at present levels and production is not lowered, most manufacturers believe that they can hold prices at present levels, according to a survey of current business practices by the National Industrial Conference Board, released over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 (UP) -An increasing number of women are representing the Governments of various nations in international conferences and organizations, the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department reported today.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 11 -- Genuine optimism concerning Indonesia can be discerned here at last. It is generally assumed that Premier Louis J. M. Beel will give a heartening report when he addresses Parliament on Tuesday on the subject of his recent trip to the former colonies.

KENNETH S. DAVIS, who wrote a novel about an alcoholic, "In the Forests of the Night," long before such novels became fashionable, and also an excellent biography of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, "Soldier of Democracy," doesn't like the present state of civilization any more than most of us. But, unlike many of us, he doesn't look for improvement from political, economic or religious sources.

Iva Kitchell, to whom, happily, nothing in the choreographic world is sacred, presented her annual program of dance satires and burlesques at the Ziegfeld Theatre last night and mowed them down. The ballet, the modern dance, the scarf and garland dance, and this year the opera ballet all came in for lambasting and general slaughter.

NANKING, Jan. 11 -- Another sharp upward spurt by China's intractable price level has increased pressure on the Government to seek more fundamental curbs on inflation. At present these consist of official restrictions on the flow of capital and periodic police crackdowns on "black marketers."

An exhibition of colorful glazed faience and glassware of ancient Egypt, including pieces 5,000 years old, will open at 10 A.M. today at the Brooklyn Museum. The 150 objects were selected from the museum's new additions and from seldom-displayed examples.

VIENNA, Jan. 11 -- The Soviet Union seems determined to prevent the partition of Austria if it can be avoided. It has demonstrated lately in two different ways its eagerness to keep the door to an Austrian peace treaty open.

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 11 -- Another upswing in prices of foodstuffs next spring attributable to a lack of farm machinery was forecast today by C. Erwin Frudden, president of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 11 -- There was no falling off in the volume of steel business last week. In this and other areas there was an actual increase in demand, but most steel producers were unable to promise more material than had been included in quotas, for the first quarter of the year.

NANKING, Jan. 11 -- Warnings have gone out from United States consulates to all American missionaries living north of the Yangtze River in Central China against the danger that their cities and towns may be occupied by the Chinese Communists.

The church must have the power to cut through those things that oppose its truths, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers, pastor of the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle at Fifty-sixth Street, declared yesterday morning.
Jk property tax survey of 321cities throughout the countryshows their per capita assessedvaluation increased' 15.7 per centin 1947 over 1946 while the taxrate dropped for the first time infour years.

The Silver Skates will be on view at Madison Square Garden tonight. This ice skating festival, the twentyfourth annual one conducted by the News Welfare Association, will be made up of a varied program of championship races and ice carnival performances by amateur and professional stars.

Manhattan College's track coach, George Eastment, is eyeing two Metropolitan A.A.U. indoor championships to be decided Saturday night at the Twenty-third Regiment Armory, Bedford and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn.
President Truman expressed hope yesterday that the United States soon would admit a substantial number of displaced persons from Europe.

Housewives no longer order meat by the pound, one of the local butchers told us recently. Instead, they ask how much of a certain cut they can get for the amount of money they have to spend. This seems to indicate that there is plenty of use nowadays for macaroni products, one of the best foods for extending a small amount of meat into enough for adequate servings.

CHICAGO, Jan. 11 -- Grain prices were on the upgrade last week on the Board of Trade, with oats and soy beans selling at record high levels, corn at new seasonal peaks and May wheat, at the extreme, 7 3/4 cents a bushel under the recent top.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 11 -George Reuter, chairman of the Bavarian labor union and Social Democratic Deputy in the Economic Council at Frankfort on the Main, today issued the strongest blast to date against Dr. Johannes Semmler's recent attack on the British and United States Military Governments.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 11 (AP) -- The substitution of an income tax for the state sales and use tax would shift the tax burden to a minority of the population and put Connecticut at a disadvantage with New York State, the Connecticut Public Expenditures Council asserted tonight.

Two pretenders to the world welterweight title now held by Ray Robinson will be on exhibition tonight at the St. Nicholas Arena, when Gene Burton, Harlem, clashes with Kid Gavilan, Cuban flash, in the feature of ten rounds.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 11 -- A new organization, Protestant in name and inviting the support of the Protestant churches and other religious and non-religious bodies, proclaimed its appearance on the national scene today with a manifesto urging reaffirmation of the American principle of separation of church and state.

The most significant fact that emerges at the very start of the great debate over the European Recovery Program is that, despite criticism of its details, the program as such has already gained such wide acceptance that there is scarcely any outright opposition to it.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, moved yesterday to bring the city-state dispute over state aid for child care centers to a head when he announced that he would argue for state funds at a meeting of the State Youth Commission in Albany on Jan. 22.
CHICAGO, Jan. 11 (AP) -- A new bowling alley in which lighted images replace the pins, and no boys are needed to set 'em up again, was previewed here today.

In a White Paper issued in 1944 the Churchill Government outlined a program of medical reform which has been amplified and enacted by the Labor Government. In July, 1948, any resident of Great Britain will be entitled to medical and hospital care, drugs, home nursing, appliances and limited dental service regardless of income -- all to be paid for partly by contributions to the social insurance fund, mainly by taxation.

Dr. Emanuel Neumann, president of the Zionist Organization of America, urged last night that arms and equipment be made available "at once to the embattled and beleaguered Jews of Palestine, legally, openly and promptly through United Nations channels."

Two murals by A. J. Tobias will be executed in the auditorium of James Madison High School, Bedford Avenue and Quentin Road, Brooklyn, as a memorial to ninety-two students who lost their lives in World War II, Max Newfield, principal, announced yesterday.

With reserve supplies of No. 6 fuel oil in this area 23 per cent below last year, a possibly severe shortage of this heavy industrial grade fuel, used mostly to heat large buildings, may develop in a month or six weeks, Brice P. Disque, head of the Coal Consumers Protective Committee, a fuel dealers' organization, declared yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 11 (AP) -- The semiofficial French Press Agency announced today that it had discharged its Moscow correspondent, Jean Champenois, on grounds that he had not complied with an order to return home.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 12 -- Karl Krauch, chairman of the board of I.G. Farbenindustrie and a chief defendant in the trial of top executives of the German chemical cartel, took the witness stand in his own defense today in an attempt to explain away the damaging testimony introduced by the prosecution.

Forty-six men -- all who were aboard the Army transport Joseph V. Connolly when she caught fire at sea 1,000 miles east of New York early yesterday -- were rescued last night after they had tossed on the stormy Atlantic for many hours in four lifeboats.

The Rev. Lyman R. Hartley has resigned his pastorate at the Fort George Presbyterian Church, effective Feb. 1, to accept a fulltime post as chaplain of the Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, it was announced yesterday at a meeting of the Presbytery of New York in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street.

The Board of Higher Education approved last night a preliminary budget of $18,724,910 for operating the four municipal colleges during the 1948-49 fiscal year. Of this amount the city will be asked to appropriate $14,660,177.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Your personal stake in the high cost of government will be $270 in the new fiscal year if you are an average American.
The United States is now on a road leading to a depression by 1952, Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers of America, CIO, said yesterday.

"The Making of an Insurgent: An Autobiography, 1882-1919," by Fiorello H. La Guardia, has been scheduled for May publication by Lippincott. It contains the autobiographical material upon which the former Mayor was working at the time of his death last year.

First reports of 1948 sales by distributors in machine tool, electrical and mill supply lines show that strong demand has continued for the first weeks of the year, with increasing numbers of inquiries for large orders recorded in both New York and Chicago, spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

A decision that may affect the legitimacy of 20,000 children conceived through artificial insemination was reserved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg, in a suit brought by Mrs. Julie Strnad, 31 years old, of 303 East Ninety-fourth Street.

The Ingalis Shipbuilding Corporation of Pascagoula, Miss., is soliciting "new business," including contracts for the construction of tanks, railroad cars, locomotives, steel pipe and the fabrication of steel for all purposes.

Bank managements have a responsibility in the current inflationary situation "which cannot be avoided by pointing out that others have equal or larger responsibilities," S. Sloan Colt, president of the Bankers Trust Company, declares in his annual report.

John E. Swift, Supreme Knight of the Knights of Columbus, in a statement released yesterday on behalf of his organization through the Chancery Office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, sharply criticized the manifesto issued in Washington on Sunday by a new group called Protestants and Other Americans for the Separation of Church and State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Those items in President Truman's budget message which Republican critics of his state of the Union speech called added "New Deal" proposals come to an estimated total of $571,000,000 in new expenditures for the next fiscal year.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Princeton's quintet turned in its second straight Eastern Intercollegiate League victory tonight, presenting a smooth passing attack which routed Dartmouth, 55 -- 42, in the new Dillon gymnasium.

Early attempts to push up the aircraft shares yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange met with resistance following President Truman's budget message, and the market closed fractions to a point lower. Transactions totaled 1,000,000 shares against 980,000 on last Friday.

LAST autumn the publishing project known as "The Society in America Series" got off to a good start with Cleveland Amory's authoritative and amusing "The Proper Bostonians." Probably no other volume in the series will have so rewarding a subject, a homogeneous society identified for generations with a peculiar local culture, bound by powerful tribal tabus and populated by so many eccentric individualists.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- Non-residents who are subject to the New York State income tax can save up to $21 each under an amendment of the State Tax Law that becomes effective this year for the first time. About 70,000 will benefit, most of them by not more than $4.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 12 -- In a packed courtroom in the Palace of Justice, Mme. Milada Radlova described today the Berlin visit in March, 1939, on which her father, Emil Hacha, then President of Czechoslovakia, signed away the sovereignty of Bohemia and Moravia.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Allan Knight Chalmers, who are leaving Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, where he served as pastor for seventeen years, were honored last night at a dinner in the church for which the Interracial Fellowship of Greater New York and fourteen other organizations were sponsors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A $13,500,000 financing program for the Wisconsin River Power Company, a subsidiary of the Consolidated Water Power and Paper Company, will be considered at a hearing on Jan. 22, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Following is the text of President Truman's budget message, sent to Congress today:

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The State Senate adopted unanimously tonight the administration's tax deficiency bill appropriating $26,220,250 to cover non-budgeted expenditures arising out of the increased cost of food. The Assembly is scheduled to approve the bill tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Leaders of the Republican party in Congress, mincing no words as President Truman submitted his $39,669,000,000 budget for the next fiscal year, made it unmistakably clear today that they planned to do a thorough pruning job on it.

The best that Branch Rickey could do in a baseball way at his weekly press conference yesterday was to declaim with some emphasis that "the Dodger team that goes to Santo Domingo this spring will be the best team that I ever have taken south."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- Beginning a new era in opera relations between Los Angeles and New York, the full Metropolitan company will play a twelve-day "season" here from April 13 to 24, it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 -- With a gift of 880,000 shares of Sun Oil Company common stock, the four children of the late Joseph N. Pew, founder of the oil company, and Mary Anderson Pew have established the Pew Memorial Foundation, it was revealed today when articles of incorporation were filed in Common Pleas Court here.
The Gulf Oil Corporation expects to offer to its stockholders 2,269,050 shares of additional capital stock about Jan. 27, it was announced yesterday.
Holding within a narrow range, cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 7 to 16 points net higher than Saturday's final level.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The prepared statement of Secretary of State Marshall before the House Foreign Affairs Committee today follows:

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 12 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi at his daily prayer meeting tonight announced that he would start a fast of indefinite duration tomorrow to bring about greater unity between the Hindu-Sikh and Moslem communities of India.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- In a move of startling suddenness the Supreme Court today commanded Oklahoma to provide virtually immediate legal education for a Negro woman. The court acted under the constitutional guarantee of equal protection for all citizens.

The football Giants gave Coach Steve Owen a battery mate for Paul Governali yesterday when Bill Swiacki, spectacular Columbia end, was signed to a two-year contract. The salary terms were not revealed.

ST. MORITZ, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Art Devlin of Lake Placid, N.Y., the United States ski-jumping champion, probably will not see service in the Winter Olympics Jan. 30 to Feb. 8 because of a knee injury sustained in recent training at Davos.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- During the first quarter of 1948 American business, exclusive of agriculture, expects to spend about $4,100,000,000 for new plant construction and new equipment, it was announced today in a survey made public by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Department of Commerce.

The nation's steel industry increased its productive capacity in 1947 by almost 3,000,000 net tons to a total of 94,233,640 tons, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, announced yesterday in his annual report on steel-making facilities.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan 12 -- New cargo handling gear designed to save from 25 to 50 percent in the cost of loading and unloading ships was shown here today by the Lake Shore Engineering Company with the cooperation of the United States Maritime Commission.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Britain and France have tentatively decided to call a conference of the sixteen nations participating in the European Recovery Program, it was learned today. Barring a last-minute hitch here, or the unexpected refusal of some of the fourteen other nations, the meeting will be held in Park early in February.

In language more blunt than any Western statesman had used thus far, Deputy Prime Minister Herbert Morrison has called on Soviet Russia to discard its "provocative policies," by which it is not only impeding economic recovery but also "running the risk of war at some time."

Sales of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., during the quarter ended with last December were the highest for any comparable period on record, R.W. Moore, president, informed stockholders at the annual meeting held yesterday at Jersey City, N.J. Increased sales of carbonated beverages accounted for the bulk of this rise, he explained.

Nineteen local housing authorities will receive bids until Jan. 27 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $35,369,000. An issue of $18,367,000 of the Chicago Authority maturing on Nov. 9 is the largest single offering.

A desperate rally over the last three rounds earned Kid Gavilan, Cuban welterweight, a draw last night in his ten-round battle against Gene Burton, Harlem, before a crowd of 3,648 at the St. Nicholas Arena. The receipts amounted to $9,013.

Giuseppe Valdengo, baritone, again proved his popularity with Metropolitan Opera audiences when he gave his first performance in the role of Amonasro in Verdi's "Aida" last night. Loud applause greeted him as he entered and cheers hailed his performance.
An unsettled market in butter caused price fluctuations yesterday of as much as 21 cents a pound in retail stores only a few blocks apart.

Although property tax rates in American cities during 1947 held close to 1946 levels, the per capita assessed valuation increased 15.7 per cent, according to a survey by the Bureau of Government Research, Detroit, assisted by the Volker Fellows of the National Training School for Public Service, The Associated Press reports.

In your letters column of Jan. 3 Thomas Dunbabin, discussing the proposal that Spanish be adopted as the third working language of UNESCO, with French and English, implies that I supported this proposal in speaking for the United States delegation at the Mexico City conference; and that I stated that if only two languages could be used I personally preferred Spanish to French.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Jan. 12 -- Sitting on a solid silver throne with the bejeweled royal crown and sceptre on a side table, 89- year-old King Gustaf V performed today the solemn annual ceremony of opening the Riksdag [Parliament] for the forty-first time in his record reign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall today identified Soviet Russia as a threat to world political stability, and again warned Congress that it should authorize the full European Recovery Program requested by the Administration or reject the proposal entirely.

A cooking school that charges about 25 cents for each lesson may sound like something out of a history book, but although this is the fee at the Grace Institute, 149 West Sixtieth Street, the course is up-to-the-minute. At the session we attended yesterday, the young housewife-students learned how to prepare a meat-stretching beef loaf.
Approval of a project of Sweet Briar College for a junior year study group in Paris was announced yesterday by the Institute of International Education, 2 West Forty-fifth Street.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 -- The Government today started both criminal and civil anti-trust proceedings against the General Electric Company, the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and eight smaller electrical companies charging conspiracy to restrain trade in the sale of certain electrical devices on the Pacific Coast.
The Joseph V. Connolly, 7,176-gross ton Liberty ship, brought the first American war dead from Europe, arriving last Oct. 26 with 6,248 coffins.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- The search for an "amicable division" of waters flowing across a third of the border between the United States and Canada was undertaken today by the International Joint Commission. Officials described the assignment as probably the largest project the commission ever had been asked to undertake.

Jake LaMotta, Bronx middleweight, refused yesterday to sign a waiver of immunity and was not permitted to testify before the February, 1947, grand jury that has been seeking links between professional prizefighting and the underworld, the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Thirty Roman Catholic students withdrew from Baldwin-Wallace College today after a priest told them they could not attend the Methodist school's compulsory chapel or required courses in philosophy of religions "without acting in bad faith and being guilty of a serious sin."

Your editorial on "Weather Forecasting" in the Jan. 6 issue states the case very well. The accuracy of weather forecasting is "better than many suppose, yet not good enough." Since the record snow on Dec. 26-27, 1947, our forecasters in New York and Washington have re-examined the weather maps carefully for some clue that would show how the heavy snowfall might have been foreseen.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 7 per cent over the like week of 1947, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the four weeks ended on Saturday the bank reported a gain of 6 per cent.

DUBLIN, Jan. 12 (AP) --President Sean T. O'Kelly dissolved the Dail (Parliament) today and set Feb. 4 as the date for a new general election in Ireland. The balloting promises to be the most keenly contested of any Irish election since Prime Minister Eamon de Valera won power in 1932.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman today asked the Congress to earmark almost one-half of $10,900,000,000 in appropriations and authorizations recommended for defense in the next fiscal year for the benefit of the United States Air Force.

Following a day of continued sessions of various racing boards and commissions Leonard H. Thomson of Detroit was re-elected president of the American Power Boat Association at the Hotel Lexington. All the delegates from many yacht clubs are in New York for the thirty-eighth annual Motor Boat Show at the Grand Central Palace.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- Moshe Shertok, head of the political department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, announced today that the agency would ask the United Nations Security Council to establish an international police force to help carry out the partition of Palestine.

A British importation entitled "Power Without Glory," described as a crime play, makes its bow this evening at the Booth Theatre under the auspices of John C. Wilson and the Messrs. Shubert. The work is written by Michael Clayton Hutton, regarded highly among London's gifted young dramatists.

Statistics and argument in support of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee's demand for a 15 per cent increase in rentals on 1,600,000 dwellings in this city and Long Island were presented yesterday to the Rent Advisory Board. Joseph D. McGoldrick, the chairman, presided at a four-hour session in the Bar Association Building at 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

"Buck price advances at every turn" and be prepared to cooperate with manufacturers and labor groups in price rollbacks on specific items, retailers were advised last night by Dr. Malcolm P. McNair, Professor of Marketing, Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

LONDON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Henry Longhurst, a former Conservative member of the House of Commons, and a pre-war captain of the Cambridge University golf team, is a comparatively young man who knows his way around golf courses. He is a student of the game, both in theory and practice.

A "destination count" of all trucks entering the city through tunnels and over bridges was started yesterday by the police as they intensified efforts to remedy the growing traffic paralysis in mid-Manhattan.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 12 -- Plans for the government of the new Jewish state will be complete to the smallest detail by the end of this month, the Jewish Agency for Palestine announced here today.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Apart from trading in road transport shares, business in the stock markets here today was quiet.

It is a rare occasion when a soloist makes his audience feel that the emphasis is on what he plays and not on how he plays it. Joseph Schuster's performances at Town Hall last night provided such an occasion.

GENEVA, N. Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Dr. Alan Willard Brown, 37-year-old assistant to the Dean of Columbia College, Columbia University, today was named president of the Colleges of Seneca -- Hobart and William Smith.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Announcement that the Government was back in the market as a buyer of flour and intimations that purchases of wheat would be resumed shortly started a buying movement in wheat futures on the Board of Trade today.
Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday for public support of the "Cardiac Crusade" of the New York Heart Association as he characterized heart disease as "Public Enemy Number One."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman disclosed in his budget message to Congress today that he would ask Congress soon to authorize a foreign aid program for China and other countries not specified.

American shareholders in Cia Hispano-Americana de Electricidad (CHADE), the Spanish holding company that controls important power and light properties in Argentina, are being invited to deposit their shares with the Guaranty Trust Company of New York not later than Jan. 20.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court upheld today the denial of unemployment compensation to workers who stayed away from their jobs because they refused to cross a picket line.

The tenth national biennial convention of Women's American ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training) closed yesterday with election of officers. The two-day meeting, attended by 500 women from 76 chapters in all parts of the country, was held in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.
LONDON, Jan. 12 -- Deliveries of steel to Britain's shipyards this year will be 20 per cent less than last year, Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a press conference today.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Jan. 12 -- Dr. Hans Schlange-Schoeningen, bizonal food and agriculture chief, said tonight he would request extraordinary police powers to force farmers to deliver crops and cattle. He disclosed that he previously had suggested such a measure to the United States and British Military Governments, with no response.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Harold E. Stassen today challenged the right of Edwin W. Pauley to retain his post in the Department of the Army after "speculating" in the food commodity markets.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Employment among screen actors is at the lowest ebb in the history of the film industry, President Ronald Reagan of the Screen Actors' Guild told a labor institute at the University of California at Los Angeles last night.

More than 225 apartments have been rented from plans in the Walden Terrace $10,000,000 development for 850 families now under construction at Sixty-fourth Avenue and Ninety-eighth Street, Forest Hills, Queens, Richard L. Rafalsky, president of Mark Rafalsky Co., renting agents, reported yesterday.

To please subscribers of the National Orchestral Association who prefer to hear familiar classics, Leon Barzin dispensed with all novelties at his concert with the training orchestra last night. He played only three staples of the repertoire, Weber's "Euryanthe" Overture, Mozart's "Jupiter" Symphony and the Franck Symphony.

BATON ROUGE, La., Jan. 12 -- Anticipating the time when the nation's crude oil production will be inadequate to meet its needs, the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) is directing its research toward the development of processes for the production of synthetic liquid fuels from natural gas and coal, E.V. Murphree, president of the Standard Oil Development Company, said today at the dedication of a new laboratory building here.

Replying yesterday to criticism of his proposal for a one-year lottery under city supervision for a hospital building fund, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council expressed his belief that New Yorkers would support the plan by a 90 per cent majority.
The coffee sitdown strike was put into practice in Brooklyn yesterday.
Rousing himself from a reverie, an imaginative and inquisitive friend of this department remarked, with a sad shake of the head: "It's shocking!"

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- The Government began developing the core of its unfair labor practice case against the AFL International Typographical Union today in testimony intended to establish that the union dominated and coerced the Chicago printers in an illegal bargaining policy which resulted in a city-wide newspaper strike.

ALBANY, Jan. 12 -- The Young Commission agreed unanimously tonight to recommend to Governor Dewey and the Legislature the establishment of a state university to consist of a series of community colleges in various parts of the state, at least two medical centers and other professional schools.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 12 -- The barter mart, an institution sponsored by the United States Army where Americans and Germans theoretically could trade personal property without resort to the black market, is to pass out of the German scene by May 1, the Army announced today.

Pocket Books, Inc., announced yesterday that through its sales of 200,000,000 copies of the 25-cent paper-bound editions of best-sellers and classics, it has earned for authors and publishers more than $2,000,000 in new income.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The Governments of India and Pakistan have notified the United Nations Security Council that they will take no action in the Kashmir dispute that will be "incompatible" with the Charter, it was disclosed today.

William Woodward was re-elected chairman of The Jockey Club at the annual meeting of the organization yesterday. Also re-elected was Joseph E. Davis to the post of secretary treasurer. George D. Widener was named vice chairman to succeed A.H. Morris.

A real estate agent, who admitted his guilt after being confronted with recordings of telephone conversations in which he demanded a $150 "bonus" for an apartment, was sentenced yesterday in War Emergency Court to a five-day workhouse term and paid a $250 fine rather than spend an additional thirty days in jail.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- Aroused by the two-day stoppage of fuel oil deliveries in Westchester last week in a labor dispute, the County Board of Supervisors today began studies of means of commandeering and delivering fuel in such emergencies -- somewhat as the Federal Government might operate a coal mine.

Representatives of the maritime industry, labor, the Federal Government and electronics research will join Jan. 20 in the observation of the first anniversary of the United States Maritime Service's loran-radar school in a special ceremony at the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, 80 Broadway, it was announced yesterday.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 12 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea held its first meeting today in historic Duk Soo Palace here. Dr. K.P.S. Menon of India was elected temporary chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The University of Pennsylvania announced today its proposed football game with the University of Michigan next September has been called off because of scheduling difficulties.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Navy, after fourteen years of playing football with its own officers as head coaches, went into the market today for a civilian to replace Capt. Tom Hamilton, who steps up to the post of Director of Athletics.
ROME, Jan. 12 -- A mandate over the former Italian colony of Somaliland has been requested by the Italian Government in a memorandum to the conference of deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers.

At the opening of the century what is loosely called "heart disease" accounted for 118.1 deaths per 100,000 population of this city. The rate has steadily increased ever since, until last year it reached 400.2 per 100,000. No age group has been spared. More children, for example, are killed by some impairment of the circulatory system than by poliomyelitis, measles, whooping cough, scarlet fever and diphtheria combined.

Hope for sure relief from the fuel oil shortage in the New York area and New England was focused sharply yesterday on additional oil tankers that will become available this month and next through the United States Maritime Commission.

No one should assume that DeWitt Bodeen has committed a crime by writing "Harvest of Years," which was put on slowly at the Hudson last evening. He has put together a wholesome and philosophical homily about a Swedish farm family in California.

Consolidations and improvements in five city departments aimed at saving an estimated $30,000,000 annually were recommended to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission, which said the savings could be made without pay cuts or job eliminations.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 12 -- The necessity for reducing the manufacturers' $5,000,000,000 bill for handling materials was stressed at today's opening session of the Materials Handling Exposition.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 12 -- The basic facts about United States labor and its relationship to this year's Presidential election, as seen by the American Federation of Labor, were placed before a key committee of the Inter-American Labor Conference here today. T.J. Lloyd, international vice president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of North America, made the exposition.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 -- Despite tight supplies and high prices in the food field, grocery advertising in newspapers during 1948 "will at least equal 1947 figures and very likely exceed them," Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., told a luncheon session of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association's semi-annual convention today at the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

The second trial of Benjamin Feldman, 40-year-old Brooklyn pharmacist accused of the strychnine-poison murder of his wife in 1943, got under way yesterday in Kings County Court before Judge Carmine J. Marasco.

Harmonious relations between labor and management, coupled with the skill of those engaged in the apparel industry and the talent of the city's designers, are establishing New York as the world's fashion center, not only in the artistic but also in the economic sense, speakers declared last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

As the facts come out about the attempted shipment of high explosives to Palestine it is plain that no matter who broke what laws a terrible mistake was made. These explosives were handled at an appalling risk to innocent persons. Some of them were mislabeled and conveyed surreptitiously.

The 520-page report on five major city departments handed to Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission originated in a request made by the Mayor himself last April. At that time Mr. O'Dwyer gave the commission a free hand, made the services of expert city employes freely available, and now that the survey is completed has directed publication as delivered to him, without regard for its timing or adverse political consequencies.

Ever since the end of the war refugee camps have been a sad feature of European life. It would be in the American tradition and in line with the humanitarian policies we now profess to help solve this problem by admitting a reasonable number of such refugees to this country.

Before the Second World War came to a close a number of studies were made by disinterested organizations of the post-war budget situation. The lowest estimate made of federal expenditures contained in these was $16 billions, the highest approximately $30 billions.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 22.4 per cent in December, compared with the corresponding month in 1946, according to a compilation covering thirty-nine companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:
I have just finished reading THE TIMES' New Year's story on Palestine: "Red Fifth Column for Palestine Feared as Ships Near Holy Land."

Ship construction costs in Great Britain are so high and the backlog of orders so large that any company without new tonnage on order must wait at least three years, according to John J. Walsh, general manager of the Furness Lines in the United States.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 12 -- The American Red Cross began its nation-wide peacetime blood program, aimed eventually to supply 3,700,000 pints a year for medical use throughout the United States, in Rochester today.

ROME, Jan. 12 -- A new effort was made tonight to settle the bank strike, which completed its fourteenth day today. These negotiations bore a special urgency because Government tax collectors went on a sympathy walkout this morning.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange, officials of the company and Wall Street operators puzzled yesterday over the latest, strongest and most confusing report of the oft-rumored sale of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, Pa.

YANINA, Greece, Jan. 12 (AP) -- A member of the military echelon of the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans said tonight the United Nations observers had witnessed artillery firing on Greek troops from Albanian soil.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A stronger campaign than ever before to repeal the Federal margarine tax will be directed toward this session of Congress, Ersel Walley of Fort Wayne, Ind., president of the American Soy Bean Association, said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on investors' objections to a $10,565,227 claim by the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company against its subsidiary, the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway Company.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman was elected last night as chairman of the Board of Overseers of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America by a unanimous vote at the annual dinner meeting of the board at the seminary, Broadway at 122d Street.

By this time it should be clear to readers of these columns that Monday nights are given over to the enjoyment of such gifts as are offered by the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company. Already as you know, "The Mikado" has been offered as well as "Trial by Jury" and "The Pirates of Penzance," and last night the visitors from abroad trotted out the melodious "Iolanthe."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- A maneuver intended to force the Republican leadership to permit universal military training to go before the House for a decision at this session was begun today. The outlook for its proponents, however, was considered gloomy.

CHICAGO, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The youngest and strongest of United States' Olympic speed skating teams may challenge the favored Norwegians in the 1948 winter games at St. Moritz, Switzerland, Jan. 30 to Feb. 8.
Frank Briggs of Paterson, N.J., won the race of champions, the feature attraction on the program of the Silver Skates at Madison Square Garden last night.

Although the volume of commercial paper outstanding at the end of December was 26 per cent above the level at the close of 1946, the total for the month was unchanged from the total at the end of November, it was reported yesterday.

Joseph P. Selly, president of the American Communications Association, CIO, and eight other union leaders were arrested late yesterday afternoon while picketing outside the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation headquarters at 67 Broad Street.

NANKING, Jan. 12 -- The Supreme Nationalist Command was reported today to have written off isolated Changchun, Kirin and Szepingkai and decided to concentrate its forces for the defense of Mukden and the west Liaoning corridor on a shortened Manchurian front.

Ohio State's "borrowed time" gridiron victory over Northwestern was the outstanding sports oddity of 1947 according to the nation's sports editors participating in The Associated Press' year-end poll.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- President Truman, presenting the second-largest peacetime budget in the country's history, asked Congress today for $39,669,000,000 to run the Government in the 1949 fiscal year beginning July 1.

Where the Hippodrome stood, on what is now the Avenue of the Americas, covering the blockfront between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, a mammoth parking garage, worthy of its mammoth predecessor, is to be built and many New Yorkers on reading that news probably realized that sub-consciously they had hoped that another bigger Hippodrome might arise there to perpetrate the traditions of bigness clustering around the spot.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 12 (UP) -- Canada's hopes in the 1948 Winter Olympic Games suffered another rude jolt today when Pierre Jalbert, 23-year-old skier from Quebec, broke his leg in a downhill practice run.

BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- It was learned that Soviet soldiers in the Russian sector of this city yesterday arrested and held in custody Dr. Herman B. Wells, special adviser to General Clay on cultural matters and four other citizens. Dr. Wells is president of the University of Indiana, on leave.

WARSAW, Jan. 12 -- The central executive committee of the Polish Socialist party today elected a new five-man Politburo. The bureau's composition reflects the party's determination to maintain the closest working unity with the Communists and at the same time retain the Socialist party as an independent force in Poland.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 12 -- Princess Elizabetha, former Queen of Greece, and Ileana, Archduchess of Habsburg, the last of the Rumanian royal family, left Bucharest for exile tonight.

Mayor O'Dwyer's appeal to all building crafts to sign long-term wage stabilization agreements brought immediate results yesterday when two of the eleven unsigned union-employer groups entered into contracts running until June 30, 1950.

John Dall has been signed for the role of Brandon in "Rope," the initial production of the Alfred Hitchcock-Sidney Bernstein independent film producing organization, Transatlantic Pictures. Simultaneously it was made known that Joan Chandler, local stage actress who appeared in the film, "Humoresque," will play the feminine lead opposite James Stewart and that Farley Granger has been borrowed from Samuel Goldwyn for the role of Phillip.
Homemakers who are debating whether to buy a new automatic washer or a non-automatic machine, or to send their laundry out, may be helped by the results of a new study of laundering cost.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Grover Loening, aeronautical engineer, received today the President's Medal of Merit for work in aviation in World War II. The presentation was by Gen. Carl Spaatz, chief of staff of the Air Force. W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, was among those at the ceremony.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 12 -- At a meeting of the board of directors of Gold-Uranium Exploration, Ltd., held here today, Gene Tunney, former world heavyweight champion, was elected president and Dr. C. Whitney Banks, surgeon, of New Rochelle, N.Y., chairman of the board.

Orders booked by more than 275 exhibitors during the opening yesterday of the twenty-third winter New York Lamp Show in the Hotel New Yorker were substantial to heavy, according to manufacturers. Buyers stated that they are placing orders in quantity but added that purchasing is a "fill-in proposition to meet inventory needs" rather than unrestrained order placing.

LONDON, Jan. 12 -- British diplomatic sources confirmed tonight that Britain was supplying arms to Egypt, Iraq and Trans-Jordan, but asserted that she was doing so in fulfillment of "contractual obligations" made since the end of World War II.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 12 -- The United Nations and the United States agreed today to give the international organization the exclusive right of accrediting any correspondent to this headquarters, but reserved for the United States the ultimate authority to expel any writer it chooses.

The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Harlem member of Congress and pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 132 West 138th Street, appeared yesterday in Felony Court as a complainant against a church aide accused of grand larceny and then won the defendant's release in his custody pending grand jury action.

PARIS, Jan. 12 -- Dr. Frederic Joliot-Curie, French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, announced to the Academy of Sciences here today the discovery in France of a new type of radioactive body found in cosmic rays whose great penetrating power permits a more complete disintegration of the atom.

The one-story taxpayer building containing eight stores at 3109 Bainbridge Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Tradewell Foods, Inc., from Jacob E. Schorsch. The property, on a plot 100 by 100 feet, was sold for cash above a mortgage of $60,000.
A net profit of $2,337,641 for the fiscal year ended with last October was reported yesterday by Servel, Inc. in its annual statement to stockholders.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Highlight quotations from President Truman's budget message to Congress:
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower refused comment today on the action of supporters in entering his name in the Republican primary in New Hampshire.

Some encouraging factors in New York's campaign against accidents are to be found in the annual report of the Greater New York Safety Council. For the ten-month period for which figures were available deaths from accidents in the city, with a total of 2,895, showed a decrease of 3.4 per cent below the same period last year.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 12 (AP) -- Darby d'Amour, from John W. Galbreath's Darby Dan Farm, raced through deep, holding mud today to capture the featured sixth event of six furlongs, much to the delight of the majority in the crowd of 12,644 at Gulfstream Park.
BERLIN, Jan. 12 -- The Americans will not abandon Berlin and do not intend to be forced out by the Russians, Maj. Gen. George P. Hays, United States Deputy Military Governor, said today.

HANKOW, China, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The slaying of two United States women missionaries and a Finnish medical missionary by "bandits" 150 miles northwest of this Central China city last week has set off a mass evacuation of foreign religious workers.

In undertaking to condemn the methods of the investigation recently conducted by the Un-American Activities Committee of Congress into alleged subversive elements in Hollywood, Jacqueline Westerman, in your issue of Dec. 23, makes a charge against this committee which is entirely without basis.
NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 12 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper's $200,000 libel action against T. James Tumulty, Hudson County Assemblyman, was dismissed today by Circuit Court Judge Joseph L. Smith.

Net sales of the Marion Power Shovel Company last year exceeded $19,500,000, increasing more than $10,000,000 over the $9,415,986 volume transacted in 1946, Harvey T. Gracely, president, reported yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 12 -- Universal-International has signed Bela Lugosi to play Count Dracula, Lon Chaney Jr. to play the Wolfman and Glenn Strange to play Frankenstein's monster in the studio's next Bud Abbott-Lou Costello comedy, "The Brain of Frankenstein," which will go before the cameras on Feb. 2, with Charles Barton directing.

Leonard M. Weisman, 32-year-old head of three export and shipping concerns, announced yesterday that Foundry Associates, Inc., would take steps, legal if necessary, to recover all of the 200 tons of the explosive M-3 it bought from the War Assets Administration.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- New legislation asked by President Truman accounts for $5,735,000,000, or more than one-seventh of the total Federal spending proposed in today's $39,700,000,000 budget for fiscal 1949.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, will make his television debut next Monday, when he appears as a witness before the House committee investigating his union's sundry practices in the world of radio.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, urged Congress today to grant stand-by authority to ration meats and to control their prices at the wholesale level.

DETROIT, Jan. 12 -- Production of smaller, lighter cars to sell at retail for substantially lower prices than now exist is favored by more than 60 per cent of motorists, according to a country-wide survey presented here tonight at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

WHENEVER Al Schacht describes the emotions he experienced on the occasion of his first pitching effort in the big leagues, the Clown Prince whimsically remarks: "I wasn't hot. I wasn't cold. I was just mediocre."

Pressing his "comeback" campaign, Beau Jack, Georgia Negro who formerly held the world lightweight boxing championship, yesterday was signed to battle Billy Graham, hard-hitting East Sider, in the Madison Square Garden ring on Feb. 20.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Senator Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin told Canada today that plans to cut down exports of pulpwood from Ontario "would have very adverse effects" on the pulp and paper industry in the United States.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 12 -- Despite record enrollments, American colleges and universities are in desperate financial straits, educators attending the annual conference of the Association of American Colleges, warned here today.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A legislative investigation of "unfair, unwholesome and deplorable" conditions in professional boxing was asked tonight by Senator Isidore Dollinger, New York City Democrat.
Random notes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Eleven persons resigned from Government service while they were being investigated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation under the new Federal loyalty program, the FBI said today.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind dismissed yesterday for lack of jurisdiction a suit brought by tenants of unfurnished apartments at the Hotel Marcy, West End Avenue and Ninety-fifth Street, against the City Rent Commission and Bing and Bing, operators of the hotel.

Evidence unearthed in the death of 81-year-old Mathilde Molsberger, wealthy spinster of 131 East Ninety-third Street, started the District Attorney's office yesterday on an investigation of the death of a second woman, who died in 1936 in the same apartment building.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Federal Barge Lines contributed a gloomy picture of current finances in the budget submitted to Congress by President Truman today. The organization pinned hopes for continuance of operations on plans for new equipment.

HAVANA, Jan. 12 -- Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation, today urged the trade conference to write security for foreign investments into the proposed world trade charter, to encourage and not obstruct the economic development of the world's backward countries by private capital.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- The Treasury Department disclosed tonight that it plans to pay off $103,500,000 in Government debt in the form of 91-day treasury bills maturing on Jan. 22.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 12 -- About 600 volunteers for the Arab "People's Army" have left Lebanon for Syria in the last few days, a source in the Labanese Palestine Committee said today. According to an unconfirmed report, 200 Iraqi volunteers have also reached Syria.

The students of Section 21, Metropolitan Vocational High School, sent $10 yesterday to the Neediest Cases Fund for Case 106, "Fearful," the story of a 63-year-old woman who lives alone, fearful she may have cancer.

TOKYO, Jan. 12 -- The defense of Hideki Tojo and twenty-four other Japanese on trial before the international military tribunal as major war criminals closed this afternoon after almost one year. The presentation of the defense began Feb. 24, 1947, when Dr. Ichiro Kiyose, chief Japanese counsel, outlined to the eleven-nation court for the first time the contention -- maintained ever since by most defendants -- that the was was forced on Japan.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 12 (AP) -- A Notre Dame official tonight said it had "no reason to disagree" with The Associated Press poll which named Notre Dame the national football champion at the end of the regular season.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12 (UP) -- The San Francisco Clippers of the Pacific Coast League will make their second bid for a franchise in the National Football League at the annual N.F.L. meeting opening in New York City Wednesday, Commissioner Bert Bell revealed today.

Pointing out that the confused system of taxation on one hand and Government price-fixing on the other make up a sizable element of cost, Saul Cohn, president of City Stores Company, warned yesterday that the retailer's prerogative in pricing is rapidly diminishing.

Will you permit me, an unknown and undistinguished citizen of London, to express to the people of the United States of America our very deep gratitude for the innumerable practical acts of generosity and good-will which they have so willingly undertaken in order to relieve suffering and hardship in this and in many other countries.

Out-of-town clubs will seek to steal the show in the collegiate basketball twin bill booked for Madison Square Garden tonight. In the opener, Syracuse University's veteran five matches shots with City College, while St. Louis University, Missouri Valley Conference champion, tackles Long Island University in the nightcap.

An officer of the Communist party of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, filed yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court an affidavit denying that the organization advocated revolution by force or that it was affiliated with the party in Soviet Russia.

Learning of offers to sell Japanese cotton goods in domestic markets in the face of official assurances that they would not be marketed here, textile manufacturers expressed indignation and concern yesterday over the future economy of the industry.

Temperatures generally above the freezing mark kept New York from being smothered yesterday under another deep covering of snow. Rainfall during Monday night changed to mixed snow and rain or snow during the day, but in most of the city it melted nearly as fast as it fell.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Anglo-French talks with a view to calling another sixteen-nation conference on the Marshall program had to be postponed for one day. Herve Alphand, director of economic affairs of the French Foreign Ministry, reached London only tonight after having been delayed by a gale over the English Channel.
ITHACA, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- New York University's unbeaten basketball team won its tenth straight game tonight, conquering Cornell, 58 -- 53, before a crowd of 8,000.

When President Truman proposed last week, in his message to Congress on the State of the Union, that the Federal Government broaden its present program of social services, some Republican critics leaped promptly and eloquently to the conclusion that this would involve the expenditure of astronomical sums -- from which the Democratic party would hope to benefit in an election year.

Tomorrow midnight is the deadline for final quarterly payments on the 1947 declaration of Federal income tax, and for the amended declaration for 1947 by those whose previous estimates of income have missed by 20 per cent or more. Quarterly payments are due from persons whose tax has not been paid through withholding or other payments.

Jersey Joe Walcott, who almost dethroned heavyweight champion Joe Louis Dec. 5, staged the outstanding comeback of 1947 in the opinion of the sports editors participating in the annual Associated Press year-end poll.
JERUSALEM, Jan. 13 -- British troops went into action against Arab raiders again today in the Lake Hula region and on the Jerusalem-Hebron road in the south.
CINCINNATI, Jan. 13 -- After a spirited debate the Association of American Colleges today voted overwhelmingly against any form of compulsory universal military training.

Mme. Lilly Dache is to be commended for the manner in which she presented her millinery collection yesterday. She ensembled hats and dresses and coats, thus completing the silhouette. The dresses were made in her own establishment according to her individual style conception; the coats were fashioned after her suggestions by Lalli.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- In one of the basketball season's upsets, the Boston College Eagles, playing an aggressive, tight defensive game tonight downed highly favored Manhattan College, 66 -- 57, before 6,058 fans at Boston Garden.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Shopping for home furnishings or fashion accessories will be simplified as a result of the opening here today at Bamberger's of the Bamberger-Pratt Studio. The studio, a revolutionary type of classroom, will be used to train store personnel in the finer points of decorating and clothing so that they will be able to advise homemakers on their choices.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Fletcher R. Smith, Syracuse, N. Y., president of the National League of Wholesale Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Distributors, said today that railroad proposals for increased freight rates pose an immediate and major problem for the group since they will eventually destroy that industry or drive it to trucks.

Three narcotics squad detectives, including a woman, uncovered yesterday pure cocaine worth $75,000 at underworld retail prices -- largest quantity seized in recent years -- and arrested two men for illegal possession.

Fostoria Glass Company, the only important producer of household glassware which has not raised prices since last September, plans no immediate increases, W. F. Dalzell, president, said yesterday. Several retailers declared that the company will probably hold the price line well into the second half of the year at least.

Though more foods are available now than in March, 1947, when the contents to go into CARE's standard package were set up, that assortment can't be improved upon, for it provides the highest possible food value at its price -- $10. This is the decision reached by a group of leading nutritionists called in recently by the organization to scrutinize its ready-assembled parcels for possible changes or additions.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 13 -- The Arab League is expected to meet again this month to straighten out the differences that beset it during the December meeting. The main business will be an attempt to conciliate Haj Amin el Husseini, the Mufti of Jerusalem, who is exiled here, and King Abdullah of Trans-Jordan who have been feuding over procedure in the Palestine "invasion.''

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Edwin W. Pauley, whose commodity speculations have been tinder fire in Congress, asserted tonight that he expected to finish his mission as special assistant to Secretary of the Army Royall and to leave the department "some time this month."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Defenders of the President's recent message on the state of the Union, in which he fired verbal buckshot at a great number of targets without regard to the fact that some are out of range and others cannot be brought down with such ammunition, are taking much comfort in the fact that no one has criticized Mr. Truman's "aims."

PARIS, Wednesday, Jan. 14 -- After the re-election of Edouard Herriot as President of the National Assembly yesterday, a controversy arose over the selection of the vice presidents and other subsidiary officials. Communist members then engaged in obstruction that turned the first sitting of 1945 into one of the wildest in the annals of an often turbulent body.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The State Department, it was learned today, has divided the sixteen Marshall Plan countries into four categories in accordance with tentative estimates of their ability to pay for any further aid from the United States.

Owing to a trend toward an increasing life span and a decreasing birth rate, the greatest need in general hospitals is for "beds to serve persons in the second half of life," the Hospital Council of Greater New York said yesterday in a bulletin.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- Finance Minister Rene Mayer said today he would soon visit London to consult Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, regarding the reconvening of the sixteen-nation European Economic Conference, or at least its steering committee.

A banking group headed by Hallgarten Co., R. W. Press-prich Co. and the Adamex Securities Corporation placed on the market yesterday after the close of trading on the New York Stock Exchange a new issue of 185,000 shares of $1 par value common stock of the Joy Manufacturing Company.

During the first quarter of 1948, according to a survey just completed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, American business, exclusive of agriculture, plans to spend $4.1 billions on new plant construction and equipment. This would be an increase of 30 per cent over actual expenditures for the corresponding period in 1947.

Maintenance of the 1947 dividend rate of the First National Bank of New York depends on the course of interest rates, Alexander C. Nagle, president, indicated yesterday at the bank's annual shareholders' meeting. The annual dividend has been $80.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The French Communist party regards the unsuccessful November - December strike wave as only an "episode" in a vast struggle, and a class "battle" rather than a class war. It now is engaged in organizing and preparing for future "battles" and seeking to improve its efficiency on the basis of the lessons learned during the early winter strike.

Church World Service relief for overseas war victims in 1947, including cash donations, totaled $14,500,000, an increase of $1,000,000 over 1946, the Rev. Dr. A. Livingston Warnshuis, executive vice president, announced yesterday.

Norfolk, Va., sold yesterday $2,500,000 of general improvement bonds due Jan. 1 from 1953 to 1972, to Blyth Co., Inc., and associates at a bid of 100.169 for 2.60s, an interest cost of 2.588 per cent. The bonds were reoffered at prices yielding from 1.60 per cent to 2.75 per cent.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- The big film producting-distributing companies must be divested of their large theatre holdings, and other major theatre circuits not affiliated with production or distribution must also be broken up in order to assure a free and open system of marketing pictures, Samuel Goldwyn declared today.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13 -- The pro-government news agency Andi which, according to authoritative reports, is subsidized by the Peron regime, has fallen out of favor, at least temporarily, it became known today.

Many dinner parties will be given in advance of the performance of "Antony and Cleopatra" tonight at the Martin Beck Theatre which has been taken over to raise funds for the Madison Square Boys' Club. Mr. and Mrs. H. Howard Babcock will give a supper party at the Stork Club after the benefit.

Loss of industrial production in New York State because of strikes in 1947 was less than half that in 1946, according to data obtained yesterday from the State Labor Department. The peak year for strike activity in both the state and the nation was 1946.

LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Britain and the United States are going to invite French representatives to a conference in Berlin to discuss the new Anglo-American proposals for "Bizonia," it was learned on good authority here today. These talks could be expected to prove a first step on the road toward "Trizonia," should they succeed.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 13 -- An Inter-American Labor Confederation, to be known as the CIAT, was established here tonight as the four-day Inter-American Labor Congress closed. At the final session a five-man commission of honor rejected charges made yesterday by Luis Morones of Mexico against a United States delegate, Serafino Romauldi of the American Federation of Labor.
