The Board of Health decided yesterday to take over on March 1 regulation of an estimated 20,000 self-service, coin-operated washing machines in apartment houses in the city. This will enable health inspectors to enforce sanitary regulations concerning hot water and drainage and to penalize offending operators by revoking permits.

PRAGUE, Jan. 13 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Ministry of Information disclosed yesterday that regulations were being drawn up for "state regulation of the book market" to get more "progressive" books to the public.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 13 -- Lewis B. Schwellenbach, Secretary of Labor, expressed the belief today that labor would cooperate in efforts to curtail further wage increases "if given some real assurance that price rises will be checked."
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- The War Office declined today to reveal the specifications or value of the military arms and equipment being transferred by Britain to Iraq, Egypt and Trans-Jordan.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Civil authorities resumed control of Iran today for the first time in almost six years as the Government abolished martial law, which had been in effect almost continuously since. Allied forces entered the country in 1941.

Resurgence of retail advertising in which unwarranted claims are made concerning the value of goods offered shows that the comparative price mania is deeply ingrained in the minds of many retailers, Hugh Smith, manager of the Better Business Bureau of Philadelphia, asserted yesterday.

Astronomical figures soaring up into the Amos and Andy realm began emerging yesterday from the National Motor Boat Show. On a day when the weather man couldn't make up his mind whether to turn on the rain or the snow and therefore alternated with both, thousands of show-goers arrived at Grand Central Palace early and stayed inside this snug harbor until late, looking at boats, talking boats and evidently buying boats.

Americans everywhere will agree with the compliment paid to the Salvation Army by Secretary of Argiculture Anderson recently when he said that the organization had found "a most practical way of expressing the ideal of brotherhood." Furthermore, we can all prove our good-will by contributing liberally to the Army's 1948 campaign for $1,000,000 for its maintenance fund.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Justin Miller, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, asserted today that James C. Petrillo broke off collective bargaining with the radio networks over the question of "live music" after Jan. 31 because the broadcasters declined to ask President Truman to veto the Lea Bill.

Parental rights in the case of a child brought into being by artificial insemination are equal to those acquired by a foster parent who has formally adopted a child, Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg ruled yesterday in a suit brought by Mrs. Julie Strnad, who sought to have her husband, Antoine Strnad, barred from visiting their 4-year-old daughter Antoinette.

Petitions have been signed by members of ten Protestant churches in Brooklyn to protest the proposed condemnation by the city of the Brooklyn Friends School and Meeting House property as a site for a new jail, it was reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A new type of consular convention designed to place consular relations on a modern and standard basis has been signed with Costa Rica, the State Department announced today.

L. Raymond Billett of Chicago, a partner in the investment banking firm of Kebbon, McCormick Co., was elected yesterday chairman of the board of governors of the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc. He succeeds Herbert F. Boynton of H. F. Boynton Co., Inc., here.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Jan. 13 -- Clydeside, the largest shipbuilding center in Great Britain and cradle of the great Cunard liners, has reacted sharply to the proposals in the United States Government's report on economic aid to Europe.

Jackie Cranford undertakes another step in his campaign along the heavyweight title trail Jan. 30, in Madison Square Garden, when the young Washington, D. C., boxer opposes Gino Buonvino, Bari, Italy, in a bout scheduled for ten rounds.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- Several delegations on the United Nations Military Staff Committee have begun discussing the question of how big an international force would be required to carry out the partition of Palestine if the Arabs offered serious resistance, it was learned today.

The memory of Felix M. Warburg, noted philanthropist who would have been 77 years old today, was honored yesterday with the presentation of a forty-six-acre tract of land in New Castle, Westchester County, as an addition to the state park system.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- The Chicago Orchestral Association, which conducts the affairs of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, today abruptly dismissed its new conductor, Dr. Artur Rodzinski, effective with the close of the present season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 13 -- Cargo movements totaling 6,520,762 measurement tons to Pacific bases were directed and controlled during 1947 by the San Francisco Port of Embarkation, Brig. Gen. Neal H. McKay, port commander, reported this week in a summary of the year's operations.

Neither rain nor snow seems able to slow down the Yankee rush to convince the baseball universe that signing up a world championship cast can be no serious problem if you tackle the job liberally enough. Yesterday General Manager George M. Weiss announced that two more important members have come into the fold for 1948.

The Schulte Real Estate Company, Inc., has sold the four-story store, loft and apartment building at 647 Eighth Avenue to Cawley's, Inc., represented by George Kittner, attorney. The property, assessed at $113,000, is on the west side of the block between Forty-first and Forty-second Streets.
The Superior Oil Company of California reported yesterday for the quarter ended on Nov. 30 a net profit of $3,461,440 after all charges, including $4,790,063 for depreciation, depletion and interest.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 13 -- Passage of the so-called "unification bill," or National Defense Act, last year has not altered in any important particular the concepts, policies or organization of the Air University, which is commanded by Maj. Gen. Muir S. Fairchild.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

TENAFLY, N. J., Jan. 13 -- Universal military training was advocated and assailed by military and educational authorities who participated this afternoon in THE NEW YORK TIMES' "What's On Your Mind?" Forum conducted before the Tenafly Woman's Club and broadcast over station WQXR.
SEATTLE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Times said today that Howie Odell, head football coach at Yale, would be the new gridiron mentor at the University of Washington.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The discovery of a new particle in the atom nucleus, touched upon yesterday by Frederic Joliot-Curie, French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, in a paper read to the Academy of Sciences, was explained here today by its discoverer, Prof. Pierre Auger of the faculty of science of the University of Paris, He called it a possible key to hitherto untapped sources of enormous power of the nucleus.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- President Truman took a direct hand in the campaign for his re-election for the first time today as he cleared the way for a series of conferences between leaders of the Democratic and Liberal parties in New York State.

A response to the criticism from overseas charging that American golf "has gone to seed" and that the basic rules of golf are being abandoned, came yesterday from Ed Dudley, president of the Professional Golfers Association of America.

MONTEREY, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Frenzied gold "prospectors" using shovels and rakes, aided by construction bulldozers, by tonight had dug $20 gold pieces with a total face value exceeding $6,000 from a vacant lot being cleared here for a new school building.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board issued today his sixth complaint against the International Typographical Union, AFL. He directed the complaint specifically at the dispute in Chicago, where newspaper printers have been on strike more than six weeks.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange again held yesterday within a narrow range, reflecting slower cotton goods and spot markets. Final prices were 2 to 14 points net lower.

Stanley Weiner, a talented young violinist, made his recital debut in Times Hall before an enthusiastic audience last night. He has been heard this season as concertmaster and soloist with the New York City Symphony. Last night's performance was marked by most of the good, as well as some of the less-good aspects of the orchestral musician.

American motion-picture companies now can liquidate millions of dollars blocked in six European countries, including France and Italy, by producing pictures in those countries or sending location crews there to photograph sequences in pictures, it was disclosed yesterday by Gerald M. Mayer, chief of the International Department of the Motion Picture Association of America.

Cats are not so "catty or vain" as women, according to a beauty parlor operator who deserted his women customers yesterday to comb the gray tresses of his Blue Persian for the opening of the Atlantic Cat Show at the Great Northern Hotel.

A shortage of new capital, unless relieved by higher corporate earnings or investment by the public, may cut gross national production this year by $15 billions or 7 per cent, Morris Natelson, head of the industrial department of Lehman Brothers, investment bankers, warned yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 13 -- Warner Brothers will institute a new program of low-budget film production with the start tomorrow of "Fighting Terror," in which Wayne Morris, Fred Clark, Mary Stuart and Lois Maxwell will appear.

Valuable help to the Communists of China has come from party members in the United States and especially from those in the Soviet Union, according to a Chinese Communist handbook made public yesterday by the American China Policy Association.

Although clouded by the forthcoming Presidential election, the economic outlook for 1948 indicates a year of further inflationary trends, good business and profits, according to Leo Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America.

Reporting on last year's operations of the Trade Bank and Trust Company, Henry L. Schenk, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the decline in net operating earnings to $195,295 from $240,170 in 1946 was accounted for by increased salaries and operating expenses.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Jan. 12 (Delayed) -- Premier Georgi Dimitrov tonight warned the Parliamentary Opposition, which consists of nine Social Democrats, to remember the fate of Nikola Petkov, the Opposition Agrarian leader, who was executed in September.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander met yesterday with representatives of trucking, labor, railroad, real estate, manufacturing and shipping interests in an effort to lay the groundwork for a solution of the traffic problem in the garment area.

Representatives of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company, the Kings County Lighting Company and the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company conferred yesterday with officials at Police Headquarters on possible measures for a gas-supply emergency.

Forty-seven persons contributed $601 to THE NEW YORK TIMES Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, bringing the total so far in the thirty-sixth annual appeal to $355,082.22. The number of contributors stands at 12,700.

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- The battle between the Communist-directed General Confederation of Labor and the anti-Communist Force Ouvriere led by the Socialist Leon Jouhaux has reached its acute stage with the traditional January drive for the renewal of union cards.

The New York Rangers are in third place in the National Hockey League standings and the Chicago Black Hawks in the cellar, but the Windy City skaters have been far from a soft touch for the New Yorkers. In fact, the season's series between the teams has been top-heavy in Chicago's favor, 4 -- 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- The United Nations Economic and Social Council will meet here Feb. 2 to begin debate on forty agenda items involving the economic problems of Europe, the Far East, Latin America and the Middle East.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Marshall Plan for European aid was endorsed as "indispensable" today by the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America.

Judge Jonah J. Goldstein of the Court of General Sessions was installed last night as president of the Grand Street Boys Association for the thirteenth consecutive year. Presiding at the induction ceremonies in the association clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street, was Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally.
Mayor O'Dwyer renewed yesterday his opposition to the plan for a St. Lawrence Seaway, sending telegrams to that effect to President Truman and Senators Robert F. Wagner and Irving Ives.

One feels ungracious, in view of the money and effort bestowed upon the newly mounted "Ring" cycle at the Metropolitan, in putting down some unavoidable disparagements. This refers to the performance of "Walkuere" given yesterday afternoon as the second opera of the special matinee cycle.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 13 (AP) -- A margin as thin as the blade of an ice skate separated the champion, Hans Gerschwiller of Switzerland, and his principal challenger, Richard Button of the United States, at the close of the men's compulsory figure skating in the European championships today.

BOSTON, Jan. 13 -- The resignation of Reginald F. Cahalane, executive director of the Massachusetts Blue Cross since its inception in 1937, was announced today by the board of directors. The post pays $18,000 annually. Roger W. Hardy, Boston lawyer and clerk of the board, was named acting director.
DETROIT, Jan. 13 -- Methods of speeding production to meet the increasing demand for motor vehicles were emphasized today at the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers here.

Final registration and enrollment figures for 1947 were released yesterday by the Board of Elections. They showed that 2,223,422 of the city's voters, out of 2,362,748 who registered, enrolled in one of the four recognized parties.

A lawyer who on Saturday in Felony Court took the part of the apartment - house superintendent and the undertaker accused of an alleged will forgery involving a quarter-of-a-million-dollar estate withdrew from the case yesterday.

A new two-story and basement emergency accident building will be constructed at Roosevelt Hospital, starting in three or four weeks, it was announced yesterday. The building, the cost of which was estimated at $600,000, will be on Fifty-eighth Street near Ninth Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Jan. 13 -- State institutional care for chronic alcoholics was advocated today by the Westchester Joint Committee on Alcoholism in a report filed with the State Interdepartmental Council in Albany.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 -- The Philadelphia National Bank today reported net operating earnings of $4,113,581 in 1947, against $4,973,584 in 1946 and gross operating earnings of $10,318,134 last year, compared with $11,254,459 in 1946, with the major difference occurring in interest received on Government security holdings.

Two new exhibitions open today at the Museum of Modern Art -- one including recent acquisitions for the museum's permanent collections, the other, small paintings by French children selected from work done in competitions in France since 1935. They are installed in a series of connecting galleries on the ground floor.

In view of the slight firming of interest rates in recent months, bank earnings during 1948 should be as good as, and "possibly better" than, in 1947, according to Walter G. Kimball, chairman of the Commercial National Bank and Trust Company of New York.
The past year, according to the records of the New York Conservation Department, set a new record for lawlessness in hunting and fishing, as well as a new high for the total fines paid.

Stocks moved sluggishly during yesterday's trading on the New York Stock Exchange until the final hour when liquidation struck on a heavy scale. Prices closed fractions to 2 points lower with the volume increasing as values declined. Transactions aggregated 950,000 shares, compared with 1,000,000 shares on the previous day. Trading between 1 and 2 o'clock was at such a slow pace that the ticker was idle for minutes at a time.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 13 -- A far-reaching plan for transit consolidations in north Jersey with a rail tunnel under the Hudson River to midtown Manhattan was set before the New Jersey Legislature today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

Due to an enlarged potential market for manufacturers and dealers in musical instruments, Louis G. La Mair, president of the National Association of Music Merchants, Inc., predicted yesterday a year of expansion in this field.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Sears, Roebuck Co., retail and mail order merchandisers, issued today its spring and summer general catalogue with the observation that prices averaged 2.8 per cent higher than in the comparable book a year ago.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 13 -- Simplification and standardization of equipment, designed to lower distribution and production costs and reduce waste of energy, was advocated today by a series of speakers at the National Materials Handling Exposition.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan 13 -- Following a victory at the polls over his legislative opponents and the imposition of an unprecedented ban on attendance at his press conference for representatives of all daily newspapers in the state, Gov. James E. Folsom has departed from the Capitol on a vacation of indefinite duration.

PARIS, Jan. 13. -- (UP) -- The namesake of Charlie Chaplin's villainous "Monsieur Verdoux" sued two moving picture companies for damages today after a Paris court had rejected his plea for a change in the name of the veteran screen comedian's latest picture.

In all the forecasts of problems to come before the New York Legislature, including the program outlined by Governor Dewey, we regret to discover that consideration of state aid to public libraries is among the missing. We find this omission a source of concern and regret.

In a day when dead cats for tossing into neighboring yards are no trouble to find, trust "Topics of The Times" to suggest, instead, another bouquet. The column of Jan. 1 reminded us that fifty years after 1898 (when Spain lost her last American possessions) ties of language and culture still remain. The point is important.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade were firm at the start today, only to break sharply later under profit-taking sales and then rally sharply with feed grains in the lead. Corn, oats and soy beans sold at record prices as the result of the late upturn, and the finish was about the top.
A shameful aspect of recent events in Palestine has not been brought before the American people -- therefore this letter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- building program for passenger ships, to cost $150,000,000 a year for four years, recommended recently by a Presidential advisory committee appeared today to have been shelved by the Administration. President Truman asked Congress for only $24,180,000 for new ship construction, including reconditioning and improvement, during the twelve months beginning July 1.
The first spot sales of 1948 crop sugars were reported yesterday at 5.70 cents a pound, compared with 6.32 cents charged by the Government on its remaining stockpile of 1947 crop sugar.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 13 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea met today behind closed doors.

GENEVA, Jan. 13 -- The survey of European economic recovery now being completed by the Economic Commission for Europe will show far greater progress toward satisfactory production levels than has generally been supposed, Gunnar Myrdal, executive secretary of the commission, said here today.

A campaign to raise funds for musical training and rehabilitation of hospitalized veterans was begun yesterday by the Hospitalized Veterans Music Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund at a meeting in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Legislation to abolish the Court of General Sessions and the County Courts in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Richmond was introduced in the State Legislature today by Senator Pliny Williamson of Westchester County and Assemblyman Harry A. Reoux of Warren County, chairmen of the Legislative Judiciary Committees.

"Advances in Military Medicine," the fourth in the series on the history of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, has been scheduled for publication on Jan. 26 by Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown. The two-volume edition is divided into six sections with an additional chapter on penicillin.

The suggestion made in your editorial of Jan. 2, "A Tax Return Time-Saver," will have to await the millennium, for a number of reasons. For one thing, you would have that old bugaboo, "invasion of states' rights"; also, New York State allows a deduction for expenses for education of children at college, whereas Uncle Sam does not. Some taxes are allowable deductions on the federal return, but are disallowed by the state.

THE Navy has been dragging its anchor for a mighty long while as a result of its insistence on graduate coaching for its football teams. But the midshipmen have finally hauled up anchor and the bridge has signaled the engine room for full speed ahead. Civilian coaching has been restored, and hope for the future with it.

At the ninety-fourth annual meeting of the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company yesterday, Dunham B. Sherer, chairman, told stockholders that while gross operating earnings rose $549,764 to $14,046,456, expenses were up $907,394 to $10,274,357, leaving earnings at $3,772,098 at the end of 1947, or $357,624 below the earnings reported at Dec. 31, 1946.
LONDON, Jan. 13 -- Only a small amount of business was done in the stock markets here today and price movements generally were restricted.

Production of steel in the United States last year, according to the official tabulation of the American Iron and Steel Institute, amounted to 84,787,501 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, establishing a new record for peacetime operations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- J. A. Krug, Secretary of the Interior, warned today that known United States petroleum reserves would be exhausted in ten years at the current rate of consumption and asked Congress for fewer laws and more funds to develop shale oil deposits and synthetic liquid fuels.

HAVANA, Jan. 13 -- The United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, which opened Nov. 21, is officially scheduled to end Thursday, but it is so far from agreement on several major issues that the official target date may have to be postponed for at least another month.

The Quantacolor system of color harmony, which offers a short-cut to picking pleasing color schemes was discussed last evening by Howard Clark in the second of a series of talks on contemporary problems in design sponsored by the New York chapter of the Women's Architectural Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association and the American Newspaper Guild of the CIO differed sharply today over the "professional" status of reporters, with premium pay for overtime past forty hours a week at stake.

Five complaints of exporters regarding the recently announced export licensing policy of the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce were answered here yesterday by Francis E. McIntyre, assistant director, and George Bell, associate director. During a press conference at the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce offices in the Empire State Building, they declared the new rules uphold, rather than restrict, rights of private export agencies.

Some excellent British actors have crossed the Atlantic to bring us a mediocre British play. It is Michael Clayton Hutton's "Power Without Glory," put on at the Booth last evening. That title might do double duty as criticism of the production. For the actors, who have come here to repeat their London experience, bring power to a melodrama that lacks glory.

A general rent increase in this city would not be justified, but if granted would be followed by demands for wage increases, Daniel Allen, political action director of the Greater New York CIO Council, declared yesterday. Taking part in a conference of tenant, consumer and labor organizations at Freedom House, 20 West Fortieth Street, he demanded that rents be decreased by an amount suitable to the "gross deterioration" of services furnished tenants.

Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall said yesterday in Washington that the War Assets Administration would cancel the sale of 200 tons of the explosive M-3 that was purchased by Foundry Associates, Inc., for eventual shipment to Palestine.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 13 -- Unrest because of food shortages may spread throughout the bizonal area earlier than has been expected, it was indicated today. Bizonal food and agriculture officials went into session here today seeking, even in advance of the mandate of the new economic administration, to centralize the existing food collection agencies.

If the nation is to meet its major problem of the wage-price spiral, business and labor must conduct their relations on a more moral basis, Louis Broido, executive vice president of Gimbel Bros. said yesterday. He addressed the annual meeting and spring merchandising clinic of the Millinery Merchandising Executive Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Federal Government, through the Department of Justice, asked the Supreme Court today for aid in enforcing a three-year-old lower court ruling holding the Aluminum Company of America to be a monopoly.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Following is the summary of the report of the President's Air Policy Commission given out this evening at the White House:

Legislation to cure "most glaring evils" ascribed to contemporary Congressional investigating committees was recommended last night by Federal Judge Charles E. Wyzanski of Boston and Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora of New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The proposal to transfer 500 ships to European nations under the Marshall recovery program was described today by Representative Willis W. Bradley of California, as a threat to national security and a disaster to the American Merchant Marine.

The president of Colonial Airlines decided yesterday that if the police could not prevent robberies of his company's office at 51 Vanderbilt Avenue, perhaps they could be averted by offering substantial rewards.

TRENTON, N. J., Dec. 15 -- Faced with a heavy task because of the extensive changes in governmental organization and procedure demanded by the revised state constitution, the 1948 New Jersey Legislature convened today, heard the extensive legislative program of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll, named necessary officers and recessed after a traditional first-day session.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 13 -- Commercial and industrial employes in Argentina now have one day of rest for every two they work, a factor in the present terrific inflation, according to private interests, which have begun a campaign for fewer holidays.

While it expressed approval of Mayor O'Dwyer's plan for a higher subway fare, the New York Board of Trade announced yesterday that it would oppose his legislative program for increasing the debt limit and imposing additional taxes until the transit system was completely self-supporting.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 (AP) -- H. R. Lake, president of Santa Fe Skyway, Inc., air freight subsidiary of the Santa Fe Railway, announced today it had been decided to abandon operations of Skyway "in the immediate future."

PARIS, Jan. 13 -- A talk today with Leon Jouhaux, leader of "Force Ouvriere," pointed up the great importance of the break in the ranks of French workers not only on the internal struggle now moving into another critical phase but on the part France will play in the European recovery program.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 13 -- Mohandas K. Gandhi began his fast for inter-community unity at 11 o'clock this morning upon finishing his usual frugal breakfast of goats' milk, boiled vegetables and fruit juice. Except for hot water, salt and lime juice he has pledged to take no nourishment until he is satisfied of a "reunion of hearts" between Moslems and Hindus and Sikhs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 (AP) -- Non-farm employment rose to an all-time high of nearly 51,000,000 in December, topping November by 400,000, the Census Bureau reported today.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 3,348, compared with 2,185 in the previous week and 3,565 in the corresponding week of 1947, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- Immediate and substantial enlargement of the Air Force for "survival in the air age" was urged tonight in a report by the President's Air Policy Commission. The chairman of the commission, which spent five months surveying the air position of the United States, is Thomas K. Finletter of New York.

Outclassing his opponent, Georgie Small, 161 1/2, Brownsville, gained a technical knockout triumph over Irish Billy Walker, 166, Saybrook, Conn., in 2:20 of the third round of the main attraction carded for eight stanzas at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Jan. 13 -- The new federal system of government for Indonesia, containing varying degrees of independence for its component parts, is to be pushed toward realization with all possible speed, the Dutch Premier, Dr. Louis S. M. Beel, stated today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 12 (AP) -- Five men were killed and four injured today when an Eastern Airlines plane smashed into a wooded slope on the Maryland side of the Potomac River near here.

The $145,000 mortgage obtained by the Albert Bonier Publishing Company was on the five-story office and store building at 605 Madison Avenue, and not at 605 Fifth Avenue as was published in yesterday's paper.

SEATTLE, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The fifteen passengers and members of the crew of the small steamer Aleutian Mail and an estimated crew of nine on a foundering Army barge in western Alaska waters were rescued late today.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The National Football League's "long season" that ended three days after Christmas, 1947, is slated for much-winded debate at the Loop's annual meeting, but little -- if any -- schedule change is expected.

Virgil M. Graham, director of technical relations for Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., Flushing, has been elected chairman of the Joint Electron Tube Engineering Council, sponsored by the Radio Manufacturers Association and the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

At a special meeting of the International Business Machines Corporation, stockholders yesterday approved a split-up of the company's capital stock whereby stockholders of record Jan. 23 will receive three-quarters of an additional share of stock for each share then held. Scrip certificates will be issued for fractional shares. Certificates for the additional stock will be mailed on Feb. 6, or as soon thereafter as practicable.
The New York public schools' proposed budget for 1948-49, to be issued today at the Board of Education, is expected to total about $208,000,000, a record, it was learned yesterday.

Emil Von Elling, whose appointment as an assistant Olympic track and field coach was announced Sunday, was the recipient of congratulations from all hands at the track writers' weekly scrimmage with the fried chicken at the New York A. C. yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 13 -- Newspapers are gaining faster in their share of the total advertising dollar than any other medium, Alfred Stanford, new national director of the Bureau of Advertising, ANPA, told delegates to the semi-annual convention of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association today in a morning session at the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

A dollars-and-cents indication that the efficiency of the detective division of the Police Department has benefited from the "continuous survey" policy initiated by Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander was seen by observers at headquarters yesterday.

The Army transport Joseph V. Connolly was reported still afire at 3 P. M., E. S T., yesterday with the heat intense at a distance of one-quarter mile, but there was no indication that she was sinking.

Plans for the nineteen-story and penthouse building containing 595 suites to be erected by the New York Life Insurance Company on the former Third Avenue Railway carbarn site between Second and Third Avenues and Sixty-fifth and Sixty-sixth Streets were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings.

At the eighty-third annual meeting yesterday of stockholders of the Central-Penn National Bank of Philadelphia, Horace P. Liversidge, chairman of the board of the Philadelphia Electric Company, and William Park, president of the American Stores Company, Philadelphia, were elected directors of the bank.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 13 (AP) -- The Netherlands Government took a preliminary step today toward formation of a federated United States of Indonesia with the installation of an Interim Government made up of seven representatives of Dutch-controlled areas.

When President Truman appointed an Air Policy Commission last July he expressed the hope that it would make its investigation so broad in scope that its recommendations could "serve as a guide for formulating a carefully considered national air policy." The Commission's report, which was made public yesterday and is summarized in other columns of this newspaper this morning, lives up fully to that expressed hope.

Sightless David MacLevy, 73-year-old ex-convict, who once went to jail because he didn't like the caviar his grocer sent him, will arrive here from California in his accustomed style to face a grand larceny charge that may mean a life sentence, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced last night that he had ordered a broad survey designed to rezone New York, with particular reference to the use of land in the outlying areas. He said he had just finished conferring with Robert F. Wagner Jr., City Planning Chairman, and Lawrence M. Orton, a member of the City Planning Commission, and had directed that the work begin.

The rayon industry, with current productive capacity of 1,022,000,000 pounds annually, will increase its potential by 15 per cent in the next two years, according to the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., yesterday.

"Strange Bedfellows," tonight's arrival at the Morosco, is a byproduct of "Harriet," in which Helen Hayes starred five years ago. What's the connection? "Harriet" was written by Colin Clements and Florence Ryerson, husband and wife team, and directed by Ella Kazan.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 13 (AP) -- Racing to his second straight local conquest, Sophocles carried the Baltimore-owned silks of Mrs. Alice Hecht to an easy length-and-a-half triumph in today's feature at Gulfstream Park, witnessed by a throng of 13,200.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- Legislative approval of $4 to $6 weekly increases in unemployment insurance benefits and rejection of union-sponsored proposals to set up a system of dependency allowances seemed assured today as the Joint Committee on Labor and Industry held its first meeting of the session.

Most of the 18,471 fans who saw St. Louis University hand Long Island University a 68-57 setback last night at Madison Square Garden were convinced they had seen one of the best college basketball teams ever to have performed on Eighth Avenue.

"An Ideal Husband," which opens at the Roxy, is this morning's lone film newcomer. Filmed in Technicolor, the drama was produced and directed by Sir Alexander Korda from the play by Oscar Wilde and a screen play by Lajos Biro and is being released by Twentieth Century-Fox.

The steadily increasing proportion of debt to equity in the capital structures of corporations is "an unsound trend," in the opinion of officials of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, N. Baxter Jackson, chairman, stated yesterday.

ATHENS, Jan. 13 (UP) -- Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the United States Aid Mission, said today that he might return to Washington within a few weeks to review the entire aid program. He indicated that he did not see eye to eye with Greek officials on economic and military policies.

An agreement calling for the production of motion pictures especially for television has been concluded between the National Broadcasting Company and Jerry Fairbanks Productions, it was announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 13 -- The Young commission on the need for a state university has approved recommendations calling for a complete revision of the concept of state scholarships for college students and an increase in the number of such awards.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development has no need for additional funds at present, and as a consequence does not expect to issue any new securities in the near future, officials of the organization disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- The Department of the Army announced today a new three-month program for the enlistment of "specially qualified Negroes for duty with specified units of the Army Ground Forces and technical services."

Ellabelle Davis has had a lot of grooming since her debut five years ago. On the basis of her first Carnegie Hall concert last night, one would say the soprano has both gained and lost in the process.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 -- A Senate committee took a stand today against civilian posts going to personnel from the armed forces who retained their full military status.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- An agreement was reached today to consolidate for hearing purposes two complaints of unfair labor practice against the International Typographical Union, AFL. Union counsel had protested against "outrageous persecution" and threatened to withdraw from the principal case.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Representative John McDowell asserted tonight that Ferenc Vajta, Hungarian refugee, gained entrance to the United States without a passport.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The forword and summary of President Truman's economic report to Congress follows:

The police began yesterday an investigation into the theory that Benjamin (Chippy) Weiner, 43-year-old ex-convict who was shot fatally at his lower East Side apartment, was involved in the racket of-receiving stolen merchandise.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 14 -- Braving bitter, freezing winds, a great crowd today jammed this capital's principal stadium to welcome the United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea.

In an attempt to unravel one of the most perplexing stock deals that has appeared in financial circles in recent years, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein ordered subpoenas issued yesterday to three principals involved in the mysterious effort of certain unidentified persons to gain control of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh.

In the metropolitan area 4,611 disabled veterans still need jobs, as compared with 6,573 a year ago, M. Joseph Tierney, director of the New York State Employment Service, declared yesterday. New applications for aid last month totaled 679, as against 1,276 in December, 1946.

PRAGUE, Jan. 14 -- Czechoslovakia's Communists have promised, in the interests of the policy of the Communist Information Bureau, to bring back to this country the principle of national minority privileges that was abolished after the war, according to information from the Democrats, the majority Slovak party.

The Tishman Realty and Construction Company has sold the store property at 504 and 506 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, to Chicago investment interests represented by Sanford S. Ruttenberg. This property, together with adjoining Fulton Street frontage and the remainder of the T-shaped plot with outlets on Bond Street and Hanover Place, under other ownership, is occupied by the McCrory Stores Corporation.

Hempstead, L.I., Union Free School District No. 9 sold yesterday $1,885,000 of bonds due June 1 from 1949 to 1977 to a banking group headed by Bankers Trust Company at a bid of 100.55 for 2.70s. About half of the issue was immediately placed with investors on reoffering at prices ranging from a price to yield 1 per cent to a dollar price of 99 for maturities extending from 1974 to 1977.

Despite current conditions, term loans are desirable investments provided they are made on the basis of sound credit, John E. Bierwirth, president of the New York Trust Company, asserted yesterday at the bank's annual shareholders' meeting.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The War Ministry said tonight that Greek Government forces had recaptured the village of Arakhova in the rugged Pindus Mountains from guerrilla troops who suffered "terrific losses."

"Engineered buying" by retailers will be the next major change in merchandising, following the development in recent years of specialization, occasion ready-to-wear and new buying centers, Irwin D. Wolf, vice president of Kaufmann Department Stores and the May Department Stores Company, predicted yesterday.
The downward trend of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange persisted yesterday with final prices 5 to 21 points net lower than the day before.

A memorial dinner was held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to start a drive to raise funds for a Jimmy Walker memorial. It attracted an audience of politicians, stage and screen figures, and leaders of the garment industry, with which the late Mayor had been associated.

Municipal bond men face today a succession of sales which add up to an unusually heavy schedule for a Thursday. Chief interest lies in the pricing of $10,000,000 of South Carolina highway obligations carrying maturities bunched from 1954 to 1957.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that without a European recovery program "the Army and its budget should be immediately and measurably increased."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Miss Susan B. Anthony 2d, announced today that the Congress of American Women would protest a restricted visa granted by the United States to Mme. Francoise Leclerc, allegedly the communistic representative of the Women's International Democratic Federation, who arrived here today.

Net income of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for the eleven months to Nov. 30 declined $23,441,763 to $118,948,846 from the amount reported for the first eleven months of 1946, it was disclosed yesterday in the company's reports to the Federal Communications Commission.

Letters asking support for Mayor O'Dwyer's legislative program for 1948, including an 8-cent fare on the municipal transit lines, were sent yesterday to all members of the Legislature by the Transport Workers Union, CIO. They were signed by City Councilman Michael J. Quill, international president of the union, and Austin Hogan, president of Local 100, many of whose members are employed on the city lines.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- A Government lending agency is needed to cope with emergency situations which involve the national interest, Henry T. Bodman, a member of the board of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, told a Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee today as he urged that the RFC be continued.

Plans for coordination of an overseas advertising campaign to generate better understanding and knowledge of American democracy and provide information on the sources of rehabilitation aid are being considered by the Advertising Council, it was learned yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 14 -- Undefeated Columbia gained its tenth victory and its third Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League triumph by conquering Yale, 56 -- 44, before a capacity crowd of 2,400 on the Payne Whitney court tonight.
Mayor O'Dwyer stepped yesterday into the controversy over the "no contract" policy adopted by the International Typographical Union, AFL, as a means of fighting the Taft-Hartley law.

The Chase National Bank in 1947 did the most business for any year in its history, but earnings declined from $22,141,000 to $19,826,000, chiefly because of a sharp drop of profits on securities, according to the annual report of Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman. Copies of the report are being mailed to the bank's 91,000 shareholders prior to the annual meeting to be held Jan. 27.

The heavy demands for funds by industry and municipalities will influence interest rates to higher levels in 1948, James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company, predicted yesterday. In his report to stockholders at their annual meeting, Mr. Blaine listed the company's net operating earnings in the year ended on Dec. 31, 1947, at $1,771,974, compared with $1,716,771 at the close of the previous year.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The United States refused today the request of Yugoslavia for the release of her funds of up to $70,000,000 that are frozen in this country.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Armed will make his first big effort of the year tomorrow toward regaining world money-winning honors among the thoroughbreds when he runs in the $25,000 added Gulfstream Park Handicap, closing day feature.

From the way play started at Madison Square Garden last night, it looked as if the New York Rangers again would be unable to shake the virtual jinx held over them this season by the Chicago Black Hawks. For early in the second period of the National Hockey League clash, the last place Hawks had a two-goal advantage and there didn't appear much hope the Blue Shirts would snap out of it.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Army rejected today suggestions that it was "propagandizing" the public to put pressure on Congress for universal military training but served notice that "every legitimate medium" would be used to explain the program to the country at large.

THE Yankee outfield for 1948 now may be considered intact -- provided, of course, that Charlie Keller is intact. With the signing of King Kong for an estimated $25,000 salary, the Bronx Bombers have reunited the swarthy slugger with Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich, a rather fair-to-middling trio, eh, wot?

In one of the Roman Catholic Church's most solemn and impressive ceremonies, a priest of the New York Archdiocese, Msgr. Patrick A. O'Boyle, was consecrated yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral as first Archbishop of the newly established Archdiocese of Washington, D.C.

KHYBER PASS, Pakistan, Jan. 13 (Delayed) -- Welcoming the Prime Minister of Pakistan, Liaqat All Khan, to the Khyber Agency, Abdul Latif Khan, chief of the Malikdin Khel, one of the Afridi tribes, said that the 60,000 tribal raiders in Kashmir would never withdraw.

With a little assistance from Aristophanes, Florence Ryerson and Colin Clements have written a comedy about the battle of the sexes, "Strange Bedfellows," which I was put on at the Morosco last evening. Since the authors are married, they probably are acquainted with the battle of the sexes which day by day is exhausting the manpower of the world.

The Schools Motion Picture committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Although business was not large on the first day of the new account, a better tendency was noticeable in the stock markets here today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Up to 75 per cent of the deer in the 40,000 game-protected acres of the Bear Mountain section of the Palisades Interstate Park and adjacent Rockland County forests will die within the next few weeks if they are not fed and protected from dogs, according to a survey today by Gus Hlaverty, Chief of the Palisades Interstate Park Police.

Dorothy Minty, violinist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. In an exacting program composed of the Dohnanyi Sonata, Op. 21; the Hindemith Concerto and the Chausson Concerto for piano, violin and string quartet, Miss Minty disclosed new powers, not only as interpreter, but in technical skill. Her performances were imaginative, intense and alive, as well as colorful and comprehending.

An old holding of the Courtlandt F. Bishop Estate in midtown-Manhattan has passed to new control with the sale of the four-story building at 1125 Avenue of the Americas, between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, to David S. Meister, operator, in a cash transaction negotiated by Arnold T. Milton, broker, and reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Budget Bureau and the State Department appear to have failed in their attempt to place the operating details of the Economic Cooperation Administration, in addition to its over-all policies, under the hour-by-hour "direction and control" of the Department.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

The Sarasol Realty Corporation, of which Dr. Solomon Simon and Sarah W. Simon are the principals, have purchased the six-story, eighty-four-family apartment house at 1725 Andrews Avenue, the Bronx, from Jacob Levine and Charles Chatzinoff.

While thousands of others milled around Grand Central Palace yesterday, climbing and descending boarding ladders of the yachts anchored indoors at the National Motot Boat Show and wearing out salesmen with the questions, owners of waterfront service stations joined with Government officials in an all-day conference on marinas at the Hotel Sheldon.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Governor Dewey welcoming into the New York National Guard today the 10,000th recruit of the post-war enlistment drive, said that the state's Guard was now the largest in the country. It numbers 11,550 officers and men.

Whatever difficulties had existed in the renewal of the Twentieth century Sporting Club's lease of Yankee Stadium as a boxing arena dissipated yesterday. After a s of conferences among Sol iss, representing Twentieth century Club, Madison Square en, represented by Brig. Gen.

Sidney Waugh, American sculptor and designer of glass, has been elected president of the National Sculpture Society, it was announced yesterday by John J. Cunningham, director of the society. The office was held previously by Donald De Lue.
WASHINGTON, Jan, 14 -- The first unfair labor practice case to arise under the Taft-Hartley Law was put before the National Labor Relations Board today by Robert N. Denham, general counsel.

The Moore-McCormack liner Argentina "re-enlisted" yesterday in the Naval Reserve and received the reserve's pennant that attests to the vessel's fitness as a naval auxiliary and also that at least half of her officer personnel are members of the reserve.
Since children come to school reflecting all kinds of family standards, teachers must know what is back of them and "not be shocked," Miss Jennie N. Haxton declared yesterday.

VIENNA, Jan. 14 -- Members of the Rumanian royal family, who passed through Vienna early this morning in a special train en route to Switzerland predicted that a Rumanian-Bulgarian-Yugoslav union headed by Marshal Tito would be formed shortly as a sequel to the forced abdication of King Michael.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Two members of President Truman's Cabinet informed Congress today that the Administration would immediately impose price control on coal, petroleum, steel, lumber, textiles and farm machinery, if given the authority.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set down for argument on Feb. 27 the applications of Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of directors of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, and Robert J. Bowman, president, for authority to hold interlocking directorates of the New York Central and C. O. boards as a step toward ultimate unification of the two systems.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- The Italian Government protested today to the British Government, through both the Italian Embassy in London and the British Embassy in Rome, against the riots that occurred two days ago in Mogadiscio, capital of the former Italian colony of Somaliland, and resulted in the death of forty-two Italians.

It is scarcely surprising to find that President Truman's Second Annual Economic Report, submitted to Congress yesterday, is a decidedly more ambitious and finished document than either his maiden effort of January a year ago or his mid-term report of last July.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- The Public Service Commission, beset by many demands for a thorough investigation of the breakdown of service on the Long Island Rail Road after the Dec. 26 record snowstorm, announced today that it would conduct a public hearing in New York starting at 10 A.M. next Monday.

James N. Spear, vice president and treasurer of Spear Co., home furnishings chain, was elected president of the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association at the annual meeting of the directors of that group yesterday in the Vanderbilt Hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A relatively small growth in bank deposits in 1947 compared with preceding years is a matter of satisfaction that that particular phase of inflationary pressure has eased considerably, Sir William Goodenough, chairman of Barclays Bank, declared today in his annual statement to stockholders.

"Secret Beyond the Door," a psychological melodrama, starring Michael Redgrave and Joan Bennett, will have its local premiere this morning at the Winter Garden. Universal-International is releasing the Diana Productions offering, which was produced and directed by Fritz Lang and is being presented by Walter Wanger.

Twenty-six contributions amounting to $442.24 were received yesterday for the Neediest Cases Fund conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES, increasing the total of the thirty - sixth annual appeal to $355,524.46.

"Jefferson the Virginian," the first volume of a four-volume biography by Dumas Malone, has been scheduled by Little, Brown for publication on April 13, the anniversary of Thomas Jefferson's birth. It covers his life up to his departure for France after the American Revolution.
Leaders of the American Communist party hailed the Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace at two rallies last night as they marked the twenty-fourth anniversary of Lenin's death.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The House opened debate today on a significant revision of the Army's traditional judicial system that would permit enlisted personnel to serve on courts-martial and prescribe other major reforms of the processes of military justice.
Subscriptions totaling $1,177,269 have been received in the post-war campaign for funds being conducted to improve the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park, it was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has, according to I. K. Sedin, Minister of the Textile Industry, shown remarkable progress in textile output in 1947. Greater things are expected in 1948.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- War Assets Administration officials advised the Senate Agriculture Committee today that the Agriculture Department and the armed services have agreed to the disposal of the two largest war-built Government alcohol plants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- President Truman's cost-of-living tax adjustment bill was introduced in the House today. It calls for a $40-per-person reduction to individual income taxpayers and a 75 per cent excess profits tax on corporations to offset the revenue loss.

Steve Owen, George Halas, Greasy Neale, Jock Sutherland, Curly Lambeau and their colleagues of the National Football League's coaching set went into a huddle last night at the Hotel Commodore to discuss possible rules changes for 1948.

The twelve-story apartment house for forty-nine families at 945 West End Avenue, corner of 106th Street, was sold by the Finn Realty Corporation to the 48 Holding Corporation, which was represented by Gerard M. Bloomfield, attorney. Kies Schulman were the attorneys for the seller.

OTTAWA, Jan. 14 -- Even with prices rising it is possible for a Canadian family of five to have a balanced home diet at a cost of 15 1/2 cents per meal, or $16.36 a week, according to the Canadian Department of Health and Welfare.

A complete overhauling, reorganization and centralization of the city's licensing and inspection practices to eliminate confusion and overlapping was recommended yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission in making public the text of the first section of its 500-page report on the five city departments it surveyed at Mayor O'Dwyer's request.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday followed an uneven pattern, with traders restricting operations pending release of President Truman's second annual economic report. Although stocks closed mixed, there was a firmer undertone.

Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, the Texas tomboy who became the first American to take the women's British golf championship, yesterday was named woman athlete of the year for 1947 in the annual Associated Press poll.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The State Department asserted today that Oscar Niemeyer, a Brazilian architect, could not enter this country because he was an avowed Communist.

ROME, Jan. 14 -- A strong plea for resumption of trade relations between Italy and Germany was made during a press conference today by Minister of Foreign Trade Cesare Merzagora. Special emphasis was given to the occasion by the presence of the United States Ambassador James Clement Dunn and the British, French and Russian Ambassadors.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- A new deal for British science designed to integrate it fully into Britain's industrial recovery program was announced tonight by Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, speaking at a labor meeting at Letchworth in Hertfordshire.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The Soviet Union belongs to only three of ten specialized agencies of the United Nations, while the four other great powers -- China, France, Britain and the United States -- belong to all ten, according to a chart compiled today by the United Nations bulletin.

A clash of unbeaten quintets will distinguish tonight's college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden, New York University and North Carolina, paired in the second game, both boast perfect records. The Violets have won ten, the Tarheels twelve.

It was extremely gratifying to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES, Jan. 4, of Governor Dewey's expected statement supporting fair educational practices in New York State. The recently publicized Report of the President's Commission on Higher Education emphasizes the need for the extension of educational opportunity generally and for the elimination of barriers caused by discrimination.

ATHENS, Jan. 14 -- Dwight P. Griswold, United States director of the Greek aid program, announced today that, with the agreement of the Greek Government, the National Defense Corps would be increased from the present forty-two battalions of 500 men each to fifty-four battalions of the same strength.

Comment from the aviation industry, airline heads and manufacturing concerns in the New York area and elsewhere yesterday indicated general approval of the report of the President's Air Policy Commission.

The chairman of the 1948 campaign of the Greater New York Fund will be Henry C. Alexander, vice president of J.P. Morgan Co., it was announced yesterday by Henry C. Brunie, president of the Empire Trust Company and of the fund.

A wise step toward economy and efficiency in the armed services, which is one of the many far-sighted recommendations of the President's Air Policy Commission, is that now contemplated by Secretary of Defense Forrestal in merging the Air Transport Command of the Air Forces and the Naval Air Transport Service of the Navy into one organization.

Directors of the Interchemical Corporation yesterday authorized the payment on Feb. 1 of a 60-cent dividend on the common stock. This is an increase of 10 cents over the previous quarterly rate. A year-end extra of $1 was paid in December.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Warning that the economic boom might spin away with its good features, leaving only grave consequences, President Truman today again requested Congressional action on all points of his anti-inflation program and on his plan for a $40 income-tax credit.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The Republic of Indonesia threatened today to bring the Netherlands up before the United Nations Security Council for creating a "puppet interim government" in the East Indies.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- British motion-picture exhibitors expect to feel the pinch of the American producer's boycott of this market within a few weeks, the general council of the Cinematograph Exhibitors Association stated bluntly tonight.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The policy of the United States is to remain in Berlin in discharge of its obligations, Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett declared at a news conference today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- It seldom happens that Europe finds itself short of advice from the United States in general or Capitol Hill in particular, but the sixteen Marshall-plan countries are in that position today.

The city has sent out letters to all operators of excursion craft requesting them to file dock permit applications before Feb. 1, to avoid last-minute confusion when the excursion season opens in the late spring, it was reported yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Jan. 14 -- While special committees began today to revise the present bizonal agencies into the projected economic government, food ministers, trade union leaders and representatives of industry have been called to meet with British officials in Duesseldorf tomorrow to discuss the critical food situation in the Ruhr.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander and State Fuel Coordinator Charles H. Sells will go this morning to Washington to seek relief from the heating crises that threaten this part of the country for the remainder of the winter.
During 1947 the number of ships in the privately owned and operated merchant marine of the United States increased from 701 to 1,003, the National Federation of American Shipping announced yesterday.

Shirley Booth is the latest signatory to be recruited by CBS in furtherance of its plan for expanding house program properties. Her production, a situation comedy in which the actress will take the part of a schoolteacher, is approaching the audition stage and is expected to be ready for the kilocycles by next month.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Renewed rumors of an impending devaluation of the pound sterling brought an emphatic denial today from Britain's Treasury. These rumors, which started in the financial area of London, were fed by reports from Washington and Canada that such action was in prospect.
Reporting on its 1947 business, officials of the Irving Trust Company told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday that the operating profit was $6,305,551, against $6,764,109, the year before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. John Kerr Rose, a professional employe of Congress, acknowledged today that he speculated in grain while serving as a consultant on world grain requirements to the Select House (Herter) Committee on Foreign Aid.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Prospects for a reduction in lumber prices to cut home construction costs were seen today by Representative Gamble, Republican, of New York, after Congressional conferences with representatives of the lumber industry.

The cooperative weather thus far this winter continues to delight the army of skiers in Northeastern United States and Canada, reports last night indicating that new deep powder once again surfaces trails and slopes. While rain followed in the wake of snow in the metropolitan area two days ago, snow visited the Northlands.

Five men surrendered yesterday to the Federal Bureau of Investigation in connection with the seizure Jan. 3 of 60,000 pounds of TNT, a large part of which was being shipped to Palestine. The five were arrested on bench warrants issued last Monday and arraigned before Federal Judge William Bondy.

IT is interesting to speculate on what many of the novels about World War II would have been like without the influence of Hemingway. He not only affected the style in which they were written but also the content -- the world of these writers' experience fell into patterns from the Hemingway point of view. What other points of view and styles they might have followed we shall never know.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The year 1947 broke all records for construction spending, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today, estimating total building expenditures in the twelve months at nearly $15,000,000,000. The Bureau forecast that 1948 will exceed even that mark by some $200,000,000.

The executive committee of the North American Yacht Racing Union made the new right of-way rules that were used widely on an optional basis last season its permanent rules last night after hearing expressions of opinion from delegates that were mainly favorable at the annual meeting in the New York Yacht Club.

An exhibition of one of the world's most famous collections of early eighteenth century European porcelain was opened yesterday afternoon in the fifth-floor gallery of Frank Partridge, 6 West Fifty-sixth Street. Assembled by Otto Blohm of Hamburg over a period of twenty years before the war, it is being dispersed by his widow under the auspices of Stoner Evans, dealers in line porcelain.
Feng Yu-hsiang, the "Christian general" of China, who has been a prominent figure there for thirty years, formally assumed the role of a political exile yesterday.

Your editorial of Jan. 7 entitled "The GOP and UMT" listed General MacArthur as favoring UMT. Actually General MacArthur has remained completely silent on this issue, making no public statements. However, the general is known to be opposed from his many comments to individuals who have visited him in Japan.

Somewhere in Germany is stationed a private first class who has endorsed army life in a manner to which public relations officers would like to become accustomed. PFC Brown has rejected a plea by the Attorney General of American Samoa to go home and assume his rightful position as high chief Lafoai Lauvale Lutu, Peni of 30,000 Samoans.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark ordered a Federal grand jury investigation today of lobbying practices before the Congress.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- The United States will soon reopen the highly strategic North African air base at Mellaha, in Libya near Tripoli, it was disclosed today. United States transport planes used the field during the war.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Antara, news agency of the Indonesian Republic, quoted informed sources today as saying that "matters concerning a plebiscite under international observation" were included in the latest proposals of the United Nations Good Offices Committee for a cease-fire in the Netherlands Indies.

The Fair Trade laws which apply to liquor retailers in New York State should be extended to cover wholesalers, James S. Hamlin, vice president of Henry Kelly Importing and Distributing Company, New York, and president of the Greater New York Wholesale Liquor Dealers Association, Inc., told industry members at their annual dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Jan. 14 (AP) -- Dick Button, 18-year-old Englewood, N.J., youth, won the men's European figure skating championship tonight, defeating the defending titleholder, Hans Gerschwiller of Switzerland, by 11 place points to 18.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Jan. 14 -- Brig. Gen. Robert Wood Johnson, chairman of the board of Johnson Johnson, New Brunswick surgical supply manufacturers, was invited today to become the Democratic organization's candidate for the Senate nomination this year to succeed Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, of Montclair.
Nicholas Marinaccio, 19 years old, was sentenced yesterday by Bronx County Court Judge James M. Barrett to from thirty-five years to life for the hold-up slaying last Aug. 1 of a Bronx storekeeper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 7:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Although he was acquitted in a Federal court in Chicago, James C. Petrillo, in absentia, received considerable rough verbal treatment at the hands of a predominantly hostile House Labor Committee here today.

In its forthright order to the State of Oklahoma to provide legal education for a young Negro woman the Supreme Court reaffirmed its eight-year-old decision that educational privileges cannot be denied any qualified applicant on artificial grounds of race or color.

Mayor O'Dwyer urged support yesterday of the campaign for $200,000 for the maintenance of the Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He stressed the dependence of the city on all voluntary hospitals because of "the helpless condition" of the city's institutions.

The formation of a new book corporation, to be known as Hendricks House-Farrar, Straus, was announced yesterday by Farrar, Straus Co., Inc., in association with Hendricks House. It will operate as the college division of Farrar, Straus Co.

Twenty-five survivors of the burned funeral transport Joseph V. Connolly who had ridden out a North Atlantic storm in open boats before they were rescued, reached La Guardia Field by air from Halifax, N.S., last night.

The daily average gross crude oil production reached a new high of 5,313,137 barrels in the week ended last Saturday, surpassing the previous peak of 5,295,350 barrels last October, and increasing 21,900 barrels over last year's 4,530,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

In recognition of a department store's public service responsibilities, the Tobe Award, the fifth annual prize to be bestowed on American retailers for outstanding contribution in their field, was presented last night to Mrs. Beatrice Fox Auerbach, president of G. Fox Co. of Hartford, Conn.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 14 (AP) -- Capt. Tom Hamilton, holding that "coaching inadequacy" needn't be blamed for Navy's poor record in football since the war, came out today for a sound athletic policy land "realistic" support as the basis for the dawning of a new sports era at the academy.

American drawing, which has recently been coming of age, does not get its best showing in the Third Biannual Exhibition of Drawings, which opened yesterday at the National Academy of Design and will continue until Jan. 24.

At the dinner in which ten civic groups paid tribute to progress made in Mayor O'Dwyer's first two years in office the Mayor himself broke two pieces of excellent news. He made known for the first time his intention to build housing without rental subsidy, a departure in policy of much importance.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 14 -- The National League of Wholesale Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Distributors today adopted as their main function for 1948 and succeeding years a retailer educational and training program in all forty-eight states and United States possessions which is expected to revolutionize retail handling and selling of perishables.

The nightly touted revue, "Make Mine Manhattan," which is said to poke fun at the foibles of New York life, makes its local debut this evening at the Broadhurst Theatre. The show is sponsored by Joseph M. Hyman, who in past seasons co-produced with Bernard Hart "Dear Ruth" and "Christopher Blake." The opening night curtain will rise at 8:10 sharp.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 14 -- The Jewish colony of Kfar Etzion, thirteen miles south of Jerusalem, was besieged tonight by Arabs after twenty-four hours of raids on traffic along the main highway to Jerusalem.

PARIS, Jan. 14 -- The early creation of a customs union between France and Italy is recommended by a joint committee representing the Governments of the two countries in a report soon to be published.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The Senate heard a plea today for financial support for America's Olympic teams, but out of the Senators' own pockets, not the United States Treasury.
Both the small game and big he kill in Pennsylvania showed increase in 1947, as did the aber of hunters and the num- of violations.

Patrick J. Meehan, acting Commissioner of Licenses, told Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday that his department would need $293,665 for its 1948-49 fiscal needs. At the same time, Commissioner Meehan pointed out that the department revenues were $1,268,533 for the present fiscal year, the highest in the department's history.

There is no longer much argument about Prokofieff's Classical Symphony or Hindemith's "Mathis der Maler," or at least there should not be. Both works seem to have won their way into the repertory. When Serge Koussevitzky coupled them with Tchaikovsky's Sixth Symphony in last night's Boston Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall he was probably presenting them as a matter of course, as one would any works that had established their right to belong.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told the Women's National Press Club today that this country could live in the same world with Russia and peaceably "but it will have to come from a recognition that we are stronger in every way than they."

I notice under the heading "U.N. Lists Deficits" that Ethiopia will balance imports against exports. Therefore there is no deficit in the case of Ethiopia and that country ought not to have been mentioned under the list of deficits. A hasty reader might not observe this.

An illuminating illustration of the workings of the "people's democracy" imposed on Eastern Europe by Soviet Russia has just been furnished in Bulgaria. There that stalwart exponent of such a "democracy," Premier Georgi Dimitrov, an ex-Russian citizen, former Secretary General of the Comintern, inventor of the "Trojan Horse" tactics of Communist penetration and "hero" of Hitler's Reichstag fire trial, presented his budget to the National Assembly.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Henry Ford 2d declared here tonight that his automobile company would not raise prices for the sake of increased profits. He said any mark-up in the 1949 version of the Ford car would be the result of higher production costs and greater value.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 14 -- The Arab League will offer its good offices to the Governments of India and Pakistan to mediate their dispute over the Princely State of Kashmir, according to advices received from Damascus by the Syrian delegates to the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Gulf Oil Corporation, Pittsburgh, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange commission today covering 2,269,050 shares of additional capital stock, $25 par value.

Sherman Billingsley, who makes it a business to be nice to people, and Miss Vera M. Boudin, a lawyer, forgot their night-club and courtroom manners yesterday and hurled verbal unpleasantries at each other.

In its editorial of Dec. 29 on the current Polish terror THE NEW YORK TIMES has rightly raised the entire question of the guarantees of Polish freedom made by the United States and the other Allies. Pertinently, your editorial asks what the Western democracies are going to do about it.

NANKING, Jan. 14 -- A Sino-British dispute over the eviction of 2,000 Kowloon City squatters grew more intense today. The Chinese Foreign Ministry pressed for the release of two Chinese nationals sentenced to jail by a Hong Kong court on charges of obstructing an eviction process.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- The first direct information on Great Britain's plans to withdraw from Palestine this summer was presented to the United Nations Palestine Commission today by Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative.

For the first time since 1941, under a complete reversal of sales policies, the Kellog division of American Brake Shoe Company will install a firm price marketing policy on all its products, effective Feb. 1, William T. Kelly, president of this division, revealed here yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 14 (UP) -- Development of a new drug compound which has given "complete relief" to fifteen of twenty-one hay fever sufferers was announced by a scientist at the Indiana Section of the American Chemical Society yesterday.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- A constitutional amendment that would enable New York and other large cities to raise more revenue from real estate taxation appeared certain tonight of favorable action at this session of the Legislature. But it could not become effective unless ratified by next year's Legislature and approved in a statewide referendum.

A little belatedly, perhaps, a correspondent writes in to say that, while he agrees heartily with our comment of some days ago about the upstairs back porch that President Truman wants to put in the South Portico of the White House, and feels, as we do, that it has no place there, he'd like to remind us that the upstairs back porch is an American institution -- especially in the South and West.

WARSAW, Jan. 14 -- The parade of Eastern Europe's top political and economic bosses to Moscow in recent months reflects Russia's determination to shape up a rival economic program before the Marshal Plan can begin to function, in the opinion of economic observers here.
CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- James C. Petrillo today was acquitted of the Government's criminal charge that he violated the Lea Act.

BOSTON, Jan. 14 (AP) -- The highflying Detroit Red Wings broke their first-place National Hockey League tie with the idle Toronto Maple Leafs by pulling from behind into a 3-3 tie with the Boston Bruins tonight before 13,900 fans at the Boston Garden.

This seems to be the year for reports on progress. Exhibits for the Golden Jubilee this summer will show how the Department of Markets and other of the city's services have advanced in the last fifty years. For an account of what's been happening in the past 100 years in nutrition there is the interesting history that the Community Service Society has compiled in connection with the centennial anniversary being celebrated this year.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- British reporters received an opportunity today to inspect the three huge S.R.45 flying boats under construction at Cowes for Britain's overseas airlines. The aircraft, the first of which is expected to be ready for service late next year or early in 1950, weigh 140 tons and are capable of carrying eighty to 140 passengers (depending upon the length of flight) at an estimated speed of 350 miles an hour.

NEW DELHI, India, Thursday, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, now in an acute phase of his fast for communal peace, took cognizance at his prayer meeting last night of a reported train massacre in Pakistan in which there were only 750 known survivors of 2,400 non-Moslem refugees.
