Annual military expenditures of between $15,000,000,000 and $25,000,000,000 are forecast within the next few years if measures already authorized or projected are approved by Congress.

ALBANY, Jan. 14 -- Machinery for settling grievances of classified Civil Service workers employed by the state is provided for in bills introduced in the State Legislature today under bipartisan sponsorship.

Up until 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon Jerry King, 10 years old, of 442 West Fifty-eighth Street, had intended to be a soldier when he grew up. Then, along with twenty other youngsters, he toured the Swedish-American liner Drottningholm, rechristened for the day the S.S. March of Dimes.

Dr. Lawrence D. Reddick, curator of the Schomburg Collection of Negro Literature and History in the West 135th Street Branch of the New York Public Library, resigned yesterday. He said he was dissatisfied over slowness in providing his department with adequate facilities and staff. Dr. Reddick will become chief librarian of Atlanta University on April 1.
LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Britain and France bowed gracefully to Washington's veto today and postponed indefinitely their invitation to the sixteen European nations to confer in Paris on the Marshall Plan.

The acquittal of James O. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on charges of violating the Lea law emphasizes afresh that curbing the absolute powers of this union leader will be neither an easy nor a simple task.

The Lawyers Trust Company reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that operations during 1947 showed a net increase in undivided profits of $203,681 to $1,110,560, equal to $3.28 a share, compared with $5.20 a share in 1946.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 -- Taking an unprecedented step, the Association of American Colleges voted today to create a national commission to help eliminate discrimination practiced against minority groups seeking admission to college.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today suspended Lana Turner for refusing to play Milady De Winter in the studio's projected screen version of "The Three Musketeers." Explaining the suspension, a studio spokesman said that Miss Turner had agreed ten weeks ago to start the picture on Jan. 5 and that she had requested and received a $25,000 advance against her salary to spend on a New York vacation.

TOKYO, Jan. 14 -- Premier Tetsu Katayama this morning officially barred Rikizo Hirano, veteran Japanese Socialist, from all political activities. This followed last night's decision of the Central Screening Committee that Mr. Hirano was subject to the Allied purge directive because of his pre-war activities.

The state began yesterday to present evidence in support of its indictment against Benjamin Feldman, Brooklyn pharmacist, who is being retried in Kings County Court on the charge of having poisoned his wife, Harriet.

The acquittal of James O. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, on charges of violating the Lea law emphasizes afresh that curbing the absolute powers of this union leader will be neither an easy nor a simple task.

The Lawyers Trust Company reported yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders that operations during 1947 showed a net increase in undivided profits of $203,681 to $1,110,560, equal to $3.28 a share, compared with $5.20 a share in 1946.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 14 -- Taking an unprecedented step, the Association of American Colleges voted today to create a national commission to help eliminate discrimination practiced against minority groups seeking admission to college.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 14 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today suspended Lana Turner for refusing to play Milady De Winter in the studio's projected screen version of "The Three Musketeers." Explaining the suspension, a studio spokesman said that Miss Turner had agreed ten weeks ago to start the picture on Jan. 5 and that she had requested and received a $25,000 advance against her salary to spend on a New York vacation.

PRAGUE, Jan. 14 -- Jim Smith, acting American vice president of the International Union of Students and head of its Department of Intellectual Cooperation, said today that majority sentiment in the organization was that students should be united throughout the world gainst what the majority considered to be imperialism and fascism.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it would henceforth be its policy to deny summarily, under certain conditions, any request for exemption from the competitive bidding requirements of Rule U-50 of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 14 -- Dr. Martha Eliot, associate chief of the United States Children's Bureau, received today the Parents' Magazine medal for outstanding service to children for her work as wartime director of the emergency maternity and infant care program and as present chief medical consultant of the International Emergency Children's Fund.

CHICAGO, Jan. 14 -- Grain markets fluctuated in a nervous manner on the Board of Trade today. Prices broke early, only to rally later. Corn, oats and soy bean futures sold at record levels and May wheat was within 3/4 cent a bushel of the seasonal peak.

A record-shattering budget estimate of $208,965,145 for New York's public school system in 1948-49 was announced yesterday at the Board of Education. With this sum the school officials propose to increase substantially the number of teaching positions, purchase greatly increased amounts of instructional materials and expand generally the city's educational services.

DETROIT, Jan. 14 -- Conservation of oil and gasoline is needed because of lack of refinery facilities rather than deficiency of natural resources, Reginald J.S. Piggott, president of the Society of Automotive Engineers, said today at the annual meeting of that organization here.

A technicality yesterday deprived a breed winner at last February's Westminster Kennel Club show of the right to participate in the Westminster at Madison Square Garden Feb. 11 and 12. The dog was the Pekingese, Sheraton Dorian, owned by Mrs. Ruth Burnette Sayres of Westbury, L.I.

An analysis of five of the recent reports by the British "working party" committees, sent here to do on-the-job studies comparing American factory methods with those of Britain, shows that the committees agree that productivity per American worker exceeds that of his British counterpart in each of the industries surveyed, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 14 -- Businessmen and Government officials who have been conferring on means for increasing Australia's dollar exports have listed commodities that could become large dollar earners ranging from opal ore to children's books.

Higher replacement prices have complicated the problem of current fur promotions at retail. Some of the larger stores have taken cuts in their mark-ups to feature promotional offerings. In general, however, the strong price situation has tended to limit the scope of these sales in most sections.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 14 -- Six scoring records were broken tonight as the Pennsylvania basketball team defeated Gettysburg, 84-45, at the Palestra.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 14 -- Principally as a result of some peerless foul shooting, Princeton overcame a five-point half-time deficit to hand Army its second straight defeat, 52 to 46 in the Field House today. The Tigers, Army's oldest intercollegiate basketball foes who first came to West Point in 1904, connected with seventeen of twenty free throws in the second half.

A nine-story office building to be erected on Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles, Calif., for the home office of the Carnation Company, manufacturer of evaporated milk, has been purchased by the New York Life Insurance Company and leased back to the milk concern.

The board of governors of the Brooklyn Heights Association, a civic group, announced yesterday a unanimous protest over proposed condemnation by the city of the building at 112 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, occupied by the Brooklyn Friends School and Meeting House, as a site for a new jail.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Food Minister John Strachey stated today that the fats ration would be restored to eight ounces a week, beginning Feb. 1, by raising the margarine allocation from three to four ounces. He added, however, that the fats ration would have to be reviewed after three months when the effect of the cuts in the British food supplies from dollar sources would be particularly marked.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, has told the other delegation heads that the United States will not make any concession "now or ever" on import quotas and other quantitative restrictions, it was learned today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 14 -- Navy regained its winning stride today by defeating Maryland's basketball team, 51 to 47. Though there never was more than a 7-point spread, both teams were ineffective most of the way.

The board of governors of the Brooklyn Heights Association, a civic group, announced yesterday a unanimous protest over proposed condemnation by the city of the building at 112 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, occupied by the Brooklyn Friends School and Meeting House, as a site for a new jail.

LONDON, Jan. 14 -- Food Minister John Strachey stated today that the fats ration would be restored to eight ounces a week, beginning Feb. 1, by raising the margarine allocation from three to four ounces. He added, however, that the fats ration would have to be reviewed after three months when the effect of the cuts in the British food supplies from dollar sources would be particularly marked.

HAVANA, Jan. 14 -- Clair Wilcox, acting chairman of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment, has told the other delegation heads that the United States will not make any concession "now or ever" on import quotas and other quantitative restrictions, it was learned today.
The most important structural improvement of the post-war period for the Broadway sector at the upper fringe of Times Square will result from a $15,000,000 deal consummated yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Following is the text of the so-called "Protocol M," embodying alleged Communist plans for disruption in Germany as made available in English tonight by the British Foreign Office:

The Eastern regional savings and mortgage conference of the American Bankers Association will be held March 15 and 16 at the Pennsylvania Hotel it was announced yesterday by L.A. Tobie, president of the A.B.A. savings division.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- A new Cabinet was formed for the Union of South Africa today with Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts as Prime Minister, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of Defense.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Military conscription and an annual defense budget approximating the four-year cost of the Marshall Plan were declared by two of the nation's top defense officials today to be the only alternatives to a European Recovery Program consistent with the national security.

Industrial accidents in New York State totaled 787,245 during 1947, the greatest number ever recorded, Miss Mary Donlon, chairman of the State Workmen's Compensation Board, reported yesterday on the basis of records kept by her agency.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 15 -- The Rev. Walter W. Van Kirk of the department of international justice of the Federal Council of Churches, declared here today that sectarian and denominational bickering "is the scandal of Christianity."

CRANFORD, N.J., Jan. 15 -- A little red-gloved hand that protruded above the ice-crusted waters of the Rahway River here this afternoon led to the discovery of the body of Peter Shoukimas, 3-year-old son of Dr. and Mrs. John Shoukimas, who disappeared at 10:30 A.M. yesterday while playing near his home about a block from the stream.

Though consumer resistance to meat has been strong for the past few days and trading virtually has been at a standstill, the resultant drop in wholesale prices, reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, has not shown up in retail stores.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- Vehicle inspection regulations throughout the country, including the proposed legislation in New York, will remain seriously hampered unless a universal method of testing brakes is adopted, according to findings of the braking committee of the Society of Automotive Engineers reported at the annual meeting here today.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and representatives of the four networks resumed yesterday afternoon their negotiations on a new contract. They will meet again today and also next Tuesday in Washington.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- India warned the United Nations Security Council today that its "small war" against Moslem raiders in the mountain state of Kashmir might flare any day into full-scale conflict with Pakistan.

The establishment of local committees of the National Catholic Resettlement Council in the 117 dioceses of that denomination throughout the country to aid displaced persons who gain admission to this country, was agreed upon yesterday at a meeting of the recently formed organization in the Vanderbilt Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Harry Carlson, Democratic national committee man of New Hampshire, the state in which Republican supporters of General of Army Dwight D. Eisenhower have filed a full slate, today told President Truman the Democrats would carry the state in this year's Presidential election.

SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 15 -- The United Nations Temporary Commission on Korea held its third meeting here this morning. It was announced that "the Commission resolved to take steps to guard against any misconstruction being placed upon the initial presence of the Commission in South Korea or upon the acceptance by its members of courtesies that have been extended to them in Seoul."

Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding throughout the nation on Dec. 31 last year amounted to $261,269,000, an increase of $16,117,000 above the level of the previous month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The United States Fleet, hit by peacetime manpower shortages, has only two battleships in active service, officials said today as the Navy disclosed that the 45,000-ton New Jersey and Wisconsin had been put in "mothballs" Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The House approved today a comprehensive reform of the practices of military justice. By a unanimous vote, the chamber passed and sent to the Senate a measure making fundamental changes in the Articles of War to bring about equalization and improvement in the treatment and punishments given the respective ranks.

Maggie Teyte, the English soprano, gave a recital last night at Town Hall which attracted a capacity audience. Again, the artistry of her work evoked prolonged ovations, leaving no doubt of the high esteem in which she is held by the musical public.

DETROIT, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Detroit Symphony Orchestra notified the American Broadcasting Company and Detroit Federation of Musicians today of its intention to cease Sunday evening programs Jan. 25 over an ABC network.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Harvey Bundy and James Grafton Rogers, two former Assistant Secretaries of State, will make a study of the foreign affairs activities of the Federal Government, with former Secretary Henry L. Stimson as their adviser, Herbert Hoover announced today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- France, Great Britain and the United States are in accord that it would be premature to have a full, formal conference at this time of the sixteen European nations that are cooperating under the Marshall Plan. This was declared today by Henri Bonnet, the French Ambassador, after a conference at the State Department with the Under-Secretary, Robert A. Lovett, and Lord Inverchapel, the British Ambassador.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Jan. 15 (AP) -- United States bobsled teams finished third, fourth and sixth today as a Swiss two-man crew won the Deterding Cup in a warm-up competition for the winter Olympics.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Department store sales in the week ended Jan. 10 were 8 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

HAVANA, Jan. 15 -- Cuba's Government will waive the profits tax on sugar producers as a means of helping them to pay the high wage level recently decreed by President Ramon Grau San Martin, the Cabinet has decided.

A state of "pay pandemonium" exists among the city's 150,000 civil service employes who work under a system of personnel administration that is "a wonderland of technical gobbledegook," the Citizens Budget Commission charged yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 15 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall warned here tonight that any "radical alteration" in the Administration's European Recovery Program would "jeopardize the prospect" of a successful conclusion of the task. He spoke at the seventy-fourth annual meeting of the Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce.

To continue the upward sales trends enjoyed by the two stores in 1947, John E. Raasch, president of John Wanamaker, Philadelphia and New York, yesterday announced a number of administrative changes and appointments, effective Feb. 2.

A check for $36,046 to provide fellowships for American students in Sweden was presented yesterday to Lithgow Osborne, president of the American-Scandinavian Foundation in a ceremony at its headquarters, 116 East Sixty-fourth Street.

The Yankees, it was learned yesterday, became the latest major league club to fall under the vigilant eye of Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler's office. They were fined $500 for violation of the high-school rule which precipitated such a merry row between the commissioner and the White Sox last fall.

It was announced a few days ago that the Bolivarian Society of the United States, an organization interested in keeping green in these northern latitudes the memory of Simon Bolivar, the famous South American Liberator, had made an offer to Mayor. O'Dwyer to sponsor the building of a plaza commemorating Bolivar in Central Park, fronting the Avenue of the Americas.

The final chapter in dissolution of the $465,000,000 American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., began yesterday with the company's call for exchange of 2,343,105 common shares for an equal number of common shares of the West Penn Electric Company, top holding company for the electric properties.

OTTAWA, Jan. 15 -- Price ceilings have been reimposed in Canada on meat and butter, and the Government has announced that it will seek parliamentary extension of authority to control prices and rents until March 31, 1949.

The Citizens Budget Commission has now made public about half of its long report on the study of five New York City departments of government. Each new installment brings fresh evidence of the magnitude of the survey undertaken last spring; of the wide scope of the inquiry made and, finally, an appreciation of the huge task that the city itself faces in remedying the ills uncovered.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Robert Riggs turned aggressor tonight and defeated John Kramer, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5, at the County Center. It was the third successive victory for the national professional tennis champion and put him ahead by 7 matches to 6 in their tour across the country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Senator Vicente J. Francisco, Philippine member of the United Nations Palestine Commission, proposed today that the Security Council authorize an economic boycott or take other enforcement measures short of war, to carry out the partition of Palestine.

HALLANDALE, Fla., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mike Basile of the Bronx laid the whip twice to Rampart, Mrs. Helen K. Haggerty's 6-year-old coal black mare, to upset Calumet Farm's mighty Armed in the $27,050 Gulfstream Park Handicap, closing feature at that track today. Rampart paid $53.70 for $2 as she outran Warren Wright's champion by a short head.

Meals given to poor and homeless men and women by the Salvation Army throughout the world in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, 1947, totaled 33,772,383 while 10, 941,102 beds were supplied, according to the forty-third issue of the Salvation Army Year Book, for 1948.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Department took the first step today toward the creation of a powerful subcommittee which intends to try to bring about an investigation of Attorney General Tom C. Clark despite formidable Democratic opposition.

Statesmen and scholars, members of the faculty and friends of Columbia University joined last night in a tribute to Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, the university's acting president, for his forty-two years of service on Morningside Heights.

The State of South Carolina sold yesterday $10,000,000 of highway certificates, due 1954 to 1957, to a banking group headed by the National City Bank and the Northern Trust Company at a bid of 100.07 for 1 3/4s. Other bids ranged from 100.043 for 1.80s to 100.09 for 1.90s.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Glenn L. Martin, aircraft builder, said today commercial airlines must supplant their obsolete equipment with faster, more economical planes if they are to make money. Mr. Martin, head of the Baltimore aircraft firm which bears his name, told a Senate committee there is no question "that the airlines of the country greatly need new, modern, fast twin-engine equipment."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Intimations that the American Federation of Musicians may be in collusion with amplitude modulation (standard) broadcasters to hamper development of frequency modulation broadcasting were made today at the House Labor Committee's hearing on monopolistic practices by unions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Emphasizing that the oil shortage may last another two or three years, Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug called today for a 15 per cent voluntary cut in the consumption of gasoline, fuel oil and gas and set forth a six-point conservation program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 15 -- Members of the United Nations Security Council are following closely the negotiations for a settlement of the dispute between the Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic. It is understood that a meeting of the Council will be requested as soon as the Committee on Good Offices submits a report.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, closing 1 to 5 points net lower.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- French parliamentary machinery jolted and screeched through another boisterous sitting of the National Assembly today when the Communist design for systematic obstruction was made clearly evident.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Eight jet-propelled Army fighter planes made a 970-mile non-stop flight from Miami, Fla., to Washington today in 2 hours 12 minutes. The planes, belonging to the 336th Squadron of the Fourth Fighter Group, landed at 1:05 P.M. at Andrews Field.

ATHENS, Jan. 15 (UP) -- Dwight P. Griswold, chief of the United States Mission for Aid to Greece, said today that he probably would return to Washington soon to testify before Congressional committees on the Marshall Plan. He said he was not certain he would go, but if he did he would stay two or three weeks.

This winter would not be so upsetting as it has been if we still had horse-drawn sleighs. But we have no horse-drawn sleighs, except in museums or in the unlikely event that someone gets one out in order to call attention to an imaginary motion picture called "Sleighbells."

The continuing promising outlook for business in the heavy goods industries in conjunction with the large money supply make for optimism in the short-range economic outlook, but other economic forces point to an early exhaustion of the inflationary boom, possibly -- preferably, too -- in 1948, Dr. Marcus Nadler of New York University told the finance conference of the American Management Association in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- Floyd Odlum, chairman of the board of RKO and president of the Atlas Corporation, which controls RKO, indicated in a statement issued today that there is no prospect of an immediate sale of the Atlas Corporation's RKO holdings to Howard Hughes or any other purchaser.

An experimental plan to choose applicants for high administrative jobs in the New York public school system on an interneship basis was announced yesterday by a special committee of the Board of Education.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 15 -- The threat of a general strike in the Ruhr valley was in the air tonight as British authorities confirmed the authenticity of "Protocol M," a document said to outline a Communist plot to sabotage the Marshall Plan by crippling industries and transport in the Ruhr.

Negotiations are under way between two locals of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes that may result in extending the jurisdiction of the Harlem local -- Auxiliary Local No. 1A -- or in ending the traditional barrier to Negroes in Broadway's Theatrical Protective Union No. 1.

Apathy characterized trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and prices held to a narrow range in the second dullest session of 1948. Volume again failed to reach a million shares, the turnover of 780,000 shares being 40,000 below Wednesday's level.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The new Congress-provided $1,000,000 voluntary grain conservation drive got under way today. At the same time a House committee started probing legality of the $500,000 Luckman committee funds, half of which were turned back to the Treasury.

The most comprehensive, and in its combined impact most convincing, analysis of why the European Recovery Program is necessary to peace was presented yesterday in plainspoken and, we believe, irrefutable statements by some of the nation's top-ranking authorities.

HONOLULU, Jan. 15 -- Brig. Gen. David A.D. Ogden, United States Army construction engineer, has been selected island commander of the Eniwetok atomic test site. The Honolulu Advertiser will say tomorrow.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Four state legislators from New York City today were named to a subcommittee of the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulation to review practices of the New York Fire Insurance Exchange which reportedly transacts almost 90 per cent of New York City's business in that field.

A resolution of protest against the proposed 25 per cent increase in annual license fees of taverns and liquor stores in New York City was authorized yesterday by the directors of the Metropolitan Package Stores Association, Inc., during a meeting at the Park Central Hotel, Executive Director Gerald Dunne revealed in a statement following the meeting.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Eastman Kodak said today in a statement on a $3,000,000 antitrust suit filed against it by Revere Camera Company that its film was being distributed on "an impartial, nation-wide basis to photograph dealers."

Ten major food items, the price of which totaled $2.36 in 1939, now cost New York housewives $5.18, Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz reported yesterday. Commissioner Schulz said he had made the comparison of department figures at the request of consumer organizations.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- A galaxy of high-ranking United Nations officials assembled here today under the chairmanship of Trygve Lie, the Secretary General, to discuss coordination of activities of the principal specialized agencies with each other and with the United Nations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 15 -- RKO today announced the signing of Victor Mature on a one-picture deal to play the leading role in "Mr. Whiskers," which Allen Rivkin has written from a screen story by Irwin Gelsey dealing with a foreign-born racketeer who, on the eve of his deportation, suddenly realizes the significance of American citizenship. Sid Rogell will produce the film next summer.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- Trygve Lie, United Nations Secretary General, was the target today for some of the pent-up resentment of Geneva correspondents, particularly French-speaking reporters, over the bad and steadily worsening service given the press in the United Nations' European headquarters.

If the countries that have expressed willingness to aid displaced persons in Europe make good their promises, the 1,000,000 refugees in Germany and Austria "should be settled in their ultimate destinations in two or two and a half years," Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, who left La Guardia Field on a three-week inspection tour of several European countries, asserted yesterday.

FLETCHER PRATT writes with equal gusto about the Napoleonic wars and the second World War. As a naval historian, a military commentator and war correspondent he occupies a niche all his own, a writer who can hardly impose a decent restraint upon his enthusiasm for nautical warfare, a rewriter of official material who never hesitates to express his own opinions, an authoritative specialist and boyish fan at one and the same time.

One of the most encouraging aspects of a Senator's official duties is reading letters he receives from school children in his own and other states. Children often write warm, penetrating letter about the major problems that confront our democratic society.

North Carolina was no match for N.Y.U. in the court battle between these undefeated basketball teams last night at Madison Square Garden. The Violets, having built a 29-9 bulge at the half, won in a romp, 63 -- 34, and made it eleven straight for the current campaign.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 15 -- Jewish settlers, using aircraft for the first time, beat off a heavy Arab attack on settlements at Kfar Etzion, near Hebron, today. The fight there, and others in Haifa and near Beersheba, produced one of the heaviest daily casualty lists to date, with twenty-nine killed and seventy-five wounded so far.

Being in an amicable mood, they have put together a very pleasant musical revue. They are Arnold B. Horwitt, who has written sketches and lyrics, and Richard Lewine, who has written the music, and they call it "Make Mine Manhattan," which was done at the Broadhurst last evening.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Jan. 15 (AP) -- All-America Quarterback Johnny Lujack of Notre Dame, on the threshold of a lucrative professional football career, described as "really terrific" his selection today as 1947's male athlete of the year in The Associated Press poll.

Mayor O'Dwyer asked the business men of New York yesterday to join him in a fight against ratification of the St. Lawrence Seaway treaty pending in Congress. While the Mayor had indicated previously opposition to the seaway construction, his speech yesterday before the Rotary Club, at a luncheon meeting at the Commodore Hotel, was the first indication that the Mayor intended to wage an all-out fight.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 15 (AP) -- The American freighter Adrian Victory, listing 45 degrees and her starboard weather deck railing already under water, wallowed precariously in heavy Atlantic seas tonight some 335 miles off the Virginia Capes, but help was close at hand.

We have always preferred "Das Lied von der Erde" to all other of the symphonic works of Gustav Mahler. Bruno Walter specializes in Mahler. He signalized his return to the podium of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with this particular composition, which he prefaced with a delightfully gemuetlich reading of the Beethoven Fourth Symphony.
The Maritime Commission announced yesterday that eighteen tanker operators had pledged themselves to keep in domestic service all the tank ships purchased from the commission in recent deals.

A former Czechoslovakian lawyer, who is alleged to have sent Panamanian instead of United States visas to Hungarian relatives of a family here and to have obtained $390 for his services, was held for grand jury action yesterday when he was arraigned in Felony Court. Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone set his bail at $5,000.

"The Men We Marry," which will pass in review tonight at the Mansfield, establishes Edgar F. Luckenbach as an independent producer. No longer, says the young scion of the steamship family, will he permit himself to dip into a vast exchequer by backing shows produced by others, a costly procedure thus far, or serve as second fiddle in the capacity of co-sponsor as he did in behalf of last season's "Portrait in Black."

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Industrials opened lower in early dealings on the stock market here today but with some investment buying, prices recovered to close in some cases with small gains. Rising hopes that the government will permit early resumption of midweek greyhound racing again led to buying of greyhound stadium issues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- A trial examiner for the National Labor Relations Board today rejected the attempt of the office of Robert N. Denham, general counsel, to prove that strikers were guilty of coercion and restraint in certain picket line activities.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- A War Assets Administration spokesman has informed Representative Hugh D. Scoot Jr., Republican, of Pennsylvania, that he agrees with Mr. Scott that WAA advertising should not suggest that industry move from one section of the country to another.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 -- Members of the San Francisco Longshore Local of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union have defeated a proposal of the local's officers to reduce the longshore working force by 500 men as a means of bettering work opportunities on the waterfront.

TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 15 -- New Jersey Republican and Democratic leaders still were on the hunt today for candidates for United States Senator after the first choice of each party had given a flat refusal.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Eleven weeks of negotiations by the United Nations Good Offices Committee appeared near a successful conclusion today with reliable reports that a military agreement implementing the United Nations cease-fire order would be signed, probably on Saturday, by the Netherlands Government and the Indonesian Republic.

A freak storm that held up the United States liner America for fourteen hours was described here yesterday by her master, Commodore Harry Manning, after the ship arrived from Europe with 794 passengers.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- The Government tackled the "featherbedding" charge against the International Typographical Union, AFL, today with evidence designed to prove that the union's "bogus" rule raises the labor costs of one Chicago newspaper unnecessarily more than $50,000 a year.

Russeks is prepared to meet the spring with delicately cool tones. They are two-tones of a golden beige, which this Fifth Avenue specialty shop calls "coffee and cream," and gray. These were put over with conviction at a showing held yesterday noon in the Terrace room of the Plaza Hotel.

Proving that a low price need be no obstacle to fashion, the Millinery Stabilization Commission presented a showing of budget hats yesterday at the Hotel Astor that reflected a comprehensive picture of the style highlights for spring. The trend was definitely toward youthful hats, with all manner of little sailors favored.
Morris Schachter, 18 years old, surrendered yesterday to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, becoming the sixth person under arrest accused of participating in attempts to ship TNT to Palestine.

SAVANAH, Ga., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Less than a half dozen changes, none of major importance, were made in the collegiate playing code as the National Football Rules Committee wound up its annual meeting here today.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Democratic legislative leaders reported widespread support today for their proposed constitutional amendment barring the state from mandating any further local expenses without providing the funds to finance them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Swift Co., meat packers, declared today a special dividend of $1 a share on its capital stock, payable on March 1 to shareholders of record Jan. 30. This was in addition to the declaration of a quarterly payment of 40 cents a share to be made on April 1 to shareholders of record of Feb. 27.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- David B. Robertson, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, tonight authorized a strike of firemen on all Class I railroads in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission withdrew today last month's dismissal order to allow the Electric Power Company of New Jersey, Inc., six more months in which to apply for a permit for a hydroelectric development project on the Delaware River.

The traditional elegance of jacquard-patterned silk damasks has been given a contemporary slant in the modern textured fabrics that went on exhibit yesterday at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 20 West Fifty-fifth Street. Franco Scalamandre and his wife, Flora, as well as their two children, Gino and Adriana, have contributed designs to the museum's first display of modern weaves.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Reports of forthcoming revaluation of the franc have brought foreign orders for French goods to a standstill according to Charles Gruere, president of the National Federation of French Export and Import Companies.

An attractive middleweight bout, in which Tony Janiro, popular Youngstown (Ohio) battler, will clash with Lavern Roach of Plainview, Tex., headlines the boxing program at Madison Square Garden tonight. Admission prices range from $12 to $2.50.

A Moslem student attending Columbia University's Teachers College on a scholarship from the Indian Government jumped to his death early yesterday morning from the ninth floor of Furnald Hall, a university dormitory for men students. The student was identified as Habeeb Ahmed Faruqi, 40 years old, of Kachiguda, Hyderabad, a south central province in India.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- A program to encourage farmers and other land owners in halting the progressive depletion of New York State's forests was proposed in the Legislature today by Senator Chauncey B. Hammond of Chemung County and Assemblyman Benjamin H. Demo of Lewis County, both Republicans.

Oil -- an estimated 1,800 gallons of it -- covered a street in the Bronx yesterday, but nobody, least of all residents in the vicinity of 176th Street and Morris Avenue, was happy about it. They would have preferred it in their oil burners.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Brig. Gen. Ames T. Brown, State Adjutant General, said today that he saw no urgency for a general overhauling of the State Military Law this year. Such a revision has been recommended by a special National Guard committee as a necessary precaution against a sudden outbreak of atomic warfare.

LONDON, Jan. 15 -- Britain signed a twenty-year treaty with Iraq today that in effect guarantees the protection of that country. This is an event of great importance to Middle Eastern strategy and constitutes the first step in what it is hoped will be a widespread defensive network in the Middle East -- and defensive these days means defense against the "iron curtain."

The Professional Golfers Association refusal to accept the entry of two Negro golf professionals for the Richmond, Calif., Open Tournament that opened yesterday is neither sportsman-like nor American. It is in contrast to the attitude of most other sports organizations in the United States, where Negroes are among the top athletes.
For the first time since the end of the war, New York's municipal colleges will show no increase in enrollment for the coming spring semester, and student population may even decline.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 15 --Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, asserted tonight that control of the air was of supreme importance, and that he would like to see the United States have an air force clearly superior to that of any other country.

BERLIN, Jan. 15 -- Despite an angry statement by a United States Military Government official that no action would be taken against Dr. Johannes Semmler, bizonal economics chief who denounced the three Western powers, it was learned today he probably would be ousted.

Today's events: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera House, 8:30 P.M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Anna Xydis, piano, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Walter Hautzig, Town Hall, 8:30; Chamber Music Concertante, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:45; Pro Arte Quartet, Museum of Modern Art, 8:30; Juilliard String Quartet, Juilliard Concert Hail, 8:30; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.

Westchester golfers can be assured of a full tournament program for 1948, according to the plans revealed yesterday at the annual meeting of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LYNCHBURG, Va., Jan. 15 -- The suggestion that "trained and experienced men" like Bernard M. Baruch and Herbert Hoover be called upon to set up the machinery for administering the Marshall Plan was made today by James A. Farley, addressing the Lynchburg Chamber of Commerce at its annual meeting.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- The summer of 1942 is revealed as one of the most crucial periods of the war, if not the most crucial, in dispatches of Field Marshall Sir Claude J.E. Auchinleck, published today.

RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 15 -- Josephus Daniels, editor and publisher of The News and Observer for fifty-three years, who was a former Secretary of the Navy and one-time Ambassador to Mexico, died here at his home today at 1:20 P.M. after an illness of eleven days.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce announced today that beginning March 1, commercial shipments of all commodities to Europe will require individual licenses.

PARIS, Jan. 15 -- Diplomatic sources believe that France is about to open secret negotiations with Spain with the object of resuming normal relations and reopening the frontier between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 10 were 831,447 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 149,409 cars, or 21.9 per cent more than were loaded in the preceding week, 494 cars, or 0.1 per cent more than in the corresponding week of last year and 58,559 cars, or 7.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.
Thirty-four contributions amounting to $1,461 were received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES for its Hundred Neediest Cases Fund, increasing the total of the thirty-sixth annual appeal to $356,985.46.

Federal Judge John Bright dismissed yesterday a plagiarism suit brought against Daphne Du Maurier, British novelist, by J. Clifford MacDonald of Tampa, Fla., as son and administrator of Mrs. Edwina DeVin MacDonald. The suit had charged that Miss Du Maurier's best-selling novel "Rebecca" was based on a short story written by Mrs. MacDonald in 1924 and a novel she published in 1927.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- During the week ended Jan. 14, member bank reserve balances increased $360,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

PRAGUE, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Canadian skating queen, attractive Miss Barbara Ann Scott of Ottawa, successfully defended her European figure-skating championship today against the challenge of eighteen experts from five other countries.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, intends to appoint a labor advisory committee, composed of representatives of both AFL and CIO unions, to advise Manhattan members of the Legislature on labor legislation, it was learned yesterday.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- Evidence has been discovered that prehistoric man inhabited the Sinai Peninsula before the Neanderthal occupation of Mount Carmel in Palestine, according to a report of the University of California African expedition.
Appointment of James D. Glenn as general manager of stainless steel sales was announced yesterday by the Crucible Steel Company of America.
LONDON, Jan. 15 -- British motorists were warned today that they might have to go at least another year without gasoline for pleasure driving.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, too weak to walk tonight after three days of fasting, was aware that some militant malcontents had shouted in the streets and outside his house, "Let Gandhi die!"

CHARLESTON, S.C., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Anthony J. Drexel 3d, 34, a member of the Drexel banking family, was killed at his plantation home near here last night by the discharge of a souvenir German pistol. Coroner M.D. Jackson of Berkeley County, after an inquest, recorded the death as an accident.

A history and an analysis of anti-Semitism in America has been scheduled for publication by Little, Brown on March 12, under the title "A Mask for Privilege: Anti-Semitism in America." It is written by Carey McWilliams, author of "Brothers Under the Skin" and "Factories in the Field," who feels that "anti-Semitism is a social disease." The book has been selected for March by the Book Find Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Two suits asking more than $250,000 in damages will be filed, probably tomorrow, in behalf of two Los Angeles Negro professional golfers barred from the Richmond open golf tournament by the Professional Golfers Association, Attorney John Rowell announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Three Supreme Court justices disqualified themselves today from participating in hearings of the racial "covenants" case.

I am in agreement with C.E. White house's "Formula" for the possible prevention of war as described in his letter to THE TIMES of Jan. 6, proposing the creation of an international police force. I do not see, however, how such a police force could be used in Palestine, for by so doing it would be contradicting the very article of the Charter which is proposed to initiate it.

The North Country should be alive with skiing enthusiasts this week-end as reports last night indicated an excellent period of sport, with deep powder snows on firm bases and cold temperatures making up the favorable picture.

The sale yesterday of the Detroit Lions, one of the National League's three moribund franchises, to a syndicate of wealthy businessmen from the Motor City, strengthened the hand of the league in its continuing struggle for prestige and patronage against the All-America Conference.

CHICAGO, Jan. 15 -- The Progressive party in Illinois, preparing to advance Henry Wallace's independent bid for the Presidency, said today that it would not suport Paul Douglas, Democratic choice for the Senate seat held by C. Wayland Brooks, a Republican.

The New York County Committee of the American Labor party announced yesterday through City Councilman Eugene P. Connolly, secretary, that it was starting a campaign to obtain a minimum of 250,000 signatures to pledge cards in support of the Presidential candidacy of Henry A. Wallace.

Supporters of Federal legislation for a Permanent Fair Employment Committee were told last night that they must eliminate Communist aid if they are to avoid "the kiss of death." In pressing the need for such legislation in behalf of Negroes and other minority groups, A. Philip Randolph, president, Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, AFL, accused American Communists of having used the fight against racial discrimination as a device to advance the cause of Russia.

Mayor O'Dwyer's proposal for relaxation of limitations on real estate taxes and municipal borrowing power brought sharp protests yesterday from realty men and other representatives of property-owning groups.

As a grand jury began to hear evidence yesterday against two men charged with preparing a fraudulent will for Miss Mathilde Molsberger, Assistant District Attorney Karl Grebow announced that he was studying circumstances surrounding the death in 1943 of a third elderly Yorkville woman.

Almost six months after the Dutch colonial government in the Netherlands Indies began its military "police action" against the Republic of Indonesia, it is reported that terms of a truce have been agreed upon that has some prospect of success.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas went to the White House today to urge President Truman to look with favor upon a bill now in preparation which would establish state ownership of tidal lands, oil bearing and otherwise, within their boundaries.
CHICAGO, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Proposals to suspend or repeal the State ban against the use of oleomargarine in State institutions and private institutions receiving public moneys are slated to face strong opposition in the legislature from up-State Republicans, it was learned today.

Overriding the recommendations of the newly elected officers of the New York Newspaper Guild, CIO, the Representative Assembly of the guild elected early yesterday morning an opposition slate of sixteen executive committee members.

Unionized ironworkers were urged yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer to postpone a strike scheduled for tonight on new schools, power plants, hospitals and housing developments. The Mayor sent a telegram to officers of the International Association of Bridge, Structural and Ornamental Ironworkers, AFL, requesting that the walkout be deferred at least until Tuesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 15 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, in providing new financing for Europe, stands ready to assist whatever agencies may be established to implement the European Recovery Program, John J. McCloy, president of the world institution, declared tonight at the first annual "forecasting" conference of the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce.

PRAGUE, Jan. 15 -- Fear was expressed here today that behind the tight secrecy surrounding the negotiation of the Czechoslovak-Bulgarian treaty of alliance was a demand that Czechoslovakia pledge herself to fight in any conflict in which Bulgaria might become involved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman reiterated today that he was determined to have a porch despite considerable public opposition to the alteration. Every change in the White House has caused a row, the President said at his press conference. Mrs. Millard Pillmore almost was lynched for introducing the first bathtub there, he added.

HAVANA, Jan. 15 -- The Committee on Intergovernmental Commodity Agreements of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment completed its work today on its part of the proposed world trade charter -- safeguards to limit the restrictive influence of such agreements on world trade.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- President Truman disclosed today that he had received a letter of resignation from Theodore P. Wright, the Civil Aeronautics Administrator.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The Senate committee investigating alleged "insiders" in the commodity markets intends soon to put Senator Elmer Thomas, Democrat, of Oklahoma, on the stand in public session to explain his speculative dealings, Chairman Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, asserted today.

To make sure that the European Recovery Program is not too little and too late, the United States must be able to back it up not only with dollars but with armed strength and economic might, Senator Leverett Saltonstall of Massachusetts declared last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 15 -- Stringent measures to wipe out the alleged black market in adoptions are being prepared for introduction at this session of the Legislature with an excellent chance of passage, it was disclosed today.

Braving the cold weather, 800 members and officials of other Congress of Industrial Organizations unions in the city joined the American Communications Association early last night in a mass picketing demonstration outside the offices of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation at 67 Broad Street.
Changes in personnel practices and policies of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Madison Avenue and 123d Street, were announced yesterday by Frederick Brown, president.
The Flushing National Bank, Flushing, Queens, had total loans of $6,065,022 on Dec. 31, against $4,869,454 a year before, it was announced yesterday. Deposits rose about $340,000 to $10,555,029.
The Cabinet Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens prevented Toronto from taking the National Hockey League lead tonight by drubbing the Maple Leafs, 8 -- 4. The Canadiens spotted the Leafs, who trail first-place Detroit by a point, a 3-2 first-period lead and then stormed back with two goals in the middle session and four in the final.
The Flushing National Bank, Flushing, Queens, had total loans of $6,065,022 on Dec. 31, against $4,869,454 a year before, it was announced yesterday. Deposits rose about $340,000 to $10,555,029.
The Cabinet Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

Credited with saving two lives in the snow last Dec. 26 and 27, a Newfoundland dog named Butch received the John P. Haines Medal for heroism at the annual meeting last night of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 (AP) -- President Truman was profoundly grieved today at news of the death of Josephus Daniels.
The American Press Institute of Columbia University will open a three-week seminar for twenty-seven city editors and assistant city editors on Monday, it was announced yesterday.

A prospective drop in exports and the expected inroads of foreign shipping will reduce the total tonnage of United States dry cargo ships in operation in 1948 by 23 per cent, in the opinion of the Association of American Ship Owners.

Further recommendations for reduction of Federal taxes and revision of the Federal tax system have been approved by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York and are being forwarded to members of Congress, Thomas Jefferson Miley, secretary of the association, reported yesterday.

The nation's retailers and Government were urged yesterday to take specific steps to combat inflation and price increases in a resolution adopted by the National Retail Dry Goods Association at its annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

MONTREAL, Jan. 15 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens prevented Toronto from taking the National Hockey League lead tonight by drubbing the Maple Leafs, 8 -- 4. The Canadiens spotted the Leafs, who trail first-place Detroit by a point, a 3-2 first-period lead and then stormed back with two goals in the middle session and four in the final.

Whereas winter's coldest day probably kept many home at their firesides, the thousands who did queue into Grand Central Palace for the National Motor Boat Show had the luxury of more elbow room than usual and shorter waiting time at the boarding ladders.

The new line of 1948 Ford trucks will be put on public display today in dealer showrooms in this city and throughout the country, C.J. Seyffer, northeastern regional manager of the Ford Motor Company, announced yesterday.
CAIRO, Jan. 15 (Reuters) -- King Yahya, ruler of Yemen, has died at the age of 85, according to reports received in Cairo tonight.
State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein yesterday continued his inquiry into the attempted purchase of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh, but he disclosed none of his findings.

ATHENS, Jan. 15 -- Reports from Naupactos on the north side of the Gulf of Corinth indicated that Greek Army reinforcements sent against the guerrillas who for some time yesterday held the town of Arakhova, had pursued but had not caught up with the retreating rebels.

CAIRO, Egypt, Jan. 15 -- The regular armies of the Arab countries will occupy all of Palestine as soon as the British withdraw, Assad Dagher Bey, chief of the press section of the Arab League, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Average primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended on Jan. 10, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The severest cold wave of the winter chilled the country east of the Rocky Mountains yesterday and pushed the mercury here down to 8.9 degrees at 6:15 A.M --the lowest reading of the season.

It is very confusing, really. Don't Mr. Wallace and Senator Taft know they're breaking all the rules, Queens-berry and otherwise, by batting on the same side in a race for the Presidential nomination?

Praise for the report of the President's Air Policy Commission, quoted in this newspaper yesterday as coming from an important cross-section of the aviation industry, will doubtless be attributed in some quarters exclusively to the factor of self-interest. But the aviation industry is in a particularly good position to know that for "Survival in the Air Age" this nation must be strong in the air.
A total of 17,322 antlered deer was gathered in by New York hunters during the recent season, an all-time record for this state, and an increase of about 10 per cent over the 1946 take.

GENEVA, Jan. 15 -- Extension of the "freedom of the road" agreement of nine European countries to all Europe will be sought by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe, it was indicated today by commission sources.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 15 (AP) -- Shooting what he described as "the finest round of my career," E.J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., posted a seven-under-par 65 today to lead after the opening round of the 72-hole $10,000 Richmond Open Golf Tournament.

The public library systems in the five boroughs asked Thomas J. Patterson, Budget Director, for $2,000,000 in additional funds yesterday for operation of libraries during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

The size of orders being placed by several leading industrialist purchasing agents here has been increased about 300 per cent in efforts to cover inventory requirements for the next six months, spokesmen revealed yesterday. Indicating that this is a major shift in policies, the executives said that until now they had purchased for 60-day maximum inventory requirements, but now were buying for 180-day inventory needs.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Jan. 15 (AP) -- Scores were injured tonight in a riot between followers of W.A. Bustamante, labor leader, and the People's National party. The police battled the two gangs for five hours before restoring order. Twenty-three persons were arrested.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- The long-sought 40-hour week was recommended today for 4,700 vehicle and garage employes of the Railway Express Agency in the New York metropolitan area by an emergency board named under the Railway Labor Act.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 15 -- Decrying the minor role now given to religion in the curriculum, national educational leaders advocated that greater emphasis be placed on religious courses in the college program. They urged that all students be required to take courses in religion as part of their academic program.

CONGERS, N.Y., Jan. 15 -- Bryce W. Witt, 17 years old, a scholarship freshman at Columbia College and a pre-engineering student, was killed today by the 6:49 A.M., southbound train at the Congers West Shore Railroad Station. Clarkstown police found the body 936 feet south of the station, but have been unable to find a witness.

The report of the Dow Chemical Company and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on Nov. 30, made public yesterday, shows a net profit of $9,096,337, after charges of $15,604,633, a provision of $5,681,712 for Federal taxes, and $826,584 for the employes' retirement plan.
DETROIT, Jan. 15 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, will open the third round of post-war wage increase demands by asking a rise of at least 30 cents an hour, it was learned tonight.

The seasonal decline in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System has been arrested, and the total of such commitments at the close of the week ended on Wednesday night was $3,000,000 above the level of the previous weekly period, it was announced yesterday.

Emerich Juettner, 72 years old, also known as Edward Miuller of 204 West Ninety-sixth Street, was released yesterday in his own custody to await grand jury action by United States Commissioner Garrett W. Cotter on a charge of possessing nine copper plates from which counterfeit bills could be made.
The Board of Estimate unanimously approved yesterday a zoning change that will permit construction of a $30,000,000 private housing development in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

"For One Night," a new French film, will have its premiere at the Little Carnegie Playhouse next month, it was announced yesterday by Distinguished Films, the distributors. The film, an adaptation of the Emile Zola story, "Pour Un Nuit d'Amour," stars Odetie Joyeaux and features Robert Blin and Alerme.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15 -- Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan denied today that his sponsorship of President Truman's tax adjustment bill indicated the intention of other Ways and Means Committee Democrats to withhold their support.

A 40-year-old transit patrolman was shot and wounded critically early yesterday morning by a patrolman in the IND Rockaway Avenue station, Brooklyn, after he had fired three shots wildly into the air at Rockaway Avenue and Fulton Street, then fled into the subway station with drawn revolver.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Provisions for a Government-sponsored "normal home life" for 139,000 British boys and girls who are presently growing up outside a home atmosphere are embraced in the Labor Government's children's bill published today.

Walter Hautzig, pianist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. When the youthful artist made his local debut in 1943 his playing promised far more than reached fulfillment at this latest appearance. At times, his work was sensitive, but it showed a loss rather than a gain in emotional intensity and interpretive skill.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 16 -A battle over two directorships and the presidency of the Tarrytown National Bank and Trust Company will be submitted to the Controller of the Currency in Washington for decision, according to an agreement, reached today by the contestants.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee promised today to reconsider its rejection of the nomination of Maj. Gen. Laurence S. Kuter to be chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board after President Truman characterized the action as a "disservice" in time of emergency.

PARIS, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Paris newspapers said today that local constabulary apparently had frustrated an attempt to parachute arms of supplies to an underground group in the Cher Department of central France.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- A solution of the displaced persons problem by acceptance of a "fair share" of non-repatriatable war victims by each member of the United Nations will be urged by William Hallam Tuck, executive secretary of the International Refugee Organization Preparatory Commission at the commission's next session which begins here on Jan. 20.

The Rev. Dr. John A. Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, Princeton, N.J., and the president since Jan. 1, last, of the International Missionary Council, will deliver the 1948 Croall Foundation lectures at Edinburgh University, Edinburgh, Scotland.

Construction of the Brownsville Health Station, first of fifteen such units to be added to the Health Department's chain of neighborhood clinics, will begin as soon as weather permits, it was said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- New and severe restrictions on aliens coming here as visitors were approved by Attorney General Tom C. Clark today. The new regulations are designed to keep a closer check on persons suspected of subversive activity.

Trans-Atlantic Airways' domestic branch will parallel extension of its new Douglas "Sky Coach" service to forty-five cities with a newspaper advertising campaign expected to expend $800,000 by the end of the year, it was disclosed yesterday.

A tiff that could sprout into a sizable feud between the Yankees and Giants seemed in a rapid stage of development yesterday. It came as an aftermath to the slapping of a $500 fine on the Yanks by Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler for illegally signing Harry Nicholas, 18-year-old Valley Stream High School pitcher, last summer.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- A two-man team of specialists, one French and one British, will tour the countries participating in the European Recovery Program during the coming weeks to investigate the efforts each country is making to help its own economy and to cooperate in the general European rehabilitation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Alexander Bittelman, a national committeeman for the Communist party in the United States, has been arrested in Miami, Fla., for deportation, the Department of Justice announced today. Bittelman lives on Mount Airy Road, Croton-onHudson, and is described as general secretary of the Morning Freiheit Association, 50 East Thirteenth Street, New York.

" England, A History of The Homeland," by Henry Hamilton, will be published Monday by W. W. Norton. Mr. Hamilton, Jaffrey Professor of Political Economy at the University of Aberdeen, stresses the social institutions and the way Englishmen lived and worked at different periods.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Jan. 17 (AP) -- An anti-British demonstration gripped Canton for three hours yesterday. Rioting Chinese mobs invaded and burned the British Consulate and several business establishments, injured six Britons and threatened harm to a number of Americans.

Can manufacturers and users denied here yesterday that a new restriction order had been issued by the Department of Commerce curbing uses of tin cans for brewers, dog-food packers and others. They said no such order has been released and that reports conveyed by Government officials that new curbs have been definitely decided upon were "misleading to the public."

h)0*0*0*iGENEVA, Jan. 16 -- The budgets of several specialized agencies of the United Nations came under attack today in a closed session of the coordinating committee of the Economic and Social Council.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 16 -- Denouncing the customary allotment of accommodations, western Republicans today demanded an increased supply of tickets and hotel rooms in connection with the party's national convention, opening here the week of June 20.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, took the lead today in the third postwar round of wage-increase demands by announcing that on Feb. 28 it would ask the General Motors Corporation for a flat rise of 30 cents an hour, plus fringe benefits which would vary in amount as to individual plants.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Milton A. Reckord, president of Havre de Grace, said tonight he considered it "very poor policy" for New Jersey horse racing tracks to select dates which coincide with the Maryland schedules.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The United Nations Good Offices Committee announced today that the Dutch and Indonesians had agreed to truce proposals and indicated that the agreement would be signed tomorrow after eleven weeks of negotiations.

Behind only in the opening seconds of play. Long Island University enjoyed an easy time of it last night and conquered the Springfield (Mass.) College Quintet, 56 -- 37, before 2,700 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory. In the first game of the varsity doubleheader.

Failing in his early efforts to halt the activities of the Crown Heights section of the Communist party, Joseph Goldstein, Brooklyn attorney, filed yesterday with District Attorney Miles F. McDonald a complaint charging the organization with perjury.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Coupling a five-under-par 67 today to his first-round course record 65, E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock, Ark., posted a total of 132 to retain his lead at the halfway mark of the seventy-two-hole Richmond open golf tournament.

Prevented from participating in commencement exercises because of the outbreak of World War I, sixty-one alumni of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance, class of 1917, will receive their "diplomas" this evening at the school's class reunion dinner at the Lafayette Hotel.
The price of milk, which apparently had been pegged at the current level till April, may rise 1/2 cent a quart on Feb. 1, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) - Secretary Clinton P. Anderson made public today the names of twenty-seven additional direct or indirect employes of the Agriculture Department who have reported that they have speculated in commodities since Jan. 1, 1946.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 16 -- Although workers in three cities staged twenty-four-hour work stoppages today, tension in the Ruhr eased somewhat following an announcement of unprecedented offers by officials of other states to share their meager food rations with the hard-pressed industrial cities of North Rhine-Westphalia.
SHANGHAI, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The slaying of another woman missionary in central China was reported today by the China Inland Mission, bringing to five the number reported killed recently in that region.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 16 (AP) -- Yugoslavia has proposed that she and thirteen other members of the Inter-Allied Reparations Agency establish a "common stand" on the allocation of factories from western Germany.

The State Commission Against Discrimination announced yesterday it had reached an agreement with the Grand International Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers to eliminate the application in New York State of provisions of the constitution and by-laws in conflict with the state anti-discrimination law.

MINEOLA, L. I., Jan. 16 -- Commissioner John M. Beckmann ordered today the biggest shakeup in the history of the Nassau County Police Department effective Feb. 1. About one-third of the department's 721 men were affected.

We print on this page today a letter from the president of a group of patient, overworked, underpaid city employes. They are the probation officers in three city courts, Domestic Relations, Magistrates' and Special Sessions.h)0*0*0*iThere are only about 250 of these probation officers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A crackdown on doctors suspected of "chiseling" in the care of ailingh)0*0*0*iwar veterans was announced today by the Veterans Administration.

Larger lumber mills will follow the lead of the Weyerhaeuser Timber Company and reduce prices at least 10 per cent within the next sixty days, wholesalers and yard representatives agreed yesterday. A manufacturers' spokesman said that price reductions by larger operators as a result of the Weyerhaeuser action "are quite possible in the near future."

Stocks improved moderately yesterday in dull trading, following four successive days of declining prices. The recovery, paced by the railroad shares, lent a firmer tone to the list, but theh)0*0*0*iimprovement failed to widen interest in the market.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Jan. 16 -- Six German defense attorneys in the trial of Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach and his associates are behind bars tonight in the jail adjoining the Palace of Justice here, in company with their clients.

President Truman praised the American Jewish Committee yesterday for its efforts in promoting and preserving civil rights in the United States. In a message to Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee, and read to the annual meeting of the organization in the Commodore Hotel, President Truman said:
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Discussing the conversation between M. Mayer and Sir Stafford in London, the French press referred today to an impending monetary operation in France as "imminent."

After the Federal Bureau of Investigation had received a tip that the United States liner America was to be "sabotaged," the police, Coast Guard and other agencies made a fruitless three-and-a-half-hour search of the 26,314-ton vessel at her West Twenty-first Street pier last evening.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 16 -- A Canadian Prices Board official has announced the Government and representatives of the furniture manufacturing industry have agreed to relax import restrictions on certain types of woods.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- A return toh)0*0*0*ithe doll's hat of 1940, tiny tambourines and tricornes, cascades of straw spaghetti and nose veils of mesh so heavy that they are virtually domino masks are some of the high lights of Albouy's fascinating collection, the first of the Paris milliners to be opened officially.

Distributive education has a "wonderful opportunity to do a sorely needed job for the small store or independent retailer," Norman Richman, personnel director of Kresge-Newark, Inc., said yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Representatives of airport operators in nineteen principal cities of the United States brought to a close yesterday a two-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by forming an organization to be known as the Airport Operators Council.
Negotiations are nearing completion here for the construction of thirteen new "super tankers" as part of the tonnage replacement plans of three major oil companies, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- More than two score representatives of various groups of postal employes of the Greater New York City area appeared here today in support of legislation to grant an increase of $1,000 a year to all postal employes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The participation of Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson and Associate Justice Stanley F. Reed in a recent denial of a petition by the Supreme Court was criticized by a holder of bonds of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad in a plea for rehearing filed in the court today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- An air supply device for submerged vessels operable from within, by means of which air can be drawn through intervening water to the interior of submarines or other craft, was patented this week by Charles E. Beeman of Grand Rapids, Mich.

The N.Y.U. swimming team maintained its undefeated record in metropolitan competition yesterday when it defeated Fordham, 56 -- 18, in the Rose Hill pool. The Violets previously had beaten Manhattan, Brooklyn College and Brooklyn Poly.

The bill passed by the House of Representatives making reforms in Army courts-martial procedure is good as far as it goes. It accomplishes one fundamental reform asked by practically every civilian group that has studied Army procedures, namely, establishment of an independent Judge Advocate General department.

BERLIN, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today that sabotage against the Western Allies already had started and could be expected to increase in an all-out Communist drive to wreck the Marshall Plan and the merger of the Western occupation zones in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who shuns politics but has not said whether he would accept the Republican Presidential nomination, got a campaign song indirectly today.
ANKARA, Turkey, Jan. 15 (Delayed) -- The Turkish Government will ratify soon an agreement signed with the United States for the inauguration of a highway program in Turkey, it was learned here today.

A total of $$52 from forty-onecontributors was received yesterdayh)0*0*0*by THE NEW YORK TIMES fortics Hundred Neediest Cases Fund,increasing the total of the thirtysixth annual appeal, which wasstarted last Dec. 7, to $357,$37.46.

Home for former Army Sgt. Max Tkachuk, a veteran of Saipan, his wife, Helen, both 26 years old, their two children, Anna, 5, and Nicholas, 4, has been a battered 1930 sedan for the last week. Last night things began to look up a little.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 16 (AP) -Competent medical sources said today that 78-year-old Mohandas K. Gandhi, in the fourth day of his fast, could endure another six days "at the utmost" without seriously endangering his life.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange developed some weakness yesterday, but closed mixed, 32 points lower to 14 points net higher. The near months showed the most weakness.

Prepared for title competition by a month of handicap racing, New York's outstanding runners, hurdlers, walkers and jumpers will convene tonight at the Twentythird Regiment Armory in Brooklyn for the Metropolitan A.A.U. senior indoor track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- John W. Snyder, Secretary of the Treasury, told Congress today that enactment of the Knutson Tax Reduction Bill would create a Federal deficit of $2,100,000,000 in the 1949 fiscal year, beginning next July 1.

CINCINNATI, Jan. 16 -- Overall study of the "total strategy of Protestantism," said to be the first of its kind in the United States and calculated to require three years was urged here today, in a resolution adopted by the National Protestant Council on Higher Education.

The question of whether emergency anti-inflation controls should be introduced in this country over meat and certain other key commodities is currently the subject of hearings before a Senate committee as well as being theh)0*0*0*icenter of nation-wide public controversy.

THE lady came to a violent end -- she killed herself. That did not at first glance seem to be in character, for she was so gentle and quiet and retiring. All the community knew that she was troubled, but there were various different theories about, as well as several obvious causes of, her unhappiness. Just why, then, did Katharine Bennett kill herself?
An exhibition of decorative art objects of the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries given by an anonymous donor opens today at noon at the Newark Museum. The display will continue until March 15.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The Ministry of Supply issued a statement tonight indicating that discussions will be reopened on the question of prices for Malayan tin ore.

A three-point program urging women to take the initiative in fighting inflation through a nationwide self-imposed food economy program was suggested yesterday at the eighty-fifth convention of the Long Island Federation of Women's Clubs in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, submitted today to "cross-examination" on Russia's atomic proposals and made it clear that his country wanted responsibility for carrying out important parts of any control plan placed in the hands of individual nations rather than an international agency.

Mrs. Sylvia Weiner, 34 years old, was held yesterday in $25,000 bail in connection with the slaying on Tuesday night of her husband, Benjamin, an ex-convict, in their apartment at 68 East First Street. Mrs. Weiner, who was arraigned in chambers before General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan, was booked by telephone at the Elizabeth Street police station.
In a story about American information activities in Germany appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Dec. 28, 1947, your Berlin correspondent, Delbert Clark, writes:

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 16 -Bombs exploded near two Socialist open-air meetings last night injuring a woman bystander as the party, which is among President Juan D. Peron's strongest opponents, launched its campaign for the March parliamentary elections.
