CULVER CITY, Calif., Jan. 16 -Irene, well-known California designer, has just presented her first collection in her own establishment. While she is working independently in her own business she will continue to design for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, with whom she has been associated for some years.

The Swedish American linerh)0*0*0*iDrottningholm, which sailed yesterday for Gothenburg in command of Capt. John Nordlander, will come to New York only once more, and thereafter will fly the flag of Panama in the emigrant run between Genoa and east coast ports of South America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -The fate of racial restrictive covenants agreements under which property owners agree to exclude Negroes or other groups from specified residential areas -- rested tonight with six Supreme Court justices.

Keyes Winter, president justice of the municipal courts in the five boroughs, asked Budget Director Thomas J. Patterson yesterday for a cost-of-living bonus of $3,000 for each of the sixty-seven municipal court justices.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- A hearing by the National Labor Relations Board on unfair labor practice charges against the International and Chicago Typographical Unions, AFL, was directed mainly today toward alleged slowdowns in Chicago newspaper composing rooms just before the strike on Nov. 24.
Trade here this week continuedto maintain about the same rateof dollar gain as in the precedingweek. Department stores had inCreases ranging up to 10 per centover a year ago.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16 -- Reviving memories of the Mississippi River's glorious past, two tugboats chugged up the big stream toward St. Louis tonight in a 1,051-mile race to test steam against diesel power.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey formally entered the race for the Republican nomination for President today.

ALBANY, Jan. 16 -- The legal staff of the State Department of Education is preparing a measure for introduction at the current session of the State Legislature to provide educational services for rural children potentially equivalent to those available in urban areas.
ALBANY, Jan. 16 Democratic leaders in the State Legislature declared today that they would sponsor a measure providing for a $7,000,000 appropriation for state aid to libraries.

The need of speedy action at Albany to assure the validity of the city rent law was indicated yesterday when the Appellate Division in Brooklyn heard arguments on a decision invalidating part of Local Law 66.
The New York City Housing Authority rejected yesterday a bid of 1.17 per cent submitted by the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, the only bidder, for $2,299,000 of loan notes due Aug. 10.

ATHENS, Jan. 16 (UP) -- Twenty United States Army officers, all combat veterans, had their final briefing today and on Monday will join Greek Army units in the field to advise them on operationsh)0*0*0*iagainst the Communist-led guerrillas.

The plan outlined by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll for reorganizing the semijudicial functions of administrative agencies would make New Jersey the first state to set up an independent panel of officials, under court supervision, to hear such cases as those involving motor vehicle violations, tax appeals and trade licensing.

As in other years, the annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers has thrown light on public preferences as well as technical developments in motor car improvement. A survey made public at the meeting indicated that there is a strong market for smaller, lighter cars to sell for substantially lower prices.

Dates and places for 1948 championship meets and tournaments of the Amateur Athletic Union were announced yesterday. First of the big title events will be the men's indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 21.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) Asserting that America "must try to wage a peace and win it without going to war," Representative Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota todayh) 0*0*0*ipresented a program that he said could secure peace in America and in the world.

John Cashmore, Borough President of Brooklyn, expressed his concern yesterday over the proposal to condemn the property of the Brooklyn Friends School and Meeting House on Schermerhorn Street as a site for a new jail, and said he would meet a committee of the Religious Society of Friends at 4 P.M. on Wednesday to discuss the matter.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Jan. 16 -- Whatever may happen in the future of Java, the Netherlands was pledged this afternoon to abstain from the use of military force in the event of another emergency unless the United Nations grants permission to do so.

Announcement in Albany of Governor Dewey's candidacy for the Republican nomination for President was expected by his supporters here to give impetus in many states to the drive for the election of Dewey delegates to the Republican National Convention.

In a move to expedite the approval of renewal applications for the 1948-49 license period and to familiarize industry members with the forms required, the State Liquor Authority for the first time held a conference with the heads of more than thirty retail and wholesale associations yesterday at the SLA headquarters, 1775 Broadway.

A woman who allegedly made derogatory remarks about the physical, condition of two paraplegic war veterans was haled before Magistrate Charles F. Murphy in Long Island City Magistrate's Court yesterday on a charge of disorderly conduct.

LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Yugoslavia is accused of having violated the Hague Convention and the peace treaties dealing with Trieste in a strongly worded note from the British Government that was published today.

VIENNA, Jan. 16 -- Two American colonels assigned to the military attaches office of the United States legation in Budapest were arrested Wednesday by a Sovieth)0*0*0*iArmy colonel, held incommunicado and sent to Vienna that night under an armed guard.
Another cold wave, expected to equal in intensity the one Thursday that brought frigid weather to the nation east of the Rocky Mountains, is charted to close in on the Eastern seaboard today.

Ahead at one stage by fourteen points in the second half, Fordham had to withstand a strong Villanova rally to win its ninth straight basketball victory, 59 -- 57, before a crowd of 3,600 persons at the Rams' Rose Hill gymnasium last night.

That unterrified foxhunter, Hezekiah Cobb, tells us that the fine open weather of recent days in his part of the country -in sharp contrast with what has happened in New York -- has produced a great turnout of deer hunters.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 16 -- President Truman told members of the American Council for Judaism today that the task they had assumed should prove an inspiration to all Americans.
Effective tomorrow there will be a new schedule of commuter trains on the Harlem Division of the New York Central, it was announced yesterday by the railroad.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Jan. 16 -- Knowledge of the use of penicillin to treat the venereal group of diseases has progressed to the point where minimum effective doses can be specified for general use by physicians, Dr. John Mahoney, chief of the venereal disease laboratory of the United States Public Health Service, said here today.

The Improvement in journalistic standards undoubtedly will be a factor contributing to the solution of some of the serious problems of the world, Dr. Charles Phillips Cooper, Professor Emeritus of Journalism at Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Terry Fahye, a man with triple identity who was barred perpetually in 1939 from engaging in security dealings in New York, is the mysterious central figure who attempted to engineer a $9,150,000 stock purchase plan to gain control of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh.
SEATTLE, Jan. 16 (AP) -- The University of Washington today signed Howard Odell, ringmaster of the "Yale Circus," as head football coach to succeed Ralph (Pest) Welch.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Jan. 16 -The United States was charged with turning its back on the Americas in an editorial in the Tiempo today. The editorial says that the newspaper has never been anti-United States but maintains the United States is making a big mistake in considering the rehabilitation of Europe before helping Latin America.
LONDON, Jan. 16 -- Oil shares were the leaders in an otherwise quiet stock market here today.

A New York County grand jury indicted yesterday three men alleged to have engineered a completely fraudulent will in the hopes of sharing the bulk of the $281,000 estate left by an 81-year-old spinster who died last June 30.

Today's events: "Lucia di Lammermoor," Metropolitan Opera Company, 2 P.M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor; Marina Koshetz, soprano; Eunice Alberts, contralto; Wellesley College Choir directed by Margaret Mcdonald Winkler, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Annabelle Ott, soprano, Town Hall, 3:00; National Music Festival, Carnegie Hall, 5:30; Celia Saloman, piano, Town Hall, 5:30.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- Pakistan officially accused India today of systematic military aggression and a deliberate campaign to wipe out the Moslem population of more than a dozen provinces.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 6 -- Accused by the police of having stolen four containers filled with March of Dimes contributions from a midtown postoffice branch, Williamh)0*0*0*iHirsh, 45 years old, of 114 Fleming Avenue, was charged today with petty larceny and held for appearance tomorrow before Police Judge P. James Pellechia in First Criminal Court.

PARIS, Jan. 16 -- The scenes in the National Assembly this week were as ominous in their way as the November strikes. There was an element of farce in the performance, as when the Communists hurled epithets like "chewing gum" and "Coca-Cola" across a chamber filled, they said, with "American puppets."

There has been no studied effort to create a French atmosphere at Le Moal, a small restaurant at 811 Third Avenue, near Fiftieth Street, but in an unpretentious way the place is typical of some little bistro in Brittany. Wellcooked food and prices as modest as the decor are the attractions on which Mme.

The United States Olympic Committee yesterday announced the make-up of the "official" hockey squad it will send to the fifth Olympic Winter Games, which start at St. Moritz Jan. 30. Fifteen men, including seven college students, are on it; thirteen will leave by plane for Europe tomorrow night and the others will head for Switzerland later in the month.

We are indeed grateful to THE TIMES for your sustained efforts in behalf of civil services generally, and your special observations with respect to the recognized inequality in the pay scales of probation officers.

Demands of the Furriers Joint Council of New York, CIO, including safeguards against various phases of the Taft-Hartley Law, were under consideration yesterday by the Associated Fur Coat Trimming Manufacturers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, indicated today that Congress would insist on "policing" any loans under the European Recovery Program to prevent diversion of funds for unauthorized purposes.

The Soviet Government is scheduled to receive one Italian battleship, one cruiser, three destroyers, two torpedo boats, two submarines and about thirty miscellaneous naval auxiliary craft under the terms of a hitherto undisclosed annex and protocol to the Italian peace treaty, it has been learned from an unimpeachable source.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- An official Chinese technical mission arrived here today to consult with American officials on an aid program for China on the pattern of that projected for Europe under the Marshall Plan.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Jan. 16 (UP) -- The showing of American movies starring six of Hollywood's most outspoken antiCommunists was outlawed today, and Leftist newspapers hailed the move as the banning of "American trash."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Alexander S. Panyushkin; the new Soviet Ambassador, indicated today,h)0*0*0*iafter a fourteen-minute conference with Robert A. Lovett, UnderSecretary of State, that negotiations would be resumed "in the near future" for an adjustment of Russia's lend-lease account with the United States.
SEOUL, Korea, Jan. 16 -- The United Nations Commission on Korea today took the first step in an attempt to penetrate into Soviet-occupied North Korea.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 16 (UP) -A $37,000,000 Chinese scrap metal deal, said to be the largest in the history of the American steel industry, was revealed here today. W. T. Davis, the man who engineered the deal, and his bankers said he stood to make more than $5,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Strong appeals were made here today for the United States to lift its arms embargo against Palestine. One was made at the State Department, by a delegation of the American Jewish Labor Council. The other was made by Israel Rokach, Mayor of Tel Aviv, at a news conference.

The projected CBS show starring Goodman and Jane Ace of "Easy Aces" fame now is expected to be ready to make its bow in another month. Candidates for the supporting role will be auditioned this afternoon and several advertisers have expressed interest in sponsoring the series.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Theh)0*0*0*ioffice of the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board started today the most comprehensive attack it has yet made against the International Typographical Union by seeking a country-wide injunction in Federal Court.

In one of the coldest Januarys on record there has been a consolation for the past ten days at the National Motor Boat Show at Grand Central Palace. It didn't cost much to look at yachts and dream about next summer's vacation, come June, July and August, but even that thrill ends tonight.

Few additional controls over the American economy should be necessary for successful functioning of the Marshall Plan, Richard Bissel Jr., executive secretary of the Harriman Committee on the Marshall Plan and associate professor of economics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said yesterday.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- The crucial national convention of the Japanese Socialist party on which may depend the fate of the Government headed by the party leader Premier Tetsu Katayama, began a four-day session today with administration chiefs under attack by the Left-Wing.
Henry G. Ulrich, warehouse manager, has been appointed general manager of the New York Brass and Copper Company, Inc. John J. Condon has been appointed sales manager.

David Goldstein, 40-year-old former manager of Aetna Coated Fabrics, Inc., of 30 East Twentieth Street, was sentenced to a year and a day in prison and fined $2,000 by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday as a result of his conviction last month on a perjury charge.
Lavern Roach, the fighting marine from Plainview, Texas, gambled for high stakes last night and won.

LONDON, Jan. 16 (Reuters) - The mystery of "Mister X," the anonymous British business man who is backing Filippo del Giudice, film producer, in his plan to boost British movies in the United States, has been solved. William Grimshaw Riley, close personal friend of Sir Stafford Cripps, British Chancellor of the Exchequer, acknowledged last night "that I am the 'Mister X' referred to in the press."

Advocating the reduction of Government expenditures as reflected in the proposed annual budget, Ellsworth C. Alvord, Washington attorney and tax authority, declared yesterday that $40,000,000,000 would not be available for spending in 1949.

Two men tricked a dress manufacturer in a pretended sale yesterday, with his help loaded $2,700 worth of dresses into a truck, then tied him and a salesman and drove away, police of the Elizabeth Street station reported.

Tall, bony Per Andersson was happily aboard a train for Manistique, Mich., yesterday morning instead of being bound for Sweden on the Drottningholm. The blueeyed, weather-beaten, 68-year-old farmer made his first journey to this country last month to search for relatives.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -Construction of 10,000 freight cars a month for two years or three was urged by a Senate Interstate Commerce Subcommittee today to relieve a national shortage.
STORRS, Conn., Jan. 16 (AP) -- A University of Connecticut scientist announced today the development of a new poultry feed which, he said, allowed chickens, to "eat less and grow more."

Some of the foremost players of the day, enacting memorable scenes from their most famous shows, will appear tomorrow evening at the benefit for the American National Theatre and Academy, the organization established to help the theatre as a whole.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- Grain markets continued their upward movement on the Board of Trade today. May and cash corn and March oats and soy beans reached new high records. May corn has established a new high for seventeen straight days and May oats have closed higher for eleven straight days.

It is pleasant to read that picture slides are returning to favor. A generation ago the stereoscope was standard equipment in the parlor. The new picture-viewing devices have been brought up to date with roll films instead of postcards, but the underlyingh)0*0*0*iprinciple is the same.

With the assertion that traffic in congested midtown is "fluid," Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander voiced the city's opposition yesterday to proposals to set up a traffic control board and a parking authority.

British and American occupation forces in Germany deserve credit for good work, Viscountess Astor said last night after her arrival on he Queen Mary with Viscount Astor and their son, the Hon. Michael L., and his wife.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- The Senate unanimously approved today a bill to give the full sanction of Congress to a great lift in volume in the "Voice of America" abroad with which to counterattack the hostile world-wide propaganda of the Soviet Union.

Brisk order taking on women's and misses' coat, suit, and dress lines was reported yesterday by garment manufacturers. Retailers appear confident that spring dollar volume will surpass that of last year, manufacturers said, and they are buying to the limit of departmental budgets.

Anna Xydis, who appeared in a piano recital at Carnegie Hall last night, plays dependably as far as the mechanics of going through a piece are concerned. Her fingers are accurate, and she can manage the most difficult passages with assurance.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, Jan. 16 -- A reference to "considerable uranium resources" in South Africa gave an unexpected tone to the Speech from the Throne at the opening of the parliamentary session here today. The matter was considered of sufficient importance for the Governor General, Gideon Brand van Zyl, to announce that Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts himself would introduce legislation to control the mining and the use of uranium.

The Manhattan Shirt Company had record sales of $27,579,809 in the fiscal year ended on Nov. 30, according to its annual report, issued yesterday. The net profit was $1,045,476, after charges of $1,653,476 and a provision of $608,000 for Federal income taxes.
The reissue of "Ninotchka," Metro -Goldwyn-Mayer's 1939 spoofing of the Communist way of life, in which Greta Garbo starred, will begin an engagement today at the Little Carnegie.
A variety of oils and watercolors in modes ranging from semiabstraction to academic portraiture is on view in local galleries.

Joe Louis' dismal winning effort against Jersey Joe Walcott was the biggest disappointment of 1947 to the sports editors of the nation who contributed answers toh)0*0*0*ithe annual Associated Press yearend poll.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The United Nations Commission on the Status of Women today issued an unofficial appeal urging "the many millions of women throughout the world to work in every possible way for the peace and prosperity of people everywhere."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Howie Odell, holder of an appointment unprecedented in Yale's 77-year football history, who gave up his post as head coach today to go to the University of Washington, left behind a record of 35 victories to 15 losses and two ties in six seasons -- by no means the best record ever achieved at Yale but an outstanding one in recent years.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 16 An automatic stamp-vending machine, first of its type to be placed in a postoffice in the United States, was unveiled today at the Rochester postoffice.
Storms and heavy seas continued to slow Atlantic shipping yesterday.

WARSAW, Jan. 16 -- Today, on the eve of the third anniversary of Warsaw's liberation, the Polish Government has announced that once again the capital is the first city in the land, with a population of 566,000.

Army's basketball team visits its most-frequent opponent, Columbia, at University Hall tonight when the cadets will try to duplicate theh)0*0*0*istreak-busting performance with which the Lion football team ambushed Army last October. Only a few standing room tickets remain for the contest which will start at 8:30.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 16 (AP) -Answering assertions of British Army officers that a plane believed to be Jewish had fired on a Royal Air Force reconnaissance plane over the Hebron battle zone yesterday, Haganah said the plane in question was carrying blood plasma from Tel Aviv to a Jewish settlement and was unarmed.

JERUSALEM, Saturday, Jan. 17 -- Haifa, scene of some of the heaviest fighting in Palestine, continued in a state of general disorder today, although it was apparent that the tempo had dropped considerably. Zionist fighters, who took the offensive in Haifa on Thursday night and yesterday, asserted that they had killed eighty-two Arabs in twenty-four hours.

TOKYO, Jan. 16 -- Before the end of the month company reorganizations under the economic decentralization law are due to start. Among them are several corporations in which United States and other foreign investors owned important equities before the war.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 16 An automatic stamp-vending machine, first of its type to be placed in a postoffice in the United States, was unveiled today at the Rochester postoffice.

The vast ski area carved out on Silver Depository Hill at West Point, a development designed and patterned by the late Capt. Victor Constant, killed two years ago while training for the national downhill-slalom championships at Franconia, N.H., will be officially dedicated to his memory one week from tomorrow.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 16 -- Premier Georgi Dimitrov of Bulgaria signed a pact of mutual assistance with Rumania today. Declaring that the Greek civil conflict was sustained by the United States and Britain with troops and money, he noted that this strife provided "a hotbed of war" in the Balkans.

DETROIT, Jan. 16 -- New York City was urged by Austin M. Wolf, New York automotive engineer, today to dig itself out of its traffic and parking problems by building underground facilities. He termed relief measures thus far "too little and too late to be of any permanent assistance."

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 16 - New Jersey assets of David H. Blair, 68-year-old, money broker and head of D. H. Blair Company, Inc., of 29 Broadway, New York, were ordered frozen here today by Advisory Master in Chancery Nicholas A. Tomasulo, who signed an order of sequestration on petition of Mrs. Ella Blair of 101 West Fifty-third Street, New York.

HAVANA, Jan. 16 -- The general committee of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Employment decided at a closed meeting tonight to try to conclude the conference during the first part of February. The chairmen of twenty subcommittees were instructed to turn in reports by Jan. 31 so that final meetings of the full committees and plenary sessions can beh)0*0*0*iheld.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Jan. 16 -- The United Nations Palestine Commission took up today the vital question how armed militia that would be responsible for keeping internal order could be established in the proposed Jewish and Arab states.
PARIS, Jan. 16 -- Soviet diplomacy is engineering a new type of bilateral alliances between Eastern European states.

TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Although blowing up on one hole, Miss Betty Jameson of San Antonio, Texas, fired a one-over-parh)0*0*0*i76 today for a 36-hole total of 151 and a five-stroke lead in the Tampa women's open golf tournament.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 16 (AP) -Woodruff Randolph served with notice of the NLRB petition this afternoon, issued a statement in which he said the injunction "asks that the ITU officers be restrained from everything publisher aides claim we are doing that they do not like."

NANKING, Saturday, Jan. 17 -Sir Ralph Stevenson, the British Ambassador, protested to the Chinese Foreign Ministry last night and reserved the right to demand compensation for the attack on the British Consulate General and other British property in Canton.

Two deals of less than earthshaking consequence and the rehiring of an assistant coach were the only concrete developments to emerge from the second session of the National Football League's annual midwinter parley yesterday.

The annual Yorkville Dinner Dance was given last night in its traditional setting, the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The fete is held each winter under the auspices of the Yorkville Community Association, 205 East Eighty-fifth Street, to advance its recreational, educational and vocational projects for underprivileged children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Jan. 16 EagleLion today signed Joan Bennett to play opposite Paul Henreid in "Hollow Triump," a photoplay by Daniel Fuchs based on a novel by Murray Forbes, which is scheduled for the cameras next month, with Steven Sekeley directing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 -- Members of the Republican National Committee will meet here next Monday and Tuesday to approve the budget for the coming campaign and set a date for the opening of the national convention at Philadelphia in June.

Six string and wood-wind players who call themselves the Chamber Music Concertante joinedh)0*0*0*iforces last night for the second time this season to provide Carnegie Recital Hall listeners with some rare and charming music. Some of the eighteenth-century works which dominated the list may be more fun to play than to hear, but one found much to intrigue the ear in Mozart quartets for flute and oboe and strings and in Scarlatti's Toccata, Aria, Minuetto, Giga.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 The House Labor Committee heard from representatives of the recording industry today that the TaftHartley Act is the probable cause for the ban by James C. Petrillo against union musicians playing for their disks.
MADRID, Iowa, Jan. 16 (AP) Sixty-three elderly persons, including "about a half dozen" over 90 years old, were herded safely out of a raging fire at the Iowa Lutheran Home for the Aged today.

The lowest of three bids received yesterday by the Board of Transportation for the steel work on the proposed $12,000,000 addition to its IRT power plant on West Fiftyninth Street was one of $654,955 submitted by the Harris Structural Steel Company of 419 Fourth avenue.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 The national board of the Progressive Citizens of America sounded the call tonight for the more than 500 delegates to the first annual PCA convention to endorse Henry A. Wallace's independent campaign for the Presidency.

A new series of conferences sponsored by the United States Mediation and Conciliation Service failed yesterday to achieve any progress toward a settlement of a fifteenday-old strike against four cable companies that handle two-thirds of all foreign cable traffic.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -Charles P. Gross, retired major general and former chief of the Army Transportation Corps, will join the United States Military Government in Germany, it was announced today. Mr. Gross, who retired from the Army in 1945, served as chairman of the New York City Board of Transportation until last October.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 (AP) -- A Senate committee told the steel industry today it must take the lead in wiping out a flourishing "gray market" if it hopes to avoid new Government controls.

h)0*0*0*iUnited States aid to China on a government-to-government basis to exclusion of private business would be "unwise and unsound," the National Foreign Trade Council declared in a statement issued yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 16 (AP) -- Delegate, a chestnut gelding owned by Herbert M. Woolf's Woolford Farm, beat the Sunshine Stable's favored Buzfuz at the wire today in the $10,000 added six-furlong Inaugural Handicap as Hialeah Park opened forty days of racing before 15,581 fans who turned out despite cold and cloudy weather.
The Army transport Joseph V. Connolly, which burned and was abandoned at sea last Monday, is still afire and afloat, Coast Guard and Army sources reported last night.

If there had never been a play before in the history of the world, "The Men We Marry," acted at the Mansfield last evening, would be remarkable. It has characters, dialogue, a plot and three acts, which would be sensational inventions if they were new.

Preservation of freedom of expression, for which Benjamin Franklin always fought, is more significant today than ever before, Council President Vincent R. Impellitteri declared yesterday at exercises marking the 242d anniversary of the birth of the American statesman, journalist and educator.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Jan. 16 -- Seton Hall's basketball team made it victory No. 10 tonight with a 68-46 conquest of Scranton University, its oldest rival, before a throng of 2,800 fans who turned out to greet the Pirates after three victories in four games on the road.

ATLANTIC CITY, Jan. 16 -Equipment valued at nearly $5,000,000 was put on public display by 135 exhibitors as the forty-first annual exhibit of the Canning Machinery and Supplies Association opened here at Convention Hall today.
ROME, Jan. 16 -- The Italian Cabinet today approved a decree providing a decrease of prison sentences for political and a great variety of other crimes.
I was so impressed and felt such a lifting of spirit when I volunteered at the Church World Service Center, 214 East Twenty-first Street, that I want to pass on to others what I learned there.

CHICAGO, Jan. 16 -- The wage and working-rules dispute between the railroads and three brotherhoods of railroad operating employes reached a critical stage today as Government mediators in the case announced failure to effect a settlement.

Removing tonsils or adenoids sometimes has serious effects on the personality of the patient by damaging the speech-making parts of the throat, Dr. James S. Greene said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

VIENNA, Jan. 16 -- United States representatives proposed at today's meeting of the Allied Council to turn back to the Austrians a large measure of control over Austria.h)0*0*0*iSoviet representatives countered with an accusation that the Western powers had blocked demilitarization to "transform Western Austria into a military base for AngloAmerican imperialism."

KENNETH HIEBER, original musical director of the Lemonade Opera, resigned last November. The rift in the ranks was deeper than it appeared. Arthur F. Devine, stage manager, resigned at the same time and within a few weeks four of the fifteen singers left.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 -- Important discoveries of tombs from the fourth and second centuries before Christ and the first century of the Christian era have been made by the British administration in Cyrenaica, authorities announced here today.

WHILE a snappy, attractive title won't turn a so-so picture into a thumping box-office success and a wordy, meaningless tag won't necessarily put an otherwise attractively, adorned film in the red, it is always desirable, of course, that the title of a picture be both eye-arresting and provocative.

The Maritime Commission announced last week two decisions affecting its post-war trade routes. Route No. 11, between United States South Atlantic ports, Eire and northern Europe, has been awarded to the South Atlantic Steamship Company, and the route has been extended to include Hampton Roads ports.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- The United Nations Security Council called on India and Pakistan today to take measures immediately to end the fighting in Kashmir and to appeal to their peoples to respect the Council's request for a truce.

J. B. Priestley's broadcast, after a recent -- and presumably brief -- visit, scarcely does justice to a man returning from a meeting of UNESCO, which seeks to promote international understanding through an exchange of cultures.

PEARL HARBOR, Jan. 17 -- A saga of three Gilbertese natives who were adrift in the Pacific for fifty-seven days and cast away upon a tropical atoll in the Carolines for eighty additional days has been revealed here.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- Yale gained its twenty-seventh straight dual swimming meet victory and fifth of the present season by defeating Pennsylvania in Hutchinson Pool today, 55 -- 20.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the double bill performance of "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of St. Barnabas House, a temporary shelter for women and children of the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

ALTHOUGH it got scant attention in the news reports of the President's Air Policy Commission last week, the recommendation that new commercial passenger planes be given a longer test period before being put into regular service is likely to generate much discussion in future weeks.

PROPHECY is always at premium but the parts of this solidly statistical little book which are likely to have more than academic appeal are those which may suggest something of the shape of 1948. Two pertinent facts emerge from the graphs, tables, and text prepared by Prof. Ewing of the Univ. of Oklahoma.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Undefeated Rhode Island State College, kings of firehouse basketball, had to resort to the ancient art of "freeze" tonight to whip a St. Joseph's College quintet, 82 to 78, and gain its ninth straight victory in the second game of a basketball double-header before 6,236 at Convention Hall.

THIS is a controversial book, and some of the controversies will derive less from what it says than from how it says what it has to say on race, culture, and what Professor Fairchild calls "nationality." The first few chapters contain a readable and reasonable, though oversimplified, account of what we know and do not know about race.

ATHENS, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has released 58,000 ounces of bar gold belonging to Greece so that the Greek Government can, by free sales in Athens, try to halt the drop in the drachma, it was learned here today.
CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong in yesterday's two-hour session and closed 6 to 25 points net higher.

THIRTEEN years ago this week in this Review: A book about Ellis Island ("In the Shadow of Liberty" by Edward Corsi) made front-page, and Charles Poore wrote: "It is to America what notes on the players at the back of a theatre program are to the play . . . there's material for a whole cycle of novels and plays."

Research is now under way at Harvard School of Dental Medicine to determine whether certain chemicals added to sugar will retard the production of acid in the mouths of cotton rats. In test-tube experiments recently published by Dr. Leonard S. Fosdick of Northwestern University Dental School, Chicago, glyceric aldehyde, a rare sugar, stopped sugar from fermenting under the action of bacteria which are always found in the mouth.

State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein continued yesterday his investigation into the attempt to engineer a $9,150,000 stock purchase deal to gain control of the Follansbee Steel Corporation of Pittsburgh.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- In his three messages to Congress over the last ten days, President Truman has fashioned a sort of economic manifesto that will apparently have to serve the Democratic party through the general elections of next November. Most Republicans in Congress have shown they are willing to accept political battle on the terrain the President has outlined.

ROME, Jan. 17 -- In a speech delivered at the National Congress of the Italian Republican party in Naples this morning Foreign Minister Count Carlo Sforza reviewed Italy's principal international problems and dealt with Communist accusations that the United States was trying to enslave Europe through the Marshall Plan.

A significant phrase crept into last week's hearings in Washington on the European Recovery Program. What, it was asked, would be the cost of not having an ERP? The direct and immediate cost would be an enormous increase in necessary expenditures for defense. As Secretary Forrestal said, "We would have to appropriate as much for defense in a single year as for the entire Marshall Plan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- Edwin W. Pauley, who is resigning as special assistant to Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, "sometime this month," also has submitted his resignation as adviser on reparations matters, to George C. Marshall, Secretary of State.

Making up the five-goal handicap they handed out within two periods, the Ramapo poloists recorded their third success in as many New Jersey division matches in the Metropolitan High Goal League by halting the Jockey Hollow Polo Club, 13 to 10, in the main match of the indoor doubleheader staged at the Squadron A Armory last night.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 17 -- Ten distinctive styled models and the new "Dynaflow Drive" transmission were presented today by the Buick division, General Motors Corporation in the 1948 line of cars. Thirty engineering advances and improvements were introduced.

A larger number of new car deliveries are promised in this area because more than 123 automobile dealers have shown marked success in uncovering large quantities of iron and steel scrap in automobile repair shops and garages in eastern New York, northern New Jersey and Connecticut areas, J. D. Platt, zone manager of the Packard Motor Car Company, revealed yesterday.

The report submitted to Governor Dewey's State Inter-Departmental Council at Albany by the Westchester Joint Committee on Alcoholism is timely and thorough. The committee of Westchester physicians, psychiatrists, penologists, civic leaders and social workers, organized by the White Plains Rotary Club in 1946, rightly emphasizes that from an economic standpoint, if from no other, "the problem of alcoholism is now the most costly of any of our health and social problems."
Nkemjika Akwiwu, 20 years old, circled over Queens yesterday, gasped at the strange whiteness below him and landed in America to study medicine.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York announced yesterday that it has set aside Tuesday as "Dedication Day." It will seek to raise $500,000 on that day to attain impetus to carry it over its $15,000,000 objective.

ON the sixth of February next Dean Dixon's American Youth Orchestra will give the first of a series of "Symphony at Midnight" concerts in Town Hall. These concerts will begin as a matter of fact at 11:30 P. M.

THIS is the armchair season in gardening, the time of year that finds the grower happily thumbing the pages of brilliantly illustrated catalogues carefully designed to destroy all his sales resistance. He finds the lyrical descriptions and the vivid colored plates of new entries a thing of beauty and intriguing as a shade tree on a hot day.

A busy week of auction sales at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, begins tomorrow with the dispersal of part one of the collection of rare Japanese color prints formed by the late Carl Schraubstadter of New York.

Displaying excellent racquet work, Charles Brinton, national champion, moved into the semifinal round of one of the newest events in squash racquets: the Harry Cowles Tournament that was staged for the second time at the Harvard Club yesterday.

THE word is that Feb. 12 has been set as the date for the Metropolitan Opera's first presentation of Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes." Emil Cooper will conduct. Polyna Stoska will have the role of Ellen Orford, the school teacher, and Lawrence Tibbett will sing Capt. Balstrode.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- A co-founder of Alcoholics Anonymous said today at the opening of the first international convention of the organization that it could be expected that at least 20,000 new members would be added to the roster this year, to lift the total to more than 80,000.

EVERYONE -- even a music critic -- has a right to dislike anything. The Constitution is behind Olin Downes when he reviews the new production of "Das Rheingold" and goes into some detail to tear down Lee Simonson's scenery.

Two buildings on the lower West Side were ordered closed yesterday after tons of water cascading from a broken pipeline through a thirteen-story loft building at 47 West Street made it structurally hazardous, in the opinion of city inspectors. The other structure adjoins at 74 Washington Street.

STOWE, Vt., Jan. 17 -- Seventy top-notch amateur skiers and ski instructors, 6 inches more of powder snow on a 3-foot packed powder base and a new challenging course on the standard trail comprise the background of the giant slalom race tomorrow in the memory of the late Capt. Victor Constant, West Point ski coach and mountain trooper.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Western Kentucky rolled to a 74-52 decision over Canisius tonight before 9,682 Memorial Auditorium fans for its eleventh basketball victory in twelve starts. DePaul won its eleventh victory in fourteen games by tripping Niagara, 56 -- 53, in the opener of the double-header.
EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 17 -- Michigan State College's controversial Jenison athletic scholarships were tossed into discard today.

It is by way of sex that the contributing characters are presented and fathomed, that wrongs are righted, revenges taken, and maturity attained, and that the central drama develops.

COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., Jan. 17 -- After the failure of a third attempt to deliver fuel oil to a picketed distributor in this community, Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper warned this afternoon that he might instruct state troopers to escort the four railroad tank cars containing 40,000 gallons to their destination.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 17 -- A scientific rainmaking expedition, well supplied with dry ice to drop into clouds, went to Richmond Airdrome, near here, to do something about the weather. The weather was hot and dry, the air clear.

Celia Saloman, pianist, gave a recital in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon before a good-sized and appreciative audience. Her program was divided by periods, Schumann's "Carnaval" and two transcriptions of Bach organ pieces in the first half,

The carpet industry is making all possible provisions to service the mass market, and a large portion of overall production now centers in inexpensive axminster products, Steele M. Winterer, vice president of A M Karagheusian, declared in an interview last week.

The Army cargo transport Lieut. Alexander R. Nininger, steaming from St. John's, Nfld., to the side of the burned transport Joseph V. Connolly, will try to start salvage operations today, the Army Port of Embarkation reported last night.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Georgi Dimitrov, Communist Premier of Bulgaria, said today that Eastern European nations within the Soviet orbit intended when the time was ripe to form a federation of states as allies of Russia.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17 -- General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower was acclaimed by thousands today as his motorcade moved over midtown streets to Franklin Institute, where he, received the Poor Richard Club's 1948 Medal of Achievement.

IN the literature of protest in America from John Woolman to Richard Wright, the writings of Jack London must occupy a place very near the top. To London the brotherhood of man was no mere exercise in economic adjustment but a passionate gospel and he preached it with an intensity and dialectical skill that made his books virtual manuals among Socialist readers of his day.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Southern tip of Sakhalin Island, across from the northern end of Japan, is a fully armed Russian military establishment and submarine base, guarded by 30,000 Soviet troops, Chinese repatriates from the island said today.

GENEVA, Jan. 17 -- An obscure little committee working away here has discovered that if a half dozen Government authorities could be persuaded to take a few minor measures, Europe's silica brick problem could be largely solved.

WITH the current actor unemployment situation stirring everyone in the theatre, the reaction against the season's trend toward importing British players was bound to come. It's been rumbling for some time, in fact, and last week the cloakroom gossip disclosed that various native players have been submitting petitions to Actors' Equity seeking the tightening of restrictions against alien performers.

PEIPING, Jan. 17 (AP) -- William Freeman, Peiping manager of Claire L. Chennault's Chinese Air Transport Line, said today that arrangements were being made to fly about 7,000 persons from besieged Mukden to Peiping, starting within a week.

The United States Government was urged yesterday to take action on "the cynical defiance of the United Nations by Arab member states," in a sermon by Rabbi Israel Goldstein in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, Eighty-eighth Street, near Broadway.

Completing two weeks of intensive combing of apparel offerings in New York's wholesale markets buyers last week began their homeward trek to prepare for intensive mechandising of stepped-up price lines. Prices have been concentrated in lines which can be priced just below the point where consumers have ceased to buy in volume, but high enough to assure good quality standards.

THE right to express editorial opinions on all matters, including political candidacies and political issues, in our belief, has little or nothing to do with the housing campaign being conducted by Station WMCA. Your article last Sunday confuses political campaigning with campaigning on behalf of improvement of conditions which menace the health and well-being of a community.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 17 -- American Jews owe it to their country and to the world to declare their relationship to the new state created by the United Nations partition of Palestine, Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism, said tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 17 -The former Communist Deputy Gregorio Bezerra has been jailed in the city of Joao Pessoa in the northeastern State of Parahyba and will be tried before a military court on charges of sabotage in the burning of the barracks of the Fifteenth Infantry regiment at Joao Pessoa, the War Ministry said here today.

The United States must combat Soviet expansion "with food and fuel and with creative ideas and lofty ideals," rather than by "striking a military posture," John Foster Dulles told the Foreign Policy Association yesterday at a luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed at 9:27 o'clock last night from Pier 90, North River, breaking her own turnaround record by 1 hour and 9 minutes.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Angry because seven Newark policemen have been assaulted while making arrests since Dee. 1, Public Safety Director John B. Keenan ordered Police Chief John Haller today to instruct his men to "take off the kid gloves when the occasion warrants."
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 17 -- This southernmost capital in the Western world is more than ready for the two United States naval vessels due here Tuesday.

(5) John Foster Dulles on the Little Assembly -- dull (to most readers). (6) "How the President Does His Job" -- intriguing. (7) College Humor -- swell.
