We try to keep up an intelligent interest in the arts and letters.

The letter of Charles Belous, lamenting the plight of the liberals, in itself reveals the cause of weakness in the liberal movement. He says that the liberals and progressives have been the victims of unfair attacks as Communists, radicals and crackpots. But he neither essays the definition of liberalism nor indicates the standards to which one may repair to find the tenets of liberalism made clear.

THE 550-man crew of the converted liner Washington, scheduled to make its first transatlantic voyage to Cobh, Southampton and Le Havre on Feb. 4, was graduated last week from the United States Maritime Commission training center at Sheepshead Bay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Atlantic Fleet will put to sea soon to engage in thirty-nine-day training maneuvers in the Western Atlantic and Caribbean areas. In the program will be a simulated attack and amphibious landings by marines in a key operation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 17 -- Defeating Yale, 58 -- 54, before 2,600 spectators in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium tonight, Cornell maintained its unsullied record in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League despite a second-half uprising which carried the Elis within four points of tying the loosely played contest in the closing minutes.

THERE are a lot of theories about what the B. stands for in the name of B. Traven, the mystery man (or woman, nobody really knows) of modern fiction. Some people say the initial stands for Bruno, some hold out for Barry and there are those who insist on Benedict; but a good many folk say it just stands for Bashful.

BRYAN MORGAN'S novel, written in his twenty-fifth year, has maturity, ability, a nice leisurely way with words, good taste and little flavor; it has everything in fact but the symptoms of creative struggle which we are apt to deplore in a first novel and which we heartily miss when they're absent.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Buffalo State Teachers College will field a varsity football team next fall for the first time in its 76-year history, Athletic Director Hubert E. Coyer announced today. The student athletic council voted unanimously to add football to the program, but the action still must be approved by the faculty board of athletic control, which Coyer said "undoubtedly will approve football in accordance with the wishes of the students."

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 17 -Georgia politics, allowed to simmer down over the year-end, started boiling again this week. The Herman Talmadge-Gov. M. E. Thompson feud once more went before the State Supreme Court.

NOW that the Charles Boyer-Jessica Tandy vehicle, "A Woman's Vengeance" (the Aldous Huxley tale which formerly bore the titles, "The Gioconda Smile" and "Mortal Coils"), is awaiting release by Universal-International, Director Zoltan Korda is ready to return to the family fold.

BURTON EDWIN SHOTTON, a mild-mannered and unobtrusive man of 63, was casually watching a minor league game in Miami last April, scouting players for his close friend, Branch Rickey. He was handed a telegram and stuck it in his pocket unopened.

FOR THIS WEEK: Try knocking lumps of snow and ice out of house gutters so that the accumulation will not damage shrubs when it melts. And if snow is still hard to dislodge from prized small evergreens, throw a pailful of water or try the hose when the temperature is above freezing. . . . Remove snow from the sashes covering coldframes. . . .

TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 17 -- A new addition to the Willys-Overland Motors line, the Jeep station sedan, was announced today by Arthur J. Wieland, vice president in charge of distribution. He added that the new units were now on display in dealer showrooms throughout the country and would sell for $1,865 f.o.b. Toledo.

ATHENS, Jan. 17 -- The text of the second interim report of the United Nations Special Committee on the Balkans, sent by the committee from its headquarters at Salonika to Lake Success, was made public here today by the Greek Ministry of the Press.
ARCADIA, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Olhaverry, ancient gray galloper from Chile, pulled another surprise victory out of the hat today.
W. Donald McNeill of Orange, N. J., again heads the ranking of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association and Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange, N. J., goes to the top of the women's division.

Activity in all departments at retail stores last week was fairly good, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Dress sections were active, south shops, north shops, sporting goods and lingerie departments busy, and housewares business good. Hat bar trade, the report said, was excellent.

THIRTY years of development of Soviet literature have as yet found no authoritative and reasonably complete chronicler in English. For that matter, neither has the Soviet Union produced such a chronicler. This lack is unfortunate, for the bulk of Soviet literature has an importance quite unconnected with its artistic achievements.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -Rural mail carriers pleaded today for an $800 increase in take home pay, declaring the present $9,076 top annual average income was seriously depleted by the high cost of operating a car.

The proposal recently made in Congress to have proceeds from Finland's payments on its debt to the United States set aside in a fund to finance studies by Finnish citizens "for the purpose of enabling the people of Finland to have the services of a new generation of technical experts to aid them in their efforts to rebuild the shattered economy and destroyed areas of their country" is a very fitting and apt one.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- A group of eight fifteenth and sixteenth century paintings from the famous Ralph and Mary Booth collection of Detroit, has been presented to the National Gallery of Art, David E. Finley, director of the museum announced today.

RICHMOND, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Cracking par for the third straight day, E. J. (Dutch) Harrison of Little Rock posted a two-under-par 70 today for a total of 202 to retain his lead at the end of the third round of the 72-hole Richmond $10,000 golf tournament.

In his controversial letter of Jan. 11, J. Rankin objects to the precedence given Hollywood films on Bosley Crowther's list of the ten best movies of 1947. In his enumeration of several "outstanding" foreign films of last year, ("Tawny Pipit," "I Know Where I'm Going," "Odd Man Out," "The Adventuress" and "The Captive Heart") J. Rankin proclaims that we must concede another bad year for Hollywood.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Republicans may let the Truman-Marshall foreign policy down. And even the Democrats have their shaky days, but the Communists abroad and their supporters at home can still be counted on to get the Marshall Plan through Congress.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- A plea that thousands of displaced persons now in camps in Germany and Austria be admitted to "vast territories in the Americas and the British dominions with huge resources yet to be exploited" was voiced here today by Bernard Cardinal Griffin, Catholic Archbishop of Westminster.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Three goals by Princeton in the first seven minutes of play were enough to upset the "official" United States Olympic Committee hockey team tonight in Baker rink. The Tigers went on to inflict a 6-2 setback to the All-Stars.

The growing deadlock between the Administration and Congress, particularly on the Republican side, on how to alleviate some of the nation's economic maladjustments had a depressing effect on sentiment in the financial community last week.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Jan. 17 -- As the strikers in three cities in this area returned to their jobs this morning, ending a week of, sporadic stoppages, persistent reports circulated here that the Communists of the area were undergoing a major policy struggle in connection with the Marshall Plan.

Re the photo which accompanied "The Case for Federal Aid to Our Schools," by George D. Aiken, one might have a tendency to pass up the fact that the flag is hung incorrectly, but when it accompanies an article dealing with the inadequacies of the American school system, this is unforgivable.

AN eleven-day round trip by car to New Orleans, just completed, may give motorists contemplating a junket to Mardi Gras, which comes the second week in February this year, helpful hints on routes and budgets. We found driving to be perhaps the most interesting and most economical way to get to New Orleans, certainly for groups of two to six, capacity for the family automobile.
PARIS, Jan. 17 -- A Communist-supported Committee of Aid to "Democratic Greece" was announced in the newspaper Humanite today.

The Comet Class Yacht Racing Association recommended to its fleets last night that the new North American Yacht Racing Union rules governing racing be used in next season's sailing competitions. The recommendation was approved at the annual meeting of the Comet Class at the New York Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- President Truman today ordered temperatures in Government office buildings and other establishments, including residences, held down to 68 degrees to save fuel, and placed a forty-mile speed limit on Government vehicles in order to save gasoline.

Ernest Ansermet, the eminent Swiss conductor, led the NBC Symphony Orchestra last night in the first of a series of four concerts which he is scheduled to direct at Radio City. This was the first time that Mr. Ansermet had appeared in this city since 1916, when he made his initial visit to America as conductor of the Diaghileff Ballet Company.

THE tremendous proportions of the St. Lawrence River project are shown in the accompanying maps and drawing. For fifty years the complete development of the river has been vigorously debated. Today what is officially called the St. Lawrence Seaway and Power Project is before Congress for action.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Henry A. Wallace, rousingly endorsed for President by the Progressive Citizens of America, told 600 cheering delegates to the annual PCA convention today that the way to end inflation was "to take the profit out of it."

STANFORD -- Texts on Democracy As the first step in a program to teach American youth the values of their ideals and institutions, Stanford University is preparing a series of books describing various aspects of American life and the national heritage. The books, financed by an $80,000 gift, are for use in elementary and secondary schools and are expected to be ready by next year.

The Senate's unanimous approval last Friday of the State Department's cultural and informational program is as good an evidence as could be had of the changing climate of opinion in this country. Six months ago there was so much opposition to this measure and so much indifference to it that the Senate did not even bring it to a vote.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Two members of the British House of Commons, Christopher N. Shawcross, Labor, and Malcolm Bullock, Conservative, conferred here today with members of the French Council of the Republic concerning formation of an interparliamentary group for the construction of a bomb-proof tunnel under the English Channel.
The New York chapter of the National Lawyers Guild proposed yesterday a city income tax equivalent to the 40 per cent reduction in the state income levy.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The adoption by the French Government within a fortnight of a special export franc of approximately half the exchange value officially attributed to the existing currency is now taken for granted in financial and political circles here.

EVERYBODY with a warm heart likes both Yugoslavia and Yugoslav people, regardless of their political shading. Rebecca West, novelist-essayist, and Ray Brock, the correspondent, adored the country and its vivid inhabitants from what one might call the right-wing side of the fence, politically.

Probability of an early ballot deadlock at the Republican National Convention on the nomination for President was indicated yesterday by reports of correspondents of THE NEW YORK TIMES in key states, following announcement that Gov. Thomas E. Dewey would run, if nominated by the convention.

NANKING, Jan. 17 (Reuters) -- The anti-British riots in Canton yesterday and the spread of agitation today were described as "a dangerous parallel" to the Boxer Rising of 1900 by semi-official Chinese quarters here today.

PRESIDENT TRUMAN has ten points in his anti-inflation program, but retail merchants in their convention here last week were willing to settle for seven. These seven were highly practical points and, if carried out, would remove Mr. Truman's worry about spiraling prices.
Last week was a week of statistics. Within two days the President sent to Congress two messages that were unusual in bulk and wordage and crammed full of facts and figures.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 17 -- A one-hand push shot from beyond the foul circle by George Lawry, Princeton captain, in the final second of play, gave the Tigers a 56-55 victory over Syracuse in a nip - and - tuck struggle in the Princeton gym tonight.

IN leading, a player is usually as careful in his selection of the card as he is in his selection of the suit. When he is following suit, or trumping, he is not always so careful -- without much thought, he plays the lowest card.

As we start the New Year here in England I would like to thank all those Americans who have helped us during the past year. I do not mean those who have so generously sent parcels of food and clothing, though these have been most acceptable.

A LONG with The British North America Act of 1867, which forms Canada's Constitution, Canada inherited the practices, precedents, customs and contradictions which the British had created during many centuries of political struggle towards a balanced system of government.

OTTAWA, Jan. 17 -- Following the reimposing of price ceilings on meat and butter, it was announced here today that the maximum price of butter to the consumer has been fixed at 73 cents a pound in Ontario and Quebec, with a few cents more or less in the other provinces.
NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 17 -- The three physicians in constant attendance on Mohandas K. Gandhi issued a bulletin tonight saying that a continuation of his fast was "not advisable."

THE first part of this book examines the origins and present nature of the caste system in India. In it the author reviews the literature of the subject a procedure which saves him from distraction by the multitudinous details of Indian life as they would be met by an on-the-spot observer.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The State Department published today a volume of selected documents on the Paris Peace Conference of 1946, thereby making them available to the general public.

Miss Kathleen A. Smith, known throughout lower Harlem as the friend of "problem pupils" in Public School 168 on East 105th Street, was honored by friends, associates and former pupils on the eve of her retirement on Feb. 3 after more than fifty years' service.

A comprehensive program for the improvement of rural education, calling for equal opportunities for all children and Federal aid to the schools, has been proposed by the Colorado Association of School Boards.
Political words were in the air last week -- words like "dark horse," "electoral votes," "primaries," "balance of power." The political derby of 1948 was getting away.

In letters forwarded to the International Telephone and Telegraph Company, the American Communications Association, CIO, and the All America Cable Employes Association, independent, listed yesterday their members sitting on each other's negotiating committees as "consultants."

WHILE Florida hotel operators, especially those in and around Miami Beach were reporting a slow start for the winter season, the Florida State Hotel Commission last week listed 1,522 hotels is operation throughout Florida, with 83,805 rooms and accommodation for 125,000 persons.

FOR its first official exhibition, the newly formed Irish Academy in America last week assembled a number of traditional academic paintings and sculptures by Irish artists in America and Ireland at the Demotte Gallery.

A resolution calling upon the city government to make provision for the continued employment of 956 temporary public school teachers scheduled to be released from their posts during the spring term was adopted unanimously yesterday by fifty members of Teachers Union, CIO.

OTTAWA, Jan. 17 -- It is expected here that Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King will on Tuesday announce his intention to retire from public life next year, and that at the same time he will propose that a Liberal party convention be held this coming summer or fall to appoint his successor as party leader.

Dr. Jorge Garcia, Granados, Guatemalan representative to the United Nations, told the Pan American Women's Association yesterday that there was no possibility of political liberty without an economic freedom.
WASHINGTON, (AP) -- Idaho retained its record as largest producer of silver and zinc in the United States in 1947, the Bureau of Mines has announced.

Renewal of the fight of retailers against price increases through tighter buying procedures, changes in retail price lines and narrower margins on cost-of-living items was indicated here last week following the strong anti-inflation program suggested to the nation's merchants at the annual convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

For those who like to sing, the temptation to give whole-heartedly with all their vocal resources is a constant temptation. Annabelle Ott, soprano from Washington, who was heard here for the first time yesterday afternoon at Town Hall, succumbed to it rather too often.

The demand for products of the rubber industry will continue at a high level in 1948, based on present indications, Herbert E. Smith, president of the United States Rubber Company, declared in his year-end review.

FLINT, Mich., Jan. 17 -- "Dynaflow," the new no-shift, clutchless transmission, is the outstanding feature of the 1948 Buick line. It is a development of the transmission used in the Hell-Cat tank destroyers built by Buick during the war and refined for use in passenger cars.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Jan. 17 -- Delegates to a special meeting of the California Republican Assembly, an unofficial party organization, today endorsed Gov. Earl Warren for President and urged election of a California delegation at the June 1 primary pledged to his nomination.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- Otis Chatfield-Taylor, 47 years old, socially prominent New York playwright and writer, died in Ossining Hospital last night from injuries suffered a few hours earlier when his automobile skidded and overturned on the Albany Post Road near his home.

THE renascence of Arthur Miller's excellent "All My Sons" which, despite its obvious merits, was allowed to close after three weeks in Chicago, is attributable solely to courage and enterprise on the part of the Dramatic Guild of

THE late Paul Valery was a man of letters devoted above all to the exercise and celebration of the intelligence. The mind, in its manifold operations and possibilities, was at once his theme and inspiration, his desire and solace.
OMAHA, Jan. 17 -- The Midwest was busy this week gathering food and cash for a new "Friendship Train."

BERLIN, Jan. 17 -- On June 5, 1945, the Governments of France, Russia, Great Britain and the United States divided Germany into four zones for administrative purposes and added that "the area of 'Greater Berlin' will be occupied by forces of each of the four powers. An inter-Allied governing authority consisting of four commandants, appointed by their respective commanders in chief will be established to direct jointly its administration."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 17 -- Louisiana Democrats who go to the polls on Tuesday in a primary election to nominate a Governor and other state officers will have before them the names of three principals who also sought the Governorship in 1940, when the old Huey P. Long machine went down to defeat.

MUNICH, Germany, Jan. 17 (AP) Dr. Kurt Schumacher, leader of Germany's Social Democratic party, said bluntly tonight that the fight between democracy and communism in central Europe would be decided with bread.

Nine-year-old Johnnie Austin always had been a "slow learner." His parents tended to blame his shyness, inability to get along well with his playmates, lack of cooperation and interest at home, and his desire to play alone, to the fact that his twin sisters, who were 12 when he was born, had overprotected him.

IN arriving at your conclusion that stations should not be permitted to editorialize, based on their scarcity, combined with public ownership, you have overlooked the complete revolution in the field which has just taken place. The number of regular AM broadcasting stations operating and authorized to be constructed has doubled since the war.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Winter planting, extensively undertaken throughout agricultural France, has been equally active in the political fields. The estimates for this latter crop, unless nipped by some sudden frost, are a blooming of sporadic Communist social disorders, strikes and even armed sabotage in the early spring. On the other hand, the de Gaullist planters are reported to be assiduously cultivating a change in the Government to be brought about by new elections.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- The Joint Economic Committee agreed today that it would not have time to make an adequate report on President Truman's economic message by Feb. 1, as required by law. The group consequently authorized its chairman, Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, to prepare a measure for Congressional enactment postponing the deadline until March 1.
GSTAD, Switzerland, Jan. 13 -- There is no displaced persons problem in Switzerland, and not enough communism to amount to anything.

PRUDENCIO DE PEREDA "discovered" Hemingway in his last year in high school. Later, during the Spanish war, he worked on two films with Hemingway in Spain. Now he speaks of his mentor as "a single, true, real influence.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Jan. 17 -- This community's year-round vacation-center program received a severe blow early today when fire of undetermined origin destroyed Seneca Lodge, a log cabin, with a loss estimated at $100,000.

Gentle spoofing underscored by nostalgia was in order last night when sixty-one alumni of the New York University School of Commerce, Class of 1917, who were unable to attend commencement exercises because of the outbreak of World War I, finally received their "diplomas."

Geologists have found Arctic shells on the bottom of the Gulf of Mexico, which proves, according to Dr. Parker D. Trask of the U. S. Geological Survey that the shoreline must have been only a few miles away. Trask infers that during the Ice Age enough water was locked on the continents in the form of glacial ice sheets to lower the ocean level all over the world thousands of feet.
TRENTON, N. J., Jan. 17 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll arranged today mediation board conference in Camden for tomorrow, seeking to end a labor dispute tying up fuel oil for 1,200 south Jersey consumers.

ALTHOUGH the soil is still as hard as a stone, the vegetable grower has plans brewing. Urgent requests for Freedom gardens, plus the arrival of dozens of new catalogues, spur him to prepare for the coming season.

While the casual visitor to Colonial Williamsburg may have thought that this restoration of a stage of history was long ago complete, the trustees have just announced the resumption of the building program interrupted by the war. It will take from five to ten years to complete the last bit of stage business being started now.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. of New Jersey, chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor in the House, announced last night that he had summoned James C. Petrillo, head of the American Federation of Musicians, to appear before the committee this week for a showdown on his ban on the making of phonograph records.

SOMEWHERE there ought to be an organization to award Allan R. Bosworth an Oscar. He has gone and done what has long needed doing. He has written a topflight, irreverent, jolly book about going to the country for permanent residence after years in city work.

SHOULD you happen to be walking through West Sixty-seventh Street toward Central Park early one of these mornings, no matter how cold it may be, the chances are that you will see a stocky man, with wavy white hair, wearing neither hat nor coat, striding along with a forceful gait.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- A technique termed by British producers the "establishment of merchandise bridgeheads" in the United States is finding widespread favor among producers of consumer goods here. The plan, which really involves selective selling within a specified area in the United States, is intended to tailor export demand to current productive capacities of producers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The Washington Caps' basketball team tonight defeated the New York Knickerbockers, 78 to 62, before nearly 5,000 fans to knock the Knicks out of undisputed possession of first place in the Basketball Association of America Eastern Division.

MARTINEZ, Calif., Jan. 17 (AP) -- Three Negro golfers filed damage suits aggregating $315,000 today, contending that they were barred from participation in the $10,000 open golf tournament at nearby Richmond.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Jan. 17 -- A controversy was aroused here today by the publication in the Socialist le Peuple of what is purported to be a document proving that King Leopold on his free will made two journeys to Germany and Austria in the autumn of 1944, while the Belgians thought him imprisoned in his palace at Aleken, near Brussels.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- The condition of the health of Dr. Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, is causing grave concern to European diplomatists. It is a subject of private speculation almost as much as the reported illness of Premier Stalin.

SKIING enthusiasm has been running "ski-high" this season, thanks to the elements, which have made good sport possible since Thanksgiving Day here in the East and six weeks earlier than that day in the Rocky Mountains and Pacific Northwest.

Frederic Joliot-Curie, French High Commissioner for Atomic Energy, told the French Academy of Sciences last week that Prof. Pierre Auger, leading French authority on the cosmic rays, had discovered a new fundamental particle. This new particle the professor calls meson-lamda.

ALBANY, Jan. 17 -- The New York State Association of Young Republican Clubs, which is said to have a potential vote of 250,000, unanimously adopted a resolution today calling for the nomination of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey for President as "the strongest candidate, upon whom all elements within the party can best unite."

THE thriller which leads away from rather than toward whodunit must live by its wits more fully than any other. For one thing, it breeds a livelier state of mind in the average consumer. The gullible reader, prepared to drop off under the influence of deepening mystery, is transfixed to discover, in the first few pages, that he alone knows all.

LONDON, Jan. 17 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Rene Mayer, French Minister of Finance, concluded two days of discussions of French financial problems and Anglo-French trade here today.

The metropolitan press published pictures last week of a rocket-powered sled built by the Northrop Aircraft Company which had reached a speed of 1,019 miles an hour at the Muroc Air Base, California. Brief and obscure descriptions accompanied the pictures. The sled, it seems, had runners that gripped the rails of a standard-gauge track 2,000 feet long.

AS might be expected from Anthony Quayle, author of such suspenseful novels as "Eight Hours From England," and actor, soldier and stage director, the action and dialogue of his latest effort are both glib and fast.

ONE man's esthetic is another man's anesthetic, which, say John Gielgud's partisans, is why some critics have failed to grasp the grandeur of his performance in "Crime and Punishment." Thus, where one critic found Mr. Gielgud's Raskolnikoff "sharp, lean, tormented * * * superbly acted," another paid appraiser of theatrical wares gazed upon the same gaunt features and asked his typewriter where the Mad Hatter had lost his price tag.

IN its relations with Soviet Russia is the United States dealing with a nation that falls within any accepted form of a national state and one whose motivation and policies can be evaluated in terms of historical precedent?

BRUCE MARSHALL, who became pretty famous in 1931 when his "Father Malachy's Miracle" was published, and still more famous in 1945, when "The World, the Flesh and Father Smith" was published, sailed into New York -- his first visit -- in time for the weather miracle.

BATAVIA, Java, Jan. 17 -- The Netherlands and the Indonesian Republic signed today a truce that in effect gives the Dutch at least temporary control of the most productive areas of Java and Sumatra, rich in oil and rubber.
HAVANA, to the American visitor, is a gay, glamorous city of the tropics, but to the political exile seeking a safe haven it is the '"Capital of Exiles" of the Western Hemisphere.

THE provincial notion that a radio program must originate from either New York or Hollywood has been pleasantly and divertingly dispelled by the new series entitled "R.F.D. America," presented at 9:30 Thursday evening over the Mutual network and WOR.
Please accept my congratulations on your column, "Regarding Some Ugly Comments, etc.," in Sunday's (Jan. 11) TIMES.
Miss Sonja Henie and her Hollywood Ice Revue are scheduled for a New York appearance once more, the skating show opening at Madison Square Garden on Thursday evening.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Koussevitzky, gave the first performance of Nicolas Nabokov's score for soprano and orchestra, "The Return of Pushkin," at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The soprano was Marina Koshetz, daughter of Nina Koshetz.

NOT since Jim Kjelgaard's first entry have we had a more welcome addition to the ranks of boys' authors than Mr. Hungerford, a naval officer in the recent war and now teacher of English at Northwestern University.

THIS is the story of Charles-Edouard Brown-Sequard, doctor of medicine, practicing scientist in the most hallowed clinics and laboratories of Europe and a peripatetic to the arid outposts of American medicine. He was born in 1817, on the English island of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean, of an Irish - American sailor from Philadelphia and a French mother.

LUDWIG LEWISOHN believes that, especially in marriage, people should be clear and can- did with each other, should seek only what is good and lovely. Courageously facing the truth, they should never be furtive or malicious or put up with meanness, spiritual mediocrity and shabby compromises.

AMONG the hardest hit victims of the stoppage in record-making, assuming that the stoppage continues for long, will be the contemporary composers, especially Americans. Living composers of other lands will suffer also, but there is more likelihood that their music will be recorded in their own countries and imported here.

MARK on your calendar of significant events in the evolution of the theatre hereabouts, Agnes de Mille's direction of the entire production, not merely the dancing, of "Allegro," and hasten over to the Majestic Theatre box office at the earliest opportunity to see what she has done.

PEARL HARBOR, T. H., Jan. 17 (AP) -- A towering wall of water lashed up by a typhoon crashed across much of the Island of Yap yesterday just forty-eight hours after the great blow itself had virtually levelled that outpost with 100-mile an hour winds, the Navy reported today.
Restoration of consumer rationing of scarce goods was advocated yesterday by the Liberal party.

THE midwinter garden course at Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, will open on Wednesday with a lecture by Clarence E. Lewis on "Flowering Shrubs Offer Form and Color." The over-all title for the four talks to be given on consecutive Wednesdays is "Garden Setting for Your Home." The series is sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PARIS, Jan. 17 -- Emile Bollaert, High Commissioner to Indo-China, after concluding conferences here this week, will leave Tuesday with the purpose of renewing talks with former Emperor Bao Dar in the Far East Feb. 13.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 -- This country is expected to have on the average ten pounds less meat per person during the year 1948 than in 1947. Hence last week's warnings to Congress by Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson that meat rationing may be necessary by spring.
A severe winter storm reached New York and other seaboard cities from the Midwest last night. Snow began to fall at 8 P. M. and was expected to continue until this afternoon.

The Toronto Maple Leafs will be on deck against the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. The rivalry between the teams is one of the closest in the league, and the clash promises to attract a capacity crowd of more than 15,000 fans.

The General Electric Company is using the same advertising methods that helped make it the nation's biggest electrical manufacturer to try to convince its 197,000 employes that they should forego demands for a third round of post-war wage increases.

THIS story which appeared in France shortly before the Allied invasion is unshadowed by the dark years of the occupation. It is a tale in the romantic tradition which children have always loved, told with Gallic verve. Aurora, a beautiful and adored medieval princess, had everything in the world to make her happy, so, of course, she was bored, knowing neither laughter nor tears.

DURING the whole of two bright, sizzling days in the summer of the year, small, blond Joel Knox has been traveling from New Orleans to join his unremembered father in a remote, run-down country house at Skully's Landing.

THESE five slim, well-produced volumes inaugurate the Schocken Library that will appear at regular intervals in the form of fiction, poetry, anthologies and similar matter. The purpose of the series is to represent the sweep of Judaic classical traditions and their impingements on contemporary times.

THIS is a unique type of medical biography -- an attempt to tell, through an anthology of the writings of many physicians over some four hundred years, the story of the "universal doctor." It does give an amazingly comprehensive picture of the evolution of the modern physician, and particularly the ethical concepts with which the profession of medicine has surrounded itself.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Profit-taking knocked all grains lower on the Board of Trade today as fairly heavy selling came from commission houses. Traders said the slump was a natural development after the persistent rise of the last two weeks, which had carried corn and oats to high records.

Artificial ears have been grown on frames of tantalum wire, more than 5,000 skull injuries have been repaired with tantalum plates, thousands of severed or injured nerves have been restored with tantalum foil and miles of tantalum wire have been used by surgeons for sutures.

The scoring of their eleventh successive triumph of the season -- and their fifteenth in a row since March 1 of last year -- was pretty much of a routine accomplishment for Columbia University's basketball forces in the Morning-side Heights gymnasium last night.

If President Truman's tax reduction proposal of a cost-of-living credit of $40 for each taxpayer and dependent has done nothing more, it has brought about a nation-wide discussion of the terrific tax load now being borne, and the relation of this burden to inflation which, in effect, is another form of taxation.

Six years ago this month a thousand college and university presidents met in Baltimore to determine how they could best readjust their programs to meet the emergency caused by the war. They pledged an all-out campaign to help defeat our enemies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (AP) -- Dr. Daniel Poling, churchman who served on the nine-member Presidential commission that urged universal military training, vigorously denied today that such training would be "peacetime conscription" or that the trainees "would be as young soldiers were during the war."

Daniel Walpole, 34-year-old unemployed laborer, turned out early yesterday morning to be hapless burglar. He suffered a superficial bullet wound in his thigh when he fled after an attempt at robbery. An ambulance, removing him to Bellevue, collided with a taxicab. He suffered a fractured nose and painful cuts of his face.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander paid tribute last night to the members of the Police Department for their work in helping the city to dig out from under the recent big snowfall. The city executives, both former patrolmen, were guests of. honor at the thirty-fourth annual Police Ball, sponsored by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and attended by 15,000 persons at Madison Square Garden.

Back in 1890 a Yale man named Andrew B. Graves bought a bulldog which was eventually named Handsome Dan. That's one of the reasons, fifty-eight years later, that sixty-two squash tennis players, including eight seeded men, again are battling for a bronze trophy, which is a replica of the original Yale bulldog.

NEWARK, N. J., Jan. 17 -- The police in New Jersey and six other states, assisted by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, were engaged today in the final phase of breaking up what is described as the largest ring of automobile thieves to operate in the United States.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Jan. 17 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that a separate law school must be set up in Oklahoma for Mrs. Ada Lois Sipuel Fisher, 23-year-old Negro woman who seeks admission to the law school at the University of Oklahoma.

FATHERS toiled early and late, "eager in pursuit of business," and had no time for their children in the year 1842. An article on "Paternal Neglect" in the contemporary Parent's Magazine offers just one sign of changing times, which Anne L. Kuhn has noted in a study of parent education literature for the years 1830 to 1860.

Army's swimming team easily conquered Columbia, 55 -- 20, in the University Hall pool yesterday for its first Eastern Intercollegiate league triumph of the season. The setback was Columbia's second in a row.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture tonight made public a list of 3,201 traders in eggs on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on July 31, 1946. The list carried the name of William M. Boyle Jr. of Washington, D. C.

DETROIT, Jan. 17 -- More than 200 members of the national council of the General Motors division of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted today to forego 10 cents of their demand for a wage increase of 30 cents an hour if the company would present an "acceptable pension plan."

JERUSALEM, Jan. 17 -- The ambush by Arab fighters of a Jewish shock force sent to aid the settlement of Kfar Etzion was confirmed today with the discovery of thirty-five bodies near the Arab village of Surif, twelve miles southwest of Jerusalem.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 17 (UP) -The Army told its troops throughout the world tonight that racial and religious prejudice endanger democracy and world peace.
